title: 3 DRAFTEES SIGN WITH THE GIANTS
description: The Giants, who 24 hours ago had four draft choices unsigned, were down to one today.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday SALSA IN BROOKLYN The Prospect Park Bandshell will ring with the sounds of jazz and salsa this weekend when Celebrate Brooklyn presents a festival of Latin music. Tonight at 8, a double bill will feature Daniel Ponce and Bobby Sanabria and Acension (rain date: tomorrow at 3). Tomorrow night at 8, Tito Puente, a winner of three Grammy awards, will appear with his Latin Jazz Ensemble; the Roland Vasquez Band, with Nicky Marrero on timbales, will also perform (rain date: Sunday at 3). Finally, on Sunday night at 8, La Gran Manzana and Louie Ramirez and Ray de la Paz will conclude the festival (rain date: Monday night at 8). Admission for all concerts is free, but a $1 contribution is suggested. The bandshell is near the corner of Prospect Park West and Ninth Street. Information: (718) 768-0699.

title: GOULD INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a special non-cash charge of $130 million as a provision for future estimated losses primarily associated with fixed-price defense contracts awarded in 1982 and 1983. c-Net loss d-After a special charge of $159.2 million related to a writeoff of $160 million from reducing the size of the company's semiconductor operations for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: ART: A LOOK AT 20TH-CENTURY PORTRAIT DRAWINGS
description: YOU might not think it, but ours has been a very good century for the portrait drawing. Despite the photograph, despite the newsreel, despite television, the portrait drawing has kept its place in the hierarchy of human activities. In terms of the mass market, there is no demand for it. Gone are the times when newspaper editors hired the best painters to provide ''an artist's impression'' of the main event of the day in time for the next morning's paper. Publishers are sparing with their favors. Private commissions at the highest level are few. But, all this notwithstanding, the portrait drawing has done rather well.

title: DOLLAR HITS LOW LEVEL VS. YEN
description: With the dollar falling to the lowest level against the Japanese yen since the late 1940's, gold bullion prices soared to a two-year high in active trading yesterday.

title: NOBILITY HOMES reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
description: b-Net income

title: Treasuries Show Solid Gains
description: Prices for Treasury securities posted solid gains yesterday, reflecting both good retail demand for shorter-term issues and dealer positioning in advance of next week's Treasury refunding.

title: Tarrytown Guitarists
description: Sunnyside, in Tarrytown, N.Y., was Washington Irving's estate, and, on Sunday at 7:15 P.M., the guitarists MaryAnn and James Larusso will perform music the author might have enjoyed during his travels in Spain, Italy and Germany.

title: ART: CHINESE PAINTING AND WESTERN MODERNISM
description: FOR anyone who wants to know why Chinese painting has been important to so many Western artists, ''The Mountain Retreat: Landscape in Modern Chinese Painting'' is the show to see. There are numerous links between its 43 paintings and modern Western art. Indeed after seeing this excellent show - in the library of Hofstra University in Hempstead, L.I., through Aug. 22 - the recent claim of the Chinese painter Wang Jiqian that ''modern art is a branch of Chinese painting'' may not seem quite so farfetched.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Jay Hoggard Quartet, the West End Cafe, 2911 Broadway at 114th Street (666-8750). The vibraphonist Jay Hoggard divides his performing between relaxed pop-jazz outings and the more challenging modern jazz that has made him one of the leaders on his instrument. In demanding jazz tunes, he reveals his dazzling speed, his shimmering sense of melody and his command of the vibraphone's percussive side - with four mallets, he can sound like a Balinese gamelan. Mr. Hoggard's current engagement promises to be a powerful one, since his quartet includes the drummer Pheeroan Aklaff, the bassist Lonnie Plaxico (an alumnus of Art Blakey's Jazz Messengers) and the brilliant pianist Geri Allen. Tonight and tomorrow sets begin at 9 and 10:30 P.M., midnight and 1:30 A.M.; on Sunday, shows are at 9 and 10:30 P.M. and midnight; there is a $6 cover and a $7.50 minimum.

title: SMART ACTOR PLAYS DUMB
description: Bill Pullman, who won praise with his film debut as the slow-witted Earl in the comedy ''Ruthless People,'' had no thought of trying out for the small part.

title: A SUBWAY JOLT FOR THE MEXICANS: THE 3-CENT FARE
description: Ever since it opened in 1969 the Mexico City subway has been one of the world's great urban transportation bargains. For a single peso - 0.15 cents in United States money - passengers can ride anywhere on the 75-mile Metro system and get off at any of its 109 stations.

title: FOR 6 WEEKS, CENTRAL PARK IS CENTER STAGE
description: IT was a hot afternoon and people slouched on the benches inside the Central Park Bandshell, sitting out the threat of a summer storm. Suddenly a small, agile woman appeared at the front of the stage and began to swing a fluorescent, whirring tube, kicking her booted foot high, green skirts flying, as cameras snapped away. Danitra Vance, the comedian, had arrived for a photo session, and she had an instant audience and an exuberant new character to play.

title: SCREEN: STEPHEN COLLINS IN 'CANYON'
description: ''CHOKE CANYON'' is mildly enjoyable if you ignore the story, which only distracts attention from the explosions, fights and chases. Some of the chases are dazzling, especially the pursuit by a double-winged stunt plane of a helicopter ferrying a huge metal ball on a cable through the red pinnacles and gorges around Arches National Park in Utah. But the plot supplies such lamebrained inspiration for the action - a squeaky-clean scientist who is selflessly trying to create clean energy and blow the whistle on nuclear pollution is hunted by the agents of an evil businessman - that what enjoyment there is in the fearless ingenuity of the combatants soon evaporates.

description: HALFWAY through 1986, the United States trade deficit has hit a new high of $83.9 billion - about $170 billion at an annual rate. The worsening trade performance is adding to worries about the ability of the American economy to keep growing.

description: Charles H. Barrow, president of the Northern Trust Corporation, the fourth-largest bank holding company in Illinois, said yesterday that he was taking early retirement ''to seek another challenge.''

title: Eugene B. Casey Dies at 82, A Farm Adviser to Roosevelt
description: Eugene B. Casey, a Maryland philanthropist and builder who served in the the Franklin Roosevelt Administration as a farm policy adviser, died Tuesday at his home in nearby Potomac, Md. He was 82 years old.

description: Eastern Air Lines Inc., reeling from an industrywide fare war, reported yesterday a second-quarter loss of $44 million, compared with a profit of $25.5 million, or 37 cents a share, for the corresponding period a year ago.

title: 3-Mile Island Operator Would Release Steam
description: The GPU Nuclear Corporation, the operator of the nuclear power plant at Three Mile Island, said today that it wants to boil 2.1 million gallons of leftover radioactive water and release the steam into the atmosphere over two and a half years.

title: DROUGHT THREATENS SMALL TOWNS' SUPPLIES OF DRINKING WATER
description: For more than a century people here have drawn their drinking water from the Ellijay and Cartecay Rivers, two spring-fed streams that seemed impervious to drought.

title: Mr. Gorbachev's China Shuffle
description: Predictably and intelligently, Mikhail Gorbachev has in effect begun his long journey to Washington in distant Vladivostok, ''but a step from the People's Republic of China.'' Approaching another meeting with President Reagan, he invites the Chinese to repair relations with the Soviet Union and to look toward a ''radical reduction'' of the costly armies that guard their frontier. If he cannot yet play a Chinese card he does not possess, Mr. Gorbachev wants at least to reshuffle the deck and deal himself a stronger hand.

title: Grace's Third Account
description: Grace & Rothschild yesterday announced its third account, Lebenthal & Company, the municipal bond house. It is leaving Chiat/Day. Plans call for a campaign that includes material for television, radio and print.

title: DANCE: FESTIVAL OFFERS 'FRANTIC ROMANTICISM'
description: ''FRANTIC ROMANTICISM,'' choreographed by Paul Andrew Thompson, is a breath of fresh air in a superannuated dance season. Mixing professional modern dancers with city high school students who are just beginning their training, the production is a marvelous brew of homemade surrealism.

title: 2 Candidates Emerge For U.S. Thrift Agency
description: Two individuals have now emerged as the most likely candidates to replace two departing members of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board -the Federal agency that regulates the nation's 3,500 savings and loan associations - and many in the industry have already expressed their concern.

title: STEEPLECHASE THROWS BETTORS
description: Steeplechasing returned to New York for the first time this year today in the third race at Saratoga, with the usual results: A Jonathan Sheppard-trained entry was bet down to odds-on favoritism, handicappers threw up their hands in confusion but bet anyway, and the race proved both vexing and entertaining.

title: FOUR BRASH MUSICALS RE-CREATE OLD BROADWAY ON OFF BROADWAY
description: IN the era before Broadway became enamored of the so-called ''conceptual musical,'' the term ''musical comedy'' meant exactly what it said - a show at which audiences would find laughter as well as song. But on Broadway nowadays, lavish spectacle has begun to supersede merriment, and the humor one finds is often more intellectual than farcical. But fans of oldtime musical comedy need not despair. Wacky fun, uproarious horseplay and side-splitting jokes are doing just fine Off Broadway, where an old-fashioned musical-comedy renaissance is under way.

description: The French Legislature adopted a bill today to turn 65 state-owned companies over to the private sector. The passage came after the bill was amended to compensate for European Community objections to limits on shareholding by foreign investors.

description: New York City's taxi fares should be raised, given the findings of a new study, the chairman of the Taxi and Limousine Commission said yesterday.

description: The head of the Government's central personnel agency is recommending major changes in Federal law to require the dismissal of Government employees found to be using illegal drugs.

description: The prices that farmers get for raw products rose 2.6 percent in July, partly because of a record jump in broiler chicken prices, an Agriculture Department report showed today.

title: Friend of Bias Pleads Not Guilty
description: A plea of not guilty to four drug-related charges has been entered by the lawyer for Brian Lee Tribble, who was with Len Bias, the University of Maryland basketball star, on the morning he died.

title: RARELY USED DOCTRINE IS CITED

title: HIT OR MISS, KITTLE IS HERE
description: To one way of thinking, it doesn't really matter what the numbers say. Ron Kittle, swaying in the batter's box, whirling the bat in slow motion with one hand, ever so sure that the power he is feeling in his body will radiate through his arms and into the bat, is quite a compelling picture. It is impossible to watch him and not wonder what exactly will ensue.

title: Indicators' Index Delayed

title: Hafts Agree to End Bid for Safeway
description: The Haft family of Washington agreed yesterday to drop its hostile takeover bid for Safeway Stores, but Wall Street sources said that the family's Dart Group Corporation had won the right to buy as many as 500 Safeway stores in the Washington and Los Angeles areas.

Revenues increased 4.1 percent, to $3.83 billion, from $3.68 billion for the quarter a year ago.

title: Talks Open on Pullout Of Troops in Afghanistan
description: The Foreign Ministers of Pakistan and Afghanistan, meeting under the auspices of the United Nations, resumed indirect negotiations today on the six-year-old Afghan conflict. They are expected to concentrate on setting a timetable for the withdrawal of Soviet troops.

title: 'World of Photography' On Channel 13
description: What is the fifth rule of professional photography? In ''The World of Photography,'' the comedian William Wegman tells us, ''If you don't get a model release, it will come back to haunt you.'' The show, which airs Sunday evening at 10:30 on Channel 13's avant-garde performance series ''Alive From Off Center,'' presents Mr. Wegman as just the sort of character who could end up becoming every model's nightmare. With a cynicism that is matched by a glib know-it-all pretentiousness and made up to look like a Mephistophelean hybrid of Donald Sutherland and Frank Zappa, he explains his profession to a fawning, dull-witted pupil, played by the performance artist Michael Smith. Teacher and student wander through the corridors of an institution that has a special ''paparazzi department.''

title: 'CANDLELIGHT' GOES OUT
description: In the fall of 1974, a funny thing happened on the Harvard campus. A scout representing a National Football League combine was seen walking through the square. N.F.L. scouts don't normally appear on Ivy League campuses. Was he confused? Was he lost? In fact, he had come to test Pat McInally, a Harvard senior. The scout carried a standard list of questions that is given to all potential draftees, and he would administer it to McInally, a wide receiver and punter.

title: PHOENIX MAN ASSERTS REHNQUIST HARASSED VOTERS

Corporations Have Civil Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: BIG BANDS BRIGHTEN NEW YORK CLUB SCENE
description: IT takes some nerve, and no little maneuvering, to assemble a big band in 1986. Promoters and club owners are geared to smaller groups; record producers cheerfully substitute synthesizers for horn sections. Yet musicians and audiences still savor the chance to hear individuals creating an ensemble. Against the odds, three big bands are in town this weekend - groups whose music demands between 10 and 16 living, breathing, improvising players.

title: OHIO ART CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: HAZELTINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

Blind but Mobile
description: A guide dog lay under the piano.

title: SANDINISTA HEADS WEST AFTER A 6-DAY WOOING OF NEW YORK
description: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua left New York City yesterday, bound for Denver and an appearance at the convention of the National Bar Association, after six days of intensive diplomacy that found him pressing the Sandinista case and cause in settings as diverse as the United Nations and the Brooklyn waterfront.

title: 'Zorba' to End
description: This weekend will mark the last performances of the musical ''Zorba,'' with Anthony Quinn, at the Westbury Music Fair, Brush Hollow Road, Westbury, L.I. Appearing with Mr. Quinn is the actress Lila Kedrova, who was also featured with him in the film ''Zorba, the Greek.'' Shows are today at 8 P.M., and tomorrow and Sunday at 2 and 8 P.M. Tickets are $20, $25 and $30. Information: (516) 333-0533.

title: Citicorp Consolidating Its Ad Agency Lineup
description: Citicorp is making changes in its agency lineup that result in a consolidation of its ad agencies. The beneficiaries: N. W. Ayer and Foote, Cone & Belding Communications.

title: KETCHUM & CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After a reversal of a tax credit of $224,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $144,000 for the year. c-After tax credits of $102,000 for the quarter and $461,000 for the year. d-Net income

title: Summer Symphony
description: The Summer Symphony, under the direction of George Rothman, will play works by Mozart, Beethoven and Schumann tonight at 8 at Rathaus Hall, on the Queens College campus.

title: Heavy Traffic: Beach Bummer
description: The project was supposed to take only 18 months and disrupt traffic for only one summer. But rebuilding of the half-mile Coney Island viaduct on New York City's Belt Parkway now lags at least a year behind schedule.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday about children's falls from apartment windows misstated the address of an 8-year-old girl, Jennifer Rios, who was injured on Tuesday. Her building is at 37 East First Street in Manhattan, not 37 First Avenue.

title: NBC AGAIN TOPS EMMY LIST
description: ABC's ''Moonlighting'' and five NBC programs, including the top-rated ''Cosby Show,'' swept the nominations today for television's 38th annual prime-time Emmy Awards.

title: BRINTEC CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain from the repurchase of certain long- term debt instruments prior to scheduled maturity of $955,000 for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Bob Dorough, Gregory's, 1149 First Avenue at 63d Street (371-2220). Bob writer, admits that he is ''hooked on old songs.'' But that's only the beginning of his addiction. He is also hooked on be-bop, jazz humor and his own songs - which include lyrics to Paul Desmond's tune ''Take Five,'' and one for which he used the definition of ''love'' in Webster's New Collegiate Dictionary as a lyric. He sings them with an unabashed Arkansas twang and, with his bassist, Bill Takas, takes off on piano solos that cover blues, boogie-woogie and pop songs kicked along with an Erroll Garner beat. Mr. Dorough starts bubkeeps going until 3 A.M. There is a $6 cover charge both nights and a two-drink minimum.

title: ANGELS WIN, 8-5, ON 2 SLAMS
description: Brian Downing and Bob Boone hit first-pitch grand slams in consecutive innings today to lead the California Angels to an 8-5 triumph over the Oakland A's.

title: FIRST CENTRAL FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: CORRECTION
description: The headline and opening paragraph of a Miami dispatch on Monday, about a change in categories for AIDS victims, incorrectly described the application to Haitians.

title: PULASKI FURNITURE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 6
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in June.

title: Coke-Dr Pepper Deal Is Blocked
description: A Federal District Court Judge today issued a preliminary injunction against the Coca-Cola Company, halting its bid to buy the Dr Pepper Company for $470 million.

title: Teen-Ager Is Accused Of Computer Tapping
description: The police have accused a teen-age boy of using his home computer to break into computers nationwide, including those of school systems and Congress.

title: EXCERPTS FROM QUESTIONING OF REHNQUIST IN SENATE COMMITTEE
description: Following are excerpts from a transcript of hearings before the Senate Judiciary Committee in Washington yesterday on the nomination of Associate Justice William H. Rehnquist to be Chief Justice of the United States, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: THERE may be Tex-Mex restaurants with good food or good drink or even both, but they don't have the spirit, according to Edward Gregg Wallace Jr. of Houston.

title: OLYMPIC GOLD NETS PRO GOLD
description: Since 1976, an Olympic medal has been the best way for a fighter to get rich quickly as a professional. The value of Olympic success in Montreal was reflected in the $1.6 million, 13-fight deal that Dennis Rappaport and Mike Jones, co-managers of Howard Davis, struck with CBS for their boxer at the start of his career.

title: Net Executive Resigns
description: Lewis Schaffel, the executive vice president and chief operating officer of the Nets, resigned yesterday to join an ownership group attempting to bring a National Basketball Association expansion franchise to Miami. The group is headed by Zev Bufman, a theatrical producer, and Billy Cunningham, the former Philadelphia 76er star and coach.

title: BOARD RULES HIRSCHFELD IS QUALIFIED FOR PRIMARY
description: The State Board of Elections, in a rebuff to Governor Cuomo, ruled yesterday that Abraham Hirschfeld had qualified for the Sept. 9 Democratic primary ballot for lieutenant governor.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Scott Skiles, the first-round pick of the Milwaukee Bucks out of Michigan State in the college draft and the Big Ten's leading scorer last season, pleaded no contest yesterday to a charge of drunken driving. The judge deferred Skiles's sentencing for up to five weeks pending a presentencing report.

title: PO FOLKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
description: b-Net income

title: A PACT IN GOAL POST INJURY
description: Margaret Cimino, the Harvard student seriously injured when she was struck by a falling goal post at the Yale-Harvard football game on Nov. 19, 1983, will receive an out-of-court settlement of $925,000, according to her lawyer, Kenneth Finger. Miss Cimino, of North Tarrytown, was injured as fans tore down the goal post at the game's end. She filed a $50 million lawsuit against yale and the City of New Haven.

title: A Poultry Play In Drought
description: NEVER let it be said that adversity cannot provide opportunity on Wall Street. The worst drought in a century for the Southeast has taken its toll not only in human lives but also in crops, livestock, chickens and turkeys.

title: NATIONAL HEALTH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a writeoff of $340,000 related to debt refinancing for the quarter and 9 months.

title: Converse Receives Bid From Interco
description: Converse Inc., the sports shoe maker based in Lawrence, Mass., has received an offer of $28 a share from Interco Inc. in a takeover bid valued at $146 million. Converse stock rose $10 a share yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, closing at $26.75.

title: MACMILLAN BLOEDEL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a $45 million gain on the sale of part of its interest in a Dutch paper company. There were no share earnings in the year-ago 6 months' results because preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income.

title: EUROPEAN BLOC REJECTS GATT FARM ACCORD
description: European Community countries rallied round France today in rejecting agricultural concessions that have been backed by the Reagan Administration in preparatory talks for upcoming international negotiations on free trade.

DELAYED SENIORS WAIT AND PRACTICE
description: In one of the offices of the Commemorative tournament, a young volunteer was saying, ''I'll find out as soon as that guy gets off the phone.''

ALASKAN WILDLIFE REFUGE IS EYED BY OIL INDUSTRY
description: The next great conflict pitting energy development against wildlife conservation is gathering momentum on the nation's Arctic frontier.

title: Renaissance Festival
description: Period entertainment, from jousting to Shakespeare, will be featured at the Ninth New York Renaissance Festival, which opens tomorrow at Sterling Forest, Tuxedo, N.Y. The festival, which runs Saturdays and Sundays through Sept. 21, also features dancing, music, games, crafts and food.

title: MASSENET'S QUIXOTIC VISION
description: It is surprising that Jules Massenet, who at least partly deserves his reputation for having written operas primarily out of ''an insistent concern with feminine sexual psychology'' (as Martin Cooper puts it in the New Grove Dictionary), should have composed an operatic version of ''Don Quixote.'' That rarity, first performed at the Monte Carlo Opera in 1910, enters the repertory of the New York City Opera tonight in a production starring Samuel Ramey and conducted by Mario Bernardi.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL METS VS. MONTREAL EXPOS, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M., Radio - WHN 1050, 7:30 P.M.) YANKEES VS.

title: Kenya Detains U.N. Editor
description: A United Nations journalist in Kenya was stripped of his passport and briefly detained there last week, officials of the world body said today. The officials said the journalist, Salim Lone, the New York-based editor of the Africa Emergency Report, was taken from his hotel room by security officers Tuesday and again on Wednesday. He was released Wednesday after strong protests by United Nations officials.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Those who persistently and voluntarily engage in illegal acts should not be permitted to enter or remain in the Federal work force.'' - Constance Horner, director of the Federal Office of Personnel Management, urging that Government employees who abuse drugs be dismissed. [ B4:5. ]

title: Achille Lauro Defendant Seized in West Berlin
description: A Lebanese man convicted and sentenced in absentia in Italy for his role in the Achille Lauro hijacking has been arrested in West Berlin, the police reported today.

title: Louganis Takes Platform Diving
description: Greg Louganis earned three perfect 10's tonight on his way to victory in the 3-meter platform diving competition at the United States Olympic Festival.

description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $251,000 for the quarter and 6 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $763,000 and $1,113,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Dynamics Director Is Backed
description: An independent hearing examiner at the Department of Defense ruled yesterday that Lester Crown, a member of the board of the General Dynamics Corporation and the company's largest shareholder, could keep his top-secret security clearance.

title: HETEROSEXUAL AIDS CATEGORY ALTERED BY U.S.
description: Federal health officials today revised a reporting category for AIDS cases, reflecting new knowledge about heterosexual transmission of the fatal disease.

description: The company said its results reflect a 50-percent stock dividend paid July 1.

Crude Oil Ends Lower; Petroleum Products Off
description: Prices of crude oil and petroleum products closed lower on the world oil market yesterday after fluctuating sharply on confusing reports of the meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

title: Western Union And GTE in Deal
description: The GTE Corporation said it had agreed to buy Airfone Inc., which provides airline-passenger telephone service.

AUCTIONS
description: THE decline of the dollar against foreign currencies over the last year had a major impact on art-auction sales worldwide, and helped swell totals to record levels in this period, according to spokesmen at Sotheby's and Christie's, which issued preliminary sales figures yesterday for the 12-month season ending Aug. 31.

description: b-Includes $399,780 from fire insurance claim for both quarter and 6 months. c-Net loss

title: NEW ASSIGNING SYSTEM CUTTING COURT BACKLOG
description: A new system of one-judge, one-case justice has cut the backlog of pending felony cases in New York City by more than 16 percent since it was introduced in January, court administrators announced yesterday.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report last Sunday in the Going On in the Northeast column gave an incorrect date for a performance at Tanglewood in Lenox, Mass. The ''Brass Spectacular'' will be presented tonight (not tomorrow) at 9.

title: AMERICAN HERITAGE LIFE INESTMENT reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes capital gains of $329,946 for the quarter and $510,346 for the 6 months. c-Includes capital gains of $57,791 and $77,484 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Diner's Journal
description: THE sunny and bucolic Provence region of France seems to strike a nostalgic chord in nearly all who pass through. If you did not have the good fortune to return for a summer vacation this year, some consolation may be found at a handsome new bistro in Greenwich Village that specializes in that area's fresh and herbaceous cuisine. Called Provence, it is owned by Michel Jean, former maitre d'hotel at Regine's and captain at Le Cirque, and his wife, Patricia. They took over a dark, wood-trimmed Italian restaurant with a backyard garden called Gordon's and brightened it with pale yellow walls, scallop-shaped sconces and dried flowers.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL CLEVELAND (AL) - Signed Greg Swindell, pitcher, and assigned him to Waterloo of the Midwest League.

title: STILL NO OPEC ACCORD
description: A deeply split Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries muddled through a fourth day of inconclusive talks today in desperate search of a formula to stop the slide in oil prices.

title: Xerox, Unit Offer Bonds in Europe
description: The Xerox Corporation and the Xerox Credit Corporation are each selling $100 million of bonds in the Euromarket through Nomura International Ltd.

title: 3 Concerts Scheduled For Waterloo Festival
description: Three concerts are on the Waterloo Festival schedule this weekend. Tonight, faculty artists from the Waterloo School of Music will play chamber music by Copland, Strauss, Poulenc and Vincent D'Indy at Lenfell Hall on the campus of Fairleigh Dickinson University in Madison, N.J.

title: BILL WOULD CURB PRETORIA DATA
description: A Senate committee is preparing legislation that would limit the information American intelligence agencies could share with South Africa about that country's black opposition groups, committee members said today.

Chico Hamilton
description: The drummer Chico Hamilton is leading his sextet, featuring three alto saxophonists, tonight through Sunday at the Whippoorwill, 18 East 18th Street (675-7100). Sets are at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is a $15 cover tonight and tomorrow, a $10 cover Sunday and a two-drink minimum.

title: PLANE CRASHES IN MEXICO CITY
description: A small plane crashed on a major downtown avenue today, grazing a building, damaging five cars and injuring at least 16 people, the officials said.

description: A surprising debate has opened in Britain on the value of the Commonwealth, sparked by the angry quarrel over South Africa.

title: Kemp and Foggy Bottom
description: If Representative Jack F. Kemp wins both the Republican Presidential nomination and the general election in 1988, look for some fairly fundamental changes over at the State Department. The Fund for an American Renaissance, the tax-free foundation of which the upstate New Yorker is honorary chairman, is undertaking a ''project for an effective United States foreign policy,'' to develop new ways for the country ''to expand freedom and maintain peace.''

COMMUNISTS CLAIM COMRADESHIP WITH REBELS
description: The shadowy South African Communist Party surfaced here on the occasion of its 65th anniversary Wednesday, packing a meeting hall as it shared a stage with the African National Congress and ridiculed charges that Communists dominate the congress, the leading group fighting white domination of the nation's black majority.

title: ENERGY FACTORS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
The Bottom Line
description: In this era of Government economy, the old axiom that liberals are carefree spenders and indifferent bookkeepers may have to be re-examained. The House Wednesday Group is a caucus of 35 Republican lawmakers who used to call themselves ''liberals'' but now prefer ''moderates''; its deputy staff director, Gretchen Pagel, was disturbed to discover the other day that a Washington bank had imposed a $4.81 serv-ice charge on the group's checking account.

title: UNENFORCEABLE COVENANTS ARE IN MANY DEEDS
description: Testimony by Associate Justice William H. Rehnquist about two deed covenants has directed new attention to a widespread practice in American real estate: the effort to control the future uses of property, or to protect it against a presumed misuse, by deed restrictions.

description: The share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in June.

title: Fundamentalist to Face Charge in Custody Case
description: A State Court of Appeal reinstated a criminal charge today against a fundamentalist woman who cited her ex-husband's homosexuality as a motive for taking their son from him.

title: U.S. AND JAPAN RESOLVE DISPUTE ON MICROPCHIPS
description: The United States and Japan today announced a settlement of a bitter trade dispute involving computer chips.

title: FOR L.I. BLACKS, PROSPERITY IS A RELATIVE TERM
description: Lawrence Cooper sat in the living room of his home here and talked enthusiastically about his role as managing partner in a black-owned Burger King franchise now under construction in Brooklyn.

title: Heavy Traffic: Crosstown Triumph
description: Weekday cab and bus riders in midtown Manhattan are hailing a bold experiment creating special bus and taxi corridors on 49th and 50th Streets. It has speeded midtown traffic and reduced air pollution.

title: PANEL SETS ASIDE AQUINO JUDGEMENT
description: A special commission today set aside the results of a trial that acquitted the former military chief, Gen. Fabian C. Ver, and 25 others in the 1983 murder of President Corazon C. Aquino's husband, Benigno.

title: SCREEN: FROM GEORGE LUCAS, 'HOWARD THE DUCK'
description: THE amazing news about Howard the Duck has nothing to do with what he looks like on screen, or whether the film shares the goofy irreverence that made the 1970's comic book, on which the movie is based, a cult favorite. The surprise is that Howard turns out to be dispensable in his own movie. ''Howard the Duck'' begins as a mild satire about a duck who fell to earth, but midway through, the star is upstaged by horrifying demons and dazzling light shows.

title: DR. STANLEY T. MICHAEL
description: Dr. Stanley T. Michael, a psychiatrist, died of cancer last Friday at his home in Ossining, N.Y. He was 74 years old.

description: International

title: A Marketing Director To Become a Professor
description: Robert F. Lauderborn is resigning his job as director of marketing communications and corporate advertising at the International Paper Company on Aug. 15 to become the first James L. Knight Professor of Advertising at the University of North Carolina School of Journalism.

title: MAYOR HAS BIG TROUBLE IN 'THE CITY' ON ABC
description: ''THE CITY'' is about a regular guy, who, pressed beyond endurance, kidnaps a rich newspaper publisher and threatens to blow his head off. Not to worry, however, because things turn out all right, sort of, in the end. The utterly goofy, but not entirely implausible, one-hour ABC movie can be seen on Channel 7 at 9 tonight.

title: A COMPOSER AT HOME IN TANGLEWOOD
description: The British composer Oliver Knussen has been closely associated with the Tanglewood Music Center for most of his life - first as a student, later as a visitor and conductor, and now, this summer, as the center's composer-in-residence.

description: This September, after he turns 16, Frank Stewart hopes to work in a Burger King in the South Bronx. But Frank, who is in the Clean Team/ Green Team summer employment program, recently wrote his job description for 1996:

title: RESTAURANTS
description: I'M not sure where young upwardly mobile professionals in Mexico City dine these days, but I suspect their haunts have a few things in common with Rosa Mexicano on 58th Street and First Avenue in Manhattan: a stylish ambiance, gregarious clientele, a good-time bar and a diverse range of bracing foods. Rosa Mexicano eschews the leaden and starchy cliches of most Mexican restaurants in New York and attempts to serve what Mexicans really eat. It's also one of the few such places where you will not wish for a stretcher to carry you home after dinner.

description: An expanded, five-year renewal of the multibillion-dollar Federal program to clean up thousands of toxic waste dumps finally cleared a Senate-House conference committee by voice vote tonight.

description: Orders to United States factories for manufactured goods dropped three-tenths of 1 percent in June, the fourth decline in the last six months, the Government said today.

description: A leading member of the trade union Solidarity, Bogdan Lis, was released from prison today, becoming the first prominent opposition figure to be freed under Poland's new clemency act.

description: Assets of the nation's 363 money market mutual funds rose $543.8 million, to $231.54 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

description: It was a hearing filled with dramatic exchanges, literate oratory, old yarns and fast-paced legal jousting.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: ''I JUST asked Richard. I said, 'What's what?' He said, 'Oh, yes, you're doing it.' I said, 'Well, thank you.' I was happy, of course.''

title: Boyd Suspension Ends
description: The Boston Red Sox will reactivate Dennis (Oil Can) Boyd today, ending weeks of suspension for the pitcher after personal problems on and off the field. After hospitalization and a complete medical evaluation, which Boyd said included negative test results for drugs, the team physician, Dr. Arthur Pappas, gave him medical clearance to resume full activity.

title: JEFS SPICE WINNER IN OAKS
description: Jefs Spice won by two lengths in the first heat and took the second heat by a nose tonight to capture the $397,000 Hambletonian Oaks for 3-year-old filly trotters at the Meadowlands.

description: b-Net loss and includes net of $18,936,000 from discontinued operations. Preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income in the latest quarter. The year-ago quarter figures include equity income of $15.8 million from First Nationwide Financial Corp., which was sold in December 1985, and $3.1 million from the materials distribution business, the sale of which is being finalized. The company said its equity in net loss from its 50 percent interest in National Steel Corp. totaled $2,297,000 in the latest quarter, compared with a loss of $10.8 million for the year-ago period. The sales increased during the latest first quarter due to the acquisition of Foxmeyer Corp. in March 1986, and the Permian Corp. in August 1985.

title: SENATE SUPPORTS REPEAL OF A DOMESTIC OIL TAX
description: The Senate, in a surprise move, tonight voted to repeal the so-called windfall profits tax on domestic oil, a tax that is no longer raising revenue because of the sharp decline in oil prices.

title: Moffett's Bid Rejected In Primary Challenge
description: The State Supreme Court today rejected former Representative Toby Moffett's request for a hearing on a lower court's dismissal of his suit challenging the Democratic primary in Waterbury.

title: HIS MYSTERIES WON AWARDS
description: Stanley Ellin, a critically acclaimed mystery writer, died yesterday at Kings County Hospital in Brooklyn after suffering a heart attack about a week ago. He was 69 years old and lived in Brooklyn and Miami Beach.

title: Still Wooing Labor
description: The unavoidable fact that the endorsement of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. did not elect Walter F. Mondale President in 1984 does not seem to have reduced interest in labor's stamp of approval among potential contenders for the 1988 Democratic nomination.

title: Biaggi, en Espanol
description: Representative Mario Biaggi got a postcard the other day addressed to ''Estimado Representante Biaggi'' and opening ''Las importaciones estan perjudicando la economia Americana [ Imports are harming the American economy ] .''

title: Tying Reagan's Hands
description: Once again a Soviet-American arms control conference has broken up in frustration, with the U.S. side intransigent in defense of President Reagan's decision to abandon the unratified SALT II treaty. But finally the House of Representatives may be ready to put severe pressure on Mr. Reagan for movement on important arms control issues.

title: OSHKOSH B'GOSH INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Vuckovich to Return
description: Pete Vuckovich, the American League Cy Young Award winner in 1982 who decided to quit pitching last spring, will return to the mound in the minor leagues with the Milwaukee Brewers' Vancouver affiliate, initially for long-relief pitching. Vuckovich, 33 years old, announced March 30 that his playing days were ended after he had a shoulder problem in 1983, missed the 1984 season and underwent surgery last September after a 6-10 record in 22 starts in 1985. But while throwing for batting practice and working as a Brewers scout since March, he felt his shoulder was improving.

title: Delusions About Mental Health
description: With a rush, New York City's psychiatrists are practicing defensive medicine. That creates a crisis for already crowded mental hospitals, but it's hardly a surprise. It was a carelessly released mental patient who is accused of hacking and killing people with a sword on the Staten Island ferry on July 7. Mental health administrators sought to dismiss his release as an aberration. Actually, it reflects two decades of failure in the way society handles the mentally ill.

description: For some time now, it has been the fashion to offer last hurrahs for New York's Irish-American community. When they emigrated from the city to the suburbs in the 1950's, when they moved out of the working class and the Democratic Party, when they lost control of City Hall and the telephone company, when the prizefighters and crooners and writers were no longer Irish, it was said that the group was heading for bland assimilation.

title: BROADWAY
description: A LOT of New York brownstones are microcosms of the city, and one of them will be on stage Oct. 30 for the opening of the Roundabout Theater Company's 21st season. Unsurprisingly, the production, a musical, is called ''Brownstone,'' and if a little memory bell rings, it's because it was produced at the Hudson Guild in 1984. However, things have changed since then - lots of reworking, rewriting, re-everything, although, when it was originally produced, the script won the Richard Rodgers award for Best New American Musical. The musical, written by Andrew Cadiff, who is also directing, with a score by Peter Larson and Josh Rubins, is a tale of the life and loves of five young people - including a leftover flower child and a lawyer - who live in the same building.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, AUGUST 1, 1986
description: The Economy The U.S. and Japan settled their most heated trade dispute, involving computer chips. Japan said it would not sell chips in the U.S. below fair value and would give Americans access to the Japanese market. U.S. companies said they were pleased to end the dispute, which underscored the U.S.-Japan battle for the fast-growing $25 billion world market. [ Page A1. ] The settlement could mean a $2 billion increase in annual sales for American industry. [ D5. ] House conferees accepted limits on I.R.A. deductions as part of their bargaining position on tax revision legislation. [ D1. ] The Senate voted to repeal the so-called windfall profits tax on oil. The surprise move was expected to run into opposition in the House. [ A10. ] Weakness in the manufacturing sector was evident in a monthly survey of purchasing managers that featured gloomy reports in most categories. [ D1. ] Factory orders for manufactured goods fell 0.3 percent in June, the Commerce Department said. [ D6. ] Farmers' prices for raw products climbed 2.5 percent in July, helped by record prices for broiler chickens. [ D6. ] Markets The dollar's fall helped gold soar to a two-year high in active trading. The dollar reached its lowest level against the yen since the late 1940's, falling to 153.785 yen in New York. Traders reacted to remarks by Secretary of State Shultz that driving down the currency's value was one way to fight the nation's large trade deficit. In New York, gold bullion futures jumped $10.70, to $362.70 an ounce, the highest level since July 1984.

title: Zondervan Board Bid
description: The British investor Christopher John Moran, who controls 29.1 percent of the Zondervan Corporation, has demanded that the company grant him a majority of the seats on the board. Mr. Moran made his demand in a letter Wednesday to Zondervan that was contained in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. In the letter, Mr. Moran said he had the support of an additional 22 percent of Zondervan's shareholders and reiterated his offer to acquire the Grand Rapids, Mich., Bible publisher. In April, Mr. Moran first made his offer to acquire Zondervan for $23.50 a share, or a total of $86.5 million, but the Zondervan board rejected it. Mr. Moran, who controls a London-based private investment company, set a deadline of Aug. 6 for a response.

description: Chi Chi Rodriguez walked into the room today just as Arnold Palmer was finishing his interview.

title: FOR L.I. BIRDS, SURVIVAL HELP ALONG SHORE
description: For years, the battle has been one-sided: as more and more swimmers, surfers and sunbathers have gathered on Long Island's beaches, the birds that also spend each summer on the shore have been pushed out or crushed underfoot.

title: 4 REBUT TESTIMONY OF REHNQUIST ON CHALLENGING OF VOTERS IN 60's
description: Four witnesses, including a former Federal prosecutor, today contradicted Justice William H. Rehnquist's sworn testimony about his role in Republicans' Election Day efforts to challenge voter qualifications in Phoenix in the early 1960's.

title: CATTLE DRIVES BRINGS TRAFFIC TO HALT
description: Traffic backed up for eight miles on part of the New Jersey Turnpike today when the morning rush hour gave way to a cattle drive.

title: 2 Gallo Founders Sued by Brothers
description: A rift in the Gallo wine family widened as Joseph Gallo sued his famous older brothers, Ernest and Julio, seeking what he contends is his rightful inheritance - a one-third interest in their winery, the E.& J. Gallo Winery.

title: Bringing Computer Literacy to the Literati
description: ''I'm dying! I'm dying! I'm dying!''

title: Case of the Bleeding Jacket
description: JUST as the lunchtime crowd outside the Seagram Building was breaking up the other day, it began to rain. One noontime diner, on a 15-block walk back to his office, hurried along in the shower unprotected. He scoffed at the umbrella men with their $3 specials and the crowds huddled under restaurant awnings. Waiting out the storm was not for him.

description: Now the fierce partisan, now the student of the Constitution, with biting sarcasm or gentler gibes, Senator Orrin G. Hatch emerged from the Supreme Court confrimation hearings this week as the principal defender of the Reagan Administration and its nominee for Chief Justice, William H. Rehnquist.

title: STEELWORKERS OUTSIDE GATE EXPECT A LONG STOPPAGE
description: On the first day of the stoppage at the USX Corporation, five steelworkers sat in lawn chairs on the dirt beside the road, a blue plastic canopy stretched above them to block the sun, and discussed the prospects for settlement.

BUILDING OUTLAYS RISE
description: Construction spending rose one-tenth of 1 percent in June as gains in residential construction only partly offset weakness in other areas, the Commerce Department said today.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article in some copies of Metropolitan Report yesterday about the confirmation of Robert N. Wilentz as Chief Justice of the New Jersey Supreme Court misstated his remarks about his living arrangements in New York. The justice, who has lived virtually full time in Manhattan since his wife began chemotherapy there in 1984, said that if a bill to tighten residency rules for New Jersey officials became law and was found constitutional, he would either comply or resign.

title: Who Should Live, Who Should Die
description: To the Editor:

title: Man Killed Chasing Suspect
description: An East Hartford man died today after being shot while pursuing a man who did not pay for a pizza, the police said. Sgt. Gerald Kumnick said that Panpellis Filakouris, the 40-year-old owner of North Main Pizza, was shot in the abdomen at his pizza parlor at about 10:30 P.M. Thursday and taken to St. Francis Hospital, where he died at 2:30 A.M. Friday. No arrests have been made and the case is under investigation, Sergeant Kumnick said.

title: ASTREX INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The company said the latest quarter loss includes net unrealized losses on valuation of marketable securities of $791,000.

title: Ideal's Restructuring
description: Ideal Basic Industries Inc. of Denver said yesterday it had reached agreement with its preferred stockholder, the Anschutz Corporation, under which all of Anschutz's shares would be converted into common stock and Anschutz would receive 30.6 million new Ideal common shares, about 17.3 percent of the company's outstanding shares after a financial restructuring is completed.

title: ISC SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
PRETORIA DECREE IS AMENDED TO LIFT COURT CURB ON POLICE
description: President P. W. Botha amended the seven-week-old state of emergency regulations today to restore sweeping powers to regional police commissioners, whose authority to issue orders under the decree had been ruled illegal by a regional supreme court.

title: HICKAM, DOW B. INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
7 Policemen Arraigned In Exam-Peddling Plot
description: A police chief, two captains, a lieutenant, a sergeant, two officers and a retired aide to the State Senate pleaded not guilty today to charges of conspiracy and perjury.

title: Republicans and Robertson
description: Democratic leaders have challenged six Republican Presidential aspirants to take issue with the Rev. Pat Robertson's remark that ''Christians feel more strongly about love of country, love of God and support for the traditional family than do non-Christians.''

title: OPERA: MASSENET'S 'QUICHOTTE'
description: Massenet's ''Don Quichotte'' is a gentle old opera in the sentimental French tradition, a work perhaps easier to love than to admire. Masterly in a minor way, it can work its wiles only when a bass of great authority appears, falls in love with the title role and persuades a company to let him sing it. That is exactly why the New York City Opera's new production of ''Don Quichotte,'' which had its premiere last night, turned out to be a notable event. Mr. Ramey, as sweetly befuddled an old chevalier as ever tilted at a windmill, immediately took control of the stage, and finally of the audience's heart, in a performance that for once justified opera's often-abused star system.

title: Thurmond on Homosexuality
description: Excerpts from an exchange between Senator Strom Thurmond, chairman of the Judiciary Committee, and Jeffrey W. Levi, executive director of the National Gay and Lesbian Task Force, at a hearing on the nomination of Associate Justice William H. Rehnquist to be Chief Justice, July 31:

title: UNCOMPROMISING JERSEY CHIEF JUSTICE: ROBERT NATHAN WILENTZ
description: Former Governor and Chief Justice Richard J. Hughes sat in the State Senate chamber Thursday night as the 40-member house agonized over the reappointment of the man who had succeeded him as Chief Justice, Robert N. Wilentz.

description: Transparent rubber has been invented for the Battelle Development Corporation of Columbus, Ohio.

title: I.C.C. Asked to Lift Bar to Rail Merger
description: The Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation said it would ask the Interstate Commerce Commission to reverse its decision to block the proposed merger of the Santa Fe and Southern Pacific railroads into what was to have been the country's third-largest rail system. ''I will try to get the decision turned around as soon as possible,'' the holding company's president, John J. Schmidt, said this afternoon at a news conference.

title: GENERAL REFRACTORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $300,000 for the quarter and $500,000 for the 6 months. c-After tax credits of $450,000 and $950,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Dick Howser, the manager of the Kansas City Royals, who had surgery for a brain tumor 11 days ago, paid a surprise visit to the Royals' office for an hour Thursday to meet with team officials. Howser, who is undergoing radiation treatment five times a week, plans to speak to his team when it begins a home stand Aug. 12. . . . The New Orleans Saints signed their No. 1 draft choice, Jim Dombrowski, an offensive tackle from Virginia, to a four-year contract.

title: One That Got Away
description: To the Editor:

title: Allied-Signal's Buyback Program
description: Allied-Signal Inc. said that its board had considered various proposals to reduce the number of common shares it has outstanding but decided to stick with a buyback program that is already under way.

title: NOBLE AFFILIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income and includes losses from discontinued operations of $4,191,000 for the quarter and $8,485,000 for the 6 months.

title: Ted Turner's Bow to Soviet Anti-Israel Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: Millionaire for a Handshake
description: Larry LaGrow and Kay Lascelle, who had a handshake agreement to share if either won the Illinois lottery, said today that they would stick by their agreement after Mr. LaGrow won $3.3 million.

title: First Oklahoma Halts Paying Debt
description: The First Oklahoma Bancorporation said it was temporarily suspending payment of the principal and interest on more than $130 million of debt and that further payments would await a management review. The company's major subsidiary and only banking unit, the First National Bank and Trust Company of Oklahoma City, was declared insolvent earlier this month and sold to First Interstate Bancorp of Los Angeles.

title: McEnroe Marries
description: The tennis star John McEnroe married the actress Tatum O'Neal in a private ceremony yesterday at St. Dominic's Roman Catholic Church in Oyster Bay, L.I. The 27-year-old groom, whose parents live in Oyster Bay Cove, has been living with the actress since 1984, She had a son by him on May 23.

title: Examination For Wynegar
description: Butch Wynegar has been quiet the last few days, often shunning interviews, since Joel Skinner, acquired in the trade on Tuesday, was named the regular catcher. A teammate said Thursday that Wynegar seemed to be depressed. Today a club spokesman, Harvey Greene, announced that Wynegar was ''tired,'' had left the team Thursday morning and returned to New York for tests. The Yankees placed Wynegar on their restricted list, meaning he cannot play or sign with another team.

title: NWA-Pilots Deal
description: Northwest Airlines' parent company, NWA Inc., said it had reached an agreement with the Air Line Pilots Association to avoid laying off pilots on its current seniority list for at least one year after it acquires Republic Airlines Inc. The Transportation Department approved the merger, which is expected to take place by mid-August, on Thursday. NWA said it had offered the same deal to Republic pilots, who are represented by the same union, and that the pilots are considering the offer.

title: DOWNEY SAVINGS & LOAN ASSOCIATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the year-ago quarter net includes a special loan transaction which contributed about $7 million to income.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, AUGUST 2, 1986
description: International

title: MOSCOW VODKA IS UP AND, WHAT'S WORSE, OUT
description: The mood of the crowd outside the No. 14 liquor store in central Moscow was sullen today. The price of vodka was up. Again. Fifteen months after the Government announced stiff measures against alcohol abuse, and 11 months after prices were raised, the cost of a bottle of vodka went up by 20 to 25 percent.

title: Labor Endorses Republican
description: The state branch of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. voted overwhelmingly today to endorse Gov. James R. Thompson for re-election, the first time in the state labor federation's history that it has endorsed a Republican. The Governor's main opponent, Adlai E. Stevenson 3d, won the endorsement in 1982. One delegate, Tom Stockton, said, ''What you saw here today was not an endorsement for a good Governor, but rather an anti-Adlai sentiment that prevails.''

title: JEFFERSON NATIONAL BANK reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BLOCK DRUG CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Craxi Sworn In Again As Italy's Premier
description: Italy's 45th postwar Government was sworn in today, and Bettino Craxi, a Socialist, is again the Prime Minister.

title: PACT REACHED ON NEW CONCRETE PLANT
description: Mayor Koch, aiming to break what he called a monopoly in the concrete industry in Manhattan, announced yesterday that a plant would be built along the Hudson River to supply concrete at reduced prices for at least five years.

title: Making Arms in the Revolving Door
description: July was not a splendid month for the image of America's arms makers.

title: WEAR-AND-WASH HAIR COLOR IN RAINBOW SHADES
description: New hair-coloring mousses and gels allow the consumer to flirt with contemporary fashion without marrying it: they come in such shades as bright orange, red, gold and green, along with more natural colors, but they wash out with shampoo.

title: Who Will Go to Pretoria?
description: White House sources say the effort to settle on a choice for an ambassador to South Africa is intensifying and a selection will be made soon. But five people are still in the running, only two of whom have been publicly named, Terence A. Todman, the senior black officer in the Foreign Service, and another ca-reer diplomat who is black, Edward J. Perkins, the leading State Department expert on Liberia. Mr. Todman has been considered the favored candidate for the job, particularly since Mr. Perkins's expertise continues to be badly needed as Ambassador to Liberia. But Mr. Todman's purportedly cautious approach to human rights issues has been criticized by some State Department officials, and he is said to be unenthusiastic about the Pretoria post, although he would accept it if asked.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SOLIDARITY'S DAY

title: Progress Is Reported In Actors' Union Talks
description: Negotiators for actors and producers reached a ''philosophical agreement'' on some major issues, a union official said today, and both sides said they hoped a strike could be averted.

title: Tandon Ties Loss to Shifts
description: The Tandon Corporation announced today that it would discontinue the domestic manufacturing of its Winchester disk drives. It also said that its shift to microcomputer manufacturing would result in a substantial loss for the third quarter and affect earnings at least through the end of the year.

title: SENATE UNIT VOTES STRICT SANCTIONS ON SOUTH AFRICA
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted overwhelmingly today for strict economic sanctions on South Africa, including a ban on any new loans or investments by American businesses.

title: WAS AIDE TO PIUS XI
description: Carlo Cardinal Confalonieri, the dean of the College of Cardinals for the last nine years and a leading aide to Pope Pius XI in the 1920's and 30's, died today at the Vatican. He was 93 years old.

title: Surgeon Married To Miss Chandler
description: In the chapel at the Brick Presbyterian Church in New York yesterday Gail Chandler, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kent Chandler Jr. of Lake Forest, Ill., was married to Dr. James Pinchot Gaston of New York and Hurricane Island, Me., a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. William Gaston of New York. The Rev. Dr. Herbert B. Anderson performed the ceremony.

title: Insurance Plan After Layoffs
description: A NEW law took effect last month requiring employers to offer continued health care coverage to retired or laid-off workers and their dependents. As a result, millions of Americans will be able to buy medical and hospital insurance at a price far below what it would cost them to purchase individually, if indeed they were able to purchase it at all.

title: Entry Is 4-5 Choice In Hambletonian
description: A field of 25 will compete in the featured stakes and a field of two in a supporting stakes Saturday as the Meadowlands stages the Hambletonian Trot and the United States Pacing Championship.

title: Cuomo Says Hirschfeld Is Unfit to Be Governor
description: Governor Cuomo declared yesterday that Abraham Hirschfeld, the developer who is challenging Representative Stan Lundine for the Democratic nomination for lieutenant governor, is ''not qualified to be governor.''

description: Three men were arrested yesterday on Federal charges that they participated in one of the largest thefts of cash in United States history, the $7.9 million robbery of a Wells Fargo depot in Manhattan last year.

description: The cruise liner Emerald Seas set sail for the Caribbean with about 900 passengers today, two days after an explosion and fire forced the evacuation of the ship and injured 17 people.

description: Malaysians will vote in national and state elections this weekend that Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad has been been portraying as a choice between stability and chaos.

title: Tatiana Schaufuss Is Dead; Founded Immigrant Center
description: Tatiana Schaufuss, co-founder of the Tolstoy Foundation, a refugee aid organization, and founder of the Tolstoy Foundation Nursing Home in Valley Cottage, N.Y., died July 25 at the nursing home, where she lived, after a long illness. She was 95 years old.

title: Salon Bon Ton
description: The funk group Salon Bon Ton will be host at a free concert and jam session, featuring a performance by the dancer Jody Oberfelder-Rheim, tomorrow from 1 to 5 P.M. at Battery Park. Audience members are invited to bring instruments. Information: 675-8189.

title: PITTSBURGH & WEST VIRGINIA R R reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Quotation of the Day
description: ''I pray for those being held captive, and I also pray for my captors.'' - The Rev. Lawrence Martin Jenco. [ 2:5. ]

title: Ex-Mayor Gets Prison Term
description: Former Mayor William C. Rado of Naugatuck was sentenced today to two years in prison and fined $3,000 for taking three $1,000 bribes from a local contractor five years ago. Mr. Rado was expected to be released on a $5,000 bond, while awaiting a hearing on his appeal of last month's conviction. Mr. Rado was sentenced to two years on each of the three counts. The terms would be served concurrently.

description: b-Net loss

title: Fly in the Soup?
description: Five years ago, workers in the Senate restaurants tried to organize and force their employer, the Senate, to bargain with them. In response, the Senate proposed turning the restaurants over to private contractors. The workers voted to stop organizing, and the Senate stopped proposing to turn to private contractors.

title: Recreating the 40's and 50's In the West Village
description: From the stoop of his restaurant, shuttered for three days while a movie is filmed at the corner of Perry and West Fourth Streets, Estefano Arguellez surveyed a line of vintage cars parked at the curb, all with the bulbous silhouettes of the 40's and 50's.

title: MEDSTAT SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $55,000 for the quarter and $115,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss

title: The Legacy of Secretariat
description: Lady's Secret runs against the boys in the Whitney Handicap today at Saratoga, and the Saratoga yearling auctions begin Tuesday night at the Humphrey S. Finney Pavilion a few blocks away. There is a connection here.

title: AIR CARGO WAR RPOVES COSTLY
description: By most measures, the air cargo business appears to be booming. Big gains were posted in revenue, pounds carried and number of shipments in 1985 and, by one estimate, the market for shipping everything from envelopes to heavy machinery will nearly triple this decade, from $3.8 billion in 1980 to $10.9 billion in 1990.

title: THE SCREEN: JASON LIVES IN 'FRIDAY THE 13TH, PART VI'
description: It is a dark and stormy night. Tommy Jarvis escapes from the mental institution where he has been since he killed Jason, the town terror who hacked his way through dozens of bodies in five previous ''Friday the 13th'' movies. Tommy is a driven man, compelled by a logic known only to scriptwriters of sequels. He is determined to dig up and destroy Jason's corpse, just to make sure he's dead, like going back to make sure you've turned off the stove after you've left the house. Tommy digs up the decomposing body, the music swells, lightning strikes Jason through the heart and . . . well, you know the rest. This movie, after all, is called ''Friday the 13th, Part VI: Jason Lives.''

title: RYAN HOMES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

PATENTS;
Phone Mount for Bed
description: John J. Rosten of Pacoima, Calif., a member of the Inventors Licensing and Marketing Agency in Tarzana, was granted patent 4,602,755 this week for a telephone mount for a hospital bed designed to be clamped to the bed's top rail within the patient's reach. There is room to store extra cord, which will not be an underfoot hazard for personnel working around the bed. The bed can be raised and lowered without moving the phone.

title: JAPANESE UNEASY ON CHIP PACT
description: Some semiconductor makers said here today that they fear Japan's new semiconductor agreement with the United States could undermine their competitiveness against emerging chip manufacturers in such countries as South Korea.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 10. 1. A second row of armor plates down the spine. Paleontologist now believe the animal had a single line of plates that operated as solar energy panels. 2. Father Jenco, an American priest who was freed after nearly 19 months as a hostage in Lebanon, would reply ''a taxicab'' when his captors asked him if he wanted anything. 3. The hull, in 14,000 feet of water, looked as though the collision had loosened or buckled the hull plates, rather than gashed the starboard side. 4. Miss Dori calmly switched violins three times during a performance of Leonard Bernstein's ''Serenade'' because the E string on two of the instruments broke. 5. Contamination of the city's water supply was apparently caused by gypsy-moth caterpillar droppings. 6. LeMond became the first non-European to win the Tour de France, the world's premier cycling event, since it was first held in 1903. 7. Air Force Secretary Edward C. Aldridge said it had been decided to shut the shuttle-launching port at Vandenberg Air Force Base in California because shuttles can lift twice as much cargo from the Kennedy Space Center in Florida and, with only three shuttles now available and a backlog of satellites to be lofted, it did not make sense to use Vandenberg. 8. A hole over the South Pole in the ozone layer, which shields the Earth from the Sun's ultraviolet rays. 9. King Hassan II of Morocco resigned as summit chairman of the Arab League after strenuous criticism from some Arab countries of his recent meeting with Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel. 10. Bagels. 11.

title: Federal Plan Outlined
description: House leaders today outlined the major elements of a comprehensive antidrug bill and vowed to spend whatever is needed to reduce drug abuse.

title: CALIFORNIA TOWN, ALL SET FOR SHUTTLE, PLANS A SMALLER FUTURE
description: For several years residents here have been preparing for thousands of tourists to descend for West Coast launchings of the space shuttle and for hundreds of aerospace workers to bring those launchings about. A construction boom deposited half a dozen new motels along the main streets, and tracts of new houses and apartments filled fields where farmers once grew flowers for seed for gardeners around the world.

title: State Moves on Crack
description: In an emergency response to the proliferation of the drug crack, New York State will order its residential drug-treatment programs on Monday to disregard already overcrowded conditions and try to admit more addicts, the state's top drug-treatment official said yesterday.

title: Man Swept Away by Flood
description: Thunderstorms drenched western New York today, causing waist-high flash floods that forced the evacuation of more than 200 families. One man, Samuel Skrzypek of Saline, Mich., was swept away by floodwaters and was presumed dead, the police said.

title: We Need a Secretary Of War Against Drugs
description: ''A War Worth Waging, Carefully'' (editorial, July 18), on United States actions to combat drug sales from Bolivia, underscored the many complications in our war against illegal drugs. In view of the national crisis that the arrival of crack has brought, fighting this war should become our top domestic priority.

title: SECRET WEAPON FOR ATTACKING HARD-SHELLED CRABS
description: After 26 years of eating hard-shelled crabs in Washington crab houses, up and down the Maryland and Delaware coast and on the shores of the Chesapeake Bay, I considered myself a pro at extracting the sweet, white meat locked in the hard red shells. title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 46. 1. Something is missing in this new paleontological profile of the Stegosaurus, one of the most familiar dinosaurs. What is it? 2. ''A taxicab,'' was the Rev. Lawrence Jenco's invariable reply. What was the question and what were the circumstances? 3. A discovery by the expedition that photographed the wreck of the Titanic seems to dispel a belief about how the vessel sank and may explain why so many of the survivors said they barely felt a jolt as the ship sideswiped an iceberg. What is the discovery? 4. Mi Dori, a diminutive 14-year-old violinist, pulled off a triple play at a rare Tanglewood performance. What did she do? 5. Caterpillars were the culprits in a mystery that baffled Rochester, N.Y., for three weeks. Explain. 6. Greg LeMond's achievement was a first. What did he do? 7. A new, $2.8 billion facility on the West Coast that has never been used will be closed, the Air Force announced, at least until 1992. What facility is it and what is the reason? 8. In three weeks an unusual research expedition will fly into the dead of the Antarctic winter to study a hole whose growth is a cause of alarm. What hole is it? 9. Citing ''upheavals,'' a head of state resigned as chairman of a multinational group. Who is he, what group is it and to what was he referring? 10.

title: Bond Prices Decline Modestly
description: Recovering from early losses that at times exceeded half a point, Government bond prices closed with modest losses yesterday. Bill rates finished basically unchanged after moving narrowly all day.

title: Harvard Student Settles
description: The Harvard University student who was struck in the head by a goal post at the 100th Yale-Harvard football game in 1983 will receive payments expected to total about $850,000, according to New Haven city officials.

title: New Toyota Car
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation of Japan said it would begin production of a new subcompact car next month at a factory it owns jointly with the General Motors Corporation in Fremont, Calif. Toyota said it expected to build between 10,000 and 12,000 of the new FX 16 cars in 1986, with 1987 production projected at between 40,000 and 50,000.

title: A 3RD CAR BOMB ROCKS BEIRUT
description: A large bomb exploded at a busy intersection in Christian East Beirut today, and the police said one man was killed and 30 people were wounded.

title: U.S. IS SENDING AID TO FARMERS HURT BY DROUGHT
description: A multibillion-dollar Federal program to give financial relief to tens of thousands of farmers in the drought-seared Southern and Middle Atlantic states was put into action today, a week after the Administration said it could not legally take such action.

title: PLAN FOR A 5-YEAR TOXIC WASTE PROGRAM IS PRAISED
description: A $9 billion plan to strengthen the Federal program to clean up toxic industrial pollution, approved by a conference committee Thursday night, met wide acceptance from environmental groups today.

title: BERLINER ESCAPES IN RUSSIAN DISGUISE

The committee is made up of representatives of the insurers, suppliers and utility companies owed money by LTV, along with one union representative.

title: NETWROKS' MOVES MARK THE END OF BROADCAST ROW
description: When the Sixth Avenue el was still a recent memory and when ad agencies, not networks, produced most of the programs in television's infancy, the Avenue of the Americas north of 42d Street was a corridor bustling with postwar energy. Up and down the avenue that came to be called Broadcast Row, young men and a few women tackled with vigor a novel new medium - live television - that captured the imagination of the country.

title: CONCERN IS ON RISE OVER WIND SHEAR
description: Pilots, air traffic controllers and airline operators are warier than ever of thunderstorms and potentially disastrous wind shears, the sudden shifts of wind that can slam a low-flying plane to the ground, and their caution has led to more delays on landings and takeoffs, according to officials of the Federal Aviation Administration and the Airline Pilots Association.

title: A TASTE FOR PICTURESQUE SALT-AND-PEPPER SHAKERS
description: Novelty salt-and-pepper shakers, produced mostly from the 1920's through the 1960's, may be viewed as the ultimate in trivia, as souvenirs of travel or as trendy collectibles. Gideon Bosker sees them as all these things, as well as ''another vehicle for looking at American 20th-century culture,'' he said recently.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The State Department and the Central Intelligence Agency are constantly trying to discredit me and they're not going to be able to do it.

title: BURGUNDY ON A BUDGET
description: IF I HAD A CAN OF SPRAY paint, I would aim it at the wall of a tony Madison Avenue wine shop and write: ''Inexpensive Burgundy is an oxymoron.'' Make that ''Good inexpensive

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
SHAKESPEARE-ON-HUDSON
description: TWENTY-FIVE years ago, Fred Blais was impressed with the way his drama students were performing Shakespeare at Croton High School - so impressed, in fact, that he decided to extend the season. That summer, students and others performed ''Romeo and Juliet,'' ''Julius Caesar'' and ''Anthony and Cleopatra'' - and the Croton Shakespeare Festival was born.

title: KLAUS BARBIE AND THE CONSCIENCE OF THE LITERATI
description: WORLD WAR II continues to haunt the French. Unprepared, the French military capitulated almost immediately to Germany, and France was the only major European power to be occupied. The coming trial in Lyons of Klaus Barbie, the head of the Gestapo in that city, will resurrect France's deepest trauma: its noble and ignoble history during the German occupation.

title: 6 WORLD LEADERS URGING THATCHER TO BACK SANCTIONS
description: The leaders of six Commonwealth nations gathered here today to meet with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and step up their calls for her to put economic risk second to ''moral principle'' and end her opposition to sanctions against South Africa.

title: AIDS FINDING MADE BY A VIRUS EXPERT

title: CANADA VS. PORNOGRAPHY: EVEN PLAYBOY MAY FALL

title: A THEATER WHERE THE SHOW GOES ON, UNLESS IT'S RAINING

title: Medical Care

description: THE Croton dump finally has closed, but the Hudson River Fishermen's Association is still not satisfied.

title: The Message Of the Meter
description: Using figures provided last week by private accountants hired by the city, the new chairman of the Taxi and Limousine Commission concluded that a taxi owner who drives his cab an average of 40 hours a week can expect to net about $13,000 a year before taxes.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
COIN SHOW TO OPEN IN MILWAUKEE
description: Starting Wednesday, the year's biggest coin show will take place in Milwaukee's Exposition and Convention Center. It will be the 95th anniversary convention of the American Numismatic Association.

title: JOHN ALCOTT, AN OSCAR WINNER FOR CINEMATOGRAPHY, IS DEAD
description: John Alcott, an Academy Award-winning cinematographer whose camerawork illuminated some of the most noted films of the director-producer Stanley Kubrick, died of natural causes Monday while vacationing in the south of France. He was 55 years old and lived in Studio City, Calif.

title: NEIGHBORS REBUFF PHILADELPHIA KOREANS
description: There were about 100 of them, mostly gray-haired residents of the tight, prideful Olney neighborhood in north-central Philadelphia. Northeastern cities have long had many neighborhoods like it: predominantly white, middle-class enclaves of modest means, modest homes and a fierce sense of community identity.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Vevay, Ind.;
A River Town Gets a Boost
description: FOUR years ago, Paul W. Ogle visited his old hometown and was disheartened by what he saw.

title: LADY'S SECRET TAKES THE WHITNEY BY 4 1/2 LENGTHS
description: Lady's Secret today became the first filly since Gallorette in 1948 to win the Whitney Handicap when she splashed to a front-running 4 1/2-length triumph against six male rivals at Saratoga.

title: Betsey Benedict Marries
description: Betsey Brinkerhoff Benedict, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John P. Benedict of Essex Fells and Mantoloking, N.J., was married yesterday to Kenneth Elliot Higgins Jr., a son of Dr. and Mrs. Higgins of Fairfield, Conn. The Rev. David Earnest performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Church of St. Simon-by-the-Sea in Mantoloking. Mrs. Higgins is a sales representative for Gould Fabrics Inc. in New York. Mr. Higgins is an associate director of Bear Stearns & Company in New York.

title: P.L.O. STRUGGLING TO KEEP MANDATE
description: The Palestine Liberation Organization, frustrated by attempts to wage both war and peace since its expulsion from Beirut four years ago, is now struggling to protect its mandate to be the sole representative of the Palestinians in any Middle East settlement.

title: MANAGERIAL FUNCTIONS OF RETURNEES CITED
description: I would like to defend myself and others like me who have come home to ''roost'' after college.

title: COWS, COLLEGES AND CONTENTMENT
description: We approach Northfield, Minn., across the flat fields south of Dundas. The red sun of midsummer is in our eyes and the radio plays polka music. Enthusiastic voices inform us that we have lived, unawares, through half of National Pork Month. Troubled commentators discuss plummeting land prices and mortgage debt.

title: Blacks Develop Tennis Potential
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Miss Livieri, Teacher and Executive Is Married to William M. S. Bloomer
description: The marriage of Sharon Ann Livieri, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Livieri of Woodbridge, Conn., to William Martin Shepard Bloomer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David Eardley Bloomer of Oley, Pa., took place yesterday in New Haven. The Rev. Dorsey McConnell, an Episcopal priest, and the Rev. Richard Russell, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Battell Chapel on the Yale University campus.

title: 37 FOOD OUTLETS CITED BY NEW YORK OFFICIALS
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 37 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: Tornado Hits Detroit, Overturning 2 Autos
