description: A tornado touched down today in downtown Detroit, overturning two cars on an interstate highway and injuring two people, the authorities said.

title: TAPE DEPICTS ASIAN GANG WITH U.S. BRANCHES
description: A Federal jury in Manhattan has heard the secretly taped conversation of a reputed gang leader boasting that his organization, the United Bamboo, resembled the Mafia.

title: Miss Rockafellow Becomes a Bride
description: Carolynn Hall Rockafellow, an associate at Credit Suisse First Boston Ltd., and Francisco Javier Lopez-Balboa, an associate in the capital markets department at Merrill Lynch & Company, both in New York, were married yesterday. The Rev. Roland M. Jones performed the ceremony at St. Mark's Episcopal Church in New Canaan, Conn.

title:
STAGE VIEW;
THEATER'S ARTISTS OFFER AN ANTIDOTE FOR PESSIMISM
description: ''I talk about the theater as an art. I never talk about it in any other way. I never think about it in any other way,'' said Robert Edmond Jones, the consummate stage designer.

title: Proper Behavior Not Much to Ask
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: RAIL SERVICE TO CAPE HAS CAUGHT ON
description: Before they boarded Amtrak train No. 270 last Saturday morning, Mark Zelek and Alicia Castilla, two Manhattan lawyers, had talked about a Cape Cod vacation for almost two years. In addition to the lure of sand and sun, Mr. Zelek's family in Harwich, Mass., had been lobbying for a visit, especially since their daughter, Alicia Zelek Castilla, was born 10 weeks ago.

title: Cable TV
description: ''Key Exchange'' should make a welcome film premiere this week on cable, in contrast to many plastic exercises purporting to mirror today's young people. Writing in The Times, Vincent Canby felt that this 1985 study of some Manhattan yuppies held ''wit, candor and a sweetness that never slops over into sentimentality.'' The appealing young protagonists are Brooke Adams, Ben Masters and Daniel Stern, and Barnett Kellman makes an auspicious screen debut as the director, after piloting the source -Kevin Wade's slight but charming three-character play - Off Broadway. HBO is showing the movie on Wednesday night at 9; WHT takes over on Friday evening at 8 and later at 3 A.M.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: KOREA: The First War We Lost. By Bevin Alexander. (Hippocrene, $24.95.) Victory, like beauty, it seems, is in the eye of the beholder.

title: Giants Put 6 on Waivers
description: The Giants reduced their roster to 82 today by waiving 6 players, including a 1986 draft choice.

title: NO ONE WEARS ANTLERS IN SEATTLE'S NEW 'RING'
description: Wagner's ''Ring des Nibelungen'' is an Everest (or, perhaps, a great white whale) for every opera company - 16 hours of turbulent music drama divided into four interrelated installments. So difficult is the ''Ring'' cycle, so seemingly impossible to bring off completely, that when the first recording was issued in 1966, it was treated as an event of premiere musical importance.

title: OPERA: MASSENET'S 'DON QUICHOTTE' IS REVIVED
description: MASSENET'S ''Don Quichotte'' is a gentle old opera in the sentimental French tradition, a work perhaps easier to love than to admire. Masterly in a minor way, it can work its wiles only when a bass of great authority appears, falls in love with the title role and persuades a company to let him sing it. That is exactly why the New York City Opera's new production of ''Don Quichotte,'' which had its premiere Friday night, turned out to be a notable event. Mr. Ramey, as sweetly befuddled an old chevalier as ever tilted at a windmill, immediately took control of the stage, and finally of the audience's heart, in a performance that for once justified opera's often-abused star system.

title: Beirut Message Rejects Hostage Negotiations
description: A statement that purported to come from Islamic Holy War, the Lebanese terrorist organization that is believed to hold at least three American hostages, rejected any negotiations with the Reagan Administration, Pope John Paul II or the Archbishop of Canterbury for the hostages' release.

title: Data Update
description: * Rates on most adjustable mortgages are set 1 to 3 percentage points above these indexes.

title: CLASH IN CAPITAL ON REHNQUIST DATA REPORTED GROWING
description: A confrontation seemed to be looming today between a bipartisan group of Senators and the Reagan Administration over Congressional access to sensitive papers written by William H. Rehnquist when he was a high-ranking Justice Department official in the Nixon Administration.

title: STRAWBERRY PATCH AND ITS LESSON IN GREED
description: IT'S the same every year: Our friends come from New York for the weekend; we go out to dinner, we swim in the pool, and on Sunday morning, we pick strawberries.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: INCIDENT AT BIG SKY: The True Story of Sheriff Johnny France and the Capture of the Mountain Men. By Johnny France and Malcolm McConnell.

title: WHAT IS AFRO, WHAT IS AMERICAN
description: GOING TO THE TERRITORY By Ralph Ellison. 338 pp. New York: Random House. $19.95.

title: American in Paris
description: Greg LeMond might want to make that, love, war and bicycle racing. On his way to becoming last week the first American ever to win the Tour de France, the world's most prestigious race for human powered machines, Mr. LeMond said he felt he had been betrayed by one of his French teammates, Bernard Hinault. Mr. Lemond had helped Mr. Hinault to win the race last year, and this year thought they had agreed that turnabout was fair play.

title: LET THE BUYER BEWARE
description: MAFIA BUSINESS The Mafia Ethic and the Spirit of Capitalism. By Pino Arlacchi. Translated by Martin Ryle. 239 pp. New York: Verso/Schocken Books. $17.95. THE Mafia has long been a beneficiary of its own mythology. Its image as a kind of perverse Robin Hood gang that stole from everyone but had a code of honor and respect - and sometimes had something left over for the poor - could only help in its wars with prosecutors and the police. Law enforcement officers and district attorneys often suffer from a less than heroic public image, and the Mafia's cries that it was being persecuted or, worse still, didn't exist at all, sometimes won a sympathetic public hearing.

title: THEATER'S PROBLEMS ARE COMPLEX
description: To the Editor:

title: Lower Black Enrollments
description: THE NUMBER of blacks enrolled in four-year colleges continues to dwindle, according to biannual figures released in June by the United States Department of Education.

title: NEW CASSETTES: A PAIR OF COMEDIES ABOUT CONNIVERS
description: The Sting Starring Robert Redford, Paul Newman, Robert Shaw; directed by George Roy Hill, 1973 MCA Home Video 129 minutes. $24.95.

title: Why I Read To My Class
description: In a seventh-grade English class we are reading silently the last page of Steinbeck's ''Of Mice and Men.'' For days we have been discussing together the symbiotic relationship of George and Lennie, the elements in each man that support the other in a world where loneliness is symbolized by the disparate characters gathered in the bunkhouse of an isolated ranch.

title: Bonus Fliers
description: To the Editor:

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: CUTLASS IN THE SNOW By Elizabeth Shub. Illustrated by Rachel Isadora. 46 pp. New York: Greenwillow Books. $11.75. (Ages 6 to 9). FIRE ISLAND, the scrubby windswept land barrier that runs parallel to much of New York State's Long Island, has in this century become a summer vacationer's paradise. Cooled by two large bodies of water, its wide sandy beaches are pounded by the Atlantic Ocean on the south, while on the north the Great South Bay separates it from Long Island.

title: The Administration's Unofficial Secrets Act
description: Britain, with no First Amendment, has an Official Secrets Act, empowering the Government to ban information on national security grounds. In the United States, despite the First Amendment, the Reagan Administration in recent months appears to have laid the foundations for an Unofficial Secrets Act.

title: ALAN HOVHANESS OFFERS HIS 61st SYMPHONY
description: HE may well be the most prolific composer of his time. At the age of 75, Alan Hovhaness has written literally hundreds of songs and choral works, an assortment of chamber music for various groupings of instruments, dozens of compositions for solo piano and, just recently finished, his 61st symphony. Tonight at 8 o'clock at the Lakeside Theater in Eisenhower Park, East Meadow, L.I., the Universal Symphony, under the direction of Lawrence Sobol, will present the New York premiere of Mr. Hovhaness's ''Mount St. Helens Symphony,'' and the composer is in town for the festivities.

title: LONG WAIT ENDING FOR MEXICO QUAKE VICTIMS
description: When two earthquakes struck this capital last September, 11 members of the family of Pablo Montoya and his wife, Ester Castelozo, were buried alive when their tenement building collapsed.

title: Dorothy Hardin Is Wed in Jersey
description: Dorothy Ruth Hardin, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Paul Hardin of Madison, N.J., was married yesterday to William Perry Holmes, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James C. Holmes of Birmingham, Mich. The ceremony was performed at the United Methodist Church in Madison by Bishop Paul Hardin Jr., the bride's grandfather, who is retired Bishop of the South Carolina Area.

title: 6 Illegal Aliens Escape From Detention Center
description: Six illegal aliens, all of whom were charged with crimes and were awaiting deportation, escaped from a Federal detention facility in lower Manhattan last night by sliding down bedsheets from a fourth-floor bathroom, the police said.

title: Catholics Protest To Pretoria
description: The United States Catholic Conference has sent the South African Government a strong protest against ''unwarranted attacks'' on ministers of the church and, in particular, the continued detention of the General Secretary of the Southern Africa Catholic Bishops Conference, church sources said this week.

title: Teresa Smagorinsky Is Wed in Princeton
description: Teresa Smagorinsky, an applications manager at A.T.&T. Network Systems in New York, and Harold Wade Thompson, a financial planner for A.T.&T. Technologies in Berkeley Heights, N.J., were married yesterday. Mayor Barbara Sigmund of Princeton, N.J., officiated at the Princeton House of Princeton University.

title: FIRE RIGS OF OLD PARADE FAVORITES
description: IF ANTIQUE fire engines are the stuff that children's dreams are made of, then New Jersey has enough of these glimmering emergency chariots to ply the imaginations of anyone - young or old.

title: ARTS INSTITUTE STUDENTS TO DISPLAY THEIR TALENTS
description: STUDENTS involved in the Summer Arts Institute, housed at Rutgers-New Brunswick, will perform and display their works Friday and Saturday.

title: Solo Voyagers
description: To the Editor: I would like to comment on a question in the Q & A column in the June 29 issue of the Travel section.

title: Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: SENATE

title: Marion Hepburn Grant Dies; Wrote Books on Connecticut
description: Marion Hepburn Grant, a Connecticut historian and a sister of the actress Katharine Hepburn, died Friday at her seaside home here, apparently of a heart attack. She was 68 years old.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
GOING PLACES
description: IT is a Saturday aftenoon and it is raining. Big, fat drops, sometimes tapering to a steady cold drizzle, never once letting up to allow in a ray of summer sunshine.

title: TO FREE INHIBITIONS, STONY CREEK GROUP TRIES IMPROVISATION
description: ANYONE who happens into the Stony Creek improvisation workshop on a Saturday morning may interpret the scene on stage as six actors in search of their sanity. If they are not speaking gibberish or flinging their limbs about erratically, they may be acting out a skit in somewhat surreal dialogue.

title: SURVEY: NEW N.C.A.A. STANDARDS SIDELINE MORE THAN 200
description: MORE than 200 high school football and basketball players scheduled to receive athletic scholarships to college this year have failed to meet new minimum academic standards and thus are ineligible to compete, according to a New York Times survey of Division I colleges and universities.

title: BOMB KILLS 4 IN SOUTH AFRICAN ENCLAVE
description: Four people died and more than 20 were wounded today when a bomb exploded in a butcher's store in Walvis Bay, an enclave in South-West Africa where South Africa has a naval base, the authorities said.

title: Dewey Ship's Hopes Sinking
description: Preservationists have raised only a fraction of the money needed to save Adm. George Dewey's flagship, the Olympia, from repossession by the Navy, and hopes are diminishing that the funds can be found.

title: Karen L. Saunders Is Wed on L.I. to Lyle A. Bakst
description: At Temple Sinai in Roslyn Heights, L.I., last evening Karen Lynn Saunders, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Saunders of Rockville Centre, L.I., was married to Lyle Avery Bakst, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bennett Bakst of Woodmere, L.I. Rabbi Norman Kahan, assisted by Cantor Mark Horowitz, performed the ceremony.

title: Police Indicted In Massachusetss
description: The Federal prosecutor in Boston was not just bandying words when he said group of indicted police officers ''posed a serious threat to law enforcement'' in Massachusetts. Crimes laid to the group included bank burgling, drug dealing and, as of last week, stealing police examinations to raise their own scores and lower those of their rivals.

title: Reagan Nominates 9 Admirals
description: President Reagan has nominated nine admirals for promotion or new assignment, including an unusually rapid ascent from one-star to three-star rank for a former aide to Navy Secretary John F. Lehman Jr. Sources at the Pentagon, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the nominations were tied in large part to efforts by Mr. Lehman to win a promotion for the former aide, Rear Adm. Paul D. Miller, 44 years old. Mr. Lehman persuaded Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger and Mr. Reagan to support Admiral Miller for the job of commander of the Seventh Fleet, in Japan.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: ART IN COMPETITION ''Moving, frightening, witty and beautiful,'' was how Linda Shearer described the 118 paintings, drawings, sculpture and mixed-media works that she selected as juror for the 37th annual Art of Northeast U.S.A. exhibition opening Saturday in New Canaan.

title: DEBATE IN OSSINING ON AN M.T.A. PLAN
description: SITUATED along the banks of the Hudson River, the Sparta section of Ossining is the town's oldest surviving settlement. Once a thriving river port, it is now a tranquil neighborhood spread over a dozen acres with an eclectic blend of architecture.

title: Cause and Effect At Woburn, Mass.
description: The families of leukemia victims in Woburn, Mass., won the first round of a toxic-waste lawsuit last week when a Federal court jury found that W. R. Grace & Co. ''substantially contributed'' to the contamination of two city wells. The next round, though, may be harder.

title: MUNICIPALITIES URGED TO GIVE BUILDING SITES FOR HOMELESS
description: ROBERT Schulman, a major Westchester developer who is also chairman of the county's Commission on the Homeless, said last week that he would meet soon ''with a number of supervisors and mayors to discuss land they have for low- and moderate-income housing.''

title: THEATER'S PROBLEMS ARE COMPLEX
description: To the Editor: Albert Innaurato's article on the plight of the playwright in the American theater catalogues the symptoms of the disease without looking at the causes [ ''A Playwright Decries an Era of 'Hit Flops,' '' July 20 ] .

title: THE MAN WHO BUILT THE METS: FRANK CASHEN
description: AFTER A HUMID afternoon and a cleansing shower, it's a gorgeous July evening, a great night for a ball game in Rochester. At Silver Stadium, a pretty, old ball park with its rickety stands embrac-ing the diamond and local advertise-ments painted on the outfield fence, the Rochester Red Wings, a minor league affiliate of the Baltimore Orioles, are about to take on the Tidewater (Va.) Tides. Tidewater is the top farm club of the New York Mets.

title: The Missing Case
description: THE James Joyce Society of Washington devised a contest to give away a case of Irish whisky. The liquor, hidden somewhere in the city, was meant to be found by a devotee of Joyce, someone who could decipher the arcane clues that the society would issue from time to time.

title: ROTATING VIEW AND VERSATILE MENU
description: ''I NEVER eat in a restaurant that's over a hundred feet off the ground and won't stand still.'' That quote by Calvin Trillin has long reflected this reviewer's attitude toward high-rise restaurants that rotate slowly as you eat.

title: NEW & NOTEWORTHY
description: THE BEANS OF EGYPT, MAINE, by Carolyn Chute. (Warner, $3.50.) Carolyn Chute's portrayal of a dynastic poor-white family in rural Maine and a neighbor woman who marries into the incestuous clan is ''startling and original,'' Bertha Harris wrote in The Book Review in 1985. Beneath its surface, she said, is a ''relentlessly bleak vision. But vital clues to the novel's meaning might easily escape the reader who stops to laugh or gag or figure out who belongs to whom - or make a moral or political judgment.'' PICTURES FROM AN INSTITUTION: A Comedy, by Randall Jarrell. (University of Chicago, $7.95.) A series of sketches portrays the denizens of a progressive college for women, including a nasty novelist intent on skewering her colleagues in her latest work. Calling the novel a work of ''kaleidoscopic brilliance,''

title: A SAD FAREWELL TO MY QUIET WOODS
description: AT dinnertime recently we were startled to see someone in a bright red baseball cap bouncing along the side of our backyard fence that faces the woods.

title: PREPARING FOR THE FIRST DAY OF SCHOOL
description: The first day of school. Are there five other words in the language capable of evoking as much anxiety and anticipation in children, words that trigger as many powerful memories among adults? As a rite of passage, the first day of school is as evocative in 1986 as it was four centuries ago, when Shakespeare described ''the whining schoolboy, with his satchel, and shining morning face, creeping like snail unwillingly to school.'' But according to educators, psychological experts, parents and children themselves, the meaning of this universal experience has been changing dramatically.

title: NEW CASSETTES: A PAIR OF COMEDIES ABOUT CONNIVERS
description: Hugh Shannon: Saloon Singer V.I.E.W. Video 55 minutes. $39.95.

title: Instant Analysis for Bond Trading
description: MY introduction to bond trading came by way of Charles Atwater, a broker at the offices of what was then Richard W. Kohn & Company, now a remote outpost of E.F. Hutton & Company in Newark. In the heyday of Syntex, National Video and Bowmar Instruments, Kohn & Company still had a chalkboard where young runners actually wrote by hand the up-to-the-minute quotes of the market-making stocks.

title: A Full-Scale Hotel on a Floating Base
description: OVER the next four years, cruise lines will spend nearly $1 billion on seven new ships that will make room for 9,000 new passengers. For example, Kockums of Sweden just delivered a new 48,000-ton, 1,896-passenger vessel to Carnival Cruise Lines and will deliver a similar one in March 1987. The price tag: $280 million total for both ships. Jos. L. Meyer of West Germany delivered a $150 million, 42,000-ton, 1,000-passenger ship this month to Home Line Cruises Inc. and is building two similar ships for Royal Cruise Line Ltd., which are to be delivered in 1988 and 1989.

title: No Need to Doubt Cannibalism in New Guinea
description: To the Editor:

title: Monster Shows: Sea Changes
description: Placemats at dockside seafood restaurants often feature drawings of spouting whales and dancing dolphins, all of whom are presumably disporting themselves in the waters nearby.

title: TESTING AN OVERWORKED GREETING
description: 9419>SOME expressions are used so frequently that after awhile their repetition makes them sound almost meaningless. Nary a day goes by that we do not receive at least a half-dozen ''Have a nice day'' greetings voiced to us bystore clerks, bank tellers or passing acquaintances. I have a theory that some of these overworked expressions are not even heard by the other party.

title: Swim Mark Set
description: Tamara Costache of Rumania was timed in 25.31 seconds in a women's 50-meter freestyle race, breaking her world record of 25.35 seconds, Bulgaria's BTA press agency reported from Sofia. Miss Costache set the record Friday, the first day of the 18th Balkan Swimming and Diving Championships.

title: PETTY-BOURGEOIS CASANOVA
description: JOURNAL OF MY LIFE By Jacques-Louis Menetra. Edited, and with an introduction, by Daniel Roche. Translated by Arthur Goldhammer. Foreword by Robert Darnton. Maps. 368 pp. New York: Columbia University Press. $30. IN the 18th century the most dazzling jewel in the crown of France was the city of Paris, the scene of rapid social mobility and fusion, where the nobility and the bourgeoisie shared the same turf with merchants and shopkeepers, artisans and laborers. Paris spawned a heterogeneous society that was permeated by the written word. Parisians of all stripes, educated or not, burned with the fever to write on many topics, including themselves. ''Infected by the craze for life in the great city,'' one aspirant wrote, ''the disease overcame me, and I became an author too.'' People distributed broadsheets, posters, pamphlets and treatises throughout the city. Literate Parisians (around 66 percent of men, 62 percent of women) transmitted news to less literate cohorts, bridging the gap between elite and popular culture. In this heady milieu, a glazier, Jacques-Louis Menetra, wrote and rewrote ''Journal of My Life'' between 1764 and 1802. Despite his disclaimer (''Journal of my life written for me''), Menetra too courted the amorphous public.

title: Cynthia Greenleaf Wed to J.F. Fanton
description: The marriage of Cynthia Greenleaf and Jonathan Foster Fanton, president of the New School for Social Research, took place yesterday in Lakeside, Mich. The Rev. Richard Warch, president of Lawrence University and a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Greenleaf family home.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE BIRTH AND DEATH OF THE MIRACLE MAN. By Albert Wendt. (Viking, $18.95.) The modern Samoans in Albert Wendt's stories are dutiful Christians, their children training to be government clerks on the mainland. But the shades of ancient island gods and ancestors still swirl around their heads, binding them to the mysteries - of nature, mortality and clan honor - that form the background for these gentle but powerful tales. In ''Prospecting,'' several villagers and their European boss pan for gold and unearth the skeletons of a whole town whose inhabitants were slaughtered in a long-ago battle. The prospectors fall into deep grief, which is assuaged only when their boss agrees to bury the skeletons, with complete funeral rites, in their own churchyard. Mr. Wendt also makes room in the teeming Samoan universe for private, solitary rites of passage. In ''The Balloonfish and the Armadillo,'' he describes the hardened pain of a middle-aged man whose father was wrenched away from him as a child. The pain now manifests itself as a chronic migraine he envisions as a spiky Samoan blowfish inflated to its full, menacing size. After his father's death, the hero uncovers the truth about him - reading through his letters, hurling books into a bonfire - which makes it possible to continue his own life. Mr. Wendt generously dusts his stories with ironic, knowing playfulness. In ''I Will Be Our Saviour From the Bad Smell,'' a village is suddenly enshrouded by an abominable smell which unsettles everyone but the hero, for whom the Bad Smell is a precious gift.

title: Sunday Observer; THE DAY OF THE YOUNG FOGY
description: A GOOD PLACE TO see Young Fogies is on the MacNeil/Lehrer NewsHour. When you tune in, look for the young man disagreeing with everything the young man from the American Civil Liberties Union just said. He will be the Young Fogy.

title: IN THE HEART OF PARIS, SHRINES TO FINE FOOD
description: Living in Paris has always seemed a privilege to me, especially when one lives next to the Place de la Madeleine. For, besides being the best food market in the world, the Place is loaded with wonderful memories - of Proust, who was born nearby, at 9 Boulevard Malesherbes, of King Edward VII, the original boulevardier, and of the charmingly naughty belle epoque.

title: THE BURDEN OF THE BRONZE
description: ON this Hall of Fame weekend at Cooperstown and Canton, bronze is beautiful. Streaked with sentiment, bronze plaques in Cooperstown and bronze busts in Canton are awarded to the new inductees, as they are in other sports hall of fame ceremonies, a reminder of what an athlete accomplished. But for others in their families, the burden of the bronze endures, usually unfairly, sometimes painfully, as it has recently for three sons of hall of famers.

title: Susan Hebel Is Bride
description: Susan Lee Hebel, a daughter of Helen I. Hebel and Robert W. Hebel, both of Cleveland, was married yesterday to John Barclay Fullerton, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John S. Fullerton of Oyster Bay, L.I. The Rev. Charles G. Newbery performed the ceremony at St. John's of Lattington Episcopal Church in Locust Valley, L.I. The bride's father is president of the Romec Division of Lear Siegler Inc., an aeronautical parts manufacturer in Elyria, Ohio. The bridegroom's father, a promotion and fund-raising consultant, was a director of Operation Sail 1986.

title: KOCH AND HISPANIC-ISSUE PANEL DIFFER
description: Mayor Koch says he sees no need to name a Hispanic person to the city's seven-member Board of Education, although such an appointment is expected to be one of the key recommendations from his Commission on Hispanic Concerns.

title: BILLY JOEL REACHES OUT TO EMBRACE POP
description: ''I 'm 37, and there's no point in pretending I'm a teen-ager anymore,'' Billy Joel reflected last week. ''That doesn't mean I don't love rock-and-roll, but I love other kinds of music just as much. George Gershwin was the greatest American composer because he worked in all different mediums and brought the street into the opera house.''

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: A POLKA FESTIVAL . . .

title: DETROIT GRUMBLES AND COPES IN GARBAGE STRIKE
description: Through the 18 days since a municipal strike started and garbage pickups stopped, Porter Daniels has been putting his trash in plastic bags in his garage. On Friday he stuffed three bags into his green Volkswagen, drove to a dump and debated whether the walkout had hurt his city's reputation.

title:
BLACKBOARD NOTES;
Socrates to The Rescue
description: WHILE state legislatures across the country struggle to find funds to improve public schools, the 83-year-old philosopher Mortimer J. Adler has come up with a plan that won't cost a cent. He calls it the ''Wednesday Revolution.''

title: HONOLULU
description: Hawaii expects a surge of visitors this year as travelers from the United States and abroad forgo trips to Europe and the Middle East. And many first-time visitors may be surprised by what they find in the 50th state.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, AUGUST 3, 1986
description: Pressure on Margaret Thatcher to put economic risk second to ''moral principle'' and end her opposition to sanctions against South Africa, will come from leaders of six Commonwealth Nations who gathered in London for a three-day meeting starting today with the Prime Minister. Heads of Government from Canada, India, Australia, Zimbabwe, the Bahamas and Zambia will participate in the meeting against a background of growing sentiment in the United States Congress for action against the Pretoria Government. [ Page 1, Col. 6. ]

title: The Monsters In My Head
description: I identified with Frank Langella's emotions and experience in his article ''The Monsters in My Head'' (About Men, July 13).

title:
ANTIQUES;
'CARAVAN' HEADS FOR SALEM COUNTY
description: THE AREA that was once John Fenwick's colony in the Province of West Jersey, a place with a rich and colorful history and a significant architectural heritage, will be the destination Saturday of an all-day motor-coach exploration sponsored by the Newark Museum.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: HARNESSING PEACOCKS. By Mary Wesley. (Scribners, $16.95.) Mary Wesley's sly romantic comedy is such a good read that it is sure to attract new fans, as well as satisfy her old ones.

title: The Group, 12 Years Later
description: Anita Shreve's article ''The Group, 12 Years Later'' (July 6), made me very sad. Today, you couldn't find a group of women who had the time to sit around and talk.

title: FIVE SUNDAY PROGRAMS BEGINNING FOR BRONX ART ENSEMBLE
description: AT a time of year when most other summer festivals are winding up, we have the great delight of welcoming the start of the Bronx Arts Ensemble's yearly series of free concerts, outdoors in Van Cortlandt Park and indoors at Fordham University's Keating Hall. ''Summer Music '86'' is the umbrella banner for these five Sunday programs, beginning this afternoon as Andrejs Jansons leads the wind contingent of the ensemble in Serenades by Beethoven, Donizetti and the greatly gifted American composer Robert Baksa.

title: CORPORATIONS CONTINUE TO CALL FOR THE MOVERS
description: BACK in the gloom of the late 60's and early 70's, New York City's economic enervation might have been symbolized by the image of a giant corporation with its bags packed.

title: MOTHERS AND SONS: HEARTS UNITED BY AN UNCOMMON BOND
description: I AM the mother of a son, the sister of a brother. I am a daughter, a former wife and daughter-in-law. Through all these roles in my life, I have never lost my amazement at the intricacies of the mother-son relationship. And also through these roles I have learned clearly that, as the late Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas said, ''Nobody can misunderstand a boy like his own mother.''

title: Theater
description: The art of the monodrama is illuminated this weekend by two highly disparate performances - Billie Whitelaw and Ethyl Eichelberger. Miss Whitelaw, one of the foremost interpreters of the works of Samuel Beckett, is in residence at the Pepsico Summerfare in Purchase with a return engagement of Beckett's short plays ''Rockaby'' and ''Footfalls'' and a reading of the story ''Enough.''

title: JAPANESE STEEL'S DARKEST DAYS
description: FOR more than a century, the Nippon Steel Corporation has been the symbol of industrial Japan. But now, as Japanese steelmakers fight a deepening crisis, Nippon Steel, Nippon Kokan and other big manufacturers are reshaping themselves, trying to cut their dependence on steel in hopes of surviving better than their American counterparts. Many have started to branch out, adding such things as industrial ceramics and silicon wafers, while still keeping their commitment to steel.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: EFFORTS are under way on both the Federal and state levels to map aquifers more precisely and gain a clearer understanding of how they behave and how to protect them.

title: THE 60'S IDEALS, THE 80'S DEVELOPMENTS
description: Regarding the recent Opinion Page article by Kenneth Marion [ ''A Former Student Activist Runs Up the Flag'' ] and the letter to the editor by Hedda Marcus, one wonders, whom are they trying to convince? They both begin by identifying themselves as ''children of the 60's,'' and then in the same sentence reidentify themselves as suburban professionals of the 80's.

title: The American Idea
description: The excerpt from the late Theodore H. White's unfinished article, written to commemorate the Fourth of July, moved me deeply, much more so than any part of the television coverage that I happened to watch (''The American Idea,'' July 6). Mr. White's eloquent prose reads like poetry, and recalls my passion for the classics years ago.

title: IN AUSTRALIA, BICENTENNIAL WITH A YAWN
description: Australia is getting ready for a yearlong birthday party in 1988, the 200th anniversary of the first migration from Europe. It was in January 1788 that Britain, having lost its trans-Atlantic prison colonies to the American Revolution, began unloading convict ships here.

title: Permit Seeker Barred From Paying for Judge
description: A State Supreme Court justice has blocked the state from holding hearings on a permit for a proposed garbage-burning plant at the old Brooklyn Navy Yard under an arrangement in which the company seeking the permit was to pay the salary of the judge conducting the hearings.

title: IN WASHINGTON, RICH LEGACIES OF TWO COLLECTORS
description: It so happens that two of the first people I ever met in Washington were Duncan Phillips and his wife, Marjorie. With his pencil-thin silhouette, his very high collar, his even higher brow, his luxuriant mustache and his ever straight and ardent gaze, he was an impressive figure.

title: 'In' and 'Out' Degrees
description: The latest figures from the United States Department of Education on undergraduate fields of study confirm that today's college students are keeping their eyes glued to the job market. Business and management, which ranked behind education and the social sciences in the number of degrees awarded in 1974, surged ahead by 1984.

title: OPEC Tries Again to Come to Terms
description: OPEC squabbled again, as falling oil prices continued to leach revenues from members. Some ministers said they would voluntarily trim production, but only if everyone else would. Plans for binding quotas were still being considered, but the problem of cheating remains. Mistrust is so rampant in OPEC, analysts say, that no nation is willing to act first and risk losing market share. Oil prices are continuing to sink, and even gasoline prices, which usually rise during the summer driving season, have dropped to levels not seen in years.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL METS VS. MONTREAL EXPOS, at Shea Stadium, 1:30 P.M. (Television - Channel 9, 1:30 P.M., Radio - WHN 1050, 1:30P.M.) YANKEES VS.

title: Elizabeth Alling Is Wed in Maine To John B. Hildt
description: St. Ann's Episcopal Church in Kennebunkport, Me., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Elizabeth Dwight Alling and John Bradley Hildt. The Rev. Laman H. Bruner, assisted by the Rev. Clarke K. Oler, performed the ceremony.

title: A Bipartisan Slap At South Africa
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee took a step last week toward the imposition of economic sanctions against South Africa. After defeating a proposal to mandate the withdrawal of all American investment from South Africa, it approved other sanctions by a bipartisan vote of 15-2.

title: Mexico
description: To the Editor: To readers of the article ''The Buses That Bind Mexico'' (Travel, May 25), I would like to say: Don't encumber yourself with bottled mineral water. In even the smallest grocery store in Mexico you will find canned fruit juice in a convenient size (ready to drink, not concentrated) and in many varieties from apple and pear to mango and guava, all delicious and perfectly safe.

title: JOHNSON AT 80
description: To the Editor:

title: HARDY SUCCULENTS ADD TEXTURE TO A SUMMER GARDEN
description: Years ago, my husband and I naively thought that we could afford to collect netsukes - those exquisite little pieces of sculpture used in Japan to counterweight a purse or pouch suspended from the traditional wide belt. We soon discovered that this was far too expensive a hobby. Instead, I contented myself with collecting sempervivums. The pleasures are similar.

title: WITHIN US ALL LURKS THE SECRET OF CLASSIC HORROR
description: Whether you greet the appearance of James Cameron's ''Aliens'' and Stephen King's ''Maximum Overdrive'' with anticipation or resignation, they attest that horror movies, unlike most of the characters in them, are very much alive - and doing very well at the box office. The appeal of movies designed to scare the pants off us has provided fodder for graduate students, psychologists, sociologists, critics and dinner-party conversationalists since at least ''The Cabinet of Dr. Caligari'' in 1919. The new ones are spectacular in a blow-you-out-of-your-shoes way, but the old ones gave us more to think about and dream about.

title: 3 TERRACES
description: A RELAXED COUNTRY ATMOSPHERE

title: The Past in Mr. Rehnquist's Future
description: An embarrassing thing has happened to William Rehnquist on his way to confirmation as Chief Justice of the United States. His testimony has been contradicted, and his credibility severely undermined, by a highly effective witness before the Senate Judiciary Committee.

title: SO THE RED SOX LEAD IN AUGUST? ARE WE REALLY WORRIED?
description: ON a wintry night during the Jazz Age, a man and his flappers hailed a cab and were wisked out to Fenway Park. The driver, a wizened old fellow who thought he had seen everything, watched incredulously while the man placed a key in the door of the stadium and ushered the girls inside. Ten minutes later, the passengers returned.

title: Keel Design Is Focus of America's Cup
description: The winged keel - the wonder of sailboat design that led to the United States' loss of the America's Cup in 1983 - has turned up again as a focus for international syndicates campaigning boats in the next match.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article about Pakistan in the World section on July 27 incorrectly described the trial of former Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto. Mr. Bhutto, who was executed in 1979 for conspiracy to commit murder, was convicted in 1978 in a civilian court, not a military one.

title: Operation PUSH Ends Boycott of CBS Station
description: The civil rights group Operation PUSH will end its 11-month boycott of WBBM-TV because the CBS-owned station has improved its hiring of minorities, a PUSH spokesman said today.

title: Susan E. Rosen Becomes a Bride
description: Susan Ellen Rosen, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin W. Rosen of Greenwich, Conn., and Palm Beach, Fla., was married last night to Andrew David Alisberg, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Norman Alisberg of West Hartford, Conn. Rabbi Maurice Davis performed the ceremony at the Rosen home in Greenwich.

title: TO CRACK TOUGH CASES, MAHATTAN PROSECUTOR'S SQUAD COMBINES AGENCIES
description: The line between what the police do and what prosecutors do is traditionally marked by the arrest of a suspect. Until that point, through the investigation process, the police are in charge. After that, through the compiling of evidence, prosecutors take the lead. The demarcation is always clear. In a cramped office on the ninth floor of the Criminal Courts Building in lower Manhattan, however, the police-prosecutor lines have merged in a way that has changed expectations and perspectives on both sides of the street -though not always smoothly and easily.

title: NEW YORKERS, etc.
description: IT sounds like a cinch. Just sit down for a few minutes every day and scribble. No imagination required. It's not going to be a novel or even the plot for a television series. It is - maybe - going to be a personal diary, a record of what you did, where you did it, with whom you did it, where you went, who you saw, what you said, what they said, who had a face lift, what the weather was like, what you're going to do to the repairman who swore your freezer was O.K. two days before it went on the blink - all the fascinating minutiae of modern life.

title: Questions Raised on Co-op Law
description: IN the six months since the Court of Appeals struck down the payment of a ''flip tax'' by New York City co-op owners, there has been consternation and uncertainty in the co-op community.

title: Anita B. Clifford Married to Michael Jerome Rich
description: The marriage of Anita Bradshaw Clifford, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Charles Clifford of Darien, Conn., to Michael Jerome Rich, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Rich of Cincinnati, took place yesterday at St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Morristown, N.J. The Rev. David P. Hegg 2d performed the ceremony.

title: ECUADOR IS BRIMFUL OF PANAMA HATS
description: Many years ago, Ecuadorean consuls used to put ''Panama Hats Are Made In Ecuador'' on all written communications, hoping to rectify the perpetual mistaken identity that their country's hats had always endured. The gambit didn't work. ''I see they are now making Panama hats in Ecuador,'' people remarked, according to Victor von Hagen in ''Ecuador the Unknown.''

title:
BLACKBOARD NOTES;
Sophie's Prize Is The Richest
description: AS A POPULAR author of light fiction for The Saturday Evening Post, The Woman's Home Companion and The Ladies' Home Journal in the early part of the century, Sophie Kerr loved stories with a happy ending. So before her death in 1965, at the age of 85, she set in motion one final plot that is happily concluded every June.

title: Deep Pockets
description: Sometimes some money is better than other money, and Milton J. Petrie has been around enough of it to know which kind is best. Last week, Beth Israel Medical Center announced that Mr. Petrie had given the institution $10 million in what Morton P. Hyman, Beth Israel's chairman, said was ''the most valuable kind of money to have'' - unrestricted funds.

title: SOME OPENING GAMBITS ON TAX REVISION
description: LIKE negotiators from a giant company and a powerful union in the early stages of collective bargaining, the House and Senate conferees charged with writing the most thorough changes in the income tax laws in more than 40 years spent last week preparing positions that they hope will give their side the edge in the next two weeks of crucial negotiations.

title: PRISONERS IN EL SALVADOR SAY CHURCHES AID REBELS
description: The Salvadoran Government appears to be engaged in a major confrontation with church officials after repeated accusations by police informers that churches have knowingly aided leftist guerrilla groups.

title: THE LEGEND OUTSTRIPPED THE MAN
description: JESSE OWENS An American Life. By William J. Baker. Illustrated. 289 pp. New York: The Free Press. $19.95. AS dramatic as a black-and-white photograph taken in the twilight of innocence, Jesse Owens's performance at the 1936 Olympics remains one of the most striking triumphs in American folklore. It was three years after the Nazis had come to power. Adolf Hitler temporarily toned down his anti-Semitic campaign and welcomed the world's athletes to Berlin. Nazi pageantry emphasized the militant nationalism of the era; Nazi racism made athletic contests between Germans and American blacks into symbolic tests of Aryan supremacy.

title: Getting Ready For Prime-Time
description: Members of the Senate once seemed about as likely to permit live television coverage of their proceedings as they were to, say, surrender their reserved parking spaces. But last week, after a three-month experiment with telecasts that resulted in generally favorable reviews, the Senate shrugged off its reservations and voted 78 to 21 for permanent gavel-to-gavel coverage.

title: DANES IN DANCE
description: To the Editor:

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Interstate Tiff On Sales Taxes

title: SIX H.M.O'S APPLY TO STATE IN A WAVE
description: A HALF-DOZEN new health maintenance organizations are forming in Connecticut.

title: A Doctor Glut?
description: To the Editor:

title: Reagan and Gorbachev Tone Down the Rhetoric
description: WITH two and a half years remaining in his Presidency, Ronald Reagan appears to have concluded that if he is to leave a legacy in foreign policy it will be in the achievement of significant arms accords with Moscow and a more realistic relationship between the superpowers.

title: POSTINGS: On the Docket; L.I. Reincarnation
description: For more than 30 years, a 2 1/2-story brick building in Lynbrook, L.I., served as the village hall. Then the Nassau County District Court moved in, helping to preserve the 55-year-old structure for more than a decade.

title: Lawyer Married To Polly Kurimai
description: Pollyalice Kurimai, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Kurimai of Fairfield, Conn., was married at the United Church of Christ there yesterday to Lloyd D. Pedersen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Richard Pedersen of Ridgefield, Conn. The Rev. John Butosi performed the ceremony, assisted by C. Richard Pedersen, the bridegroom's brother and an Episcopal seminary student.

title: WHEN IDEOLOGY WAS THICKER THAN MONEY
description: THE FBI-KGB WAR A Special Agent's Story. By Robert J. Lamphere and Tom Shachtman. Illustrated. 320 pp. New York: Random House. $18.95.

title: A Winning Team: Mr. Casler and the Shadow
description: In a big city, Scott Kinney might have been lost. Poor, he was raised at various times by his mother, his father and in foster care. He was placed in special classes at school, dropped out and even as a little boy stayed on the streets late at night.

title: U.S. Sends Chile a Message
description: As recently as four years ago, the State Department reported ''improvements'' in Chile's human rights record, a finding Elliott Abrams, an Assistant Secretary of State, said was justified. The Reagan Administration has long since abandoned the upbeat view of Gen. Augusto Pinochet's Government, however, and last week, Mr. Abrams was advocating punitive action.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: FREE HAMPTON CONCERT Fans of Lionel Hampton say that a ticket to a ''King of the Vibes'' concert is cheap at any price. But on Thursday evening, when the jazz great performs in New Brunswick with his 17-piece band, the bargain will be beyond hyperbole.

title: Battleship to Be Overhauled
description: The battleship Wisconsin, mothballed since 1958, left Philadelphia on Friday for a two-year overhaul in Pascagoula, Miss.

title: ON ORCAS ISLAND, LIFE IN THE SLOW LANE
description: In the 1790's Capt. George Vancouver, the English explorer, had the devil of a time navigating the west coast of North America from what is now Seattle to the top of Vancouver Island. His difficulty had nothing to do with winds and tides and recalcitrant gobs, all of which he handled with ease; he simply couldn't figure out where he was once he'd entered the myriad islands of the archipelago known as the San Juans. In the process, the captain lost his temper, which sea captains of lesser renown from that day to this have been known to do when floating in wobbly circles.

title: AUTHOR'S MARRIAGE NOT IN TROUBLE
description: Thank you for informing me that the omission of the first five paragraphs of my article (''Friends, It Seems, Are Not Perfect,'' Westchester Opinion, July 13) was an accident rather than an editing decision. It appears the first page of the manuscript was not included in the copy received by your office.

title: SPECIAL-INTEREST SIGNS ARE NOT THE ANSWER
description: Let me begin by saying that I do not feel that Steven Schnur has a ''holier than thou'' attitude concerning the use of the yellow, diamond-shaped sign in his car window. I do feel, however, that he failed to point out some implications of such signs, which cause me to object to them.

title: BASING NATIONAL POLICY ON PERSONAL EXPERIENCE
description: AS has been the case from the start of his Administration, Ronald Reagan continues to be influenced heavily by his personal experiences as he shapes, and articulates, important White House initiatives. For instance, many of his closest aides, asked to explain the foundations of his attitudes about South Africa's minority Government, agree that he regards Pretoria as under siege by violent elements. It is, these aides say, a condition similar to his experiences while Governor of California in the late 1960's, when the assault came from students opposed to the Vietnam War.

title:
CABLE TV NOTES;
COMPUTERIZED CHARACTER RETURNS IN A BIGGER ROLE
description: By virtually any standard, Max Headroom lacks depth.

title: In Re Rehnquist
description: Eighteen years ago, another President, Lyndon B. Johnson, nominated a sitting Justice of the Supreme Court, Abe Fortas, to be Chief Justice - and both were rebuffed by a Senate controlled by Mr. Johnson's own party.

title: Burmese Cuisine
description: To the Editor: Andrew Sinclair states in his excellent article on Burma (Travel, June 8), ''Actually, Burmese cooking is excellent unless it tries to imitate British cooking from the last occupation.'' And in another article, called ''Logistics of a Visit to Rangoon and Beyond,'' there is the comment: ''Burma is not a country known for its own cuisine.''

title: AN OUTLINE OF PLANS FOR THE FUTURE
description: The United States Postal Service has announced its stamps and stationery program for 1987. Given the significant number of changes from the originally announced 1986 program, collectors can expect some revisions in next year's plans.

title: AGING OF WATER SYSTEMS A NORTHEASTERN EPIDEMIC
description: Environmental officials and industry analysts in the Northeast say the safety of drinking water supplies is increasingly threatened by aging urban water systems in metropolitan areas, outdated water-treatment plants and chemical and industrial pollutants.

title: CHILDREN, PARENTS AWAITING 'RONALD'
description: Thanks to the efforts of a McDonald's owner-operator and Monmouth Medical Center, a Ronald McDonald House will become a reality here.

title: A TALE OF TWO AREAS ON AN ISLE OF CONTRASTS
description: AFTER a 30-year love affair with Fire Island, I went and bought a house on the North Fork. The origins of this faithlessness were simple: dollar signs. By the time I could even toy with the idea of buying a house, they were asking six figures for a shack on Fire Island.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Spurring Growth Overseas

title: CHALLENGING THE KENNEDY 'MAGIC'
description: ALL POLITICS IS local,'' Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. is fond of saying, and the wisdom of that remark has never been more evident than now, as O'Neill, at the age of 73, prepares to set his duties aside. This is his last term as a Representative serv-ing 520,691 residents of the Eighth Congressional District of Massachusetts, a post he has held for 34 years, and his last year as Speaker of the House, his platform for the last 10. In Somerville, Belmont, Arlington, Watertown and Cambridge, in Charlestown, East Boston, Back Bay, Waltham and up on Beacon Hill, the people who first voted O'Neill into office and the ones too young to remember are under siege by a squad of candidates who want his seat.

title: FURTHER CUTBACKS IN PIKE PROJECT SOUGHT
description: EARLIER this summer, two key state agencies announced plans to scale down the proposed widening of the New Jersey Turnpike. And now officials of East Brunswick Township -home of perhaps the stiffest remaining pocket of local resistance to the $2.2 billion project - have produced a series of documents to support further cutbacks.

title: SOUTH'S STELLAR BANK GAMBLES ON GROWTH
description: EVEN on weekday mornings, only a handful of people mill about the main street here, waiting for buses or idling by the granite statue of a soldier that honors the Confederate war dead. An old man walking down the street volunteers a cheery hello to a perfect stranger.

title: SHUT TIGHT THE MEMORY BAG
description: ZOMBIE JAMBOREE By Robert Merkin. 335 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $16.95. ZOMBIES. The living dead. Alienated creatures who think they're alive and simulate life's activities but who are dimly aware that all their passions and desires are counterfeit. As George Romero suggested in his wickedly funny movie, ''Dawn of the Dead,'' these zombies are all around us. They haunt our shopping malls, riding escalators and listening to background music, emptily searching for the next bargain item; they sit in our suburban ranch-style homes, mesmerized by images and slogans that engage their fake emotions and programmed longings. Robert Merkin's ''Zombie Jamboree'' is a painful yet often hilarious indictment of the processes that produced a specific group of zombies -Vietnam veterans.

title: TWO PRISON CAMPS PROPOSED BY KOCH
description: Mayor Koch has proposed building two prison camps to hold 10,000 people awaiting trial on drug charges or convicted of misdemeanor drug offenses as a way to house the increasing number of prisoners arrested in the city.

title: IN A CORNER OF UTAH, A PIONEER PAST
description: When the Mormon explorer Parley P. Pratt first approached the Virgin River basin in 1850, he was justifiably intimidated by the fierce and alien landscape.

title: THE ONE-SIZE-FITS-ALL GENERATION
description: I HAVE got used to a homogeneous society where Burger Kings now dot even the Iowa landscape, and ''ban the bomb'' rallies are as commonplace in the backwoods as they are in the cities. I have accepted the fact that the person getting a body wave in the seat next to mine is likely to be my best friend's husband.

title: NO HINT OF LOGIC IN SOVIET POLICIES FOR JEWS
description: MY RECENT five-day trip to the Soviet Union left me with a great deal of information and impressions, all of which I feel I should convey to my constituents.

title: THEATER'S PROBLEMS ARE COMPLEX
description: To the Editor:

title: MASSAPEQUA
description: ''THE way we welcome new families is through their children,'' Ivan W. Hametz, a member of the Massapequa School Board, said of his community. ''When children get involved in the many activities in the town, their parents are automatically drawn into the community.''

title:
DINING OUT;
WELCOME SURPRISE AT THE SHORE
description: AFTER stepping around barefoot beachgoers clutching ice cream cones on the sidewalk outside, there is a feeling of serendipity when you enter Cafe Loren. Who would expect such a pretty countrified restaurant to occupy the unpretentious building sandwiched behind the neon-lit Avalon Freeze.

title: CITY'S HUM WILL FADE INTO SOUNDS OF SILENCE
description: From the steamy George Washington Bridge Bus Station, their minds wandered to what seemed to them a far-off and wondrous place where no horns blared, no sirens screamed, no tenements or sweltering city streets could intrude.

title: REAGAN WARNS OF IMPORT QUOTAS
description: President Reagan warned today that ''you can bet there would be retaliation'' from the nation's trading partners if the United States imposed new quotas on imports of textiles, shoes and copper.

title: SMALL MOVIES FILLED WITH BIG TALENT GIVE THE SCREEN A HEAVY BRITISH ACCENT
description: About once a decade or so, the crisis-prone British film industry enjoys a sudden burst of vitality whose reverberations are felt even in the chauvinistic American market. In the 1930's, Alfred Hitchcock's early triumphs, including ''The 39 Steps'' and ''The Lady Vanishes'' and such Alexander Korda productions as ''The Private Life of Henry VIII'' and ''The Ghost Goes West,'' found audience favor on both sides of the Atlantic. The postwar years marked the rise of such directorial talents as David Lean (''Brief Encounter,'' ''Great Expectations''), Carol Reed (''Odd Man Out,'' ''The Third Man'') and the Powell-Pressburger team (''Black Narcissus,'' ''The Red Shoes''). The 50's brought mordant satirical comedies from the Ealing Studios, and the early 60's, the pre-mod naturalism of such restless film makers as John Schlesinger, Lindsay Anderson and Tony Richardson.

title: Ready, Set, J-u-m-m-m-p
description: JUDGES, are you ready? Today's event is the freestyle broad-puddle jump. The venue is midtown Manhattan, 57th Street and Fifth Avenue to be precise, in the middle of a summer downpour.

title: Katherine Stutt, Teacher, Is Wed to Michael Brewer
description: At the Old Parish Church in Weston, Vt., yesterday Katherine Fraser Stutt, the daughter of Judith Simpson Stutt of Weston and William C. Stutt of Brooklyn, was married to Michael Jarvis Brewer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael F. Brewer of Chevy Chase, Md. The Rev. F. Goldthwaite Sherrill 2d performed the Episcopal ceremony.

title: C. K. Sieracki Is Wed To Margaret Stiassni
description: Margaret J. Stiassni, a daughter of Mrs. John E. Gerli of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Charles Stiassni, was married yesterday to Christian K. Sieracki, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Carl Sieracki of Burlington, Conn. The Rev. George F. Dakin Jr., a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Community Church in Kenwood, Calif.

title: Cheryl Lynn Edwards Is Married to Paul T. Denis
description: The marriage of Cheryl Lynn Edwards, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Larry K. Edwards of New York and Raleigh, N.C., to Paul Thomas Denis, a son of Helen C. Denis of Grosse Pointe Woods, Mich., and the late Judge J. Patrick Denis, took place yesterday. The Rev. Dr. Donald Strobe performed the ceremony at the First United Methodist Church in Ann Arbor, Mich.

title: SANCTIONS WILL CROSS THE COLOR LINE
description: SOUTH Africa's mining barons produced a statistic the other day that seemed to reinforce an argument made by many in the West who oppose the imposition of sanctions on this country. If South Africa were cut off economically from the West, an employer group called the Chamber of Mines said, then 35,000 of the 110,000 black coal miners would be jobless. And those are in just one part of one industry. The calculation is disputed by the National Union of Mineworkers, which represents half the nation's 550,000 black mine workers. But it underscores the dimensions of the debate on who would be hurt most in an economy ringed by embargoes, surviving under siege.

title: CONSTITUTION TERMED A SYMBOL OF UNITY
description: Adam Charnes's letter (June 15) was headed ''Scare Tactics.'' It was referring to the article ''The Constitution Is in Danger,'' and he claimed that scare tactics and not facts were used by the writer.

title: PLAN A LONGER STAY? NEW INNS WANT YOU
description: People traveling in Connecticut will soon have an alternative to the traditional hotel room. Places that fall somewhere between hotels and apartments are to open their doors this summer in Windsor, New Haven and Shelton.

title: Ships That Can Double as Classrooms
description: DO you want to learn to use an I.B.M. PC? To solve a murder mystery? To sail with an N.F.L. football team?

title: The Grandfather Lectures
description: One Friday morning early in 1980, Senator Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia was on the floor and spotted his granddaughter, Mary Anne Moore, in the Senate gallery with her fifth-grade classmates and their teacher. In his dual role of the moment as Senate Democratic leader and proud grandfather, he delivered an impromptu speech on the Senate and its history and customs, aimed principally at the small live audience.

title: EVANGELIST OF THE REVOLUTION
description: A SON OF THUNDER Patrick Henry and the American Republic. By Henry Mayer. 529 pp. New York: Franklin Watts. $22.50. PATRIOT publicists celebrated Patrick Henry's speeches as epics. Gentlemen politicians compared him to Cicero. A sometime friend and rival paid him the ultimate compliment: Henry spoke, Thomas Jefferson observed, ''as Homer wrote.''

title: NEW CASSETTES: A PAIR OF COMEDIES ABOUT CONNIVERS
description: Kind Hearts and Coronets Starring Dennis Price, Alec Guinness, Valerie Hobson, Joan Greenwood; directed by Robert Hamer, 1949 Thorn EMI/HBO Video 101 minutes. $39.95.

title: CONSUMER RATES
TEACHING THE YOUNG TO EAT SENSIBLY
description: AT the Hill Central Elementary School in New Haven recently, children of all ages gathered to talk about food. The lesson for the day was the importance of calcium. In front of the room stood a four-foot cardboard bone, complete with smile and blue eyes, to the children's delight.

title: C. T. W. Kunstadter Weds Ruth Udell
description: Ruth Ann Udell, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Udell of Elkins Park, Pa., was married in Glenside, Pa., yesterday to Christopher T. W. Kunstadter, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Kunstadter of New York and London. The Rev. Marguerite Lovett, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony at the Grey Towers Castle at Beaver College, where the bride's mother, Anita Magistro Udell, is chairman of the department of foreign languages.

title: Gregory Popejoy Wed to Ms. Hamilton
description: Virginia Hamilton, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Reid Hamilton of New York, was married yesterday to Gregory McCarl Popejoy, a son of Edward Mack Popejoy of Sacramento, Calif., and the late Mrs. Popejoy. The Rev. Richard Leonard performed the ceremony at the Unitarian Church of All Souls in New York.

title: Verse and 'The Golden Gate'
description: To the Editor:

title: SMALL BANKS FOR SMALL BUSINESSES
description: AT a time when mergers and acquisitions are widespread in the banking industry, the formation of two new independent commercial banks might seem to be an audacious move. Yet the organizers of the Business Bank of Westchester and the State Bank of Westchester, who have years of big-banking experience behind them, say that small businesses need small banks. It is this market - the small-to-medium businesses doing $5 million to $100 million a year in sales -that the two new banks will concentrate on.

title: ON CASTING OFF A LOSING SPELL
description: For a while it looked as though Lev Alburt had become the victim of an evil spell in the two U.K.-U.S. challenge matches that he played. He could do everything but win a game.

title: BALLET AND DIAGHILEV AS PIONEERS IN MODERNISM
description: Dance is so rarely seen within an overall cultural context that even an attempt by literary critics to force a pattern in this regard may be welcome. ''The Triumph of Pierrot: The Commedia dell'Arte and the Modern Imagination,'' a new book by Martin Green and John Swan, is a stimulating study of modernism in which dance, or rather ballet, is given an unexpected central role. The authors wrote separate chapters and collaborated on the concluding section.

title: FINE 'BEST LITTLE WHOREHOUSE,' PARDNER
description: THE Angelettes, the Aggies, the Dogettes and the Waco Wackos are in tip-top shape at the Darien Dinner Theater, folks. So are the other habitues, hangers-on, troublemakers and troubleshooters at Miss Mona's Chicken Ranch - or, as it is more widely known, ''The Best Little Whorehouse in Texas.''

title: SPREADING THE ANTI-NUCLEAR GOSPEL IN EUROPE
description: For Michael Undorf, the logic of venturing into Czechoslovakia and Hungary to spread Austria's antinuclear gospel was obvious. ''Chernobyl came from the East,'' said Mr. Undorf, a part-time university student and full-time campaigner against nuclear power.

title: Irish Pound's Value Cut 8% in Attempt to Increase Exports
description: Ireland devalued its pound by 8 percent today in an attempt to increase its exports by making them cheaper, especially in Britain.

title: Closing Delays
description: To the Editor:

title: LUCILLE BALL DUSTS OFF HER SLAPSTICK
description: On Stage 1 at the old Samuel Goldwyn studio on a hot day in the middle of last month, Lucille Ball came back. Barking the familiar laugh that blends a strangling airdale with a porpoise, mugging for assistant directors and stagehands who weren't even born when ''I Love Lucy'' went on the air in 1951, Lucille Ball came back to weekly television - 12 years after she left it.

title: PROGRESS IS REPORTED IN SRI LANKA TALKS
description: For the first time in at least six months, participants in negotiations to end the violent guerrilla insurgency in Sri Lanka say they have achieved marked progress in narrowing their differences.

title: Q and A
description: A Co-op Renter's Rights Question: I am a rent-stabilized tenant in a building that became a co-op recently under a noneviction plan. Another tenant in the building has bought my apartment and is thus my landlord. He claims he has the right to a set of keys to the apartment and may enter it when he wishes. I have always left a set of keys with the superintendent so there is access in case of emergencies or for repair work. Must I now permit the new owner to enter the apartment when he wishes without advance notice? . . . E. N., Manhattan Answer: The law says that the owner has right to reasonable access, particularly if he is in the process of selling the unit. But the tenant has the right to privacy and to be present while the owner is in the apartment.

title: MARIETTA, SEDUCED BY MUSIC
description: DELIRIUM ECLIPSE & OTHER STORIES By James Lasdun. 200 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $15.95. THE best of these stories are brilliant enough to point a shadow - long, as shadows are at sunrise - from this first book toward a valuable literary career. The worst of the stories seem to be the young British writer James Lasdun's apprentice work, now unmistakably outgrown.

title: TV'S TESTING
description: To the Editor:

title: SOUTHERN SHORE FLAVORS
description: NO SOONER had I put my spoon to the she crab soup than the room went dark. Outside, 40-mile-an-hour winds slammed ashore, bending the shrubby yaupon trees and bringing a dose of rain that formed small lakes around the Ocracoke, N.C., Island Inn and Dining Room, where I was having dinner. Eaten blind, as it were, the tangy coral-hued soup - made of female blue crabs and their roe, sherry and a cream of celery base -took on new significance, the flavors lingering pure and vibrant in the mouth. ''Don't you panic, anyone,'' came a woman's low voice. ''We'll have you all lit in just a minute.''

title: U.S.F.L. Learns The Meaning Of a Dollar
description: When the verdict came last week in its suit against the National Football League, the United States Football League was $1 richer and nearer to death. The upstart league's case was not exactly lost - the jury found that the N.F.L. had violated one section of the antitrust laws - but the decision sent owners into deliberations over whether the league, while hemorrhaging millions, could continue.

title: A MISFIT AMONG TRUE BELIEVERS
description: THE AYATOLLAH IN THE CATHEDRAL By Moorhead Kennedy. With an afterword by Louisa Kennedy. 241 pp. New York: A Myrin Book/Hill & Wang. $17.95. IF you can recall the name of any of the 52 Americans held hostage by revolutionary students in Iran from Nov. 4, 1979, until Jan. 20, 1981, chances are it is that of Moorhead (Mike) Kennedy. Perhaps that is because of the effective job done by his wife, Louisa, as spokesman for the families of the hostages during their captivity. Perhaps it is because of the thoughtful articulateness that he displayed when he went before the cameras himself following his release, so that during the months and even years afterward he was repeatedly called upon to reflect on ''the hostage experience.''

title: EXPLORING PUGET SOUND'S PORTS OF CALL
description: During a sand-art festival on a Puget Sound beach at low tide, beachcombing families meander around castles, sea monsters and a shapely Miss Liberty. Clam shells form the monster's eyes and steam from dry ice snakes from its nostrils, but it is Miss Liberty that garners a blue ribbon. After the tide turns and the sculptures slowly crumble into the sea, children find a new sport - leaping and trampling on the imaginative art that only hours before they had helped to create.

title: MUSIC: PERGOLESI AND MOZART AT BERKSHIRE OPERA
description: Western Massachusetts makes creative use of the baronial mansions that hide behind its fir groves and stone walls. The Cranwell Estate, a mile or two from the center of town and long abandoned as a residence, was, until recently, a rigorous school for boys, and has now been transformed into a resort and conference center.

title: BEADWORK, ACRYLICS AND AIRPLANES
description: At the heart of this beautiful and moving book are the mural paintings that cover Ndebele tribal houses in the South African Transvaal. Margaret Courtney-Clarke, a photojournalist raised in South-West Africa, traveled to remote dwellings in the Transvaal and in NDEBELE: THE ART OF AN AFRICAN TRIBE (Rizzoli, $45) she has recorded the art of the Ndebele women, including beadwork and ceremonial objects.

title:
NATURE WATCH;
NORTHERN KINGFISH
description: Menticirrhus saxatilis Size: To about 18 inches.

title: Ortega Has Learned How to Press the Flesh
description: IT would be difficult to think of another instance in which the leader of a nation with which the United States maintains a de facto state of war has circulated freely in this country and taken his case directly to the American people.

title: ROY COHN, AIDE TO McCARTHY AND FIERY LAWYER, DIES AT 59
description: Roy M. Cohn, the flamboyant, controversial defense lawyer who was chief counsel to Joseph R. McCarthy's Senate investigations in the 1950's into Communist influence in American life, died yesterday at the age of 59. He lived in Manhattan and in Greenwich, Conn.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: WITH blood supplies dangerously low at a number of hospitals in New York and New Jersey, some businesses and institutions have gone to surprising lengths to attract potential donors.

title: People's Woes
description: To the Editor:

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: RHODE ISLAND SEAFOOD GALA

title: FOCUS: Philadelphia; 'Old City' Stirring With Life
description: THE Chocolate Works looms, large and Victorian, on one corner of the Philadelphia neighborhood known as Old City. On another corner sits Smythe's Stores with a handsome, cast-iron facade. Still another block features the Castings, a collection of industrial buildings dating from the 1700's that until recently was a foundry.

title: STATE AWARDS FELLOWSHIPS
description: AN ARTIST who once said, ''I'll never go back to New Jersey,'' returned last year to her hometown of Oceanport in Monmouth County, and this year received the largest state fellowship for crafts since the program was begun more than six years ago.

title: Deborah W. Lippincott Weds
description: At St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Jamestown, R.I., yesterday Deborah Wharton Lippincott, a daughter of Mrs. Anthony N. B. Garvan of Springhouse, Pa., and Barton H. Lippincott of Philadelphia, was married to Nils Christer Mattsson, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Henrik Mattsson of Stockholm. The Rev. Frederick Spulnick performed the ceremony.

title: NEW CASSETTES: A PAIR OF COMEDIES ABOUT CONNIVERS
description: The Ike and Tina Turner Show Vestron MusicVideo 21 minutes. $16.95.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: HOVHANESS CELEBRATION While 75th birthdays are usually special occasions, when the milestone belongs to a world-renowned composer the celebrating tends to become public. This is Alan Hovhaness's 75th year, and the celebration is tonight at Eisenhower Park's Chapin Lakeside Theater in East Meadow. The composer will be present to hear the New York premiere of his ''Mount St. Helens Symphony, No. 50,'' and receive commendations. The music will be performed by the Universal Symphony, under the baton of the Long Island conductor and musician Lawrence Sobol, a Hovhaness disciple. The citations will come from Meet the Composer, a government-financed organization that promotes the work of living composers, and Broadcast Music Inc., an industry group. The free program is at 8 P.M.LIBERTY AGAIN

title: On Language; THE FADING TOVARISH
description: ONE OF THE MORE curious problems spawned by the Russian Revolution is how to address a stranger. Tovarish (comrade) would seem the logical choice, followed perhaps by grazhdanin (citizen), the classic revolutionary salutation. Yet, over the decades, both words have gathered overtones that now render them ill-suited for hailing a total stranger.

title: HORNUNG LEADS 5 INDUCTED INTO HALL
description: Five players were inducted into the Pro Football Hall of Fame today bringing the total membership to 133 since it was established in 1963.

title: NEW CASSETTES: A PAIR OF COMEDIES ABOUT CONNIVERS
description: Britten's 'Peter Grimes' A Royal Opera House, Covent Garden, production, featuring Jon Vickers, Heather Harper, Norman Bailey; with Colin Davis conducting, 1981 Thorn EMI/HBO Video 155 minutes. $39.95.

title:
IN NEW JERSEY;
Developer Climbs High Road in Wayne
description: ALONG the northeastern border of Wayne sits High Mountain, rising to 871 feet and offering a clear view of the Passaic Valley and, about 20 miles to the east, Manhattan's skyline.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: CAMEO CARICATURES %TIn ''Villette,'' Charlotte Bronte satirizes a set of paintings depicting four conventional types of 19th-century women. She is quoted in ''Women Writing About Men'' (Pantheon), by Jane Miller. The first represented a ''Jeune Fille,'' coming out of a church-door, a missal in her hand, her dress very prim, her eyes cast down, her mouth pursed up - the image of a most villainous little precocious she-hypocrite. The second, a ''Mariee'' with a long white veil, kneeling at a prie-dieu in her chamber, holding her hands plastered together, finger to finger, and showing the whites of her eyes in a most exasperating manner. The third, a ''Jeune Mere,'' hanging disconsolate over a clayey and puffy baby with a face like an unwholesome full moon. The fourth, a ''Veuve,'' being a black woman, holding by the hand a black little girl, and the twain studiously surveying an elegant French monument, set up in a corner of some Pere la Chaise. All these four ''Anges'' were grim and grey as burglars, and cold and vapid as ghosts. What women to live with! Insincere, ill-humoured, bloodless, brainless nonentities!

title: BACK-TO-BASICS TRAINING
description: THE basic sauces that are frequently used in summer for salads and marinade for barbecuing are all sold prepared in supermarkets and fancy food shops. Mayonnaise, vinaigrette, spicy tomato-based barbecue sauce and the popular herb-based pesto -constantly called upon for mixing, mellowing and seasoning - can be kept on the pantry shelf, in the refrigerator or freezer.

title: INCREASINGLY POPULAR COTTON SWEATERS
description: HIGH ON THE LIST OF A SWEATER'S VIRTUES ARE ITS beefy texture and insulating bulk. These qualities, once exclusive to woolens, have been translated into cotton, with the result that this comparatively lightweight and absorbent material is now regarded as a sweater fiber for all seasons.

title: NUTRITION QUACKERY: BIG BUSINESS
description: IF A PHYSICIAN told a patient with arthritis to take 200 tablets of aspirin in one dose, the patient would probably think the physician was out of his mind, ignore the instruction and consider suing him for malpractice.

title: Farrakhan Visit Linked To Philadelphia Group
description: A community group under investigation on charges of misusing funds spent more than $8,000 in public money to finance an appearance at a 1984 banquet by Louis Farrakhan, the leader of the Nation of Islam, according to a report published today.

title: THE RIDDLE OF QUEEN VICTORIA'S STOCKINGS AND OTHER REFLECTIONS OF A BIOGRAPHER
description: INSPIRATION comes to biographers as much as to novelists but cannot be commanded by any cerebral tricks. Nevertheless one can do something to help it breathe.

title: COUPLES, FROST TIED FOR LEAD
description: Fred Couples battled gusty winds and crusty greens for a 73 that left him in a tie for the lead today after three rounds of the $500,000 Western Open. Couples was tied with David Frost, who moved up with a one-under 71.

title: ROCK OF PHAGES
description: XORANDOR By Christine Brooke-Rose. 211 pp. New York: Carcanet. $15.95. ONE of the most enduring stock figures from the repertory company of science fiction is the Bright Kid. He may be only normatively bright, like the young hero of ''E.T.,'' or a full-fledged juvenile Einstein like the Wunderkind heroes of Theodore Sturgeon's ''More Than Human'' or John Hersey's ''Child Buyer.'' The vicarious appeal of such a protagonist is not to be wondered at. Just think of the first time you beat a grown-up at chess or in some other way demonstrated that older and wiser don't necessarily come as a matched set. The Bright Kid as Hero is not, of course, confined to science fiction (think of Dickens and Twain), but he seems to have a natural tropism for the genre, perhaps because so much of the science fiction audience is comprised of Bright Kids or grown-ups wistful for their Orphan Annie years, when ''Tomorrow'' was a tune they could completely believe in.

title: FURTWANGLER'S WAY: CONDUCTING AS A CREATIVE ART
description: The posthumous vindication of Wilhelm Furtwangler is gratifying to those who have long admired the mystical, transcendent power of the conductor's interpretations, but it is hardly surprising in view of contemporary musical tastes. Whether or not one accepts the notion of a new Romanticism, there is no denying that subjectivity and overt emotionalism are once again fashionable. After decades of Toscanini-inspired discipline and objectivity, the pendulum has once again swung toward a more expressive position. Furtwangler - a personification of the German Romantic tradition - has benefited immensely from this development.

title: JAPANESE IRKED, KEEP FIGHTING THE U.S. NAVY
description: A combination of local hostility and political activism has dimmed United States Navy hopes for a new landing strip in Japan that the Navy considers vital to train aircraft carrier pilots.

title: 2 Are Charged in Manila Over Death at a Rally
description: Two men have been charged with beating a man to death in front of dozens of onlookers after a rally by followers of former President Ferdinand E. Marcos, the police said today.

title:
GARDENING;
LOSS OF AMERICAN ELM IS STILL FELT
description: WHAT we wouldn't give these hot summer days for the shade of an old, spreading American elm. There are not many left, however.

title:
ON LONG ISLAND;
With Rise in Co-ops, Evictions Are Worry
description: CO-OP conversions in Suffolk County is creating a boon for buyers seeking affordable housing. In several complexes now on the market, where amenities include pools and other recreational facilities, one-bedroom apartments are available for less than $65,000.

title: Diane Elizabeth Rapalus Is Married to John A. Beir
description: The marriage of Diane Elizabeth Rapalus, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Joseph Rapalus of Longmeadow, Mass., to John Alexander Beir, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Franklyn Beir of New York and Lakeville, Conn., took place yesterday at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Longmeadow. Msgr. Thomas F. Devine performed the ceremony.

title: Where Labor Goes for College-Style Learning
description: It is not your usual retreat.

title: Rehnquist Is Cross-Examined By Senate Panel
description: William H. Rehnquist, who ordinarily asks the questions, was answering them last week, and not to everyone's satisfaction.

title: JOHNSON AT 80
description: To the Editor:

title: Will 'Son of Cube' Bring Another Bout of Rubikmania?
description: THERE might be someone, somewhere who is still agonizing over Rubik's Cube. But for the most part that frustrating artifact of the early 1980's has been retired to the attic, the garbage heap, and, with a bow to its elegance and ingeniousness, to the permanent collection of the Museum of Modern Art.

title: EXPOS WILL BE PLAYING FOR BIG STAKES IN THE FREE-AGENT CASE
