description: The hearing into allegations of a free-agent conspiracy by the owners resumes in Los Angeles this week, and the outcome could be the most criticial decision for the players and the owners since free agency emerged from another grievance more than 10 years ago. Two of the players whose future the case could help determine are Tim Raines and Andre Dawson of the Montreal Expos. And their future could make an impact on the Expos' future.

title: FRENCH DEBATING IMMIGRATION LAWS
description: The Interior Minister's efforts to ease procedures for the expulsion of foreigners have led to a heated debate over French immigration policy.

title: POSTINGS: In Ocean County; From $82,000 Up
description: Last August, two young business partners, Charles Biderman and Karen Dempsey, started selling Jackson, N. J., town-house development at prices that began at $61,900. All 153 houses were spoken for in a single weekend.

title: NO END IN SIGHT TO SIKH-HINDU STRIFE
description: In a burst of gunfire, arson and rock throwing, angry mobs of Sikhs and Hindus did more than wreck the tranquillity of a middle-class neighborhood in western New Delhi last weekend.

title: SATELLITE DISHES: ANOTHER ASPECT
description: Regarding the article ''Satellite Dishes: L.I. Laws Blur the Picture'' [ July 20 ] , a significant cause for alarm concerning the use of satellite dishes was not even mentioned.

title: THE POET'S LANDSCAPE
description: The idea initially was not only to escape but to escape to some place lovely, and not only to escape to some place lovely, but to make a literary pilgrimage: We would go to Wordsworth country in the Lake District.

title: Low S.A.T. Scores Perplex Women
description: IT IS well documented that women as a group get higher grades than men in both high school and college. But when it comes to the Scholastic Aptitude Test, it is men who turn in the higher scores.

title: And Not a Moment Too Soon
description: POSTMASTER General Albert V. Casey held a news conference last week to announce: (a) the United States Postal Service had discovered and was attempting to deliver a batch of 42-year-old V (for victory) Mail, and (b) the delay was not the Postal Service's fault.

title: This Week, It's 'Welcome Back, Mac'
description: APPROXIMATELY 5,000 placards reading ''Help Us Welcome Mac Back'' have been printed for the occasion. Representatives of the British, West German and Swedish press will join a large American contingent chronicling the event in an idyllic setting still renowned more for downhill racers than weekend hackers. And ticket sales indicate that a record number of fans will be climbing Stratton Mountain in Vermont this week, lured in part by the opportunity to witness John McEnroe's return to the men's tennis tour.

title: WHETHER KLEZMER OR CLASSICAL, IT'S MUSIC FOR THIS MAN'S CLARINET
description: In the beginning, when the Lord was creating sea and land, light and darkness and other perennial pairings, He did not create for music, as nearly as one can tell, such categories as classical and klezmer. This divine omission is at the heart of the concept of music's universality that Giora Feidman, a man whose soul speaks through his clarinet, would be fanatic about were he at all a man given to fanaticism; passion, yes, fanaticism, no.

title: POLICE CORRUPTION PLAGUING FLORIDA
description: Each passing week seems to bring another new drug-related charge against some local police officer as the rising tide of cocaine smuggling exposes more and more officers to bribes and payoffs.

title: ''EVERYTHING IS DONE FOR THE CO-WORKER''
description: THE Japanese have become known for using their own distinct philosophy and new technologies to build automobiles.

title: LP'S CELEBRATE VOCAL GLORIES OF THE PAST
description: As compact disks point decisively toward the future, anthologies in the conventional LP format (particularly in the field of vocal recordings) celebrate the glories of the past. A number of such ventures have been welcomed by vocal collectors during the past few years. The Metropolitan Opera Guild has issued six double-disk sets honoring the Met Centennial, paralleled (but not duplicated) by a joint RCA-Metropolitan Opera Guild edition called ''100 Singers/100 Years.'' Even more wide-ranging are the collections of treasures assembled in EMI's three monumental volumes called ''The Record of Singing,'' embracing a ''Who's Who'' of vocal eminences from the dawn of recordings to 1939, with a sequel rumored to be under way.

title: MISKITOS ARE ARGUING WITH THEMSELVES
description: SO far they have played a bit part in the guerrilla campaign against the Nicaraguan Government, but there are big plans for the Miskito Indians.

title: FESTIVAL STAR, SIDETRACKED BY NEW RULES, MUST DELAY CAREER
description: BY the end of the first day of competition, Rumeal Robinson had established himself as one of the five best basketball players at the Olympic Sports Festival.

title: BOOKSHELF
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Carolyn Corbin Yeager Wed to Greg D. Lewis
description: Carolyn Corbin Yeager and Greg David Lewis, principals of Lewis Associates, a sales promotion company in Miami, were married yesterday at the Bedford (N.Y.) Golf and Tennis Club. Jeffrey D. Buchanan, the Bedford Town justice, officiated.

title: CLIMBING THE STAIRWAYS OF PILGRIMS AND KINGS
description: One of the saddest losses of our civilization is of city steps, wrote Eleanor Clark in her book, ''Rome and a Villa.'' In addition to their function of emphasizing entrances, steps have played an important decorative role in many great architectural conceptions. Nowhere does this seem more evident than in Rome, which, because of its position on seven hills, has always required the intervention of steps - a necessity that has become a legacy, albeit diminished by the advent of elevators and escalators - solutions which, although they may be more convenient, nevertheless demand less personal involvement.

title: TWO EMPTY SEATS FILL IMAGINATION AT CONCERT
description: UPON entering the concert hall, I immediately noted the large sign, reading ''Sold out.'' It made me feel good, privileged that I was able to obtain tickets to a concert that had a beautiful program performed by a famous orchestra under a celebrated conductor. I knew when I first read about it - several months ago - that it would be a fine performance. Thus, I immediately mailed a check for tickets. Because I acted fast, I got my reward: tickets to a sold-out concert - tickets that a great number of music lovers were not able to obtain.

title: Grading Cabbies
description: CONCERNED about the city's image among travelers, an advisory task force of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey decided to give taxi riders a chance to rate the service they received.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE NEMESIS AFFAIR: A Story of the Death of Dinosaurs and the Ways of Science. By David M. Raup. (Norton, $14.95.)

title: A LOSS FOR TV
description: To the Editor:

title: THE RETURN OF DR. K
description: DWIGHT GOODEN, his fastball crackling, his curveball dropping as suddenly as a duck shot in the air, has begun his charge for a third straight award-winning season. He was Rookie of the Year in 1984, Cy Young Award winner in 1985, and, if Friday night is any indication, he may be headed for Comeback of the Year in 1986.

title: WHILE FUNNY, SIGNS IN CARS SHOULD GO
description: I can certainly appreciate Stephen Schnur's desire to let the world know that there's a ''Baby on Board'' in his automobile [ '' 'Baby on Board': A Note to Those Who Care,'' Westchester Opinion, July 13 ] .

title: FINNISH STEW OF MEATY RICHES
description: Two things are said about South Karelia, an area of southeast Finland surrounding Lake Saimaa. The first, which the Karelians say, is ''We may be poor, but we're not hungry.'' The second, which is said about the Karelians, is ''The Karelians are poor because they eat too well.''

title: CRUISE BARGAINS ON DECK FOR THE FALL
description: Fall - when children are back in school, the summer vacation crush has subsided and the year-end holiday travel season has yet to begin - is traditionally a slack time in the travel industry and consequently a time for travelers to save money by taking advantage of off-season rates. This is particularly true for cruise takers, for whom the opportunities this fall are better than usual. The threat of terrorism has drastically reduced the number of Americans going abroad, and cruise lines that have been unable to sail profitably in the Mediterranean and elsewhere in Europe have had to cut their season short. In reshuffling itineraries, some lines, even ones that have rarely offered discounts in the past, have reduced fares as much as 50 percent.

title: HELMS IS FACING INQUIRY ON CHILE AND U.S. SPYING
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation is seeking to determine whether Senator Jesse Helms or one of his aides passed sensitive American intelligence information to the Chilean Government, according to Congressional and Reagan Administration officials.

title: A NEW PROGRAM TO TREAT GAMBLERS
description: THE compulsive gambler, the experts say, is generally an energetic and competitive family man who tends to have a manipulative and dominant personality. With the advent of his addiction, he feels omnipotent, becomes hypersensitive, depressed, anxious and in need of immediate gratification.

title: NEW YORK REMAINS NO. 2 IN GROWING APPLES
description: New York retained its position last year as the No. 2 apple-producing state, behind Washington, despite early reports that it had dropped to third, according to figures released last month.

title: SPEND AND SPEND, TAX AND TAX
description: A HISTORY OF TAXATION AND EXPENDITURE IN THE WESTERN WORLD By Carolyn Webber and Aaron Wildavsky. Illustrated. 734 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $24.95. AARON WILDAVSKY, now the president of the American Political Science Association, is one of America's leading political scientists. He and his co-author, Carolyn Webber, an associate of the Institute of Urban and Regional Development at the University of California at Berkeley, have undertaken an extremely ambitious task and one that, if successfully completed, would be highly valuable. They have attempted to write a history of taxation and expenditure in the Western world, from Mesopotamia in 3300 B.C. to Ronald Reagan's America. (Actually, the story largely ends about 1970, with President Reagan added occasionally as a postscript.) And they have tried to deduce from this history the answers to a number of basic questions, including why taxes and expenditures grow, why budget deficits rise, and why countries have the kinds of taxes and expenditures they do.

title: The Group, 12 Years Later
description: I believe Anita Shreve had a prior agenda when she set out to write about the group 12 years later.

title: The Real Issue in the Geneva Talks
description: Recent communications between Washington and Moscow suggest that some progress on arms control and disarmament may yet be possible before the end of the Reagan Administration - despite differences between the two sides on the question of limiting strategic defense weapons.

title: SEEKING SOLUTIONS IN 'U.N. OF WESTCHESTER'
description: RELATIONS between North Tarrytown's sizable minority population and its mostly white police force remain unsettled in the wake of a confrontation earlier this summer that involved several hundred black and Hispanic residents and 35 law-enforcement officials, including reinforcements from eight other jurisdictions.

title: AROUND THE TOWN OF STAFFORD, MERGER IS A FIGHTING WORD
description: AT a town meeting five years ago, Norman L. Milliard fielded questions on a report he had helped write on whether the borough of Stafford Springs should merge with the surrounding town of Stafford. Thinking back on it, he shudders.

title: When Presses Will Roll At Nicaragua's Prensa
description: To the Editor:

title: READING PROGRAM KEPT AFTER PROTEST
description: HEWLETT-Woodmere School District officials have decided to retain a popular remedial reading program and rehire several part-time teachers because of community protests over the scrapping of the program.

title: WHAT AMERICA SHOULD DO ABOUT SOUTH AFRICA
description: WHAT SHOULD THE UNITED STATES DO about South Africa? This is a simple question to which there is no simple answer, if there is an answer at all. Of course, if the desire to distance the United States from a morally repugnant system is paramount and if the objective is to punish South Africa for its glaring sins of omission and commission, regardless of the consequences, then sanctions and disinvestment spring readily to mind. And if political expediency is also part of the picture, then calling for economic sanctions must surely be irresistible.

title: DODGERS TOP REDS ON 1-HITTER
description: Enos Cabell hit a grand slam to break a tie in the eighth inning, and Alejandro Pena and Tom Niedenfuer combined on a one-hitter today, giving the Dodgers a 7-1 victory over the Cincinnati Reds.

title: Monster Shows: Blitz Bowl
description: For almost a week behemoths with nicknames like Mongo and Manimal and Refrigerator and Too Tall have walked the streets of London. Today, they'll give Britons their first live look at ''American football'' - as opposed to English football, which Americans call soccer. The Chicago Bears, reigning Super Bowl champions, will take on the Dallas Cowboys at Wembley Stadium.

title: SUFFOLK TAKEOVER OF LILCO CLOUDED
description: A $7.3 billion plan approved by the Suffolk County Legislature last week to take over the Long Island Lighting Company is facing obstacles that its proponents concede may prove its undoing.

title: A New Theory In Rochester
description: Since July 7, when the Monroe County Health Department warned Rochester's 240,000 residents that fecal coliform bacteria had been found in the water system, people in the upstate New York city had been boiling their water, buying it in bottles or carrying it in from the suburbs. Meanwhile, scientists tried to find the source of contamination.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Aaron Pryor, the former junior-welterweight champion who had been charged with driving under the influence of cocaine in Cincinnati last May, has been acquitted of the charge by a jury there.

title:
GARDENING;
LOSS OF AMERICAN ELM IS STILL FELT
description: WHAT we wouldn't give these hot summer days for the shade of an old, spreading American elm. There are not many left, however.

title: Dollars for Scholars
description: 'In the mid-1970's, state legislatures began pulling back in their appropriations, so public universities became more aggressive in raising funds from the private sector.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Houston; Clouds Over Clear Lake
description: IT has been the one bright spot on the Greater Houston real-estate scene, a high-tech, space-age community that has prospered consistently while the oil bust and widespread overbuilding have dragged down the rest of the market.

title: GASTINEAU, JETS' STRONG MAN, HAS YET TO SATISFY OWN GOALS
description: When things go bad for Mark Gastineau, there is always his body.

title: Miss Rosenberg Becomes a Bride
description: Anne-Marie Rosenberg, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward R. Rosenberg of Greenville, Del., was married yesterday to Thomas Frederic Woodhouse, a son of Mrs. Charles Trowbridge of Little Compton, R.I., and Hilary Woodhouse of Milwaukee. The Rev. Dr. John Walton performed the ceremony at the Westminster Presbyterian Church in Wilmington, Del.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a producer's schedule change, an article and a picture caption on page 1 of the Arts and Leisure section today and a theater listing in The Guide (section 2A) about the revival of ''A Raisin in the Sun,'' at the Roundabout Theater, are outdated. The opening has been postponed to Aug. 14.

title: Q&A
description: East Africa Question:Are October and February preferred months for travel in Kenya and Tanzania? What inoculations and medicines are required and needed? - L. V. S., Fair Lawn, N.J. Answer:Travel planners familiar with Kenya and Tanzania say the period to be avoided is late April and May, the season called the long rains. Kenya is on the Equator and Tanzania just below it, so the generally warm weather does not vary greatly, although daytime temperatures in the January-to-March period are usually higher - often in the 80's rather than the 70's. Animals by the thousand can be viewed in both countries the year round, but the time of year and location are factors to consider.

title: Wooing the Young and the Restless
description: ACCORDING to research done for the Cruise Lines International Association, an industry trade group, nearly 50 million people in North America are ''demographically and psychographically suitable for taking cruises.''

title: L.I. COMPNAIES LEARNING JAPANESE BUSINESS WAYS
description: IN THE recent Hollywood film ''Gung Ho'' a group of American auto workers are shocked when a Japanese company buys their plant. Japanese productivity standards, based on each worker's giving his all to the company, come up against American individuality - with comic results.

title: GOING TO SANDY HOOK? NO PASSES TO DISCARD
description: The irony of Marcie Dardin's comments in her lament over the demise of the Jersey Shore sunbather is that she invokes a Noel Coward comment to support her views.

title: PROUD OF HIS FOIBLES, BUSY AS A LAZY BEE
description: THE PAPERS OF SAMUEL MARCHBANKS Comprising ''The Diary,'' ''The Table Talk'' and ''A Garland of Miscellanea'' by Samuel Marchbanks. By Robertson Davies. 540 pp. New York: Elisabeth Sifton Books/Viking. $22.50. SOME 40 years back the city of Peterborough in eastern Ontario had a distinction in the Canadian urban pantheon about on a level with that among American cities of Springfield, Mass. It was principally renowned for the giant lift lock on the canal that passed by the town; this engineering marvel lifted not only the boat but the lock and the water in which the vessel floated. It was considered something of a flaw, in a commercial way, that the canal didn't go much of anywhere. The Peterborough Examiner, the newspaper of the town, had a standing about like that of The Springfield Republican.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week: Finish summer pruning. . . . If annuals, vegetables or young perennials look yellow and skimpy, water with quick acting water-soluble fertilizer. . . Deep soak established plants particularly lilacs and azaleas and don't neglect peonies and astilbes. . . . Keep after insect problems: beetles, slugs, scales and aphids.

title: R. S. Sands Married To Nancy Zingesser
description: The marriage of Jessica Nancy Zingesser, a daughter of Virginia Zingesser of White Plains and Dr. Lawrence Zingesser of New York, to Robert Scott Sands took place last evening at the Pierre in New York. Rabbi Martin Zion performed the ceremony.

title: AMERICAN IN MOSCOW IS CONVICTED IN SCHEME TO SMUGGLE OLD VIOLINS
description: A Fordham University graduate has been convicted in Moscow City Court of being part of a ring that netted more than $225,000 by smuggling 18th-century violins out of the country and selling them at auction in the United States, according to Soviet press reports today.

title: Data Bank: August 3, 1986
NEW MORTAR FOR OLD: REPAIRING BRICK WALLS
description: MOST homeowners think that brick walls are virtually maintenance-free. But in reality, brick does in time require some attention - primarily tuck pointing, the process of replacing or repairing mortar joints that have started to crack or crumble.

title: GEORGIA HEAT, USUALLY UNBEARABLE, IS NOW DEADLY IN DROUGHT
description: The sun burns so fiercely in central Georgia that the area is known as the heat belt. In a normal year the heat is insufferable. In this year of drought it has become deadly.

title: Stepping Up the Risk in Mutual Funds
description: WALL STREET's money managing firms greeted the past year's surge of investor enthusiasm with an array of new and aggressive mutual funds. Starting small, with emphasis generally on lower-capitalization issues - and often containing some volatile new issues - the funds shot ahead in 1986's zesty first half, before falling back recently. Even with the setback, the performances of some of the jazzier funds are remarkable - if not sustainable.

title: Two New Graves in Soviet Linked to Chernobyl Accident
description: Two new graves were found today in a cemetery section reserved for Chernobyl victims, indicating that the world's worst nuclear accident might have claimed two more lives.

title: It's Faster, But Is It Better?
description: AS A TOOL for improving the teaching of writing, computers may eventually rank right up there with the invention of papyrus and ink-filled quills.

title: ROZELLE
description: For 11 weeks, Pete Rozelle and Harry Usher sat in a Federal courtroom, listening to testimony and waiting for five women and one man to decide whether Rozelle's National Football League had violated antitrust common laws at the expense of Usher's United States Football League.

title: A Stoppage at USX
description: Through 27 years of good times and bad, USX Corporation's employees had not hit the bricks. But last week the United Steelworkers began picketing USX plants in nine states in a work stoppage that affected about 22,000 union members.

title: The Little House
description: A FEW YEARS AGO, not long after I had gotten out of college, yet before I figured out how I was going to make my way in the world, I came upon the idea of building a small, one-room house for myself in the woods. I had recently returned from a tumultuous trip through Italy with my girlfriend and returned home penniless, homeless, unemployed and certainly more confused than I had been when I left, a month or two before.

title: Monster Shows: History, Replated
description: So the Stegosaurus, favorite of budding dinosaur lovers through the ages, had only one row of those amazing armor plates. That is what scientists, having reexamined the available fossil material, now tell us.

title: More Charges Of Cheating in Minority Hiring
description: New York State's Minority Business Enterprise program has been in trouble almost from the beginning. Since December 1981, prime contractors on publicly financed construction projects have been required to subcontract at least part of the work to companies controlled by members of minority groups.

title: JENCO GETS A JOYOUS WELCOME HOME
description: Holding flags and signs reading ''Welcome home Father Martin,'' the people of Joliet, with a little help from friends in Indiana, Wisconsin and New York, today welcomed home the Rev. Lawrence Martin Jenco, seven days after Moslem extremists in Lebanon released him.

title: Sleepy Time
description: To the Editor:

title: New Transfer Tax Targets Co-ops
description: THERE'S a new real estate tax looming over the New York skyline this month, one intended to let the city tap into the dramatic increase in the value of cooperative apartments.

title: ALABAMA DEMOCRAT CALLS FOR NEW RUNOFF AFTER COURT'S REBUFF
description: Attorney General Charles Graddick, stunned by a court order overturning his victory in the Democratic Party's gubernatorial primary runoff, called for a new election today, saying, ''I am not a sore loser.''

title: G.O.P. TAKING FIRST STEP TOWARD '88 IN MICHIGAN
description: The process is complicated and the results will be murky. But the election of thousands of precinct delegates in Michigan's Republican primary Tuesday will produce the first winners and losers of the party's 1988 Presidential marathon.

title: THE COMMONWEALTH LEANS HARD, AND THATCHER IS FEELING IT
description: PRIME Minister Margaret Thatcher will confront six other Commonwealth leaders here starting today, aware of the threat that the 49-nation organization could break up because of Britain's resistance to economic sanctions against the Government of South Africa.

title: Suzanne J. Hepworth Marries Olavo Panico
description: At St. Maria Goretti Roman Catholic Church in Lynnfield, Mass., yesterday Suzanne Judith Hepworth, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Derek Graham Hepworth of Lynnfield, was married to Olavo Grasseschi Panico, a son of Emir Paulo Panico of Ribeirao Preto, Sao Paulo, Brazil, and the late Mrs. Panico. The Rev. John H. Flynn performed the ceremony.

title: How to Run an Efficient Three-State, Fare-Card Transit System
description: To the Editor:

title: ON THE LAM FROM RACE AND GENDER
description: DESSA ROSE By Sherley Anne Williams. 236 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $15.95.

title: New Law Worries Soviet Tutors
description: THOUSANDS of people - including many Jewish ''refuseniks'' dismissed from their jobs for seeking to immigrate to Israel - earn their living by tutoring the children of Communist Party members and others who want to get into the country's universities and more specialized institutes of higher learning. Now new laws may threaten this arrangement.

title: Anita Bower Is Bride Of Dr. David R. Ross
description: The marriage of Anita Bower and Dr. David Robinson Ross took place yesterday at the Quaker Meeting House in Adams, Mass., after the custom of the Society of Friends.

title: QUESTION IN ANTITRUST CASE: WAS PUBLIC INTEREST SERVED?
description: IN the confusion surrounding the jury's compromise verdict in the antitrust trial involving the United States Football League and the National Football League, observers are contemplating whose interests were served, those of the U.S.F.L. or of the N.F.L.

title: ON THE S.S. PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT (OR, BANDS ACROSS THE SEA)
description: LIKE thousands of other New York-area people, I'm saddened when I drive under what is left of the West Side Highway and pass the vast, silent spaces on the Hudson where the great superliners docked during their glory years.

title: Coming Clean, Sort of
description: George O'Dowd, the British rock star who, as Boy George, is noted for affecting frocks and eye makeup, was not exactly a vision of contrition last week after he pleaded guilty to heroin possession and was fined the equivalent of $370. Appearing on ''Good Morning America'' in a segment broadast from London, he said he was worried about having his American visa revoked even though he was, he said, no longer a heroin addict.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption with an article about Stockholm in the Travel section of July 13 misnamed a plaza.

title: First Hospital Just for AIDS Is Being Set Up in Houston
description: The nation's first hospital dedicated solely to research and treatment of AIDS has been created, and the first patients are to be accepted Sept. 2.

title: QUEEN CLOSES GAMES
description: The 13th Commonwealth Games ended today to the strains of bagpipes and drums after an exciting last day's track and field program in which England emerged as the top nation in the gold and overall medals standing.

title: Eve Smith to Be Wed To Jonathan Rounds
description: Dr. and Mrs. David Smith of New York and Westhampton Beach, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Eve Karen Smith, to Jonathan Lincoln Rounds, a son of Austin L. Rounds of Wilmington, Mass., and the late Anne M. Jones. An Oct. 19 wedding is planned.

title: Hot on Erving Trail
description: A confidant of Julius Erving, who has been a sounding board for Erving at other critical stages of his professional life and who spoke on the condition that his name would not be used, said bluntly yesterday, ''I think Julius is going to Utah.''

title:
RECORDINGS;
SONGS OF A BYGONE ERA STILL WORK THEIR MAGIC
description: Gone are the days, alas, of household music. Gone the pre-electric age of catches, glees and sentimental ballads, when the only way to hear a new song at home was to sing it yourself after dinner. Gone, alas, the convivial gatherings round a table, voices blending in part music, throats moistened with a decanter of port, gone the fire-lit evenings round the bric-a-brac laden harmonium or rosewood piano (with real ivory keys) reading through Balfe's edition of ''Moore's Irish Melodies'' and trying out Signor Tosti's latest Neapolitan canzone. Gone the halcyon age that deemed the ability to read music a requisite accomplishment of well-bred young men and women.

title: ACCUSATION OF HARASSMENT IS ISSUE IN BRONX SURROGATE RACE
description: A pending investigation into the conduct of Bronx Surrogate Bertram R. Gelfand has become the focus of a challenge to his renomination.

title: Actors' Strike Averted After 14 Hours of Talks
description: Negotiators for actors and producers reached a tentative contract agreement today, averting a strike by 92,000 performers that threatened to delay the fall television season, a spokesman for the producers said.

title: Eliot H. Ammidon, a French Teacher, Marries Philip Jacobs, an Accountant
description: Eliot Hamilton Ammidon, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hoyt Ammidon Jr. of Princeton, N.J., was married there yesterday to Philip Morgan Jacobs, the son of Kareen M. Jacobs of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Jay Winfield Jacobs. The Rev. Daphne Hawkes, an Episcopal priest, and the Rev. Dr. George Pera, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony in the chapel at Princeton University, from which the couple graduated.

title: COMPOSER TO PERFORM
description: STEVE REICH has been spending this summer in Vermont, composing a large orchestral work for the San Francisco Symphony. ''I'm renting a place near a running brook,'' he said. ''I hope it will prove inspirational.''

title: A Summer House Without Uncle Sam
description: VACATIONERS in the market for a second home, as well as people who already own them, may want to rethink their plans for that seashore or mountainside cottage as a result of the tax revision proposals before Congress. Many rules concerning vacation homes are likely to be tightened, to the extent that, in the view of some tax advisers, it could make economic sense to act now to get under the current, more generous measures. If owners are contemplating selling, experts say, they should sell now to benefit from more generous capital gains treatment. Alternatively, would-be home-buyers might consider buying sooner than planned, to lock in more liberal tax breaks.

title: John S. Sheldon Plans a Wedding To Gigi Guenther
description: Mary Margaret Guenther, a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Carl D. Guenther of Dhahran, Saudia Arabia, and John Stevens Sheldon, a vice president in mergers and acquisitions at Goldman, Sachs & Company in New York, plan to be married Sept. 27. Mr. Sheldon is a son of Edith Stevens Sheldon of Wayzata, Minn., and the late Albert M. Sheldon Jr., and a grandson of the late John P. Stevens Jr. of Plainfield, N.J., who was chairman of J. P. Stevens & Company, the textile concern.

title: KING OF DIAMONDS, BILL SAVITT, RETIRES
description: BILL SAVITT'S life story hangs on the walls of his Hartford office and overflows into his jewelry store.

title: 'Smart' Arms and the Man
description: Anyone who has confronted a dense computer program will recognize a growing problem that is troubling the military: All those ''smart'' weapons we rely on so much these days are getting ''brilliant,'' smarter than the people who are supposed to operate them.

title:
MINOR LEAGUES '86: LOGAN EASLEY;
A PITCHER'S ZEROS ADD UP TO SUCCESS
description: LOGAN EASLEY is an improbable hero. The 24-year-old relief specialist for the Albany-Colonie Yankees of the Eastern League is in the midst of the sort of season minor leaguers dream about. In his last 47Y innings, he has not yielded an earned run. In 59 Z innings over all, he has struck out 65 batters and walked only 16. His earned run average - going down and counting - is 0.75, and he has 15 saves, including three last week. His current scoreless streak began May 7.

title: BUSH DIFFERS WITH JORDANIAN ON PEACE PROSPECTS
description: Vice President Bush arrived here today on the third leg of his Middle East trip after disagreeing with the Jordanian Prime Minister about the prospects of advancing the Middle East peace process.

title: Suzanne Moyers, A Schoolteacher, Becomes a Bride
description: Suzanne Moyers and John W. Passacantando were married yesterday at the Garden City (L.I.) Community Church. The Rev. Ralph E. Ahlberg performed the Congregational ceremony.

title: Invasion Of the Arbs
description: In response to William Safire's article ''Invasion of the Arbs'' (On Language, June 22), let me put his mind at rest. Arbitrageur, to my French ear, would be as much a barbarism as arbitrager to his.

title: MUSIC: ROBERT SHAW CONDUCTS AT MOSTLY MOZART
description: ROBERT SHAW is now the music director of the Atlanta Symphony. But he remains best-known nationwide as a choral conductor, and Friday's sold-out Mostly Mozart Festival concert at Avery Fisher Hall let us hear why both parts of that proposition are true.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of film distributors' changes of plans, a picture caption on page 17 of the Arts and Leisure section today and two film listings in The Guide (section 2A) are outdated. ''Stand by Me'' will open this Friday at the Coronet Theater, Third Avenue at 59th Street. ''The Fly'' will open Friday, Aug. 15, at the Criterion, 86th Street East and Movieland Eighth Street theaters.

title: JACKIE JOYNER SETS HEPTATHLON RECORD
description: Jackie Joyner ended two days of spectacular individual performances here tonight and entrenched herself as the world's best heptathlon competitor by shattering the world mark she set less than a month ago at the Goodwill Games in Moscow.

title: MEMORY OF A FRIEND KILLED ON THE ROAD
description: In your Sunday, July 13, Westchester Opinion I read ''A Mother's Fear Nearly Comes True'' and ''Baby on Board.''

title: Hong Kong Is Declared Cholera-Infected Area
description: Health officials said today that three more people had been diagnosed as having cholera, prompting them to declare the British colony a cholera-infected area.

title: Using Morals, Not Money, on Pretoria
description: I share the skepticism of President Reagan and Secretary of State George P. Shultz as to whether wider economic sanctions are likely to move the South African Government toward ending apartheid and the disenfranchisement of its black peoples. I also agree that the multinational firms in South Africa are a positive force toward achieving these goals and should be encouraged to remain. At the same time, I agree with the critics of our South African policy who believe it is high time for the Western democracies to move beyond ''constructive engagement.''

title: TURNING THE BRIDGEPORT ZOO AROUND TO SERVE THE ANIMALS
description: CONNECTICUT'S only major zoo, beset by troubles in recent years, is about to get a facelift.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: ANIMAL KINGDOM (I): BISON EDWIN F. TUCCIO of Riverhead said he wanted ''to preserve the rural character of his neighborhood.'' So Mr. Tuccio has started a buffalo herd. As his wife, Dorothy (Dee) Muma, says, ''Buffalo are about as rural as you can get.''

title: Julie Fuller Weds
description: At the Loyola College Chapel in Baltimore yesterday Julie Fuller and John Stephen Buscema, Loyola graduates, were married in a Roman Catholic ceremony performed by the Rev. Kevin Wildes. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Garland Fuller of Joppa, Md. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. John S. Buscema of Oradell, N.J.

title: More Ducks Expected to Fly South This Fall
description: ESTIMATES of the number of North American ducks that will wing south this fall are more optimistic than they were a year ago, according to a recent report issued by the wildlife services of the United States and Canada.

title: Guarding Against a Third Energy Shock
description: WHY would a car company favor fuel economy regulations? I do not want to pretend to an excess of virtue or public spiritedness, compared with our competitors, who are on the other side of this question. But in our view, energy conservation is not just good public policy, but good business.

title: A JOHN KENNEDY HOME HAD A RESTRICTIVE DEED
description: John F. Kennedy purchased a Washington home whose deed barred its sale to blacks, U.S. News & World Report reported today.

title: KEAN CALLED INSENSITIVE TO PROBLEMS OF CITIES
description: Sadly lost in most media coverage of New Jersey's current ''budget crisis'' is the fact that the Legislature and the public are being forced to make false choices by a Governor who has shown callous insensitivity to the problems of our cities.

title: The Civil War In Beirut Springs Back to Life
description: The sporadic civil war in Lebanon, now in its 11th year, produced two more spectacular acts of terrorism last week: a car bomb explosion that killed 33 people and injured 140 people in Christian East Beirut on Monday, and another the next day that killed 25 and wounded 180 in Moslem West Beirut.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''OPEC has never shone for its logic, but this time it's worse than ever. We are going around in circles.'' Etienne Guy Mouvagha Tchioba, Gabon's oil minister.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: There are people who pretend to be something they are not, but for an over-zealous volunteer working to help re-elect Representative Robert G. Torricelli, Democrat of the Ninth District (Bergen County), a guise proved embarrassing.

title: SIBERIAN FISH ARE THE FOCUS OF AN ACCORD
description: The chance to fish for the giant Siberian taimen, long just a gleam in the eye of American anglers, should soon be possible under an agreement signed recently by Soviet and American fishing groups.

title: HASSAN TRIES TO PLAY THE MIDDLEMAN
description: KING HASSAN II of Morocco is said to have ''baraka'' - Arabic for a special kind of good fortune that comes from God. Those so endowed are believed to be both inspired and protected. It is still unclear whether the King's meeting with Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel 10 days ago at the Moroccan resort of Ifrane was an act of inspiration, or a folly for which he will need protection. But it was the sort of dramatic surprise that King Hassan has savored throughout his 25-year reign.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: Higbee Beach, a lonely stretch on the Delaware Bay coastline of Lower Township in Cape May County, is no longer a haven for nude bathers.

title: WHY ASIANS ARE GOING TO THE HEAD OF THE CLASS
description: Le Thi Ngoc, a 32-year-old computer technician in Fremont, Calif., follows a set schedule when she comes home from work. After preparing dinner, she spends the next two hours helping her 10-year-old son, Alan, with his homework. Alan is not allowed to watch television on weeknights, and if he plays with his G.I. Joe toys when he is supposed to be doing his schoolwork, his mother throws them away. ''Helping my son to do well in school is a sacred duty; you want your family to do well,'' said Ms. Ngoc, who fled Vietnam in 1975. ''I'm not like Americans who believe in freedom, freedom to let their kids do whatever they want.''

title: The Group, 12 Years Later
description: Thank you for Anita Shreve's article. As a syndicated advice columnist for 15 years, I am still receiving letters from women whose lives were changed by the National Organization for Women and other women's organizations.

title: Ms. O'Brien Weds in Rye
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection in Rye, N.Y., yesterday Karen A. O'Brien, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kevin J. O'Brien of Harrison, N.Y., was married to Stephen C. Lichtenauer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Lichtenauer of Indianapolis. Msgr. Donald J. Pryor performed the ceremony.

title: Miss Povich To Be Bride
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. David Povich of Washington of the engagement of their daughter Johanna Celia Povich to Timothy Lake McDonough, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard C. McDonough of Mantoloking, N.J.

title: THE CASCADES: GLACIERS, LAKES AND SOLITUDE
description: Some people go to the mountains to conquer. Others seek a retreat for the soul, a restorative healing ground high above the troubles at sea level. Dusan Jagersky went to the North Cascades because he fell in love with a picture. A Czech emigre on the run from the Russian tanks that rolled into Prague in 1968, Mr. Jagersky found himself in Grand Central Terminal staring at a framed picture of Mount Shuksan, a 9,127-foot cone of chaotic ice surrounded by meadows so primitive that many have never been touched by a hiker's boot. After locating the peak on a map, he followed his heart to the northwest corner of the country, near the Washington-Canada border, and eventually pioneered several new climbing routes around the mountain he had first seen in the crowded train station.

title: Suzanne Hammett Marries G. J. Muth
description: Suzanne Hammett, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. A. Lawton Hammett 2d of Stamford, Conn., and Waterford, Me., was married yesterday to Gregory J. Muth, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence William Muth of Lavallette, N.J., and Palm Coast, Fla. The Rev. Richard Mayberry performed the ceremony at St. Francis Episcopal Church in Stamford.

title: JAZZ: A SHARING OF STYLES
description: ''WHEREVER I go in the world,'' said Bill Lowe, a trombonist, ''I can find at least five people who can play the blues.''

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: The Magic of India And Other Bargains Nardin Fine Arts was established four years ago in the Yellow Monkey Village in Cross River after earlier incarnations on Madison Avenue in Manhattan and in Mount Kisco. Nardin thus is celebrating its 10th year in business with 10 or 20 percent reductions on Far Eastern, African and a few American items, among them sculptures, tribal masks, statues, paintings framed in silk, framed gouaches or manuscript remnants, embroidered and mirrored cloths, baskets and storage containers, jewelry and evening purses, rugs and prints by Hirschfeld and Calder.

title: Encouraging Hispanic Students To Stay in School
description: THIS summer in Chicago, 15 Hispanic teen-agers who might have joined rival gangs are instead playing on the same baseball team. In the fall they will begin their third year of high school in a dropout prevention program.

title: BEST SELLERS: August 3, 1986
description: Week This Last on Week Fiction Week List 1 WANDERLUST, by Danielle Steel. 1 3 (Delacorte, $1795.) A rich orphan comes of age while she travels the world. 2 RED STORM RISING, by Tom Clancy. 1 Putnam, $19.95.) Without using nuclear weapons, the West staves off the Russians in World War III. 3 A MATTER OF HONOR, by Jeffrey 2 5 Archer. (Linden/Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) Nazi intrigue and a family secret that could change the course of the cold war. 4 LAST OF THE BREED, by Louis L'Amour. 3 8 (Bantam, $17.95.) The adventures of a United States Air Force major in Siberia. 5 ACT OF WILL, by Barbara 4 7 Taylor Bradford. (Doubleday, $17.95.) Three generations of talented, ambitious women in England and New York. 6 A PERFECT SPY, by John le 6 15 Carre. (Knopf, $18.95.) The tale of Magnus Pym, a British secret agent, and his father, Rick, a flamboyant con man. 7 THE GARDEN OF EDEN, by Ernest 9 10 Hemingway. (Scribners, $18.95.) A writer and his wife have affairs with the same woman on their European honeymoon; Hemingway's last unpublished novel. 8 I'LL TAKE MANHATTAN, by 5 15 Judith Krantz. (Crown, $18.95.) Rich, beautiful Maxi Amberville conquers the world of magazine publishing. 9 THE EIGHTH COMMANDMENT, by Lawrence 8 9 Sanders. (Putnam, $18.95.) The theft of a priceless Greek coin brings a New York dynasty's scandals to light. 10 THE BOURNE SUPREMACY, by Robert 7 22 Ludlum. (Random House, $19.95.) The hero of ''The Bourne Identity'' foils a plot to seize Hong Kong and bring China into conflict with the West. 11 THE GOOD MOTHER, by Sue Miller. 10 12 (Harper & Row, $17.95.) A woman's attachment to her daughter presents her with a dilemma. 12 THE MAMMOTH HUNTERS, by Jean M. 12 37 Auel. (Crown, $19.95.) Ayla continues her adventures in the prehistoric world. 13 BARRIER ISLAND, by John D. MacDonald. 11 7 (Knopf, $16.95.) One man sets out to thwart a multimillion-dollar Mississippi land swindle. 14 TAMING A SEA-HORSE, by Robert 14 8 B. Parker. (Seymour Lawrence/Delacorte, $15.95.) The private eye Spenser tracks a young woman through the seamy byways of a pleasure empire. 15 KATE VAIDEN, by Reynolds Price. 1 (Atheneum, $16.95.) At the age of 57, a Southern-born woman looks back on her checkered life. Nonfiction 1 FATHERHOOD, by Bill Cosby. 1 13 (Dolphin/ Doubleday, $14.95.) Anecdotes and ruminations from the television star and father of five. 2 YOU'RE ONLY OLD ONCE! by Dr. Seuss. 2 21 (Random House, $9.95.) A checkup at the Golden Years Clinic in pictures and rhyme. 3 ROCK HUDSON: His Story, by Rock 3 6 Hudson and Sara Davidson. (Morrow, $16.95.) An account of the actor's life written with his cooperation. 4 JAMES HERRIOT'S DOG STORIES, by James 4 12 Herriot. (St. Martin's, $19.95.) Fifty tales by a Yorkshire veterinarian about his favorite animal. 5 FORD: The Men and the Machine, 6 7 by Robert Lacey. (Little, Brown, $24.95.) A history of the automobile company and the dynasty. 6 ''AND SO IT GOES,'' by Linda 5 8 Ellerbee. (Putnam, $16.95.) Television journalism as experienced by a former NBC correspondent. 7 A CAST OF KILLERS, by Sidney D. 7 3 Kirkpatrick. (Dutton, $17.95.) The investigation, by the film director King Vidor, of a celebrated Hollywood murder case. 8 WHEN ALL YOU'VE EVER WANTED ISN'T 12 16 ENOUGH, by Harold S. Kushner. (Summit, $16.95.) A rabbi on ''the search for a life that matters.'' 9 THE UNDERGROUND EMPIRE, by James 15 3 Mills. (Doubleday, $22.95.) How the global war on the drug trade is being waged and being stymied. 10 NECESSARY LOSSES, by Judith Viorst. 8 15 (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) Life is a series of losses, the author argues, and we must confront them to grow. 11 MURROW: His Life and Times, by A. M. 11 3 Sperber. (Freundlich/Kampmann, $25.) The career of the CBS newscaster. 12 IN SEARCH OF THE TROJAN WAR, by Michael 10 5 Wood. (Facts on File, $22.95.) Archeologists' search for the truth behind the Homeric legend. 13 THE MAN WHO MISTOOK HIS WIFE 9 18 FOR A HAT, by Oliver Sacks. (Summit, $15.95.) Strange neurological disabilities. 14 BUS 9 TO PARADISE, by Leo 13 25 Buscaglia. (Slack/ Morrow, $16.95.) Another trip with the ebullient advocate of the virtues of love. 15 ENTER TALKING, by Joan Rivers 12 with Richard Meryman. (Delacorte, $17.95.) The talk-show hostess' long professional climb. 16 THE TRIUMPH OF POLITICS, by David 14 12 A. Stockman. (Harper & Row, $21.95.) Why President Reagan was unable to balance the budget. Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 THE ROTATION DIET, By Martin 1 11 Katahn. (Norton, $15.95.) A regimen based on the Vanderbilt University Weight Management Program. 2 FIT FOR LIFE, by Harvey 2 50 Diamond and Marilyn Diamond. (Warner, $17.50.) A diet for weight loss and physical fitness. 3 CALLANETICS, by Callan Pinckney 3 36 with Sallie Batson. (Morrow, $17.95.) Exercises designed to enable women to look ''10 years younger in 10 hours.'' 4 MODERN PREVENTION: THE NEW MEDICINE, 1 by Isadore Rosenfeld. (Linden/Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) Ways to ward off a variety of complaints and diseases. 5 MEDICAL MAKEOVER, by Robert 5 3 M. Giller and Kathy Matthews. (Beech Tree/Morrow, $16.95.) A ''no-willpower program for lifetime health.'' In Advice and How-to, five titles are listed because, beyond that point, sales in this category are not generally large enough to make a longer list statistically reliable. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the bookselling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. And Bear in Mind

title: McCOVEY TO JOIN HALL OF FAME TODAY
description: Willie McCovey, remembered as much for a last out he made as for his 521 home runs, will be inducted into the Baseball Hall of Fame Sunday along with two old-timers, Bobby Doerr and the late Ernie Lombardi.

title: Packer's Crime
description: To the Editor:

title:
GARDENING;
LOSS OF AMERICAN ELM IS STILL FELT
description: WHAT we wouldn't give these hot summer days for the shade of an old, spreading American elm. There are not many left, however.

title:
A VOICE FROM CALCUTTA;
'We Don't Need Pity. India Can Look After Itself'
description: THE gunfire in Punjab has sent up a smokescreen that is hiding much of the truth about India's ability, self-confidence and perception of its future. Bad news, as we all know, drives out the good, not because journalists are a satanic breed, but because readers find good news boring after a very short while.

title: Malcolm Aldrich, 86; Headed a Foundation
description: Malcolm Pratt Aldrich, the former president and chairman of the Commonwealth Fund, a national philanthropic foundation, died of pneumonia Thursday at Southhampton (L.I.) Hospital. He was 86 years old and lived in East Hampton, L.I.

title: Delights and Limitations of Automatic Focusing
description: AUTOMATIC focusing, the distinguishing mark of an increasingly popular breed known as ''point-and-shoot'' cameras, has entered the territory of the sophisticated 35-millimeter single-lens reflex, better known as the SLR. It looks to be the feature of the future.

title: Last Vestige of a Silly Energy Policy
description: THIS fall, the National Highway Traffic and Safety Administration must once again decide whether to roll back the Federal fuel economy standards. General Motors and Ford have petitioned the Administration to lower the CAFE (Corporate Average Fuel Economy) standard for model year 1987. Their eminently sensible reasons are that enforcing the standard would hurt consumers and introduce harmful economic distortions while largely failing to produce the energy savings that they were intended to promote.

title: ELDER, 9 UNDER, LEADS SENIORS
description: Minutes before the thunderstorm broke, Lee Elder completed a six-under-par round of 64 today to take a four-stroke lead in the second round of the Commemorative, the Senior PGA Tour's only event in the New York metropolitan area.

title: WHY ASIANS ARE GOING TO THE HEAD OF THE CLASS Some Fear Colleges Use Quotas to Limit Admissions
description: THE remarkable academic success of Asian-Americans has touched off a growing national debate about whether some colleges are erecting informal quotas to limit their admissions. Administrators from Harvard and Princeton to Berkeley and Stanford strongly deny there are such quotas. But more and more Asian-American students, faculty members and community leaders have complained that some Asian-Americans are being turned down despite having higher scores than other applicants.

title: Golf for Senior Women
description: The commissioner of the Ladies Professional Golf Association is against it, but there is a move afoot to start a senior tour for female pros.

title: Impatient Builders Starting to Provide Public Services
description: FACED with financially strapped governments unable to pay for crucial improvements in public services, developers throughout the region have shown themselves willing to build the bridges, roads, and other improvements that normally would be a public responsibility.

title: Counting the Votes
description: Most members of Congress and many voters believe the most basic responsibility of any lawmaker is to show up on the floor when the votes are counted and take a stand, right or wrong. At election time, it can be hard for members to justify how they voted on every issue, but easy to demonstrate that they didn't duck any.

title: CONCERT: JULIO IGLESIAS
description: TWO years ago, the Spanish pop idol Julio Iglesias released his first English-language album as part of an elaborate campaign to conquer the American record market. That campaign only partially succeeded.

title: PLAINFIELD TOLD TO REINSTATE WORKERS IN DRUG SUIT
description: A Federal judge has ruled that 16 Plainfield firefighters and a civilian Police Department employee suspended after surprise urine tests found traces of illegal drugs must be temporarily reinstated.

title:
ART;
AN AIR OF MYSTERY IN THREE EXHIBITS
description: REAL ART WAYS, Hartford's longstanding not-for-profit arts space, is not living up to its acronym. Very little seems raw about its modified high-tech quarters at 94 Allyn Street. The discreet blue awning above the door signals coziness.

title: POSTINGS: Filling a Gap; Newcomer on 46th
description: With porthole windows and three-ton moorings implanted in the sidewalk, the Goldberg Marine Supply Company at 12 West 46th Street long had been one of the most distinctive storefronts in Manhattan.

title: Tulasne to Face Novacek in Final
description: Thierry Tulasne of France came from behind after a rain delay to rout Jimmy Arias in straight sets tonight, joining unheralded Karel Novacek of Czechoslovakia in the final of the $220,000 D.C. Tennis Classic.

title: POSTINGS: Where Gershwin Played; Condos on Ave. B
description: On the third floor, George Gershwin gave his first public concert. Much later, in the basement, a splinter group of the Black Panthers turned fire hoses on the electrical system as a protest, largely destroying the building's systems and causing it to be condemned.

title: Peter S. Rose Fiance Of Denise S. Berman
description: Announcement has been made by Mala Berman of Potomac, Md., and Frederick S. Berman of Alexandria, Va., of the engagement of their daughter Denise Starr Berman to Peter Seth Rose, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Zeldon E. Rose of West Long Branch, N.J., and St. Thomas, V.I. A November wedding is planned.

title: DO TEACHERS DESERVE ALL THAT MONEY?
description: THIS year, our public school teachers have the opportunity to begin receiving the financial support due their profession - if our towns give them the available state funds. This decision rests in the hands of town leaders - boards of education and finance, or town councils - and town residents, where there are town meetings.

title: WILENTZ ISSUE MAY CHANGE RESIDENT LAW
description: THE debate over whether Chief Justice Robert N. Wilentz of the State Supreme Court lives in New Jersey or New York City has focused attention on a little-known act dating back to the state's first constitutional Governor, William Livingston.

title: IN LANGAUGE TORN FROM SLEEP
description: THE SELECTED POETRY OF YEHUDA AMICHAI Edited and translated by Chana Bloch and Stephen Mitchell. 173 pp. New York: Harper & Row. Cloth, $22.95. Paper, $12.95. TRAVELS By Yehuda Amichai. Translated by Ruth Nevo. Bilingual. 137 pp. New York: The Sheep Meadow Press/Persea Books. Cloth, $13.95. Paper, $9.95. YEHUDA AMICHAI'S ''Selected Poetry'' is a retrospective of his life's work thus far, the artistic record of his own highly personal 30-year war on forgetfulness and silence. Mr. Amichai is an essentially autobiographical poet with the rare ability to characterize the complex fate of the modern Israeli, the private individual inevitably affected by the public realm of war, politics and religion. In a way, the poet is like one of Emerson's ''representative men'' transferred to Jerusalem and updated for the second half of the 20th century, a prophet who shuns the traditional role and speaks in the guise of an ordinary Jewish citizen concerned with his people and his place. One of his achievements is to bring to life the individuals behind the blind statistics, to register the human implications of history. Speaking about his own richly felt inner life, he ends up telling the tale of his tribe.

title: MUSICAL IS FOUND WANTING
description: DURING his first couple of years as producer-director of the Off-Broad Street Theatre, New Jersey's only dessert-theater (as the publicity brochure has it), Robert Thick assiduously avoided putting on ''They're Playing Our Song.''

title: Italian Court Convicts 31 In Organized-Crime Trial
description: A court convicted 31 people on organized-crime charges today and sentenced them to prison terms ranging from 4 to 28 years.

title: Tax Burden to Remain on the Same Shoulders
description: To the Editor:

title: The Group, 12 Years Later
description: With the exception of one privileged member, the women in the group appear to have given up; their regret and lethargy punctuate the entire article. Have these women lost their zeal or has the author simply failed to convey the full picture, choosing instead to emphasize complacency, self-doubt and disappointment? And if the depiction is realistic, is it the implication that such an attitude is shared by other feminists?

title: STATE PANEL CRITICIZES EMERGENCY PSYCHIATRIC CARE
description: A New York State commission said yesterday that senior physicians should be required to better monitor emergency psychiatric patients to reduce the likelihood of incidents like the one in which two passengers were slain aboard a Staten Island ferryboat.

title: Music
description: Three kinds of Caribbean pop come to downtown clubs this week - styles from Jamaica, the Dominican Republic and Puerto Rico. Tonight, the Village Gate (Bleecker and Thompson streets) will present the Skatalites, a Jamaican band whose music is part of reggae's roots. From 1963 to '65, the Skatalites were Jamaica's top studio band, melding pop tunes, big-band-style saxophone solos and Jamaica's syncopated ''ska'' beat, definitively set down by the drummer Lloyd Knibbs and the bassist Lloyd Brivitte.

title: The Group, 12 Years Later
description: When asked what sets her apart from other members of the group, Brenda Boozer replies, ''I've been successful.'' This remark bears the marks of 1980's feminism in the era of egoism.

title: BRINGING FRESH APPROACHES TO AGES-OLD JEWISH THEMES
description: ''J ewish Themes/Contemporary Artists II'' is a prophetic show. It is significant not so much for the quality of its art - although some works are first-rate - as for what it has to say about the possibilities for art in the postmodern era. Even more than ''Choices'' at the New Museum of Contemporary Art and ''Images of the Unknown'' at P.S. 1, both of which took place earlier this year, it announces that old themes and new art, that big subjects and fresh approaches to media and materials, can now enhance each other in cogent and dramatic ways.

title: PATERNITY EAVE: A TREND IS BORN
description: BEFORE Elliot Baron's son was born, he made plans to take a leave from his job to care for the baby.

title:
ART;
SCULPTURE ADDS LIFE TO OFFICE COMPLEX
description: WHEN this writer first visited Blue Hill Plaza in Pearl River in Rockland County three years ago, it was to pursue the story line of a white elephant of an office complex -called a laughingstock by some -getting new life, through art.

title: S. D. Cashin Wed To Maria L. Hoyt
description: Maria Louisa Hoyt, a daughter of Mary Pierrepont Conrad and Edwin Chase Hoyt, both of Albuquerque, N.M., was married yesterday to Stephen Douglas Cashin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Marshal Cashin of Rome, Washington and Cotuit, Mass. The Rev. Conran Runnebaum performed the ceremony at Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church in Arroyo Seco, N.M.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: New Bedford, Mass.;
Single-Family Comeback
description: NOT in 25 years has this fishing port of nearly 100,000 residents seen a subdivision of single-family homes as large as Heritage Green Estates, according to Napoleon Oliveire, a building inspector here.

title: AGUILERA STRONG AS METS TOP EXPOS
description: One of the last pockets of resistance to the Mets' blitzkrieg probably disintegrated yesterday when the Montreal Expos reported disabling injuries that could end the season for two of their regulars: Hubie Brooks, the star shortstop and leading hitter in the National League, and Mike Fitzgerald, the team's No. 1 catcher.

title: Phoebe Anderson Wed in Bay State
description: Phoebe Dare Anderson, an elementary schoolteacher in Melrose, Mass., and Stephen Joseph McCarthy, a senior analyst for the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston, were married yesterday at the Episcopal Church of Our Redeemer in Lexington, Mass. The Rev. Alden Flanders performed the ceremony.

title: America's Drug Problem, Cont.
description: It has been difficult over the years to tell when one antidrug campaign ends and another begins. So the public officials who last week discussed new strategies against what is commonly referred to as a national crisis were careful to point out what is different - and more determined -about their latest efforts.

title: THEATER'S PROBLEMS ARE COMPLEX
description: To the Editor:

title: Winter Wedding For Miss Frank
description: A December wedding is planned by Eleanor Waldrop Frank and John Wharton Hazard Jr., the parents of the bride-to-be, Dr. and Mrs. Randolph Adams Frank of Washington, have announced.

title: 100 Tennessee Residents Win Pollution Lawsuit
description: A judge has ordered a chemical company to pay $12.7 million to people living near a landfill, ruling that the company disregarded their health in its site selection and management of the dump.

title: CRAXI SPINS IN ITALY'S REVOLVING DOOR
description: EVEN for aficionados of politics, the Italian version often seems to be played with no clear rules on an uneven field by contestants who saunter in and out for no apparent reason.

title: Article 420786 -- No Title
description: DAY, BERRY & HOWARD of Hartford, Connecticut's largest law firm, is the first tenant to sign a lease at Canterbury Green, a $38 million office, retail and apartment complex that is to open next April in downtown Stamford.

title: GOING TO SANDY HOOK? NO PASSES TO DISCARD
description: Marcy Dardin (Personally Speaking, June 29) cannot possibly throw away her season pass to Sandy Hook [ and the Gateway National Recreation Area ] because she cannot have one to throw away.

title: Mary Beth Crowley Weds T. J. Smith in Connecticut
description: Mary Beth Crowley, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard M. Crowley of New Canaan, Conn., was married there yesterday to Timothy Jerome Smith, a son of Kevil Smith of San Francisco and Judge Jerome A. Smith of Saratoga, Calif. The Rev. Peter Cullen performed the ceremony at the St. Aloysius Roman Catholic Church.

title: CAUTIOUS PLAY AT CHESS MATCH AVOIDS MISTAKES AND VICTORY
description: Anatoly Karpov and Gary Kasparov, perhaps mindful of their mistakes in the previous game, put forth only dull and cautious play in drawing the third game of their world championship chess match in London on Friday. The first three games have all been draws.

title: BLACKS ON STAGE: THE PROGRESS IS DECEPTIVE
description: Depending on the perspective, this might be regarded as a particularly salutary time for black theater and black theater artists. Such performers as Debbie Allen, Whoopi Goldberg, Cleavon Little, Gregory Hines, Ben Vereen and others have been scoring great personal successes on stage and on screen. Almost every season there is at least one Broadway musical featuring black performers. Next Thursday, the latest example, ''Honky Tonk Nights,'' a chronicle of black vaudevillians, opens at the Biltmore, and, reminding one of the vitality of black playwriting, there is, coincidentally, a revival of ''A Raisin in the Sun'' opening Wednesday at the Roundabout. Currently, under Joseph

title: The Group, 12 Years Later
description: The five case studies Anita Shreve presents are certainly interesting, but are they representative? Ms. Shreve appears to sketch the women's movement in the United States as a white and upper-middle-class phenomenon. Of the five women, one is a Juilliard graduate, the second owns her own restaurant, the third works as a research scientist, the fourth is an opera star and the fifth an actress.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: WANDERLUST. By Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $17.95.) Danielle Steel's new romance novel is a delicious, lightweight treat. Audrey Driscoll, age 26, with her coppery hair, creamy skin, passion for exotic places and sizable fortune, hardly seems a candidate for spinsterhood, but that seems to be her fate in San Francisco in the 1930's.

title: A WALL, AN IDEA, THEN A 70-FOOT CANVAS
description: BETH NEVILLE has always painted ''large.'' It's an artistic characteristic that ''comes from growing up on a 150-acre farm in Columbia County, N.Y.'' she said. ''Every time I try to paint small, it's a disaster.''

title: Interstate Banking
description: To the Editor:

title: A Favorite Robbery Target
description: A service station here was robbed of about $40 Thursday by the same bandit who had already struck there seven times since March 23, the police say.

title: FIREFIGHTER FLASHBACK
description: MUCH of the history of firefighting in the United States was written in the Northeast, and a few notable events occurred in New Jersey. Among these were the fire that swept the Hoboken waterfront in the summer of 1900, killing 400 people.

title: GOOD CAJUN COOKING, AND MORE
description: ALTHOUGH the name J-Dave's is as much a play on K-Paul's Louisiana kitchen in New Orleans as the blackened salmon on the menu is borrowed from Paul Prudhomme's blackened redfish, this fairly new place in Patchogue is not strictly Cajun. The Cajun food is very good, however, and the rest, an eclectic mix, is nearly as satisfying.

title: Allison Stark Engaged To Jeffrey P. Stodghill
description: Allison Tracy Stark and Jeffrey Paxson Stodghill, 1981 graduates of Yale University, plan to be married Sept 7. The future bride is a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William Stark of Washington, who have announced her engagement to a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Stodghill of Louisville, Ky.

title: New Lunch Bunch
description: It was bound to happen sooner or later. For $25, Washingtonians, and presumably New York shuttle hoppers for that matter, can join a group called PowerLunch!

title: WHY ASIANS ARE GOING TO THE HEAD OF THE CLASS 'I Promised My Father to Uphold Our Family Honor'
description: WHEN Jason Tang arrived in the United States in 1980, after two years in a refugee camp in Malaysia for Vietnamese boat people, he barely spoke English. All he could say was, ''How are you? I'm 12.'' What was worse, Jason had not been in a regular school since 1975, when the Vietnam War ended and he was a second-grader. The new schools set up by the victorious Communists ''only taught about Lenin and Marx and Ho Chi Minh,'' he recalled. So his family kept him home.

title: Keep Your Missiles Off the Ocean Floor
description: To the Editor:

title: A DAUGHTER GOES AWAY TO COLLEGE, A FATHER REVIEWS THE PAST
description: MY daughter is going to college this fall, and life to her is endless possibilities. She reaches out to embrace the world, usually unaware of its pitfalls. Through the years I have been her psychiatrist, chauffeur, doctor, maid and banker. Now, I will just be dad, back home.

title: Taking a Leaf From the Japanese
description: ''THE raspberry bushes are being eaten by Japanese beetles!''

title: Seven Are Hurt in Evacuation Of a People Express Jetliner
description: Seven people suffered minor injuries today after a People Express jetliner bound for Newark International Airport made an emergency landing at the airport here, officials said.

title: AN OPEC MEETING SEEMS AT IMPASSE
description: An emergency ministerial meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries was virtually in a shambles today, amid bitter recriminations that Saudi Arabia was seeking to depress oil prices to cripple Iran's war effort against Iraq, a Saudi ally.

title: MUCH OCEAN POLLUTION GETS ITS START ON SHORE
description: POLLUTION has struck early and hard at New Jersey's beaches this summer, forcing the closing of 15 different stretches of the state's 127 miles of oceanfront for several days at a time since early June. The closings have taken place from Keansburg, in Monmouth County, to points as far south as North Wildwood, in Cape May County, and the state's $11.4 billion tourist industry is worried.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: SHALLOWS. By Tim Winton. (Atheneum, $14.95.) Australia is so far beyond the exclusive claims of either the Old World or the New that it may be impossible to live there as anything but a stranger. In this fine second novel by Tim Winton, the 1984 winner of Australia's Miles Franklin Award, a young woman named Queenie Coupar, fifth-generation inhabitant of an Australian whaling town called Angelus, abandons her job as a local tour guide and joins a group of foreign environmentalists who have come to shut down the town's commerce. Thus, for reasons buried and unnamed, she alienates herself from even the common strangeness of her own people. Her grandfather, Daniel, who raised Queenie as his own daughter, broods on the distant lies surrounding his wife's death and nurtures the bitterness of a youthful rebellion that came to naught. Queenie's husband, Cleve, is generally despised as dim and ineffectual. During his night watch on the town pier he reads a journal written a century and a half earlier by Daniel's ancestor - a whaler and maritime deserter who speaks to Cleve's evolving comprehension of the things which make men guilty and survive. Mr. Winton is not always in control of the material. His metaphors are relentlessly literary, from the symbolism of the whales to the sexual sterility of ruthless and decadent tycoons; and the narrative sometimes lingers over pastoral moments while cascading across crucial ones -such as Cleve's search for the journal's missing years - in fewer than two pages.

title: Metering Water
description: To the Editor:

title: INDIANS BEAT YANKEES IN 10TH, 6-5
description: With their manager ejected for protesting a strike call, the Yankees continued to struggle today on a road trip in which they have won only once in six games. They lost, 6-5, on a run-scoring single by Cory Snyder off Dave Righetti with one out in the 10th inning after rallying to tie in the ninth.

title: WHY SOME OLD SHOWS NEVER FADE
description: Why do some television series linger on in syndication year after year, resisting a final interment? There is no single reason. Some of the old series were huge hits when first shown in prime time; others barely made it. Some were wonderfully well produced; others were downright tacky. There is not much to connect ''Star Trek,'' say, with ''Gilligan's Island,'' or ''The Honeymooners'' with ''Lost in Space.'' At some level, however, they have all become imbedded in the popular culture, even if scarcely an adult can be found who will ever admit to watching anything as vacuous as ''Gilligan's Island.'' Old series that endure and become much loved have no common denominator save one: They all wear remarkably well.

title: New Clues to The Titanic's Fate
description: A long-held belief about the sinking of the unsinkable Titanic - a theory that survived decades of official investigations and historical scrutiny - was laid to rest last week. A research team that explored the wreck of the luxury liner last month said it saw no signs of the 300-foot gash that was supposed to have been made in the starboard side when the Titanic struck an iceberg in the north Atlantic on April 14, 1912.

title: CHURCH IN BANKRUPTCY BID, CITING SUIT
description: The Bible Speaks, a fundamentalist Christian church, has filed for protection under Federal bankruptcy law because of a lawsuit by an heiress seeking the return of nearly $7 million she donated to the church.

title: Susan Kempton Is Married To James S. Mulholland 3d
description: Susan Kempton and James Sylvester Mulholland 3d, 1984 graduates of Bates College, were married yesterday at the Episcopal Chapel of the Transfiguration in Bretton Woods, N.H. The Rev. Perry A. Kingman performed the ceremony.

title: Making Headway On Health Costs
description: In 1984, Margaret M. Heckler, then Secretary of Health and Human Services, said the Reagan Administration had ''broken the back of the health care inflation monster.'' Federal officials did not go quite that far last week when they reported the 1985 figures on spending for health care, but they did let it be known that they think the problem is no longer out of control.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: THE last children's party I attended I was the guest of honor or something like that because I was about 7 or 8 and it was my birthday. I horrified my parents. I had invited Tony, a poor boy who went to school with me, and when he arrived at the door I greeted him with ''Where's my present?'' Tony gulped and said, ''I didn't bring one.''

title: Recent Sales
description: Kendall Park $135,000 10 Emerald Road *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 24-year-old colonial; *2*new roof, doors, windows; taxes $2,124. Point Pleasant $97,900 1518 Northstream Parkway *2*3-bedroom, 1-bath, 28-year-old Cape Cod; hardwood floors, *2*pool, fenced-in yard, corner lot, 2-car garage; taxes $1,123. South Plainfield $139,900 121 West Golf Avenue *2*6-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 60-year-old two-family; rec room, wine cellar, *2*2-car garage, separate utilities, slate roof; taxes $1,902. OTHER AREAS Levittown, L.I. $123,000 47 Glade Lane *2*3-bedroom, 1-bath, 38-year-old Cape Cod; dining room, *2*den, eat-in kitchen, aluminum siding; taxes $2,000. title: USHER
description: For 11 weeks, Pete Rozelle and Harry Usher sat in a Federal courtroom, listening to testimony and waiting for five women and one man to decide whether Rozelle's National Football League had violated antitrust common laws at the expense of Usher's United States Football League.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: ONASSIS: Aristotle and Christina. By L. J. Davis. (St. Martin's, $16.95.) L. J. Davis, a contributing editor to Harper's and Manhattan Inc., begins this book with the death of Aristotle Onassis and tells a tale of personalities, intrigue and tragedy.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A music listing today in The Guide (section 2A) for Steve Lawrence and Eydie Gorme at the Garden State Arts Center gives their performance dates incorrectly.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: August 3, 1986
description: Fiction

title: SOUTH AFRICANS FIGHT PRESS LAWS
description: A group of prominent writers and publishers in South Africa has formed an Anti-Censorship Action Group in an effort to overcome laws restricting the freedom of expression and information under the state of emergency.

title: ''BEST LITTLE WHOREHOUSE'' IN DARIEN
description: THE Angelettes, the Aggies, the Dogettes, and the Waco Wackos are in tiptop shape at the Darien Dinner Theater, folks. So are the other habitues, hangers-on, troublemakers and troubleshooters at Miss Mona's Chicken Ranch, or as it is more widely known, ''The Best Little Whorehouse in Texas.''

title: MARCHES IN MOSCOW, MOCK MURDER ON A CANAL
description: Watching Moscow's Big Parade

title: SO YOU WANT TO ENDOW YOUR UNIVERSITY
description: Suppose a prosperous couple wakes up tomorrow itching to make a large donation to the college or university of their choice. (Hey, it happens.) Let's call these hypothetical people John Q. and Jane Majorgift and assume that, while they doubtless have noble motives for giving that have nothing to do with taxes, deep down they also wouldn't mind having their names immortalized by attaching them to a building, a room, an endowed faculty chair, a student scholarship, a study carrel, a library fund or a campus tree. But before the Majorgifts randomly dispatch their check, or put themselves in the friendly but firm hands of a university's fund-raising staff, there are a few things they should consider.

title: MCI STRUGGLES TO WARD OFF DEREGULATION'S STING
description: MCI COMMUNICATIONS has grown up.

title:
WINE;
EXPLORING ALSATIAN WINES
description: IN line with restaurants and retail outlets nationwide, area establishments often find difficulty in selling Alsatian Gewurztraminers. While most producers of this flavorful French white turn out good quality products for the price charged, labels frequently list intimidating tongue-twisting names. Also, the flavor and bouquet of the wine defy adequate description and it is put up in tall, tapering bottles -more characteristic of German wines - giving consumers the impression that the contents are sweet, when in actuality most of these wines are dry.

title: LOOKING ABROAD TO FILL OUR BELLIES
description: EVERY morning, 18-wheelers, gears grinding, back into the loading dock at the Giant Food supermarket on Rockville Pike just north of the capital. Aluminum doors clatter open, clerks scurry inside, and a dazzling array of food begins to move from the trailers to the shelves.

title: MILESTONE FOR CONSERVATIVE JUDAISM
description: With a prayer shawl draped around her shoulders, Rabbi Leslie Alexander rose to read the Torah today to worshippers at sabbath services at Congregation Adat Ari El, a scant day after becoming the first woman to serve as a rabbi at a major Conservative Jewish congregation.

title: Divining the Dow
description: Is the stock market's sharp decline nearing a bottom? A check with three technicians yielded a bounty of answers - but no consensus. John A. Mendelson, the Dean Witter Reynolds analyst who turned bearish just before stocks began their slide, does not think the slump is over.

title: Ayn Rand's Philosophy
description: To the Editor:

title: Karen Kjorlien Becomes a Bride
description: At St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Wianno, Mass., yesterday Karen Ann Kjorlien, a banking officer at Chemical Bank in New York, was married to James Gary Phillips, a partner in the Phillips Janson Group, a New York architectural firm. The Rev. Robert Brock performed the ceremony.

title:
GARDENING;
LOSS OF AMERICAN ELM IS STILL FELT
description: WHAT we wouldn't give these hot summer days for the shade of an old, spreading American elm. There are not many left, however.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: SINISTER FORCES. By Patrick Anderson. (Doubleday, $16.95.) If your nightmares are haunted by hawkish conspirators, if the Watergate hearings were your idea of summer entertainment, or if you're still wondering who really killed John F. Kennedy, then Patrick Anderson's latest thriller will prove good company.

title: ON BORDER PATROL: ARRESTS AND FUTILITY
description: It is the dead zone between midnight and dawn, and John Tiltti smokes an unfiltered cigarette as he cruises the moonlit levee of the Rio Grande. A United States Border Patrol agent for 17 years, he shows neither sympathy nor interest in the aliens whom he hunts and who are arrested by the hundreds here each day.

title: A TRIUMPH FOR A GREEK POLITICIAN
description: The languid leader of Britain's famed Bloomsbury Group, Lytton Strachey, is quoted as saying that politics is no more than ''a fairly adequate substitute for bridge.'' Whether this barb was aimed at the bridge-players as well as the politicians is not clear.

title: Bucks Sign Skiles
description: His legal problems behind him, Scott Skiles, the former Michigan State basketball star, has signed a three-year contract with the Milwaukee Bucks and the Bucks say they are delighted to get him. ''Scott is a terrific player and he'll do whatever it takes for the team to succeed,'' said the Bucks' coach, Don Nelson, who said he expected the scrappy, hard-driving Skiles to be a key motivator.

title: RENEWAL OF UNION SQ. PARK IS HAILED
description: The flowers are blooming in Union Square Park.

title: STUDENT DEBT RESHAPING COLLEGES AND CAREERS
