description: Ann VanCott and Mike Usman met and fell in love last year when they were first-year students at the New York Medical College in Valhalla, N.Y., and when it came time to get married, the ''something borrowed'' part was easy. The two aspiring physicians started off married life with what has come to be known as a ''negative dowry'' of $66,000 in college and graduate-school loans. That total will climb to $234,000 by the time they graduate from medical school and reach $334,000 in 1992, when they complete their residencies and must begin paying off their debts.

title: TOO-DENSE SHRUBBERY CAN BE A LIABILITY
description: One night, a few years ago, a friend in town called to say that his house had been robbed while he and his wife were out to dinner. Would I come right over? The burglars got in through a rear, second-floor window 15 up a sheer wall. ''How in the world could they have got up there?'' a detective on the scene was asked. There were no intervening roofs, porch posts or any other parts of the house that could have aided ascent.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE FALL OF THE ROMAN UMPIRE. By Ron Luciano and David Fisher. (Bantam Books, $15.95.) Ron Luciano was one of those umpires who appears to feel that a multidecibel voice yelling ''yer-r-r-r-r out!'' or ''stri-i-i-i-ke!'' decides baseball games.

title: Terri Minsky Is to Marry David Blum in September
description: Terri Minsky, an entertainment editor at The Daily News, and David Blum, a contributing editor for New York magazine, plan to be married Sept. 14, the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Howard Minsky of Pittsburgh, have announced. Mr. Blum is a son of Albert Blum of Las Cruces, N.M., and Roslyn Blum of Portland, Ore.

title: MANAGERIAL FUNCTIONS OF RETURNEES CITED
description: Joanne Bonwick's review of the effects of chickens (children) returning ''home to roost,'' thereby disrupting orderliness in their parents' homes, uncovered much that is familiar.

title: Mies's Legacy
description: To the Editor: In reference to Paula Deitz's excellent and comprehensive article ''A Two-Day Tour of Mies's Legacy'' (Travel, June 8), it would appear heretical to offer criticism of the late architect's work. However, further judgment should be made on, at least, one of his buildings. I refer to S. R. Crown Hall on the Illinois Institute of Technology campus. As a structure and design concept it serves as a splendid monument to Mies van der Rohe. However, as a building for architecture and design students it fails as a work and study space.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
GOOD SHOW, WHAT?
description: Last Sunday some vendors at Memorial Stadium in Mount Vernon were selling copies of American Cricket magazine and videotapes on the art of batting. Others sold the usual hot dogs and sodas. Around noon, 11 Indian players walked onto the field dressed in blue T-shirts, white trousers and canvas shoes. They were loudly cheered by more than 5,000 spectators.

title: AMERICANS ACCUSE GUATELMALA REBELS
description: The family of an American journalist who disappeared in Guatemala last year has concluded that he and a companion were captured and killed by guerrillas.

title: Justice on Trial In Philippines
description: Corazon C. Aquino has long accused Ferdinand E. Marcos of playing a role in the 1983 assassination of her husband, Benigno, as he was escorted by security men from a plane at Manila airport in the Philippines. Last week, Mrs. Aquino - who became President with the help of army units after Mr. Marcos claimed victory in a highly disputed election - had new ammunition.

title: ADULT EDUCATION GOES TO MARKET
description: It's summer in the city, and so the New School for Social Research is offering such courses as ''Summer Salads and Soups'' (taboulleh, peach amaretto), ''Summer Music'' (Western Wind at the Frick, Mostly Mozart at Lincoln Center) and a ''Summer Soundtrack'' of new films (with guest appearances by Hollywood actors, directors and screenwriters). For those fancying a heavier diet, there are more traditional academic courses in literature (''The New Narcissism,'' ''The Greek Myths and Their Influence'') and politics (''The American Presidency Today''). If there seems to be a course for every palate at the New School, that's the general idea. ''Summer at The New School,'' proclaimed a brochure sent to thousands of New Yorkers last spring. ''It's whatever you want it to be.''

title:
DINING OUT;
NEW SEAFOOD SPOT IN YONKERS
description: MAJOR renovation has spruced up considerably the quarters last occupied by A Family Affair. Although we wish the cooking were better, The Seafood Peddler has, nevertheless, much in its favor. Attractive illumination, high ceilings, bright green padded booths, a few thickly cushioned peacock chairs and blond laminated woods give a luxurious edge to what is basically an unpretentious dining spot, one that seeks to please a large segment of the general public.

title: East Germany Calls Story of Escape a Lie
description: East Germany today denounced as a lie an account by Heinz Braun, who said he escaped to West Berlin by driving through a Berlin wall checkpoint with three mannequins dressed as Soviet officers.

title: MAKING OURSELVES COMFORTABLE
description: HOME: A Short History of an Idea. By Witold Rybczynski. Illustrated. 256 pp. New York: Viking. $16.95. IT suited someone to title this book, ''Home: A Short History of an Idea,'' but it is about comfort and the source and spread of domesticity as much as it is about ''home,'' a word which stands for a loosely bagged collection of concepts more complex and distantly historical than this book is prepared to deal with. Nor is it about an idea, really, because there is no treatment of what people have thought about private housing, or the homeland, or alienation or nationality or personal identity. It is devoted to social practices, not social theories. There is little analytic penetration of its principal notions, either, although a term like ''comfort'' badly needs it. Rather the book treats of cultural values like privacy as they became current, or conditions such as cleanliness as they began to be striven for, of feelings toward what is called the cozy or the snug, of relations of intimacy as they were increasingly sought, as well as of the significance of materials, building types, and furnishings in the service of what would become ''home, sweet home'' - including its female rulers, the habits they encourage, the objects they enshrine in their domain.

title: 3 Days of Rain Flood 125 Pakistani Villages
description: Rivers and streams overflowing their banks after three days of rain have flooded at least 125 villages throughout Pakistan, officials said today.

title: Alaska
description: To the Editor: Apropos a reader's inquiry for ways other than cruises to see Alaska (Q & A, Travel, May 18): It is possible to rent a car and drive around much of this remarkable state.

title: SOME TIPS FOR KEEPING ANIMALS HEALTHY
description: BLUE was feeling much better. He was as frisky as one could expect for a 15-year-old golden retriever that had had surgery only a few weeks before. Blue's problem had been a hairball in his small intestine, a common ailment for dogs and, especially, cats during the summer months when shedding increases and the animal, grooming itself, ingests hair.

title: AN ORANGE JUICE IDEA AFTER AN ICE CREAM EXPERIENCE
description: ''MAYBE that's the reason I came up with this product,'' said Steven Smith of Great Neck, ''because I had been in ice cream.''

title: MASSENET -- MINOR BUT SIGNIFICANT
description: Success breeds success, folklore tells us.

title: NUMBERS AREN'T ALWAYS A TRUE MEASURE OF QUALITY
description: Numbers have a particular persuasiveness, but in interpreting the numerical specifications of sound equipment, a measure of skepticism is sometimes appropriate.

title: STEPS AWAY, AN ENCLAVE
description: ''M y fish fresh, Madame? The freshest in Paris!''

title: SCHOOL EXPANSION DRAWS OPPOSITION
description: A NUMBER of Smithtown residents and at least two town officials are seeking to prevent a state-aided school for emotionally disabled youngsters from expanding.

title: More Ups and Downs for The Economy
description: It probably was not much solace for the nearly 8.2 million Americans who cannot find work, or for Republicans standing for election this fall, but the Government reported last week that unemployment in July had fallen below 7 percent for the third time since Ronald Reagan moved into the Oval Office.

title: GROUP MARCHES ON WITH FIFE AND DRUM
description: WHEN they line up in concert formation, the members of the Ancient Mariners Fife and Drum Corps have a semblance of military order. Fifers form the middle rank, with a color guard and drums to each side. In front stands the drum major, Kevin Brown, holding a six-foot baton topped with a brass eagle.

title: Priest Is Freed
description: The Rev. Lawrence Martin Jenco, who had been taken hostage 18 months ago in Beirut, came home last week. In the weeks after he was released in Lebanon, the 51-year-old priest from Joliet, Ill., met with Pope John Paul II, the Archbishop of Canterbury and President Reagan.

title: Military Presence In a Park
description: THE United States Air Force alarmed some nature lovers and local politicians in Martin County, Fla., by disclosing plans in 1983 to use a 10-acre chunk of a state park as the site of a tracking station for its space launchings.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: HAVING EVERYTHING RIGHT: Essays of Place. By Kim R. Stafford. (A James R. Hepworth Book/ Confluence Press/Kampmann, 9 East 40th Street, New York, N.Y. 10016, $14.95.) When the Kwakiutl Indians found a riverside meadow ''where people gather abundant berries and make good life,'' they named it ''Having Everything Right.'' Kim R. Stafford borrows that name for any encounter of person and place that heals or transforms our lives. These beautiful, sensitive ''essays of place'' celebrate the Oregon country where Mr. Stafford lives and teaches. He blends natural history, Indian myths, pioneer folklore and modern working-class yarns with a pilgrim's spirituality and a poet's intensity. Mr. Stafford, who directs the Oregon Writing Project at Lewis & Clark College, is particularly attracted, as were Thoreau, Whitman and the Beat poets, to eccentrics and outcasts, the people he calls ''local saints.'' We meet, for example, Abe Johnson, the ''bird man of Cline Falls,'' who lives in a shack surrounded by elaborate feeders made of old auto parts and who, like a shaman, coaxes magpies and chickadees to land on his shoulder and pluck food from between his lips. In other essays a place is the central character. In ''A Few Miles Short of Wisdom,'' Mr. Stafford visits the Big Hole National Battlefield in southwestern Montana, where 800 Nez Perce once besieged a troop of United States Cavalry for 36 hours before withdrawing silently in the night. Mr. Stafford finds the spirit of the place on the field, where he discovers small tokens left by generations of Nez Perce who have come by night to honor the dignity of their ancestors.

title:
ART;
EAST END ARTISTS WITH AN IMPACT
description: EVEN though East End galleries frequently highlight that area's talent, the current installation at the Vered Art Gallery stands out because it updates recent New York exhibitions for its four participants: Helen Hoie and Miriam Schapiro of East Hampton, and Elizabeth de Cuevas and Howard Kanovitz of Amagansett.

title: Royals Pound Red Sox
description: George Brett drove in three runs with a double and a single, and Steve Balboni hit a three-run homer during an 11-run seventh inning today as the Kansas City Royals routed the Red Sox, 13-2. The Royals snapped a four-game losing streak.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN CRUISES
description: NO longer content to be the exclusive domain of the rich and elderly, the $6 billion cruise industry is going after younger, less affluent passengers. ''We are trying to defy the old myth that a cruise is only for someone terminally rich and boring,'' says Richard Steck, a spokesman for the Miami-based Royal Caribbean Cruise Lines.

title: OLD UNIONISTS TALK PROUDLY OF FLINT STRIKE
description: A lovely, bittersweet affair it was, the sitdowners' last picnic.

title: Maryland Files Lawsuit Over Savings and Loans
description: The State of Maryland has filed a $450 million lawsuit against 10 former officials of a corporation that once insured 102 Maryland savings and loan associations, blaming the officials for last year's crisis in the industry.

title: Sanctions to Redress the Balance
description: Congress and the Commonwealth now need to vote some sanctions against South Africa to demonstrate that President Reagan and Prime Minister Thatcher have misrepresented Western values and interests in that nation's terrible conflict. It is Pretoria's racism that is immoral, and not, as they contend, the struggle against it. Lacking any political rights, the black majority must either enlist outside pressure or turn to violence - a desperate violence that would inflame and damage civilized societies around the world.

title: Asbestos Checks Lag
description: THE VOLUNTARY asbestos identification program that has been in place in the nation's schools since 1979 is ''not being properly implemented,'' and as a result, millions of students and teachers continue to be exposed to potential health hazards, according to a new study conducted by the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: Art
description: While most summer group shows are somewhat perfunctory, those at the Paula Cooper Gallery (155 Wooster Street) tend to be worthwhile. One reason is that they bring together not only new but often unexpected work by familiar artists. The current changing show, through Aug. 28, includes recent paintings and sculptures by Jennifer Bartlett, Lynda Benglis, Elizabeth Murray and Joel Shapiro, as well as photographs by Peter Campus. There is also a 1969 sculpture by Tony Smith and one from 1974 by Donald Judd.

title: NUCLEAR KOSMOS IS WINNER
description: Nuclear Kosmos edged Royal Prestige by a neck to capture the $1,172,082 Hambletonian in straight heats at the Meadowlands this afternoon.

title: THEATER'S PROBLEMS ARE COMPLEX
description: To the Editor:

title: LATIN AMERICAN STUDIES EMERGE FROM THE ACADEMIC SHADOWS
description: On a wall near the entrance to Columbia University's School of International Affairs, someone has scrawled ''CIA Out of Central and South America.'' At Northwestern University, outside of Chicago, a faculty member was denied tenure after she had disrupted a speaking engagement by anti-Sandinista guerrilla leaders from Nicaragua. Recalling the ferment generated by the war in Vietnam, the heated national debate over United States policy toward countries such as El Salvador and Nicaragua has sparked intense interest and reflection on the nation's campuses.

title: REAL AUTUMNS DON'T WEAR PINK
description: JUST for ''a kick,'' Chris Janus of Derby went to a consultant to find out what colors looked best on her. The result: ''It's almost changed my life,'' she said. ''And, I'm not being overdramatic.''

title: DROUGHT THREATENS THE SOUTH'S ECOLOGY
description: DURING most summers, the surface of Lake Sidney Lanier covers more than 61 square miles of north Georgia, a huge reservoir created in the 1950's when the Army Corps of Engineers dammed the Chattahoochee River above Atlanta.

title: G.O.P. GEARING UP FOR A RARE PRIMARY
description: CONNECTICUT Republicans, who last elected a governor in 1970, have embarked on an unusual course for 1986 -a preliminary bout among three gubernatorial candidates to get the winner in shape for the title match Nov. 4 against William A. O'Neill.

title: AGING DANCERS
description: To the Editor:

title: NASA BREAKS SOME MORE BAD NEWS
description: IF AMERICANS found any hint of solace in the Challenger disaster six months ago, it lay in the space agency's assurances that the astronauts were likely killed instantly: no one, it seemed, could have survived the fireball that seared across the sky.

title: What Happens in 'The Landing'
description: To the Editor:

title: Harlem's 116th Street Struggling Back
description: FROM Morningside Park to the Harlem River, 116th Street in Harlem is showing signs of improvement, shaking off the lethargy of a sinking throughfare in the west and building upon the already bustling economic life of the east.

title: BUILDING PROJECTS
description: If 17-year-old Sam Jones ever gets around to writing a ''What I Did Last Summer'' essay, his camping report will sound rather unusual. Sam is spending his summer helping to build a 12,000-square-foot log residence, and although he used to fear the sound of power tools, he now loves using them.

title: Bringing Balance To Hall of Fame
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE GREENING OF THURMOND LEANER. By Michael Zagst. (Donald I. Fine, $17.95.) Thurmond Leaner, the petulant hero of Michael Zagst's first novel, is determined to make a living on the professional golf circuit.

title: POLL IN SOUTH AFRICA SHOWS A RISE IN WHITES' DISTASTE FOR APARTHEID
description: South African whites are increasingly unhappy with the apartheid system and a majority now want the nationalist leader Nelson Mandela freed from prison, according to a new public opinion poll.

title: CALIFORNIA'S BACK-TO-BASICS REFORMER
description: Bill Honig bounded into his office, as he usually does, with the nervous energy of a jittery shore bird. On this morning in early June, though, Mr. Honig, who is California's Superintendent of Public Instruction, had more reason than usual to relax. Voters had just returned him to office with 78 percent of the vote, probably the largest margin of victory ever recorded in a contested state election.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a passage in the Stage View column on page 3 of the Arts and Leisure section today is misworded. The final sentence in the next-to-last column should read, ''When the artist in the theater is selective, his choice can make the banal wonderful, the filthy fascinating, the extraordinary real.''

title: HISTORICAL GROUPS FIGHT OVER WAR OFFICE
description: THE War Office, on the west side of the town green in Lebanon, was where strategists for such Revolutionary War leaders as George Washington, Israel Putnam and William Williams met to discuss battle tactics.

title: Speaking Out for the Silent Service
description: As befits advocates of the ''Silent Service,'' the Naval Submarine League keeps a low profile. Its telephone number is unlisted, and its headquarters is in the basement of a suburban house in northern Virginia away from the prying eyes of this city.

title:
Market Place;
Trust's Focus: Small Stocks
description: CHARLES ALLMON, publisher of Growth Stock Outlook, an investment advisory service in Chevy Chase, Md., wears another hat, too. He is president and chairman of the Growth Stock Outlook Trust, a closed-end investment company that made its debut as a new issue in March and now trades on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: BEHIND THE OPEC DEADLOCK
description: The Organizaton of Petroleum Exporting Countries is bogged down in what some analysts believe is one of the most serious crises in the group's 26-year history.

title: Washington Watch; Wirth Financial System Report
description: For years, the future of the nation's financial system has been on the mind of Timothy E. Wirth, Democrat from Colorado and chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Subcommittee on Telecommunications, Consumer Protection and Finance.

title: Germans Get 3 Suspects In an Ice Cream Parlor
description: Three of the nine suspected Red Army Faction members sought in a hunt for the killers of a nuclear physicist have been arrested by the police, who took them by surprise in an ice cream parlor in Russelsheim, about 15 miles southwest of Frankfurt, officials said today.

title: Southern Exposure
description: The football Giants, who have been in training camp in Pleasantville, N.Y., since July 16, will get a change of scenery this week. They will open their preseason schedule against the Falcons Wednesday night in Atlanta, then spend the next four days training with and against the Falcons at the Falcon complex in Suwanee, Ga., outside Atlanta.

title: EAST SIDE MAN FATALLY STABBED
description: A 23-year-old man was fatally stabbed in the chest yesterday morning after he kicked in the door of a former girlfriend's East Side apartment in an effort to win her back, the police said.

title: YANKEE MAVERICK SETS THE PACE
description: IT was late morning in Cleveland, and nearly all the Yankees were on the field going through baseball's rituals: shagging flies, aiming for the fences, strolling in the outfield, getting into a baseball state of mind.

title: MCCOVEY INDUCTED INTO HALL OF FAME
description: An annual ritual of an abiding summertime faith was re-enacted here today as official baseball immortality was conferred on three legends of the game: Willie McCovey, the free-swinging San Francisco slugger who tamed the winds at Candlestick Park in the 1960's and 1970's; Bobby Doerr, the sure-handed, clutch-hitting second baseman who sparked the Boston Red Sox through the 1940's, and Ernie Lombardi, the lumbering, strong-armed catcher whose powerful line drives for the Cincinnati Reds and three other teams turned rival infielders into outfielders from 1931 to 1947.

title: Washington Watch; Banking Bill Sparks Revolt
description: PARLIAMENTARY polemics have begun in the House over the fate of banking legislation this year, with the drama involving a revolt by the Republican members of the House Banking Committee against their Democratic chairman, Fernand J. St Germain of Rhode Island.

title: Lincoln Drew the Line on Combating Dissent
description: To the Editor:

title: Nomination Set To Energy Post
description: President Reagan will nominate Martha O. Hesse to be a member of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission and will designate her chairman after confirmation, the White House said Friday.

title: Backlogs in the Courts Found Relatively Low
description: About half of all felony charges filed in the courts of 12 major jurisdictions were resolved within three and a half months, the Justice Department said today.

title: Perverse Logic on Contras
description: The emergence of the human rights argument for attempting to overthrow the Nicaraguan Government -that is, the contention that the United States should get rid of the Sandinistas militarily because they closed La Prensa, exiled a bishop and cracked down on domestic dissidents - can be seen as a perverse tribute to the human rights movement. Never before has the United States asserted that it is undertaking or sponsoring a war to promote human rights.

title: THE ENGLISH ROAR FOR THE REFRIGERATOR
description: The American flag flew over Wembley Stadium here today and the band's repertory ranged from Bruce Springsteen's ''Born in the U.S.A.'' to ''Deep in the Heart of Texas.'' And when William (The Refrigerator) Perry, the Chicago Bears' touchdown-scoring defensive tackle, was sent in for a successful 1-yard plop for a score late in the first half, the roar that emanated from the crowd watching the Bears play the Dallas Cowboys equaled any he receives on the other side of the Atlantic Ocean.

title: Ohio River Lock Work Backs Up Barge Traffic
description: Repair work on a lock on the Ohio River is creating traffic jams that mean delays of almost two days for barges.

title: From Inmate to Intern At Park Ave. Law Firm
description: It is a long way from being an inmate at a state prison on Staten Island to being an intern at a prestigious law firm on Park Avenue.

title: When Wages Fly Higher Than Airlines
description: Do pilots, mechanics and flight attendants need special Government protection against layoffs or wage reductions when airlines merge? There's little economic justification for it. In fact, by making failing airlines less attractive as merger candidates, it might even cost jobs. But the airline unions have enlisted influential House members to press their case, including the chairmen of the Public Works Committee, James Howard, and the Aviation Subcommittee, Norman Mineta. If the issue is left to insiders to settle, Congress may go along.

title: Body of Man, Shot 15 Times, Is Found With Vials of Crack
description: The body of a 24-year-old Brooklyn man with 15 bullet wounds was found by the police on a street in St. Albans, Queens, last night, along with nearly a dozen vials of crack, a highly addictive form of cocaine.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, AUGUST 4, 1986
description: The Economy

title: Over There
description: American skiers seem to have been on the skids since the glory days of the Mahre brothers and Cindy Nelson, but the nation has been zipping right along in a key component of the World Cup competition - persuading the tour's European-oriented officials to schedule races in the United States.

title: No Headline
description: State Supreme Court justice said yesterday that the criminal justice system treats minority defendants like ''aliens,'' and called for psychological training for judges.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Has a Mets' player ever led the league in home runs for a season?

title: France Sets Privatization
description: The first three state-owned groups to be sold under France's ambitious privatization plans will be a bank, a finance house and an industrial group, Finance Minister Edouard Balladur said today.

title: LaRouche Target of Suit By Jersey Bank He Used
description: The political extremist Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. and his organizations have been accused of racketeering and fraud in a Federal suit brought by a New Jersey bank that contends it was bilked of thousands of dollars in unauthorized credit card charges.

title: POLICE FLOOD MIDTOWN FOR CONCERT AT GARDEN
description: New Yorkers often complain, as the saying goes, ''there is never a cop when you need one.'' Not so this weekend in midtown Manhattan.

title: WRONG SIGNALS ON ANTITRUST
description: The Transportation Department's decision last week to allow Northwest Airlines and Republic Airlines to merge will speed concentration in an industry that already has enough of it. President Reagan should reverse the decision. Even the Justice Department, which seldom sees a merger it doesn't like, opposes this one, estimating it will boost air fares by $64 million.

title: Peru Debt Moratorium
description: The Peruvian Government is extending for three months a moratorium on the repayment on the principal of the estimated $4.4 billion it owes to private, foreign banks. The Government has not repaid any principal on its medium- and long-term debt to private foreign banks since March 1983.

title: Advertising; 2 Meredith Magazines Set Combination Deal
description: Better Homes and Gardens and The Ladies' Home Journal, Meredith magazines with a total circulation of 13 million, offer a combination discount to national advertisers.

title: Advertising; At Tuesday Team II, 3 Are Together Again
description: Tom Messner and Barry Vetere, two of the three creative directors at Ally & Gargano, have left to join Walter Carey, once of Leber Katz Partners and their former associate at the Tuesday Team, the agency specially formed to get President Reagan re-elected. They are starting a new agency called Tuesday Team II.

title: Advertising; Mancuso/Duck Forms As Health Care Agency
description: Jo Mancuso, after serving as an account person at three health care agencies, has opened her own at 116 East 27th Street.

title: The Latest Home For Kentucky Fried
description: Richard P. Mayer, chairman and chief executive of Kentucky Fried Chicken, has worked under the parentage of Heublein, RJR Nabisco and soon Pepsico. In that regard, he describes the chicken chain as something like the Hope diamond. ''It has traded hands many times, but each time the value has gone up,'' he said yesterday.

title: Bridge: Rising Young Player Shares A Life Master Pairs Crown
description: If a world-famous player sits down in, say, the Life Master Pair Championship with a partner who is unknown on the national scene, there are two plausible explanations.

title: JETS' TOP DRAFT PICK OUT
description: The hyper-extended left knee suffered by Mike Haight in Saturday's scrimmage against the Washington Redskins at Easton, Pa., is expected to sideline the Jets' No. 1 draft choice for four to seven days. The injury forced the offensive tackle from Iowa to miss practice yesterday at the team's Hofstra University training camp.

title: KITE CAPTURES 4-WAY PLAYOFF
description: Tom Kite, behind by nine shots at one point, sank a four-foot birdie putt on the first extra hole today to win a four-man playoff for the title in the Western Open golf tournament.

title: I Am a New Yorker!
description: To the Editor:

title: A CHILD'S LOT IN UGANDA: AT 14, A COMBAT VETERAN
description: Four-foot-tall Dagala Nasaneili dragged the wooden stock of the heavy AK-47 assault rifle along the ground as he watched the prisoners in white T-shirts and shorts gather scraps of firewood. His teeth worked a strand of dried grass.

title: Deng Jiaxian, China Scientist; Developed Nuclear Weapons
description: Deng Jiaxian, a physicist educated in the United Sates who was instrumental in developing China's atomic and hydrogen bombs, has died of cancer, the official New China News Agency reported Sunday. He was 62 years old.

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary of the classics scholar Sir Moses I. Finley on July 11 misstated his age. He was 74 years old.

title: YANKS TRIUMPH; 4-3 LOSS PUTS EXPOS IN 3D
description: When it was over, Dave Johnson considered that the Montreal Expos had come to town with a winning record over the Mets and were leaving now in a state of collapse, and said:

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: BOURGUIBA, OUSTING PREMIER, STILL IN CHARGE AT 83
description: President Habib Bourguiba, who turned 83 years old on Sunday, has presided unchallenged over Tunisia for three decades, and although he suffers from arteriosclerosis, his power as President for Life is undiminished.

title: CANADA'S DISMAY OVER WHEAT
description: The United States Senate's vote two weeks ago to extend the sale of subsidized wheat exports to the Soviet Union and China, vigorously opposed by Secretary of State George P. Shultz and the Australian Government, has also led to dismay on the table-flat Canadian prairie.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Tobacco Co., Stamford, Conn., an independent subsidiary of American Brands Inc., has promoted Vivian A. Parks Jr. to controller and vice president.

title: Court Studying Bid to Curb NL
description: A Federal District Court in Manhattan has reserved decision on a motion from a group led by Harold Simmons, a Dallas investor, for a preliminary injunction against implementation of the preferred share purchase rights plan of NL Industries.

title: HAMMERMILL REJECTS $52-A-SHARE BUYOUT BID
description: The Hammermill Paper Company said yesterday that its directors had unanimously rejected an unsolicited, $52-a-share cash offer from a group led by Paul A. Bilzerian, a Los Angeles investor.

title: U.S.F.L. HEADS TO MEET
description: Owners of the eight surviving United States Football League teams will meet today to decide if the league will continue after winning $1 in its antitrust suit against the National Football League.

title: Home in Queens Is Damaged By Gunfire and a Pipe Bomb
description: A pipe bomb and about a dozen gun shots shattered the windows of a home in Rosedale, Queens, yesterday morning, causing extensive damage to its interior. No one was injured in the incident, which occurred at about 4 A.M. on a quiet residential street.

title: CLERGY EXPANDS ITS ROLE IN FIGHT AGAINST CRACK
description: Outraged at the pervasive presence of the drug crack on the city's streets, New York churches are holding prayer vigils, offering drug counseling and planning educational programs in a flurry of church activism that, according to one Bronx pastor, has not been matched since the civil-rights era.

title: HARRELSON IS ANGRY
description: Ron Hassey, acquired by the White Sox last week in a six-player trade that sent Ron Kittle to the Yankees, could go on the disabled list with bad knees, and Ken Harrelson, the Chicago club's vice president, is angry about it.

title: About Roy Cohn
description: ''I bring out the worst in my enemies,'' Roy Cohn once told me, ''and that's how I get them to defeat themselves.''

title: FOREIGNERS TAKE SHARE OF INDIA'S SCOOTER MARKET
description: Taking advantage of liberalized import laws, motorcycle and scooter giants from Japan and Italy are joining with Indian companies in a bid to capture this country's vast market in ''two-wheelers.''

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: DEMON BOX. By Ken Kesey. 384 pages. Viking. $18.95. SIGNALS of sanity and strength. First, there's the photo of Ken Kesey on the back of his new book, ''Demon Box,'' a peculiar mixture of essays and short stories, nonfiction and fiction. He's smiling radiantly, he's driving a tractor, he's handsome. Then there's the abundance of energetic creatures who populate this book: bulls and billy goats; runners and wrestlers; the author's 86-year-old grandmother and an Egyptian pyramid guide with an endless supply of hustles.

title: ANNUAL COST OF COLLEGE WILL RISE 6% THIS FALL
description: The cost of a bachelor's degree has climbed to a record of nearly $70,000 at the nation's most expensive college and the average annual bill for any college this fall will rise 6 percent, the College Board has reported.

title: Dollar in Record Low
description: The dollar dropped this morning to 152.95 yen, its lowest level ever against the Japanese currency, dealers here said. It was down sharply from 154.00 yen in New York and 154.10 at the Tokyo close on Friday. The dollar started into a swift slide today in Australia and New Zealand and opened here at 153.20 yen in light trading.

title: OIL INDUSTRY'S BULLS ABANDON OPTIMISM
description: Early this year, when crude oil prices plunged from $27 to $12 a barrel and sent shock waves through the oil industry, George M. Keller, the plain-spoken chairman of the Chevron Corporation, helped lead the industry's bullish countercharge.

title: Great Salt Lake Shrinks Less Than Usual for July
description: The Great Salt Lake, swollen to record levels, dropped only three inches last month as cool weather slowed its evaporation rate.

title: ASTRONOMERS PROPOSING 2 TECHNIQUES TO DETECT PLANETS LIKE EARTH
description: Astronomers have proposed two new techniques in using telescopes in orbit around Earth to determine whether planets similar to this one are orbiting nearby stars and if there is life on them.

title: Otmar Emminger, 75, West German Banker
description: Otmar Emminger, a former head of West Germany's central bank, has died in the Philippines, the bank said today. He was 75 years old. Dr. Emminger, an expert on international currency issues, died Saturday in Manila, where he was working as an adviser to the Philippines Government on behalf of West Germany.

title: REHNQUIST IN ARIZONA: A MILITANT CONSERVATIVE IN 60'S POLITICS
description: In the city where William H. Rehnquist began the legal career that took him to the United States Supreme Court, there is little dispute that he played a major role in resisting Democratic efforts to attract black and Hispanic voters to the polls in the early 1960's.

title: 3 AWARDED PRESTIGIOUS PRIZE FOR BREAKTHROUGHS IN MATH
description: The most prestigious prize in mathematics, the Fields Medal, was awarded today to mathematicians from West Germany, the United States and Britain for breakthroughs in number theory and topology.

title: Converse Head Sees A Change in Ownership
description: ''The last five years have been very enjoyable, running our own operations, being responsible for our own destiny,'' said John P. O'Neil, the 64-year-old president and chief executive officer of Converse Inc., a North Reading, Mass., manufacturer of athletic shoes.

title: RATE SQUEEZE SNARES DEALERS
description: On the trading floor of Dillon, Read & Company is a pot sprouting a vigorous green plant, labeled with a brass plaque: ''The Perfect Hedge.'' It is an amusing reminder that, despite an array of sophisticated market techniques, there is no hedge, or foolproof protection, against a steep decline in the value of a security.

title: CONGRESS; A Dam in the Book of Diplomatic Appointments
description: Jesse Helms has been called the only Senator with his own foreign policy, and periodically over the last five years, he has used the rules and customs of the Senate to delay, and occasionally derail, a series of diplomatic nominations.

title: Catching Up
description: * After hitting a solid .285 with 19 home runs and 77 runs batted in at Tidewater last year, Billy Beane seemed on the verge of beginning a glittering career with the Mets who had selected him in the first round of the free agent draft in 1980. But the right-handed-hitting outfielder was shocked to be traded to the Minnesota Twins on Jan. 16 in the deal that brought Tim Teufel to New York and then he suffered a shoulder injury that limited his playing time in spring training. Except for a game on April 29 in Yankee Stadium in which he slugged a home run and four singles, the 6-foot-4-inch, 195-pound rookie saw little action and was sent to Toledo on June 20 with a .156 batting average in 64 times at bat. He was recalled to the Twins four days ago after hitting .294 with five homers and seven stolen bases in 32 games. ''To be productive I just need a chance to play every day,'' he said from Minneapolis. ''And I don't think the Twins called me back to sit on the bench. I felt frustrated this spring, but I'm fine now and I think I'm on an upswing. I'll admit I expected things to be a lot different for me this season, but I'll have to persevere: I've still got confidence in my ability. So far the highlight of my career was that game at Yankee Stadium against Ron Guidry.

title: Books: Art and Society
description: VELAZQUEZ. By Jonathan Brown. Illustrated. 322 pages. Yale University Press. $45.

title: Gridiron On Thames
description: SUMMER in England. A year ago you could not walk on the sidewalks of Chipping Camden or Bath because of the jetloads of Yanks, but the fear of terrorists has caused the few Americans to speak in whispers, lest their accent give them away on the underground.

title: BRIEFING; All Ears
description: Washingtonians have been telling affectionate Averell Harriman stories since the distinguished diplomat and public servant died 10 days ago at 94 years of age. One of them involves the fact that the former New York Governor had suffered a correctable hearing loss for years and recently got a new hearing aid that used a separate, hand-carried radio to pick up and transmit sound to the ear device.

title: Greyhound Net Rises
description: The Greyhound Corporation on Friday reported earnings of $46.6 million, or 99 cents a share, for the second quarter ended June 30, up 19.8 percent from $38.9 million, or 80 cents a share, for the quarter last year.

title: ECONOMIC CALENDAR
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: Matthew B. Hills Wed To Lisa Debra Berman
description: Lisa Debra Berman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul I. Berman of Edison, N.J., was married yesterday to Matthew Bruce Hills, the son of Mr. and Mrs. David Hills of Toronto. Rabbi Gerald Lee Zelizer performed the ceremony at the Livingston (N.J.) Country Club.

title: ELDER TAKES SENIORS GOLF BY 2
description: Lee Elder, never threatened or challenged, coasted today to win the Commemorative tournament by two strokes. It was his first victory this year on the Senior PGA Tour and his seventh in less than three seasons on the circuit for players who are at least 50 years old.

title: When 2,000 Square Yards Is Just a Small Amount
description: More on carpeting. Lots of it.

title: Advertising; Prevention Magazine's New Focus
description: AFTER about a decade of working in Emmaus, Pa., and living in nearby Allentown, Sanford T. Beldon will not find it easy to tear himself away from the cows and return to the hustle of Manhattan. But there are few big ad agencies or advertisers in the vicinity of Emmaus, so the new publisher of Rodale Press's Prevention magazine will make the sacrifice.

title: PHOTOS SAID TO SHOW NEW ACTIVITY AT MAIN SOVIET NUCLEAR TEST SITE
description: A private concern says satellite photographs show new activity at the Soviet Union's main nuclear test site, indicating that the Russians may be preparing to end their yearlong moratorium on underground testing of nuclear weapons.

title: JUSTICE DEPT. IS SEEN RESPONDING QUICKLY ON REHNQUIST DATA
description: The Justice Department is expected to formally respond by late Monday or early Tuesday to the latest request from senators to see legal opinions written by William H. Rehnquist when he was Assistant Attorney General in the Nixon Administration, governmental officials said today.

title: New Jersey's Bold AIDS Experiment
description: The merest drop of blood drawn up into a needle by an infected drug addict can hold enough AIDS viruses to infect the needle's next user. That's why half of New York's 250,000 intravenous drug addicts, for whom sharing needles is both need and rite, have become carriers of the deadly disease. These addicts can transmit AIDS to anyone with whom they share a needle, perhaps to their sexual partners and, most tragically, to any children they bear. A bold experiment contemplated in New Jersey offers a rare chance to halt the wildfire spread of AIDS among addicts and their contacts.

title: Arms Control Tricks
description: The poker player has four cards face up on the table in front of him: two jacks, two sevens. He draws a fifth, looks at it, puts it face down and says, ''A third jack - that's it, a full house.'' ''May I see it?'' his opponent asks. ''Oh no,'' he says. ''That's against the rules.''

title: 2 of 4 Saved in Avalanche In Washington State
description: An avalanche buried four climbers on Mount Baker today. Rescuers freed two of the victims within two hours, then suspended a search for the others because further avalanches were feared.

title: SIR IAN LEAVES THATCHER'S FRONT LINE
description: When Sir Ian MacGregor, who ran first Britain's state-owned steel corporation and then the Government-held coal business, steps down next month, it will bring to an end six years at the front line of the Thatcher Government's efforts to make British industry more competitive. Indeed, it often seemed to be a battle zone.

title: WILLIAM B. WILLIAMS, RADIO PERSONALITY, DIES
description: William B. Williams, the radio personality of four decades who never wavered in his commitment to the old favorites of popular music, died yesterday at Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan after a long illness. He was 62 years old.

title: TRAVEL IN U.S. IS UP, BUT BELOW HOPES
description: Halfway into what was expected to be a banner season for domestic tourism, there appear to be more Americans traveling in the United States this summer than last, but their numbers are falling short of predictions.

title: AN AUGUST RITE RENEWED: THE FRENCH HIT THE ROAD
description: The photographs from old magazines show the weekend, 50 years ago, starting with a kind of victorious pandemonium.

title: 2 FILMS FROM BRITAIN ON CHANNEL 13
description: ''FOUR ON THIRTEEN,''

title: LONGEVITY MARKS A 'FARM IN THE CITY'
description: Wedged between the Southern State Parkway and the Long Island Rail Road tracks, a mere five miles from the city line, George A. Grossmann and his wife, sister and children farm seven acres of sandy soil that have been the family business and passion since 1895.

title: People Who Die Because a Gun Is Available
description: To the Editor:

title: JOYNER LEAVES MARK ON FANS
description: For nearly two years, Jackie Joyner has been on a mission to make the heptathlon a respected and widely accepted event in the United States. She has traveled coast-to-coast and around the world, never missing an opportunity to promote her event.

title: BRIEFING; A Small Point
description: In Representative Fernand J. St Germain's 25 years in the House, many colleagues of the Rhode Island Democrat have learned one of his distinctions: he does not use a period after the first two letters of his last name, thereby implicitly avoiding any claims on sainthood. This year, the National Republican Congressional Committee has been running television spots against Mr. St Germain in Rhode Island, prompting the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee to call for an investigation of whether these amount to a campaign contribution to the Congressman's Republican opponent, John A. Holmes Jr.

title: NICARAGUAN LEADER ENDS HIS U.S. TRIP WITH CHICAGO VISIT
description: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua returned to Managua today, ending a weeklong trip to the United States As the last stop of his trip, Mr. Ortega spent Saturday in Chicago as the guest of the Rev. Jesse Jackson, who said he was seeking to create a discussion to help bring about peace.

title: DYKSTRA MAKING MOST OF CHALLENGE
description: LEN DYKSTRA, New York's other center fielder, has neither the renown nor the annual salary of Rickey Henderson. But his impact on the Mets, for whom he plays, is no less great than Henderson's on the Yankees. Just 23 years old and less than a year removed from the minor leagues, Dykstra has risen quickly to prominence and has taken his teammates with him.

title: MIDDLE WESTERN FARMERS CONFRONT A NEW PROBLEM: NO STORAGE SPACE
description: Already beset by heavy debts and low prices, many Middle Western farmers are now facing a grain storage squeeze of historic proportions.

title: A Historic Dedication To the Carpet Business
description: ''Our Novelties for the Fall trade are now on exhibition,'' the advertisement proclaimed in 1886. ''This assortment surpasses that of any previous season. An early inspection invited. W. & J. Sloane, Broadway, 18th & 19th sts.''

title: VENEZUELA TO SEEK DEBT LAW CHANGE
description: Venezuela's Finance Minister, Manuel Azpurua, has reassured bankers in the United States that his Government will seek to ease the terms of a law passed by Venezuela's legislature last month for debt repayment that the foreign banks have found unacceptable, according to officials at several major banks.

title: D'AMATO, CITING ESCAPES, ASSAILS IMMIGRATION AIDE
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato called yesterday for the resignation of the city's top immigration official after a Saturday night breakout by six immigrants from a Federal detention center in lower Manhattan.

title: Shuffle for Mormon Church
description: The Mormon Church has announced the appointment of Elder Joseph B. Wirthlin to the presidency of the First Quorum of the 70, which assists the Quorum of the 12 and the governing First Presidency of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints. Mr. Wirthlin was also named Friday as executive director of the church's three magazines and head of the curriculum department, posts that were held by Elder Carlos E. Asay, who will replace Mr. Wirthlin as president of the church's European operations.

title: Malaysian Incumbents Retain Wide Margin
description: The coalition Government of Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad retained a commanding majority in the national Parliament in voting that ended Sunday. It easily fended off a challenge from Islamic fundamentalists.

title: Washington Watch; S.E.C. Takeover Concerns
description: Though the Securities and Exchange Commission has been loath to take strong steps to regulate the takeover frenzy, it remains concerned about certain key areas.

title: Floods in China Kill at Least 233
description: Floods have killed 233 people in the southwest China province of Yunnan over the past few days, the China Daily reported today.

title: OLDER FRIENDS: THE REWARDS OF GIVING
description: New research underscoring the importance of friendship in the lives of the elderly has shown that, unlike the young, older people derive more satisfaction from giving to friends than getting. The research has also revealed significant differences between the friendship relationships of elderly men and women, which may reflect lifelong patterns.

title: FISH STORY: THE ONE THAT DIDN'T GET AWAY
description: In Louisiana, there are fish stories, and there are tall tales, and then there is jail. The difference between them can be a fine line.

title: Advertising; Architectural Digest Gets First Ad Agency
description: Architectural Digest, flagship of the Knapp Communications Corporation and regarded as one of the country's grand magazines, has asked Warren Pfaff Inc. to to be its first ad agency.

title: DETROIT WORKERS APPROVE 2d PACT, ENDING STRIKE
description: Striking municipal workers ratified a new contract tonight, and their president said that the strike, which had stopped buses and garbage trucks for 19 days, was over.

title: Advertising; Second Shop Shares Florida Citrus Work
description: DFS/Dorland Worldwide, New York, which started working for the Florida Citrus Department in 1972, is losing $4 million of the approximately $24 million of annual billings to the Fry-Hammond-Barr agency of Orlando, Fla.

title: Digging Out of the Trade Deficit
description: America's foreign trade deficit roars on at a record clip. Domestic growth has slowed and pressure mounts for unilateral protection against imports. The Reagan Administration, floundering in a mess of its own making, pleads for patience at home while it tries to force other governments to sell less to us and buy more from us. Getting into this jam was easy. Getting out won't be.

title: ARSON IS SUSPECTED
description: A man, a woman and a child were killed and 16 families were routed and left homeless before dawn yesterday when a fire apparently set by an arsonist roared through the upper floors of a four-story apartment building in Mount Vernon, N.Y.

title: OPERA: 'OBERON,' AT TANGLEWOOD
description: Every composer's stock rises during a centennial, bicentennial or tricentennial year. 1986 marks the 100th anniversary of the death of Franz Liszt, a fact that has been duly noted in several New York concerts this year, with more promised for the fall. It is also the 200th anniversary of the birth of Carl Maria von Weber and, on Saturday night, the Boston Symphony Orchestra, under the direction of Seiji Ozawa, presented a semistaged production of the composer's last opera, ''Oberon,'' at Tanglewood.

title: Letter: On Star Wars; To Protect Missiles, and People, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: YANKS TRIUMPH; GET 10 RUNS IN 5TH INNING
description: There was Lou Piniella, his hands reaching over the edge of the dugout roof, his back turned to the field. It seemed inevitable that there would come a point this week when he would not be able to watch his team anymore.

title: Thai Premier Reported To Accept Offer
description: Prime Minister Prem Tinsulanonda has accepted an offer from four parties to stay in office for a third term, The Nation newspaper reported today.

title: COUNTRY MUSIC WOOS NEW LISTENERS
description: A generation ago, as the new music of the Beatles took the outside world by storm, a small boy in Philadelphia, Miss., spent long dusky evenings in a little club called the Busy Bee Cafe, thrilling to the bittersweet soul and whimsy of black rhythm and blues. He was the only white person there. On other evenings, sometimes, his grandfather would bring out his fiddle, and the bow would dance across the strings as night settled on the house.

title: BOGGS HELPS RED SOX DEFEAT ROYALS, 5-3
description: Wade Boggs broke a tie with a two-run single in the seventh inning and Jim Rice drove in two runs with a homer and sacrifice fly today, leading the Boston Red Sox to a 5-3 victory over the Kansas City Royals.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Aug. 4, 1986: *2*MONDAY Airborne Freight Jefferson-Pilot Corp General Motors Lockheed Corp *2*TUESDAY Adams-Millis Corp Koger Properties CBI Industries Inc MCorp Central Ill Pub Serv Mickelberry Corp Electrospace Systs Monarch Machine Tool Emerson Electric Co Motorola Inc General Housewares Overnite Transp Goodyear Pioneer Corp Hershey Foods Revco D S Inc IE Industries Timken Co Kansas City Pwr & Lt *2*WEDNESDAY Carter Hawley Hale Murphy Oil Eagle-Picher Indus Peoples Energy Great North Nekoosa Reichhold Chemicals Ingersoll-Rand Thomas & Betts Corp Leggett & Platt Utilicorp United Inc *2*THURSDAY Avon Products GTE Corp Bemis Co Inc Gulf State Utilities Chemed Corp MDU Resources Group Contel Corp Munford Inc Dart & Kraft Inc Supermarkets Genl Dover Corp Universal Leaf Tobacco *2*FRIDAY Deluxe Check Printers Lear-Siegler Eastman-Kodak Co

title: BRITAIN CAUTIONS ON ECONOMIC WAR AMONG AFRICANS
description: Britain warned a conference of Commonwealth leaders at its opening session today of the danger of ''economic warfare'' in southern Africa.

title: SOVIET WILL ALLOW SHCHARANSKY KIN TO LEAVE COUNTRY
description: The mother and brother of Anatoly B. Shcharansky, the Soviet human rights activist who was freed in February after nine years in prison and labor camps, have received permission to join him in Israel, the brother said today.

title: New Spark
description: Sparky Anderson has impressive credentials: He is the only manager in baseball history to lead teams to 100-victory seasons in each league, playoff sweeps in each league and a World Series championship in each league. His Detroit Tigers have struggled this season and only recently have threatened with a move toward the top of their division, moving from 13 games out at the all-star break to seven games out after yesterday's loss to Chicago. Nevertheless, Anderson says this has been his best year of managing in his 17-year career.

title: Acquittal by Jury And Punishment
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFING; Strength in Numbers
description: The national trend toward corporate consolidation seems to be affecting one of Washington's most active businesses, public relations. Ernest Wittenberg Associates, a 25-year-old concern whose founder worked in the Kennedy White House, is expected to announce today a merger with the E. Bruce Harrison Company, which was established in the capital in 1973.

title: Callie Hancock Wed to Robert Cerutti
description: The marriage of Caroline Louise Hancock, an architect at CUH2A Architects in Princeton, N.J., to Robert Dennis Cerutti, a project manager of the Hillier Group, architects and planners in Princeton, took place yesterday at the Prospect House in Princeton. Mayor Barbara B. Sigmund of Princeton performed the ceremony.

title: Forests Burn in France
description: Firefighters and special aircraft battled seven new forest fires today in three regions in the south of France, the civil defense authorities said. The fires were in the Ardeche area north of Montpellier, near Calmette in the Gard area slightly to the south and in the Pyrenees near the Spanish border.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, the picture used with a report on the Hambletonian harness race in some copies yesterday showed a horse from a different race.

title: UNIONS IN NEW YORK REGION SEE A WHITE-COLLAR FUTURE
description: Organized labor in the New York metropolitan area, hurt by sharp drops in membership caused by the decline of manufacturing industries, is looking to workers like Kay Krane for its future.

title: 12-Year-Old Jersey Boy Killed In Van Crash in Pennsylvania
description: A speeding van carrying 15 campers crashed into a tree and overturned, killing a youngster and injuring 14 others, two of them critically, according to authorities.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL YANKEES VS. MILWAUKEE BREWERS, at Yankee Stadium, 7:30 P.M. (Television - SportsChannel, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770, 7:30 P.M.) METS VS.

title: CARL LEWIS DROPS OUT OF JUMP
description: Carl Lewis, who had been favored to win the long jump competition in the United States Olympic Festival, pulled out of the event at the last moment tonight, then hinted that his injured left knee may keep him from competing for the rest of the year.

title: ILLEGAL MILITARY LOBBYING ON CHEMICAL ARMS SEEN
description: Two Congressional opponents of building new chemical weapons asserted yesterday that the Pentagon illegally hired lobbyists and public relations consultants to urge the improvement of the country's chemical arsenal.

title: Czech Wins Final In Upset of Tulasne
description: Karel Novacek of Czechoslovakia capped an improbable week today by shocking Thierry Tulasne of France in straight sets to capture the $220,000 D.C. Tennis Classic.

title: BECOMING AN 'INSTANT STEPMOTHER'
description: AT the age of 35, Adrian Rothenberg, an industrial film producer, had never had children. When she decided to marry Alan Hirsh, a childhood friend, a year ago she was suddenly thrust into the role of stepmother to his two sons by a former marriage.

title: LEBANON KIDNAPPERS DENY REPORTS OF SECRET MESSAGES
description: A statement published here today that purported to come from the Islamic Holy War organization denied that the group had given a freed American hostage messages to carry to President Reagan, Pope John Paul II and the Archbishop of Canterbury. It also repeated its threat that it would kill the other American hostages it says it is holding unless its demands are met.

title: Eagle Chief Assesses An American Tragedy
description: The first Eagle computer, like the Apple computer, was developed in a garage. Apple, of course, is an American success and Eagle, perhaps, an American tragedy.

title: FRANK KEARNS
description: Frank Kearns, who during 17 years as a foreign correspondent for CBS covered London, Paris, Rome and the Middle East, died of cancer Friday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan.

title: Article 521486 -- No Title
description: The Treasury will begin its three-part quarterly refunding with the auction of $9.5 billion in three-year notes tomorrow. On Wednesday, the Treasury will auction $9.5 billion in 9 3/4-year notes, and it will complete the refunding on Thursday, with the auction of $9 billion in 29 3/4-year bonds. This week's $28 billion refunding is expected to raise $13.62 billion in new cash.

title: DODGERS SWEEP REDS TO WIN SEVENTH IN ROW, 2-1
description: Orel Hershiser and Ken Howell combined on a four-hitter and Bill Madlock singled home the tie-breaking run in the sixth inning today as the Los Angeles Dodgers beat the Cincinnati Reds, 2-1, for their seventh straight victory.

title: Outdoors: No Promises
description: ALTHOUGH it engenders small pleasure, I can report that some of the advice I occasionally offer to other anglers has merit.

title: Erving Has Talks With Jazz Owner
description: Larry Miller, the owner of the Utah Jazz, flew to Philadelphia yesterday and met with Julius Erving and the player's agent, Irwin Weiner.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Washington dispatch on Thursday about United States policy toward Chile misstated a provision of the Chilean Constitution pertaining to a new government in 1989. The Constitution does not explicitly provide for a transition to civilian rule. It specifies that the junta's four military leaders will nominate a single presidential candidate, who may be either a military officer or a civilian.

title: Lilly Jaray Is Married To David M. Ostrove
description: Lilly Jaray, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Steve Jaray of Roslyn Heights, L.I., was married yesterday to David Mark Ostrove, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Ostrove of Roslyn, L.I. Marvin Axelrod, a leader of the Ethical Culture Society, performed the ceremony at the Tavern on the Green in New York.

title: FILIPINO FAMILY TELLS HUNGRY MAJORITY'S STORY
description: Ten-year-old Willy is the educated member of the Arguilles family, with three years of schooling, but his ambition to work in a scrap-metal shop may be beyond his reach.

title: IN WASHINGTON, TAX BILL KEEPS AIDES ON THE RUN
description: Joe Gale was going through his Nautilus routine, weights hoisted high above his head, when a man sidled up to him and said, ''Can we talk about the rehabilitation tax credit?''

title: 'FRESNO,' AN UPSIDE-DOWN 'DALLAS'
description: Two arch-rivals have fallen in love. In a weak moment, Carol Burnett, the raisin queen of Fresno, Calif., has surrendered to the amorous advances of Dabney Coleman, her ruthless competitor for the thriving raisin crop of the San Joaquin Valley. The two are enjoying an intimate breakfast after a night of unexpected passion, when her avaricious son, Charles Grodin, storms in to break up their tryst. ''You're potting soil,'' Mr. Grodin screams at Mr. Coleman. ''You're fertilizer.'' ''I don't think you'd say that if you took the time to get to know me,'' the unruffled Mr. Coleman murmurs in reply.

title: DESPITE A DRIVE BY GORBACHEV, ECONOMY LAGS
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev's main domestic initiative, the revitalization of the Soviet economy, is off to a rocky start, according to Soviet officials and Western diplomats.

title: Timothy Rice Married To Audre J. Melsbakas
description: At St. Peter's-by-the-Sea Episcopal Church in Ogunquit, Me., yesterday Audre Johanna Melsbakas, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ceslovas Melsbakas of Oswego, N.Y., and Ogunquit, was married to Timothy Joel Rice, a son of Nancy M. Rice of Hamburg, N.Y., and the late Richard R. Rice. Bishop William H. Marmion, who is retired from the Episcopal Diocese of Southwestern Virginia, performed the ceremony.

title: M.V.P. Vote For Carter
description: IN the National League East, the only suspense concerns the possibility of a Mets player winning the Most Valuable Player award for the first time. With the Mets 18 1/2 games ahead of the third-place Montreal Expos, their manager, Buck Rodgers, has conceded that the divisional race is over. But the campaign for the m.v.p. award is about to begin.

title: JAPAN BOND ROLE CALLED SIGNIFICANT
description: As the Government bond market prepares to absorb the $28 billion in securities the Treasury will auction this week at its quarterly refunding, the question that continues to dominate trading is how much Japanese investors will buy.

title: IN NEW JERSEY, NO BOOM ALONG THE BOARDWALK
description: On the boardwalk here, a fortune teller in scarf and shawl offered to solve the mysteries of life, love and career for a dollar.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Living Section last Wednesday about farm stands incorrectly identified the father of District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau of Manhattan. He was Henry Morgenthau Jr.

title: BILLIE HOLIDAY DOCUMENTARY ON 13
description: REMEMBERING Billie Holiday in her novel ''Sleepless Nights,'' Elizabeth Hardwick came as close as anyone to capturing the essence of a performer who, after all that has been written about her, remains a profound enigma. ''The heart always drew back from the power of her will and its engagement with disaster,'' Ms. Hardwick wrote. ''Stately, sinister and determined, somehow she had retrieved from darkness the miracle of pure style.''

title: Not-So-Vital Statistics On Rep. Mike Synar
description: Representative Mike Synar, a four-term Democrat from Oklahoma, stepped to the center of the budget wrangling on Capitol Hill with his legal challenge to the budget-balancing law. His suit contesting its constitutionality won in the Supreme Court last month, and the Congress and Administration are now struggling to find another way to impose some discipline on the budget.

title: Advertising; People
description: * Michael F. Hoynes has been promoted to executive vice president and James B. Bernegger and David Roethgen to senior vice presidents at FCB/Leber Katz Partners.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We have many problems, a pile of them in fact. What we need here is a big bulldozer.''

title: Rookie Tries to Fit In
description: Erik Howard is 21 years old, big and strong. Until now, his problems were relatively minor.

title: U.S. Veterans Deserve First-Class Citizenship
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Killed by Lightning On a Maryland Beach
description: Lightning struck and killed three vacationers on the beach today and injured two people, the police said.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, AUGUST 4, 1986
description: International

title: Board President Backs Drug Education Effort
description: A full day of instruction in the fall will be devoted to teaching public school students about the hazards of the drug crack, the president of the Board of Education, Robert F. Wagner Jr., said yesterday.

title: U.S.-Europe Trade Talks Fail
description: The United States and the European Community failed today to resolve a lingering dispute over citrus and pasta products, and the community warned that a major trade war could break out if the impasse continued.

title: BUSH IS HOPEFUL ON MIDEAST PEACE
description: Vice President Bush visited multinational peacekeeping forces serving in the Sinai Desert today and said he believed peace would ''certainly'' come to the Middle East within a decade.

title: Caracas Picks Bank Chief
description: Hernan Anzola Jimenez, formerly Minister for State Companies, was appointed president of the central bank of Venezuela last week.

title: Beginning of the End for the Beacon Theater?
description: To the Editor:

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SUMMER TREATS One of this summer's midday cultural events at various downtown locations is the Monday Music Series at the Vietnam Veterans Plaza. Today Brazuka, a Brazilian group directed by Cliff Korman, will perform its country's music using both traditional Brazilian and modern electronic instruments. The group merges South American rhythms with New York sounds, sort of a samba with a funk twist, according to Tony Whitfield, associate director of the Lower Manhattan Council and organizer of this program.

title: ALASKANS ARE DEEPLY DIVIDED ON FEDERAL ROLE IN LAND USE
description: This hamlet in the heart of the Wrangell Mountains feels as if it were a million miles from nowhere, and its handful of year-round residents like it that way.

title: AT 79TH ST. BASIN, LIFE IS BY THE TIDES
description: Aboard the Prelude, everything sways with the gentle rhythm of a backyard hammock. To Ed Bacon, who calls the 45-foot sailboat home, life afloat is the ultimate exercise in relaxation, a ceaseless, effortless form of yoga. The best way to describe the Prelude, is, in his words, ''a womb with a view.''

title: IF USX SHUTDOWN DRAGS ON
description: A lengthy shutdown of steel operations at the USX Corporation would bolster the earnings of its competitors. But in the long run it would have a profoundly negative impact on the steel industry, analysts say.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in Sports People on Friday about Scott Skiles's plea of no contest to a charge of drunken driving omitted the arrest date. Mr. Skiles, the former Michigan State basketball player, was arrested on Nov. 7.

title: LAC OUIMENT WINS JIM DANDY
description: Lac Ouimet led every step of the way to score an impressive 8 1/2-length victory today in the $115,600 Jim Dandy Stakes at Saratoga in the absence of Ogygian, the heavy favorite, who was scratched when the track came up muddy.

title: IKE AMATEUR RETURNS
description: The Ike Championship, for 30 years one of the leading amateur golf tournaments in the metropolitan area, is being revived this week and installed as an official competition of the Metropolitan Golf Association.

title: New Ocean-Bed Hot Springs Are Discovered in the Pacific
description: A new field of mineral-rich hot springs spouting chemically rich fluids into the sea from the ocean floor has been found in the Pacific Ocean 285 miles west of the Washington-Oregon line, researchers revealed.

title: BRIEFING; The Harvard Birthday
description: When Harvard University celebrated its 300th anniversary in 1936, President Franklin D. Roosevelt, Class of 1904, went back to Cambridge as principal speaker. Now the 350th birthday of the nation's oldest institution of higher education is approaching, and Prince Charles of Britain is coming over, but President Reagan won't be there, having declined an invitation.

title: OIL'S COLLAPSE LEADS TO RISE IN ARSON
description: When Robert Lowery's home in suburban Harris County burned to the ground last December, he told a dramatic story of being robbed at gunpoint by a man who then set the house afire, destroying a neighbor's home in the process.

title: The U.N. Today: Aug. 4, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Special Committee on Decolonization - 10:30 A.M.

title: The Limit in Offshore Oil Drilling
description: To the Editor:

title: Banks Face End of Deductions
description: The nation's big banks stand to pay tens of millions of dollars more in taxes in the next five years if, as appears likely, Congress repeals two of their tax deductions.

title: FINANCE OFFICIAL CRITICIZES CITY PENSION FUND EARNINGS
description: New York City's three largest public-employee pension funds would have earned up to $1 billion more over the last five years by following different investment strategies, Mayor Koch's Finance Commissioner has asserted.

title: MUSIC: HANDEL'S 'THEODORA' AT CARAMOOR FESTIVAL
description: The Caramoor Festival has added ''Theodora,''

title: BACK AT IT AGAIN, PUNCH AND JUDY
description: On weekends in the summer months, a hooknosed puppet bedecked in a red frock coat, yellow stockings and stocking cap can be found delighting a crowd gathered at Covent Garden here.

title: Peggy L. Epstein Becomes a Bride
description: At Congregation Emanu-El of Westchester in Rye, N.Y., yesterday Peggy Louise Epstein, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alan R. Epstein of Rye, was married to David Allen Tanner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Tanner of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbis Daniel Wolk and Jack Stern performed the ceremony.

title: SOUTH AFRICA VISIONS
description: When President P. W. Botha announced his newest rebuff to the West last week, he did so with the air of a man sure of both his destiny and his moral rectitude.

title: NEW RULES DRAWING A DIFFERENT BREED OF TEACHER
description: Robert Hickson, a 30-year-old mathematician with a love of teaching and a doctorate from the London School of Economics, was hired by the Board of Education two years ago to teach at a vocational high school in Brooklyn.

title: New Delegate to U.N. Is Appointed by Soviet
description: Aleksandr M. Belonogov, a Soviet career diplomat, has been appointed chief delegate to the United Nations, the Foreign Ministry said today.

title: ISRAELIS CONTEST U.S. SUBPOENAS IN INQUIRY ON BOMB TECHNOLOGY
description: Israeli officials are contesting subpoenas from Federal grand juries investigating whether Israel illegally tried to export American technology for manufacturing cluster bombs, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: DUCOMMUN INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $86,000 for the quarter and $136,000 for the 6 months.

title: Manila's Plan To Lower Debt
description: President Corazon Aquino has approved a program to lower the nation's $26 billion foreign debt and attract money for business by persuading overseas creditors to convert some loans into investments, her office said today.

title: Money and Sex
description: To the surprise of some, the report of the Attorney General's Commission on Pornography, which contains some salacious examples of the material under study, has not become a best seller.

title: Advertising; Regional Business Periodicals
description: SOME like them because they're considered perky and determined. Others say they're just dull and trivial. But whatever they are, the local business publications around the country appear to be doing well these days in comparison with the big, national business magazines.

title: BankAmerica and Arco Sell Plaza
description: The BankAmerica Corporation and the Atlantic Richfield Company said today that they had signed an agreement to sell their interests in the Arco Plaza in downtown Los Angeles to the Shuwa Investments Corporation.

title: ATLANTIC CITY ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
EXILE, BACK IN RIO, AGITATES FOR CHANGE ON THE LEFT
description: By the time an amnesty permitted Fernando Gabeira and other former guerrillas to return home from exile in 1979, there was already a consensus among Brazilian leftists that the armed struggle had been a mistake.

title: One Year Later in Peru
description: Abruptly, the presidency of Alan Garcia in Peru has turned from promise to peril and he has mainly his own demagogy to blame. The bold young leader who last year proclaimed a limit on debt repayment and promised renewal for a fragmented society is himself falling victim to the economic and social pressures he hoped to reverse.

title: ALLIED RESEARCH ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Q&A
description: Q.

title: CALCULATIONS TO ENGINEER BETTER VALVES
description: IN the annals of engineering, a special place must be reserved for nature's own heart valve, a filmy, pliant, translucent arrangement of three tiny parachute-like cups.

title: JIFFY LUBE INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
'WORLD WALK,' ALBERT SPEER AT SPANDAU
description: LIKE ''Darkness at Noon'' and ''Judgment at Nuremberg,''

title: PITT-DES MOINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HEALTH-MOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Negotiations For Byoir Sale
description: Hill & Knowlton Inc., the nation's second-largest public relations firm, said yesterday that it was negotiating to acquire Carl Byoir & Associates, the third-largest public relations agency, from Foote, Cone & Belding Communications Inc.

title: CERADYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Child Dies on Ship; F.B.I. Charges Mother
description: An 18-month-old girl was found dead today aboard the cruise ship Emerald Seas, the same vessel that was damaged last week by an explosion and fire.

title: MOHAWK DATA SCIENCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After net from the reversal of estimated loss on dispositions of $6,722,000 for the quarter and year. c-After an estimated loss on dispositions of $76,094,000 for the quarter and the year. d-Net loss

title: A South Africa Policy Machiavelli Could Live With; Children Into Criminals
description: To the Editor:

title: LAC MINERALS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Lac Minerals said the Page-Williams mine accounted for 6 cents a share of the latest quarter's net and 12 cents a share of the latest 6 months' net. It also accounted for $31.7 million of the revenue for the quarter and $50.1 million for the 6 months.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, AUGUST 5, 1986
description: International

title: Union Spokesman Sees Delay in Steel Talks
description: A union spokesman said today that a delay was likely in talks to resolve the dispute between the United Steelworkers and the USX Corporation that has idled 22,000 members in nine states.

title: ESI INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from TGC Industries of $199,851 for the quarter and $164,817 for the 6 months. c-Includes income from TGC Industries of $79,064 and $116,603 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. The company said it expects to spin off its Geophysical Services business as TGC Industries Sept. 15 to shareholders of record July 15.

title: SPACE PLAN AND ARMS LIMITS SHAPE BUDGET DEBATE
description: The House and the Senate began debate today on separate bills for the Department of Defense, both of which are major challenges to the Reagan Administration's Pentagon policies.

title: GULF APPLIED TECHNOLOGIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GRADCO SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $95,000. c-Net loss

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: To Stop Violence
description: A homosexual man is beaten from time to time by his live-in lover. Not knowing where to turn for help, he goes to a neighbor.

title: PRESIDENTIAL REALTY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After net gains from sales of properties and investments of $297,000, or 9 cents a share, for the quarter and $453,000, or 14 cents a share, for the 6 months. c-After net gains from sales of properties and investments of $136,000, or 4 cents a share, for the quarter and $144,000, or 4 cents a share, for the 6 months. Revenue represents gross revenue, which excludes revenue from sales of properties and investments.

title: AT LIBRARY, 3 CENTURIES OF PARIS OPERA BALLET
description: The Paris Opera Ballet has recently come and gone but it has left behind an exhibition that is both visually striking and selectively informative about the tradition behind the world's oldest dance company.

title: A South Africa Policy Machiavelli Could Live With; Sanctions in Mississippi
description: To the Editor:

title: FLEW ACROSS ATLANTIC IN 1936
description: The British aviation pioneer Beryl Markham, who in 1936 became the first person to fly solo across the Atlantic from east to west, died Sunday at a Nairobi hospital, her lawyer said today. She was 83 years old.

title: Former Bell Company Reaches Union Pact
description: In the first agreement reached between a former Bell System operating company and the Communications Workers of America since divestiture, the union today announced a pact with Pacific Telesis, parent company of Pacific Bell and Nevada Bell.

title: Financial Network Forms Marketing Unit
description: Financial News Network Inc., which produces and distributes television programming by satellite, has restructured its sales and marketing operations into a new wholly owned subsidiary, Financial News Network Sales Inc., with Scott Hults as its president. Formerly, Mr. Hults was vice president of sales and program development.

title: CLASHES GO ON IN RACE FOR GOVERNOR
description: ''Arrogance,'' ''self-righteousness,'' ''acting like McCarthyites.'' That is how Andrew P. O'Rourke, the Republican gubernatorial candidate, today characterized Governor Cuomo and his fellow Democrats.

title: Reliance Ruling In Blair Fight
description: A Federal appeals court judge in Albany ordered a stay of a lower court's ruling that would have required the Reliance Capital Group to release the shares of John Blair & Company collected in its $360 million tender offer. Judge Roger J. Miner also ordered a freeze on the withdrawal rights on Reliance Capital's offer, pending an appeal hearing scheduled for Aug. 15.

title: Toy Maker In Disney Pact
description: Worlds of Wonder Inc., the maker of electronic toys best known for Teddy Ruxpin, the talking bear, said today that it had signed a multiyear, exclusive licensing agreement with the Walt Disney Company to make, market and distribute toys based on Disney characters.

title: CJI Industries In Financing
