description: CJI Industries, formerly known as Central Jersey Industries, brought to market yesterday about $350 million of preferred stock and debt securities through underwriters led by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.

title: Indianapolis Bond Yields Are Set
description: A $93.9 million financing by the Indianapolis Local Public Improvement Bond Bank was tentatively priced yesterday through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: Tax Reform in the Democratic Party Spirit
description: To the Editor:

title: Steel Forecast Reduced
description: The European Community today lowered its steel forecast for the third quarter amid worsening market conditions. Its steel output estimate was reduced by 700,000 metric tons, to 28.3 million tons, compared with 28.7 million tons produced a year ago. Its steel consumption estimate was reduced by 500,000 tons, to 25 million tons, compared with 23.9 million tons used a year ago.

title: The 'Lion' in Summer
description: Some residents of this Chicago suburb thought they saw a lion today, prompting the police and animal control officers to go on a hunt. But the search was called off when officers determined the ''lion'' was a German shepherd dog with a ''summer haircut.'' The dog's coat was cropped except around the head and neck where it was shaggy and at the tip of its tail where there was a puff of fur, said Police Chief Ronald Hauri.

title: 'The Ike' Tourney Begins
description: The patio of the Tuxedo Club's golf house is decorated with pictures of Dwight D. Eisenhower as a five-star general, President and former President, most with golf clubs in hand. Standing amid the display is a one-foot-high bust of Eisenhower, wearing the Army jacket he made famous.

title: Costly Approach to Saving Medicare Funds
description: To the Editor:

title: LIFELINE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a tax credit of $83,000.

title: AFTER MANVILLE: MIDDLE-AGED AND JOBLESS
description: Since he was laid off on June 20 from the ceiling components shop at the Manville Corporation here, John Felegi has found central New Jersey's job market - one of the nation's strongest - to be unfamiliar terrain.

title: People
description: Rodger Groves has been elected executive vice president at Cunningham & Walsh.

title: TRANSTECH INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net losses and includes net from discontinued operations of $71,152 for the quarter, and includes a loss from discontinued operations of $123,609 for the 6 months.

title: LATE RALLY PUSHES DOW UP BY 6.33
description: A dramatic last-hour rally led by blue-chip oil shares helped the market to overcome earlier technical weakness and close with a modest gain yesterday. The strength of the oil sector reflected reports that OPEC members were drawing closer to an agreement that would lower their present production ceiling.

title: TEXON ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Year to April 30
description: b-Includes a loss on the sale of property of $2.8 million and $47,069 for the latest and previous years, respectively.

title: Caging of Dealers in Drugs Is Proposed by Councilman
description: To the chorus of voices demanding tougher measures to combat drug abuse, a City Councilman, the Rev. Wendell Foster, added his own yesterday. He proposed caging drug sellers and ''putting them on exhibit.''

title: MEI DIVERSIFIED reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: MID-AMERICA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 25
description: b-Net income

title: SEISMIC ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NEW SHOCK THERAPY FOR SNAKEBITES
description: A CHAT in a London laboratory between an American missionary physician who practices in the Amazon and two tropical disease experts has led to a new electric shock therapy that saves the lives of snakebite victims but that defies scientific explanation.

title: NORD RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After tax credits of $200,000 for the quarter and $370,000 for the 6 months.

title: Carbide Case Set for Bhopal
description: The Indian Government's long-delayed suit against the Union Carbide Corporation will be filed this month and tried in Bhopal, site of the disastrous 1984 poison gas leak, high-ranking Indian officials said today. The suit will for the first time specify what the Indian Government considers fair compensation for the world's worst industrial accident.

title: Poor Nations' Inflation Dips
description: Inflation dropped in poor countries last winter but is still much higher than in the United States and other prosperous industrial areas, figures from the International Monetary Fund showed today.

title: Victims Board to Get Harris Book Profits
description: Profits from Jean Harris's recently published book must be turned over to the Crime Victims Board, the chairman said Monday.

title: SETON CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Impala Plans KDI Proxy Fight
description: The Impala Pacific Corporation, which holds a 31.2 percent stake in the KDI Corporation, said that it planned to begin a proxy contest to replace KDI's eight-member board. Impala, the Hong Kong-based subsidiary of Ariadne Australia Ltd., an investment group based in Brisbane, Australia, had previously said that it intended to buy up to 50 percent of KDI shares on the open market.

title: TEXAS TO WEIGH A RISE IN TAXES IN FISCAL CRISIS
description: A fundamental credo of Texas business people is that taxes are bad for business. Now the state's business leadership is doing a most un-Texan thing: calling for higher taxes as the Legislature convenes this week in emergency session to deal with a fiscal crisis.

title: MAYO MOURNS ONE WHO PUT SHRINE ON MAP
description: Unlike many of the far-flung sons of County Mayo, Msgr. James Horan returned to its harsh dark beauty today. He was mourned as a patriarch who blended the gifts of a salesman with a country priest's appreciation of a miraculous apparition.

title: MOHASCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an after-tax restructuring charge of $4.3 million for the quarter and 6 months.

title: Vote on Disability Payments
description: A bill authorizing a 2 percent increase in disability benefits to 2.3 million veterans was passed today by the House and sent to the Senate. The measure has been estimated to cost $156 million for the fiscal year 1987, which begins Oct. 1.

title: AMERIBANC INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax benefits of $640,000 and $961,800 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Offer for NL Is Extended
description: The NL Acquisition Corporation, an investment group controlled by the Dallas investor Harold C. Simmons, said it had extended its $15.125 offer to buy the common stock of NL Industries from noon yesterday until midnight. Mr. Simmons's group said that as of 11 A.M. yesterday, it had received tenders of about 3.9 million of the company's nearly 60 million shares.

title: HIGUERA DEFEATS YANKEES AGAIN
description: One week and three tries after they made a trade to bolster their lineup against left-handed pitchers, the Yankees still can't win games started by opposing left-handed pitchers.

title: UNITED MEDICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an unrealized loss on foreign currency of $1,060,000.

title: Topics; Affirmative Actions: Bad Deeds
description: Racial and religious covenants in deeds for homes owned by William Rehnquist may not disqualify him for Chief Justice, but they point up the need to purge the artifacts of bigotry that still lurk in real estate deeds.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, AUGUST 5, 1986
description: International

title: ASBESTOS, ONCE A LIVING, IS NOW A FATE
description: Once the factory here and its 5,000 workers were the pride of what is now the multinational Manville Corporation. But both the asbestos plant and the asbestos work force grew old, and both were in poor shape. A month ago, as part of a national reorganization, what once would have seemed impossible came to pass: the Manville Corporation ended 74 years of production in Manville, N.J.

title: READING & BATES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a writedown of $8 million taken against the current value of domestic oil and gas properties and a gain of $3.9 million from a restructuring by Scotdril, a 50-percent owned joint venture, of the remaining three years of its drilling contract with Sovereign Oil and Gas. c-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $2,785,000, $2,088,000, and $3,739,000 for the latest 6 months, the year-ago quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: O'Grady's Suspension
description: Mac O'Grady may have to begin serving his six-event suspension from the PGA Tour next week. A Federal court judge in San Diego yesterday refused to grant O'Grady a preliminary injunction that would have prevented the PGA Tour from carrying out its penalty against him.

title: MONTANA POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NEW YORK POLICE NOW SEIZING CARS IN ARRESTS FOR POSSESSION OF CRACK
description: When law-enforcement officials stopped 43 people whose cars were cruising last week in areas of Manhattan where drugs are widely sold, they not only arrested them on charges of possessing crack. They also seized their cars.

title: HELP! ERROR MESSAGE
description: LIFE could be so easy! But when it comes to computers . . .

title: LOMAS MORTGAGE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The year-earlier figures are not available. The company began operations late last year.

title: LINDAL CEDAR HOMES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $62,740 for the quarter and 6 months. c-After an extraordinary gain of $58,313 for the quarter and 6 months.

title: Belgian Debt Accord Set
description: The Belgian Government, trying to tackle a huge public debt problem, has reached an accord with the country's financial institutions that will save it up to $2.3 billion in interest payments over five years, Government officials said today.

title: ROCKAWAY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
New York State Begins $400 Million Refunding
description: A $400 million issue of New York State general obligation refunding bonds was tentatively priced yesterday through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: PROVIDENCE ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
REAGAN SEEKS DRUG TESTS FOR KEY U.S. EMPLOYEES
description: President Reagan today called for mandatory drug tests for Federal workers in sensitive jobs, and said he and his Cabinet might set an example and take the tests themselves.

title: Ferdinand L. Mayer Is Dead; U.S. Diplomat in 20's and 30's
description: Ferdinand L. Mayer, a retired Foreign Service officer, died Sunday at the Weston Haddon Convalescent Center in Bennington, Vt. He was 99 years old.

title: AMEDCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,116,000 and $1,920,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $4,717,000 for the quarter and $4,690,000 for the 6 months.

title: A Letter to Kemp
description: Faye Wattleton, president of Planned Parenthood, was described as ''dumbfounded'' not long ago when she received a ''Dear Faye'' letter from none other than Representative Jack F. Kemp inviting her to join a group of his key advisers, and not incidentally to make a contribution of $1,000. The reason for her dismay, of course, is that Planned Parenthood has publicly proclaimed Mr. Kemp its chief enemy, ''out to destroy our nation's family planning program.''

title: SYRIAN TROOPS START PATROLS IN SHIITE OUTSKIRTS OF BEIRUT
description: Lebanese troops and policemen backed by Syrian soldiers deployed today in the predominantly Shiite Moslem southern suburbs of Beirut as an explosion ripped through a cafe in East Beirut, the Christian sector of the capital, killing two people and wounding 30 others.

title: Moffett Says He Won't Run For Governor as Independent
description: Former United States Representative Toby Moffett said today that he would not run for governor as an independent candidate and urged his followers to support Democratic Gov. William A. O'Neill's re-election.

title: DRANETZ TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Saving the Mets
description: Jesse Orosco, who set a Mets' single-season record with 31 saves in 1984, now seems ready to become the club's career leader.

title: CONCERT: BERNSTEIN IN THE PARK
description: THE classical music world has few popular legends, but Leonard Bernstein is certainly one of them. And although he is a great conductor and fluent composer, it was the educator that the vast Central Park audience cheered last night.

title: GUARDIAN PACKAGING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
EXPOSAIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
WISCONSIN POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
KEITHLEY INSTRUMENTS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HARLEY-DAVIDSON INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
description: b-After a tax credit of $1,698,000 for the quarter and 6 months. c-After a tax credit of $1,551,000 for the quarter and 6 months.

title: JEFFERSON-PILOT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After capital gains of $2,579,000 for the quarter and $3,692,000 for the 6 months. c-After capital gains of $3,302,000 for the quarter and $12,364,000 for the 6 months. The figures were adjusted for 3-for- 2 stock split paid June 17.

title: INNOVEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The share earnings reflect 3-for-2 stock split paid in March.

title: Saudi Budget Delayed
description: The national budget of Saudi Arabia, the world's biggest oil exporter, has been delayed again for another five months because of uncertainties over petroleum prices, the Government announced today.

title: BRONX LANDLORD OWES $104,000 IN BACK TAXES
description: The owner of the Bronx building where a 5-year-old boy fell to his death last week - a building cited for 605 housing-code violations and which is $120,000 in arrears to the city for taxes and repairs - also owes about $104,000 in back taxes and has 352 housing-code violations on five other buildings he owns in the borough, city records show.

title: CONSOLIDATED-TOMOKA LAND CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
WHITE SOX DEFEAT RED SOX ON ERRORS
description: A throwing error by Roger Clemens in the eighth inning set up the game's only run, and Jose DeLeon combined with two relievers on a three-hitter tonight to give the Chicago White Sox a 1-0 victory over the Boston Red Sox.

title: DEFICIT NOW SEEN AS ABOVE CEILING SET BY CONGRESS
description: The Congressional Budget Office now projects that the 1987 budget deficit will be $173 billion, almost $30 billion above its ceiling in the budget-balancing law, according to Congressional sources.

title: MOOG INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
OPEC REACHES TENTATIVE ACCORD ON IRANIAN PLAN TO LIMIT OUTPUT
description: Ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries unanimously reached a tentative agreement tonight on an Iranian proposal to limit the group's production in a bid to stop the steep decline in prices.

title: REPCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $3,000 and $40,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net loss Year-ago quarter and 6-month earnings are restated to reflect the company's change in the method it used in accounting for development costs on a large contract in 1985.

title: PROGRESS ELUDES TAX CONFEREES
description: House and Senate negotiators on tax revision legislation remained at odds today over how much to raise taxes on business.

title: At Long Last, the 'Pumpkin Papers'
description: Several rolls of film retrieved from inside a hollowed-out pumpkin that contributed to the 1950 perjury conviction of Alger Hiss will soon be available to the public at the National Archives.

title: SERVICE FRACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GIANT YELLOWKNIFE MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
KENT ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
GRUMMAN'S CHIEF TEST PILOT DIES IN CRASH OF WORLD WAR II BOMBER
description: The chief test pilot of the Grumman Corporation, a highly decorated former Marine aviator who had flown 330 combat missions and tested some of the world's most sophisticated aircraft, was killed yesterday in the crash of a World War II-vintage torpedo bomber in a remote section of northeastern Connecticut.

H.C.A., Equitable In Joint Venture
description: The boards of the Hospital Corporation of America and the Equitable Life Assurance Society have approved the formation of a joint venture health-care company, the Equicor-Equitable H.C.A. Corporation, which had been announced in principle in March. The companies said that they would each contribute $87.5 million in cash and more than $200 million more in assets to give the new unit equity of more than $400 million.

title: Plane With 13 Aboard Is Down Off St. Vincent
description: A small commercial plane with 13 on board crashed off the island Sunday night.

title: AS DETROIT SETTLES ONE STRIKE, OTHER LABOR DISPUTES PERSIST
description: Trash collectors and other city workers returned to their jobs here today after signing a new three-year contract, ending a 19-day strike.

title: MINORITIES IN WESTERN EUROPE: HEARING 'NOT WELCOME' IN SEVERAL LANGUAGES
description: Eric Sinester, a former policeman from the South American nation of Suriname who is now an adviser to the Amsterdam police, told a story the other day. It seems that one of the first blacks on the Amsterdam force had arrested a white robber - and was himself arrested when white officers arrived to find a black man holding a gun.

title: PACT LIMITS KOREAN TEXTILE IMPORTS
description: The Reagan Administration today announced a four-year pact with South Korea to restrain growth in its textile imports to eight-tenths of 1 percent a year.

title: Reactions to Robertson As Candidate Reported
description: Nine percent of Americans have a favorable opinion of the Rev. Pat Robertson, the television evangelist who is seeking support for a possible Presidential candidacy in the Michigan Republican primary Tuesday, while 12 percent have an unfavorable view and 79 percent have no opinion, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

title: A South Africa Policy Machiavelli Could Live With; No Cheerleading
description: To the Editor:

title: JOHN R. CLARK
description: John R. Clark, mathematician and professor emeritus of education at Teachers College of Columbia University, died July 27 at the Foulkeways Retirement Community in Gwynedd, Pa. He was 98 years old. Dr. Clark, who was head of the Department of Mathematics Education at Teachers College, wrote more than a dozen mathematics textbooks, and was honorary national chairman of the National Council of Teachers of Mathematics, which he helped to establish.

title: BOWLING IS LURING NEW FANS
description: Bankers, lawyers, actors and musicians are the kinds of people crowding New York's bowling alleys these days, knocking down pins along with the notion that bowling is a sport reserved for blue-collar workers.

title: U.S.F.L. CALLS OFF 1986 FALL SEASON
description: The team owners of the United States Football League voted yesterday to call off the 1986 season and attempt to field a more powerful, larger league next year.

title: G.M. Names Two Officers
description: The General Motors Corporation board named two new vice presidents and approved a job swap between two executives, the nation's No. 1 auto maker announced today.

title: What We Do Better
description: The United States is losing now on the two most crucial, emotional issues that stir opinion around the world - arms control and South Africa.

title: New Chairman For Republic
description: The Republic Pictures Corporation said today that Russell Goldsmith, general partner of the Paragon Group, would be named chairman and chief executive of the entertainment company. George C. Hatch, the current chairman, will remain on the board, and Aubrey W. Groskopf will retain his positions as president, chief operating officer and board member.

title: Talking Business with Mascotte of Continental; Putting Limits On Liability
description: This year 32 states enacted measures that change the way liability damages are awarded. This is important to the insurance industry, which has long pushed for tort reform that would limit the awards in court decisions.

title: Texas University
description: A $221 million bond issue by the Board of Regents for the University of Texas System was tentatively priced yesterday through underwrters led by the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York. Underwriters noted good investor demand for the bonds, which are rated A-1 by Moody's and AA by S.&P. Yields on the general revenue refunding issue range from 5 percent for bonds due in 1987 to 6.50 percent in 1991, 7.70 percent in 1996 and 8 percent in 2001. For bonds with a longer maturity, an 8 percent bond due 2005 is offered at 99, to yield 8.10 percent, and a 7 percent bond due 2007 is offered at 90.85, to yield 7.90 percent.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Alumax Inc., San Mateo, Calif., an integrated U.S. aluminum company, has named Paul E. Drack president and chief executive, effective Aug. 15.

title: Third Filipino Charged In Killing at Rally
description: A third man was charged with murder today in the death of a man attacked by a crowd of supporters of former President Ferdinand E. Marcos, the police said.

title: 200 OFFICERS SENT TO BRONX AFTER NEW ETHNIC VIOLENCE
description: Two Yugoslav brothers were beaten Sunday night in the Bronx, apparently the victims of an ethnic attack in retaliation for an assault last week on two Puerto Ricans, the police said yesterday.

title: SOVIET AND ISRAEL AGREE TO BEGIN CONSULAR TALKS
description: The Soviet Union announced today that it would start discussions with Israel this month on the opening of consulates.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Commercial Shearing Inc., Youngstown, Ohio, said it had sold its stamping and forging unit to Wozniak Industries, a private company in Oak Brook Terrace, Ill. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Bankrupting the Ayatollah
description: Pumping at nearly six million barrels a day, triple the volume of a year ago, Saudi Arabia - working with its junior partner, Kuwait - has driven the international price of oil down to $10 a barrel, earning the gratitude of consumers and the open hostility of other producers of oil, who have charged the Saudis with greed and irresponsibility.

title: Governor Is Slain By Peruvian Rebels
description: Five people, including a district governor, were killed in guerrilla attacks over the weekend in this southeastern state, the police said today. Leftist guerrillas of the Shining Path movement were suspected.

title: From Timbuktu
description: The Mayor of a town whose name is often used to mean a place that does not exist arrived in New York yesterday to say that reality was catching up with that meaning, that Timbuktu may eventually be ''covered by sand and disappear.''

title: AMERICAN STUDENTS DIG INTO ETRUSCAN HISTORY
description: Every morning just after dawn a group of American students hike up to a long, flat hilltop known in Tuscan folklore as Il Piano del Tesoro, the plain of treasure.

More Sex

title: MCENROE SHIES AWAY FROM SCRUTINY
description: He scooped a half volley on his backhand and pushed it past Jimmy Connors just like in the good old days, when he was No. 1 and their rivalry was intensified by a clash of personalities and styles. Game and one-set match to John McEnroe, 7-5. A few people even began to applaud.

title: MET SURGE STOPPED AS DARLING LOSES
description: Possibly because the Mets are so far in front, the silly season may be upon us in baseball. To wit: The Mets, who have grown accustomed to seeing other teams lose, saw the Chicago Cubs lose several things today in Wrigley Field.

title: LAW OF PHYSICS: STIRRING INTEREST IS TEACHING KEY
description: Dr. Robert Prigo lowers his athletic body cautiously on a bed of nails. An assistant places a second board, spiked with nails, on Dr. Prigo's chest, puts a cinder block on top later, and, to the crescendo of accompanying death-scene music, brings down a sledgehammer that shatters the block. Dr. Prigo gets up, smiling.

title: SOUTH AFRICA TO LIFT SOME MINOR SEGREGATION RULES
description: The Ministry of Constitutional Development and Planning said today that the Government planned to let all restaurants and movie theaters decide whether to serve people of all races.

title: SMALL JEWISH CONGREGATIONS ATTRACTING MORE WORSHIPERS
description: Congregation Chizuk Hadas in Flatbush is situated in a long narrow room that was once the ground-floor apartment of a two-family house.

title: Voest-Alpine Unit Sale in Jeopardy
description: A deal by Austria's state-owned giant Voest-Alpine to sell its deficit-ridden American subsidiary, Bayou Steel, has run into trouble just two weeks after Voest said the sale was a formality. A Voest spokesman, Fritz Orasch, said that negotiations over the deal had reached a stalemate after the buyer, the RSR Corporation of Dallas, had sharply cut its offer price at the last moment, citing troubles in the United States steel industry.

title: Eastern Air Move
description: Eastern Air Lines Inc. said that effective Oct. 1 it would suspend its Miami-to-London daily nonstop services, as part of an overall realignment of its route system. Eastern said the economics of the route deteriorated sharply when the discount carrier Virgin Atlantic became the fourth airline on the route in April. Eastern said it would sell or lease the McDonnell Douglas DC-10 assigned to the route.

title: Navy Secretary Wants a Tall Ship
description: John F. Lehman Jr., the Secretary of the Navy, wants to spend about $20 million to build a sailing vessel like the tall ships that visited New York for the Fourth of July weekend.

title: The U.N. Today: Aug. 5, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Special Committee on Decolonization - 3 P.M.

title: U.S. and Swiss In Air Accord
description: Airlines will soon be allowed to set their own fares for flights to Switzerland originating in the United States because of a new air traffic agreement, the State Department said today.

title: PRODDING THE ESTABLISHMENT, AMONG OTHERS
description: At one of the first dinner parties Alice-Leone Moats held after arriving here in 1975, the socialite, author and former war correspondent was asked whether she liked the city. ''It's wonderful,'' she said. ''The parties remind me of the Gay Nineties - the men are gay and the women are in their nineties.''

title: Shakespeare in the Bronx
description: A free performance of Shakespeare's ''As You Like It'' will be given by the Riverside Shakespeare Company tomorrow at 6 P.M. at the New York Botanical Garden, Southern Boulevard and Fordham Road, the Bronx.

title: BOBBY CZYZ FIGHTS BACK
description: When Bobby Czyz first appeared on television screens in the early 1980's he was depicted as a boxing Galahad: a good-looking, clean-cut kid who graduated sixth in a class of 335 students at Lakeland Regional High School in Wanaque, N.J., and just the sort of boxer that middle America could take to heart.

title: MEDICAL IMAGING CENTERS OF AMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
EQUATION FOR BEAUTY EMERGES IN STUDIES
description: THE beauty of the female face, it appears, is mathematically quantifiable.

title: Werner Groshans, A Realist Painter, Dies in Catskill, N.Y.
description: Werner Groshans, whose paintings in the magic-realist style won him a measure of recognition and numerous awards and grants in New Jersey and New York over several decades, died last Thursday of cancer at the Green County Memorial Hospital in Catskill, N.Y. He was 73 years old, and lived in Catskill.

title: Powerful Risk in Power Politics
description: There's no mystery about Governor Cuomo's decision to dismiss Paul Gioia, chairman of the state's Public Service Commission. The two have been at odds on policy, notably the decision to pass on to Long Island consumers some costs of the unopened Shoreham nuclear power plant. And since the Governor inevitably suffers political heat for utility rates and service, it's wholly understandable for him to want a chairman who shares his views. The question is, how faithfully. Traditionally, the chairman has been allowed the leeway to put long-term energy and communications needs ahead of politics. If the Governor's decision politicizes the chairman's job, the state will lose a critical buffer in the process of setting policies that are wise but not necessarily popular.

title: MCGRATH RENTCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
REHNQUIST PAPERS STILL SOUGHT
description: With questions still unresolved about the nomination of Associate Justice William H. Rehnquist of the Supreme Court to be Chief Justice of the United States, the Senate Judiciary Committee is to begin consideration Tuesday of President Reagan's other Supreme Court nominee, Judge Antonin Scalia of the Federal appellate bench.

title: HUGHES TOOL PRESIDENT ADDS POST OF CHAIRMAN
description: The Hughes Tool Company, an oilfield-services company and the world's largest drill-bit manufacturer, named William A. Kistler Jr., president and chief executive, to the additional post of chairman yesterday. He succeeds James R. Lesch, who held the position from 1981 until his retirement on July 31.

title: KASPAROV GIVEN EDGE
description: The fourth game in the world chess championship adjourned tonight, and experts said the defending champion, Gary Kasparov, held a winning position against the challenger, Anatoly Karpov.

title: WESTERN FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said that due to a merger in July 1985, year-ago share earnings are not meaningful.

description: Home Shopping Network said it was buying three UHF television stations in the New York City area and in Boston for about $46 million in cash.

title: 'CLOSING' UNDER BLUE SKIES
description: Behind the white double doors of the Salon Concorde B in the Parker Meridien hotel, United States Football League club owners were deliberating on how to invest $3 in damages from the National Football League following last week's jury verdict in the antitrust trial. Across the Gothic columns of the hotel's atrium, under crystal chandeliers in the Salon Vendome, microphones awaited an announcement as puffy white clouds floated across blue skies painted on the walls and ceiling.

title: COMPUTERS ATTACK HEART DISEASE
description: CROSSING the traditional lines between disciplines, biologists in the United States and Canada are borrowing from computer science and theoretical physics to achieve a new understanding of the normal and abnormal rhythms of the heart that make the difference between life and sudden death.

title: Biplane Pilot Killed in Crash
description: The pilot of a homemade plane died of his injuries tonight, after the aircraft had crashed into a backyard here, the police said. The pilot, Edwin Tarr, 44 years old, of Montvale, died shortly after 6 P.M. at University Hospital in Newark, where he was taken after the crash. The engine of the biplane, which had apparently taken off from Linden Airport, reportedly backfired and stalled before crashing at the home of George and Pat Hardman at 3 P.M.

description: Helionetics Inc., the defense company that filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy laws last week, said today that William M. Duke would replace Michael M. Mann as president and chief executive.

description: Vice President Bush met here today with President Hosni Mubarak and told him that domestic budget considerations would not allow the United States to provide additional aid to help Egypt meet pressing financial needs.

title: NOTES ON FASHION

At the Four Seasons one recent lunchtime were the fashion designers Bill Blass, Michaele Vollbracht and Giorgio Sant'Angelo. Mr. Sant'Angelo was talking about his new couture showroom atop the Cable Building at Broadway and Houston Street, where he will soon give fashion shows in a converted penthouse basketball court.

Only 2 Americans in 100 are Asian, yet last year they made up 11 percent of the freshman class at Harvard - and 21 percent at M.I.T. Asian-Americans typically score 30 points higher than Caucasians on the math section of the Scholastic Aptitude Test.

The other day, Earl Weaver of the Orioles asked for the score in the Yankees-Indians game and was told the Indians were leading. The Baltimore manager then had to ask: ''Who am I rooting for, New York or Cleveland?''

title: Nobody's Perfect
description: It had to happen sometime to Logan Easley, the relief pitcher for the Yankees' Albany-Colonie farm team in the Class AA Eastern League. After going 52 innings over a span of two months without allowing an earned run, Easley finally surrended a pair to the Glens Falls Tigers Sunday night in Albany. The 24-year-old split-fingered fastball specialist, who had last allowed an earned run on May 4, has 15 saves and a 0.97 earned run average to go with his seven victories and five defeats.

description: The New York-based Loews Corporation said that it had raised its stake in CBS Inc. from 20.98 percent, to 22.46 percent. Laurence A. Tisch, chairman of Loews and a member of the CBS board, had said previously that Loews might eventually raise its stake in CBS to 25 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Loews said it bought 349,600 CBS common shares on the open market from July 22 through Aug. 4, for prices ranging from $133.50 to $137.50 a share.

description: The State Department confirmed today that Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union will meet here on Sept. 19 and 20 to talk about prospects for a summit meeting.

description: Buoyed by reports that OPEC ministers were on the verge of an accord that would substantially curtail the group's oil output, prices of crude oil and petroleum products surged yesterday to some of their sharpest gains of the year on the world oil market.

She handed them to a park ranger, who walked sheepishly to the lip of the Great Stage in Central Park.

description: Middle- and long-distance runners are not the only Irish athletes being recruited by American colleges.

title: Erving, 76ers Agree
description: Julius Erving is expected to announce today that he reached a one-year agreement yesterday with Harold Katz, the 76er owner, to finish his pro career in Philadelphia. The agreement reportedly was hammered out during a meeting yesterday with Katz at his home in Hunterdon, Pa.

description: A condemned murderer who escaped from a county jail remained at large today after officers recaptured a woman who fled with him.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The St. Louis Cardinals said outfielder Willie McGee has been placed on the 15-day disabled list with a pulled right hamstring suffered Saturday night in a game against the Pirates at Pittsburgh. . . . Greg Koch, the senior member of Green Bay's offensive line, was placed on waivers yesterday. Koch, age 31, has played both tackle and guard. . . . Sean Farrell, the Tampa Bay Buccaneers starting right guard, will undergo arthroscopic knee surgery this week and probably be sidelined four to six weeks. . . . Mike Ruth, the nose tackle from Boston College, signed with the New England Patriots.

title: A NEW MEDIUM CATCHES ON
description: When Karen Ragland of Austin, Tex., took her 15-month-old daughter to the dentist for the first time, she had plenty of questions about her baby's new teeth. Instead of requiring a long lecture from her doctor, Mrs. Ragland found the answers to her questions on the waiting-room wall.

title: AMERICAN VICTIMS OF A-BOMB
description: SOME Americans died when the United States dropped an atom bomb on Hiroshima.

description: The request from an Upper West Side restaurant to erect a large clock on a Broadway sidewalk had proceeded smoothly through the city's complicated approval process. The application was certified as complete by the city's Planning Commission in April; the local community board approved it in June, and the commission had scheduled a vote for tomorrow.

description: Hundreds of black students walked out of a Soweto high school today after soldiers guarding the school confiscated a military-style jacket from a pupil and refused to return it, a school official said.

title: FOR INMATE-WRITER, A NEW CONTROVERSY
description: Jack Henry Abbott, a convicted murderer and bank robber who was briefly the toast of some New York literati in the early 1980's, has a new book being prepared for publication. Originally scheduled for release this fall, the book has been delayed until next spring because of a series of disputes - disputes reminiscent of an earlier controversy that swirled around Mr. Abbott.

title: Shultz Assails Grain Policy
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz today criticized President Reagan's approval of subsidized grain sales to the Soviet Union today, saying it betrayed American principles.

description: An open pit mine has come back to life at the edge of this crumbling city in the Rockies, ending three years of idleness here in the copper industry, enforced by a crippled market.

title: DROUGHT AREA WAITS FOR AID AND MORE THAN A LITTLE RAIN
description: Moderate rainfall in much of the South and Middle Atlantic region over the weekend provided the first substantial break in the scorching, dry conditions that have plagued the 10-state area for months.

title: Children's World's Fair To Receive Assistance
description: The Children's World's Fair, which will be held Sept. 25-28 in Flushing Meadows Park at the site of the 1964 World's Fair, is getting some advertising assistance from Allied Outdoor and Ad Net. Allied Outdoor is donating billboard space in Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx in mid-August, while Ad Net is coordinating the ad campaign, which will begin in magazines early next month.

title: Broward County
description: A $175 million issue of Broward County, Fla., public improvement refunding bonds was tentatively priced to yield a maximum 7 7/8 percent for bonds due in 2012 through underwriters led by Paine Webber Inc. Bonds with shorter maturities are offered with yields ranging from 5.80 percent in 1989 to 6.30 percent in 1991, 7.10 percent in 1996 and 7.60 percent in 2001. Rated A-1 by Moody's and A+ by Standard & Poor's, the bonds are backed by the full faith and credit of the county.

title: MUSIC: CONTEMPORARY WORKS, AT TANGLEWOOD
description: Oliver Knussen, the Tanglewood Music Center's composer-in-residence, has said that he wanted the 1986 Festival of Contemporary Music, which began Saturday afternoon in the theater-concert hall here, to reflect synthesis and diversity. To judge from the first three concerts and a perusal of programs yet to come - the festival continues through Thursday night - this listener would conclude that Mr. Knussen has succeeded in his objective, and provided some engaging listening as well.

title: Our Fragile, Fractured Economy
description: Many Americans admire Margaret Thatcher. They cite her tough attitude toward the Russians, her gutsy conduct of the Falklands war and her stalwart support for the bombing of Libya. There is an irony about this, for in Britain the perspective is different. She is seen by many as the Prime Minister who presided over the devastation of the British economy.

description: FRENCH researchers have developed a genetically engineered vaccine that can be administered in the wild to combat rabies, a fatal disease that kills thousands of domestic animals and several people each year worldwide. The virus is transmitted by the bite of an infected animal.

title: Rallying for More Reagan
description: Ever since the 22d Amendment to the Constitution took effect in 1951, limiting a President to no more than two terms or 10 years in office, there have been periodic efforts to repeal it.

title: SHOPSMITH INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Word War on Drugs
description: It's turning into Drug War Summer. With the emergence of crack, the cheap and powerfully addictive form of cocaine, Americans are alarmed, even disgusted. And when the public is agitated, can politicians be far behind? Surely not, as demonstrated by futile attacks on deserted drug labs in the Bolivian jungle, and now by President Reagan's newest verbal assault. The key word is verbal, for so far, this is mostly a war of words.

title: UNITED INSURANCE COS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TEXRON OFFICIAL TO HEAD BEECHAM
description: Robert P. Bauman, the vice chairman of Textron Inc., was named yesterday to one of the top jobs in British industry: chairmanship of the Beecham Group, the international pharmaceutical and consumer products concern.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in the Executive Changes column of Business Day yesterday misidentified the organization that has hired Albert H. Rothaus as an executive vice president. It is the New York Mercantile Exchange.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Eric Davis, the Cincinnati Reds' outfielder, was named National League player of the month for July. During the month he had 32 hits in 84 times at bat for a .381 average, including 9 doubles, 6 home runs, 16 runs batted in and 23 runs scored. . . . Dick Versace, the Bradley University basketball coach who was expected to be dismissed after the 1986-87 season because of recruiting violations, was named an assistant coach of the Detroit Pistons. . . . Larry Bethea, former defensive lineman of the Dallas Cowboys, has been arrested on a charge of assaulting his wife. He also has a charge of grand larceny against him for stealing $64,000 from his mother. . . . Renaldo Nehemiah, the world- record holder in the 110-meter high hurdles who was recently cleared to return to track after a four-year career in the National Football League, arrived in Italy to prepare for his comeback race tonight.

title: BUSH'S HOPES IN MICHIGAN RACES ARE SUPPORTED BY A POLL OF VOTERS
description: Michigan Republicans went to the polls today to elect precinct delegates in a primary that posed the first major test of Vice President Bush's ability to survive early challenges to a bid for the Presidency from his party's conservative wing.

title: LOEWS A SUCCESSFUL COMPANY
description: If Preston Robert Tisch, president and chief operating officer of the Loews Corporation, moves to Washington to become Postmaster General it will be the first time he and his brother Laurence, the chairman of the corporation, have not worked together in their adult lives.

title: Writer of Labor Anthem Dies
description: Florence Reece, a writer and social activist whose song ''Which Side Are You On?'' became an anthem for the labor movement, died Sunday of a heart attack. She was 86 years old.

title: STARS PAY TRIBUTE TO WILLIAMS
description: An overflow crowd attended the funeral yesterday of the radio personality William B. Williams.

title: JUSTICE KNEW OF DEED IN '74
description: Justice William H. Rehnquist disclosed in a letter made public today that his lawyer had informed him in 1974 that the deed to a Vermont summer home he was about to buy had a clause barring its lease or sale to ''anyone of the Hebrew race.''

title: Thomas J. Valentino Is Dead; Early Sound Effects Producer
description: Thomas J. Valentino, among the first to develop libraries of sound effects and taped music, died Monday at his home in Forest Hills, Queens, after a long illness. He was 79 years old.

title: People
description: * Joseph P. Palladino has joined Korey, Kay & Partners as senior vice president, account executive.

title: AQUINO AIDE BEGINS TALKS WITH REBELS
description: Negotiators for the Government and the Communist insurgents opened talks in Manila today in a secret meeting that the Government representative later characterized as a reunion of ''old friends.''

title: MARCOS ITEMS PREVIEWED FOR AUCTION
description: Imelda Marcos spent $100 million for jewelry, art and furniture in New York City over the last decade, officials of the new Philippine Government said yesterday as some of Mrs. Marcos's other possessions were on show for an auction preview in Manhattan.

title: Bridge: Split Regional Tournament Set in Secaucus and Albany
description: An experiment made a year ago was highly successful and is now being repeated. It is a ''split regional'' tournament, with play at the Meadowlands Hilton in Secaucus, N.J., and at the Thruway House in Albany. Here is the schedule: Today - Novice Pairs (Albany only), 1:30 P.M.; Men's and Women's Pairs, 1:30 P.M. and 8 P.M.; Knockout Teams (Secaucus only), 8 P.M.

title: Praise and Pillory for a Liberal Lobby Group
description: They almost did it.

title: SENATE PANEL, 15 TO 14, APPROVES AID TO CONTRAS
description: The Senate Appropriations Committee today narrowly approved President Reagan's request to send $100 million in aid to the rebels fighting the Nicaraguan Government. The bill also contained $300 million in aid for fledgling democracies in Central America.

title: EXCERPTS FROM THE LONDON COMMUNIQUE
description: Following are excerpts from the final communique issued today by the seven Commonwealth leaders after their meeting on South Africa:

title: AT OXFORD, OLD BOYS CELEBRATE 'THE ILLUSION OF BEING SPECIAL'
description: ON a peerless summer evening, some 200 men of varied nationality and race but similar age (late 40's) and intellience gathered on an ancient lawn to resample their youth and slyly assess the impact of time on one another. It would have been called a class reunion in America, but here this assembly had a different name and a different aim from those organized there. It also boasted an altogether distinctive atmosphere.

description: WHERE the kitchen is concerned, one of the brightest stars in the Lone Star State is 34-year-old Stephan Pyles. This young chef has come a long way from his formal training in voice and piano. He has been praised from one coast to the other.

description: Two men were charged Monday night with sodomizing, sexually abusing and endangering the welfare of a 14-year-old boy who had been living in the Times Square area, the police said yesterday.

description: A $238 million issue of general obligation bonds from the State of Minnesota, which will be used to refinance various outstanding debt, was priced yesterday through underwriters led by the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York.

title: FIRST VICTORY IN CHESS MATCH GOES TO CHAMPION
description: Gary Kasparov yesterday became the first to score a victory in the world chess championship when Anatoly Karpov resigned the fourth game of their match in London without resuming play. The 23-year-old champion has taken a 2 1/2-to-1 1/2 point lead over the 35-year-old ex-champion.

title: WHEN MAKING A SELECTION...
description: CONFRONTED with a restaurant list of Italian wines, how do you begin to make a selection? Use the accompanying chart as a guide, but if you find a wine you like, seek out a wine shop that stocks it. Try different producers and vintages. When you find a producer whose wine pleases you, try other wines in the same line. Then branch out within the same region.

title: German Escape Termed A Hoax on Berlin TV
description: An East Berliner who maintained he escaped to the West in a mock Soviet military car with three tailor's dummies dressed as Soviet soldiers has admitted his story was a hoax, the West Berlin television said today.

title: U.S. Judge Delays Trial of Friedman
description: The Federal trial of Stanley M. Friedman, the Bronx Democratic leader, and five co-defendants on charges relating to the municipal corruption scandal was tentatively delayed yesterday to Oct. 6.

title: New York Immigration Head To Keep Job, D'Amato Is Told
description: New York City's top immigration official will remain in his post despite a recent rash of escapes from a Federal detention center in lower Manhattan, the Federal Commissioner of the Immigration and Naturalization Service, Alan Nelson, told Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato.

title: TIMES SQUARE TO STAY BRIGHT IN CITY'S PLAN
description: The Koch administration will propose that developers in Times Square be required to festoon new buildings with arrays of brightly lighted signs as flashy as anything on Broadway, the chairman of the City Planning Commission said yesterday.

title: BANESH HOFFMANN, AN AUTHOR AND COLLABORATOR OF EINSTEIN
