title: Nine-Pronged Attack Retakes a Street in Queens
description: Springfield Lane reappeared yesterday.

title: A GARDEN GROWS IN BROOKLYN
description: The kids on the corner of Crystal and Wells Streets in Brooklyn say that all anyone wants to do around here anymore is talk about growing vegetables. ''They're doing it right now,'' said Destiny McIntosh, 8 years old, pointing to people who turned out to be doing just that.

title: Soviet 'Son of Rambo'
description: To the Editor:

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: I ATTENDED an outdoor barbecue at a neighbor's home the other day and was fascinated to find the host grilling loin lamb steaks, a cut of meat that is little used in American homes but a cut that I often served years ago when I was chef at Le Pavillon Restaurant. They are commonly called lamb steaks or ''double'' chops and are made by cutting through the center bone of a loin of lamb to produce a single piece of meat - two matching chops joined together by that single bone. The virtue of the lamb steaks is the ease of cooking and the appearance, which is very appealing.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 6, 1986
description: The OPEC Accord

title: 240 HIDDEN ARTWORKS BY ANDREW WYETH SOLD
description: A Pennsylvania art collector said yesterday that he had purchased 240 previously unknown works by Andrew Wyeth that the artist had kept secret from everyone, including his wife, for the 15 years during which he painted them.

title: FOCUS OF TRIAL OF EX-CITY AIDE SHIFTS TO TAXES
description: Defense lawyers for John J. McLaughlin, the former president of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, sought yesterday to refute the prosecution charges that Mr. McLaughlin underreported his income on his state tax returns.

title: MUNFORD INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Philadelphia Removes Korean Street Signs
description: Flags fluttered today in place of Korean-language street signs that the city removed after they were criticized by residents and damaged by vandals.

title: EXCERPTS FROM SHUTTLE PANEL'S HEARING ON DISCLOSURE OF MEMOS ON FLAWS
description: Following are excerpts from the transcript of a closed hearing Feb. 10 by the Presidential commission that investigated the loss of the space shuttle Challenger. The article in The New York Times referred to by the chairman was published Feb. 9 and reported that internal space agency memorandums had warned that flaws in the booster rocket seals could cause a catastrophic accident.

title: Don't Skip English
description: To the Editor:

title: CUBS DEFEAT METS
description: If they had not been 17 1/2 games in front, it would have been a memorable loss, maybe a catastrophic one, considering the way it happened: Jerry Mumphrey pinch-hit a three-run home run off Roger McDowell with two down in the eighth inning at Wrigley Field today and the Chicago Cubs beat the Mets again, 8-5.

title: Craxi Redux
description: Bettino Craxi's resignation in June as Italy's Prime Minister drew sighs of relief from his opponents. They were envious of his success in leading a five-party coalition for 34 months, a postwar record. At last this flexible Socialist, a virtuoso at outflanking left, right and center, would be gone.

title: SOUTHERN CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Lilco Is Seeking Cause Of Explosion at Motel
description: The Long Island Lighting Company called in a metallurgical engineering company today to aid in finding the cause of a natural gas explosion that injured seven people Monday night at the Howard Johnson motel here.

title: Fighting in Beirut Mars Syrian Effort
description: Gunners exchanged mortar fire across the Green Line today, killing a policeman and marring Syrian security in the Moslem area.

title: Marino's Warning
description: Dan Marino, the Miami Dolphin quarterback who missed 37 days of training camp last year in an unsuccessful effort to force a renegotiation of his contract, says he may stage an even longer walkout next year.

title: PRETORIA IMPOSING AREA TRADE LIMITS ON BLACK NATIONS
description: South Africa said today that it would impose economic countermeasures against black-ruled neighboring countries after the announcement of new economic sanctions against Pretoria by the Commonwealth.

title: The Man Who Improved on the Way America Looks and Works
description: To the Editor:

title: DROUGHT-PARCHED FARM LOST AT GEORGIA AUCTION
description: Gordon Mead sat at ease in his favorite chair at 6 P.M. Monday, a casualty of the collapse of traditional farming here. There was nothing more to do.

title: GASOLINE PRICE RISE OF 10 cents TO 20 cents IS SEEN IF OPEC'S CURB SUCCEEDS
description: The agreement by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to curb its crude oil production could push gasoline prices up by 10 to 20 cents a gallon, to more than $1, for the first time in months, oil analysts and industry officials said yesterday.

title: DELCHAMPS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
U.S. WITHDRAWS SUBPOENAS FOR ISRAELIS IN AN ARMS CASE
description: The Justice Department announced today that it had withdrawn subpoenas that would have required several Israeli officials to testify about allegations that Israel illegally tried to import American technology for making cluster bombs.

title: Something About Chiefs
description: There was bound to be fireworks when Selma Scold, the flamboyant and always tiresome kneejerk liberal, took over this space as guest columnist last week.

title: All the Capital's Gewgaws
description: ''Can I get a backscratcher?'' implored 7-year-old Emily Dunlop.

title: BASQUE GUERRILLAS THREATEN TO ATTACK FOREIGNERS
description: Basque separatist guerrillas threatened today to attack citizens of European Community countries in Spain to protest the group's support for the Madrid Government, diplomatic sources said.

title: MALTA SAYS LIBYA GOT A TIP ON RAID
description: Prime Minister Karmenu Mifsud Bonnici said today that Malta had given Libya advance notice of the American air attack in April and would do so again if it had similar information.

title: RABBIS WANT SYNAGOGUE BUILT ON TEMPLE MOUNT
description: In a step that defied both civil and religious law in Israel, a group of prominent rabbis issued a formal call today for the construction of a synagogue on the Temple Mount, an area sacred to Moslems and forbidden to Jews.

title: Reagan News Conference
description: President Reagan will hold a news conference next Tuesday in Chicago, the White House spokesman, Larry Speakes, said today. Mr. Speakes said the President would answer questions from the White House press corps and local reporters in a session that would be made available for live broadcast by television networks. The news conference will be held at P.M. (8 P.M. Eastern time).

title: Poaching With Panache
description: I HAVE never been an uncritical fan of nouvelle-style cuisine, which sometimes sacrifices substance for style. Yet some of the more imaginative practitioners of this culinary style have invented many engaging cooking techniques.

title: Big Step Toward Efficient New York Courts
description: To the Editor:

title: Why Have Lawyers Proliferated?
description: The lawyers are coming to New York. Lots of them.

title: PAN AM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said operations in the year-ago periods were substantially reduced by a strike. The company said the results for the latest periods do not include its Pacific division which was sold. The company also said it had foreign currency exchange losses of $16.8 million in the latest quarter, compared with $2.7 million in the year-ago period; most of the exchange loss this year is related to Japanese yen debt.

title: HEAD OF LOEWS LIKELY CHOICE FOR POSTMASTER GENERAL'S JOB
description: The United States Postal Service Board of Governors has selected Preston Robert Tisch, president of the New York-based Loews Corporation, as the new Postmaster General, sources close to the Postal Service said today.

title: Commercial Paper Halt
description: The American Board of Trade has been permanently enjoined from issuing commercial paper and the court has appointed a special master to oversee the closing of the company's commercial paper program, the Securities and Exchange Commission said.

title: Ruth Is No Help To the Red Sox
description: The days and the lead dwindle down to a precious few. So what's a team to do?

title: China Is Said to Study Proposal by Gorbachev
description: Deng Xiaoping, China's top leader, said today that a speech by Mikhail S. Gorbachev calling for improved Chinese-Soviet ties contained positive elements but that China needed to study it carefully, Japanese sources said.

title: KOREAN TEMPLE COOKING WARMS THE BODY, SOOTHES THE SOUL
description: DURING his 18 years as a Buddhist monk, Kim Yon Shik grew into an ardent fan of temple cooking, the distinctive cuisine based upon fresh vegetables gathered in the country's woods and mountains. And when, at the age of 32, he left the monastery in which he had lived since he was 14, he decided that this cuisine deserved a wider audience.

title: Examiner Allowed In Robins Case
description: Federal District Judge Robert R. Merhige Jr. authorized William White, a trustee named by the Justice Department, to appoint an examiner with ''very broad powers'' in the A. H. Robins Company bankruptcy case.

title: INTEL WILL LAY OFF 1,300 EMPLOYEES
description: The Intel Corporation, a semiconductor manufacturer based in Santa Clara, Calif., said today that it would phase out its plant in Barbados, laying off about 900 employees over the next several months. The company said it also plans to lay off about 420 employees in Puerto Rico by year-end.

title: PREVIOUS SHUTTLE CREW AVOIDED POSSIBLE DISASTER BY 31 SECONDS
description: The Presidential space shuttle commission reported today that a launching preceding the Challenger disaster was stopped within 31 seconds of a potentially catastrophic flight because fatigued console operators inadvertently drained some of its fuel.

title: CORRECTION CHIEF TO BE REPLACED, KOCH AIDES SAY
description: Mayor Koch has decided to remove the Correction Commissioner, Jacqueline McMickens, and offer her a job as a member of the Housing Authority, according to mayoral advisers.

title: Things in the Mail
description: The way to get the attention of a member of Congress, some lobbyists believe, is not to visit or send a telegram but to send a thing. As a result, all senators and representatives received this week two white Ralph Lauren sport shirts, one made in this country and one abroad.

title: Seas of People
description: On the evening of July 4, walking west toward the Battery to watch the fireworks, one could watch as the setting sun lighted and framed the bobbing heads of what seemed like a million other people, strolling along in a soft roar of jokes and chatter. Much of Liberty Weekend was like that, surrounded by, and warmed by, seas of people.

title: DIVERSIFIED ENERGIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Expansion Demand Is Strong, but League Appears Hesitant
description: The expansion rush is on, and the price tag of $25 million in cash for a team has not been a deterrent. Orlando, Fla., which has the experience of Pat Williams, the former Philadelphia 76er general manager, to guide it, has already chosen a nickname -Magic.

title: PICASSO PAINTING STOLEN FROM AUSTRALIAN MUSEUM
description: Thieves stole Picasso's painting ''Weeping Woman'' from the National Gallery of Victoria in Melbourne, Australia over the weekend and have sent four ransom notes threatening to destroy the work unless their demands are met, a spokesman for the museum said yesterday.

title: Cult Peanut Butter
description: If there is a cult peanut butter it is Red Wing, made in Fredonia, N.Y., and sold mainly upstate. Red Wing's loyal fans often buy supermarket private label brands with yellow plastic lids on the insider's theory that these are also made by the Red Wing Company, which packs its peanut butters with yellow lids.

title: FANSTEEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Transactions
description: BASKETBALL DETROIT (NBA) - Named Dick Versace assistant coach. FOOTBALL GREEN BAY (NFC) - Signed Karl Swanke, tackle, to a series of one-year contracts.

title: Let Me Count the Ways
description: Is there a woman alive who hasn't wanted to know, at one time or other and beyond the shadow of a doubt, if she is attractive to the opposite sex? If her eyes have that old come-hither look and her mouth that adorable kiss-me-quick quiver? If her nose can be left to itself, or if it could use a nip and a tuck and a pinch through the nostrils? Of course there isn't, and that's why any woman aware of the great experiment undertaken by Michael Cunningham of the University of Louisville will think of spending a few minutes with a mirror and a ruler.

title: LIQUOR LABELING REJECTED
description: A Federal appeals court ruled yesterday that beer, wine and liquor bottles do not have to carry labels listing all ingredients.

title: Israel Gets an Antiracist Law; It Permits Some Exceptions
description: The Israeli Knesset today approved an antiracism bill so diluted that the parties that first suggested it voted against it, and Rabbi Meir Kahane, the rightist whose activities the bill was aimed to curtail, voted in its favor.

title: CINCINNATI FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes capital gains of $1 million for the quarter and $7.6 million for the 6 months. c-Includes capital gains of $500,000 and $4.9 million for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: BRONX NICHE IS SHATTERED BY CHANGE
description: The events themselves have fostered a simple ethnic equation. On July 28, eight white youths armed with baseball bats beat two Puerto Ricans who had wandered into a park in the Belmont section of the Bronx. Six days later, a group of Hispanic and black youths retaliated, jumping two Yugoslav brothers who had come to Belmont to attend a wedding reception.

title: GEICO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes capital gains of $31,943,499 for the quarter and $47,548,047 for the 6 months. c-Includes capital gains of $19,529,049 and $31,113,602 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Paying Dearly for Textile Quotas
description: To manufacturers and unions in the textile and clothing industries, the issue is simple: Us versus Them, America versus all those foreigners. Thus, what Congress should do about President Reagan's veto of the textile quota bill is also simple: override it. That, the industry contends, would save jobs and profits.

title: TESTING CONFIRMS SAFETY
description: FOUR months after methanol-contaminated table wine killed at least 21 people in Italy, American consumers can shop for Italian wine with confidence, according to the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms.

title: No Headline
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Eating the Lotus Of Movie Stardom
description: Imagine if you could take a pill that would make you cool. I don't mean cool in the sense of low temperature, but cool as in hip, with-it, admired, buffed out, radical.

title: Carl Byoir Deal
description: Hill & Knowlton Inc. confirmed that it had agreed in principle to acquire most of Carl Byoir & Associates from Foote, Cone & Belding Communications Inc. Terms were not disclosed, but sources close to the companies said the price would be between $10 million and $15 million for the the nation's third-largest public relations firm.

title: Reactions to Robertson As Candidate Reported
description: Nine percent of Americans have a favorable opinion of the Rev. Pat Robertson, the television evangelist who had Presidential convention delegate candidates running in the Michigan Republican primary Tuesday, while 12 percent have an unfavorable view and 79 percent have no opinion, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

title: IKE TOURNEY TO BALDWIN
description: John Baldwin, a 41-year-old investment banker who once played on the professional tour, won The Ike championship today by four strokes.

title: CBS NEWS IS CRITICIZED FROM INSIDE
description: CBS News management, which recently decided to relinquish the ''CBS Morning News'' in favor of an entertainment program, has been criticized from within over the action.

title: GERALD F. LIEBERMAN
description: Gerald F. Lieberman, a freelance writer, died Saturday at Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn as a result of a stroke he suffered July 25.

title: AT HIROSHIMA SEASON, ONE B-17 SURVIVOR'S QUEST
description: For Jose Holguin, a search for the long-lost remains of his wartime comrades is a dimly lighted path that brought him to Japan this week. This, he recognizes, is where the road probably ends.

title: 10-Day Car Sales Rise 4.3%
description: The domestic automobile manufacturers today reported a 4.3 percent increase in car sales in the last 10 days of July and a 2.4 percent gain for the entire month, but a sharp drop in annualized selling rates prompted some analysts to warn that the new-car market may be softening.

title: REAGAN LOBBIES FOR HIS TEXTILE VETO
description: Reagan Administration officials warned today that if Congress did not sustain President Reagan's veto of protectionist textile legislation there would be widespread foreign retaliation that would imperil the world trading system and wipe out jobs.

title: Good and Bad News for Grey
description: Grey Advertising got both good and bad news yesterday.

title: TOKYO COURT RULES BUSINESS MUST RECKON WITH OLD WAYS
description: Japan's modern fascination with things Western is well known, but the Japanese Supreme Court struck a blow for traditionalists last month.

title: Punishment Won't Solve the Drug Problem
description: To the Editor:

title: 'AS IS,' A PERSONAL STORY OF AIDS
description: IN ''As Is,'' which is being rebroadcast tonight at 12:30 on Showtime, William M. Hoffman encourages us to see his characters as they see themselves -without sentimentality or stoicism but as people suddenly forced to confront realities of death and survival. The play is a compassionate collage of events in the lives of two homosexuals, one, a poet who contracts AIDS, the other, his former lover who devotes himself to caring for the victim. As directed on the stage by Marshall W. Mason, ''As Is'' was impressionistic, with overlapping scenes and with most of the actors doubling in roles.

title: RANDOM HOUSE PUBLISHER A HUMAN-RIGHTS ACTIVIST
description: Almost every Wednesday morning as many as 25 people gather around a conference table on the 12th floor of the Random House headquarters on Manhattan's East Side. But this is not an editorial-board meeting. It is the weekly get-together of officials of Helsinki Watch and Americas Watch, private organizations that monitor human-rights practices in various parts of the world.

title: Citicorp Rates Fall at Auction
description: Rates fell yesterday at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for belwether issues.

title: From Sand to Street
description: 1. Beachgoing Glamour

title: Unprovoked Adventures on a Trip to Panama
description: To the Editor:

title: LIFE OF INGRES PRESENTED IN 'ARTISTS AND MODELS'
description: ''ARTISTS AND MODELS: INGRES'' is a dramatized version, made for the BBC, of the life of Jean Auguste Dominique Ingres, one of the great French artists of the 19th century. The program, written and directed by Leslie Megahey, is one of a feature-length series that aims to cut a new kind of profile for films about art. And to a considerable extent it succeeds. It can be seen on the Arts & Entertainment cable network tonight at 9 o'clock.

title: GENEVA AGREEMENT PLEASES SOUTHWEST
description: Oilmen across the Southwest hailed the agreement by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to cut oil production as a sign that their protracted nightmare of sliding revenues, rising debts and deepening layoffs might have ended.

title: D+ GIVEN TO L.I.R.R. BY RIDERS
description: The Long Island Rail Road received a D plus in performance in the results released today from an opinion poll to which 2,031 commuters responded.

title: 'NEGLECT' CHARGED IN DELAYS IN SETTLING OF ESTATES IN CITY
description: The State Attorney General and the State Comptroller charged today that hundreds of estates have gone unsettled for years - and some for decades - as a result of ''a pattern of inexcusable neglect'' by Manhattan's Public Administrator.

title: Tall Ship? Short Answer
description: All that Secretary of the Navy John F. Lehman Jr. wanted was a tall ship, and about $20 million to build her by.

title: TESORO PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After writeoffs of $46.5 million on oil and gas reserves and writedowns of $25.5 million relating to a receivable from the Government of Trinidad and Tobago. c-Net loss d-After writeoffs on value of oil and gas reserves of $29.4 million and $39.4 million for quarter and 9 months, respectively. Preferred dividends exceeded net income in the latest quarter.

title: Agency Sets Issue In Connecticut
description: The Connecticut Housing Finance Authority is offering $70 million of revenue bonds, with a maximum yield of 7.40 percent for 7 1/4 percent bonds due in 2003 and priced at 98 1/2, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE BLOOD OF KINGS. Dynasty and Ritual in Maya Art. By Linda Schele and Mary Ellen Miller. Illustrated. 335 pages. George Braziller/Kimbell Art Museum. Cloth, $45; paper, $28. NOW that they've been deciphered, the beautiful, cold stone walls of the Mayan ruins offer up some bloody and grotesque stories: a woman threads a rope of thorns through her tongue; a man lacerates his penis with a stingray spine, a captured soldier is methodically scalped and disemboweled.

title: Diverse Catholicism
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: U.S. AND SOVIET PLAN EXCHANGES IN MANY FIELDS
description: The United States and the Soviet Union announced agreement today on 13 educational, scientific and cultural exchanges.

title: Cannon Release Near
description: Billy Cannon, the 1959 Heisman Trophy winner from Louisiana State who has been serving a five-year sentence for his part in a $6 million counterfeiting scheme, has been transferred to a halfway house in anticipation of an early release.

title: BMJ FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The 1985 results are adjusted for the effect of a 100-percent dividend paid June 16, 1986.

title: From One Opera to Another
description: Ordinary citizens are not the only ones who get pestered by fund-raising telephone calls. Martin Feinstein, general director of the Washington Opera, was relaxing at home the other night when he was called to the phone and importuned for a contribution to help sustain the ''Live from the Met'' broadcasts of the Metropolitan Opera in New York.

title: BUSINESSLAND INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary tax benefits of $911,000 for the quarter and $2,070,000 for the year. c-Includes an extraordinary tax benefit of $195,000 for both the quarter and year.

title: MARSHALL INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The share earnings are adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split paid July 7.

title: COMMONWEALTH CHIEFS REBUKE THATCHER HARSHLY
description: Commonwealth leaders criticized Britain today after their failure to win Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's support for firm sanctions against South Africa.

title: SENATE REJECTS DEEPER CUTS IN MISSILE DEFENSE PROGRAM
description: The Senate today narrowly rejected two efforts to cut even more deeply into President Reagan's $5.3 billion request for his space-oriented defense against missiles.

title: GIANTS PLAY FALCONS TONIGHT
description: If the Giants are headed for the Super Bowl, as many pro football people predict, they must fight their way through four exhibition, 16 regular-season and two or three playoff games. The long road will begin Wednesday night when they open their preseason campaign against the Falcons.

title: UNR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $109,856 and $205,545 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net loss and includes a loss from discontinued operations of $186,798 and $434,793 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and for both periods, an estimated loss on the disposition of discontinued operations of $5 million.

title: Mavis McIntosh Riordan, 83; Represented Noted Writers
description: Mavis McIntosh Riordan, a longtime literary agent whose clients included John Steinbeck, died Saturday of congestive heart failure in the Ocean Manor nursing home in Scituate, Mass. She was 83 years old. Mrs. Riordan, who was born in Madison, Wis., and attended the University of Wisconsin, came to New York in the 1920's and began her career as a literary agent in 1927, when she established the McIntosh & Otis agency with Elizabeth Otis.

title: Oregon Bills Gorbachev
description: The Oregon Health Division has sent a bill to Mikhail S. Gorbachev for expenses incurred while monitoring radiation levels after the Chernobyl nuclear accident. It cost the division $73,060 to monitor air, rain, drinking water, vegetation and milk when radiation from the disaster drifted over the Pacific Northwest. The state legislative Emergency Board instructed the agency to seek repayment.

title: 200 POLICE OFFICER BEING ADDED TO DIVISION TO COMBAT NARCOTICS
description: More than 200 officers will be added to the New York City Police Department's narcotics division over the next several weeks, bringing the unit to 1,000 officers, the most in the department's history, police officials said yesterday.

title: Court Continues Fruehauf Bidding
description: A Federal appeals court ordered a continuation of the bidding in which investors led by Asher B. Edelman are competing with a management group to buy the Fruehauf Corporation.

title: Room, Board and Bytes
description: Smithsonian Institution employes may be more cerebral than other Washingtonians, or it may be a genuine sign of the times. A classified advertisement in the current issue of The Torch, the Smithsonian house organ, offers an apartment for rent with ''kitchen and computer privileges.''

title: WEST'S SANCTION PLANS: HOW THEY COMPARE
description: As Western governments move to impose economic penalties on South Africa, they have settled on some common elements.

title: Freddie Mac Plans Weekly Auctions
description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, known as Freddie Mac, plans to start selling certificates backed by multifamily mortgages on a weekly basis rather than periodically as it has done in the past.

title: A Final Favor
description: Richie Adubato's legacy to the Knicks, when he left to become an assistant coach for the Dallas Mavericks, may be Alvin (Bo) Dukes, a 5-foot-8-inch free agent. When the Knicks were putting together their rookie and free agent camp, Coach Hubie Brown asked Adubato, an aide, to find a point guard to back up Rory Sparrow.

title: WHEN LOVE FOR A HORSE DEFIES REASON
description: I DON'T smoke, drink or run around with loose men. I keep a horse. The horse was acquired from my 14-year-old son in the same manner that most parents acquire a piano (I have one of those, too): i.e., child wants piano lessons so parent buys piano; child grows disenchanted and parent dusts piano. Both a horse and piano weigh about 1,000 pounds, require a substantial investment and consume much space.

title: Search Unable to Find Plane Believed Lost Over Caribbean
description: A full day's search failed to find a trace of a Twin Otter commercial plane believed to have crashed in the Caribbean with 13 people aboard, officials said today.

title: GENERAL DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
KATY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $280,000 for the quarter and $433,000 for the 6 months; a gain on the sale of discontinued operations of $4,404,000 for the quarter and 6 months, and extraordinary gains of $56,000 and $948,000 from the termination of a pension plan for the quarter and 6 months, respectivley. c-Net income

title: WINE TALK
description: FOR Lucie T. Morton, a ''vine watcher'' and foe of ''grape variety racism,'' America east of the Rockies is the country's ''new wine frontier.'' The region's future, she says, lies in wines made not only from classic European vinifera grapes such as cabernet sauvignon and chardonnay, but also from underappreciated native varieties such as magnolia in Florida, scuppernong in North Carolina, Norton in Missouri, Cynthiana in Arkansas and Delaware in New York.

title: FED NOMINEE EXPECTS RATES TO FALL
description: The Reagan Administration's nominee for the vacant seat on the Federal Reserve Board predicted today that interest rates would continue to fall, and he said he sees room for another cut in the Fed's discount rate.

title: UNIONS REJECT PENSION CRITICISM
description: Union representatives yesterday harshly criticized the City Finance Commissioner, Abraham Biderman, for questioning the way public employee pension funds have been invested.

title: 5,000-Meter Mark Falls
description: Ingrid Kristiansen strengthened her credentials as the world's best female distance runner yesterday when she regained the world record for 5,000 meters by trimming more than 10 seconds off the mark set by Zola Budd last August.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL YANKEES VS. MILWAUKEE BREWERS, at Yankee Stadium, 7:30 P.M. (Television - SportsChannel, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770, 7:30 P.M.) METS VS.

title: Market Place; Allied-Signal's Blurred Image
description: THE past few years have been busy ones for the old Allied Corporation. It has acquired the Bendix Corporation, an auto parts and aerospace company. Also it has owned and sold a big stake in the Martin Marietta Corporation and the RCA Corporation, merged with the Signal Companies, spun off a lot of slower-growth businesses into a new company, the Henley Group, and sold a half interest in its oil and gas operations.

title:
Economic Scene;
The Corporate Links Abroad
description: BEHIND America's staggering, but still growing, trade deficit, a fundamental change is taking place in how trade is conducted.

title: BREWERS DEFEAT YANKEES IN 10TH
description: Dennis Rasmussen made a strong return last night, giving the Yankees the type of starting pitching to which they have not been accustomed. The Yankees, however, still lost, dropping a 10-inning, 2-1 decision to the Milwaukee Brewers.

title: MAKING HEALTHFUL BROTH
description: THAT old kitchen standby, a can of stock or a dried bouillon cube, is uncomfortably salty for modern tastes. Most brands contain monosodium glutamate and salt, and some list salt as the primary ingredient. Low-sodium items have an unfresh taste from the chemicals used. Potassium chloride, monoammonium glutamate, disodium inosinate and disodium guanylate are common. These are not dangerous but leave an unpleasant aftertaste. Only Health Valley Beef Flavored Broth has an acceptable taste and low sodium; it can be found in health food stores.

title: WHERE BLUEBERRIES AND OPTIMISM MIX
description: THE lowbush blueberry is tiny, dark, sharp and sweet - a distinctly Down East fruit. It grows wild, close to the ground in spare soil where little else thrives, concentrating within its small compass far more flavor than the cultivated highbush blueberries grown in gentler climes. Now is the height of the harvest when millions of pounds are headed for the processing factories of eastern Maine.

title: Donnelley's Yellow Pages
description: THE 1984 divestiture of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company not only created competition in the fields of telephone and communications technology, it also unloosened A.T.&T.'s near monopoly on the Yellow Pages telephone directories.

title:
SOME QUESTIONS FOR THE A.B.A.;
Should We Reject the Soviet Bar?
description: American lawyers gathering at the American Bar Association's annual meeting in New York City this week have a chance to right a grievous wrong in its dealings with the Association of Soviet Lawyers. They must decide whether they will continue to lend professional legitimacy to lawyers in a totalitarian police state.

title: AVERY INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
description: b-After a gain of $866,000. The company said the latest quarter and year results include a $697,000 pre-tax charge on the disposal of a leasehold. The year results also include a $2.5 million pre-tax writeoff of a coal processing facility.

title: Real Estate; Murray Hill Renovation
description: LONG a desirable residential neighborhood, Murray Hill, the East Side enclave of low-rise structures and shady streets between 34th and 42d Streets, is emerging as a vital commercial district as its office buildings, restaurants and hotels are upgraded by owners seeking to capitalize on its proximity to midtown.

title: ALVIN R. GRANT
description: Alvin R. Grant, retired senior vice president of Madison Square Garden Center, died of cancer Friday in Palm City, Fla., where he lived since his retirement last November. He was 65 years old and a former resident of Scarborough, N.Y.

title: SHUTTLE PIONEER NAMED MARSHALL'S SPACE CHIEF
description: The man responsible for developing the main engines of the space shuttle and then managing NASA's investigation of the Challenger disaster was named director of the space agency's beleaguered Marshall Space Flight Center in Huntsville, Ala., yesterday.

title: CARPENTER TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After extraordinary charges of $2,138,000 and $3,772,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-After an extraordinary charge of $5,655,000 for both the quarter and year.

title: Bush, Leaving Mideast, Offers Plan for Talks
description: Vice President Bush ended a 10-day trip to the Middle East today by proposing a ''framework'' for negotiations by Egypt, Jordan and Israel.

title: COLUMBIA SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The 1985 share earnings are restated for a distribution of series -A- preferred stock.

title: TREASURIES DROP AFTER OIL PACT
description: Prices for Treasury securities slumped yesterday as the credit markets began weighing the inflation implications of the new OPEC production agreement.

title: Hitting Stride
description: When Don Baylor was hit by a pitch from Jose DeLeon of the Chicago White Sox on Monday night in Boston, it was the 23d time this season that Baylor had reached first base the hard way - by absorbing the impact of a thrown baseball. Baylor is now one behind the American League's single-season record he shares with Bill Freehan of the Detroit Tigers and Norm Eberfeld of the Washington Senators.

title: Split Trial Asked In Donovan Case
description: A co-defendant in the criminal trial of former Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan, Raymond Schiavone, said yesterday that he was suffering from a heart illness and would be unfit to stand trial for a year.

title: HELMS AIDE SAID TO BE THE FOCUS OF INQUIRY ON DISCLOSURE OF DATA
description: The Justice Department investigation of a reported unauthorized disclosure of secret information to the Chilean Government is focusing on an aide to Senator Jesse Helms, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: Oil Stocks Continue to Strengthen
description: Oil stocks continued to dominate the market yesterday. The prices of all major oils were up and they accounted for nine of the 10 most actively traded issues. But, analysts nevertheless found yesterday's market weak and suggested that recent lows may have to be tested before any significant advance could be supported.

title: Coke Dropping Dr Pepper Bid
description: The Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that it was ending its agreement to acquire the Dr Pepper Company, at the request of Forstmann Little & Company, an investment firm that bought Dr Pepper in February 1984.

title: SCREEN: 'NO SURRENDER,' A COMEDY
description: A COMEDY about the murderous warfare between the Protestants and Roman Catholics of Northern Ireland? That, in short, is ''No Surrender,'' but that's too short to do justice to the seriously funny movie that opens today at the Waverly. The intelligent and pungent screenplay by Alan Bleasdale has plenty of laughs, but they come out of despair, like bits of green in a graveyard.

title: BASEBALL ARBITRATOR DISMISSED
description: The Player Relations Committee, the owners' labor arm, dismissed baseball's impartial arbitrator yesterday. The move came as Thomas Roberts, the arbitrator, was conducting a critical hearing into the players' charges that the owners had conspired to restrict the movement of free agents last winter.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 6, 1986
description: International Pretoria will impose trade curbs against black-governed neighboring countries because of new economic sanctions against South Africa imposed by the Commonwealth. Foreign Minister Roelof F. Botha said the new economic countermeasures would include import licenses, a levy on goods traveling across the country and stricter frontier controls. [ Page A1, Column 1. ] 13 more U.S.-Soviet exchanges have resulted from the meeting last November held by President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev. The agreements on educational, scientific and cultural exchanges bring them to a higher level than that of late 1979, when President Carter cut them off to protest the Soviet intervention in Afghanistan. [ A1:2. ] Malta gave Libya advance notice of the American air attack in April and would do so again if it had similar information, Prime Minister Karmenu Mifsud Bonnici said in an interview. He said Maltese air controllers had notified Libyan controllers soon after the detection that ''a number of unidentified planes'' were flying toward North Africa. [ A1:3. ] American Army actions in Bolivia have dramatically cut cocaine trafficking, and Washington is considering providing more economic aid to Bolivia, according to the American ambassador in La Paz. Bolivian officials say the decreased cocaine production has seriously damaged the nation's economy. [ B4:1-3. ] National The Administration retreated and agreed to give the Senate Judiciary Committee access to memorandums and legal opinions prepared by William H. Rehnquist when he was a Justice Department official in the Nixon Administration. The action came after 10 Senators, all eight Democrats on the panel and two of its Republicans, got ready to vote to issue a subpoena for the material.

title: U.S. Criticizes OPEC Agreement
description: The Reagan Administration yesterday criticized the OPEC agreement to increase oil prices by limiting production as unwarranted interference in the free market and a possible threat to national interests.

title: More Tests for Wynegar
description: The agent for Butch Wynegar lifted some of the mystery surrounding the catcher's departure from the Yankees, issuing a statement before last night's game that said Wynegar had been ''emotionally confused'' and ''distraught'' and was undergoing ''intensive medical and psychiatric review.'' Ron Shapiro, Wynegar's Baltimore-based agent, said: ''Butch has been very emotionally confused for the past month, and last week he became distraught and withdrawn to the point of not being able to play baseball.

title: President Resigns Western Air Post
description: Western Airlines said yesterday that Robin H. H. Wilson had resigned as president and chief operating officer, effective immediately. Donald J. Lloyd-Jones, who has worked as a consultant to Western and other companies since 1984, will succeed Mr. Wilson.

title: Ranger Rooter
description: Phil Esposito, the new vice president and general manager of the Rangers, made clear in bold tones the enthusiasm he hopes will permeate his ''new Rangers generation'' at an informal meeting with reporters yesterday at Madison Square Garden.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article and a picture caption yesterday about a concert in Central Park included an erroneous date supplied by the New York Philharmonic for Leonard Bernstein's most recent previous appearance there with the orchestra. It was July 4, 1976.

title: Digital Models
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation has introduced two new members of its VAX line of minicomputers.

title: No Headline
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: PUBLIC SERVICE CO OF NEW MEXICO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
The Perils of Byrd
description: Though Senator Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia does not have to run for re-election this fall, he has plenty of political problems on his plate. He faces the challenge in November of helping Democratic colleagues regain majority control of the Senate, which would require a net gain of four seats and could enable him to shift his title from minority to majority leader.

title: AVANTI! QUALITY ITALIAN WINES SHOW THEIR COLORS
description: THERE was a time within the memory of many over-40 Americans when Italian wine was something rough and red that came in a straw-covered flask and was served mostly in spaghetti joints and pizza parlors on the outskirts of college towns. In those days you took the empty bottle back to a dormitory room where, with a candle stuck in its neck, it was an unmistakable badge of sophomore sophistication.

title: RED SOX CONTINUE TO SLIP
description: Carlton Fisk and Harold Baines hit home runs, and Richard Dotson pitched three-hit ball for seven innings tonight as the Chicago White Sox spoiled the return of Dennis (Oil Can) Boyd with a 3-1 victory over the Boston Red Sox.

title: SERGE VERHOVSKOY
description: Serge Verhovskoy, professor emeritus at St. Vladimir's Orthodox Theology Seminary, died Monday at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 79 years old.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The blacks will pay, not Australia, the Commonwealth, the European Community.'' - Foreign Minister Roelof F. Botha of South Africa. [ A1:1. ]

title: ANN BREWER CLIFT
description: Ann Brewer Clift, an artist and Red Cross volunteer who devoted more than 5,000 hours to teaching art to mental patients during the 1950's and 1960's, died of liver cancer Friday at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan. She was 75 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: SENATE UNIT WINS ACCESS TO MEMOS REHNQUIST WROTE
description: The Reagan Administration backed down today and agreed to give the Senate Judiciary Committee access to memorandums and legal opinions prepared by William H. Rehnquist when he was a Justice Department official in the Nixon Administration.

title: Suspect in Ship Death Was Held as Stowaway
description: A mother and her 18-month-old daughter were under guard as suspected stowaways hours before the child died in their cruise ship cabin, according to court documents released today.

title: TEXTRON MAKES OFFER TO ACQUIRE EX-CELL-O
description: Textron Inc. offered to buy the Ex-Cell-O Corporation yesterday for at least $68 a share in cash, or a total of $972 million.

title: Chiefs Sign Top Pick
description: Brian Jozwiak, the first-round draft choice of the Kansas City Chiefs from West Virginia, ended a 19-day holdout by signing a series of contracts.

title: The Starting Line
description: It won't be in the same class as the Tour de France, but New York will stage its first professional cycling race next month with hopes that it may blossom into an annual event that will attract a top international field by 1988.

title: ALABAMA DEMOCRAT SEES NO NEW RUNOFF
description: With Gov. George C. Wallace retiring, this was to be the summer of a new beginning in Alabama politics, a chance for voters to choose a fresh face to lead the state into the 1990's. But so far the new era has got off to a false start.

title: Hitting Stride
description: When Don Baylor was hit by a pitch from Jose DeLeon of the Chicago White Sox on Monday night in Boston, it was the 23d time this season that Baylor had reached first base the hard way - by absorbing the impact of a thrown baseball. Baylor is now one behind the American League's single-season record he shares with Bill Freehan of the Detroit Tigers and Norm Eberfeld of the Washington Senators.

title: CONFEREES REMAIN DIVIDED ON BUSINESS TAXES
description: House and Senate tax conferees remained divided today on the pivotal issue of how much to raise taxes on business, but most of the lawmakers said they thought they could eventually reach an agreement.

title: No Headline
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Thatcher in Hospital For Hand Operation
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher entered a London hospital for a one-hour operation on her hand today.

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: THE most hateful words I've heard in the last three years were ''He'll need surgery.'' It was not major surgery, thank God; we brought him in early in the morning and carried him out at sunset. But giving anyone permission to open up the blue-white body of your 2-year-old is dreadful. I even held him while they administered the anesthesia, a bright idea I pursued with great parental indignation for the sake (allegedly) of the child's psychological well-being, so that he would not be surrounded by strangers.

title: ROBERT FROST WHITNEY
description: Robert Frost Whitney, a former reporter and editor in Washington for both The Washington Post and The New York Times, died Sunday at the Westminster Canterbury House, a retirement home, in Richmond.

title: No Headline
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Early Oil Price Climb Cut in Record Trading
description: Prices of crude oil and petroleum products gyrated wildly on world oil markets yesterday as participants continued to grapple with the long-term import of OPEC's new accord.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Alumax Inc., San Mateo, Calif., an aluminum company, has named Paul E. Drack president and chief executive, effective Aug. 15.

title: On Blacks in Office
description: The number of blacks elected to office in the United States rose from 6,056 to 6,424 in 1985, or a little more than 6 percent, but that figure is less than a cause for rejoicing at the Joint Center for Political Studies, the research group that compiled it. The center says blacks now constitute 11 percent of the country's population of voting age but still hold less than 1.5 percent of its elective offices.

title: PRICE BLUR AT END OF OIL ACCORD
description: Even as some non-OPEC nations agreed to cut their oil production, OPEC ministers from several Persian Gulf countries suggested today that a new collapse of oil prices could result when the organization's new accord expires Oct. 31.

title: Zayre Foresees 44% Drop in Net
description: The Zayre Corporation, one of the nation's largest discount retailers, said that it expects a 44 percent decline in net income for the second quarter, a sharp departure from previous forecasts from analysts. Maurice Segall, Zayre's president and chief executive, said that the net income for the quarter, which ended July 26, was estimated at $9 million, or 15 cents a share, before an extraordinary charge of 6 cents.

title: Minority Rule
description: To the Editor:

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: THE problem of bedsores is not one that the medical profession likes to think about.

title: HARSH WORDS ON FLOOR BETWEEN DOLE AND BYRD
description: A simmering dispute between Senator Bob Dole, the majority leader, and Senator Robert C. Byrd, the minority leader, boiled over tonight in a highly unusual display of irritation and insult on the Senate floor.

title: Police Officer Drowns In River Rescue Attempt
description: A highly decorated police officer drowned Monday in the Anacostia River in an attempt to save a mental patient who leaped off the 11th Street Bridge and fell nearly 45 feet into the murky river.

title: Players Seek Releases
description: With the United States Football League's season canceled and with the start of the National Football League's season just over a month away, agents representing top players under contract to U.S.F.L. teams were scrambling yesterday to obtain releases from the clubs so they could begin negotiating with N.F.L. teams. At the same time, Doug Allen, the executive director of the United States Football League Players Association, was preparing to meet tomorrow with the U.S.F.L. owners' representative, Larry Csonka, in hopes of working out an arrangement that would clear the way for U.S.F.L. players to join the N.F.L.

title: Panel to Look at Role Of Board of Estimate
description: The Manhattan Borough President, David N. Dinkins, said yesterday that he had formed a six-member commission to examine the role of the Board of Estimate and to consider alternative ways of organizing the board.

title: 3 ARRESTED IN 2D BRONX ATTACK
description: Three Hispanic youths were arrested in the Belmont section of the Bronx last night and charged with beating two Yugoslav brothers with a baseball bat Sunday night in what the police said was apparently in retaliation for an assault last week on two Puerto Rican youths.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: REMEMBERING THE SPITBALL Does anyone else in New York know what it is to play ball at twilight? To stand in an enormous country yard And be taught to thro w a spitball by your favorite uncle? To be the youngest of five boys and to have your uncle teach only yo u The Pitch.So you can beat your Hercules brothers Just Once. J.E. HARRIS

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SOUNDS AND MOTION Olu Dara is a jazz trumpeter who has been identified with the local avant-gardists - David Murray and Hamiet Bluiett. He is from southern Mississippi, and his music reflects this background in addition to being a combination of jazz, funk and African idioms. He leads a group called the Okra Orchestra, which has sometimes been subtitled an ''exotic rhythm band.''

title: McEnroe Speaks Out Again
description: If he were in search of answers, then the six-month sabbatical John McEnroe took from tennis only served to raise more questions. He has returned feeling like a boxer, he said, facing a barrage of punches in the first round, each one a blur. And just like always, McEnroe doesn't choose to duck.

title: JOBS PLAN EXPANDS AT SHELTERS
description: With proof of its success beside him - two men who were once destitute and now have jobs - Mayor Koch yesterday morning announced that the city would expand a pilot program intended to help residents of city shelters find work.

title: PARIS HOUSES OFFER FRIVOLITY MARRIED TO HIGH FASHION
description: A LIVELY spirit permeated the Paris couture shows for fall and winter last week because of the efforts of Christian Lacroix for Jean Patou. For the first time in many years, a new designer made an impact on the venerable couture industry. Some of his design exuberance spilled over into the collections of other houses.

title: LUCAS LEADS IN MICHIGAN RACE
description: William Lucas, the Wayne County Executive who seeks to become the nation's first elected black governor, appeared to be leading in the race for Michigan's Republican gubernatorial nomination tonight.

title: Ashton-Tate Deal
description: The Ashton-Tate Company said it would buy privately held Decision Resources Inc. for $13 million. Both companies produce software for machines compatible with International Business Machines Corporation computers. Decision Resources, a five-year-old company based in Westport, Conn., specializes in business graphics software and earned $933,000 in 1985 on sales of $9.5 million.

title: JETS SORTING OUT LINEBACKERS
description: Much was made over the Jets' drafting four offensive tackles last spring, using their first two picks for Mike Haight of Iowa and Doug Williams of Texas A&M. So much so, in fact, that much less notice was paid to the fact that they also drafted four linebackers.

title: Moving Outdoors At Lincoln Center
description: Lincoln Center moved outside yesterday, spreading music and dance into the adjacent plazas and Damrosch Park.

title: Pan Am's Loss: $152.4 Million
description: The Pan Am Corporation, citing the severe impact of weak trans-Atlantic air passenger traffic, said yesterday that it had lost $152.4 million in the second quarter, more than twice the deficit it registered a year ago.

title: REAGAN PREDICTS IMPACT OF JUDICIAL APPOINTEES
description: President Reagan said today that by the end of his second term 45 percent of all Federal judges would be his appointees whose decisions on abortion, pornography, crime and other issues would have a long-range impact.

title: Head of Del Monte Unit Moves to Tofutti Brands
description: Francis I. Mullin 3d, the president of Del Monte Franchise Beverages U.S.A. in Atlanta, was named president and chief operating officer of Tofutti Brands Inc. yesterday, titles previously held by David Mintz, Tofutti's chairman, chief executive and founder.

title: Franciscans Find Site On 8th Ave. for New Shelter
description: The dream of three Franciscan priests to turn money from the city into a residence for mentally disabled homeless people is to move a step closer to reality tomorrow, when St. Francis Friends of the Poor takes title to a dilapidated building in Chelsea.

title: Arco to Sell Part Of Chemicals Unit
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company said it had agreed to sell about one-fifth of its $2 billion-a-year chemicals division to privately held Horsehead Industries Inc. Terms of the deal with Horsehead, a diversified manufacturer based in New York, were not disclosed.

title: Two Papuan Ministers Quit
description: Tom Muliap, Minister of the Environment, and Aruru Matiabe, Minister of Education, resigned today to avoid embarrassment to the Government because of criminal charges they face. Mr. Muliap has been accused of drunken driving, and Mr. Matiabe of misappropriating Government funds.

title: FORECAST 1979 GASOLINE SHORTAGE
description: Dan Lundberg, the oil industry analyst who accurately forecast the 1979 gasoline shortage and whose biweekly survey of nationwide gasoline prices was widely quoted, died Sunday at a Torrance hospital, where he was taken after becoming ill on Santa Catalina Island, his wife, Mesa, said. He was 73 years old.

title: OWENS BID BY WICKES REPORTED
description: The Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation, a major manufacturer of building materials, has received a takeover offer from the Wickes Companies, a rapidly expanding West Coast conglomerate, according to Wall Street sources.

title: 'VISIBLE TARGET,' ON NISEI INTERNMENT
description: ''VISIBLE TARGET'' is wondrously well done, a film that should be seen. It takes an often-told story -the internment of Japanese-Americans during World War II - and invests it with new meaning. The 30-minute documentary, on Channel 13 at 11 o'clock tonight, is free from cliche.

title: Foreign Students and U.S. Largess
description: When the Agency for International Development started bringing students from developing nations to the United States 20 years ago, the goal was to immerse them in the American system.

title: LASER PRECISION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: SOUTH CAROLINA FEDERAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago share earnings are not available; the company went public June 30.

title: MARKET FACTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
DREYER'S GRAND ICE CREAM reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
COLUMBIA GAS SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an after-tax charge of $10.3 million to record a writedown of the carrying value of Canadian oil and gas properties for both the quarter and 6 months, and the 6-month period also includes an after-tax charge of $38.8 million to increase the reserve for unrecovered gas purchased costs. c-Net loss d-Includes an after-tax charge of $207 million establishing a reserve for unrecovered gas purchased costs.

title: SOUND WAREHOUSE reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
BIOCRAFT LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Down at the Wollman
description: As he walked onto the construction site at the Wollman Memorial Skating Rink in Central Park yesterday, Donald J. Trump was being stripped of one property he has never had.

title: CABLEVISION SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge from the redemption of debentures of $11,268,000 for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: Dept. of Pen and Sword
description: A new newsletter, Kwacha News, has appeared in Washington, a publication of the Free Angola Information Service, the educational arm of the Union for the Total Independence of Angola.

title: ORANGE COUNTY, ONCE BUCOLIC, NOW BUSTLES
description: Two years ago, when the Amannas moved into the spacious, hilltop house they had designed themselves, with a formal parlor, an airy kitchen and land for the family's four horses, they thought they had come to this quiet corner of Orange County to stay.

title: BEATRICE UNIT'S SALE IS REPORTED
description: The BCI Holdings Corporation has sold the Beatrice Companies' personal products division - which includes Playtex products, Jhirmack hair care and Almay cosmetics - for more than $1 billion, industry sources said yesterday.

title: NEW SKULL FINDING CHALLENGES VIEWS
description: A 2.5-million-year-old skull, found last year in Africa by American and Kenyan scientists, may shake some old branches on the family tree of early man, the discoverers of the skull said yesterday.

title: CARLTON DECIDES TO RETIRE ON A MILESTONE
description: Steve Carlton, a four-time Cy Young Award winner, announced his retirement today, the day after he collected his 4,000th career strikeout.

title: INSPIRATION RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $3.4 million for the quarter and $1.8 million for the 6 months. c-After an extraordinary gain of $7.5 million from the adoption of FASB No. 87 and 88 with respect to the company's Canadian pension plans.

title: President Resigns Post With Chi-Chi's Chain
description: Joseph P. Smaha, president and chief operating officer of Chi-Chi's Inc., the Mexican-food restaurant chain, resigned yesterday to pursue personal business interests. The resignation is effective Sept. 1.

title: MUSIC: LOS VECINOS AT S.O.B.'S
description: NEW YORK CITY has a world-class merengue band with a modern twist -Milly, Jocelyn y los Vecinos (the Neighbors). The group played Tuesday at Sounds of Brazil as a preview of its 13th album, ''Special Delivery.''

title: Presidential Air
description: Presidential Airways said it had completed its acquisition of the commuter carrier Colgan Airways.

title: Farmer in the Limelight
description: Except for ranking members like, say, Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., members of the House of Representatives don't hold many fund-raising events in Washington. When they do, they don't normally attract luminaries from the Senate like Edward M. Kennedy, Gary Hart, John Glenn, Dale Bumpers, Jim Sasser and Thomas F. Eagleton.

title: SOUTHWEST GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
RIBI IMMUNOCHEM RESEARCH reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
IEC ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
WINFIELD PACES YANK VICTORY
description: Now that the Mets have released George Foster, Dave Winfield is the highest-paid player in New York who has to wonder whether he will be in the lineup on a given night. Winfield, though, may have earned himself another start with his performance last night.

title: BAY STATE GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a loss of $2,262,000 from discontinued operations. The company said it changed its year to end Sept. 30 instead of Dec. 31.

title: IRANIAN-SAUDI TALKS CREATED OPEC PACT
description: The agreement reached this week by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries was fundamentally a political accord forged in hours of bitter haggling by the oil ministers of Saudi Arabia and Iran, according to ministers and delegates who took part in the eight days of negotiations that ended here Tuesday.

title: 119 Aliens Are Arrested Living Under Highways
description: Federal agents arrested 119 suspected illegal aliens from an encampment under a freeway interchange today and found jewelry and other property believed to have been stolen, the authorities said.

title: DEATHS OF TWO IN HOTEL ROOM AT CASINO LINKED TO CYANIDE
description: Two Atlantic Community College students whose bodies were found in an Atlantic City casino hotel room in May died of acute cyanide poisoning, and investigators are treating the deaths as homicides, the Atlantic County Prosecutor announced yesterday.

title: OPERA: SANTE FE OFFERS LUDLAM'S 'FLEDERMAUS'
description: In the Santa Fe Opera's new production of ''Die Fledermaus,'' two schools of humor collide. The smile and the belly laugh compete fiercely here, and at Tuesday night's performance - played in the cool desert air of this ever-fascinating performance space - the latter combatant seems to have won.

title: ITT FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: ITT Financial is a unit of ITT Corp.

title: RECYCLING WORRIES ON PLASTIC BOTTLES
description: ON the side of a can recently tested by the Coca-Cola Company the words ''recyclable plastic'' are written in bold letters. But the plastic can, which has been test-marketed in Columbus, Ga., has raised concerns among environmentalists and recycling experts.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The Municipal Assistance Corporation for the City of New York is tentatively offering $392 million of refunding bonds, Series 59, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

title: Guess Who's on Deck
description: The Library of Congress is putting Casey at the bat again.

title: BETHLEHEM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-The company broke even.

title: TISCH, NEW POSTMASTER, GIVES HIS VIEWS OF THE JOB
description: Preston Robert Tisch was formally introduced here today by the United States Postal Service as the nation's new Postmaster General and immediately indicated that he felt he was in charge.

title: Stocks Close Mixed; Dow Up 2.53
description: Stock prices ended mixed yesterday, as caution over the Treasury's three-part refunding helped stymie activity.

title: ORION RESEARCH INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
description: b-Net income and includes a tax credit of $61,000, or 2 cents a share.

title: Advertising; The Public Relations Takeovers
description: ADVERTISING agencies that have been scooping up public relations concerns in recent years may slow down a bit after Tuesday's acquisition of the No. 3 public relations agency, Carl Byoir & Associates, by the No. 2 public relations agency, Hill & Knowlton, a subsidiary of the JWT Group.

title: NAC RE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $2,083,000 and $2,078,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes realized investment gains of $1,884,000 and $2,112,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: FAMOUS RESTAURANTS reports earnings for Qtr to July 13
description: The company said the results include tax credits of $230,000 and $505,000 for the latest quarter and 6 months, respectively, and $131,000 and $352,000 for the year-ago quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: GARDENAMERICA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $342,000 for the quarter and $1,812,000 for the 9 months and a gain of $1,769,000 on the disposal of discontinued operations for the quarter and 9 months.

title: DNA PLANT TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: EQUAL EMPLOYMENT OFFICIAL WINS APPROVAL FOR 2d TERM
description: Clarence Thomas, whose leadership of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission has been criticized by civil rights groups, won overwhelming bipartisan approval today for a second four-year term as chairman.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL YANKEES VS. MILWAUKEE BREWERS, at Yankee Stadium, 7:30 P.M. (Television - Channel 11, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770, 7:30 P.M.) METS VS.

title: WALKER, HIRAM RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income c-After tax credits of $11 million and $27 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. d-After tax credits of $4 million. The company said the decrease in earnings in the latest 9 months resulted primarily from $42 million and $66 million lower earnings from operations in the distilled spirits and natural resource segments, respectively; $21 million in higher finance charges; and $35 million of costs incurred in connection with the company's response to the events leading up to the acquisition of a majority interest in the company by Gulf Canada Corp.

title: NORTH CAROLINA DEMOCRATS ASSAIL OPPONENTS ON LOSS OF TEXTILE BILL
description: In North Carolina, which has lost 17,000 textile jobs in the last 18 months, Democrats moved quickly today to accuse the Republican Party of responsibility for Congress's failure to save legislation to help the textile industry.

title: YEARLONG SOVIET ATOM-TEST HALT EXPIRES
description: A yearlong Soviet halt in testing nuclear weapons expired today, on the anniversary of the 1945 atomic bombing of Hiroshima.

title: Anderson, Clayton Offer
description: Two New York investment firms yesterday sweetened their cash offer to buy Anderson, Clayton & Company, to $56 a share, or about $683 million. The firms, Bear, Stearns &

title: Law on Takeover Of Queens Utility
description: Governor Cuomo announced yesterday that he had signed into law a bill that requires New York City to take over most of the Jamaica Water Supply Company. The bill's sponsors have said the takeover will eventually open the way for the company's 90,000 Queens customers to begin receiving water from the city's upstate reservoirs rather than from the company's outmoded wells.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, AUGUST 7, 1986
description: Companies

title: SAMUEL COLT
description: Samuel Barrymore Colt, a member of the theatrical family, died last Friday at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 76 years old.

title: NEVADA POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CORCOM INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: LEAR SIEGLER INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a $31 million after-tax charge to increase the company's aircraft product liability reserve and an after-tax gain of about $17 million from the disposition of six operations for the quarter and year.

title: METS TO DROP FOSTER AMID RACIAL CONTROVERSY
description: George Foster's career with the Mets came to a controversial close today after the 37-year-old power hitter got into a dispute with Manager Dave Johnson over Foster's remarks on racial influences in baseball.

title: PACIFICARE HEALTH SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HOUSE BACKS VETO OF BILL TO CURTAIL IMPORTED TEXTILES
description: The House of Representatives voted today to uphold President Reagan's veto of a bill that would have placed strict limits on imports of textiles from 12 countries, most of them in Asia.

title: Company Policy
description: When Robert Wick Public Relations entered a team in the Corporate Challenge race in Central Park on Tuesday night, the whole company competed.

title: D.D.B. Group Reports 12.1% Drop in Income
description: The Doyle Dane Bernbach Group yesterday reported a 12.1 percent decline in net income in the second quarter compared with the year before despite a 9.2 percent gain in revenues.

title: Dept. of Twisted Arms
description: Representative Duncan L. Hunter, a third-term Republican from California, was taken aback a few days ago when he telephoned Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger to talk about strategic home porting of Navy vessels, an issue of some interest to Mr. Hunter as a member of the Armed Services Committee. He managed to make most of his points, but Mr. Weinberger suddenly made it clear he wanted to talk about something else: Mr. Hunter's position on efforts to override President Reagan's veto of the textile trade bill.

title: TEXAS LEGISLATURE MEETS TO CONFRONT HARD TIMES
description: Saying that Texans faced the ''hardest times of our lives,'' Gov. Mark White today called on the State Legislature to pass an ''emergency temporary'' increase in the sales tax, cut government spending substantially and trim the pay of state employees 3 percent.

title: DATRON SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MOORE CORP LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: All figures are in U.S. funds.

title: BURST AGRITECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net income

title: GIANTS DEFEATED IN PRESEASON DEBUT
description: The Giants gained 473 yards tonight, the Falcons only 179. Phil Simms of the Giants threw picture-play touchdown passes of 42 yards to Lionel Manuel and 35 yards to Bobby Johnson for the first two touchdowns of the game.

title: Senate Gets Impeachment Bill
description: A House delegation walked to the Senate today and formally presented charges of ''high crimes and misdemeanors'' against Federal District Judge Harry E. Claiborne, clearing the way for the first Senate impeachment trial in more than half a century.

title: Timothy Dalton Chosen As New James Bond
description: The British actor Timothy Dalton has been named to replace Roger Moore as James Bond in the 25th anniversary film about Ian Fleming's dashing secret agent, producer Albert Broccoli said today.

title: EX-AIDES CHARGE BROOKLYN COLLEGE VIOLATED RULES
description: When Brooklyn College's athletic program jumped from Division III to Division I four years ago, many people at the school dreamed of the glory of big-time sports. But the dream is threatening to become a nightmare, with only the problems big-time.

title: COIN PHONES reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The company is a development stage enterprise and went public in June.

title: NEWHALL INVESTMENT PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain on the sale of property of $14,162,000 and $16,086,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes a gain on the sale of property of $2,805,000 for both periods.

title: Sense, Nonsense and Chemical Warfare
description: In July 1944, when Allied bombing failed to knock out the German V-2 missile sites then nearing completion, Winston Churchill was so agitated by the impending threat that he urged an attack with poison gas. General Eisenhower dismissed the idea out of hand. ''Let's, for God's sake, keep our eyes on the ball and use some sense,'' he replied.

title: Ex-New Yorker
description: At Madison Square Garden, where he starred as an all-America sharpshooter for St. John's, Chris Mullin denied reports yesterday that he had been unhappy in his National Basketball Association rookie season with the Golden State Warriors and hoped to be traded to the Knicks.

title: Touche Ross Appoints
description: Touche Ross & Company, the national accounting firm, said yesterday that it had elected Daniel J. Kelly, currently in charge of the firm's Michigan practice, as chairman. Mr. Kelly, 50 years old, succeeds W. Grant Gregory, who previously announced his intention to retire. Mr. Kelly will be working with Edward A. Kangas, who continues as chief executive.

title: Drug Deals, and Wheels
description: The same Federal law allowing the seizure of Lamborghinis and stretch limos from big-time drug merchants also permits confiscating the cars of small-time crack users. New York officials are starting to do just that, and good for them. Car seizure is a heavy penalty, but crack is a heavy drug.

title: CIPRICO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CLEAR CHANNEL COMMUNICAIONS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TRUMP WON'T KEEP PLAYERS FROM N.F.L.
description: Donald Trump, the owner of the Generals, said yesterday he would not try to keep his three star players, Herschel Walker, Doug Flutie and Jim Kelly, from joining the National Football League in the wake of the cancellation of the United States Football League's 1986 season.

title: KEEPING INSECTS AWAY
description: HOMEOWNERS who want to use their patios or yards at this time of year are often faced with the problem of flying insects that bite, sting or buzz around annoyingly.

title: KIM WILLIAMS, COMMENTATOR AND WRITER, DIES IN MONTANA
description: Kim Williams, a naturalist, writer and guest commentator on National Public Radio's daily news program ''All Things Considered,'' died of cancer yesterday at her home in Missoula, Mont. She was 62 years old.

title: SUMITOMO OF JAPAN PLANS TO BUY A STAKE IN GOLDMAN, SACHS
description: Goldman, Sachs & Company, a premier investment banking house and one of the last independent partnerships on Wall Street, announced yesterday that it was negotiating to sell a large stake to the Sumitomo Bank Ltd., Japan's - and the world's - third-largest bank.

title: HERS
description: MY house has a cat door. The smallest, smartest and most elegant of the cats disdains the cat door. She regards it, I think, as a kind of service entrance. The other cats use it in their varying styles. The smallest cat's son raises the cat door's flap with a stiffened forepaw, takes a shifty at the landscape - right, left - closes his eyes, tilts his chin and dives outdoors, launching himself like a swimmer entering an icy sea. The most trusting cat tumbles out and tumbles in shouting, ''I'm leaving!'' ''I'm home!'' The raccoon uses the cat door. The raccoon is in no sense a pet. It is not my racoon. And yet it is not not my raccoon either. The raccoon as a house guest is a mess, but considered purely as a raccoon the raccoon is a major hit. I am crazy about this raccoon, but as my mother used to say in not wholly dissimilar contexts, he can't see me for dust.

The year-ago 6 months revenue includes $28 million and the year-ago 6 months pre-tax income includes $200,000 relating to a foreign subsidiary sold in 1986. The year-ago second quarter revenue includes $17.4 million and the year-ago second quarter pre-tax net includes $1.4 million related to the foreign subsidiary sold in 1986. They announced two-year contract extensions yesterday for both Max McNab, the general manager, and Doug Carpenter, the coach, added Ron Smith from Team Canada as associate coach and signed three free agents.

title: G.M. TO CLOSE A PARTS PLANT AND LAY OFF 1,200 UPSTATE
description: The General Motors Corporation announced yesterday that it would gradually end its engine parts foundry operation in Massena, N.Y., over the next two years, leaving 1,200 of the plant's 1,300 employees at least temporarily out of work.

title: City-Builder Pact On an Esplanade
description: A developer has agreed to build a two-block esplanade on the East River between 36th and 38th Streets in return for permission to construct about 40 extra apartments in a new 43-story building.

Packwood Tax Effort
description: In an effort to move the tax conferees closer to a final bill, Senator Bob Packwood suggested a plan tonight that would increase business taxes $119 billion over the next five years.

description: President Reagan, overruling his budget advisers, has ordered continued buying of crude oil for the Strategic Petroleum Reserve and directed that purchases be accelerated when prices are low, it was announced today.

title: Soccer Fans Riot Over Demotion
description: Fans of the soccer club Lazio hurled stones and smashed windows today because their team was demoted to the league's Third Division as the result of a game-fixing scandal in Italian soccer. Lazio was one of three teams demoted Tuesday after a five-day hearing into charges that at least six First Division and 26 Second Division games were rigged last season.

description: ''We will not take away the eyeglasses and the canes and the crutches of the people who need them.

title: Shell Raises Prices in East
description: The Shell Oil Company has increased its wholesale price of gasoline in markets east of the Rocky Mountains, but the Houston-based company said the move was not related to the OPEC agreement limiting production. Shell said it had increased wholesale prices by 9 cents in the Indianapolis area and by 1 to 2 cents in other markets.

title: RECORD SHOWS NASA AIDE TOLD OF DOUBT ON SEALS
description: Only 10 days after the Challenger disaster, the program manager for the space shuttle told a Presidential commission in closed session that the space agency suspected for nearly a year that cold temperatures could touch off the erosion of critical safety seals on the shuttle's solid fuel rockets.

title: UNCOMMON WINDUP FOR JOHN
description: For one frightening instance in the first inning of his previous start, as a line drive rocketed toward his left calf, it was not unreasonable to wonder if the baseball career of Tommy John would end on a mound in Lakeland, Fla., in the first inning of a Class A game.

title: 276-149 HOUSE ROLL-CALL VOTE
description: Following is the roll-call vote of 276 to 149 by which the House of Representatives today sustained President Reagan's veto of rollbacks in textile and apparel imports. A ''yes'' vote is a vote to override the veto.

title: 50% CADILLAC FAIRVIEW STAKE FOR SALE
description: Cemp Investments Ltd., a Bronfman family concern, said yesterday that it had decided to sell its majority interest in the Cadillac Fairview Corporation, the largest publicly traded real estate development and management company in the United States and Canada.

title: BUSH CLAIMS CLEAR VICTORY IN MICHIGAN VOTE
description: Vice President Bush today claimed a clear victory in Michigan's election Tuesday of precinct delegates to start the process of selecting the Republican Presidential nominee, based on early returns and polling data.

title: Cash Positions: New Views
description: BECAUSE equity mutual fund managers are paid to invest their shareholders' money and not sit on it, many analysts have traditionally viewed high cash holdings as potentially strong upward pressure on the market. But that view is changing, as analysts begin to inspect more closely which kinds of funds hold most of the cash.
