description: William J. Schroeder, who died yesterday after surviving 620 days with a permanent artificial heart, had been given little more than a week to live when he became the second recipient of the device in an operation on Nov. 25, 1984, at Humana Hospital-Audubon in Louisville, Ky.

title: ETHER, TIED TO DRUGS, FOUND IN QUEENS
description: Fifty one-gallon and five-gallon cans of volatile ether and acetone, suspected of having been used to make cocaine, were found in a wooded area off a Queens street yesterday, reflecting what law-enforcement authorities believe has been a big increase in the processing of raw cocaine in the New York metropolitan area.

title: ROHATYNS PLAN TO ASSIST A CLASS OF POOR CHILDREN
description: Felix G. and Elizabeth Rohatyn, critics of ostentatious charity balls, said yesterday that they planned to join a philanthropic trend that involves a personal commitment as well as a financial one.

title: ARTS INSPIRE CRAFTS AT HAMPTONS SHOW
description: Today's functional crafts may look like ancient architecture, collage paintings or even beings from science fiction movies, as arts furnish unconventional sources of inspiration. You can no longer say, Gertrude Stein fashion, ''A lamp is a lamp is a lamp.'' In two current exhibitions in the Hamptons, a lighting fixture by Ron Puckett resembles a Grecian pedestal, while C.S. Designs uses an angular metal sculpture to enclose a spotlight.

GARDENING: CITY: What to Do in August;
BEATING THE HEAT, TENDING LAWNS
description: WITH the city's buildings and streets acting as a massive solar collector, gardens on rooftops and balconies now become subject to almost desertlike conditions. Even after a good August rain, soil in terrace planters quickly turns dry as the sands. So an urban gardener's primary duty now is diligent watering.

Getting Into Swim of Things
description: Today is Dave Horning's 38th birthday and to celebrate he had planned three hurried but salubrious dips in a trio of widely separated bodies of water until a late weather forecast postponed them for a day.

title: A DOCUMENTARY SERIES, 'HAMMER AND THE CROSS'
description: ''THE HAMMER AND THE CROSS,'' a four-part series, examines the conflict between Christianity and Communism, two of this century's great antagonistic forces. The first episode suggests, however, that the conflict isn't really a conflict; it's a search for mutual accommodation. Anyone who thinks otherwise, apparently, is benighted. The series begins on Channel 13 at 10 o'clock tonight.

ISRAELIS' PARDONS IN SCANDAL UPHELD
description: In a move that may prevent the spread of a major scandal, Israel's Supreme Court today upheld the legality of presidential pardons given the head of the country's domestic intelligence service and three aides in the deaths of two captured Palestinian bus hijackers.

title: Get It Right for Once
description: ONE of the features of every Congressional election cycle is the attention focused on the increased amounts of money spent on various campaigns, where it came from and what it all means for the integrity of the legislative process. Congress then attempts to grapple with the problem, but inevitably fails because there is no consensus on what should be done. The problem then gets worse next time around and the process starts anew.

title: HIRSCHFELD SAYS ACCENT REMARK WAS JUST A JOKE
description: Abraham Hirschfeld's thick Eastern European accent has become an issue in the race for lieutenant governor of New York, either, as his opponents say, because Mr. Hirschfeld is exploiting his Jewish heritage for political advantage or, as Mr. Hirschfeld said, because his sense of humor was misunderstood.

title: OIL MARKET STABILIZES, IGNORING BIG INVENTORY
description: The oil market yesterday shrugged off an industry report showing increases in crude oil and product inventories. The market seemed to steady after two days of volatile trading and sharp price increases sparked by the OPEC production-limiting agreement.

title: NAVY PORT FOR S.I. BACKED IN SENATE
description: The Senate, over the objections of the Pentagon, today approved a proposal to create a joint command for the military's special operations forces.

title: JAPANESE MAVERICK EXPANDS
description: Japan's Sumitomo Bank, which is negotiating to acquire a stake in Goldman, Sachs & Company, is not a familiar name in America. But it is the third-largest bank in the world and has a reputation as an innovative and highly profitable maverick that is moving aggressively into foreign markets.

title: DANCE: JACOB'S PILLOW PRESENTS TRISHA BROWN
description: The Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival provides top-notch new dance entertainment for the adventurous summer theatergoer. But often the festival offers a chance at a provocative second look at familiar choreography. The Pillow's Ted Shawn Theater has a proscenium stage like many in New York, but the size of its stage and the degree of its incline create a peculiarly intimate view of the dancers and the dances. Simple dances suddenly become teeming microcosms on that smallish stage. Others are revealed in a new, almost skeletal bareness, as was the case on Tuesday, when the Trisha Brown Dance Company opened a week's engagement.

description: Governor Cuomo is setting up a high-level panel to study ways of dealing with the increasing problem of crack and other narcotic substances, administration officials said tonight.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: MANY homes in rural locations and vacation areas are situated beyond municipal roads and services, with waste systems that are not connected to regular sewers. The sewage is disposed of through an underground septic tank and a drainage field or leaching field (or a seepage pit in some cases). These allow water and effluent to seep into the ground for eventual purification by natural bacterial action.

description: Poland's authorities are moving toward freeing Adam Michnik, a veteran opposition campaigner for the banned Solidarity trade union, a Supreme Court judge said today.

title: BECKER ADVANCES IN TRANQUIL SETTING
description: There is no need to wear a hat and sunglasses here to conceal his identity, order room service rather than venture to the hotel restaurant, or sneak out a side door instead of leaving the conventional way. A week in tranquil Stratton Mountain, Vt., is as close as Boris Becker gets to being just one of the guys nowadays and it is a welcomed change for a teen-ager who has already won Wimbledon twice and is expected to be the sport's next dominant player.

title: LIBERALS PORTRAY SCALIA AS THREAT BUT BAR GROUP SEES HIM AS OPEN
description: Some civil rights and feminist groups today assailed Judge Antonin Scalia as hostile to the concerns of women, the poor and members of minorities, and the A.F.L.-C.I.O. said he seemed to favor a ''profound'' shift from Congress to the President of the power to set national policy.

title: Cuba Warns of Boycott
description: Unless North Korea and South Korea are co-hosts for the 1988 Summer Olympics, Cuba will not participate, Fidel Castro says. The Cuban leader told the official organization of the Communist Workers Party of North Korea, ''The firm stand of Cuba is not to participate in the Olympic Games if they are not co-hosted.''

description: The Justice Department has dropped plans to propose a highly conservative Texas law professor for a seat on a Federal appeals court in New Orleans, Reagan Administration officials said today.

description: Renaldo Nehemiah made a strong comeback to track today after a four-year absence, winning the 110-meter hurdles in 13.48 seconds.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from Washington yesterday, about the selection of a Postmaster General, incorrectly described the Consolidated Rail Corporation, known as Conrail. Amtrak was not involved in the restructuring of bankrupt railroads under the corporation.

title: 2d BLACK IS EXPECTED TO RULE OUT AMBASSADORSHIP IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: State Department officials said today that they expected Terence A. Todman, the Ambassador to Denmark, to remove himself from consideration as envoy to South Africa.

title: VHC LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $155,000 and $242,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net loss and includes losses from discontinued operations of $23,491 for the quarter and $70,252 for the 6 months. The results for 1985 include a reclassification of sales and expenses to account for the sale of the company's remaining health food stores that were sold in June 1985.

title: PULLMAN-PEABODY CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $516,000 and $1,834,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $165,000 and $485,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, plus an extraordinary item of $1 million and $4.9 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, as a tax benefit of net operating loss carryforward. Results for 1985 have been restated for discontinued operations which reflects the previously announced sale of certain businesses. The company issued approximately 18.9 million shares of its common stock for all the outstanding common stock of Peabody International Corp. on Oct. 25, 1985, and this merger which is valued at approximately $118 million will be accounted for as a purchase. The company acquired all the common stock of REDM Industries on Oct. 1, 1984, and this transaction was accounted for as a purchase.

title: COALITION OF UNIONS' WANTS 3 CITY DAILIES TO OPERATE JOINTLY
description: A coalition of 10 labor unions representing workers at three major New York City newspapers proposed yesterday that publishers of the papers consider combining their production, advertising and circulation operations.

title: Computer Failure Snarls Chicago Air Traffic
description: The main computer used by air traffic controllers at Chicago Center, the Federal Aviation Admistration's busiest facility, failed Tuesday, delaying hundreds of flights, an agency spokesman said today.

title: 3 American Soldiers Found Dead in Korea
description: Three American soldiers on duty in South Korea have died from unknown causes, Army spokesmen said here today.

title: A SUMMER PLACE
description: SOMETIMES it has a proper name, Ar-kala, perhaps, or Timbers Hill. More often it is simply ''the farm,'' ''the cottage,'' ''the lodge'' or ''the place.'' It is in the woods, by the lake, at the shore.

title: Canada Pays Off Debt
description: Canada paid off the last $600 million of a record $2.56 billion debt it incurred earlier this year to protect Canadian currency from money speculators, according to a Finance Department report released today.

title: COVINGTON TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $539,000 for the quarter and $903,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss

title: Cuba Debt Pledge Seen
description: Cuba has promised to clear arrears of up to one month on its short-term commercial debt to Western creditors soon, but has given no deadline, business and diplomatic sources said today. Cuba suspended principal and interest payments on its medium- and long-term debt on July 1, pending the completion of negotiations to reschedule its overall $3.5 billion debt.

title: PROMOVISION VIDEO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ESCAPE WAS HOAX, BERLIN POLICE SAY
description: A police spokesman today confirmed reports that a tale of a spectacular escape from East Berlin last week was a hoax.

title: PUBLIC SERVICE CO OF NEW HAMPSHIRE reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a charge relating to a reserve for non-recovery of investments of $353,521,000 for both periods. c-Net income

title: MORTGAGE RATES SHOW SLIGHT DROP
description: Interest rates on both fixed-rate and adjustable mortgages fell slightly from early June to early July, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported yesterday.

title: CAVALIER HOMES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $30,000.

title: Art Auction to Benefit An Advocacy Group
description: Works by artists such as Roy Lichtenstein, James Rosenquist, Claes Oldenburg and Jennifer Bartlett will be auctioned at a benefit on Oct. 14 at the Puck Building, 295 Lafayette Street.

title: MICROSEMI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
REHNQUIST MEMOS FROM NIXON YEARS STUDIED BY PANEL
description: A day after the Justice Department turned over to the Senate Judiciary Committee 25 documents by Justice William H. Rehnquist, two committee members said nothing was emerging to suggest he was involved in questionable activities at the department during the Nixon Administration.

title: AIRMAN CONVICTED OF SPYING CHARGES
description: An airman was found guilty of espionage today for passing classified Air Force documents to Federal Bureau of Investigation agents posing as Soviet spies.

title: CONCERT: HOLLIGER AT MOSTLY MOZART
description: IT'S beginning to sound like an old refrain, but there is simply no way of avoiding the statement again; Heinz Holliger's skill and artistry as an oboist make him one of the wonders of the music world today.

title: GENERAL BINDING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

title: WICKES BID FOR OWENS $70 A SHARE
description: The Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation said yesterday that it was studying an acquisition offer of $70 a share from the Wickes Companies. But there were early indications that the company's management was strongly opposed to combining with Wickes.

title: NATHAN'S FAMOUS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
BPI SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Comings and Goings
description: Gene Michael, the Chicago Cubs' manager, has been suspended for three days and fined an undisclosed amount for his actions in Monday's game against the Mets. Michael was ejected for arguing a call and turning around the cap of Umpire Dave Pallone during the argument.

title: Ruth Ross, 56, Is Dead; First Editor of Essence
description: Ruth Ross, the first editor in chief of Essence, a black women's magazine, died Tuesday of cancer at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. She was 56 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: ELECTRONICS IS CHALLENGING TRADITIONS OF MUSIC
description: An entire new family of electronic instruments is proliferating through the music world, instruments that could alter the sounds and shapes that have defined Western music for two centuries.

title: ROCKWELL OFFICER WILL HEAD HANNA
description: The M. A. Hanna Company, one of the world's largest producers of iron and ore, said yesterday that Martin D. Walker, executive vice president of the Rockwell International Corporation, Pittsburgh, had been named chairman and chief executive.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article Tuesday about the coloring of black and white films incorrectly described the status of an application for a copyright on a colored version of Frank Capra's ''It's a Wonderful Life.'' The Library of Congress has not acted on the application. A decision is still pending on the issue of coloring as a subject of copyright.

title: Bridge: New York Experts Triumph In a Knockout Event on L.I.
description: The events preferred by tournament players correlate roughly with their ability. Most players of middle stature favor pair games, or perhaps Swiss teams, in which they meet a wide variety of opponents and score well on a good day.

title: Koch Appoints Medical Advisers
description: Mayor Koch yesterday created a seven-member advisory board to assist the city's Chief Medical Examiner's office and appointed Dr. Martin Cherkasky, a former director and president of Montefiore Hospital, to head the group.

title: METS WIN IN 12TH ON WILSON'S HIT
description: The Mets finally solved the Chicago Cubs today after four straight losses in a week's time. They did it with some of their old flair: Mookie Wilson poked a two-run single into right field off Lee Smith in the 12th inning to steer the Mets to a 7-6 victory.

title: Accounts
description: * Medley Wine, Summit Laboratories and the Graduate Management Admissions Council to J. P. Martin Associates.

title: HADSON PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an after-tax gain of $14,361,000 on the sale of the company's United Kingdom properties. The year-ago second quarter and 6 months' revenue were restated to include a $30,991,000 gain on the sale of the U.K. properties.

title: Out of Control On Arms
description: HAVING abandoned its allegiance to the second strategic arms treaty, or SALT II, the Administration has now trained its sights on the Antiballistic Missile Treaty of 1972, an essential component of the effort to keep the arms race from going completely out of control.

title: MSGR. THOMAS F. LITTLE
description: Msgr. Thomas F. Little, who served for many years as an official of the Legion of Decency, which represented the Roman Catholic viewpoint on morality in movies, died Sunday at Nazareth House, a Catholic nursing home in San Diego.

title: JAZZ: RICHARD DAVIS AND BAND AT SWEET BASIL
description: THE bassist Richard Davis and the drummer Frederick Waits are the heart of the Richard Davis band that is playing at Sweet Basil through Sunday. The relaxed, slightly behind-the-beat swing typical of so many jazz rhythm sections is not for them.

title: Competing for the Last Word on Drug Abuse
description: Less than a month ago, Dr. Carlton Turner, President Reagan's top adviser on drug issues, could hardly have been more adamant when he said the White House had no plans to recommend significantly increased Federal spending on drug programs, despite increasing attention being given to the subject.

title: American Steel Is Sacrificing Enough
description: To the Editor:

title: ESQUIRE RADIO & ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
3 Slams Set Record for Game
description: Larry Parrish's two-run double capped a six-run rally in the eighth inning as the Texas Rangers beat the Baltimore Orioles, 13-11, in a game in which three grand slams set a major-league record.

title: BancTexas Resignation
description: BancTexas Group Inc. said today that Charlie Thomas, a Houston businessman and owner of the Houston Rockets basketball team, had resigned as co-chairman of the bank holding company in order to accept the same position at the privately held First Texas Savings Association in Dallas. Federal law prohibited him from holding both positions, a BancTexas spokesman said.

title: U.S. BISHOPS BACK CURBS ON PRETORIA
description: For the first time, Roman Catholic bishops in the United States have endorsed economic sanctions against South Africa.

title: GALVESTON-HOUSTON CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a writedown of $1.6 million of the value of certain property and equipment.

title: REMOTE CONTROL
description: A CALL home can get an answer even when nobody is there. While any answering machine can do that these days, General Electric has a new electronic appliance, the HomeMinder, that will not only answer the phone, but also, at the touch of a few buttons on the telephone, flip on the air-conditioner, turn on the stereo and the outside lights and start heating up some soup in the microwave oven.

title: Doubts Are Voiced Over Basque Threat
description: Police experts and Basque radicals expressed strong doubts today about the authenticity of purported threats by Basque guerrillas against citizens of European Community countries in Spain.

title: JAZZ: HENDERSON AT VANGUARD
description: JOE HENDERSON, the tenor saxophonist who is leading a quartet at the Village Vanguard through Sunday, was a mainstay of the Blue Note label's mid-1960's roster. He seemed equally at home playing alongside hard boppers like Lee Morgan, fronting John Coltrane's rhythm section, or blending with post-modern expressionists such as Andrew Hill and Eric Dolphy.

title: NORMAN FAVORED TO WIN PGA TITLE
description: Greg Norman stands as an obvious favorite to win the 68th PGA Championship, which starts on the Inverness Club course Thursday. Norman has led going into the final round of the three majors played this year, missing the Masters by a stroke, finishing 12th in the United States Open in June and winning the British Open three weeks ago by five shots.

title: Baxter to Sell Flint Division
description: Baxter Travenol Labortories Inc. said today that it had agreed to sell its Flint pharmaceutical unit to the Boots Company P.L.C. for $555 million.

title: Rape Suspect Pleads Innocent
description: The man accused of being the ''Spiderman rapist,'' who scaled apartment buildings and a private house to get at his victims, pleaded innocent yesterday to raping, robbing and beating with a hammer a legally blind woman.

title: Pacific Telesis Unit To Make Refunds
description: Pacific Bell, a unit of the Pacific Telesis Group, was ordered by the California Public Utilties Commission to make refunds to customers for services they received but did not want.

title: THE LEGACY OF TEDDY WILSON'S SUBTLE APPROACH
description: WHEN the pianist Teddy Wilson died on July 31, jazz lost yet another master from the swing era. That loss had added impact because it came just six weeks after the death of Benny Goodman, whose trio and quartet were national showcases for the Wilson piano style. Yet with a recording career that spanned 50 years (from his first disks with Louis Armstrong in 1933) and performances that reached a worldwide audience, the Wilson style will be with us for a long time - even, ironically, affecting those who have never heard him play a note.

title: Moody's Changes: Upgrades Prevail
description: For the first time in many years, upgrades exceeded downgrades in revisions of municipal bond ratings during the first half of 1986, according to Moody's Investors Service.

title: New York, Los Angeles Favored as Test Sites
description: A SAMI study released Tuesday said that more new test-market brands were introduced in food stores in metropolitan New York and Los Angeles/San Diego, the nation's two largest markets, than in any other major market during the year ended May 23.

title: CAMERON IRON WORKS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

PAUL DE GROOT
description: Paul de Groot, who led the Dutch Communist Party for more than two decades, died Sunday in a nursing home here, a party spokesman said today. He was 87 years old.

title: Q&A
description: Q. In our 60-year-old house the basement pipes are covered with asbestos and over this is a plaster covering. The plaster has disintegrated in various places and is hanging down, exposing the asbestos. We have wrapped old terry-cloth towels around this to prevent asbestos dust from scattering, since it is a big and dangerous job to remove all the asbestos. Is there something else we can wrap around the present covering to preserve it? A. Asbestos pipe wrappings of this kind should be covered - or removed - by a contractor who is trained to do this type of work and has the safety masks and other equipment needed to do the job without creating a hazard inside the house.

title: BRENNAN TO QUIT BROKER POSTS
description: Robert E. Brennan, the embattled chairman and chief executive of First Jersey Securities Inc., said yesterday that he would resign his management posts at the brokerage concern to pursue other business and philanthropic activities and possibly a political career.

title: STOPPING STUDENTS FROM STARTING TO SMOKE
description: IN San Francisco, sixth graders write essays about how cigarette advertising links smoking to images of beauty, sex appeal and personal success. In New York City, seventh and eighth graders practice refusing cigarettes from friends. In New Orleans, junior and senior high school students meet to talk with nonsmoking members of the Saints football team because school officials believe that professional athletes as role models are more convincing than textbooks.

description: Nearly 100 inmates at the Rikers Island Correctional Institution for Men barricaded themselves in a ground-floor dormitory last night to protest a plan by prison officials to place additional beds in the overcrowded facility, according to the head of the corrections officers union.

description: The Coca-Cola Company said that it had agreed to sell Embassy Home Entertainment, a home video company, to Nelson Entertainment Inc. for $85 million.

title: Both Sides of Debate Are Stirring Reaction
description: Congressional proponents of stiff economic sanctions against South Africa seemed to be trying to set off a diplomatic chain reaction last week when the Senate Foreign Relations Committee gave overwhelming bipartisan support to such a program. Senator Richard G. Lugar, who heads the committee, said as much when he expressed the hope that its action might help in ''getting a point across'' to Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, who was then about to confront a special conference of Commonwealth leaders on the sanctions issue. That idea did not just occur to the Indiana Republican; it had been forcefully put to him a few days before the vote by representatives from the Commonwealth, including former Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser of Australia and General Olusegun Obasanjo, a former Nigerian head of state, who were hoping to move Mrs. Thatcher.

description: b-Net loss The company said its income from investment activities was $10,202,000 in the latest quarter compared to $1,250,000 in the year-ago period, and that income from investment activities in the latest 6 months was $13,910,000 compared to $4,278,000 in the year-earlier period.

title: CITY CRITICIZED IN REPORT ON DRUG-ABUSE POLICIES
description: New York City's drug abuse policies are poorly coordinated, overlapping and in need of central direction by the Mayor's office, according to a report by leaders of nonprofit drug treatment programs in the city.

DROUGHT EASING, AFRICA HAS NEW ENEMY: LOCUSTS
description: When the rains finally came last year to this drought-riddled continent, they brought with them swarms of locusts. Agricultural experts now say the locusts threaten to cause catastrophic plagues that could affect a great swath of sub-Saharan Africa.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: DEAL WOULD DOUBLE JAPANESE PRESENCE
description: Sumitomo Bank Ltd.'s interest in investing $500 million in Goldman, Sachs & Company is the latest and, by far, the biggest example yet of an increasingly rapid Japanese expansion into America's financial marketplace.

title: New, Improved Dummy
description: After 15 years of being bashed, battered and otherwise abused by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, the dummy used in the agency's frontal crash tests for vehicles is being sent to the great emergency room in the sky.

title: PEKING IS MAKING OFFER TO VIETNAM
description: China has offered Vietnam ''tremendous'' aid to rebuild its economy and closer diplomatic relations in an effort to persuade Hanoi to withdraw from Cambodia, Prince Norodom Sihanouk said at a news conference here today.

description: The police said an American songwriter was found dead today in a London mansion owned by Boy George, the pop singer who pleaded guilty last week to heroin possession.

title: MAAZEL CONDUCTS 'ROMEO'
description: TONIGHT'S performance of Tchaikovsky's ''Romeo and Juliet,'' which can be seen on the Bravo cable network at 9:30, has virtually everything going for it - everything, that is, but a convincing interpretation.

title: Hussein Flies to Alexandria For Brief Talk With Mubarak
description: King Hussein of Jordan flew into Alexandria, Egypt, today for brief consultations with President Hosni Mubarak that were thought to focus on Vice President Bush's recent visit to their countries as well as the new frictions between Jordan and the Palestine Liberation Organization last month.

title: The Suzman Plan
description: The Big Lie being sold and swallowed in the debate on South Africa is this: If you are against sanctions, you are for apartheid.

title: Foes of Abortion And Death Penalty
description: To the Editor In your July 31 editorial ''Contradictions,'' you too quickly include pro-life activists, whom you describe as often in favor of capital punishment. This may be true of some prominent political figures but is probably not true of pro-life activists or perhaps the general public. There are no national survey data comparing opposition to abortion and support for capital punishment. It would be interesting to have such data.

title: Ducking the (Even-Bigger) Deficit
description: The economy's expansion has slowed, cutting Federal tax collections. The Pentagon is overspending again. Farm subsidy costs are up. The combined result is another record deficit. Even the Administration finally admits it. The President's Office of Management and Budget now estimates the deficit at $230 billion, $28 billion more than it forecast only six months ago.

title: BLUE JAYS 8, ROYALS 0
description: Jimmy Key and Tom Henke combined on a five-hit shutout and Garth Iorg drove in three runs to power Toronto.

description: A Queens woman, convicted for her role in bringing 50 Taiwanese women to the United States to work as prostitutes, was sentenced yesterday to 12 years in Federal prison.

title: AT MAINE CHURCH FAIRS, NO HARD SELL
description: ON a recent hot day in Brooksville, Me., (population 753), Blanche Varnum, 89 years old, sat by her window with a view of blue delphiniums and a rocky pasture, knitting a pair of mittens to be sold in a few days at a church bazaar. Mrs. Varnum's sawtooth-patterned mittens are recognized all over the Penobscot Bay area, and so far this year she has knitted 30 pairs, mostly to benefit local churches.

description: The reputed leader of the Colombo organized-crime family, Carmine Persico, will be allowed to conduct his own defense at a major Mafia trial to begin next month in Federal District Court in Manhattan, the judge who is to preside at the trial announced yesterday.

description: A Federal appeals court in New York yesterday issued an injunction that prevents Harold C. Simmons, the Dallas investor, from continuing with his tender offer for shares of NL Industries until Aug. 28.

title: THE FINNISH WAY TO RELAX - AT 200 degrees
description: IT's dark, cramped and 200 degrees Fahrenheit. Sitting naked, you strain for breath, fighting the heat, your lungs searing. The sweat runs off in rivers, collecting in little puddles on the wooden floor.

title: THE SLAM: SO NEAR AND SO FAR
description: More than any golfer since Jack Nicklaus was at his best, Greg Norman has demonstrated this year just how feasible the Grand Slam is. But also just how fragile it is. So near. And yet so far.

description: The Saatchi & Saatchi Company said it would complete today its acquisition of Ted Bates Worldwide Inc., following shareholder approval yesterday.
