title: M/A-Com Sells Units
description: The General Instrument Corporation, a leading maker of cable electronics equipment, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the cable and home communications businesses of M/A-Com Inc. for $220 million.

title: TIPS ON REPAIRING A BENTWOOD HAT AND COAT STAND 4:3>
description: The number of Thonet bentwood hat and coat stands that once stood in restaurants, hotel lobbies, meeting rooms and other gathering spots must have been prodigious. (The maker's name can usually be found impressed in bold print on the underside of one leg on these stands.) But fashions changed, closets and racks came along and bentwood was cheap enough to be considered disposable. The few I have come across have not exactly survived unscathed, but a not-too-badly damaged stand can be repaired and restored by someone with average skills.

title: WYETH'S MODEL? NOBODY IS TELLING
description: In a third-floor gallery of the Brandywine River Museum here, there hangs a dry-brush watercolor by Andrew Wyeth. It portrays a striking blond nude by an open window. She is glancing across the room toward an unseen object or person, in apparent expectation. The painting is titled, ''Lovers.''

title: CONSOLIDATED CAPITAL INOME OPPORTUNITY reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a provision for loan loss reserves. The company said net income in all periods is after depreciation.

title: CYPRUS ATTACK SEEN AS WORK OF NEW TERROR GROUP
description: A rocket and mortar attack against a British air base in Cyprus last Sunday appears to have been the work of a new underground terrorist group with Libyan links, diplomats here say.

title: STATE OFFERS 4 VERSIONS OF BOULEVARD TO REPLACE DEFUNCT WESTWAY PROJECT
description: Four scaled-down alternatives to the abandoned Westway project -from rebuilding the current West Side roadway with few changes to constructing a new road with overpasses, underpasses and pedestrian crossings - were made public yesterday by the State Transportation Department.

title: JUDGE RULES AGAINST F.T.C. ON TOBACCO ADVERTISEMENT
description: An administrative law judge ruled today that a complaint filed against the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company by the Federal Trade Commission should be dismissed because the First Amendment fully protected an ''editorial advertisement'' in which the company discussed the health risks of smoking.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL CHICAGO (AL) - Placed Bob James, pitcher, on the 15-day disabled list; Neil Allen, pitcher, on the 21-day disabled list, and Joel McKeon, pitcher, on the 60-day disabled list. Recalled Bobby Thigpen, pitcher, from Birmingham of the Southern League.

title: UNITED CABLE TELEVISION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $4,857,000. c-Includes an extraordinary charge of $1,925,000.

title: Neilson Wins Suit
description: Roger Neilson, currently an assistant coach with the Chicago Black Hawks and former head coach at Vancouver, has won his breach-of-contract suit against the Canucks and has been awarded $173,000 in a British Columbia Supreme Court judgment. Neilson, known for his use of videotapes in coaching, was also awarded interest and costs, which brings his total award to the equivalent of more than a quarter-million American dollars.

title: Politics of Protection
description: The surge of American protectionism that has just fallen short of victory in the House of Representatives is a bipartisan disaster. President Reagan and Congressional Democrats share responsibility for a phenomenon that threatens the whole postwar pattern of international economic growth and prosperity. And the House's narrow failure to override the Reagan veto of a textile quota bill will not end the phenomenon.

title: VIRGINIA BEACH FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
LUMEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Yields Off For C.D.'s
description: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds fell for the week ended yesterday.

title: Why New York City's High Schools for the Gifted Must Go
description: To the Editor:

title: ADIA SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in June.

title: Unhappy Dealings
description: The Philadelphia 76ers' attempt to sign Derek Smith, the free-agent guard, abruptly ended early yesterday when Smith signed a Sacramento Kings offer sheet believed to be worth more than $5 million over the next five years. Smith's agent, Ron Grinker, reportedly broke off negotiations with the Sixers' owner, Harold Katz, saying that Katz had treated him and Smith as ''a couple of school kids.''

title: 14-YEAR-OLD DRIVER DIES WITH 3 OTHERS IN CRASH
description: Four people were killed and one was critically injured yesterday morning when two luxury cars, one of them driven by a 14-year-old girl, collided head-on along a rural road in Farmington, Conn., the police said.

title: SHIFT OF EXECUTIVES AT JONATHAN LOGAN
description: The chairman and chief executive officer of Jonathan Logan Inc. has been asked to devote all of his time to the jewelry division as it goes public.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, AUGUST 8, 1986
description: The Economy

title: Airman Gets 25 Years as Spy
description: Airman 1st Class Bruce Ott was sentenced today to 25 years in Federal prison for trying to sell information about a secret spy aircraft to covert agents of the Federal Bureau of Investiation who were posing as spies for the Soviet Union.

title: OVER 2,000 LAID OFF IN LTV SHUTDOWNS
description: The LTV Steel Company, which last month filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy laws, yesterday announced several plant shutdowns and a sweeping layoff of more than 2,000 workers.

title: PATRIOTS BLOCK OUT TROUBLE
description: They talk about it and yet they don't talk about it: the drug situation that turned the New England Patriots into a bitter, confused team the day after their unexpected appearance in the Super Bowl.

title: SOUTHERN DROUGHT STRAINING BROTHERLY RELATIONS
description: Sheltered from the smothering sun outside, two brothers and a friend sat in the air-conditioned office of the local cotton gin, a place of lost business and hurt quiet amid the drought and heat that have enveloped this area.

title: HISTORY IN THE SEA: DIRIGIBLE'S WRECKAGE FOUND OFF JERSEY
description: A marine research team said yesterday that it had found the wreck of the Navy dirigible Akron, which crashed and sank off the New Jersey coast in 1933, killing 73 crew members in one of the most controversial air disasters of its time.

title: 30-Year Bonds Well Received
description: Prices of Treasury securities rose smartly yesterday as the credit markets absorbed the third and final leg of the Treasury's $28 billion quarterly refunding in considerably better shape than results of the first two auctions would have suggested.

title: Baldwin Takes Amateur Medal
description: Fresh from a victory Tuesday in the Ike Championship, John Baldwin, a 41-year-old investment banker, won the medal today in the 84th amateur championship of the Metropolitan Golf Association.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL YANKEES VS. KANSAS CITY ROYALS, at Yankee Stadium, 7:30 P.M. (Television - Channel 11, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770, 7:30 P.M.) METS VS.

title: Great White Sharks: Fierce but Necessary
description: Great white sharks pose the greatest danger to human beings of all the roughly 350 species of shark in the world, according to a shark specialist at the Steinhart Aquarium in San Francisco, Dr. John E. McKosker. But the danger is not great.

title: GULF RESOURCES & CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a charge of $8 million on the value of oil and gas reserves. c-Net income and includes net from discontinued operations of $3,041,000 for the quarter and $4,655,000 for the 6 months.

title: TESTS OF CAR SAFETY SHOW SOME GAINS
description: The Government's 1986 automobile crash tests showed poor performances by more a third of the 26 cars tested, including two new, low-cost imports and Ford's popular Taurus and Sable.

title: COMB CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a pre-tax investment gain of $4,891,000 for both the quarter and 6 months. Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in June.

title: Senator Biden Linked To a Restrictive Deed
description: A Republican supporter of the nomination of Associate William H. Rehnquist of the Supreme Court to be Chief Justice today disclosed records that showed a home in which Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. lived for three years had a deed barring ownership by blacks.

title: ADDISON-WESLEY PUBLISHING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Hammermill Sees Possible Buyers
description: The Hammermill Paper Company, which recently rejected an unsolicited $722 million takeover bid as ''inadequate,'' said that it had started discussions with other companies interested in buying all or parts of the concern. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Hammermill also said that W. Craig McClelland, Hammermill's president and chief executive, met Wednesday with Paul A. Bilzerian, the California investor whose group made the bid, which comes to $52 a share.

title: Generals' Walker Pursuing Cowboys
description: The Dallas Cowboys' dream of a two-Heisman backfield came a step closer to reality yesterday when Herschel Walker, the United States Football League's leading running back, announced that he had secured his release from the New Jersey Generals' owner, Donald Trump, and would begin negotiations with the Cowboys next week.

title: Clark Center Reunion
description: Former dancers and students at the Clark Center will take part this weekend in the last two performances of a dance festival at the Douglas Fairbanks Theater, 432 West 42d Street.

title: ROYAL DUTCH-SHELL GROUP OF COS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Royal Dutch Petroleum's share of group earnings amounted to $1.94 for the latest quarter and $4.38 for the latest 6 months, compared with $1.92 and $4.78 for the year-ago periods, respectively. Shell Transport & Trading's share of group earnings totaled $1.10 for the latest quarter and $2.48 for the latest 6 months, compared with $1.08 and $2.70 for the year-ago periods, respectively. b-After net inventory holding losses of $547 million for the latest quarter and $1,401,000,000 in the latest 6 months on those inventories accounted for on a first-in, first-out basis, compared with 1985 losses of $87 million in the quarter and $94 million in the 6 months. The company said that there were currency exchange losses of $190 million in the latest quarter compared with $39 million in the year-ago period, and that for the current 6 months currency exchange losses totaled $302 million compared with $160 million in the year-ago period.

title: Krukow Reactivated
description: The San Francisco Giants reactivated Mike Krukow, their All-Star pitcher, from the disabled list and said he will start Sunday in Atlanta.

title: CIPHER DATA PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
YANKEE PITCHING BLASTED BY BREWERS
description: Unlike Ron Guidry the night before, Joe Niekro did nothing last night to brighten the Yankees' pitching outlook for their stretch run in the season's final eight weeks. Neither did a couple of the Yankees' left-handed relievers, Al Holland and Rod Scurry.

title: REAGAN HINTS HE MAY REJECT SOME SPACE SHUTTLE CONTRACTS
description: President Reagan today indicated that he was ready to restrict the space agency from honoring some of its contracts for launching foreign and commercial satellites when space shuttle flights resume, White House officials said. But they suggested that he would approve some launchings on a priority basis, Mr. Reagan overruled some of his senior advisers at a meeting of the Economic Policy Council as he presented a broad outline of the Administration's policy. He ordered the National Aeronautics and Space Administration to draw up a list of launching priorities for outstanding contracts NASA has for placing foreign and commercial payloads in orbit over the next eight years, the officials said.

title: Puerto Rican Theater To Open 19th Season
description: ''Lady With a View,'' a musical by Eduardo Ivan Lopez and Fernando Rivas, will open the 19th season of free outdoor performances by the Puerto Rican Traveling Theater tonight at 6 at Riverside Park, 103d Street and Riverside Drive.

title: Simmons' NL Bid Is Not Extended
description: Harold C. Simmons, the Dallas investor, said his $900 million offer to buy NL Industries, the New York-based oilfield services and chemical company, expired yesterday and would not be extended.

title: Halliburton Loss Widens
description: The Halliburton Company, a diversified oilfield services concern here, said today that it lost a record $524.6 million in the second quarter ended June 30 compared with a loss of $474.8 million in the comparable period a year earlier.

title: DELMARVA POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Foreign Policy, Farm Policy: A Loud Feud
description: The people responsible for shaping United States farm policy and those who shape foreign policy have long been at odds. But it had been a largely quiet feud. Until late last week. Then the dispute, between those who say that American farmers need to be supported at any cost and those who say that diplomatic relations are more important, broke noisly into the public realm after President Reagan sided with the farm authorities and approved the sale of 3.85 million tons of subsidized American wheat to the Soviet Union.

title: Jersey County Sets $67.9 Million Issue
description: Monmouth County, N.J., is offering $67.9 million of general improvement and reclamation center bonds through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: Advertising; ITT Unit Names Fallon For XTRA Computers
description: The ITT Information Systems division of ITT Corporation, San Jose, Calif., has named Fallon McElligott, Minneapolis, to handle its ITT XTRA family of microcomputers, which adds up to seven figures in billings.

title: Bomb Threat Halts a Train
description: An Amtrak train bound for New York from Washington was halted at the Baltimore-Washington International Airport stop tonight after officials received a telephone call saying one of the passengers was carrying a bomb. No bomb was found and the train was allowed to proceed after about an hour.

title: Tax Reform: Last Lap, or Last Legs?
description: Just weeks ago, tax reform seemed a sure winner. The bills passed by the House and Senate differed. But the White House and Congressional leaders agreed on basic principles and everyone was betting that this historic legislation would be ready for the President's signature by Labor Day. America's tax system would finally be governed by law rather than by loophole.

title: CORRECTION
description: A performance schedule in Weekend on Aug. 1 with an article about outdoor theater gave incorrect locations for Jacob Riis Park and Kissena Park. Jacob Riis is in Rockaway, Queens; Kissena is in Flushing, Queens.

title: Henry J. Smith, 67, Is Dead; Led State Bar Association
description: Henry J. Smith, a Westchester County lawyer who had been president of the state, county and White Plains bar associations, died Tuesday at his home in Greenburgh, N.Y., after a long illness. He was 67 years old.

title: CENTRAL LOUISIANA ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
'THE OUT-OF-TOWNERS,' A SUMMER SERIES OF DANCE
description: New York City may be the dance capital of the world, but dance is alive in other places. And Dance Theater Workshop celebrates that ubiquity with ''The Out-of-Towners,'' a summer series that has just opened at the Bessie Schonberg Theater, where it will run through Oct. 5. The series, founded in 1977, will present eight experimentalist choreographers and performance artists, many in their New York debuts, from as far away as Australia and California and as close by as Connecticut. Each has developed a style - and lives a professional life - that draws on communities outside New York City.

title: EL PASO'S 'YAWNS' TURN TO ANXIETY AS PROTESTS BLOCK 2 OF 4 BORDER BRIDGES
description: When Mexican political dissidents staged a sit-in July 14 at two bridges connecting El Paso and Ciudad Juarez, Mexico, people here barely blinked. When a blockade began July 24 on the busiest border bridge, there was some irritation but little serious concern.

title: FIRES IN SOUTH OF FRANCE DEVASTATE FORESTS IN SCENIC TOURIST REGIONS
description: Fires in southern France have devastated large areas of forest and brushland in recent weeks, much of it in scenic tourist areas.

title: FORMER CONVICT'S ROLE IN MILITARY PROJECTS CITED
description: Two giant military contractors hired a former convict and high school dropout as an engineer on two of the nation's most sensitive military programs, without discovering either his F.B.I. record or the falseness of his education credentials, according to court records filed today.

title: LAW FIRM WITHDRAWS PLAN TO MOVE TO TIMES SQUARE
description: One of the city's largest and most prominent Wall Street law firms has decided to withdraw from a commitment to move to Times Square as part of the $2 billion redevelopment of the area.

title: STATE JUDGE RULES ASSEMBLYMAN FROM BROOKLYN OFF PRIMARY BALLOT
description: Roger L. Green, a State Assemblyman running in the Sept. 9 Democratic primary, was ruled off the ballot yesterday by a State Supreme Court justice who said the candidate's nominating petition lacked information required by state law.

title: SOUTH AFRICA ENDS CURBS IN ONE AREA
description: Curfews in black townships and bans on political meetings and mass funerals in eastern Cape Province have been lifted in an administrative move, the South African Police said today.

title: AUGAT INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Home Oil Pact
description: Interprovincial Pipe Line Ltd. said it had signed a definitive purchase agreement for its previously reported $1.1 billion acquisition of Hiram Walker Resources Ltd.'s subsidiary the Home Oil Company. The definitive agreement is subject to certain closing adjustments, including a reduction in the price of about $45 million for long-term debt of Home Oil, the company said.

title: CHIEF STEWARD SHIFTED TO MINOR TRACK
description: Salvatore J. Ferrara, the chief steward at Aqueduct, Belmont Park and Saratoga, has been reassigned to Finger Lakes, a minor track in Canandaigua, N.Y., for his participation in the disqualification of the wrong horse in the second race at Saratoga last Saturday.

title: BANKS' NON-LOAN PROFITS EBB
description: Earlier this year, the nation's big banks reported booming profits from foreign-exchange commissions, securities trading and surging values of bond portfolios. But such huge windfalls in areas outside of lending were unlikely to go on forever, and they did not. As a result, many banks have reported flat or reduced earnings for the second quarter.

title: FARM POPULATION DROPS AS DEPRESSION CONTINUES
description: The nation's farm population has dropped 11.6 percent since the start of the depression in American agriculture in 1980, according to a study published today by the Department of Agriculture and the Department of Commerce.

title: EX-LAWYER AT TOP IN GROCERIES
description: Leonard Lieberman, who gave up practicing law to join three entrepreneurs in the grocery business 23 years ago, became the chairman of the board of the Supermarkets General Corporation yesterday.

title: Dyson Announces Divesting Of South Africa-Linked Stock
description: John S. Dyson, a candidate for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator from New York, announced yesterday that he had completed divestiture of his investments in companies that do business in South Africa.

title: NORSTAN INC reports earnings for Year to April 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $3,220,000. c-Net income and includes net from discontinued operations of $64,000.

title: DEVELOPMENT CORP OF AMERCA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $141,000 for the quarter and income from discontinued operations of $132,000 for the 6 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $319,000 and $729,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. The company said the latest quarter and 6-month period also include a gain of $3,142,000 from the sale of a shopping center. The 1985 results are restated for termination of pension plan.

title: CABLE SYSTEMS ORDERED TO CARRY LOCAL STATIONS
description: The Federal Communications Commission today adopted a rule ordering cable systems across the nation to carry local television station signals until 1991.

title: REPUBLICANS PROD THE WHITE HOUSE TO MOVE ON DRUGS
description: Facing intense Republican pressure to seize the narcotics issue quickly, the White House tentatively plans to propose a $100 million program next week aimed at combating the use of drugs in schools, Administration officials said.

title: Advertising; Print for Frye Boots
description: Frye Boots, the 123-year-old shoe manufacturer, will initiate its first consumer print campaign since Stanley Kravetz bought the company from Alberto-Culver last July. Ally & Gargano put together the two- and three-page black and white 1960's nostalgia package, which will first appear in three issues of Rolling Stone, beginning with the Aug. 28 issue.

title: PRATT & LAMBERT INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CORRECTION
description: A report in the Advertising column of Business Day on Aug. 1, about the Grace & Rothschild agency's gaining the account of Lebenthal & Company, incorrectly described the relationship between Lebenthal and the Chiat/ Day agency. Lebenthal, a municipal bond concern, left Chiat/Day in 1983.

title: Topics; Moving On/Moving In; Lodging a Complaint
description: There is really only one terrible thing about moving to New York, says a newcomer we know, and it isn't what you might expect.

title: HEIR IN FLORIDA IS FOUND GUILTY OF MURDERING 2
description: Steven W. Benson, an heir to a $10 million tobacco fortune, was convicted of first-degree murder today in the bombing deaths of his mother and her adopted son.

title: PIC 'N' SAVE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings for 1985 have been restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in May 1986.

title: INSTANT FAME: STARS AS PALS
description: The other night, Susan Thomas got a chance to put her arms around Bruce Springsteen. Phillisia Bonneau grasped Hulk Hogan's biceps, and Nadia Krupa Jiwnani, a 9-year-old tourist from London, stood on a stool, the better to pose with her idol, Madonna. Well, sort of.

title: JUDGE RULES OUT SUFFOLK ATTEMPT AT BUYING LILCO
description: A State Supreme Court justice here blocked a Suffolk County law today that provided for a public takeover of the Long Island Lighting Company.

title: Brooklyn Inquiries Set
description: Investigations into allegations of irregularities in the Brooklyn College basketball program, made by the school's former athletic director and sports information director, were ordered yesterday by the college and its parent organization, the City University of New York.

title: FILM: SPIKE LEE'S 'SHE'S GOTTA HAVE IT'
description: NOLA DARLING, the heroine of ''She's Gotta Have It,'' a movie by the young black film maker Spike Lee, has too many men in her life. She doesn't think so, but each of her three lovers does. The situation is not entirely comic; while the film satirizes selfishness, sexual stereotypes, role-playing among black men and other follies, its presentation of Nola turns serious, even poignant. In fact, the story is so good that I regret the film is sometimes technically messy and some of Mr. Lee's directing experiments ill-conceived.

title: WHAT'S GOING ON AND WHEN AT LATINO FESTIVAL
description: Festival Latino, sponsored by the New York Shakespeare Festival, will run through Aug. 31. Admission to events at the Delacorte Theater, Central Park at 81st Street, are free; tickets are $12 to all events at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street. Tickets are $5 to events at Thompson Park, near Monticello, N.Y. To reach Thompson Park, take the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway to Exit 16 (Harriman) and take Route 17 West; continue about 50 miles to Exit 105B and take Route 42N to Kiamesha Lake; make left onto Anawana Lake Road and continue for about two miles to Kutsher Road; take Kutsher Road to Hurleyville (Old Liberty Road) and continue to Town Park Road, which leads to Thompson Park.

title: FOR TOON, TRIP BACK TO GLORY
description: There will be many memories for Al Toon, the Jets' wide receiver, when he returns to the University of Wisconsin for an exhibition game Saturday afternoon against the Green Bay Packers in Madison.

title: Chicago Pacific Move Awaited
description: NAME-BRAND products were the choicest acquisition targets during much of 1985, but the tempo of such buyouts has slowed considerably this year. One company, however, that is believed to still be actively prowling for acquisitions with famous names is the Chicago Pacific Corporation. Last year it purchased the Hoover Company, well known for its vacuum cleaners.

title: Party Time
description: To the Editor:

title: ENRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $1.7 million for the quarter and income from discontinued operations of $4.8 million for the 6 months. The 1985 results have been restated for the company's previously announced change in accounting to successful efforts from full cost for its exploration and production operations. The company said the 1986 quarter results were reduced by $10.1 million after-tax from severance and relocation. The company said the 1985 quarter included a $21.3 million after-tax non- recurring charge taken to reflect expenses arising from the merger.

title: MITEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
Bet-a-Million Bush
description: Whatever, if anything, Vice President Bush won in the crucial, go-for-broke, early-bird Michigan Republican primary cost his backers a cool million dollars, which maybe they should think is not so cool.

title: Putting Some Teeth Into Fast-Food Regulation
description: To the Editor:

title: What Andrew Young Said to Bishop Tutu
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, AUGUST 8, 1986
description: International

title: Traffic Agent Stabbed
description: A traffic agent was stabbed in the chest for no apparent reason yesterday at a crowded midtown Manhattan intersection by a 34-year-old man from Philadelphia, the police said.

title: BLOOMFIELD SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a gain of $8.5 million from the early retirement of debt for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Net loss

title: TO IMPROVE SCHOOLS, LET PRINCIPALS TEACH AND TEACHERS TEACH
description: To the Editor:

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Gulf States Utility
description: The Gulf States Utilities Company said, as expected, that it would halt payment on its 26-cent quarterly dividend that was to have been made to shareholders on Sept. 15. The utility, which provides electricity in the area ranging from Baton Rouge, La., to the suburbs of Houston, was denied a request for a $360 million rate increase by regulators in Texas and Louisiana last June.

title: Sanyo Plans Overseas Move
description: The Sanyo Electric Company, one of Japan's largest electronics manufacturers, said today that it plans to move 70 percent of its computer-chip production overseas by 1990.

title: TEXAS EASTERN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $63.8 million and $71 million for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net income and includes a loss from discontinued operations of $10.4 million and $15.5 million for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. Latest-quarter and 6-month results include charges of $72.8 million associated with the company's plans to divest most of its remaining petroleum service subsidiaries. Results for 1985 have been restated because of a change in accounting method for oil and gas operations from the full-cost method to the successful-efforts method, and the company did not provide share earnings for its income from continuing operations for the year-ago period.

title: Driesell Memo
description: Coach Lefty Driesell of Maryland wrote a memo to the school's athletic director, Dick Dull, about two weeks after the death of Bias advocating a shorter playing season and fewer midweek games. According to The Baltimore Sun, unidentified sources told the newspaper that the two-page memo aired the coach's concern that athletes miss too many classes during the basketball season.

title: EXTRAVAGANZA OFFERS A FEAST OF LATIN EVENTS
description: THE Latin in Manhattan, they're acting, singing, dancing. At least, the 400 of them who are here for the Festival Latino in New York are doing just that in what has become one of the world's most important arenas for Hispanic performing arts. The festival, which runs through Aug. 31 with representatives from more than a dozen countries, occupies the outdoor Delacorte Theater and the downtown Public Theater of the New York Shakespeare Festival -whose leader, Joseph Papp, has been the guiding light of this annual event.

title: A Channel 13 Documentary
description: On the Composer Rochberg The composer George Rochberg's odyssey could have come from a novella by Thomas Mann: A gifted and successful modernist composer, bedecked with honors and commissions, undergoes a wrenching ordeal when his son is stricken with a brain tumor. The boy dies after a three-year battle, and the composer moves away from the abstract quality of his early work in favor of a direct emotionalism that sometimes calls to mind the yearning adagios of Gustav Mahler.

title: NORMAN LEADS BY 2 AT PGA TOURNEY
description: Eighteen days after winning the British Open, Greg Norman set out after his second major victory with an Inverness Club course record of six-under 65 today in the opening round of the 68th PGA Championship.

title: Two Promoted by Times Co.
description: Michael Golden, production manager of Family Circle magazine, has been named circulation manager of the publication and a senior vice president of the Retail Magazine Marketing Company, a division of The New York Times Company's magazine group.

title: Dining Out Guide; Accent on Seafood
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. THE CAPTAIN'S TABLE, #860 Second Avenue, at 46th Street (697-9538) -**(May 4, 1984) Lavish floral bouquets and stained-glass panels enhance the decor of this intimate East Side restaurant. The variety of local and imported fish is impressive, some of it tantalizingly displayed at the entrance. Appetizer options include moules mariniere, clams Casino, subtly seasoned shrimp cocktail and mixed seafood salad. Delicate fishlike loup de mer and monkfish are cooked to perfection. Other main course choices are red snapper en papillotte, baked in a zesty marinara sauce with shrimp, mussels and bay scallops.

title: FLORIDA COUNTY OFFERS $112 MILLION OF BONDS
description: Volusia County, Fla., is offering $112 million of general obligation school district bonds through underwriters led by the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago.

title: LEISURE TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MTV President Plans Ventures
description: Robert Pittman, the president of MTV Networks Inc., has agreed to form several entertainment businesses with MCA Inc., a motion picture concern, and Viacom International Inc., a New York-based entertainment company,Viacom said yesterday.

title: IMMENSE DAMAGE SEEN FROM EX-C.I.A. EMPLOYEE
description: Edward L. Howard, the former Central Intelligence Agency employee who reportedly defected to the Soviet Union, has done immeasurable damage to national security by disclosing what he knows about American intelligence operations and personnel, Government officials said today.

title: CARDINAL LEADS ANTIDRUG VIGIL ON 5TH AVENUE
description: In the flickering light of candles held by many demonstrators, more than a thousand people stood on Fifth Avenue in front of St. Patrick's Cathedral last night to pray and exhort their neighbors and public officials to bring about a drug-free New York.

title: ITT Plans to Sell Rayonier Unit
description: The chairman of the ITT Corporation, Rand V. Araskog, indicated yesterday that the recent sale of a majority stake in ITT's telecommunications business was not the final chapter in its restructuring. Mr. Araskog, at a news conference preceding a meeting with analysts, said the company intends to sell Rayonier, its forest products subsidiary, and it might put other small units in Europe on the block.

title: CONSUMER BORROWING EASES A BIT
description: Americans took out $5.07 billion more in consumer credit than they paid off in June, down 21 percent from the May increase, the Federal Reserve Board said today.

title: HEALTH-CARE COMPANY INDICTED OVER MEDICAID
description: A home-health-care company based in Plainview, L.I., and five of its officers and employees have been charged with stealing $1.82 million in Medicaid reimbursements by employing home-care aides who did not meet state qualifications, state officials said yesterday.

title: SUN CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes equity in net earnings of the company's 44 percent-owned Chromalloy American Corp. of $8,605,000 and $10,088,000 for the latest quarter and 6 months, respectively, and $120,000 and $118,000 for the year- ago quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes equity in net loss of Chromalloy's discontinued operations of $2,436,000 and $3,719,000 for the latest quarter and 6 months, respectively, and $2,066,000 and $2,295,000 for the year-ago quarter and 6 months, respectively. Fully-diluted amounts are not presented for 1985 as they are antidilutive.

title: Bridge: The Winners in Pairs Event Play a Hundred Miles Apart
description: In team competitions, whether bridge-related or not, the winners and runners-up in an event can be expected to face each other. This is nearly always true in Swiss teams and entirely true in knockout and round-robin play.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE AYATOLLAH IN THE CATHEDRAL: Reflections of a Hostage. By Moorhead Kennedy. 241 pages. Hill and Wang. $17.95. THE MASTER TERRORIST: The True

title: House Votes $350 Million In Aid to Philippines
description: The House today approved $350 million in new economic and military aid for the Philippines, including $200 million in cash to help the Government of President Corazon C. Aquino meet budget deficits.

title: A Broadway Revival
description: Missing: the graciously undulating marquee that has welcomed generations of playgoers with Baroque splendor to the Lyceum Theater off Times Square.

title: METROMAIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 1
description: b-Includes a $1 million, or 10 cents a share, gain from Officers Life Insurance.

title: 12 ARE TO BE HIRED TO ENFORCE CITY LAW ON WINDOW GUARDS
description: Mayor Koch yesterday announced a series of measures intended to strengthen the enforcement of the city's window-guard law, including the hiring of 12 inspectors to work on the problem full time.

title: TENNESSEE SPEAKER TAKES NOMINAION IN GOVERNOR'S RACE
description: Ned McWherter, the Tennessee House Speaker, today defeated four rivals for the Democratic nomination for Governor. He will face former Gov. Winfield Dunn in the November election.

title: FUSION MACHINE AT PRINCETON OUTHEATS SUN'S CORE TENFOLD
description: The giant fusion machine at Princeton University designed to tame the energy source of the sun has achieved a temperature of 200 million degrees Celsius, or roughly 400 million degrees Fahrenheit, the Department of Energy said yesterday.

title: CELEBRATING THE CLASSIC AND CLASSICAL GERSHWINS IN A GUILD HALL TRIBUTE
description: With 1987 marking the 50th anniversary of George Gershwin's death, the deluge of tributes has already begun. Beyond the buoyant romanticism of his classic songs, Gershwin's passionate vision of American music as an endless melting pot continues to exert a profound impact. The Gershwin legacy is so rich in its cross-cultural connections and so innova-tive in its breaking down of conventional musical categories that it can be scrutinized from any number of perspectives and reveal fresh insights.

title: CONFEREES GET CLOSER ON I.R.A.'S
description: House and Senate negotiators on tax revision legislation appeared today to be in accord on the tax treatment of Individual Retirement Accounts.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Chaka Khan and Colonel Abrams, Pier 84, 12th Avenue at 45th Street (ticket and weather information: 249-8870). Chaka Khan has such a strong vocal personality that she hurtles over the conventional boundaries of rock, soul and jazz with a carefree iconoclasm. Brash, fearless and loud, Ms. Khan has a piercing voice that swoops, glides and pirouettes through the trickiest pop-jazz phrasing. While her devil-may-care attitude is better-suited to uptempo songs than to more reflective material, when handed the right ballad she also projects a stormy intensity. The pop-funk singer Colonel Abrams, who opens for Ms. Khan, is a solid dance-pop balladeer in the Luther Vandross mode. Showtime is tonight at 7:30, and tickets are $15.

title: PROSPECT GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary gains of $427,000 and $1,829,000 from the benefit of a tax credit for the quarter and the 6 months, respectively. c-Net loss

title: JET AMERICA AIRLINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: U.S. HOPING FOR A REPLY TO OFFER, SENDING TOP ARMS TEAM TO SOVIET
description: An American arms control delegation is going to Moscow over the next few days with no specific agenda, but in the expectation that the Soviet Union may respond to recent American proposals, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: Fine-Tuning Bo Jackson
description: Avron Fogelman, a co-owner with Ewing Kauffman of the Kansas City Royals, announced this week that Bo Jackson will play in his first major league game sometime in September.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: ROB REINER, the son of the comedian and film maker Carl Reiner, is still much more famous for his television portrayal of Michael (Meathead) Stivic on ''All in the Family'' than for directing films. But his three features, ''This Is Spinal Tap,'' a viciously accurate documentary spoof of a heavy-metal rock band, the romantic comedy ''The Sure Thing,'' and now ''Stand by Me'' - an adventure drama about four small-town boys, which opens today - have established him as a director with a keen eye for veracity. Especially with ''Stand by Me,'' adapted from Stephen King's novella ''The Body,'' he took the story very personally.

title: THEATER: 'HONKY TONK,' ABOUT BLACK VAUDEVILLE
description: IF energy were the principal criterion in determining the quality of a Broadway musical, ''Honky Tonk Nights'' might stand high on the Richter scale. Despite the hand-clapping enthusiasm - and the musicality - of the cast, however, the show that opened last night at the Biltmore Theater is pallid entertainment. The book is bare and the songs, for the most part, have a bland familiarity.

title: Advertising; Addendum
description: * Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt, Chicago, has made an initial endowment of $100,000 to the University of Chicago Graduate School of Business.

title: CENTRAL VERMONT PUBLIC SERVICE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

description: The father of a former Wall Street analyst has agreed to pay the Government $1 million in profits and a record $2.1 million civil penalty to settle Federal insider trading charges relating to the merger of the General Electric Company and the RCA Corporation, according to court papers filed yesterday.

title: Shanghai's Wartime Jews Are Object of Study
description: The Chinese Government has agreed to join an American interfaith foundation in undertaking a study of the Eastern European Jews who found refuge in Shanghai in World War II, the American group said yesterday.

title: HALLIBURTON CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes special writedowns of $502,915,000, which includes $308.6 million for oil field services and products and $194.3 million for marine engineering and construction for the quarter and 6 months. c-After an extraordinary charge of $328,012,000, which was a provision for anticipated settlement of litigation relating to the south Texas Nuclear Power Project for the quarter and 6 months.

title: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Duncan Hill Group, a maker of pipes and tobacco and smoking pipes in North Canton, Ohio, to Fisher Advertising, Chicago.

title: Interco Completes Converse Buyout
description: Interco Inc. said it had entered into a definitive agreement to acquire the outstanding shares of Converse Inc. at $28 a share, or a total of $146 million. Interco currently holds 500,000 Converse shares, or about 9.6 percent of the total outstanding, and as part of the agreement Converse has granted it an option to buy another 1,042,000 shares.

title: 'ROWDIES,' A COMEDY ABOUT SECURITY GUARDS
description: TELEVISION has had comic cops. ''Rowdies'' is about comic security guards. At the same time, it's not really a comedy; its ethos is indeterminate. What do you say about a program that opens with a burglar being thrown through a plate glass window, and concludes with assorted characters being sprayed with what looks like whipped cream? Whatever you say, ''Rowdies,'' a one-hour ABC film, is on Channel 7 at 9 o'clock tonight.

title: In the Wings
description: John McEnroe has returned and Jimmy Connors doggedly hangs on to his ranking in the top five. A number of other Americans, among them Tim Mayotte and Brad Gilbert, are ranked in the top 20.

title: Mackerras and Mozart
description: Sir Charles Mackerras will lead the Mostly Mozart Orchestra in works by Mozart and Schubert, with the pianist Alicia de Larrocha as soloist, at Avery Fisher Hall tonight and tomorrow night at 8. Tickets are $8 to $15. Information: 874-2424.

title: HEALTHPLEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SCREEN: EDWARDS'S 'FINE MESS'
description: TOWARD the end of Blake Edwards's ''Fine Mess,'' which opens today at the Baronet and other theaters, things rise to low farce. A fancy bedroom, a Mafia godfather, the godfather's bimbo of a wife, the wife's bed mate, the bed mate's feckless pal, the pal's infatuated girlfriend, a couple of clumsy hoodlums, a butler with pretensions, a player piano and a door handle that won't stay put are brought together to produce several laughs. They are a long time coming and not worth the wait.

title: Seattle Financing Tied to Sales Tax
description: A $80 million financing by Seattle was awarded to Bear, Stearns & Company in competitive bidding yesterday.

title: REHNQUIST PANEL GETS MORE MEMOS
description: Democratic members of the Senate Judiciary Committee today requested and received access to additional documents dating from William H. Rehnquist's service as head of the Justice Department's Office of Legal Counsel.

title: Japan Blocks Chip Sales
description: Japan has blocked unusually heavy American orders for semiconductors, to insure the success of a new microchip trade pact between the two countries. The Ministry of International Trade and Industry is temporarily withholding export certificates for 256-kilobit dynamic random access memories, a chip that makes up 80 percent of Japan's chip exports to America. The ministry moved at the end of July to halt shipments to American customers who wanted orders filled before the accord on price monitoring took effect Aug. 1, an official said today.

title: What Andrew Young Said to Bishop Tutu
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 NORTH BERGEN AIDES HELD IN ILLEGAL DUMPING SCHEME
description: Ten men, including the North Bergen Clerk and two other township officials, were arrested today on racketeering charges stemming from a $5 million-a-year scheme to dump tons of construction debris from New York illegally in North Bergen and Newark.

title: CORROON & BLACK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $109,000 and a loss on disposal of discontinued operations of $1,979,000.

title: HODGSON HOUSES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company is also listed on the Boston Stock Exchange.

title: Likely Fairview Buyers Include the Reichmanns
description: The wealthy Reichmann family is widely considered here to be the most likely buyer of the Cadillac Fairview Corporation, a move that would create an enormously powerful force in North American real estate.

title: HIGH-WIRE CIRCUS COUPLE FROM SOVIET DEFECTS TO U.S.
description: A husband-and-wife tightrope act from the Moscow Circus defected in Argentina and flew to the United States today in a bid for political asylum.

title: CLOROX COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
AUCTIONS
description: EVEN the auction catalogue had to call the item ''unusual.'' It consisted of the natural head of a fox, right down to the whiskers, although the eyes were glass. The head was mounted on a silver cup with a scrolled handle topped by a silver cluster of grapes. At Christie's Fine English and Continental Silver auction last year, the work carried an estimated value of $1,000 to $1,500. But the bidding never got over $850. In the words of the auction trade, the item - listed in the catalogue as ''An Unusual Victorian Silver-Mounted Fox Mask Stirrup Cup, London, 1857'' - was ''bought in,'' temporarily acquired by the gallery in a transaction where no money changed hands.

title: A Third Eye and Ear
description: The idea is spreading that nuclear arms control is everybody's business, not just the nuclear powers', because everybody would be affected by nuclear war. The atom has no respect for neutrality.

title: NEW ARMS CHAPTER: A CAST OF 10
description: MAYNARD W. GLITMAN: United States negotiator on intermediate range nuclear arms in Geneva...Was deputy negotiator to Paul H. Nitze when talks opened in 1981...Career Foreign Service officer...52 years old...Headed a delegation to the East-West talks in Vienna on reducing conventional forces in Central Europe.

title: CONGRESSIONAL OFFICE AT ODDS WITH WHITE HOUSE ON DEFICIT
description: The Congressional Budget Office today differed significantly with the White House in its predictions for economic growth and the Federal budget deficit for 1987.

title: Diner's Journal
description: WORD is spreading quickly around TriBeCa about a new Tuscan-style trattoria that serves brassy regional pastas and grilled seafood in a relaxed and airy setting. Called Barocco, it is in a spare, high-ceilinged former art gallery at the corner of Church and Walker Streets.

title: AT SOUTH AFRICA BORDER, WHITE FARMERS DIG IN
description: The white farmers of this settlement on the Botswana border are preparing for a conflict against black insurgency. To some, the struggle already seems lost.

title: Advertising; USAdvertising
description: Lorimar-Telepictures, parent company of both Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt and USAdvertising, said that it would be converting the Union, N.J., office of Bozell into USAdvertising. That will add 50 more members to the staff of USAdvertising, increasing it to 87 in New York and New Jersey, as well as doubling its billings to $50 million.

title: JAMES A. FARLEY Jr.
description: James A. Farley Jr., a former chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission and the son of the former Postmaster General, died Wednesday of complications after heart-bypass surgery at the Seton Medical Center in Daly City, Calif. He was 58 years old.

title: ON ROD AND REEL, A 3,450-LB. SHARK IS LANDED
description: There was whooping and shouting and carrying on here when Donnie Braddick returned to the docks with what is apparently the largest great white shark ever taken on a rod and reel.

title: EASTERN UTILITIES ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Transactions
description: BASEBALL BALTIMORE (AL) - Activated Eddie Murray, first baseman, from the 21-day disabled list; optioned Nate Snell, pitcher, to Rochester of the International League.

title: SARE KING WONG
description: Sare King Wong, a senior adviser to Taiwan's Kuomingtang Party, died Friday. He was 91 years old and lived in San Francisco.

title: MUSEUM CHIEF QUITS TO WRITE NOVELS
description: The Smithsonian Institution's National Air and Space Museum announced today that its director, Walter J. Boyne, was resigning to devote himself to a career of fiction writing.

title: Escaped Killer Caught After 4-Day Manhunt
description: Richard Foster, the condemned killer who escaped from prison and eluded a manhunt for four days, was captured tonight while trying to sneak past law officers with a hostage, the authorities said.

title: ALLEGHENY & WESTERN ENERGY reports earnings for Year to June 30
NUI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: FORMER CITY COMMISSIONER CLEARED AFTER INQUIRY
description: Patrick W. McGinley, who resigned as the city's Investigation Commissioner last January because he was himself under investigation, will not be charged with any crime, the Manhattan District Attorney announced yesterday.

title: To Improve Schools, Let Principals Teach and Teachers Teach
description: To the Editor:

title: Jury Finds That Flynt Libeled Penthouse Aide
description: A Federal jury found today that Hustler magazine and its publisher, Larry Flynt, had libeled an executive at Penthouse, and the panel awarded the executive $2 million in damages. Hustler said it would appeal.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: THE guests on the yacht Entrepreneur Monday evening gathered around the video screen, looked at the tape showing Evelyn Lauder's face and sang ''The Evelyn Lauder Marching Song'' in unison. It was Mrs. Lauder's birthday and she had agreed to let her husband, Leonard, mark the occasion with a semisurprise party. Until the moment came, she had no idea where the yacht would go - around the East and Hudson Rivers to see the Statue of Liberty - nor who was on the guest list, a melange of 99 childhood, college, business and art world friends. ''There were faces that I loved there, a brass quintet, a palm reader and four wonderful birthday cakes,'' Mrs. Lauder said.

title: LOEWS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $10.6 million for the quarter and $13.5 million for the 6 months. Loews said it has accounted for its investment in CBS Inc. on the equity method beginning with the 1986 second quarter. Accordingly, the net for the latest second quarter has been retroactively restated.

title: EVENTS: AMERICAN SYMPHONY TO PAUL ZALOOM
description: The following events in the Lincoln Center Out-of-Doors Festival are free and open to the public. Information: 877-2011. Today At 5 P.M. Fountain Plaza. D. J. McDonald and Dancers. ''Lost Tribes.'' At 8:15 P.M. Damrosch Park. ''Sister Suzie Cinema,'' a doo-wop opera.

title: Kean Plans Travel For New Business
description: Governor Kean said today that he will leave Sept. 7 for a 17-day trip to China and South Korea to promote business for New Jersey companies and foreign investment in the state. He will visit Hong Kong, Hangzhou and Peking in China, and Seoul, South Korea, before returning on Sept. 24.

title: DYNASCAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: 6 NATIONS URGE HALT IN NUCLEAR TESTING
description: The leaders of six nonnuclear countries called on the United States and the Soviet Union today to halt all nuclear testing under a verification plan that the six Governments would administer.

title: Stocks Up Moderately; Dow Moves 6.75 Higher
description: With blue-chip issues providing some underpinning for the market, stock prices rose moderately yesterday as caution continued over the course of interest rates and the economy.

title: THE TENSE, SECRET TALKS BEHIND GOLDMAN MOVE
description: As the news that the Sumitomo Bank Ltd. was negotiating to buy a large stake in Goldman, Sachs & Company began to sink in yesterday, professionals at the Wall Street firm were quick to quip that it will change its name to Goldman, Sake.

title: PARCELLS GIVES MIXED REPORT ON OPENER
description: The Giants' offense, Coach Bill Parcells said today, was inconsistent, but the starters did all right once they got going. He said the first defense did well enough, but the second defense made mental errors. The special teams, he said, were a fiasco.

title: Waterloo Festival
description: The last weekend of the Waterloo Festival will feature performances of Howard Hanson's ''Elegy in Memory of Serge Koussevitsky,'' Aaron Copland's Symphony No. 3, and Tchaikovsky's Concerto No. 1 in B flat (Op. 23), with the pianist Alexander Toradze, tomorrow night at 8:30 at Waterloo Village.

title: Rehnquist to Scalia, Bitterness to Bonhomie
description: After the rancorous partisan disputes that marked the Senate hearing last week on Chief Justice-designate William H. Rehnquist, the session this week on Associate Justice-designate Antonin Scalia began almost like a bipartisan celebration of the American dream.

title: INDEX TO JUSTICE DEPT. DOCUMENTS RECEIVED BY PANEL IN REHNQUIST HEARING
description: Following is an index to Justice Department documents given to the Senate Judiciary Committee in response to an Aug. 4 request for information relative to Justice William H. Rehnquist, whose nomination to be Chief Justice of the United States the panel is considering:

title: SEIBELS BRUCE GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of $593,505 for the quarter; includes capital gains of $403,327 and $2,301,919 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively; and includes a previously announced $16 million reserve deficiency for both periods. c-Includes capital losses of $131,639 and income from discontinued operations of $497,769 for the quarter, and for the 6 months, capital gains of $76,440 and income of $1,785,704 from discontinued operations.

title: FIRST MISSISSIPPI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a pretax writedown on the value of oil and gas reserves and related assets of $19 million for the quarter and $50 million for the year. c-Net income and the year includes income of $900,000 from discontinued operations.

title: The Global Pocketbook
description: WHEN the Federal Reserve head, Paul Volcker, told Congress last week that the sagging American economy needs a bail-out from West Germany and Japan, it was a far cry from how the Reagan team used to brag about America's status as the world's economic locomotive. Even so, it was an understatement of our weakness.

title: AMERICAN INTERNATIONAL GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes realized gains $8,245,000 for the quarter and $20,647,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes realized gains of $11,656,000 and $22,138,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: UCCEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $2,105,000 for the quarter, and for the 6 months, includes a loss of $1,485,000 from discontinued operations and a tax credit of $3,465,000. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $315,000 and $386,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and extraordinary credits of $1,145,000 and $1,945,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Grievance Filed Over Arbitrator
description: The Major League Baseball Players Association took the first step yesterday in its attempt to keep its free-agent conspiracy case alive before Thomas Roberts, whom the owners have fired as baseball's impartial arbitrator.

title:
ECONOMIC SCENE;
U.S.-Japanese Corporate Ties
description: FED by a high savings rate, a huge surplus in balance of trade and strong corporate profits (until just recently), Japan has built up a huge capital base with which it could invest in foreign companies or build plants abroad. But because protectionist spirit has been rising in the United States Congress, many Japanese companies are choosing instead to form international alliances that link the biggest and strongest companies in both countries.

title: Fostina Dixon
description: The saxophonist and singer Fostina Dixon will lead her group, Winds of Change, in a free concert today at 12:30 P.M. in Bryant Park, between Fifth Avenue and Avenue of the Americas at 42d Street behind the New York Public Library. Information: 505-5660.

title: KDI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HELMS ASSAILS MANY OVER CHILE
description: Senator Jesse Helms said tonight that the State Department, the Central Intelligence Agency and the news media were all combining to produce a ''massive campaign of disinformation'' about the situation in Chile under the military regime of Gen. Augusto Pinochet.

title: Iraqi Planes Attack Targets in Iran
description: Iraq said its warplanes today hit Iran's Kharg Island oil terminal three times, and an oil refinery, a power station and two generators in Isfahan, Iran's second-largest city, which is 240 miles from the Iraqi border.

title: The Cloud Over Jesse Helms
description: Hours after the C.I.A. gave a briefing on Chile to a member of the staff of Senator Jesse Helms, Chile's military rulers learned that United States intelligence had confidential information about the violent death last month of an American teen-ager during a demonstration in Santiago. So, at least, runs the complaint of the State Department.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds increased $507.6 million, to $232.04 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: BROADWAY
description: SAMUEL BECKETT directing Samuel Beckett is news. When it is the only production of his play ''Krapp's Last Tape'' that Beckett ever directed, that is also news. And when this particular production is performed by Rick Cluchey, a former San Quentin inmate, a close friend and protege of the playwright who has interpreted Beckett's works in Europe and Australia but never in New York, that is even bigger news.

title: HANOVER INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After capital gains of $4,150,000 for the quarter and $5,686,000 for the 6 months and a tax credit of $13,773,000 for the quarter and 6 months. c-After capital gains of $8,657,000 for the quarter and $9,303,000 for the 6 months and a tax credit of $513,000 for the quarter and 6 months.

title: Charges Dropped In Shelter Fire
description: A judge today dropped charges against an unemployed maintenance man accused of setting a fire that left 50 cats and dogs dead at the Elmsford Animal Shelter last year.

title: Poindexter's Blues
description: Buster Poindexter will sing blues, pop and rhythm and blues tonight and tomorrow at Tramps, 125 East 15th Street (777-5077), with sets at 9:30 P.M. and midnight. There is a $10 cover and a two-drink minimum. On Sunday, the country-rock singer Kristi Rose will perform with her band, the Dying Breed, at 9:30 P.M. and midnight, with a $5 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title: TWO SIDES IN SALVADOR FAR APART ON NEW TALKS
description: Promised talks between the Salvadoran Government and leftist rebels are being delayed because the two sides remain far apart on the date, locale and security measures for the meeting, a Government spokesman said today.

title: NEW COLOMBIA CHIEF STRESSES DOMESTIC PROBLEMS
description: The new President of Colombia took the oath of office today with a pledge to give priority during his four-year term to combating ''absolute poverty'' and ending decades of political violence.

title: For Alaskan Town, Two Sunsets Today
description: The sun sets twice Friday. At least at the Chukchi Sea coastal town of Kotzebue in northwest Alaska.

title: Salazar to Return
description: ''I look at this as the start of my second career,'' said Alberto Salazar, announcing that the New York City Marathon on Nov. 2 would be his first marathon since the 1984 Olympics.

title: Libyan Funds Frozen To Cover Italian Debt
description: An Italian court has frozen $4.9 million in Libyan Government funds on deposit here to cover longstanding debts owed to two Italian companies.

title: ENVOY TO DENMARK CALLS U.S. POLICY ON APARTHEID NOT YET CREDIBLE
description: Terence A. Todman, the United States Ambassador to Denmark, said today that the Reagan Administration should not appoint a new envoy to South Africa until it develops a more credible opposition to apartheid.

title: People Who Need Dollars
description: Campaigns of six Democrats running for the Senate stand to profit considerably from a $1 million Hollywood fund-raising party next month starring Barbra Streisand, who has not sung in public for six years, and Robin Williams, the television and film comedian. Tickets, available by invitation only, will cost $5,000 a couple, for a limit of 400 people.

title: A New 'Carmen'
description: Bizet's ''Carmen,'' in Frank Corsaro's provocative new conception, will be presented by the New York City Opera tonight at 8.

title: GAME GUERRERO
description: Not all athletes these days want to take the money and run. Some take the money and try to run, but can't. Or do so limpingly.

title: Reading O'Neill
description: When is an endorsement not quite an endorsement?

title: White House Reviews Rules
description: The White House said today that it had reviewed more than 2,200 proposals for regulatory changes by its executive agencies in 1985.

title: BEATRICE UNIT SALE CONFIRMED
description: BCI Holdings, confirming reports that it would sell the Beatrice Companies' personal products operations for $1.25 billion to an investment group, announced yesterday that it would retain a 20 percent interest in the new company.

title: Kirkland at Joanna
description: The pianist Kenny Kirkland is appearing tonight through Sunday at Joanna, 18 East 18th Street (675-7900). Sets are at 8:30 and 11 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is a two-drink minimum.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Sun Ra, the Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street (228-7880). Sun Ra's jazz experience stretches from the Fletcher Henderson Orchestra of the late 1940's to the earliest fusions of electronics, free-form and tribal polyrhythms in the 60's.

title: FLORIDA FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income and includes an extraordinary credit of $4,652,000 for the quarter and $6,274,598 for the year from termination of a plan and FHLB dividend. The company attributed the latest year loss to $73.5 million in loss provisions on loans and real estate investments.

title: DOLLAR GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
RESTAURANTS
description: OF all the culinary trends that have sprouted in New York City in recent years, however fleeting, one that has thrown strong roots and become part of the landscape is so-called California cuisine. This winsome approach to cooking involves minimalist techniques of grilling and sauteing fish and meat, and mating them with light, vegetable-based sauces and enough fresh greenery to make a nutritionist swoon. Though clearly derivative of French nouvelle cuisine, California cuisine, with regional accents ranging from Tex-Mex to New England, is distinctly all-American.

title: HARTMARX'S ROAD TO GROWTH
description: The Hartmarx Corporation, the nation's leading producer of tailored clothes for men, has long tried to be all things to all people.

title: INSTRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a tax credit of $109,000. The share earnings reflect 2-for-1 stock split paid in June.

title: ART: BOTANICAL SHOW AT HISTORICAL SOCIETY
description: AT this point in the summer there is much to be said for an exhibition that takes up very little space, can be looked at leisurely and in silence, and is mostly about birds and flowers, all of them at peace with one another and painted up to look their very best.

title: Garn Ends Bank Effort
description: The chairman of the Senate Banking Committee said today that he had abandoned his effort for this year to push for greater securities powers for the nation's 14,000 commercial banks. Jake Garn, a Utah Republican, said he would try to get his committee to approve a banking bill that would not include new businesses for banks such as selling commercial paper and mutual funds. He had included these powers in a bill introduced earlier this summer, but a lack of broad support in his committee and the Treasury's opposition to other aspects of the bill undermined his effort.

title: Sweetened Revco Bid Seen
description: A group trying to acquire Revco D. S. Inc., the drugstore chain, in a leveraged buyout is expected to sweeten its offer to about $38 a share, or $1.27 billion, sources close to the situation said today.

title: PUERTO RICO CALLS FOR INQUIRY IN BRONX ATTACK ON 2 YOUTHS
description: The Commonwealth of Puerto Rico has asked the Federal Government to investigate the attack last week on two Puerto Rican teen-agers by a group of white youths in the Bronx.

title: ANTHONY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 5-for-4 stock split paid in June.

title: OLD AND NEW BLEND IN GOSPEL MUSIC
description: ''Never in my life,'' said Shirley Caesar, who will be topping the quadruple-billed gospel concert tomorrow at the Apollo Theater, ''have I been tempted to sing anything else but gospel music. No, no, no, no, no.''

title: A NEW PLAN TO PROMOTE SLOW-SELLING CONVERSION
description: Since last November the owners of North Shore Towers, a development of three 33-story buildings that straddles the Queens-Nassau County border, have been trying to convert their complex into a cooperative. It has not been easy. In one of New York State's largest non-eviction conversions, the owner of the 10-year-old rent-stabilized complex is offering 5,975,452 shares -representing 1,844 apartments and 2,492 parking spaces - for a maximum selling price of more than $677.5 million, according to the prospectus.

title: Fred C. Foy, 81, Retired Chief Of Koppers Co. in Pittsburgh
description: Fred C. Foy, former president, chief executive officer and chairman of the Koppers Company, a Pittsburgh conglomerate, died Monday at his home in Rector, Pa. He was 81 years old.

title: KMG Main Denies Merger Report
description: KMG Main Hurdman, the international accounting firm, said that it had received offers to merge with ''a number of accounting firms,'' including Peat Marwick. But it denied a report in The Wall Street Journal that it is close to a combination with Peat Marwick, and it said any merger was some time off.

title: An Elaborate Process Of Lost and Found
description: Missing: the money, passports and personal papers of Amos Elon, the Israeli writer.

title: Israeli Mission to South Africa
description: Israel sent a high-level delegation to South Africa tonight to negotiate a renewal of trade and credit agreements.

title: Hussein and Mubarak Finish Talks in Egypt
description: King Hussein of Jordan and President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt ended 24 hours of talks on Middle East peace prospects today amid a news blackout.

title: IN SARATOGA, LOOKING PROPER AT THE RACES
description: A century ago Henry James described this summer resort as a place ''where the greatest amount of dressing may be seen by the greatest number of people.'' It is still a dressy place, never more so than in August, when the wardrobe required for the racing season and its surrounding social whirl is enough to burst a Saratoga trunk.

title: Change in Will Linked To Saigon Aide's Death
description: A former South Vietnamese envoy and his wife had disinherited the son who is charged with murdering them here last month, a police detective said today.

title: INDIANA PASTRAMI? HEBREW NATIONAL PLANS MOVE
description: Who cares where the beef is. The question of the hour is: Where will the pastrami be?

title: New York Group Lists Detentions in Poland
description: A New York group says the Polish Government has continued to use imprisonment as a weapon against Solidarity supporters despite periodic amnesties.

title: T.W.A.-Ozark Merger Backed
description: A Government hearing officer today recommended approval of Trans World Airlines Inc.'s $250 million takeover of Ozark Air Lines Inc., rejecting Justice Department findings that the merger would harm competition. A final decision rests with

title: POSSIBLE PERJURY BY DEAVER FOUND IN STAFF'S REPORT
description: A Congressional subcommittee investigating the activities of Michael K. Deaver has received a report recommending that an independent counsel examine evidence of ''possible perjury'' by Mr. Deaver in his testimony before the panel, the chairman said today.

title: WINSTON MILLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss and includes a loss from discontinued operations of $600,000 and $541,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Certainly if a C.I.A. agent defects to the Soviet Union, it damages us.

title: WARD DRIVES IN 5 TO HELP EDGE ORIOLES
description: Gary Ward drove in five runs, including the first of four runs in the seventh inning, as the Texas Rangers came from behind for the second straight game and beat the Baltimore Orioles, 9-8, tonight.

title: RALPH THOMAS HORGAN
description: Ralph Thomas Horgan, an officer of Josephthal & Company Inc., a Manhattan brokerage concern, died of sclerosis of the liver Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 80 years old.

title: LAW NOW LETS NEW YORKERS GET LIQUOR WITH CREDIT CARDS
description: New York consumers may now use credit cards to buy wine and liquor at liquor stores, under a bill signed into law today by Governor Cuomo.

title: No Contamination Is Found In Kool-Aid by Investigators
description: Three Brooklyn stores pulled packages of Kool-Aid from their shelves after a telephone caller said he had laced them with cyanide, but a check failed to turn up any contamination, Federal authorities said yesterday.

title: A Chance at Life for AIDS Sufferers
description: BY now, we all know the gruesome statistics.

title: Oil Prices Rise a Bit; Traders Are Watchful
description: Prices of crude oil and petroleum products rose moderately in the world oil markets yesterday. Analysts said traders had adopted a wait-and-see attitude about whether the production-limiting agreement reached by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries could send prices higher.

title: DEBATE IN CAPITAL GROWING ON PLANE IN FIGHT ON DRUGS
description: Reagan Administration officials are resisting a Congressional effort to have the Navy pay for the manufacturer's alterations of a Navy plane to make it capable of intercepting drug runners, according to Government and industry officials.

title: Man Slain on Queens Street
description: A 52-year-old Queens man was fatally shot on a street in Jackson Heights early yesterday while picking up cans that he apparently intended to redeem for the deposits, the police said. They said the victim, identified as Louis Fehsenfeld of 37-55 79th Street in Jackson Heights, a Parks Department employee, was shot in the chest shortly after 4 A.M. after he was approached by two or three men in their 20's in front of 34-24 82d Street. Mr. Fehsenfeld died at the City Hospital Center at Elmhurst, the police said. The motive for the shooting was unclear.

title: Disarm the Ballot Booby Traps
description: This year's orgy of court fights over New York's September primary ballot has claimed nearly 200 victims - candidates thrown off merely for deviating from strictest adherence to the form for nominating-petition cover sheets. Just yesterday, a State Supreme Court judge disqualified an incumbent Brooklyn Assemblyman, Roger Green, for the same trivial error - even though he had 2,792 signatures, five times the required number. Scores of valid candidacies are in jeopardy throughout the state.

title: ROB REINER'S 'STAND BY ME'
description: SINCE ''Stand by Me'' is rated R, owing to all the dirty talk, unaccompanied children under 17 are not supposed to be admitted to the Coronet and the other theaters where it opens today. Some 15-year-olds may well enjoy this tale about some 12-year-olds, so parents will have to decide how much they are willing to endure for their kids.

title: PERICLES J. LANTZOUNIS
description: Pericles J. Lantzounis, a real-estate developer in the Yorkville section of Manhattan and a leader of the Greek community in New York, died last Friday at Beth Israel Hospital. He was 85 years old.

title: GREY ADVERTISING INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Revenue represents gross billings.

title: A FLURRY OF FESTIVALS, INDOORS AND OUT
description: The Gershwin at Guild Hall festival will be presented through Sept. 20 at Guild Hall, 158 Main Street, East Hampton, L.I. Tickets for each event range from $4 to $20; tickets to the benefits are $20. ''Ira - The Words, George - The Music,'' an exhibition of art, documents and other items, will be on view tomorrow through Sept. 21.

title: Topics; Moving On/Moving In; Colombian Challenge
description: Before the administration of Belisario Betancur, many Colombians saw politics as the closed game of a narrow political class. Mr. Betancur, a populist Conservative who completed his presidential term yesterday, attacked that perception head on, and he leaves Colombian democracy stronger than he found it.

title: KASPAROV DONE IN BY WEAK POSITION
description: Unexpectedly faulty positional judgment brought about the downfall of Gary Kasparov on Wednesday in the fifth game of his world championship chess match with Anatoly Karpov in London. Thus, the 23-year-old champion had no sooner achieved a one-point lead over the 35-year-old former champion in the previous game than he saw it taken away.

title: Zionism Isn't Always America's Best Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: Joseph Thomas Dies; Jazz Saxophone Soloist
description: The jazz musician Joseph Thomas, best known for his work as a tenor saxophone soloist with the Jimmie Lunceford Orchestra from the early 1930's until 1947, died last Sunday. He was 77 years old.

title: Court Throws Out Suit Against Ozzy Osbourne
description: A judge today threw out a lawsuit against the rock star Ozzy Osbourne and two record companies. The suit charged that the British singer's music contributed to the suicide of a teen-ager in 1984.

title: Dakota Staton Sings
description: The singer Dakota Staton will give a free concert today at 12:15 P.M. at Chase Manhattan Plaza, Nassau and Liberty Streets, concluding the Women in Jazz Downtown series. Information: 269-0320.

title: Deep Shortstop
description: Rena Lenhardt, the sister of the late Ernie Lombardi, represented her brother at the Baseball Hall of Fame induction ceremonies in Cooperstown, N.Y., on Sunday and recalled that infielders often played the hard-hitting but slow-footed catcher back on the outfield grass. She said he once remarked, ''I was in the majors for four years before I realized that Pee Wee Reese was an infielder.''

title: No Free Network
description: What kind of social group would invite you to a cash-bar party with the argument that buying your own drinks exemplifies ''the true spirit of the conservative free market philosophy''? And advertise ''a limited supply of potato chips, pretzels, etc. but no free lunch''?

title: 20 Are Hurt as Tornado Strikes Providence
description: A tornado, with heavy rain, struck the downtown section of Providence in the evening rush hour today, damaging buildings, flipping parked cars and flooding roads. At least 20 people suffered minor injuries, hospital officials said.

title: STAGE: 'PEDRO NAVAJA'
description: ALTHOUGH it flays more malefactors than a medieval morality play, ''La Verdadera Historia de Pedro Navaja,'' Pablo Cabrera's crackling musical, is beneficent; you walk away from it convinced that salvation by sin may not be an unreasonable undertaking after all. The folly of the crooks, prostitutes and hypocrites harms only themselves, and not much.

title: A FLURRY OF FESTIVALS, INDOORS AND OUT; DOO-WOP TO CALYPSO IN ALFRESCO SETTINGS AROUND LINCOLN CENTER
description: ''We have more creative latitude than we would if we had to sell tickets,'' Leonard de Paur, the director of Lincoln Center Out-of-Doors, said recently. ''We can do all the things Lincoln Center is famous for - symphonic concerts, chamber music and so on -but we are also able to experiment a bit, to try something new.''

title: SENATE, WITH BUSH VOTING, REJECTS MEASURE AGAINST NERVE GAS BOMB
description: With Vice President Bush casting a tie-breaking vote, the Senate today killed an amendment intended to block the first limited production of a disputed nerve gas bomb. The tally was 51 to 50.

title: 3 From Hunt Family Sue
description: Three Hunt family members, Caroline Hunt Schoellkopf, Margaret Hunt Hill and Haroldson L. Hunt Jr., filed a lawsuit Wednesday asking that they not be held liable for damages that might result from multibillion-dollar lawsuits involving their brothers and 23 banks because they no longer have ownership interests in the Placid Oil Company, one of the Hunt companies.

The Los Angeles Lakers have signed Billy Thompson, their first-round pick, to a multiyear contract. The 6-foot-7-inch Thompson played for Louisville, last season's National Collegiate Athletic Association champions. The Lakers did not disclose the contract's terms.

title: Advertising; Time Plans Preview Of a Style Magazine
