title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday SOUNDS OF SUMMER A hybrid of two popular summertime festivals begins this evening with its own name and an eclectic program. The New York Summer Festival combines the all-day Motown concerts-in-the-park of the Southern Queens Summer Festival with the intimate nightclub performances of the New York Folk Festival, and throws in some arts-and-crafts exhibits and children's games as well. The two festivals, each in its sixth year, are being fused with the help of Folkworks, a production company, and will run through next weekend. Tonight at Speakeasy, a revival of star performers of past folk festivals will feature Tom Intondi, David Massengill, Nikki Matheson and Dave Sear. Shows are at 8:30 and 11 P.M. and admission is $6. The club is at 107 Macdougal Street at Bleecker, near the West Fourth Street-Washington Square subway station. Tomorrow, a ''Sixties-Eighties'' picnic at Roy Wilkins Park in St. Albans, Queens, will run from noon to 7 P.M. Featured are Eddie Kendrick and David Ruffin, the former lead singers of the Temptations, known for such hits as ''My Girl'' and ''The Way You Do the Things You Do''; also on the bill are Tommy James and the Shondells. Sunday, also from noon to 7 P.M. at Roy Wilkins Park, a concert of African and calypso music will feature the Mighty Sparrow, Calypso Rose, Dinizulu and others. Admission for each concert is $10 in advance and $12 at the park. The park is at 119th Avenue and Merrick Boulevard; there will be shuttle buses every 15 minutes from the 169th Street station of the E and F subway lines.

title: Emilio Fernandez, 82, Mexican Film Director
description: Emilio (El Indio) Fernandez, one of the most important figures in the Mexican film industry, died Wednesday of a heart attack at his Mexico City home. He was 82 years old. Mr. Fernandez, who was born on March 26, 1904, in the northern state of Coahuila, began his film career playing bit parts and supporting roles in Hollywood, later achieving some prominence as an actor in Mexico.

title: MCENROE WINS AND REFLECTS ON OUTBURST
description: How long John McEnroe chooses to play professional tennis may not ultimately be determined by his ranking on a computer. After only four days and two matches in his first tournament since returning to the Grand Prix tour, it has become clear to McEnroe that before his considerable skills diminish, he may be forced to leave because of an attitude he says is now unacceptable.

title: UROLOGICAL PROBLEMS ARE DESCRIBED BY EXPERTS AS COMMON IN OLDER MEN

title: THE FACTORY-BACKED USED CAR
description: Ken Gann was a little leery about buying a used car - especially for $23,000. ''I didn't trust them,'' said Mr. Gann, who is president of Florida Express Airline in Orlando. In February, however, Mr. Gann passed over the Lincolns and Chryslers he had been eyeing, and paid that much for a gray 1983 Jaguar XJ6 sedan. And a few weeks later, he persuaded his son, Mike, a 22-year-old defensive end with the Atlanta Falcons, to buy a black 1982 XJ6 for $20,000.

SCREEN: 'TRANSFORMERS,' ANIMATION FOR CHILDREN
description: It wasn't quite pearls at the opera or green hair at rock concerts, but the audience at ''The Transformers -The Movie'' was de rigueur in its own small way. A girl who looked 4 or 5 carried a Transformer toy - part doll, part car, the toys represent robots that can be changed into trucks, spaceships and other high-tech objects. Across the aisle, a slightly older boy waved a Transformer comic book. As the offscreen dynamics reveal, the Transformers - enormously popular toys that became a television cartoon, then an animated movie - are the latest fusion of commerce and childhood imagination.

title: 183 Evacuated as Ship Runs Aground in Alaska

Mike Sanders, a swingman, signed a three-year contract with the Phoenix Suns. . . . Col. Harvey Schiller, a chemistry professor who has been serving as the Air Force Academy's faculty representative to the National Collegiate Athletic Association and as a member of the N.C.A.A. executive committee, was named commissioner of the Southeastern Conference. . . . Harry Holt, a tight end, ended his holdout yesterday and reported to the Browns' training camp. . . . The National Football League yesterday voided the New Orleans Saints' contract with Antonio Gibson because the strong safety had not obtained a written release from the Baltimore Stars of the United States Football League.

title: Response to Grievance
description: Barry Rona, the head of the Player Relations Committee, which handles labor matters for major league owners, said a grievance filed by the Players Association protesting the owners' dismissal of baseball's impartial arbitrator, Thomas Roberts, in the middle of a hearing was ''absurd.'' Rona said the collective- bargaining agreement gives either side the right to dismiss the arbitrator at any time.

NEWS SUMMARY SATURDAY: AUGUST 9, 1986
description: International Congress's first move to halt testing of nuclear weapons was taken in the House, which voted to impose a yearlong moratorium on all but the smallest American underground nuclear tests if the Soviet Union would reciprocate and agree to allow verification devices on Soviet territory. The measure, which would be binding on the Reagan Administration if incorporated into final legislation, was approved by the unexpectedly large margin of 234 to 155. [ Page 1, Col. 6. ] Another huge car bomb exploded in the mainly Moslem sector of Beirut, killing 17 people and wounding 90 others. It was the seventh terrorist bombing in Lebanon's capital since July 28, and it was followed by two hours of artillery and rocket exchanges across the city's dividing line. The shelling inflicted more casualties in residential areas. [ 1:1. ] Insights from a Soviet defector helped prepare President Reagan for his meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev in Geneva last November, according to American officials. The officials said the defector, a former K.G.B. official named Oleg G. Gordiyevsky, had provided Mr. Reagan with important insights into the Soviet leader and Soviet policy. They said Mr. Gordiyevsky had advised Washington that Soviet leaders, while relentless in trying to expand their nation's influence, were ready to bargain seriously. [ 1:2. ] An envoy's comment that U.S. policy toward South Africa lacked credibility was ''distorted'' and taken out of context, the State Department said. The envoy, Terence A. Todman, who is black, is Ambassador to Denmark. Mr. Todman, a career foreign service officer who President Reagan was reported to have been considering as a new envoy to South Africa, made the remark Thursday in a news conference in Copenhagen.

title: Storer Offer For Wometco

title: Easing the Pain of Mass Transit
description: It will cost many billions, we are told, to improve New York City's transit system. Some of the features that make it the most unpleasant travel experience of any great city may be immune even to the billions. (One, perhaps, is graffiti, but it is amazing to note some clean cars, and one wonders why whatever it is that keeps them clean wasn't tried 10 years ago.) Which brings to mind the fact that so many things could be done that cost very little and would do a great deal to improve comfort and convenience and increase ridership - which would serve further to keep down crime.

description: Twenty-five years ago President John F. Kennedy said, ''The slogan 'It's deductible' should pass from our scene.'' description: The Northern Trust Corporation, the fourth-largestbank holding company in Illinois, said that it had acquired the First Lake Forest Corporation, the holding company of three suburban banks, for $61.9 million in cash. The acquisition gives Northern Trust a strong position in the lucrative Lake County area, north of Chicago along Lake Michigan. The Lake Forest Corporation, which has $419 million in assets, owns the First National Bank of Lake Forest, the Lake Forest National Bank and the First National Bank of Lake Bluff.

title: I Can't Come to the Phone Right Now
description: Inveterate readers of Miss Manners and others who believe in the possibility of distinguishing gentlemen from cads ought now to come out of the closet and identify the latest guerrilla action against socially acceptable behavior. The enemy this time is, of course, the phone answering machine. Recent statistics suggest that at least 10 percent of all American households own one of these devices, so the trend may well be irreversible, but acquiescence in the face of barbarism has never been the hero's way out.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 46. 1. ''Love,'' the artist's wife said, alluding to a trove of artworks that includes the painting from which this detail is taken. Who is the artist and what were the circumstances? 2. ''We've committed ourselves to exchange information with all friendly countries, north and south,'' said a prime minister, telling why his country had given Libya advance notice of the American air attack in April. Identify the prime minister's country. 3. According to President Reagan, by the end of his second term, (25/ 35/45/55) percent of all Federal judges would be his appointees. 4. ''If you come to New York to buy crack, bring carfare and be prepared to take the bus back,'' said Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward. To what was he referring? 5. The playing field, Wembley Stadium, was British, and so was the crowd, but the event was distinctly American. Explain. 6. Frank Mundus, whose achievements have made him legendary in fact and probably in fiction, added to his renown. What did he and a partner, Donnie Braddick, accomplish? 7. According to a report by the Presidential commission on the space shuttle program, a launching preceding the Challenger disaster by 22 days was stopped within 31 seconds of a potentially catastropic flight because of a human error. What happened? 8. Two nations that have not had diplomatic relations for 19 years will soon begin discussions in Helsinki on the opening of consulates.

title: Mexico Inflation Eases
description: The pace of inflation in Mexico slackened slightly in July with consumer prices rising 5 percent, bringing the total increase to 47.6 percent in the first seven months of the year, the nation's central bank reported. That is 17.5 points above the rate in 1985, when it totaled 30.1 percent at the end of July. Analysts have predicted that inflation will exceed 80 percent this year.

title: BAD BUSINESS AT SARATOGA
description: The horseplayers who have been howling for the heads of the three Saratoga stewards since those judges disqualified the wrong horse in the second race last Saturday finally got their wish Thursday, or at least a third of it. Salvatore J. Ferrara, the chief steward, has been ''reassigned'' to Finger Lakes Race Track in Canandaigua, N.Y. This punitive action by the State Racing and Wagering Board was the equivalent of sending Ferrara to the minor leagues, if there were a Double A franchise in Siberia. There was no joy in this announcement, nor any justice. Ferrara and two colleagues in the stewards' stand disqualified Allumeuse for a foul clearly committed by another horse. It was not even a close call. Allumeuse was 5 yards away from the incident. It is difficult, though not impossible, to see how the stewards blundered so badly. What horseplayer has not watched a race, once in his life, rooting for the wrong horse all the way around the track?

title: SCREEN: 'CRAZY SUMMER'
description: There are all kinds of movies. Movies that entertain, that frighten, that excite, that thrill, that move, that make you laugh and that make you think. ''One Crazy Summer'' cannot be accused of being any of these - although there are a few jokes at which you may find yourself smiling. In fact, the film is so successful at turning your brain into something resembling mashed potatoes that it is not clear when you'll be able to respond to intelligible stimuli again.

title: 'School Ties'
description: While it's easy enough to quibble with the Duke of Wellington's famous remark that ''the battle of Waterloo was won on the playing fields of Eton,'' readers of British memoirs can hardly deny the hold that the English public school system has had on its young charges. W. H. Auden once observed that he hated fascism because in public school he'd lived in a fascist state; and Cyril Connolly wrote about how that rarified brand of upper-class education condemned its unfortunate alumni to a state of perpetual adolescence - never able to recapture the heady romanticism and elitist sense of entitlement experienced during those years, they continue to live in the past, little boys forever caught on the cusp of failed dreams.

Andersen would be given power to inspect and grade apples, and assess growers to pay for a marketing campaign.

title: Q&A
description: Duty-Free Limits Question:We are going on a Caribbean cruise from San Juan, calling at Barbados and St. Thomas and ending in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. What is the amount of duty-free items each person is allowed to bring back and how much is payable if that amount is exceeded? Do returning tourists also have to pay a customs fee? - D. S., Bellflower, Calif. Answer:As Puerto Rico is part of the United States, purchases made there are not subject to duty by the United States Customs Service. The first $400 worth of items bought by travelers arriving from foreign countries is exempt from duty. But if a ship calls at St. Thomas in the United States Virgin Islands then its passengers' allowance is increased.

title: Carolyn Brodsky to Wed

Mr. Crear, a general manager of and partner in Tuff Luff, a marine manufacturing company in Minneapolis, graduated from the University of Minnesota.

description: ABOUT A WEEK BE-fore summer officially began, my local Paris cafe posted a huge sign reading ''L'ete arrive!

title: PARTIES EYING UPSETS IN TWO HOUSE RACES
description: AS Connecticut's six United States Representatives head into their re-election campaigns, leaders of each party are hoping to pick up perhaps one Congressional seat from the other.

title: CLASSIC STONEWARE FROM CONNECTICUT
description: Peaceful and relatively secluded, the small towns and villages of northwestern Connecticut have long been a haven for artists and artisans. Many of the barns and sheds found on older properties have been converted - a skylight added, a wood-burning stove installed - into studios for painting, sculpting, woodworking and other creative pursuits.

title: HOUSING COSTS DEBATED
description: LONG ISLAND officials have begun to heed the calls for more affordable housing, but some critics say the officials continue to ignore the needs of low-income people.

title: 29 YACHTSMEN READY TO SAIL THE WORLD
description: Sailing a boat alone round the world is an adventure by most standards. But for many of the 29 competitors waiting to begin the BOC Challenge this month, it is a yacht race in which high technology appears to be turning adventure into heated competition.

title: FOR THE TRINTIGNANTS, LIFE IS A MOVIE
description: Imagine first a pair of lovers looking like brother and sister; make them charming, passionate, highly intelligent, painfully sensitive and stingingly articulate. Now, set them loose as provocative alter egos who live, work and raise children in an elaborate house of mirrors. Inside they feed off each other's changing moods and ricocheting reflections, but against the pains of the world outside they always protect each other as the closest of friends.

title:
THE LIVELY ARTS;
DANCE HERITAGE TAKES LOCAL STEP
description: WHEN Lee Theodore founded the American Dancemachine back in l975, she thought the company and its body of work would be constantly evolving. For though dedicated to reconstructing and preserving theater dance, the repertory would have to change to make way for what was new and exciting on Broadway.

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: SUN RA: A JOYFUL NOISE: Produced and directed by Robert Mugge, 1980, Rhapsody Films, 60 minutes. $59.95.

title: Leah A. Luhr Is Bride Of Kevin M. Kearney
description: St. John the Baptist Roman Catholic Church in Kenmore, N.Y., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Leah Adair Luhr and Kevin Miles Kearney. The Rev. Edward Kearney, an uncle of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony.

title: NO TENSE LIKE THE PRESENT
description: NO attentive reader could fail to be aware that the present tense is in ascendancy. Jay McInerney's ''Bright Lights, Big City,''

title: What's All This Talk Of Western Values?
description: To the Editor:

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: FLOWRERS FOR BALANCHINE

title: SINGING TO THE LUTE - AND LOVING IT
description: If there is one singer who has come to represent on record the sound of ''early music'' it is the English soprano Emma Kirkby. She has sung in New York before in the series ''Music before 1800'' and at the Cloisters, but tomorrow night she is to make her Lincoln Center debut singing Handel cantatas in the Mostly Mozart Festival and on Thursday night she will perform at Tanglewood.

title: A TOWN IN VERMONT THANKS ITS DOCTOR
description: As a parade, it was more for the fans of Dr. Seuss than John Philip Sousa.

title: THE DEVASTATING EFFECTS OF HEAT AND DROUGHT
description: THE rains that washed over much of the South and the Middle Atlantic states last weekend, and the lower temperatures they ushered in, brought a measure of encouragement to those scorched regions last week. So did the House of Representatives' passage, by a vote of 418 to 0, of a $530 million farm relief package similar to one approved earlier by the Senate. The Congressional measures, coupled with a Reagan Administration assistance program estimated at well over $1 billion that went into effect a week ago Friday, would provide grain, feed, cash and other forms of aid to tens of thousands of farmers in a 10-state region stretching from Alabama to Pennsylvania. The degree to which farmers have already been hurt by months of high temperatures and scant rainfall is apparent from the accompanying tables, in which all figures are estimates. Meteorologists say it will take weeks of rain to end the drought. But for the next few days, at least, they are predicting that the weather in most of the affected region will be dry.

title: Iranian Shelling of Basra Said to Kill 6 and Hurt 38
description: Iranian border gunners today shelled Basra, Iraq's second-largest city, killing 6 civilians and wounding 38, the Iraqi military command said.

title: BRADLEY PRESSES FOR CARE AT HOME
description: THE Senate Finance Committee has approved a proposal by Senator Bill Bradley for a $20 million, four-year statewide home health-care demonstration program in New Jersey to provide assistance to ailing, elderly people and their families.

title: THE COMPOSERS AMONG US
description: IN a four-acre retreat overlooking the Hudson River lives the composer who has been called the ''father'' of American music. Aaron Copland, who will be 86 years old in October and was honored last month with the National Medal of Arts, gives credit to his wooded surroundings when discussing the musical compositions that have also earned him a Pulitzer Prize and the Presidential Medal of Freedom.

title: PORT JEFF EYES PARKING FEES
description: Parking problems in Port Jefferson, one of Long Island's most popular summer tourist spots, have prompted a proposal by the Village Board to begin charging for parking downtown and limiting parking time.

title: SPIKE LEE MAKES HIS MOVIE
description: As a child growing up in Brooklyn, Spike Lee loved almost everything about the movies. But it never failed to puzzle and distress him that so little of the vibrant black life surrounding him was reflected realistically on the big screen - or portrayed at all, for that matter.

title: Mary A. Citrino Wed to Wake Smith
description: Mary Anne Citrino, a daughter of Jean Citrino-Adubato of Nutley, N.J., and the late Robert Joseph Citrino Jr., was married yesterday to Todd Wakelee Smith, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thornton E. Smith of Plandome, L.I. The Rev. Dr. Robert K. Massie, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Princeton University Chapel.

title: OF SUPERTITLES, LIMERICKS AND VARIOUS WEIGHTY MATTERS
description: There ought to be a graceful way to ease into a column of notes and random observations, such as the one that here follows, but I have never found it. Best to plunge right in.

title: Framers' Intentions
description: To the Editor:

title: SENATORS WILL PROPOSE LIMIT OF MORTAGE TAX DEDUCTIONS
description: Senate conferees on the tax bill agreed tonight on a proposal limiting the amount homeowners could borrow against their personal residences in order to claim more tax deductions.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: Hudson County officials have committed about $180,000 to putting out an underground blaze in Lincoln Park between Routes 1 and 9 adjacent to the Hackensack River.

title: A GUIDE ON SCENIC PROTECTION
description: THE region's first handbook for local officials on the newly emerging ''science'' of scenic preservation has recently been published by a leading environmental organization.

title: YET ANOTHER CRISIS IN THE CITY'S JAILS
description: LESS than 24 hours after City Hall aides disclosed last week the imminent removal of Correction Commissioner Jacqueline McMickens, 45 inmates at the Rikers Island Correctional Institution for Men, angered when prison authorities attempted to move 25 additional bunks into an already overcrowded prison dormitory, brandished makeshift weapons and briefly seized part of the facility.

title: BOB DYLAN AND NEIL YOUNG FACE LIFE IN THE 80'S
description: Can old rockers learn new tricks? Or will they? Those questions are posed, and partially answered, on new albums by two rock songwriters who have been active since the 1960's - Bob Dylan and Neil Young.

title: LATIN LOVER
description: O tempora! O mores! Latin must be dead if an expert involved in coining a Latin equivalent for ''automobile'' keeps the Greek prefix ''auto'' and rejects the perfectly good Latin word ''mobile,'' as in perpetuum mobile. What was wrong with the obvious choice ipsomobile (something which is moved by itself)? JOHN RAUSEN New York City

title: THE NICHOLSON METHOD
description: It may be interesting to note that the four actors mentioned by Mike Nichols (''There is James Cagney, Spencer Tracy, Humphrey Bogart and Henry Fonda. . . . After that, who is there but Jack Nicholson?'') had no time for Method acting.

title: SCIENCE FICTION
description: ''Infuriating'' is the word for KITEWORLD by Keith Roberts (Arbor House, $15.95) - one of the best science fiction novels of recent years, with one of the worst ''surprise'' endings I have ever read. Mr. Roberts is the author of ''Pavane,'' a brilliant alternative-history novel (set in a world in which the Spanish Armada defeated the English fleet in 1588), and ''The Chalk Giants,'' a strong post-nuclear-holocaust story. ''Kiteworld'' is also set in a wounded world of survivors, a truncated England known as the Realm, controlled by a Church that itself controls the principal technology - huge kites that fly day and night along the borders of the Badlands, manned by observers who keep an eye out for Demons. As described in the Church's litany, these Demons sound like guided missiles of the previous era, now enshrined in a myth that dominates the lives of the inhabitants of the Realm.

title: MARINA EXPANSION STIRS NORTHPORT
description: A PLAN by a real estate firm to renovate and expand a marina on the Northport Bay has met vociferous opposition by Northport village officials and local residents who fear the $25 million project will overwhelm the waterfront community.

title: BAR'S 'CONSCIENCE' IN RIGHTS SECTION
description: When Associate Justice William J. Brennan Jr. of the Supreme Court spoke to the American Bar Association's Section on Individual Rights and Responsibilities Friday night, he said that were it not for the section, some issues might not be addressed by the association.

title: Trade Arts, Not Jabs
description: At the beginning of his Administration, Mr. Reagan described the Soviet Union as an ''evil empire'' run by ''immoral'' leaders who were guilty of ''lying and cheating to advance their goal of world domination.'' But things change.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: SHIFTING gears from serious reading, summer browsers sometimes turn up unfamiliar roads.

title: Mary Cleary Is Bride of Hugh Mahabir
description: Mary Loretta Cleary, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Malachy F. Cleary of New Rochelle, N.Y., and New York, was married yesterday to Hugh Mulchan Mahabir, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Roy Mahabir of Port of Spain, Trinidad, and Montreal. The Rev. Robert H. Springer performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Chapel of Our Lady in Cold Spring, N.Y.

title: CARL S. FORSYTHE
description: Carl S. Forsythe, a New York lawyer who was treasurer and a director of the New York-based Versailles Foundation, which has contributed funds for the restoration of the historic chateau, died of cancer Thursday at Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived in Greenwich.

title: Barbara Susan Laney Wed to Jon Swenson
description: Barbara Susan Laney, the literary manager of Jujamcyn Theaters, which owns five Broadway theaters, and Jon Malcolm Swenson, president of Ameristone, a subsidiary of the Turner Corporation, a construction concern, were married yesterday in Rye Beach, N.H. The Rev. David C. Glendinning, an Episcopal priest, officiated at an outdoor ceremony in the Straw's Point section of Rye Beach.

title: Latin Lovers
description: E.J. Dionne Jr.'s article on Latin revived memories of my introduction to and permanent infatuation with the language of the Romans (''Latin Dead? Veni, Vidi, Vici,'' On Language, July 20).

title: THE BARITONE AND THE BAR: HE MIXES SINGING AND LAW
description: WHEN the American Bar Association meetings began last week at the Hilton Hotel in New York City, Roy Fischer of Merrick was prowling the premises: attending seminars, taking notes, talking to people about trends in the law. He was searching for new ideas for legal treatises in his capacity as an assistant editorial director in the real property and probate division of Matthew Bender & Company, a publisher of legal works.

title: THE COURT, THE CONGRESS AND THE WHITE HOUSE
description: DURING the days or weeks a Supreme Court nominee spends under the Congressional microscope, the three branches of Government intersect as they rarely do at any other time.

title: For Schroeder, Just 620 Days
description: ''If it works out, it's wonderful,'' William J. Schroeder told his brother the day before becoming the second recipient of a Jarvik-7 artificial heart. ''If it doesn't, maybe it'll help somebody else.''

title: ARABS REPORT PROGRESS TOWARD ENDING P.L.O. RIFT
description: Three factions of the Palestine Liberation Organization have announced progress in efforts to heal a three-year rift within the group.

title: FAITH AND CHARITY MAKE A MOVIE OF A HIT PLAY
description: In a neat white farmhouse by the side of a country road, just after 6 P.M. on an evening in early fall, a woman is preparing to kill herself. Of all the unlikely subjects for a Hollywood movie, '' 'night, Mother'' seems among the most improbable. Hollywood is clever at animating nightmares, at turning into rubber and plastic the tangled, slithery hordes of alien things that crawl through our unconscious. Audiences feast on disguised fears. However, they have usually recoiled from straight jolts of bad dreams that don't go away in daylight. In '' 'night, Mother'' a 36-year-old woman decides to take control of her life by ending it. The mother who has never understood her is the only barrier on her road to the grave.

title: Bringing Order to Catalogue Chaos
description: LIBRARIANS and archivists, despite the similarity of their fields, have for years been at each other's throats over one issue: standardization. The librarians, who are most likely to preside over the use of the historical records contained in archives, argue for a uniform on-line cataloguing method, much like the Dewey decimal system for books. But until recently, archivists insisted that they had to be allowed to sort things in whatever way made most sense to them.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: 25-MILE BIKE RALLY Some residents of Harrison, Rye Brook, Purchase, Mamaroneck, Scarsdale, Eastchester and New Rochelle may be startled out of their weekend sleep-ins when 5,000 bicyclists wheel past their doors from 8 A.M. to noon next Sunday. The county is one of seven locations nationwide where the Grape Nuts Bike Festival is being held.

title: TASK FORCE NETS FEW JAIL TERMS
description: An undercover police task force formed last year to arrest people who solicit child prostitutes in Times Square has made 74 arrests, but only two of the arrests resulted in prison sentences, officials said.

title: GAPS IN RETRAINING EFFORT ARE SEEN IN AN ERA OF MAJOR INDUSTRIAL CHANGE
description: With manufacturing employment continuing to decline, experts on the workplace say there are not enough public or private programs to train displaced workers for other jobs.

title: NANOMACHINES TO OUR RESCUE
description: ENGINES OF CREATION By K. Eric Drexler. With a foreword by Marvin Minsky. 298 pp. New York: Anchor Press/Doubleday & Company. $17.95.

title: The Military Mind
description: Few who have seen today's American military officers in action rather than in the Washington bureaucracy would recognize them in Arthur T. Hadley's article ''The Split Military Psyche'' (July 13). The peg-in-the-hole Army officers he describes are a long way from the independent thinkers who are pioneering high-tech land warfare.

title: DIRECTORY PUBISHING: LOW-RISK VENTURE
description: SIX years ago, when Kerry M. Franzman was driving home from a dinner meeting at 11 P.M., he suddenly realized that he was short of gas and short of cash. ''I was somewhere around Chappaqua, in an area not familiar to me,'' he recalled. ''I had $2 in my wallet and a near-empty tank. I left the parkway and started searching for a gas station and a branch of my bank that had 24-hour machines. I couldn't find either of them. But it was that incident that gave me the idea for a directory with lists of useful information - things like 24-hour service stations - for people in Westchester.''

title: 13th Drug Ring Suspect And $3 Million Seized
description: Federal agents here reported the seizure of $3.4 million in drug money in New York State today and the arrest of a 13th suspect in what authorities called the biggest cocaine smuggling ring in the nation.

title: Verbatim; Looking for a Lifeline
description: 'USS is now facing an economic showdown with nonunion competitiors, bankrupt competitors and foreign competitors.

title: ROMANCE NARROWS THE GENERATION GAP
description: Marriage, as ever, is much on the minds of movie makers this season. Three big movies now playing around the country look at the institution over three generations. ''Nothing in Common,'' a sentimental comedy that features a virtuoso performance by Tom Hanks, begins when he learns that his mother has walked out on his father after 36 years. ''About Last Night. . .,'' the shaky but not altogether unrewarding version of David Mamet's play, ''Sexual Perversity in Chicago,'' ends with the young protagonists about ready to try the more-or-less permanent arrangement that they have been avoiding. And Mike Nichols's polished ''Heartburn'' is all about a marriage that fails.

title: MAKING THE MOST OF TAX REVISION
description: ON THE eve of sweeping tax revision, taxpayers struggling with their 1986 finances face uncertainty at almost every turn. No one yet knows which proposals will become law, or when. Even after enactment, ''there will be enough wrinkles so that we expect business to increase this year,'' said Mark Bass, co-owner of the Pennington/Bass Companies, a financial planning firm in Lubbock, Tex.

title: SWITCH BENEFITS RICHMOND
description: A year ago, Tim Richmond was an unhappy racing driver, without a victory for more than a year and quarreliing with his racing team. Now thanks to a new car owner and crew chief, Richmond will go into today's Budweiser at the Glen, at Watkins Glen, N.Y., as the hottest driver on the Winston Cup stock car circuit.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article last Sunday about water quality in the Northeast gave a capacity figure ambiguously for a filtration plant being built in New York City. The plant, at the Jerome Avenue reservoir, will treat about 1 percent of the 300 million gallons supplied each day by the Croton reservoir system. The Croton system supplies about 10 percent of the city's water.

title: Princeton Bridal For Miss Kansas
description: Katherine Elizabeth Kansas and Richard Evans Gentry Jr. were married yesterday at Trinity Episcopal Church in Princeton, N.J., by the Rev. Richard A. Bower.

title: PREPARE A PICNIC FOR SUMMER FARE
description: ONE of the most enjoyable ways to dine before the theater or a concert in the summer is to take along a picnic. The meal can be spread out on a lawn or table at the premises or eaten at a chosen spot along the way.

title: LINKING A VCR TO CABLE CAN BE KNOTTY
description: Every video watcher eager to record cable programs faces the often perplexing task of linking the VCR to the cable terminal.

title: BEQUEST BENEFITS WILTON MUSEUM
description: AN unexpected inheritance from an antique collector has enabled the Wilton Historical Society to redesign and enhance its museum's permanent period rooms and to mount an exhibition in honor of the benefactor.

title: DISCIPLINE, DESIRE: EAGLE-FLIGHT BASICS
description: ON Thursday nights, the sounds of car horns and blaring radios give way to the cadence of marching boots in the parking lot of Bethel Baptist Church.

title: A 'True Fan' Recalls the Past
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: AFTER THE OPEC ACCORD
description: The depressed stocks of oilfield services companies recovered last week after OPEC agreed to a temporary production ceiling of about 16 million barrels a day. The agreement, which lifted prices from recent lows of $6 a barrel into the teens, raised hopes that the industry's long slump might have touched bottom.

title: Helping an Industry Fight the Good Fight
description: THE United States and Japan recently signed an agreement that will radically restructure their semiconductor trade. Neither protectionist nor overtly mercantilist, the agreement promotes American interests while helping world trade.

title: James Agee's Despair
description: To the Editor:

title: LIKE A SCOLDING FATHER, STATE COMPTROLLER IS WARNING TEXANS THE FREE RIDE IS OVER
description: ''I've been in government for 30 years and I cannot even recall Texas having a no-growth budget,'' the State Comptroller said as he surveyed the wreckage of the Texas budget, already $3.5 billion in the hole by his estimate.

title: MASTERLY ENSEMBLES HIGHLIGHT THE EARLY MUSIC BOOM
description: The early music boom continues, with no sign of cessation. In the last few years, virtually all of the Bach cantatas and Handel oratorios have been recorded, and we have begun to become acquainted with the operas of Rameau and Lully, the chamber music of Leclair and Buxtehude, and a trove of other music unknown only a generation ago. A new breed of superstar has emerged - the scholar-performer - and aficionados debate the relative merits of Trevor Pinnock, John Eliot Gardner, Simon Standage, Ton Koopman and a host of other artists.

title: TEEN-AGERS HELP REBUILD HOUSES, HOPES IN YONKERS
description: AS clouds of dust filled the rooms and hallways, a group of teen-agers from Zelienople, Pa., were sweeping, shoveling and carting piles of debris out of an abandoned apartment building in Yonkers one day last week.

title:
CABLE TV NOTES;
AMERICA THROUGH FOREIGN CORRESPONDENTS' EYES
description: Developments in the United States frequently hold tremendous significance for other nations; yet all too often, American television carries only sketchy coverage of how events and actions originating here are perceived in foreign countries. ''The Foreign Correspondents,'' a discussion series beginning this Saturday afternoon at 3:30 on the Cable News Network, will try to provide some of those missing viewpoints.

title: 13 ARE ARRAIGNED AFTER DRUG SWEEP
description: Thirteen people, including a New Jersey psychiatrist who asserted he was doing research on crack, were arraigned in Federal court yesterday after a police sweep in Washington Heights netted 22 suspected buyers and sellers of the drug.

title: A SON'S DEVOTION REVIVES A 30'S MUSICAL FOR BROADWAY
description: When ''Me and My Girl'' opens at the Marquis Theater tonight, it will mean something pretty special to Richard Armitage, the driving force behind its revival first in London, now in New York. That's not just because he's a theatrical agent, 57 years old, with no previous experience of production. It's not just because the idea of restaging a bouncy 30's British musical was thought absurdly risky by most of the leading British impresarios. It's not even just because there wasn't so much as a proper script of the show in existence when the work of revival began.

title: George V. Higgins Defended
description: To the Editor:

title: A SURPRISE PARTNER FOR GOLDMAN, SACHS
description: Sumitomo wants to become a limited partner in Goldman, Sachs, and has offered to pay $500 million for a 12.5 percent stake in the big securities firm. Sumitomo would not, however, have voting rights. The bank, Japan's third-largest, already owns a bank in California, as well as operations in other foreign countries, but it wanted a piece of the American securities market. And Goldman, facing the retirement of senior partners who would likely withdraw millions in capital from the firm, needed an infusion of new capital. But few analysts - or Goldman executives - expected the contributor to be Japanese.

title:
THE CAREFUL SHOPPER;
BANANA REPUBLIC: FOR SAFARIS, CITIES
description: Banana Republic Travel & Safari Clothing outposts have been established in Connecticut in Westport and at the Stamford Town Center - with four in Manhattan - in eight years of supplying surplus clothing and hats, sturdy replicas and specially designed answers to travelers' needs.

title: TOPICS
description: GIVEN the choice between grass and concrete, I would opt for the latter.

title:
ON LONG ISLAND;
Where Did All the Hamptons Renters Go?
description: ''IT'S been a very weird season,'' said Janet Fletcher, who together with her husband Paul owns a four-bedroom contemporary house in Southampton with an inground pool, water views, fireplaces and large decks.

title: Drama in a Parking Lot
description: Evidently audience behavior at the Westbury Music Fair is subject to considerable variation. The one attending the July 6 matinee of ''South Pacific'' neither arrived tardily nor departed prematurely, faults noted by Leah D. Frank in connection with her recent review of ''Zorba.''

title: 'ANTONY' AT DREW: STAB AT GREATNESS
description: AN exotic, almost forbidding aura surrounds Shakespeare's ''Antony and Cleopatra.''

title: Bologna
description: To the Editor: Scholarly, sybaritic Bologna comes alive in William Weaver's fine article (Travel, June 6) and, as he points out, the city is not sleeping on its laurels.

title: A LEGACY OF WAR: UGANDA'S ORPHANS
description: In a shaded corner, a frail, emaciated child, his skin rough like coarse vinyl, squatted in the dirt, rocking back and forth.

title: BEACH POLLUTION: SOME GOOD NEWS, SOME BAD
description: THE weekly testing of water quality at coastal beaches has brought good news and bad.

title: HOW SOVIET SCIENCE HAS MADE MORE OF LESS
description: Over lunch last month in Moscow, Dr. Roald Z. Sagdeyev, director of the Space Research Institute of the Soviet Academy of Sciences, took issue with Russian officials who defended the record of technology at the Chernobyl nuclear reactor. The truth, he said, was that bad Soviet equipment contributed to the disastrous fire at the reactor in April, an accident that the officials blamed on human error. With a smile, Dr. Sagdeyev added that similar equipment is used to control Soviet nuclear-tipped missiles and that the West, in its own interest, should lift its ban on the export of advanced computers and similar high technology to the Soviet Union. ''That would be the smart thing,'' he said.

title: U.S. Report on Smut Sells Out in Jacksonville
description: The report of the Attorney General's Commission on Pornography sold out within two weeks of its arrival at the Government Printing Office bookstore here, the store manager says.

title: Concert's Legacy
description: SHE was singing in the rain in an orange sequin bodysuit when her Central Park concert had to be canceled because of a downpour one summer night in 1983. But Diana Ross was not deterred.

title: Saratoga Springs
description: To the Editor: As a veteran of many parents' weekends at Skidmore College (which were always highlighted by as many meals out as possible), I would like to add several restaurants to those mentioned in the What's Doing in Saratoga Springs (Travel, June 29): The Ash Grove Inn on Church Street, a few minutes out of the center of town; Someplace Else in Schuylerville, a few miles east of Saratoga near the Hudson River; the Caunterbury Restaurant, which has a stream running through it; and Sunday brunch at the Gideon Putnam Hotel. (The brunch is always heavily booked; try to get reservations for seats in the Arches, a solarium.)

title: THE GREENING OF SINAI MIXES WATER AND HOPE
description: LIKE a mirage shimmering in the desert, the Sinai Peninsula in the long years under Israeli occupation enticed Egypt as a panacea for many ills. Not only did recovering the territory mean the restoration of lost dignity. The land itself, half the size of New York State, was also envisioned as a home for Egypt's overflowing population and a potential breadbasket for a nation that could no longer feed itself.

title: MOSCOW SEES A BIGGER ROLE FOR ITSELF IN THE PACIFIC
description: THE Soviet Embassy called in the Bangkok press corps last week to direct attention to a July 28 speech in Vladivostok by Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: Karen Wolfgang, Lawyer, Marries C. Erik Swanson
description: Karen Eleanor Wolfgang, a daughter of Profs. Marvin E. Wolfgang and Lenora D. Wolfgang of Philadelphia, was married there yesterday to C. Erik Swanson, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Swanson of Camillus, N.Y. The Rev. Stanley E. Johnson, an Episcopal priest and chaplain of the University of Pennsylvania, performed the ceremony at the University's Wharton Sinkler Estate.

title: Keeping Tabs on the Corporate Past
description: BACK in the days before corporate culture became a buzzword, before corporate biographies flooded bookstores, before lawyers persuaded chief executives that they must keep records for possible use in litigation, archivists were virtually nonexistent on corporate payrolls.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: PARLOUR 4 AND OTHER STORIES. By J. I. M. Stewart. (Norton, $14.95.) J. I. M. Stewart is obsessed with the idea of what might have been.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: August 10, 1986
description: Nonfiction General

title: SUNSET-WATCHING AND GROWING PAINS
description: Helga Houmere led two dozen visitors past the makeshift ballfield (''Zero Mostel used to umpire here''), past the wild strawberries and raspberries and into the woods where she compared small stems of balsam fir and red spruce.

title: CLASSY CATHY RALLIES TO WIN ALABAMA BY A NECK
description: Classy Cathy outdueled Valley Victory down the stretch at Saratoga today to score by a long neck in a surprisingly slow Alabama Stakes that only further muddled the 3-year-old filly division.

title: Unser Holds Off Elliott
description: Al Unser Jr. outran Bill Elliott today to win the Budweiser International Race of Champions event at Watkins Glen International and the championship of the 10th IROC series.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: CRUISE ON THE CONNECTICUT

title: PROSPECTS
description: Fear of Inflation

title: CAMBODIA REFUGEES STILL TELL OF 'YELLOW RAIN'
description: As Peo Pum tells the story, a helicopter approached the lake where he and some other fishermen were working back in July 1984 and tried to spray a yellow dust on the woods.

title: Xerox in Context
description: To the Editor:

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL YANKEES VS. KANSAS CITY ROYALS, at Yankee Stadium, 1:30 P.M. (Television - Channel 11, 1:30 P.M., Radio - WABC, 770, 1:30 P.M.) METS VS.

title: AFFORDABLE NEWCOMER IN WESTPORT
description: CALLING Westport's newest restaurant the Riverside more aptly refers to the street it is on than the river view. True, the Saugatuck River can be glimpsed beyond the buildings across the street. Be that as it may, the Riverside is a welcome addition to Westport's ever-volatile restaurant scene, especially so because its prices are among the lowest we have encountered in months at an upscale restaurant.

title:
ART;
AT THE HUDSON MUSEUM, A TRIPLE FEATURE ON THE WORLD OF MOVIES
description: EITHER by testing the waters yourself or by reading the critics you trust, you know that the movies are in a bad way this summer. And to make things worse you have to stampede into a crowded viewing room, one of as many as a dozen fashioned out of a once much-larger theater to see the movies everyone is complaining about. One answer is the revival house, and that is what the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers has become this summer. It's a journey back to the days when moviegoing was an unalloyed pleasure.

title: Money and Politics
description: More and more, politics is money, and the source of it increasingly bothers some people. In recent years, because of the money they control, political action committees have become a major force in American politics, particularly Congressional politics.

title: NEW GUIDELINES FOR CLEANUP OF WASTE SITES TO AFFECT L.I.
description: WITH more than 1,000 hazardous waste sites in New York State, including 131 on Long Island, officials in the State Department of Environmental Conservation say that this summer they will be focusing their attention on the question ''Just how clean is clean?'' and developing a set of guidelines to answer the question.

title: NEW MILFORD EATERY SERVES HEARTY FOOD AND SPIRITED FUN
description: THE neatly lettered sign at the bottom of the driveway promises ''Dependable Home Cooking,'' illustrated with a steaming cup of coffee. Over the front porch another sign, this one bright neon, urges passers-by to ''Eat.'' Sagging wicker chairs, a row of newspaper racks and citronella candles line the way to the door.

title: Abigail Huffman Wed in Brooklyn
description: At the Plymouth Church of the Pilgrims in Brooklyn yesterday Abigail Mary Huffman, a daughter of Evelyn Louise Huffman and John Arthur Huffman, both of Kansas City, Mo., was married to William Hiram Wood 3d, the son of Mr. Wood Jr. of Watertown, Mass., and the late Patricia Stevens Wood. The Rev. Dr. Avery Manchester performed the Congregational ceremony Maude Else Huffman was her sister's maid of honor.

title: THE CURIOUS CASE OF JOHN B. COLEMAN
description: IN the waning morning hours, a few breakfasters were finishing their meals at the homey Jockey Club in the Ritz-Carlton on New York's Central Park South. The setting was faultless - the English-pine bar, the pink tablecloths, the wooden walls adorned with hunting scenes.

title: THE IMPORTANCE OF SILENCE
description: My neighbor has a lovely garden, and as the weather turns fine, he sits in it - grass underfoot, flowers around him, blue sky through the branches up above. To double his pleasure, he adds his portable radio - the glories of summer and ''La Traviata'' too.

title: Moon's Life After Prison
description: FOR nearly a year, the Rev. Sun Myung Moon directed the affairs of his Unification Church from a prison cell in Danbury, Conn., where he was serving time for Federal income-tax evasion. Church leaders visited him regularly for guidance about running the religious and social programs of the church, as well as its considerable real-estate holdings.

title: WHEN THE TELEPHONE MESSAGE WAS DELIVERED ON HORSEBACK
description: IN the beginning, there was a different Long Island. That is to say, the sounds of the suburbs were not yet abroad in the land.

title: Wall St. M.B.A.'s
description: To the Editor:

title: Oratory and Politics
description: Christopher J. Matthews, administrative assistant and press spokesman for the House Speaker, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., for more than five years, has been recognized for outstanding performance by his peers in the National Association of Government Communicators, who voted him an award he will formally receive in November. Once a speechwriter for President Carter, who did not always see eye to eye with Mr. O'Neill, Mr. Matthews moved to Capitol Hill after the 1980 election returns eliminated his White House job, on one hand, and elevated the Speaker to the role of senior elected Democratic official in the country, on the other.

title: I.R.A. ON DISPLAY FOR NORAID GROUP IN ULSTER
description: His Irish roots are three generations distant, and his ancestry is half-Italian at that, yet Richard Lawlor was front and center today as a visiting group of sympathetic Americans heard a defense of the violent tactics of the Irish Republican Army.

title: DEVELOPERS DISPUTE LEVIES FOR RECREATION
description: TOWNS and villages across northern Westchester are re-examining the ''recreation fees'' they charge developers, raising some as much as sixfold. Officials maintain that the increases are justified by rises in land values and the increased need for recreation for a growing population. Developers, however, charge that higher fees are only another attempt by towns to discourage development, particularly of affordable housing.

title: DATA BANK August 10, 1986
Defending Gallo
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Women Defeat Czechs In Basketball
description: Katrina McClain scored 19 points as the United States defeated Czechoslovakia today, 89-61, giving the Americans the Group B lead in first-round competition of the Women's Basketball World Championships with a 2-0 record.

title: MOSCOW GOES AFTER PARIS CHIC...
description: OUTSIDE Moda, this city's hottest new retail outlet, lines stretch for blocks. Billed as the prototype of a new generation of Soviet shops designed to offer stylish, quality clothing, Moda draws thousands of shoppers every day who wait two or three hours to get a glimpse of the brighter future for Soviet consumers that the Kremlin leadership has pledged to create.

title: Page Smith Wed To Kurt Wilson
description: St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Darien, Conn., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Page Shelton Smith, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Chester Taber Smith Jr. of Darien, to Kurt Andrew Wilson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William John Wilson of Sparta, N.J. The Rev. Walter H. Taylor performed the ceremony.

title: LATIN LOVERS
description: Latin and German may make strange bedfellows. But having grown up in Munich and having battled my way through six years of Gymnnasium Latin, a flash of lightning hit when I read E. J. Dionne's article.

title: Julia Brown, a Writer, Marries Clifford Thompson
description: The marriage of Julia Farrington Brown, a freelance writer, and Clifford Brian Thompson, a third-year student at the University of Houston Law Center, took place yesterday in South Hadley, Mass.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: IT CAME FROM THE SWAMP: Your Federal Government at Work. By Susan Trausch. (Houghton Mifflin, $15.95.) Susan Trausch is an accomplished practitioner of a certain kind of entertaining newspaper writing.

title: MUSIC: HEINZ HOLLIGER COMPLETES ENGAGEMENT
description: HEINZ HOLLIGER is a technical master of his instruments -those of the oboe family - but it is another dimension of his work that sets him particularly apart and makes him an admirable model for emulation by other musicians. Mr. Holliger completed his current Mostly Mozart engagement Thursday at Avery Fisher Hall, playing in four pieces for woodwind ensemble, and the pre-eminent thing he did was to interest himself in every note of every phrase.

title: FLASHBACKS TO HOLLYWOOD'S HALYCON DAYS
description: ''H ollywood: Legend and Reality,'' which opened Tuesday at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum (2 East 91st Street), encompasses both the glamorous and the nitty-gritty in looking back on the film industry. More lighthearted than scholarly, it employs 400 photographs, posters, costume and production sketches, special-effects models and equipment to explore its subject - from the pioneers of the 1910's to the wizards of the 80's. Seven video monitors with illustrative film excerpts provide diverting way stations throughout.

title: Lease Police
description: To the Editor:

title: TO ITS FANS, RIVER IS WORTH THE WORK
description: FROM its beginning in a quiet pond to its end in a bustling bay, the Pawcatuck River is drawing its share of attention this summer.

title: GOING ANYWAY: THE DECISION NOT TO CANCEL
description: We travel each summer to the Mediterranean. We go because we are happy there. My husband and I are not rich, and if we were careful people, we wouldn't spend such extravagant slices of income on vacations. But not to go has become almost unthinkable. We regard the trip as rather like going to the well. We drift, we rest, we mend shattered nerves from the year just past, and we gather our resources for the hectic months ahead. We like the lesser-known stretches of the southern French coast, from Nimes west to the Spanish border. We greet the towns of Montpellier, Beziers, Pezenas and Sete like old friends, and we meander lazily within easy reach of sunny, sandy beaches and the cool, wine-rich mountains of the Languedoc region. This year, for the first time, we took our 5-year-old daughter with us.

title: Cornelia S. Guest To Be the Bride Of R. A. Mitchell
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Spencer-Churchill Guest of New Canaan, Conn., and Fishers Island, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cornelia Schermerhorn Guest, to Robert Allan Mitchell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Adrian E. Mitchell of Bridgeport, Conn.

title: Gorbachev Has a Cold
description: Soviet officials have told a visiting Japanese Communist Party group that Mikhail S. Gorbachev is sick with a cold, Japanese sources said today. He postponed a meeting with a visitors, originally scheduled for Wednesday.

title: CONCERT: DE LARROCHA
description: IN 1840 an important musical autograph was sold at auction to someone who did not respect its historical value. That, sad to say, can still happen in 1986, but even the most callous acquisitor today would pale beside the wretch who took home the score of Mozart's original finale to his 14th piano concerto. This charming rondo was not just taken apart leaf by leaf; some pages were even cut into quarters.

title: DID THE MINISTER DO IT?
description: FALL RIVER OUTRAGE Life, Murder, and Justice in Early Industrial New England. By David Richard Kasserman. Illustrated. 280 pp. Philadelphia: The University of Pennsylvania Press. Cloth, $25. Paper, $14.95.

title: Beth Ann Felshman Plans To Marry Robert F. Braun
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Felshman of Plandome, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Beth Ann Felshman, to Robert F. Braun, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Braun of Neptune, N.J.

title: A New Life For Hot Rod
description: IT was mid-June, and a jury in New Orleans would soon return a verdict on charges that he had shaved points in basketball games for Tulane, charges that two teammates under immunity from prosecution and a third as part of a plea bargain had testified were true.

title: Miss Simons Has Wedding
description: Hilary Wadsworth Simons, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Wadsworth Simons Jr. of New York and New Marlborough, Mass., was married yesterday to David Blair Miller, a son of Dr. and Mrs. William Edward Miller of Unionville, Pa. The Rev. David Dean performed the ceremony at United Methodist Church of New Marlborough in Southfield, Mass.

title: POSTINGS: Warehouse Conversion; TriBeCa Rentals
description: In the process of converting two slender warehouses into apartment buildings, a partnership led by Anthony M. Kissling and Donald P. Parson plans to carve out a large atrium, ''skin'' and replace the facade and realign the windows.

title: BECKER'S LATE RALLY DEFEATS McENROE
description: This was a match that Wimbledon was deprived of twice, one that would be called a classic if it were played again a month from now in the United States Open. Instead, Boris Becker and John McEnroe met on a scenic mountaintop in Vermont today, the boy wonder of professional tennis against the player described by his peers as an uncompromising genius, back on the tour after a six-month sabbatical.

title: MASSACHUSETTS TO LOOK AT SEX BIAS IN COURTS
description: The Legislature has allocated $121,000 for what is expected to be a two-year study of discrimination against women in the state courts.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: Hallock Traditions

title: Sally Menke, Editor, Weds Aldo L. Parisot
description: The marriage of Sally JoAnne Menke to Aldo Luis Parisot took place yesterday at the home of the bridegroom's mother, Ellen Lewis Parisot, in Wilton, Conn. The Rev. Stephen Furrer, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Polish Sailboat Late For 4th Is Late Again
description: The Polish sailboat Stomil, which arrived late for the Liberty Weekend celebration in New York and was thought to be lost on the Great Lakes after leaving Buffalo more than a week ago, docked safely today at Navy Pier, a day late.

title: FOR BUYERS OF FM TUNERS, SOME HELPFUL DEFINITIONS
description: As a rule, a stereo system is used far more for listening to the radio than for playing records or tapes. Yet of all the various specifications encountered in audio, none seem more enigmatic to the typical listener than those referring to the performance of FM tuners.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
SOUTH FORK STATUS SYMBOLS
description: That the houses of the Hamptons have long been architecture's answer to a chorus line comes as no surprise to anyone who has witnessed the development of Long Island's south shore for the last two decades. In practically every style imaginable - modern, postmodern, pseudo-shingle and so many shades in between - custom-designed houses by some of the country's most acclaimed architects strut their stuff on the South Fork, each proudly exalting its owner's affluence, each brazenly shouting for more attention than the next.

title: Hot Home Market Returning to Normal
description: THE frenzied housing market of this spring has calmed in many parts of the New York metropolitan area, and some sales prices are sliding back from the winter's peak.

title: Donna Lynch Is Married To Paul Eugene Fischer
description: At St. John of the Cross Roman Catholic Church in Middlebury, Conn., yesterday Donna Ruth Lynch and Paul Eugene Fischer, 1982 graduates of Duke University, were married by the Rev. John G. Fanning.

title: H.M.O. Defense
description: To the Editor:

title: A Tobacco Ad Wins Protection
description: ''Editorial advertisements,'' those fully paid journalistic-corporate hybrids that have blossomed on Op-Ed pages around the country, have created a legal dilemma. Are they protected by the Constitution, like the neighboring editorials, or are they truly advertisements and thus subject to Government regulation?

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: AS hobbies go, Belford M. Giberson of Millville has one that is somewhat unusual and the objects of his collecting passion tend to pop up in the most unlikely places.

title: A RUSSIAN DEFECTOR, NOW BACK IN SOVIET, IS REPORTEDLY WELL
description: A Moscow newspaper today quoted Vitaly Yurchenko, a reputed Soviet defector, as having said that he is alive and well and back at his old job.

title: Manila Opens Talks With Rebels
description: Breaking the ice was easy last week as a Philippine Cabinet minister opened negotiations with leaders of the 17-year-old Communist insurgency in a suburban Manila home. Agriculture Minister Ramon Mitra said the Communists, Saturnino Ocampo and Antonio Zumel, were ''old friends'' from the days when they were all journalists, before Ferdinand E. Marcos declared martial law in 1972. Mr. Mitra and Mr. Ocampo also reminisced about their lost time as political detainees under martial law.

title: Julia Auwarter, Student, Weds Thomas C. Gleason
description: Julia Anne Auwarter, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond George Auwarter of Brookville, L.I., and New York, was married yesterday to Thomas Clement Gleason, a son of Mrs. Frank Gleason of Yonkers and the late Mr. Gleason. The Rev. Mario Costa performed the ceremony at the St. Paul the Apostle Roman Catholic Church in Brookville.

title: Stepping Up, Out and Down: Staircase of Youth
description: Some good doctors in Baltimore are pulling our legs.

title: AN ARTIST'S RADICAL SHIFT
description: CAROL ROSEN'S solo show at the State Museum here represents a phenomenon of reversal. Comprising 10 major works and a group of small studies, the exhibition demonstrates radical shifts from black works constructed of paper and reeds to white ones of painted canvas stretched over wood.

title: NORMAN RETAINS LEAD
description: Greg Norman scratched out a spectacular par 5 at the 13th hole today with a left-handed third shot and a 60-foot chip into the cup to maintain his four-shot lead through three rounds of the 68th PGA Championship at the Inverness Club.

title: CONSUMER RATES
Illegal Aliens' Health - and Ours
description: Should undocumented aliens be eligible for Medicaid? Yes, says a Federal district judge in Brooklyn. No, says a New Jersey Congressman worried about the cost. The concern is understandable, but this social service expenditure is cost effective as well as humane.

title: Orphan Drugs
description: To the Editor:

title: Skirts As Long As Days of Summer
description: LONG skirts, dresses and coats - light and airy as a perfect souffle and comfortable enough for the sultriest temperatures - have captured the midsummer fancy of a lot of women.

title: VIENNA AT TWILIGHT
description: THE PLAY OF THE EYES By Elias Canetti. Translated by Ralph Manheim. 329 pp. New York: Farrar Straus & Giroux. $22.50.

title: London Paper Says the Queen Had Tests at Heart Hospital
description: Queen Elizabeth underwent secret heart tests at Britain's leading cardiac hospital amid tight security Tuesday morning, The Sunday Mirror said today.

title: POSTINGS: 64 for Suffolk; Factory-Builts Up to $220,000
description: The suburban dream is a single-family house on an acre of wooded land. One can almost see a family gathered at the edge of a lot, watching as their house grows slowly, board by board.

title: LESSONS OF MIDLIFE DATING
description: The Sunday New York Times has been a mainstay of my life, and, recently, the About Men column has become a favorite feature. Women have spoken openly about themselves for many years; it's gratifying that men are sharing their experiences and feelings so that we may know them, too.

title: GENDER BENDERS
description: CHICKEN SOUP AND beef soup. Which is masculine and which is feminine?

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on page 17 of the Arts and Leisure section today about the Trintignant family misidentifies the theater for ''A Man and a Woman: 20 Years Later.'' The film opens on Friday at the Cinema 1, Third Avenue and 60th Street.

title: DANCE: FAMILY NIGHT FOR THE CLARK CENTER
description: IT was family night on Friday at the Douglas Fairbanks Theater as Clark Center celebrated itself in the closing days of its summer dance festival. No ordinary family celebration, the evening was a tribute to Louise Roberts, director of the center, whom Alvin Ailey called ''a great mother figure.''

title: Linda F. Gering Engaged To Wed Neil I. Kreisberg
description: Linda Fern Gering, the special events coordinator at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, and Neil Ivan Kreisberg, an executive vice president of Grey Advertising Inc., plan to be married Sept. 24.

title: THEFTS AND FEAR CLOSING OPEN DOOR OF CHURCHES
description: New security guards have been hired. An eight-foot-high iron fence with a locked gate is being built. A portico where street people cluster is being sealed off.

title: Japan's Toehold On Wall Street
description: Goldman, Sachs & Company, one of Wall Street's top investment banking houses, did not look far for its latest offering. It said last week that it was negotiating to sell a large stake of itself.

title: Louganis and Mitchell Retain Diving Titles
description: Greg Louganis and Michele Mitchell, the defending champions, survived tough challenges today to keep their United States platform titles in the Phillips 66-United States Diving Championships.

title: THE COSTS OF BEING ALL THINGS TO ALL PEOPLE
description: One advantage of a professor's long summer is the chance to read and reflect on books everyone has been talking about. One of the most startling to come along in some time is David A. Stockman's ''The Triumph of Politics,'' his inside account of the ''Reagan revolution.'' Few recent memoirs depict so vividly the incompetence of people in high places, or deflate so brutally expectations of rational governance.

title: TAKING A FRESH LOOK AT FOREIGN YET FAMILIAR LANDS
description: One of photography's most exalted and dependable functions over the last 150 years has been to supply reports on the look and life of far-off lands. From the Egyptian pyramids to California's Yosemite Valley, camera pictures have served as our first introduction to the splendid and the exotic. Lately, however, as the stockpile of travel pictures has mounted, the world has seemed to shrink, and with it our capacity to be amazed. Familiarity breeds contempt - or at least ocular calluses. It is no small achievement, then, when a photographer is able to convince us that the world remains as strange and foreign to us as it did to our 19th-century forebears.

title: Making the Grade
description: As many as 10 of the 23 recruits at Oklahoma and 7 of 27 at Houston will be barred from participating in football this fall because of the National Collegiate Athletic Association's new academic standards for freshman eligibility, according to published reports.

title: IT SEEMED A GOOD IDEA AT THE TIME
description: ICEBOUND The Jeannette Expedition's Quest for the North Pole. By Leonard F. Guttridge. Illustrated. 357 pp. Annapolis, Md.: Naval Institute Press. $23.95.

title:
GARDENING;
NATIVE PLANTINGS RECLAIM THE ROADSIDES
description: ONE has but to travel the interstate highway system to fully appreciate how much gardeners have become enslaved by gardens. In the 1950's and 60's, when the superhighways were new, they were planted - landscaped, if you will - as a part of our national beautification emphasis.

title: Madison on the Privacy of American Bedrooms
description: To the Editor Prof. Michael Kammen quotes James Madison to support his view that the Supreme Court's recent ruling on Georgia's sodomy law was ''lamentable.'' It is a dubious argument. Madison's remarks in Federalist 14 on the American people's ''numerous innovations'' and their rejection of ''a blind veneration for antiquity'' referred to the new structure of government established by the Revolution, which had not followed exactly any past model, and the need, as Madison put it in the same essay, to ''improve'' that ''structure of the Union'' with the proposed Constitution of 1787. It is hard to see how this can be construed as evidence that the Court's decision was ''utterly at odds'' with the Framers' views.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Loudon County, Va.; Seized Glebe Up for Auction
description: IN January 1985, the United States Marshal's Service seized Shelburne Glebe, a 1,000-acre estate that is registered as a historic landmark and is nestled here among the horse farms of this verdant Virginia county.

title: SKETCHES FROM LIFE AND DEATH
description: TO THE KWAI - AND BACK War Drawings, 1939-1945. By Ronald Searle. Illustrated. 192 pp. Boston: The Atlantic Monthly Press. $29.95.

title: WHAT'S ALL THIS TALK OF WESTERN VALUES?
description: To the Editor:

title:
NUMISMATICS;
SOUTH KOREA DESIGNS COINS FOR THE OLYMPICS
description: The Republic of Korea (South Korea) has unveiled the designs of 20 special coins it will issue to commemorate the 1988 Summer Olympic Games in Seoul. The set will include eight coins in gold and 12 in silver. All will have legal tender status.

title: THE NICHOLSON METHOD
description: In some quarters, Mr. Nicholson is praised for things such as improvising his lines and rewriting scenes.

title: THE PRESSURE BUILDS AT BIG BLUE
description: ON bulletin boards and in memos throughout the vast empire that is the International Business Machines Corporation, the word has gone out. Management wishes to reassure employees that they will not, repeat not, be laid off.

title: GLIMPSE OF 12TH CENTURY SPAIN
description: No town in Spain today could better fend for itself against medieval forces than Ciudad Rodrigo, 150 miles west of Madrid on the border with Portugal. Encircled by uninterrupted 12th-century ramparts, Ciudad Rodrigo looks out over the surrounding plains and distant hills as if maintaining the notion that chivalric fortification on a modest promontory threatens invaders. For 800 years the town was close to impenetrable. Even today, only three vaulted gateways reached by cobblestoned inclines give access through the massive walls.

title: Christina Chase Weds Christopher Simonds
description: Christina Ginnel Chase, a daughter of Peter J. Chase of Greenwich, Conn., and Faith DeWitt Chase of New York and East Hampton, L.I., was married yesterday to Christopher Lansing Simonds, a son of Charles Sprague Simonds of Westport, Conn., and Cassandra Goss Simonds of Darien, Conn. The Rev. Francis Creamer, assisted by the Rev. Bryan Williams, performed the ceremony at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in East Hampton.

title: SUICIDE ON STAGE
description: Robinne Lee, Traci Robinson and Melanie Williams are spending their summer acting out a story they have experienced first-hand.

title: Harriman Was Prescient About Vietnam
description: To the Editor:

title: BEARING A BURDEN
description: SOME PEOPLE IN Tennessee want Goldilocks out of the classroom. They say she undermines standards of Christian morality.

title: ENVIRONMENT
description: HOUSE and Senate conferees have agreed on all but one issue in their deliberations on a new Superfund law: Who pays?

title: BEST SELLERS: August 10, 1986
description: Weeks This Last on Week Nonfiction Week List 1 FATHERHOOD, by Bill Cosby. 1 14 (Dolphin/ Doubleday, $14.95.) Anecdotes and ruminations from the television star and father of five. 2 YOU'RE ONLY OLD ONCE! by Dr. Seuss. 2 22 (Random House, $9.95.) A checkup at the Golden Years Clinic in pictures and rhyme. 3 ROCK HUDSON: His Story, by Rock Hudson 3 7 and Sara Davidson. (Morrow, $16.95.) An account of the actor's life written with his cooperation. 4 JAMES HERRIOT'S DOG STORIES, by James 4 13 Herriot. (St. Martin's, $19.95.) Fifty tales by a Yorkshire veterinarian about his favorite animal. 5 ''AND SO IT GOES,'' by Linda Ellerbee. 6 9 (Putnam, $16.95.) Television journalism as experienced by a former NBC correspondent. 6 FORD: The Men and the Machine, 5 8 by Robert Lacey. (Little, Brown, $24.95.) A history of the automobile company and the dynasty. 7 A CAST OF KILLERS, by Sidney D. 7 4 Kirkpatrick. (Dutton, $17.95.) The investigation, by the film director King Vidor, of a celebrated Hollywood murder case. 8 NECESSARY LOSSES, by Judith Viorst. 10 16 (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) Life is a series of losses, the author argues, and we must confront them to grow. 9* WHEN ALL YOU'VE EVER WANTED ISN'T 8 17 ENOUGH, by Harold S. Kushner. (Summit, $16.95.) A rabbi on ''the search for a life that matters.'' 10 MURROW: His Life and Times, by A. M. 11 4 Sperber. (Freundlich/Kampmann, $25.) The career of the CBS newscaster. 11 THE MAN WHO MISTOOK HIS WIFE FOR 13 19 A HAT, by Oliver Sacks. (Summit, $15.95.) Strange neurological disabilities. 12 THE UNDERGROUND EMPIRE, by 9 4 James Mills. (Doubleday, $22.95.) How the global war on the drug trade is being waged and stymied. 13 BUS 9 TO PARADISE, by Leo 14 26 Buscaglia. (Slack/ Morrow, $16.95.) Another trip with the ebullient advocate of the virtues of love. 14 A LIGHT IN THE ATTIC, by Shel 169 Silverstein. (Harper & Row, $13.50.) Light verse, with drawings by the author. 15 IN SEARCH OF THE TROJAN WAR, by 12 6 Michael Wood. (Facts on File, $22.95.) Archeologists' search for the truth behind the Homeric legend. 16* THE PASSION OF AYN RAND, by Barbara 1 Branden. (Doubleday, $19.95.) The life of the author of ''The Fountainhead.'' August 10, 1986 Fiction 1 WANDERLUST, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, 1 4 $17.95.) A rich orphan comes of age while she travels the world. 2 RED STORM RISING, by Tom 2 2 Clancy. (Putnam, $19.95.) Without using nuclear weapons, the West staves off the Russians in World War III. 3 A MATTER OF HONOR, by Jeffrey 3 6 Archer. (Linden/Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) Nazi intrigue and a family secret that could change the course of the cold war. 4 LAST OF THE BREED, by Louis 4 9 L'Amour. (Bantam, $17.95.) The adventures of a United States Air Force major in Siberia. 5 ACT OF WILL, by Barbara 5 8 Taylor Bradford. (Doubleday, $17.95.) Three generations of talented, ambitious women in England and New York. 6 THE GARDEN OF EDEN, by 7 11 Ernest Hemingway. (Scribners, $18.95.) A writer and his wife have affairs with the same woman on their European honeymoon; Hemingway's last unpublished novel. 7 THE EIGHTH COMMANDMENT, by Lawrence 9 10 Sanders. (Putnam, $18.95.) The theft of a priceless Greek coin brings a New York dynasty's scandals to light. 8 THE BOURNE SUPREMACY, by Robert 10 23 Ludlum. (Random House, $19.95.) The hero of ''The Bourne Identity'' foils a plot to seize Hong Kong and bring China into conflict with the West. 9 I'LL TAKE MANHATTAN, by Judith 8 16 Krantz. (Crown, $18.95.) Rich and beautiful Maxi Amberville conquers the world of magazine publishing. 10 A PERFECT SPY, by John le Carre. 6 16 (Knopf, $18.95.) The tale of Magnus Pym, a British secret agent, and his father, Rick, a flamboyant con man. 11 THE GOOD MOTHER, by Sue Miller. 11 13 (Harper & Row, $17.95.) A woman's attachment to her daughter presents her with a dilemma. 12 THE MAMMOTH HUNTERS, by Jean M. Auel. 12 38 (Crown, $19.95.) Ayla continues her adventures in the prehistoric world. 13 BARRIER ISLAND, by John D. 13 8 MacDonald. (Knopf, $16.95.) One man sets out to thwart a multimillion-dollar Mississippi land swindle. 14 TABLE MONEY, by Jimmy Breslin. 1 (Ticknor & Fields, $17.95.) The home life of an alcoholic Queens blue-collar worker and his gritty wife. 15 Q CLEARANCE, by Peter Benchley. 2 (Random House, $16.95.) A White House speechwriter reluctantly becomes a Presidential confidant. Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 THE ROTATION DIET, By Martin 1 12 Katahn. (Norton, $15.95.) A regimen based on the Vanderbilt University Weight Management Program. 2 FIT FOR LIFE, by Harvey Diamond 2 51 and Marilyn Diamond. (Warner, $17.50.) A diet for weight loss and physical fitness. 3 CALLANETICS, by Callan Pinckney 3 37 with Sallie Batson. (Morrow, $17.95.) Exercises designed to enable women to look ''10 years younger in 10 hours.'' 4 JANE FONDA'S NEW WORKOUT & WEIGHT-LOSS 1 PROGRAM, by Jane Fonda. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) The actress adds a diet to a less taxing version of her exercises. 5* MEDICAL MAKEOVER, by Robert M. Giller 5 4 and Kathy Matthews. (Beech Tree/Morrow, $16.95.) A ''no-willpower program for lifetime health.'' The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from 2,000 bookstores in every region of the United States, statistically adjusted to represent sales in all bookstores. In Advice and How-to, five titles are listed because, beyond that point, sales in this category are not generally large enough to make a longer list statistically reliable. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the bookselling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. And Bear in Mind (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) HOME: A Short History of an Idea, by Witold Rybczynski. (Viking, $16.95.) Mr. Rybczynski, an architect, traces the development of such values as privacy, individuality and comfort (a notion very hard to define) as they reveal themselves in the corresponding development of structures meant for people to live in. DESSA ROSE, by Sherley Anne Williams. (Morrow, $15.95.) An absorbing, poetic novel whose heart is a growing relationship between a fugitive slave woman and an aristocratic Southern bride, its plot enlivened with a daring caper scheme. THE FBI-KGB WAR: A Special Agent's Story, by Robert J. Lamphere and Tom Shachtman. (Random House, $18.95.) Mr. Lamphere, who was much involved with exposing spies in the 1940's and 50's, reveals how it was done - partly through the discovery, kept secret for many years, of a Soviet code book. XORANDOR, by Christine Brooke-Rose. (Carcanet, $15.95.) In this engaging tour de force of science fiction, two bright children investigate the mind of a sentient rock in Cornwall. DELIRIUM ECLIPSE & OTHER STORIES, by James Lasdun. (Harper & Row, $15.95.) This first book by a young British writer exhibits ingenious premises, care for detail and a wide range of narrative, rhetorical, inventive and meditative techniques. THE AYATOLLAH IN THE CATHEDRAL, by Moorhead Kennedy. (Myrin/Hill & Wang, $17.95.) The memoirs of a former Foreign Service officer, one of the 52 American hostages held in Teheran, who since his ordeal has found some members of the American peace movement as rigid as any Iranian ideologue. THE SOVIET PARADOX: External Expansion, Internal Decline, by Seweryn Bialer. (Knopf, $22.95.) A distinguished scholar of international affairs argues that the Soviet leadership dares not risk internal reform and badly needs to assert Soviet world power.

title: GRAVESEND
description: THE first residents of Gravesend were reluctant to leave. They liked the neighborhood, and even after they had sold the land they kept trying to move back.

title: LAWYER WINS VINDICATION OVER 1982 BURGER OPINION
description: Four years ago, Chief Justice Warren E. Burger said in a widely publicized dissent that a Denver lawyer admitted to practice before the Supreme Court lacked ''good moral and professional character.''

title: ANOTHER DEADLY CAR BOMB IN BEIRUT
description: Beirut pressed on last week with its devastating war against itself. A car bomb killed 17 people and wounded 90 in mainly Moslem West Beirut.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: BIOGRAPHY OF BROKEN FORTUNES: Wilkie and Bob, Brothers of William, Henry and Alice James. By Jane Maher. (Archon, $22.95.)
