While their gifted older brothers were kept at home to puzzle their proper callings in life, Wilkie and Robertson James (''the boys'') were given their father's blessing to enlist in the Union Army.

title: ORTON'S 'BUTLER' STAGED AT ARENA
description: In ''What the Butler Saw,'' the Joe Orton satire of psychiatry now at the Arena Players Repertory Theater, the cast of characters include a psychiatrist who is attempting to ''misbehave himself'' with a young secretarial applicant, a randy blackmailing bellboy who has compromising photographs of a doctor's wayward wife, an insane doctor who turns out to be the government minister in charge of psychiatric hospitals, and a bemused police officer who is searching for the private parts of the deceased Sir Winston Churchill.

title: Bell Homer Helps Reds Beat Valenzuela
description: A two-run home run by Buddy Bell off Fernando Valenzuela broke open a pitching duel with John Denny today and sent the Cincinnati Reds to a 6-2 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: TWO FESTIVALS OFFER SOUNDS TO 'STRETCH' THE EAR
description: THERE are two summer festivals named for Connecticut's most famous composer, and since Charles Ives said he loved things that would ''stretch your ears,'' he probably would have loved them both.

title: On the Trail Of Illegal Trash
description: On a New York City building site, what comes down can cause more trouble than what goes up. The high cost of removing construction debris was reflected in racketeering charges announced last week after 100 investigators fanned out from predawn rendezvous sites to make arrests in what was described as a $5-million-a-year scheme to haul tons of the stuff out of New York and dump it illegally in New Jersey.

title: OF BOOKS, CLASSES AND WHEELCHAIRS
description: AS I SIT correcting papers in my third-floor office, I can hear the elevator doors slide open and close at the end of the hall. Mixed with the voices of students passing through the halls is the steady hum of a machine.

title:
NATURE WATCH;
VICEROY BUTTERFLY
description: Size: Two and a half to three and a half inches.

title: SENATE VOTES BILL THAT SCALES BACK ANTIMISSILE SHIELD
description: The Republican-controlled Senate, meeting in a rare Saturday session, tonight wearily approved a scaled-down $295 billion military bill that would mean a major reduction in President Reagan's antimissile research program.

title: FOR BASEBALL LEAGUE'S HEAD, NO TASK IS MINOR
description: BEFITTING their stature in the sport, the presidents of the American and National baseball leagues oversee their respective domains with large staffs in spacious suites on Park Avenue in Manhattan. By contrast, the president of the Double-A Eastern League, Charles E. Eshbach, lives -and runs his league - in a totally different milieu.

title: REAGAN, IN RADIO TALK, ASSAILS REHNQUIST CRITICS
description: President Reagan today denounced Congressional critics of Justice William H. Rehnquist, his nominee for Chief Justice of the United States, saying that they were motivated by political considerations.

title: Data Update
description: Source: HSH Associates *Rates on most adjustable mortgages are set 1 to 3 percentage points above these indexes.

title: Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: SENATE 1. Space Shield: Vote on an amendment to the military programs bill for the fiscal year 1987 that would have cut the President's strategic defense initiative request to $3.56 billion. (The President's original $5.3 billion request has already been cut to $3.95 billion by the Senate Arms Services Committee.) Rejected 50 to 49, Aug. 5. 2. Staten Island Navy Base: Vote on an amendment to the 1987 military programs bill that would have deleted $56.2 million for the Navy plan to build a battleship berth on Staten Island. Rejected 65 to 34, Aug. 6.

title: HIGH IN THE CATSKILLS, A ZEN RETREAT RELIEVES ANXIETIES
description: One by one, carrying simple wooden bowls and chopsticks, they entered the room. First the monks, with their shaved heads and long brown robes, and then the guests, in their denim jackets and jumpsuits. The abbot slapped together two flat sticks, and oatmeal was passed along the low table where the group sat in silence on the floor.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on July 13 about gazebos misidentified this year's recipient of the Arthur Ross Award for landscape design. He is J. Liddon Pennock Jr.

title:
DINING OUT;
CHARM AND SERVICE IN PURDY'S
description: THE familiar note at the bottom of the Box Tree's menu reminds diners that they dine ''where only the best will do.'' As a result of several recent visits, we would qualify that motto as being a noble aspiration for the kitchen, for the success of dishes served here seemed to depend upon the chef of the the evening, and the schedule of who is cooking on what night is dizzying. It may be that with kitchen responsibility spread so thinly, too many cooks are desiccating and burning the food.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN MANAGING ARCHIVES
description: THE goals and methods of archives management have not changed much in the last few decades. Archivists still sift through personal and corporate papers, letters and diaries, meeting minutes and memorabilia, all in hopes of accurately reconstructing the past.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: TALES OF PAN Written and Illustrated by Mordicai Gerstein. 63 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $12.95. (Ages 6 and up)

title: WHITE HOUSE QUIETLY PUSHES CASH WELFARE PLAN
description: White House officials are quietly encouraging state welfare officials to make proposals that would provide poor people with cash in place of assistance such as food stamps, Medicaid, public housing and school lunch subsidies.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
BRONTE GATHERING
description: An international assemblage of Bronte scholars and aficionados will gather at Pace University's Briarcliff campus Tuesday through Saturday for what is being called the First Pace Bronte Conference. The theme of the conference is, ''Sisters in Contention,'' with special attention to the novels ''Jane Eyre,'' ''Wuthering Heights'' and ''Agnes Gray.'' Brian Wilks, director of the International Conference of Bronte scholars at the University of Leeds, in England, will lead the conference.

title: PATIOS VS. A WIDER STREET
description: NEVADA AVENUE is one of a dozen narrow streets in the West End section of the City of Long Beach. To let traffic flow through such streets - less than 20 feet wide -residents routinely, and not entirely legally, park their cars with two wheels well up onto the sidewalk.

title: Maspeth
description: To the Editor:

title: KIYOKO'S LANTERN, OGATA'S FROGS
description: A LATE CHRYSANTHEMUM Twenty-one Stories From the Japanese. Edited and translated by Lane Dunlop. Illustrated by Ryohei Tanaka. 178 pp. San Francisco: North Point Press. $16.50.

title: SOVIET DIPLOMACY GIVEN A NEW LOOK UNDER GORBACHEV
description: The Soviet Union's foreign-policy apparatus has been undergoing a major overhaul, including the most thorough reorganization of the Foreign Ministry in memory, according to Soviet officials and Western diplomats.

title: Country Club Becomes a Battleground Over Growth
description: A DEVELOPER'S plan to transform a rural New Jersey country club into a high-priced condominium community with an 18-hole golf course has turned the 275-acre site into a philosophical and legal battleground between advocates of controlled growth and those who would retain the open space.

title: THE WAR BETWEEN MEN AND WOMEN (CONTD.)
description: HOW MEN FEEL Their Response to Women's Demands for Equality and Power. By Anthony Astrachan. 444 pp. New York: Anchor Press/Doubleday. $19.95.

title: Panama Issues Report About Its Drug Battle
description: The Government has made public a detailed defense of its battle against narcotics in response to charges by United States officials that Panama's military chief is involved in drug trafficking.

title: PACKAGING BRIGHTER FUTURES FOR DOWN'S SYNDROME PATIENTS
description: WHEN Colleen and Allen Tooley's third daughter was born two years ago, the Burlington Township couple knew almost nothing about the condition called Down's syndrome.

title: IN VENICE, THE SWEEP OF HISTORY
description: It has been said a thousand times before, but it must be said again: Venice is unique, the most wonderful creation among historic cities. I regard New York as the most splendid urban creation of our 20th century, but it has taken many centuries to build up the fabulous creation that Venice is, on its islands and waterways. There is nothing to equal it.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article about MCI last Sunday misstated the scope of the company's foreign operations. MCI serves 45 foreign countries, 17 of them directly and the rest through foreign state-owned telephone networks.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Off Delaware, A Treasure Hunt

title: DURACELL NEIGHBORS URGED TO TAKE TESTS
description: bECAUSE of significant levels of lead and mercury left in the ground by the Duracell Corporation after the plant closed in December 1984, North Tarrytown residents who live within a half-mile radius and former employees have been advised to seek testing for traces of those elements in their bodies.

title: VISITING FREUD'S HOME IN LONDON
description: Victorian bourgeois living rooms were often cluttered with objects, but even by those standards Sigmund Freud's study at 20 Maresfield Gardens, the house in London where he spent the last year of his life, contains an exceptional number. Throughout his life Freud was a passionate collector of antiquities, especially of Roman, Etruscan, Assyrian and Egyptian statuettes, and these crowd the top of his desk and overflow onto the bookshelves. There are cabinets packed with Greek pottery, bronzes and other objects, a number of beautiful Oriental rugs and some exquisite pieces of antique painted furniture.

title:
EDUCATION WATCH;
RETHINKING 'CAREER' HIGH SCHOOL ADMISSIONS
description: NEW YORK CITY has eight ''educational option'' public high schools, each emphasizing a broad career area. Although these institutions - from Murry Bergtraum High School for Business Careers in Manhattan to Clara Barton High School for the Health Professions in Brooklyn - are required to admit students of varying ability, the Board of Education says it is concerned that they have become unfairly selective, skimming off too many promising applicants who would otherwise go to the neighborhood high schools. At the eight ''option'' schools, 25 percent of the entering students read above their grade level, 50 percent are average readers and 25 percent read below grade level. Under admissions proposals the board has approved pending hearings next month, 50 percent of the students at the ''option'' schools would be selected at random from the tens of thousands of applicants each year, and 50 percent would be chosen by the schools. (The plan would not affect the four ''specialized'' institutions, such as the Bronx High School of Science.) Jane Perlez, a reporter for The New York Times, discussed the proposals with Margaret Nuzum of the Educational Priorities Panel, a group that supports them, and Saul Bruckner, the principal of the career-track Edward R. Murrow High School, who opposes the changes. Excerpts follow. MARGARET NUZUM Step Toward Equity

title: Susan A. Bartlett Is Engaged
description: Announcement has been made by May Parish Bartlett of Boston and Dark Harbor, Me., and Joseph W. Bartlett of New York of the engagement of their daughter, Susan Appleton Bartlett, to Douglas Edmondson Crater, a son of Mrs. Henry A. Jandl of Richmond and the late David Hopkins Crater. A December wedding is planned.

title: A Cheer for Postmodernism
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: INDEPENDENT: A Biography of Lewis W. Douglas. By Robert Paul Browder and Thomas G. Smith. (Knopf, $30.) This is a balanced and authoritative biography of an influential but now largely forgotten American political figure of the middle 20th century.

title: GOODBYE, MR. Z., I GRADE YOU TOPS
description: HE was of below-average height, short in fact, yet he projected a distinguished appearance. His bronze-colored hair, striped with lines of gray, revealed his age. He was, I recalled, a modest man.

title: Marjorie Harvey And D. S. Swift To Marry in Fall
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Curran Whitthorne Harvey Jr. of Baltimore of the engagement of their daughter, Marjorie Merwin Harvey, to Donald Scott Swift, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Roland Barr Swift of Basking Ridge, N.J. The wedding is planned for October. Miss Harvey, who graduated from the Garrison Forest School and New England College, is a store manager in New York for J. McLaughlin Inc., a sportswear company.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: After 12 years of planning and three years of construction, the problem-plagued Route 88 bridge in Point Pleasant has finally opened. Sort of.

title: Dance
description: ''Tango Argentino'' has departed from Broadway, but enthusiasts of that earthy, stylized dance form will have another chance to see it when Ana Maria Stekelman opens the dance segment of the Festival Latino in New York with ''Jazmines-Tango,'' on Wednesday at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park. A founder and director of Grupo Danza Contemporanea of Buenos Aires's San Martin Municipal Theater, Ms. Stekelman will appear in a theater-dance piece set to 15 well-known tangos, sharing the stage with musicians playing the piano, bandoleon, violin, flute, and double bass. Her partner is Jorge Romano, and there will be a scenario written by Ms. Stekelman and Niko Vasiliadis.

title: A Rebuke On Testing
description: The House of Representatives has handed President Reagan a stiff and long-overdue rebuke - one that may result in a Congressional limit on the nuclear tests he has been conducting at will, often for specious or hidden reasons and in defiance of world opinion.

title: INDUSTRY ASSISTING TEACHERS
description: ''WHAT'S a person like you doing in a place like this?'' is a question that Business Industry Science Education Consortium interns - high school teachers spending their summer vacations doing industrial research - must have been asked.

title:
ART;
'FOUR WINNERS': A SHOW THAT PROVIDES ROOM FOR THOUGHT
description: WORKS by the four top award winners in last year's annual juried exhibition at the Fine Arts Museum of Long Island in Hempstead are now featured in concurrent one-person shows. The museum's ample wall space allows each artist to present a substantial body of work, offering a welcome opportunity for viewers to assess their achievements in depth.

title: Diane S. Archer Planning to Wed Stephen Presser
description: Diane Strom Archer and Stephen Presser, Harvard Law School graduates who practice in Manhattan, plan to be married Sept. 20, the parents of the future bride, Dr. and Mrs. Joel S. Archer of New York, have announced. Mr. Presser is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Presser of Jacksonville, Fla.

title: BOOKSHELF
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: WISHES AND GOALS AT CAMPS FOR CITY CHILDREN
description: When 36 new counselors arrived here at Camp Anita Bliss Coler, one of their first activities was to gather around an empty tea kettle and fill it with wishes.

title: Making a Purchase Profitable
description: AS bed-and-breakfast establishments and small country inns grow in popularity the idea of running one becomes less of a pipe dream and more of a practical investment option.

title:
GARDENING;
NATIVE PLANTINGS RECLAIM THE ROADSIDES
description: ONE has but to travel the interstate highway system to fully appreciate how much gardeners have become enslaved by gardens. In the 1950's and 60's, when the superhighways were new, they were planted - landscaped, if you will - as a part of our national beautification emphasis.

title: POSTINGS: Garden City Complex; Adding Offices
description: Late in the 19th century, when Alexander Turney Stewart, an Irish millionaire, bought the 4.3 acres now known as Garden City, L.I., he paid almost $55 an acre for his parcel. Today, the developers of a five-story building in Garden City plan to charge their tenants about $25 a square foot.

title: WHEN HUSBANDS STAY BEHIND
description: GIGGLING like Girl Scout campers, the four sophisticated Long Island matrons piled into the Honda for their week in the country.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: Virginia Ridgely Weds S. A. Howe
description: Virginia Sellman Ridgely and Samuel Armstrong Howe were married yesterday in Holderness, N.H. The Rev. John Branson, an Epsicopal priest, performed the ceremony on an island in Squam Lake. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Beverly S. Ridgely of Providence, R.I., and Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Howe Jr. of Lyme, Conn.

title: Falwell Awarded $200,000 In Case on Hustler Parody
description: The Rev. Jerry Falwell is entitled to $200,000 awarded by a jury that found he suffered emotionally from a parody in Hustler magazine but was not libeled, an appeals court has ruled.

title:
ABOUT MEN;
Learning Greek
description: WHEN I REACHED 50, I decided, as many men do, to prepare for age. My method was to lose weight, stop drinking and learn ancient Greek. The first two took far less effort than the third, both to accomplish and to explain. Seven years later, I'm still trying to tell people why I took up Greek.

title: Kristina Gulick Is Married To Erik Michael Schaefer
description: The marriage of Kristina Gulick, the director of the parents' program at the University of Vermont, and Erik Michael Schaefer, a doctoral candidate in medical microbiology at the university, took place yesterday.

title: A Plan to Keep Broadway Bright
description: Over the years, an intriguing if minor sticking point has cropped up in proposals to redevelop Times Square: how to preserve something of the carnival-like atmosphere of the area while discarding its more tawdry characteristics.

title: CATALOGUE LISTS FILMS ON ART
description: A CATALOGUE listing more than 500 documentary films and videotapes on the fine arts will be available next month to schools, museums and libraries throughout the country, as well as to the home-video market.

title: THEY'RE KEEPING THEIR MINI-SERIES ALL IN THE FAMILY
description: Steve Krantz can't stand the word ''trashy.'' It's an adjective he's heard more than once in reviews of his wife Judith's best-selling novels and the television mini-series he produces from them. ''Trashy is a cheap word,'' he said recently, while in town for the filming of ''I'll Take Manhattan,'' an eight-hour dramatization for CBS-TV of Mrs. Krantz's current best-seller, set in the world of magazine publishing. ''It shows an incredible poverty of language.''

title: Reagan Saves His Trade Policy, But Just Barely
description: President Reagan used his formidable powers of persuasion to protect his trade policies last week, defeating an attempt in the House of Representatives to override his veto of a bill that would have limited textile, shoe and copper imports.

title: Tapley Allen Has Wedding
description: Tapley Allen, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas F. Allen of Swampscott, Mass., was married yesterday to Steven R. Sheresky, a son of Lyn Revson and Kenneth Sheresky, both of New York. The Rev. Robert E. Slater, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents, assisted by Rabbi Allan Press.

title: COLLECTING: THE BUY'S THE THING
description: Most buyers of records -popular or classical - are casual, once-in-a-while buyers. But there are also ''serious'' buyers; there is even a fat record-review bimonthly, Fanfare, that describes itself as ''the magazine for serious record collectors.'' What drives the ''serious'' collector is often a subject for discussion - usually among serious collectors themselves or among their put-upon spouses, who are weary of the never-ending demand for more space.

title: First Aid for In-Field Breakdowns
description: THE workshop student, several thousand miles from home, came up to me with a zoom lens in one hand and six ball bearings in the other. ''These fell out of the mount the last time I took the lens off the camera,'' he said. ''Do you think I can still use it?''

title: Deidre Foley a Bride
description: Deidre Foley, a daughter of Barbara Foley of River Vale, N.J., and Tupper Lake, N.Y., was married yesterday to Dr. Jeffrey Oppenheimer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Oppenheimer of Leonia, N.J. Rabbi William Kramer performed the ceremony at his home in Westwood, Calif. Mrs. Oppenheimer is a certified patent agent with Lockheed of California in Burbank. Dr. Oppenheimer is a resident in the neurosurgery department at the Los Angeles County/University of Southern California Medical Center in Los Angeles.

title: CORRECTION
description: In the Practical Traveler column last Sunday, a Dec. 5 cruise under the heading Pearl of Scandinavia was incorrectly described. The rates and departure dates in this paragraph were all for ''Bali, Bangkok and Beyond,'' a 13-night journey. The group rates for this cruise, as well as for other examples cited, depend on the date and the cruise specialist forming the group.

title: Children of Divorce Are Not Always Scarred
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: CHOCOLATE: An Illustrated History. By Marcia and Frederic Morton. (Crown, $19.95.) This book is as luscious as its subject, as rich as a Sacher torte, a $36 pound of Swiss truffles or a beloved, familiar Hershey bar.

title: SALVADOR REBELS ARE BEING BLAMED AS MINES KILL OR HURT MORE CIVILIANS
description: More than 100 civilians have been killed or wounded by land mines in El Salvador this year, according to human rights organizations, the army and the United States Embassy here.

title: Chinese Officials Hold Talks With Mongolia
description: Chinese officials are holding talks with representatives of Mongolia in a bid to improve strained relations, China announced today.

title: LANDFILL LIMITS SAID TO ENCOURAGE DUMPING PLOT
description: The dual solid-waste-disposal problems of rising costs and dwindling landfill space in the metropolitan area provided the incentive for an illegal dumping scheme that officials say generated $5 million a year for 10 people who were charged with racketeering on Thursday.

title:
ART;
SOMETHING -- BUT WHAT? -- IS HAPPENING IN NEW JERSEY ART
description: SOMETHING is happening in the realm of art in New Jersey but there is uncertainty about exactly what it is. No art theorist has put forward a ''New Jersey School of Art.''

title: Strings Going Strong
description: Classical music has become more popular in Washington in recent years. And now two string quartets based at the Smithsonian Institution have developed such enthusiastic followings that one of them is moving to a larger performance hall, making a more attractive setting available for the other.

title: CASTRO'S ADVENTURES ABROAD
description: Caribbean Tempest. By Pamela S. Falk. Illustrated. 336 pp. Lexington, Mass.: Lexington Books/ D. C. Heath & Company. $29.

title: Foreign Exchange
description: To the Editor: As a follow-up to a recent letter (Travel, July 6) that mentioned being cheated at the bank in a railroad station in Italy, I'd like to add a postscript.

title: 14 Are Gannett Center Fellows
description: Fourteen people from the news media and higher education have been named to fellowships at the Gannett Center for Media Studies at Columbia University.

title: Moratoriums Stir Debate in Westchester
description: ''WE'RE not saying we don't want other people to move in,'' said John Schwarten, an Irvington resident. ''We just want a more specific plan, so that Irvington can keep its unique qualities.''

title: HIGH DRAMA AND SOME LOW COMEDY
description: The winners of the Spingold Knockout Team Championship in Toronto last month were a highly experienced group. Malcolm Brachman of Dallas, the team captain, was supported by three of the professionals who helped him win the world team title in 1979, Mike Passell, Bob Goldman and Paul Soloway, and by two players almost as well known, Mark Lair and Ron Andersen.

title: MALTA SAYS IT WARNED LIBYA OF U.S. RAID
description: What did Libya know and when did it know it? According to Prime Minister Karmenu Mifsud Bonnici of Malta, Maltese air controllers warned Libya of the impending American air strike - and would do so again. In an interview last week, Mr. Mifsud Bonnici said the planes were picked up on radar 30 to 45 minutes before the raid, and Libya was notified shortly thereafter.

title: If Not Westway, Then What?
description: If City Hall and Albany can reach agreement expeditiously and if construction then progresses without serious delays, the West Side road improvements that are to be financed with some of the Federal funds traded for the abandoned Westway project just might be finished sometime in 1992.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: MOTHERS TALKING: Sharing the Secret. By Frances Wells Burck. (St. Martin's, $15.95.) Frances Wells Burck, author of ''Babysense,'' presents 42 mothers speaking in their own voices about mothering.

title: Police in India Capture 5 Top Sikh Militants
description: Police officials said today that they had made a major breakthrough in their drive against Sikh gunmen by capturing five militants, including two top leaders of the extremist movement.

title: A FUTURE WITH NO PERHAPS
description: SUNSET POSSIBILITIES And Other Poems. By Gabriel Preil. Translated, and with an introduction, by Robert Friend. With a preface by T. Carmi. Bilingual. 147 pp. Philadelphia: The Jewish Publication Society. Cloth, $12.95. Paper, $8.95.

title: NEW JERSEY IS WINNING ITS BATTLE IN THE PINELANDS
description: INCONGRUOUS though it may seem, one-fifth of New Jersey - the most densely populated state in the nation - is a pine forest, nearly wild in places, where the weak soil keeps some mature trees only cornstalk high and the flat terrain, once at the bottom of the ocean, makes a 180-foot knoll prominent enough to be considered a mountain.

title: TO ASSIST HANDICAPPED, A ROBOT THAT CAN HEAR
description: Richard A. Foulds and his laboratory associates have been working for a year and a half on a robot they hope will push buttons at the command of a voice.

title: DONATIONS FOR ORGAN TRANSPLANTS RISE AFTER NEW LAW
description: Christopher Seibert of Holbrook died of injruies sustained when a car hit him in June 1985. He was ''a good boy who cared about his family, his friends and his future,'' a teacher said in a note to his parents.

title: ALL-RUSSIAN PROGRAM SET
description: AN all-Russian program featuring fireworks and cannon will be presented Saturday at the Garden State Arts Center here by the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra.

title: LITERARY DEVICES ARE INFLUENCING DANCE
description: A move away from abstraction is very much the trend of dance in the 1980's, and it is now becoming clear that this characteristic is much more multi-faceted than was first apparent.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Ruminating in the Open Air Perhaps no other city in the world has been described so lovingly and so often as Paris. In ''The Contract'' (Henry Holt), J. W. Rhoads evokes spring in the Luxembourg Gardens.

title: STATE'S POPULATION SHOWS INCREASE, DANBURY GAIN HIGHEST
description: THE Danbury area continues to be the fastest growing in the state, while the economically strong Stamford area has experienced a population decline, according to population estimates of the United States Census Bureau.

title: DRUGS AND PARENTS' FEAR TAINT WASHINGTON HTS.
description: Angel Gonzalez, 14 years old, left a note on the kitchen table, as he always does before going out to meet his friends on St. Nicholas Avenue and 175th Street. ''Mom,'' he wrote, ''I'm going bike riding. I'll be back later.''

title: One Park Avenue to a City Is Quite Enough
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE QUICK AND THE DEAD. By Z. Vance Wilson. (Arbor House, $17.95.) This exciting first novel shows the South of the 40's and 50's edging toward secularism.

title: Headliners; A National Treasure
description: In keeping absolutely secret for 15 years a major body of his work, Andrew Wyeth may have raised discretion to an art. Last week a Pennsylvania collector astonished the world of fine arts by disclosing the existence of 240 previously unknown paintings and drawings by Mr. Wyeth, who completed the works - virtually all of a woman known only as Helga - between 1970 and 1985 and kept them secret even from Betsy, his wife of 46 years.

title: North Korea Says South Fired at Guard Post
description: In the second such accusation in a week, North Korea said today that South Korean troops fired large-caliber machine guns and automatic weapons across the demilitarized zone at a North Korean guard post.

title: LEBANON CAPTORS WARN WASHINGTON
description: A statement purportedly issued by the Islamic Holy War organization warned the United States today that its policy in Lebanon was harming the case of American hostages held here.

title: Grounded Cruise Ship Is Freed in Alaska
description: The cruise ship North Star, which ran aground on a reef in Alaska's Inside Passage Friday, was floated free with high tide early today and towed to the Indian village of Klawock for repairs, the Coast Guard said.

title: I-78 'MISSING LINK' TO OPEN
description: A MILESTONE in New Jersey's highway system will be passed this week when a 5.5-mile segment of Interstate 78 is formally dedicated and opened.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Everything's normal, everything's fine.'' - President Reagan. [ 1:4. ]

title: OFFICIALS CITE 38 FOOD OUTLETS
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 38 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: DANCE: WIL SWANSON AND MINNEAPOLIS GROUP
description: DANCE THEATER WORKSHOP'S ''Out-of-Towners'' summer series, which opened on Thursday at the Bessie Schonberg Theater, introduces New Yorkers to new or relatively unfamiliar choreographers and dancers and provides the artists with a New York forum.

title: CONTINENTAL OFFERINGS AND SPECIALS
description: TABLES, the 18-month-old restaurant on Route 22 in Mountainside, received its name for the most logical of reasons -because a restaurant is full of tables. At least that is what we were told by the owner, Theodore Biniaris Sr. The interior has no recognizable style, but instead is a mixture of many. There are wood shingles, both brick and paneled walls, white pine doors with stained-glass windows, red carpets black banquets, freestanding tables and chairs.

title: Headliners; A Slugger's Last Rap
description: To the management of the New York Mets, the problem with outfielder George Foster, once a prolific home-run hitter, was that he was not performing very well at bat. He had hit only 13 home runs this season, for a salary of $2 million, meaning the Mets had paid him more than $153,000 for each dinger, as the players call the biggest hit.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Leavenworth, Wash.; How To Go 'Old Bavarian'
description: THE question facing James Willems eight years ago was how to transform his roadside gas station into something that might fit into an old Alpine village. One resident suggested calling it Das Chevron Haus and dressing up his attendants in lederhosen.

title: What's Behind Foster Furor
description: AMID the cloud of racial controversy over George Foster's abrupt departure from the Mets, the real reason has been overlooked: Davey Johnson's obsession with ''keeping the accelerator on the floor,'' to use Frank Cashen's description of the manager's dugout philosophy. Both on and off the field, it now develops, Johnson apparently thought that baseball's $2 million pinch-hitter was preventing him from trying to extend the Mets' lead in the National League East.

title: Christiane Wiese and Kurt Wyckoff Are Married in Fire Island Ceremony
description: The marriage of Christiane Carden Wiese, a daughter of Mrs. Charles Thoburn Maxwell of Bronxville, N.Y., and Peter Christian Wiese of New York, to Robin Kurt Wyckoff took place yesterday at the Church at Point O'Woods, Fire Island, L.I. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Van Wyckoff of Atlanta. The Rev. Martin B. Copenhaver of the First Congregational Church in Burlington, Vt., performed the ceremony.

title: Wonders of the Natural World Are Inspiring New Books
description: IF a flood of published words is a valid indication, the American fascination with the natural world shows no sign of abating.

title:
INVESTING;
A NEW WAY TO PLAY THE BOND MARKET
description: SINCE January, institutional investors, such as the $18 billion Retirement System of New York City, have poured billions of dollars into bond index funds. Unhappy with money managers who have been unable to generate returns higher than the popular bond indexes, these big players instead are turning to bond programs designed basically to mirror the performance of a broad index -typically Salomon Brothers' Investment-Grade Bond Index, the Shearson Lehman Brothers Government/Corporate Index or an index developed by Merrill Lynch & Company.

title: Lisa I. Spector Weds Adam Wise Rothkrug
description: Temple Beth-El in Great Neck, L.I., was the setting last night for the wedding of Lisa Ilene Spector, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph K. Spector of Kings Point, L.I., to Adam Wise Rothkrug, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Rothkrug of Great Neck. Rabbi Jerome Davidson, assisted by Cantor Barbara Horowitz, performed the ceremony.

title: LESSONS FOR CHINESE GROUP AT CITY U.
description: At Medgar Evers College in Brooklyn, they saw a remedial class for incoming freshmen. At the College of Staten Island, they visited a robotics lab and library. For the 25 educators from China, it was an unusual opportunity to get a glimpse of how the ''broad masses'' are educated in America.

title: JOURNALIST FOUNDED UNITED NEWS OF INDIA
description: Dattatray Wagle, a journalist and founder of the United News of India, died Friday at the Hackensack Medical Center of cardio-pulmonary arrest. He was 84 years old and lived in Oradell, N.J.

title: PARCELLS ANGERED BY DORSEY'S PLAY
description: Eric Dorsey, the first-round draft choice, spent his second day with the Giants today, and for the second day he received a lashing from Coach Bill Parcells.

title: BATTLE IN SCARSDALE OVER USE OF ESTATE OF HARRY WINSTON
description: WITH the score 1-to-1 so far in a court battle over the former Scarsdale estate of Harry Winston, the jeweler, lawyers for the village of Scarsdale and for Mr. Winston's heirs have begun taking depositions from each other's witnesses for a third round.

title: Jill Runcie to Wed Lee Sharp Lorenz
description: Jill Alison Runcie, a vice president of Decker Decker & Freas, a marketing and communications firm in New York, and Lee Sharp Lorenz, the art editor of The New Yorker magazine, plan to be married Sept. 27.

title: ELECTRIC SUPPLY TERMED MARGINAL
description: Marginal. That's how the North American Electric Reliability Council describes this summer's electric supply situation on Long Island. In a recent report, the council said Long Island is the only area of the United States that will have trouble meeting peak electric demand this summer.

title: Forest Service Backs a Plan To Protect Owls in Northwest
description: The United States Forest Service has urged a compromise between environmentalists and the timber industry that would preserve hundreds of thousands of acres in the Pacific Northwest to protect the northern spotted owl.

title: FOR JAPAN, EVEN THE WAR TAKES A BACK SEAT TO TRADE
description: AS ALWAYS in this season, Japan is consumed with memories of its suffering at the end of World War II. Wednesday was the 41st anniversary of Hiroshima's nuclear destruction. Yesterday thousands of people gathered for remembrances of the Nagasaki bombing. On Friday, Japanese will pause to recall the day in 1945 when the Emperor told them to ''endure the unendurable'' by surrendering.

title: Logic Behind Yankees' Trades
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Christopher Gruseke Wed to Alison Acker
description: Alison Mary Acker, a daughter of Julia Muirhead Acker and Richard Chapman Acker, both of Wheaton, Ill., was married yesterday to Christopher Robert Gruseke, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph S. Gruseke of Westfield, N.J. The Revs. Sinclair D. Hart and Peter T. Elvin performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Williamstown, Mass.

title: David Boies 3d Wed To Robin Lou Weiss
description: Robin Lou Weiss and David Boies 3d were married yesterday at the United Methodist Church of Cloverdale, Calif., by the Rev. James Hazen. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Richard Barry Weiss of Washington and Mr. Boies Jr. of New York and Caryl Maniscalco of Monte Rio, Calif.

title: Mishap in Naples
description: To the Editor: I am writing this with the hope that our recent experience in Naples, Italy, can serve as a warning to others.

title: Thatcher Gives A Bit on Sanctions Against Pretoria
description: THE only acceptable sanctions against South Africa would be ''those that won't have any practical effect,'' an aide to Margaret Thatcher had predicted, only partly in jest. Last week, as some of her partners in the 49-country Commonwealth threatened to break it up unless Britain acted, Prime Minister Thatcher agreed to join a proposed West European ban on South African coal, iron and steel - goods Britain imports in relatively small amounts.

title: CHANNEL ISLE WITH TWO ACCENTS
description: It may be difficult to make up one's mind which nation governs Jersey, the largest of the Channel Islands just off the coast of France. When the sun shines it is surely French: The air is clear and the architecture is reminiscent of a small town in Normandy. When it rains, however, and Jersey is backlit with wet, gray skies, the island's true English colors emerge. It is then that the visitor realizes most around him are speaking English, the food is of English standard and the bargain prices on tax-free, low-duty items are paid for in pounds sterling.

title: HERE LIE THE FAMILY PHOTOS: ARCHIVES CAN MEET MODERN NEED
description: UNTIL my father asked, ''What are you kids going to do with all the pictures after Mom and I are gone?'' I hadn't given the problem more than a passing thought. He wasn't referring to anything framed or commercially valuable, he was talking about the 90-odd photo albums and 50 slide carrousels scattered in closets and on bookshelves throughout the house, the legacy of Kodak's successful campaign to convince the American public that a life unrecorded was a life lost. Beginning with the birth of my older brother in 1950 and continuing through three more sons, this ''work in progress'' had documented the frozen smiles and stilted poses of our every holiday gathering, camp visit, birthday celebration, and graduation exercise. In page after page, we could track the inexorable aging of relatives and follow the course of American fashion: the 1950's crew cuts, the 60's shoulder-length hair, the rising and falling hemlines, the broadening and narrowing of ties - but we rarely did. After generating a brief flurry of interest, most of the albums languished in dark closets, vaguely embarrassing to its subjects.

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: POULENC'S 'DIALOGUES OF THE CARMELITES': An Australian Opera production, featuring Joan Sutherland, Isobel Buchanan, Lone Koppel, Heather Begg, Anne-Maree McDonald; with Richard Bonynge conducting, 1984; Sony Video, 155 minutes. $79.95.

title: Cambridge Bridal For Dr. Davidson
description: Dr. Daphne Loe Davidson and Thomas Robert Schwartz were married yesterday at the Harvard Memorial Church in Cambridge, Mass. The Rev. Dr. Frederick Reisz performed the Lutheran ceremony.

title: Lisa Demartini Marries C. H. Ogburn
description: Lisa Gould Demartini, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Felix Eugene Demartini of Englewood, N.J., was married yesterday to Charles Harris Ogburn, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Hubert Ogburn of Anchorage, Ky. The Rev. Harry Pritchett performed the ceremony at All Saints Episcopal Church in Atlanta.

title: FIGHTING NARCOTICS IS EVERYONE'S ISSUE NOW
description: AFTER the Defense Department scuttled last week a Navy plan to build itself a $20 million square rigger, an officer was only half joking when he said: ''What we should have done is tell everyone our new tall ship was going to be for drug interdiction. It would have sailed right through.''

title: S. M. Bliss Is Wed To Julie Halleran
description: The marriage of Julie Anne Halleran, an assistant media director at Grey Advertising Inc. in New York, and Stephen Mattison Bliss, an equity trader with Mabon, Nugent & Company in New York, took place yesterday at All Saints-by-the-Sea Episcopal Church in Southport, Me. The Rev. Christopher Sherrill performed the ceremony.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
SELF
description: THERE is nothing new in this story. No breakthroughs, no discoveries, no startling emotional syndromes. Nothing to raise the eyebrows and make one say, Oh my, how unusual.

title: PHONE UNION CALLS NEW YORK STRIKE
description: Telephone workers in New York, parts of Connecticut and New England went on strike at 12:01 this morning, but negotiations for employees of four other regional telephone companies continued across the nation.

title: Farm Sale Is Near
description: A tangle of lawsuits surrounding the proposed sale of the famous Spendthrift Farm near Lexington, Ky., may be close to resolution, according to Robert Hagopian, who hopes to take control of the thoroughbred operation later this month. He said a key $6 million lawsuit had been settled and predicted that two others would soon be resolved.

title:
GARDENING;
NATIVE PLANTINGS RECLAIM THE ROADSIDES
description: ONE has but to travel the interstate highway system to fully appreciate how much gardeners have become enslaved by gardens. In the 1950's and 60's, when the superhighways were new, they were planted - landscaped, if you will - as a part of our national beautification emphasis.

title: SLOUCH AWAY, YANKEE FANS, BOSTON WILL SURVIVE
description: LAST week, Sidney Zion addressed the-then current status of the race for the old gonfalon in the American League East. He did so in part by recounting the tale of his rudeness to a hospitable Bostonian on a June night in 1978 in Fenway Park. Rebuffing the chap's commiserations that the Yankees were trailing by eight and a half games, he sneered that no Yankee fan - a species about as common as the whooping crane, but not as valuable - is ever much concerned about the Red Sox until after Labor Day. And then not at all.

title: A GRAND TOUR ALONG THE GRANDEST CANAL
description: The busy and somewhat scruffy northwestern flank of Venice where the causeway from the mainland ends is a workaday gate that at once leads to the equivalent of an admirable marble corridor. The broad, opulent passageway that in an inverted S winds to St. Mark's Square, the city's incomparable parlor, has since the Middle Ages been known as the Grand Canal. It is one of the most magnificent two miles in the world - a watery boulevard.

title: RISING CONCERN ON DRUGS STIRS PUBLIC TO ACTIVISM
description: From the street corners of New York City to City Hall, Congress and the White House, concern about illegal drugs has exploded this summer, bringing a level of activism among church and community groups unseen in the last decade.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE EIGHTH COMMANDMENT. By Lawrence Sanders. (Putnam's, $18.95.) Lawrence Sanders' list of best sellers includes adventure yarns, erotic psychodramas and a few quasi police procedurals featuring unlikely investigators whose personalities provide as much allure as the intricacies of the cases they unravel.

title: James Greenfield Marries Claire Lobo
description: Claire Renata Lobo, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Orlando Hyndman Lobo of Bethesda, Md., was married there yesterday to James Donald Greenfield, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Kraus Greenfield of New York and Hartland, Vt. The Rev. Sylvia J. Lewis performed the ceremony at the River Road Unitarian Church.

title: Christine Williams to Wed
description: The engagement of Christine Marie Williams and Brian Foley, 1983 graduates of Villanova University, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Roland B. Williams of Waldwick, N.J., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Foley of Scotch Plains, N.J.

title: John Stamatopoulos Plans Miss deGersdorff to Wed
description: Mrs. Francis Eugene Gilbertson of Rumson, N.J., and Carl August deGersdorff of New York and Alford, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Susan Van Wyck deGersdorff, to John George Stamatopoulos, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George John Stamatopoulos of Melrose, Mass.

title: DOWN 6-1, METS WIN BY 10-8
description: ''Slump'' is probably not the right word. Maybe ''malaise,'' or ''flat feeling.'' Whatever it is, the Mets seemed to have a slight case of it tonight as they turned into the eighth inning trailing the Montreal Expos, 6-1, with only two hits to show for their evening's work.

title: VERSATILE BLUEBERRY BLOOMS IN MAINE
description: Every year, from the balmy end of July to the frosts of mid-September, wild blueberries blanket the state of Maine, which provides about 95 percent of the country's supply, according to the State Department of Agriculture. The sweet, sharp fruit is everywhere - underfoot whether you're on the cliffs of Monhegan Island or exploring the meadows and bogs at the foot of Mount Katahdin, 10 steps away if you're strolling down a dusty country lane, or as close as the pickup trucks dotting the shoulder if you're driving down Route 1.

title: FINDING BEAUTY, SEEKING ROOTS
description: The first time my brother came out to see me in Sag Harbor was in January of last year, by which time I had lived here for four years. He's not the visiting kind; his style is to stay put and let people come to him. It's a survival of the family style, I suppose. My parents never went anywhere. Their parents never went anywhere. Whole bevys of uncles, to be sure, picked up and moved to Cleveland, St. Louis, Florida, but they always came back from time to time. To Westfield, New Jersey. That's where my brother, whose name is Charles, still lives and maintains the tradition, in a big old fading Gray Gardens of a house with 20 rooms or so, a bunch of kids, a housekeeper, occasional guests, and dogs and cats in constantly changing numbers. He's not rich but he is the Town Attorney, everybody in Westfield knows who he is, and he's a happy man. He's where he belongs.

title: Cooperstown
description: To the Editor: James Sterngold's thorough article on visiting the charming town of Cooperstown, N. Y. (Travel, June 29) was especially appreciated by my family, since we had just returned from a vacation there. He certainly captured the spirit of a visit to the area.

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: THE 39 STEPS: Starring Robert Donat, Madeleine Carroll, Godfrey Tearle, Peggy Ashcroft, John Laurie, Wylie Watson; directed by Alfred Hitchcock, 1935, The Voyager Company, 87 minutes. $39.95.

title: Cable TV
description: ''Silverado'' (1985) hits cable this week, and about time. Janet Maslin of The Times called this highly entertaining movie, with its wonderful title, a ''sweeping, glorious-looking western that's at least a full generation removed from the classic films it brings to mind.''

title: SOLUTIONS FOR PROBLEMS THAT OFTEN CAN ARISE AROUND THE HOUSE
description: IN an effort to catch up on the backlog of mail received here, this week the entire Home Clinic column is devoted to questions from readers about some frequently encountered problems that homeowners face.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: Nature enthusiasts and volunteers at the Marine Mammal Stranding Center in Brigantine are having a whale of a time this summer, especially in recent weeks, when those mammals have made numerous appearances.

title: Town Marks the Site Of Woodstock Fest
description: Without fanfare, the town of Bethel has erected a roadside marker at the site of the 1969 Woodstock rock-music festival.

title: THE THEATER HAS ITS BRIGHTER SIDE, TOO
description: To the Editor:

title: WORLDWIDE SPORTS EVENTS SET THE THEME
description: The stereotype of a stamp collector is different from that of a sports fan. And yet, sports-on-stamps is one of the most popular philatelic themes.

title: MUSIC: PHILADELPHIA ORCHESTRA AT SARATOGA CENTER
description: Saratoga Springs has a past that is bawdy and glorious - a sort of patrician Las Vegas cum Newport for the gilded age. Its present-day appeal is built upon memory, fantasy, horse racing and, since 1966, the Saratoga Performing Arts Center.

title: Lex Tomlinson Weds Martha L. Cohen
description: The marriage of Martha Lee Cohen to Alexander Cooper Tomlinson 3d, a son of Elizabeth B. Tomlinson of Oyster Bay, L.I., and Mr. Tomlinson of Washington, took place yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Donn I. Cohen of York, Pa., parents of the bride. Judge Emmanuel Cassimatis of the Court of Common Pleas in York performed the ceremony.

title: Stepping Up, Out and Down: Faceless
description: A Manhattan woman left her apartment last Saturday night with her keys in one pocket and $1.25 for the Sunday paper in the other. En route to the newsstand she saw a shabby old man with one of those cane-like walkers calling out to passers-by, ''Hey, can I talk to you a minute?'' Everyone kept on going, heads lowered or turned away.

title: A CAT'S LIFE, OR A TALK WITH TIGER
description: MY 11-year-old cat decided to speak to me after all these years. I was astonished, of course, as you would be, too, if words came from your cat's mouth instead of meows.

title: O LITERARY PIONEERS!
description: PRAIRIE WOMEN Images in American and Canadian Fiction. By Carol Fairbanks. Illustrated. 300 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $22. PLAINS WOMAN The Diary of Martha Farnsworth, 1882-1922. Edited by Marlene Springer and Haskell Springer. Illustrated. 322 pp. Bloomington: Indiana University Press. $27.50.

title: Why Kill Nicaraguans?
description: President Reagan urges the Republican Senate to give him $100 million in aid for the ''contra'' rebels in Nicaragua and he's likely to prevail. The big test, after all, was in the Democratic House, where he won in June, after a speech in which he promised that the contras would clean up their act and American diplomacy would seek ''real democracy.'' Yet many Americans remain passionately opposed to the contra war, and rightly so, for the President's promises remain unrealized.

title: PSYCHO-DYNAMISTS AND OTHERS
description: A GIRL OF FORTY By Herbert Gold. 254 pp. New York: Donald I. Fine. $16.95.

title: AT YOUTH THEATER, LEARNING BY DOING
description: THE scene was a recent costume fitting for the Hartford Stage Company's Youth Theater production of ''Wonderful Town.'' The designer Chris Larsen Nelson turned to a confused teen-ager in the chorus and explained about the youth's costume.

title: THERE'S NO PLACE LIKE A PENSIONE
description: Many people in Italy prefer pensioni to hotels. They like to return to find the same faces, the same persevering rubber plants, the same well-darned antimacassar on the back of a familiar armchair - a place where the routine never varies and the candy jar is always in the same place.

title: Ruth Lewis Is a Bride
description: The marriage of Ruth Honey Lewis, the daughter of Joyce Brandt Lewis and Charles M. Lewis, both of New York, to Heath Culp, a son of Dr. Lawrence H. Culp of Menlo Park, Calif., and Dr. Claire Langston of Houston, took place yesterday in Austin, Tex. The Rev. Robert Ledbetter, a United Methodist minister, performed the ceremony in the All Faith Chapel at Camp Mabry. The bride and bridegroom are seniors at the University of Texas.

title: ON THE JOB
description: To the Editor:

title: Gomez Reaches Final In Austria Tournament
description: Andres Gomez of Ecuador defeated Emilio Sanchez of Spain, 6-4, 6-3, today to gain the final of a $150,000 Grand Prix tennis tournament.

title: THE FRENCH CELEBRATE A SUMMIT OF THEIR OWN
description: The French are marking the 200th anniversary this weekend of the first successful ascent of the ''monarch of mountains,'' as Lord Byron called Mont Blanc, the highest and most celebrated peak in Europe.

title: RESTFUL SUNDAYS
description: WHEN I was a child, Sunday was a big day in our house. My father was a minister and in those far-gone times, the father, no matter what his calling, was head of the household.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: NEW JERSEY. By Joseph Monninger. (Atheneum, $17.95.) Given the image of New Jersey in some people's minds, the title of Joseph Monninger's third novel may do the book a disservice.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Chicago;
5 Projects End Hotel Hiatus
description: FOR more than than a decade, only one new hotel was built in this city's downtown area.

title: A Baseball Man Who Is in a League All by Himself
description: STANDING just inside the gate at Beehive Stadium here last Wednesday, Joe Buzas greeted scores of fans as they entered the ball park for a game between his New Britain Red Sox and the Waterbury Indians of the Class AA Eastern League.

title: Stepping Up, Out and Down: Mattress Month
description: August is the month for mattress sales, and the nation's department stores are therefore filled with Americans displaying their sleeping postures.

title: A MESSY FIRST ROUND FOR REPUBLICANS
description: MICHIGAN Republicans cast the first ballots in their party's 1988 Presidential nomination process last week, and the results did little to alter the playing field.

title:
GARDENING;
NATIVE PLANTINGS RECLAIM THE ROADSIDES
description: ONE has but to travel the interstate highway system to fully appreciate how much gardeners have become enslaved by gardens. In the 1950's and 60's, when the superhighways were new, they were planted - landscaped, if you will - as a part of our national beautification emphasis.

title: MANY ARE CALLED, 12 ARE CHOSEN
description: ANATOMY OF A JURY The System on Trial. By Seymour Wishman. 322 pp. New York: Times Books. $17.95.

title: The Nicholson Method
description: I read with fascination Ron Rosenbaum's article ''Acting - The Creative Mind of Jack Nicholson'' (July 13). It was a delightful look into the life of one of the world's most tantalizing actors!

title: RED SOX EDGE TIGERS
description: Wade Boggs went 4 for 4 and raised his major league-leading average to .356 tonight as the Boston Red Sox beat the Detroit Tigers, 8-7, for their third straight victory.

title: HOUSE PARTIES AND BOX LUNCHES: ONE WRITER'S SUMMER AT YADDO
description: In 1900 Spencer Trask, a New York financier, and his wife, Katrina, formed the Corporation of Yaddo, a nonprofit organization the purpose of which ''is to maintain a residence and retreat for persons actually and usefully engaged in artistic and creative work.'' After their deaths, and beginning in June 1926, the Trask estate in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., known as Yaddo began to receive its first guests - writers, visual artists and composers. Since then, in the words of John Cheever, a very frequent guest, ''the 40 or so acres on which the principal buildings of Yaddo stand have seen more distinguished activity in the arts than any other piece of ground in the English-speaking community or perhaps in the entire world.'' In the following memoir, written to celebrate Yaddo's 60th year, one writer describes what Yaddo was like for her.

title: Senna Wins No. 1 Spot For Hungarian Race
description: Ayrton Senna of Brazil won the pole position today for Sunday's Hungarian Grand Prix, the first Formula One auto race to be held in a Soviet bloc country.

title: DECIDING WHEN AND WHERE TO CAMP
description: Camping is one of the least expensive and to many, one of the most appealing, ways to travel. With little more than a tent, a sleeping bag and a flashlight you can camp from Maine to California for less than $10 a night. If the rough is too rough, recreational vehicles come equipped with the luxuries some can't bear to leave at home.

title: Veronica Spencer Weds a Physician
description: The marriage of Veronica June Spencer, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Samuel J. Spencer of West Chester, Pa., to Dr. Joseph Austin Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Austin of Freeport, L.I., took place yesterday. The Rev. Dr. Harold Braxton performed the ceremony at the Shiloh Baptist Church in Wilmington, Del.

title: ONE MAN VS. EVEREST
description: THE 29,028-FOOT SUMMIT of Mt. Everest was first attained in 1953 by Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay, who reached the highest point on Earth with the aid of 10 other climbers, 30 Sherpas and several hundred low-altitude porters. Now a controversial and iconoclastic mountaineer named Roger Marshall is fixing his sights on the summit. But this week, when Marshall fills his rucksack with a tent, extra pairs of mittens and exactly three days' worth of food, he will be facing Mt. Everest alone. Marshall's attempt on the mountain - without company, without bottled oxygen or even a rope - is one of the boldest expressions yet of superalpinism, the trend among the world's elite mountain climbers to create new challenges for themselves, which in the last decade has revolutionized the sport.

title: Miss Currey Is Wed to David Chapman
description: Stephanie Hampton Currey, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Brownlee O. Curry Jr. of Nashville and Southampton, L.I., was married in Southampton yesterday to David Shields Chapman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John D. Chapman 2d of Cincinnati. The Rev. Malcolm L. Foster performed the ceremony at St. Andrew's Dune Episcopal Church.

title: IN SEARCH OF A TRUE COMMUNITY
description: HERE in New Jersey, the hottest of the home-rule hotbeds, we are fond of talking about our ''communities.''

title: SABERHAGEN TRYING TO PICK UP PIECES
description: Winning the Cy Young Award and being named Most Valuable Player in the World Series last year seems a long time ago to Bret Saberhagen of the Kansas City Royals.

title: ANALYTIC BRAINS FOR HIRE
description: THE PROBLEM SOLVERS A History of Arthur D. Little, Inc. By E. J. Kahn Jr. Illustrated. 234 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $19.95.

title: G.M. OFFERS FREE REPAIR OF FAULTY SEAT BELTS
description: The General Motors Corporation, which markets 44 percent of all the cars sold in the United States, has decided to offer free repairs of defective seat belts in its cars and trucks.

title: THE FASTER TRACK
description: THIS SUMMER, lawyers are paying extra attention to stories in legal periodicals detailing the job choices of the 34 young lawyers who have just finished one-year stints as clerks to the Justices of the United States Supreme Court. The clerks are the elite of the profession, and since almost any legal job is theirs for the asking, their career plans are widely seen as a good indication of what is hot. Usually, some of them go to the largest corporate law firms in New York, some to smaller firms in Washington and other cities, and some to fellowships or academia. But this year, three of the clerks are leaving the law altogether - one to investment banking, one to management consulting and one to a think tank.

title: STUDENTS DO BETTER ON PROFICIENCY TEST
description: THE results of the high school proficiency test, long awaited and debated since the examination was administered in April, were announced here last week by the state's Department of Education.

title:
ART;
AETNA'S ECLECTIC COLLECTION ON VIEW IN HARTFORD
description: LIKE many other American corporations, the Aetna Life Insurance Company is building an art collection. But instead of buying blue-chip pieces or commissioning celebrated artists, Aetna is filling its buildings in the Hartford area with primarily local talent and assorted decorative work.

title: SCHOOL PRIZES: WRONG EMPHASIS
description: I'M at the beach with a group of children as I write, but my thoughts keep going back to the awards assembly at the close of school in June.

title: MALTA-LIBYA RELATIONS ARE REPORTED TO COOL
description: Longtime ties between this island nation and Libya have cooled in recent months despite continued statements of support on both sides, according to Maltese officials, business officials and diplomats.

title: A RISE IN CRIME STIRS FEAR OF GUATEMALA'S NEW DEMOCRACY
description: Violent crime has sharply increased in Guatemala in recent months, and political leaders said in interviews that they feared it could threaten the country's fragile six-month-old democracy.

title: NEW COLOMBIA PRESIDENT FACING OLD PROBLEM OF GUERRILLA WARFARE
description: Four years ago, just minutes after he was sworn in as President, Belisario Betancur, in an emotional address to a huge crowd that filled the historic Plaza Bolivar, renewed his campaign pledge to end decades of internal warfare.

title: SHOREHAM LEGAL FIGHT INTENSIFIES
description: In a courtroom in Hauppauge last week, lawyers representing the Long Island Lighting Company and Suffolk County vigorously debated the legality of a $7.3 billion county plan to take over the company while a State Supreme Court justice, William R. Geiler, looked on with a bemused expression.

title: GIFTED STUDENTS DESERVE PUBLIC SUPPORT
description: ''BEGIN by drawing a picture of whatever's on your mind,'' I suggested to the fourth-grade student who had arrived early for my Gifted Creative Writing course.

title: 10 People Are Injured In Brooklyn Jail Fight
description: Six city corrections officers and four inmates received minor injuries Friday evening during a scuffle at the Brooklyn Correctional Facility, a Correction Department spokesman said.

title: FOR DAVE JOHNSON, NO LET UP
description: How much is enough?

title: ...AND PARIS PURSUES SOVIET SALES
description: TWO top French designers and a handful of European clothing manufacturers are conspiring with the Kremlin to smarten up Russia's drably dressed citizenry - and to get a crack at a huge, untapped market for fashionable clothes.

title: A SAN ANTONIO PLAN TO LIMIT SPENDING IS HANDILY DEFEATED
description: A proposal to limit city spending was easily defeated today after Mayor Henry Cisneros led a well-financed campaign against the plan.

title:
ANTIQUES;
STATELY HOME OF GOLF MEMORABILIA
description: THE 18th-century English explorer whose fate was dramatically sealed in a hostage crisis on the islands he christened in honor of his less-than-distinguished patron, John Montagu, fourth Earl of Sandwich (then influential First Lord of the Admiralty), is immortalized at the United States Golf Association Museum here as a contemplative participant in the leisurely pursuit of golf.

title: Mary Steward Mills Wed To John Francis Barrow
description: Mary Steward Mills, an editor, and John Francis Barrow, an associate, both of McKinsey & Company management consultants in Sydney, Australia, were married yesterday in Trenton.

title: Comings and Goings
description: A Yankee minor-leaguer, Brad Arnsberg, lost a no-hitter with one out in the ninth inning but finished with a two-hitter as Columbus beat Syraucse, 9-0, in an International League game. At one point, Arnsberg retired 21 consecutive batters. . . . Terry Raffensperger, 38, of Tulsa, Okla., was paralyzed from the neck down following a wreck on a wet roadway in the Lake Afton Grand Prix in Wichita, Kan. His Formula 440 roadster was struck by another car during a practice run, said George Morrison, the chief steward of the race.

title: THE SKY'S NO LIMIT IN PROGRAM THAT TRAINS INNER-CITY TEEN-AGERS
description: IT was 10 years ago that the Rev. Russell White, pastor of the Bethel Baptist Church on Wallace Street here, came upon six local youths hanging out on a street corner, apparently looking for trouble.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: FIRST IN FLIGHT?

title: PORT CHESTER RENEWAL
description: Port Chester will get the Federal money it needs to carry out a $250 million renewal of its downtown and its waterfront - but in the wake of the grant, conflict has already broken out among village officials.

title: WHEN THE SLUSH PILE COMES TO LIFE
description: We expect a lot from television; it is supposed to amuse, inform, edify and entertain.

title: 6 Problems With The Contras
description: Since leaving the United States Senate in 1981, I have not once tried to influence the judgment of my former colleagues. But I urge them now to re-examine their support for the ''contra'' war against the people and the Government of Nicaragua.

title: PACIFIC ISLE IS SENDING A 15-FOOT DRUM TO THE U.N.
description: A drum more than 15 feet tall has begun its voyage from a remote South Pacific island to East 42d Street in New York.

title: CHANGE IN TURKEY CLOUDED BY TRIALS
description: More than 1,500 Turks have been on trial before military courts since 1982, severely curtailing the defendants' civil rights and freedom to work, travel and speak freely, Western diplomats and others here say.

title: CITIES LOOKING TO AQUARIUMS AS AN ECONOMIC LURE
description: Civic leaders of this economically depressed city believe they have found just the thing to cure their ailing waterfront: sharks. They say a $30 million aquarium may help turn a 75-acre park on the Delaware River into New Jersey's biggest tourist attraction.

title: OPERA: NEW PRODUCTION OF WAGNER'S 'RING' CYCLE IN SEATTLE
description: The Seattle Opera put itself on the national musical map in 1975 when it inaugurated its annual summer cycles of Wagner's ''Ring des Nibelungen.'' No other middling-sized regional American company had assayed this operatic Everest before (few of the big companies had tried it, either), and no one had undertaken annual performances as a festival.

title: Harry J. Doyle Is Dead at 67; A Former Revlon Executive
description: Harry J. Doyle, who was a senior executive of Revlon Inc., the cosmetics company, died Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 67 years old and also lived in Wilton, Conn.

title: TOPICS
description: I WAS intrigued by Elex Ingersoll's article about her attitude toward ironing during her retirement [ ''The Pleasures, Yes, of Ironing,'' Opinion Page, July 20 ] .

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT;
LABOR TROUBLE IS BREWING
description: AS baseball's midsummer pennant races intensify in the rush toward October, news of other professional team sports begins to command attention as well. Notably, this summer stands in contrast to the past decade in which the focus has been on player gains in escalating salaries and the ability to enhance one's value through free agency in moving, or threatening to move, from one club to another.

title: ON THE STAGE OR SCREEN, CHARISMA SELLS TICKETS
description: Even before it opened at the Public Theater, ''Cuba and His Teddy Bear'' sold out its entire engagement, and continued to do extremely good business when it transferred to Broadway. The reason is simple; the star of the Reinaldo Povod play is Robert De Niro, who has demonstrated his remarkable talent and his popularity in a score of films. The fact that the play received mixed reviews does not seem to matter an iota to his admirers. They want to see Mr. De Niro act on stage (and a certain number also want to see his co-star, Ralph Macchio) - and they are not disappointed. By no means is this a star turn. Although he has not acted in the theater for many years and has never before appeared on Broadway, Mr. De Niro has an immediate, visceral presence, endowing his character, that of a New York drug dealer with strongly paternal instincts, with a dimension almost equal to that of his film roles.

title: THE THEATER HAS ITS BRIGHTER SIDE, TOO
description: To the Editor:

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL DETROIT (AL) - Placed Lance Parrish, catcher, on the 15-day disabled list, retroactive to July 30. with recurring back problems; acquired Mike Heath, catcher, from St. Louis for Ken Hill, minor-league pitcher, and a player to be named; purchased the contract of Jack Lazorko, pitcher, from Nashville of the American Association.

title: POP: FROM WILLIE COLON, PAN AMERICAN MUSIC
description: IF Lionel Richie or the Miami Sound Machine can have major pop hits with a hint of Latin flavor, then maybe one of salsa's top bandleaders, Willie Colon, can do the same. That seems to be the strategy behind the singer-trombonist's recent forays into pan-American pop, which cast him as a romantic tenor instead of an aggressive trombone soloist or an exhortatory salsa singer.

title: L.I.Man Is Given Prison Term In Beating Death of Mother
description: A prison term of 16 months to 4 years was imposed on a man who beat his mother with an iron pipe when she refused to serve him spaghetti and meatballs for Thanksgiving dinner.

title: A RARE STUDY OF BLACK IMMIGRATION
description: The exhibit on black immigrants now at the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture seems as natural to the curator as his lingering accent from Panama or the salt-and-pepper beard that frames his face.

title: LILY BIRNBAUM JAVITS
description: Lily Birnbaum Javits, an artist who started painting at the age of 65 and the senior member of a family that included Senator Jacob K. Javits, died Thursday, after a series of strokes, at the Good Samaritan Hospital in Palm Beach, Fla. She was 91 years old and lived in Manhattan and Palm Beach.

title: ARABS AND JEWS IN ISRAEL
description: But if ye will not hearken unto me, and will not do all those commandments . . . I will break the pride of your power; and I will make your heaven as iron, and your earth as brass. - Leviticus 26:14, 19.

title:
IN NEW JERSEY;
For Atlantic City's Inlet, Signs of Rebirth
description: UNTIL the 1950's, when a large number of families tired of city life fled to the suburbs, the Inlet was an exclusive neighborhood of oceanfront streets lined with grand old houses in the northeastern corner of Atlantic City.

title: DOROTHY ELDRIDGE
description: Dorothy Eldridge, director of the New Jersey chapter of SANE, an organization promoting peace, died of cardiopulmonary failure on July 30 at St. Mary's Hospital in Passaic, N.J. She was 82 years old and lived in Nutley, N.J.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: WORKING PROFILE: Marino de Medici; A Scribe at the Circus Maximus on the Potomac
description: Marino de Medici, Washington correspondent for the Italian newspaper Il Tempo, thinks he has one of the world's best beats.

title: A Near-Miss for The Columbia
description: Things could hardly have gone worse on the last, fatal flight of the Challenger. But last week the Presidential commission investigating that disaster had disquieting news about the shuttle flight preceding it. According to a staff report, on Jan. 6 the shuttle Columbia came within seconds of lifting off despite a potentially catastrophic shortage of fuel.

title: STATEMENT LEADS TO INDICTMENT IN '79 SLAYING
description: Seven years after a Queens man was bludgeoned to death, the authorities say they have solved the crime because of statements a state psychiatric patient made to a psychiatrist.

title: UPDATING THE CARRIAGE TRADE
description: UTILITARIAN BUILDINGS that were considered common, nondescript structures earlier in this century - barns or carriage houses or chicken coops, say -have an appeal today for some people that far surpasses the conventional home. Tucked away on parcels of land that were once part of large estates or farms, these forthright buildings are sought after by those passionate souls who are tenacious enough to undertake the renovation of quirky places.

title: MUSIC IN THE SOUTH PACIFIC, ART FROM THE RENAISSANCE
description: FAR EAST TOUR FEATURES SONG AND DANCE

title: IN NORFOLK, THE END OF A MEDICAL ERA
description: A 50-YEAR medical practice has ended in Norfolk, and there is nobody to start a new one.

title: SHE FOUND A HOME AND LEFT IT
description: FREEDOM AT A PRICE An Englishwoman's Life in Czechoslovakia. By Rosemary Kavan. Introduction by William Shawcross. Epilogue by Jan Kavan. Illustrated. 278 pp. New York: Verso/Schocken Books. $13.50.

title: Credit Limits
description: To the Editor:

title: WE WENT TO EUROPE ANYWAY
description: WE are the only ones among our friends who travel not to cancel plans for a vacation in Europe this summer. In every case, as it almost was in ours, fear of terrorism was the motivating factor, with fallout from Chernobyl hovering in second place.

title: YANKS WIN, 3-2, ON HOMER IN 9th
description: Brian Fisher was in the dugout, putting on his warmup jacket, standing with his back to the field. He knew Dan Pasqua was batting and he said to no one in particular, ''Hit one out now.'' Fisher still was facing into the dugout when Pasqua swung. ''I heard it,'' the pitcher said. ''It sounded awesome. You can tell when the ball is crushed.''

title: INDIA SECURITY CRIMPS STYLE OF POLITICIANS
description: The turmoil in the Punjab has had a ripple effect that has changed the way of life for many politicians in this capital.

title: Real Issue In Football Trial
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: NIGHTS. By H. D. (New Directions, Paper, $19.95.) 1986 is the centennial of the birth of H. D., a poet who is still - after two major biographies and a slew of critical studies - too often known only as the author of her early, Imagist poems and the friend of Ezra Pound.

title: NEW & NOTEWORTHY
description: GREASY LAKE: And Other Stories, by T. Coraghessan Boyle. (Penguin, $6.95.) The heroes in T. Coraghessan Boyle's second collection of tales include suburban teen-agers, an aging Mexican ballplayer, a senile old man, a Depression-era blues singer and a Presidential candidate who promises to replace the moon. Larry McCaffery said here last year that even the most realistic stories seem bizarre, but he added that ''Mr. Boyle's perception of what is happening in contemporary America seems remarkably sure and accurate.'' THE MERCHANT OF PRATO: Francesco di Marco Datini, 1335-1410, by Iris Origo. (Nonpareil/Godine, $14.95.) Francesco di Marco Datini was not only a pros-perous and important 14th-century Italian merchant-banker, but also a prodigious writer. When he died in 1410, he left behind hundreds of thousands of documents, personal and professional. He was ''an interesting man who lived in a fascinating age,'' Sidney Painter said in The Book Review in 1957, and Iris Origo's biography, based on this mine of documents, ''is both a scholarly monograph . . . and a literary work of art.'' Her characters, he said, ''live and breathe, hate, love and believe.''

title: CRIME
description: Margaret Truman has given us murder in the White House, on Capitol Hill, in the Supreme Court, in the Smithsonian, on Embassy Row and at the F.B.I. Now we have MURDER IN GEORGETOWN (Arbor House, $16.95), all about the murder of a senator's daughter.

title: Orphan Drugs
description: To the Editor:

title: 'A Cast of Killers'
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MILITARY MIND
description: Arthur Hadley's article might go one step further -to consider the preparatory education at the service academies.

title: Belated Credit
description: It was 50 years ago Friday that Kee-Chung Sohn, a 24-year-old Korean runner, blew past the defending champion, Juan Carlos Zabala of Spain, at mile 24. Sohn went on to win the marathon at the Berlin Olympics by a margin of 2 minutes.

title: Recent Sales
description: Avenel $103,000 521 Jansen Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 2-year-old, 2-story mother-daughter; living room with fireplace, deck, basement apartment; taxes $963.

title: SCARSDALE SUMMER MUSIC THEATER GIVES YOUTHS PROFESSIONAL POLISH
description: JIM PITOFSKY is struggling. When Erika Lipsky puts her arms around him, he must look as though he wants to get away from her - but not completely. Acting flustered, he waves his arms and sways on his feet, trying to convey the nuances his director has asked for.

title: 3,500 Protesters March At the Berlin Wall
description: About 3,500 demonstrators marched through the city center today to protest the Berlin wall, and the United States Ambassador to West Germany, Richard Burt, predicted the barrier would someday be ''one of history's bad memories.''

title: Linda Phillips Is Wed to Phillip Ratner
description: Linda Phillips, public relations director of Sotheby's International Realty in New York, was married yesterday to Phillip Ratner, an associate professor of mathematics and computer science at Dowling College. First Selectman Ann Mandel of Darien, Conn., performed the ceremony at the bride's home in Darien.

title: MOFFETT SEES SIGNS OF DISAFFECTION
description: TOBY MOFFETT says that he is firm in his decision to support the ticket headed by Governor O'Neill, a fellow Democrat, but that it may be difficult to get Moffett supporters to go along. In fact, he said he thought some of his supporters would vote for Julie D. Belaga, if she gained the Republican nomination.

title: THE LIBERAL TECHNOCRAT QUAGMIRE FACTORY
description: INTERVENTION How America Became Involved in Vietnam. By George McT. Kahin. 550 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $24.95.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, AUGUST 10, 1986
description: International An overhaul of Soviet diplomacy has been carried out under Mikhail S. Gorbachev, giving foreign policy-making a more pragmatic bent, according to Western diplomats and Soviet officials. The framing of major decisions, which Andrei A. Gromyko had largely appropriated to the Foreign Ministry in the past, has been shifted to the Communist Party's Central Committee, with Anatoly F. Dobrynin, the former Ambassador in Washington, in a key role. [ Page 1, Column 3. ] Efforts to heal a rift in the P.L.O. have made some progress, according to three factions of the Palestine Liberation Organization that recently held a meeting in Moscow. The assessments were made public in Beirut after the meeting. The Kremlin is said to have been pressing the P.L.O. to close ranks in preparation for a possible Middle East peace conference, in which the Russians would like to take part. [ 8:1. ] National The Senate moved toward approval of a scaled-down $295 billion military programs bill that makes a major reduction in President Reagan's antimissile research program. The Senate was forced into a rare Saturday session because of the push to complete major legislation before the scheduled start of the three-week summer recess Aug. 15. In a separate matter, Republican and Democratic leaders came to a procedural agreement to allow votes on both sanctions against South Africa and military to Nicaraguan rebels. [ 1:6. ] President Reagan underwent a two-hour urological examination at the Bethesda Naval Medical Center and declared afterward, ''Everything's normal, everything's fine.''

title:
ARITHMETIC OF THE NICARAGUAN RESISTANCE;
Aiding Them Could Serve 2 Purposes
description: President Reagan's proposal to give aid to the Nicaraguan democratic resistance, which comes up for renewed debate in the Senate next week, deserves approval. But the aid will be wasted unless we also develop a comprehensive program to insure that the democratic revolution is not once again hijacked by totalitarian forces, as happened in 1979 when the Sandinistas seized power.

title: VALENZUELA MASTERLY AMID DODGER MISHAPS
description: ON the surface, it appeared to be business as usual.
