title: LABOR DEPARTMENT DIPLOMAT: WILLIAM BROCK 3d; Walking a Tightrope Between Business and the Unions
description: WHEN Bill Brock was named Secretary of Labor last year, there was much talk of his becoming a pro-labor voice in an Administration viewed as hostile to labor's interests.

title: Michelle Fahey to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Fahey of Rye, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Mary Michelle Fahey to William Eliot Ganon, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Ganon of Pompton Plains, N.J. Miss Fahey, known as Michelle, graduated from Skidmore College and is an account executive with the J. Walter Thompson Company in New York. Her fiance, a sales representative for Newsweek magazine, graduated from Muskingum College. An October wedding is planned.

title: LIVES OF THE POET
description: ARCHIBALD MACLEISH Reflections. Edited by Bernard A. Drabeck and Helen E. Ellis. Foreword by Richard Wilbur. Illustrated. 291 pp. Amherst, Mass.: The University of Massachusetts Press. $19.95.

title: Just a Fancy Form of Protectionism
description: THE recent semiconductor pact with Japan is the latest step in an accelerating retreat by the United States from its commitment to the principle of free trade. At this rate, within a few years virtually the whole of our trade will be ''managed'' under agreements that set limits on trade flows and market shares. A naive observer, who believed that governments mostly act in their own national interest, might think that there was at least a reasonable case for this change in policy. Unfortunately, there is nothing good to be said about the drift to managed trade. Managed trade is bad economics and an invitation to political abuse.

title: 50 YEARS LATER, BITTER MEMORIES OF THE BERLIN GAMES
description: WHILE others marched, Marty Glickman, Sam Stoller and 381 other American athletes sauntered into Berlin's Olympic Stadium on Aug. 1, 1936, in the parade of nations opening the Games of the XIth Olympiad. For Glickman, Stoller and all the athletes, the Olympics proved that the practice time and the games of youth were worthwhile, a chance to meet and maybe beat the world's best.

title: THE REAL REWARDS OF RUNNING: A SENSE OF DIRECTION AND BELONGING
description: I RAN red lights, knowing full well that police cars lurked around the corner. I littered the streets with impunity, talked to strangers and even accepted sweets from them.

title: SURGEON'S MISSION TO THE PHILLIPINES
description: ''I THINK we made 18 plane hops altogether,'' said Dr. Robert W. Bernard, a Westchester plastic surgeon, recalling his journey last January, half way around the world to remote areas of the Philippines, where he and colleagues from throughout the United States performed cleft lip and palate surgery on poor children.

title: Kirsten M. Dahl Becomes a Bride
description: At the Old Narragansett Church in Wickford, R.I., yesterday Kirsten Maria Dahl, the daughter of Verna Dahl Wallace of Newington, Conn., and the late Magnus Gottfried Dahl, was married to Timothy Collins Jr., a son of Elizabeth Boyle of Littleton, Colo., and Mr. Collins of Reno. Canon John Hall performed the Episcopal ceremony.

title: TECH CENTER: SATELLITE CLASSES
description: THE concept of spreading the benefits of the best of higher education by beaming advanced-degree courses from lecture halls by satellite to learning sites anywhere in the country will become a reality later this month at the Federal Aviation Administration's Technical Center here.

title: Headliners; A Debt Repaid
description: Preston Robert Tisch, who became a multi-millionaire running a family business that includes Loews hotels and theaters, Bulova watches and Lorillard tobacco, seems to figure he owes somebody something. And what better way to reduce the debt than by keeping the mail on time? Upon his selection last week as the 68th Postmaster General, Mr. Tisch said he cherished ''the opportunity to repay some of what this country has afforded us.''

title: Irradiated Food
description: To the Editor:

title: Uncertainty Over Occupied Units
description: THE uncertainties surrounding proposed Federal income tax reforms have substantially reduced sales of occupied apartments to investors over the past few months. But brokers and sponsors say conversions of existing rental buildings under noneviction plans are likely to continue because tenants still want to buy their own apartments.

title: OPEC PACT WILL RAISE OIL PRICES, IF IT REALLY STICKS
description: AN agreement to reduce crude oil production, signed by OPEC ministers in Geneva last week, sent a flickering ray of hope to oil men from Oklahoma to Oman.

title: TRACKING RENTS ON THE KEYBOARD
description: AS THE personal computing software market grows and matures, the trend toward specialization becomes increasingly evident. This evolution reveals a two-pronged pattern. On the one hand, we see programs singular in their orientation being released as add-ons or templates for specific general-purpose software packages such as data base managers or spreadsheets. On the other hand, we find counterparts conceived as stand-alones being published to deal exclusively with specific sets of problems.

title: PETER SELLARS, DIRECTOR OF THEATER IN KENNEDY CENTER, TAKES A LEAVE
description: Peter Sellars, the precocious 28-year-old director of the American National Theater at the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington since 1984, will begin a year's leave this month, Roger L. Stevens, the chairman of the Kennedy Center, said yesterday.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''I do believe firmly that we would have had sheer chaos in international trade if this bill had become law.'' - Clayton K. Yeutter, special trade representative, on the bill limiting textile imports.

title: Harness Racing Gets Support
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: THE HOMELESS BECOME A PRESENCE IN TEXAS
description: JERRY COLLINS has big plans. Mr. Collins is the director of the Star of Hope Women's Shelter, one of the few facilities here where homeless families can find a place to stay. And he thinks his organization can eventually run as many as 10 or 12 such shelters throughout Houston.

title: Suzette Faux Weds B. E. Bensinger 3d
description: Marie Suzette Smith Faux, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Byron Smith of Lake Forest, Ill., and Hobe Sound, Fla., was married yesterday to B. Edward Bensinger 3d, a son of Mrs. Bensinger of Chicago and Montego Bay, Jamaica, and the late Mr. Bensinger. The Rev. Leslie Thomas performed the Presbyterian ceremony at the Bethel Church in Hopewell, Jamaica.

title: SOVIET DISSIDENTS NOW WORK ALONE
description: THE Soviet human rights movement, battered by a decade of Government crackdowns, has turned increasingly inward, each man focused on his own case, few interested in the common improvement of human rights.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: BEYOND THE FAIRNESS DOCTRINE;
A New War on Corporate 'Propaganda'
description: SINCE 1980, when the Reagan Administration all but ceased enforcing the Fairness Doctrine, advocacy advertising on television by corporations and private organizations has exploded. By my conservative estimate, these interests spent $1.8 billion in 1985 to communicate their ideas on various public policy issues. That figure is rising by 10 to 15 percent a year.

title: Metro-North Riders Delayed Because of Signal-Box Blaze
description: A signal-box fire under Park Avenue halted Metro-North Commuter Railroad service for nearly an hour last night, delaying suburban theatergoers and other travelers into and out of Grand Central Terminal.

title: FANCY-LEAVED FERNS WILL ADD TEXTURE AND FORM TO THE GARDEN
description: A few hours spent with John T. Mickel will convince anyone that ''ferns are ferntastic.'' This sign appears on his office door on the upper floors of the headquarters building at the New York Botanical Garden, but Dr. Mickel is often heard to say it. Although he takes no credit for the phrase's origin (it belongs to the New York Chapter of the American Fern Society), it is a truism that ''ferntastic ferns'' drive this expert.

title: 2 DEMOCRATS GAIN IN GEORGIA DRIVE
description: When Wyche Fowler Jr. and Hamilton Jordan emerged as the leading contenders for the Senate seat held by Mack Mattingly, Republican of Georgia, a lot of Georgia Democrats were not hopeful about November.

title: David Citarelli Is Wed To Glynis M. Pussilano
description: Glynis Maury Pussilano, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James T. Pussilano of Allendale, N.J., was married yesterday to David James Citarelli, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent J. Citarelli of Wayne and Lavalette, N.J. Msgr. Edward Kavin performed the ceremony at St. Gabriel the Archangel Roman Catholic Church in Saddle River, N.J. He was assisted by the Rev. Noel McSweeney, a cousin of the bride.

title: EX-HOUSING CHIEF IS TARGET OF INQUIRY
description: A Federal grand jury is looking into allegations that John Simon, while he was the chief executive of the city's Housing Authority, leaked confidential information to the head of a tenants group, warning him about an undercover corruption investigation, according to law-enforcement officials.

title:
WHAT'S DOING IN THE;
TWIN CITIES
description: Twins they are not and never really were, though visitors often think the similarities between Minnesota's green and livable Twin Cities, Minneapolis and St. Paul, outweigh their differences.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN POLICE BREAK UP FUNERAL
description: The police used tear gas today to disperse a crowd of about 2,000 mourners at a funeral in Johannesburg's black township of Soweto, and authorities evicted families who have refused to pay rent in two townships south of the city, officials said.

title: PLANNING FOR HOUSING IN STAMFORD
description: On the Opinion page of July 20 there appeared a provocative commentary on the growing cost of housing in lower Fairfield County [ ''When Price Decides Who Lives Where'' ] . Authored by Susan J. Hutchinson, a former First Selectman of Weston and now a Housing Advocate for the Fairfield County Home Builders Association, it encourages communities to recognize that ''the builder is our community planning partner'' and that through improved dialogue, a variety of creative housing policies and regulations might be considered and adopted, thus encouraging an increase in the housing supply.

title: TERRORISM AND TRAVEL IS STUDY AT COLLEGE
description: ANNE PHILIPPON said that the fear of terrorism in Europe was why her East Hartford travel business has not done too well this year.

title: Susan Bauer Engaged
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Bauer of White Plains of the engagement of their daughter, Susan Marie Bauer, to Mark Loomis Peterson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Tom Loomis Peterson of Lexington, Mass. Miss Bauer, who is with the International Business Machines Corporation in White Plains, graduated from the Putney School and attended the New School for Social Research. Her fiance, a video consultant with I.B.M. in Thornwood, N.Y., graduated from the Loomis Chaffee School and New York University.

title: Airport Chapels To Be Retained
description: A YEAR ago, when the Port Authority drew up ''JFK 2000,'' an expansion plan for Kennedy International Airport, something was missing. Tri-Faith Chapel Plaza, which for 20 years has been the home of the airport's Protestant, Catholic and Jewish houses of worship, was to be demolished to make way for a new passenger complex.

title: MUSICAL PATH TO A GUGGENHEIM
description: WHEN Michelle Ekizian recalls her days at the Quaker Ridge Grammar School in Scarsdale, she remembers in particular a student in her second- or third-grade class.

title: THE WELCOME MAT, A BIT ASKEW
description: THEORETICALLY, I like the idea of houseguests. In articles about the Hamptons, they always arrive late Friday afternoon in their own car. They bring several bottles of good wine, a two-pound porterhouse steak or an assortment of imported cheeses.

title: Adios Pace Winner Sets World Record
description: Barberry Spur, the winner of the Cane Pace, captured the $233,450 Adios Pace today, setting a world record for two heats by 3-year-old pacers on a five-eighths-mile track.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Philadelphia dispatch on Aug. 3 about a neighborhood dispute over street signs in Korean misidentified a speaker at a community meeting. She was Natalie K. Levant.

title: JETS' OFFENSE SPUTTERS IN ROUT BY PACKERS
description: From the moment Bobby Humphery bobbled the opening kickoff, this was not the Jets' day to flex their muscles in a college town that had never been the host to a pro game.

title: BROOKLYN PASTOR WITH A VIVID PAST
description: NEXT year will mark the hundredth anniversary of the death of Henry Ward Beecher, the colorful clergyman and orator who rose to prominence as pastor of Brooklyn's Plymouth Congregational Church. Widely regarded as America's most important 19th-century clergyman, Beecher became famous in the Civil War era as the country's first activist preacher. While embracing a wide-ranging social agenda that included temperance, women's suffrage and public education, he achieved his greatest renown as an outspoken opponent of slavery.

title: POSTINGS: Mitchell-Lamas; Going Private
description: Over the last few years, residents of the state's 269 Mitchell-Lama projects have been concerned and confused by the efforts by some developers and tenants to remove their projects from the middle-income housing program and convert them into private, market-rate rentals or cooperatives. The program, now three decades old, has led to the construction of 111,000 apartments.

title: IS THE PRICE FOR GLORY TOO HIGH?
description: Should one accommodate oneself to each opponent?

title: LABOR'S HOLDING ITS OWN, AT LEAST IN PUBLIC SECTOR
description: THIS summer, as strikes by municipal workers in Philadelphia and Detroit disrupted those cities and drew attention from the rest of the nation, what went unnoticed was that these were the first major public employees' walkouts in years.

title: PIPELINE PLAN TAKES SHAPE AND BUFFETING
description: AS PLANS for a $360 million gas pipeline through western Connecticut grow firmer, so too does the opposition of many local residents.

title: OBSESSED BY AMBITION, SAVED BY ART
description: VELAZQUEZ Painter and Courtier. By Jonathan Brown. Illustrated. 322 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $45.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: PASAQUINA. By Erin O'Shaughnessy. (Saybrook/ Norton, $16.95.) This is a book about a village - the remote mountain village of Pasaquina, El Salvador.

title: THEATER OF IMAGES DISCOVERS THE WORD
description: Avant-garde directors working in the discipline known as the theater of images, or mixed-media, made an important discovery this past season. They discovered the playwright.

title: CATCHING TUNA FOR BOTH SPORT AND PROFIT
description: THERE may not be any place to order fresh sushi or sashimi at the fishing docks in Montauk, but much of the midsummer action there concerns itself with these Japanese delicacies.

title: Art
description: One of the major events of the high summer season is the retrospective exhibition of sculptures by John Chamberlain that opened 10 days ago at the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles and can be seen there through Oct. 5. Chamberlain has a loose general reputation as a man who makes sculpture out of crushed automobiles, and for that reason he is often thought of as someone who uses the apparatus of obsolescence to disreputable macho ends.

title: Alaskan Yukon
description: To the Editor:

title: AN OLD STATION ON THE RIGHT TRACK
description: THE Station in Water Mill is a stunner. The former railroad station, which had been used as a boutique and a thrift shop for a number of years, was recycled as a handsome restaurant last year.

title: STATE AID TO ARTS INCREASES
description: THE State Council on the Arts has awarded $10,269,304 -the largest total in its 20-year history - to artists and cultural organizations for fiscal 1987.

title: Q and A
description: Symbols of the Past Question: The Sunset Apartments, on the northeast corner of 85th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, is being converted into a co-op. When inspecting the building I noticed that there are two Jewish stars above the front door. What can you tell me about this building and why the design is there? . . . A. M., Pine Brook, N.J. Answer: Christopher Gray, an architectural historian who heads the Office of Metropolitan History, said the orange brick-and-stone tenement done in a neo-Roman style was built in 1889. It was designed by John G. Prague, a fairly well-known architect and builder of the period who designed and developed other properties on the Upper West Side in partnership with others. In addition to the Sunset Apartments, Mr. Prague developed the residences on the rest of the block between 85th and 86th Streets on Amsterdam Avenue.

title: U.S.F.L. Decides To Hang It Up For the Season
description: Six days after the United States Football League was awarded only $3 of the $1.69 billion it had sought in an antitrust suit against the National Football League, it said, in effect, ''wait'll next year.'' But there were many doubters, especially after the upstart league gave its 530 players permission to pursue careers in the N.F.L. or the Canadian Football League.

title: THE 'ISLAMIZATION' OF PAKISTAN: STILL MOVING SLOWLY AND STILL STIRRING DEBATE
description: Nine years after Pakistan started to make its laws conform with the teachings of Islam, religious and political leaders agree that the changes in the country have been largely marginal or cosmetic.

title: Schroeder, Longest User of Jarvik Device, Helped Prove Hearts Can Be Replaced
description: The ordeal of William J. Schroeder cannot be overstated. He suffered greatly. But he and Dr. Barney B. Clark, the first two recipients of permanent artificial hearts, and the others who have followed will stand out as heroes of medical science.

title: 300 YEARS OLD AND NEVER OUT OF STYLE
description: THE PANAMA HAT TRAIL A Journey From South America. By Tom Miller. 271 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $15.95.

title: STATE LEADS IN MOVE FOR NUCLEAR DISARMAMENT
description: NEW JERSEY is speaking loudest among the 50 states in support of nuclear disarmament. Last week, leaders of a nuclear disarmament coalition presented Governor Kean with copies of resolutions adopted by 42 municipalities and four counties that urge President Reagan to respond immediately to the Soviet Union's unilateral moratorium on nuclear weapons testing by joining with that country in a verifiable suspension of testing.

title: SOLUTIONS FOR PROBLEMS THAT OFTEN ARISE AROUND THE HOUSE
description: IN an effort to catch up on the backlog of mail received here, this week the entire Home Clinic column is devoted to questions from readers about some frequently encountered problems that homeowners face.

title: PEDESTRIAN MALL IN FREEPORT WILL REVERT TO A STREET
description: Freeport is taking a step backward in time to try to lure shoppers back to the shops that are now part of the Freeport Mall on South Main Street.

title: Lessons Of Midlife Dating
description: Noel Perrin seems not to have learned the simplest lesson of middle-age dating, which is that the ''glue'' is still there (''Middle Age Dating,'' About Men, July 6). That first meeting of minds -through a shared joke, simultaneous thought, new idea, common interest - can be as exciting as the initial sexual attraction used to be.

title: CABLE TV UNAVAILABLE TO THOUSANDS IN MANHATTAN
description: Cable television service is unavailable to more than 3,200 Manhattan households that have requested it, many of them in SoHo, TriBeCa and Harlem, according to a report by the borough's two cable franchises. The companies are telling city officials that it would be impractical to provide service to many of these residents.

title: SENATE COMMITTEE APPROVES AID FOR CONTRAS
description: The Senate Appropriations Committee voted, 15 to 14, last week to approve President Reagan's $100 million aid package for the Nicaraguan rebels. Opponents have threatened a filibuster, but both sides predicted that the plan will win final approval.

title: Two Forecasts On the Deficit
description: Congress will not know for sure until Friday, when its budget office and the President's announce their final calculations, whether or by how much spending will have to be reduced or taxes raised to bring the Federal deficit within the limits set by the budget-balancing law.

title: NEW RULES CONSIDERED IN WAR ON OZONE POLLUTION
description: From Richmond, Va., to Portland, Me., the war against ozone is being lost across the broad arc of the Northeast megalopolis, and Federal officials are considering adding regulations on everything from the stripes that divide highway lanes to the smell of fresh-baked bread.

title: THE WOMAN WHO RULED THE HAREM
description: VALIDE By Barbara Chase-Riboud. 429 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $17.95.

title:
FOCUS: Pittsburgh;
New Glow For Golden Triangle
description: FOR decades, the dominant players in the downtown real estate market here have been home-grown companies that grew up to become multinational corporations. From the Point at its tip to Grant Street at its base, grand monuments to steel, aluminum, glass and finance adorn the skyline of the Golden Triangle.

title: Patchwork Indians Enjoying Role in Pennant Race
description: Think of that: ''This is August and we're under two digits in games behind.'' Last week was not one of the season's best for the Cleveland Indians. They watched the Yankees score 10 runs in one inning against them and then they lost a pair of doubleheaders to the Detroit Tigers. But they still have not reached double digits, as Joe Carter noted, in the games-behind column of the American League East standing.

title: Court Fines LaRouche $2,000 For Not Answering Questions
description: Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr., the political extremist, has been fined $2,000 in Federal District Court for failing to answer questions from NBC about his personal finances.

title: HONG KONG'S TEMPLE OF NOURISHMENT
description: Walking under the pillared granite arches, the pai lau, of the Taoist temple of Ching Chung Koon in Hong Kong, is almost disquieting. There is an immediate sense that you have been drawn back in time to an earlier China, to a place where tradition is revered and symbolism governs. One of the rites practiced by worshipers in the temple is to eat a meal consising solely of vegetables, food that Taoists believe contributes to the proper balance of the spirit. Visitors can also enjoy these repasts, and 10-course banquets, in the temple's restaurant. The largest of Hong Kong's Taoist enclaves, Ching Chung Koon is also renowned for its miniature trees and plants and its porcelain.

title: COMMUTING BY HELICOPTER
description: MICHAEL MORTARA, an investment banker, used to rise before dawn to drive from his home in Litchfield to his desk in Manhattan. He would stay in New York during the week, seldom traveling home. But Mr. Mortara can be found in Litchfield much more often these days, since he joined the growing ranks of business people who commute by helicopter.

title: INNER-CITY STUDENTS TO STUDY SEA LIFE
description: TWENTY students from Essex County vocational schools were to start a two-week learning adventure this morning, heading by bus for the New Jersey Marine Sciences Consortium's field station in Seaville, Cape May County.

title: ZAHRINGER TO MEET HOUSEN IN FINAL
description: With three successive birdies in the home stretch, George Zahringer 3d, the defending champion, came from behind today to beat John Baldwin, 1 up, in a semifinal of the 84th Amateur Championship of the Metropolitan Golf Association.

title: JURY ACQUITS 6 AND FINDS 3 GUILTY OF PLOTTING TO FREE INMATE
description: A jury in Madison County Superior Court today acquitted six of nine defendants accused of conspiring to storm a courtroom to free an inmate at the Indiana Reformatory on trial for manslaughter.

title: R. D. Truesdell Jr. Wed To Dawn Della Vecchia
description: At St. Mark's Roman Catholic Church in Jamestown, R.I., yesterday Dawn Marie Della Vecchia, a daughter of Louis B. Della Vecchia of Jamestown and the late Jeanne L. Della Vecchia, was married to Richard David Truesdell Jr., the son of Mr. Truesdell of East Falmouth, Mass., and Elizabeth V. Truesdell of Belmont, Mass. The Rev. William O'Neill performed the ceremony.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: The State Supreme Court's decision upholding Ocean City's Sunday closing ordinance may be appealed to the Federal courts one day, but Boardwalk merchants say the ruling already is causing substantial economic losses.

title: It's East-West Business As Usual Despite Defectors
description: The Soviet Union said last week that it had granted asylum to a former employee of the Central Intelligence Agency, Edward L. Howard, who was suspected of selling secrets to the Russians when he disappeared last September. The Soviet statement said Mr. Howard had sought asylum because of the need ''to hide from the U.S. secret services, which were persecuting him.''

title: Music
description: This is a strong week for Mostly Mozart. In addition to the original instruments concert Monday night (see the feature on Emma Kirkby in the Arts and Leisure section), there will be two performances of this year's major operatic effort, ''La Finta Giardiniera,'' Thursday and Saturday evening. This comic opera is a product of Mozart's 18th year, and has rarely been done in America or anywhere.

title: SUN, SAND AND SINGLES: THEY MEET AT THE BEACH
description: FOR single people, the beach has always been more than a place to get a tan. From Brighton Beach in the 1950's to Asparagus Beach in the 1970's, the beach has also served as a release from the stress of daily drudgery or the pressures of upward mobility in the workplace and in society.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE SWORD & THE MIND. Translated by Hiroaki Sato. (Overlook Press, $16.95.) Worthy samurai in 17th-century Japan were the original intended readers of this philosophically rich discourse.

title: Economic Blues
description: To the Editor:

title: JEAN ARP - A PIONEER WORTHY OF HONOR
description: As to what will be made of the now-imminent centenary of the birth of Jean Arp - sculptor, poet, maker of reliefs, collagist and for many years a discreet but animating force in the development of 20th-century art - the news has yet to come in. Fireworks crafted with Arp-like fancy may soar above the cathedral of his native Strasbourg. White wine from the Valais may spout from the fountains of Zurich, in which he spent some of his most creative years. In Meudon, not far from Paris, the birds, the butterflies and the hares for which he felt a watchful tenderness may flock to the garden of the house that he maintained for 40 years. Or, the world being what it is, and Arp having been the least pushy of men, there may be nothing much of anything. Either way, Sept. 16, 1886, is a date worth remembering.

title: REAGAN UNDERGOES URINARY TESTS AND REPORTS, 'EVERYTHING'S FINE'
description: President Reagan underwent a two-hour urological examination at the Bethesda Naval Medical Center today and declared afterward, ''Everything's normal, everything's fine.''

title: Lazar Is Indicted, McGinley Cleared In City Scandal
description: Alex Liberman, a former director of leasing for New York City, started a 12-year jail sentence in November 1984 after pleading guilty to charges that he had extracted almost $1.2 million in bribes from landlords seeking to rent space to city agencies. Last week it appeared that he might have cooperated with prosecutors in return for a promise of early release.

title: MEASURE SEEKS PUBLIC-PRIVATE AID FOR HOME CARE OF ELDERLY
description: ABOUT 16,000 frail, elderly New Jerseyans who are too poor to pay for home health services but not poor enough to qualify for public assistance could receive needed care under a bill considered last week by the State Senate's Committee on Aging.

title: ATLANTIC CITY RAIL LINK WORK BEGINS
description: The newest attraction in this waterfront city of casinos and beaches is a bright orange machine that is longer than a football field and looks like a praying mantis.

title: Catching Up
description: * As the first woman to play basketball in a men's professional league, Nancy Lieberman is not posting impressive statistics or proving a box-office bonanza. But she is earning the admiration of her coach, Henry Bibby.

title: FAMILIES, DELAYED 5 YEARS, MOVE INTO BRONX HOMES
description: Nineteen families who have waited five years for the completion of a development project in the South Bronx moved into their houses yesterday - even though there were no toilets, electricity or appliances.

title: Bomb in West Germany Destroys a U.S. Car
description: A ''small and simple'' homemade bomb destroyed a civilian car belonging to a member of the United States military, the police said Sunday.

title: State Stiffens Its Laws On Official Corruption
description: Stiffer prison terms await corrupt public officials and those who try to bribe officials under the terms of legislation signed by Governor Cuomo.

title: JAPAN PHONE COMPETITION STIRS
description: Officially, Japan's century-old telecommunications monopoly ended in April 1985, when a law opening the market to competition went into effect. Practically, however, the monopoly ended just a few days ago, when the first of many would-be competitors cut a ribbon, flipped a switch and began offering its customers telecommunication services at rates from 20 to 25 percent lower than Nippon Telegraph and Telephone.

title: Loyalty and Then Some
description: The Ripon Society has prided itself over the years on being younger, more academic-oriented and more progressive in philosophy than the rest of the Republican Party, but it has nevertheless remained resolutely inside that party. Just now, with the Democrats trying to regain in November the Senate majority they lost six years ago, the society is proclaiming and demonstrating its supervening loyalty to the G.O.P.

title: CONFEREES TO STEP UP TAX EFFORT
description: After four weeks of reviewing and refining their positions, the House and Senate negotiators on tax revision legislation plan to sit down together this week to try to write a final bill that could affect the finances of nearly every person and company in America.

title: Schering-Plough Sues Competitor Over Claim
description: Schering-Plough is suing the Noxell Corporation and its advertising agency, SSC&B: Lintas Worldwide, a division of the Interpublic Group, accusing them of false advertising.

title: Jerusalem Book Fair Plans Spring Seminar
description: The Jerusalem International Book Fair and the Aspen Institute for Humanistic Studies will sponsor a seminar next spring on ''The Future for Publishing Across Language Frontiers,'' Teddy Kollek, Mayor of Jerusalem, has announced.

title: Grand Central Clock Gets a Makeover
description: The face the 13 1/2-foot illuminated clock in Grand Central Terminal has changed again, getting its sixth -and perhaps final - sponsor in more than two decades of conspicuous timetelling.

title: IMPEACHMENT MAY FOCUS ON INTRIGUE
description: When the impeachment trial of Federal District Judge Harry E. Claiborne opens, probably in September, the Senate will be urged to hear a story of intrigue, colliding ambitions and struggles for power involving many leading Nevadans.

title: CITY TEAM WINS BASKETBALL GOLD
description: New York City, led by 20 points from, Derrick Chievous, defeated the Western regional team, 97-94, today to win its sixth consecutive basketball gold medal during the final day of competition at the Empire State Games.

title: ON CITY'S PLAYGROUNDS, BOTH JOY AND DANGER
description: There is wide disparity in the conditions of New York City's 852 playgrounds, a citywide survey by The New York Times has found. While many are clean, leafy places of joy, excitement and safety, others are filthy, ugly places of boredom, danger and fear.

title: CITY STUDIES OVERHAUL OF CABDRIVER LICENSING
description: The chairman of the city's Taxi and and Limousine Commission said yesterday that the commission was considering sweeping changes in the licensing of drivers of medallion cabs, including a tiered system that would provide rewards for career drivers.

title: ANDREWS TRIES TO REBUILD HIS CAREER
description: IT was early in the preseason game between the Giants and the Falcons in Atlanta last Wednesday. Lawrence Taylor, the Giants'

title: What It Takes to Be America's Chief Justice; Belated Disclosures
description: To the Editor:

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: AFRICA OF THE HEART. By Joseph Hone. 287 pages. William Morrow. $16.95. TO Joseph Hone's father and godfather, Africa represented what the American West represented to the early pioneers: it was a new frontier, a place of possibilities, a colonial escape-hatch where they might leave behind their dreary lives in England and begin glorious new lives in the sun. They spoke of hunting fabulous wild game there, of starting a farm in some secluded Happy Valley, of leading dangerous expeditions into the continent's interior.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The pictures now have to be seen, and let the imagination run free.'' -Andrew Wyeth. [ C14:4. ]

title: Cornman Adds a 3d Baruch
description: Exclusive Partner held off I'm a Banker and then survived a foul claim to win the Bernard Baruch Handicap today at Saratoga and give his owner, Paul Cornman, a third consecutive victory in the race.

title: CITY RETAILERS POST SALES GAIN
description: Five of New York's large retailers had an average sales gain of 8.2 percent in July over the year-earlier month, while their overall sales in the metropolitan area were up 6.7 percent, according to a monthly spot-check.

title: LTV's Creditors Organizing
description: When the LTV Corporation announced the largest bankruptcy filing in the nation's history, analysts and lawyers predicted a protracted process for settling the company's more than $4 billion debt with more than 20,000 creditors.

title: Market Place; Why Wall St. Likes Oil Rise
description: IF the stock market has been rising since last fall because of declining oil prices and lower interest rates, as is generally believed, why did Wall Street stage an impressive rally last week when OPEC appeared successful in its effort to raise energy prices?

title: Sudanese Leader Signs Oil Pact With Libya
description: The Sudan and Libya have signed an agreement for the Sudan to buy Libyan oil with money withheld from Sudanese workers in Libya, Prime Minister Sadeq al-Mahdi of the Sudan said today after a short visit to Tripoli.

title: LABOR REPORT SAYS UNION RAISES ARE BELOW THAT OF NON-UNIONISTS
description: Wage increases in new contracts for union workers in private industry this year are roughly half the size of previous raises, but economists say the picture may not be so bleak as it appears.

title: Over 24,000 Acres Burn In Western Brush Fires
description: Range fires ignited by summer lightning storms burned out of control in tinder-dry Utah and Nevada today, consuming more than 24,000 acres.

title: PUSH BY BANKING LOBBYISTS
description: A high-stakes lobbying effort to preserve as much as $4 billion in tax deductions for the banking industry is having only modest success.

title: CORRECTION
description: A listing by United Press International on July 23, of Federal impeachments that preceded Judge Harry E. Claiborne's, incompletely described the outcome of the 1876 move to impeach Secretary of War William W. Belknap. The House voted unanimously for impeachment, and Mr. Belknap resigned the same day. The Senate failed to muster the two-thirds needed to convict him; most of those voting for acquittal said they did so because the Senate had no jurisdiction over an official who had resigned.

title: ULSTER EXTREMISTS JOIN AGAINST PACT
description: In an odd note of agreement with their adversaries, the nationalist Roman Catholics of the Falls Road area held a parade of their own today and voiced denunciations of the British-Irish treaty.

title: OF TEXAS WATERWORKS, A LOTTERY, AN EVICTION
description: There haven't been any falls in Wichita Falls for about a century, nor any wells in Mineral Wells since 1972. But now they want to put the falls back in Wichita Falls and the wells back in Mineral Wells.

title: Washington Watch; A New Twist For Trade Law
description: AS the Senate moves this week toward a vote on economic sanctions against South Africa, it is likely to give new muscle to an unfair-trade law that has become the workhorse of the Reagan Administration's efforts to redress the trade deficit.

title: ROHATYN QUESTIONS HOUSING DELAY AND HINTS OF STALL ON FUNDS
description: The chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, Felix G. Rohatyn, says he is puzzled by long delays in the city's effort to build 800 subsidized apartments using M.A.C. money, and he has asked the Koch administration for an explanation.

title: ZAHRINGER TOP AMATEUR
description: George Zahringer 3d, a 33-year-old stockbroker who plays out of Deepdale Country Club, won the Metropolitan Amateur today for the fourth time. He beat Bob Housen, a five-time New Jersey amateur champion, 1 up, in the 36-hole final match at Quaker Ridge Golf Club.

title: Party for Poet (Princess)
description: There hasn't been a good deal of poetry on Capitol Hill since Senator Eugene McCarthy slipped not so gently into that dark night of political retirement/oblivion some 16 years ago, but there may be a few lines quoted there this evening. Representative Jim Wright of Texas, the House majority leader, is giving a book party for his sister, Mary Connell, whose collection of poems, ''Help Is On The Way,'' has been published by Max Reinhardt in London and is scheduled for distribution here in the fall by Salem House Publishers of Topsfield, Mass. Graham Greene, in his introduction to the book, expressed particular pleasure with these Connell lines as the poet describes her frustration at being unable to conjure up a prince:

title: Henry Steinglass, Lawyer, Married to Judith Sagarin
description: Judith Sagarin and Henry J. Steinglass were married yesterday at the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue in Manhattan by Rabbi Helene Ferris.

title: 130,000 OTHERS AVERT WALKOUTS
description: Nearly 70,000 communications workers struck telephone companies in New York, parts of New England and 12 states in the West and Middle West yesterday in the industry's second major contract dispute since the breakup of the Bell System in 1984.

title: Heiress Leaves $20 Million
description: A granddaughter of Adolph Coors, founder of the Coors brewing fortune, has bequeathed $5 million each to an animal protection society in Denver, a college in Millbrook, N.Y., that went bankrupt in 1977, St. John's Episcopal Cathedral in Denver and the Metropolitan Opera Guild in New York. The granddaughter, Margaret Collbran, died Feb. 17 at the age of 75 and did not know that Bennett College, which she attended in the 1930's, had gone bankrupt. An Oct. 20 probate hearing is to settle the disposition of Bennett's share.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, AUGUST 11, 1986
description: The Economy

title: THE GIANTS' KEEPERS OF THE FLAME
description: IT started a generation ago with Sam Huff, the first of professional football's celebrated linebackers. It has continued in recent years with such Pro Bowl regulars as Brad Van Pelt, Harry Carson and Lawrence Taylor.

title: Advertising; Integrating Saatchi's Services
description: SAATCHI & SAATCHI of London, the world's largest advertising agency after last week's acquisition of Ted Bates Worldwide, will speed up the integration of its diversified communications and business services by tapping one of the best-known American business academicians for guidance, according to people close to the agency.

title: TOP U.S. OFFICIALS ARRIVE IN MOSCOW FOR TALKS ON ARMS
description: A group of senior American officials arrived in Moscow today for high-level talks about the latest American and Soviet arms control proposals.

title: Publisher of Hustler Is Admitted to Hospital
description: Larry Flynt, the publisher of Hustler magazine, was admitted to a hospital today suffering from an undisclosed illness, officials said.

title: VALERIE EDINGER MARRIED TO F.J. KNECHT
description: Valerie Jean Edinger, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Charles B. Edinger of Dix Hills, L.I., was married yesterday to Frederick Jordan Knecht, the son of Mr. and Mrs. David J. Knecht of Bedford, Mass. Rabbi A. Bruce Goldman and the Rev. David Weissbard, a Unitarian minister, officiated at the home of the bride's parents.

title: Account
description: * Baker Instruments Corporation, a maker of medical testing equipment in Allentown, Pa., to Justamere agency, Hopatcong, N.J.

title: Fish Are Now Able to Survive In Low-Salt Great Salt Lake
description: Fish have appeared in the Great Salt Lake, which was previously so salty that only brine shrimp, algae and bacteria lived in it, a biologist says.

title: Peruvian Jet Fighters Attack Cocaine Sites
description: The Peruvian Government, vowing to wage a battle alone against drugs, has started a major anti-cocaine operation and sent two squadrons of air force planes against traffickers' bases in the Amazon jungle.

title: BUCKLEY-LITTLE CATALOGUE IS SOLD
description: The Buckley-Little Catalogue, in which authors list their out-of-print books, has been sold to Kraus Reprint and Periodicals, one of the largest reprint publishers in the world.

title: Coleco Likely to Shift A Major Assignment
description: Coleco Industries, the producer of Cabbage Patch Kids and other toys, will reportedly shift a large chunk of its advertising - more than $20 million in billings - to Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt.

title: NORMAN IS LEADER
description: Greg Norman's march toward the PGA Championship was delayed for a day when heavy rains made the Inverness Club course unplayable. Officials of the Professional Golfers Association of America suspended play at 2:31 this afternoon, moments after Norman and Bob Tway hit their drives on the second hole to the middle of the fairway.

title: UNION CARBIDE SAYS UPSET WORKER SET OFF THE BHOPAL PLANT DISASTER
description: The Union Carbide Corporation said yesterday that it believed that a disgruntled plant worker had set off the poison gas tragedy that killed more than 2,000 people in Bhopal, India, in 1984. A spokesman said the company's own investigation was now centered on one specific individual, but the spokesman declined to identify the person.

title: Accord With Transit Workers Averts Strike in New Orleans
description: Negotiators for 625 drivers of city buses and streetcars reached a tentative agreement today, averting a strike that could have affected 200,000 commuters on Monday morning.

title: End the Hudson Sniping
description: The war across the Hudson is heating up again following a decision in Washington, under prodding from New York, to revoke a $9 million Urban Development Action Grant to Jersey City. The reason: Jersey City could not show its development would not siphon jobs from New York.

title: One Victim's Case for Banning the Cigarette Industry's Ads
description: To the Editor:

title: Rolling Powder Kegs in the Army
description: The Army's new Bradley Fighting Vehicle is meant to carry troops into battle; it endangers them terribly. A hit from the standard Soviet antitank round will ignite its fuel and ammunition, incinerating the seven-man crew. The Army could fix the problem by storing the inflammables away from the crew. But it doesn't want to halt production; Congress might sour on the program altogether.

title: Climber Dies on Mont Blanc, Raising Toll to 11 This Month
description: A French climber was killed today on Mont Blanc when he fell down a crevasse, bringing to five the number of deaths on Europe's highest mountain this weekend, the police said.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, AUGUST 11, 1986
description: International

title: RAIDERS DEFEATED BY 49ERS
description: Joe Montana and Jeff Kemp threw touchdown passes for San Francisco in the first half, and the 49ers' defense got 12 sacks today in a 32-0 victory over the Los Angeles Raiders.

title: What It Takes to Be America's Chief Justice
description: To the Editor:

title: Futures Dealer Note Offering
description: In an unusual financing, the Refco Group Ltd., parent company of the world's largest futures commision merchant, announced Friday that it had sold $52.5 million of seven-year unsecured senior notes through a private placement with a group of 10 institutions. The offering is believed to be the first such placement by any company in the futures industry.

title: PADRES TOP ASTROS, END 5-GAME SLIDE
description: Dave Dravecky won for the first time in six weeks as the San Diego Padres ended a five-game losing streak today with a 5-3 victory over the Astros, the leader in the West.

title: HAMILTON BEACH SEEN UP FOR SALE
description: Hamilton Beach, the appliance maker that was one of the prizes the Belzberg family won when it acquired the Scovill Corporation, is up for sale, according to sources on Wall Street who say discussions with potential buyers have taken place in the last few months.

title: Justice in the Senate
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee hearings have left, to put it at a minimum, an uncomfortable feeling about Justice William H. Rehnquist. When candor would have been easy, he was evasive. When a willingness to reflect on his past actions would have been disarming, this usually disarming man was woodenly unreflective.

title: INSENSITIVITY TO THE DISABLED
description: New research has shown that the families of children with disabilities are often subjected to stares, embarrassed silences, rude comments and disrespectful questions. The negative reactions, which are a major cause of stress, come not only from strangers, but also from neighbors and even friends, relatives and medical and service personnel.

title: Man's Bomb Threats Disrupt Rally on L.I.
description: A man disrupted a candlelight vigil at the Soviet enclave here late Saturday when he made two bomb threats by telephone and said a sniper would shoot at a crowd of protesters.

title: Philippine Activist Receives High Award
description: President Corazon C. Aquino gave the nation's highest civilian award today to a former senator who has fought for decades to remove United States military bases from the Philippines.

title: ISRAELIS STRIKE
description: Gunbattles raged all day today between rival Christian factions in East Beirut, and spread north to the port of Junieh and east to the mountains.

title: P.L.O. DENOUNCES PLANS TO DEVELOP WEST BANK UNDER OCCUPATION
description: Leaders of the Palestine Liberation Organization today denounced plans backed by Israel and the United States to improve living conditions in the occupied Arab territories, describing them as attempts to perpetuate Israeli occupation.

title: What It Takes to Be America's Chief Justice; Damaging Deeds
description: To the Editor:

title: CURBS SOUGHT IN CAESAREAN DELIVERIES
description: Despite efforts by medical authorities to curb deliveries by Caesarean section, new Federal data show that they have continued to rise, prompting calls for a renewed campaign.

title: Light Schedule for Weekly Auctions
description: The Treasury, which last week successfully auctioned $28 billion worth of new medium-term and long-term securities, has a much lighter load scheduled for this week. And given the uncertain near-term outlook for interest rates, participants in the taxable corporate bond market say that a number of tentatively scheduled issues may not be priced this week.

title: Derailed Tankers Cause 18-Hour Evacuation
description: About 3,000 residents were forced to flee their homes after three tanker train cars carrying volatile gas derailed, officials said today.

title: MISSTEP AT BANK OF NEW YORK
description: Eight years ago, the Bank of New York shifted into high gear with a strategy for diversification and expansion that paid off with record earnings quarter after quarter and a record stock price year after year. But one of the bank's cylinders, real estate construction lending, is misfiring badly.

title: John Henry Has Leg Problem
description: John Henry, thoroughbred racing's career earnings leader, has developed a swelling in his lower left foreleg that has put his comeback plans on hold, said Ron McAnally, his trainer.

title: THE NUMEROUS DISTORTIONS CLOUDING 'KAFKAESQUE'
description: THE name of Franz Kafka was invoked several times in connection with the recent antitrust suit by the United States Football League against the National Football League. Harvey Myerson, the attorney for the U.S.F.L., referred in his summation to the ''Kafkaesque'' world of the N.F.L., where ''black is white and white is black.'' And a week ago, in an interview with a reporter from this paper, Pete Rozelle, the commissioner of the N.F.L., said of the U.S.F.L.'s reaction to the jury's verdict - which found the N.F.L. had violated antitrust law but awarded the U.S.F.L. only $1 in damages - that ''it reminds me of Kafka, who wrote that white was black and black was white.''

title: KING ENDS DROUGHT BY TAKING PLAYOFF
description: Betsy King rallied from a four-shot deficit on the front nine, fell into a tie with JoAnne Carner on the back nine to force a playoff, then made par on the second extra hole to win the $230,000 Henredon Classic today.

title: Platinum Cost Seen Surging
description: Platinum was the powerhouse of the precious metals complex last week, and analysts have predicted continued surges in its price as speculation grows that South Africa, the world's largest producer, will limit supplies in retaliation for economic sanctions.

title: Fruehauf Set To Proceed
description: The Fruehauf Corporation said yesterday that a Federal court's ruling allows it and Merrill Lynch & Company to proceed with a $48.50-a-share leveraged buyout so long as Fruehauf provides Asher B. Edelman, a New York investor, and any other bidders with the same financial data given to Merrill Lynch.

title: Shipbuilder Deal Is Denied
description: The Congoleum Corporation denied published reports yesterday that its Bath Iron Works subsidiary, one of the largest shipbuilders for the Navy, would be sold to a New York investment bank.

title: Canadian Joblessness Up
description: The Canadian unemployment rate jumped to a seasonally adjusted 9.9 percent in July from its four-year low of 9.5 percent in June, the Government's Statistics Canada said Friday. The actual number of jobless rose by 26,000, to 1,231,000.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Aug. 11, 1986: *2*MONDAY FPL Group Inc Meredith Corp First Mississippi Corp *2*TUESDAY Briggs & Stratton McDermott Intl Champion Spark Plug Tyco Labs Hammermill Paper *2*WEDNESDAY Colt Industries General Re Corp Fireman's Fund Soo Line Corp *2*THURSDAY Acme Elec Kimberly-Clarke Advest Group Inc Lincoln Natl Corp Carpenter Technology Mapco Inc Carson Pirie Scott Sabine Corp Conrac Corp Singer Co KDI Corp Wal-Mart Stores *2*FRIDAY Centel Corp IC industries Chelsea Industries Reynolds Metals Hospital Corp Amer Texas Utilities

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Can Co., Greenwich, Conn., has elected to its board Ronald E. Goldsberry, president and chief operating officer of Parker Chemical Co., a subsidiary of Ford Motor Co.

title: Corgi Named Best
description: A red-and-white Pembroke Welsh corgi, Ch. Walborah's Rugby V. Marjoe, owned by Joseph and Mary Vaudo, was named best of 1,132 dogs today at the Sand and Sea Kennel Club show. Rugby, who was handled by Joy Brewster, is the top-winning corgi in the history of the breed with 26 top awards and 119 group victories.

title: The Editorial Notebook; The Soviet Science Gap
description: At the small town of Serpukhov, south of Moscow, Soviet physicists are busy building the world's largest atom-smashing machine. The venture is quite in keeping with the Soviet love of gigantism and enormous investment in science. The 1.5 million Soviet scientists, a quarter of the world's total, include individuals of great talent. Yet they contribute surprisingly little to world science. Their lack of productivity is a critical weakness in the Soviet Union's economic and military strength.

title: Chance Meeting Ends, Seaman's Search Begins
description: ''Her name was Nancy - that's it, Nancy. I didn't even get her last name.''

title: Playing Baseball in Wales
description: ON our first morning in Wales, our host Alastair made a pot of tea and announced, ''So, we're off to a baseball game on Saturday.'' We indulgently ascribed his talk to Celtic mysticism, visions of long-lost cities in the driving surf, ancient Druid deities in the mist. If Alastair thought he could find a baseball game in Wales, more power to him.

title: UNCERTAINTY MARS PAKISTAN'S GAINS
description: With a brisk rate of industrial production and excellent harvests, Pakistan has in recent years achieved a growing economy that most analysts say is contributing heavily toward political stability.

title:
25 Years Later: Peering Over the Wall;
The East's Ties to The West
description: At first the Wall was a crude expanse of barbed wire, and even its sponsor, Nikita Khrushchev, called it ''an ugly thing.'' Today, it is a more normal-looking concrete and steel construction, if one can use the word ''normal'' for a barrier surrounded by explosives and automatic shooting devices designed to prevent people from leaving their country.

title: CUOMO BACKS A PLAN FOR MORE JUDGES IN CITY
description: Governor Cuomo announced his support yesterday for a plan to provide as many as 40 new judgeships in New York City over the next two years to ease the strain on the overburdened Criminal Court.

title: TEXTILE INDUSTRY DISMAY AT VOTE ON TRADE VETO
description: Textile manufacturers, who have long cried for protection against imports, say they are disappointed -but not defeated - by last week's vote in the House of Representatives to uphold President Reagan's veto of a bill to limit textile imports. While the industry had hoped for victory, it had not expected it.

title: Why Aren't These Men Smiling?
description: It was an extraordinary scene.

title: The Untouchables at the Chase Manhattan
description: To the Editor:

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Nelson Expansion Seen In Embassy Home Deal
description: Barry Peter Spikings, president of Nelson Entertainment Inc., sees the acquisition of Embassy Home Entertainment from the Coca-Cola Company for $85 million as an opportunity to expand the home-video unit to an integrated entertainment company with access to top-quality releases.

title: Banking Assignment
description: The Marine Midland Bank, New York, has awarded the advertising and direct-response account for its newly established corporate, institutional and international banking sector to Grey and Grey Direct. Billings are about $2 million. Benton & Bowles has been handling the bank's retail advertising.

title: Official Denials Are No Help to Iraq's 300 Abducted Children
description: To the Editor:

title: 4 GUNMEN KILL EX-COMMANDER OF INDIAN ARMY
description: A retired army Chief of Staff who was India's most decorated soldier was shot and killed in his car today in the western city of Pune, a few days after receiving a death threat from Sikh militants.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: ON THE TIP Perhaps the last time you were on Manhattan's southern tip was with the millions who went for the Liberty Weekend festivities. If you were, you know that the throng was so dense that you could get little sense of the neighborhood. The tip is still busy, as befits a world financial center, but it is considerably less crowded. This is a good time to enjoy Battery Park, whose 20 acres overlook the harbor and the Statue of Liberty and include Castle Clinton, the former immigrant station of Castle Garden.

title: BRAVO PRESENTS STRAVINSKY'S 'FLOOD'
description: ''THE FLOOD,'' a ''musical play'' created especially for the television medium, is one of the last major works of Igor Stravinsky (indeed, of the music from the composer's final decade, only the ''Requiem Canticles'' is of equal magnitude). Esteemed by some critics, ''The Flood'' has never been popular. ''Its world premiere on June 14, 1962, by way of a CBS telecast, was the only event during Stravinsky's 80th birthday year that did not bring him ovations,'' Lillian Libman writes in her memoir, ''And Music at the Close.'' She continues: ''As for Stravinsky's score, it was so surrounded by Breck Golden Showcase commercials, and a hodgepodge of documentary film clips, eulogies, flood legends, and rehearsal excerpts, plus an introductory minor epic rivalling the speech of Polonius in pomposity, no amount of concentration could afford it a fair hearing.'' The press was generally negative. ''The hour as a whole was enough to retard the progress of the arts in this country by a great deal,'' wrote The New York Times. ''Literature, music, art objects, and by implication their creators, were made to seem insufferably pretentious, disorganized and dull.''

title: U.S. Women Top Hungary, 78-63
description: Katrina McClain scored 21 points as the United States, the 1984 Olympic champions, built a 43-34 halftime lead today and went on to beat Hungary, 78-63, for its third victory in Group B of the women's world basketball championships.

title: CITY OPERA: SPACAGNA AS 'BUTTERFLY
description: PUCCINI'S ''Madama Butterfly'' is often a very affecting opera, but it is far from perfectly wrought. The heroine, in particular, is a creation of infinite paradox. She is, we are told, a 15-year old girl, all innocence and delicacy. Yet there is nothing particularly girlish about the music Puccini has provided her: it demands remarkable stamina, and a temperament more endemic to a Tosca than a Susanna. In some 20 years of Butterfly watching, this listener cannot recall a completely convincing rendition of the title role, and the New York City Opera performance Saturday night did not offer an exception.

title: Brazil Begins Currency Fight
description: The Brazilian Government has begun a major crackdown on the illegal but normally tolerated black market for dollars in an attempt to restore confidence in the country's economic policies, a Finance Ministry official said Friday.

title: EUROPEAN AIRLINES: DEREGULATION TARGET
description: The Belgian Transport Minister, Hermann de Croo, a supporter of liberalizing the European airline industry, recently said that it cost less to fly from Brussels to Nice via New York City than via Paris. Mr. de Croo was exaggerating a bit to make his point: the lack of competition in Europe, he believes, has pushed airline ticket prices artificially high.

title: OPEC DEAL MEANS HIGHER INFLATION, EXPERTS SAY
description: Higher oil prices, fluctuating between $15 and $20 a barrel for the rest of the year, would spur moderately higher inflation within a matter of months and slower economic growth for 1987 than had been forecast, according to several economists.

title: 'HOMELESS' NEW YORKERS: POSTSCRIPT IN SOVIET
description: Joseph Mauri arrived here from New York last week to be feted by Soviet press organizations as the flesh-and-blood reality of homelessness and joblessness in America.

title: Generous Donations
description: The banking political action committees have been generous contributors to a number of Senators, especially those on the Senate Banking Committee, according to a recent study by the U.S. Public Interest Research Group. From 1981 through the first quarter of 1986, the bank P.A.C.'s have contributed more than $5.5 million to Senate candidates, including $4.8 million to current members of the Senate, and $1.3 million to current members of the Banking Committee.

title: GRENADA NOW SUNNIER, WITH CALYPSO ON ITS MIND
description: Nearly three years after United States troops invaded Grenada and toppled a hard-line leftist regime, this mountainous, jungle-covered island with paradisiacal beaches is returning to the peaceful, easygoing rhythms of the English-speaking Caribbean.

title: U.S. SAID TO PLAN MOVES TO TIGHTEN EMBARGO ON CUBA
description: President Reagan plans to tighten the United States economic embargo of Cuba that was first imposed in the early 1960's, Administration officials said today.

title: What It Takes to Be America's Chief Justice; A Complete Answer
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge: Experimental Split Tourney Is a Big Success Once Again
description: One might suppose that officials involved in a split regional championship, hustling between two sites 150 miles apart, would be in danger of schizophrenia. Euphoria was, however, the state of mind of Joan Levy and other organizers in Secaucus, N.J., and Albany during the past five days, for their second experiment in tournament splitting was highly successful and seems likely to be a regular feature of the calendar.

title: PINA BAUSCH AND SUSAN SONTAG ON 13
description: THE lineup is impressive on ''Pina Bausch With Susan Sontag'' and ''Pina Bausch 1980,'' which Channel 13 airs tonight at 10 o'clock as part of an ongoing salute to Channel 4, Britain's alternative television network. But the two and a half hours we spend in the company of these two formidable cultural figures seem strangely insubstantial.

title: JAMES V. DAY
description: James V. Day, who had served 23 years as a member of the United States Maritime Commission, died Friday in the Eastern Maine Medical Center at Bangor.

title: Bond Market's Revival Seen
description: The bond markets, which dote on bad economic news, almost seem certain to flourish in coming weeks. In spite of revival efforts, the outlook for growth remains tepid at best, most analysts say. That means interest rates, which have been falling for the better part of a year, are likely to decline further.

title: Cuba, Rumania in Pact
description: Cuba and Rumania have signed a new economic and technical cooperation agreement aimed at raising bilateral trade by 20 percent, to $1.7 billion, in the 1986-90 period, the official daily, Granma, said Friday. The agreement was signed in Havana by the Rumanian Deputy Planning Minister, Ion Ceausescu, and the Cuban Planning Minister, Jose Lopez Moreno.

title: 3,500 in West Berlin March to Protest Wall
description: About 3,500 demonstrators marched through the city center Saturday to protest the Berlin Wall, and the United States Ambassador to West Germany, Richard R. Burt, predicted the barrier would someday be ''one of history's bad memories.''

title: A Modest Bill for Banking
description: With the retreat last week by Jake Garn, the chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, from his plans to push for comprehensive banking legislation this year, the prospects of closing the limited-service bank loophole became more distant.

title: Banana Club Meets Electrical Women
description: Several years ago, ours became one of the few private homes with its own copy of ''The Encyclopedia of Associations.'' That random acquisition has become our atlas of the world's random charms. When life seems flat and homogeneous, this unassuming reference work is a happy reminder of the countless private grails out there, all quietly coexisting.

title: Pamela Bankert Weds
description: Pamela Bankert, a third-year law student at Rutgers University, and Rupert Brandt, a carpenter in Amawalk, N.Y., were married yesterday in Suffern, N.Y. Judge William K. Nelson of the Rockland County Court officiated at the home of the bride's brother and sister-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. Bates Bankert. The couple's parents are Mrs. Willard E. Bankert of New York and the late Mr. Bankert, and Harvey Brandt of Somerville, N.J., and Pauline Perkins of Brockton, Mass. The couple will use the surname Bankert.

title: 'THE HUMAN ANIMAL,' A 5-PART SERIES
description: HOORAY for healthy sex; why should it be such a problem? Phil Donahue addresses himself to this in ''Love and Sex,'' the first part of a five-part NBC series, ''Phil Donahue Examines the Human Animal,'' beginning at 10 P.M. on NBC. Earnestness and entertainment run neck and neck.

title: One Victim's Case for Banning the Cigarette Industry's Ads; Madison Before Mill
description: To the Editor:

title: A FED STAR ADJUSTS TO LIFE ON OUTSIDE
description: When Nikko Securities announced in June that Stephen H. Axilrod was joining the Wall Street firm as vice chairman, officials at a rival Japanese securities house fired a telex from Tokyo to inquire of their own Wall Street subsidiary: ''Who is this Stephen Axilrod?''

title: Rehnquist's View on Memos Disputed by Aide to Jackson
description: Elsie Douglas, secretary to Associate Justice Robert H. Jackson of the Supreme Court, says Justice William H. Rehnquist is smearing the reputation of a great man by maintaining that memorandums Mr. Rehnquist wrote in 1952 supporting racial segregation reflected the view of Justice Jackson, now dead.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Has a team ever led its league with more than 200 home runs in a season without having in its lineup the player who led the league in home runs that season?

title: PROFITS DISAPPOINTING FOR MANY COMPANIES
description: Second-quarter corporate profits have proved disappointing to many companies that thought a weaker dollar, falling interest rates and lower oil prices would be the right ingredients to turn around the nation's sluggish economy.

title: Laurie Lister and Mark Fleischman Are Married
description: The marriage of Laurie Elizabeth Lister to Mark Fleischman took place yesterday at the bridegroom's home in Garrison, N.Y. Justice of the Peace Carmine Ricci of Cold Spring, N.Y., officiated.

title: OPERA: SANTA FE OFFERS 'THE KING GOES FORTH
description: For most of its length, Aulis Sallinen's new opera, ''The King Goes Forth to France,'' is more fulfilling to think about than actually to behold. Yet patience is partially rewarded. In the earlier scenes, Mr. Sallinen's music seems almost intimidated by its subject matter, but its lyric tendencies grow in confidence with the progress of the evening.

title: NEW CHIEF OF CITY'S HIGH SCHOOLS HAS A PLAN TO TURN AROUND THE 5 WORST
description: The new director of the city's high schools, Dr. Frank L. Smith Jr., has set himself a formidable task: making some of the worst schools in a system in distress into good ones.

title: Catherine Finch Weds
description: At the Saugatuck Congregational Church in Westport, Conn., yesterday Catherine Ellen Finch, the Mount Sinai services program administrator of the alcoholism treatment program at the City Hospital in Elmhurst, Queens, was married to James William March, executive director and counsel of the Insurance Brokers' Association of the State of New York.

title: Electronic Earful
description: Some Capitol Hill lobbyists concerned with the tax revision bill have gone electronic. When last week's closed Senate Finance Committee meetings broke up and reporters were interviewing lawmakers in the corridor, lobbyists pressed close and held up cordless cellular telephone sets. Thus, the latest reports on legislative progress by committee members could be heard immediately and directly by the powerful special interest leaders in their offices downtown.

title: G.O.P. SENATORS SEEN WITH BIG CASH ADVANTAGE
description: With less than three months remaining until the fall elections, most incumbent Republican Senators have a large advantage in campaign funds over their Democratic challengers. This means the Democrats are facing an uphill struggle in their fight to regain control of the Senate after six years of Republican rule.

title: A RETIRED JUSTICE
description: Margaret Mary Mangan, a former State Supreme Court justice who wrote a decision a decade ago upholding New York City's right to require window guards in apartments where children live, died Friday night at the Jersey Shore Medical Center in Neptune, N.J. She was 79 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: GEDMAN SLAM PACES RED SOX
description: Rich Gedman hit a pinch-hit grand slam, capping a five-run rally in the eighth inning today, as the Boston Red Sox scored a 9-6 victory over the Tigers.

title: A Gathering in Moscow That Proved Irresistible
description: Behind the meeting starting Monday in Moscow between American and Soviet arms control officials is a revealing tale of one small meeting and how it grew.

title: Killer in Pennsylvania to Die
description: Martin D. Appel, 28 years old, has been sentenced to death for murdering three bank employees in a June robbery that netted less than $2,300. He pleaded guilty July 22 to homicide charges filed after he and Stanley Hertzog, 29, of Allentown, walked into the First National Bank of Bath in East Allen Township and opened fire.

title: TRAINER IS WAITING FOR OGYGIAN'S TURN TO SHINE
description: JAN NERUD, his face grim with resigned annoyance yesterday morning, cast a long and wary eye at the ceiling of gray clouds that has hung over Saratoga Race Track for the last 10 days.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: The Bureaucracy; What This Means is - Oh, Never Mind
description: The bureaucracy sometimes moves in a mysterious way, its wonders to perform.

title: SENATE'S CUTS WOULD SLOW WORK ON MISSILE DEFENSE, DIRECTOR SAYS
description: The Senate's cut in President Reagan's military programs proposal will slow research efforts on an antimissile shield, but will not decimate the program, its director said today.

title: McEnroe's Blueprint
description: If Marshall Happer, the administrator of the Men's International Professional Tennis Council, decides to give up his position, he might want to approach John McEnroe about becoming his successor. McEnroe certainly does not lack for opinions about the state of professional tennis.

title: Off Duty, Officer Makes Children Laugh
description: Ernest Desire is a clown. He fights crime with outrageous puns meant to disarm the youngest children and toughest criminals.

title: 2 DEAVER INQUIRIES ARE REPORTED EXTENDED TO ASIA
description: Federal investigators looking into the propriety and legality of lobbying by Michael K. Deaver, the former White House deputy chief of staff, have broadened their inquiry to include his business dealings in Asia, according to Congressional and Reagan Administration sources.

title: ROUNDUP OF QUARTERLY EARNINGS AND SALES AT 296 COMPANIES
description: (Loss) * Not applicable, loss in 1985 period. .... Loss in latest quarter. N.A. Not available. (1) Quarter ended in April. (2) Quarter ended in May (3) Quarter ended in July.

title: RICHMOND WINNER AT WATKINS GLEN
description: Tim Richmond passed Darrell Waltrip with 12 laps to go today and then pulled away to win a 119-mile Nascar event at Watkins Glen.

title: WALTON SEES GAINS DESPITE TROUNCING
description: The Jets never - well, hardly ever - win their first game of the exhibition season. They've done it once since 1975. And when they appear more intent on resting regulars and learning about untested players, that record is not about to change.

title: EGYPT-ISRAEL BORDER TALKS PROGRESS
description: Negotiators for Egypt and Israel reported today that they had resolved all but two conditions for the international arbitration of their border dispute over the slice of beachfront called Taba.

title: De Leon Defeats Greer in Title Bout
description: Carlos (Sugar) De Leon, the World Boxing Council cruiserweight champion, stopped Michael Greer in the eighth round today to retain the title.

title: Generous Harvest
description: For Don Nelson, it all began more than 30 years ago. Hog prices tumbled and the family farm in Sherrard, Ill., that his grandfather, father and uncle had owned and worked ever since Nelson remembered, failed. For Nelson, now the coach of the Milwaukee Bucks, the memories of those dark days were rekindled last May when he received a letter from Clarence Willcome, a Wisconsin farmer who asked for help to save the farm he was about to lose.

title: JUSTICE DEPT. AIDE DEFENDS RULING ON BIAS AGAINST VICTIMS OF AIDS
description: The author of the Justice Department's opinion that people with AIDS are not always protected by a Federal law outlawing employment discrimination against the handicapped said yesterday that the department had no intention of fostering discrimination against people with AIDS.

title: METS GET 4 IN 7TH TO WIN
description: In the latest episode of life on a roll, Sid Fernandez was sitting in the Mets' dugout in the seventh inning contemplating the fact that he hadn't won a game in a month and had a pretty good chance of losing this one: The Mets were trailing the Montreal Expos, 2-1, and Fernandez had just been lifted for a pinch-hitter.

title: Ashton-Tate 'Mac' System
description: Ashton-Tate, the leading vendor of data management programs for personal computers, will introduce on Monday its first product for Apple Computer Inc.'s Macintosh computer.

title: Prove Yourself Innocent
description: The President of the United States proudly handed over a sample of his urine last weekend, before an unrelated urological examination, to prove that the Oval Office is a ''drug-free workplace.'' The Vice President is scheduled to deliver his specimen to drug testers today, demonstrating he has neither a narcotics addiction nor mind of his own.

title: BENDEL'S NEW OWNER TALKS ABOUT CHANGE
description: Leslie H. Wexner sat at a table in his temporary New York headquarters, doodling X's in circles on a yellow legal pad and sipping diet cola from a can. The jacket of his three-piece suit was off and his sleeves were rolled up. He had just returned from Paris and was talking about the art he had seen. He talked of Picasso and Braque, of Solanger and Kline, of the evolution of modern art, of how one artist influences another without diminishing either artist.

title: Officer Charged in Car Death
description: A New York City probationary police officer was charged today with driving over two pedestrians here, killing one. He was suspended from the force.

title: Harnessing Retirees' Clout
description: One of the largest and potentially most powerful organizations in the country, the American Association of Retired Persons, has decided to go into electoral politics for the first time. With 21 million members, it is the United States' largest single group of older people, who make up the fastest-growing segment of the population and one with more time for political activity.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Endowment Accepting Applications for Grants
description: Grant applications are now being accepted by the National Endowment for the Humanities for radio and television programs based on the lives of ''prominent historical figures in American thought, history and literature,'' a spokesman for the endowment said. The grants, part of the Humanities Projects in Media, are available for planning, writing the scripts or producing the biographies.

title: HERBERT MOLS
description: Herbert Mols, the manager of the 1972 United States Olympic basketball team and one of the original organizers of the Empire State Games, died today, apparently of a heart attack. He was 71 years old.

title:
25 Years Later: Peering Over the Wall;
Next Door, Forbidden World
description: On Aug. 13, the Berlin Wall will be 25 years old. The Wall changed the fluid, chaotic, postwar division of Berlin forever; it also changed the way new generations of Berliners would see their city and the world.

title: THEATER: ROBERTY LINDSAY IN 'ME AND MY GIRL'
description: THERE is nothing more primal in the lexicon of musical comedy than the number in which the young hero declares his undying love for the woman of his dreams. About a half-hour into ''Me and My Girl,'' the restored 1937 English musical now on Broadway, that number is to be found in its most cliched form: every word, note and gesture collides with a civilization's collective memory of vintage stage and movie musicals.

title: Goldin Won't Release Botnick Severance Pay
description: City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin has added Victor Botnick, who resigned recently as chairman of the Health and Hospitals Corporation, to his list of former Koch administration officials whose severance pay he will not approve.

title: Outdoors; White-Water Thrills
description: THE roller coasters and upside-down rides at adventure parks summon participants because of the risk and the fear - all self-imposed. For many these are attractions and they will be conquered.

title: Kramer Signs
description: Tommy Kramer, the Minnesota Vikings' No. 1 quarterback, signed a three-year contract extension today, General Manager Mike Lynn announced. Kramer is in the last year of his current contract, which pays him $600,000 per year. The new deal is reportedly worth $2.3 million and will run through 1989, which would be Kramer's 13th season.

title: YANKEES ROUTED BY ROYALS, 13-3
description: In Lou Piniella's view, the Yankees' game with Kansas City yesterday was over before it was over. ''This one was over halfway through it,'' the manager said after the hitting-poor Royals drubbed the Yankees, 13-3. It was only one loss, but it was symptomatic and should prompt the Yankees to wonder if their pennant race is over before it's over.

title: IN ATLANTA'S PRIMARY, OLD FRIENDS ENDORSE MARTIN LUTHER KING 3D
description: Martin Luther King 3d, the eldest son of the slain civil rights leader, will challenge a white incumbent Tuesday for a seat on the Fulton County Commission here. He is running with the backing of Mayor Andrew Young and other black political figures.

title: WYETH SAYS WORKS 'HAVE TO BE SEEN'
description: Andrew Wyeth had only one thing to say yesterday to art lovers interested in the story behind his newly discovered ''Helga'' paintings. ''The pictures now have to be seen,'' he said, ''and let the imagination run free.''

title: PETER WEINBERG, 38, CHANNEL 13'S CHIEF OF MUSIC PROGRAMS
description: Peter Weinberg, the director of music programming for Channel 13, died Saturday at Roosevelt Hospital, according to a Channel 13 spokesman. He was 38 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Allegheny Selects A 'Friendly Leader'
description: Not many executives would want to trade places with Oliver S. Travers Jr. As the new chairman and chief executive officer of Allegheny International Inc., Mr. Travers takes the helm of a company that faces an inquiry by the Securities and Exchange Commission, as well as a spate of lawsuits from stockholders charging that the company and its board made reckless business decisions.

title: U.S. AND EUROPE SETTLE PASTA AND CITRUS DISPUTE
description: The United States and the European Community agreed today to end their ''pasta war'' and remove nine-month-old restrictions on some food exports and imports, officials said.

title: BUTCHERS, BAKERS AND INTIMACY
description: THEY know the intimate details of our lives - about our counting the gray hairs on our heads and the fallen hairs on our combs; about beef at our dinner table because we ate hamburger at lunch; about our habit of wearing our hearts, along with our ball-point pen marks, on every white shirt pocket and sleeve.
