They know, and yet because ''they'' are our hairdressers, butchers, baby sitters, cleaners and cobblers - business people in service industries -they shouldn't know. And that is precisely where the problems start.

title: Man Leaps to Death From a 5th-Floor Rail
description: A 40-year-old Boston man jumped to his death yesterday from the fifth-floor railing of a fire escape on West 43d Street as 100 people watched from the street.

title: The Money Curve for Congress
description: Exponential growth is Washington, D.C.'s middle name. In two generations, the Federal Government has gone from worrying about millions to billions to trillions. In five years, the national debt has doubled. There's similarly steep growth evident in the money curve for Congress. Campaign contributions are flooding out of the PAC's, the political action committees that have sprung up on behalf of every imaginable special interest.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Lundberg Son Assumes Family Company Titles
description: Jan Christian Lundberg, the son of Dan Lundberg, the well-known gasoline industry analyst, has officially assumed the titles of president and chief executive of Lundberg Survey Inc., the family company, and publisher of the Lundberg Letter in the wake of the Aug. 3 death of his father.

title: LENDL OVERPOWERS BECKER TO WIN FINAL
description: What Boris Becker discovered today was that it is not easy playing tennis with a John McEnroe-induced hangover. Less than 24 hours after one of the more tumultuous days in his brief career, Becker walked onto the court for the final of the Volvo International. Drained of emotion, he said, he was unable to muster even one Becker Boogie - the celebratory little dance that has become his trademark - for the fans.

title: 3-YEAR-OLD IN BRONX DIES IN A 2-STORY FALL DESPITE WINDOW BAR
description: A 3-year-old Bronx resident fell two stories to his death from a hallway window last evening even though it was fitted with a window guard, the police said.

title: Volcker-Pohl Talks
description: The United States Federal Reserve chairman, Paul A. Volcker and the Bundesbank's president, Karl Otto Pohl declined comment after meeting here tonight, following Mr. Volcker's arriveal in nearby Frankfurt to attend the funeral of Otmar Emminger, a former Bundesbank president.

title: RUBBERNECKING ON BILLY DAY
description: ''WHAT are you doing today? '' a friend asked. ''Going to Yankee Stadium.'' ''Who's playing? ''

title: Deaver Safari Will Continue
description: Michael K. Deaver said today that he had no plans to cut short a safari to answer charges that he may have lied about his lobbying.

title: Lauren Taslitz is Married To Dr. William Bloomer
description: Lauren Stacie Taslitz, an assistant general counsel, and Dr. William David Bloomer, a professor and chairman of the department of radiotherapy, both at the Mount Sinai Medical Center in New York, were married yesterday.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: CITY VOTERS TO TESTIFY IN SUIT OVER HIRSCHFELD'S PETITIONS
description: New York City voters whose names are on nominating petitions for Abraham Hirschfeld will be bused to Albany today to testify in a lawsuit in which Representative Stan Lundine, Governor Cuomo's choice for lieutenant governor, is seeking to remove Mr. Hirschfeld from the Democratic primary ballot.

title: FEARSOME FOE EMERGES IN SRI LANKA
description: To the world's roster of guerrilla leaders whose strategic brilliance is matched by their ruthlessness, people here say they have added a new name. His followers call him ''Tamby'' - Tamil for ''Little Brother'' - but he was born Velupillai Prabakaran 32 years ago in what is now northern Sri Lanka, the center of Tamil nationalism.

title: CATSKILL RESORTS WOO YOUNG SET
description: For the Abbate teen-agers, staying at the Villa Roma resort here has been the family's most exciting vacation yet - except, perhaps, for the camping trip when they got chased by a bear.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL YANKEES VS. CLEVELAND INDIANS, at Yankee Stadium, 7:30 P.M. (Television - SportsChannel, 7:30 P.M., Radio -WABC, 770, 7:30 P.M.) METS VS.

title: CONTRAS' LIKELY TACTICS INCLUDE TAKING A TOWN
description: If Nicaraguan rebels receive the $100 million that the United States Congress appears ready to agree to give them, they will work toward seizing a town and can also be expected to launch bolder attacks on military targets, according to diplomats, political leaders and military analysts in the region.

title: Solicitous Host
description: As a longtime resident of Cooperstown, N.Y., the upstate lakeside community renowned as the site of the Baseball Hall of Fame, Tom Goodyear tries to do his civic duty in helping the town celebrate the national pastime.

title: Clemens Suspended
description: Roger Clemens of the Boston Red Sox, who has more victories this season than any other pitcher, was suspended for two games by the American League yesterday, but will not miss a start. The league announced that Clemens, who has a 17-4 record, was disciplined for bumping Umpire Greg Kosc in an argument in Chicago July 30.

title: PACIFICORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ISRAELI JETS POUND LEBANON TARGETS FOR SECOND DAY
description: Israeli jets attacked what the Israelis described as Palestinian guerrilla targets in Lebanon today for a second consecutive day.

title: SAUDIS SAID TO END 'INCENTIVE' PRICING FOR OIL
description: Saudi Arabia has apparently told its customers that it is ending the short-lived practice of selling huge volumes of oil at special ''incentive'' prices, according to industry experts. The incentives encouraged bigger purchases by offering discounts on the total amount of oil bought.

title: NATIONAL MINE SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $196,000. c-Includes a tax credit of $235,000 but is before net from discontinued operations of $474,000. Year-ago sales are restated.

title: NATIONAL WESTERN LIFE INURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After gains on investments of $2,399,389 for the quarter and $2,400,279 for the 6 months. c-After gains on investments of $387,515 for the quarter and $447,202 for the 6 months and tax credits of $151,000 and $174,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Letter for Deaver Urges Inquiry on Perjury Issue
description: Attorneys for Michael K. Deaver, the lobbyist who was formerly White House deputy chief of staff, said today that a House panel should refer any evidence of possible perjury by him to a court-appointed independent counsel ''for full and impartial investigation.''

title: Interest Rates Drop Slightly
description: Short- and long-term interest rates fell slightly yesterday, as investor demand continued strong for recently auctioned Treasury issues.

title: West Side Coalition Opposes Towers Set For Lincoln Center
description: A coalition of community groups on the Upper West Side has mounted a campaign against a proposal by Lincoln Center to build two new towers, one of them 54 stories high.

title: LASER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $110,000. The company said the year-ago quarter results include $452,000 in sales and a loss of $62,000 relating to an Industrial Laser subsidiary which was divested by the company in September 1985.

title: Circus Offers Soviet Couple Time to Polish High-Wire Act
description: Two high-wire walkers from the Moscow Circus who defected to the United States were offered equipment, food, shelter and time to polish a new act before they get a final audition with ''The Greatest Show on Earth.''

title: A Bias Against Jews That Was Very Real
description: To the Editor:

title: HUNDREDS PROTEST SUPREME COURT SODOMY RULING
description: As members of the American Bar Association held a dinner inside, hundreds of protesters gathered last night on the plaza of Lincoln Center to protest the recent Supreme Court ruling that Constitutional guarantees to privacy do not protect homosexual sex.

title: Iraqi Aircraft Attack Iranian Oil Refinery
description: Iraqi aircraft raided the Isfahan oil refinery in Iran today, and shipping sources said an Iranian helicopter attacked a supertanker loaded with oil in the Persian Gulf.

title: O'CONNOR GIVEN PERES INVITATION FOR ISRAELI VISIT
description: John Cardinal O'Connor, who called for the creation of a homeland for Palestinians after he visited Lebanon last June, has received a formal invitation from Prime Minister Shimon Peres to visit Israel, diplomats and Jewish leaders said yesterday. The intention, as one diplomat put it, is for the Cardinal to ''see the other side of the story.''

title: MEM CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Italy Issues Warrants For Three Jordanians
description: Warrants have been issued for three Jordanian terrorist suspects, including two brothers held in the West Berlin disco bombing and an attempt to bomb an Israeli jetliner, the ANSA news agency said today.

title: CONCORD COMPUTING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: BIG BANK'S FINANCIAL CHIEF QUITS
description: Saying he was exhausted and emotionally drained, the chief financial officer of the ailing BankAmerica Corporation resigned suddenly yesterday less than six months after taking the job.

description: b-Net income

description: David H. Swanson, a senior vice president and president of the trade and financial services group at the Continental Grain Company, has been named president and chief executive of the Central Soya Company.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: BRIDESHEAD BENIGHTED. By Auberon Waugh. 221 pages. Little, Brown. $16.95.

title: Foreigners' Edge In Getting Kidneys
description: Foreign citizens are sometimes put near the head of the line for kidney transplants at American hospitals, even though nearly 10,000 Americans are on waiting lists, according to a Federal study made public today.

title: Northrop Case Sentencing
description: A former engineer on the Northrop Corporation's Stealth bomber project was sentenced today to five years in Federal prison and five years' probation. He was also ordered to repay Nothrop $144,000 for steering subcontracts to a concern that he controlled.

title: BEL FUSE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
RUMORS, DEMAND LIFT GOLD
description: Prices of precious metals surged yesterday, fueled by rumors about South Africa and strong demand from a wide range of investors, including the Japanese Government.

title: Latin America's Bold New Partners
description: Can Latin American democracies build a common market modeled on the European Community? That's what Argentina and Brazil would do with a tariff union intended to increase and reorient trade and make political partners out of longtime rivals for regional dominance.

title: BRENTWOOD INSTRUMENTS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Democrats in Alabama Refuse Runoff Request
description: A Democratic Party subcommittee today refused a request from Attorney General Charles Graddick for an immediate runoff in the race for the gubernatorial nomination.

title: People
description: * Philip E. Cohen and Russell K. Shaffer have joined SSC&B: Lintas USA as senior vice presidents.

title: More Outlays For Israeli Jet
description: The Defense Department is releasing $67 million for contracts involving Israel's Lavi jet fighter, but it expects Israel to consider any alternatives for the program that the Pentagon can suggest this fall.

title: BAY PACIFIC HEALTH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

title: Bodzianowski's Answer
description: Craig Bodzianowski, a promising cruiserweight whose career was interrupted when he lost part of his right leg in a motorcycle accident in 1984, won his third bout since the accident.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, AUGUST 12, 1986
description: International Arms control talks in Moscow between American and Soviet officials were described by the head of the American delegation as ''serious'' and ''exploratory.'' The American, Paul H. Nitze, who is arms adviser to Secretary of State George P. Shultz, said the talks would continue today. They are part of an effort to prepare for the next summit meeting. [ Page A1, Column 1. ]

title: ANGOLA REPORTS PRETORIA RAID
description: Angola asserted today that South African forces had attacked a town and Government troops nearly 200 miles inside southern Angola. But the South African- and American-backed rebel group fighting the Marxist Government here claimed responsibility for the attack.

title: BEARINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said in the latest year, it had a one-time charge for an inventory write-off recorded during the third quarter, which reduced net by $6 million, or $1.50 a share.

title: EX-OFFICIAL'S USE OF FUNDS DEFENDED IN COURT BY EXPERT
description: A tax expert testified yesterday that ''there is a reasonable basis'' for John J. McLaughlin to have taken legally some of the money the prosecution charges he stole from Ann L. Maytag, the washing machine company heiress.

title: HORN & HARDART CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $1,310,000 for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Net income The company said the latest quarter loss resulted primarily from losses in the Bojangles's subsidiary.

description: b-Net loss

title: HARLEYSVILLE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The company went public in May, 1986. The company said the latest quarter revenue reflects increased participation in pooled property and casualty insurance business.

title: The Surge In Hispanic Broadcasts
description: AS the Hispanic population in the United States has grown in size and influence, so has the Spanish-language broadcasting industry. The clearest sign so far that the business has come of age was Hallmark Cards Inc.'s announcement last month that it would purchase the nation's largest group of Spanish-language television stations.

title: Not Bullish Enough
description: An 1,800-pound bull charged past the New York Stock Exchange Sunday evening, as two police snipers, weapons poised, did nothing.

title: EATON FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Revenue represents total income.

title: SBARRO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Figures were adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split paid July 10.

description: The company said the wider loss is primarily due to a $226,000 increase in research and development expenditures and a one-time tax charge of $350,000 related to a change in its tax relationship with Thermo Electron Corp.

title: SCHOOL BOARD PLANS TO LEASE 13 CHURCH SITES
description: The Board of Education plans to lease 13 spaces from religious institutions to be used for teaching remedial classes to parochial school students, despite a Supreme Court ruling last year that barred public school teachers in church schools.

title: REAGAN TO OFFER AID FOR FARMERS
description: On a trip to Illinois Tuesday to garner farm state support for Republican candidates, President Reagan will announce plans to increase fees paid to farmers for storing surplus grain, Administration sources said today.

title: CEM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
A.B.A. MAINTAINS AN AGREEMENT WITH SOVIET LAWYERS' GROUP
description: The American Bar Association's policy-making group refused yesterday to cancel an agreement that it has entered into with a Soviet lawyers' group that even the A.B.A.'s leadership concedes is an agency of propaganda.

title: VILLAGE LIFE IN FRANCE: WHERE DOES MURDER FIT IN?
description: This town of new stucco apartment houses standing against the gray-green backdrop of the Maritime Alps was recently shaken when a local officeholder was arrested and charged in connection with a bungled bank robbery in which an auxiliary policeman was slain.

title: CYPRESS SAVINGS ASSOCIATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
A New Agency Wins Prince Spaghetti Sauces
description: Solin Associates, a newly established agency, will handle the Prince Company's Prince spaghetti sauces, Aunt Millie spaghetti sauces and a new sauce line called Classico.

title: Put Chile's Loan Requests on Definite Hold
description: To the Editor:

Griffith Signs Pact
description: Darrell Griffith, the high-scoring guard, who sat out last season with a broken bone in his left foot, has signed a six-year contract with the Utah Jazz. It was the longest contract the Jazz had ever given a player.

title: EMPI INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $57,500.

title: 7 From Security Force Seek Israeli Amnesty
description: Seven more Israeli internal security agents applied for presidential amnesty today in connection with the beating deaths of two Palestinian bus hijackers and a subsequent cover-up, although none had been charged with any crime.

title: Closing the Gap
description: When Billy Martin's No. 1 joined 11 other Yankee numbers in official retirement on Sunday, the ceremony made the single-digit uniform number a rarity in the Bronx. No longer to be worn by future Yankees are Martin's 1, Babe Ruth's 3, Lou Gehrig's 4, Joe DiMaggio's 5, Mickey Mantle's 7, the 8 shared by Bill Dickey and Yogi Berra and Roger Maris's 9.

title: In Pursuit of the Truth
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Settlements With S.E.C.
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission settled charges today against the chief executives of two companies and a New York-based private holding company, all accused of filing delinquent statements detailing their trading activity in 1984 and 1985.

title: BAMBOO GANG SPOKE OF CRIMES, INFORMER TESTIFIES
description: A key undercover informer testified in a racketeering trial yesterday that he had heard members of the United Bamboo gang talking about murder, gambling, prostitution and drug dealing.

title: Iron Worker's Helper Is Back on Top
description: After 55 years Jack Hartigan returned yesterday for the first time to the Empire State Building, which he helped put up. Mr. Hartigan was an ornamental iron workers' helper and for a year he fastened stainless-steel beams to the outside of the building from the 3d to the 84th floors.

title: AMERICAN RELIANCE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $45,000 for the quarter and $61,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes realized investment gains of $32,000 and $62,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: MCELROY HEARS IT ALL
description: Management had spoken, and Reggie McElroy could not help but hear. He makes his living as an offensive tackle, and when the performance of the Jets offensive line inspired comments from the customers at Giants Stadium last year, the sounds were not pretty.

title: COMPUTER TELEPHONE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
EXCERPTS FROM SPEECH BY GOVERNOR TO THE BAR ASSOCIATION
description: Following are excerpts from a speech yesterday by Governor Cuomo at the national convention of the American Bar Association:

title: Choices for Mexico
description: Top Mexican officials don't hide their doubts about the motives behind recent harsh accusations from Washington. With a thin, embarrassed smile, they say they wonder why the attacks linked to drugs, corruption, emigration, election hanky-panky have poured out all at once.

title: CHANGES ON CANADA'S WALL ST.
description: With its partnerships, its old money and its easy arrogance, Bay Street, the hub of the Canadian securities industry here, is reminiscent of Wall Street a decade or two ago. But like Wall Street, Bay Steet is changing its staid ways. ''The game is over for the private club,'' said Austin Taylor, chairman of McLeod Young Weir Ltd., the country's fifth-biggest securities firm and a respected member of the old guard.

title: NATIONAL CONVENIENCE STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Market Place; How Investors Sniff Out News
description: ONE of the most talked about events on Wall Street last week was something that did not take place. Two top-ranking BankAmerica officials unexpectedly canceled a meeting with financial analysts, and this led to widespread speculation, and headlines, that the troubled financial institution was about to be acquired.

title: TIGERS SHUT OUT RED SOX
description: Jack Morris pitched a three-hitter for his league-leading fourth shutout, and John Grubb and Lou Whitaker each had a home run as the Detroit Tigers beat the Boston Red Sox, 5-0, tonight to salvage the final game of a four-game series.

title: V.A. TO REDUCE HOSPITALS' UNITS IN HEART SURGERY
description: A special panel has found that many of the Veterans Administration's heart surgery units have been performing so few operations that mortality rates were above normal in some cases, and V.A. officials said today that about one-third of them would be closed.

title: Flying High
description: This summer has been a joy for Rob Dromerhauser, a 23-year-old bachelor from Bay Shore, L.I., who works for the Baltimore Orioles. In his second year as a baseball professional, he stays at fine hotels, dines at quality restaurants and hangs out with major league players.

title: 'MOST DANGEROUS SCHOOLS' IN NEW YORK MAY BE THE SAFER SCHOOLS

description: In a normal year, acorns begin to fall here in late October. But in this year of heat and drought, many began to fall in July, creating a situation that could hurt the region's wildlife.

description: ''The Hunt for Red October,'' Tom Clancy's 1985 best seller about a Soviet submarine commander's attempt to defect to the United States, received the kind of reviews most first novelists only dream about. But the remark the author cherishes most was not necessarily intended as a compliment.

description: A State Department official said today that proposed Congressional cuts in spending for international affairs would have devastating effects on national security.

description: In marked contrast with last August, water levels at New York City's reservoirs are ''significantly above normal,'' according to the city's Department of Environmental Protection.

description: After months of adversity that made him the object of both sympathy and ridicule, Adlai Stevenson 3d appears to have revived his troubled campaign for Governor.

description: At least 18 Brooklyn residents, subpoenaed to testify on the challenge to Abraham Hirschfeld's petitions, rode a bus to Albany yesterday, their enthusiasm for democracy apparently tarnished.

description: Cleveland's irrepressible Indians, scrapping to stay alive in the American League East race, were sabotaged by the enemy within last night. The enemy, disguised as the Indians' relief corps, snatched a victory from the grasp of Phil Niekro and handed it to the Yankees.

title: BECK OF RANGERS WILL SEEK TRADE
description: The gathering today was to have been a simple one, the new general manager and the head coach meeting with reporters for an informal talk over lunch. But the talk now promises to develop into yet another dramatic news conference in a Ranger offseason marked by drama.

title: Juror: Maryland 'Clean'
description: A member of the grand jury that investigated the death of Len Bias, the Maryland basketball star, said today that ''the team as a whole looks pretty clean.''

title: CONGRESS; Another New Twist To the Games That The PAC Men Play
description: Harriett Woods, the Democratic candidate for Senator from Missouri, was in Washington recently to raise money for her campaign. One morning a small group of contributors paid $1,000 each to have breakfast with her.

title: INDIA SAYS CARBIDE WITHHELD ITS FINDINGS ON BHOPAL CASE
description: The Government of India said yesterday that it had not been told by the Union Carbide Corporation that the company suspected an individual of sabotaging its Bhopal chemical plant.

description: New York State's Chief Judge lashed out last night at politicians, including Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York, who blame judges for the failures of the criminal justice system to curb drug-related crime.

title: THE PROBLEM WAS IN THE CABLES
description: Last week's column ended with the quandary that resulted when, preparatory to reviewing a new telecommunications package, I hooked together a computer and a modem and loaded the software only to find that, while everything was in working order, nothing functioned.

The bonds are rated Aa by Moody's and AA+ by S.& P.

title: MENTAL IMAGES: NEW RESEARCH HELPS CLARIFY THEIR ROLE
description: Mental images can be so fleeting, lasting in some instances mere hundreths of a second, that even the person creating the image may be unaware that a picture has come and gone. For scientists, this imagery has been so elusive that studying it seemed a most unpromising pursuit.

title: 4 Escape From Jersey Prison
description: Four inmates, including a convicted murderer, escaped from the medium-security Leesburg State Prison tonight by cutting through the bars of a cell window and two chain-link fences, authorities said. The escape occurred about 8:30 P.M., while most of the prison's more than 800 inmates were either in their cells or in indoor recreational facilities, a Corrections Department spokesman, James Stabile, said. The inmates, who fled into the sparsely populated Pine Barrens that surround the compound, were detected by an infrared alarm when they left the housing unit, he said.

description: A report delivered to the Senate Judiciary Committee today discloses that Associate Justice William H. Rehnquist used increasing doses of a prescribed hypnotic drug from 1972 to 1981 to ease the pain from severe back problems, according to Congressional officials.

description: Exotic, colorfully plumed birds, imported from the Southern Hemisphere to be sold as pets, are thriving throughout southern Florida, to the delight of bird watchers but to the distress of biologists and game wardens who see the birds as potentially dangerous intruders.

description: Fresh from a five-day fact-finding tour of Angola, Mayor Andrew Young of Atlanta will hold a news conference on Capitol Hill this morning to denounce covert United States aid to anti-Communist rebels in that country.

description: Viktor V. Dementsev, chairman of the State Bank, said today that Soviet citizens had given $700 million to a fund to aid the victims of the Chernobyl nuclear disaster.

title: WROTE OF AND STUDIED THE MING DYNASTY
description: Dr. L. Carrington Goodrich, a leading scholar of the Ming Dynasty and the Dean Lung professor emeritus of Chinese at Columbia University, died of a heart attack Sunday in Yonkers. He was 91 years old and lived in the Bronx.

title: Former Libyan Diplomat Is Released in Rome
description: A former Libyan diplomat, who is suspected of organizing terrorist actions here, was released from jail today over the protests of investigating magistrates.

DEMOCRATS' IDEAS ON ECONOMY SHIFT
description: Many leading Democrats, including some Presidential aspirants, are reaching for new themes in economic and industrial policy that depart sharply from those the party has stressed for decades.

Dwight Faulkner Dies; An Investment Banker
description: Dwight F. Faulkner, a vice chairman and director of Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc., died Thursday of cancer at Sharon (Conn.) Hospital. He was 60 years old and lived in Sharon.

title: Reagan's Conference Set for TV and Radio
description: President Reagan's news conference tonight will be broadcast live at 8 P.M. on the ABC, CBS and NBC television networks, and on CNN, the Cable News Network.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article Aug. 2 about the relocation of television network offices in New York misstated the plans of NBC to move. Its leases at 30 Rockefeller Plaza begin to expire in 1994, and while the network intends to relocate its studios and production facilities, no moving date has been set.

title: CUOMO PUSH ON HIRSCHFELD'S PETITIONS WOULD BE AN EXPENSIVE ONE TO LOSE
description: Many politicians do not take Abraham Hirschfeld's candidacy seriously. Governor Cuomo does. So seriously, in fact, that by mounting a major effort to knock Mr. Hirschfeld out of the Democratic primary for lieutenant governor, the Cuomo forces have taken a calculated and expensive political risk. Their effort to deny Mr. Hirschfeld a place on the Sept. 9 primary ballot has already involved hundreds of campaign workers, including many state employees who say they are working on their own time, lawyers and process servers. It has involved the checking of thousands of voter registration records, the subpoening and busing of witnesses yesterday from New York City to State Supreme Court in Albany and court orders keeping Board of Elections employees working on weekday and weekend overtime.

title: Boesky Acquires Robertshaw Stake
description: The New York investor Ivan F. Boesky has purchased a 5.8 percent stake in the Robertshaw Controls Company. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Boesky said that he had acquired the Robertshaw shares ''in connection with merger arbitrage and other investment activities.''

title: Hirschfeld Donates $550,000 To Aid His Primary Campaign
description: Abraham Hirschfeld has received one donation in the last month - for $50 - while pumping $550,000 of his own money into his bid for the Democratic nomination for lieutenant governor, financial statements showed today.

title: 7 Unions Map Frontier Plan
description: Seven union locals are working on a joint strategy for their role in United Airlines' planned takeover of Frontier Airlines. The acquisition has been blocked by a dispute over proposed lower wages for Frontier workers absorbed by United.

title: THE CAPITAL SPENDING SLUMP
description: When the International Business Machines Corporation announced a sharp drop in second-quarter earnings last month, it blamed larger economic forces. Capital spending by all corporations is down, I.B.M. said, and that means I.B.M.'s customers are not buying as many computers as before.

title: Philippine Rebels Reject Conditions for Talks
description: Representatives of the National Democratic Front, the Communist rebel group, rejected the Philippine military's conditions for giving them safe conduct to attend cease-fire negotiations with the Government.

Brennan Jr. of the Supreme Court misstated the circumstances of his speech at the convention of the American Bar Association. title: Stay of Execution in Texas
description: A Federal district judge issued a stay of execution today for a man who had been scheduled to die Wednesday for the rape and murder of a student at Angelo State University, court officials said. The judge, David Belew, issued the stay without comment for Randy Dale Mayo, 26 years old, who was convicted in the April 13, 1984, rape, stabbing and beating death of Kimberly Sue Reeves.

title: FOR MEN, BRITISH TRADITION
description: ''It feels like home,'' Ashley Lloyd-Jennings, the English clothier, said as he inspected the details - an antique hat stretcher, a pair of riding boots made for Edward VIII, brass racks and striped wallpaper - the decor of the first Hackett boutique outside London. The shop opens Thursday at Bergdorf Goodman.

description: IN recent months, many directors have hesitated to serve on corporate boards because it has become so expensive or difficult to obtain insurance to protect against personal liability from lawsuits filed by shareholders or others.

title: THE THEATER: 'LADY WITH A VIEW'
description: ALTHOUGH the Statue of Liberty has been exhaustively extolled from the four corners of the land this summer, nowhere have its praises been sung more vociferously than in ''Lady With a View,'' a show written by Eduardo Ivan Lopez, with music and lyrics by Fernando Rivas. The musical (''Una Dama Con Vision'' in Spanish), which is touring the metropolitan area under the auspices of the New York-based Puerto Rican Traveling Theater, treats the familiar symbol of freedom almost as a religious icon - in one scene, the statue's physical dimensions are intoned with the sort of awed solemnity normally reserved for those of a phenomenon like Mount Everest.

title: European Air Travel Is Down
description: European airline passenger traffic fell 1.7 percent in the first half of 1986 from the period a year earlier, but cargo traffic rose 8.6 percent, the Association of European Airlines said today.

title: CJI INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said in the latest periods preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income.

title: SOUTHERN GOVERNORS ASK U.S. TO SHORE UP AILING INDUSTRIES
description: A panel of Democratic and Republican governors from the South pressed the White House today to protect the region's traditional industries from cheap foreign imports, despite President Reagan's opposition to trade barriers.

title: Yehoshua Cohen Dies; Linked to '48 Killing
description: Yehoshua Cohen, a member of the pre-independence Israeli underground whom historians have linked to the assassination in 1948 of a United Nations mediator, Count Folke Bernadotte, has died, the Israeli news agency Itim reported today. Mr. Cohen was 64 years old.

title: Local Government Use Of Taxable Bonds Rises
description: Local government authorities, which normally sell tax-exempt bonds whose interest is not subject to Federal income tax, are increasing their use of the taxable bond market.

David Dominelli, the San Diego financier who defrauded investors of over $120 million. Also sued were the law firms of Rogers & Wells; Wiles, Circuit & Tremblay, and Abramson & Fox.

description: Infants born infected with the AIDS virus who are carriers of the AIDS virus often have similar facial malformations, according researchers who conducted a study last year at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine in the Bronx.

description: Cold, hungry and crowded into two lifeboats, 152 men, women and children were spotted through the fog off Newfoundland yesterday and picked up by three Canadian fishing boats. They said they had been adrift for five days, the Canadian Coast Guard reported.

title: AIDS SAY EDUCATION CUTS WILL FINANCE DRUG PLAN
description: Education Department programs would be cut back to provide funds for the Reagan Administration's proposed $100 million program to combat drug use by schoolchildren, officials said today.

title: Soviet Commander Named
description: East Germany identified the new commander of the 400,000 Soviet troops in East Germany today as Gen. Valery A. Belikov, who has commanded the Carpathian Military District in the southwestern Soviet Union since 1979. General Belikov is replacing Gen. Pyotr G. Lushev.

title: BURGER SUMS UP TENURE IN LAST SPEECH IN OFFICE
description: In his final address to the American Bar Association as this nation's Chief Justice, Warren E. Burger offered a review of some of the major themes he has sounded before: opposition to advertising by lawyers, concern about the contingency fee system and chagrin at the behavior of some lawyers after the Bhopal industrial accident.

Japan Posts Trade Record
description: Japan announced a new record monthly trade surplus today, shattering any prospect of a quick reversal in its top-heavy trading account with the rest of the world.

title: COURT BARS DRUG TESTING OF TEACHERS
description: A state appellate court - in a case that represents the first major test in New York of mandatory drug tests for public employees -ruled yesterday that probationary teachers in a Long Island district cannot be compelled to submit to urine tests for drugs.

title: Kennedy Center Names Six to Lifetime Awards
description: The Kennedy Center today announced the recipients of its ninth annual honors for lifetime achievement in the performing arts, for the first time picking someone who was born as late as 1930, the blues-gospel singer Ray Charles.

title: F.B.I. CHIEF HAILS GAINS ON TERROR
description: William H. Webster, Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said yesterday that by applying ''lawful techniques,'' the bureau has been ''extraordinarily successful'' in reducing incidents of terrorism in the United States in the last six years. He added, ''Those principles can be applied on the international stage.''

title: POLAND RELEASES A JAILED ACTIVIST
description: Adam Michnik, the 39-year-old historian and Solidarity adviser, was released from prison today under a limited amnesty, according to opposition sources.

title: Bridge: New Instructional Program For Apple II Is Being Shown
description: A quantum leap in the technique of bridge instruction was provided last year by Random House. Advanced students who loaded the company's ''Tournament Bridge'' program onto a personal computer found themselves forced to rely on skill: luck would never save them.

title: GOODEN WINS 12TH
description: Dwight Gooden won No. 12 and the Mets won No. 75 tonight, and then Dave Johnson sat back and considered the joys of being 40 games over the .500 mark and said, with a little smile and a lot of greed: ''I'd like to be 50 over.''

title: Perils of Deferring S.D.I.
description: PRESIDENT Reagan's announcement last week that he remains committed to the eventual deployment of strategic defenses deserves applause. But there are some of us who fear that S.D.I. - the Strategic Defense Initiative - still won't happen. The reason we're worried is that Mr. Reagan has also reportedly offered to defer deployment of any American defenses against Soviet missiles for five to seven years.

title: Teams Talk to Foster
description: George Foster, who was released by the Mets last week after a controversy involving race, said yesterday that his representatives had spoken to the Chicago White Sox and Detroit Tigers.

title: New York's Federal Traffic Jam
description: The Verrazano-Narrows Bridge across the mouth of New York harbor from Staten Island to Brooklyn is a local structure built with local financing. Yet thanks to the meddling of Senator Alfonse D'Amato of New York and Representative Guy Molinari, representing Staten Island, its toll collections are controlled by no less a figure than the Secretary of Transportation in Washington.

description: Foote, Cone & Belding Communications said that its second-quarter net income fell 13.3 percent, to $5.2 million, or $1.24 a share, from $6 million, or $1.44 a share, in the corresponding period last year.

description: Keith Hernandez, the Mets' first baseman who hit .429 with 2 home runs and 12 runs batted in, was named the National League's Player of the Week, the league office announced yesterday.

title: Article 534586 -- No Title
description: The International Paper Company agreed yesterday to acquire the Hammermill Paper Company for $1.1 billion in a deal that would create one of the nation's largest forest products companies.

description: Stephen M. Wolf, who took Republic Airlines from the brink of bankruptcy to profitability, has been appointed chairman, chief executive officer and president of Flying Tiger Line in Los Angeles and a director of its parent company.

title: U.S.-WEST GERMANY RATE PLAN SEEN
description: Central bankers of the United States and West Germany have agreed to consider a coordinated round of interest rate cuts in September to spur economic growth, a senior German official said today.

title: National Medical To Buy Its Stock
description: National Medical Enterprises, which two months ago announced a major restructuring of its businesses, said it would buy back 10 million shares, or nearly one-eighth of its stock. The stock repurchase was valued at $216.2 million based on today's closing price of $21.625, up 25 cents.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Ameritech Publishing Inc., Troy, Mich., said it had acquired a portion of American Telephone and Telegraph Co.'s overseas directory marketing business. Terms were not disclosed.

title: SQUID REVEALS ENGINE DRIVING THE INTERNAL TRANSPORTATION SYSTEM OF CELLS
description: Aided by an extremely powerful video-assisted magnification system applied to nerve fibers of squid, researchers have discovered the protein that acts as a main engine for internal transportation in the nerve cells of those, and perhaps all, higher animals.

title: COLLEGE BOARD, TEST SPONSOR, CHOOSES ITS NEXT PRESIDENT
description: Donald M. Stewart, the 48-year-old president of Spelman College in Atlanta, has been named the next president of the College Board. He will succeed George H. Hanford, who is retiring, in early 1987.

title: INDIA ON ALERT BUT QUIET AFTER SLAYING
description: Security forces were on a high state of alert today after the assassination Sunday of a retired Indian Army Chief of Staff just days after he received a death threat purportedly sent by Sikh extremists.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, AUGUST 12, 1986
description: Companies

title: Cut Some Fat Out of Davis-Bacon
description: Should Uncle Sam offer construction workers a special boost to keep their wages high? Yes, Congress said in 1931, when rural blacks displaced by the Depression began to compete for urban construction jobs. The Davis-Bacon Act required contractors on federally funded construction to pay the ''prevailing wage.''

description: b-Net income

description: These share earnings do not reflect the July 1986 share split.

title: NASA EXPERTS DESIGN NEW SHUTTLE ROCKET
description: Engineers have developed a new solid rocket engine design that will prevent a failure like the one that caused the explosion aboard the space shuttle Challenger, according to an engineer at the space agency.

title: BUT AREN'T TRUTH AND BEAUTY SUPPOSED TO BE ENOUGH?
description: Could the mathematicians, winners of the most prestigious awards of their discipline, please tell the audience what their work is good for?

title: Mars Acquires The Dove Bar
description: Mars Inc., the candy maker, confirmed yesterday that it had acquired Dove Bar International Inc., which makes the popular hand-dipped ice cream bar. Terms were not disclosed.

title: I.B.M. CUTS PC PRICES FOR DIRECT SALE
description: Stepping up its battle against low-price competitors, the International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it had lowered the price of its five-year-old personal computer by 20 percent for customers who buy directly from I.B.M.

title: BRIEFING; To Philadelphia
description: To celebrate the bicentennial of the compromise that established the formula for popular representation, the two houses of Congress may hold a joint commemorative session in Philadelphia, birthplace of both the nation and its lawmaking bodies, next July 16.

description: PLAYING chess against a computer is often a game for masters and masochists.

title: Redskins Eye Williams
description: The Washington Redskins announced yesterday they have acquired the National Football League rights to Doug Williams, a former N.F.L. quarterback, from the Tampa Bay Buccaneers.

title: CHECKROBOT INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The company said it is a development stage company which was organized in April 1985 by Sensormatic Electronics Corp. to continue the development, production and marketing of the Expressit self-checkout system.

description: A table in Business Day on Friday with an article about the banking industry's second-quarter earnings stated some incorrect figures that were supplied by the banks for the loan quality and change in earnings of the 15 largest banks. Corrected tables appear today on page D22.

CANADIAN PACIFIC
description: Canadian Pacific Ltd. said it would buy its Algoma Steel Corporation unit's stake in Amca International for $193.4 million (Canadian). Algoma Steel owns 11.7 million shares of Amca, or 34.5 percent. Canadian Pacific owns 61 percent of Algoma Steel and 16.1 percent of Amca.

title: A Malfunction Brings Shoreham Shutdown
description: The Shoreham nuclear power plant, where low-level testing is being conducted, was shut down today because of a malfunctioning water-level instrument inside the reactor that was giving inaccurate readings.

title: SPEECH IN SCHOOLS: HOW FREE?
description: CONTROVERSY over obscenity, pornography and constitutional protection of free speech and publication has raised questions over what students in public schools may say and what publications may be sold at college bookstores.

title: WON WIMBLEDON TITLE IN '63
description: Chuck McKinley, described by his one-time United States Davis Cup captain, Judge Robert Kelleher, as ''the toughest little guy with the sweetest nature I've ever known,'' died yesterday in Dallas of brain cancer, only a month after he was inducted into the Tennis Hall of Fame in Newport, R.I. He was 45 years old.

title: HEALTHCARE INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $430,000 related to the refinancing of indebtedness.

title: Hess, in Letter, Says He Is in Severe Pain
description: Hitler's former deputy, Rudolf Hess, 92 years old, has told his family that he is in severe pain because of a hernia and cannot sleep at night, according to excerpts from a letter published today.

title: Texas Power Bond Yield Set
description: The Texas Municipal Power Agency is tentatively offering $95 million of electric revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 8.20 percent for an 8 percent issue due 2012 at a price of 97.861 through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: 9-10 PICK WINNER IN DIANA
description: Duty Dance looped the field from far back and went on to score a 1 1/4-length victory over Dismasted in the $129,800 Diana Handicap today at Saratoga.

description: b-Net income

CUOMO SEES PERIL IN PICKING JUDGES ON IDEOLOGY BASIS
description: Declaring that Federal judges were being selected on the basis of their political ideology, not on merit, Governor Cuomo warned yesterday that the practice potentially posed ''a grave danger'' that could ultimately undermine public confidence in the courts.

title: U.S. MAY BACK SOME CHANGES IN ALIENS LAW
description: The Reagan Administration said today it still opposed sweeping changes in a law that excludes aliens on ideological grounds, but the Administration offered to work with Congress on more modest changes.

title: COURT VOIDS PRETORIA'S DETENTION LAWS
description: A provincial supreme court ruled today that the parts of South Africa's emergency decree permitting detention without trial and for indefinite periods were invalid.

title: SIM-KAR LIGHTING FIXTURE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GIANTS SCREENING ROOKIE DEFENDERS
description: With their training-camp squad reduced by dismissal of 10 players today, the Giants settled into two weeks of intense work that will go far in deciding the defensive makeup of the team, according to Coach Bill Parcells.

title: BUEHLER INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary credits of $445,000 and $782,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Partners National Sets Acquisition
description: American Medcenters Inc. said it had agreed to be acquired by Partners National Health Plans for $41 million, or $8.50 a share.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: A NEW LOOK Whippoorwill is a new jazz club at 18 East 18th Street (675-7100) in a neighborhood being transformed not to jazz but to the sleek restaurants patronized by young upwardly mobiles. It is not a precinct that has any jazz tradition in the way Greenwich Village and midtown Manhattan have. It is a zone of old buildings and new establishments with a night life that tends to eating and music that may be lively but is mostly not live.

title: CONFEREES READY FOR SHOWDOWN
description: Beginning what may be the climactic week of negotiations on tax revision legislation, House and Senate conferees remained at odds on several important issues today and made plans to start bargaining face to face Tuesday.

title: LIFE INVESTORS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $5,053,000 for the quarter and $6,541,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes realized investment gains of $593,000 and $1,739,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: DIAGNOSTIC-RETRIEVAL SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
VIATECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: LOEWS INCREASES ITS STAKE IN CBS
description: The Loews Corporation, the largest shareholder in CBS Inc., increased its stake in the company yesterday to almost 25 percent. This raised new questions about future control of the network at a time when it is struggling against dwindling revenues and its weakened standing in entertainment and news ratings.

title: CARDINAL DISTRIBUTION INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
TWAY WINS PGA WITH BIRDIE SAND SHOT AT 18TH
description: Bob Tway holed a 25-foot bunker shot on the final hole today for a birdie to win the 68th PGA Championship. Tway's victory stunned Greg Norman, who had led the tournament for the first three rounds and was four shots ahead of Tway with eight holes remaining.

title: TRANSAMERICA AGREES TO SELL BUDGET RENT A CAR
description: The Transamerica Corporation said today that it had agreed to sell the Budget Rent a Car Corporation, the nation's fourth-largest car rental concern for $205 million in cash and the assumption of Budget's $296 million of debt. The buyer is a new company formed by Gibbons, Green, vanAmerongen Ltd., an investment banker specializing in leveraged buyouts.

title: ALTERNACARE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $17,000 and $48,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net income

title: NEW 'PRISONER OF ZENDA' IS PRESENTED ON A&E
description: ''THE PRISONER OF ZENDA'' is a trifle. It has been ever since it was published in 1894. Nonetheless, it is a trifle, so to speak, of consequence; it seems to insist on enduring. Ruritania, the country where it takes place, is part of the public imagination. We can see Ruritania again, in a three-part ''Prisoner of Zenda,'' beginning on the Arts & Entertainment network at 8 tonight.

title: K MART STORES PRESIDENT WILL RETIRE IN FEBRUARY
description: When Norman G. Milley, the president of K Mart Stores Group, began working full time for the S. S. Kresge Company more than 40 years ago, he earned $21 a week and worked 60 hours.

title: McEnroe Team Wins
description: John McEnroe, beaten in the singles semifinal of the $315,000 Volvo International tennis tournamment last week, his first competition since he ended his vacation from competitive tennis, teamed with Peter Fleming yesterday to win the doubles honors. McEnroe and Fleming, playing together for the first time in a year, defeated Paul Annacone and Christo Van Rensburg of South Africa, 6-3, 3-6, 6-3.

title: ENDOTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $100,507 and $303,140 for the quarter ad 9 months, respectively. c-Net loss

title: U.S.-SOVIET PARLEY ON ARMS IS OPENED IN A MOSCOW VILLA
description: American and Soviet arms-control officials met here today for eight hours in talks that the chief American negotiator called ''serious'' and ''exploratory.''

title: Bush Joins in Drug Testing
description: Testing for drugs began in earnest at the White House today, with Vice President Bush and an undisclosed number of Presidential aides taking part. President Reagan took the test Saturday before traveling to Bethesda Naval Hospital for a urological examination. Larry Speakes, the White House spokesman, refused to say how many aides had volunteered, and said results would be kept confidential.

title: REAGAN TO PRESS MEXICO ON DRUG FIGHT, AIDE SAYS
description: President Reagan, who is to meet this week with President Miguel de la Madrid, will urge the Mexican leader to undertake greater efforts to curb narcotics trafficking, a ranking Administration official said today.

title: THERMO ELECTRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TEAM INC reports earnings for Year to May 31
description: The loss for fiscal 1986 is after a writedown of $1,292,000 on property, plant and equipment.

title: Toyota to Stress U.S. Production
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation, the leading seller of imported cars in the United States, will increase emphasis on North American manufacturing to meet demand, company officials said.

title: EMPIRE OF CAROLINA INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BENIGN VIEW OF BLACK BEARS
description: Teddy bears, bear hugs, Smokey the Bear and Care Bears notwithstanding, in the popular mind bears are dangerous, even ferocious animals that readily attack unsuspecting humans.

title: THE FOSTER CLOUD
description: George Foster called a news conference yesterday because ''a cloud'' had come over his life, he said, and he wanted to ''clear the air.'' The conference was held at Shea Stadium, and he was joined in front of the cameras and pencils by Frank Cashen, the bow-tied general manager of the Mets.

title: PATIENT TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a charge of $43,000 from the reversal of a tax credit. c-After a loss of $97,000 from discontinued operations.

title: VIETNAMESE REVIVE ANCIENT MEDICAL ARTS
description: The Vietnamese, short of medicines, medical equipment and the money to buy them, are reviving and encouraging the use of the country's ancient healing arts.

title: Lefty K's
description: Steve Carlton, whose retirement announcement last Wednesday came one day after he joined Nolan Ryan (4,209) as the only major league pitchers to reach 4,000 strikeouts, is by far baseball's top left-hander in that department.

title: COMPUTER LANGUAGE REEARCH reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: CORRECTION
description: A diagram accompanying an article in Science Times Aug. 5 on heart research contained an incorrect description. The aorta was incorrectly identified as the right atrium.

title: OPERA: SANTA FE OFFERS 'AGYPTISCHE HELENA'
description: Richard Strauss was fascinated by matrimony - its appearances and realities -and two of his loveliest minor works are devoted to these mysteries. ''Intermezzo,'' staged here by the Santa Fe Opera two years ago, plants both feet firmly in the middle class, recalling quasi-autobiographically a rupture Strauss had experienced with his own wife.

title: WHITTAKER BUYBACK PLAN LIFTS STOCK ABOVE $33
description: The price of the Whittaker Corporation's stock jumped yesterday by $6.125 a share, to $33.375, as investors responded to the company's plan for a buyback of up to nearly half of its 12.9 million common shares outstanding.

title: U.S. VESSEL ESCORTS CRAB BOATS
description: Fishing boats accompanied by the Coast Guard entered a disputed area of the Bering Sea today to retrieve crab pots that were abandoned after they were pursued by Soviet craft.

title: Skylines and the Balance of Power
description: If there is anything that distinguishes the capital from every other major city in America, it is the absence of a skyline.

title: CARE ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Twelve Words vs. a Presidential Candidacy
description: To the Editor:

SFM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

AMERICAN PASSAGE MARKETNG reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said it revised previously reported figures for the first half of 1986, as a result of the discovery of clerical errors and adjustments in its method of recognizing certain revenue. The effect of the adjustment was to reduce net income for the 6-month ended March 31 to $366,000, or 12 cents a share, from $387,000, or 13 cents a share. Revenue for the 6-month period was revised downward to $11,954,000 from $12,049,000 as previously reported.

title: 'Most Dangerous Schools' in New York May Be the Safer Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: DOW RISES BY 28.54, TO 1,811.16
description: Stock prices surged ahead yesterday, propelled by falling interest rates and buying programs sparked by positive index futures figures. Only a relatively low trading volume marred the strong daylong advance.

title: Taiwan, U.S. Settle Trade Rift
description: The United States and Taiwan have settled a customs valuation dispute that Washington said artificially raised Taiwan's duties on imports by more than $217 million, the White House announced today.

title: COSMO COMMUNICATONS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.S., IN TALKS WITH AUSTRALIA, BARS DEFENSE OF NEW ZEALAND
description: The United States announced today that it was formally suspending its military obligations to New Zealand under the Anzus treaty because of New Zealand's refusal to allow American ships carrying nuclear weapons into its ports.

title: CLAYTON HOMES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 5-for-4 stock split paid in May.

title: 200 Jobs Cut By Micro Devices
description: Advanced Micro Devices Inc., a leading semiconductor manufacturer, has yielded to economic hardship and ended its no-layoff policy.

title: FLORIDA ROCK & TANK LINES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FIRST CONNECTICUT SMALL BUSINESS INVESTMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

MOORE FINANCIAL GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The loss is the result of an increase in the allowance for credit losses for Idaho First National Bank of $22 million.

title: Careers; A Human Element in Designing
description: MORE and more, H.F.'s and I.D.'s are teaming up to meet customer needs. H.F.'s are human factors experts, skilled in psychology, and I.D.'s are industrial designers, expert in designing products.

title: CALIFORNIA REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes gains on the sale of real estate of $1,085,000 for the quarter and $1,170,000 for the 6 months.

title: BETSY WYETH TALKS OF HELGA, ART AND THE MEANING OF 'LOVE'
description: Betsy Wyeth, the wife of the artist Andrew Wyeth, said yesterday that when she said her husband's paintings of the model Helga where about love, she meant ''the love for hills, the love for breathing, the love for storms and snows.''

title: LONG-SOUGHT I-78 LINK TO EASE JERSEY TRAVEL
description: The long-delayed, 5.5-mile ''missing link'' of Interstate 78 is finished now - right down to its elevated pathways for horses and wild animals - and is scheduled to open Wednesday.

title: NEW WORLD PICTURES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary tax credit of $495,000, or 5 cents a share.

title: New Report Sets Limit on Neutrino Mass
description: SEEKING to determine whether the elusive subatomic particles called electron neutrinos are sufficiently massive to cause ultimate collapse of the universe, researchers at the Los Alamos National Laboratory in New Mexico have reported that those particles can have only an extremely small mass, even smaller than had been postulated earlier.

title: ELECTROMEDICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: End to the Berlin Wall Advocated by Reagan
description: President Reagan says that East Germany should dismantle the Berlin wall and that its continued existence ''will remain a burden on our relations with those regimes responsible for it,'' according to an interview made public today.

title: 'THE FATHER,' BY STRINDBERG, ON A&E
description: NOBODY has been able to report from the front lines of the war between the sexes with the vehemence of August Strindberg, the Swedish writer whose naturalism so shocked Western thinking at the turn of the century. ''The Father,'' which is not often given a staging these days, receives a formidably dramatic one on the Arts & Entertainment cable channel at 9 P.M. today and at 1 A.M. Wednesday. ''The Father'' wastes no time on subtleties. The battle lines are clearly delineated from the opening lines and the action is never confused. The Captain, living in a country house in Sweden, is a man who has given up his army career to devote himself to his family, his scientific research and the dominating role such a man was accustomed to back then, in 1887. His only complaint is that his household is filled with dominating women - his wife, his daughter, his childhood nurse, his mother-in-law.

title: NATIONAL CONTROLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $128,000 and $253,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes tax credits of $117,000 and $238,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. Results for 1985 include a $400,000 pre-tax payment received in settlement of litigation.

title: HELMS SAYS INTELLIGENCE AGENCIES MAY HAVE SPIED ON HIM IN CHILE
description: Senator Jesse Helms today asked the Justice Department to determine whether the Central Intelligence Agency or other intelligence services had spied on him and his staff when they went to Chile last month.

title: WOMEN IN NEW YORK POLITICS FIND FAST TRACK HAS SLOWED
description: New York was once filled with women who were coming on so fast and so strong in politics that the elections could not arrive quickly enough.

title: BUFFETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 16
Q&A
description: Q. How are 3-D or three-dimensional movies made? A. To produce a 3-D or stereographic movies, pictures of the same scene are taken from two viewpoints, one about two inches to one side of the other, according to John Brumage, a consulting engineer for the Marks Polarized Corporation, one of the largest makers of 3-D glasses. The two pictures are superimposed on a screen, where moviegoers view them using the glasses, which are made of a polarizing material that separates the images.

title: NEW ROLE FOR WOMEN: NUNS GUIDE A BROOKLYN PARISH
description: Three nuns run All Saints Roman Catholic Church in a rather poor parish in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn.

title: 188 YEARS AFTER SINKING, H.M.S. DeBRAAK IS RAISED
description: One-hundred and eighty-eight years after she sank in a squall, the British warship H.M.S. deBraak rose from the bottom of Delaware Bay tonight.

title: Test for Drugs? Yes and No
description: Why all the outrage over the President's putting himself, the Vice President and other high officials through urinalysis tests for drug use? Some testing makes sense. The public-policy task is to decide when.

title: Accounts
description: * Landis & Gyr, a products and systems manufacturer based in Switzerland, to Marquardt & Roche, Stamford, Conn.

title: PLANS FOR SPACE SHUTTLES FLOURISH OUTSIDE THE U.S.
description: DESPITE the Challenger disaster and the dark shadow it cast over the American space shuttle program, the idea of reusable vehicles flying to and from orbit continues to appeal to many nations. Their leaders seem to believe that to be a major political and economic power in the 21st century will require fleets of advanced and versatile spaceships, and their engineers are busy giving form to these ambitions.

title: Halliburton to Link Unit With Dresser
description: The Halliburton Company and Dresser Industries, two of the nation's largest oilfield-services concerns, said today that they intend to combine their drilling-fluid divisions in a joint venture, forming the world's largest drilling-fluid operation.

title: Border Patrol Pilot Hurt In Manhunt for Escapee
description: A Border Patrol pilot was critically injured today when his plane crashed in the desert while searching for the last of 16 Cuban prisoners who escaped from a Federal immigration detention center.

title: THE HAMPTONS: ROMANCE AND FESTIVITIES
description: ''This is the worst,'' said Patrick Hanson, standing outside the Parrish Art Museum here Saturday afternoon.

title: PANEL ASSAILS PENTAGON OVER LOSS OF SECRETS
description: At a hearing full of contention today about the loss of 1,400 secret documents, Representative John D. Dingell accused the Defense Department of ''hiding its failures, abuses, cost overruns, late deliveries and general embarrassments behind a screen of national security.''

title: DISPUTED GREEK STATUE TO GO ON EXHIBITION
description: A 2,500-year-old Greek statue with a mysterious past - regarded as one of the most important works of art to have entered the United States since World War II - is scheduled to go on display in October at the J. Paul Getty Museum in Malibu, Calif.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL YANKEES VS. CLEVELAND INDIANS, at Yankee Stadium, 7:30 P.M. (Television - Channel 11, 7:30 P.M., Radio - WABC, 770, 7:30 P.M.) METS VS.

title: Gerald Eskenazi on Pro Football; IN N.F.C., EMERGENCE OF PASSING GAME
description: You like the long pass, the touchdown bomb? Watch the American Football Conference. You want runners? Catch the National Football Conference.

title: Shoulder Belts Urged For Back Seats of Cars
description: The National Transportation Safety Board recommended today that shoulder safety belts be installed in the rear seats of all new automobiles to enhance passenger safety.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: FASHION is change, and this week's fashion news is full of changes. The much-delayed opening of the new women's store at Barneys New York (announced for next Monday) has been delayed again. ''We need a new more weeks,'' said Gene Pressman, the executive vice president at Barneys. The opening is now scheduled for the first week in September - with any luck. ''IT'S like steering the Queen Mary - turn the wheel in 1975, and in 1985, people notice,'' said Nick Hilton, president of Norman Hilton, the 98-year-old label known for its natural-shoulder men's suits.

title: Crying 'Foul' At the Stadium
description: Two baseball fans who claim they were physically assaulted by Yankee security guards and members of the Burns International Security Services' force at Yankee Stadium last month will answer summonses on complaints of disorderly conduct at Bronx Criminal Court on Aug. 20. Both parties have indicated they are contemplating legal action against the Yankees and the Burns organization.

title: HOUSE MOVES TO RETAIN TRAINER JET MADE ON L.I.
description: Taking up its version of the 1987 military programs bill, the House of Representatives voted 213 to 190 today to maintain production of the troubled T-46A trainer aircraft.

title: Togolese Thwart Plan To Attack U.S. Embassy
description: A terrorist attack on the United States Embassy here using explosives sent from Libya has been thwarted with the arrest of nine people and the discovery of the explosives, Togo's Interior Minister said today.

title: Nigerian Bus Crash Kills 72
description: Seventy-two people died and 30 were seriously injured when two buses collided Sunday in the southern Nigerian state of Bendel. A police spokesman, Bayo Balogun, said today that the accident occurred between Benin City and Agbor, 40 miles east of here. He said the exact cause of the accident was not known.

title: U.D.C. CONSIDERS USING 42D ST. THEATERS FOR NONPROFIT TROUPES
description: In what would be a significant change of plan, the head of the State Urban Development Corporation said yesterday that he wanted to convert most of the low-price movie theaters on 42d Street into a center for nonprofit performing-arts groups as part of the Times Square Redevelopment Project.

title: Latin Trade Proposal
description: Latin American countries should form a common market to defend themselves against developed nations' trade barriers and farm export subsidies, Edward Saouma, Director General of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization, said today at a members' meeting.

title: BRIEFING; Peanuts Heard From
description: Some good news emanates from the Southeast amid one of the worst droughts of the century.

title: INTERNATIONAL CONTAINER SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $59,531, or 3 cents a share.

title: Less Phosphorus Found in Water
description: The amount of phosphorus entering sewage treatment plants near Washington, D.C., has declined by 72 percent since Maryland banned detergents containing phosphate, according to a report published today.

title: U.S. IS QUESTIONED ON '79 ARMS PACT
description: The chairman of the House intelligence committee has challenged Reagan Administration allegations that the Soviet Union has not adhered to the strategic arms treaty of 1979.

title: ASTROCOM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
METROPOLITAN FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company went public in November 1985 and did not report per share earnings for the year-ago periods.

description: b-After net realized investment gains of $71,978 for the quarter and $102,291 for the 6 months. c-After net realized investment gains of $1,771 for the quarter and investment losses of $3,230 for the 6 months.

title: ENSECO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a tax credit of $527,000 for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Net income The acquisitions of California Analytical Labs and Rocky Mountain Analytical Labs in June are accounted for on a pooling-of-interest basis.

title: Rights Group Faults Guatemala for Patrols
description: A Guatemalan program of rural security patrols is being used as an instrument of Government oppression, Americas Watch, a New York-based human-rights group, charged in a report released today.

title: AS HOSTS, SENATORS ARE READY, WILLING BUT HARRIED
description: Senator Christopher J. Dodd made a big mistake the other day. His staff forewarned him, but he just would not listen. Against better advice, on his way to an important committee meeting, he walked through the reception area of his office.

title: Hubris, Not an Iceberg, Sank the Titanic
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: A review of the film ''Maximum Overdrive,'' in Weekend on July 25, misidentified the actor playing ''the noble blond boy.'' He is Holter Graham.

title: U.S. WILL EMPHASIZE POSITIVE AT MEETINGS
description: A few years ago, when unrest in Central America threatened to explode and the regional crisis was the prime topic of talks between Mexico and United States, a high-ranking Mexican official suggested ruefully that perhaps his country needed to do something awful to attract American attention to its problems.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 13, 1986
description: Markets

title: New Drug Penalties Urged
description: The City Council majority leader, Peter F. Vallone, yesterday called for five-year mandatory jail sentences for drug dealers and the creation of a bounty system to encourage citizens to report such criminals. Mr. Vallone made the statements during a City Hall news conference to announce that the City Council would hold public hearings on the city's drug problems.

title: PASSAGE FORESEEN ON BUDGET DEVICE
description: House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. predicted today that the House would approve a proposal this fall for a new mechanism to make Federal spending cuts automatic.

title: Xerox Announces A New President
description: The Xerox Corporation named a president and a vice chairman yesterday. At the same time, the chairman and chief executive, David T. Kearns, said he planned to follow the established company practice of giving up the job of chief executive when he turns 60 in 1990.

title: BRIEFING; Mark Your Calendars
description: The nation's celebration of the 200th birthdayaof the Constitution on Sept. 17, 1987, will be followed by a series of state observances, beginning with a Ratification Ball in Delaware the following Dec. 7, the anniversary of that state's approval of the Constitution, which was the first.

title: JETS' PASSERS SEEK PROTECTION
description: While everyone waits for the Jets to forge an offensive line, the quarterbacks get battered.

title: WINE TALK
description: IN the hierarchy of wines, those born of a so-called noble grape occupy the throne. The aristocrat in West German vineyards is riesling, which aptly reigns near castles high above the Rhine. In France, on the slopes of the Vosges, the grape is ranked the ''king of Alsace.''

title: ENTEX ENERGY DEVELOPMENT LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The company said the latest quarter and 6-month period includes a $14.7 million writedown relating to oil and gas properties.

title: KEY TRONIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the latest quarter loss is attributable to a $2.1 million writeoff associated with the previously disclosed planned closure of its Newport, Washington, manufacturing facility.

title: DROUGHT EFFORTS DEFENDED BY AIDE
description: A Federal agriculture official told Southern governors today that the Reagan Administration was doing all it could to aid farmers in the Southeast suffering the region's worst drought in a century.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: A BIG SCENE There are few stage backdrops, if any, that can match the supreme splendor of New York harbor as seen from Brooklyn Heights, a view that is high, wide and extremely handsome, with its own star, the Statue of Liberty, at stage center. This formidable show-stopper is not so much a rival as a fringe benefit for the outdoor theater scheduled for 7:30 tonight at the Pierrepont Street Playground, where the street enters the Brooklyn Heights Promenade.

title: Oil Rises Moderately; Attack On Iran Is Cited
description: Prices of crude oil and petroleum produce prices advanced moderately yesterday on the world oil market.

title: 2 HEALTH CENTERS PLANNED
description: Two international health research and training centers will be established at the University of Illinois to help spread advaced medical technology to other countries, the university announced today.

title: The U.N. Today; Aug. 13, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Special Committee on Decolonization - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: STUDENT IS HELD
description: A student at New York City Technical College went on a rampage through the downtown Brooklyn campus yesterday afternoon, shooting five people, one of them fatally, and exchanging gunfire with police officers before giving up, the police reported.

title: CHEMICAL LEAMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HARPER GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $259,000 for the quarter and $514,000 for the 6 months.

title: U.S. JUDGE INVALIDATES JERSEY ATOM-FREE ZONE
description: A Federal judge today struck down an ordinance declaring Union County a nuclear-free zone, saying that it was an unconstitutional and unenforceable infringement of Federal powers to regulate the nuclear industry.

title: AMERICANS ABROAD: TAX DEFICIENCY
description: A Congressional report released today shows that many Americans living abroad have failed to file income tax returns and that Americans at home are also deficient in reporting foreign income.

title: ULSTER'S PROTESTANTS MARCH TO TRADITIONAL TUNE OF 'NO!'
description: The Rev. Ian Paisley, carrying on a ''no surrender'' tradition that goes back three centuries, paraded past crowds of cheering Protestant loyalists today. His appearance was plainly designed to scotch talk that his time is passing as leader of the province's resistance to political change.

title: Shipper Fined In Soviet Deal
description: A fugitive California businessman has been fined $1.2 million and denied all export privileges by the Commerce Department for illegally shipping advanced computers to Moscow.

title: Homeless-Couples Policy
description: New York City will allow homeless married couples who are childless to stay together in shelters set up for families, instead of having to separate to stay in men's and women's shelters, city officials said yesterday. Last year the Legal Action Center for the Homeless brought suit against the city, seeking the policy change.

title: STUDY OF VETERANS' HOSPITALS
description: The first column in the chart below shows the total number of operations done in the fiscal years 1983 and 1984 for the 52 highest risk surgical procedures. Other minor surgical procedures were not counted. The second number is the percent of patients who died. The third number shows the number of open-heart surgery cases performed in the fiscal year 1985 and the percent of those patients who died. Some Veterans Administration hospitals do not have open-heart surgery units. Hospitals performing fewer than 100 surgical procedures in 1983-84 are not shown.
