title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: I CAME late to the down comforter. I thought it was a fad. Ducks have never looked particularly warm and cozy to me, and $200 seems like an awful lot to pay for a blanket. Now I admit I was wrong. Even on summer nights I lie beneath its featherweight, and feel secure. Over the intercom on the table just next to my left ear, I imagine I can hear the sounds of the children snuffling softly in the rooms on the floor above. There is pink fiberglass insulation in my crawl space and an infrared light illuminating the backyard with a bulb the electrician says may last my lifetime, if I don't live too long. And downstairs my book shelves are filled with books.

title: Economic Scene; Taking a Look At Job Quality
description: THE nation's increasingly service-oriented economy has led to a perception that good jobs are being lost in exchange for inferior jobs. The service-producing sector is often thought to be dominated by low-paying, dead-end jobs, requiring minimal skills, while declines in manufacturing reduce good job opportunities.

title: U.N. FORCE BATTLES LEBANESE MILITIA
description: Shiite Moslem militiamen clashed with United Nations peacekeeping troops in southern Lebanon overnight and today.

title: CHELSEA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
description: b-Includes an after-tax gain from the sale of a building of $693,000 for both the quarter and 9 months.

title: CANADA DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income c-Includes a gain on investments of $19.9 million for both the quarter and 6 months, and income from non-consolidated subsidiaries of $13.6 million and $8.8 million for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: Main Hurdman Gets Ernst Bid
description: KMG Main Hurdman said yesterday that it had received an ''informal offer'' to merge with Ernst & Whinney, another large accounting firm.

title: CITY GAS CO OF FLORIDA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HOUSE PANEL SAYS DEAVER WAS LYING IN MAY TESTIMONY
description: A House subcommittee said today that Michael K. Deaver, the former deputy White House chief of staff, lied in sworn testimony this spring, and it asked an independent counsel to investigate the possibility of perjury charges.

title: Fruehauf Said To Reject Deal
description: The investor Asher B. Edelman and Merrill Lynch & Company, the two competing bidders for the Fruehauf Corporation, worked out a settlement agreement last weekend that was ultimately rejected by the Fruehauf board, according to sources familiar with the pact.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: DACHA CHATS
description: It is not often that American and Soviet officials can get together to talk about arms control in a place where disclosures about the discussion are not almost instantaneous.

title: People
description: * Jerry Luedke and Mati Otsmaa have been appointed senior vice presidents at DFS Dorland/San Francisco. Joann Fraser has been elected a vice president.

title: WHAT STIRS THE FIGHT ON RADON
description: In the weeks since state officials announced plans to ship about 10,000 cubic yards of radium-contaminated soil to Vernon Township, residents of the Sussex County community have protested vigorously. The state plans to blend the tainted dirt with clean soil. Here are some of the questions raised by the state's plan and answers culled from materials and reports on the situation:

title: DOME MINES
description: Dome Mines Ltd., said it had agreed to sell 1.7 million shares of Campbell Red Lakes Mines Ltd. for about $18.70 each, or about $30.5 million.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Calvin Klein Industries has appointed John K. Kabay senior vice president and chief financial officer.

title: ONE DAY IN THE VIDEO RENTAL WHIRL
description: It is one minute to nine in the morning, but already there are people waiting outside Tower Video as the doors are unlocked. For the next 15 hours, the store will be thronged with customers seeking gremlins and goonies, aliens and mass murderers, old-fashioned movie legends and rock stars with green hair, exercise tapes and lessons on everything from Italian cooking to waltzing with Betty White, not to mention Ronald Reagan's life story. As usual, it will be a busy day. 9 A.M. Frank Pace is the first customer. He is returning a copy of ''Desperately Seeking Susan,'' and despite the movie's charms, he was not amused. ''The tape had a lot of static,'' he complains. ''Every half hour it needed to be cleaned again.'' The clerk doesn't charge him for the rental, and Mr. Pace leaves, looking mollified. 9:11 A.M. The likes of Madonna are not under consideration for Liliana Garcia, an opera buff who is contemplating the relative merits of ''Cosi Fan Tutte'' and ''A Year in the Life of Placido Domingo.'' Her choices, however, are broad: open from 9 A.M. to midnight, 365 days a year, the Tower outlet at Broadway and 67th Street is one of the city's largest video rental stores, offering 6,500 copies of nearly 4,000 different titles. With video-cassette recorders now found in more than one-third of all American homes and selling at a rate of more than a million a month, the rental and purchase of cassettes represented a $4 billion industry last year.

title: BASIC AMERICAN MEDICAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Finns Rebuff Soviet Defector
description: Finland today refused asylum to a defecting Soviet soldier, Igor Azhevsky, but said it would deport him to a third country. The soldier was sentenced by a court at Imatra to a suspended five-month prison sentence and fines of $920 for crossing the border, for theft and other offenses. He was picked up by the police on July 1 and was convicted for being drunk while driving a motorbike he had stolen.

title: COMAIR INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
THE SALAD BAR: A BOOM IN THE MOVABLE FEAST
description: THEY began in restaurants 20 years ago as serve-yourself affairs amounting to a few raw vegetables and a couple of chopped-up fruits with your choice of dressings and a piece of bread on the side. Today, they have blossomed into the deluxe salad bars found in supermarkets and greengrocers. Few neighborhoods are without them and their assortments of almost every imaginable hot and cold salad, along with a few that are hard to imagine and even harder to call salads.

title: TOM GORMAN
description: Tom Gorman, an umpire for 25 seasons in the National League, died Monday night after suffering a heart attack at his home in Westwood, N.J. He was 67 years old.

title: Owens's Stock Up And Active
description: The stock of the Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation remained well above the $74-a-share price of a hostile tender offer from the Wickes Companies yesterday as investors anticipated that a defensive restructuring might be in the works.

title: No Comeback
description: John Henry, the 11-year-old big-money gelding who had been in training for a comeback race, has been sent back into retirement because of a leg ailment similar to one that led to his initial retirement last year. ''This type of thing would heal in a couple of months, but two months is too long,'' said his trainer, Ron McAnally, who had been planning for John Henry's comeback in the Ballantine Classic at the Meadowlands Sept. 3, the same race John Henry won in his last outing in October 1984. In eight seasons of racing, John Henry won 39 races and a record $6,597,947 and eight Eclipse Awards, including two as Horse of the Year.

title: MUSIC: EMMA KIRKBY
description: THE English soprano Emma Kirkby is one of the big stars of the early music movement, with many best-selling recordings and ample exposure on classical-music radio stations. But for some improbable reason Monday evening's concert at Avery Fisher Hall - sold out, of course - marked not only her Mostly Mozart Festival debut but also her Lincoln Center debut. Thus do the guardians of our concert life keep the supposedly sophisticated New York audience abreast of international musical trends.

title: Sikh Militant Seized; Tied to Killings of 50
description: The police captured a Sikh militant today who has been accused of masterminding the killings of 50 people, including the slaying of 14 Hindu bus passengers last month.

title: The Whistle-Blower's Plight
description: Shortly after Allan McDonald and Roger Boisjoly, two engineers from Morton Thiokol Inc., testified publicly that they had opposed the launch of the Challenger space shuttle, the company transferred them to jobs of lesser responsibility. Although they were later reinstated, their experience demonstrated one of the hard truths of corporate and public life: employees who blow the whistle on their employers run high risks.

title: MARK GREEN AND DYSON TRADE BARBS
description: In one of the most vituperative political debates in New York in recent years, John S. Dyson and Mark Green repeatedly questioned each other's credentials tonight in their first encounter of the Senate Democratic primary campaign.

title: Saberhagen Disabled
description: Bret Saberhagen, the American League Cy Young Award winner last year, was placed on the 15-day disabled list by the Kansas City Royals yesterday. Although the Royals did not release any information about the nature of Saberhagen's injury, the 22-year-old right-hander has struggled this season and complained recently of a sore shoulder.

title: Australia-U.S. Gold Tie
description: In another step toward the globalization of commodity markets, New York's Commodity Exchange was granted authority today to establish a trading link with the Sydney Futures Exchange in Australia. The United States and Australian exchanges hope to begin trading gold bullion futures contracts in October.

title: A Harness Put on Americans by the Liberals
description: To the Editor:

title: Fight on Presidential Debates
description: The League of Women Voters said today that the Republican and Democratic National Committees were trying to ''pull the rug out from under us'' and take over sponsorship of Presidential debates in 1988.

title: HOUSTON OIL FIELDS COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a writedown of $5.9 million relating to the value of oil and gas properties.

title: BROCCOLI'S BONUSES
description: BROCCOLI is a nearly perfect vegetable in terms of nutrition. It is a cruciferous vegetable, one of a broad category within the cabbage family that form a cross (hence, cruciferous) on the flower bud. Others include cabbage, Brussels sprouts, kohlrabi, cauliflower and turnip greens. They all share certain nutritional properties, among them low calories, high calcium values and a possible function in the body as cancer inhibitors.

title: Soviet Trawler Leaves Disputed Fishing Area
description: A Soviet trawler caught fishing in the same disputed Bering Sea waters from which American boats were chased has left, officials said today.

title: TESTING FOR DRUG USE ON VOLUNTARY BASIS IS URGED BY PRESIDENT
description: President Reagan said tonight that voluntary drug testing, which he is encouraging in the Government and elsewhere in the nation, would not violate the constitutional rights of employees.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: ANYONE who has followed this column has probably noticed the large number of suggested recipes that use skinless, boneless chicken breasts as a principal ingredient. There are several reasons for this. Chicken breasts are the finest - or supreme - part of the bird, which is why in French they are referred to as ''supremes de volaille.''

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL YANKEES VS. CLEVELAND INDIANS, at Yankee Stadium, 7:30 P.M. (Television - SportsChannel, 7:30 P.M., Radio -WABC, 770, 7:30 P.M.) METS VS.

title: LATE SURGE SENDS DOW UP BY 24.33
description: Late buying sent stock prices soaring again yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average climbing 24.33 points, to 1,835.49. That was its best level of the day and marked a gain of 52.87 points for the first two days of the week.

title: UNITED OKLAHOMA BANKHARES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: FOWLER TAKES STRONG LEAD IN SENATE RACE IN GEORGIA
description: Representative Wyche Fowler Jr. built a commanding lead early today over the former White House aide Hamilton Jordan and was close to winning outright the Democratic primary for the United States Senate.

title: How Financiers Relax
description: What separates the men from the boys is their toys.

title: Lashkari Found Free of Drugs
description: The New York State Racing and Wagering Board today overturned the disqualification of Lashkari from the $2 million Breeders' Cup Turf race last Nov. 1 because the State Testing Laboratory at Cornell University has reversed its initial finding that the colt raced with a prohibited medication commonly known as ''elephant juice.''

title: Pessimism On Trade Gap
description: A manufacturing industry group said today that it sees little improvement in the huge United States trade deficit through 1987, in part because its own members are too complacent about meeting foreign competition.

title: TREASURE FEARED LOST IN RAISING HULL
description: Salvagers triumphantly brought ashore today what remains of the hull of the 18th-century British warship H.M.S. deBraak after it had spent 188 years and 84 days at the bottom of Delaware Bay.

title: HANDY & HARMAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,115,000 from the sale of a gold manufacturing facility and a loss of $475,000 from the company's Far East joint venture operations. c-Net income The company said the latest 6-month results were adversely affected by a writeoff of a major credit loss amounting to $2,700,000, or 20 cents a share after taxes.

title: Sanitary Athleticism
description: Team members agree that Alvin Thomas is at his best during the 50-meter barrel-roll, and that Phillipa Perry's expertise lies in garbage-bag tying. Gregory Malave believes his greatest feat is shoveling during the four-way bag-fill.

title: The One-Point Price for Tax Reform
description: One thing tax reform must do in this era of huge Federal deficits is to bring in as much revenue as present tax law. That could be done by: (A) Closing the loopholes that reduce the taxes owed by individuals and businesses, a course resisted by some Senate members of the committee now fine-tuning the tax reform bill. (B) Compensating for lost revenue with tax trickery just devised by some senators. (C) Raising revenue with a straightforward rate increase of 1 percent, as proposed by the Senate Finance Committee chairman, Bob Packwood.

title: SCOTT PUTS ON HIS PATTON STARS AGAIN
description: ''After 35 years in the business, people still identify me more with Patton than any other character,'' George C. Scott said recently. ''Even today, truck drivers and garbagemen and cabdrivers will call out to me on the street, 'Hey, General, how are you doing?' ''

title: Key Changes At Northwest
description: NWA Inc., the parent of Northwest Airlines, named Steven G. Rothmeier chairman and chief executive of both NWA and Northwest, which today became the nation's third-largest airline by completing the $884 million acquisition of Republic Airlines, Reuters reported. Mr. Rothmeier had been president and chief executive. In addition, James A. Abbott, an executive vice president was named vice chairman, and John F. Horn, also an executive vice president, will become president and chief operating officer.

title: 3 Jersey Escapees Seized
description: Police and corrections officers tonight captured three of four inmates, including a convicted murderer, who had cut their way out of Leesburg State Prison Monday evening, corrections officials said.

title: C-TEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a gain of $232,000 from the adoption of FASB Board Statement No. 87. c-After a loss of $41,000 from discontinued operations. Share earnings reflect a stock split paid in June as a dividend of one share of a newly created Class B common for each common share.

title: LANDING GEAR HAS PROBLEMS IN NAVY'S NEWEST JET FIGHTER
description: The Navy's newest jet fighter, the F-18 Hornet, has experienced occasional problems with part of its main landing gear, which can buckle under the stress of abrupt landings on aircraft carriers, the manufacturer said today.

title: TIGERS SPOIL CARLTON'S DEBUT
description: Steve Carlton, signed by the Chicago White Sox today, lasted only three innings and was the losing pitcher tonight in his American League debut, giving up six runs in the 7-3 loss to the Detroit Tigers.

title: AMERICAN SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN (MIAMI, FLA) (N) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary gains of $2,540,000 and $17,297,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net loss and includes a $68,726,000 pre-tax provision for possible loss on the E.S.M. repurchase agreement transactions, and after an extraordinary gain of $1,586,000.

title: Leader of Chicken Unit To Head All of Wendy's
description: Wendy's International Inc., the fast-food restaurant chain, said yesterday that James W. Near, president of Sisters Chicken and Biscuits restaurants, a Wendy's subsidiary, has been named president and chief operating officer of the entire company. Mr. Near, 48, replaces Ronald P. Fay, 57, who has retired but remains a director.

title: ALLIED SECURITY INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FRENCH BUYER FOR U.S. GAS PRODUCER
description: The world's largest producer of industrial gases, L'Air Liquide S.A. of France, has agreed to acquire Big Three Industries, an industrial gas producer in the Southwest, for $1.05 billion, the companies said today.

title: Passing Over Other Schools
description: When Ty Detmer was a junior last fall at Southwest High School in San Antonio, he compiled some outstanding football statistics: 209 completions, 3,551 yards and 36 touchdowns.

title: Popular Wall St. Tools Combined in Note Sale
description: Two of Wall Street's more popular financing tools of recent years - the use of insurance for debt securities and the conversion of assets into marketable securities - have been combined in an $82.2 million sale of notes due in three months to five years.

title: REAGAN SUPPORTS A WESTERN PARLEY WITH SOUTH AFRICA
description: President Reagan tonight expressed support for a meeting of Western nations with South Africa to seek to resolve the crisis there.

title: IMREG INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company is a biotechnology research and development concern and didn't have any revenue.

title: WHOLESALE GASOLINE PRICES JUMP
description: Wholesale gasoline prices have jumped in the week since OPEC agreed to curb production, and retail prices should quickly follow, probably with rises of a few cents a gallon, gasoline industry consultants and analysts said yesterday.

title: Dean Witter Executive Adds Title of Chairman
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company announced yesterday that Philip J. Purcell would become chairman of its Dean Witter Financial Services Group as of Sept. 1, replacing Richard M. Gardiner, 63, who is retiring. Mr. Purcell, 42, has been president and chief operating officer of Dean Witter since 1982.

title: COAST R V INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
COLONIAL GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Go Ahead: Spoil My Day
description: I meant to write something today that would be light of heart, full of gaiety and leave everybody feeling wonderful about being alive in this magnificent country at this delightful moment in history. Then a man phoned about taxes.

title: Pollution-Control Facilities Bonds
description: A $110 million issue of Florida general obligation bonds was offered yesterday with yields ranging from 5 percent for those due in 1988 to 6.80 percent in 1996 and 7.25 percent in 2008 through underwriters led by the Bankers Trust Company.

title: SPURS' MOORE PUTS ILLNESS BEHIND HIM
description: Sunday was a big night in Johnny Moore's comeback. The San Antonio Spurs' point guard scored 50 points for his Austin, Tex., team in a pro-am league sponsored by the National Basketball Association. Feats like that might be commonplace when pros showcase themselves in offseason playground and charity games. For Moore, however, the performance was more important. It said he was on his way back.

title: 29 Ice Cream Brands Recalled in Middle West
description: Twenty-nine brands of ice cream were recalled in 11 states today because the ice cream may be contaminated with bacteria.

title: FOR KASPAROV, SETTLING ON DRAW ENDS GAME 6
description: Gary Kasparov got what he presumably wanted - a draw in the sixth game of his world-championship defense in London yesterday against the 35-year-old former titleholder, Anatoly Karpov.

title: LIMITED INC reports earnings for 13wks to Aug 2
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in June 1986.

title: BRIEFING; Peabody Heard From
description: A familiar name from the Democratic politics of the 1960's has reappeared in New Hampshire, where Endicott (Chub) Peabody is seeking the Democratic Senate nomination and the right to challenge Senator Warren B. Rudman, a Republican seeking a second term.

title: IDAHO EMERGENCY DECLARED IN FIRES
description: About 10,000 firefighters struggled today to contain more than 500 fires set by lightning while weather forecasts indicated conditions that could bring more of the electrical storms that started the crisis Sunday in remote areas of Oregon, Washington, Idaho and Montana.

title: EQUITABLE OF IOWA COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $10,997,000 and $14,769,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes realized investment gains of $713,000 for the quarter and $13,638,000 for the 6 months.

title: Calling Signals
description: Ken O'Brien, the Jets' starting quarterback, taking snap as Coach Joe Walton looked on yesterday at practice. (NYT/Barton Silverman)

title: ALTERNATIVE HEALTH CARE SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: BAKERIES, like psychoanalysts, close shop in August. At least many bakeries do. Analysts head for Martha's Vineyard or Cape Cod. They leave behind the names of their stand-ins. Bakers, perhaps, take trips to Sugarloaf Mountain in Maine or even Pound Ridge, N.Y. They leave sweet cutesy signs in their store windows.

title: Advertising; This Time, An Agency Split-Up
description: AFTER a seemingly endless series of mergers and strategic alliances among advertising agencies, something different happened yesterday: An agency split up with one of its subsidiaries.

title: A HOT SUMMER AND AN EVEN HOTTER HIT
description: The lines are long at the box office. The producers are finished mopping the sweat off their brows. It may be summer in the city but, it seems, Broadway has a new hit.

title: FREMONT GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes realized gains of $488,000 for the quarter and $486,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss d-Includes realized gains of $140,000 for the quarter and $20,000 for the 6 months, and income from discontinued operations of $28,000 for the quarter and $125,763,000 for the 6 months.

title: Simmons Stake
description: Harold C. Simmons, the Dallas investor who recently bought control of NL Industries, has exercised an option to purchase 800,000 shares of the Louisiana Land and Exploration Company and now holds 5.1 percent of the energy concern, he said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing. In a previous filing, Mr. Simmons said that he had purchased Louisiana Land shares ''in order to acquire a significant equity interest'' and that he would review his investment ''continuously.''

title: REPLY BY DEAVER'S LAWYERS TO CHARGES BY HOUSE PANEL
description: Following is a statement by Miller, Cassidy, Larroca & Lewin, the law firm of Michael K. Deaver, responding to charges today that the former White House deputy chief of staff may have committed perjury in testimony before the committee:

title: BOTHA TALK URGES END TO 'DEFEATISM'
description: President P. W. Botha urged white followers tonight to ''shed the spirit of defeatism and doubt'' about the nation's future and rally to his tentative program to change racial policies.

title: SEABOARD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
DATA ON REHNQUIST SAID TO DETAIL INCREASED DOSES
description: A confidential medical assessment of the health of Associate Justice William H. Rehnquist has found that he used three times the amount of a pain-killing drug than had originally been prescribed to ease his severe back pains, according to two officials who said today that they had knowledge of the report.

title: AID FOR CONTRAS SURVIVES KEY VOTE IN SENATE
description: The Reagan Administration's proposal to send $100 million to the rebels seeking to overthrow the Nicaraguan Government survived a key Senate vote tonight.

title: NASA PICKS NEW ROCKET DESIGN FOR SPACE SHUTTLE
description: The space agency said today that it had selected a new rocket design for the space shuttle that would be safe and would also enable the agency to continue to use all of its existing rocket segments.

title: Omissions in a Message From a La Prensa Owner
description: To the Editor:

title: Blood Check on the Run
description: To the Editor:

title: MOSCOW TALKS, AT AN END, ARE CALLED BUSINESSLIKE
description: Soviet and American officials ended two days of high-level arms-control talks today, but declined to say whether they had narrowed differences and improved the chances for a meeting later this year between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: Thrift Unit Starts Fresh
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today that it would remove the First Federal Savings and Loan Association of Rochester from a program under which ailing thrift instititions would be merged and placed under the agency's control.

title: LABORITE LEADER'S WIFE: A POLITICAL PARTNER, TOO
description: One recent morning's newspapers carried a picture of Glenys Kinnock setting out from Northampton on an antinuclear march on behalf of the Campaign for Nuclear Disarmament.

title: Large Loss At People Express
description: People Express Inc. yesterday reported a second-quarter loss of $74.5 million, which was higher than some analysts expected, compared with a $13.1 million profit in the second quarter of 1985.

title: MAKING HEALTHFUL STRIDES AT AREA SHOPPING MALLS
description: It's 8 in the morning and already hot enough to fry spit.

title: RUSSIANS ARRIVE FOR U.S. TALKS
description: A Soviet Foreign Ministry official and his delegation arrived in Washington today for several days of meetings with American officials that are to begin Wednesday, the State Department said today.

title: CITY LEGAL CHIEF SEES A PROBLEM IN BRIBE INQUIRY
description: The Koch administration's chief lawyer warned yesterday that prosecutors may be setting a bad example in the municipal corruption scandal by prosecuting the public officials who take bribes without also going after the private business executives who pay the bribes.

title: V.A. REPORTS 'ERRORS' IN DOZENS OF DEATHS AFTER HEART SURGERY
description: An internal audit of Veterans Administration hospitals found ''preventable'' medical errors in the cases of a large number of patients who died after heart surgery, a House subcommittee disclosed at a hearing today.

title: Let Lincoln Center Grow
description: Whether measured by artistic influence or economic impact, Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts is surely the most dramatic achievement of public and private cooperation in New York since World War II. Challenged now to provide for needs stimulated by its success, the center has devised an expansion plan that deserves the support this week of the New York City Board of Estimate.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Food Notes column in The Living Section last Wednesday gave an incorrect price for The Wine Spectator's 1986 ''California Wine Maps Guide.'' It costs $3.95 plus $1.25 postage.

title: Pentagon Lifts Ban Against Fiat
description: The Pentagon today ended a ban against doing business with Fiat S.p.A., Italy's giant auto company despite Libya's continued part ownership in the firm. The agreement cleared the way for Fiat-Allis, a subsidiary of Fiat S.p.A. of Turin, to get a $7.9 million contract to build United States Marine crawler troop vehicles and compete for anti-missile research contracts.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in some editions July 21 by The Associated Press incorrectly described an appearance in Tel Aviv by the violinist Itzhak Perlman. In part of a scene from Puccini's ''Tosca,'' Mr. Perlman sang the role of the jailer, a part he had sung previously in public.

title: 2 TAXI GROUPS URGE A TRIPLING OF MEDALLIONS
description: Representatives of some owners and drivers of nonmedallion taxicabs proposed yesterday that their portion of the taxicab industry be brought under control of a restructured City Taxi and Limousine Commission, and that the number of medallion taxicabs be more than tripled, to 40,000.

title: DOME MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $25,117,000 from share issue by Campbell Red Lake Mines. c-Includes a charge of $9,619,000 related to decline in quoted value of a stock holding.

title: Letter: On Home-Based Work; Who Will Guard Against Sweatshops?
description: To the Editor:

title: Professor Emeritus of Yale Wins Kyoto Prize in Science
description: The 1986 Kyoto Prize in Basic Sciences, carrying a stipend of 45 million yen (roughly $300,000), has been awarded to G. Evelyn Hutchinson, Sterling Professor of Zoology Emeritus at Yale University. The prize is one of three awarded annually by the Inamori Foundation of Kyoto, Japan, the others being in the fields of advanced technology and either the creative arts or ''moral sciences.''

title: BRIEFING; On TV in the Court
description: The Supreme Court may be edging toward allowing television and radio coverage of the public sessions in which lawyers argue their cases before the justices. In Senate Judiciary Committee hearings on his nomination as Chief Justice, Associate Justice William H. Rehnquist said in response to a question: ''If I were convinced that coverage by television of the Supreme Court would not d/stort the way the Court works at present, I would certainly give it sympathetic consideration.''

title: REVERE COPPER & BRASS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $543,000 for the quarter and $6,522,000 for the 6 months and losses on disposal of discontinued operations of $13,420,000 and $27,797,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net income and includes losses from discontinued operations of $2,916,000 for the quarter and $3,903,000 for the 6 months and tax credits of $1,964,000 and $6,242,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: WOOLWORTH, F W CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31

title: OLD AND NEW THRIVE AT VERMONT STORE
description: AT the turn of the century, when a customer bought coffee at F. H. Gillingham's general store, chances were that Frank Henry Gillingham, or ''F. H.,'' as he was called, would have ground the beans himself in a big, red, iron Universal grinder. Today, F. H.'s 30-year-old great-grandson, Jireh S. Billings, grinds it in the same machine.

title: ARROW ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of $3,632,000 in connection with the redemption of debentures for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Net income

title: IN THE 'LITE' DECADE, LESS HAS BECOME MORE
description: It used to take so much time -days, sometimes weeks - to read a classic. ''Moby Dick,'' alone, runs 710 pages. Today, thanks to a small publishing house called Workman, it takes a minute. Through abridging, reabridging and editing out ''rambling soliloquies,'' Workman boasts that it has ''cut down the literary canon to a lean pistol,'' producing an audio-cassette tape that offers listeners ''Ten Classics in Ten Minutes.''

title: Market Place; Agri-biotech's Prospects
description: INVESTORS frustrated by the poor performance of agriculture-related stocks - fertilizer, farm machinery and the like - might benefit from taking a closer look at the biotechnology sector of the industry.

title: Different Strokes
description: Don Mattingly stroked a bases-loaded single to right field off Frank Wills on Monday night to drive in the winning run in a 6-5 victory for the Yankees over the Cleveland Indians.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES

title: Continental Deal
description: The Continental Illinois Corporation said it plans to acquire First Options of Chicago Inc., the nation's largest options clearing firm, from Spear, Leeds & Kellogg.

title: 30 Britons Evacuated From Southern Sudan
description: Britain evacuated 30 of its citizens from the southern Sudan today amid a rebel siege of a provincial capital and a famine threatening thousands of people with starvation.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 13, 1986
description: International

title: CANADIAN PACIFIC LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $362.5 million for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Net income The company said the $362.5 million charge in the latest 6-month period includes a $260.9 million writedown of container and bulk shipping fleet, a $96 million charge related to assets and operations of Algoma Steel Corp. and AMCA International Ltd. and a charge of $5.6 million related to offshore insurance operations.

title: IRAN AND IRAQ TRADE STRIKES ON REFINERIES
description: Iran fired a long-range missile into the Iraqi capital of Baghdad today, according to reports from both countries. Hours later, reports said, Iraqi jets raided an Iranian oil terminal, setting three supertankers ablaze, The incidents appeared to be a new and serious stepping up of the nearly six-year-old war between the two Persian Gulf nations.

title: CORVUS SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $7,977,000 and a loss on disposal of discontinued operations of $9,934,000. c-After unusual pre-tax expenses of $3,884,000 from restructuring and $777,000 from expenses related to merger for the quarter and year, and losses from discontinued operations of $3,456,000 for the quarter and $7,198,000 for the year.

title: Times Sq. Project Deserves Second Thoughts
description: To the Editor:

title: METS ARE STOPPED BY PHILLIES' GROSS
description: The Mets don't lose too often these days, and neither does Rick Aguilera. But they both took the tumble tonight, and afterward Manager Dave Johnson said: ''I think we'll survive.''

title: BOB EVANS FARMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 25
description: The 1985 share earnings reflect a 5-for-4 stock split to be paid in September.

title: JUDGE ALLOWS SANITATION HIRINGS
description: A state appellate court ruled yesterday that the City Sanitation Department could hire 180 new sanitation workers - including the department's first women - even though the union is challenging the entrance test.

title: Venezuela Halts Fund
description: Venezuela's minister of finance, Manuel Azpurua, announced today that the Government would ''liquidate'' a special state fund established to help private sector borrowers repay $7 billion of foreign debt. The minister did not say whether the Government had developed some other repayment plan covering private debt, much of which is owed to United States banks. But foreign bankers said the Government would probably revive a program under which certain debtors could have access to a special exchange rate subsidy.

title: A Harness Put on Americans by the Liberals; Midway Majority
description: To the Editor:

description: About 75 refugees from the IRT Lexington Avenue line commuted yesterday from Roosevelt Island to Wall Street by boat.

description: THE muggy dog days of summer always inspire me to create quick, light meals that require minimal fussing at a hot stove. The dishes I prepare, whether for family or guests, usually revolve around grilled entrees and the freshest seasonal produce.

description: In another restructuring move to emphasize its food businesses, the Quaker Oats Company said today that it would divest itself of its specialty retailing line.

Deaver, the former White House deputy chief of staff, in testimony before the subcommittee on May 16, 1986. Introduction

description: As the Senate resumes its search for an appropriate South African policy, both the opponents and defenders of the idea of imposing economic penalties on the South African regime are mistaken about what tough sanctions will actually achieve.

Walker Visits Cowboys
description: Herschel Walker, accompanied by his agent, Peter Johnson, yesterday made his first appearance at the Dallas Cowboys' training camp at Thousand Oaks, Calif.

title: 9 ZUCCHINI, SAUTEED, HOLD THE PANCAKES
description: THE zucchini season is here again, and we can look forward to another bumper crop of humorous articles about this beautiful, delicious vegetable. Gardeners who deal calmly and sensibly with an excess of beans or tomatoes react to a proliferation of zucchini by writing articles (even books) that make unkind jokes about the vegetable and suggest elaborate ways of getting rid of it. Cooking and eating the zucchini are recommended only as a last resort.

description: Craig Thompson, a journalist, author and public-relations executive, died of cancer on Sunday at the Orlando (Fla.) Regional Medical Center. He was 79 years old and lived in Orlando.

description: Cheryl Miller scored 21 points as the United States defeated Australia, 76-50, today to clinch a berth in the medal round of the women's World Basketball Championships.

description: This is the house that Barry built. It is 10 feet tall, 12 1/2 feet long and 6 feet wide. And it contains all of the knowledge known to man.

title: CONGRESS; Aspin and Armed Services: Can the Center Hold?
description: Representative Les Aspin has spent most of the past week on the House floor, managing the Defense Department's 1987 bill. But more is at stake than $300 billion in new and continuing military programs.

title: HEAVY JAPANESE PURCHASES SPUR THE PRICE OF GOLD
description: For much of this year, the Japanese Government and its citizens have been buying billions of dollars worth of gold, purchases believed to have provided a prop of $40 or $50 an ounce to world gold prices.

title: Transactions
description: FOOTBALL BUFFALO (AFC) - Signed Will Wolford, a first-round draft choice and an offenive tackle.

title: Ex-Aide of Deere Guilty
description: A former Deere & Company steel buyer, Richard Neyens, has pleaded guilty in Federal court to charges of setting up a phony company that sold overpriced steel to the farm-equipment manufacturer. He faces up to 15 years in prison and a $4,200 fine and could be ordered to repay Deere up to $1.6 million the Moline-based company lost in the scheme, Assistant United States Attorney L. Lee Smith said on Monday. Mr. Smith added that Mr. Neyens had pocketed $823,000.

title: ORION CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After investment gains of $3,919,000 for the quarter and $9,022,000 for the 6 months and tax credits of $2,594,000 and $3,207,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-After investment gains of $4,227,000 for the quarter and $5,546,000 for the 6 months. d-Net loss Both latest periods' results include a pre-tax gain of $5,772,000, or $3,117,000 after tax, relating to Guaranty National Corp.'s common stock public offering. The year-ago 6 months' revenue restated to reflect the deconsolidation of Guaranty's financial statements since the company's investment in Guaranty now is being carried on the books using the equity method of accounting.

description: When they picked Larry up on a beach near Jamesport last fall, he was in sorry shape, too cold and tired even to lift his head.

title: Lloyd's Rate Rise Seen
description: Insurers at Lloyd's of London are about to announce a sharp rise in rates for tankers in the Persian Gulf, following today's Iraqi raid on Sirri Island and recent Iranian attacks on shipping in the waterway, brokers said. Sources at a leading war risk brokers firm said they expected to be told by Lloyd's underwriters Wednesday of at least a 100 percent rise in premiums for insuring tankers in the area.

title: PEOPLE EXPRESS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a $7.1 million non-cash foreign currency charge to earnings associated with Swiss franc-denominated debentures issued in January. c-Net income

title: FILM: 'THE LIBERATION OF AUSCHWITZ' OPENS
description: IT is more than 40 years since Allied troops opened the gates of the Nazi death camps, and one might suppose that by now, after all the reports and studies, the diaries, documents and documentaries, our responses would have numbed and we could see the shrunken figures in their striped pajamas and remain unmoved. But each time the subject returns, as nightmares will, we find ourselves stunned afresh.

title: WAL-MART STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
REAGAN PLEDGES HIS COMMITMENT TO HELP FARMERS OVERCOME CRISIS
description: President Reagan tonight pledged an ''unshakeable'' commitment to the nation's farmers and vowed to act on their behalf for as long as he is office.

title: NEW HOPE IN PRYOR'S CAMP
description: The words on the T-shirts and caps of the camp aides read, ''AARON PRYOR IS BACK.''

title: EX-MEMBER OF BOARD OF EDUCATION
description: James Marshall, a lawyer and philanthropist who was on the Board of Education 17 years and was its president from 1938 to 1942, died Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 90 years old and also had a home in New Hope, Pa.

title: PENNEY, J C CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 26
description: b-After extraordinary after-tax charges of $11 million for the quarter and $35 million for the 6 months, related to debt restructuring.

title: By TIM PAGE
description: Felix Salzer, an American musicologist of Austrian birth whose writings and classes at the Mannes College of Music had a pronounced influence on the study of theory and analysis in the United States, died Sunday after a long illness. He was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: CORRECTION
description: A caption accompanying a diagram of the United States space shuttle in Science Times yesterday incorrectly estimated the shuttle's payload capacity. The shuttle was designed to carry 65,000 pounds of cargo but payloads carried thus far have not exceeded 50,000 pounds. The combined weight of the shuttle orbiter and its payload is 250,000 pounds.

title: Nikolai M. Druzhinin, Noted Soviet Historian
description: Nikolai M. Druzhinin, a noted Soviet historian, died Friday, the newspaper Pravda announced today. He was 100 years old.

title: GWENDOLYNY P. BROWN
description: Gwendolyn Powell Brown, director of computer education for Community School District 3 on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, died of a pulmonary embolism Sunday at Columbia Memorial Hospital in Hudson, N.Y. She was 54 years old and lived in Manhattan and in Germantown, N.Y.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: THE laments are all too familiar: ''I can't seem to lose weight in the right places.''

title: MARTIN BIRNBAUM
description: Martin Birnbaum, a Yiddish poet whose work was published in the United States, Europe and Israel, died at Mount Sinai Hospital Friday of a heart attack.

title: Working Profile; Fervor and Foment on Safety Issues: James E. Burnett
description: After James E. Burnett received a call from the White House a month ago, telling him that President Reagan had nominated him for a third two-year term as chairman of the National Transportation Safety Board, the former Arkansas traffic judge expressed relief at the resolution of a bitter dispute over his leadership.

title: 'BIG GAMBLE IN ATLANTIC CITY' ON CBS
description: WHAT have the casinos brought to Atlantic City?

title: MORENO IN 'RITA,' A COMEDY
description: EVEN though ''Rita,'' a new television sitcom starring Rita Moreno, fits snugly into a formula that has scarcely changed in the last 15 years, one has to admire the deftness with which a time-honored formula has once again been reworked. The half-hour premiere episode, at 9:30 tonight on Channel 2, concisely sketches six characters - a New York City family of five and the housekeeper.

title: Treasury Rates Hold Steady
description: Interest rates on Treasury securities were little changed yesterday, despite widespread talk about the likelihood of interest-rate cuts by the world's largest economies within the next month or so.

title: POP: SOSA INN PROGRAM OF PROTEST SONGS
description: WITH her bountiful voice, her subtle timing, her international repertory and her fine-tuned sense of drama, the Argentine singer Mercedes Sosa ranks with the world's finest popular singers. She has chosen to devote herself to nueva cancion (''new song''), the romantic protest songs of Latin America - and she may well be their most eloquent interpreter. Monday, she brought a virtually reverent crowd to the Delacorte Theater, where she topped a program of nueva cancion performers - billed as the Concert for Peace and Friendship - that also included Grupo Mancotal from Nicaragua and the singer Eugenia Leon from Mexico.

title: U.S. CHIPS FACE TEST IN JAPAN
description: The recent agreement between the United States and Japan for the resolution of their long-simmering trade dispute over computer chips called for Japan to make its demanding market more accessible to American manufacturers. The pact is expected to allow American companies to raise their sales over the next five years to about 20 percent of the market here, more than double their current share.

title: Orbiting the Wall
description: That ignoble monument to Communism's failure, the wall through Berlin, was built 25 years ago on Soviet orders, to halt the humiliating flood of refugees from East to West. The tide then dwindled to a trickle, but those who somehow got past the wall were granted automatic asylum by West Germany. Now, with malign cunning, East Germany is inviting the wretched of the earth to avail themselves of the asylum forbidden its own people.

title: GENERAL NUTRITION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 19
description: b-After a charge of $3,500,000 for the settlement of a lawsuit.

title: Accounts
description: * New Woman, a fitness center chain in the New York-New Jersey-Connecticut area, to Princeton Partners, in New Jersey.

title: SENATE APPROVES CURB ON PAC CAMPAIGN GIVING
description: The Senate today approved a proposal for a major change in the way political campaigns are financed by voting to place limits on the contributions Congressional candidates can receive from political action committees.

title: House Approves a Proposal To Bolster Embassy Security
description: The House today approved the Administration's $1.1 billion proposal to improve security at United States embassies and other Government offices abroad.

title: GRAPHIC TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: THE PLACE WHERE REAL TEXANS EAT SOUP
description: THE regulars at El Mirador don't like to use the word addiction, but they also make no pretense about being in full control of their lives on Saturday afternoons.

title: Striking Detroit Drivers Accept New Contract
description: Striking suburban bus drivers ratified a new contract today, ending a five-day walkout that had halted service for 40,000 commuters.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: From Teas to Takeout Lamston's has just opened its second Cookworld. This one, at 205 East 42d Street, is a food, gift, table and kitchenware emporium about triple the size of the original Cookworld in the World Trade Center, which opened in November 1984.

title: Bridge: Player in California Tourney Resigns as League Member
description: The Summer National Championships of the American Bridge Association, being played this week in Los Angeles, are the biggest since the organization was founded 34 years ago by black players who had been excluded from some club and tournament play.

title: NAILS ARE GETTING READY FOR DATE AT BOTTOM LINE
description: THE NAILS have come a long way since the late 1970's, when they played mostly Jamaican-derived ska and reggae and were opening shows around New York City for British ska bands like Madness. In those days they were mostly energy and rough edges, and this writer remembers them mainly for the excellence of Douglas Guthrie's sly, serpentine saxophone work.

title: CHAIRMEN SEEK ACCORD
description: After an unusually acrimonious session this morning, House and Senate conferees broke up this afternoon expressing optimism about the prospects of reaching agreement on a comprehensive tax revision bill this week.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Arthur A. Marshall Jr., the prosecutor handling the case concerning the death of Len Bias, said that Lefty Driesell, the Maryland basketball coach, has been issued a subpoena.

title: 9 Colombian Soldiers Killed in Rebel Ambush
description: Nine Colombian soldiers were killed today when leftist guerrillas attacked an army patrol. The Defense Ministry said it was the fourth rebel attack since President Virgilio Barco Vargas took office five days ago.

title: To South Africa's Rulers, the Enemy Is the West
description: To the Editor:

title: ARC INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Year to April 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $399,800. c-Includes an extraordinary gain of $2,630,259 on the sale of recreational properties, and tax benefits of $1,485,000. The company said the latest year results include sales of $6.3 million generated by wholly owned subsidiary Cabletel Communications Inc., acquired in December 1985.

title: REVISING FASHION'S CALENDAR
description: It may be August outdoors, but in the department stores mannequins are swathed in January's leathers and furs. By the time January comes, of course, it will be summer in the stores, with overcoats all but sold out and mannequins diving into swimsuits.

title: LED DRIVE FOR TAX LIMIT
description: Howard Jarvis, a flamboyant Californian who helped start the nation's tax revolt of the late 1970's, died tonight at Midway Medical Center in Los Angeles.

title: NEWPARK RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from joint venture operations of $3,708,000 for the quarter and $5,364,000 for the 6 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,364,000 for the quarter and $1,444,000 for the 6 months.

title: Final Comment
description: It was a long day for Bob Tway. He won the PGA Championship Monday afternoon in Toledo, Ohio, by sinking his ball out of a sand trap on the 18th green at the Inverness Club, then there were the ceremonies, the interviews, the theft of a watch and some money from his golf bag, connecting flights and other delays before he got to Castle Rock, Colo., the site of the next PGA Tour event.

title: HOUSE, 239 TO 176, DECIDES TO REDUCE 'STAR WARS' MONEY
description: The Democratic-controlled House of Representatives handed the Reagan Administration two defeats on military policy today by cutting the budget for the space-based missile-defense program and by requiring adherence to the unratified 1979 strategic arms treaty.

title: FIRST EXECUTIVE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes realized gains of $6,513,000 for the quarter and $12,623,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes realized gains of $9,767,000 and $14,905,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: U.S. SAID TO BACK AFFIRMATIVE ACTION CHALLENGE
description: The Justice Department will not challenge 51 affirmative action plans around the nation, as it had hoped, but will give its tacit approval to unions and individuals who challenge voluntary plans that ''invoke racial preferences that trammel or infringe unnecessarily on the rights of third parties,'' William Bradford Reynolds, the Assistant Attorney General for Civil Rights, said yesterday.

title: CUOMO COURT NOMINATIONS NOT IDEOLOGICAL, EXPERTS SAY
description: In his judicial nominations, Governor Cuomo has, for the most part, met the standards that he has urged President Reagan to apply to Federal nominations, legal scholars, judges and lawyers say.

title: Clio Awards to Honor Marketing in Spanish
description: The Clio Awards will go bilingual next year. Radio, television and print categories designated for Spanish-language advertising in the United States are being added to the competition, reflecting the growth of Hispanic marketing efforts.

title: DOING BUSINESS WITH CITY: DELAY FED BY CAUTION
description: Earlier this year, people in and out of government were saying that the corruption scandal had stalled, even paralyzed, the city's ability to conduct business, to approve contracts, to hire.

title: CLIPS FROM TOP TO TOE
description: 1. Dressing Up Shoes Give an old pair of shoes a brand new look with these French-made shoe clips by Isabel Canovas.

title: LYLE K. ENGEL, BOOK PRODUCER, 71
description: Lyle Kenyon Engel, who produced hundreds of books, of which there are more than 100 million copies in print, died of leukemia Sunday at Jackson Memorial Hospital in Miami. He was 71 years old.

title: Lloyd Burlingham Dies at 75; Was Foreign Service Officer
description: Lloyd Burlingham, a former Foreign Service officer with the United States Information Agency, died of cancer Sunday at his home in Perry, N.Y. He was 75 years old.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''We are confident that after a full and impartial investigation, Mr. Deaver will be cleared of any wrongdoing, including the suggestion today that he may possibly have committed perjury.''

title: Lieberman Out
description: Her credentials as a pioneer secure, Nancy Lieberman, the first woman to play in a men's professional basketball league, has left the Springfield Fame because of a thumb injury and says she will not be able to return to the United States Basketball League this season.

title: SRI LANKANS FOUND ADRIFT PAID UP TO $5,000 TO REACH CANADA
description: One hundred and fifty-two people found crammed into two lifeboats off Newfoundland were identified today as Sri Lankans who had apparently paid thousands of dollars to be brought by freighter to the shores of Canada.

title: Tandon Loses $20.3 Million
description: The Tandon Corporation said today that it lost $20.3 million for the quarter ended June 29, compared with a loss of $15 million a year ago. Revenues were $51.8 million, down 16.9 percent from $62.3 million for the third quarter of 1985.

title: Chilean Court Blames Army for Burning Death
description: A military court reversed a civilian judge today and accused an army patrol commander of ''unnecessary violence'' in the burning death of a Chilean-born United States resident during anti-Government demonstrations.

title: Kennecott Plans To Recall Workers
description: The Kennecott Corporation said it would begin recalling employees to prepare for resumption of production at its giant Utah Copper division.

title: U.S. TO DEFINE 'LIGHT' ALCOHOL BEVERAGES
description: A Federal agency, saying it hoped to ''minimize consumer confusion in this complex area,'' announced today that it would attempt to determine what constitutes ''light'' or ''lite'' alcoholic beverages.

title: AMERICAN MUSEUM OF HISTORIAL DOCUMENTS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: European Trade Delay
description: The European Community has delayed ratifying an accord with the United States that would reduce trade curbs on various products, including citrus and pasta, a trade official said today.

title: Score 2 for Fairness In Divorce Courts
description: The New York State Legislature has begun to remedy the lopsided application of divorce statutes by passing two bills that were signed earlier this month by Governor Cuomo - one that toughens sanctions against fathers who fail to make child support payments and another that tries to equalize distribution of income in a divorce. These actions should be applauded for seeking a remedy for judicial decisions that have favored breadwinner spouses. But more needs to be done.

title: STUDY EXPECTED TO URGE SMOKING BAN ON ALL DOMESTIC FLIGHTS
description: A study by the National Academy of Sciences recommends that the Government ban cigarette smoking on all domestic airline flights, contending that smoke in large jetliners is harmful to health and safety, sources said today.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Beck Won't Play in 1986-87
description: Phil Esposito and Ted Sator, the head Rangers, called a news conference yesterday to announce that Barry Beck, the defenseman who is the team's captain, has decided he doesn't want to play hockey for the Rangers this season. But he apparently doesn't want to play for anyone else either.

title: Charges Filed
description: Robin Monsky, the Atlanta Braves' director of media information whose duties were sharply curtailed in June, ostensibly because of her insistence on circulating batting and other statistics pointing up team weaknesses, has concluded that the real reason she was barred from road trips and banned from the field before home games was because she is a woman. Ms. Monsky made the charge in a complaint mailed Monday to the Atlanta office of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission. The Braves' general manager, Bobby Cox, denied that Ms. Monsky's gender had anything to do with limiting her duties, but also said that it was not because of the ''negative statistics'' either.

title: CHINESE NOODLES, THE PASTA BEFORE MARCO POLO
description: WHEN I see packages of freshly made Chinese noodles, I often think of the ''bamboo stick'' noodles of my childhood in Canton and how I watched them being made.

title: STODDARD SAVES YANKS AFTER NIEDRO EXITS EARLY
description: If he had a chance to keep himself in the Yankees' starting pitching rotation, Joe Niekro pitched himself out of it last night. Tim Stoddard, on the other hand, pitched himself into the good graces of the manager by restoring some semblance of sanity to a game that threatened to become one of the more forgettable played at Yankee Stadium this season.

title: COMMUNICATIONS GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $38,000 for the latest quarter and $15,000 for the year-ago period.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The Ohio Public Facilities Commission is offering $120 million of higher education facilities revenue bonds through underwriters led by the Chase Manhattan Capital Markets Corporation.

title: THE RIPPER RETURNS
description: Rip Van Winkle returned. Since the last time he had seen a major-league baseball game, he had been in Monterrey, Queretaro, Puebla, Toluca, Mexico City, Moscow, Leningrad, Helsinki, Frankfurt, Cardiff, Laugharne, St. David's, Tregaron and London.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * American Motors Corp., Southfield, Mich., said its stockholders had approved an issue of eight million shares of a new class of senior convertible preferred stock, which would be sold to the public for about $187 million.

title: Mobil in Canada
description: The new head of the Mobil Corporation's Canadian unit was quoted today as saying that plans to develop the Canadian Hibernia oilfield and the Venture gas field would be postponed for at least two years. Mike Smith, former head of Mobil's Norwegian unit, said in an interview with the Norwegian Journal of Commerce and Shipping that low oil prices were behind the Mobil decision.

title: HEALTHCARE SERVICES OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
RETAIL SALES ADVANCED BY A SLIGHT 0.1% IN JULY
description: Retail sales rose a tiny one-tenth of 1 percent in July as department store and furniture store strength only partly offset a big drop in auto sales, the Government said today.

title: STUDY SAY BIRTH CONTROL PILL IS NOT A BREAST CANCER PERIL
description: Longtime use of birth control pills does not increase a woman's risk of breast cancer even if she has a family history of the disease, the largest study ever conducted on the question has concluded.

title: WURLITZER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $863,000.

title: Premium Put On Daring
description: This week's PGA Tour event, The International, will use modified Stableford scoring, a system developed in 1931 by Dr. Frank B. G. Stableford in Britain and still used there, as well as in Australia and South Africa.

title: PRESIDENT WINS TEST IN SENATE ON CONTRA AID
description: The Senate gave President Reagan a major foreign policy triumph tonight by approving his request for $100 million in aid to the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: When Landscaping Blurs Architecture
description: LAST winter we stripped all the ivy off the walls of the house, the garden, off the boles of the trees, and most of it off the ground. I had been observing its not-so-slow encroachment passively, perhaps even feeling that to be enveloped in a green mantle like a rising tide from the earth itself was some sort of signal of acceptance; of creation's blessing on my boldness in being here at all.

title: MANHATTAN NATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes realized gains of $740,000 for the quarter and $832,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes realized gains of $44,000 for the quarter and $581,000 for the 6 months.

title: Perry's Farm Fails
description: Gaylord Perry, the only pitcher to win the Cy Young Award in both the American and National Leagues, is now among the ranks of farmers in financial trouble. He and his wife have filed for bankruptcy, claiming debts of $1 million due to troubles similar to those that are plaguing many of their North Carolina neighbors.

title: QUAREX INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
DATARAM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $375,000, or 19 cents a share, from the sale of securities.

title: Air Liquide Issue
description: L'Air Liquide S.A. said it planned a new issue of stock to help finance its proposed $1.05 billion acquisition of Big Three Industries of Houston.

title: BERCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
description: b-Net income

title: HOUSE BUDGET PANEL LOOKS FOR $10 BILLION IN NEW CUTS
description: The House Budget Committee has began searching for about $10 billion in new budget cuts, its chairman said today.

title: People
description: * Harvey Greisman has been appointed director of corporate affairs at GTE, Stamford, Conn.

title: SCEPTRE RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.S. AND SOVIET SAID TO TRY TO LIMIT FALLOUT PACT
description: The United States and the Soviet Union are trying to limit a proposed international convention that would require countries to report fully on any release of radioactivity, according to officials here.

title: QUESTECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: 2 CHAIRMEN NEAR TAX AGREEMENT
description: After they had been closeted all afternoon and late into the evening in a small room on the second floor of the Capitol, Senator Bob Packwood and Representative Dan Rostenkowski indicated tonight that they were on the verge of agreement on the main elements of a tax revision bill.

title: Schools Will Toughen Regulations on Crack
description: Schools Chancellor Nathan Quinones said yesterday that to impress upon students the dangers of the drug crack, stiffer rules would be enforced starting this school year.

title: NEW JERSEY RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: A COUSIN'S DEATH SPURS A LAWYER'S OBSESSION
description: Early yesterday morning, Daniel Wotman made his regular visit to the corner of Broadway and Cathedral Parkway in upper Manhattan. He laid his suit coat over the railing of a subway entrance and he put his briefcase down on the sidewalk. Then, he opened it and withdrew 200 fliers, each with the college graduation picture of an eager and gangly young man beneath thick black letters saying ''TRAGIC ACCIDENT.''

title: SILTEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After pre-tax charges of $7,026,000 for the quarter and $7,756,000 for the 6 months for facility consolidation and a pre-tax charge of $3,243,000 for inventory writeoffs and reserves for the quarter and 6 months and tax credits of $3.5 million and $3,675,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: REP. FOWLER BEATS JORDAN IN GEORGIA
description: An Atlanta Congressman, Wyche Fowler Jr., will be the Democratic challenger next fall against Senator Mack Mattingly as a result of his impressive victory in Tuesday's primary over Hamilton Jordan.

title: STOCKS AND BONDS RISE SMARTLY
description: The stock market recorded a strong performance yesterday, shrugging off talk of a correction with its third gain of the week.

title: CAR SALES WERE UP 7.4% IN EARLY AUGUST
description: Sales of new American-made cars rose 7.4 percent in the Aug. 1-10 period, on a daily sales basis, from early August of last year, the leading manufacturers reported today. Light-truck sales were even stronger, climbing 18.4 percent from last year's period.

title: MODULAIRE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
UNIT DRILLING & EXPLORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Leaders in Philadelphia Assail Racial Incidents
description: The Philadelphia Commission on Human Relations convened a meeting of city leaders today to discuss a recent series of racial incidents while four religious groups issued a joint statement condemning racial intolerance.

title: To Save the Children
description: To the Editor:

WILFRED AMERICAN EDUCAIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.S. AIDES QUALIFY REMARKS FAVORING TALKS WITH PRETORIA
description: The Administration moved today to qualify President Reagan's announced support for an international conference with South Africa, indicating there had been a misunderstanding of President P. W. Botha's proposal for such a parley.

title: Nonsmokers' Air Discount
description: Continental Airlines said yesterday that it would offer discounts on future travel to all nonsmoking passengers on a trial basis.

title: LYNCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HERS
description: A FRIEND of mine has challenged, in a brusque and fatherly manner, my driving technique. He objects to the way I deploy my feet - I seem to be using one too many of them on the brake and accelerator pedals. I am wounded by his comments instead of grateful and puzzled by my reaction. It is news to me that I am supposed to use the same foot on brake and accelerator and news I should welcome; that procedure does seem logical and safer. In any case, I am not obliged to change my arrangements on his say-so.

title: Monitor Picked For Robins
description: A former bankruptcy court judge from Utah was appointed today to oversee the A. H. Robins Company, which has sought protection from creditors because of a flood of damage claims filed by Dalkon Shield users. The appointment of former

title: STUDENT CHARGED IN KILLING ON CAMPUS IS CALLED LONER
description: The college student accused of killing one person and seriously wounding four others Tuesday in a shooting rampage on a Brooklyn campus was a loner who spent some time in a Georgia mental institution and kept his distance from people, his family and neighbors said yesterday.

title: KEYSTONE CAMERA PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Moral Subsidies For Moscow
description: A few months ago, not long before Kurt Waldheim was inaugurated President of Austria, it was suggested that, as a form of moral protest, James Levine, the renowned artistic director of the Metropolitan Opera, should cancel his scheduled appearances at this summer's Salzburg Festival, where he has performed annually for the past decade. The suggestion created something of an international stir. But Mr. Levine is not a political person, and nothing came of the idea.

title: APPLIED DNA SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: INDUSTRIAL DESIGNERS TAKING THE HIGH ROAD
description: ''MANY people think God designs products, or that they spring from the head of Zeus,'' said Katherine J. McCoy, co-chairman of the design department at the Cranbrook Academy of Art in Bloomfield Hills, Mich.

title: HOUSE VOTES TO DELAY 2 WEAPONS IN NEW ARMS SETBACK FOR REAGAN
description: The House today dealt the Reagan Administration new setbacks on arms control, voting for a one-year moratorium on testing of the antisatellite missile in space and narrowly approving a one-year delay in the production of new chemical weapons.

title: SUPERTITLES, THE DEMYSTIFIERS OF OPERA
description: AUDIENCE polls at the New York City Opera and the Chicago Lyric Opera have indicated an overwhelming enthusiasm for supertitles, but there are still pugnacious voices raised against the practice. Supertitles are a childishly didactic insult to the literate opera audience, we read. They subvert any motivation to prepare oneself properly for the operatic experience. They absolve the singer of the need to articulate the text. They destroy the moment-by-moment, word-to-note correlation of musical drama.

title: Saying No to $10 Million
description: Although it is by no means unheard of, it is worthy of note when a Federal agency spurns a budget increase.

title: Off the Street And Into the Park
description: There was a touch of the Olympics in Central Park yesterday. A young runner carried a torch around the cheering crowd in front of the bandshell. Dozens of purple, red, white, blue and orange balloons were released into the air from black plastic garbage bags.

title: SCHWAB QUITS BANK AMERICA BOARD
description: Charles R. Schwab, the discount broker who has become known as the dissident on the board of the Bank America Corporation, has resigned as a director of the ailing bank holding company.

title: NEW QUEST FOR AUTHENTICITY
description: STRIDING onto terrain that has long been a no man's land between historical scholarship and home restoration, Ann Kiewel faced the audience of 50 people in the front parlor of an 1830 mansion. ''Homeowners,'' she said, ''meet your local historians. We're glad that you're here, and I urge all of you to get to know one another today.'' The group set about doing just that. On this particular morning people from four states gathered to participate in a daylong workshop that blended historians' insights about the architecture of the 19th-century house with panel discussions among homeowners in historic districts, and hands-on demonstrations of restoration arts.

title: ENVIRODYNE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $800,000 and $1,000,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes tax credits of $992,000 for the quarter and $1,703,000 for the 6 months. The company said the latest quarter and 6-month periods include the results for Viskase Corp., acquired in February.

description: There were no share earnings for the latest periods after preferred dividends.

description: The company said net income in the latest quarter and year-ago quarter reflects a new accounting procedure adopted after the company went public in March.

PLAINS PETROLEUM LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The year-ago 6 months' revenue excludes the effect of $1,885,000 of revenue applicable to price increases on 1984 gas production which were reported in the first half of 1985.

title: British Output Down
description: Britain's seasonally adjusted output in all industries fell by 1.2 percent in June from May, and was down 1.3 percent from a year earlier, according to an initial report today from the United Kingdom Central Statistical Office.

title: ROYALE AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: TOM GREENWADE
description: Tom Greenwade, the scout who signed Mickey Mantle and helped persuade the Brooklyn Dodgers to bring Jackie Robinson into the major leagues, died Saturday.

title: I.B.M. Aide Is Named Head of Torchmark
description: The Torchmark Corporation, an insurance and financial services holding company in Birmingham, Ala., yesterday named Jon W. Rotenstreich, a 43-year-old vice president and treasurer of the International Business Machines Corporation, as its president.

title: SEAVER WINS 310TH, BEATING ROYALS, 5-2
description: Jim Rice drove in two runs on three hits tonight as the Boston Red Sox defeated the Kansas City Royals, 5-2, and ended a three-game losing streak. Tom Seaver (6-10) scattered nine hits over seven and two-thirds innings for his 310th career victory. Seaver, who struck out four and walked one, shut out the Royals after the first inning. Calvin Schiraldi finished up for his fourth save.

title: MEXICO JAILS EX-POLICE OFFICIAL IN BRIBE CASE
description: A former police commander has been sentenced to four years in prison for taking a bribe from a reputed drug trafficker accused in the slaying of a United States narcotics agent.

title: Group Raises Stake in Kaiser
description: A group led by the investor Joseph A. Frates of Tulsa, Okla., said today that it had increased its stake in the Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation to 26.5 percent, or about 11.8 million shares, from 21.6 percent. The announcement was the first move by the group since its attempt to replace Kaiser's board was defeated by shareholders on April 29.

title: NEWPORT ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

description: b-After a charge of $2,097,000 for the repurchase and retirement of $762,000 of subordinated notes. c-Net income The year-ago results restated to reflect the adoption of Statement of Financial Accounting Standands No. 87.
