CORRECTION
description: Because of a mechanical error, an obituary July 29 of Dr. Amolak Ram Mehta, a retired deputy director general of health services for the Government of India, incorrectly described him as a former Cabinet member. The article also misidentified one of his survivors, Ashok Mehta. Mr. Mehta is one of Dr. Mehta's three sons.

title: Noted Army Division Returns From Limbo
description: To the Editor:

title: UNIVERSAL MEDICAL BUILDNGS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PROS BIRDIE AD BOGEY THE BRITISH WAY
description: The PGA Tour introduced today a new golf tournament, The International, with a new scoring format based on points.

title: Paola Welles Dead in Crash
description: Paola Mori Welles, the widow of the actor and director Orson Welles, died Tuesday of head injuries suffered in an automobile accident, the authorities said today. Mrs. Welles, who was 57 years old, died of head injuries several hours after the crash, which occurred near her Las Vegas home. The police said the car in which she was riding pulled into the path of another car. Mrs. Welles, the Countess di Girafalco, who acted in Italian films as Paola Mori, was the third wife of the actor, who died last October. They had a daughter, Beatrice.

title: VSE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
The DuBois Memorial
description: Just before her death in April 1977, Shirley Graham DuBois, widow of W. E. B. DuBois, voiced concern that her husband's work in Ghana would not be continued and that his contributions to that African nation would not be remembered.

title: EMC INSURANCE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes capital gains of $99,457 for the quarter and $152,944 for the 6 months. c-Includes capital gains of $225,120 and $220,084 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: WHEN PARENTS VISIT THE FIRST APARTMENT
description: SUSANNAH GAYLORD raced around the apartment, pulling piles of clothes off the floor, twisting garbage ties and trying to compensate as best she could for the lack of a vacuum. It was Miss Gaylord's first apartment, and her parents were on the way.

title: U.S. Women Gain Semifinal
description: Cheryl Miller scored 22 points today to lead the United States to a 99-74 victory over China and a berth in the semifinals of the Women's World Basketball Championships.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: ALTHOUGH a broken window pane has often been the subject of humorous cartoons, most homeowners find that a broken pane is not at all funny. When a window does get broken, whether through an accident or vandalism, replacing the glass has a high priority, to keep out wind and rain as well as to conserve energy.

title: CITY'S AIDES SAY A NEW BUILDING RISES TOO HIGH
description: By the time the order to halt work was issued in mid-July, the concrete superstructure for all 31 floors of the apartment building under construction at 108 East 96th Street had been completed.

title: BUSINESSES FARMS FEED ARE COLLAPSING IN SOUTH
description: Here and across the South, in the areas hardest hit by drought, the historic spirit and economic structure of the region's agriculture are breaking down.

title: Postage-Due Notice Change
description: The postage-due stamp is being discontinued in its present form, the United States Postal Service said Monday. In use since 1879 to show how much money was owed when a mailer had not prepaid the full amount of postage, the red stamp with black numbers is to be replaced by postage meter labels and rubber stamps.

title: ALOHA INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain of $2.8 million from disposal of a leasehold interest in a DC-10 aircraft.

title: Always a Hit
description: Saturnino Orestes Arrieta Armas Minoso, who was known as Minnie during his playing days with the Indians, the White Sox, the Cardinals and the Senators, will carry a three-game hitting streak into Sunday's Equitable Old-Timers game at Comiskey Park in Chicago. The 63-year-old outfielder has played in 3 of 19 games already played in the 26-game series to raise money for former players in need of financial assistance.

title: BOARD PUTS ASIDE SCHOOL VANS PLAN
description: Facing the threat of a lawsuit, the city's Board of Education decided yesterday to put aside its plan to lease sites at 14 religious institutions for remedial instruction of parochial school students.

title: PETROMINERALS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The year-ago 6 months results include a writedown of oil and gas properties of $4,752,000, net of taxes.

title: MUSIC: CONCERTOS OF MOZART AND HAYDN
description: MOZART shared the spotlight with his mentor Franz Joseph Haydn Tuesday night when Sergiu Comissiona led the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra in a program of concertos and symphonies at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: AUTOCLAVE ENGINEERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The company said the latest quarter results include a pre-tax writedown of $660,000 for changes in product line and market specifications and a writeoff of about $100,000 for a terminated research project in settlement of a royalty claim.

title: Panel Clears Fed Nominee
description: The Senate Banking Committee today approved the nomination of H. Robert Heller, the California banking economist, to become a member of the Federal Reserve Board.

title: TRACTOR SLUMP SEEN ENDING
description: Charles B. Weeks and his wife, Lois, see nothing but ''great opportunity'' for the tractor dealership they recently bought in Belvidere, Ill. ''There is a lot of old and used equipment out there that has to be traded in,'' Mr. Weeks said.

title: PETROLEUM EQUIPMENT TOOLS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Bouncing Back To a Golden Year
description: Saturday will bring special memories for the 10 surviving members of the American basketball team that went to the 1936 Olympics in Berlin. The team won all four of its games and took the first gold medal in the sport on Aug. 16, 1936 with a 19-8 defeat of Canada in the final played on a clay tennis court.

title: 20 JUDGES TO SHIFT TO CRIMINAL COURT
description: Twenty of the 57 judges sitting in New York City's Civil Court system will be transferred to Criminal Court next month to stem a ''crisis'' brought on by the increase in drug arrests this year, the state's Chief Judge said yesterday.

title: Redskins Sign Bryant
description: Kelvin Bryant, the United States Football League's second-leading career rusher behind Herschel Walker, signed a four-year contract with the Washington Redskins today, reportedly worth $3 million.

title: MORLAN INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
All Yields Off Again
description: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds fell in the week ended yesterday. Some analysts believe yields will decline to levels approaching those on passbook savings accounts, especially if there is another cut in the discount rate.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Ameribanc Investors Group, Washington, D.C., has elected Arthur C. Weid chairman of its board of trustees, succeeding Peter S. Zwart.

title: USING ENGLISH ELM
description: English elm, apart from occasionally producing the much-prized burl veneer, has not excelled as a furniture wood. Its use has been limited mainly to straight-forward chairs and the seats of Windsor chairs. Its medium-brown wood darkens somewhat with age, and a curly and erratic grain with large pores usually distinguishes the surface, depending on where the log was sliced.

title: WALKER AND COWBOYS AGREE ON TERMS
description: Herschel Walker, the 24-year-old running back who had been the United States Football League's most celebrated player, agreed to terms today on a five-year contract with the Dallas Cowboys.

REFAC TECHNOLOGY DEVELOPENT CORPORATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings were restated for 20 percent stock dividend on Dec. 31, 1985.

title: RE-CREATING THE PERIOD DETAILS OF A 1795 CONNECTICUT HOUSE
description: NOT all authentic restorations start with a passion for such work. When Peter Anderson, a data-processing supervisor at the Travelers Insurance Company in Hartford, and his wife, Margaret, purchased a five-bedroom, center-chimney house in Southington, Conn., 11 years ago, they didn't know - or care - that it dated back to 1795. At $38,500 it was affordable, albeit rather shabby, and initially they intended only to make it more comfortable.

title: But Not as Chief Justice
description: What test should the Senate apply to his nomination as Chief Justice of the United States? It should be, says William Rehnquist, ''Have I fairly construed the Constitution in my 15 years as an Associate Justice?''

title: PAKISTAN SEIZES HUNDREDS OF DISSIDENTS
description: Hundreds of political dissidents, including the opposition leader Benazir Bhutto, were arrested or forced to restrict their movements today in the widest crackdown on Government critics since martial law was lifted last year.

title: TWO GOALS IN A PLAN FOR SUBWAYS SEEM INNFEASIBLE, OFFICIAL INDICATES
description: The Transit Authority will probably fail to meet two of its year-end subway ''passenger environment'' goals, an agency executive indicated yesterday.

title: A Case of Saving Face
description: To the Editor:

title: KOENIG INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Bills Sign Harmon
description: Ronnie Harmon, who rushed for 2,442 yards and 22 touchdowns during his four seasons at Iowa and starred at Bayside High School in Queens before that, has signed a series of one-year contracts with the Buffalo Bills. The 22-year-old Harmon was the first of Buffalo's two first-round draft choices. . . . The Chicago Bears signed their first-round choice, Neal Anderson of Florida, a running back.

title: Anticrime Demonstration
description: About 17 million people took to their front stoops Tuesday night in the third annual National Night Out against crime, the demonstration's organizer, Matt Peskin, said today. More than 4,700 communities in 49 states participated in the neighborhood watch, as against 2,100 communities last year, he said. Alaska was the only state that did not participate.

title: ELDON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for 16wks to July 12
STAGE: 'ABOUT LOVE,' WITH NORMA ALEANDRO
description: ABOUT halfway through the one-woman show in Spanish by the Argentine actress Norma Aleandro, I removed the headset that was available for simultaneous English translation. Language almost did not matter. Miss Aleandro's eyes and hands and balletic movements succeeded, like a pantominist's, in conveying the meaning of her small, personalized stories.

title: AMERICAN EDUCATIONAL COMUTER INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss The company said the earnings for 1986 were negatively impacted by about $65,000 due to a receivable reserve established against the entire account of a major distributor that filed for Chapter 11 protection during the second quarter.

title: '20/20' CHALLENGES REPORTS ON TRIBE
description: IT is not often that one network bashes another's news story; when bashing does take place, however, it can be fun to see. ABC's ''20/20'' tonight bashes a report that was on NBC. Are the Tasadays of Mindanao in the Philippine Islands a primitive people, or are they political, anthropological and public-relations fakes? NBC, as well as many print organizations, said the first; ''20/20'' says the latter. The program can be seen on Channel 7 at 10 o'clock.

description: To the Editor:

title: Hallmark TV Deal Opposed
description: A group of Hispanic executives who want to acquire the nation's largest group of Spanish-language television stations has filed a motion in Federal District Court in Los Angeles seeking to block the sale of the stations to Hallmark Cards Inc. and a Chicago investment concern.

title: REAGAN AND DE LA MADRID HAVE A 'FRUITFTUL' SESSION

New Coppola Film to Close Festival
description: ''Peggy Sue Got Married,'' a new film by Francis Coppola, will have its premiere at Avery Fisher Hall on Oct. 5, the last day of the 24th New York Film Festival. The festival, which highlights 26 feature films from around the world, opens Sept. 19 with ''Down by Law'' by Jim Jarmusch; opening-night screenings are at 7:45 P.M. at Alice Tully Hall and at 9 P.M. at Avery Fisher Hall. All of the other films, with the exception of closing night, will be shown at Alice Tully Hall. The short films to be shown have yet to be announced. On the schedule are these films: ''The Blind Director'' by Alexander Kluge (Sept. 21 and 22); ''Cactus'' by Paul Cox (Sept. 23 and 26); ''Charlotte and Lulu'' by Claude Miller (Sept. 24 and 25); ''Dancing in the Dark'' by Leon Marr (Sept. 25 and 27); ''Decline of the American Empire'' by Denys Arcand (Sept. 27 and 29), ''Directed by William Wyler'' by Aviva Slesin and ''Dodsworth'' by William Wyler (Sept. 20).

AMERICAN HEALTHCARE MANGEMENT reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
The Arm on Reagan
description: Was Ronald Reagan used, and was the White House staff manipulated, by Michael Deaver in landing a $2-million-a-year group of accounts with the South Korean Government? The White House Counsel, Peter Wallison, thinks not; I think so. 1. While representing Philip Morris in its efforts to penetrate the lucrative South Korean cigarette market, Mr. Deaver - in Seoul last summer - approached Kim Kihwan, the Korean President's confidant, with a pitch for the Government's business. He also assured Richard (Dixie) Walker (the right-winger, not the right fielder) that President Reagan had decided to extend his appointment as Ambassador to South Korea. Ambassador Walker knocked himself out to help Mr. Deaver. 2. On Oct. 1, 1985, the eager-to-please Ambassador Walker called Mr. Deaver in Washington. According to the thorough reporting in the Far East by Martin Tolchin and Stuart Diamond of The New York Times, Ambassador Walker says Mr. Deaver suggested that Dr. Kim meet President Reagan in the Oval Office. I suspect the South Koreans were led to believe that the Deaver magic could bring this about. 3. Ambassador Walker that day cabled Gaston Sigur of the National Security Council on the C.I.A. ''back channel,'' circumventing the usual State Department communications. In that cable, which has been read to me, Ambassador Walker said that Dr. Kim was on his way to Washington carrying a letter about Korean-American trade from the Korean President to the U.S. President, and that having him deliver the letter in person would dramatize its importance. Mr. Deaver's hand was concealed: at first, Ambassador Walker tried to hide his own role in setting up the meeting but, when recently reminded by the White House of his cable's existence, called The Times back later with the painful truth. 4.

title: BUSINESS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, AUGUST 14, 1986
description: The Economy The heads of the Senate and House tax delegations neared an agreement on the main elements of a tax overhaul bill. Representative Rostenkowski said that he and Senator Packwood might have a completed package ready to present to the other conferees by noon today. If so, the conference committee should be able to reach a basic accord by the end of the week, when Congress begins a three-week recess, although formal approval cannot come until after Labor Day. [ Page D1. ] Retail sales inched up 0.1 percent in July. The rise would have been more, but a big drop in auto sales held the total down. Many economists are optimistic about consumer buying in the months ahead. [ D1. ] Sales of new American-made cars rose 7.4 percent in the Aug. 1-10 period, compared with the period last year. [ D6. ] A bill to help deal with failures of financial institutions was approved by the Senate Banking Committee. The bill would provide $15 billion over three years to the fund that insures thrift institution deposits, and it would give Federal regulators emergency powers to arrange bank takeovers. [ D15. ] The House Budget panel is seeking ways to cut $10 billion in Federal spending. [ A24. ] Companies Charles R. Schwab resigned from the BankAmerica board. Mr. Schwab had become known as the dissident among the ailing bank's directors. He joined the board in 1983 after selling his Charles Schwab & Company discount brokerage to the bank in a deal that made him BankAmerica's largest shareholder, but he has since sold most of his stock. Mr. Schwab said last night that he was leaving the board to give full attention to the brokerage.

description: WHEN Scali, McCabe, Sloves acquired a majority interest in Fallon McElligott in February, it was buying into a Minneapolis-based shop with a growing national reputation. Yesterday Scali announced that it would purchase a majority stake in another hot regional agency. This time it is the Martin Agency of Richmond, and as with Fallon McElligott, Scali said the main attraction was the shop's creative reputation.

Name That Team
description: It isn't true that having the name ''Williams'' automatically qualifies a player for a football scholarship at the University of Florida, but it doesn't seem to be a handicap. The Gators could start as many as five Williamses this season - Anthony (fullback), David (offensive tackle), Jarvis (defensive back), Keith (defensive tackle) and Wayne (tailback).

title: Remaking an 1835 Stoop
description: DONNA and Jack McCarthy wanted a traditional single-family row house in Brooklyn Heights, but a dozen years ago they could afford only one that had been ruined architecturally. The interior of the 151-year-old brick house had been chopped into apartments, and its exterior had been stripped of its ornate cornice, ironwork and stoop.

description: b-After a gain of $4.1 million from the sale of interest in a uranium property. c-Net loss The year-ago results are restated to reflect the spinoff of Plains Petroleum Co. in September 1985.

title: Memo Tells of Idleness At Transit Repair Shop
description: Workers at the Coney Island subway maintenance shop were playing cards and standing around idle when a Transit Authority official made a surprise inspection last week, according to an internal agency memo.

title: Market Place; Streamlining Transamerica
description: THE Transamerica Corporation's sale of the Budget Rent a Car Corporation this week marks a major step in the once-unfocused conglomerate's effort to return to its roots in insurance and financial services. But the company may not find any immediate rewards on Wall Street.

title: Los Angeles Deputy Exonerated in Shooting
description: No charges are to be filed against the sheriff's marksman who killed the manager of a Beverly Hills jewelry store in the mistaken belief that he was the gunman who had killed two hostages in a robbery attempt, prosecutors say.

title: LOTUS PLANS VOLUME SALES
description: The Lotus Development Corporation, the largest maker of software for personal computers, said yesterday that it would sell software in volume directly to major corporate customers and that it would allow those customers to remove copy protection devices from the software.

title: Bridge: At 16, Twins From England Will Play for a World Title
description: When the world championships begin in Miami Beach next month, journalistic attention will likely not be focused on the bunches of past and present world champions taking part. Instead the interviewers and photographers will probably be pursuing two young men from Manchester, England, who are celebrating their 16th birthday today.

title: Businessland To Buy Morris
description: Businessland Inc., the operator of one of the nation's largest chains of personal computer stores, has agreed to buy Morris Decision Systems Inc., a closely held marketer of personal computers and local area networks for large companies in New York. The price, which will be paid in Businessland common stock, has yet to be made final.

title: OVERLAND EXPRESS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income and after an extraordinary gain from an accounting adjustment of $811,000.

title: CITY ACTS ON CROWDING IN ITS PSYCHIATRIC WARDS
description: New York City will seek to relieve serious overcrowding in its municipal psychiatric wards and emergency rooms by shifting patients who are no longer considered dangerous or troublesome to unused medical and surgical beds, city officials said yesterday.

title: VISTA RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a pre-tax credit of $718,423 representing the excess of the assets in a terminated pension plan over the cost of paid-up annuities covering benefits earned by employees.

title: WINERY IN BROOKLYN IS SAID TO BE SELLING MANISCHEWITZ LINE
description: The Monarch Wine Company of Brooklyn has agreed to sell its Manischewitz brand to the upstate Canandaigua Wine Company and plans to shut down the Brooklyn winery where the well-known kosher wines are made, industry sources said yesterday.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for belwether issues.

title: DANCE: STEVE KRIECKHAUS
description: STEVE KRIECKHAUS is a slight, mild-looking young man with a soft and polite voice. It soon becomes apparent that that impression is deceptive. There is that moment when, without warning, Mr. Krieckhaus vaults over the desk where he has been writing, moving within a second from one casual, innocent stance to another. His eyes begin to look a little mad and his body almost too controlled. And we soon realize that we are in the presence of an artist of extraordinary gifts and daring. ''Missouri Driver's Licence,'' a program performed on Tuesday as part of Dance Theater Workshop's Out-of-Towners series, promises to be a highlight of the year. Mr. Krieckhaus will perform it again at the Bessie Schonberg Theater on Monday and Tuesday.

description: When the American Bar Association's annual meeting ended in Manhattan yesterday, Eugene C. Thomas, a gregarious Westerner, took over the presidency with an agenda that includes a program to combat illiteracy in the nation and efforts to make A.B.A. membership accessible to all American lawyers, regardless of financial status. Mr. Thomas also wants to change the public's perception of the group as a trade association.

description: Iran said it bombed an oilfield in northern Iraq today. The report came a day after Iran fired a long-range missile into Baghdad, the Iraqi capital, and Iraqi jets retaliated by attacking an Iranian oil-export terminal at Sirri in the Persian Gulf.

description: In the six months since Yoweri Museveni and his National Resistance Army took power in this country, the slaughter of political dissidents, and of families and children, has apparently stopped.

title: Q & A
description: Q. To protect the top of my cherry wood dining table, I covered it with a felt-lined plastic cover. However, heavy items placed on top of this caused the felt to stick to the table in places, leaving spots that I have been unable to remove. What will take these marks off? A. In most cases the stuck-on felt can be removed by spreading a light film of salad oil or lemon oil over the area and letting it soak for about an hour, then rubbing it off with a clean dry cloth. Keep rubbing until no more will come off, and change cloths frequently to avoid spreading the residue.

title: Ex-Cello-O Meets
description: After a day of deliberations in New York, the Ex-Cell-O Corporation's board adjourned yesterday evening without responding to the Textron Corporation's unsolicited $68-a-share bid for the industrial company. Ex-Cell-O's stock closed at $74.625, up 62.5 cents. Textron's stock fell 37.5 cents, to $56.625.

Now Wall Street data management experts are dreaming of the day when such systems might capture the expertise of top traders, deal makers and analysts in programs that could enhance the performance of less-skilled or inexperienced employees.

title: India Passes New Laws In Anti-Terror Campaign
description: Three days after a former army Chief of Staff was assassinated by suspected terrorists, the Indian Government pushed through legislation today that will enable it to take direct control of the battle against Sikh terrorism in northern India.

description: Seven maintenance workers were hospitalized after a leak of chlorine gas from an Exxon chemical plant here, a company official said.

'A MAN AND A WOMAN,' REKINDLING A CLASSIC
description: Twenty years have passed since Claude Lelouch's star-crossed lovers embraced on the shores of Deauville in the French film maker's classic romantic saga, ''A Man and a Woman.'' But the images remain vivid.

title: Long-Term Securities Strong
description: Prices of long-term Treasury securities posted strong gains yesterday in a rally based largely on technical factors but underpinned by growing hopes of a new round of internationally coordinated interest rate cuts.

description: The show must go on in city government.

title: Come In, New Delhi
description: If all goes well, a telephone will ring about 9 A.M. today in the office of Secretary of Commerce Malcolm Baldrige, and the party on the end of the line will be R. N. Mirdha, India's Minister of Communications and Home Affairs. Assuming this happens, Mr. Mirdha will just have completed the first direct-dial telephone call from India to the United States. The new service reflects the facts that 500,000 Indians now live in this country and that the United States is the largest single customer for Indian exports.

title: Persevered Romps By 10 1/4 in Sanford
description: Persevered, a son of Affirmed, the 1978 Triple Crown winner, scored a runaway 10 1/4-length victory today in the $85,200 Sanford Stakes for 2-year-olds at Saratoga Race Track.

title: One Foreigner's Costly Illusion About China
description: To the Editor:

title: LeMond Wins Fifth Leg of Race
description: Greg LeMond, spurred by a cheering hometown crowd, won the fifth stage of the Coors International Bicycle Classic today, edging ahead of a bunched field near the end of the 99.5-mile leg.

title: Buying Off the Farmer
description: Federal farm programs have degenerated into a morass that bleeds taxpayers without benefiting farmers. We will spend some $30 billion on farm programs this year - plus another $10 billion or so in higher food prices. Yet rural America keeps suffering.

title: FRENCH FABRIC
description: WHAT Laura Ashley did to popularize English country furniture and home accessories, Howard Kaplan hopes to do for the French country look. In his newly renovated French Country Store, he offers an array of new French country-style furniture, fabric, wallpaper and dinnerware - and a custom design service.

title: Fahlgren & Swink Wins Entire Totes Account
description: Totes, the umbrella and rain gear maker, has consolidated its entire account at Fahlgren & Swink of Cincinnati. The move will triple the agency's Totes billings to $1.1 million Over the last four years, Fahlgren worked on new product campaigns, while Sive Associates was assigned the rest of the account.

title: STAGE: 'TRAS-ESCENA,' BY COLOMBIAN TROUPE
description: IT'S two hours to curtain time and, as it always happens, nothing is going right. The dictatorship is trying to modify the production, a transportation strike is threatened, the Indians refuse to go onstage without first being paid, an understudy is ill-equipped for his leading part and they've sent over the wrong scenery. Life backstage is more exciting and real than life onstage, and it is backstage that is the stuff of ''La Tras-Escena,'' the play offered Monday and Tuesday at the Public Theater by Colombia's Teatro la Candelaria as part of the Festival Latino.

title: SHOE-TOWN INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
I.B.M. ENLISTS CARNEGIE-MELLON'S AID ON SOFTWARE
description: The International Business Machines Corporation today announced a three-year multimillion-dollar project in artificial intelligence with Carnegie-Mellon University, as part of what the company called ''a major new I.B.M. initiative'' in advanced software.

title: JIM BELUSHI IN COMEDY ON CABLE
description: BECAUSE the comic actor and writer James Belushi bears such a strong resemblance to his late older brother John, one has tended to see him as a mild-mannered shadow of his more famous sibling. But ''Jim Belushi - Birthday Boy,'' the half-hour special this evening on Cinemax at 10:30, offers further proof that the younger Belushi, who has already established himself as a disciplined character actor, has refined his own comic persona, and in some ways it is the opposite of his brother's.

title: TEMPO ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
AID TO FARMERS: CURE OR BAND-AID?
description: A decision by President Reagan on farm aid will cost the Government hundreds of millions, save many farmers thousands of dollars, save some of their farms and in some instances ease a threat of deepening distress for some rural communities.

title: Early Saves
description: Todd Worrell starred for the St. Louis Cardinals in 1985 postseason play, pitching in four National League championship playoff games and three World Series contests, but he is still considered a rookie because he pitched only 21Z innings in 41 days during the regular season. Last Sunday the 6-foot-5-inch right-hander broke the major league record for saves by a rookie with his 24th and added one more on Monday night.

title: CHESS GAME IN TITLE MATCH IS ADJOURNED
description: The seventh game of the world chess championship adjourned today when the champion, Gary Kasparov, playing Black, sealed his 41st move. Experts said the game was likely to end in a draw.

title: CORRECTION
description: In an article Tuesday about women in New York politics, the state Democratic chairman, Laurence J. Kirwan, incorrectly described Gail Shaffer, the New York Secretary of State. She is the third woman to hold that post, after Florence E. S. Knapp and Caroline K. Simon.

title: ABM A KEY THEME IN MOSCOW TALKS, U.S. AIDES REPORT
description: Administration officials said today that Soviet interest in the Moscow arms talks this week focused on the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty, which may have to be modified as part of a package calling for reductions in nuclear offensive weapons and allowing some work on future defensive systems.

title: Master Plan Is Vital to Manhattan's West Side
description: To the Editor:

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: NOW AND THEN In the arena of pop music, now quickly becomes then. Then, 25 years ago, the Jazz Brothers, fresh from high school, were a new acoustic band with a hard-bop repertory. Now, a new Jazz Brothers, with three of the originals, is in business, celebrating that beginning a quarter-century ago with a tour that has begun at the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street (475-8592).

Comings and Goings

The 6-foot-9-inch, 225-pound forward from Madrid had just returned from 10 days with Portland's team in the Los Angeles Summer Pro League. . . . This time it's really official: Tony Perez said this season, his 23d, would be the final one of his major league career. Perez, 44 years old, had issued conflicting statements the last two days.

title: Dear Sir
description: Misdirected political mail is a growing hazard of computerized campaigns. When Terry Sanford, Democratic nominee for the Senate from North Carolina, got a letter from his Republican opponent, James T. Broyhill, he saw a political opening.

description: Fidel Castro, the Cuban leader, has received several medals from Communist nations on the occasion of his 60th birthday, which he celebrated today, the official newspaper Granma has reported. The Soviet Union presented him his third Order of Lenin, and he was also awarded medals by Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, Hungary, Cambodia, Mongolia, Poland and Vietnam.

description: Representative Bill Alexander, on a trip last year to Brazil, had heard there were news reports about the excursion, but he didn't realize how bad it was until he landed back in the United States and called his district office in Jonesboro, Ark.

title: SENATE UNIT APPROVES SCALED-DOWN BANK BILL
description: Concerned about the safety and soundness of the nation's financial system, the Senate Banking Committee unanimously approved a bill today to help Federal regulators deal more expeditiously with record failures of both commercial banks and thrift institutions.

title: COMPENSATIONS; Good Work
description: As New York's homeless population mushrooms, city officials have been stung by charges that they pay too little attention to moving them into permanent houses or jobs. Now, in a three-month pilot program, the city's Department of Employment has succeeded in finding permanent work for residents of one of the city-run shelters.

title: AFTER 25 YEARS OF BERLIN WALL, THE VIEWS ARE STILL DIVIDED
description: The leaders of a divided Germany today marked the 25th anniversary of the wall that sunders Berlin, on this side proclaiming the barrier a bold triumph and in the West declaring it a cause for shame and mourning.

title: ALTOS COMPUTER SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Abdullah Ibrahim and Ekaya, Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South above Bleecker Street (242-1785.) The South African pianist-saxophonist Abdullah Ibrahim leads a tautly arranged septet, Ekaya. Its winds can shout like a big band or unveil the assertive solos of Carlos Ward on alto saxophone and Ricky Ford on tenor saxophone; its rhythm section, anchored by Ben Riley's drumming, specializes in a rolling beat that Mr. Ibrahim brought from Cape Town. As a pianist, Mr. Ibrahim can deliver richly ringing solos - Keith Jarrett probably learned his two-handed tremolos from Mr. Ibrahim - and his compositions are steeped in gospel, Duke Ellington and Cape Town traditions. Filled out and expanded by Ekaya, his music carries warmth, intelligence and emotional depth. They are at Sweet Basil through Sunday. Sets are at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M today and tomorrow and at 10, 11:30 and 2 A.M. Sunday; there is a $10 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: British Jobless Rate Up
description: Britain's unemployment rate rose in July for the eighth consecutive month, to 11.7 percent of the work force, the Government said today.

title: Ford Acquisitive
description: The Ford Motor Company, with $7.1 billion in cash, remains interested in a non-automotive acquisition, its chairman, Donald E. Petersen, said. ''But our posture is one of patience, and I have no predictions,'' he said in an interview. Ford, the No. 2 automaker, was a losing bidder last year for the Hughes Aircraft Company, the military electronics giant that the General Motors Corporation bought. Mr. Petersen said Ford considers aerospace, electronics and financial services the three major diversification areas that ''make the most sense for us.''

President Reagan will give him an Award for Entrepreneurial Excellence this afternoon at the White House, and Mr. Leonard is staying over to give a speech on ''The Four Secrets of Success'' Monday at the White House Conference on Small Business.

title: BHUTTO IS JAILED
description: The Pakistani authorities arrested and jailed the opposition leader Benazir Bhutto today, as street protesters stepped up a campaign against the Government of President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq.

title: COMPUTERS' MORRIS SET FOR BUSINESSLAND ROLE
description: Anthony T. Morris, who in six years cultivated a $40 million-a-year business, agreed Wednesday to sell his three computer centers to the industry's giant, Businessland Inc. The centers - two in New York and one in Westport, Conn. - are called Morris Decisions Systems Inc. They will become Businessland outlets.

title: ENGINEERS' FIRM CLEARED BY JURY IN FALL OF BRIDGE
description: A Superior Court jury, rejecting the state's arguments, decided today that a New York engineering firm was not responsible for the collapse of a portion of the Mianus River bridge three years ago. Three people were killed and three were injured in the collapse.

title: OPERA: 'LA FINTA GIARDINIERA' AT MOSTLY MOZART
description: IN ''La Finta Giardiniera'' we hear Mozart, a talented 18-year-old, reaching out toward his own genius and sometimes nearly touching it. It is a bridge opera, fascinating on its own terms but not to be dismissed on any terms. This somewhat rambling and feebly plotted comic opera, which has been known to the general public only by hearsay until until recent years, never rises to the level of his later ''Nozze di Figaro'' or ''Cosi Fan Tutte'' - after all, only a few other operas do, and several of them are by Mozart himself. In no other way, however, can a decent performance of ''La Finta Giardiniera'' be disappointing to anyone concerned with the composer's incredible flowering as a musical dramatist.

title: US SUGAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Food Company Destroys Contaminated Chickens
description: Nearly 819,200 chickens owned by the Banquet Foods Corporation have been destroyed since Friday after a carcinogenic insecticide was discovered in chickens from 38 flocks, a Food and Drug Administration official said today.

title: AN ULSTER MILITANT GOES TO MEET THE FOE
description: Peter Robinson of Northern Ireland made a rare daylight appearance in the Irish Republic today, being hooted and hollered at as he quickly drove south across the green hills to the courthouse to answer charges of causing trouble in a midnight border raid.

title: Exorcising The Demons
description: Over the last four years, Frank Cashen has been followed by furies wearing blue jeans and Met T-shirts, chanting vile imprecations at him on the Flushing El.

title: FILM: 'INFERNO,' MYTHIC HORROR TALE
description: THERE ought to be a checklist for slice-and-dice movies. It would include such items as quantity of blood, depiction of grotesque murders, variety of method and duration of the victim's death agony. Critics could give each item a little skull and crossbones, so four death-heads would mean a classy carve-up, guaranteed to turn a few stomachs. ''Inferno,'' written and directed by the Italian film maker Dario Argento, would get the highest rating. It is proof that you don't have to be American to make gratuitously gory films.

title: THE SCREEN: 'MY AMERICAN COUSIN'
description: FOR anyone who was a teen-ager in the 1950's, ''My American Cousin'' is a ride down memory lane. It's not fast enough to be a drag race, but it's as comfortable as an old jalopy.

title: BRIEFS
description: * General Motors Corp., Detroit, has scheduled a news briefing for today on the future of its North American heavy-duty truck business. Expectations are that it will announce a merger with A.B. Volvo of Sweden.

title: STAGE: AT ROUNDABOUT, 'A RAISIN IN THE SUN'
description: THE events of every passing year add resonance to ''A Raisin in the Sun,'' Lorraine Hansberry's play about a black family in Chicago in the 1950's. It is as if history is conspiring to insure that the play will be a classic. And the 10 to 15 minutes of dialogue in the original that has been dropped from performance versions since the play opened on Broadway in 1959 and that is restored in the revival by the Roundabout Theatre Company make ''Raisin'' seem more original, and seminal, than ever. Miss Hansberry's prescient exploration of the conflicts over race, class, roots, women's liberation and personal values that have transformed our thinking but not our society is so powerful that the many flaws in the play are of no consequence.

title: Solo Drum Concerts
description: The drummer Jerome Cooper continues his five-week series of solo concerts tomorrow at 8 P.M. at 177 Franklin Street. Admission is $7; information: 219-3651.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, AUGUST 15, 1986
description: International

title: U.S. Reorganization?
description: To the Editor:

title: ART: AMERICAN PAINTINGS, 1797 to 1927, AT I.B.M.
description: THERE has crept into town, with minimal fanfare, an exemplary small anthology of 19th- and early-20th-century American painting. Not only are the paintings in it very good, almost without exception, but more than once they make a collective point of the kind that most anthologies either miss or do not even attempt.

title: Peace in Dallas?
description: Tex Schramm, the Dallas Cowboys' president, is an old hand at soothing injured egos, and after a meeting with Tony Dorsett, Schramm said the running back had withdrawn his demand to be traded and his threat to be a ''disruptive force'' on the team following the signing of Herschel Walker to a reported five-year, $5 million contract.

title: TOUGHER PLAN ON PESTICIDE CONTROL IS APPROVED BY SENATE COMMITTEE
description: The Senate Agriculture Committee has unanimously approved a plan to strengthen the nation's pesticide control law and sent it to the full Senate.

title: A NEW UPHEAVAL IN SOFTWARE
description: For a few years after it was founded in 1978, the Micropro International Corporation boasted the personal computer industry's most popular word processing software, Wordstar. But as Wordstar has been overtaken by newer and flashier programs, Micropro has struggled to regain lost market share and earnings.

title: NORTHWESTERN NATIONAL LIFE INURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After capital gains of $1,241,000 for the quarter and $6,498,000 for the 6 months. c-After capital gains of $2,230,000 for the quarter and $2,910,000 for the 6 months.

title: Parcel Service Workers Find 12 Human Heads
description: United Parcel Service employees discovered 12 human heads when they opened a package that was leaking, officials said Wednesday.

title: The Cost of Being an Asian-American Superachiever; Is Diet the Answer?
description: To the Editor:

title: Baby Born Prematurely To Brain-Dead Woman
description: A frail premature boy was delivered today from a brain-dead woman who was kept on a life-support system at a judge's order despite the objections of her husband.

title: Stock Stirs After Move By Schwab
description: Reacting to the resignation Wednesday of Charles R. Schwab from the board of directors, the stock of BankAmerica Corporation yesterday moved in fits and starts amid heavy trading.

title: MARANTZ CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HOUSE APPROVES SHORT-TERM INCREASE IN DEBT CEILING
description: The House of Representatives today approved a short-term increase in the Federal debt ceiling as the House and the Senate strove to begin their three-week summer recess Friday. The vote was 216 to 199.

title: TIMES SQ. BELL TOWER: THE WRONG CENTERPIECE
description: Is a seven-story, Italianate-style bell tower the answer to Times Square's problems? Park Tower Realty, the development company that plans to construct four huge office towers as the centerpiece of the city and state's Times Square redevelopment project, seems to think so.

title: SIMMONS CONTROLS NL AFTER TWO-MONTH BATTLE
description: After two months of battling to take over NL Industries, Harold C. Simmons, the Dallas investor, gained control of NL today by reaching an agreement to place five representatives on the company's new nine-member board.

title: RESIDENTS IN PATH OF NORTHWEST FIRES FACE FIGHT-OR-FLIGHT DECISION
description: Gene Riley said he has lived along the Middle Fork of the Payette River for five years.

title: DANCE: FESTIVAL LATINO OFFERS 'JAZMINES-TANGO'
description: THE Festival Latino's dance component got off to a disappointing start with Ana Maria Stekelman's ''Jazmines-Tango,'' performed on Wednesday night at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park. The suite of dances failed to live up to its billing as ''an original tango-ballet.'' Ms. Stekelman and Niko Vasiliadis have put together scenarios that often looked like faded vaudeville skits. And the heavy-footed dancing seldom suggested the real artistry of the earthy, complex tango.

title: SMITH INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a $27.8 million provision for damages and related expenses in connection with ongoing patent litigation with Hughes Tool Co. for the quarter and 6 months. c-After $11.7 million in layoff and relocation expenses relating to workforce reductions and consolidations of several operating divisions.

title: DR. ALAN W. BROWN
description: Dr. Alan Willard Brown, former president of Hobart and William Smith Colleges in Geneva, N.Y., died of a stroke Sunday at his summer home in Charlotte, Vt. He was 75 years old and also lived in Mayaguez, P.R.

title: ZAPATA CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a $28.5 million writedown of oil and gas properties for the quarter and 9 months. The 9 months is also after a second quarter writedown of $42.5 million on oil and gas properties.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, AUGUST 15, 1986
description: The Economy

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: ON Fridays, when the sun sinks on the West Side of Manhattan, young lawyers put aside their appellate briefs and rising bankers stop writing prospectuses. Out come the Vuarnet sunglasses, Bain de Soleil, swim trunks and sun dresses. It's Hamptons time. ''The adrenaline starts flowing,'' said Adam Flatto, 23 years old, who leaves his office at the Georgetown Group Inc., a real-estate development concern, for a summer house in East Hampton.

title: LORIMAR-TELEPICTURES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a $23,903,000 pre-tax gain from the sale of the company's Warner Communications Inc. common stock purchased in 1985 for investment purposes. c-After an extraordinary charge of $75,000. The company said the 1985 quarter results are restated on a pooling of interest basis.

title: ALC COMMUNICATIONS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the 1985 results for both periods have been restated on a pro forma combined basis as though the Allnet-Lexitel combination had taken place Jan. 1, 1985.

title: Hidden French 'Parallels'
description: This year's customary French summer scandal has gone much further than usual. It is touching on what the French call ''parallel diplomacy,'' the hidden system of relations with French-speaking Africa, and ''parallel financing,'' the hidden system of funding political campaigns.

title: Concert in Oyster Bay
description: The Orchestra of St. Luke's, under the direction of Michal Feldman, will play music by Strauss and Lehar at the Planting Fields Arboretum tomorrow night at 8.

title: New Jersey Symphony
description: Hugh Wolff will conduct the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra in a program of works by Borodin, Stravinsky, Rachmaninoff and Tchaikovsky at the Garden State Arts Center tomorrow night at 8:30. Tickets are $10. The center is just off Exit 116 on the Garden State Parkway in Holmdel, N.J. Information: (201) 442-9200.

title: Queens College Concert
description: The Summer Symphony, under the direction of JoAnn Falletta, will play a concert of works by Rossini, Weber, Bizet and Borodin at Rathaus Hall on the Queens College campus tonight at 8.

title: ENERGAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: DOW RISES BY 0.42, TO 1,844.91
description: The stock market ended higher again yesterday as it continued to be buoyed by the prospects of further interest rate cuts.

title: Hudson Valley Music
description: The Wind Symphony from the Hudson Valley Philharmonic, under the direction of Imre Pallo, will perform at Boscobel's second annual Gala Sunset Concert and Lawn Picnic tomorrow night at 6:30.

title: Marcos Backers Accused Of Plot to Kidnap Aquino
description: Defense Minister Juan Ponce Enrile asserted today that the military had uncovered a plot by supporters of Ferdinand E. Marcos to kidnap President Corazon C. Aquino and restore the former President to power.

title: LIBERTY HOMES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GOLFERS ADAPT PLAY TO SCORING CHANGE
description: On the second day of The International, a new PGA Tour event based on the Stableford point system, the competitors, a crafty lot quick to observe and adapt, evolved appropriate tactics for a tournament that awards points for eagles and birdies and subtracts them for bogeys.

title: DOUBLEDAY, THE PUBLISHING HOUSE AND METS' OWNER, MAY BE FOR SALE
description: Doubleday & Company, the publishing house that also owns the New York Mets, appears to be for sale, publishing sources said yesterday.

title: From Novosibirsk to Andover
description: On the vast Siberian plain outside Novosibirsk lie the new buildings of Akademgorodok, a research center that is sort of a Soviet M.I.T., Cal Tech and new town rolled into one.

title: SCREEN: 'MANHUNTER'
description: ''MANHUNTER,'' Michael Mann's adaptation of Thomas Harris's novel ''Red Dragon,'' may not persuade you that its hero, the F.B.I. agent Will Graham, operates on the same skewed wavelength as the cracked killers he specializes in tracking down, but the movie drives along with such intensity for much of the time that you can just let it work on your senses without worrying about whether it makes sense. The main trouble is Mr. Mann's taste for overkill; attention keeps being diverted away from the story to the odd camera angles, the fancy lighting, the crashing music, and you realize you're being had. It's like catching a glimpse of the gimmicks in the magician's bag.

title: FILM: 'THE FLY,' WITH JEFF GOLDBLUM
description: IN the 1958 movie ''The Fly,''

title: MITCHELL EXCELS AS METS SPLIT WITH THE CARDINALS
description: In his rookie season, Kevin Mitchell has had no easy time while playing for a Met team that is coasting to a division title. Mitchell had to win his way onto the roster in spring training and then had to play six different positions in the field and bat in nine positions in the lineup before Manager Dave Johnson found a permanent spot for him as the left fielder.

title: From Norwest To Salomon
description: David Jarvis, vice chairman and chief financial officer of the Norwest Corporation, has resigned to join the London office of Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: BSN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $46,000 for both the quarter and 6 months, and the 6-month period also includes a gain of $44,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: VALLEY FORGE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After tax benefits of $301,466 for the quarter and $520,076 for the 6 months. c-After tax benefits of $275,637 for the quarter and $476,723 for the 6 months.

title: Diner's Journal
description: ANDRE SOLTNER of Lutece was wowed by the cooking; so, too, was Jean Louis Palladin of the Watergate in Washington, which has prompted a flock of nervous chefs to scurry over to the new restaurant in the Drake Hotel on Park Avenue at 52d Street. The restaurant, called Lafayette, is the creation of Louis Outhier of the famed three-star (Michelin) l'Oasis at La Napoule on the French Riviera. Mr. Outhier is the consultant to seven such restaurants around the world, including two in this country, one in Boston and now one in New York.

title: HANDYMAN CORP reports earnings for 26wks to June 28
description: b-Includes gains on the sale of real estate of $500,000 for the 26 weeks and $3 million for the 52 weeks. c-Includes gains on the sale of real estate of $3.9 million and $5.4 million for the 26 weeks and 52 weeks, respectively.

title: FLEXSTEEL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain from the termination of a pension plan of $577,596. c-Includes a gain from the termination of a pension plan of $675,000 for both the quarter and year.

title: TIMBERLAND INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MCO RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a writedown of $8.1 million on the value of oil and gas properties for the quarter and includes a $12.4 million writedown for the 6 months.

title: DAMSON OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The company said the loss in the latest 9-month period was primarily attributable to a writedown of oil and gas properties during the second quarter of about $68.5 million to comply with SEC accounting requirements.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: WORKING PROFILE: Clayton K. Yeutter; On the Front Lines in the Trade Wars
description: For United States Trade Representative Clayton K. Yeutter, the summer doldrums have become the guns of August.

title: OIL COMPANIES PUT OFF DEMOLISHING OFFSHORE RIGS
description: Two major oil companies have postponed further dismantling of old offshore platforms by the use of dynamite after environmentalists expressed concern that the explosions might be killing rare sea turtles and other marine life.

title: Destination of Munitions Unclear
description: An Administration official said today that the illegal ammunition shipment in which Nancy Reagan's personal maid was charged might have been destined either for the Government of Paraguay or for a smuggling operation in that country. He said the Administration had not yet firmly established an ultimate destination.

title: Buyout Is Set For Coke Unit
description: The Coca-Cola Bottling Company of New York Inc. has agreed to spin off its New England operation in a leveraged buyout led by Charles E.F. Millard, who resigned as chairman and chief executive of the New York company. The board elected Edward F. O'Reilly, 48 years old, the company's president, to succeed Mr. Millard.

title: TONY LAMA CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: UPSETS MARK TORONTO TENNIS
description: Kevin Curren used his booming serve to eliminate top-seeded Ivan Lendl, and Robert Seguso slowed John McEnroe's comeback, headlining a string of upsets today in third-round play at the Canadian Open tennis tournament.

title: A RICH ARRAY OF SUMMER ART, FROM NEWBURGH TO NEWARK
description: WITH an array of works by such internationally renowned artists as Alexander Calder, Robert Indiana, Jasper Johns, Roy Lichtenstein, Louise Nevelson, Isamu Noguchi, Richard Pousette-Dart, Mark Rothko and David Smith, a group of museums situated in a rough exurban quadrangle stands ready to reward the devotee of art.

title: The U.N. Today; Aug. 15, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Special Committee on Decolonization - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: CRYSTAL OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a $10 million writedown of the value of oil and gas properties for both the quarter and 6 months. c-After income from discontinued operations of $189,000 for the quarter and $103,000 for the 6 months, and the 6-month period also includes a $184 million writedown of the value of oil and gas properties.

title: CUBIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: VIOLENT BATTLE FOR TOURISTS IN NIAGARA FALLS
description: A few years ago, the road signs to the waterfalls here were vanishing so often that the state finally stopped replacing them.

title: WASHINGTON REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NATIONAL COMPUTER SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
High Thai Official Is Shifted To Office of Prime Minister
description: Prasong Soonsiri, head of the National Security Council who has been Thailand's top official for refugee affairs, is being moved to another position, according to the television news.

title: ARKLA INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $497,000 for the quarter and $416,000 for the 6 months, and the 6-month period also includes a gain of $9,813,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: HAMBURG POLICE HOLD 2 IN INQUIRY ABOUT TAMILS OFF CANADA
description: The police arrested two Sri Lankans here today during an inquiry into whether 152 of their compatriots found drifting off Canada had come from West Germany.

title: Don't Call Teaching 'Women's Work'
description: To the Editor:

title: After 300 Years, Flushing Remains a Model of Peaceful Diversity
description: To the Editor:

title: The Cost of Being an Asian-American Superachiever; Flawed Theory
description: To the Editor:

title: Guinness Sells Huge B.P. Block
description: Guinness P.L.C., the British brewery and distilling company, said that it had sold 18.8 million shares of the British Petroleum Company in one of the largest block trades in British history. Guinness said that it sold the shares for $:5.75 each, or a total of $:108.1 million.

title: 9 Arrested on Charges In Cocaine-Ring Case
description: Nine people were arrested yesterday, including a former assistant district attorney, an executive in the City Comptroller's office, a city correction guard and a head nurse, in connection with what Federal authorities said was a $20 million-a-month cocaine ring in New York.

title: BUNNY WAILER AND REGGAE AT THE GARDEN
description: ''MANY people think reggae music just came along out of the blue,'' said Bunny Wailer, who arrived in New York City this week to prepare for a concert at Madison Square Garden tomorrow. ''But reggae has been growing in Jamaica since the 50's, and in our concert we're going to show people where reggae came from, as well as where it's at, and some of the people may not realize that reggae is for dancing as well as for listening. So we're going to have dancers come on stage to dramatize the fact that reggae is music like, say, the twist; it has rhythm, it's for dancers. This is the kind of presentation reggae needs to get it to the people, to be understood.''

title: Dept. of Late Mail
description: Mail deliveries have been running up to two weeks late on the House side of Capitol Hill for several months, and the fault is said to be neither snow, rain, heat nor gloom of night, but budget cuts.

title: SAFETY STANDARD IS SET ON RADON IN U.S. HOMES
description: The Environmental Protection Agency today set a safety standard for radioactive radon gas in residences and estimated that as many as eight million homes in the United States may exceed it.

title: SENATE UNIT BACKS REHNQUIST, 13 TO 5
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee voted today to recommend confirmation of President Reagan's nomination of William H. Rehnquist to become Chief Justice of the United States and of Judge Antonin Scalia to succeed him as an Associate Justice.

title: G.M. Plant Moves
description: The General Motors Corporation said today it would temporarily lay off 8,200 workers and close some plants for model changeovers and inventory adjustments. The new layoffs involve plants in Detroit, Pontiac and Flint, Mich. About 17,000 other workers will return to their jobs Tuesday at plants in Lansing, Mich.; Van Nuys, Calif.; Lakewood, Ga.; Linden, N.J., and a second plant in Pontiac.

title: Roosevelt I. Tram Shut By Electrical Problem
description: The tramway between Roosevelt Island and Manhattan was closed indefinitely yesterday because of an electrical problem, a spokesman for the Roosevelt Island Operating Corporation said last night.

title: ZEMEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a tax credit of $76,000 for the quarter and 6 months.

title: JET ROOKIE QUARTERBACKS AVOID A SACK
description: The Jets' two rookie quarterbacks, Tom Ehrhardt and Marty Horn, survived another elimination today as the squad was cut from 84 players to 74.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about the inflationary consequences of OPEC's agreement to cut production incorrectly listed Saudi Arabia's rank among the world's oil-producing nations. It is third largest, following the Soviet Union, which is the leader, and then the United States.

title: BEDOUINS OF SINAI: NOMADS NO MORE, YET UNSETTLED
description: As Ashish Aniz, a wiry young Bedouin, told it, he had built a wall around his new stucco house only to have the Egyptian authorities send a tractor one day to knock it down.

title: BROADWAY
description: ''THE COLORED MUSEUM,'' says the man who wrote it, George C. Wolfe, ''is a series of 12 exhibits, if you will -where the myths and the madnesses of black/Negro/colored Americans are stored. The 'soft sculptures' in that museum are human beings.''

title: More Travels
description: Not too many years ago, Presidential aspirants who visited New Hampshire before the election year opened felt compelled to provide a nonpolitical explanation. Nelson A. Rockefeller ostensibly traveled to Hanover and environs to attend alumni weekend at Dartmouth, but almost always in October, immediately preceeding New Hampshire's Presidential primaries.

title: Smoking, Smoke and Free Speech
description: Though smoking is dangerous, the tobacco industry would like to argue otherwise. Can government stop cigarette manufacturers from making their arguments in public? The staff of the Federal Trade Commission contends that the companies may not comment on smoking and health without undergoing F.T.C. review for possible false advertising.

title: 16 on Iranian Tanker Reported Killed by Raid
description: Sixteen crewmen on the Iranian-owned supertanker Azarpad were killed in the Iraqi raid Tuesday on Iran's key Persian Gulf oil terminal at Sirri Island, survivors from the vessel said today.

title: Accounts
description: * JFY-Audit America, a direct marketing firm, to Gleckler & Spiegel.

title: WESTBURNE INTERNATIONAL INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SPENCER-DEVLIN IRKED BY A 75
description: Muffin Spencer-Devlin did not quite pick up where she left off at the MasterCard International, which started today at three Westchester golf courses.

title: 'THE PRICE,' A SERIES FROM BRITAIN, ON 13
description: ''THE PRICE'' crackles; it runs and jumps right along. In its secret heart there may be only a soap opera joined with a thriller, but there is so much high style that it is unlikely anyone will care. The British-made, six-hour mini-series, which has nothing to do with the play of the same name by Arthur Miller, is about a kidnapping in Ireland. Watch the opening two-hour segment, on Channel 13 at 10 P.M. on Sunday, and you will probably return for the rest.

title: The Cost of Being an Asian-American Superachiever
description: To the Editor:

title: Child Survives Plunge From Elevated Station
description: A 2-year-old boy survived a 30-foot plunge from a Queens elevated station yesterday after he slipped through a six-inch gap between a train and the platform and a second, foot-wide gap caused by a missing strip of wooden slatting at track level.

title: Constitutional Time Bomb in the Tax Bill
description: To the Editor:

title:
A RICH ARRAY OF SUMMER ART, FROM NEWBURG TO NEWARK;
For Summer Fun, Artistic Interiors and Landscapes
description: DOTTING the landscape in Connecticut, New Jersey and Westchester are some imaginative exhibitions with generous amounts of art. The quality of these shows - and these are off-season exhibitions - makes one realize that the usual compass of the New York art world should be widened.

title: Senator Ervin's Wife Dies
description: Margaret Bell Ervin, wife of the late United States Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr., died today.

title: Reader's Digest Officer
description: The Reader's Digest Association, the magazine publisher, said yesterday that Richard F. McLoughlin, 57 years old, would become president and chief operating officer at year-end. Now vice chairman, he will replace William J. Cross, who is retiring but will remain on the board.

title: Port Authority Bonds
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey yesterday offered $100 million of 35-year consolidated revenue bonds, designated Series 56.

title: High Time Under Pressure
description: It sounds oppressive - seven days in a cramped pressurized chamber on City Island simulating underwater conditions.

title: CANDIDATES MOVE TO REDUCE DRUG ABUSE
description: Governor Cuomo and his Republican opponent, Westchester County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke, each announced plans yesterday to step up the fight against drugs.

title: FOR PLEBES, COMPUTERS NOW STANDARD ISSUE
description: When the 1,200 West Point plebes arrive next week from summer training to begin classroom work, they will find personal computers on their desks, part of a technological revolution sweeping the military academies.

title: THE RULES
description: This week's PGA Tour event, The International, is using modified Stableford scoring, a system developed in 1931 by Dr. Frank B. G. Stableford in Britain and still used there, as well as in Australia and South Africa.

title: BOARD OF ESTIMATE BACKS LINCOLN CENTER ADDITION
description: The first major addition to Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts in 17 years was approved unanimously late last night by the city's Board of Estimate.

title: ASEA AB reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 1-for-2 stock dividend paid in June.

title: WAY BANDY, MAKEUP ARTIST AND BEST-SELLING WRITER, DIES
description: Way Bandy, one of the fashion world's best-known and highest-paid makeup artists and a best-selling author, died Wednesday at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. He was 45 years old and lived in Manhattan, Nantucket, Mass., and Key West, Fla.

title: Giacomin Is Back
description: There are some Ranger fans who have never forgiven the club for trading Ed Giacomin, the popular goaltender, to the Detroit Red Wings in 1976.

title: REPUBLIC GYPSUM CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HANOI FREES U.S. 'ADVENTURER' MISSING FOR A YEAR
description: The White House announced today that Vietnam had released a United States Army veteran who set sail from the Philippines 16 months ago in an attempt to bring out a Vietnamese woman.

title: Very Late Innings
description: As many fans with sore posteriors may have suspected, major league baseball games are running longer this season. The average game these days lasts about 2 hours 48 minutes, which is seven minutes more than in 1985 and 23 minutes more than a decade ago.

title: Bank Merger Set In New England
description: The Bank of New England Corporation has agreed to acquire the Conifer Group Inc. of Worcester, Mass., forming one of the largest banks in New England. It will have assets of $24 billion and 481 banking offices in Massachusetts, Connecticut, Rhode Island and Maine.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in some copies of Metropolitan Report on July 29 about the indictment of Nanco Inc., a Queens construction company, incorrectly reported the status of another company, Leskay Construction Services. Leskay was not one of the companies that Nanco was accused of using as fronts to evade requirements that it give part of a city contract to concerns owned by members of minority groups or women.

title: WILL DOW'S PARTY LINGER ON?
description: Is there life left in the bull market?

title: CHAIRMEN HIT A SNAG ON TAX BILL
description: Senator Bob Packwood and Representative Dan Rostenkowski hit an unexpected snag late tonight in their effort to reach agreement on tax revision legislation.

title: Michael J. Hamburger, Ex-U.S. Budget Adviser
description: Michael J. Hamburger, a former consultant to the Federal Office of Management and Budget, died Sunday at Northern Westchester Medical Center in Mount Kisco, N.Y., after apparently suffering a heart attack at his home. He was 47 years old and lived in Mount Kisco.

title: APARTHEID FOE CRITICIZES REAGAN
description: The Rev. Allan Boesak, an outspoken South African opponent of apartheid and president of the World Alliance of Reformed Churches, criticized the Reagan Administration here today for what he called its ''immoral stance on apartheid.''

title: Bronx Arts Ensemble
description: The Bronx Arts Ensemble will present a program of music by Mozart, Tchaikovsky and Samuel Barber at Rockwood Drive Circle, in Van Cortlandt Park, Broadway and Moshulu Avenue, the Bronx, on Sunday afternoon at 2.

title: SOUTH AFRICA VIOLENCE ON RISE AGAIN
description: An increase in violence was reported around South Africa today, much of it in the nearby black township of Soweto.

title: ART PEOPLE
description: ROSALYN DREXLER, the playwright-novelist-painter and one-time wrestler, has conjured up a critically successful show of paintings at the Grey Art Gallery, 33 Washington Place, at Washington Square East.

title: FREEDOM SAVINGS & LOAN ASSOCIATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an $8 million loss from operations, a $41 million addition to the allowance for loan losses and a $12 million writedown of the value of real estate and securities. c-Net income

title: Travels With Reagan
description: President Reagan will interrupt his fall political schedule to fly to Atlanta Oct. 1 and dedicate the Carter Library, Museum and Policy Center where the records of the 1977-80 administration of his predecessor, Jimmy Carter, are to be kept. The $25 million complex, which includes a conference center, is situated on the three-acre hilltop from which General William Tecumseh Sherman watched the Battle of Atlanta in the Civil War.

title: ALABAMA DEMOCRATS SEEK A DECISION ON NOMINEE
description: A special panel of five Democratic leaders began deliberations here today to decide whether they should award the gubernatorial nomination to the candidate who lost the party's June runoff or call for a new election next month.

title: A BOGUS DENTAL PRACTICE LEADS TO FRAUD CHARGES
description: An unlicensed dentist and two construction contractors cracked New York's Medicaid security system and stole $360,000 by using the name of an unsuspecting Manhattan dentist and creating a bogus practice with a phantom office and fictitious patients, a grand jury charged yesterday.

title: Italy Balks at Citrus Pact
description: Italy will veto an agreement negotiated by the United States and the European Community to end a trade dispute unless the pact is changed radically, Italian Trade Ministry officials said today.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL CHICAGO (NL) - Purchased the contract of Mike Martin, catcher, from Pittsfield of Eastern League. BASKETBALL

title: Topics: Questions of Respect; Chile Tries Again
description: Credit Chile's highest military court with a step toward retrieving justice a civilian court sought to deny.

title: SCOUTING
description: When Herschel Walker reached an agreement with Dallas Wednesday to play with the National Football League team for the next five seasons, the verbal understanding marked the jackpot payoff of a gamble the Cowboys took on April 30, 1985, when they picked the former University of Georgia running star as the second selection in the fifth round of the draft.

title: NAVY'S DISPUTED PROGRAM FOR NEW PORTS GAINS SUPPORT IN CONGRESS
description: The Navy has gained Congressional support for its plan to build new ports around the country despite expressions of grave misgivings by military experts, according to members of Congress and Navy officials.

title: German Rate Kept Steady
description: The Bundesbank's policy-setting council did not change monetary policy at its meeting today, a spokesman for the central bank said.

title: NEW FASHION MAGAZINES: A DARING FOCUS
description: ''I can't believe it,'' Annie Flanders said the day she learned that Details, the Manhattan-based monthly fashion magazine she founded in 1982, would go national in September, nearly doubling its current 45,000 distribution. ''I thought we were a little magazine.''

title: AIDES SAY REAGAN WILL ORDER NASA TO BUILD SHUTTLE
description: President Reagan will give the go-ahead Saturday for the space agency to construct a replacement shuttle orbiter, Administration officials said today.

title: TRILOGY LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
INTERNATIONAL CONTROLS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the year-ago figures do not include results of Transway International Corp., acquired Dec. 27, 1985.

title: Canadair Winner
description: Bombardier Inc. of Montreal is the successful bidder for Canadair Ltd., the financially troubled Government-owned aircraft maker, it was reported.

title: Beavers
description: While Congress was in recess last month, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York discovered a beaver resident in a stream on his farm in Delaware County and phoned the local game warden to come catch and deport it. The local officer told the Senator that wardens didn't do that any more because there were too many beavers and not enough places to relocate them and they just came back again.

title: How America Stands on South Africa
description: If the Senate needed any more reason to approve sanctions against South Africa today, President Reagan provided it with his dreadful message of mumbling indifference in his news conference Tuesday. He keeps snatching at any straw to justify the truculent Pretoria regime, while falsely insisting that only its radical opponents favor punitive sanctions.

title: Trivia Trouble
description: When he learned that on the cover of his ''Baseball Trivia Book To End All Baseball Trivia Books,'' the author would be described as ''Baseball's Reigning Triviot Scholar,'' Bert Randolph Sugar knew he was in for trouble.

title: SARA LEE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
Day for Solemnity
description: The mood at the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue on Wednesday evening was solemn, as congregants filled the darkened 89-year-old sanctuary, its stained-glass windows and wooden balconies draped in black.

title: 14 LATIN VIDEOS ON CABLE TV
description: Fourteen videos from Latin America will have their American premiere on cable television during the ''Festival Latino in Video,'' which begins Monday at 8 P.M. The videos, which are in Spanish or Portuguese, will be shown evenings at 8 on Cable Channel L-TV through Aug. 28. The host for each program will be Joseph Papp, head of the New York Shakespeare Festival Public Theater, which is sponsoring the series.

title: PERU FACES CREDIT BAR BY THE I.M.F.
description: Peru has opened itself to being declared ineligible for further credits from the International Monetary Fund by paying only a small share of its outstanding debt to the organization.

title: Earnings Sag For Navistar
description: The Navistar International Corporation, the nation's largest maker of medium- and heavy-duty trucks, said today that sluggish capital spending made its net income drop 91 percent, to $5 million, or 1 cent a share, in its fiscal third quarter, ended July 31, from $54 million, or 39 cents a share, a year before.

title: U.S. AGENT IS REPORTED ABDUCTED AND TORTURED BY MEXICAN POLICE
description: An agent of the United States Drug Enforcement Administration working in Guadalajara, Mexico, was abducted by the police, detained overnight, interrogated and tortured by officers before being released today, Federal officials said.

title: SCREEN: 'NEXT SUMMER'
description: ''NEXT SUMMER,'' written and directed by the French film maker Nadine Trintignant, falls into an odd category for a film made in the 1980's, when the fire of the women's liberation movement is no longer fanned to so bright a flame. It is an unabashedly feminist statement.

title: Burger King Chooses Castor Spanish
description: After a seven-way competition, Burger King has named Castor Spanish International, the largest Hispanic-run shop in the country, to help it capture the Hispanic market in the United States .

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Our struggle to bring democracy back to this country will go on until Gen. Mohammad Zia ul-Haq's Government comes to an end.'' - Benazir Bhutto, the Pakistani opposition leader, before her arrest. [ A1:6. ]

title: Bridge: Two No-Trump Response Has Had a Varied History
description: Some bridge ideas cross the oceans to the United States quite quickly while others take many years and some never arrive at all.

title: FROM BRAZIL TO MEXICO: SCHEDULE AT THE PUBLIC
description: Today At 8 P.M. ''Malandro'' (Brazil), directed by Ruy Guerra; an adaptation of ''The Threepenny Opera.'' Admission by invitation. Tomorrow At 4:30 P.M. ''Oriana'' (Venezuela/ France), directed by Fina Torres; tale of a girl's loss of innocence. (Also Aug. 21 at 9:30 P.M.) At 7 P.M. ''Sera Posible el Sur'' (Argentina/West Germany); chronicle of trip to Argentina by Mercedes Sosa, called the ''Mother Courage'' of Latin America.

title: The Primary System Is Broken, and It's Time to Fix It
description: IN Michigan's Presidential primary last week, voters were ostensibly asked to choose the delegates who will eventually determine which Presidential candidate Michigan will support in the 1988 Republican convention. But exit polls showed that three-quarters of the voters didn't know which candidate the delegate they chose was pledged to back.

title: Work-Force Shifts in 80's
description: THE 1980's are two-thirds over - or will be by the end of the month. How do they shape up?

title: SCREEN: CANDY IN 'ARMED'
description: IF the very sight of John Candy, the outsized comedian, strikes you as a hoot, then perhaps ''Armed and Dangerous'' is for you. It is difficult to imagine who else this latest movie about a pair of bumblers could be for.

title: A Face That Sells?
description: A photograph of Governor Cuomo dominates an advertisement by Bachrach Photographers that appears in the Aug. 11 issue of The New Yorker magazine.

title: DRUG ABUSE CENTERS, BADLY OVERCROWDED, STRUGGLE TO ADD BEDS
description: In the hallways of a Daytop Village drug treatment residence in Queens, mattresses lean against the walls during the day to be squeezed into odd corners at nightfall, and dormitory rooms are crammed with bunk beds an arm's length apart.

title: AMERICAN WOODMARK reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
JOHN BAYLESS, MOSTLY IMPROVISING
description: ''Mostly Mozart is now 20 years old,'' Gerard Schwarz, the festival's music director, said recently. ''We've built a good orchestra, we've played all the great symphonies and piano concertos, and our audience is secure. But now we arrive at the real challenge. If we don't want to repeat ourselves again and again, what do we do? Where do we go from here?''

title: AIR FORCE'S SIGNAL TOWER NETWORK GAINS IN COURT
description: A Federal district judge in Eugene, Ore., ruled today that the Air Force could go ahead with construction of a tower there that is part of a national communications network designed to withstand nuclear attack.

title: ELBIT COMPUTERS LTD CP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
REHNQUIST QUIET OVER TRUST, ILL BROTHER-IN-LAW CONTENDS
description: The disabled brother-in-law of William H. Rehnquist maintains the Supreme Court Justice acted unethically by failing for more than 20 years to tell him about a trust fund set up to help him through his illness.

title: A PROJECT IN JERSEY EVOKES COLONIAL ERA
description: The residents of Poet's Corner, a development of 376 twinned homes here, are to live along streets named after the great of American literature: Alcott, Dickinson, Millay, Twain, Longfellow, Bukiet.

title: SCOTTY'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: FREUD AND HIS FATHER. By Marianne Krull. Translated by Arnold J. Pomerans. Illustrated. 294 pages. W. W.Norton. $18.95.

title: Coleco Cuts Jobs
