description: Coleco Industries will lay off 100 employees, or 14 percent of its Hartford-area work force, this week, a company spokesman said. Analysts said the cutbacks were the result of reduced sales of Cabbage Patch Kid dolls and a lukewarm reception to the company's Rambo toy.

title: GOVERNOR SIGNS BILL MANDATING BUS SEAT BELTS
description: New school buses in New York State will be required to have seat belts under a bill signed into law by Governor Cuomo. The action, announced yesterday by the Governor, makes New York the first state to have such a requirement.

title: LEUCADIA NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $219,000 for the quarter and $497,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes a tax credit of $1,343,000 for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: Michel Petrucciani
description: The pianist Michel Petrucciani is leading a trio tonight through Sunday at the Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South below 11th Street (255-4037). Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is a $10 cover and a one-drink minimum.

title: EX-CELL-O REJECTS TEXTRON'S OFFER
description: The Ex-Cell-O Corporation said yesterday that its board had rejected Textron Inc.'s offer of $68 a share, or $900 million, for the maker of aerospace and automotive parts.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: SINCE cautiously entering the movie business four years ago, ''American Playhouse,'' public television's weekly dramatic series, has proved to be a consistently creative seedbed for quality low-budget films. Its prestigious successes have included ''Testament,'' ''Smooth Talk,'' ''El Norte'' and ''A Flash of Green.''

title: Kiri Te Kanawa Sings With the Boston Pops
description: Although one applauds the audacity it takes for a classically oriented singer to relax into a pop mode or for a pop singer to have a go at opera, recent attempts by singers like Kiri Te Kanawa, Elly Ameling and Linda Ronstadt to cross over from their respective genres have only tended to underscore how clearly the lines are drawn between the pop and classical vocal realms.

title: S.E.C. in Complaint On Belzberg Filing
description: A Belzberg family investment company and Marc Belzberg, the company's vice president, were accused by the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday of failing to file timely reports on the wealthy Canadian family's accumulation of Ashland Oil Inc. shares during its attempt five months ago to take over the oil company.

title: NATIONAL GYPSUM CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-National Gypsum was acquired by Aancor Holdings Inc. effective April 29, and as a result of this action, which included new interest charges, discontinued operations and other non-cash charges to earnings, net earnings for 1985 is not comparable and, therefore, have not been included.

title: GAP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $633,000 for the quarter and $1,526,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid Aug. 1.

title: Israeli Police Bar Jews At Temple Mount Prayer
description: The police today prevented about 30 militant Israeli Jews from illegally praying on the Temple Mount, a site sacred to Moslems and Jews.

title: LATIN FILM SERIES OPENING TONIGHT AT THE PUBLIC
description: The film director Miguel Littin set out last year on a daring mission that had the ring of a movie thriller. Twelve years after his exile from Chile following the 1973 military coup, he shaved off his beard and mustache, dyed his black hair light brown, donned glasses and natty attire and even worked with psychologists to change his personality. Thus disguised, he returned to Chile to interview opponents of the Government of Gen. Augusto Pinochet.

title: Incumbency: Asset or No?
description: Since 1965, 19 people have been appointed to the Senate to fill vacancies created by death or resignation. Last month, after the death of Senator John P. East of North Carolina, James T. Broyhill became the 20th.

title: Byers to Retire
description: Walter Byers, who became the first executive director of the National Collegiate Athletic Association in 1951 and has held the post ever since, has told the organization's executive committee that he wants to step down before he reaches the mandatory retirement age of 70 in 1992. To accommodate him, the committee announced plans to pick a successor by next July.

title: ROUSE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $84,000 for the quarter and $146,000 for the 6 months. The company said its revenue in the prior year periods reflects only continuing operations.

title: New Setup At Burroughs
description: The Burroughs Corporation said yesterday that it would create a new executive office next month immediately after it completes the purchase of all outstanding Sperry shares.

title: 'MICROSOFT WORKS'
description: The Microsoft Corporation, based in Redmond, Wash., introduced a multi-function program for the Apple Macintosh, called Microsoft Works, which will be shipped Sept. 30. The new program, patterned after the popular Appleworks program for the Apple II, provides a word processor, data base, spreadsheet with graphics and a communications module. It will have a suggested retail price of $295.

title: Another U.S. Policy War for 'Democracy'
description: By just two votes, the Senate cut off a filibuster against sending $100 million to the anti-Government ''contras'' in Nicaragua. Senator Biden of Delaware drew the obvious conclusion: there's ''genuine, unquestioned division in this country'' about President Reagan's goal of overthrowing the Sandinista regime.

title: Champion Notes
description: A $150 million note offering by the Champion International Corporation was priced yesterday through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. The 8 1/2 percent noncallable notes due in 1993 are offered at par.

title: Buster Poindexter
description: Buster Poindexter will sing blues, pop and rhythm-and-blues songs tonight and tomorrow at Tramps, 125 East 15th Street (777-5077), with sets at 9:30 P.M. and midnight. There is a $10 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title: SCREEN: 'MAN AND WOMAN'
description: AT some point in producing ''A Man and a Woman: 20 Years Later,'' it seems to have occurred to Claude Lelouch that squeezing from a middle-aged couple the sort of romantic effusions that brought an Academy Award to his 1966 movie with the similar name might prove labored. Anyhow, that may explain his loading on of plot adventures and tricks of the cinematic trade, like a used-car salesman tossing in accessories to keep the buyer's mind off how the car runs. The movie opens today at Cinema I.

title: Bomb Wrecks Canadian Mall
description: A bomb exploded at a shopping mall early today, wrecking some 20 stores and causing damage estimated at $4 million, the police said. No one was hurt.

title: Girl Turns In Parents To Police for Drug Use
description: A 13-year-old girl who fought with her parents over their drug use finally turned them in to the police, along with a trash bag filled with pills, marijuana and cocaine she found at home, the police said today.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday FOOTAGE OF AUSCHWITZ

title: Leucadia Unit Will Be Sold
description: The Leucadia National Corporation said today that it had agreed to sell its consumer finance group, which operates 177 offices in 21 states principally as the City Finance Company, to the Great Western Financial Corporation.

title: LIFE IN HISPANIC QUEENS: TOGETHER, YET SEPARATE
description: Pedro Monge, a native of Cuba, citizen of the United States and resident of Queens, remembers the party of Cubans and Ecuadoreans at which someone made an innocent remark about Cuban black beans. Soon, he recalls, the casual aside turned into a debate over whether Cuban or Ecuadorean cuisine was tastier.

title: DILLARD DEPARTMENT STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
BOLT BERANEK & NEWMAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
AUCTIONS
description: THE story behind the Guernsey auction of Americana this weekend in Tuxedo, N.Y., began in the spring. At that time, the auction house received a 10-page letter in minuscule script from Wilmer Bader, a Middle Western farmer with a brainstorm. He listed a mind-boggling array of items he wanted to sell, and wrote: ''I wished you could see it all. It's just so much I can't explain it all to you.''

title: TRAVELERS ADVISORY: MORE DELAYS AHEAD FOR WEEKEND TRIPS
description: Even the experts often learn too late.

title: Citicorp Issue
description: Citicorp yesterday began offering $250 million of 10-year subordinated notes through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc. The notes, which carry a 8 1/4 percent coupon, are offered at par. Noncallable for five years, they are rated Aa-2 by Moody's and AA- by S.& P.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: WHEN Susan and Barry Wine, owners of the sumptuous Quilted Giraffe, decided to open a second restaurant in the arcade of the A.T.&T. building on Madison Avenue, they described it as a breezy, informal spot with Quilted Giraffe-style food at lower prices. More than a year overdue, the Casual Quilted Giraffe has opened and, as expected from this trend-setting duo, it is, well, unique - and sure to be controversial.

title: AMES DEPARTMENT STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 26
description: The 1985 figures include results of G.C. Murphy Co. from June 7, 1985.

title: KARPOV'S EFFORT AT COMPLEXITY RESULTS IN DRAW
description: Anatoly Karpov and Gary Kasparov agreed to a draw in the seventh game of their world championship chess match yesterday in London without resuming play.

title: An All-Day Festival On East Fourth Street
description: A daylong festival of music, dance, theater and comedy is planned tomorrow from noon to 10 P.M. on East Fourth Street, between Second Avenue and the Bowery.

title: Can Teamwork Help Us Avert Global Depression?
description: JUST when weak growth in the Western industrialized nations calls for greater cooperation among them, frictions are mounting. To strengthen world recovery, a common effort by these nations is urgently required to lower interest rates, help debtor nations finance the imports required for faster growth, and reverse a deteriorating world trade environment.

title: PRESIDENT CHOSEN AT B.F. GOODRICH
description: Leigh Carter was named president and chief operating officer of the B. F. Goodrich Company yesterday.

title: Harvest Fair Planned At Floyd Bennett Field
description: Home gardeners who are especialy proud ofofheir tomatoes, eggplants, carrots, marigolds and roses can enter them at a Harvest Fair tomorrow at Floyd Bennett Field, Gateway National Recreation Area, Brooklyn. Winning gardeners will receive ribbons, while the actual prize winners will be distributed to local charities.

title: NO QUICK RETURN SEEN FOR WYNEGAR
description: Butch Wynegar, who left the Yankees July 31, will not be returning soon, his agent said yesterday.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Cannon Group Inc., a Los Angeles movie producer, has appointed Mark Baron to the new position of executive vice president of marketing.

title: AS MEXICAN CHIEF ENDS VISIT, THE FIRST NOTES OF DISCORD ARE HEARD
description: As he concluded his visit here, President Miguel de la Madrid of Mexico offered and received his first criticism today in what has been an unusually harmonious three-day encounter with United States officials.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Carl Lewis, the four-event Olympic champion who came in third in the 100-meter dash at a track meet in Zurich Wednesday night, withdrew from a meet in West Berlin dedicated to the four-event 1936 Olympic champion, Jesse Owens, and said a ''nagging knee problem'' would keep him out of competition until February. . . . Steffi Graf, the 17-year-old tennis star who broke a toe in a freakish accident during the Federation Cup competition last month, is expected to recover in time to play in the United States Open, her father said. . . . Marvelous Marvin Hagler, the middlweight boxing champion, is expected to announce next week that he will fight Sugar Ray Leonard in Las Vegas. . . . LeRoy Ellis, a center and forward for 14 years in the National Basketball Association after an outstanding career at St. John's, has been hired as an assistant to the new head basketball coach at Southern California, George Raveling. . . . Charles Pittman, a free-agent forward, ended his four-year career with the Phoenix Suns by signing a guaranteed one-year contract with Verace of the Italian League. His agent said Pittman signed for a substantially greater salary than the $105,000 he earned as a reserve with Phoenix last season.

title: MICHAEL L. HAIDER, 81, RETIRED OIL EXECUTIVE
description: Michael L. Haider, former chairman of the board and chief executive officer of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), forerunner of the Exxon Corporation, died yesterday of complications resulting from Alzheimer's disease at his home in Atherton, Calif. He was 81 years old.

title: Bonds Dip as Germans Demur
description: Prices of Treasury securities fell slightly yesterday, reflecting traders' disappointment with both the West German Bundesbank's failure to ease interest-rate policy and with a slightly higher Federal funds rate in the United States market.

title: The Big Profits In Gold Options
description: WHILE many investors in gold did well during the latest surge in prices, those who made the most money with the least risk were those who bought call options on bullion when the market turned higher early last month. Since then, the price of gold bullion has risen from $345 an ounce to $387 as of yesterday's close.

title: OXOCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The latest 6 months' results includes a writedown of $19,953,900 on oil and gas properties. The year-ago 6 months' results includes a similar writedown of $28,338,770 and writedowns on assets of $12,068,822.

title: Carbide Restates Profit
description: Union Carbide Corporation today restated its second-quarter net income at $388 million, or $3.97 a share, reflecting a one-time gain of $333 million, mainly from divesting its battery products business. In July, the company reported, without the special gain, a 46 percent decrease in earnings. Net income a year ago was $101 million, or 48 cents per share.

title: Grey Gets Account Of Olive Garden Chain
description: Grey Advertising has been awarded the seven-figure Olive Garden account by the General Mills Restaurant Group. Olive Garden, an Italian restaurant chain in the Sun Belt, was previously at Young & Rubicam/Zemp in Tampa, Fla.

title: TELE-COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes pre-tax gains on the sale and exchange of assets of $88,342,000 for the quarter and $91,123,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes pre-tax gains of $3,113,000 for the quarter and $3,925,000 for the 6 months on sale and exchange of assets.

title: KENNINGTON LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
INTEGRATED RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Ater losses from discontinued operations of $2,966,000 for the quarter and $10,395,000 for the 6 months, and the 6-month period also include a charge of $10,510,000. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $604,000 and $1,168,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. d-Net income The company said there were no share earnings after preferred dividend requirements for the latest quarter and year-ago 6 months.

title: Tribute to Indians
description: A tribute to American Indians is planned by the Urban Park Rangers tomorrow from 10 A.M. to 7 P.M. at Inwood Hill Park in upper Manhattan.

title: FMI FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $50,549,000 for both the quarter and 6 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $197,000 and $531,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: HAMSHO STOPS BURTON
description: Mustafa Hamsho, a 32-year-old middleweight from Brooklyn, knocked out Richard Burton, a promising fighter from the Bronx, at 2 minutes 24 seconds of the seventh round of a scheduled 10-round bout at the Felt Forum last night.

title: Topics: Questions of Respect; The Foster Flap
description: Baseball reflects society. Jackie Robinson's passage through the color barrier in 1947 made more than sports news. Last year's cocaine scandal displayed a shadowy side of the game, and the culture.

title: Dining Out Guide: Casual
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given.

title: MYERS, L E CO GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
STUDENT SEIZED IN SHOOTOUT GOT CARE IN GEORGIA
description: The student accused of shooting five people, one fatally, in a rampage through the campus of New York City Technical College on Tuesday was in a mental hospital in Georgia on three occasions, the police said yesterday.

title: Caterpillar Layoffs
description: Caterpillar Inc. said it had temporarily laid off 1,085 workers in Illinois, most in assembly operations, because a strike by the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace workers at its Joliet, Ill., plant has led to a lack of components. That strike began Aug. 1. The layoffs, which will begin Monday, will involve 700 workers in Decatur, 250 at East Peoria and 135 at Aurora.

title: INVENTORIES UP IN JUNE AS SALES BOUNCE BACK
description: Inventories held by American businesses rose in June at the fastest pace in three months while business sales rebounded after a huge downturn, the Government reported today.

title: PIZZA INN INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a gain of $18,659,000 on the sale of Quality Sausage Co., a charge of $6.1 million for a pre-tax reserve related to restaurant closings and lease terminations and a pre-tax charge of $2,613,000 reflecting an accounting change for the quarter and 6 months.

title: ROCK AND SALSA IN THE GREAT OUTDOORS
description: MUSIC will be bouncing off concrete, splashing on the Hudson, rippling into the East River and ricocheting off office buildings this weekend. It will also be rolling across meadows and floating into the sky; it may even enjoy a spectacular sunset or two. Whatever else might be said about August weather here, it brings music out into the open. It also takes musicians off the late-night vampire shift and brings them into the daylight.

title: Manning Leaves J.W.T.
description: BURTON J. MANNING, the chairman and chief executive of J. Walter Thompson U.S.A. since 1980, resigned yesterday. He is being replaced as the head of the domestic arm of the world's fourth-largest advertising agency by Bertram M. Metter, who has spent 23 years at Thompson, most recently in charge of the agency's efforts to attract new business.

title: Antinuclear Group Marches Into Chicago
description: About 250 nuclear disarmament advocates walked into Chicago today on their transcontinental Great Peace March.

title: SCREEN: 'DOLLY BELL,' FROM YUGOSLAVIA
description: IT is a typical Eastern European committee meeting. A paunchy bureaucrat with snow-white hair and an ill-fitting suit addresses a solemn-faced audience. ''Comrades,'' he says, ''the situation is very grave.'' From his manner he might be setting up a new five-year plan. But no, this is something else. He wants the local youth club to form a band. This is a committee mandate for spontaneous creativity.

title: Two Exhibitions Worth Visiting On Long Island
description: TWO substantial shows on Long Island are:

title: ANGOLA REPORTS REPELLING ATTACK
description: Angola said today that South African forces had lost 95 men in two days in an attempt to capture the Angolan town of Cuito Canaval, 156 miles north of the Namibian border.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Pinetop Perkins, the Abilene Cafe, 359 Second Avenue at 21st Street (473-8908). In his youth, Pinetop Perkins played bracing blues piano behind Sonny Boy Williamson and other Mississippi delta legends. In later years, he was an important member of the band that backed Muddy Waters. His occasional vocals on Muddy Waters records revealed an attractive, smoke-cured timbre and an affection for rocking urban rhythm-and-blues, surprising in view of the fact that his piano playing is pure blues. The music begins around 9 tonight and tomorrow; there is a $10 cover charge.

title: City Agrees to Wiring Of Cable TV in Stages
description: A plan to allow cable television to be installed in phases in the Bronx and most of Brooklyn was approved last night by the city's Board of Estimate.

title: RED SOX TRIUMPH, LEAD YANKEES BY 4
description: Tony Armas knocked in four runs, three of them in the third inning on his seventh home run of the year, and Don Baylor singled in the go-ahead run as the Boston Red Sox beat the Kansas City Royals, 11-6, tonight.

title: FORSCHNER GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain from discontinued operations of $578,000 and a loss from discontinued operations of $71,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, an extraordinary credit of $1,416,000 from the sale of Woodstream stock for both the quarter and year, and tax credits of $295,000 for the quarter and $1,109,000 for the year. c-Net loss and includes losses from discontinued operations of $91,000 for the quarter and $2,900,000 for the year.

title: CAR BOMB BLAST KILLS 20 IN EAST BEIRUT
description: A car laden with what the police estimated was 280 pounds of explosives blew up on a crowded street in the predominantly Christian sector of the capital today. The authorities said 20 people were killed and 100 wounded.

title: FILLY'S DAZZLING SPEED STILL THE TALK OF SARATOGA
description: Regardless of whether Ogygian can win the Travers Stakes here Saturday off a six-week layoff, and whatever the outcome of the shootout between Precisionist and Lady's Secret at Monmouth earlier that afternoon, the most startling racing performance of the month may have already passed.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for belwether issues.

title: New York's Blunt Impeachment Tool
description: To the Editor:

title: Daisy Systems In Shake-Up
description: The Daisy Systems Corporation, the troubled maker of computer systems used to design electronic circuits, today announced a major restructuring of its management.

title: FGIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the share earnings and shares outstanding are fully diluted.

title: MEXICO SAYS IT HAS STARTED AN INQUIRY INTO CASE OF U.S. DRUG AGENT
description: Mexico's Attorney General has sent a team to the western city of Guadalajara to investigate the case of an American narcotics agent whom the United States says was tortured, a spokesman for President Miguel de la Madrid said today.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for belwether issues.

title: New 'Models' in Car Loans
description: THE Big Three auto companies have long been adept at coming up with car models tailored to the needs of different customers. Now their captive finance subsidiaries are beginning to adopt some of the same tactics in developing new ''models'' of financing packages aimed at certain segments of the buying public.

title: BOSTON BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
SBE INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After tax credits of $58,000 for the quarter and $225,000 for the 9 months. c-After a tax credit of $123,000.

title: Pay-as-You-Went
description: To the Editor:

title: MOSCOW REPORTS A-PLANT WORKERS IGNORED WARNINGS
description: The Chernobyl nuclear disaster in the Soviet Union last April occurred when workers running a test shut off key emergency equipment, then ignored warnings of problems, according to a report prepared by Soviet officials.

title:
PATENTS;
Clip-on Surgical Light Utilizes Fiber Optics
description: A surgical light that can be clipped onto an abdominal or other tissue wall near the site of an operation was patented this week.

title: KURZWELL MUSIC SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FANUEIL HALL MARKETPLACE AFTER 10 YEARS
description: Not even last week's tornado warnings dissuaded tourists by the tens of thousands from inching, gawking, eating and slurping their way through the old Quincy Market, which was renovated 10 years ago this month and transformed into a kind of upscale carnival. The sunnier weather that followed packed in about 100,000 more.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * De Tomaso Industries, Red Bank, N.J., said it had received $26 million in financing from the Italian Government for a venture with the Chrysler Corp.

title:
PATENTS;
Lightning Deterrent on Towers
description: A LIGHTNING deterrent that is already used to protect more than 100 radio and television transmission towers was patented this week by the inventor and manufacturer. Vernon A. Gillem, president of Verda Industries in Seminole, Fla., was granted patent 4,605,814.

title: Della Femina Sold
description: Della Femina, Travisano & Partners, a medium-size advertising agency that has often made a big splash with its ad campaigns, has agreed to be taken over by Wight Collins Rutherford Scott P.L.C., a major London-based advertising concern. Jerry Della Femina, chairman, did not disclose the price, but said the agency had turned down two slightly higher offers.

title: TALKS CONTINUE AS PHONE STRIKE REACHES 6 DAYS
description: Outside New York Telephone Company headquarters at the Avenue of the Americas and 42d Street - where several thousand telephone workers had rallied Thursday, cheering and vowing to continue their strike - three strikers lounged on police barricades yesterday, almost unnoticed by passers-by.

title: HOW AMERICAN'S HANOI ESCAPADE WENT AWRY
description: A 44-year-old American who calls himself a ''scholar-adventurer'' said at a news conference here today that he deliberately sailed a small boat into Vietnamese waters 16 months ago hoping to be noticed, so he could beg the authorities for help in releasing a Vietnamese woman he wanted to marry.

title: NEIGHBORS VOW TO FIGHT LINCOLN CENTER EXPANSION
description: Opponents of a Lincoln Center expansion plan said yesterday that they would continue to press their lawsuit challenging the proposal, which received final approval late Thursday night from the Board of Estimate.

title: Another Warning Issued About Tainted Food
description: For the second time this week the Food and Drug Administration is warning consumers to be alert for dairy products contaminated with a potentially dangerous bacteria.

title: VOLLEYBALL COACH CREATES OWN STYLE
description: Alexandra Dunphy, age 8 months, made her first trip to New York this weekend. She traveled to Japan four months ago and will be in France this fall. Her father is the coach of the United States volleyball team. Alexandra will have an opportunity to watch a lot of volleyball, even if she never remembers anything she sees.

title: Micropro Layoffs, Reorganization Set
description: The Micropro International Corporation, known for its Wordstar word-processing software, said that a major reorganization aimed at improving profitability and market share would result in the layoff of about 20 percent of its 208 employees in the United States, but that personnel would be added in sales and support.

title: Getting Serious About Mexico
description: For Washington, this might well turn out to be the Decade of Mexico, and this week might turn out to mark an improvement in, at least, the tone of United States-Mexican relations. President Reagan's meetings with Mexico's President, Miguel de la Madrid, have brought him clearer understanding of how gravely our southern neighbor is challenged, and with what potential consequences on this side of the border.

title: LESLIE FAY COMPANIES reports earnings for 13wks to June 28
description: The net income and share earnings are pro forma. The company said the share earnings are based on the number of shares outstanding prior to the company's initial public offering which occurred on Aug. 1, 1986.

title: I.R.E. FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PLAYBOY ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $11,228,000 for the quarter and $51,674,000 for the year. c-After a loss of $739,000 from discontinued operations and an extraordinary charge of $87,000. d-Net income and after a loss of $280,000 and an extraordinary gain of $2,456,000.

title: CATHOLIC SCHOOL EXPELS GIRL OVER ABORTION STAND
description: An 11-year-old girl has been told by her pastor that she cannot return to St. Agnes Roman Catholic School in Toledo, Ohio, because she had publicly supported the right to abortion.

title: Foster Debut: A Home Run
description: George Foster was signed by the Chicago White Sox today, then made his American League debut a rousing success tonight by hitting a home run against the Milwaukee Brewers in a 4-3 loss.

title: SENATE VOTES BILL TO PROD PRETORIA
description: The Senate tonight ignored the objections of the Reagan Administration and overwhelmingly approved a set of tough economic sanctions designed to undermine the system of racial separation in South Africa.

title: MILK AS A SLEEP INDUCER AND OTHER CONTROVERSIES
description: Several recent De Gustibus columns have created more controversy than it seems possible to generate from a few hundred words.

title: MAIL CAMPAIGN SUCCEEDS
description: Because of a successful mail-solicitation campaign, Channel 13 has canceled a weeklong on-air fund-raising drive, which was to have started today. The station expects to reach its goal of $750,000 through donations from current and new members and will offer programming without fund-raising breaks through Aug. 24. Programming during what the station calls the ''no-pledge'' period will feature the premiere of ''The Price,'' a three-part British mini-series, as well as the film ''The Music Man.''

title: KAPOK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: SOVIET BUILDING 2 BIG RADARS
description: The Soviet Union has begun construction of two new large early-warning radars, Administration officials said today.

title: Not So Dumb Animals
description: ADAM'S TASK: Calling Animals by Name. By Vicki Hearne. 274 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $17.95.

title: WELLS AMERICAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
THIRD WORLD MUSIC IS PICKING UP STEAM
description: On a recent weekday, Char Eberly telephoned Rio de Janiero to confirm arrangements for the first appearance in the United States of the Brazilian singer Jorge Ben at Sounds of Brazil and Beyond, the club she helps manage. Her calls went unanswered. The next day she learned why: ''The whole country shut down after 2 o'clock to watch the World Cup soccer games,'' she said. Such are the vagaries of bringing third world music to New York City, which is what Sounds of Brazil, at 204 Varick Street, has been doing for four years.

title: WORLD AIRWAYS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After capital gains of $25,226,000 for the quarter and $45,864,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss and includes capital gains of $50,000 for the quarter and $1,642,000 for the 6 months.

title: PRODUCER PRICES FELL 0.4% IN JULY
description: Producer prices fell four-tenths of 1 percent last month for the fifth decline of the year, the Government reported today, The drop in the Labor Department's Producer Price Index was almost entirely a result of a 19.3 percent plunge in wholesale gasoline prices in July. Nearly all other commodities rose in price and food was up a sharp 1.9 percent.

title: MADISON GAS & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
COLOMBIANS FIGHT A 'PLAGUE' THAT WON'T LET GO
description: This country's reputation as the world's main supplier of cocaine is a source of endless embarrassment to law-abiding Colombians who travel abroad.

title: MARCOS FURNISHINGS ARE AUCTIONED IN QUEENS
description: Antiques dealers, amateur home decorators and collectors of curiosities jammed into an auction last night to buy memorabilia of Ferdinand E. and Imelda Marcos, sometimes paying twice the expected prices.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: WALK UNDER WATER

title: Article 582886 -- No Title
description: Turner Broadcasting Systems Inc. said today that it lost $85.8 million in the second quarter and that it expected large losses to continue because of continuing expenses resulting from its $1.2 billion acquisition of MGM and its extensive film library.

title: OGYGIAN'S DAY OR IS IT?
description: Imagine a small child waiting 10 months for the circus to come to town. The big day finally arrives, but the lions and tigers have fleas, the star trapeze artist has a bellyache, and storms are threatening to blow down the big top and cancel the show. The child breaks into tears. That is how the Ogygian fan club was feeling yesterday on the eve of the Travers Stakes at Saratoga race track. Today was supposed to be the day of triumph and vindication for the magnificent colt, the day he would finally show the rest of the world that he was the best 3-year-old. Instead, everything is against him and even the fan club is hoping, rather than promising or even betting, that he will win in spite of circumstances.

title: Playboy Posts Loss in Quarter
description: Playboy Enterprises Inc. said today that it lost $16.3 million in the fourth quarter, compared with a loss of $816,000 a year ago.

title: I.M.F. Bars Peru From New Loans
description: Peru was declared ineligible today for new loans by the International Monetary Fund in a move likely to distance the country further from sources of both public and private finance. The sanction was expected.

title: Body of Woman Found in Alley
description: The bruised and strangled body of a young woman was found today in an alley behind a shopping area in this Long Island town, the police said.

title: Wider Use of Medicaid For Abortion Is Backed
description: The Senate Appropriations Committee voted today to exempt victims of rape and incest from a ban on the use of Federal Medicaid funds for abortions.

title: CITY MAY FACE REVENUE CRISIS, REPORT WARNS
description: New York City tax collections were so much lower than expected in the fiscal year that ended in June that, if the trend continues, the city may have to take ''more stringent actions,'' a top official in the State Comptroller's office has warned.

title: AUTODESK INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
LANDMARK LAND CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Bridge; College Teammates Reunite And Win a National Crown
description: Many of the stars of today had their first exposure to national competition in the intercollegiate championships, a popular par event in the 40's and 50's. In 1954 Trinity University in San Antonio was represented by two young men destined for quite different careers.

title: ARMADA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: ROYAL PALM BEACH COLONY INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: There are no comparable year-ago figures because the company changed to a Sept. 30 year from an April 30 year.

title: Baby Is Weak After Birth To Brain-Dead Woman
description: Doctors said today that a premature baby boy weighing 1 pound, 1 1/2 ounces who was born Thursday to a brain-dead woman had little chance of survival.

title: The Plaintive Tune Of 'Repeal 22'
description: Lafayette Park, which is across the street from the White House and serves as the capital's year-round camping ground of ideas, offered a new exhibit last week. Amidst the usual eyesores there arose fresh new placards carrying a demand to ''Repeal 22'' - the 22d Amendment, which limits the Presidency to two terms and will thus keep Mr. Reagan from running for a third, should he be in a mind to do so.

title: VOCAL AND AGGRESSIVE VALLONE REDEFINES ROLE
description: During his first eight months in office, Peter F. Vallone, the City Council's new majority leader, has increased the Council staff to 133 from 86. He has created his own investigative unit and hired a lobbyist to represent the Council in Albany.

title: Lawyer Is Named to Head Bureau of Transit Operations
description: City Transportation Commissioner Ross Sandler yesterday named Henry F. White Jr., a lawyer and naval reserve officer, to be deputy commissioner in charge of the newly created Bureau of Transit Operations.

title: Envoy to Egypt Confirmed
description: The Senate, on a voice vote, confirmed Frank G. Wisner today as Ambassador to Egypt. Mr. Wisner, a career Foreign Service officer, is currently Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs. He will succeed Nicholas A. Veliotes.

title: Blundering on the Bench
description: A judge's order telling a legislature not to vote on an issue must rate as one of the most extreme forms of judicial activism. Yet this week not one but two justices of New York's Supreme Court issued such orders enjoining New York City's Board of Estimate from voting on the Lincoln Center expansion proposal. Not until the Appellate Division set those orders aside was the board free to give its unanimous approval to the project.

title: COMDIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.S. PROTESTING MEXICO 'TORTURE' OF DRUG AGENT
description: The United States issued a strong protest to Mexico today over what the White House called ''the unprovoked and totally unjustified detention and torture'' of a Drug Enforcement Adminstration agent by the Mexican police this week.

title: Destination the Orient
description: Tomorrow, 100 musicians of the District of Columbia Youth Orchestra will depart for a three-week concert tour of China. The tour is billed by its organizers, Friends of the D.C. Youth Orchestra, as the first time a performing group so young (8 to 18 years of age) has undertaken such a tour. Their 10 concerts will be performed in Hong Kong, Taiwan and several cities on the mainland, including two in Peking.

title: SERVOTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After tax credits of $169,000 for the quarter and $291,000 for the 6 months. c-After tax credits of $176,000 for the quarter and $291,000 for the 6 months.

title: United, Pilots End Pay Talks
description: Talks between United Airlines and its pilots' union over differences stalling the carrier's efforts to buy ailing Frontier Airlines broke off without an agreement today.

title: DIAGNOSTIC MEDICAL INSTRUENTS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After tax credits of $100,000 for the quarter and $378,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss

title: Ex-Diplomat From Colombia Cleared of U.S. Drug Charge
description: The Justice Department has dropped charges that a former Colombian diplomat was involved in an American cocaine-smuggling ring.

title: PRESIDENTIAL LIFE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After realized investment gains of $2,169,000 for the quarter and $4,369,000 for the 6 months. c-After realized investment gains of $1,229,000 for the quarter and $1,481,000 for the 6 months and tax credits of $1,218,000 and $2,029,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: AVNET INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a special charge of $8 million resulting from the disposition of two businesses and writedown of inventories for both the quarter and year, and gains of $500,000 and $2.6 million for the quarter and year, respectively, for adoption of new pension accounting standards. c-Net income

title: G.M., Volvo Set Truck Linkup
description: The General Motors Corporation, at the bottom of the depressed heavy-duty truck market, said today that it plans to phase out its sole big-truck assembly line and combine American and Canadian operations with A.B. Volvo of Sweden. G.M. and the Volvo White

title: SCOTT'S LIQUID GOLD INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After tax credits of $38,000 for the quarter and $106,000 for the 6 months. c-After tax credits of $108,000 for the quarter and $162,000 for the 6 months.

title: U.S. WHEAT HELP FAILS TO SPEED SOVIET BUYING
description: Two weeks after President Reagan authorized the sale of subsidized wheat to the Soviet Union, Moscow has not yet purchased a single bushel of grain from American traders, the Department of Agriculture said today.

title: MOSCOW REPORTS A-PLANT WORKERS IGNORED WARNINGS New Safeguards Drafted
description: Representatives of 62 nations agreed today on a set of new international safeguards against the spread of radioactive fallout resulting from a nuclear accident.

title: Joseph Bolton 3d, 75, Officer Joe on WPIX
description: Joseph Reeves Bolton 3d, who was known to a generation of young New Yorkers as Officer Joe, the host of children's film programs on WPIX in the early years of television, died of a heart ailment on Wednesday at Santa Monica Hospital in California. He was 75 years old and had lived in retirement in Santa Monica for 11 years.

title: That Michigan Squabble
description: Selection of Republican precinct delegates in Michigan took place nearly two weeks ago, on Aug. 5, and the squabbling still goes on among Presidential contenders over who came out the winner.

title: COMMERCIAL LAUNCHING BY NASA ORDERED SHIFTED TO PRIVATE SECTOR
description: President Reagan has ordered the space agency to yield its commercial launching business to private industry and to build a fourth space shuttle to replace the lost Challenger, the White House announced today.

title: Oil Stocks Strong; Dow Gains 10.69
description: The stock market, buoyed by the oil stocks, ended broadly higher yesterday for the fifth session in a row.

title: Bid for Color Tile
description: Color Tile Inc., a leading retailer of home improvement products in the United States and Canada, said that an investor group composed of senior management and major shareholders had offered to acquire the company for $25 a share, or a total of $237 million.

title: P.&G.'S DENTAL BREAKTHROUGH
description: In 1960 the Procter & Gamble Company shook up the toothpaste industry by getting the American Dental Association to endorse Crest as effective against cavities. Now Procter has scored another coup: It has won the A.D.A.'s seal of approval for a new mouthwash that, the Cincinnati-based consumer products giant says, fights the plaque and gum disease that at some time afflict almost everyone.

title: UNKNOWN GOLFERS IN SPOTLIGHT
description: With the top 12 female professionals absent, the MasterCard International of the L.P.G.A. tour at three Westchester golf courses is giving an opportunity for relative unknowns, such as Colleen Walker, to make a name for themselves.

title: CATERINA JARBORO
description: Caterina Jarboro, a soprano who made her United States debut in Verdi's ''Aida'' in 1933, a black woman taking the lead role in an all-white company, died Wednesday at her home in Manhattan after a brief illness. She was 90 years old.

title: JACKPOT ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
President Gets Bill Banning Most Armor-Piercing Bullets
description: The Senate has passed and sent to President Reagan for his approval a bill banning armor-piercing bullets.

title: HOUSE APPROVES MILITARY BILL THAT REJECTS REAGAN POLICIES
description: Congress struggled to clear the way for its three-week summer recess early today after the Democratic-controlled House approved a 1987 military programs bill Friday that rejects Reagan Administration policies on arms control, new chemical weapons and a space-based defense against missiles.

title: CAMPBELL RED LAKE MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $1,752,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary charge of $16,814,000 for the 6 months. Revenue represents bullion revenue. All figures are in Canadian dollars.

title: Britain's I.C.I. To Buy Glidden
description: Imperial Chemical Industries, the giant British industrial concern, said yesterday that it would acquire one the largest paint companies in the United States, Glidden Coatings and Resins, for $580 million. The move, rumored for months, would make I.C.I. the world's largest paint producer.

title: Anderson, Clayton Rejects 2d Offer
description: Anderson, Clayton & Company said its board had rejected a sweetened $56-a-share, $679 million buyout bid from Bear, Stearns & Company and Gruss & Company and would continue to pursue a self-tender offer and sale of stock to an employee stock ownership plan. ''The board believes this approach is in the best interests of the stockholders, and has rejected the Bear, Stearns-Gruss proposal because it would require a sale of the company and completely terminate stockholders' interest in the company,'' said W. Fenton Guinee Jr., president and chief executive.

title: MARY S. RAMSDELL
description: Mary S. Ramsdell, believed to be one of the first women in the United States to be a state trooper, has died at a nursing home, the Massachusetts State Police announced today. She was 96 years old.

title: BLOCKER ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TAMILS OFF CANADA FLED GERMANY, POLICE SAY
description: A group of Sri Lankan refugees rescued off the coast of Newfoundland four days ago embarked on their journey to Canada in a tramp freighter from northern West Germany on July 28, the Hamburg police said today.

title: A Banker, 38, Wins 2-Million Lotto Prize
description: A 38-year-old trust officer for the Bankers Trust Company won $2 million in Wednesday's New York Lotto 48 drawing. Lottery officials believe he is the first banker to win a million-dollar prize in the New York lottery.

title: SANCTIONS AND SOUTH AFRICA: COMPARING THE PLANS
description: In recent months there have been a series of proposals for economic and other sanctions against South Africa to oppose its policy of apartheid. The plans would affect the South African economy to various degrees. Following is a breakdown of the provisions of each and, using the most recent figures available, a look at the possible economic ramifications for South Africa. Senate Approved Aug. 15; would take effect if reconciled with the House version and signed into law by President Reagan or, in case of Presidential veto, if veto was overridden by both houses of Congress.

title: ASTEC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a charge of $151,000 in connection with the company's initial public offering and the elimination of the investment tax credit.

title: OPERA: 'GIARDINIERA,' TEEN-AGE MOZART
description: In ''La Finta Giardiniera'' we hear Mozart, a talented 18-year-old, reaching out toward his own genius and sometimes nearly touching it. It is a bridge opera, fascinating on its own terms but not to be dismissed on any terms. This somewhat rambling and feebly plotted comic opera, which has been known to the general public only by hearsay until recent years, never rises to the level of his later ''Nozze di Figaro'' or ''Cosi Fan Tutte'' - after all, only a few other operas do, and several of them are by Mozart himself. In no other way, however, can a decent performance of ''La Finta Giardiniera'' be disappointing to anyone concerned with the composer's incredible flowering as a musical dramatist.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, AUGUST 16, 1986
description: International

title: PANTASOTE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After tax credits of $304,000 for the quarter and $583,000 for the 6 months. c-After an extraordinary charge of $10,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $53,000 for the 6 months.

title: DBA SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
Seth Allen, Director, Writer And an Obie-Winning Actor
description: Seth Allen, a Brooklyn-born actor and director, died of cryptococcal meningitis Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 45 years old.

title: Senate Approves Bill to Cut Protection for Ex-Presidents
description: The Senate today approved and sent to the House a bill that would limit Secret Service protection for former Presidents, their families and their widows.

title: A. Marcus Hemphill Is Dead; TV Writer and a Playwright
description: A. Marcus Hemphill, a New York playwright and television writer, died Monday at Cabrini Medical Center after a long illness. He was 56 years old and lived in the Bronx.

title: ZEHNTEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
description: b-Includes provisions of $1.7 million for the quarter and $2.5 million for the year to cover the cost of additional facilities consolidation and employee severance implemented at year-end. The year loss also includes a capital loss of $1.6 million on the sale of the company's Aerotronic subsidiary. c-After a tax credit of $495,000.

title: HOTEL PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
RICHARD SNEIDER, EX-DIPLOMAT, DIES
description: Richard L. Sneider, a former United States Ambassador to South Korea and Deputy Assistant Secretary of State, died of cancer today at his summer home in Brandon, Vt. He was 64 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: SLATTERY GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $2,008,000 for the quarter and 6 months. c-Net income and includes net of $76,000 for the quarter and a loss of $89,000 for the 6 months, both from discontinued operations.

title: CITY OPERA: 'CENDRILLON' WITH FAITH ESHAM
description: CHARM is an elusive quality and all but indefinable. That I understand. Still, I make so bold as to say flatly that the New York City Opera's ''Cendrillon,'' which returned last evening after a three-year absence, is certain to charm you, unless you have passed irrevocably into adult cynicism. Of course, if you have reached the stage of cultural development where the tale of Cinderella's mistreatment at the hands of her stepmother and the ugly sisters brings only a yawn, this staging of Massenet's opera is not for you. For all others, however, a captivating night in the theater is assured.

title: Unusual Compliment
description: If Jacques Demers ever needs a recommendation as a hockey coach, he could hardly wish for a more glowing tribute than the one provided yesterday by the St. Louis Blues, the club he abruptly quit in June to join the Detroit Red Wings.

title: Oregon to Compensate Victims of Commune
description: The state reached a settlement today that will establish a fund of up to $5 million to compensate victims of criminal acts by organizations set up by followers of the Indian guru Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh.

title: GENERAL CERAMICS INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: The company said the fiscal 1985 share earnings was negligible.

title: MANGOOD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FLIGHT DELAYS AT BUSIEST AIRPORTS REPORTED UP 31% OVER LAST YEAR
description: Departure and landing delays are plaguing nearly a third more flights at the nation's busiest airports so far this year than last, the Federal Aviation Administration reported today. The figures show the airports with the most delays are in Newark, New York and Boston.

title: Will There Be Lawyers?
description: In the category of things we somehow have neglected to worry about, the Congressional Office of Technology Assessment reports, ''People living and working on the space station may not enjoy the protection of many of the laws we take for granted on earth - laws that regulate commerce, property and personal interaction.''

title: CHANCE TO START GIVES HOSTETLER A BOOST >
description: Jeff Hostetler, beginning his third season as a National Football League quarterback, will do something Saturday night he has never done before. He will start a pro game. When the Giants oppose the Green Bay Packers in an exhibition game at County Stadium in Milwaukee, Hostetler is scheduled to play behind the Giants' starting offensive line for the first quarter and part of the second. He will be followed by Phil Simms, the nominal starter, and Jeff Rutledge, the nominal first backup.

title: DECORATOR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title:
PATENTS;
2-Channel Equipment For High-Definition TV
description: A high-definition television broadcasting system has been invented for use in direct satellite transmission to the home.

title: ACCORD ON TAXES HAS BEEN REACHED, PACKWOOD SAYS
description: After almost 12 hours of tense negotations, Senator Bob Packwood said early today that he and Representative Dan Rostenkowski had reached agreement in principle on the main elements of a comprehensive tax revision bill.

title: A Misguided Policy on Ethiopia
description: For several years the C.I.A. has apparently been channeling hundreds of thousands of tax dollars to dissidents inside and outside Ethiopia who claim to be able to start a democratic resistance movement, which the Administration can then support as ''freedom fighters'' against the Marxist Government. According to press reports, one such group is a post office box in London, and another has ''agents'' and ''cells'' inside Ethiopia.

title: TV: CHANNEL 31 VIEWS 'NONTRADITIONAL' DANCE
description: The seventh program in the ''Alive From Off-Center'' series, to be broadcast tonight at 10 on Channel 31, opens with the odd observation that dancers don't ordinarily line up in formation as they do in this look at ''nontraditional'' choreography. Dancers do line up that way, of course, in everything from ''Swan Lake'' to ''Primitive Mysteries.'' But the program has far more to offer than the lineups of the 1980's.

title: STUDY WARNS AQUINO OF RISK OF 'INCIDENT' IN PHILIPPINES
description: ''Hidden conspirators'' behind the takeover last month of the Manila Hotel remain active, and there are ''high risks'' of another, perhaps more serious, incident when President Corazon C. Aquino leaves this month for Indonesia and next month for the United States, according to the findings of a Government investigation.

title: Attorney General Meese Is Not a Foe of the Bill of Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: UNITED HEALTHCARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After tax credits of $520,000 for the quarter and $920,000 for the 6 months. The year-ago results restated to reflect acquisitions.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL CHICAGO (AL) - Signed George Foster, free-agent outfielder who was released by the Mets Aug. 6. Optioned Steve Lyons, outfielder-third baseman, to Buffalo of the American Association.

title: CHANCELLOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TEXAS UTILITIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Boy Held in Slaying Released to Parents
description: A 12-year-old charged in the Aug. 8 stabbing death of a Brooklyn youth has been released into his parents' custody pending a Sept. 2 court appearance, authorities said yesterday.

title: FOES OF NEW PORTS FOR NAVY DROP AMENDMENT IN HOUSE
description: House opponents of the Navy's plan to build new ports around the country today withdrew an amendment to block the use of $54.5 million for the plan.

title: FOX PHOTO reports earnings for Qtr to July 26
Bell Companies Cleared To Go Outside Regions
description: The regional telephone companies formed in the breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company can provide specialized telephone services outside their geographic regions without getting special permission, the United States Court of Appeals ruled today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I think we need stiffer, sterner punishment - this is not Draconian.

title: RELIANCE TO GET BLAIR
description: The tough four-month-old battle for John Blair & Company ended unexpectedly late yesterday when a Federal appeals court decision in favor of the Reliance Capital Group L.P. removed the final obstacle to its takeover of the media group.

title: UNITED FIRE & CASUALTY CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After capital gains of $254,306 for the quarter and $523,415 for the 6 months and a tax credit of $122,069 for the quarter and 6 months. c-After capital gains of $428,147 for the quarter and $696,915 for the 6 months. The share earnings restated for 3-for-2 stock split in March.

title: Becker Gains Canada Semifinal
description: Boris Becker of West Germany, the only survivor among the top seeded players, advanced to the semifinals of the Canadian Open today with a 6-4, 7-6 victory over Bud Schultz of the United States.

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary on July 25 about Dr. Fritz Albert Lipmann, a biochemist who isolated a substance vital to human metabolism, misstated the circumstances under which he made the discovery. He carried out the research at Massachusetts General Hospital.

title: FIRES IN THE WEST START TO DIE DOWN
description: Wildfires touched off by lightning that destroyed millions of dollars of dry timber and rangeland across the West dwindled yesterday to 44,000 acres in Oregon and Idaho.

title: Slow Night at Track
description: It is a well-established fact that a fast human can outrace a slow horse, at least if the human is unfettered and the horse is forced to pull a sulky and driver, and the distance isn't much more than a 100-yard dash.

title: Lehrman Weighing Senate Bid
description: Lewis E. Lehrman, the wealthy businessman who challenged Mario M. Cuomo for the governorship of New York in 1982, said today that he is ''seriously considering'' challenging Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan in 1988. Mr. Lehrman, a Republican, said that in his work here as chairman of Citizens for America, a foundation that supports President Reagan's policies, he had developed ''important economic and national security programs,'' which, he said, might best be presented through a Senate race.

title: Raising the Taxi Fare Is No Solution
description: The new chairman of New York City's Taxi and Limousine Commission, Gorman Gilbert, says that a fare increase might be necessary if a recent estimate that taxi drivers working 40 hours a week earn only $13,000 annually proves correct. But whether or not the figure is accurate, a fare hike wouldn't help most drivers and would only divert attention from the industry's fundamental problem: the medallion system.

title: More Firepower
description: The Rangers, who had the second worst record in the National Hockey League in goals scored last season, have been looking for some sharp-shooting potential, and yesterday they found it. They signed Mike Donnelly, the left wing who set a single-season scoring record at Michigan State with 59 goals in 44 games last season.

title: Security and All the President's Employees
description: The White House has always posed a special dilemma for the officials who are responsible for protecting the President and his family.

title: About That Confusion on the Botha Speech
description: In his news conference Tuesday night, President Reagan endorsed a call for Western nations to meet with South African officials to seek to ''bring along an end to apartheid.'' He said such a meeting had been proposed that day in a speech by Prime Minister P. W. Botha of South Africa.

title: PENNSYLVANIA ENGINEERING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After extraordinary charges of $240,000 for the quarter and $514,000 for the 6 months. c-After extraordinary charges of $205,000 for the quarter and $473,000 for the 6 months.

title: YANKEES DEFEAT ROYALS
description: Honest Brian Fisher was not always so honest. When the manager would come out to the mound in a crisis and ask him how he felt, Fisher would answer as so many pitchers do, quite automatically, ''Oh fine, just fine.''

title: CAREERCOM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Lincoln Fails the Test
description: Abraham Lincoln is in trouble. ''Positive,'' the Director of the Federal Bureau of Urinalysis has just told him.

title: Advancing Into the Ice Age
description: On a sweltering day last week, I sought comfort at a neighborhood eatery, where I ordered a large iced tea. What I got was a glass of slush, for the tea had been poured over shaved ice. But even worse, the tiny fragments melted so fast that all of the fun was taken away.

title: Paterson Election Voided by Judge
description: A Superior Court judge has ruled that a City Council election in May was invalid because of voting irregularities.

title: Japan Report On Economy
description: The growth rate of Japan's exports began to slow in 1985 but the nation's trade surplus has continued to mount in dollars because of the yen's rise against the American currency, according to an annual report on the Japanese economy.

title: NEW GOLF FORMAT GETS MIXED NOTICES
description: It was Candor Hour today on the second round - and third day - of The International, a new PGA Tour event based on point scoring. The reflections of professional golfers, famous and not so, revealed some of the frailties of the Stableford system, particularly as it has been spiced up for television.

title: NEW UNREST HITS PARTS OF PAKISTAN
description: Scattered anti-Government protests and clashes with the police erupted in Karachi and parts of rural southern Pakistan today. The reports of new unrest came as opposition leaders vowed to mount a major agitation demanding the release of the opposition leader Benazir Bhutto and hundreds of others arrested this week.

title: OKLAHOMA BANK GIVEN $130 MILLION
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation announced today that it had provided $130 million of emergency aid for the Bank of Oklahoma in Oklahoma City to keep the $600 million institution from failing.

title: Jazzing Around Wins at Saratoga
description: Jazzing Around, perhaps the fastest 2-year-old to emerge from the New York breeding program, scored a runaway 9 1/2-length victory over Brothers in Law in the $71,200 Empire Stakes today at Saratoga race track.

title: JETS MOVING HAIGHT TO GUARD
description: Mike Haight wolfed down a hastily piled club sandwich at noon today and, showing no effects from his injured knee, said, ''Gotta run. Gonna meet my wife for a few minutes.''

title: FORECASTS DELAYED TAX PACT
description: This morning's apparent agreement on tax revision followed weeks of grueling negotiations and tough concessions making up a compromise that was snagged Thursday night not because of specific tax issues, but because of new estimates of Government revenues, diminished by revised forecasts of a weakening economy.

title: INDUSTRIAL OUTPUT FELL 0.1% IN JULY
description: Output at the nation's factories, mines and utilities declined in July for the third consecutive month, underscoring the continued weakness in the industrial sectors of the economy but providing few new clues about whether the economy as a whole is headed for a rebound or a recession in the months ahead.

title: Students Who Are Athletically Gifted
description: To the Editor:

title: HERITAGE ENTERTAINMENT YEAR reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
L.I. TOURNAMENT KEEPING McENROE
description: In most instances, John McEnroe would rather play in the Hamlet Cup Invitational in Jericho, L.I., the week before the United States Open instead of entering a grand prix event such as the one being held in Cincinnati next week.

title: CARDS TOP METS WITH 3 IN 10TH
description: At the start, the St. Louis Cardinals fielded a team that had hit a combined total of six home runs so far this year. They had a 36-year-old pitcher on the mound. They were trying to revive after four months of groping for the offense that won the National League pennant last year, and they were doing it against the team with the best record in baseball.

title: Carnegie Radio Drive
description: Marilyn Horne, Yo-Yo Ma and Yehudi Menuhin will be among those interviewed on Sept. 14 on WNCN-FM (104.3) as part of Carnegie-Thon, a daylong radio subscription drive for the concert hall. Subscribers will be able to order their tickets for the upcoming season, while listening to a variety of music and interviews. There will also be premiums for subscribers and a raffle. The drive begins at 3 P.M. and lasts till 11 P.M.

title: REVCO D.S. BOARD ACCEPTS $38.50 BID
description: Revco D.S. Inc. said today that its board had accepted an investor group's sweetened offer of $38.50 a share in cash, or $1.29 billion, to buy the drug-store chain.

title: UNIVERSAL HOLDING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss The loss in the latest 6 months was primarily attributable to a one-time charge of $716,000 in the 1986 first quarter related to a contractual obligation to the recently deceased former chairman of the company.

title: Shultz Stops in Haiti To Show U.S. Support
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz visited Haiti briefly today in what he said was an effort to underscore the United States' support for Haiti's transition to democracy.

title:
PATENTS;
Flowmeter Measures All Liquids and Gases
description: Thomas J. Scarpa, who operates the Edinboro Computer Instruments Corporation in Edinboro, Pa., received a patent this week for a flowmeter, which he describes as having no moving parts and is suitable for measuring all types of liquids and gases, including steam.

title: DEL-VAL FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NEXT YEAR'S BATHING SUITS: ADDED COVER
description: As next year's beach clothes made their debut in New York, it was the skirted styles with a young look that caused the most talk. The Gottex swimsuit fashion show opened with a bevy of models wearing short red terry cloth beach coats belted in black patent. The coats flared out like skating skirts as the models twirled around the stage and the audience at the Parsons School of Design broke into applause.

title: SENATE ROLL-CALL ON SANCTIONS
description: Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate voted tonight for a package of economic sanctions against South Africa: FOR SANCTIONS - 84 Democrats - 47 Baucus, Mont. Bentsen, Tex. Biden, Del. Bingaman, N.M. Boren, Okla.

title: WEDCO TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $37,805.

title: CUOMO ASKING FOR SENTENCES OF UP TO LIFE FOR CRACK SELLERS
description: Governor Cuomo is proposing legislation under which anyone convicted of selling a small amount of crack - a minimum of three vials, or about $50 worth - could be sentenced to up to life in prison.

title: AMERICAN MEDICAL BUILDING INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: U.S. HEALTH AIDE ADMITS MISTAKE IN TESTIMONY ON KIDNEY DIALYSIS
description: A senior Federal health official says he gave inaccurate and misleading testimony when he assured Congress there was no evidence of any health hazard in the re-use of kidney dialysis devices.

title: TENNECO DEAL SET
description: Tenneco Inc. said it had reached a definitive agreement for the previously announced sale of its insurance operations to the ICH Corporation for $1.36 billion. Tenneco said it expected the transaction, which is subject to regulatory approval and certain other conditions, to be completed by year-end.

title: DENNING MOBILE ROBOTICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company is a development stage firm and did not report anyrevenue.

title:
PATENTS;
Laser Power Increased With Radiation Energy
description: The power output of certain lasers can be increased by 50 percent or more by the injection of radiation energy, according to a patent granted this week to Dr. J. Gary Eden, professor of electrical engineering at the University of Illinois in Urbana, and two students, Andrew W. McCown and David G. Geohagen.

title: LONGVIEW FIBRE CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Sperry Sought Honeywell
description: During its fight earlier this year to remain independent, the Sperry Corporation offered to acquire its rival, the Honeywell Corporation, one of the nation's largest computer makers, for $105 a share, or nearly $5 billion.

title: Bipartisanship Cannot Legitimize Contra Aid
description: To the Editor:

title: 450 Silent Roommates
description: Jonathan Green never dusts.

title: U.S. SAYS RADON GAS IS STATES' FIGHT
description: The Environmental Protection Agency said today that state governments would have to bear the primary financial responsibility for helping homeowners meet the safety standards on the hazardous gas radon that the agency set Thursday.

title: Paul Henshaw, Ex-President Of the Homestake Mining Co.
description: Paul C. Henshaw, former president and chairman of the Homestake Mining Company, died Tuesday.

title: MAY PETROLEUM INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After writedowns of oil and gas properties of $10.2 million for the quarter and $12 million for the 6 months.

title: 4 Found Innocent In Pledge Hazing
description: Four fraternity brothers have been acquitted of hazing a pledge whose feet became frostbitten when beer was poured on them and they were held out a car window.

title: DEMOCRATIC LOSER IS RULED ALABAMA RUNOFF'S WINNER
description: The Alabama Democratic Party today gave its nomination for Governor to the candidate who lost the party's runoff election in June, ruling that his opponent had won with illegal ballots cast by Republicans.

title: SOME BANKS LOWER CREDIT-CARD INTEREST
description: A list of 50 banks and savings institutions that have reduced the interest rates they charge credit-card customers has been released by Representative Charles E. Schumer, a member of the House Banking Committee.

title: U.S. Ideological Test For Asylum Seekers
description: To the Editor:

title: A Damaged Soviet Satellite May Make Striking Re-entry
description: A damaged Soviet satellite is expected to return to Earth Saturday, promising to make a ''spectacular re-entry'' as it breaks up in the atmosphere, space experts said today.

title: Article 589786 -- No Title
description: The House today approved a five-year $90 billion program for highways and mass transit after reversing itself and reviving the Los Angeles Metro Rail subway.

title: REUTER INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Helen Mack, 72, an Actress In Silent and Talking Movies
description: Helen Mack, a child actress who appeared in both silent and talking motion pictures as well as on the stage, died of cancer Wednesday at the home a friend, Aleen Leslie, with whom she lived in Beverly Hills, Calif. She was 72 years old.

title: 7th TV Outlet For Murdoch
description: As part of his effort to build a fourth television network, Rupert Murdoch has agreed to buy WXNE-TV, an independent station in Boston. Terms were not disclosed yesterday, but people familiar with the negotiations said the price is about $28 million.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, AUGUST 16, 1986
description: The Economy

title: Triton Sets Deal For Worldwide
description: The Triton Energy Corporation has agreed to acquire the Worldwide Energy Corporation for $30 million in stock and the assumption of $60 million of Worldwide's long-term debt. A Triton spokesman said the merger would provide 25 million barrels of oil reserves in North America at a price of less than $4 a barrel.

title: Article 482886 -- No Title
description: The Boeing Company said today that British Airways had placed what could become the largest order ever for new planes.

title: James A. Lovkay Wed To Catherine A. Wales
description: At Trinity Episcopal Church in Southport, Conn., yesterday Catherine Anne Wales, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gwynne H. Wales of Greenwich, Conn., was married to James Andrew Lovkay, the son of Carole Puglesi and John Lovkay, both of Hartford. The Rev. Stephen J. Chindlund performed the ceremony.

title: HMG PROPERTY INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ENSOURCE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes writedowns of $7,200,000 for the quarter and $14,700,000 for the 6 months on the value of oil and gas properties. c-Net income and after a pre-tax charge of $1,413,000 representing settlement of arbitration and litigation for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASKETBALL COCA-COLA N.B.A. PRO-AM SUMMER LEAGUE CHAMPIONSHIP, at Nat Holman Gym, City College, 138th Street and Convent Avenue, Manhattan, 3 P.M. Consolation game 1 P.M. STROH'S RUCKER ALL-STAR CLASSIC, at Holcombe Rucker Memorial Playground, 155th Street and Frederick Douglass Boulevard. Playoffs 3:30 and 5:30 P.M.

title: A Dying Man's Warning
description: One of his best friends, Ken McFeeley, a police officer, is dying of lung cancer.

title: BELIEVABILITY OF BOTNICK AS WITNESS QUESTIONED
description: Victor E. Botnick, a former top aide to Mayor Koch, was not called to testify in the bribery trial of John J. McLaughlin because of questions about his credibility that investigators uncovered, according to a statement by a prosecutor at the trial.

title: LYNDEN INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: CHARTER-CRELLIN INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GREENERY REHABILITATION GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in July.

title: UNIFAST INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
A DRUG AGENT FOR 8 YEARS
description: Victor Cortez Jr., who is said to have been detained, beaten and tortured by the Mexican police, has been a special agent of the Drug Enforcement Administration since March 1978.

title: MISCHER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: 1. Despite scientific tests, the authenticity of the larger-than-life-size marble sculpture of a youth, regarded by many experts as one of the most important works of art to have entered the United States since World War II, has yet to be fully established. 2. Sri Lanka. West Germany. 3. False. 4. In 1970 the Democratic-controlled Senate rejected one of President Nixon's Supreme Court nominees, G. Harold Carswell. Such a defeat is unlikely in this instance because the Republicans now control the Senate and the Judiciary Committee's 10 Republicans voted unanimously to recommend confirmation. 5. Toronto. 6. According to East German officials, the militiamen who guarded the initial barrier, a barbed wire fence, had not even been given live ammunition for their rifles. The wall was put up to stem a growing exodus of East Germans to the West. 7. Mr. Rose was vindicated because in saying that Mr. Rose was ''of good moral and professional character,'' Chief Justice Warren E. Burger reversed an opinion he expressed four years ago in a dissent from the lawyer's first admission to the Supreme Court Bar. 8. New York. 9. Until the discovery of the fossil bones of the Protoavis, recently dug out of 225-million-year-old mudstone, the 150-million-year-old Archaeopteryx had been considered the world's oldest known bird. 10. A desk computer. 11. Doubleday & Company. The New York Mets. 12. Mrs. Castelo, Nancy Reagan's personal maid, was arraigned on charges of helping to illegally export munitions to Paraguay, where the naturalized United States citizen was born. 13.

title: The New Age of Vaccines
description: Vaccines have not changed greatly, at least in concept, since Edward Jenner learned how to protect against smallpox in 1796. Injecting a killed or weakened virus perks up the body's immune system for future defense against the live carrier of disease - but with the risk of occasionally harming the recipient. Now a quite novel method gives hope of averting that risk and creating vaccines against hitherto unattacked diseases. The technique's debut is signaled by the Food and Drug Administration's recent approval of a vaccine against the often fatal hepatitis B virus.

title: GREEN MOUNTAIN POWER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MYSTERY SHROUDS EFFORT TO DEPORT JAPANESE INSTRUCTOR LIVING ON L.I.
description: Last month, Choichiro Yatani, a Japanese citizen who for the last nine years has lived quietly in the United States as a student and a teacher, returned from an academic conference in the Netherlands.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from Washington Wednesday about a study of mortality rates at Veterans Administration hospitals misstated the status of the hospital in Providence, R.I. As the accompanying chart correctly noted, 6.8 percent of its patients who underwent major surgery died. The hospitals with the lowest rates were in Saginaw, Mich., with 2.3 percent mortality, and Reno, with 2.6 percent.

title: Bond Prices Narrowly Mixed
description: Government bond prices meandered within a narrow range yesterday, with the shorter maturities showing an upward bias and the longer end of the market essentially unchanged on the day. Treasury bill rates were slightly lower, as the Federal Reserve continued its accommodative credit posture.

title: STATE U. AT BUFFALO GETS NATIONAL QUAKE CENTER
description: A $50 million national center for earthquake research will be established at the State University of New York at Buffalo, the university announced yesterday.

title: D O C OPTICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
600 IN A SOUTH AFRICAN PRISON SAID TO BE ON HUNGER STRIKE
description: Six hundred political detainees were reported today to have gone on a hunger strike to protest South Africa's emergency decree. The authorities denied the report.

title: IPCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
A Time to Do More Than Hail the Constitution
description: To the Editor:

title: DIXON TICONDEROGA CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $205,427. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $295,584 for the quarter and $337,641 for the 9 months.

title: And the Winner Is . . .
description: The National Republican Congressional Committee has awarded a free trip anywhere in the world to a retired Arkansas couple in a lottery designed as a publicity gimmick to discredit Representative Bill Alexander, the Democrat who is seeking election to a 10th term in Arkansas' First Congressional District. The stunt backfired a bit, however, inasmuch as the winners turned out to be staunch Alexander supporters.

title: Awaiting a Blockbuster From Leningrad
description: It is a confusing moment at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: STUDENT HELD IN COLLEGE SHOOTINGS IS TO UNDERGO PSYCHIATRIC EXAMS
description: The student accused of shooting five people, one fatally, on the campus of New York City Technical College on Tuesday is to undergo a series of psychiatric examinations next week while his lawyer prepares a defense that may include a insanity plea.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 46. 1. This is a 2,500-year-old Greek statue with a mysterious past. Explain. 2. Although the 152 refugees found drifting in two lifeboats off the coast of Newfoundland said they were members of a predominantly Hindu minority group and had left an island nation where Buddhists are dominant, there were reports that the group had actually embarked from another country.
