Identify the island nation and the country. 3. Food products that are labeled ''lite'' must have fewer calories than their regular counterparts, according to Federal regulations. True or false? 4. By a 13-to-5 vote, the Senate Judiciary Committee recommended that the full Senate confirm Justice Willliam H. Renquist as Chief Justice of the United States. In 1970 the Senate rejected the Judiciary Committee's recommendation of a Supreme Court nominee. Why is it unlikely that such a recommendation would be defeated in this instance? 5. With its partnerships, its old money and its easy arrogance, Bay Street, the hub of a foreign securities industry, is reminiscent of Wall Street a decade or two ago. Where is Bay Street? 6. The Berlin wall appears to have been erected 25 years ago largely as a bluff. On what is that opinion based, and why was the wall built? 7. The Supreme Court unanimously granted Michael T. Rose, a Denver lawyer, permission to practice before its bar. Why is that noteworthy? 8.

title: 3 Engineers Settle Case Against Federal Utility
description: The Tennessee Valley Authority has reached an agreement with three engineers who said they had been harassed for disclosing safety problems, a spokesman for the Federal utility said Thursday.

title: ZEUS COMPONENTS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SKYWEST INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
RECALL FOR TOY HELICOPTER
description: The Consumer Product Safety Commission has announced that a toy flying helicopter caused serious eye injuries to at least 15 people and is being recalled voluntarily by one of its distributors.

title: INDEPENDENCE HOLDINGS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a realized loss of $432,000 for the quarter and a realized gain of $2,520,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes realized gains of $1,512,000 and $1,632,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: BOLT TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a charge of $5,758,000 from a writedown of assets.

title: Boy Killed in Sinking Of a Boat off Queens
description: A 7-year-old Queens boy out on a boat ride with members of his family died last night after their power boat was struck by a large wave and sank just east of the Throgs Neck Bridge, the authorities reported.

title: KARPOV RUNS OUT OF TIME AND FORFEITS IN 8TH GAME
description: Gary Kasparov won the eighth game in his defense of the world chess championship today when Anatoly Karpov ran out of time with 10 moves to make. Kasparov now leads, 4 1/2-3 1/2.

title: SNYDER OIL PARTNERS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Reflects writedowns of oil and gas properties of $11.5 million for the quarter and $44.5 million for the 6 months. c-Net income

title: Patricia A. McDonnell Wed to Mark S. Clifton
description: Patricia Augusta McDonnell, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert McDonnell of Hamden, Conn., was married yesterday to Mark Sterling Clifton, the son of Mrs. Norman E. Clifton of Madison, Conn., and the late Mr. Clifton. The Rev. John G. Macort performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church-on-the-Green in New Haven.

title: OCEANEERING INERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BEHIND THE SCENES IN TAX BILL DRAMA
description: From the start, the sweeping overhaul of the nation's tax code was high legislative drama.

title: CORRECTION
description: A table in Business Day yesterday with an article on the four-year-old upturn on Wall Street inadequately described some of the figures given for the stock performance of A.T.&T. The 138.08 percent increase in stock values from the start of the bull market until the market hit its peak in July represented not just A.T.&T., but also the seven regional telephone companies spun off in 1984.

title: NRM ENERGY CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The latest quarter and 6 months include a $7.8 million writedown of oil and gas assets.

title: PRICE NASA WILL PAY FOR 4th ORBITER
description: With President Reagan's decision to build an orbiter to replace the destroyed Challenger, the space agency appears to have won a major victory as it struggles to recover from the largest disaster in the history of space exploration.

title: 52 Are Reported Killed In Honduran Air Crash
description: The wreckage of a Honduran military transport plane that was carrying 52 people was found today in eastern Honduras, officials said. The military said there were no survivors.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Broadway column in Weekend yesterday about Peggy Hewett gave an incorrect title for William Finn's new musical featuring a tap-dancing Eleanor Roosevelt. It is ''Famous Moms of History.''

title: CONNER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Turkish Planes Bomb Kurdish Rebels in Iraq
description: Ten Turkish warplanes crossed into Iraq today and bombed three hideouts sheltering about 100 Kurdish rebels, Prime Minister Turgut Ozal said.

title: SYNTECH INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $90,000 for the quarter and $95,000 for the 6 months and tax credits of $199,000 and $315,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $801,000 for the quarter and $1,466,000 for the 6 months. Preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income in all periods but the latest second quarter.

title: CITY OFFERS AID TO BUILD HOUSES STALLED IN BRONX
description: The city has offered $694,000 to the developer of the Croton-Mapes houses in the Bronx to permit him to complete the Crotona Park section project, a housing official said yesterday.

title: BENEFITS OF CONTAINER-GROWN PLANTS
description: WHILE container-grown plants have their drawbacks, their benefits to both nurserymen and consumers far offset their deficiencies. However, attention to the potential problems will provide greater assurance of success.

title: Miss Brown To Be Wed
description: Announcement has been made by William O. Brown and Nancy Bayard, both of Houston, of the engagement of their daughter Nancy Havilande Brown to James H. Whitcomb Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Whitcomb of New Canaan, Conn. The wedding is planned for October.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Omaha; Old Skyscraper Is Transformed
description: AS the population of this old railroad crossroads moved West in the 1960's and 70's, the downtown hotels, department stores and many offices followed, leaving old and handsome but vacant buildings behind. Over the past few years, the city has been encouraging developers to transform them into apartments and create a new residential area.

title: CARTER INJURED, OUT FOR 15 DAYS
description: The Mets' storybook season took a jolt yesterday when Gary Carter, their All-Star catcher, went on the disabled list for 15 days after he suffered a partial tear of the outer ligament in his left thumb while playing first base against the St. Louis Cardinals.

title:
MINOR LEAGUE '86: ROCKY BRIDGES;
Light Touch for Baseball Teacher
description: BOTH teams had been warned against throwing at opposing batters when Brett Gideon, a reliever for the Prince William Pirates, decided to move a Peninsula White Sox batter back from the plate on an 0-2 pitch. But the pitch nicked the hitter's jersey, prompting the home-plate umpire, Jose Morales, to eject a disbelieving Gideon from the game.

title: AT A DACHA OUTSIDE MOSCOW,DIPLOMACY IN HUSHED TONES
description: THE sight of Richard N. Perle, an Assistant Secretary of Defense and implacable critic of the Kremlin, huddling with Soviet officials outside Moscow last week spoke eloquently of the improved but still uncertain prospects for a meeting this year between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: CHARACTER TRAITS
description: EDWARD W. HAYES becomes expansive when he talks about his custom-fitted suede-and-crocodile shoes.

title: PLAYING THE ODDS
description: The recent Summer National Championships in Toronto gave Canada a world record: The biggest tournament ever played anywhere. In ten days the total table count was 21,075, eclipsing by 1,258 the record set a year ago in Las Vegas. The peak was a session in which 4,756 players took part.

title: DEMOCRATS IN PRIMARY PRESS DRIVE FOR CONGRESS
description: FOUR Democratic candidates for the 20th Congressional District seat held by Representative Joseph DioGuardi, a freshman Republican-Conservative, begin their final campaign efforts this week with less than a month to go before the Sept. 9 primary.

title: NATIONAL GALLERY TO EXHIBIT RENAISSANCE SCULPTURE
description: During the Renaissance, fine sculptors, many whose names will never be known, created smaller versions of classical pieces, and for a time their work enjoyed a vogue.

title: Melpo Maria Voulieris Is Wed to Warner A. Fite
description: Melpo Maria Voulieris, the daughter of Madeline Voulieris of New York and Dimitrios Voulieris of Clearwater, Fla., was married yesterday to Warner Alderson Fite, a son of Constance A. Fite of New York and the late Dr. Warner Fite. The Greek Orthodox Church of the Annunciation in New York was the setting for the ceremony performed by the Rev. Arthur Pappas.

title: OGYGIAN SCRATCHED
description: Wise Times, the little colt who charged from far back to score an upset on a sloppy track in the Haskell Handicap three weeks ago, proved that it was no fluke today. In a virtual rerun, he looped the field and splashed to the wire to win the $294,500 Travers Stakes by a head at Saratoga Race Track.

title: IN CHINA, A NEW PASTIME, THOUGH NOT QUITE NATIONAL
description: THE North China air was a cool 55 degrees and the silver poplar trees were budding. A slight breeze puffed swirls of dust up from the athletic field. The players were already warming up, woolen winter underwear peeping out from under the cuffs of their baggy pants. Their movements were awkward and a constant laughter belied their nervousness.

title: JAZZ: PAT MARTINO PERFORMS IN A TRIO
description: AFTER a few years of illness and recovery, the guitarist Pat Martino has returned to performing with one of jazz's most individualistic styles intact. He brought a trio to Fat Tuesday's for two nights, and in his closing set on Wednesday he was quietly dazzling.

title: Paging Rambo
description: Robert Schwab 3d, a 44-year-old Vietnam veteran, said he sneaked back to Southeast Asia in a small boat last year to bring out a woman he left behind in 1975, a feat that would have represented ''something no American ever had in Vietnam - victory.'' Released last week from a Vietnamese prison where he spent the last 16 months, Mr. Schwab said the adventure ''really was a failure.''

title: CARE FOR YOUNG HEART PATIENTS
description: AMID crib toys, teddy bears and some of medicine's most sophisticated equipment, children - from infants to teen-agers - are recuperating from heart surgery in the new pediatric cardiac surgical intensive-care unit at Children's Hospital of New Jersey here.

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: THE Mall at Mill Creek, part of Hartz Mountain Industries' office and town-house community, Harmon Meadow in Secaucus, will open Aug. 30. It is 85 percent leased.

title: Kerry Bryan, Actress, Wed To a Teacher
description: The marriage of Kerry Lamb Bryan, a daughter of the Venerable and Mrs. Robert Bryan of Ipswich, Mass., and Harrington Harbour, Quebec, to Bayard Field Brokaw, a son of Edwina Shea Millington of Greenwich, Conn., and the late William Vail Brokaw, took place yesterday at the Ascension Memorial Episcopal Church in Ipswich. The Rev. Charles Clark, headmaster of St. Paul's School in Concord, N.H., performed the ceremony.

title: 121-STORY OFFICE TOWER PROPOSED FOR NEWARK
description: When Harry Grant dreams, he dreams big.

title: 3 STATES TIGHTER LIMITS ON EMISSIONS FROM INCINERATORS
description: Three states and an environmental group have asked the Federal Government to adopt new rules governing the emissions of municipal incinerators, saying they are a significant source of air pollution.

title: AN UNRULY TAXI INDUSTRY IS HAILING HIGHER FARES
description: THE question these days for New York City's taxicab owners and drivers is not whether it should cost more to take a cab, but how much more. Representatives of the industry plan to request at a Taxi and Limousine Commission hearing this week a fare hike ranging from 20 to 40 percent.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: TRASH REMINDERS IN PHILADELPHIA

title: TURNING THE PC INTO A LANDLORD
description: ''MULTITASKING,'' ''networking,'' ''integrated windows,'' and a few other buzzwords extol the ability to run a number of different software packages in the course of a single job. The fact remains, however, that most people by far use primarily a single software package, typically a word processor, a data base manager or a spreadsheet.

title: DORY LOVES JOHN, JOHN GOES TO CALIFORNIA
description: THE MOON PINNACE By Thomas Williams. 374 pp. New York: Doubleday & Company. $17.95.

title: THE CONVOLUTED PATH OF THE CITY BENCH
description: THE question of who shall control the appointment of judges runs through New York's political history like a soap opera; the characters and immediate concerns change, but the issue itself goes on and on. So it was only another twist in the plot last week when Governor Cuomo and New York's chief judge, Sol Wachtler, proposed a convoluted solution to the caseload crisis in New York City's Criminal Court, a long-running problem that has been aggravated by a sharp increase in drug arrests, particularly involving the cocaine-derivative crack. Judge Wachtler said drug arrests in the city had increased about 50 percent over last year.

title: Article 809286 -- No Title
description: THE State Department on Aging has awarded a newly formed group called the Center for Medicare Advocacy a $90,000 grant to start a program that will help elderly people hold onto their homes longer.

title: PLEASANT SURPRISES FROM LESSER-KNOWN COMPOSERS
description: The joys of the unfamiliar are seldom so gratifying as when one discovers that a composer who has been assigned second-string status turns out to have written a superior work. And when two such experiences occur during an investigation of 20th-century music, it indeed a delight. In this case, both composers are French. The music of Joseph Guy Ropartz (1864-1955) is hardly known, even in his native land. Nothing in the handful of piano pieces occasionally heard hereabout prepares one for the impact of his Third Symphony, an hour-long musical fresco for vocal soloists, chorus and orchestra, composed in 1905 (Pathe Marconi 2703481, LP only).

title: STATE EASING RULES ON CLAMS
description: THE Department of Environmental Protection is drafting regulations that would make it easier to build docks near waters suitable for clamming.

title: LUNCHES THAT PLEASE THE EYE, TOO
description: WHERE can you go for a good but inexpensive lunch? If you are in Darien, the answer is easy: The Gourmet Table.

title: CORPORATE AMERICA BUYS ITSELF BACK
description: ONCE the ITT Corporation had decided to sell part of its telecommunications business to a French company, Rand V. Araskog, ITT's chairman, made an announcement that says a great deal about corporate America's current priorities. Mr. Araskog told securities analysts early this month that his board of directors would consider using the $1.5 billion from the sale to reduce the company's debt or to make a small acquisition. But, he added, stock repurchases are ''very much on the minds of the directors,'' and ITT could proceed with a ''consequential program.''

title: MANILA PROTESTS U.S. WARNING ON SAFETY OF AIRPORT
description: The manager of the Manila airport has asked the United States Federal Aviation Administration to carry out a new inspection and has requested a withdrawal of a Transportation Department warning that security measures at the airport are inadequate.

title: INDULGING IN THE DESSERTS OF THE CONCERT STAGE
description: Performers and listeners alike think of the encore as a delicious treat. Isaac Stern calls it a chocolate souffle, Carol Wincenc a wonderful little aftertaste, Misha Dichter a bonbon, Phyllis Curtin a real dessert.

title: BARRAQUE WORK TO BE GIVEN HERE
description: The late French composer Jean Barraque discovered Hermann Broch's book ''The Death Of Virgil'' in 1955 and, effectively, consecrated the remaining 18 years of his life to it. Barraque, an avant-garde composer who, like Pierre Boulez and Karlheinz Stockhausen, studied with Olivier Messiaen, had produced a few works prior to his encounter with Broch - notably a piano sonata, an early electronic work, and ''Sequence'' for soprano and chamber ensemble - but the remainder of his compositions, with the exception of an instrumental concerto written in 1968, were all inspired by ''The Death Of Virgil.''

title: COCAINE'S VICIOUS SPIRAL: HIGHS, LOWS, DESPERATION
description: TIME was when people were surprised by the confessions of entertainers or businessmen who, after months or years of using cocaine, craved it so much that they lost their jobs and families in its pursuit. After all, many experts had said the drug was not physically addictive. The recent rise in the popularity of crack, a potent form of cocaine that is smoked rather than sniffed, has produced even more startling tales. Some users say they became slaves to crack in just days or weeks.

title: Marc Schlossman Wed To Janine DiGiovanni
description: Janine DiGiovanni, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent L. DiGiovanni of Tinton Falls, N.J., was married yesterday to Marc Schlossman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Schlossman of Winnetka, Ill., and Lake Geneva, Wis. Msgr. Alfred Smith performed the ceremony at St. Rose Roman Catholic Church in Belmar, N.J.

title: Q and A
description: Town-House Insurance Question: I own and occupy a two-family townhouse in Greenwich Village and I have been unable to get the amount of homeowner's insurance coverage that I feel reflects the high replacement costs in Manhattan. According to the contractor who has worked on the building, it would cost $800,000 to replace the house, including the custom interiors. But after on-site inspections from insurers, the maximum I can get is $250,000 on a coinsurance basis for a one-year policy. This policy would be the same as my previous policy but will now cost 300 percent more. Can you explain this situation and suggest a consumer organization that would be able to advise me about shopping for real-estate insurance? . . . B. W., Manhattan

title: Elizabeth Abell Is Bride of Matthew J. Harrington
description: Elizabeth Ann Abell, a daughter of Elizabeth Phelps Abell of Northfield, Ill., and David Robert Abell of Winnetka, Ill., was married yesterday to Matthew Jerome Harrington, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John M. Harrington Jr. of Winchester, Mass. The Rev. Dr. Nicholas Taylor, an Episcopal priest, and the Rev. John P. Poles, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at Christ Episcopal Church in Winnetka.

title: IMPORTING A LOWER STANDARD OF LIVING
description: AMERICANS fear for their economic future. Real incomes are declining. Mass firings of blue-collar and white-collar employees are common. Pension benefits are disappearing, as companies such as LTV, the huge steelmaker, fail. Parents are losing the expected security of their later years, and their are giving up the idea of living as well as their parents.

title: MELVILLE ASHORE
description: Unlike Ishmael of ''Moby Dick,'' Herman Melville spent most of his life on land. He was born and died in New York City. He spent his adolescence in Albany and nearby Lansingburgh, where he began writing. He passed his most creative years on his farm, Arrowhead, outside Pittsfield, Mass.

title: 'OLYMPIC' GAMES SEEN AS BALM FOR AIDS FEAR
description: For the past nine days 3,400 amateur athletes from 37 states and 16 foreign countries, most of them homosexuals, have been competing here in an Olympic-style sports event, Gay Games II.

title: PUTTING PERSPECTIVE ON A NIGHT'S EVENTS
description: IT was an ordinary Wednesday night in November. I had come home late from school, eaten a leisurely supper, and waited until almost 11 o'clock to begin reconciling my bank statement. Seated at the kitchen table, going over checks and columns of figures, I'd look up every so often at the darkened deck and the inky water lapping at my sea wall.

title: THE GHETTO AT THE TIBER'S EDGE
description: Rome's Jewish quarter provides an orderly, contained respite from the sprawling nonchalance that characterizes the rest of the city -as if the ghetto walls, pulled down a hundred years ago, still somehow regulated peoples' lives. In the streets, you might pass two men conversing animatedly in Italian; but if they're wearing yarmulkes, as many do, they're probably not meandering from cafe to cafe. They might be headed for the central synagogue, the Tempio Maggiore, the heart of Roman-Jewish life at the Tiber's edge, where rabbis keep the faith in Italian and Hebrew; to a meeting at the Bar Toto on Via del Portico d'Ottavia (which serves kosher coffee); or to the palm-ringed Piazza Giudia to collect a child playing there after Hebrew school. A quiet determination to maintain Jewish life - and life in general -comes with the territory. As one administrator of the synagogue says, ''We have always been here, and here we shall remain.''

title: NEW TROUSSEAU: MORE THAN LINENS
description: WHAT is a trousseau? The conventional answer is the collection of linens, intimate apparel and household goods a bride has accumulated over many years, or acquires in one big shopping spree right before the wedding.

title: IN WESTPORT, HELP FOR NEW YOUTHS
description: WHEN 16-year-old Michelle Karlbergs and her 13-year-old sister, Tracy, moved with their parents to Westport in late June, they knew no one in town. The daughters of a corporate executive, they have lived in five states, and each time they have moved, they started school without friends.

title:
THE REGION;
Lincoln Center Plan Approved
description: Though the opponents included civic organizations, elected officials, tenants' groups and the local community board, Lincoln Center's supporters said it had to have its 54-story tower, and last week New York City's Board of Estimate agreed.

title: AMERICAN CAN SELLING ITS CAMPUS
description: AMERICAN CAN COMPANY, which built the first corporate campus in Fairfield County, is selling its 625,000-square-foot headquarters in back-country Greenwich, Conn., for $170 million. It will take back a 10-year lease on 300,000 square feet for its own operations and provide rental supports for the remaining space for five years.

title: Wendy Robin Wheeler Weds Ian Stanley Reid
description: The marriage of Wendy Robin Wheeler, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm F. Wheeler of Darien, Conn., and Newport, R.I., to Ian Stanley Reid, took place yesterday at the Hampshire House in Boston. Justice of the Peace Richard J. George performed the ceremony.

title: Roy Cohn's Descent on the Libraries of Europe
description: To the Editor:

title: Deborah Trilling Engaged
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Lionel Trilling of Chappaqua, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Eve Trilling, to Leon M. Feder, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Josef Feder of Bronxville, N.Y. The future bride is a campaign professional with the United Jewish Appeal-Federation of Jewish Philanthropies in Manhattan. Mr. Feder is a programmer analyst for the Crossland Savings Bank in Brooklyn. A November wedding is planned.

title: SUFFOLK SEEKING NEW APPROACH TO LILCO
description: BLOCKED in a state court from promoting a $7.3 billion plan to take over the Long Island Lighting Company, officials in Suffolk County are looking at alternative ways to assure that the utility's Shoreham nuclear power plant never attains a Federal operating license.

title: KASPAROV, IN SECOND VICTORY, DISPLAY A DARING OFFENSIVE
description: Gary Kasparov's prominence as the foremost attacking player currently was confirmed by his tempestuous performance in winning the eighth game of his world championship defense against Anatoly Karpov in London on Friday.

title:
IN NEW JERSEY;
Olympia & York's Troubled Superproject
description: TWELVE years ago, Olympia & York of Toronto, one of the largest development companies in North America, acquired a 2,640-acre tract in the southern corner of Old Bridge, and since then it has been evolving an ambitious plan to turn the gently rolling terrain into a sleek modern city.

title: 5-Week Film Series
description: ''Short Takes,'' a five-week series devoted to innovative short films, will begin Sept. 23 at 6:30 P.M. at Symphony Space, Broadway and 95th Street.

title: Looking For a Mentor
description: I wonder how many other women turn to the About Men column for insights into their place in the social world and their relationships with others, both male and female (''A Mentor's Presence,'' by Howell Raines, July 20). After reading Howell Raines's article, I realized how much I've missed by failing to connect with a mentor.

title: Quisenberry Puzzled by Royals' Snub
description: First, the sponsor for whom he appears in a television commercial replaced his voice. Now the Kansas City Royals have replaced Dan Quisenberry's arm.

title: Saban Begins Again
description: He's been the head football coach at seven colleges and for three N.F.L. teams, and now, at age 64 and after a stint as a scout for the Yankees, Lou Saban, has decided to start all over at the bottom of the coaching ladder.

title: NEWSPAPER PROPERTIES, HOTTER THAN EVER
description: SEVERAL years ago, newspapers were viewed by some of their owners as the dinosaurs of the media industry. Cable television, the free shoppers and the new electronic information technologies seemed certain to siphon off readers and advertisers. Nervous publishers were eager to diversify. Today that attitude has changed. Videotex has flopped, cable TV has failed to become a major competitor for advertising, and publishers everywhere have gotten into shoppers, printing and delivering the ad-laden throwaways themselves. ''Newspaper companies are realizing that their basic business remains the most attractive of all reinvestment alternatives,'' says Joseph Fuchs, a media analyst at Kidder, Peabody.

title: OPEN'S TENNIS STARS TO COMPETE IN RYE
description: WESTCHESTER tennis fans, who bow to nobody in their enthusiasm for and appreciation of the sport, will be treated this week to a mini-preview of the United States Open championships.

title: SWEEPING TAX REVISION WINS KEY APPROVAL IN CONGRESS, SETS 28% TOP PERSONAL RATE
description: Congressional negotiators approved legislation tonight that would make monumental changes in the Federal income tax law affecting the finances of nearly every household and business in America.

title: Woman Slain in Great Neck Was Living in Nearby Village
description: A woman found dead in an alley off the main street of Great Neck, L.I., Friday morning has been identified as an Iranian who was living with a family in the nearby community of Kings Point, according to the Nassau County police.

title: ODE TO THE GENTIAN THAT WASN'T
description: WHOEVER in the home gardening world latched onto widely popularizing the cultivation of wildflowers deserves Mother Nature's gold medal.

title: Headliners; Amazing Grace
description: If, as Rear Adm. Grace Hopper contends, organizational growth requires ''a certain number of people who make themselves obnoxious,'' it might behoove the United States Navy to recruit several such folk to replace her.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''I am proud of the Congress and happy for the nation.''

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE WORLD'S HIEROGLYPHIC BEAUTY: Five American Poets. By Peter Stitt. (University of Georgia Press, $30.) Peter Stitt's argument in this book is admirably clear: Richard Wilbur, William Stafford, Louis Simpson, James Wright and Robert Penn Warren, the five contemporary poets he examines (all but James Wright are living), struggle in their poetry to link the physical world of everyday reality with the transcendental realm of the human soul and spirit.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
COOKING FOR DOLLARS
description: Jordan's Butterscotch Cookies. Veal Scaloppine With Mustard Sauce. ''It Must Be Sunday'' (waffles).

title: Tongue-in-Cheek Opinions
description: OFTEN, after I start telling someone of a big fish that didn't get away, or of how I faced death with equanimity at some disputed barricade, his eyes go out of focus, made so by boredom and disbelief.

title: FINALLY, LEGAL BETTING IN MISSOURI
description: State Senator Jim Mathewson wore a broad smile under his broad-brimmed hat as he put down $10 for a ticket on No. 6, Gullywhumper.

title: Bond Street
description: To the Editor: ''A Birthday for Bond Street'' by Donald Goddard (Travel, June 1) filled in all the gaps for me. Rarely has armchair travel been so rewarding.

title: COURTING A RESURGENCE IN THE PRICE SPIRAL
description: REPORTS of the death of inflation are greatly exaggerated.

title: AN EXCLAMATION MARK ALONG THE ROADSIDE
description: ''A photograph is not only an image (as a painting is an image), an interpretation of the real; it is also a trace, something directly stenciled off the real, like a footprint or a death mask.'' SUSAN SONTAG, ''ON PHOTOGRAPHY''

title: SEEKING THE FORMULA FOR HAPPY HENS
description: Are American chickens happy? Would happier hens lay more eggs? A team of avian scientists from Cornell University in Ithaca, N.Y., is trying to answer those questions in an effort to increase egg production and improve the living conditions of the nation's hens.

title: A DAUGHTER REMEMBERS HER FATHER'S SECRET 'INVISIBLE DRINKS'
description: IT seems almost impossible that five years have passed since my father died. I often think of him as being alive.

title: JOHN CUNNINGHAM: EVER-EMPLOYED ACTOR
description: WHATEVER happened to genuine stage actors and intelligent contemporary plays? The combination seems hard to find.

title: NEW CASSETTES: CLASSIC WESTERN, SINGULAR SONGSTER
description: FRANK ZAPPA: DOES HUMOR BELONG IN MUSIC?.MPI Home Video; 57 minutes.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, AUGUST 17, 1986
description: International Efforts to seal the Chernobyl reactor in a concrete tomb have been complicated by serious design difficulties and by inadequate supplies of concrete, according to Western diplomats and Soviet press reports. The key problem, according to these sources, is how to build a structure that will effectively entomb the still-warm reactor but not trap so much heat that a new fire or explosion could occur. [ Page 1, Column 1. ] A strategy that would constrain tests of space-based weapons by the United States and the Soviet Union for up to 10 years has been suggested by five former American policy makers. The former officials, who served in the Nixon, Ford and Carter Administrations, recommended that the United States follow what is called a ''restrictive'' interpretation of the 1972 treaty limiting antimissile defenses. They also said the United States should continue to abide by the numerical limits on long-range nuclear weapons in the unratified 1979 treaty on strategic arms. [ 1:5. ] National House and Senate negotiators struggled over the final details of legislation designed to make monumental changes in the Federal income tax system. The basic principles and elements were locked into place as the rest of Congress began the summer recess. But six of the 11 Senate conferees objected to one aspect or another of the package, and House members were holding out for more favorable treatment of middle-income taxpayers. [ 1:6. ] A self-sufficient path to space is abandoned as a goal of the space shuttle with President Reagan's order that NASA get out of the commercial launching business, aerospace experts said.

title: OFFICER SAYS HE DOES NOT RECALL KILLING WIFE
description: Looking pale and drawn, John Bruetsch mainly sits and stares at the defense table in Rockland County Court here as his trial on charges of murdering his wife, a fellow police officer, unfolds before him.

title: MONSTER CATCHES BRING FISH FEVER BACK TO MONTAUK
description: WORKERS at the Montauk Marine Basin see big fish hauled from the Atlantic Ocean almost every day. But even they have been impressed with this summer's bounty of trophies.

title: Peter E. Doering Weds Amy Lewis Of Law Magazine
description: Trinity Episcopal Church in Southport, Conn., yesterday Amy Thorne Lewis, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Pierson Lewis of Southport, was married to Peter Eckart Doering, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Eckart Doering of Riverside, Conn. The Rev. Stephen J. Chinlund performed the ceremony.

title: V.A., Under Fire, Will Close Some Heart Units
description: There is a saying in medicine: ''See one, do one, teach one.'' But in truth complicated procedures -heart surgery among them - can have a long learning curve, and studies indicate that the more a surgeon operates, the better the surgery.

title: CENTER OF UNIVERSE IS A FEW MILES SOUTH, ISN'T IT?
description: WHEN you are single, in your 20's and a nightbird, like me, New York City serves as the center of the universe. Last year I joined the ranks of the restless young adults who grew up in suburban Westchester, did abbreviated stints as commuters and now live and breathe and work and play in ''The City.''

title: POSTINGS: New Directory; Restoration Specialists
description: Terra cotta masonry is no longer a widely practiced craft.

title: Country Homes With Condo Amenities
description: GIVEN the difficulty these days of finding skilled labor and an affordable, attractive and suitably situated building lot, designing and building a country dream house may have become a somewhat dated fantasy.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: AUGUST 17, 1986
description: Fiction

title: WHEN EUROPE PULLED UP STAKES
description: THE PEOPLING OF BRITISH NORTH AMERICA An Introduction. By Bernard Bailyn. 177 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $16.95.

title: SMITHVILLE ACCORD REACHED
description: THE Historic Towne of Smithville, the largest and most controversial residential development project in the state, has a new owner and a go-ahead from its longtime environmentalist adversaries.

title: PARENTS CHALLENGE SEWANHAKA BOARD
description: THE Sewanhaka Central High School District, which has been attempting to correct what a state civil rights investigation last year called ''a pattern of racial segregation'' in its schools, now faces a new challenge.

title: 14 CANDIDATES SEEK TO UNSEAT ALASKA'S GOVERNOR
description: Fourteen candidates, a record, are hoping Alaska voters will do what the State Senate refused to do a year ago: throw Gov. Bill Sheffield out of office.

title: ASBESTOS RISKS AFFLICT OFFICE AND HOUSING MARKETS
description: UNTIL the early 1970s, when asbestos was banned for most construction uses, the carcinogen was the material of choice for fireproofing, soundproofing and insulating buildings. Now New York city and state agencies are in the process of issuing safety regulations for dealing with the hazardous material.

title: 3 Fishermen Saved in Pacific
description: Three fishermen whose wooden boat broke up in rough seas 65 miles off San Diego clung to wreckage for nearly 13 hours before they were rescued Friday by a Coast Guard helicopter. ''Oh boy, as for myself, I can say I'm not going to fish for a living anymore,'' one of the three, Robert Culwell, 43 years old, said after the rescue. The others were his nephew John Culwell, 24, and a crewman, David Shakey, 20.

title: WELFARE APPLICANTS WHO CLAIM DIRE NEED GET EMERGENCY GRANTS
description: New York City began issuing emergency cash grants last week to welfare applicants who say they have no money to buy food while their applications are being processed.

title: Stephanie Oppenheim Weds David Weinstein
description: Stephanie Elizabeth Oppenheim, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen L. Oppenheim of Monticello, N.Y., and New York, was married at the Plaza Hotel in New York yesterday to David Weinstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin Weinstein of Old Westbury, L.I. Rabbi Joy Levitt and Rabbi Lee Friedlander, her husband, officiated.

title: Miss Brown Engaged
description: Kathleen Grant Brown and Craig Evans Eney plan to be married Sept. 6. The future bride is a daughter of Kathleen Van Wyck Brown of Washington and J. Mayo Brown of Upperville, Va., who have announced her engagement to a son of Dr. Irving P. Eney of Norristown, Pa., and Patricia Evans Eney of Lafayette Hills, Pa. Miss Brown is office manager and executive assistant to the president at Rogers & Cowan in Washington. Mr. Eney is a manager at Brooks Brothers in Tysons Corner, Va.

title: CATALOGUERS MOVE UP FROM MAIL
description: SPRINKLED among the shop signs lining the promenades of New York's South Street Seaport are names that a few years ago lined mostly the mailboxes of catalogue customers - Sharper Image, Brookstone, Banana Republic.

title: Julia Dale Woods Becomes a Bride
description: Julia Dale Woods, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald D. Woods of Colorado Springs, was married there yesterday to Marc Crawford McCarthy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. W. Barry McCarthy of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Nathan Miller performed the ceremony at the Broadmoor Community Congregational Church.

title: CONSUMER RATES
FOCUS: Houston; A Fresh Approach To Zoning
description: NONE dare call it zoning, but the city of Houston - an urban monument to laissez-faire free enterprise - has begun to impose new controls that are having some of the same effects. Called ''development controls,'' they are slowly but surely altering the face of this city.

title: Sounding Off; Foster and Fairness
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Dianne Marie O'Sullivan Marries Charles W. Ahto
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of Christ the King in New Vernon, N.J., yesterday Dianne Marie O'Sullivan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Owen Michael O'Sullivan of New Vernon, was married to Charles William Ahto, the son of Charles Anthony Ahto of Florham Park, N.J., and the late Margaret Ann Ahto. Msgr.

title: CLASSICAL FINALES ON SCHEDULE AS FESTIVALS END SEASON
description: IT is going to be rather quiet in the county by the end of next weekend, as the last remaining classical summer festivals fold their musical tents and call it a season. You still have time to catch several finales, though, and enjoy a great deal of appealing music into the bargain.

title:
DINING OUT;
SEA FARE IN A LANDLOCKED SITE
description: IT'S a sign of the times that a seafood restaurant - and a landlocked one at that - is as packed on a Saturday night as a steakhouse.

title:
ART;
URBAN ANXIETIES REFLECTED IN PAINTINGS FROM EAST VILLAGE
description: DURING the last five years the New York art scene has made a dramatic shift to the east, out of what has become the high-rent, high-fashion district of SoHo and into the gritty, unchic neighborhood known as the East Village.

title: Indiana Police Trap Snares 389 Suspects
description: A four-month police undercover operation that lured fugitives into custody with offers of free trips, cash or prizes concluded Friday after rounding up 389 suspects for crimes as serious as murder and rape, authorities said.

title: Bears, Bell in Accord
description: As an all-pro strong safety in the National Football League, Todd Bell figured he was worth more money than he was offered to sign a new contract last year. He also figured he would be hard to replace, so when club officials continued to balk at his demands he decided to hold out until they realized just how indispensible he was to the team.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: HER LIVING IMAGE. By Jane Rogers. (Doubleday, $16.95.) Jane Rogers often writes beautifully in her second novel, which consists of two alternate versions of the same character's story.

title: Religion and Politics Don't Mix - or Do They?
description: The Rev. Pat Robertson has fallen from grace, according to pundits and other political experts, after finishing fourth behind Vice President Bush, Representative Jack Kemp and a block of ''uncommitted'' delegates in Michigan's recent and complicated Presidential primary.

title: Roy Cohn's Descent on the Libraries of Europe; Guilt by Association
description: To the Editor:

title: GOTTI, READY FOR TRIAL, TO FACE INFORMANTS, WIRETAPS AND AN ANONYMOUS JURY
description: On a chilly spring morning last year, while playing cards in a Queens social club, John Gotti was arrested on racketeering charges by a squad of Federal agents and New York City detectives.

title: RIDING WITH THE PACK
description: THERE IS A RACE NEXT WEEKEND. I'M 31 years old, fit, competitive as hell, but I don't have a chance. I'm a neophyte bicycle racer. My competitors are grizzled veterans with brown, windburned skin from miles of brutal training. They have tree trunks for legs and the razor-sharp eyes of predators. Worst of all, they're mostly 18 and 19 years old. But when Saturday morning comes, I'm going to strap on my helmet and wheel up to the start, ready to do my battle with age. Why? Not much in my background really explains it. As a youngster, I was uncoordinated and on the heavy side. My family played a little genteel tennis, but pain was for health nuts and flakes. High school was a hippie experience for me, no sports there. But in college, things changed, at least for a year. Maybe it was missing out on the Marine Corps, which had been my father's rite of passage, but I suddenly had something to prove. I went out for freshman crew, discovered my ability to suffer, and helped pull my shell to a record season. I drifted off after that into more occasional sports - some running, a little squash, neither with any real commitment.

title: TWO ARTISTS WHO QUALIFY AS VISIONARIES
description: How much of today's pop music could fairly be called visionary art? In the 1960's, the leading rock artists were expected to have a vision - a kind of burning dedication that fused their lives and personal development, and the evolution of their work, into a far-seeing, indivisible whole. The best artists - such as John Lennon of the Beatles, Lou Reed of the Velvet Underground and Bob Dylan - broke down barriers, creatively reimagined present-day conditions and future possibilities, and redefined themselves with almost every record release.

title: NEW CASSETTES: CLASSIC WESTERN, SINGULAR SONGSTER
description: THE ACADEMY OF ST. MARTIN-IN-THE-FIELDS; Conducted by Neville Marriner Kultur, 55 minutes. $29.95.

title: Pooling Resources
description: As owners of a nontraditional pool, my wife and I enjoyed Carol Vogel's article ''Pooling Resources'' (Home Design, July 20).

title: Beverly J. Bodnar Becomes a Bride
description: Beverly Jean Bodnar, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Charles Bodnar of Easton, Conn., and Siesta Key, Fla., was married yesterday to Walter Gregory Rodiger 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Rodiger Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., and Kennebunkport, Me. The Rev. Jerry Alan Smith performed the ceremony at the Congregational Church in Easton.

title: A MASTER AT HELM OF 'DAMES AT SEA'
description: HOW do you spruce up a tired show? At the Sharon Playhouse, the answer is clear.

title: PASSING THE BUCK FROM ONE GENERATION TO THE NEXT
description: ''GENERATIONAL EQUITY,'' clumsy though it sounds, is slowly wending its way into political discourse. And judging from recent economic developments, that should come as no surprise.

title: Buying Ammo
description: Not everybody who works in the White House gets to make decisions about international arms trade. That much was clear last week when Federal authorities charged Anita S. Castelo, Nancy Reagan's personal maid, with aiding and abetting the illegal export of munitions by purchasing two cases of .22-caliber ammunition to be smuggled into her native Paraguay. Mrs. Castelo, a naturalized American who has been on the White House staff since 1981, pleaded not guilty.

title: PAINT AND PATCHES FOR MARK TWAIN HOME
description: MARK TWAIN, who delighted in the eccentricities of his Hartford house, would no doubt be amused to see the laborious effort that a crew of workers recently went through to clean and repaint the structure's many crannies.

title: BOOKSHELF
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: SOMETHING SLEEPING IN THE HALL Written and Illustrated by Karla Kuskin. 64 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $8.95. (Ages 5 to 8)

title:
THE REGION;
Fatal Rampage on Brooklyn Campus
description: A one-man shooting rampage through the City University's New York City Technical College campus in downtown Brooklyn last week left one person dead and four others seriously wounded.

title: CODE NAME ERIC
description: HERE LIES An Autobiography. By Eric Ambler. Illustrated. 234 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $16.95.

title: Adopt a Prisoner?
description: Taking a cue from Amnesty International, the organization that works for the release of political prisoners around the world, two Democratic members of the House plan to start a program to ''adopt'' political prisoners in South Africa. The two Representatives, John Conyers Jr. of Michigan and Sam Gejdenson of Connecticut, hope to enlist the aid of other members of Congress, labor unions, civil rights organizations and others in the effort.

title: Labor Costs
description: To the Editor:

title: WALL ST. M.B.A.'S
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: An article about imported food in the same section misstated the relative costs of apples grown in Chile and sold in Boston and those grown in New York and sold in Boston. The Chilean apples are only cheaper if they are transported by ship rather than jet.

title: FALL'S COMFORT AND SECURITY
description: CHILDREN WILL FEEL SECURE and comfortable in their new fall clothes. The current predominant look is carefully styled to appear casual.

title: LOSERS STILL WEEPERS
description: KEELHAULED Unsportsmanlike Conduct and the America's Cup. By Doug Riggs. Illustrated. 308 pp. Newport, R.I.: Seven Seas Press. $19.95.

title: HOW TO MOVE AN OLD MUSEUM
description: IN the coming weeks, 150 sure-footed, well-supervised volunteers will traverse the Waterbury Green, carrying 40,000 objects destined for the new Mattatuck Museum.

title: THRIVING GAMBITS
description: There has been a lot of talk about gambit play's being outmoded, that nowadays the stratagems of defensive play have made sparkling attacking sacrifices obsolete. But is it so?

title: QUESTIONS ARISE IN DATA ON ROSTENKOWSKI TRUST
description: Representative Dan Rostenkowski received approval in 1980 from the House ethics committee to set up a blind trust based upon his written assurance that he had had no dealings as an investor or employer with the Chicago businessman he chose as an independent manager of the trust.

title: NEW CASSETTES: CLASSIC WESTERN, SINGULAR SONGSTER
description: SHE WORE A YEALLOW RIBBON Starring John Wayne, Joanne Dru, John Agar, Victor McLaglen, Harry Carey Jr.; directed by John Ford, 1949.RKO Pictures' Home Video, 93 minutes.

title: Malay Rail
description: To the Editor: The article in the June 29 Travel section on rail travel between Bangkok and Singapore made me recall a trip I made while serving as a fighter pilot in South Korea in 1977.

title: Katherine Graham Weds Fernando Diz
description: Katherine Helga Graham, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Kinne Graham Jr. of Lawrenceville, N.J., and Hardwick, Vt., was married yesterday to Fernando Diz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfonso Hispano Diz of Buenos Aires. The Rev. Arnold Brown, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Church-on-the-Common in Craftsbury, Vt.

title: 'Stealing the Language'
description: To the Editor:

title: DANCE: 'IN YOUR FACE,' BY DEBORAH ANDERSEN
description: THERE were signs of an indisputable intelligence at work in ''In Your Face,'' a program performed by Deborah Andersen on Thursday night at the Bessie Schonberg Theater as part of Dance Theater Workshop's ''Out-of-Towners'' series.

title: Wedding at Caramoor For Sally J. Greenspan
description: The marriage of Sally J. Greenspan, a daughter of Dr. Taube G. Greenspan of Stamford, Conn., and the late Charles M. Greenspan, to Edmund Rowley-Williams took place yesterday at Caramoor in Katonah, N.Y., where the bride's mother is the museum director and curator. The Rev. Harris Reardon of the White Plains Unitarian Universalist Church officiated.

title: EXPLORING BALI BEYOND THE BEACHES
description: Bali is as far away from New York as you can get, without getting closer: 13,000 miles away, on the opposite side of the world. That you are worlds away will be apparent the first time you are greeted by a Balinese. Everyone there asks three questions: Are you married? How many children? And, Where are you going? The last question is akin to the Western How are you?, and a full answer is not expected. Jalan-jalan, just walking, is sufficient. Most visitors to this small volcanic island in Indonesia are likely to stay in Sanur, Kuta or Nusa Dua, the three resort areas on the beaches of southern Bali, where there are Western-style accommodations and restaurants.

title: BEMAN WEATHERS STORMS OF PRO GOLF
description: DEANE RANDOLPH BEMAN was 13 years old in 1951 when his father came home one day with six new sets of golf clubs - one each for Deane, his two brothers, his sister and his mother and father.

title: DOMESTIC VIOLENCE IN THE STATE FOUND TO BE ON THE INCREASE
description: FAMILY violence - from slaps to murder, and including abuse of husbands, as well as wives - is increasing in the state, according to Col. Clinton L. Pagano, Superintendent of the State Police.

title: Abuse of Agent Denied By Mexican Governor
description: The Governor of the western state of Jalisco has declared that it is ''absolutely false'' that the state police tortured an American drug agent, a Government newspaper reported today.

title: G. W. Wheeler Weds Carolyn A. Cromwell
description: Carolyn Anne Cromwell, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Benjamin Cromwell of New Canaan, Conn., was married there yesterday to Gregory Walker Wheeler, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Gray Wheeler of West Palm Beach, Fla., and Harwichport, Mass. The Rev. Elwood Stark performed the ceremony at St. Michael's Lutheran Church.

title: YONKERS MALL PLAN OPPOSED
description: A PROPOSED regional shopping mall in north Yonkers is stirring strong opposition from residents in the area and provoking questions about the city's future.

title: IN JAPAN, A MORALITY PLAY
description: FOR the last week, 49 high-school baseball teams have converged on Koshien Stadium in this suburb of Osaka for an elimination tournament to determine which of them is Japan's best.

title: SOMERVILLE
description: JUST a decade ago, Somerville, N.J., the seat of Somerset County, was in trouble. The heart of the town, a 15-acre parcel on Main Street, sat vacant and the entire business district was floundering. ''The town appeared to be on the way out,'' said Mayor Emanuel R. Luftglass.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL CHICAGO (AL) - Purchased the contract of Ron Karkovice, catcher, from Birmingham of the Southern League.

title: YANK STREAK ENDED AT 4 BY ROYALS, 4-2
description: The big threat was there and the right batters were on their way up. But a bunt failed, a ground ball was turned into a double play, and another day in August passed without the Yankees making more of a breakthrough on the Boston Red Sox.

title: CONGRESS STARTS 3-WEEK VACATION
description: Congress finally headed for home early this morning after passing legislation that will raise the national debt ceiling and allow the Government to continue borrowing money while the lawmakers enjoy a three-week summer holiday.

title: HOMELESS CHILDREN ON INCREASE, STUDY SHOWS
description: THE first study of children in New Jersey who end up in temporary youth shelters is expected to show that, contrary to what was previously believed, a significant percentage are not running away from troubled homes but are seeking shelter because they do not have homes at all.

title: Dr. Lesley P. Siegel Weds
description: Dr. Lesley P. Siegel, a postdoctoral fellow in child psychiatry at the Yale Child Study Center, was married in New York last evening to Dr. Lawrence N. Levenson, a staff psychiatrist at the Veterans Administration Hospital in West Haven, Conn., and an assistant professor of psychiatry at Yale. Rabbi Charles Kroloff officiated at the Hampshire House. The parents of the couple are Helene Siegel Wertheimer of Scotch Plains, N.J., and Dr. Harvey Siegel of North Plainfield, N.J., and Dr. and Mrs. Howard Levenson of Lawrenceville, N.J.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE ADDING MACHINE:

title: Elizabeth Buck to Wed C.H. King 3d
description: The engagement of Elizabeth Rhoads Buck to Charles H. King 3d has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. William C. Buck of Villanova, Pa. Her fiance is the son of Mrs. Howard E. C. Hall of Greenwich, Conn., and Mr. King Jr. of Wilton, Conn.

title: Golf Event Loses Its Big Stars
description: Four days of elimination concluded today as 12 players from an original entry of 162 qualified for Sunday's finale of The International, a new PGA Tour event based on the Stableford point system of scoring.

title: NEW CASSETTES: CLASSIC WESTERN, SINGULAR SONGSTER
description: THE TALKING PARCEL Produced by Thames Television Thorn EMI/HBO Video, 40 minutes. $24.95.

title: TOM GORMAN'S FINAL CALL
description: WHEN Brian Gorman, son of Tom Gorman, the former major league umpire, was in grade school in Closter, N.J., a classmate asked Brian one day what it felt like when his father missed a call.

title: IT'S TIME TO PLANT FLOWER SEED - AGAIN
description: Starting perennials from seed merely follows nature's example. Planting should roughly coincide with the end of a given plant's flowering period when its seed pods mature.

title: Earthquake Jolts Moldavia
description: An earthquake shook areas of the Soviet republic of Moldavia today but caused no damage, the official press agency Tass reported. The agency said tremors in southern Moldavia measured 4.5 to 5 on the 12-point Soviet scale, a magnitude described as ''rather strong.'' In the capital, Kishinev, the tremors measured 4.0, or ''moderate.''

title: ROO ART WINS AT MONMOUTH
description: Roo Art capitalized on an early speed duel between the two favorites, Precisionist and Lady's Secret, and ran them down in the stretch today to win the Iselin Handicap at Monmouth Park.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE LONG WALK. By George La Fountaine. (Putnam, $17.95.) Although badly wounded by infelicitous prose, melodrama, implausibilities so large they're almost daring and characters who burst into polemic as if it were song, this Vietnam War novel still manages to pull itself along on sheer narrative bravado.

title: RIDE CHOSEN FOR NEW NASA JOB
description: Sally Ride, who was the first American woman in space, will be appointed special assistant to the Administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, an agency spokesman said today.

title: Untouchable Edmund Wilson
description: To the Editor:

title: REAGAN, THE FREE MARKET AND THE FARM
description: AS they often do, sometimes with telling effect when a program comes under fire, farmers have begun to treat the Reagan Administration's farm policies with bitter humor, as a North Dakota Democrat did the other day.

title: CATHOLIC SCHOOLS ADAPTING TO SHIFTS IN COUNTY ENROLLMENT
description: FOR the first time in 100 years Mamaroneck will be without a Catholic school this fall. But a few miles away, in Bronxville, St. Joseph's School will begin using newly built or renovated facilities including an auditorium, library and computer and science laboratories.

title: HOPING TO TURN 'RAGS' INTO RICHES
description: THE big new Broadway musical promises everything: laughter, tears, a rich score, a spectacular star, epic sweep, fireworks - even the Statue of Liberty. But it's in trouble.

title:
DINING OUT;
ANOTHER LOOK AT THE 1852 INN
description: WE heard recently from several of our readers whose letters question our enthusiastic review of the 1852 Inn two years ago. We went back to investigate. The menu still promises some unusual combinations, dishes that once made dining here exciting. But, sad to report, the kitchen has lost that inspired touch - or the chef who had the talent - and present efforts are, for the most part and often at best, amateurish.

title: BENEFITS OF CONTAINER-GROWN PLANTS
description: WHILE container-grown plants have their drawbacks, their benefits to both nurserymen and consumers far offset their deficiencies. However, attention to the potential problems will provide greater assurance of success.

title: REAGAN ASSAILS HOUSE DEMOCRATS ON MILITARY CUTS
description: President Reagan today attacked the Democratic-controlled House of Representatives as waging ''a reckless assault on the national defense of the United States.''

title: MOZART FESTIVAL SCHEDULES 'AMAHL'
description: DESPITE the seeming inevitability of wisecracks about current ''Christmas in August'' advertising campaigns, ''Mozart and Friends Festival '86'' will present Menotti's ''Amahl and the Night Visitors'' Saturday.

title: For Better Cabbies and Higher Pay
description: New York's taxi owners say they deserve a fare increase, their first in six years. Gorman Gilbert, the new chairman of the Taxi and Limousine Commission, apparently agrees. His staff estimates that in a grueling 50-hour week, the typical cabbie can earn only $350 to $500, without fringe benefits. That's not enough, the Commissioner argues, to attract the courteous, knowledgeable drivers the public has a right to expect.

title: PLAYING DEAD: THE MEMOIRS OF A THEATRICAL WORKING STIFF
description: It's not easy playing a corpse. I should know.

title: House Unit Seeks A Perjury Inquiry In Deaver Case
description: The troubles of Michael K. Deaver, the longtime friend of President and Mrs. Reagan and the President's former deputy White House chief of staff, deepened last week as a House subcommittee, saying he had lied in sworn testimony, asked an independent counsel to look into the possibility of perjury charges.

title: THE I.R.A. IS POINTING ITS RIFLE AT THE WORKING MAN
description: JOHN KYLE was not known to be heavily political in the pursuit of his quarry business in County Tyrone, Northern Ireland. This made it puzzling, and all the more terrifying, when the community heard how a lone gunman quietly approached Mr. Kyle as he sat at his glass in a pub in Omagh three weeks ago and shot him to death. The Irish Republican Army soon explained that because he was supplying cement and stone for the construction of a police station, Mr. Kyle was liable to execution for abetting the British ''war machine.''

title: Malpractice Crisis
description: I do not know Henry Eisenberg personally, but I feel I know him quite well simply by the story he tells as a competent and caring physician who lost a malpractice suit (''A Doctor on Trial,'' July 20). I am a specialist in infectious diseases who reviews many cases for lawyers on both sides, plaintiffs and defendants.

title: CRIME
description: Here's a rather nondescript don whose field at his university is philosophical logic and whose field in Government intelligence is Germany. Among other things, he runs a network there. The British Government, faced with an economic recession, makes budget cuts that have a wide-ranging effect. The secret-service agencies have to effect economies. The universities have to release personnel. Suddenly the don is out of both his jobs, with not even a pension to mark years of work in them. Then something comes up in the German network that makes him temporarily indispensable.

title: WILL O'GRADY OF PGA TOUR BE FOUND OUT OF BOUNDS?
description: Ever since PGA Tour Commissioner Deane Beman withheld a $500 fine from Mac O'Grady's paycheck, for insulting a volunteer at a New Orleans golf tournament in 1984, O'Grady has been on the warpath.

title: MACKEY POSTS A 65 AND LEADS BY FOUR
description: Cindy Mackey registered seven birdies in shooting a seven-under par 65 at Knollwood Country Club today. The bogey-free round was not only the best of her four-year career, but it also gave her a 10-under par total of 206 and a four-stroke lead over Colleen Walker in the MasterCard International.

title: MENDING THE MASTER'S SOCKS
description: MY LIFE WITH CHAGALL Seven Years of Plenty With the Master as Told by the Woman Who Shared Them. By Virginia Haggard. Illustrated. 190 pp. New York: Donald I. Fine. $18.95.

title: McLAUGHLIN BRIBE TRIAL HEADS FOR CLOSE AFTER TESTIMONY OF 40
description: After six weeks of testimony by more than 40 witnesses, the trial of John J. McLaughlin, the former president of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, appears headed for the jury this week.

title: Auto Speed-Up Inquiry Now Focuses on Audis
description: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has dropped an investigation of sudden acceleration of vehicles manufactured by the General Motors Corporation and is opening an investigation into alleged incidents of sudden acceleration in 300,000 Audi 5000's, made by Volkswagen of America.

title: Big Utilities Announce Nuclear Safety Effort
description: Senior executives of three large electric utilities have announced a new industry-sponsored effort they say will discipline persistent safety violators at nuclear power plants.

title: Rosemary Hier to Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Donald E. Hier of Mendham, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter Rosemary Therese Hier to George Natale Ostertag, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Ostertag of Wayne, N.J.

title: Perfect-Game Bid Lasts for 19 Batters
description: Jamie Moyer, a rookie, had a perfect game for six and one-third innings tonight, then finished with a two-hitter as the Chicago Cubs beat the Montreal Expos, 5-0.

title: Larry Flynt Quits Hospital
description: Larry Flynt, publisher of the sexually explicit Hustler magazine, was released Friday from Cedars-Sinai Medical Center. The 43-year-old Mr. Flynt entered the hospital last Sunday, reportedly suffering from an ailment whose nature has not been disclosed.

title: TEXAS COUNTY TESTS A MACHINE THAT 'PATROLS' ITS HIGHWAYS
description: Machines are watching drivers and catching speeders on some highways in south Texas.

title: Wall St. M.B.A.'s
description: To the Editor:

title: REHNQUIST AND SCALIA PASS THEIR FIRST TEST IN SENATE
description: THE Senate Judiciary Committee, divided, doubtful and tired, rendered its decisions last week on President Reagan's Supreme Court nominees. The Senators voted 13 to 5 to recommend the confirmation of William H. Rehnquist as Chief Justice of the United States, then unanimously approved Antonin Scalia's nomination to succeed him as an Associate Justice.

title: OFFICIALS CITE 42 FOOD OUTLETS
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 42 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title:
CABLE TV NOTES;
LATIN AMERICAN CULTURE IN THE SPOTLIGHT
description: Since 1976, the New York Shakespeare Festival has supported perhaps the most ambitious celebration of indigenous Latin American culture in the United States - a summertime cornucopia of plays, dance, films and music that showcases the artistic vibrancy and variety to be found in those lands.

title: Jacqueline Wong Wed To Charles Delamater
description: The marriage of Jacqueline Wong, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alex Wong of Hong Kong and Vancouver, British Columbia, and Charles Rutherford Delamater, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Hall Delamater of Weekapaug, R.I., took place yesterday at the Weekapaug Chapel. The Rev. Joseph Bishop performed the Protestant ceremony.

title:
DANCE;
FOR CHOREOGRAPHERS, ALL THE WORLD'S A DANCE STAGE
description: NEW JERSEY'S ballet and modern-dance companies have become popular havens for emerging, as well as established, choreographers to display their works.

title: 50 YEARS: A PLACE IN THE SUN IN THE BRONX
description: Not long after Robert Moses dumped acres of glistening sand into a northern cove of the Bronx, Jack Gelber remembers his immigrant parents taking him to the new beach by trolley car.

title: Betsy Lynn Weiser Is Married to Eric David Karp
description: Betsy Lynn Weiser, a vice president of Ogilvy & Mather Advertising in New York, was married last evening to Eric David Karp, a student at the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration and a former assistant vice president of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York. Rabbi Jack Stern Jr. performed the ceremony at the Century Country Club in Purchase, N.Y.

title: POLICE CHIEF ISSUE IN PEEKSKILL
description: WHERE'S the chief? In Peekskill, that question has become a rallying cry for police officers and political activists who want a police chief - a position they insist won voter approval in a referendum last November.

title: Page Robbins Married to a Radiologist
description: Page Robbins, a daughter of Mary Ann Robbins of Mill Valley, Calif., and Richard Marshall Robbins of Sausalito, Calif., was married yesterday to Dr. David J. Seidenwurm, a son of Reni Roberts Seidenwurm and Norman Seidenwurm, both of New York. The Rev. Bart Sarjeant, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Audubon Society Wildlife Sanctuary in Tiburon, Calif.

title: MAZDA IS WINNING A NEW SET OF FANS
description: THERE was a time that I wanted a new Mazda sports car badly enough to go do battle with a salesman. I hemmed. He hawed. And in the end I went away afoot, having had my first taste of scarce Japanese cars and the price-gouging that attends them.

title: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: THE POWERS THAT BE, by David Halberstam. (Dell, $5.95.) David Halberstam examines the recent history of four important news-gathering organizations - The Los Angeles Times, The Washington Post, Time Inc. and CBS - in what Richard Rovere, writing in these pages in 1979, called an ''important and admirable book.'' It is, he said, ''a prodigy of research and tendentious but sharply focused narrative and analysis.'' For a different perspective on the press, Quill/Morrow has reissued THE OTHER SIDE OF THE STORY ($7.95), in which Jody Powell, former press secretary to President Carter, takes aim at the White House press corps. ''It is a lively performance, full of spleen and not a little gall,'' Lester Bernstein said in The Book Review in 1984. LOVE ALWAYS, by Ann Beattie. (Vintage, $5.95.) A main character in Ann Beattie's third novel is Nicole Nelson, a 14-year-old soap opera star who comes to spend the summer in Vermont with her Aunt Lucy. ''Miss Beattie is one of the most graceful writers we have,'' Alice Hoffman said here last year; ''at times her prose is nothing short of exquisite. It is such sheer pleasure to read the dialogue in 'Love Always,' we almost don't care what the characters say to one another. But when we really do listen, the absence of desire is more than unsettling - it's chilling.'' THE LIFE OF HENRY BRULARD, by Stendhal. Translated by Jean Stewart and B. C. J. G. Knight. (University of Chicago, $12.95.) Stendhal (Marie-Henri Beyle) wrote this autobiography, calling himself Henry Brulard, in 1835-36, but it lay forgotten until 1890, when it was found in an attic.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: HERITAGE FESTIVAL Given Huntington's long history and its diverse population, a celebration of the town's heritage offers the best of all possible worlds. Today the Historical Society stages its 23d annual Heritage Festival, with the Huntington Militia and other Colonial activities. The community's 12 major ethnic groups have been invited to take part in providing food and entertainment. The festival is from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. at Heckscher Park, and free bus service is available along Main Street to those who park outside the immediate vicinity. Admission is $2, or $1.50 for children 5 to 12, with those under 5 free; festival-goers who show up in authentic ethnic or Colonial dress get in free.WAY OFF BROADWAY

title: IN 'RAGS' AN OPERA STAR TRIES ON A MUSICAL
description: When the composer Charles Strouse met the internationally acclaimed opera singer Teresa Stratas in New York last winter, she jokingly told him, ''The last thing I ever wanted to do was a musical.'' He replied, ''The last person I ever wanted to work with was an opera singer.''

title: OUT OF AFRICA? WELL, NOT REALLY
description: THREE months ago, Stanley Works pulled out of South Africa.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE GREAT ALONE. By Janet Dailey. (Poseidon, $18.95.) This is the kind of book often described as a ''sprawling epic'': its 716 pages span over 200 years of Alaskan history, from the arrival of Russian fur traders in the 18th century to statehood in the 20th, and seven generations of the Tarakanov family, whose fortunes and adventures perfectly parallel Alaska's.

title: MASK IT, SEAL IT, LABEL IT, MEND IT: THE MANY USES OF TAPES
description: CHANCES are that at least a couple of rolls of adhesive-backed tape can be found in almost every house - including such familiar types as the ubiquitous transparent Scotch tape, masking tape and plastic electrical tape. However, many people do not realize how useful these tapes can be, or how many other different types of pressure-sensitive tape can be handy around the home.

title: BRUSSELS
description: Until a few years ago, Brussels was frequently thought of only as a European crossroads, a city with European Community and NATO headquarters as well as restaurants that appealed to those with gusty appetites for mussels and frites.

title: Sounding Off; Foster and Fairness
description: To The Sports Editor:

title: TOURISM INDUSTRY ASKS WHERE THE BOOM IS
description: THE tourism industry is experiencing an erratic season. Some operators say they are doing better than last year, and others say worse.

title: Complex Cases Swamp Housing Court
description: THE prize is a magnificent Manhattan apartment of the sort through which Ginger Rogers and Fred Astaire danced in their escapist films of a generation ago - 2,800 square feet of elegance containing seven rooms, 4 1/2 baths and a balcony overlooking the East River. And the battle over the legal tenancy and ownership of Apartment 36E at 425 East 58th Street has been dragging on for two years with no end in sight.

title: Cable TV
description: No ripe film premieres this week on cable - last week held a bounty - but the screen fare is estimable. Early-riser science-fiction fans should catch ''Fantastic Planet'' (1973), a stately, searching animated feature from France - Sunday at 5 A.M. on USA. Another imported surprise is ''Family Game'' (1984), an amusing look at Japan's newly affluent, utterly direction-less middle-class - Tuesday on Bravo at 11 P.M. and 4 A.M. Two bright, strictly American comedies on Monday are ''Every Young Girl Should Be Married'' (1948), with Cary Grant and Betsy Drake - 10 A.M. on Lifetime - and ''The More the Merrier'' (1943), with Jean Arthur, Joel McCrea and Charles Coburn in crowded wartime Washington -10:05 A.M. on WTBS. And Buster Keaton in ''The General'' (1927) is a golden old silent nugget, with the deadpan clown at his peak - Monday at 4:45 P.M. and Thursday at 6:30 P.M. on WHT.

title: AGAIN AT THE DOMINICAN HELM
description: Joaquin Balaguer, a 78-year-old lawyer who has devoted his life to politics and literature, was inaugurated today for his fifth term as President of this Caribbean nation.

title: MARK TWAIN TAKES ON REDDING AND LOSES
description: MARK TWAIN would have had to hike up his britches and run for his life if he had attended the Town Meeting in Redding on Aug. 8. A motion to consider a Mark Twain Historic District was not just defeated 3 to 1, but it was also hooted into oblivion.

title: A NEW RESPECT FOR MILITARY ELECTRONICS
description: ALTHOUGH military spending over all may not increase significantly over the next few years, some contractors that serve a specific high-tech niche may prosper, and provide attractive opportunities for the patient investor.

title:
CRITICS' CHOICES;
Photography
description: The visitor to Jay Maisel's exhibition, ''Light on America,'' at the International Center of Photography, Fifth Avenue at 94th Street, through Aug. 31, is greeted by a huge photo mural of the New York skyline at twilight as seen from Brooklyn during a Fourth of July celebration. The Brooklyn Bridge stretches halfway across the picture, strung with cool blue lights.

title: FEARLESS STUDENTS KEEP UP EUROPEAN TRAVEL
description: Young Americans - students and recent graduates 18 to 25 years old -have not been as afraid to visit Europe this summer as have most other tourists from the United States, according to travel-industry experts.

title: HIGH SCHOOL DIRECTOR ADVOCATES THE BASICS
description: SOMETIMES, Frank L. Smith Jr., the new director of the city's high schools, says he thinks like a military commander. ''I'm trying to set up a planning procedure with the logic of Rickover's,'' he said recently of his efforts to improve five schools with high dropout rates.

title: Boston School Names Dean
description: H. Joachim Maitre, a professor of journalism and international relations, has been named interim dean of the Boston University College of Communication. Professor Maitre recently returned from a two-week trip to Pakistan to set up a program to train Afghan refugees as journalists, which several faculty members have objected to in part because it was financed by the United States Information Agency. The former dean of the school, Bernard S. Redmont, quit in July after refusing to give the Afghan program his backing.

title: Recent Sales
description: Maplewood $133,500 15 Lancaster Avenue *2*3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 40-year-old colonial; living-room fireplace, *2*den, full basement, 2-car detached garage; taxes $2,634. Millburn $217,500 59 Locust Avenue *2*3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 28-year-old Tudor; oak floors, *2*enclosed porch, den, living room with fireplace; taxes $2,749. Ramsey $170,000 23 Spruce Run *2*2-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 3-year-old town house; *2*eat-in kitchen, deck, den; taxes $2,785. Succasunna $159,900 198 Eyland Avenue *2*4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 27-year-old split-level; fenced yard, *2*family room with wood stove, 2-car garage; taxes $2,235. Summit $685,000 19 Greenbriar Drive *2*4-bedroom, 3-bath, 33-year-old colonial; 3 fireplaces, master *2*bedroom with dressing room and bath, patio; taxes $6,910. Westfield $150,000 50 Cottage Place *2*3-bedroom, 1-bath, 33-year-old ranch; wall-to-wall *2*carpeting, fenced yard; taxes $1,914. OTHER AREAS Yorktown Heights, N.Y. $159,000 3737 Foothill Road *2*4-bedroom, 2-bath, 21-year-old raised ranch; *2*deck, pool, 0.75 acre; taxes $3,400. Guilford, Conn. $357,000 35 Thankful Stow Road *2*4-bedroom, 3 1/2-baths, 7-year-old contemporary; *2*large foyer with Mexican tile, 2.6 acres; taxes $3,640. Babylon, L.I. $134,000 442 Little East Neck Road *2*3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath 35-year-old waterfront Cape Cod; *2*dining room, eat-in kitchen, 40-foot bulkhead; taxes $1,200.

title: CONGRESS LEAVES WITH A LOT STILL ON ITS MIND
description: AS Congress rushed for the doors and its summer holiday last week, its members could point to some notable accomplishments. But a longer list of pressing problems was left unresolved, and a cloud of tension and frustration hung over Capitol Hill as the legislators adjourned, looking ahead to an election less than three months away that would determine control of the Senate and the fate of President Reagan's programs.

title: 6th DISTRICT GETS PRIMARY AFTER ALL
description: FORMER State Senator Paul Amenta of New Britain has changed his mind about not forcing a Democratic primary in the Sixth Congressional District for the right to challenge Republican Representative Nancy L. Johnson, also of New Britain, in November.

title: FOR SUMMER: COOL, BRIEF AND BLACK
description: BLACK is a popular midsummer color in Manhattan. It has been for years. No one seems certain why, although there is conjecture that the wearing of black is favored by some New Yorkers, especially the more avant-garde, as a way of separating themselves from pastel-hued out-of-towners.

title: Betrayed by Walter O'Malley
description: The Golden Age of Athens lasted three decades. Brooklyn's outlasted that by seven years - and what a zesty age it was, according to Elliot Willensky in his book WHEN BROOKLYN WAS THE WORLD: 1920-1957 (Harmony, $19.95).

title: GROUP FIGHTS FORCED RETIREMENT AND OTHER BARS TO THE AGED
description: FRANCELIA BUTLER, an English professor at the University of Connecticut, has two books coming out this year, a third that has been accepted by a publisher and requests from several academic journals to write articles on her specialty.

title: Clean as New Zealand
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: IVORY BRIGHT. By Elaine Ford. (Viking, $15.95.) Ivory Bright is a cigarette-puffing 31-year-old ragamuffin with ''Ping-Pong ball ankles'' and an asymmetrical face.

title: Technology and the Bottom Line Create Profound Challenges
description: Is there any longer a need for network newscasts? Are the networks soon to become a kind of electronic Associated Press, simply feeding stories to affiliates who will then repackage them in their own newscasts?

title:
NATURE WATCH;
PINTAIL DUCK
description: Anas acuta Size: 20 to 30 inches.

title: Chinese Girl, 15, Wins Gold Medal in Diving
description: Min Gao gave China its first-ever gold medal of the World Swimming Championships as she won the women's springboard diving competition today.

title: RED, YELLOW OR GREEN, A PALETTE OF TOMATOES
description: MIDSUMMER is not only the prime season for tomatoes that are vine-ripened, richly flavored and endowed with smooth, meaty texture, it is also a time when a good tomato is not necessarily red. Yellow tomatoes, lower in acid than their scarlet counterparts, are sold at some farm stands and are also grown by adventurous gardeners. Even green tomatoes, picked unripe for pickling, making into chutney or frying, are available.

title: O'BRIEN IS SHARP AS JETS TOP BENGALS
description: With passable protection, Ken O'Brien threw two touchdowns tonight and the Jets, still playing without Freeman McNeil, produced a 28-17 exhibition victory over the Cincinnati Bengals at Giants Stadium.

title: A REBOUND, YES, BUT NOT LIKE THE '70'S
description: TO some economists, inflation is like those trick birthday candles, the ones that are impossible to blow out. A strong gust will extinguish the flame for a second or two, but inevitably it flares back to life.

title: ANTIQUES LOUNTRY-ANTIQUE SHOWS
description: A LARGE outdoor exhibition and sale devoted exclusively to quality country antiques and a more intimate show that will be held nearby in the engaging country setting of an old mill on the bank of the Delaware and Raritan Canal, bordering the Delaware River, will bring together more than 200 dealers and an expected influx of thousands of visitors.

title: PLEA FROM LOS ANGELES: BIG FILMS, COME HOME
