description: The Supervisors of Los Angeles County, who have been bemoaning a shortage of funds, have voted to try to find $100,000 somewhere in the budget to encourage the filming of multimillion-dollar movies here. The money was not much, but it showed how eager some officials have become to stop the outflow of motion picture productions from southern California.

title: FOR FRESH AIR CAMP HEAD, DAY OF SURPRISES
description: For several weeks, Owen Engler suspected that the counselors and children at Camp Hidden Valley were up to something. ''You can't be camp director for 30 years and not know when something is going on,'' he said.

title: PERU'S FORCES PRESS AHEAD IN DRUG WAR
description: A squadron of A-37 jets took off from Iquitos last weekend, dipped through rain clouds hanging over Peru's northern jungles and released bombs over two airstrips built by cocaine traffickers.

title: Frances W. Wong And Carl A. Loo Exchange Vows
description: Frances Waikwun Wong, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clifford C. F. Wong of Hong Kong and Toronto, was married yesterday to Carl Arthur Loo, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David W. Loo of Hong Kong and New York. The Rev. Edward O'Neill performed the ceremony at St. Andrew's Presbyterian Church in Toronto.

title: NEW CASSETTES: CLASSIC WESTERN, SINGULAR SONGSTER
description: BOBBY SHORT AND FRIENDS, MGM/UA Home Video; 60 minutes. $29.95.

title: South Africa Remains Defiant As Pressure Rises
description: South Africa's white leaders remained firm last week in the face of a rising tide of opposition to their racial system and the Draconian measures supporting it.

title: BENEFITS OF CONTAINER-GROWN PLANTS
description: WHILE container-grown plants have their drawbacks, their benefits to both nurserymen and consumers far offset their deficiencies. However, attention to the potential problems will provide greater assurance of success.

title: Dropping Income
description: To the Editor:

title: PLANT FEARED TAINTING WATER
description: ISLIP Town officials are demanding that state or Suffolk County agencies shut down a Brentwood-based plating company situated 200 feet from public wells. Town officials say they fear that the community's water supply, which serves 26,000 people, could become contaminated.

title: WRITERS ON THEMSELVES: MAGIC, WORKING SECRETS
description: UNTIL the 20th century it was generally assumed that a writer had said what he had to say in his works. Among the causes of the uneasiness so drolly noticeable in the usual writer-interviewer tussles is the fear, far from unjustified, that the writer's words as distractedly dictated, under random verbal prodding from a stranger, into a tape recorder will be taken as a worthy substitute for the words he or she has with such labor and love and hope of imperishability written down and seen into print. Writers take words seriously -perhaps the last professional class that does - and they struggle to steer their own through the crosswinds of meddling editors and careless typesetters and obtuse and malevolent reviewers into the lap of the ideal reader.

title: Jerusalem
description: To the Editor: We very much enjoyed Sarah Ferrell's article ''In Jerusalem, Gifts With Tradition'' (Travel, June 29), which described the WIZO shop in Jerusalem. As the author mentioned, the profits go toward supporting institutions for the care of children, women and the elderly.

title: U.S. FARM SALES STRAIN AUSTRALIA'S PATIENCE
description: Diplomats and other officials say relations with Australia, one of Washington's closest allies and an anchor for security arrangements in southern Asia, have been sorely strained by subsidized agriculture sales by the United States, which are damaging Australia's economy.

title: Data Update: August 17, 1986
Another Try in El Salvador
description: In six years of civil war in El Salvador, more than 50,000 people have been killed, almost as many as the number of Americans killed in Vietnam. Last week, the Government and the leftist guerrillas agreed to meet again in an effort to get peace talks moving.

title: NEW FROM ALASKA
description: The United States Postal Service will issue a 17-cent dog sled stamp Wednesday in Anchorage, Alaska in a ceremony at the Anchorage Museum of History and Art. It was designed by Lou Nolan of McLean, Va.

title: Serendipity In Newfoundland?
description: The ancient name of Sri Lanka was the Isle of Serendip, the home of three princes always surprised by their good luck. But for the 155 Sri Lankans rescued in two lifeboats off Newfoundland last week, much of the good luck seemed to have been planned and prepaid.

title: MILLIONS IN AFRICA HURT BY DIP IN AID, RELIEF UNITS SAY
description: A drastic drop in private and Goverment contributions to African emergency relief programs threatens millions of people still facing starvation, officials at relief and development agencies report.

title: BLOW TO NARCOTICS TRAFFIC IS SEEN IN PUERTO RICO INDICTMENTS
description: Officials of the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration say the indictments of 62 people here, in Colombia, Venezuela and the United States will have a significant impact on narcotics sold in Puerto Rico, but not on drugs that are transshipped to the United States.

title: AN ANXIOUS QUEST FOR SAFER CAPSULES
description: OVER-THE-COUNTER capsules are not ready for extinction. In fact, they are getting a technological tuck of the chin.

title: The King's Metier
description: To the Editor:

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Home-Lot Prices; Sharp Rises In Most Areas
description: THE cost of land prepared for single-family houses is rising rapidly in most parts of the country and is the leading factor pushing up new-house prices, according to a new survey by the Lomas & Nettleton Company of Dallas.

title: WESTPORT SERIES ENDING WITH A DIVERSE PROGRAM
description: THE Levitt Pavilion for the Performing Arts in Westport, which has been presenting free programs virtually on a daily basis since June, is ending its season with a diverse musical offering.

title: HYBRID TABLETS THAT GO DOWN EASY
description: WHAT do you call a cross between a capsule and a tablet? A caplet, of course. Caplets are elongated tablets that are coated to go down easy, and deliver the drug as speedily as capsules. But unlike capsules, they are difficult to adulterate.

title: VERMONT SCHOOL OFFERS A WELFARE EXIT
description: Beth Miller, dressed casually in jeans, a white shirt and sneakers, sat in her room at the Wolper dormitory at Goddard College, surrounded by textbooks, course guides, a television, the remains of breakfast, a tricycle and a jack-in-the-box.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Jack Nicklaus 2d, the golf champion's oldest son, will make his professional debut at a tournament in Memphis Aug. 28 after winning a sponsor's exemption to enter the event, which his father won in 1965. .c.c. Jack Spikes, a fullback at Texas Christian in the 1950's who later played seven years in the American Football League, pleaded guilty to defrauding a Texas bank in 1983 while serving as its board chairman.

title: U.S.F.L. PLAYERS CROWDING REDSKINS
description: IT isn't very difficult to wander into a National Football League training camp and spot the No. 1 quarterback and, in most cases, the top running back. They seem to inhabit a special space.

title: FOR BRITISH SOCCER FANS, THE VIOLENCE RESURFACES
description: After a year of relative calm, groups of English soccer fans have turned violent again.

title: Sugar Hill Conversion
description: Since 1956, the 236-apartment Hillview Building at West 145th Street and St. Nicholas Avenue has cemented a key corner of Central Harlem.

title: HISTORICAL CHAIRS
description: THE SHAKERS MADE THEM, AND Chippendale, too - children's chairs that are line-for-line copies of grown-up furniture. While some were specifically made for youngsters, others were actually salesmen's samples.

title: HOW TAX REFORM IS RESHAPING DIVORCE
description: ALTHOUGH the tax bill that is being hammered out by the House-Senate conference committee does not deal directly with divorce settlements, tax experts say it will reshape the agreements many couples make.

title: J. R. Veague Weds Winslow Mooney
description: At the Bay Head (N.J.) Chapel yesterday Gay Winslow Mooney, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Stanton Mooney of Bernardsville, N.J., and Middlebrook, Va., was married to John Randolph Veague, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William Everett Veague of Harborside, Me. The Rev. David B. Watermulder, assisted by the Rev. Charles W. Bowman, performed the Presbyterian ceremony.

title: TEXAS CUTS PROPOSED, BUT FISCAL CRISIS STILL HOLDS
description: For 10 days the Texas Legislature has been trying to decide whether to raise taxes or cut services to cover the state's budget deficit, and now a minister has invoked the name of the Lord in favor of higher taxes.

title: Noted With Pleasure
description: The Comfort Zone

title: Verbatim; Testing Freedom
description: 'No other nation has a law like our First Amendment. But then again no other Western bloc country has anything quite like the McCarran-Walter Act.

title: GIANTS WIN, 22-14, AFTER A 17-0 LEAD
description: The Giants, picked by many pro football people to become a championship team this year, acted the part tonight. They built a 17-0 lead against the Green Bay Packers in the second quarter and eased their way to a 22-14 preseason victory.

title: A Disappointment From the Deep
description: Legend has it that when the H.M.S. deBraak, a captured Dutch cutter converted to a speedy two-masted warship by the British Royal Navy, went down in a sudden squall off Delaware nearly two centuries ago, she carried a fortune in gold, silver and jewels.

title: Vietnam Crash Sites Examined by Americans
description: American experts trying to account for Americans reported missing in the Vietnam War investigated sites in Hanoi last week containing wreckage of B-52 bombers, the leader of the United States team said on his return here today.

title: ALISTAIR RAMGOOLAM DOES WELL TO BE UNEASY
description: DIGGING UP THE MOUNTAINS By Neil Bissoondath. 247 pp. New York: Viking. $15.95.

title: Picking a Doctor in an Information Vacuum
description: Years ago in this country we began to take it for granted that air travelers were entitled to all the information available on the safety records of individual airlines. Yet today a prospective hospital patient can still get virtually no information on the safety record of that hospital. A New Yorker can routinely pick up a newspaper to learn whether his choice of restaurant has been cited by the Health Department for dirty kitchens. The same New Yorker, however, has no access to the malpractice records of the doctors into whose hands he may have to place his life.

title: Guadalcanal Convicts Stage a Mass Escape
description: Prisoners lured a guard into a cell by faking illness today, stole the officer's keys and led all but one of the 141 inmates in a mass escape from jail in the capital of the Solomon Islands, the authorities said.

title: MUSIC: TWO CONCERTOS AT MOSTLY MOZART FESTIVAL
description: CONCERTOS survive and thrive not only by their own merits but by reason of their usefulness. Mozart's E flat Horn Concerto (K. 495) and the three others Mozart wrote for the instrument are, for example, oases of credibility for hornists faced with a repertory limited not only in size but in depth.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: BEHIND THE FORBIDDEN DOOR: Travels in Unknown China. By Tiziano Terzani. (Holt, $17.95.) This work grows out of the genre started by Simon Leys, another European and disillusioned Sinologist who finds the Communists have destroyed much of what was grand about China and replaced it with a cultureless totalitarianism.

title:
ART;
NEW CANAAN SHOW OF 120 JURIED WORKS
description: AS far as longevity in the volatile art world goes, the Silvermine Guild for the Arts in New Canaan is scoring some impressive numbers. The Guild itself has been around for more than 60 years and the Art of Northeast U. S. A. juried exhibition there now is in its 37th edition, through August.

title: FROM RUEFUL TO RAUCOUS
description: THE GAVIN EWART SHOW Selected Poems 1939-1985. By Gavin Ewart. 140 pp. Cleveland: Bits Press. Cloth, $14.95. Paper, $8.95. THE YOUNG POBBLE'S GUIDE TO HIS TOES By Gavin Ewart. 142 pp. North Pomfret, Vt.: Hutchinson/David & Charles. Paper, $13.95.

title: VULNERABLE PILLS IN FAIL-SAFE CARTONS
description: BECAUSE no one has found a failsafe way to make any form of pill tamper-proof, drug companies are still trying to make the bottles that contain the pills - and the boxes that contain the bottles - harder to open without detection.

title: ENJOYING A RESPITE FROM FINS, FEATHERS AND FUR
description: WE lost our dog a few weeks ago, and I have assumed a new role in the household. I am our resident witch. I don't want any more pets.

title: PAKISTAN AGAIN SEES SCATTERED PROTESTS
description: Scattered rioting and anti-Government protests continued in Karachi and rural parts of southern Pakistan for the fourth straight day today, while in Lahore 2,000 protesters held a peaceful march through the city.

title: THE USUAL SUSPECTS
description: A LOT OF THE NEWS business amounts to rounding up the usual suspects. Suppose, for instance, somebody sort of official issues a paper saying the government should outlaw pornography.

title: CAREFUL RESTORATION OF A GOULD PLAYHOUSE
description: IT is easy for visitors to overlook the Rose Cottage, nestled among groves of linden and maple trees that shade the expansive lawn at Lyndhurst in Tarrytown. In relation to the massive Greek Revival mansion nearby, once owned by the railroad magnate Jay Gould, the small building, constructed about 1912 as a children's playhouse, seems even tinier than its actual size.

title: TAX TALKS: SIGNALS AND SUSPENSE
description: It ended with handshakes and weary relief. Shortly after 11 P.M., Representative Dan Rostenkowski declared, ''The conference report is agreed to,'' and the long negotiations over tax revision legislation were finally over.

title: Chirac and Hassan Confer
description: Prime Minister Jacques Chirac of France, who has been on vacation in Morocco for a week, was received by King Hassan II on Friday night, the Moroccan news agency reported. The King was also the host of a dinner in Mr. Chirac's honor, the agency said.

title: 40 MOSQUITOS EVERY NIGHT
description: WE mark the seasons, here on the East End, in the ways of our Yankee ancestors and the Native Americans before them.

title: ART BY COLLECTIVE, ART BY CHANCE
description: EVERY Tuesday, nine artists gather at Caroline Chandler's Guilford studio to participate in an unusual lottery. They leave art to chance. Slips of paper are passed around, and each artist matches one to the piece of art she will take home. The next week, the group reconvenes and the procedure is repeated.

title: The Monkey Wrench in Arms Control
description: While the recent exchange of arms proposals between Washington and Moscow may suggest a narrowing of differences in Geneva, it has increased tensions between liberal arms controllers and their opponents in the United States. Arms control advocates such as the SALT II negotiator Paul Warnke suspect the President and his hard-line advisers of scheming to enlist the Soviet Union as an accomplice to the abrogation of the ABM treaty. Anti-Soviet hard-liners such as Seymour Weiss accuse the liberals who have responded positively to Moscow's June 11 proposal of indirectly conspiring with the Soviet Union to kill ''Star Wars.'' In such a situation, both sides, each for its own reasons, might be able to prevent any arms control agreement until the end of Ronald Reagan's Presidency.

title: Police Raid Cocaine Ring Run By Massachusetts Inmates
description: A statewide cocaine ring reportedly run by inmates using pay phones was dismantled in a series of raids at the Massachusetts state prison and nine Boston area locations, officials said today.

title: Car Bomb in Iranian City Kills 11 and Wounds 100
description: A car bomb exploded today in the Shiite Moslem holy city of Qum, killing 11 people and wounding 100, the Teheran radio reported.

title: STATE SEEKS CUT IN PSYCHIATRIC PATIENTS
description: New York State mental health officials said last week they were preparing to reduce by a third the number of patients in the state's 22 psychiatric hospitals over the next 10 years.

title: BUREAUCRACY AND ITS DISCONTENTS
description: AS a candidate for President, Ronald Reagan rarely passed up an opportunity to flay the Government for waste and inefficiency. Now his Administration is proposing a new system of merit pay for the Government's 1.6 million white-collar workers that would, the White House says, give managers a firmer hold on the bureaucracy by basing salaries more on job performance and less on longevity. Proponents say such a system would improve the morale and motivation of civil servants. Critics warn that it could be exploited for political purposes. Constance Horner, director of the United States Office of Personnel Management, the Government's central personnel agency, and Representative Steny H. Hoyer, Democrat of Maryland, a leading defender of Federal workers and their rights, recently discussed the proposal with Robert Pear, a reporter in the Washington bureau of The New York Times. Excerpts from those discussions follow. CONSTANCE HORNER Starting Over

title: Cassie Richardson Is Married
description: Catharine Dalton Richardson, a daughter of Dalton Arnold Andrews of Bethesda, Md., and R. Randolph Richardson of New York, was married yesterday to Charles Richard Macdonald, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Arthur Macdonald of Rumson, N.J. The Rev. Leo Van Winkle, a Roman Catholic priest and headmaster of the Portsmouth Abbey School, of which the bridegroom is a graduate, performed the ceremony at the Holy Cross Church in Rumson.

title: CARNEGIE RADIO DRIVE
description: Marilyn Horne, Yo-Yo Ma and Yehudi Menuhin will be among those interviewed on Sept. 14 on WNCN-FM (104.3) as part of Carnegie-Thon, a daylong radio subsscription drive for the concert hall.

title: 5 FORMER U.S OFFICIALS URGE DELAY IN 'STAR WARS' TESTING
description: Five former senior policy makers have suggested to the Reagan Administration a comprehensive strategy that would include an agreement with the Soviet Union to put off testing of space-based weapons for up to 10 years.

title: Texas In a Tailspin
description: Texas was originally settled by emigrants who found the Tennessee and Kentucky frontiers too tame (''Texas in a Tailspin,'' by Robert Reinhold, July 20). Their ethic of hard work, independence and self-sufficiency animates Texans today.

title: Data Bank: August 17, 1986
TWO COMPANIES THAT WOULDN'T GIVE UP
description: A BELIEF that bigger is better finishes off thousands of companies every year. According to the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation, a record 57,067 businesses in the country failed last year; the majority of them were victims of overexpansion and undercapitalization. But some companies refused to give up. The Novo Corporation of Scarsdale and Universal Voltronics of Mount Kisco, both facing disaster at one point, have managed to make strong comebacks by changing directions several times before becoming re-established.

title: IN LIGHT AND PLAY, A STREET IS REBORN
description: IT is quiet. In midevening, it is already dark in the houses. There is a TV's glow coming from one room, faint light through blinds in one or two more. But most rooms are dark, shades or blinds drawn.

title: Why CBS Decided, After 3 Decades, to Kill the 'Morning News.'
description: In the fall of 1981, William Leonard, then the president of CBS News, thought he had finally solved the network's most vexing and abiding news problem, the ''CBS Morning News.'' Mr. Leonard devised an anchor team of Charles Kuralt, the popular and folksy correspondent, and the promising young reporter Diane Sawyer, and then waited for the ratings to mount. They didn't. ''I failed miserably, just like all the rest of them,'' he recalls. ''We just don't seem to be able to do that. It's a mystery.''

title: Georgia Baylor Becomes Bride
description: The marriage of Pascale Florence Georgia Baylor, a third-year student at the University of Michigan Law School, to Richard Stockton Bullitt, an associate in the New York law firm of Fish & Neave, took place yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity in Lincoln, Neb. The Rev. Stephen Mues performed the ceremony.

title: A SERIOUS FARRAH FAWCETT TAKES CONTROL IN 'EXTREMITIES'
description: Physical beauty can be a trap as well as a gift, as Farrah Fawcett would be the first to testify. In 1976, Miss Fawcett burst into prominence as the comely star of the television series ''Charlie's Angels'' and America's most popular poster girl. In the years since that series, which aired on ABC from 1976 to 1981, made her an instant celebrity, Miss Fawcett, now 39 years old, has struggled to establish herself as a serious actress as well as a pretty face. But producers refused to consider her for demanding roles.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: YOU SAY YOU WANT A REVOLUTION: Rock Music in American Culture. By Robert G. Pielke. (Nelson-Hall, $24.95.) Rock-and-roll carries a lot of extra baggage in this book, which takes its title from a Beatles song.

title: 'Grant-in-Aid' Is a Key Term
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: U.S. SAYS SOVIET IS CARRYING OUT MAJOR NAVAL EXERCISES IN PACIFIC
description: The Soviet Union's Pacific Fleet has been engaged in the last week in one of the largest exercises it has conducted in recent years, United States Navy officials said.

title: BEST SELLERS: AUGUST 17, 1986
description: Weeks This Last on Week Fiction Week List 1 3 RED STORM RISING, by Tom Clancy. 2 3 (Putnam, $19.95.) Without using nuclear weapons, the West staves off the Russians in World War III. 2 WANDERLUST, by Danielle Steel. 1 5 (Delacorte, $17.95.) A rich orphan comes of age while she travels the world. 3 A MATTER OF HONOR, by Jeffrey 3 7 Archer. (Linden/Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) Nazi intrigue and a family secret that could change the course of the cold war. 4 LAST OF THE BREED, by Louis L'Amour. 4 10 (Bantam, $17.95.) The adventures of a United States Air Force major in Siberia. 5 ACT OF WILL, by Barbara Taylor 5 9 Bradford. (Doubleday, $17.95.) Three generations of talented, ambitious women in England and New York. 6 THE BOURNE SUPREMACY, by Robert 8 24 Ludlum. (Random House, $19.95.) The hero of ''The Bourne Identity'' foils a plot to seize Hong Kong and bring China into conflict with the West. 7 THE GARDEN OF EDEN, by Ernest 6 12 Hemingway. (Scribners, $18.95.) A writer and his wife have affairs with the same woman on their European honeymoon; Hemingway's last unpublished novel. 8 THE GOOD MOTHER, by Sue Miller. 11 14 (Harper & Row, $17.95.) A woman's attachment to her daughter presents her with a dilemma. 9 I'LL TAKE MANHATTAN, by Judith 9 17 Krantz. (Crown, $18.95.) Rich, beautiful Maxi Amberville conquers the world of magazine publishing. 10 THE EIGHTH COMMANDMENT, by Lawrence 7 11 Sanders. (Putnam, $18.95.) The theft of a priceless Greek coin brings a New York dynasty's scandals to light. 11 A PERFECT SPY, by John le 10 17 Carre. (Knopf, $18.95.) The tale of Magnus Pym, a British secret agent, and his father, Rick, a flamboyant con man. 12 THE MAMMOTH HUNTERS, by Jean M. Auel. 12 39 (Crown, $19.95.) Ayla continues her adventures in the prehistoric world. 13 AN ALIEN AFFAIR, by L. Ron 1 Hubbard. (Bridge Publications, $18.95.) Extraterrestrials stage disasters from Turkey to the Empire State Building. 14 SUSPECTS, by William J. Caunitz. 1 (Crown, $17.95.) Intrigue, murder and revenge in the world New York City police call home. 15 BARRIER ISLAND, by John D. MacDonald. 13 9 (Knopf, $16.95.) One man sets out to thwart a multimillion-dollar Mississippi land swindle. Nonfiction 1 FATHERHOOD, by Bill Cosby. 1 15 (Dolphin/ Doubleday, $14.95.) Anecdotes and ruminations from the television star and father of five. 2 YOU'RE ONLY OLD ONCE! by Dr. 2 23 Seuss. (Random House, $9.95.) A checkup at the Golden Years Clinic in pictures and rhyme; the first Dr. Seuss book for adults. 3 ''AND SO IT GOES,'' by Linda 5 10 Ellerbee. (Putnam, $16.95.) Television journalism as experienced by a former NBC correspondent. 4 JAMES HERRIOT'S DOG STORIES, by James 4 14 Herriot. (St. Martin's, $19.95.) Fifty tales by a Yorkshire veterinarian about his favorite animal. 5 ROCK HUDSON: His Story, by Rock 3 8 Hudson and Sara Davidson. (Morrow, $16.95.) An account of the actor's public and private life written with his cooperation. 6 FORD: The Men and the Machine, 6 9 by Robert Lacey. (Little, Brown, $24.95.) A history of the automobile company and the dynasty founded by Henry Ford. 7 NECESSARY LOSSES, by Judith Viorst. 8 17 (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) Life is a series of losses, the author argues, and we must confront them to grow. 8 A CAST OF KILLERS, 7 5 by Sidney D. Kirkpatrick. (Dutton, $17.95.) The investigation, by the film director King Vidor, of a celebrated Hollywood murder case. 9 WHEN ALL YOU'VE EVER WANTED ISN'T 9 18 ENOUGH, by Harold S. Kushner. (Summit, $16.95.) A rabbi on ''the search for a life that matters.'' 10 MURROW: His Life and Times, by A. 10 5 M. Sperber. (Freundlich/Kampmann, $25.) The career of the CBS newscaster. 11 THE MAN WHO MISTOOK HIS WIFE 11 20 FOR A HAT, by Oliver Sacks. (Summit, $15.95.) Strange neurological disabilities. 12 THE UNDERGROUND EMPIRE, by James 12 5 Mills. (Doubleday, $22.95.) How the global war on the drug trade is being waged - and is being stymied by diplomats and bureaucrats. 13 IN SEARCH OF THE TROJAN 15 7 WAR, by Michael Wood. (Facts on File, $22.95.) Archeologists' search for the truth behind the Homeric legend; tie-in to a PBS series. 14 BUS 9 TO PARADISE, by Leo 13 27 Buscaglia. (Slack/ Morrow, $16.95.) Another trip with the ebullient advocate of the virtues of love. 15 A LIGHT IN THE ATTIC, by Shel 14 170 Silverstein. (Harper & Row, $13.50.) Light verse, with drawings by the author. And Bear in Mind

title: 5-YEAR TERM FOR BAD ADVICE
description: The author of the book ''Pay No Income Taxes Without Going To Jail'' was sentenced today to five years in prison for fraud for helping clients cheat on their income taxes. The author, Phillip Fry, 42, years old, former owner of the Tax Information Center, a tax and financial investment service in New Concord, was sentenced in Federal District Court. Mr. Fry pleaded guilty June 30.

title: AQUINO IS PULLING UP THE ESTABLISHMENT BY ITS ROOTS
description: IN the central Philippines town of Cadiz, protesters barred a newly designated mayor from entering the town hall last week. In three towns just north of Manila, nobody seemed to be in charge; two mayors claimed the office in each of them. In the little town of Bongao, one of the most southerly in the archipelago, the military was negotiating with a reluctant mayor, attempting to persuade him to give way for his replacement.

title: STATE AUTO INSURER SEEKS HIGHER PREMIUMS
description: THE state agency established to insure nearly half of New Jersey's motorists insists it is going broke and will need a major premium increase - perhaps as much as $200 a year - within two years to avoid bankruptcy.

title: TAKING OVER
description: THE CORPORATE TAKEOVER CAMPAIGNS OF THE 1980's continue to roll. Seductive as gold strikes, they are attracting even the most conservative financial institutions and investors. The climate of rumor and greed they have created has spawned the largest insider-trading scandal in Wall Street's history: the ever-widening Securities and Exchange Commission investigation that resulted in the indictment of Dennis Levine and others in a multimillion-dollar conspiracy and cast a cloud over the ethics of the world's financial center.

title: Miss Austen, Lawyer, Wed
description: The marriage of Leslie Marie Austen and Willis Gilman Parsons 3d, who graduated with the class of '83 from Amherst College, took place yesterday in the Chapel of the Blessed Trinity at Boston College in Newton Centre, Mass. Msgr. Russell H. Davis performed the Roman Catholic ceremony.

title: GERMAN CAPTAIN DENIES ROLE IN TAMILS' JOURNEY
description: The West German captain of a coastal freighter accused of illegally smuggling 155 Sri Lankan refugees to the Canadian coast was reported today to have denied involvement in the affair and said he was sailing back to West Germany to clear his name.

title: And Take a Number
description: There is no question what the hot issues are on Capitol Hill just now. When a reporter asked to talk to a House member, his receptionist replied without further guidance: ''Is this on drugs or taxes?''

title: ALL THE PREACHER'S WOMEN
description: ALMOST MIDNIGHT By Don Belton. 213 pp. New York: Beech Tree Books/ William Morrow & Company. $14.95.

title: BIGGER AND WORSE
description: HOW REAL IS THE FEDERAL DEFICIT? By Robert Eisner. 240 pp. New York: The Free Press. $17.95. THE DEFICITS How Big? How Long? How Dangerous? By Daniel Bell and Lester Thurow. 142 pp. New York: New York University Press. $15.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: BLENDING THE INGREDIENTS OF YOUTH SPORTS PROGRAMS
description: What happened of the quarter-billion-dollar surplus from the 1984 Olympic Games?

title: ARATA ISOZAKI: FROM JAPAN, A NEW WAVE OF INTERNATIONAL ARCHITECTS
description: ON A RECENT AFTERNOON, the Okanoyama Graphic Art Museum in Nishiwaki, Japan, was stage and backdrop for an unusual outdoor fashion show - a show that the building itself, designed by the Tokyo architect Arata Isozaki, managed to steal. A group of five traditional Japanese drummers, wearing kimonos and headbands, called the program to order with fast, warring beats. Then a poky, forgetful one-man band took over in a Ringo Starr way, drumming when he remembered, as fashion models in billowing silk robes by the internationally known designer Issey Miyake sailed between the thick concrete columns of the museum's classical front portico.

title: BANKS HEAT UP CREDIT-CARD WAR

description: Responding to fear of AIDS, entrepreneurs are setting up commercial blood banks that freeze and store a supply of the customer's own blood for a fee.

Schaefer of Barrington, R.I. The Rev. Francis Lewis, a United Methodist minister, performed the ceremony at the Princeton University Chapel. The bride is an alumna of Smith College. Mr. Schaefer graduated from Princeton.

description: Lisa Dove Moreschi, a daughter of Drs. Patricia R. Moreschi and Anthony F. Moreschi of Wayne, Pa., was married there yesterday to Andrew Owen Reichlin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Reichlin of Shippensburg, Pa.

description: THE PHYSICIAN. By Noah Gordon. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) Populated by engaging characters, rich in incident and vivid in historical detail, the new novel by the author of ''The Rabbi'' is a pleasure.

title: TEACHERS ARE EXCUSED IN DRUG TEST RULING
description: WHEN teachers in the Patchogue-Medford school district on Long Island were informed last year that they would have to take drug tests before they would be considered for tenure, they headed not to the school nurse, as ordered, but to court.

title: Jacqueline Leung Planning to Wed Andrew Y. S. Liu
description: Jacqueline Alee Leung, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry C. H. Leung of Hong Kong, and Andrew Yiu Sing Liu, a vice president in the mergers and acquisitions department at Morgan Stanley & Company in New York, plan to be married in Hong Kong Aug. 27.

title: SPORTS TODAY

title: MALPRACTICE CRISIS
description: Dr. Eisenberg is not alone in his personal and professional reactions to this experience.

title: POSTINGS: Lafayette Square; Bridgeport: A New Look
description: To think of Bridgeport was, until recently, to imagine a grimy blue-collar city that had wilted as the rest of Fairfield County boomed.

title: 'ME AND MY GIRL' IS A NOSEGAY OF NOSTALGIA
description: The long-lost Lord Hareford, the new heir to Hareford Hall, is about to arrive at his elegant estate, and his snobbish relatives are assembled in anticipation. As ''Me and My Girl,'' a revived 1930's musical, opens, everyone is wondering what the heir will be like. When he enters in the person of the actor Robert Lindsay, he is the ultimate Cockney. He looks as if he had been blown in by the wind (the wind of good fortune, among other zephyrs), toddling at a tilt, like a rowboat rocking in a high tide. A bowler rakishly covers his brow, and, as we soon discover, the bowler is his brow. That hat is as integral to his face as are his eyes and mouth, both of which are also in perpetual comic motion. Tipping his hat from the rear of the brim, Mr. Lindsay glances around him and wonders what on earth the opulence has to do with him.

title: ROUGH SAILING FOR NEW FERRY
description: MOST operators of Long Island Sound ferries cite the rainy weather this summer as their only real difficulty. But Paul Forsberg of Montauk, owner of a ferry that started trips between Montauk and Groton, Conn., last month, has other problems, too.

title: YEARS IN U.S. GUIDE A THAI IN DEMOCRACY
description: The town of Rushford, Minn., the former Vice Presidential candidate Geraldine Ferraro and a Harvard graduation gown all played a part in sending Surin Pitsuwan to Parliament here.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: TUG OF WAR: The Battle for Italy, 1943-1945. By Dominick Graham and Shelford Bidwell. (St. Martin's, $24.95.) The tug of war in the title of this fine military history is not, as one might suppose, between Allied and German forces, but among rival Allied commanders, primarily the British and Americans. Dominick Graham, a professor of history at the University of New Brunswick, Canada, and Shelford Bidwell, author of ''The Chindit War'' and other historical works, take both a psychological and a tactical look at a campaign ''full of examples of the pitfalls of coalitionary war, and [that] offers an insight into Anglo-American relations at a period fraught with mutual dislike and suspicion.'' American and British commanders, the authors write, ''despised each other for lack of drive, attacking in insufficient strength and lack of appetite for combat.'' Even where animosity was absent, personality played a part: Mr. Graham and Mr. Bidwell describe Dwight Eisenhower, commander of Allied forces in Europe, and Sir Harold Alexander, the British commander in chief, as ''easy-going'' and ''malleable,'' and write that ''neither could make a military plan and stick to it through political and military vicissitudes.'' The book is a triumph of organization; the numerous threads of suspicion, intuition, logic and military necessity are displayed clearly, and their countless points of intersection analyzed. The result is a remarkably lucid account of a complicated campaign. The war in Italy, begun with the vain hope of an uprising by the Italian Army against the Germans, saw, among other things, a sit-down strike by British troops, was hampered at many points by weather and geography as much as by the enemy, and throughout was viewed by the Allied governments as little more than a diversion; the war in the Pacific and the invasion of Europe were the important things.

title: Keeping Tenants Informed
description: THE conversion of an industrial loft building to residential occupancy often necessitates extensive reconstruction work to bring it into conformity with residential building codes. In many instances, such work can expose tenants to considerable expense and disruption; elevator service may be interrupted, for instance, and utilities may be shut off for hours at a time.

title: GARBARGE WAS COLLETED WITH PERSONAL TOUCH
description: ANY fool knows that times change, that history has a way of casting aside old verities, customs, dearly held beliefs. The collection of garbage in the suburbs is no exception to the caprice of history.

title: LINGERIE THAT REVELS IN FANTASY
description: FEW young designers can afford their own showrooms. So some share them and others sell out of their apartments. Not Sue Ekahn. She wheels her wares up Seventh Avenue and down department store aisles in a blue-rubber-handled shopping cart.

title: HELPING PARKINSON'S FAMILIES COPE
description: JAMES FORTE of North Bellmore concentrates on his handwriting, forcing his fingers to make bold, full strokes in his notebook. He mastered penmanship many years ago, but now, in middle age, he must think about every movement as he struggles to regain his skills.

title: Pop Music
description: The protest song has changed its tune since the 1980's. It is less topical and more impressionistic, less self-righteous and more willing to use the possibilities of rock and pop.

description: The Soviet Union named Vasily G. Zakharov, a Communist Party propaganda specialist who is an economist by training, as the country's new Minister of Culture today.

In approving a replacement for the ill-fated Challenger, President Reagan said private industry would henceforth launch commercial satellites, leaving NASA to concentrate on national security payloads.

title: LOVE WAS ALL THEY KNEW TO CALL IT
description: AND VENUS IS BLUE By Mary Hood. 293 pp. New York: Ticknor & Fields. $15.95.

description: A 2-year-old girl lay barely conscious on a tattered cloth, her appendix ruptured.

description: A nuclear power plant in New Jersey was built and licensed to operate before its owners and regulators discovered that an important safety system had been designed and installed backwards, Federal officials and company spokesmen reported.

Steyer of New York, took place yesterday in the Memorial Church at Stanford University. The Rev. Richard Thayer, a Presbyterian minister, and Rabbi Charles Familant performed the ceremony.

description: At least one state, Arizona, is not waiting for Congress to limit the amount of money that political action committees representing corporations and labor unions can give to candidates for their campaigns. In fact, advocates of campaign law changes in Arizona are not waiting for their own Legislature either.

description: Christiana Coggins, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Cecil Hammond Coggins of Auburndale, Mass., was married yesterday to Richard David Franklin, the son of Mary Frances Hodge Franklin of Arlington, Tex., and Richard P. Franklin of New Castle, Ind. The Rev. Ellis Johnson, a Methodist minister, performed the ceremony at the Memorial Church at Harvard University in Cambridge, Mass.

title: ISLAND OF BALANCE AND REINCARNATION
description: The island of Bali is not a position, but a direction, a compass of the soul. A Balinese must know where north is so that he can point his head that way when he sleeps. Not to align himself to the center of his world, the sacred volcano called Gunung Agung, is to become ill, dizzy, nauseous, paling. Toward the south the feet must point, toward the sea that surrounds Bali, where temples such as Pura Tanah Lot stand as guardians of the land. To lie in reverse is to be like a dead man.

title: AN AMPLIFIER THAT ELIMINATES NEGATIVE FEEDBACK
description: Audio has its seasonal aspects, and late August is the time when new components first appear in the shops, there to await the return of high-fi fans from their summer vacations. A sampling of these early arrivals confirms that audio has reached a developmental plateau so high that basic advances are becoming rare. There are lots of clever innovations but few bold departures. Even so, one development transcends mere gadgeteering: It is the elimination of a design principle known as negative feedback.

How does one book and what are the accommodations? - J. A. B., Titusville, Fla. Reservations can be made only by travel agents - by calling 718-470-0311 or, from out of state, 800-645-5066); individuals needing information should call 516-625-0350.

I had not thought of the enigmatic Mr. Cliburn for a long time and perhaps you had not, either. In fact, there must be many young music listeners to whom Van Cliburn is merely a name in American history, like John Philip Sousa.

THE REGION;
In New York, Trying Harder To Be No. 2
description: Some powerful forces - Abraham Hirschfeld's money and Mario Cuomo's will - have been brought to bear in the contest for the relatively powerless position of Lieutenant Governor.

title: SOME SECOND THOUGHTS ABOUT NO-FAULT DIVORCE
description: WHEN California adopted the nation's first no-fault divorce law in 1970, Lenore J. Weitzman recalls that she, like many other women, was ''enthralled.'' Here was a way to avoid long, messy trials and acrimonious battles over who was to blame for a failed marriage. The partners became equals under the law. Eventually all states except North Dakota enacted some kind of no-fault law. The results were dramatic, but unexpected. Within the first year after divorce, women and children suffered a 73 percent drop in their standard of living, while men experienced a 42 percent rise, Dr. Weitzman reported in ''Divorce Revolution: The Unintended Social and Economic Consequences for Women and Children in America,'' a study of the effects of the California law. Today, legislators, women's groups and others are citing these and similar statistics in their efforts to modify the laws. Earlier this month, Governor Cuomo signed two amendments to New York's ''equitable distribution law.'' Dr. Weitzman and other experts last week discussed the economic consequences of divorce at the American Bar Association's annual meeting in New York. Excerpts follow.

So will entertainment and sports figures, press people, professional people, merchants and farmers. Some 700 ''Crocodiles'' - members of the group that calls itself the nation's oldest eating club - will observe the club's 111th anniversary Thursday afternoon with a traditional sheep roast at Hershey Lake Compounce in Bristol.

title: COMPOSING FOR FILMS ON THE SPOT
description: LOUISE, blind and begging, is taken away by a wicked old woman. Anna, an unwed mother whose child has died, is sent into a blizzard, stumbles in the snow, faints onto the ice floes and is about to tumble over a waterfall. Charlie, near starvation, cooks and elegantly begins to eat a meal consisting of his shoe.

title: TRUMP WITHDRAWAL LAID TO IMPATIENCE
description: WHEN Donald Trump, the New York real estate magnate and chief executive officer of two casinos, withdrew from the Atlantic City Casino Association last week, say industry sources and analysts, it was because ''one aspect'' of the association's business had not been accomplished ''yesterday.''

title: CUOMO'S SEARCHING FOR A ROLE THAT FITS
description: IN trying to find his place in the national political arena, Governor Cuomo at times seems unsure which role he wants to assume.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: EUGENE O'NEILL ON FILM A biographical film about Eugene O'Neill and his work, created for public television and to be shown on WNET-TV next month, will be previewed in Westport at 8:30 P.M. on Friday in the Town Hall Auditorium.

title: U.S. WILL REPAY AIDES IN RIGHT SUITS
description: Under a new policy, Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d has authorized the Government to reimburse Justice Department employees who are successfully sued for damages caused by their violation of constitutional rights.

title: Sandy Pomeroy Weds John Codd
description: At St. Augustine's Roman Catholic Church in Larchmont, N.Y., yesterday Alexandra Mary Pomeroy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Maull Pomeroy 3d of South Bend, Ind., was married to John Mahoney Codd, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin J. Codd of Richmondtown, S.I. The Rev. Ronald Anton performed the ceremony.

title: ANOTHER DEPARTURE STUNS BANKAMERICA
description: Charles R. Schwab resigned as a director of BankAmerica. Although the man who made discount brokerage a household phenomenon said he wanted to devote full time to outside activities, analysts suspected he left out of frustration. They said Mr. Schwab had pushed hard to have the bank solve its problems quickly. And they believe that Mr. Schwab's resignation, which followed by two days that of the bank's chief financial officer, will force BankAmerica to act. Mr. Schwab's resignation, meanwhile, will allow him to concentrate on running the discount brokerage he sold to BankAmerica in 1983, and that he wants to buy back.

title: CORRECTION
description: In a letter to the editor on June 22 an incorrect address was given for getting information on the music festival at Schloss Neuschwanstein in Bavaria. The correct address is Konzertgesellschaft Neuschwanstein, Verkehrsamt Rathaus, Munchnerstrasse 2, 8959 Schwangau, West Germany (telephone 81051). This year, concerts are being held at Schloss Neuschwanstein Sept. 1 to 6.

title: HIS SCULPTURE TRANSFORMS SCRAP INTO STEEL POEMS
description: To go round the retrospective of sculptures by John Chamberlain that can be seen through Oct. 5 at the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles is a remarkable experience. We see what we expect to see - the big, shiny, often brightly painted metal structures that go through the whole gamut of sculptural activity. They stand upright, like totems. They sit low on the ground - as low, in fact, as gondolas sit in the waters of the Venetian lagoon. They hang on the wall, like reliefs. They have the multiple thrust of Baroque sculpture. Once or twice they have a winged look, as if they were fragments of Greek sculpture, and just occasionally they can be read as human figures, or pairs of figures. There are times, too, when they look like Abstract Expressionist paintings that have gone on the rampage in the third dimension. Rare will be the visitor who does not find some of this surprising.

title: New York Relic Travels South
description: ''I F this ship is not saved for New York City, it will go to Virginia,'' Mayor Koch warned at a news conference in December 1984. ''I don't want people to come up later and say, 'Why didn't you tell us?'c''

description: ''It's like the tremors before the earthquake.'' - Joseph T. Arensio 2d, Birr Wilson analyst, on the changes at BankAmerica.

title: Jackson Tells Angola He Hopes for U.S. Ties
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson said today that he hoped that the conflict in Angola would end and that the United States and Angola would establish diplomatic relations, Angola's official press agency said.

description: THREE to six times a week, heart surgeons at Children's Hospital of New Jersey confront nature's mistakes and try to fix them.

He gets up from the Baldwin grand piano at the Club House in Port Washington, closes and locks the lid with a big iron clamp, a guard against gleeful amateurs knocking it out of tune while he isn't there.

William Bradford Reynolds, the Assistant Attorney General for Civil Rights, so asserted again last week during the American Bar Association's annual meeting.

description: Brenda Hale Kelley, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel F. Kelley Jr. of San Juan, P.R., and Manchester, Vt., was married yesterday to Mark Stephen Squillace, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen S. Squillace of St. Clair Shores, Mich. Justice of the Peace Martha Pelton performed the ceremony at the Bennington County Courthouse in Manchester.

description: THE HEADHUNTERS. By John A. Byrne. (Macmillan, $19.95.) In this book, executive recruiters - commonly known as headhunters - stalk their prey in the corporate jungle.

title: FOR BITING FLAVOR, TEXANS GO FOR JERKY
description: In some parts of the world, meat that has been salted and dried over smoke or in the sun has evolved into a delicacy of some distinction. Bundnerfleisch, from the Swiss canton of Grisons, has traveled to the great tables of the world, where it is presented in paper-thin slices moistened with olive oil. There is a different but delicious alternative, called jerky, in the hill country around Austin, Tex.

title: MEXICO'S DRUG EFFORT WILL ALSO BE HOME-GROWN
description: IT was no coincidence that while President Miguel de la Madrid of Mexico discussed drug trafficking with President Reagan in Washington last week, the Mexican Attorney General's office was launching a new anti-drug campaign. Twenty-five helicopters and a large crop-dusting plane - financed with American aid -took to the skies over four northern Mexican states in search of marijuana soon to be harvested for shipment across the border. The spraying is to last through February, so it will catch the 1987 opium poppy season.

title: HOSTILE TAKEOVERS: ANOTHER VIEW
description: DO shareholders own the company?

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: JOSEPH AND THE OLD MAN. By Christopher Davis. (St. Martin's, $13.95.) This first novel concerns the tender homosexual relationship between an older, Pulitzer Prize-winning novelist, called the ''old man,'' and a younger writer, Joe.

title: Weighing Books on Financial Scales
description: DURING a party at New York's Parker Meridian Hotel in 1984, which Bantam Books gave to celebrate the publication of Lee A. Iacocca's autobiography, three men huddled in a corner, carrying on a spirited discussion about scientific esoterica. One of the men was a former rocket engineer; one was Bantam author Alvin Toffler, and the third was Alberto Vitale, then Bantam's co-chief executive officer.

title: SUNNY (KIR) VS. SADIE (CHAMPAGNE)
description: REGRETS ONLY By Sally Quinn. 556 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $18.95.

title: Southern Miss. Fullback Dies
description: A Southern Mississippi fullback, Eric Sorey of Campbellton, Fla., collapsed with leg cramps this morning during practice and died several hours later at Methodist Hospital here.

title: The Lincoln-Botha Debate
description: Speaking to his party faithful in South Africa last week, President P. W. Botha flaunted this quotation from Abraham Lincoln: ''There is a physical difference between the white and black races . . . I am in favor of the race to which I belong having the superior position . . . I am not, nor have I ever been, in favor of making voters or jurors of Negroes, nor of qualifying them to hold office, nor to intermarry with white people.''

title: NEW HOME FOR PEABODY'S ASIAN ART
description: Salem's Peabody Museum, which calls itself the oldest continuously operating museum in the nation, is adding another first to its list.

title: Roy Cohn's Descent on the Libraries of Europe; A Legacy of Hate
description: To the Editor:

title: FIRST FAMILIES
description: When the Purdy, Bailey and Van Tassell families get together for a picnic in Somers next month, it will be just like old times. The names will be the same, the century different.

title: HELGA'S WORLD: THE SECRET ART OF ANDREW WYETH
description: ''H e's a secret person,'' says Betsy Wyeth. ''He still is not telling me where he painted the Helga pictures, or where he stored them, or anything.'' Yet this, Mrs. Wyeth says, is entirely in keeping with her husband's approach to his art, and to his daily routine as she has known it during the 46 years of their marriage. Each day, she says, Andrew Wyeth goes out to paint without telling her where he will be.

title: Leaders' Compromise Eliminates Deductions for State Sales Taxes
description: The bill approved tonight by the tax conference committee was based on compromises on hundreds of issues reached by Representative Dan Rostenkowski and Senator Bob Packwood, among them the repeal of deductions for state and local sales taxes and sharply limited deductions for individual retirement accounts.

title: Pakistan Jails Benazir Bhutto
description: Benazir Bhutto said she was testing President Zia ul-Haq's contention ''that democracy exists'' in Pakistan, but the authorities saw it differently. Eluding a police blockade, the 33-year-old opposition leader made a brief speech last week in defiance of the Government's ban on independence day rallies.

title: STUDENTS AGAINST THE REICH
description: SHATTERING THE GERMAN NIGHT The Story of the White Rose. By Annette E. Dumbach and Jud Newborn. 259 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $17.95.

title: IRISH WORKERS SERVE EAST END
description: EVERY summer, the East End has the same problem finding enough workers to meet the demands of the tourist season. This year a contingent of 500 young people from Ireland, most of them women, have answered the call.

title: Austrian Alps
description: To the Editor: I enjoyed Jonathan Hurdle's excellent article ''Hiking Hut to Hut in Austria'' (Travel, May 11). Coincidentally, our New York Times arrived just after we spent several days hiking in the Karwendel and equally beautiful (but smaller) Wilder Kaiser range of the Austrian Alps, to the east near Kitzbuhel. Mr. Hurdle has nicely described the pleasures of hut-hopping, something no physically active visitor to Europe should miss.

title: Bennett Machtiger Weds Susan Vary
description: Susan Marie Vary, the daughter of Dr. Eva Vary of Buffalo and the late Jeno Szentvari of Budapest, was married yesterday to Bennett Rand Machtiger, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Machtiger of Pittsburgh. Lois Kellerman, a leader of the New York Ethical Culture Society, performed the ceremony at the Burden Mansion in Manhattan.

title: IN NORWAY, A JEW'S STORY IS BEST SELLER
description: In Norway, a country with barely 1,000 Jews, the story of a young Jew growing up near Oslo during the Nazi occupation has become the nation's best seller and one of the most popular books in Norwegian history.

title: Proposal for McCallum
description: The Secretary of the Navy reportedly favors the idea. The chief of naval operations has his doubts. Other high-ranking officers are flatly opposed.

title: PRESIDENT'S ORDER ON SPACE SHUTTLE CALLED ERA'S END
description: The Administration's order that the space agency get out of the commercial launching business marks the final abandonment of the Government's two-decade struggle to run a space shuttle service that would pay for itself, aerospace experts say.

title: THE BRITAIN THAT BRITTEN CALLED HOME
description: The Suffolk coast is Britten's Britain.

title: An Era Ends At Girls' School
description: THE last remaining single-sex public school in New York City -Washington Irving - was ordered last summer to open its doors to boys by September 1986. That upset the 2,500-member student body as well as some teachers and alumnae.

title: Yacht Sponsorship Uncertain
description: The six American challengers for the America's Cup are clamoring for corporate support to meet their multimillion-dollar budget requirements. But their inability to form a united front has proved costly.

title: AFTER YOU'VE SEEN PAREE -- MONTANA
description: From the tall window of my beamed 17th-century Paris apartment, I survey two busy sidewalk restaurants, the lofty trees and bookstalls edging the Seine and the lacy spires of Notre Dame cathedral.

title: FINLAND'S FINEST
description: SUMMER IN FINLAND IS A LONG MIRACLE, a time to celebrate the sun shining incongruously at midnight after a winter of dark. In July and August, Finns on vacation at one of the country's many thousands of lakes stage crayfish parties at dusk, gathering at long tables set with bright red napkins and frosted bottles of schnapps. Piles of fresh dill fronds infuse the air with the giddy odor of herbs, subtly complementing the succulent crayfish.

title: Stafford and Pell, the New England Team
description: In 1981 a longstanding committee relationship between Senator Robert T. Stafford, Republican of Vermont, and Claiborne Pell, Democrat of Rhode Island, was turned upside down.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article about cruises in this section on Aug. 3 misstated the current status of the Queen Elizabeth 2. The ship will go into drydock on Oct. 26, following its Oct. 20 crossing from New York to Southampton.

title: Jesuit Priest Resigns Over a Questionnaire
description: A Roman Catholic priest has resigned from the Jesuit order rather than obey a command to destroy his survey of United States Catholic bishops on the issues of celibacy and women as priests.

title: Dr. W. Pepper Constable, 72, Ex-Official of Jersey Hospital
description: Dr. W. Pepper Constable, a physician and a former chief of medicine at the Princeton (N.J.) Medical Center, drowned while swimming Wednesday near his summer home on Nantucket, Mass. He was 72 years old and also lived in Princeton.

title: Carey Mack Is Bride Of Douglas J. Weber
description: Carey Underwood Mack, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Duncan Mack of Ringoes, N.J., and Chatham, Mass., was married yesterday to Douglas John Weber, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Reuel Weber of Bethel, Conn. Thomas R. Pennypacker 2d, vice chairman of the Board of Selectmen of Chatham, performed the ceremony at the Mack home there.

title: 17 SENATORS TIED TO SOUTH AFRICA STOCK HOLDINGS
description: Seventeen senators, 14 of whom voted Friday for new economic sanctions against South Africa, owned stock in 1985 in American corporations that do business with that country, according to their financial disclosure forms for last year and a list of American companies in South Africa.

title: AUCTION FINANCES SEARCH FOR MARCOS FORTUNE
description: From a Steinway concert grand piano that sold for $6,000 more than its value to an artificial plant that went for $500 more than the sellers had listed in the brochure, ''everything'' from the Manhattan town house formerly occupied by Ferdinand E. and Imelda Marcos was being snapped up last night on the second day of an auction being held by the Philippine Government.

title: TIGERS' 21 HITS ROUT RED SOX
description: Lou Whitaker led a 21-hit attack with a double and two singles, and Larry Herndon hit a pinch-hit grand slam in a five-run eighth inning today, helping Jack Morris and the Detroit Tigers to a 12-6 triumph over the Boston Red Sox.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: WHEN most people think of shipwrecks, says Robert W. Garner of Pompton Plains, ''they envision the crystal-blue waters of the Caribbean or the Florida Gulf and think of wrecks that are recognizable as ships, as if they had sunk yesterday.''

title: HONOR THY FATHER, AND THEN SOME
description: FREUD AND HIS FATHER By Marianne Krull. Translated by Arnold J. Pomerans. Illustrated. 294 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $18.95.

title: Katharine Polk Married on L.I.
description: At St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church in Locust Valley, L.I., yesterday Katharine Holliday Polk, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank L. Polk Jr. of Glen Head, L.I., was married to William W. Catacosinos, a son of Dr. and Mrs. William Catacosinos of Mill Neck, L.I. The Rev. Charles Newbery performed the ceremony.

title: LEARNING THE ABC'S -- AS WELL AS THE XYZ'S -- OF FLYING
description: The language of domestic air travel can often sound foreign to a flier. Airlines and travel agents use special words, phrases and abbreviations to describe routine matters, and even frequent fliers may not understand, or may misunderstand, some of the jargon. Following is a brief glossary of some of the terms that cause the most confusion.

title: Elizabeth Rahr Haffrenreffer Married To Oliver Scholle Jr. in Massachusetts
description: Elizabeth Rahr Haffrenreffer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore C. Haffrenreffer Jr. of Chestnut Hill, Mass., was married there yesterday to Oliver Coleman Scholle Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Scholle of Hillsborough, Calif. The Rev. Donald E. Bitsburger performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer.

title: MALPRACTICE CRISIS
description: Three days before Dr. Eisenberg's article appeared, I sat on the witness stand, as a gifted lawyer tried to discredit my 25 years as a neurosurgeon. That evening, I thought about the contrast in ethics which lies at the heart of the malpractice crisis.

title: OLYMPIC WINNERS FIGHT TO LIVELY DRAW
description: Howard Davis, a gold medalist from the 1976 Montreal Olympics, and Meldrick Taylor, a gold medalist from the 1984 Los Angeles Games , fought to a spirited 10-round draw at the Sands Hotel today.

title: BENEFITS OF CONTAINER-GROWN PLANTS
description: WHILE container-grown plants have their drawbacks, their benefits to both nurserymen and consumers far offset their deficiencies. However, attention to the potential problems will provide greater assurance of success.

title: Reagan And Sanctions
description: The Senate has cast a vote for the future in its approval of limited sanctions against the Afrikaner regime in South Africa - but not because that ruthless and determined Government is likely to do anything useful in response.

title: THREE YEARS LATER, CHICAGO'S MAYOR IS TURNING THE CORNER
description: ALL are hailing, or damning, the new Chicago Mayor, the same one who was elected in 1983, Harold Washington, but only a few months ago took the reins of government. In the three months since Mr. Washington's new City Council made its debut, it has approved nominations the Mayor made more than two years ago, reorganized its committee structure and voted for a property tax increase.

title: A COUNTRY GARDEN THRIVES IN THE SUBURBS
description: Anyone who has designed a perennial border knows how complicated a task this is. While there are many good books on gardening, with excellent illustrations, they are flat and two-dimensional. The plants themselves offer so much more.

title: Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: SENATE

title: MESSAGES SENT IN THE MEDIUM OF LIGHT
description: Who should say that summer is all sea, sun and the senses? More than ever, it is becoming the most fashionable season for staging magnificent festivals, dazzling blockbusters and numerous smaller pageants. What is happening now in Montreal is no exception. Sandwiched between the jazz and the cinema festivals, and concurrent with a Miro retrospective, the International Center of Contemporary Art has organized an extensive and somewhat conspicuous exhibition entitled ''Lights: Perception - Projection.''

title: SALVAGING LIVES AFTER TORTURE
description: JORGE, A 31-YEAR-OLD COMPUTER programmer in Toronto, has recurring nightmares about the kidnappers in Guatemala City who took him away one summer morning. They wore civilian clothes but they carried guns and were almost certainly soldiers. They took Jorge, a former student activist, to a makeshift jail where they tortured him for 24 hours straight.

title: Protesters Seized Off Spain
description: Six people were arrested today off the Atlantic coast as they protested the dumping of toxic waste into the sea, the environmentalist group Greenpeace said. It said the six had tied themselves to the anchor chains of two ships to prevent them from dumping 1,000 tons of titanium dioxide.

THERE is a grave shortage in the Bronx these days, something no hotline or rock concert or collection can alleviate. The current ownership has been retiring numbers at such a rapid clip that the Yankees are likely to run out of digits before the end of the decade.

title: GETTING THE MOST OUT OF A BATTERY
description: IF you have ever photographed a fast-moving event using a flash powered by ''AA'' alkaline batteries, you know that it can often seem like an eternity between the time you take a shot and the time your flash's batteries have ''recycled'' - that is, gathered sufficient energy to let you take another shot. And you may also be familiar with the keen disappointment of running out of useful batteries before your shoot is completed.

title: South Africa Sanctions Held in a Platinum Trap
description: To the Editor:

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
ICE CREAM
description: LILLIAN SCOFIELD and her brothers, John C. Neilsen Jr. and Christian P. Neilsen, aren't too worried about Ben and Jerry. Or Steve - as in Steve's Ice Cream. Or Haagen-Dazs, Frusen Gladje, Baskin Robbins or Schrafts.

title: Through the Taxpayer's Pockets in B Flat
description: To the Editor:

title: POSING AND SOLVING PROBLEMS IN CHOREOGRAPHY
description: Every work of art could be called an example of problem solving. In making a work, an artist has to pose, and then answer, questions of form, content, style and technique. In some works, however, the artist may specifically emphasize the process of problem solving and the appeal of such pieces may be akin to that of puzzles or riddles.

title: Classical Music
description: This is the time of year when out-of-town jaunts combining good music listening and closer association with nature than we generally enjoy are especially welcome. And, fortunately, a number of not-too-distant summer festivals offer a variety of programming from which to choose.

title: CITY OPERA: MASSENET'S 'CENDRILLON'
description: CHARM is an elusive quality and all but indefinable. That I understand. Still, I make so bold as to say flatly that the New York City Opera's ''Cendrillon,'' which returned Friday night after a three-year absence, is certain to charm you, unless you have passed irrevocably into adult cynicism. Of course, if you have reached the stage of cultural development where the tale of Cinderella's mistreatment at the hands of her stepmother and the ugly sisters brings only a yawn, this staging of Massenet's opera is not for you. For all others, however, a captivating night in the theater is assured.

title: The Vaucluse
description: To the Editor: Margaret Morganroth Gullette's marvelously evocative article on the Vaucluse (Travel, July 13) listed our company, Vacances en Campagne, as a source of rental properties in that still relatively untouristed section of Provence.

title: Indian General Who Raided Temple Is Slain
description: In 1984, Gen. Arun S. Vaidya, the Chief of Staff, supervised the Indian army raid on the Golden Temple at Amritsar, the holiest shrine of the nation's Sikhs. Hundreds of Sikhs were killed.

title: HEALTH INFORMATION OFFERED IN PUBLIC NEWARK LIBRARY
description: THE parents of a 4-year-old child diagnosed as having Kawasaki's Disease went to the New Britain Public Library to ask for information about the illness.

title: Hamilton!, Ohio, Makes Its Mark
description: ADDING an exclamation point to its name seemed a good way to make people take notice. So, by a vote of the City Council last May, Hamilton in southwest Ohio, population 65,000, became Hamilton! City Manager Jack Becker said he believed the city was the first in the country to do such a thing.

title: ART: 'THE MASTERS'
description: ''THE MASTERS,'' the current exhibition at the Fine Arts Gallery on the Southampton campus of Long Island University, brings together painting, sculpture, drawing and photography by 14 well-known artists. They are the faculty of the university's Master Workshop, an annual summer program that attracts applicants from across the country.

title:
INVESTING;
SUBARU'S DOWNHILL RIDE
description: The stock of Subaru of America Inc., the Pennsauken, N.J.-based importer of Japanese autos, lost one-third of its value between early May and late July, amid signs that the company's lusty sales growth might be slowing. Last week, with the stock around $26, some analysts and money managers called the selloff overdone.

title: HISTORICAL OCCASION
description: AFTER Karolyn Wrightson moved to ''a little gem'' of an 1850 Gothic Revival house in Hastings-on-Hudson in 1973, people kept stopping by and asking its history. One volunteered that the bargeboard decoration, a trim under the eaves, was the same as that at Lyndhurst.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Newport, R.I.;
Replicating Colonial Homes
description: THOMAS AND SHEILA GIBSON are former Navy nomads who have found an affordable way to establish roots and enjoy the time-honored look of a colonial home. Within a few months, they expect to be in their new home, a replica of a 1740 half-gambrel, named for the colonial pitched roof and configuration of windows on the first floor.

title: The World According to Congress
description: Consider the issues that occupied Congress last week just before members rushed off on vacation:

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: THE Hazardous Waste Facilities Siting Commission has eliminated two potential incinerator sites and waved a carrot in front of nine other municipalities.

title: WORKSHOPS WHERE ART IMITATES FUN
description: Time and talent go hand in hand when school is out. Add top-level instruction and well-equipped facilities and an art project becomes something to be proud of as well as fun to do. Art workshops this summer offer a range of creative possibilities for children at the Gifted and Talented Development Center at Concordia College in Bronxville, the State University of New York at Purchase and the Hoff-Barthelson Music School in Scarsdale.

title: Fossils May Link Bird to Dinosaurs
description: Paleontological assumptions, though they spring from stone, are not carved in it.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN DRUG PACKAGING
description: FOR years, the SmithKline Beckman Corporation aired a successful television commercial that showed ''hundreds of tiny time pills'' spilling from an opened Contac capsule.

title: ETHIOPIA RESETTLEMENT PLAN LOOKING BETTER
description: Local officials here, where nearly 80,000 people have been relocated as part of the Government's huge resettlement program, paint a brighter picture to this impoverished country's bleak story.

title: MOM-AND-POP MINING IS STIRRING IN THE ROCKIES
description: THREE years after the Anaconda Company said goodbye to Butte, ending more than a century of copper mining here, a new company has bought its holdings. A few weeks ago, the new owner, Montana Resources Inc., began working the dormant Continental pit, and the company said the first shipments would go out this month.

title: HOME FROM HILDA'S HILL
description: HILDA doesn't walk up that big hill anymore. She did for years, though, running the farm by herself after her husband died and her brother Johnny was addled by the sun in the 40's. It was not an easy life, but the view from the top of their hill - a mural of the Upper Midwest - was sufficient to remind her that she had surely put down roots in the right place.

title: MAGIC CASTS ITS SPELL ON COLLECTORS
description: ''I think of myself as an accumulator rather than a collector,'' said Charles Reynolds. Yet most people would say that his holdings of approximately 100 posters and 2,000 books on magic certainly constitute a collection.

title: MORALITY: MISSING IN ACTION
description: VIRTUE UNDER FIRE How World War II Changed Our Social and Sexual Attitudes. By John Costello. Illustrated. 309 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $17.95.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: JUMPING SHOW We're not Inspector Gadget, but we are here to rock. We're here to entertain you, so help up reach the top. We hope you really like our show, and now it's time for us to go. We hope you have us back again, 'cause now this is the end.

title: ART: BEHIND THE SCENES WITH 'HOLLYWOOD: LEGEND AND REALITY'
description: ''HOLLYWOOD: LEGEND AND REALITY'' is an all-star, technicolor exhibition as colorful and spirited as many of the films in it. The Cooper-Hewitt Museum show boasts 450 costumes, props, movie posters, clips and stills from about 200 movies, from the early years of the century through the 1980's.

title: GALLIC GALL
description: AS A STUDENT IN Paris some time ago, I found myself late one afternoon in the middle of a bemused crowd of Parisians at the information counter of the big department store B.H.V. I was asking where I could buy an item that I was calling a ''port-FOY,'' by which I meant a wallet - not that I had much money in those days to put into it.

title:
ART;
'INTERIORS' AT NABIS
description: ALTHOUGH it has ample couches to sink into and the reception desk boasts a friendly jar of cookies for the taking, the enormous lobby of Nabisco Brands seems like an incongruous place to show the 71 contemporary photographs - for the most part evocations and recordings of domesticity - that make up ''Interiors.''

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Cold-Country Oak, Made in the U.S.A.

title: Top Crime Figure's Son Convicted in Gambling
description: Jason B. Angiulo, the son of a top organized crime figure, has been found guilty of a gambling charge stemming from his father's illegal enterprise but has been acquitted of racketeering.

title: COMMUNITY COLLEGES NEED MORE SUPPORT
description: WHEN school bells call students back to classes this September, more than a few parents will be wondering how to finance their son's or daughter's college education short of selling the house.

title: PROSPECTS
description: A Strike Slowdown

title: THE LIABILITY INSURANCE CRISIS: A THREAT TO JOBS
description: OF the many recent trends that certified public accountants have witnessed in serving their clients, the current liability insurance crisis threatens to be one of the most destructive. On Long Island, the crisis has not only affected the quality of life, but also sapped the innovative spirit required to sustain the economic health of the region.

title: PRETORIA DERIDES VOTE BY SENATE FOR SANCTIONS
description: The South African Government, reporting 15 more blacks slain in guerrilla and township violence, today denounced sanctions approved Friday by the United States Senate as ''protectionism dressed in morality.''

title: WHY SOME NOVELISTS CAST HOLLYWOOD AS THE HEAVY
description: Robert Stone's latest novel, ''Children of Light,'' takes place largely on a movie set in Mexico. The narrator, a writer whose screenplay is undergoing filming, goes there in search of the starring actress, with whom he has had a love affair, and to see what's being done with or to his work. On neither count is he welcomed by the director, who is sensibly worried about the effects that the cocaine-snorting narrator will have on the shaky star and in any case doesn't want any writer interfering with the making of his movie.

title: Life Insurance
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a technical error, a review on Aug. 10 of a performance by the Philadelphia Orchestra contained an inaccurate sentence. The sentence should have read: ''Norman Carol, the Philadelphia's dapper concertmaster, seemed rather too suave in this context, even though his playing was not inevitably note-perfect.''

title: 'THE HAMMER AND THE CROSS': A SERIES OF DISTORTIONS
description: In its own way, ''The Hammer and the Cross'' is enthralling. The BBC series, now being shown on public television, resolutely builds a case: Communism and Christianity, rather than being in conflict, complement one another; Fidel Castro, say, or Tomas Borge, the Nicaraguan Minister of the Interior, are very much like the apostles. Marxism, meanwhile, is the ''most successful revolutionary faith of this century,'' and St. Paul, if he were around, presumably would live in Havana. ''The Hammer and the Cross'' pretends to objectivity in all this, and there are moments when one wonders whether it is stainlessly innocent or cunningly dishonest. Either way, it is a splendid example of how television can be used to disseminate propaganda. The trick is never to allow facts to stand in the way.

title: PHILADELPHIA FINDS RADICALS GOT U.S. FUNDS
description: Disclosures here that Federal community development funds were channeled to a leader of the radical group Move have spotlighted what both city and Federal officials say is a pattern of lax control over such funds.

title: 11,500 FACING STATELESSNESS IN HONG KONG
description: Christopher D'Almada e Castro was born here 76 years ago, a British subject and member of a family that has lived in Hong Kong almost from the day the British colony was founded.

title: O BRAVE U WORLD
description: NANCY MITFORD A Biography. By Selina Hastings. Illustrated. 274 pp. New York: A William Abrahams Book/ E. P. Dutton. $19.95.

title: Setting Some Limits on Radon
description: It is a lot easier to rate radon contamination than to regulate it, the Government indicated last week.

title: MALPRACTICE CRISIS
description: As the mother of three, I suggest you give equal time to hear our complaints about obstetricians and their methods. OB's treat us callously and contemptuously and get away with it when nature cooperates to produce a happy outcome.

title: Nancy L. Angus Wed in Princeton
description: Nancy Louis Angus, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Duncan Angus of Prescott, Ariz., was married yesterday to John Randolph VanPlantinga, the son of Mary C. Plantinga of Sarasota, Fla., and the late Dr. Oliver S. Plantinga. The Rev. David L. Stokes performed the ceremony at All Saints Episcopal Church in Princeton, N.J.

title: Baby in Court Battle Dies After One Day
description: A medical and legal battle over a brain-dead pregnant woman ended today with the death of her tiny baby, a day after his premature birth.

title: DENNIS FLYNN
description: Dennis Flynn, principal law assistant to the State Court of Appeals, died of a heart attack Aug. 8 at the Albany Medical Center. He was 37 years old.

title: Colombia Frees Suspect
description: Jorge Luis Ochoa Vazquez, reputed head of a major cocaine ring, was freed from jail despite American attempts to extradite him for trial on drug-smuggling charges, officials in Colombia said today. Authorities said Mr. Ochoa Vasquez dropped out of sight Wednesday after receiving a 20-month suspended sentence and a $1,000 fine on charges of falsifying documents.

title: Some Lucky Shots
description: John Clark isn't a very good golfer and has a 29 handicap to prove it. So when the 63-year-old retiree returned to the clubhouse at the Lincolnshire Fields Country Club in Champaign, Ill., on Thursday, it seemed from his rather somber demeanor that he had had an especially bad round.

title: LIVES OF THE GREAT COUPLES AND UNCOUPLES
description: THE FABULOUS LUNTS Biography of Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne. By Jared Brown. Foreword by Helen Hayes. Illustrated. 523 pp. New York: Atheneum. $24.95.

title: A Deli Owner's Suspicions Lead to Arrest of a Suspect
description: The annals of crime and of chutzpah intersected recently in the Boerum Hill section of Brooklyn when a brazen suspect was confronted by a suspicious deli owner.

title: TEXT OF PRESIDENT'S STATEMENT
description: Following is the text of President Reagan's statement, issued Saturday night, on the tax-revision agreement reached by Senate and House negotiators:

title: U.S.-Japan Textile Talks Fail
description: United States and Japanese negotiators failed to reach agreement Saturday on Japanese textile exports, and the United States Customs Service has begun spot checks at American docks for polyester fibers that may have been shipped from South Korea through Japan, a spokesman for the Office of the United States Trade Representative said today.

title: DANCE: WORKS AT FESTIVAL BY CITY BALLET MEMBERS
description: The Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival presented what must rate as one of the most interesting and spirited programs of its current season in the Choreography Project with Dancers from the New York City Ballet. Seen on Saturday afternoon, at the end of its weeklong season at the festival, the program displayed the work of four neophyte choreographers - City Ballet dancers who were encouraged by the Pillow to create new ballets. Given full stage production at the festival, the ballets were danced by members of the City Ballet and seen on a program that included two familiar works by George Balanchine.

title: NUMEROUS CHANGES WOULD RAISE BURDEN ON BUSINESS
