description: For corporate America, the new tax bill provides hundreds of changes that are intended to increase sharply the tax burden on business but also provide a more level playing field that would no longer favor investment in certain industries.

title: HOW THE TAX BILL EVOLVED
description: Following is a chronology of important events leading to the Senate and House conferees' agreement Saturday on tax-overhaul legislation: January 1977: In the final days of the Ford Administration, Treasury Secretary William E. Simon introduces ''Blueprints for Basic Tax Reform,'' which calls for a system with three tax brackets: 8, 25 and 38 percent. May 27, 1982: Senator Bill Bradley, a New Jersey Democrat, and Representative Richard A. Gephardt, a Missouri Democrat, introduce a bill that would eliminate many deductions. It also calls for reducing the number of tax rates for individuals to three, replacing the rate range of 11 to 50 percent with a range of 14 to 28 percent. In addition, it proposes taxing corporate profits at a flat 30 percent rate, dumping the graduated tax and its 46 percent top rate. This bill follows many other tax-simplification proposals.

title: British Inflation Slows
description: Britain's inflation rate in July dropped to 2.4 percent, the lowest since 1967, the Government reported Friday.

title: Bank of New England Adds Conifer to Realm
description: Five years ago, Walter J. Connolly Jr., chairman of the Bank of New England Corporation, was content to wind up his career as chief executive of the Connecticut Bank and Trust Corporation, based in Hartford.

title: THRIFT ILLS DISGUISED, STUDY SAYS
description: The nation's savings and loan associations are in far worse financial condition than Federal regulators and the thrift industry have acknowledged, new Government research suggests.

title: Stock Offering By Jerry Rubin
description: Jerry Rubin, the former political activist who is currently the head of Network America Inc., has filed an initial public offering of 1.65 million units with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The estimated proceeds of the offering is $2.97 million.

title: Gathering the Fleet
description: The task of arranging for elimination races among challengers for the America's Cup tends to be a logistical nightmare. But it keeps getting easier.

title: CROWD BEATS SLAYER TO DEATH
description: A man who killed a teen-ager early today with a shotgun, then wounded three bystanders, was jumped upon by spectators and beaten to death with a fence post, the authorities said. There were no arrests.

title: Oklahoma Bank Fails
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said Friday that the Citizens National Bank and Trust Company of Oklahoma City had failed, the 90th bank to fail this year. The bank's deposits of $157.5 million have been transferred to the Liberty National Bank and Trust Company of Oklahoma City.

title: Earle Palmer Brown In New Partnership
description: The Earle Palmer Brown Companies, the $125 million marketing agency in Bethesda, Md., will provide client services ranging from research to media-buying for a new agency opening in Chicago.

title: Truck Concern Must Refund Fees Paid by Job Applicants
description: A national trucking concern has been ordered to refund the cost of medical examinations assessed to job applicants and to pay a fine for the illegal fees, state officials announced today.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: OUTDOORS: LURING BONITO
description: EVEN veteran anglers are bedeviled by extended periods when fish elude them.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Aug. 18, 1986: MONDAY Century Tel Entpr Nafco Finl Group Esselte Bus Sys San Diego Gas & Elec First Interstate Bncrp Whirlpool Corp TUESDAY ADT Inc Kellwood Co Armstrong Rubber Longs Drug Stores Coleman Co Ohio Edison Duquesne Light RTE Corp Firestone Robertshaw Controls Hayes-Albion Corp Wolverine Worldwide WEDNESDAY Bandag Inc Mohasco Corp Fisrt Bank System Morgan Keegan Inc Geico Corp Morse Shoe Intl Minerals & Chem Northrop Corp THURSDAY Amsouth Bncrptn Grubb & Ellis Automatic Data Prcs Loctite Corp Champion Intl Owens-Corning Fiber Chesapeake Corp Perkin-Elmer Dresser Indus Springs Industries Florida Progress Corp Sterling Bancorp Fruehauf Corp Tracor Inc Greyhound Corp FRIDAY Harris Corp South Jersey Indus Piedmont Nat Gas Varian Associates Ryder System Whittaker Corp Scotty's Inc

title: NEW YORKERS' SAVINGS IN TAX PLAN ESIMATED AS HIGH AS $1.6 BILLION
description: New Yorkers may save as much as $1.6 billion in lower Federal taxes next year under the legislation drafted by Congressional negotiators, according to preliminary estimates by state tax officials.

title: Seoul Loans Seen Curbed
description: South Korea has banned further foreign borrowing by banks and the issuing of foreign-currency denominated bonds and notes, banking sources said today. There was no immediate official confirmation of the move.

title: Becker Tops Edberg in Final
description: Boris Becker defeated Stefan Edberg of Sweden, 6-4, 3-6, 6-3 today to win the $525,000 Player's International tennis tournament.

title: American Photographer Dies In Expedition on the Yangtze
description: An American photographer has died of altitude sickness during a Chinese-American expedition on the mountainous upper reaches of the Yangtze River, according to reports received last week.

title: Treasure Between Pages
description: The Library of Congress has come up with a heartwarming story to demonstrate that the humble Government worker does not always go unrewarded at the hands of an unfeeling bureaucracy. It seems that last year Inez Robinson, a temporary library employee, was microfilming a Russian book, ''Kriticheskiya Grani,'' which was published in St. Petersburg in 1910, when she found two $50 bills tucked between the pages.

title: BATTLE FOR UNION CHIEF LOOMS AS RAILROAD ENGINEERS MEET
description: A potentially bruising battle for the presidency of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers will begin in Cleveland Monday when the union opens its convention there.

title: Singapore Selling Its Expertise
description: The members of the cabin staffs of China's national airline want professional training. They come to Singapore. An Indonesian woman needs a complex bone operation. She comes to Singapore. A Malaysian businessman wants to see the newest printing technology. He comes here, too.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: VOICES AGAINST TYRANNY: Writing of the Spanish Civil War. Edited by John Miller. 227 pages. Signature/ Scribners. Cloth, $16.95; paper, $7.95. SPANISH FRONT: Writers on the Civil

title: Military Concerns May See Windfall
description: Corporate America, despite a reduction in tax rates, will face an increased tax burden of $120 billion over the next five years as a result of the sweeping tax changes contemplated in the legislation approved this weekend by Congressional conferees. But that burden will fall unevenly.

title: RAIN SUSPENDS L.P.G.A. PLAY
description: Play was suspended today midway through the final round of the women's MasterCard International golf tournament here because of rain, thunder and lightning.

title: Mary Guterson Becomes a Bride
description: Mary Guterson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Murray B. Guterson of Seattle, was married yesterday to Rob J. Crichton, the son of Judy Crichton of New York, and Robert C. Crichton of Cuttingsville, Vt. Justice Lawrence N. Martin Jr. of the New York Supreme Court performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Standard in Pound Ridge, N.Y.

title: GERMAN ECONOMY: A RETAILING PUSH
description: Frank Steinmann's store, a ragtag emporium of beer mugs and T-shirts, stays open till 10 every night - an uncommonly late hour by the tough standards of West German retail law. While the question of how long a shop stays open may seem trivial to Americans used to all-night supermarkets and Sunday shopping, it has broader meaning for the Government of Chancellor Helmut Kohl.

title: BIPARTISAN LEADERS PREDICT PASSAGE OF TAX BILL IN FALL; PRESIDENT HAILS AGREEMENT
description: Leading Congressional advocates and opponents of the historic tax revision bill that House and Senate negotiators approved Saturday night said today that the measure would almost certainly be enacted this fall but not without further struggle.

title: At 14, 500 Easy Pieces
description: Donna Klett, 14 years old, completed a 500-piece jigsaw puzzle in 1 hour, 49 minutes and 28 seconds today and won the singles title and a $2,000 prize at a national jigsaw puzzle championship contest held here.

title: RIGHETTI AND FISHER BRING TRUE RELIEF
description: IT did not seem possible the other night that there could be any more nerve-racking place in the ball park here than the dugout, where Lou Piniella's jaws were working frantically.

title: DON'T ASK DOCTORS TO DO THE IMPOSSIBLE
description: As consumers of health care, we ought to support efforts of Government and private industry to reduce costs. But as patients, we have to be concerned about several disturbing changes in the relationship between physicians and the institutions in which they practice - changes that these cost-cutting efforts have brought about.

title: Washington Watch; Shad Said to Be Leaving
description: John S. R. Shad's tenure as chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission appears to be coming to an end.

title: Economists Differ On Bill's Impact
description: Corporate America, despite a reduction in tax rates, will face an increased tax burden of $120 billion over the next five years as a result of the sweeping tax changes contemplated in the legislation approved this weekend by Congressional conferees. But that burden will fall unevenly.

title: For Banks, Key Is Economy's Health
description: Corporate America, despite a reduction in tax rates, will face an increased tax burden of $120 billion over the next five years as a result of the sweeping tax changes contemplated in the legislation approved this weekend by Congressional conferees. But that burden will fall unevenly.

title: Jeffrey S. Weinstein Weds Laurie A. Ostern in Jersey
description: The marriage of Laurie Ann Ostern and Jeffrey Steven Weinstein, who graduated from the State University of New York at Binghamton and received J.D. degrees cum laude in May from the Boston University School of Law, took place yesterday at the Livingston (N.J.) Country Club.

title: GERMANS LOOK BACK, GINGERLY, TO THE '36 GAMES
description: Seventy-seven German medal winners from the 1936 Berlin Olympic Games gathered here over the last three days for a nostalgic, and awkward, 50th anniversary reunion.

title: Business Lunches: A Mixed Reaction
description: Corporate America, despite a reduction in tax rates, will face an increased tax burden of $120 billion over the next five years as a result of the sweeping tax changes contemplated in the legislation approved this weekend by Congressional conferees. But that burden will fall unevenly.

title: HURRICANE MOVES NORTH AS COAST DWELLERS FLEE
description: Hurricane Charley moved up the East Coast into Virginia waters Sunday night after careening across North Carolina's Outer Banks with winds of 75 miles per hour and torrential rains.

title: SUDANESE AIRLINER WITH 60 ON BOARD DOWNED BY MISSILE
description: A Sudan Airways plane with 60 people aboard was shot down Saturday by Sudanese rebels using SAM-7 antiaircraft missiles, the official Sudan News Agency reported today.

title: ROYALS' GUBICZA SHUTS OUT YANKS, 5-0
description: To the last breaking pitch in the dirt, at which the batter swung crazily because it looked ''just fine'' to him, it was a confusing afternoon for the Yankees.

title: GAINT FANS FINDING REASONS TO CHEER
description: THE San Francisco Giants, whose past advertising campaigns could offer fans little more than souvenir survivor's medals for withstanding the night-time cold at Candlestick Park, have something much hotter to sell these days.

title: City's Drug Prosecutor Assails Federal Effort
description: The city's special narcotics prosecutor attacked the Reagan Administration yesterday, saying it had not done enough to combat the drug problem.

title: Thousands of Poles Greet 2 Freed Activists
description: Thousands of Solidarity supporters gave an emotional welcome today to two leading opposition figures recently released from prison.

title: India's Disservice to the Victims of Bhopal
description: To the Editor:

title: Evangelist for G.O.P.
description: The Rev. Pat Robertson, the television evangelist and potential Republican Presidential candidate, is planning a major role in the Republicans' fall campaign to hold a Senate majority. He disclosed last week that he had committed himself to appearances in 16 of the 34 states where Senate races are taking place.

title: How Portable Computers Survive Flights
description: To the Editor:

title: CRISES GENERATE NOVEL BOND SALES
description: Local governments around the country are turning to Wall Street securities dealers for novel bond sales to help solve two problems: the scarcity and high cost of liability insurance for municipal governments and the plight of farmers.

title: Abraham Havivi Marries Deborah Shira Schmidt
description: At Temple Israel in Ridgewood, N.J., yesterday Deborah Shira Schmidt and Abraham Baruch Joseph Havivi were married by Rabbi Eliezer Havivi, the bridegroom's brother, and Rabbi Morris Allen.

title: Sewage Taints L.I. Creek
description: Teams put sandbags and a boom into Newbridge Creek here today to stop the spread of waste after about 100,000 gallons of treated sewage burst through a pipe and into storm drains, the Nassau County Deputy Health Commissioner, Francis Padar, said. He said two beaches, the Biltmore Shores and Florence Avenue Beach, both in the town of Oyster Bay, were closed. The sewage line was carrying treated waste from the Nassau County Cedar Creek plant in Wantagh to tanks in Rockaway when it burst, he said.

title: Dr. Debra Weissman Weds
description: The marriage of Dr. Debra Susan Weissman, a resident in dermatology at the Mount Sinai Medical Center in New York, and Richard I. Ellenbogen, an associate in the New York law firm of Reavis & McGrath, took place yesterday at the Richfield Regency in Verona, N.J. Rabbi Dr. Leon Katz officiated. The bride, who will retain her name professionally, is a daughter of Joseph Weissman of Glen Rock, N.J., and the late Celeste Weissman. Mr. Ellenbogen is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Ellenbogen of Clifton, N.J.

title: 'It's My Tam Now'
description: WHILE Ed Hearn was leaving Shea Stadium on Saturday afternoon, his path was blocked by a rather large and rather insistent fan who wanted not only Hearn's autograph but also a long personal conversation.

title: U.S. WILL HELP TRAIN AFGHAN REFUGEES AS JOURNALISTS
description: Boston University has been awarded a $180,000 grant to train Afghan refugees as journalists and King Features Syndicate will receive $310,000 to create an Afghan news service, the United States Information Agency has announced.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: BUILDING BOOM For those who complain that construction in New York is continually getting out of scale, a visit to Charles Miniatures is recommended. This small store is at 246 Lafayette Street, between Spring and Prince Streets in the area still known as Little Italy. A sign identifies it as a place to buy furniture, building supplies, lighting fixtures, tools and lumber. But the supplies are all in miniature, accessories for ornate little plywood houses, mostly Victorian, built on a scale of one inch to a foot. They are dollhouses, some custom-made by Charles Ursitti, a promotion man whose hobby this is, and others in kits that the buyer may assemble. The store is run by Mr. Ursitti's father, Pasquale Ursitti, who has seen the neighborhood change from Italian to Asian to infiltrating gentrification.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Required Reading; Drug Test Cauldron
description: Excerpt from remarks Aug. 11 on the House floor by Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn, on the issue of drug testing:

title: CHURCH OFFICIAL PRESSES RIGHTS BATTLES OF THE 80'S
description: The new executive director of the United Church of Christ's Commission on Racial Justice, the Rev. Dr. Benjamin F. Chavis Jr., says he would like to use the commission as a vehicle to do for others what those in the civil rights movement did for him.

title: TAX SYSTEM TO REMAIN PROGRESSIVE, EXPERTS SAY
description: For people with low and moderate incomes, the tax bill represents the most important advance in Federal policy in more than a decade, according to both liberals and conservatives.

title: Harper & Row Head Is Named Chairman
description: Brooks Thomas, president and chief executive officer of Harper & Row Publishers Inc., has been named to the additional position of chairman. Some time in the next five years, he said, he will appoint a new president.

title: CONGRESS MAY REDUCE THE DEFICIT IN A TAX RISE, ROSTENKOWSKI SAYS
description: Congress may consider raising taxes this year to reduce the Federal budget deficit, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee said today.

title: Rubin Carter's Co-Defendant Is Indicted on Drug Charges
description: John Artis Jr., convicted and then cleared with the boxer Rubin (Hurricane) Carter in a widely publicized triple-murder case, has been indicted on charges that he participated in a drug ring that brought cocaine and crack from New York City to New Jersey.

title: STEERING NOMINEES OVER CAPITOL HILL: TOM C. KOROLOGOS
description: He was there this month when President Reagan's two Supreme Court nominees faced the Senate Judiciary Committee.

title: Zero Inflation in Israel
description: Israel's inflation rate, which was above 400 percent annually until a wage-price freeze began last summer, fell to zero in July, the Government said Friday. The July rate in 1985 was 27.5 percent.

title: Teen-Age Pregnancy Draws Campaign
description: The social problem: One of every seven babies in New York City is born to a teen-age mother. The advertising problem: How to convince teen-agers to get information, advice and help about sex without being preachy.

title: GROOVY TAKES SARATOGA DASH
description: Groovy, the eccentric and speed-crazy 3-year-old who has found a new career sprinting, led at every call through blazing fractions and held off Turkoman by three-quarters of a length to win the $117,200 Forego Handicap today at Saratoga.

title: INJURIES MOUNT AS METS SPLIT
description: Unless you count the music video program they taped on the field, the Mets closed a highly unrewarding weekend yesterday by splitting a doubleheader with the St. Louis Cardinals with two new injuries and four losses in six games.

title: CHILDREN AND FEARS OF DIVORCE
description: CHILDREN are haunted by anxieties and fears that seem exaggerated to the adult mind, especially when placed in the context of reality: the fear of that three-headed monster that springs to life as soon as the light goes out at night or the possibility of being abandoned.

title: Southern Yemenis Force A Passenger Jet Down
description: Two Southern Yemeni jet fighters intercepted an Air Djibouti passenger plane over the Red Sea on Saturday and forced it to land in Southern Yemen, official sources in Djibouti said today.

title: 3 Foreign Ministers in Hanoi
description: The Foreign Ministers of Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia opened their 13th semiannual meeting in Hanoi today, the official Voice of Vietnam radio said. Attending were Foreign Ministers Nguyen Co Thach of Vietnam, Phoun Sipaseuth of Laos and Hun Sen of the Vietnamese-installed Government in Cambodia, according to the broadcast.

title: CLOSING NEW YORK'S SPECIALIZED HIGH SCHOOLS WILL HELP NO ONE
description: To the Editor:

title: NASA Has Been Telling the Truth All Along
description: To the Editor:

title: Sharon Steel Reports Loss
description: The Sharon Steel Corporation reported on Friday a second-quarter loss of $8 million.

title: NOSE TO NOSE AND ARM IN ARM
description: AS usual, Joe Fields and Joe Klecko were having a football argument. They are always grousing at each other about something. And one time at midnight last season, in the house they shared on Point Lookout, L.I., while their families were back home, they took the argument to its logical conclusion.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL METS VS. DODGERS, at Los Angeles, 8:05 P.M. (Television - Channel 7, 8 P.M.; Radio - WHN 1050, 8 P.M.) GOLF L.P.G.A. TOUR: Completion of rain delayed Mastercard International, Knollwood Country Club, Elmsford, N.Y., 8:30 A.M.

title: MONUMENT TO REAGANISM JOINS POPULIST POLITICS WITH SUPPLY-SIDE CREDO
description: If Congress accepts - as by all accounts it will - the broad reconstruction of the income tax system that its tax committees approved on Saturday, Ronald Reagan will have earned himself a place among the handful of Presidents who have nurtured fundamental change. Although an army of advocates was required, the President set the tone and defined the themes of a resolute campaign to clean up a body of law that President Carter had called ''a disgrace to the human race.''

title: PHOTOGRAPHER HONORED BY MACDOWELL COLONY
description: On a hazy Sunday morning, before a crowd of several hundred artists and art-world figures gathered under a green-and-white striped tent, the question was tacitly posed: How is that thing called ''art photography'' best described?

title: REGGAE: BUNNY WAILER SINGS AT THE GARDEN
description: THOSE who pick the music they record, program or present according to the ''science'' of demographics might do well to ponder Bunny Wailer's achievement at Madison Square Garden on Saturday. The music industry's conventional wisdom regarding reggae is that it is a music with only limited appeal. Yet Bunny Wailer, a performer little known outside reggae, managed to comfortably fill Madison Square Garden for his first United States concert, without the benefit of an extensive advertising campaign or a record release on a major label - and at $20 to $30 a head. Perhaps the cream rises to the top after all, and on its own merits.

title: HealthAmerica Chief Resigns
description: The HealthAmerica Corporation, a large health maintenance organization, said Friday that Philip N. Bredesen had resigned as president and chief executive for personal reasons. Mr. Bredesen will continue as chairman.

title: A PANEL FAVORS MULTILINGUAL PLAN FOR REGENTS TESTS
description: An education task force plans to recommend that New York State's exams for a Regents high school diploma be given in foreign languages.

title: SUDANESE GUERRILLA WAR IS ROOTED IN DEEP ETHNIC DIVISIONS
description: Behind Saturday's shooting down of a civilian aircraft in the southern Sudan lies a chronic civil war, one that has pitted the Moslem-dominated north against non-Moslem forces in the south since before the country became independent 30 years ago.

title: The U.N. Today: Aug. 18, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Preparatory Commission for International Seabed Authority and Law of the Sea Tribunal - 10:30 A.M.

title:
THE TAX BILL OF 1986: HOW BUSINESS WILL BE AFFECTED BY THE BIGGER TAX BURDEN;
Shifts in Income For Executives
description: Corporate America, despite a reduction in tax rates, will face an increased tax burden of $120 billion over the next five years as a result of the sweeping tax changes contemplated in the legislation approved this weekend by Congressional conferees. But that burden will fall unevenly.

title: Topics: Health Fears/Facts; In the Dark
description: Prolonged or intense exposure to the sun's ultraviolet radiation is as bad for the eyes as for the skin. It can cause cataracts, damage to the retina and temporary night blindness.

title: 2 Seamen Die in Attack On a Tanker in the Gulf
description: Two seamen were killed and three were wounded today in an air attack on a chemical tanker in the southern Persian Gulf, shipping sources in the region said.

title: FEMALE ENTREPRENEURS THRIVE
description: Seven years ago, Prynn Kaplan was a ballet dancer with a knack for interior design. Now she runs her own construction company.

title: MANY SEEK O'NEILL SEAT, BUT ONLY ONE IS A KENNEDY
description: In the race here for the Democratic Congressional nomination to succeed Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., one of the most energetic candidates is Melvin H. King, probably the most popular black politician in Massachusetts and a widely respected civil rights leader for decades.

title: MUSIC: BAYLESS ON MOZART
description: IMPROVISATIONS based on familiar themes either comment on their originals or use them as launching fuel into the uncharted. John Bayless gave us both sides of this art in his two improvisations preceding the Mostly Mozart concert on Friday.

title: ISRAELIS AND RUSSIANS START TALKS TODAY IN FINLAND
description: Israeli and Soviet delegates meet here on Monday for the first formal talks between the two countries in 19 years, and the Soviet Union's future role in Middle East peace efforts is likely to be the underlying issue.

title: CUOMO PLAN FUELS DRUG LAWS DEBATE
description: Governor Cuomo's proposal last week for penalties of up to life in prison for drug dealers convicted of selling even a small amount of crack - three vials, or $50 worth - has renewed a two-decade-old debate in New York State: Do severe penalties reduce drug dealing or are they political responses to appease an outraged public?

title: PROPRIETY OF WITHHOLDING FOOD FROM DYING PATIENTS
description: Many seriously ill or comatose people can survive without a respirator. But none could last long without the chemicals, vitamins and artificial foods that can be pumped or dripped into the body of someone unable or unwilling to eat.

title: Karen Hesse Marries Dr. Evan Flatow
description: Karen Hesse, the daughter of Theodore A. Hesse of Babylon, L.I., and the late Virginia Mildred Hesse, was married yesterday to Dr. Evan Lloyd Flatow, a son of Prof. and Mrs. Paul L. Flatow of New York and Washington, N.J. Judge Wendell P. Levister of New York City Civil Court performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University, from which the bride received an M.B.A. degree and the bridegroom a medical degree.

title: CAR BOMBS DEAL NEW BLOW TO SHATTERED LEBANON
description: The Lebanese, already suffering from 11 years of civil war, have been afflicted by a new wave of car-bombings.

title: Market Place; Transportation Stock Strength
description: TRANSPORTATION stocks showed some major strength last week, but most analysts attributed the gains to portfolio managers and other investors shopping for bargains, rather than on any brighter outlook for the airline, railroad and trucking industries.

title: Barrios Is Victor In Road Racing
description: Arturo Barrios of Mexico City, who continued his domination of this year's road racing circuit, had an easy victory today in the 14th annual Puma-Falmouth Road Race.

title: NEO-NAZI IS FOCUS OF SEARCHING BY F.B.I.
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation is searching for a bank robbery suspect identified as a member of the neo-Nazi organization Aryan Nations, the parent group of a terrorist band that two years ago declared ''war'' on the United States.

title: BRADLEY WINNER WITH 63
description: Pat Bradley called it a career shot - a 206-yard approach for a tap-in eagle on No. 16 today - that gave her the Ladies Professional Golf Association's single-season earnings record and her fifth title in 1986.

title: Closing New York's Specialized High Schools Will Help No One New City, N.Y., Aug. 11, 1986
description: To the Editor:

title: FED NEARS A DECISION ON RATES
description: The Federal Reserve's Federal Open Market Committee will meet tomorrow to assess monetary policy, against the backdrop of an economy still mired in a path of slow growth, and in which the weakest sectors seem the least likely to benefit from additional interest rate cuts.

title: 6 Climbers Freeze to Death In Storm on K-2 in Himalayas
description: Six mountain climbers, including two women, froze to death on K-2, the world's second-highest peak, after a blizzard trapped them for more than a week, a survivor said today.

title: TAINTED WELL-WATER MYSTERY SPOILS TRANQUILLITY OF SOUTHWEST NEW YORK
description: When Marilyn Crowell turns on the faucet in her rural home here,the water smells so bad that she gags. ''It tastes terrible,'' she said. ''It smells just like gas.''

title: BRAVES SET BACK ASTROS, 4-3
description: Bob Horner broke a seventh-inning tie with a sacrifice fly, and Rafael Ramirez had three hits and scored twice as the Braves beat the Houston Astros, 4-3, today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, AUGUST 18, 1986
description: The Tax Bill of 1986

title: REACHING ACROSS RACE BARRIER, 2 SOUTH AFRICANS FIND FRIENDSHIP AND EXILE
description: It should not seem so remarkable that Sholto Ainslie and Rudzani Nemasetoni are best friends. They grew up only a few miles apart. They both study painting. They are young men in New York, a couple of handsome and footloose artists far from home.

title: INVESTMENT SHIFTS SEEN COMING SOON
description: While the proposed tax bill will change the allure of a wide range of securities over the coming years, investors are likely to act sooner rather than later in taking profits on stocks.

title: HURDLES MARK BATTERED
description: Yordanka Donkova of Bulgaria set the women's 100-meter hurdles world record twice within an hour at a Mobil Grand Prix track and field meet today.

title: Carrying a Torch
description: His name may not be a household word to sports fans around the world, but David Gershon, a business consultant and recreational long-distance runner, may deserve more recognition than he has received.

title: Car Explosion Kills Four in French Port
description: Four people were killed early today when the car they were driving exploded in this French Mediterranean port, the police said.

title: Let the Private Sector In
description: To the Editor:

title: ELATION AND NOSTALGIA ON CAPITOL HILL
description: There was elation, to be sure, but there was also nostalgia as Representative Dan Rostenkowski lifted a glass of champagne with Senator Bob Packwood last night, not long after the two had finally forged an agreement on a sweeping overhaul of the nation's tax system.

title: A Yellow-Balloon Flight From the Bronx Riviera
description: An aerial journey that began at Orchard Beach ended on William R. McGrath's lawn.

title: RENAMING FOR A HERO IS DISPUTED
description: Little Tokyo, the normally placid Japanese neighborhood in the shadow of City Hall, is divided by a rare public squabble over Mayor Tom Bradley's proposal to rename Weller Street in honor of Lieut. Col. Ellison S. Onizuka, the Challenger astronaut.

title: 7 OTHERS KILLED IN VIOLENCE IN CITY
description: A 14-year-old Brooklyn youth was killed, a pregnant woman was shot and partially paralyzed and two others were wounded early yesterday when gunfire erupted at a rap-music concert and dance in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, the police said.

title: A 'ONCE IN A LIFETIME' STROLL IN THE LINCOLN TUNNEL
description: Of the 250 or so people who approached the Manhattan entrance to the Lincoln Tunnel yesterday at 4 A.M., not one said that walking under the Hudson River had been a lifelong ambition.

title: Stokely Carmichael Is Jailed in Guinea
description: Stokely Carmichael, the American black militant, has been jailed in Guinea, where he has lived since 1969, a political co-worker said Sunday.

title: Washington Watch; The Citrus-Pasta Fight Goes On
description: The agreement reached earlier this month settling a pasta-citrus trade skirmish between the United States and the European Community will not make it through Congress without a fight.

title: Jennifer Pollock, Wed to Physician
description: Jennifer B. Pollock, a daughter of Justice and Mrs. Stewart G. Pollock of Mendham, N.J., and Niles, N.Y., was married yesterday to Dr. Albert Tin Wai Cheung, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Cheung of Fullerton, Calif. The Quaker ceremony took place at the Pollock home in Niles.

title: NEW STRICTURES IMPOSED ON TAX-EXEMPT BONDS
description: The municipal bond market, where local governments borrowed more than $200 billion in 1985, faces new limits on the amount and kind of bonds that may be issued and a new marketing challenge in selling those bonds.

title: AS POLICE STRUGGLE WITH STRING OF LOS ANGELES KILLINGS, CASE BECOMES ELECTION ISSUE
description: A police sketch of a man wanted in connection with the murders of at least 17 women was plastered on billboards throughout the city this weekend.

title: 74-Year-Old Marble Tower Regaining Some Splendor
description: Hemmed in by newer neighbors and bigger ones, the 74-year-old First Nationwide Savings Building -once the tallest structure on Broadway north of Times Square - is something of an overlooked masterpiece.

title: MCGRIFF OF GIANTS MAY MISS OPENER
description: The Giants, who spent their first month in training camp without a debilitating injury, finally have two.

title: THE UNREST IN PAKISTAN
description: The arrest of Benazir Bhutto and hundreds of other opposition leaders last week, and the subsequent violent clashes between protesters and the police, have been a setback in Pakistan's recent progress toward stability and restoration of civil liberties.

title: U.S. AND SOVIET TO RESUME TALKS ON ACCIDENTAL WAR
description: The Soviet Union and the United States have agreed to resume talks on ways to reduce the risk of accidental nuclear war, Administration officials said today.

title: POCONO EASY DRIVE FOR MARIO ANDRETTI
description: Mario Andretti, surviving another Indy-car race of attrition, had an easy victory today in the Domino's Pizza 500 at Pocono International Raceway.

title: Judith Albert Marries Michael Edward Fine
description: Judith Leah Albert, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Bernard Albert of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to Michael Edward Fine, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerrold Fine of Highland, N.Y. Rabbi Susan Einbinder performed the ceremony at Arrowwood, a conference center in Rye Brook, N.Y.

title: The Crisis of Institutional Loyalty
description: Why have we seen, in the last few years, so much of the sale of national secrets for money? A new breed of trader-traitor has arisen who puts his love of self and pelf ahead of his loyalty to his country.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * A. L. Laboratories, Fort Lee, N.J., a manufacturer of pharmaceuticals, has named Jorgen Worning to direct its international operations in Copenhagen.

title: PHONE WORKERS BEGIN 2D WEEK ON PICKET LINE
description: The strike against New York Telephone entered its second week, yesterday, with no progress reported in informal negotiations.

title: '85 RULING POSES THREAT TO PRIMARY CANDIDATES
description: From Mayor James D. Griffin of Buffalo to Assemblyman Albert Vann of Brooklyn, a little-known ruling by the state's highest court is threatening to keep political candidates off primary ballots this year.

title: WYETH'S HIDDEN HELGA AND THE ART ESTABLISHMENT
description: When Andrew Wyeth's cache of so-called ''Helga'' paintings became front-page news this month, the tumult it generated left the art world reeling and, perhaps, a bit chilled.

title: HOLLYWOOD SALUTES GENERAL DOOLITTLE
description: THE Hollywood part of ''A Hollywood Salute to General Jimmy Doolittle'' is old Hollywood: Bob Hope, Ronald Reagan, James Stewart and a few others who, presumably, really do call General Doolittle ''Jimmy.'' The other people on the two-hour program, tonight on Channel 11 at 8, are the usual show-business folks. Far and away here, old Hollywood works best.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: With a 32-29 record at Yankee Stadium this season, are the Yankees approaching any team mark for futility on their home field?

title: DEVELOPING FINNISH LAPLAND
description: With costs high and export markets distant, Kemijarvi, nestled in the Finnish forests north of the Arctic Circle, is no threat to any of the garment-making centers of the world. Yet this isolated hamlet is the home of one of Finland's most successful smaller clothing exporters, Torstai Oy.

title: M.Z. Rabin Wed To Miss Ramsden
description: The marriage of Katharine L. Ramsden to Michael Z. Rabin, the son of Dr. Pauline L. Rabin of Nashville and the late Dr. David Rabin, took place yesterday in Barrington, R.I. Rabbi Alan Flam and the Rev. Charles Baldwin, a Congregational minister, both chaplains at Brown University, performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Richard J. Ramsden.

title: WALTON IS SATISFIED WITH JETS' PROGRESS
description: Encouraged by a satisfying exhibition victory over the Cincinnati Bengals Saturday night and an even more satisfying review of the game tapes this morning, the Jets' coach, Joe Walton, made it official this afternoon.

title: Bush in the Mideast: Dispelling the Disenchantment
description: Despite a brief flurry of speculation that Vice President Bush's recent Middle East trip might be a catalyst for restarting the stalled Arab-Israeli peace talks, the Vice President's visit to the area produced no surprises on the peacemaking front - nor should it have been expected to. There are, as we have long since learned, no quick fixes for the problems of the Middle East.

title: Another Shuttle, Another Shuffle
description: Six months after the loss of the space shuttle Challenger, the White House has ambled to a sort of decision on whether to replace it. It's not a real decision, just a way to keep shuffling forward without a long-term space policy.

title: Long Will Accept 4-Year Lions' Pact
description: Chuck Long, the quarterback who was the Detroit Lions' first-round draft pick, said today that he planned to sign a four-year contract Monday with the team.

title: U.S. EXPERTS SAY CHERNOBYL'S DESIGN MADE WORKERS' RISK-TAKING WORSE
description: Operators of the Soviet nuclear power plant at Chernobyl set off the catastrophic accident there by taking too many chances with a reactor that was complicated, sensitive and hard to run, said American scientists who have learned about details of the official Soviet accident report.

title: Huge Canadian Harvest
description: Canadian farmers are almost sure to reap their largest grain harvest this fall, according to Graham Walker, a Canadian Wheat Board analyst. He said Friday that the harvest of the six most important grains should total far more than the record of 45.7 million metric tons set in 1982.

title: GIRL, 2, FALLS FIVE FLOORS TO DEATH
description: A 2-year-old girl fell five floors to her death last night after the screen on a bedroom window gave way at a housing project in Long Island City, Queens, the police reported. There was no guard on the window, the authorities said.

title: WINNER IS DISQUALIFIED
description: Adrian Moorhouse was disqualified after he had apparently beaten Victor Davis in the final of the men's 100-meter breast-stroke at the World Swimming Championships today.

title: Ecuador Cuts Forecast
description: Ecuador, hurt by the oil price slump, has reduced its projection of 1986 economic growth. The Government now expects the gross domestic product to rise 1.8 percent. Its previous estimate was 2.5 percent.

title: TAMILS TELL OF SQUALID VOYAGE FROM GERMANY
description: Sri Lankan refugees rescued from waters off Canada now say they began their trip in West Germany and not India, as they had maintained. They said they had lied at the instructions of the captain of a freighter who put them into two lifeboats off Newfoundland.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, AUGUST 18, 1986
description: International

title: Relief for the Cattle Car Court
description: The new politics of crack has achieved what years of exhortation could not: the reconstitution of New York City's shamefully depleted Criminal Court. Governor Cuomo agrees to a plan expanding the court permanently and Chief Judge Sol Wachtler offers immediate temporary relief. The benefits should last long beyond the crack crisis.

title: KEN GREEN TAKES 'POINTS' TOURNAMENT
description: Ken Green, who has endured an uneven season, today won The International, a new PGA Tour event based on points. It was his second victory in five years on the Tour.

title: Sydney Plane Crash Kills 5
description: A light plane crashed into a factory roof today, killing five of the six people on board, the police said. They said the engine of the Cherokee single-propeller plane failed minutes after takeoff from the suburban Chipping Norton airfield.

title: BRUCE R. BEILFUSS
description: Bruce F. Beilfuss, former Chief Justice of the Wisconsin Supreme Court, died Friday at his home after an illness. He was 71 years old. Mr. Beilfuss served on the court from 1963 until 1983, and for the last seven years of his term he was the court's 20th Chief Justice.

title: Nabisco President Gets Chief's Post
description: F. Ross Johnson, president of RJR Nabisco Inc., has been named chief executive, effective in January. He will succeed J. Tylee Wilson, who will continue as chairman until his retirement in January 1988.

title: SOME REAL ESTATE SHELTERS WILL END
description: A family's home would still be a tax-sheltered castle under terms of the new tax bill, but almost all the other tax advantages of real estate investing would be eliminated, should the legislation become law.

title: PIONEER IN BUYOUTS ENJOYING THE SURGE
description: When Edward W. Gibbons thinks back to his firm's first days in the leveraged buyout business, one thing stands out: for months at a time, he and his partners often went home without a paycheck. .

title: BOTANICAL ZOO UNCAGED AT ROCKEFELLER PLAZA
description: The animals came down Second Avenue, cut across 51st Street and arrived on Fifth Avenue about midnight, the rhino first, then the camel and the 11-foot-long elephant. The giraffe - 14 feet high, it had to be tilted on the flatbed truck to make it across the 59th Street Bridge - was next, followed by the lion and the kangaroo. The safari, which had started in Long Island City, Queens, earlier that evening, ended its journey in Rockefeller Center.

title: Fear and Freedom in Pakistan
description: President Zia of Pakistan wound up celebrating his country's Independence Day with nasty fireworks: police gunplay that killed five, and the arrest of the opposition leader Benazir Bhutto, who joined hundreds of her followers behind bars. That was certainly an eyeful for anyone who hoped for substance from Pakistan's show of representative government and lifting of martial law. Washington has properly if gently deplored the crackdown and should do what else it can to restore General Zia's sense of perspective.

title: Why Women's Scores On S.A.T. Are Lower
description: To the Editor:

title: RUSH ON '86 DEDUCTIONS, DELAYS ON INCOME SEEN
description: The proposed tax bill is likely to touch off both a rush by individuals in the coming months to qualify for more tax deductions than usual this year and a search for ways they can defer income until 1987.

title: MCDONNELL AND AIRBUS SEEN IN VENTURE TALKS
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation and Airbus Industrie are in serious talks that could lead to a joint European-American effort to rival the Boeing Company for dominance of the international airplane market, sources familiar with the talks said.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: While some may not agree with all of the provisions of this agreement, I believe it is in the overall economic interest of the country.

title: ETHNIC GROUPS SUPPORT RIVAL TO LEADERS' CIVIL COURT PICK
description: A primary contest for a Civil Court judgeship in Manhattan has pitted a range of ethnic interests backing the challenger, Dorothy Chin Brandt, against the Democratic leadership and its candidate, Louis B. York.

title: Second Extortion Arrest In Missing-Child Case
description: An Federal Bureau of Investigation agent and a Tulsa police officer posed as parents of a missing child and arrested a Syracuse, N.Y., man on charges of attempted extortion and fraud.

title: Hands Across America Faces Costs and Delay
description: Only about half the $41.6 million raised by Hands Across America will be given to the needy because of high administrative costs, a newspaper reported.

title: Eleanor Bidien, 65, in Peking; Long a Press Agency Worker
description: Eleanor Bidien, an American who worked for the official New China News Agency for 35 years, died of a heart attack Aug. 5. She was 65 years old.

title: Discipline Tightened In Philippine Army
description: The Philippine military Chief of Staff has threatened to court-martial any officers who disobey transfer orders, a spokesman said today.

title: WCRS Bid Was Not Highest
description: WHEN the WCRS Group, a British advertising and public relations company, first reached out about five weeks ago to Della Femina, Travisano & Partners to talk about acquiring the high-powered agency, Jerry Della Femina, the chairman and one of the founders, did not rush into WCRS's arms, he said.

title: RANGEL'S CHARM AN ALLY IN RACE FOR HOUSE WHIP
description: Standing in the vestibule outside the floor of the House of Representatives, Henry B. Gonzalez was ''Rangeled'' last week.

title: TYSON WINS 26TH, KNOCKS OUT RIBALTA
description: Mike Tyson, the undefeated heavyweight, cut 6-foot-6-inch Jose Ribalta down to size tonight with a pressuring attack that ended when Referee Rudy Battle stopped the fight at 1:37 of the final round in a 10-round bout.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Margery Seplow Married To Robert Alan Richman
description: Margery Jan Seplow and Robert Alan Richman were married yesterday by Rabbi Phillip Samuel-Siegel at the Livingston (N.J.) Country Club. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic L. Seplow of Newton, N.J. Mr. Richman is a son of Mr. and Mrs. David Richman of East Windsor, N.J.

title: Topics: Health Fears/Facts; Blood Drought
description: Blood donations always lag during the summer, but this year city blood banks are facing drought. The reason: misplaced fear of AIDS.

title: Judge Rejects Eskimo's Plea To Bar Oil Drilling Off Alaska
description: A Federal district judge has denied a temporary restraining order that would have stopped oil drilling in the Arctic Ocean because Alaskan Eskimos had not proved that such exploration would harm the endangered whales they hunt for food. The judge said it was in the national inteest to develop the offshore oil leases.

title: Susan Stern, a Trader, Wed to Hy Pomerance
description: At the Lincoln Square Synagogue in New York yesterday Susan E. Stern, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Stern of Lake Forest, Calif., was married to Hy Pomerance, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Pomerance of Palm Beach, Fla. Rabbi Manfred Fulda performed the ceremony.

title: GUARDIANS OF THE SCREEN IMAGE
description: When producers of the movie ''Top Gun'' came to the Navy with a proposed script two years ago, the opening dogfight between American and Russian aviators flying high-powered jet fighters was to have been fought over land.

title: Ozone Depletion
description: To the Editor:

title: OPERA: 'THE DRUNKARD'
description: A PERIOD piece might be described as something with relevance to one age but to no other. Thus the Light Opera of Manhattan poses itself some difficult questions in its revival of ''The Drunkard'' at the Cherry Lane Theater. Does one, for example, inject late-20th-century commentary into William H. Smith's Victorian melodrama - mainly in the form of camp? Or does one trust in the original's sincerity despite its florid, no longer ''realistic,'' conventions?

title: Women at Work
description: Nearly two-thirds of the women in the Washington area, or about 833,000 of them, are working or looking for work, a higher percentage than in any other city in the country. A study by the Greater Washington Research Center shows 65.4 percent of Washington women in the work force, as against 61 in Atlanta, 55.1 in Chicago, 53.6 in Los Angeles and 45.1 in New York. Women made up 47 percent of the Washington area labor force in 1984, also a high for all metropolitan areas in the nation.

title: Manning Chooses 'Right Kind of Agency'
description: When Burt Manning was passed over for the top job at the J. Walter Thompson Company, and it became clear that he would eventually leave his post as chairman and chief executive of the agency's domestic unit, he had his pick of some of the most attractive jobs in advertising. Hours after his resignation from Thompson was made public last week, he announced his choice: He would become a principal in and chairman of the executive committee at Jordan, Case, Taylor & McGrath.

title: The O'Neill Factor
description: Hamilton Jordan, chief of staff in the Carter White House, lost the Democratic Senate nomination in Georgia last week after a campaign in which one of his television advertisements stressed that he was not ''another Tip O'Neill.'' Officials at the Democratic National Committee and the party's Congressional campaign committees could have told Mr. Jordan that this might not be a politically profitable line to follow: Their most recent poll showed Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. with a favorable-unfavorable rating nationally of 63-27 as of late July, up from 53-30 nine months earlier. The telephone survey of 997 registered voters was subject to a sampling error of plus or minus 3 percent.

title: DAISY'S REVAMPED MANAGEMENT FACES CHALLENGE
description: The management restructuring announced Friday at the Daisy Systems Corporation should help the computer-aided engineering systems manufacturer's credibility with customers and investors, analysts said. But they added that the new management faces substantial challenges in returning the once-high-flying company based in Mountain View, Calif., to its former health.

title: O.&M. Complaint Reopened by Court
description: A Federal appeals court last week reversed a lower court that had thrown out a sex discrimination case brought against the New York office of Ogilvy & Mather and ordered the lower court to reopen the proceedings.

title: Bob Dylan to Appear in New Film by Marquand
description: Bob Dylan will star in his first feature film in eight years in a movie titled ''Hearts of Fire'' that is to begin shooting later this month, the director Richard Marquand said today.

title: New Magazine's Deal
description: In the humid hothouse of political Washington, new magazines germinate and blossom with some frequency, but not many of them try to build a subscriber base with a special introductory rate of $395 a year, ''a savings of $55 off the regular price.'' That distinction currently goes to FED Fortnightly, a new biweekly devoted exclusively to the Federal Reserve System, its policies and politics and its chairman, Paul A. Volcker. According to the magazine's editor and publisher, Paul H. Weaver, a former Washington editor of Fortune, it will combine ''the readability and high-quality writing of a news weekly with the analytical sophistication of the best financial newsletters.''

title: New Orleans Strike Averted
description: Union streetcar and bus drivers agreed Saturday to a smaller pay increase in favor of better job security in a new two-year contract that averted a strike. The new contract calls for an immediate payment of $600 to full-time drivers and $375 to part-time drivers. It will also allow the transit authority to phase out a 40-year-old overtime system that allowed some drivers to earn as much as 16 hours of overtime a week, whether they put in the time or not.

title: CHILE'S LEADER REPORTED TO REJECT U.S. CALLS FOR DEMOCRATIC CHANGE
description: Gen. Augusto Pinochet of Chile has rejected proposals of a Reagan Administration envoy for substantial improvements in Chile's human rights record and a political transition to democracy, Administration officials said today.

title: Electronics Girds For Tax Credit Cut
description: Corporate America, despite a reduction in tax rates, will face an increased tax burden of $120 billion over the next five years as a result of the sweeping tax changes contemplated in the legislation approved this weekend by Congressional conferees. But that burden will fall unevenly.

title: CARLTON WINNER OVER BREWER
description: Steve Carlton allowed three hits in seven and one-third innings for his first American League victory, and Ron Hassey, Daryl Boston and Ozzie Guillen had three hits apiece today to lead the White Sox to a 7-4 victory over the Milwaukee Brewers.

title: Heavy Industry Sees Problems
description: Corporate America, despite a reduction in tax rates, will face an increased tax burden of $120 billion over the next five years as a result of the sweeping tax changes contemplated in the legislation approved this weekend by Congressional conferees. But that burden will fall unevenly.

title: Elizabeth I. Miller Is Wed in Scarsdale
description: Elizabeth Irene Miller, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William S. Miller of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Randolph Guggenheimer 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Guggenheimer Jr. of New York. Rabbi Jack Stern Jr. performed the ceremony at the Westchester Reform Temple.

title: 'NEW WOMAN' IS NOT SO NEW, STUDY SAYS
description: The ''new woman'' of the 1980's, the one who has a small family or perhaps no children at all, the one who has the same education as her male counterparts, is not so ''new'' after all: she is, in fact, very like her grandmother.

title: A PAS DE DEUX OF FLIRTING AND FUN
description: At one point during Broadway's newest hit musical, ''Me and My Girl,'' which opened last week at the Marquis Theater, a scantily clad seductress slinks onto the stage to have her way with the play's reluctant hero.

title: The Tops in Bocce
description: Their eyes reflect the patience of a .300 hitter and the intensity of a middle linebacker.

title: ON WATER: TOO LITTLE, TOO MUCH
description: With the Great Lakes at record-breaking high levels, some officials in the Middle West have been smugly predicting that this abundance of a basic ingredient for industry would help the region regain manufacturing jobs it had lost to the parched Southeast.

title: SWEDISH CHIEF ASSAILS NUCLEAR POWER
description: Prime Minister Ingvar Carlsson assailed nuclear power today, particularly stressing the Chernobyl disaster, which has forced many Swedes to change their eating habits.

title: 'SYMPHONIE FANTASTIQUE,' ON BRAVO
description: ''A YOUNG musician of morbid sensibility and ardent imagination is in love, and has poisoned himself with opium in a fit of desperation. Not having taken a lethal dose, he falls into a long sleep in which he has the strangest dreams, wherein his feelings, sentiments and memories are translated by his sick brain into musical ideas and figures. The beloved woman herself has become a melody which he finds and hears everywhere as an Idee fixe.''

title: LAND MINE KILLS 5 BLACKS ON A SOUTH AFRICA FARM
description: A land mine exploded under a private car on a farm road today, killing three black women and two infants, the Government said.

title: Oil Industry: Damage Blunted
description: Corporate America, despite a reduction in tax rates, will face an increased tax burden of $120 billion over the next five years as a result of the sweeping tax changes contemplated in the legislation approved this weekend by Congressional conferees. But that burden will fall unevenly.

title: Debt Step Helps Auction Schedule
description: Congressional approval over the weekend of a temporary increase in the debt ceiling should mean no disruption in the Treasury financing schedule over the next several weeks.

title: MUSEUM IN PARIS TO CLOSE
description: After 39 years as the exhibition ground for France's major collection of Impressionist paintings, the Museum of the Jeu de Paume is to close on Monday, and its 500 paintings, including masterpieces by Manet, Monet, Degas, Renoir, Gaugin, Cezanne and others, will be transferred a few hundred yards to a new site across the Seine.

title: CALLING POLICE PROTECTS ABUSED WIVES, REPORT SAYS
description: Women who report violence in the home to the police substantially reduce their risk of being abused again, according to a Justice Department report issued today.

title: Hinault Is Leader With LeMond 2d
description: Bernard Hinault, who says he may retire this year, took the lead in the Coors International Bicycle Classic today, with Greg LeMond close behind.

title: U.S. Wins Final, Beating Russians
description: Cheryl Miller of Southern California scored 24 points to lead the United States to a 108-88 victory over the Soviet Union for the gold medal in the Women's World Basketball Championships.

title: Bridge: Tournament in Los Angeles Is Association's Biggest Yet
description: The biggest tournament in the 54-year history of the American Bridge Association ended Saturday in Los Angeles. To its Summer Nationals the association attracted a number of players who normally compete in the American Contract Bridge League, a much larger body.

title: IMPACT ON INDIVIDUALS TO STRETCH FAR BEYOND AVERAGE 6% CUT
description: The personal financial affairs of every American taxpayer will be touched in a fundamental way by the sweeping new tax bill approved by Congressional conferees.

title: Washington Watch; Bank Board Backs Down
description: AT times, Government agencies propose regulations that produce great hand-wringing by the regulated industries. But seldom has an outcry erupted like the one created by a rule proposed earlier this year by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board. And seldom has an agency been more embarrassed.

title: CO-OPERATIVE BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The company said Co-Operative Bank of Concord converted to stock format in December, 1985. In May, Co-Operative Bancorp was formed as a holding company with Co-Operative Bank of Concord as its principal subsidiary.

title: EASTPARK REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes gains of $138,000 and $37,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, on sales of real estate. c-Includes gains on sales of real estate of $2,000 for the quarter and $347,000 for the 6 months.

title: U.S. REVIEWING MIDEAST EVENTS TO WIDEN ROLE
description: The Reagan Administration has begun a review of what officials term the ''evolving situation'' in the Middle East, Administration officials said today.

title: Simplicity and Automation in Dialing for Data
description: TELECOMMUNICATIONS is a real love-hate experience as far as I'm concerned.

title: STRAWBERRY REBOUNDS AND POWERS METS
description: It should be known by now as the annual Strawberry blues. The Mets' powerful young outfielder goes through a prolonged slump and his team goes through a middling period of its own. When it happened this year, the old conclusion could be reached: The Mets need him.

title: IRVINE reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
description: b-Net income

title: GENZYME CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The company went public in June.

title: President Leaves Fox's Film Unit
description: Alan Horn, the president and chief operating officer of the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation, resigned yesterday because of differences with the studio chairman who hired him 10 months ago, the company said.

title: STILL WINNING
description: Carlton, 41, is one of four active pitchers with more than 300 victories. The active leaders, with their current teams:

title: IN AMERICA, PARIS BOUFFANT
description: Scarcely had the applause died down in Paris for such lively couture revivals as the bustle and the bouffant petticoated dress when similar shapes began turning up in ready-to-wear showrooms on Seventh Avenue.

title: AN AMATEUR IN TRUE SENSE
description: The man juggles for a living. George Zahringer is an associate director for Bear, Stearns & Company, the brokerage investment banking firm. That is, except on those Fridays when he is working toward a master's degree in business administration at Columbia, or when he is with his wife and three sons at home in Manhattan, or when he is playing golf.

title: BLACK INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Rights Gained for Film About Winnie Mandela
description: The exclusive rights to make a film about Winnie Mandela, the anti-apartheid activist who is married to the imprisoned South African opposition leader Nelson Mandela, have been gained by Camille Cosby, a record producer and the wife of the television star Bill Cosby.

title: HCC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
description: b-Net income

title: People
description: * Norman Bierman will join Ted Bates/New York as executive vice president of client services and director of business development.

title:
ADVERTISING;
New Center at N.Y.U. For Direct Marketing
description: The direct-marketing industry needs more direct marketers, according to Lester Wunderman. ''The problem we had, and still have in the industry, is that we're outgrowing our employee base,'' said the chairman of Wunderman, Ricotta & Kline, the Young & Rubicam unit that is the biggest agency in the business.

title: An Empress Wins
description: An Empress, dreadful on the dirt in two previous starts at the meeting, woke up on the grass to score a rallying 1 1/4-length victory over Fama in the $87,000 Nijana Stakes for 3-year-old fillies today at Saratoga Race Track.

title: CELINA FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes investment gains of $97,959 and $98,625 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes investment gains of $21,920 for the quarter and $23,481 for the 6 months.

title: The Archives: No Place for Partisans
description: No closet has more political skeletons than the National Archives, custodian of a billion Federal documents. To assure the fullest access, Congress two years ago made the Archives independent, liberating it from the General Services Administration. The hope was that the President would stiffen that independence by appointing a qualified, impartial Archivist. It appears to be a vain hope.

title: CONTROL LASER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: COSMETICS & FRAGRANCE CONEPTS reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
description: b-Net loss

title: Cuomo Asks Disaster Aid
description: Governor Cuomo asked President Reagan today to provide more Federal disaster aid for Chautauqua and Cattaraugus Counties and neighboring areas hit by flash flooding last month and Aug. 1.

title: Officials Assail Offer To Store Bone Marrow
description: New York State health and consumer protection authorities urged the Attorney General yesterday to close a Manhattan company that offers to store bone marrow for future transplants.

title: MEDAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FEDERAL SCREW WORKS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Vuckovich Comeback
description: In an attempt to get back to the Milwaukee Brewers, Pete Vuckovich, the 1982 winner of the American League Cy Young Award, is in the midst of a comeback with the Vancouver Canadians, Milwaukee's farm team in the Class AAA International League. ''I like the way it's going, too,'' said Vuckovich, who is 1-0 after two starts and two relief apparances and has not allowed an earned run in 14 innings.

title: Bridge: Video Offers a Way to Play In Partnership With Sharif
description: Some bridge enthusiasts, whether movie fans or not, have dreamed of the pleasure of having Omar Sharif as a partner at the card table. He is very nearly as expert at bridge as he is at acting.

title: INFINITY BROADCASTING reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary losses on early extinguishment of debt of $6,257,000 for the quarter and $6,806,000 for the 6 months. c-Net income

title: FIRST WORLD CHEESE reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
David T. Gibbons, 65; State Appellate Justice
description: Associate Justice David T. Gibbons of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court died of an aneurysm Sunday at his home in West Hempstead, L.I. He was 65 years old.

title: SOVIET OIL EXPORT RISE PREDICTED BY CONSULTANT
description: The Soviet Union may increase its oil exports substantially this fall, prompted by sharply higher energy production and by a need for hard currency, according to a Washington-based consulting firm. The report refocused attention on the Soviet potential for playing a big role in the world oil markets.

title: Countrywide Mortgage Offer
description: Countrywide Mortgage Obligations Inc. is offering $105 million of collateralized mortgage obligations in four parts through underwriters led by Paine Webber Inc.

title: ADVANCES IN GENETIC FORECASTS INCREASE CONCERNS
description: GENETIC analysis to predict a person's health and life expectancy may soon give society unprecedented influence over people's choices in areas ranging from life insurance to careers or even mates.

title: HAGLER BACKING LEONARD BOUT
description: Marvelous Marvin Hagler, the undisputed middleweight champion, agreed yesterday to a March 1987 fight with Sugar Ray Leonard, the former undisputed welterweight champion, according to a statement by Pat Petronelli, Hagler's co-manager.

title: Ashton Ends Copying Curb
description: Ashton-Tate, the maker of personal computer software, said yesterday that it would remove copy protection devices from all of its programs, including the popular dBase series of database managers, in response to protests from users.

title: 2 WALL STREET FIRMS WIDEN DRUG TESTING OF THEIR EMPLOYEES
description: Two Wall Street firms have toughened their drug testing programs of employees, apparently becoming the first brokerage houses to check not just incoming, but existing employees for use of illegal drugs.

title: MAYNARD OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GORBACHEV SAYS SOVIET TEST HALT IS AGAIN EXTENDED
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev announced today that the Soviet Union was continuing its yearlong halt of underground nuclear testing until next Jan. 1.

title: GTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ELDORADO MOTOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
Career; The High Salaries In Law
description: PRACTICING lawyers have an average annual household income of $121,000 at the age of 38, according to Laurence Bodine, the new editor and publisher of the Journal of the American Bar Association. Mr. Bodine, in New York last week for the association's annual meeting, conducted a survey of 500 attorneys to determine the affluence and way of life of the profession, one of the highest-paid in the country.

title: DELTA DATA SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL METS VS. DODGERS, at Los Angeles, 10:35 P.M. (Television - Channel 9, 10:30 P.M.; Radio - WHN, 1050; 10:30 P.M.) YANKEES VS.

title: Nystrom in Line for Post
description: The Islanders have called a news conference for today at which they are expected to announce that Bobby Nystrom has been named the assistant coach to Terry Simpson, the new coach.

title: Sara Lee Kiwi Bid
description: The Sara Lee Corporation said that it had offered $130 million for all the shares it did not already own in Nicholas Kiwi Australasia Ltd., the shoe polish and consumer products company with operations in Australia and New Zealand.

title: CRITICS AWAIT TAX REVOLUTION
description: By some accounts, Congress's new tax achievement is not as revolutionary as it is cracked up to be. Indeed, according to one school of thought, the tax bill that House and Senate conferees approved Saturday night mainly undoes the distortions that high inflation wreaked on the tax system over the past decade.

title: COMPLAINT BY SMALL BUSINESSES
description: Owners of small companies from around the country expressed frustration today with President Reagan's treatment of small business and complained that while Mr. Reagan had devoted much oratory to the importance of small business his policy initiatives did not reflect that concern.

title: MAY ENERGY PARTNERS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a pre-tax writedown of $4.6 million. c-After a pre-tax writedown of $8 million on oil and gas properties for the quarter and 6 months.

title: For Poland, the Carrot and the Yardstick
description: Until a few weeks ago, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski's Polish regime had been displaying a new hard line in its internal politics, the best examples being the arrests on May 31 of Zbigniew Bujak, the chief of Solidarity's underground, and of other Solidarity activists. These occurred before the party congress, and indeed may have been directly related to General Jaruzelski's wish to strengthen his hand with hard-liners.

title: Toward Domestic Oil Prosperity
description: When oil prices began to plummet earlier this year, the event was met with a general euphoria by residents and politicians in energy-consuming states. Within weeks, Texas-bashing became the nation's No. 1 pastime. Newspaper and magazine articles carried headlines like ''Texas Takes a Tumble'' and ''The Great Texas Oil Bust,'' and Yankee pundits had a field day writing columns titled ''Let 'Em Rot in the Sun'' and ''Cap a Well and Starve a Texan.''

title: CARDINAL INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Eaton Debentures
description: The Eaton Corporation, an electronics and electrical systems manufacturer, is offering $100 million of 8 percent debentures due 2006 at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. Rated A-2 by Moody's and A by S.&P., the debentures are non-callable, but allow investors to put, or redeem, the issue after 10 years at a price of 100. The debentures yield about eight-tenths of a percentage point more than the 7 3/8 percent Treasury note due 1996.

title: New Chief At Loews Hotels
description: Robert J. Hausman has been promoted to chairman and chief executive of the Loews Hotels Division, replacing Preston Robert Tisch, who has been named Postmaster General of the United States.

title: AIR DEFENSE SYSTEM FOR U.S. ARMY APPROVED
description: The Defense Department has approved an Army plan to spend $11 billion in the next 10 years on new weapons to defend infantry divisions from air attack, Army officials said today.

title: 2 East German Guards Escape Over Berlin Wall
description: Two East German border guards escaped over the Berlin wall and then tossed their guns back into the East, the West Berlin police said today.

title: NEW LASER OFFERS GREAT POWER AND FLEXIBILITY
description: RECENT advances in the free electron laser have pushed it to the forefront of efforts to harness intense beams of light for new uses in medicine, chemistry, pharmaceuticals, electronics, energy production and beam weaponry.

title: Talking Business; Call for Caution In Investment: Garnett L. Keith of Prudential Insurance
description: The Prudential Insurance Company of America has long used the Rock of Gibraltar, suggesting solidity, as its corporate symbol. But that symbol only hints at the mammoth size of ''The Pru,'' as the institution is known.

title: TERRORISM ELSEWHERE SPURS HAWAII TOURISM
description: Vacation travel, the principal industry of Hawaii, is setting new records this year, and industry analysts attribute the surge to tourists' fear of terrorism in Europe and the Middle East.

title: STEP-BY-STEP INSTRUCTIONS FOR CALCULATING THE CHANGES
description: For many taxpayers, the litmus test of whether tax revision is a good thing will undoubtedly be how they fare under the new system.

title: MACKEY POSTS 276 TO WIN FIRST EVENT
description: Cindy Mackey said she learned something about her golf game and herself in winning the MasterCard International here today. Her lesson was pleasant and profitable. But Colleen Walker's lesson was bitter and costly.

title: ANDERSON CLAYTON & CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $727,000 and $1,384,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and losses on disposition of discontinued operations of $24,612,000 for the quarter and $4,626,000 for the year. c-Net income d-After losses from discontinued operations of $7,260,000 for the quarter and $12,188,000 for the year.

title: Air Employees Entitled to Fair Treatment
description: To the Editor:

title: CODENOLL TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HADRON INCORPORATED reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HOME FEDERALL SAVINGS & LOAN OF THE ROCKES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * H. F. Ahmanson & Co., Los Angeles, a residential real estate financial services concern, has elected as a director Lodwrick M. Cook, chairman and chief executive of Atlantic Richfield Co.

title: G.M.A.C. Sale Of Certificates
description: The General Motors Acceptance Corporation is offering $1.08 billion of pass-through certificates backed by a pool of automobile and truck loan receivables through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: RED CROSS SUSPENDS FLIGHTS AFTER ATTACK ON SUDAN PLANE
description: The International Committee of the Red Cross announced today that it had halted airborne deliveries of grain to the southern Sudan after rebel forces shot down a Sudanese airliner carrying 60 people over the weekend.

title: NETWORK SECURITY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After extraordinary gains of $656,000 for the quarter and $660,000 for the 6 months. c-After extraordinary gains of $40,000 for the quarter and $77,000 for the 6 months.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a transmission error, a report in Press Notes yesterday about articles by Renata Adler in The New Yorker on two libel cases omitted a comment from The New Yorker. In response to criticism of the articles by a defendant in one of the libel cases, CBS News, a spokesman for the magazine said Friday: ''The editors here have studied the CBS News memorandum carefully. As far as they can see, Ms. Adler's facts are solid and her opinions are supported by her facts.''

title: Measuring Radiation
description: Scientists at the Sandia National Laboratory and the University of New Mexico report that a radiation-measuring device intended for use in weapon systems has been adapted for use in cancer patients undergoing radiation therapy.

title: TANDY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results have been restated to reflect plans announced in June 1986 by the company to spin out its foreign retail units.

title: ROCK: GENESIS P-ORRIDGE
description: GENESIS P-ORRIDGE (a name to conjure with) often seemed to be the most extreme and interesting personality in the innovative late-70's industrial-rock group Throbbing Gristle. After the group's last performance in 1981, Mr. P-Orridge and Throbbing Gristle's Peter Christopherson formed Psychic TV, which assembled different band personnel for specific projects and released a diverse batch of recordings, including everything from sonic art brut to chiming pop-rock like the music on the current single ''Godstar.'' Mr. Christopherson seemed to have left somewhere along the way.

title: ILLINOIS COMPANY CHARGES ISRAEL TRIED TO GAIN TECHNOLOGY SECRETS
description: Justice Department and Customs Service officials said tonight that they were investigating a dispute in which an Illinois company has accused the Israeli Government of trying to take its technological secrets.

title: Stocks Mixed as Dow Gains 13.92
description: The stock market ended mixed yesterday, but the Dow Jones industrial average continued to advance after its 73-point rise last week.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, AUGUST 19, 1986
description: The Tax Bill of 1986

title: LUGAR SEES AQUINO IN MANILA
description: Senator Richard G. Lugar, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, met today with President Corazon C. Aquino and gave her what he said was a letter of support from President Reagan, who will be her host in Washington next month.

title: Chess Game Delayed For Karpov Timeout
description: The ninth game of the World Chess Championship between the champion, Gary Kasparov and the challenger, Anatoly Karpov, was postponed today when Karpov took a timeout.

title: FUNDSNET INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
AN INTENT TO KILL DRUG AGENT SEEN
description: The Mexican policemen who American officials say tortured a Drug Enforcement Administration agent last week probably intended to kill him, officials close to the investigation of the case said today.

title: JETS' WALKER STILL FEELS SAFE
description: Wesley Walker slept soundly under a beige blanket before returning to the Jets' workouts today - as if he knew all along that with the Giants' game looming, he'd be back where he belongs.

title: Amax Layoffs, Cutbacks Set
description: Amax Inc., the world's largest producer of molybdenum, said yesterday that it was cutting production at its two major mines as a result of falling demand. The company said that as a result of the production cuts, its work force would be reduced by about 415 management and hourly workers.

title: NICHOLS-HOMESHIELD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CORRECTION
description: An article Aug. 12 on women in New York State politics misidentified a candidate in the Democratic Congressional primary in Westchester County. She is Dolores Battalia, not Delores Battaglia.

title: HOME FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN (MERIDIAN,FLA) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Murder Charge Voted In Campus Shootings
description: A Brooklyn grand jury yesterday voted to indict a 29-year-old student accused of shooting five people, one fatally, on the campus of New York City Technical College last week.

title: USE OF PLANT CAPACITY DIPS TO 78.2%
description: In a new sign of economic weakness, the Government said today that factories operated at 78.2 percent of capacity in July, for the third straight decline and lowest rate since 1983.

title: 2 COLLECTORS ASSEMBLE AUSCHWITZ DOCUMENTARY
description: Bengt von zur Muhlen concedes that he buys flat round tins of old film obsessively, ''like a stamp collector,'' and now has one of the world's biggest private film archives stashed in the basement of a stucco house in the West Berlin suburbs.

title:
THE TAX BILL OF 1986: AMERICA PLANS ACCORDINGLY;
Accounting Workload Surging
description: While members of the House and Senate conference committee enjoy a three-week recess after passing the tax revision package Saturday night, the workload has only increased for those who make a living giving tax advice.

title: 2 IOWA LEGISLATORS INDICTED IN BACHELOR PARTY CASE
description: A Jasper County grand jury today indicted two Iowa legislators and three other people on charges stemming from a bachelor party given for one of the lawmakers last April.

title: PRATT HOTEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary net credit of $274,000 for the quarter and 6 months. c-After a net credit of $8,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary gain of $49,000 for the 6 months.

title: INTERNATIONAL MOBILE MAHINES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
He Helps Hold India And America Together
