description: There are any number of foreign representatives working the corridors of power in Washington. And then there is Janki Ganju, a 59-year-old jovial extrovert who is known here as ''Mr. India.''

title: The Medical Lobbies: Differing Opinions
description: Doctors and hospitals have much in common as pillars of the medical establishment. But their lobbyists, among the more powerful in Washington, differ markedly.

title: WALKER ENERGY PARTNERS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After writedowns of $9.7 million and $14.1 million on the value of oil and gas properties for the quarter and 6 months.

title: NEW YORKERS STILL DEBATE SALES TAX
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan and Representative Charles B. Rangel traded accusations yesterday over who was responsible for the failure of the new tax plan to retain state and local sales tax deductions.

title: The Music Of Life
description: When the first full rehearsal of the Glyndebourne festival's ''Porgy and Bess'' ended, the entire cast was crying. The singers were that caught up in the tragic story and George Gershwin's expression of it in music. But more than that, they must have known they were part of a rare experience: a production that redeems an artistic vision, rescuing it from doubts, bringing it to life.

title: ROWLEY-SCHER REPROGRAPHCS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Sun Selling Arts Unit to Dainippon
description: The Sun Chemical Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to accept a sweetened, $550 million offer to sell its graphic arts material group to Dainippon Ink and Chemicals Inc. of Tokyo.

title: Anderson, Clayton Loss
description: Anderson, Clayton & Company said yesterday that it had lost $22.6 million in its fourth quarter ended June 30 because of write-downs in inventory and in its investment in a subsidiary. The food products conglomerate earned $3.4 million, or 28 cents a share, a year earlier.

title: Four-Year-Olds Can Do Without Instruction in a School Setting
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''With many new players now entering the game and building new production facilities on this continent, we're in a deadly game of musical chairs.

title: Pipe Bomb Injures 4 In Dakota Post Office
description: A pipe bomb in a package exploded at the downtown Post Office tonight, slightly injuring four workers, the police said.

title: Trio Against Drugs
description: Michael Jordan of the Chicago Bulls, Buck Williams of the Nets and Johnny Dawkins, the San Antonio Spurs' top draft choice, will take part in a program next month urging youngsters to stay away from drugs.

title: 'GODDESS OF THE EARTH,' ON 'NOVA'
description: THIS evening's provocative ''Nova'' presentation on Channel 13, ''Goddess of the Earth,'' explores the intriguing thesis that the entire earth is, in a sense, an enormous living organism.

title: CITY DOUBLES FINES FOR LANDLORDS WHO BREAK WINDOW-GUARD LAW
description: A New York City Health Department tribunal has decided to double the fines against landlords who fail to comply with statutes requiring the installation of window guards in apartments where children under the age of 10 live, officials said yesterday.

title: CBI INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain from debt restructuring of $6,917,000. c-Net loss

title: Vicorp Restaurants Sells Specialty Unit
description: Vicorp Restaurants Inc. said it had signed a letter of intent to sell its specialty restaurant subsidiary to a group including Gordon H. Miles, the chairman of Vicorp; the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation, and others.

title: DAXOR CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
World's Largest Taped Library for the Blind
description: To the Editor:

title: Heeeere's Grandy
description: After three weeks of haggling, Fred Grandy, the Republican candidate for the House in Iowa's Sixth District, has allowed videotapes of remarks he made on Johnny Carson's ''Tonight'' show a few years ago to be released.

title: The Silver Linings In Britain's Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: CETUS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
AMERICAN SHARED HOSPITAL SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title:
ADVERTISING;
Graphic Media Buys The Venet Companies
description: Venet Companies, the largest ad agency in New Jersey, with $70 million in billings, has been acquired for an undisclosed amount by Graphic Media of Fairfield, N.J.

title: Hutton Mortgage Suit
description: The E. F. Hutton Mortgage Corporation is seeking at least $148 million from Equitable Bank N.A. and has accused the bank of fraud, conspiracy and breach of fiduciary duty. The lawsuit is the latest development in a series of events that saw the mortgage broker Famco shut its doors last November. The Hutton mortgage unit later filed a separate multimillion-dollar fraud suit against Famco and its chief, Michael H. Clott, which is pending in Federal court.

title: DATAMARINE INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
Chairman of Color Tile Not Surprised by Offer
description: When Tandycrafts Inc. was spun off from the Tandy Corporation, John A. Wilson went with it. When Color Tile Inc. was spun off from Tandycrafts in April 1979, Mr. Wilson went with it again. Today, as chairman, president and chief executive of the large home improvement products retailer in Fort Worth, he is faced with the possibility of his company going private.

title: TEXTRON ACQUIRING EX-CELL-O
description: Textron Inc. said yesterday that it had signed a definitive agreement to buy the Ex-Cell-O Corporation for $77.50 a share in cash, totaling about $1.1 billion.

title: MILGRAY ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: DAIRIES FEWER BUT STRONGER
description: ''Have more milk, 'cause milk's got more,'' the National Dairy Promotion and Research Board began urging in 1983, when milk-drinking had been in an eight-year slump. The $66 million-a-year campaign got its message across: The consumption of milk and other dairy products has grown 7 percent since the ads first ran.

title: RADICAL THEORIST TAKES HIS MESSAGE TO THE WORLD
description: WITHIN days of the triumph of the Sandinista Revolution in July 1979, Nicaragua's new leaders had tracked down the Brazilian educator Paulo Freire at the university where he was lecturing in the United States and had issued him an invitation to come to Managua to help reorganize the country's education system and design its new literacy program.

title: Political Game
description: Baseball is a game of inches and, sometimes, so are political campaigns. Two front-runners in the United States Senate race in Florida are cultivating ties to baseball while raising funds for the stretch drive.

title: Quaker Deal Final
description: The Quaker Oats Company has completed the previously announced $275 million purchase of the Golden Grain Macaroni Company, whose brands include Rice-A-Roni, Noodle-Roni, Golden Grain and Mission pasta, Ghirardelli chocolate and Vernell candy.

title: Messing's Dual Role
description: Shep Messing will serve as president of the club and goalkeeper for the New York Express, which has replaced the defunct Pittsburgh Spirit in the Major Indoor Soccer League.

title: Parking Unit's Pacts Said to Lack Review
description: Eight years of contracts between the city's Parking Violations Bureau and private collection agencies should have been submitted to the State Financial Control Board for review but never were, the State Comptroller's office has charged.

title: 600 DINE AND DANCE IN A NEWPORT 'COTTAGE'
description: ''You can always get the people, you can always get the music, but you can't always get such a jewel-in-the-crown house,'' Helen Winslow was saying Saturday night as some 600 formally attired guests swirled in and out of a few of the 70 rooms of The Breakers. The grand-scale mansion - it has been called America's most famous summer cottage - was built here in the 1890's for Cornelius Vanderbilt and his family.

title: NERVOUS REGION SPARED AS CHARLEY HEADS TO SEA
description: After contributing to at least five deaths and walloping the mid-Atlantic coast with winds that sometimes topped 100 miles per hour, Hurricane Charley weakened yesterday and headed out to sea before reaching New Jersey.

title: DIVERSIFIED HUMAN REOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $126,000.

title: PORTS OF CALL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: EXPERTS EXPRESS DOUBTS OVER CONVICTING DEAVER FOR PERJURY
description: Legal experts say it is usually difficult to convict someone under the perjury laws cited in regard to the testimony of Michael K. Deaver, the former White House deputy chief of staff, before a Congressional subcommittee.

title: LASERMETRICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: BIOTECHNICA INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CITY EMPLOYEES IN HOUSTON HALT GARBAGE PICKUP
description: City sanitation workers walked off their jobs today and staged an angry protest at City Hall to protest salary cuts and added work brought on by the city's budget crisis.

title: JOHN'S LATE SUCCESS SURPRISES EVERYONE
description: His goal for the last nine starts of his career, Tommy John said yesterday, is to get 1,925 strikeouts. ''I have 2,075; I want to finish with 4,000,'' the Yankees' pitcher said. John's wife, Sally, quickly interrupted him. She wanted to make sure his listener knew he was joking.

title: Market Place; Honeywell's Prospects
description: WHEN the Burroughs Corporation was pursuing the rival Sperry Corporation last spring, one rumor came up time and again on Wall Street. A deal was brewing between Sperry and Honeywell Inc., the gossip said.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Edward McCaskey, the board chairman of the Chicago Bears, was reported in stable condition at Holy Family Hospital after suffering and apparent mild heart attack. The 67-year-old McCaskey entered the hospital late Sunday after experiencing chest pains. . . . George Brett, the Kansas City Royals' third baseman who hit .423 last week, was named the American League Player of the Week. . . . Ed Murphy, who coached Delta State Universsity the last three years, has been named head basketball coach at the University of Mississippi. . . . A. J. Foyt, a four-time Indianapolis 500 winner, took on a new role at the track Saturday when he gave away a bride, one day before competing in the Pocono 500. Foyt was sitting on the pit wall at Pocono International Raceway when the woman came up and asked if he would give her away.

title: CENTRAL RESERVE LIFE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
COMMODORE POSTS GAIN; TANDY DOWN IN QUARTER
description: Commodore International Ltd. yesterday posted its first quarterly profit since 1984, but the computer maker also reported a loss of almost $130 million for the fiscal year. Commodore also said it would receive a qualified opinion from its auditors, as it did on its 1985 financial statements.

title: Blacks' Hypertension and a Salt Link
description: Black Americans may have a genetic predisposition to high blood pressure because of an unusual ability to retain salt, according to a specialist in vascular disease.

title: REAGAN MAY SEEK TAX BILL CHANGES AFTER ENACTMENT
description: President Reagan could seek to revise the House-Senate version of the tax bill once it is enacted, White House officials said today.

title: VOTE IS TO BE SET
description: Negotiators for striking telephone workers agreed on a tentative contract with the New York and New England Telephone companies yesterday and the strikers began returning to work early this morning.

title: DRILLERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The company said in the year-ago quarter, preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income.

title: Jaguar Net Rises 24.9%
description: Jaguar P.L.C., the British luxury auto maker, said today that its net income for the first half of this year rose 24.9 percent, to $:45.1 million, or about $67.2 million at current exchange rates, from $:36.1 million a year earlier.

title: MAN SEIZED IN SLAYING OF OFFICER
description: A 32-year-old illegal alien suspected of slaying a rookie police officer in Queens seven weeks ago was captured yesterday while scrambling up a fire escape in an attempt to flee detectives who had trapped him in a Brooklyn building, police officials said.

title: TARTIKOFF ESCORTS NBC INTO THE MOVIE BUSINESS
description: When the General Electric Company acquired RCA and its network subsidiary, NBC, this year, one of the first tasks facing G.E. management was keeping Brandon Tartikoff, president of NBC Entertainment, from quitting television for the movie business.

title: PRESIDENT AND A SENATOR SEEN AS THE BILL'S POLITICAL WINNERS
description: President Reagan, a Republican who is not seeking higher office, and Senator Bill Bradley, a Democrat who probably is, emerged as clear winners from the long deliberations that produced the tax bill, in the opinion of political analysts here.

title: EXCERPTS FROM GORBACHEV'S SPEECH ON A-TEST MORATORIUM
description: Following are excerpts from the speech today by Mikhail S. Gorbachev, as distributed in translation by the Soviet press agency Tass:

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in Metropolitan Report yesterday with an article about Representative Charles B. Rangel incorrectly identified a Congressman at a party for Mr. Rangel. He was Bill Boner of Tennessee, not Tommy F. Robinson of Arkansas.

title: ARDEN INTERNATIONAL KITCHNS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Immigration Staff Is Short 150
description: The Immigration and Naturalization Service is 150 agents below strength because many investigators are quitting the agency, a spokesman for the service said today.

title: MARY DECKER SLANEY: MOTHER AND MILER
description: Mary Decker Slaney believes in schedules -for herself and also for Ashley Lynn Slaney, born May 30. Her schedule included a run on the track six days after giving birth, which she calls ''the most pain I have ever felt in my life.'' And her daughter's schedule is no less important.

title: INTEREST RATES CHANGE LITTLE
description: Interest rates were little changed yesterday. Many traders and investors were either absent on vacation or waiting for additional economic data and for the Federal Reserve to provide fresh direction to rates.

title: JOHNSON ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the year-ago quarter and 6 months net includes a gain of $178,000, or 11 cents a share on property.

title: JOHN ADAMS LIFE reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $51,000 for the quarter and $100,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes a realized investment gain of $4,000 for the quarter and a realized investment loss of $8,000 for the 6 months, and a tax credit of $68,000 for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for belwether issues.

title: Ward to Purchase Bank in Delaware
description: Montgomery Ward & Company said today that it had agreed to buy the majority of the Clayton Bank and Trust Company of Clayton, Del.

title: PROFESSIONAL CARE SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
COMPUTER IDENTICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: FLEXWATT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Oil Heiress Is Robbed For Fifth Time in 9 Years
description: The police said that a knife-wielding bandit rousted an oil heiress from her bed early today and robbed her of up to $5 million in jewelry. It was the second million-dollar theft in the city's mansion district in a month.

title: ENERGYNORTH INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Four-Year-Olds Can Do Without Instruction in a School Setting
description: To the Editor:

title: Taft Broadcasting Stake Acquired
description: The American Financial Corporation and its chairman, Carl H. Lindner, have purchased 5 percent of the Taft Broadcasting Company. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, American Financial and Mr. Lindner said they had bought the Taft shares for investment purposes only but added that they intended to review their investment on a ''continuing basis and may change their plans depending on future developments.''

title: Battery Park Authority In $180 Million Issue
description: The Battery Park City Authority, whose grand development plans were derailed in the mid-1970s by New York City's fiscal crisis and depressed real estate values, is coming of age in the financial markets.

title: ANGOLA HEAD SEEKS REAGAN TALKS
description: The President of Angola called today for a meeting with President Reagan to ease tensions between Angola and the United States, and bring peace to southern Africa.

title: STAGE: JEFFREY ESSMANN PERFORMS
description: THE continuing free summer Dance and Performance series produced at the Central Park Band Shell by Creative Time, under the aegis of the Central Park Summerstage program, offers an invaluable way to catch up on what's new and interesting in those two art forms. And if the program of performance art presented on Sunday afternoon is any guide, there is some vital work being done on the city's other stages.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: MOSTLY OVER The Mostly Mozart Festival has mostly run its course for this summer, but, like all feasts, some of the tastiest morsels are in the form of dessert. Among the desserts on this final week is Arleen Auger, the American soprano, who will appear with the festival orchestra today and tomorrow at 8 P.M. in Lincoln Center's Avery Fisher Hall.

title: AUSTRALIA DECLINES TO JOIN WAR GAMES WITH UNITED STATES
description: Australia announced today that it would not join the United States in military exercises in the Philippines next month because it did not have enough money.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL BOSTON (AL) - Assigned Steve Crawford, pitcher, to Pawtucket of the International League (AAA) for 20-day rehabilitation. Optioned Kevin Romine, outfielder, to Pawtucket.

title: MICROBILT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Wheeling Pensions
description: The Federal Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation has agreed to take over pension plans covering an estimated 13,000 retirees of the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation, officials said. The settlement is one step on a long road toward resolving the most costly pension termination by a single employer in the 12-year history of the pension agency, which underwrites the pensions of 38 million retired workers. But it leaves unresolved the larger question of how much money Wheeling-Pittsburgh may have to pay to the agency to have it assume its $475 million unfunded pension liability, officials said.

title: EXAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CHANGE AT HUMANE SOCIETY PROMPTS DEBATE
description: The departure of John E. McArdle from the Humane Society of the United States earlier this month has prompted some animal rights advocates to accuse the society of becoming more conservative in its approach to animal welfare. Officials of the society have denied the charges.

title:
ADVERTISING;
Account
description: * Charivari, a chain of high-fashion specialty stores, and Brown Group, a consumer product and specialty retailing corporation, to Keeble, Cavaco & Duka.

title: Oh, What a Feeling
description: As a rule, members of Congress hold cameras in much the same regard as they do microphones. That is, if there is one around, they feel a primal urge to stand in front of it.

title: FEDERAL REALTY INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain from the sale of real estate of $7,293,000 for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: Guinea Said to Free Stokely Carmichael
description: Stokely Carmichael, the American black militant, was released from jail today in Guinea, where he has been living, after three days of detention, a spokesman at the Guinean Embassy in Washington said today.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: DETROIT CAR MAKERS PREPARE FOR NEW ERA OF LEAN TIMES
description: The Big Three auto makers have started anew to cut jobs, close plants and revamp production to make attractive, trouble-free cars. They are doing so to arm themselves for a coming glut in the market.

title: The Language Guerrillas: A Victim's Story

title: AVANT-GARDE ART SHOW ADORNS BELGIAN HOMES
description: The home of Andre Vereecken, a psychoanalyst, is filled with texts by Sigmund Freud. What's unusual, however, is that Freud's essays are written in large letters on Mr. Vereecken's walls, and thick lines of black paint have been smeared over the words, making a thorough reading of the texts nearly impossible. Throughout the comfortable Vereecken home - in his consulting room, along the corridors and on the stairway walls - the same cacophony of partly blacked-out Freudian essays welcomes all visitors.

title: Columbia Recruit Moves Quickly
description: If Susie Grant can get across a swimming pool with the relative speed that she and her father displayed Saturday when they flew from San Francisco to New York, the Columbia women's swimming team is sure to have a record-breaking freshman. In fact, the 18-year-old high school all-America selection has posted faster times in four freestyle swimming events - at 200, 500, 1,000 and 1,650 yards - than the listed Columbia women's records.

description: The Navy's plan to build a port on Staten Island and base a battleship group capable of carrying nuclear weapons there is a bad idea that was rejected by the House but has now been revived by the Senate. A conference committee will determine its fate. It should reject this scheme once and for all.

title: LITTLE EFFECT IS SEEN ON BORROWING

Economists say studies have consistently shown that consumers are remarkably insensitive to the interest rate and tax consequences on borrowings for such items as applicances, autos and general merchandise.

The child, Kimberly Izzo of Woodbridge, N.J., was admitted to Children's Hospital of Pittsburgh Aug. 12 in critical condition after she developed an infection that attacked her liver. She was given a high priority on the hospital's waiting list for a liver transplant.

Others getting the award will be the actor Sylvester Stallone and Giovanni Agnelli, chairman of the board of Fiat Industries in Italy. title: Q&A
description: Q. What causes men to go bald more often than women? A. Men go bald because of three factors: the secretion of normal male hormones, a sex-linked inherited trait and advancing age, according to Dr. John F. Romano, a dermatologist at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. Dr. Romano said that when male sex hormones such as testosterone break down in the body, their byproducts cause hair follicles to degenerate and inhibit the formation of new hair. Because of the inherited trait, some men have hair follicles more susceptible to the breakdown of the hormones, leaving them predisposed to balding. With age, the condition becomes more pronounced, Dr. Romano said. Doctors are almost certain of the link between baldness and male hormones because of studies performed in the Middle East during the 1940's that showed a complete lack of baldness in men who had been castrated before puberty, when males begin to produce large amounts of hormones, Dr. Romano said.

title: CALIFORNIA UNITARY TAX AMENDMENTS ARE MADE
description: The California Legislature's Revenue and Taxation Committee today made slight amendments to a bill that would overhaul California's method of taxing multinational corporations. The compromise would revise the ''unitary tax,'' a misnomer for the worldwide unitary method of taxation. The method bases a multinational concern's corporation tax on a percentage of its global payroll, profits and property and is intended to keep companies from siphoning profits from California to low-tax areas.

description: Iran attacked shipping in the Persian Gulf today for the second consecutive day and Iraq reported an attack by its warplanes.

The clothes now being shown on Seventh Avenue - which will begin arriving in stores in the fall - were once dubbed ''cruise'' or ''resort'' lines. They were designed for those who whiled away winter in warmer climes. Resort also let designers put warm-weather fashions into southern stores and test ideas for their spring lines.
