Danforth has virtually guaranteed two things: a substantive debate on the details of the sweeping bill and more visibility than the Missouri Republican previously attained in his 10 years in the Senate.

title: DRUG-CRAZED SLAYER OF DRIVE-IN CASHIER IS EXECUTED IN TEXAS
description: A man who beat, slashed and burned to death a cashier at a drive-in movie theater was executed early today after the United States Supreme Court and Gov. Mark White rejected last-minute appeals.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: A Gap That Reassures
description: To the Editor:

title: Parking Computers Sought
description: The City Parking Violations Bureau announced yesterday that it was seeking a computer company to keep track of the 11.3 million parking tickets written in the city every year. The company selected after bids close Sept. 22 would supply computers and personnel to run a $3.6 million computer program designed by American Management System. Seven computer systems and 150 programs are now used to process tickets, Joseph F. Bruno, director of the Bureau, said.

title: CUTS OF $19 BILLION LISTED BY BUDGET AIDES IF CONGRESS FAILS TO ACT
description: Federal spending on dozens of military and civilian programs would be cut by almost $20 billion next year under the budget-balancing law if Congress fails to reduce deficits further, Government officials announced today.

title: Tennis Change Reported
description: There are reports that Mike Davies, the executive director of the Association of Tennis Professionals, has been dismissed by the association's board after a two-day meeting in Cincinnati, the site of this week's grand prix tournament. As the executive director of the A.T.P., which represents the players' interests, Davies and board members Ray Moore of South Africa and Harold Solomon of the United States also hold seats on the Men's International Professional Tennis Council, the governing body of tennis.

title: White House Seek Smooth Transition
description: Donald T. Regan, the White House chief of staff, said today that the Administration will seek to assure the tax revision legislation is phased in without disruption to the economy.

title: Blast Near London Palace
description: An explosion ripped through an Iranian-run video shop near Kensington Palace today, killing one person and injuring five, officials said. A police official said there was no indication it had been caused by a bomb, and authorities were investigating the possibility of a gas leak.

title: PATH WORKER IS SHOT TO DEATH IN VAN IN JERSEY
description: A PATH railroad electrician was shot through the head and killed early today while riding in a Port Authority van near a desolate trackside power station here.

title: Center of Controversy
description: Jim Fregosi, the Chicago White Sox manager, denied yesterday a published report that Carlton Fisk would be benched for the remainder of the season. The Chicago Tribune said that Fregosi planned to tell Fisk his role would be limited to pinch-hitting and grooming his replacement, Ron Karkovice, a rookie catcher.

title: JONES'S FUTURE CLOUDED
description: For Johnny (Lam) Jones, another year of promise has instead started with him on the sidelines. This time, though, his career with the Jets appears in jeopardy.

title: Jailed Polish Dissident Is Granted 2 Days' Leave
description: One of Poland's longest serving political prisoners, Leszek Moczulski, said today that he had been granted two days' leave from jail to attend his father's funeral and undergo medical tests.

title: Nystrom's View From the Top
description: While playing 14 seasons and scoring 235 goals as an Islander wing, Bob Nystrom got to know his way around the ice pretty well. But Nystrom, who was named yesterday as assistant to Terry Simpson, the new Islander coach, got hurt and discovered he hadn't known where he was going half the time.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: 2 RESIGN AS EASTERN AIRLINES BATTLES ITS SLUMP
description: Two top executives at Eastern Airlines resigned Monday in the midst of a shakeup undertaken to respond to rising complaints about canceled flights and faulty equipment, a company official said today.

title: LUCKY STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
RETIRED MEDICAL PERSONNEL ARE AIDING FLORIDA'S ELDERLY
description: When the world was younger and they were in their prime, Ernest Jacobs and Solomon Goldstein were two New Yorkers who inhabited different worlds. Mr. Jacobs was a New York mounted police officer patrolling the Broadway theater district. Dr. Goldstein was a physician in Flatbush treating middle-class families.

title: CONNECTICUT SUSPENDS WORKER IN GUN MUSEUM INVESTIGATION
description: One state employee was suspended today and a second faced dismissal proceedings in connection with questionable trades of valuable guns from a collection at the Museum of Connecticut History, state officials said.

title: FOR THE FINGER LAKES, SUMMER OF THE TOURIST
description: On the front porch of an old farmhouse here, Earl and Barbara Askins settled into rocking chairs and gazed at the gentle waves lapping against the wooded shore of Keuka Lake.

title: Senator Lugar Confers With Philippine Leaders
description: The head of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee met today with military and civilian leaders here, then flew south to the sugar-producing island of Negros.

title: U.S. TAX BILL MAY FORCE NEW YORK TO CUT HOUSING AND PUBLIC WORKS: Entrepreneur Curb Seen
description: Venture capitalists, who provide the seed money for risky but promising new businesses in the hope of giant returns, say the proposed revision of the tax system will harm newborn companies that have become so important to the economy.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: ONE of the most common health complaints among older people is difficulty sleeping. In surveys, about 30 percent say they have trouble sleeping, and the percentage who actually do may be far higher, since many elderly people accept poor sleep as an inevitable part of aging.

title: Discovery Is Reported Of Intact Mayan Ruins
description: A University of Wisconsin archeologist says he has found the undisturbed ruins of a small Mayan city on a banana plantation in Central America.

title: A New Use For Puck Building
description: WHEN two entrepreneurs took over the Puck Building at the eastern edge of SoHo in 1983, their bold plan was to upgrade the 1885 building that had housed major printing and graphic arts companies and turn it into an arts-related commercial condominium.

title: VISHAY INTERTECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PANEL CONCERNED ON NASA DIRECTION
description: The Advisory Council of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration has expressed ''great concern'' about the ability of the space agency to maintain the nation's leadership in space.

title: Bush and 1988: Like a Game of Blackjack
description: By almost any measure, Vice President Bush would appear to be the man to beat for the 1988 Republican Presidential nomination.

title: SOVIET VOICES REGRET U.S. STILL REJECTS A TEST HALT
description: The Soviet Union voiced disappointment today at the refusal of the United States to join in a halt of underground nuclear tests.

title: Jury Picking Criticized In Gotti Rackets Trial
description: Defense lawyers in the Federal racketeering trial of John Gotti and six co-defendants said yesterday that the court-devised screening process could lead to a panel of jurors who were either ignorant or inhibited.

title: Bonds From Unit In North Carolina
description: The North Carolina Municipal Power Agency is tentatively offering $266.8 million of electric revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 7.63 percent at 92 1/2 for a 7 percent issue due in 2018. Merrill Lynch Capital Markets heads the underwriters.

title: VARI-CARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Sauce of a Different Color
description: SIMPLE techniques of plate garnishing can transform a straightforward dish into something festive and memorable. One such technique - one that few people think about in the way of garnishes - is to combine two sauces with an entree or dessert.

title: PROSECUTOR SAYS SUSPECT HAS CONFESSED TO KILLING OF ROOKIE OFFICER
description: A prosecutor said in court yesterday that the man accused of shooting a rookie police officer to death in Queens last June confessed to the crime after his capture.

title: NATION GREETS TAX BILL COOLLY
description: While the tax bill has stirred expressions of euphoria among leaders in Washington, it is being greeted with less enthusiasm by political leaders around the country.

title: ASSOCIATED DRY GOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
description: The company said sales for the year-ago periods include those of Powers Dry Goods Co., a division that was sold effective at the end of June 1985.

title: SOUTHEAST STORMS BRING RELIEF, BUT NOT ENOUGH
description: A recent series of storms brought the parched Southeast some of its heaviest rains in nearly a year, but officials say that the region's worst drought in a century is still not over.

title: New President At Canadair
description: Donald C. Lowe, president and chief executive of Kidd Creek Mines, has been named president and chief executive of Canadair Ltd., an aircraft manufacturer based in Montreal.

title: MANY INDEPENDENT CABS ARE FOUND TO EVADE TAXES
description: Two-thirds of the city's independent taxi medallion owners are evading or underpaying city business taxes and routinely understating their incomes by half, a study by the City Department of Finance has found.

title: FLAVORS OF ICE-CREAM PARLORS: NOSTALGIC TO NEW
description: TWO years before the Declaration of Independence, in 1774, a New York confectioner - last name Lenzi, first name unknown - helped set off a revolution of another kind: he announced that his store would be selling ice cream. Since then, ice-cream parlors have experienced boom and bust, but the species endures. Snuggling up with a pint in front of the video-cassette recorder has its pleasures, but many people prefer to sip their sodas in public, on a stool, with the ineffable smell of chocolate and happiness.

title: Absorption of Calcium
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: HAGLER VS. LEONARD IS FAR FROM SEALED
description: Sugar Ray Leonard, the former world welterweight champion, declared in a statement yesterday that he was ''very excited'' about the prospect of fighting Marvelous Marvin Hagler for Hagler's world middleweight championship.

title: Court Bars Hebrew National From a Move to Indianapolis
description: A Federal judge has temporarily barred the Hebrew National Company from moving its pastrami operations and 129 jobs from Maspeth, Queens, to Indiana.

title: CBS NEWS AIDE GETS CORPORATE POST
description: In a move apparently aimed at polishing CBS's corporate image and calming discord within the company, Thomas H. Wyman, chairman of CBS Inc., yesterday appointed a senior CBS News executive as his new chief communications adviser.

title: Apartheid Deserves More Committed Foes
description: To the Editor:

title: MISGUIDED ATTACK ON U.S. AID TO ISRAEL
description: To the Editor:

title: WICHITA INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a $615,000 loss on the sale of oil and gas properties for both the quarter and 6 months, and writedowns of $133,000 and $5,683,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, for property and equipment.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL METS VS. DODGERS, at Los Angeles, 8:15 P.M. (Television - Channel 4, 8 P.M.; Radio - WHN, 1050; 8:15 P.M.) YANKEES VS.

title: A.T.&.T. Plan On Retirement
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that it had offered an early retirement bonus to 4,200 service technicians - about 20 percent of the 19,000 communications and computer equipment installers in the company's services division - if they agree to leave this year.

title: CARTER HAWLEY HALE STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
description: The company said the latest quarter includes a $1.2 million credit as a result of the LIFO method of inventory accounting, compared with a charge of $200,000 a year-ago.

title: BOYS' BASEBALL AND MEN'S MEMORIES
description: From the hill overlooking Lamade Stadium, the picturesque home of the Little League World Series, which opened here today, there is a long view of the Bald Eagle Chain of the Appalachian mountains. The West Branch of the Susquehanna River slices slowly through a valley etched in hues of summer green.

title: A Giant Railroad Merger Properly Derailed
description: To the Editor:

title: Charities Fear Effect of Changes
description: Officials of charitable, educational and cultural organizations said today that the new tax bill would set back their activities substantially by reducing contributors' incentives to make donations.

title: LEBANESE MILITIAS ARE BEING BUILT UP
description: Lebanese Christian and Moslem factions have begun transforming their militias into army-style units with tanks and other heavy military hardware.

title: Bond Prices Show Steep Rise
description: Bond prices rose sharply early yesterday after the Commerce Department announced that economic growth in the second quarter was weaker than previously estimated.

title: Republic Health Buyout Approved
description: The stockholders of the Republic Health Corporation have approved a proposed $565 million management buyout even though financing arrangements for the deal are incomplete.

title: Stars and Taxes
description: It was an exciting time to work for Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, who got thank-you calls from Ed Asner, Coleen Dewhurst, Charlton Heston and Tony Randall in the same day. The cause of this theatrical gratitude was the amendment he had got into the tax revision bill to allow struggling actors, musicians and other performers (those earning $16,000 a year or less) to deduct all of their sometimes considerable job-seeking expenses; under the bill, taxpayers with conventional jobs would be able to deduct such miscellaneous expenses only to the extent that they exceed 2 percent of their adjusted gross income.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: PACT DELAYS RELEASE OF GENE-ALTERED BACTERIA
description: The first release of genetically altered bacteria into the environment will be delayed at least until spring as a result of a settlement reached today in a legal dispute over the research.

title: CLOSING ARGUMENTS OFFERED IN EX-HOSPITALS CHIEF TRIAL
description: The chief lawyer for John J. McLaughlin, the former president of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, said yesterday that his client might be accused of ''making mistakes, of being sloppy or being forgetful,'' but that criminal charges against him were unsupported.

title: SHCHARANSKY'S KIN GIVEN VISAS TO REJOIN HIM
description: The Soviet authorities issued exit visas today to the family of Anatoly Shcharansky, enabling them to join the freed activist in Israel, his mother reported.

title: Bond Prices Up Sharply; Oil and Livestock Drop
description: By The Associated Press

title: Tortures Of the Saved
description: I am delighted by news that science wants to ban smoking on airplanes.

title: Reckitt & Colman Acquires Durkee
description: The international conglomerate Hanson Trust P.L.C. said today that it had agreed to sell Durkee Famous Foods to the British food company Reckitt & Colman P.L.C. for $120 million.

title: United Artists Drops Offering
description: The United Artists Corporation, which had planned to raise $300 million to repay bank debt and finance film production, has withdrawn its offering of securities.

title: Reverse Gear
description: In the official 1986-87 National Football League catalogue of ''authentic merchandise'' worn by the coaches and players of the N.F.L., ''a fan may be attracted by an advertisement for an authentic game helmet'' priced at $199. ''The same helmet N.F.L. players use now is available to the public!'' proclaims the ad copy.

title: TASTER'S CHOICE
description: T HE classic among old-fashioned parlors is Eddie's Sweet Shop in Forest Hills, Queens. If ever there was an Eddie, he is no more. For the last 18 years, the shop has been run by Joe Citrano with the help of his father, Vito, 77 years old, and son, Vito, 19. Everything is homemade: whipped cream, chocolate syrup and divine hot fudge. Mr. Citrano refuses to adulterate his ice cream with mashed-up candy bars or cookies.

title: MANHATTAN TO HONOR EXCELLENCE IN THE ARTS
description: Borough President David N. Dinkins of Manhattan announced yesterday the establishment of awards to honor excellence in the arts.

title: ALLIED STORES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
FRIENDS SAY THEOLOGIAN WILL FIGHT FOR REINSTATEMENT AS PROFESSOR
description: The Rev. Charles E. Curran will fight to be reinstated as a professor of moral theology at Catholic University of America, according to friends of the Roman Catholic theologian who was stripped of his right to teach theology by the Vatican because of his views on sexual issues.

title: FORMER CASINO AIDE IS SUING JERSEY OVER UNDERCOVER ROLE
description: A former casino executive who says he was an undercover informant on organized-crime involvement in the New Jersey casino industry sued the state in Federal court here today, charging that state law-enforcement agencies breached a contract to pay and hide him after he lost his cover.

title: HIRSCHFELD IS RULED OFF BALLOT IN PRIMARY RACE
description: Abraham Hirschfeld, who is challenging Governor Cuomo's choice for lieutenant governor, was ruled off the Democratic primary ballot today by a judge who found that there were technical violations in his designating petitions.

title: FACTORY HOMEWORKERS FEAR CHANGE IN JOB LAW
description: In a cramped, dingy room here, Elsie, a Mexican, sits at her sewing machine, hemming a pair of pants. It is a ritual she repeats with various designs on a number of garments for at least 14 hours a day, seven days a week, earning about $140 a week - less than half the Federal minimum wage of $3.35 an hour.

title: European Trade Move
description: The European Community today agreed to remove trade restrictions on imports of American lemons and walnuts as part of a previously announced plan aimed at settling a long-running trade dispute. A spokesman said all 12 member states had approved removal of the tariffs, which were imposed last November after the United States acted against pasta.

title: Fumes Force Evacuation Of Nevada Casino
description: Carbon monoxide from a faulty boiler seeped into the air-conditioning system of the Stateline Hotel and Casino just before midnight Monday, forcing the evacuation of 500 people and sickening dozens, the authorities said today.

title: Restroom Monitoring In Michigan Upheld
description: A judge ruled today that it is not an invasion of privacy to use police surveillance cameras to monitor restrooms at public rest stops.

title: The Home Team
description: When fans of the Cincinnati Reds spend an afternoon or evening rooting for the home team at Riverfront Stadium, they are doing just that. Manager Pete Rose, six of his players and Tommy Helms, a coach, all make their homes in Cincinnati.

title: EXCERPTS FROM MEMO BY THEOLOGIAN
description: Following are excerpts from a memorandum distributed last spring by the Rev. Charles Curran, a moral theology professor at Catholic University of America, describing his positions.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: OF FATS AND OILS The Center for Science in the Public Interest has petitioned the Federal Food and Drug Administration to require that any product made with tropical vegetable oils - palm, coconut or palm kernel - state on a label that the oil contains saturated fat. The petition requested that if a claim of 100 percent vegetable oil is on a front label, that label must also indicate the presence of saturated fat. When these oils are listed on the back label among the ingredients, the additional wording ''a saturated fat'' should be included.

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: EVERY family has its divisions. There are the people who like white meat and the people who like dark meat, the people who like the country and the people who like the city, the people who like showers and the people who like baths, the people who like electric blankets and the people who know deep down that some night some quirk of wiring is going to stun them like a bug flying into one of those purple bug lights.

title: 117th in a Row for Moses
description: Edwin Moses, the man who never loses, proved it again today, extending his winning streak to 117 races in the 400-meter hurdles, a record for consecutive victories in men's track and field.

title: A MONEY CHASE FOR NEW YORK
description: New York's claim to be the world's financial center took a knock yesterday.

title: Error on Fine Print
description: When you're in the heat of the pennant race, it's easy to overlook the fine print. That is apparently what happened to Lou Gorman, the general manager of the Boston Red Sox, over the weekend when he traded his shortstop, Rey Quinones, two minor league pitchers and a minor leaguer to be named later, to the Seattle Mariners in exchange for the Mariners' shortstop, Spike Owen, and a reserve outfielder, Dave Henderson.

title: Bilzerian Ends Hammermill Bid
description: A group led by Paul A. Bilzerian, the California investor, yesterday dropped out of the bidding for the Hammermill Paper Company. The action came eight days after the International Paper Company agreed to acquire Hammermill for $64.50 a share in cash, or $1.1 billion.

title: Legg Mason Deal For Howard Weil
description: The boards of Legg Mason Inc. and the Howard Weil Financial Corporation, two regional brokerages, have agreed in principle to a merger, the firms said. Legg Mason, which is based in Baltimore and publicly traded, said it would acquire Howard Weil by paying from 1.2 million to 1.45 million of its shares, which would give the transaction a value of about $35 million.

title: Jolt Cola's Contrary Strategy
description: JOLT COLA is not a subtle product. Its name alone is nothing if not jarring, and a bright yellow lightning bolt is shown ripping across the new product's packaging and advertising. But in these days of rampant health consciousness, it is Jolt's sales pitch that is most audacious. ''All the sugar and twice the caffeine,'' it proclaims. ''Sure to give you a boost every time you drink it.''

title: Trash Collectors Out A 2d Day in Houston
description: Most city trash collectors stayed off the job a second day today in a wildcat strike protesting increased workloads caused by layoffs of municipal workers.

title: HOSPITAL ACTS IN BODY PART SALES
description: A medical center has suspended two laboratory workers who reportedly sold human body parts to a doctor under investigation for a shipment of heads to Colorado.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: 1. Graceful Glasses

title: Frank X. White Is Dead at 66; Retired Business Executive
description: Frank X. White, who retired last year as a senior vice president of the Business International Corporation of New York, died Sunday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 66 years old.

title: CRS SIRRINE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Explosion at Chemical Plant
description: Nine people were injured Monday in an explosion at a chemical plant that sent a fireball 200 feet into the sky and threw debris hundreds of feet.

title: Let the I.C.C. Live
description: To the Editor:

title: HARRY L. HARTY Jr.
description: Vice Adm. Harry L. Harty Jr. of the Navy, retired, who served as the United States military adviser at the United Nations, died Friday.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: A $253.2 million issue of debt securities to finance relocation of the John Jay College of Criminal Justice was offered yesterday through underwriters led by Bear, Stearns & Company with a maximum yield of 7.40 percent for securities due in 2004.

title: 2 SHARE MET GOLF LEAD AT 66
description: Bob Bruno, who at 52 is the oldest player in the field, and Richard Siderowf, a two-time winner of the British Amateur championship, shot four-under-par 66's today to share the lead in the first round of the 71st Metropolitan Open.

title: WASHINGTON SIGNS 3-YEAR NET PACT
description: Dwayne (Pearl) Washington's education as the Nets' floor leader of the future is about to begin now that the 6-foot-2-inch guard became the seventh first-round draft choice to sign yesterday. Washington, the 13th player drafted over all, agreed to a three-year contract, reportedly worth $900,000. Washington will be paid $275,000 this season.

title: CITIZENS UTILITIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings represent series A share net. The companay said the series B share net for the latest quarter and 6 months were 64 cents a share and $1.19 a share, respectively, and the year-ago quarter and 6 months were 58 cents a share for the quarter and $1.07 a share for the 6 months period, respectively. The company said the share earnings do not reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in July.

title: C.A. McKnight, 69, Ex-Editor Of Charlotte Newspaper, Dies
description: C. A. (Pete) McKnight, editor of The Charlotte Observer for 21 years, died here Saturday. Mr. McKnight, who was 69 years old, had suffered several disabling strokes in recent years.

title: COLOR TILE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GOING OUT GUIDE
description: HOLLYWOOD MOVIES

title: New Rinks to Conquer
description: When Reijo Ruotsalainen, the talented Ranger defenseman, left the team last month to play hockey in Switzerland, the immediate reason was that Ruotsalainen, the team's second-highest scorer last season, wanted a one-year contract, while the Rangers insisted on a two-year pact.

title: 'A CURRENT AFFAIR,' TABLOID JOURNALISM
description: ''A CURRENT AFFAIR'' is tabloid journalism. Forget now the pejorative notions that cling to the phrase; ''A Current Affair'' is tabloid journalism at its best. It is zippy and knowledgeable, and when it falls on its face, at least it's in there trying. The new weeknight series, on Channel 5 at 11:30, is the equivalent of a good afternoon newspaper.

title: WHOLESALE CLUB reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BOLAR PHARMACEUTICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Bridge; Slain Member of Parliament Is Honored at Annual Match
description: When Irish terrorists bombed an English hotel in October 1984, Sir Anthony Berry, a member of Parliament, was killed. He was a regular member of the House of Commons bridge team, and a trophy in his memory was put into play this year in the annual match against the House of Lords.

title: ROTHKO ART DISPUTE ENDS QUIETLY AFTER 15 YEARS
description: After 15 years, the final curtain has unobtrusively dropped on the Rothko case, the biggest, most publicized and most protracted legal wrangle in art-world history.

title: MUSIC: MOSTLY MOZART HONORS GOODMAN
description: THE Mostly Mozart concert Monday - a chamber-music evening in Avery Fisher Hall - was to have brought the young Mendelssohn String Quartet into collaboration with two venerable soloists, the pianist Rudolf Firkusny and the clarinetist Benny Goodman. In the event, the concert was dedicated to the memory of Mr. Goodman, and his place was taken by another player with a foot on each side of music's pop-classical division, Richard Stoltzman. Mr. Firkusny, happily, was on hand to fill his engagement with spirit and sensibility.

title: A LIFELONG LOVE OF FOOD CREATES CULINARY INVENTION
description: When she goes about her kitchen duties, chopping, carving, mixing, whisking, she moves with the grace and precision of a ballet dancer, her fingers plying the food with the dexterity of a croupier. She has been called the Madonna of the kitchen, with her gold-and-platinum New Wave hairdo. She has also been referred to frequently as one of the finest young chefs in America, a superstar at age 25.

title: Connecticut Sells Transport Bonds
description: A $100 million issue of Connecticut transportation bonds was offered through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation with a top yield of 7.046 percent for bonds due in 2006.

title: Unclear, Unpresent Undanger
description: The United States Government threatens to deport Choichiro Yatani, a doctoral candidate in psychology at the State University of New York, because of a dispute about his alleged membership in the Communist Party in Japan 20 years ago. Mr. Yatani, by all accounts a model resident of this country for nine years, deserves better. So does this country.

title: MAY DEPARTMENT STORES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
BILINGUAL TESTS ARE SUPPORTED FOR THE REGENTS
description: The Chancellor of the Board of Regents, Martin C. Barell, said yesterday that he supported a recommendation that New York State's exams for a Regents high school diploma be offered in foreign languages.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for belwether issues.

title: A LOOK AT ARCHITECTURE OF PRAIRIE SCHOOL ON 13
description: ''P RAIRIE SCHOOL ARCHITECTURE'' opens with a view of rolling Middle Western wheat fields and words by Frank Lloyd Wright at his most oracular: ''Here was tremendous spaciousness,'' he pronounces.

title: WINE TALK
description: IN all that has been written about the Bordeaux wine market recently, one phrase stands out:

title: Developments in Middle East Are Positive, U.S. Declares
description: The State Department said today that there had been several positive developments in the Middle East recently and that the United States was looking at their implications for national policy toward the region.

title: CITY IN CALIFORNIA OVERTURNS PUBLIC SLEEPING BAN
description: The Mayor and the City Council, facing a nationally orchestrated demonstration to overturn a ban against sleeping in public, voted today to repeal the ordinance.

title: Top N.F.L. Rushers
description: The top career rushers:

title: ASHTON-TATE reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
DOW OFF 6.61 POINTS
description: Stock prices fell across the board yesterday, smothered by nervousnous over the course of the economy and the implications of tax law revisions.

title: Clippers Send 3 To Kings
description: The Los Angeles Clippers and the Sacramento Kings made a five-player deal last night, with the Kings obtaining two guards, Derek Smith and Franklin Edwards, and a swingman, Junior Bridgeman, in exchange for two players and two top draft choices.

title: Blast From Antitank Gun Injures 3 at Gas Station
description: A homemade 30-millimeter antitank weapon discharged at a service station today, apparently as a man was trying to sell it, setting off a fire and explosion that injured three people, officials said.

title: Mexico's Finest
description: Mexican drug trafficking is a ''horror story, increasing logarithmically, and Mexico is doing nothing about it.'' United States Customs Commissioner William Von Raab used such language earlier this year, adding that Mexican officials were ''inept and corrupt.'' Mexico protested furiously, and other Reagan Administration officials rushed to distance themselves from the Mexico-bashing.

title: Bass Hits No.34
description: Randy Bass, formerly with the Texas Rangers, hit two home runs, including a two-run shot, to lead the Hanshin Tigers to a 4-3 victory over the Yokohama Taiyo Whales in a Japanese League game. Bass, with 34 home runs, leads the league.

title: Love and the Deadbeat Dad
description: IT has become a staple of American journalism: stories about men we unthinkingly and unflinchingly call ''Deadbeat Dads.'' We all know these pieces of garbage. They get divorced, start running around with Valley Girls (or the equivalent thereof), buy foreign sports cars (convertibles, preferably), vacation only on the trendiest islands, care more about their tans than their kids and plead poverty when it comes to paying child support.

title: When a Patient May Be Dangerous
description: To the Editor:

title: Australian Government Presents Tough Budget
description: The Labor Government handed down Australia's toughest budget in 20 years today, slashing billions of dollars off public spending.

title: Ex-Head of Eaton Unit Gets Posts at Tracor
description: Mellon C. Baird was named today president, chief operating officer and a director of Tracor Inc., the company said. Mr. Baird, 55, and the former president of the Eaton Corporation's Defense and Electronics Group, will assume his position as a director tomorrow and his executive posts on Sept. 10.

title: The Trouble With 'Cashing' Welfare
description: A RECENT news report revealed that White House officials are negotiating with selected state governments to test new approaches to welfare reform. One of these approaches would involve the idea of a ''mega-block grant.''

title: DRUG TRADE BOOMERANGS ON DISMAYED COLOMBIA
description: Having long profited from satisfying the huge demand for cocaine in the United States, Colombia has for the first time recognized that it now faces a serious drug abuse problem of its own.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: THERE are probably as many ways to boil or steam lobsters as there are to fry chicken or make chili con carne. I think I have tried them all. As a rule of thumb, I cook a 1-pound lobster 7 minutes, a 1 1/2-pound lobster 10 minutes, a 3-pound lobster 15 minutes and a 5-pound lobster 25 minutes. I remove the kettle from the heat and let stand about 5 minutes, then drain.

title: East Germans Dominate Swim
description: Kristin Otto swam the fastest-ever women's 100-meter freestyle and Heike Friedrich won her fourth gold medal as the East German relay swimmers set a world record at the fifth world swimming championships today.

title: DEERE & COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income Sales represent worldwide sales. The company said worldwide results in the latest and year-ago periods benefited from the reduction of inventories valued on a LIFO basis. The after-tax benefit was $4.3 million, or 6 cents a share, and $23.5 million, or 35 cents a share, for the latest quarter and 9 months, respectively; and $22.9 million, or 34 cents a share, and $40 million, or 59 cents a share, for the year-ago quarter and 9 months, respectively. The company said the latest 9-month results were affected by an after-tax provision of $32.2 million made earlier this year for costs relating to reduction in salaried employment and the restructuring of certain manufacturing operations. Last year after-tax provisions for employment reductions were $8.3 million in the 9-month peirod.

title: SAMMY VICK
description: Sammy Vick, the outfielder replaced by Babe Ruth with the Yankees in 1920, died Sunday after a long illness. He was 91 years old..

title: Hewlett Net Increase 5.1%
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company said yesterday that it earned $123 million, or 48 cents a share, up 5.1 percent from $117 million, or 45 cents a share, a year ago. Revenues rose 11.2 percent, to $1.79 billion, from $1.61 billion in the year-ago quarter.

title: Tax Simplicity: Design vs. Use
description: DRIVING a car with an automatic transmission is simpler than driving with a standard transmission, though in design the standard transmission is the simpler of the two. It is in use that the automatic transmission is simpler.

title: JARED L. ROSENTHAL
description: Jared L. Rosenthal, former president of the Mangel Stores Corporation of New York, died of a heart attack Saturday at his home in Pompano Beach, Fla. He was 74 years old.

title: More Than a Challenge?
description: When he heard that Sugar Ray Leonard desires to return to the ring, after having fought just once in four years, Ray Arcel said, ''We have an old saying in boxing, 'To rest is to rust.'''

title: WILSON BROTHERS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a gain of $2.3 million from gain on an insurance settlement and a tax loss carryforward for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Net loss

title: U.N. Reveals Decision To Halt Food to Sudan
description: The United Nations decided last week to evacuate personnel from the southern Sudan and halt all food shipments into the area because of mounting civil war there, officials at the world organization said today.

title: U.S. TAX BILL MAY FORCE NEW YORK TO CUT HOUSING AND PUBLIC WORKS: Bonds Costs Likely to Rise
description: The new Federal tax bill may force New York City to cut its 250,000-apartment construction and renovation program in half and revamp its garbage disposal plans because of higher interest costs, city officials said yesterday.

title: Mumble Mumble on Arms Control
description: Defense Secretary Caspar Weinberger may be sitting in the same chair as his predecessors, but he is speaking a different language. That is clear from a memorandum on arms control just presented to the Reagan Administration by five wise men, former national security and foreign affairs officials who span decades, parties and ideology. What remains unclear is which arms control language the President speaks.

title: ULTIMATE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Panel at Fruehauf Evaluating 2 Offers
description: A special committee of the Fruehauf Corporation board met yesterday and will meet again today in New York to evaluate two proposals to acquire the company, according to sources close to the situation.

title: Drug-Use Testing: Costly and Corruptible
description: PRIVATE employers are beginning to line up behind President Reagan's call for mandatory urine samples to hunt out drug users on the payrolls. Two Wall Street firms are the most recent to join a list of businesses and professional sports teams that require mandatory drug tests for employees.

title: Transactions
description: BASKETBALL NEW JERSEY (NBA) - Signed Dwayne Washington, guard, to a three-year contract. FOOTBALL

title: CANNON GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said results for the latest quarter and 6 monthsreflect the acquisitions of Screen Entertainment Ltd. as of May 1 and Commonwealth Theaters Inc. as of June 16.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 20, 1986
description: The Tax Bill of 1986

title: CHERVIL: THE STAR SEASONING OF THE SUMMER
description: THINK of a few favorite midsummer foods.

title: HISTORY OF A TREAT
description: ''W E dare not trust our wit for making our house pleasant to our friend, and so we buy ice creams,'' Ralph Waldo Emerson said in 1841 in a lecture in Boston. But the history of ice cream suggests a simpler motive: desire.

title: PAKISTAN VIOLENCE EBBS AFTER 5 DAYS
description: The slum area known as Lyari in the old part of this city was strewn today with rubble and smoking skeletons of burned-out cars and trucks, the remains of five days of battles between residents and the riot police.

title:
THE TAX BILL OF 1986;
The Impact on Compensation
description: If the tax bill becomes law, Robert J. Carpenter would pocket about $250,000 less from the portfolio of stock benefits he has accumulated as chairman and chief executive of a genetic engineering company.

title: Cyclops Corp.
description: The Mutual Shares Corporation and its affiliates, which hold a combined 11.5 percent stake in the Cyclops Corporation, said they would oppose Cyclops's planned partial liquidation.

title: LANGUAGE SCHOOL A CHART OF U.S. MILITARY TIES
description: The Defense Department's English Language Center here, where military people from 70 foreign countries come to study English, is a barometer of United States military relations with others.

title: BAN ON PRIEST IS SAID TO DEFINE MORAL TEACHINGS AS INFALLIBLE
description: In censuring an influential American theologian, the Vatican significantly expanded the area of Roman Catholic teaching considered beyond debate, senior Vatican officials said today.

title: LIMIT ON EMBASSY PROTESTS IN WASHINGTON UPHELD
description: A Federal appeals court here today upheld a local law allowing the police to prohibit hostile placards and demonstrations within 500 feet of a foreign embassy.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * AMR Corp., Dallas, a holding company for American Airlines, has named Russell J. Harrison president of its new subsidiary AMR Information Services Inc.

title: NEW TARGET FOR POLICE: BICYCLE MESSENGERS
description: James Richards, bicycle messenger, rode down a sidewalk on the Avenue of the Americas yesterday on his way to a delivery. Suddenly, Police Officer Edward Tighe ordered him to dismount.

title: BOBBIE BROOKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $969,000 for the quarter and $1,945,000 for the 6 months, respectively. c-Net loss

title: QUOTATIONS OF THE DAY
description: ''Israel is not just a state. We are a people. For us the fate of Russian Jewry will remain a central consideration in our feelings, in our deeds, in our positions.''

title: WALKER ENERGY PARTNERS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After writedowns of $9.7 million and $14.1 million on the value of oil and gas properties for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Dogs in Search of Space
description: The Dog Museum of America, a gallery and collection of canine art, is moving from its headquarters at 51 Madison Avenue.

title: DEAVER INQUIRY IS BROADENED TO 2 ASSOCIATES
description: Federal investigators looking into the lobbying activities of Michael K. Deaver have broadened their inquiry to include the activities of two of his business associates, who had been officials in the Office of the United States Trade Representative.

title: DAMSON ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The company said the loss in the latest 6-month period is attributable primarily to a writedown of about $62.5 million on the partnership's oil and gas properties during the first quarter.

title: The Urban Institute, Then and Now
description: When the Urban Institute was founded here 18 years ago, probably no one envisioned that it would become a major research organization, evaluating every aspect of national domestic affairs from taxes to the performance of Presidents.

title: Jersey Issue Put At $113.5 Million
description: A $113.5 million issue of New Jersey's triple-A general obligation bonds is being offered through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

title: Grey Gets U.S. Mint's Gold and Silver Account
description: The United States Mint has assigned its worldwide gold and silver bullion campaign to Grey Advertising.

title: CP National Receives Offer
description: The CP National Corporation, a diversified utility and telecommunications company based in Walnut Creek, Calif., said today that it had received a buyout proposal from Pacificorp, a utility based in Portland, Ore.

title: CORPORATE PROFITS RISE 4.1%
description: After-tax profits of the nation's corporations rose 4.1 percent in the second quarter, reversing a decline in the first three months of the year, the Commerce Department said today.

title: YANKS STYMIED ON 14 STRIKEOUTS
description: Tommy John was gone. He had already showered and changed and left the clubhouse as the Yankees considered the developments that led to one more untimely defeat. His scoreless streak was over; he was hurt again. The night had become another loss and another lost opportunity.

title: LIONEL RICHIE'S LATEST SONGS HAVE A NEW SLANT
description: ''I CAN no longer wear rose-colored glasses all the time,''

title: MARIETTA PLANS SALES OF ROCKETS
description: The Martin Marietta Corporation said yesterday that it was prepared to sell a commercial version of its Titan rocket to companies that need to launch satellites into space.

title: Accident Fatal to 3 Was Not a Hit-Run
description: A motorist whose car struck four men, killing three and critically injuring one on the Bronx River Parkway Monday night, did not leave the scene and was not charged, the police said yesterday.

title: ACCOMPLISHMENTS ARE A KEY ISSUE IN SENATE DEMOCRATIC PRIMARY DEBATE
description: Following are excerpts from a debate yesterday between the two candidates in the Sept. 9 New York Democratic primary election for the United States Senate, Mark Green and John S. Dyson:

title: GUY F ATKINSON COMPANY OF CALIFORIA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Salvadorans to Meet Rebels At Mexico City Talks Today
description: The Government and rebels of El Salvador are to meet here Wednesday to lay the groundwork for a new attempt to end their seven-year-old civil war.

title: CARRIAGE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
IMMIGRATION SERVICE DELAYS DEPORTATION OF JAPANESE STUDENT
description: Immigration officials yesterday granted Choichiro Yatani, the Japanese graduate student accused by the State Department of subversive activities, a few more days in which to attempt to seek a hearing to disprove the charges against him.

title: WHITMAN MEDICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GIANTS AND MORRIS ARE STILL FAR APART
description: Two weeks ago today, Coach Bill Parcells told Joe Morris that the Pro Bowl running back had to do contact work or else leave the Giants' Pace University training camp.

title: DAYTON HUDSON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
What Plastic Can Do
description: Plastic power:

title:
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
Sumo to Sushi
description: Iwatora's forearms are as thick as most people's calves. His broad hands resemble small hams. Yet his touch is as delicate as a surgeon's as he fashions ruby tuna filets into flowers, dewy cucumber petals into baskets for sea urchins, and glistening squid slices into kaleidoscopic whirls.

title: A.T.&T.'S NEW LEADER TALKS ABOUT ITS FUTURE
description: At the end of this month, James E. Olson will take over as chairman of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, its first new leader since the breakup of the Bell system. A 43-year telephone company veteran, Mr. Olson started his career cleaning out manholes. He eventually was promoted to president of Illinois Bell before moving to A.T.&T. headquarters in 1977.

title: For One Theatergoer, A Broadway Finale
description: To the Editor:

title: Ruling Bars $90 Million For Chicago Schools
description: The Federal Government need not pay the Chicago Board of Education nearly $90 million for desegregation costs, a Federal appeals court ruled today. The case was sent back to the lower court that ordered the payment.

title: Twins Defeat Red Sox
description: Kirby Puckett and Kent Hrbek hit consecutive home runs in the third inning, and Gary Gaetti added a two-run homer in the sixth, leading the Minnesota Twins to a 5-1 victory over the Boston Red Sox tonight.

title: A Russian Joke
description: When the House has been debating the same bill for days on end, a little frivolity sometimes creeps into the deliberations. Last Friday night, the military programs bill was rounding out two weeks on the floor, and Representative Henry J. Hyde of Illinois, a conservative Republican, had his office produce a motion to recommit under his name.

title: Mine Hurts 7 Sri Lankans
description: Seven soldiers were wounded today when a land mine laid by separatist Tamil rebels exploded under their jeep in Sri Lanka's eastern province, the military said. A spokesman for the Joint Operations Command said guerrillas set off the explosion at Pottuvil and ran away. The soldiers did not fire at the attackers as they feared civilians nearby might get caught in crossfire, he said.

title: Nicaragua Says Rebels Killed 7 Civilians in Road Ambush
description: Rebels ambushed a truck carrying civilians in northern Nicaragua, killing seven people and seriously wounding five others, a Defense Ministry spokesman said today.

title: Key Officer Shifts Made by K Mart
description: Joseph E. Antonini, the chief executive of the K Mart Corporation's apparel division, has been named the president and chief operating officer of the company.

title: Tax Bill Alters View on Gains
description: THE proposal to change the nation's tax laws not only would have a profound effect on the way investors buy and sell stocks, but might also dictate the kinds of companies in which they are willing to put their money, according to experts on the taxation system and the securities industry.

title: JAZZ: HAMPEL AT SWEET BASIL
description: GUNTER HAMPEL, the vibraphonist and bass clarinetist, and Marion Brown, the alto saxophonist, have been associates since the late 1960's, when the saxophonist performed widely in Europe and Mr. Hampel was a member of his touring band. In more recent years, the two musicians have worked extensively as a duo, and it was in this configuration that they appeared at Sweet Basil on Monday.

title: IN CLINTON, SIDEWALKS REVIVIFIED
description: As lunch hour loomed the other day, a muddy trench blocked the sidewalk in front of the Broadway Joe Steakhouse on West 46th Street. But Matthew Kanter, the manager, said he thought it was ''super.''

title: THE SCOOP ON STORE-BOUGHT BRANDS
description: An ice-cream parlor atmosphere may be either unattainable or unimportant: many people enjoy ice cream right out of the container. For them, dozens of commercial brands crowd store shelves nationwide.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 20, 1986
description: International

title: GREEN AND DYSON EXCHANGE ACCUSATIONS
description: Mark Green and John S. Dyson, contenders for the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate from New York, repeatedly questioned each other's qualifications yesterday, often in insulting terms, and even disagreed on whether they differed substantially on issues.

title: AMERICAN OIL & GAS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a writedown of $458,000 on the carrying value of oil and gas reserves for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Net income

title: The U.N. Today: Aug. 20, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Preparatory Commission for International Seabed Authority and Law of the Sea Tribunal - 10.30 A.M.

title: Misguided Attack on U.S. Aid to Israel
description: To the Editor:

title: CONTRAS MAY NEED TO SEIZE CONTROL, REAGAN DECLARES
description: President Reagan said in an interview made public today that unless the Nicaraguan Government sought democracy, the ''only alternative'' for the rebels there would be ''to have their way and take over.''

title: SWEEPING PLAN RAISES A FLURRY OF QUESTIONS
description: In recent days, a flurry of questions have arisen over the monumental tax-revision plan approved Saturday night by Congressional conferees.

title: ROCK: CRIME AND CITY SOLUTION
description: CRIME AND THE CITY SOLUTION started their first New York performance - at the Cat Club in the early hours of Tuesday morning - carefully, navigating the prickly terrain of their songs like an infantry patrol inching its way through a minefield.

title: Widow of Chambers Dies
description: Esther Shemitz Chambers, the widow of Whittaker Chambers, who accused the former State Department official Alger Hiss in 1948 of providing secret information to the Soviet Union, died Saturday.

title: U.S. ECONOMY ROSE BY A SLIGHT 0.6% IN SECOND QUARTER
description: The nation's economy grew at an annual rate of only six-tenths of 1 percent in the second quarter, heightening fears of stagnation.

title: SURGE IN HAITIANS CAUGHT FLEEING TO U.S.
description: There has been a dramatic increase in undocumented Haitians trying to make their way to Florida aboard rickety wooden boats and tramp steamers, United States officials reported today.

title: Budget Chief On Changes
description: James C. Miller 3d, the Federal budget director, said today that the Reagan Administration was unlikely to seek major changes in the tax bill after it was enacted.

title: METS LOSE 4-0 LEAD BUT DEFEAT DODGERS
description: They have become baseball's glamour team, the dominant Mets, and they won another game tonight, 6-4 over the Dodgers. But they are not skimming along as they had been in the first half of the year.

title: Dollars and Dakotas
description: In the spirited 1986 contest for control of the Senate, North Dakota Democrats argue that they are offering contributors the best political bargain in the country: Money given to Kent Conrad, who is challenging the re-election of the Republican Mark Andrews, will buy more television time than in any other Senate race in the country, they say. Yet, if Mr. Conrad should win, his vote in the Senate would count just as much toward a Democratic majority as that of a Senator like Alan Cranston, whose television costs in California will probably exceed the entire Conrad campaign budget, which could run as high as $700,000.

title: Campbell Taggart Posts
description: Campbell Taggart Inc., the nation's second-largest producer of baked goods and a subsidiary of the Anheuser-Busch Companies, said today that Patrick T. Stokes had been named chairman and president of the company. Mr. Stokes, who is 44 years old, replaces Connie B. Lane, 62, who has been with the company for 40 years and will stay on as vice chairman and a consultant in the areas of acquisitions and new business.

title: Vapor Leak at Missile Silo
description: One of two liquid fuel components used in Titan II missiles leaked today as crews deactivated a silo, causing an orange vapor cloud and prompting the temporary evacuation of six families, the Air Force said. No injuries were reported at the site about a mile and a half north of here, the Air Force said. The Pentagon has ordered that the aging missiles, based in Arkansas, Arizona and Kansas, be deactivated.

title: EAST AND WEST
description: MY LIFE BETWEEN JAPAN AND AMERICA. By Edwin O. Reischauer.

title: SOVIET IN A SHIFT ON TROOP CHECKS
description: The Soviet Union said today at the 35-nation East-West security conference here that it was prepared to accept on-site inspections of troop movements.

title: Goodyear in Deal
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company said it had bought Britain's Engineering Consultancy Service, a former Dunlop Ltd. subsidiary that has been researching and developing automation in tire manufacturing. Terms were not disclosed. Although the deal was just announced, Goodyear said that the purchase was completed in January from BTR P.L.C., a British company that gained control of Dunlop in 1985.

title: At the Willard
description: The last shall be first when the Willard Hotel reopens today as the Willard Inter-Continental after standing empty on Pennsylvania Avenue for 18 years. Its first guests will be Tom and Joan Moore of Miami, who were the last to check out of the hotel before it closed in 1968; they had been steered there by a rising Republican Congressman, George Bush of Texas.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in some copies Aug. 8 on fusion experiments at Princeton University incorrectly described the nuclei of deuterium and tritium atoms. The nucleus of a deuterium atom contains one proton and one neutron; the tritium nucleus is formed of one proton and two neutrons.

title: Western New York State, Too, Has Its Talent
description: To the Editor:

title: SOVIET PLANNING NO MORE TALKS ON ISRAELI TIES
description: The Soviet Union said today that it planned no further talks with Israel after a 90-minute meeting in Helsinki on Monday.

title: Three Hurt in Montana Town As Ether Burns in Derailment
description: A freight train carrying chemicals derailed and caught fire today, injuring at least three people and forcing the evacuation of the downtown area, the authorities said.

title: HORMEL, GEOGE A & CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 26
France and Disney Seen Near Accord
description: France has nearly completed difficult talks with Walt Disney Productions for a European Disneyland to be located outside Paris and should have a final contract ready by mid-September, French sources said. They said a series of major problems blocking an accord had been resolved, and Sept. 15 had been set as a deadline for a final round of negotiations.

title: COLLAGEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $27,000 for the quarter and a tax benefit of $115,000 for the year, and the year also includes a pretax charge of $260,000. c-Net loss d-Includes a tax loss of $72,000 for the quarter and a tax benefit of $408,000 for the year.

title: EATERIES AIM TO ENTERTAIN
description: Ed Debevic's is a zany 1950's diner where the cooks heap on the meat loaf, the waitresses wear saddle shoes and a brightly colored sign reads, ''Ed's Chili Dog: The Cadillac of Chili Dogs.'' A half mile south stands Shaw's Crab House, a dimly lit seafood emporium reminiscent of the haunts that gangsters frequented in the 1940's. On the north side of town, Un Grand Cafe, with its brass fixtures and festive paintings, recreates the fin de siecle gaiety of a Paris bistro.

title: 2 No-Hitters, 2 Semifinalists
description: Phil Olson of Sarasota, Fla., and Wu Chun-Liang of Tainan, Taiwan, pitched no-hitters today as their teams advanced to the semifinals of the Little League World Series.

title: G.E. AIDE SAID TO BE CHOSEN TO SUCCEED TINKER AT NBC
description: The General Electric Company is expected next week to name Robert C. Wright, the president of the G.E. Credit Corporation, to replace Grant Tinker this fall as the chairman of NBC, according to network sources.

title: THE U.N. TODAY: AUG. 21, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Preparatory Commission for International Seabed Authority And Law of the Sea Tribunal - 10.30 A.M.

title: HATHAWAY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a writedown for assets and commitments related to a contract with Computer Memories Inc. of $640,000 for the quarter, and a charge of $1,135,000 to provide reserves for the exposure from assets and commitments related to a contract with Computer Memories Inc. for the year. c-Net income d-Includes income from discontinued operations of $1,452,000.

title: Italian Cyclist Wins in Colorado
description: Moreno Argentin of Italy battled rain and cold today to win the Estes Park Circuit Race of the Coors International Bicycle Classic.

title: Canadians Take Swimming Title
description: Carolyn Waldo collected her third gold medal at the world swimming championships today when Canada held off a determined challenge by the United States to win the synchronized team title.

title: RADON DISRUPTS LIVES NEAR AND FAR
description: Frank and Dorothy Fondi had just remodeled their home on Franklin Avenue here when officials of the New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection began sampling the air in the basement and drilling in their yard to determine the level of radon gas contamination.

title: Promoter Is Arrested In Slaying at Concert
description: A Brooklyn man who organized a rap music concert during which a 14-year-old youth was shot and killed last weekend was charged yesterday with the murder, the police said.

title: Topics: Touches of Class; Sports Stopgap
description: In the big-money world of intercollegiate sports, ''reform'' always comes with some fine print. So it is with the University of Maryland's decision to shorten its basketball season.

title: DEROSE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CARSON PIRIE SCOTT & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
description: b-Net income

title: 11 STATES AGREE ON PREPARATION OF JOINT LOTTERY
description: New York and Connecticut, along with nine other states and the District of Columbia, have agreed to offer a joint lottery with possible weekly jackpots of more than $40 million. Participation of several of the states, including New York and Connecticut, will require legislative approval.

title: Santa Fe Southern Offers to Sell Line
description: The Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation said that several individuals have expressed interest in buying 267 miles of track from Logansport, Ind., to Lomax, Ill.

title: ROOKIE IN BOOTH TO CALL OWN PLAYS
description: The team picture was taken yesterday, with blue blazers instead of burgundy and gold jerseys. At the team dinner last night, unbeknownst to the rookie joining CBS Sports this fall after 12 seasons with the Washington Redskins, Joe Theismann was called upon to continue a tradition that the network had borrowed from his former line of work. He was asked to perform, a cappella, his college fight song, the Notre Dame Victory March.

title: FEDERATED DEPARTMENT STORES INC reports earnings for 13wks to Aug 2
description: b-After a gain of $6.6 million from the sale of the Milwaukee-based Boston store division.

title: CONCERT: DANCES BY SCHUBERT
description: A LITTLE group of German dances by Schubert, one of many the composer tossed off, came to light about 60 years ago and was published in 1931 by Universal Edition, where Anton von Webern was doing occasional editorial work. What Webern made of them (an orchestral arrangement, which he recorded the following year in Frankfurt) provides an interesting study in the transplantation of musical styles across years, and what Gerard Schwarz and the Mostly Mozart Orchestra made of them at Avery Fisher Hall Tuesday evening provided another.

title: DAVIS PROMISE STILL UNFULFILLED
description: For Howard Davis, one of five boxing gold medalists from the 1976 Olympics, life in the pro ranks has never matched the glory of that summer in Montreal.

title: Panhandle Plans Anadarko Spinoff
description: The Panhandle Eastern Corporation, the Houston-based pipeline company that last month spurned a takeover offer, said yesterday that it would spin off its oil and gas subsidiary, the Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, to Panhandle's stockholders.

title: PANDA'S BIRTH IN CHINA HAILED
description: The birth of a giant panda Aug. 10 at a center run by China and the World Wildlife Fund is a major step in efforts to save the species from extinction, officials of the federation said today.

title: Hermione Baddeley, 77, Dies; Acted on Stage, Film and TV
description: Hermione Baddeley, a British actress who starred in London musicals and later appeared in films and on television, died Tuesday of complications from strokes, the Cedars-Sinai Medical Center said today. She was 77 years old.

title: NEW HOUSING OFF 1.8% IN JULY AS PERMITS FALL
description: Housing starts edged down 1.8 percent in July, marking the third consecutive monthly decline from boom levels hit earlier in the year, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Call in the C-Notes
description: Do you want to snatch huge profits out of the hands of the big-time drug dealers - without putting honest Americans through the indignity and loss of personal liberty inherent in drug testing?

title: ACME ELECTRIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Platinum Up By $22.30
description: The price of platinum futures jumped sharply today, climbing above $22 an ounce, despite a lack of news regarding the industrial metal.

title: Woman, 89, Slain; Helper Is Charged
description: An 89-year-old woman was killed in her apartment during what appeared to have been a robbery, the police said today, and they arrested a home-care worker and charged her with strangling the woman.

title: Turner Unit Gets President
description: Turner Broadcasting System Inc. today named Roger L. Mayer president and chief operating officer of the Turner Entertainment Company, a new subsidiary that will market the MGM/UA library of motion pictures and television programs.

title: NETWORKS REPORT TAPES GONE FROM SOUTH AFRICA SHIPMENTS
description: A complaint by an American television network that videotapes shipped from the country have disappeared in transit has led to high-level talks between United States and South African officials, it was reported today.

title: PHILLIES' CARMAN PERFECT FOR 8 INNINGS
description: Don Carman of the Philadelphia Phillies was perfect for eight innings and 100 pitches today. But as pitch No. 101 was driven to left-center field by Bob Brenly of the Giants for a double, Carman had an awful feeling.

title: ANGELICA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Chilean Guerrillas Issue Warning on Colonel
description: A Communist-led guerrilla group has taken responsibility for the kidnapping of an army colonel and has made public photographs of him with a warning that repression by Chile's military leaders would jeopardize his life.

title: Toronto in N.B.A. Bid
description: He is not necessarily giving up volleyball or polo, but Wilt Chamberlain, the former National Basketball Association star, wants to return to the N.B.A. - as an owner of an expansion franchise in Toronto. Chamberlain joined a group of Canadian investors who yesterday made a $100,000 deposit and filed a formal application to re-establish an N.B.A. team at Maple Leaf Gardens.

title: WINFIELD'S 300TH HOMER POWERS YANKEE VICTORY
description: He believes the years have made him wiser and more patient, and perhaps Dave Winfield is right. There have been grander summers in his career - a higher batting average, more imposing home run totals - but this has been a time of sweet vindication, an opportunity to prove his importance to the Yankees in their final and most critical weeks.

title: ELECTRONICS, MISSILES & COMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income and includes a gain of one cent a share from the sale of a subsidiary.

title: FLAMEMASTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
THE ELDERLY STAY WELL WITH HELP FROM PEERS
description: Agnes Brown, a trim 66-year-old in a black leotard top and lime green culottes, strode into the basement of the East Flatbush Senior Center in Brooklyn bearing a message for the 40 people seated on chairs in a large circle.

title: GRANTREE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss c-After a gain of $185,000 on the sale of real estate and a charge of $889,000 associated with the closure of certain Canadian operations.

title: A NEW APPROACH FOR HOME LAUNDRY
description: FOR those living in cramped apartments, washers and dryers often take up too much space to be practical. In the past year, however, General Electric and Speed Queen have introduced compact washers and dryers. Now, Toshiba, the Japanese consumer electronics company that has sold laundry equipment in Japan since 1930, has entered the American market.

title: EDUCATIONS SYSTEMS & PUBLIATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an interview in some copies of Business Day yesterday with James E. Olson, chief executive of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, contained contradictory statements about his age. The executive, who has been with the company 43 years, is 60 years old.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Amsouth Bancorp., Birmingham, Ala., said it agreed to acquire First Tuscaloosa Corp. for stock valued at about $105.6 million.

title: Jury Convicts Mexican Abducted to the U.S.
description: A jury returned a rape conviction today against a Mexican national who was dragged from a Mexican jail by vigilantes, brought across the border and left tied to a tree in a Texas roadside park.

title: FiatAllis Contract
description: FiatAllis North America Inc., the American subsidiary of Italy's Fiat S.P.A., has been awarded an $8.2 million contract for 133 American military construction tractors, the Defense Department said.

title: NATURE'S BOUNTY INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title:
ADVERTISING;
BELL ATLANTIC MOBILE NAMES DONER AGENCY
description: Bell Atlantic Mobile Systems has called on the W.B. Doner agency of Baltimore to handle the seven-figure account for its mobile phones.

title: RESEARCH-COTTRELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $500,000. c-Net loss and after a loss of $33 million from discontinued operations.

title: Short-Term Rates Decline
description: The sooner-than-expected cut in the Federal Reserve discount rate to 5 1/2 percent, from 6 percent, yesterday helped reduce short-term interest rates, but had less noticeable impact on prices and rates of long-term debt securities.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The Soviet Union is confident that agreements on ending nuclear tests can be reached speedily and signed already this year at the Soviet-American summit meeting.'' - Viktor F. Isakov, a Soviet official in Washington. [ A9:1. ]

title: JETS' HARPER READY FOR GIANTS
description: Once, when the Jets and the Giants went to the same bars, and bragging rights meant something, a Jets' player named Mike Battle from the University of Southern California returned a punt for a touchdown in the teams' first meeting and stayed on to play for the Jets for two years.

title: GERMAN FUNDS WERE USED TO PAY DEAVER AIR FARE
description: The United States Embassy in Bonn used West German funds, earmarked for the occupying powers in West Berlin, to pay the round-trip air fare between Washington and Berlin for Michael K. Deaver and a business associate last February, Charles Redman, a State Department spokesman, said today.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: G.B.S. George Bernard Shaw was a prolific playwright, and he has inspired a project in New York devoted solely to his work. The Shaw Project began a series of staged readings last February that, if all goes according to plan, will eventually cover some 40 plays, in roughly chronological order.

title: PROFIT SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FUDDRUCKERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: VELCRO INDUSTRIES NV reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
California Legislators Bar Spanking in Schools
description: The State Legislature has passed a bill to prohibit spanking or other corporal punishment by public school teachers.

title: DATAVISION INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: HANDMADE IN BRITAIN
description: VISCOUNT LINLEY, above left, the son of Princess Margaret and the Earl of Snowdon, and his co-designer, Matthew Rice, above right, have produced a group of home accessories in wood for the London store Fortnum & Mason.

title: To Try a Communist
description: To the Editor:
