ENGINEERED SUPPORT SYSEMS reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
MET-COIL SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes an after-tax capital gain of $288,000 on the sale of certain assets of the company's Ruesch Machine subsidiary for both the latest quarter and year. c-Includes an extraordinary gain of $279,902 from termination of one of the company's defined benefit plans.

title: TO NEIGHBORS, KILLER WAS 'CRAZY PAT'
description: The words ''loner,'' ''strange'' and ''weird'' came up again and again as neighbors and fellow workers described Patrick Henry Sherrill, whose wild rampage left 15 people dead here today.

title: LITTLEFIELD ADAMS & CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
100 Flee Flash Floods In 2 Carolina Towns
description: Torrential rains swept across drought-plagued South Carolina for the second day today, causing flooding and forcing about 100 people in two small communities to evacuate. No injuries or deaths were reported.

title: PROTEST OFF AS SANTA BARBARA LIFTS BAN ON PUBLIC SLEEPING
description: Homeless people are satisfied with a City Council decision to let them sleep in roadside shrubbery, culverts and stream beds, a spokesman said today.

title: DOWNFALL OF A TOP GRAFFITI SUSPECT
description: William Depperman's ideas have been stuck on New York for years, city officials say. And until now the Sanitation Department says it has been stuck with them.

title: New Chance for Kreis
description: E. J. (Doc) Kreis, the former Vanderbilt strength coach who resigned after he became the central figure in the steroid scandal that rocked Vanderbilt and other schools last year, has been named volunteer strength coach for the Middle Tennessee State University football team.

title: Ex-CBS Officer to Head Business Conference
description: William Lilley 3d, who recently resigned as senior vice president for corporate affairs of CBS Inc., has been named president of American Business Conference Inc. in Washington.

title: GIANTS CLAIM PLACE-KICKER
description: Bill Parcells, the Giants' coach who has been concerned about who will be his place-kicker this season, made another change today. Eric Schubert, who had a tenuous hold on the job in the current training camp, was released and the Giants claimed Bob Thomas, a veteran kicker released by Green Bay, on waivers.

title: MACY'S TO SELL SHOPPING MALLS
description: The management group that took R. H. Macy & Company private last month is asking more than $500 million for its nine shopping centers, sources in the real estate industry said yesterday.

title: FAIR LANES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Not Hiring
description: Coach Chuck Noll of the Pittsburgh Steelers, unlike some of his National Football League counterparts, is not enthusiastic about signing former players from the United States Football League. In his camp at Latrobe, Pa., he has only Van Hughes, a defensive end from the Birmingham Stallions who suffered from dehydration after his first practice on Monday and sat out Tuesday's practice.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: IT. By Stephen King. 1,138 pages. Viking. $22.95.

title: FUR VAULT INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
U.S. Surrenders to Foreign Textile Fraud and Abuse
description: To the Editor:

title: A Day of Oddities For Saratoga Fans
description: Island Sun carried top weight of 125 pounds to a one-length victory over Judge Costa in the $77,000 West Point Handicap for New York-breds today at Saratoga. Judge Costa won the race last year.

title: Filmgoers Beware
description: The message from the New York Film Festival is: Watch out for scalpers.

title: TEXAN IS EXECUTED FOR BURNING WOMAN TO DEATH
description: A Texas man was executed early this morning by lethal injection for beating, slashing and burning to death a woman at a drive-in movie theater where she worked.

title: KASPAROV-KARPOV GAME IS A DRAW
description: The world chess champion Gary Kasparov and the challenger Anatoly Karpov agreed to a draw today after only 20 moves of the ninth game in their championship match.

title: An Old Connection To the Majors
description: An item the other day in this sports section noted that six members of the Reds were graduated from local Cincinnati high schools, led by Pete Rose, the manager and first baseman. They all appeared in the lineup last Sunday before a crowd of 27,175 ''that included numerous relatives, classmates, neighbors and friends.''

title: 3 Die in Ecuador Shootout
description: Three Ecuadorean police officers died in a shootout with leftist guerrillas who raided a hospital to rescue a wounded comrade, a senior Government security source said today. The guerrillas, who have close links to Colombia's leftist M-19 guerrillas, successfully carried away the rebel who was guarded by three policemen. The conservative Government of President Leon Febres Cordero has charged that some rebel leaders have been trained in Libya and Colombia.

title: JOYCE LEADS BY 3
description: ''Three under, three beers,'' Tom Joyce said as he brought three bottles to the patio of the Nassau Country Club. He was celebrating the 67 he shot today to take the lead in the second round of the Metropolitan Open.

title: China Project Studied
description: Noranda Inc. said today that it and a Chinese nonferrous metals company have begun a feasibility study, to be completed in January, for a $140 million complex in northeastern China. The Tientsin complex, using refining technology developed by Noranda, would have an annual capacity of 100,000 metric tons of processed copper.

title: RENT-A-WRECK OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Jail Drug Offenders At Bases, Koch Says
description: Mayor Koch yesterday elaborated on his proposal to have people who have been convicted of or are awaiting trial on drug charges incarcerated in places other than traditional jail cells and at the expense of the Federal Government.

title: G.N.P. DATA IS STUDIED FOR LEAK
description: The Commerce Department said today that it had started an inquiry into a suspected leak to the financial markets of its revised economic growth rate for the second quarter, which was announced at 8:30 Tuesday morning.

title: Rev. Gaither P. Warfield Dies; Was Methodist Relief Official
description: The Rev. Dr. Gaither P. Warfield, former general secretary of the United Methodist Committee for Overseas Relief, died of leukemia Saturday at his home in Rockville, Md. He was 90 years old.

title: WHY A LOVER OF HOME-GROWN TOMATOES RAISES FLOWERS
description: I USED to be a hot-eyed tomato fanatic.

title: TEEN AGE FATHERS NOW GETTING HELP
description: PREGNANT women, many in their teens and some with toddlers in tow, fill the examining rooms and lounges in the Mother Infant Care clinic at the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey here. But the fathers of the unborn children, many also in their teens, are stopped at the door.

title: CLOTHESTIME INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 27
On the Radio
description: President Reagan may make more news with his weekly radio address, but Dr. Otis R. Bowen, Secretary of Heath and Human Services, has hit the airwaves himself with a program of medical advice, ''Housecalls.''

title: U.S. Is Investigating Ex-Mayor of Syracuse
description: Federal agents have confiscated documents from the office of former Syracuse Mayor Lee Alexander.

title: TEACHING OF THEOLOGY: WHAT IS INVOLVED AT A CATHOLIC SCHOOL?
description: Behind the Vatican's disciplining of the Rev. Charles E. Curran lies a fundamental dispute over what is involved in the teaching of theology.

title: PHARMAKINETICS LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $147,000 for the quarter and $323,000 for the year. c-Net loss

title: Mare Tops International
description: Grade's Singing, a 4-year-old mare, was installed as the 5-2 morning-line favorite today despite drawing the No. 8 post for the Roosevelt International Trot Saturday night at Roosvelt Raceway. The eight-horse field, composed of entrants from seven countries, will be raced at a mile and quarter.

title: THE STAGE: 3 PIECES BY TOBY MACLENNAN
description: TOBY MACLENNAN is a visionary whose feet are firmly planted in the ground.

title: ERLY INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $1,212,000. The company said the year-earlier quarter has been restated for discontinued operations.

title: HERS
description: HENRY JAMES, like many decorous and respectable people, entertained a lively interest in murder. He was a fan of the Scottish solicitor William Roughead, who wrote about real-life crime for the first 40 years of this century; James once told Mr. Roughead he was interested in crime because through it ''manners and morals become clearly disclosed.'' He urged Mr. Roughead to write about ''the dear old human and sociable murders and adulteries and forgeries in which we are so agreeably at home. And don't tell me, for charity's sake, that your supply runs short.''

title: Lawn Hegemony
description: It is clear to me now why the Soviet Union clings to its burdensome, ill-gotten empire in Eastern Europe - as well as its latest territory, Afghanistan. What is also coming into sharp focus is the Reagan Administration's preoccupation with ''freedom'' in Nicaragua, Grenada and further-flung places, like Angola.

title: YOUNG PHILANTHROPISTS GIVE TO NONTRADITIONAL CAUSES
description: ANNIE HOFFMAN is far from being a silver-spoon, dilettante do-gooder. She works hard - both at her pottery business and at giving away her money.

title: REGENCY ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The company said the latest year results include a net charge of $7 million from the company's discontinued cable TV business.

title: People
description: * Joseph Barrett, Richard Bonnette, Bruce Meyers and Arnold Semsky have been named senior vice presidents at BBDO Worldwide.

title: MEMORIES OF A JACK OF ALL ARTS, EVER ON THE MOVE
description: BRION GYSIN died in Paris on July 13, and it is still difficult to believe that he is no longer an active force in the world. To the age-old question ''What are we here for?,'' Mr. Gysin answered emphatically, ''We are here to go.'' And he went, it seemed, perpetually. He created impulsively, profusely, as a painter, writer, sound-poet, tape-composer, lyricist and intuitively penetrating analyst of music, magic and folklore. He threw off the sort of ideas that ordinary artists would parlay into a lifetime career, great clumps of ideas, as casually as a locomotive throws off sparks.

title: Money for the Grunt
description: Congress has been whittling away at the Strategic Defense Initiative and other less esoteric but expensive items in the Administration's defense budget. Significant reductions in S.D.I., popularly known as ''Star Wars,'' have been approved by committees in both the House and Senate, but a bit more than $3 billion remains in the program.

title: U.S. ABANDONS ATTEMPT TO DEPORT L.I. DOCTORAL CANDIDATE TO JAPAN
description: The Federal Government abandoned its efforts yesterday to deport a Japanese doctoral candidate whom the State Department had accused of being a Communist.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Hugh De Lacy, Ex-Legislator Active in Progressive Party
description: Hugh De Lacy, a Progressive Party activist who as a Democrat was a Representative in Congress from the Seattle area from 1944 to 1946, died Tuesday at Dominican Hospital after a four-year battle with cancer, a family spokesman said today.

title: A Letter to Meese
description: Relations between Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d and Bob Guccione, publisher of Penthouse, have not exactly flourished since the Attorney General's commission concluded that pornography leads to violent crime and Mr. Guccione sued the Justice Department to prevent it from urging convenience stories to stop selling his magazines.

title: Jet America Option Used
description: Alaska Air Group, in the midst of a bidding war for ownership of Long Beach-based Jet America Airlines Inc., said today it had exercised an option to buy 18 percent of the California carrier.

title: Summer Firefighter Cost Is Put at $25 Million
description: The cost of fighting this summer's rash of forest and brush fires, most of them in the West, has been at least $25 million, the director of the Bureau of Land Management said yesterday.

title: MCCALLUM ALLOWED TO PLAY IN N.F.L.
description: Napoleon McCallum, the former Naval Academy running back, was authorized - in an unusual departure from tradition - today by Navy Secretary John F. Lehman to play pro football with the Los Angeles Raiders on weekends.

title: McEnroe Is Seeded No. 9 for U.S. Open
description: Speculation was that the United States Tennis Association would ignore John McEnroe's No. 9 computer ranking and seed him among the top five for the United States Open, reflecting McEnroe's four Open championships. Instead, the U.S.T.A. remained loyal to the rankings yesterday, and now McEnroe will probably face a difficult draw in his attempt to win another singles title.

title: Growing Pains Of the Preseason
description: The players may wear the same uniforms and play by the same rules and in front of the same cheering fans, but there is a fundamental difference between exhibition football and real football in the National Football League.

title: Bolivian Labor Group Plans Big Strike Today
description: Bolivia's labor federation says it will begin a two-day general strike to press several demands, including the immediate departure of 170 United States servicemen who are taking part in an anti-cocaine drive.

title: SYSCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
MICROBILOGICAL SCIENCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: KEYSTONE INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $382,000. The company said the latest quarter and 6-month earnings include a one time charge of $2.8 million for merger-related expenses.

title: LOWE'S COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
5.9% Stake Bought In Aaron Spelling
description: The American Financial Corporation and its chairman, Carl H. Lindner, have purchased a 5.9 percent stake in Aaron Spelling Productions.

title: Bennett Arouses Moscow
description: As if he didn't have enough troubles trying to overcome the academic shortcomings of American public school students, Secretary of Education William J. Bennett is being taken to task by the Russians over the same problem.

title: Arms Tests and the Art Of Public Relations
description: The Reagan Administration, an acknowledged master of public relations, is nevertheless having trouble shaping the public debate over the issue of nuclear testing.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for belwether issues.

title: U.S. to Interview Prisoners in Cuba
description: State Department and Immigration and Naturalization Service officers will begin interviewing more than 100 Cuban political prisoners and members of their families in Cuba to decide whether they will be allowed into the United States as refugees, the Reagan Administration said today.

title: SUMMIT LINKED TO ARMS PACT, RUSSIAN INSISTS
description: A senior Soviet diplomat said today that a meeting between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev must result in substantial arms control agreements.

title: AUSTRALIAN SET TO BUY USX STOCK
description: An investment concern controlled by Robert Holmes a Court, the Australian financier, has notified the USX Corporation that it intends to buy up to 15 percent of its stock, USX said yesterday.

title: President of Glidden's Welcomes New Owner
description: The Glidden Company has been bought and sold twice this year, but its president was not complaining.

title: U.S. GETS READY TO SEND G.I.'S TO TRAIN CONTRAS
description: The Reagan Administration plans to send United States soldiers to begin training Nicaraguan rebel commanders as soon as possible after Oct. 1, according to Administration and Congressional officials.

title: A HOUSING PROJECT AT 50
description: Fifty years ago, President Franklin Delano Roosevelt dedicated America's first public housing project as part of his grand plan to offer hopes and homes to the nation's poor.

title: French Drawings at Met
description: More than 100 drawings by French masters from the 15th to 18th centuries will go on view Sept. 18 at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue and 82d Street. The exhibition will include works by Lorrain, Fouquet, Poussin, Watteau, Fragonard and Boucher. The exhibition, which will be in place through Jan. 4, is linked to the publication of the collection catalogue ''15th-18th Century French Drawings in the Metropolitan Museum of Art,'' the latest in a series that eventually will document all the museum's European drawings.

title: MASS SLAYINGS, MANY SITES
description: The killings yesterday in a post office in Edmond, Okla., represent one of the worst mass slayings in United States history.

title: Bomb Sent to U.S. Judge Disarmed in Fargo, N.D.
description: A pipe bomb concealed in a packge addressed to a Federal judge was disarmed at the Federal Building here today, two days after a similar device exploded at the Fargo Post Office, the authorities said.

title: HIRSCHFELD, OFF BALLOT, FAULTS THE LAW
description: A contradictory Election Law provision was responsible for the removal of Abraham Hirschfeld from the Sept. 9 Democratic primary ballot, an attorney for the lieutenant governor candidate charged yesterday.

title: ON 'CURRENTS,' A LOOK AT DAY-CARE PROBLEMS
description: CURRENTS,'' Channel 13's weekly series on our changing society, looks tonight at day care, or, as it calls it, ''the day-care disgrace.'' Parents who work have no one to look after their children. Grant that this is not a new problem. ''Currents,'' at 8:30, is still giving us a thoughtful, and balanced, examination.

title: DARLING AND TEUFEL INDICTED OVER FIGHT
description: Ron Darling, a Mets pitcher, and Tim Teufel, a second baseman, were indicted today on felony charges of assaulting two police officers who were trying to arrest them at a nightclub July 26.

title: Selling Sense About Sex
description: Advertising, popular songs and movies attest that sex at the age of, say, 15 has become as American as apple pie. The lives of teen-age mothers and their children attest that it is also as dumb as it always was.

title: CENTRAL SPRINKLER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in April.

title: American Express Unit Offers Notes in Europe
description: The American Express Credit Corporation is offering $200 million of 7 5/8 percent seven-year notes in the Eurobond market, with half the issue sold on a delayed-payment basis, through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc.

title: Nettles Is Replaced
description: Graig Nettles, the former Yankee star, turned 42 yesterday and got some bad news from the San Diego Padres. He was told by Manager Steve Boros that he won't be playing third base any more, but will finish the season as a pinch-hitter.

title: TAX BILL'S TIME TABLES UNLIKELY TO BE ALTERED
description: Despite remarks by the White House chief of staff that the Administration will seek to insure a smooth phase-in of the tax revision legislation, a detailed timetable for the transition has already been set by Congressional conferees and substantial changes are unlikely, tax aides said today.

title: Brass Import Ruling by U.S.
description: The Commerce Department has ruled provisionally that companies in seven nations were dumping brass sheet and strip on the American market at less than fair value and ordered temporary duties be imposed.

title: THE DANCE: 'JAZZ PARADE' AT FESTIVAL
description: Jazz dance is not just ''pizzazz,'' as Liz Thompson, director of the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival, pointed out in a curtain speech at the festival's Ted Shawn Theater tonight. Miss Thompson, who was introducing the ''Jazz Parade'' program that will be performed through Saturday, added that there was a serious and poetic as well as a commercial side to jazz dancing. It was an observation borne out by the program of works by Danny Buraczeski, Milton Myers and Otis Sallid.

title: Police Car Hits Pedestrian
description: A Mount Vernon man was reported in stable condition in the intensive care unit of Mount Vernon Hospital today after he was struck by a police car responding to a call, a police official said.

title: Big Beast in Town
description: Like most everything else in the Lone Star State, Texas roaches are big. Their shadows weigh 15 pounds. People mistake them for Volkswagens.

title: ONE KILLED IN PAKISTAN PROTEST
description: One person was killed and two were wounded today in a gunfight between anti-Government protesters and the police in Jhudo in southern Pakistan.

title: RESTORING AN 18TH-CENTURY FRENCH ECCENTRIC GARDEN
description: IN a nation that abounds in historic chateaus and gardens, what makes the impending restoration of the Desert de Retz so exciting?

title: Topics: Touches of Class; Teacher Wisdom
description: Teachers love to gripe about the boring education courses that are required to qualify for teaching jobs. Some of the most important teaching skills, they say, are learned on the job, like sensitivity and the ability to inspire students and to maintain discipline.

title: Souvenir Hawkers Beware
description: Performers and sports organizations appearing at Madison Square Garden will no longer have to go to court repeatedly to bar the sale of unlicensed souvenirs outside the arena.

title: 20% INCREASE URGED IN NEW YORK TAXI FARES
description: Representatives of taxi owners and drivers yesterday asked New York City's taxi commission to raise fares by at least 20 percent.

title: Farm Export Slump Seen
description: Agricultural exports are expected to slump to a nine-year low of $26.5 billion in the current fiscal year, as buyers delay purchases in the hope of even lower prices, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Nitpicking Democracy in New York
description: New York's Governor Cuomo acts as if there's something to celebrate in the court decision knocking Abraham Hirschfeld off the September primary ballot for Lieutenant Governor. The only thing that this decision celebrates is a defeat for democracy. It stirs more sympathy for Mr. Hirschfeld's candidacy than he seemed likely to generate on his own, and it leaves the Governor looking more like clubhouse pol than potential President.

title: Webb Buyout Bid
description: The British Printing and Communication Corporation said it has approached the board of the Webb Company with an acquisition proposal valued at about $111 million.

title: U.S. Rowers Gain Final
description: The United States' heavyweight eight took advantage of calm early morning conditions to win its repechage today and advance to the final of the world rowing championships.

title: Micropro Appoints President and Chief
description: The Micropro International Corporation, best known for the Wordstar word processing software, said yesterday that Leon Williams will take on the posts of president and chief executive officer, effective Sept. 15.

title: Pentagon Revising Rules on Contractor Profits
description: The Defense Department intends to publish soon a series of new regulations governing the profits earned by military contractors. They will be paid more slowly and asked to bear more of the early costs of manufacturing weapons, according to Pentagon officials.

title: It
description: The drain. Things down there in the drain. Things down there in the drain that might reach up and get you. The awful necessity of having to go down the drain to face those things. These are the essential fantasy-fears that underlie ''It,'' Stephen King's latest, longest and most complicated novel of terror to date. If drains ever bothered you, then ''It'' is going to suck you right in. If not - well, the story's other compensations may or may not suffice.

title: C-COR ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $18,000 and $1,340,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net loss and after net from discontinued operations of $134,000. d-Net income and after a loss from discontinued operations of $428,000.

title: HANDEL AND REAL FIREWORKS, ON A&E
description: TONIGHT'S presentation of Handel's ''Music for the Royal Fireworks,'' which will be broadcast on the Arts & Entertainment cable network at 10:30, is an example of an event that must have been tremendous fun to attend but that translates poorly to television.

title: KOCH'S CAMPAIGN VIOLATED ELECTION LAW, OFFICIAL SAYS
description: Mayor Koch's re-election campaign violated state election laws last year by failing to record and file statements on more than $45,000 of donated services from taxi and car-service companies, the city's Investigation Commissioner said yesterday.

title: METS SWEEP DODGERS IN THREE GAMES
description: The Mets are without the player whom supposedly they could not, absolutely not, no matter what, do without.

title: U.S. Surrenders to Foreign Textile Fraud and Abuse; As Exports Dwindle
description: To the Editor:

title: MUSIC: ANDREAS VOLLENWEIDER AT RADIO CITY
description: IN the Swiss electro-acoustic harpist Andreas Vollenweider, the ''new age'' music movement has found a highly marketable symbol. Mr. Vollenweider, who sold out Radio City Music Hall on Tuesday evening, is a new-fashioned hippie, who wears a beatific smile, dresses in loose-fitting white clothes and keeps his hair frizzy. When not strumming the harp, he spouts childlike psychobabble about the moon, love and benign universal forces.

title: Bridge: A Senior Event Is Captured By a Youthful-Looking Pair
description: Proof of age is commonly required in bars, but such requirements are new in bridge tournaments.

title: Q&A
description: Q. The cedar odor is gone from my cedar-lined closet. I want to renew the odor and it was suggested that I rub all the wood down with cedar oil. Do you know of a better way? A. As cedar wood ages, the aroma is lost because surfaces dry and the pores tend to get sealed with dust and dirt. In most cases sanding with fine sandpaper and then vacuuming and wiping down with a dry rag is all that is needed to restore the cedar's aroma. If this doesn't help, then cedar oil may be your best bet. Q. I am looking for a door hinge designed to raise the door slightly as it opens to permit the door bottom to clear a thick carpet on the side toward which it opens. Do you know where I can locate such hinges and can you tell me if installing them would require any modifications to the door or the door frame? A. Door hinges of this type, commonly referred to as rising butt hinges, are sold in many large hardware stores and building supply houses. If they don't have them, they should be able to order them for you. You can also order them from some mail-order houses, including Constantine's, 2050 Eastchester Road, Bronx, N.Y. 10461, telephone 800-223-8087. Q. I have two medium-size rocking chairs made of mahogany wood. The wood is stained a dark brown color and I would like to change this color into a white oil paint.

title: U.S.-Egyptian Sea Exercise
description: The United States aircraft carrier Forrestal is steaming toward the eastern Mediterranean for a routine naval exercise with Egypt, Administration officials said today. The small exercise was classified secret by the Egyptian Government, and the Pentagon declined to confirm or deny plans for it.

title: Two Men Receive Sentences Of 4 Years for Sale of Crack
description: Two Manhattan men without prior criminal records were each sentenced yesterday by a Federal judge to four years in prison for selling the cocaine derivative known as crack.

title: SPI-SUSPENSION & PARTS INDUSRIES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.S. Surrenders to Foreign Textile Fraud and Abuse; Japan Understands
description: To the Editor:

title: REVLON GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $2,794,000 for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Net loss and after income from discontinued operations of $1,544,000 and $3,374,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and a charge of $804,000 for the quarter and $699,000 for the 6 months from the reversal of a tax credit, and a gain from the reduction of debt of $1,282,000 for both the quarter and 6 months. There were no share earnings after preferred dividend requirements for the latest quarter. The company said the results include interest expense of $74.1 million in the latest 6-month period relating to the acquisition of Revlon Co. Following that acquisition, the company changed its name to Revlon Group from Pantry Pride. The company said the year-ago period results reflect the operations of Pantry Pride's Devon Stores, while the latest year results include those operations as well as Revlon operations.

title: HOSTILE BID FOR ANDERSON, CLAYTON
description: Bear, Stearns & Company and Gruss & Company said they would begin a hostile tender offer tomorrow to acquire Anderson, Clayton & Company for $56 a share in cash, totaling $697 million. The Quaker Oats Company restated its commitment to provide $250 million of the financing in return for getting to purchase the Gaines pet food division of Anderson, Clayton afterward.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: UNITED STOCKYARDS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Results for 1985 have been restated to include investment gains and real estate fees, and to reflect a 10-percent stock dividend declared December 23, 1985.

title: SANDINISTAS ASSAIL REAGAN'S THREAT
description: A Government spokesman said today that a remark by President Reagan that the Nicaraguan rebels might have to ''take over'' unless Managua made political concessions confirmed once again the real United States objective in Nicaragua.

Corrections Corp. Files for Stock
description: The Corrections Corporation of America, which manages prisons for government agencies, has filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an initial public stock offering of two million shares.

title: INTEK DIVERSIFIED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
LIFE IN PHOENIX: DOG DAYS IN DESERT SET OFF SEARCH FOR OASIS
description: Don't count on finding people at home in Phoenix this month: chances are one in three that they'll be gone, probably to San Diego, to escape Arizona's spectacular summer heat.

title: FEDERAL RESERVE REDUCES KEY RATE TO SPUR ECONOMY
description: In an attempt to stimulate the struggling economy, the Federal Reserve Board today cut its primary lending rate to 5 1/2 percent, from 6 percent.

title: Driesell Testifies
description: A grand jury investigating the cocaine overdose death of Len Bias heard testimony from the University of Maryland basketball coach, Lefty Driesell, yesterday and recessed until Tuesday. It was not known whether Driesell, who testified for about three hours, waived the immunity that would normally be included in testimony before a Maryland grand jury investigating a drug case.

title: HOFMANN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 26
description: b-Net loss

title: AVON SETS NEW STORE PROJECT
description: After a century of depending on its army of ''Avon ladies'' to sell cosmetics and fragrances door-to-door, Avon Products Inc. yesterday announced its first solo attempt to market products through department stores.

title: TURNING TO EUROPE FOR EQUITY
description: Large American companies have long viewed Europe's capital markets as fertile territory for the sale of their bonds. Now such names as Citicorp, Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, Black & Decker, Transamerica and Chesebrough-Pond's are finding they can raise equity capital there as well.

title: A RIDE ON LA CUBANA: LATIN HOME ON THE ROAD
description: The last meal, thick Cuban sandwiches of ham, pork and cheese, had been consumed at noon on a recent Thursday, and by 5 P.M. the riders were thinking about food again. The legs ached from sitting too long, and salvation - a truck stop in Virginia -was still an hour and a half away for the 53 passengers on the bus from New York to Miami. It was time for a political debate. ''Those who had the opportunity to liberate Cuba were the ones who left early on,'' said Jesus Guerra of New York City, who was born in 1959, the same year Fidel Castro captured Havana. President John F. Kennedy was to blame, someone else said. The noise level rose as others joined in. Nearly everyone seemed happy. ''This is Cuban land,'' said Maria Fernandez, a teacher from Elizabeth, N.J., referring to the bus, its largely Cuban ridership and the topic of conversation. ''When Cubans get together, it is always the same.''

title: 2d CHERNOBYL FIRE IN MAY IS REVEALED
description: There was a major fire at the disabled Chernobyl nuclear power plant on May 23, nearly a month after an explosion and fire that damaged the No. 4 reactor, a Soviet newspaper reported today.

title: Wounded In Trade War
description: Senators meeting their constituents during the August recess are hearing impassioned pleas to act quickly on a House-passed trade bill to restrict imports and ''protect American jobs.'' The demands will be hard to resist in an election year. Nine Southern Governors from both parties, for instance, have urged Congress to either ''guarantee'' open markets abroad or impose import quotas.

title: Talks in Japan On Car Parts
description: American negotiators discussed with Japanese officials today ways to end trade disputes over auto parts.

title: COMPANY NEWS;
description: South Korea's Hyundai, already known for its cut-price cars, said today that it would test-market a $699 I.B.M.-compatible personal computer, one of the cheapest of the so-called clones to be sold through American retailers.

title: HOSPITALS AGREE TO HELP CITY TREAT DISTURBED
description: New York City's private, nonprofit hospitals agreed yesterday to relieve the serious overcrowding of psychiatric patients in municipal hospitals by admitting some of the least dangerous patients overflowing from municipal psychiatric emergency rooms.

title: TRENTON LESSENING ITS REQUEST FOR DATA ABOUT AIDS VICTIMS
description: The Department of Health is amending a proposal that would force hospitals, physicians and jails to give vital information about acquired immune deficiency syndrome sufferers to the state to no longer require the victims' addresses and telephone numbers, officials said today.

title: Analog Values In Computing
description: THERE are analog watches (the ones with the hands) and digital watches, analog phonograph records and digital compact disks. Computers also were once analog and digital. But digital computers won out so overwhelmingly that people no longer bother to say ''digital computer.'' It is simply assumed that a computer is digital. But life may be stirring on the analog side. Scientists are starting to work on futuristic computers that might again make use of analog computing techniques. No one expects analog computing to recapture the mainstream of the computer world, but some think that analog techniques might be better suited for some tasks, such as recognition of objects in computer vision systems, that have so far defied solution by digital techniques.

title: A MARTYR ENSHRINED: THE LEGEND OF NINOY AQUINO
description: At 1:05 on Thursday afternoon, President Corazon C. Aquino will dedicate a flat granite slab, in the figure of a man with arms and legs akimbo, that has been set into the tarmac at Manila International Airport.

title: Numbers Don't Make An Antitrust Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: Nastase Clowns But Lendl Wins
description: Had Ilie Nastase been able to roll the clock back about a decade, his match tonight against Ivan Lendl in the $150,000 Norstar Bank Hamlet Challenge Cup might have been competitive.

title: LONDON POLICE BELIEVE BOMB CAUSED BLAST AT IRANIAN SHOP
description: A bomb is believed to have caused a blast in an Iranian-run shop in the Kensington section of London that killed one man and wounded five, the police said today.

title: Long Wait
description: Long-distance swimming, long a challenge for aquatic enthusiasts with more stamina than speed, received recognition as an amateur championship sport from the world governing body, Federation Internationale de Natation Amateur seven months ago in Bonn, West Gemany, and recently staged its first international event at Lake Windemere in the north of England.

title: AID TEAMS WORRY ABOUT THE SUDAN
description: International relief organization officials voiced concern today over the situation in the southern Sudan, saying the worsening of the guerrilla war there could touch off a famine rivaling the Ethiopian famine of 1985.

title: 3 HOPEFULS VIE FOR ATTENTION IN RACE TO CHALLENGE O'NEILL
description: With less than three weeks to go before the Sept. 9 primary election, the three Republican candidates for Governor of Connecticut are scrambling to attract attention.

title: Yield Drop Expected
description: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds are expected to decline further in the wake of yesterday's cut in the Federal Reserve's discount rate to 5 1/2 percent from 6 percent.

title: Fireman's Unit Gets President
description: Joe L. Stinnette Jr., the chairman, president and chief executive of Crum & Forster Personal Insurance in Basking Ridge, N.J., has been named president of the Fireman's Fund Personal Insurance Company in Novato, Calif.

title: KLEER-VU INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: POP: UB40 AT PIER 84
description: UB40 is a band in love with a groove - the hypnotic, mid-tempo lope of mid-1970's reggae. Above that groove, the guitarist Ali Campbell and other band members join in close vocal harmonies, singing modal melodies punctuated by horn-section riffs. More often than not, they sing about the harsh realities of living in poverty, fighting police oppression and trying to maintain hope. But it is the groove - swaying and rolling through every song, buoyant despite the unhappy lyrics it carries - that makes UB40's music so irresistible. Now and then, the tunes give way to reggae ''toasting'' - rapping - but the groove continues.

title: KELLWOOD CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After a loss of $655,000 from discontinued operations.

title: EDUCATORS SEE GREAT HARM
description: The tax legislation would cause serious economic problems for colleges and universities as well as for their faculty and students, according to school officials, who said the bill attacks higher education from numerous directions.

title: Akron Golf A Farewell
description: The NEC World Series of Golf that begins Thursday at the Firestone Country Club is the culmination of the American golf season for some of the 43 players, including the finale to what has been an exceptional season for Greg Norman.

description: Share earnings reflect a 5-for-4 stock split paid in July.

title: SUSPECT IS ARRESTED IN PATH KILLING
description: A 27-year-old sheet-metal worker was accused today of fatally shooting a PATH electrician Tuesday near the Passaic River in Kearny, the authorities said. They said the shooting was unintentional.

title: Jacksonville Kraft
description: The Jacksonville Kraft Paper Company has been purchased and its paper mill will be reopened on Jan. 15, officials said. Jacksonville Kraft's owners - Abraham Zion, the Stone Container Corporation of Chicago and the investment firm of Morgan Stanley & Company - have formed a new company to buy and operate the mill, closed last October.

title: Accounts
description: * Jaragua Hotel and Casino, a new luxury spa, resort and entertainment complex now under construction in Santo Domingo, Dominican Republic, to Smith Burke & Azzam.

title: DR PEPPER TO BE SOLD FOR $416 MILLION
description: Forstmann Little & Company, the New York investment concern, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell the Dr Pepper Company to another investor group for $416 million.

title: Comings and Goings
description: George Mira Jr., the University of Miami's premier linebacker and the son of George Mira Sr., its all-America quarterback of the early 1960's, was charged with the illegal possession of a prescription steroid after he was stopped Tuesday night after fleeing the scene of an altercation, the police. Yesterday his stepmother said the vial police officers had found in Mira's pickup truck had been left there by a friend who suffers from a thyroid condition and had a valid prescription for the compound. . . . Joe Pepitone, the former Yankee slugger, is due in court in Brooklyn today as jury selection begins in his trial on charges of illegal possession of cocaine, other substances and a pistol. . . . As his teammates continued their preparations for the Kickoff Classic against Ohio State University Wednesday, Willie Ryles, the University of Alabama defensive tackle who underwent surgery to remove a blood clot from his brain Monday afternoon, fell deeper into a coma at a Birmingham hospital. Ryles collapsed after being hit on the head in practice Monday. . . . Bob MacKinnon, assistant coach last season and a former general manager and interim head coach of the Nets, has been named the team's interim director of basketball operations. The vacancy was created when Lewis Schaffel left last month to join a group seeking a franchise in Miami.

title: Commodity Funds Recover
description: PUBLIC commodity funds, which faltered badly in the early 1980's, are staging a comeback. The funds, which trade futures contracts for soybeans, oil and Treasury bills, among other things, are the easiest, and in some cases the safest, way to play the futures market.

title: LIVINGWELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $690,000. The company said that it and a group of investors have formed a new company, Paramount Acceptance Corp., with about $35 million in capital stock.

title: LINEAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After a special charge of $443,000 for both the quarter and year. c-Includes a charge of $553,000 for both the quarter and year. The company said the charges of $443,000 in the latest periods include a reserve for inventory obsolesence of $335,000. The company also absorbed a charge of $91,000 for the settlement of a contract with the owner of Seaboard Industries, which modified some of the terms of the original agreement, giving Linear additional marketing potential for its long-range wireless product line.

title: 32 Are Hurt in Bus Collision
description: A Greyhound bus plowed into the back of a tractor-trailer loaded with lumber today, and 32 people were injured, the California Highway Patrol said. The bus, which was carrying 42 passengers from San Francisco to Los Angeles, smashed into the lumber truck shortly before 5 A.M. Officers said the bus driver and 16 of the passengers were taken to four hospitals in Bakersfield. The other injuries were described as minor to moderate.

title: Trash Pickup Resumes Despite Houston Strike
description: All but nine of Houston's 132 garbage trucks collected trash today under a police escort to prevent violence threatened by workers in a wildcat strike.

title: Lincoln's Dissenters, and the Sandinistas'
description: To the Editor:

title: TRUMPETER AND BAND LEADER
description: Thad Jones, a self-taught jazz trumpeter and cornetist whose syncopated, intricately harmonized arrangements became an ideal for a new generation of arrangers, died yesterday in Copenhagen after a four-month battle with cancer. He was 63 years old and lived in Denmark.

title: COMPUTER & COMMUNICATIONS TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
description: b-Net income The company said the latest 6-month results include a pre-tax charge of $14,191,000 related to the writeoff of certain assets and a pre- tax charge of $5,737,000 from the reversal of a previously posted gain fr om the sale of stock of its Zeta Laboratories unit.

title: CALIFORNIA MICROWAVE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Grievance Hearing Set
description: The arbitrator the baseball players dismissed last year will hear the players' grievance over the timing of the owners' dismissal of the arbitrator who succeeded him.

U.S. PROPOSES RULES TO ALLOW HOMEWORK FOR SOME INDUSTRIES
description: The Labor Department, as expected, today proposed new regulations to allow employees in six industries to work in their homes, as long as the companies get a government certificate.

title: E.P.A. FACES A SUIT ON LEAD EMISSIONS
description: An environmental group filed suit today in Federal court against the Environmental Protection Agency for failure to enforce air quality standards for lead emissions in four states.

title: On Baker's Bid
description: Former Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. of Tennessee has made no secret of wanting to run for President in 1988, but close associates say the health of his wife, Joy, is a critical factor and may keep him from the race.

title: CAPITOL AIDE CHARGED IN ANTITANK GUN BLAST
description: An Oregon Congressman's aide who also did consulting work for the Pentagon was arrested Tuesday in an accidental explosion of an antitank cannon in a Washington suburb, the lawmaker's office announced today.

title: REPORT AT U.N. BACKS CUTS OF 1,700 JOBS
description: The General Assembly will be asked to consider a sweeping reorganization of the administrative machinery of the United Nations this fall, according to a report made available today.

title: SPECIAL ITEMS HELP LIFT PERSONAL INCOMES 0.5%
description: Americans' personal incomes, bolstered by a variety of one-time special factors, rose five-tenths of 1 percent in July, the best showing in three months, the Government said today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, AUGUST 21, 1986
description: The Tax Bill of 1986

title: HOW CHILDREN AFFECT A WOMAN'S EARNINGS
description: Working women who delay childbearing beyond age 27 earn more money than those who have children before the age of 22, regardless of differences in education and experience, the author of a study says.

title: DRUG PLAN SEEKS MANDATORY TESTS OF U.S. EMPLOYEES
description: The Justice Department is considering proposing a Presidential order requiring narcotics testing for more than half of the Government's civilian employees, Administration officials said today.

title: JAMESWAY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
Big Macs in Yugoslavia
description: Yugoslavs may soon be able to switch from their own domestic hamburger, the spicy pljeskavica, to McDonald's Big Mac, the Belgrade daily, Politika, said today. The newspaper said talks were under way between the fast-food chain and Belgrade's Generalexport to open McDonald's outlets in Yugoslavia. If the talks prove successful, McDonald's would hold 49 percent and the Yugoslavs 51 percent of the total investment, as stipulated by Yugoslav law covering joint ventures, the newspaper said.

HUCK Snyder is the first to admit that the 250-square-foot studio he found in a 1950's East Village apartment house last summer was hardly the home of his dreams. ''It was in a pretty grim state of disrepair,'' said the 32-year-old artist. ''There were weird light fixtures on the walls, cords hanging everywhere, and paint encrusted the floor,'' he recalled.

title: CBS to Air Grace's Amended Deficit Spot
description: W. R. Grace & Company has been trying unsuccessfully for several months to persuade the three major television networks to air a commercial it produced warning in dramatic fashion of the dangers of the Federal budget deficit. The networks had refused to run the commercial, titled ''The Deficit Trials: 2017 A.D.,'' because they determined that it constituted advocacy advertising - taking a position on a controversial topic of public importance.

title: Loss at Deere On Sales Drop
description: Deere & Company has reported a $39.6 million loss for its latest quarter, in contrast to a profit of $4.5 million, or 6 cents a share, a year earlier.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: MOST homeowners and apartment dwellers handle at least some repair and maintenance chores themselves, and many are tackling increasingly ambitious projects. Publishers of ''how-to'' books have produced a number of new volumes that give all the information needed to complete even major jobs successfully. Here are some of the latest titles: ''The Backyard Builder,'' edited by John Warde (Rodale Press, 33 East Minor Street, Emmaus, Pa. 18049; $21.95, hard cover).

title: HUNDREDS OF BILINGUAL SCHOOL JOBS GO BEGGING
description: With the start of school in New York City less than three weeks away, roughly two-thirds of 665 new bilingual teaching jobs in the public school system remain unfilled, according to Board of Education officials.

description: b-After a tax credit of $270,000. c-Net loss

title: MEXICANS QUESTION 11 IN CASE OF U.S. DRUG AGENT
description: The Mexican authorities have detained 11 people in Guadalajara, including several Jalisco State Police officers, for questioning in connection with the detention last week of a United States Drug Enforcement Administration agent, officials from both countries said today.

title: DAMON CREATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Advertising; Outlook Of P.&G.'s Ad Chief
description: WHEN Robert V. Goldstein speaks, Madison Avenue listens. As the vice president for advertising at the Procter & Gamble Company, he oversees the world's largest advertising budget - more than $1 billion, according to Advertising Age - and a stable of 19 agencies in the United States.

title: MEXICAN PEASANT THEATER IN CATSKILLS
description: In sombreros and T-shirts proclaiming their nationality, 80 villagers from southeast Mexico arrived at Newark Airport in a Mexican military plane yesterday and were bused to the Catskills where they will offer an unusual theatrical event.

title: MAIL CARRIER KILLS 14 IN POST OFFICE, THEN HIMSELF
description: A mail carrier in trouble with his supervisors opened fire in a crowded post office here early this morning, killing 14 workers and injuring 7 others before killing himself with a bullet in the head.

title: RESTORING MURALS OF THE DEPRESSION ERA
description: Lying on scaffolding or standing on the tile floors in the Art Deco lobby of the aging post office, Anton W. Rajer completed his delicate task. His tools were cotton swabs and trisodium phosphate.

title: U.N. Command Accuses North Korea in Shooting
description: The United Nations Command said today that North Korean forces had fired across the demilitarized zone for the second time this month, setting off a five-minute exchange of gunfire.

title: FHP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The year-ago share earnings are not available because the company recently had its initial public offering. The company said the latest year results are stated as if the conversion of the company from non-profit to for- profit status had occurred July 1, 1985. The company also said that the net for the quarter and year reflect a pro- forma provision for income taxes at a 50-percent statutory rate.

title: On Statesmanship And Politics
description: Where politicians stand - and what they say - is often a matter of perspective.

title: Argentine Lawmakers Back Measure Legalizing Divorce
description: The House of Deputies overwhelmingly approved a bill today that would legalize divorce in this predominantly Roman Catholic nation.

title: Texas Bill To Aid Banks
description: Gov. Mark White today added an interstate banking proposal to the agenda of a special legislative session that will also consider a tax increase. The Governor initially called the special session for budget cuts to ease the state's $3.5 billion deficit.

title: JAYARK CORP reports earnings for Year to April 30
Jail for Soccer Rowdies
description: In an attempt to crack down on soccer violence, Parliament approved legislation Wednesday in which rowdy fans could be sent to prison for up to two years.

title: CENSURED PRIEST DEFENDS DISSENT AS A THEOLOGIAN
description: The Rev. Charles E. Curran said today that he would continue to teach Roman Catholic moral theology, including his dissenting views on sexual issues, despite the Vatican's ruling that he could no longer teach theology at the Catholic University of America.

title: HEWLETT-PACKARD CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Guards and Detectors Urged at Major Offices
description: The president of the National Association of Postmasters urged the Postal Service today to station guards and metal detectors in major post offices to battle a nationwide increase in problems with disgruntled employees.

title: Koch Endorses Dyson In Primary for Senate
description: Mayor Koch yesterday endorsed John S. Dyson's bid for the Democratic Senate nomination with a slap at his Democratic opponent and kind words for the incumbent Republican, Alfonse M. D'Amato.

title: MALRITE COMMUNICATIONS GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a charge of $1,818,000 from the prepayment of senior secured notes. c-Net income and includes a pretax gain of $5,666,000 on the disposal of certain assets.

title: RETIREMENT BENEFIT EFFECT STILL UNCLEAR
description: If the current tax bill becomes law, some workers would find that they are vested sooner in their pension plans and that they would receive larger benefits at retirement. But, on the other hand, there may be less of an incentive to take lump sums rather than monthly annuities when they retire and higher-paid executives might not be able to receive as much income from their pension plans as before.

title: Jurors Weigh Charges In McLaughlin Case
description: After hearing testimony for nearly seven weeks, jurors began their deliberations last night in the case of John J. McLaughlin, the former president of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation.

title: Minorities And the Ad Budget
description: ''Be all that you can be,'' goes the refrain in an Army recruiting campaign, suggesting that the military is the path to fulfillment. But the slogan does not necessarily apply to minority-owned advertising agencies, according to some members of Congress.

title: WORKING WOMEN SPEAK OUT ON HOME DESIGN
description: THEY took time out from their careers to discuss an important part of their lives - their homes. ''If I had my way,'' said Maxine Hirschel, who runs an advertising business in her home, ''I'd throw all my living-room furniture out and turn it into an office.''

title: Stocks Rebound; Dow Gains 18.42
description: Stocks soared yesterday, spurred by several negative economic indicators that strengthened hopes of lower interest rates.

title: GENERAL NAMED TO HEAD KENNEDY SPACE CENTER
description: Lieut. Gen. Forrest S. McCartney, commander of the Air Force space division, was named yesterday to head the Kennedy Space Center in Florida. The center, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's main site for the assembly, testing and launching of space vehicles, has been the takeoff spot for the space agency's greatest triumphs as well as its worst disaster, the Challenger explosion Jan. 28.

title: IFR SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
EVENTS: SHOW OF NEWCOMB POTTERY
description: ''Newcomb Pottery: An Enterprise for Southern Women,'' Cooper-Hewitt Museum, 2 East 91st Street, 212-860-6868.

title: Iran's 'Final Offensive'
description: The shots fired in the forgotten war on the Persian Gulf are scarcely heard. The world long ago shrugged off this bloody conflict that, incredibly, is about to enter its seventh year. Autumn will bring a dry, temperate interlude before rains turn battlefields to mud. It is then that Iran threatens to launch a ''final offensive'' against Basra, Iraq's second largest city. If Basra falls, Baghdad might well follow, spreading the aging Ayatollah Khomeini's shadow over the Persian Gulf.

title: Safeway Suits
description: Safeway Stores Inc., based in Oakland, Calif., said that it had agreed to settle all claims asserted in various shareholder suits regarding the supermarket chain's pending acquisition by a new company formed by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company and Safeway top management. Under the agreement, Safeway's board declared a cash dividend of 25.5 cents a share, payable Sept. 30 to holders of record at the close of business on Aug. 28, and a second dividend of 17 cents a share, payable Sept. 30 to holders of record as of Sept. 2.
