The company said the latest quarter and 6-month results are after a pre- tax provision of $756,000 for department closings, and the year-ago quarter and 6-month results include a provision of $251,000 for similar reasons. The company said the results for the latest periods include operating results of the company's recently acquired Four Star International Inc. subsidiary since June 29.

title: Security Pacific Growth Plans
description: The Security Pacific National Bank is interested in acquiring banks in northern California and also entering the Texas market, if the Legislature there permits acquisitions by out-of-state institutions, Richard J. Flamson 3d, the bank's chairman and chief executive, said today. ''We're interested in Texas,'' Mr. Flamson said in an interview.

title: THERMO INSTRUMENT SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
NEW YORK REASSURED IN PLANTS' BOND STATUS
description: The final Federal tax bill will contain an exception to preserve tax-exempt status for bonds to finance five garbage disposal plants in New York City and one in Nassau County, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan said yesterday.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL YANKEES VS. SEATTLE MARINERS, at Yankee Stadium, 7:30 P.M. (Television - Channel 11, 7:30; Radio - WABC, 7:30). ATLANTA BRAVES VS.

title: EXPLOSION WOUNDS 4 IN EAST BEIRUT
description: Christian East Beirut was rocked by another bomb explosion today, and the police said four people were wounded and a number of cars wrecked.

title: 5 ISRAELIS CHARGED IN DRUG OPERATION
description: Five Israeli nationals, whose conversations and transactions had been tapped and taped and then translated by Hebrew-speaking police officers, have been arrested and charged with operating a $1 million-a-week drug ring, the police said yesterday.

title: Philadelphia Debt Yields Up to 7.7%
description: A $111 million issue of Philadelphia general obligation bonds was tentatively offered yesterday with a maximum yield of 7.70 percent for bonds due in 2016 through underwriters led by Bear, Stearns & Company.

title: REXNORD INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
MAJOR HELP FOUND IN TAX BILL FOR LOW-INCOME HOUSEHOLDS
description: The new tax bill is a major step forward for low-income families, easing a tax burden that has grown increasingly heavy on them over the past decade, according to a variety of experts.

title: Deporting Dealers
description: Officials in New York have recently put forth an idea new to the otherwise familiar strategies aimed at curbing narcotics traffic. The idea is the speedy deportation of convicted narcotics offenders who are also illegal aliens. Twenty percent of narcotics convictions are said to fall into this category.

title: SCREEN: 'EXTREMITIES'
description: THE smashing, crashing, thrashing battle between Farrah Fawcett and James Russo that takes up about half of ''Extremities'' leaves the contestants in a state of exhaustion -and the movie along with them.

title: Sony-Warner Pact
description: The Sony Corporation of America said Warner Home Video had agreed to release a selection of prerecorded video cassettes in the 8-millimeter format.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for belwether issues.

title: Reagan Signs Debt Action
description: President Reagan today signed a $32 billion extension of the Federal Government's credit through Sept. 30, the White House said.

title: DUPLEX PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 26
Steven Crist on Horse Racing; MARE, 7, THRIVES AT SARATOGA
description: The fifth race at Saratoga Wednesday was as ordinary as they come on paper, a one-mile claiming race on the grass for older fillies and mares, but it may have yielded the most sentimentally popular victory and the slickest ride of the meeting.

title: PPG Entering Medical Field
description: PPG Industries, a leading maker of chemicals, glass and coatings, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the worldwide medical electronics units of both Honeywell Inc. and Litton Industries.

title: MCENROE DRAWS ANNACONE
description: Sometimes the luck of the draw means having no luck at all. John McEnroe, who is seeded ninth at the United States Open, drew Paul Annacone, a hard-serving Long Islander, in the opening round. Annacone is unseeded but ranked 18th in the world. The prospect of a difficult draw is one of the reasons McEnroe is not very optimistic about his quest for a fifth Open singles championship.

title: Garbage Trucks Roll As Houston Strike Ends
description: Almost all of the city's garbage collectors who staged a three-day wildcat strike returned to work today, including some who had been dismissed for refusing to work, officials said.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, AUGUST 22, 1986
description: The Economy

title: Peking Limits High-Rises
description: The authorities have placed restrictions on the construction of high-rise buildings in Peking in an effort to preserve the ancient city's traditional character, the newspaper Peking Daily reported today. The official New China News Agency said architects were worried that high-rise construction in the last 10 years had disrupted the architectural appeal of Peking's old-style compounds of single-story houses built around a courtyard.

title: Dining Out Guide: European Sampler
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. DIECI X, #1568 First Avenue, at 82d Street (628-6565) - **(July 18, 1986) The European continent offers a variety of cuisines for almost every taste - from light to heavy and from haute to homey. This swank East Side Italian restaurant offers some zesty and intelligently conceived food. The cozy dining room is urbane and relatively quiet, with softly illuminated tables.

title: The Editorial Notebook; The Tank Buster
description: The Army's antitank weapons leave much to be desired. Some force the infantryman to stand for long seconds exposed to the tank's machine-gunners; others lack the punch to penetrate Soviet tank armor. The Army's best hope is an unusual Air Force plane that fires slugs of extremely dense depleted uranium. The two ends of this story came into strange and fiery coincidence this week at a gas station in Arlington, Va.

title: ABC Radio Gets Winter Games
description: The organizing committee for the 1988 Winter Olympics here has given ABC the radio rights in the United States for the Games without seeking competitive bids.

title: DEVON RESOURCE INVESTORS LP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
China Daily in London
description: The official China Daily, the country's only English-language daily, will be printed in London and distributed in western Europe beginning Sept. 1, the newspaper said today. It said it had reached an agreement with the Mirror Group newspapers in Britain, owned by Robert Maxwell, giving the group the right to print and distribute the eight-page broadsheet paper in West Europe.

title: NIGHT LIFE: THE LATEST CLUBS
description: Like mushrooms after a rain, new New York clubs tend to pop up as fall nears. Already, the denizens of clubland are trading the addresses of little-known places that opened all around town this summer and are whispering tantalizing news of clubs to come.

title: CALIFORNIANS TAKE STOCK OF INFORMING ON PARENTS
description: There was a time when the family of Deanna Young played together, a time when she kicked a soccer ball around the driveway and was on girls' teams. But the Youngs' green bungalow here is empty today, the 13-year-old is in a county home and her parents have not been seen by neighbors for days. It is a family torn apart by drugs.

title: RECOGNITION EQUIPMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary gains of $885,000 for both the latest quarter and 9 months, and $478,000 for the year- ago 9 months.

title: AGENCY GETS INSIDE VIEW OF BURGLARIES
description: The Department of Investigation has a new investigation under way: Who evaded the department's sophisticated security system and robbed its new offices?

title: COMPUTER MEMORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $476,000.

title: Diner's Journal
description: DAVID BOULEY, former chef at Montrachet in TriBeCa, plans to open a French Provencal-style restaurant, called Bouley, later this year at 165 Duane Street, in the same neighborhood. The 90-seat, two-level dining room will have a 14-foot barrel-vaulted ceiling, stucco walls and a large rotisserie, Mr. Bouley said.

title: DANNENBERG ENLIVENS THE DANCE
description: Helen Dannenberg, who will perform tonight and tomorrow in Dance Theater Workshop's ''Out-of-Towners'' series at the Bessie Schonberg Theater, once choreographed a dance during which she climbed onto an ironing board. It was all right with her, Ms. Dannenberg now says, if the solo was seen as a wry ode to women's rights. But the dance, called ''Indicative Gestures,'' was actually inspired in part by the ironing board itself, which was unusually tall and had a muslin cover that reminded her of the pressing machines used by her father, a tailor. And the ironing board had a practical use. Ms. Dannenberg had just returned to the stage after a serious back injury. ''I thought I might have to lie down,'' she recalled.

title: No Place for Senators In Pinochet's Chile
description: To the Editor:

title: VIRGINIA FIRST SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes $135,000 from distribution of preferred stock dividends by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp.

title: INDUSTRIAL ACOUSTICS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
New News
description: John McEnroe says he enjoys being an athlete and acknowledges how fortunate he is to be part of such a financially rewarding profession. What he doesn't like is being treated as a celebrity.

title: NORSTAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $57,000. c-Net loss and after a loss from discontinued operations of $270,000.

title: BIG AREA STRICKEN
description: The Chernobyl disaster produced far more radioactive contamination that covered a much wider area than previously indicated, according to a Soviet report on the accident. And, it says, residents who were evacuated around the power plant may not be able to return for as long as four years.

title: IN CATSKILLS, JAZZ AND AN IRON EAGLE
description: A smorgasbord of events - jazz and brass concerts, a parade in honor of a large cast-iron eagle, a program on 19th-century gardens, and an outdoor production of Federico Garcia Lorca's ''Blood Wedding'' - awaits visitors to the Catskill Mountains this weekend. And on the east bank of the Hudson Valley, there will be a country fair and a demonstration evoking the Revolutionary War era.

title: HOLTZMAN ANNOUNCES 3 COURT UNITS FOR CRACK
description: District Attorney Elizabeth Holtzman of Brooklyn, saying that without the ability to try sellers and users of crack, the court system is a ''paper tiger,'' yesterday announced the establishment of three court sections in Brooklyn to deal exclusively with crack cases.

title: BOOM IN HIGH-RISE OFFICES TURNING SUBURBS INTO SATELLITE 'DOWNTOWNS'
description: When the American Motors Corporation opened a 25-story office building here 11 years ago, some executives worried that it was so remote that businesses would be reluctant to sign leases.

title: 'Star Wars' Is Still Only a Castle in Space
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge: The Competition Is Intense At New York's College Clubs
description: Most duplicate clubs are not competitive entities, ready to do or die against their rivals around the corner. In New York City the chief exceptions are the college clubs, whose alumni revive old sporting battles over the green baize.

title: POLICE SEARCHING FOR CRACK PIPES RAID HUNDREDS OF STORES IN CITY
description: Teams of police officers, invoking a little-used law, yesterday raided more than 200 stores in New York City that sell drug paraphernalia and seized more than 39,000 glass pipes that can be used to smoke crack, a potent form of cocaine.

title: PLANS BADLY HURT
description: The Chernobyl disaster did serious harm to the Soviet nuclear power program and has forced a review of the location and size of atomic generating plants, a Government official said today.

title: ARX INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CULLINET SOFTWARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income

title: TASTE FOR SUSHI SPURS RUSH TO HOOK TUNA OFF L.I.
description: A 509-pound giant bluefin tuna caught near here the other day brought more than just another angling thrill. It brought top dollar - $7 a pound - from Katsu Yoshino, president of a London-based seafood exporting company.

title: SERVO CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
ABC'S 'DARK MANSIONS,' A GOTHIC FAMILY SAGA
description: THE problems of the rich; they seem to stretch beyond number. The Drakes of Drake Point near Seattle have sibling rivalry, marital infidelity and possible incest and murder on their hands. They are also oppressed, apparently, by supernatural forces. ''Dark Mansions,'' a two-hour movie on ABC at 9 o'clock tomorrow night, is a soap opera with ghosts.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Stores Co., Salt Lake City, said it would report a decrease in second-quarter earnings and a flat pre-tax performance for the year.

title: Red Sox Win With 24 Runs
description: Boston's Tony Armas being congratulated by Jim Rice after hitting a grand slam home run in sixth inning against the Indians. Red Sox scored 12 runs in the inning and won, 24-5. Armas drove in six runs with two homers. (UPI)

title: TOYS 'R' US CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 3
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split effected June 27, 1986.

title: REAGAN TO RESIST ONE-ISSUE SUMMIT
description: The White House chief of staff said today that the Reagan Administration would resist any effort by the Soviet Union to limit discussions to arms control at a meeting between between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: DEFENDANT MISSING AT PEPITONE TRIAL
description: Jury selection in the Joe Pepitone cocaine trial was abruptly postponed for a day yesterday after one of the former Yankee slugger's two co-defendants failed to appear for the scheduled proceeding in a Brooklyn courtroom.

title: FESTIVALS AND FAIRS
description: Today Street Fair, Court Street, between President Street and Fourth Place in the Red Hook section of Brooklyn; sponsored by the Maria F. F. Addolorata Society. Games, food.

title: HIRSCHFELD, A PERSISTENT CANDIDATE, PRESSES AHEAD
description: Arthur Mesches was behind the counter at Art's Cleaners on Hertel Avenue in north Buffalo the other day when Abraham Hirschfeld marched in, stuck out his freckled hand and introduced himself.

title: STAGE: TERESA STRATAS AS A JEWISH IMMIGRANT IN 'RAGS,' A MUSICAL
description: TERESA STRATAS is one of those performers whose giant talent makes audiences forget just how tiny she is. That talent is to be found not only in her voice, which has entranced opera audiences for a quarter-century now, but also in her stage personality, which, like her looks, can sometimes recall the unstable mixture of street-tough sexuality and pathetic vulnerability that was Piaf. This quality has served Miss Stratas famously in her opera-house appearances as Berg's Lulu and Weill's Jenny, and it's just as well suited to her first starring role on Broadway. Rebecca, the heroine of the new musical ''Rags,'' is a Jewish immigrant determined to rise above the sweatshop squalor of the Lower East Side, circa 1910. Who better than Miss Stratas can make us believe that a frail wisp of a European woman might conquer the nasty, broad-shouldered new world?

title: Boeing Jet Order
description: Trans European Airways and Air Malta have ordered seven new Boeing 737 jets with a combined value of $185 million, the Boeing Commercial Airplane Company said.

title: INTERPHASE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Right Power
description: In addition, New York's six leading power hitters - Mike Pagliarulo, Don Mattingly, Rickey Henderson, Dave Winfield, Dan Pasqua and Mike Easler - hit only 22 of their 111 home runs off left-handers. How the eight active Yankees with more than 100 times at bat for New York had fared against left and right-handed pitching before last night's game:

title: Credit Education Secretary for Student-Aid Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: Celebrity Matches At Queens Tennis Fair
description: Tennis buffs can discuss the sport and maybe even get on the court with some professional players during a free fair on Sunday at the United States Tennis Association Center in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, Queens. Professionals will be paired with guest entertainers for a series of doubles matches that will begin at 4 P.M. Among the contenders will be Arthur Ashe, Pam Shriver, Billie Jean King, Chris Evert Lloyd, Tony Danza, Gene Wilder, Ricky Schroeder, Elke Sommer, Roberta Peters, Barry Gibb, Kristy McNichol, Dionne Warwick, Julius Irving and Chevy Chase.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: TWICE a day, six days a week, a procession of gleaming limousines lumbers up to La Cote Basque on East 55th Street, discharging prosperous citizens into its soft and familiar environs. They come seeking the old verities, to be reassured that the once-genteel Manhattan dining scene has not gone completely minimalist and hard-edged with its nouveau warehouses, T-shirted waiters, oversized plates and hamster-sized portions.

title: WITHDRAWAL OF U.S. FUNDS FOR STATES URGED AS ANTIDRUG STEP
description: A White House panel has proposed that Federal funds be withdrawn from states that do not sponsor ''adequate'' drug prevention programs, according to Government documents disclosed today.

title: HEAD OF HOUSE DEAVER PANEL CITES AN INACCURACY IN REPORT
description: The chairman of a House subcommittee has noted an inaccuracy in the panel's report that concluded that Michael K. Deaver, the former deputy White House chief of staff, lied in sworn testimony this spring.

title: Director of Unilever Joining Bankers Trust
description: Cob Stenham, the financial director of Unilever P.L.C. and Unilever N.V., is joining the Bankers Trust Company in a newly created position as executive chairman for the bank's businesses in Britain, Europe, the Middle East and Africa.

title: DORSEY FACING A STERN TEST
description: When the Giants made Eric Dorsey their first-round draft choice last April, they hoped that sooner or later he would become the starter at left defensive end. They still hope that, except now the goal is sooner rather than later because they need help now.

title: PUNTA GORDA ISLES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, AUGUST 22, 1986
description: International

title: DOUBLEDAY: A SHAKY EMPIRE
description: Data prepared by a Wall Street investment firm for the possible sale of Doubleday & Company, the publisher and owner of the Mets, shows a company with little growth in its well-known publishing business and an increasing dependency on its baseball club for profitability.

title: Record for a Ranger
description: After spending nine years in the minor leagues, Dale Mohorcic of the Texas Rangers has made it into the major league record books. The 30-year old rookie made his 13th straight appearance in relief Wednesday night, tying the 1974 record set by Mike Marshall of the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: LONG-TERM BOND YIELDS HIGH DESPITE FED'S CUTS
description: The Federal Reserve Board's willingness in the past four months to reduce the discount rate is succeeding in lowering short-term interest rates, but the benefits are slow to spread to the long-term market, where Treasury bond yields are still higher than mid-April.

title: Credibility on Chemical Arms
description: United States policy on chemical warfare has stood the test of time for more than a decade. We have renounced the first use of lethal and incapacitating chemical weapons. Our first priority has been a comprehensive, effectively verifiable, global ban on all chemical weapons. Until such a ban is attained, however, we must maintain deterrence through a strong defensive posture and a credible retaliatory capability.

title: A POLISH GADFLY PROBES BOTH SIDES OF PRISON WALLS
description: One week after he was released from prison under a partial clemency, Adam Michnik, one of the most influential theoreticians of the Solidarity underground, was fairly bursting with passionate observations and insights that he said he developed and refined in his latest confinement.

title: PRIME MEDICAL SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a charge of $225,000 in legal and investment banking fees incurred in connection with an anti-takover shareholder rights plan.

title: A Letter to Reagan
description: Eleven conservative Republicans in the House of Representatives have urged President Reagan to promote talks on power-sharing between the Government of South Africa and ''nonviolent South African groups representing blacks.''

title: ARRESTS IN PAKISTAN QUELLING WIDESPREAD RESISTANCE TO ZIA
description: Mass arrests and an extensive army presence throughout southeastern Pakistan appeared today to have suppressed the widespread anti-Government rioting earlier this week and thrown the political opposition into some disarray.

title: Sharon Steel Loan
description: The Sharon Steel Corporation said it would receive an $85 million asset-based loan from the American Financial Corporation. The troubled steelmaker, which is controlled by Victor Posner, the financier, said it would use the loan to make necessary payments to complete a pending debenture swap, to pay debt and for working capital. The loan is subject to certain conditions, among them that Sharon obtain wage concessions from the United Steelworkers union.

title: Postal Worker Accused In $200,000 Bond Loss
description: The Federal Goverment today charged a Washington postal worker with possession of bonds worth $200,000 that were taken from a registered, sealed Postal Service pouch.

title: THE LONER: FROM SHY FOOTBALL PLAYER TO 'CRAZY PAT'
description: Across a span of 27 years, old coaches remember Patrick Henry Sherrill as an earnest, quiet young football player who was ''a little bit shy.''

title: Comings and Goings
description: Moe Iba, who resigned as head basketball coach at Nebraska last March after the 19-11 Cornhuskers played in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament for the first time, has been named an assistant coach at Drake. . . . Claudell Washington, the Yankee outfielder, has filed a $62.4 million lawsuit that accuses Thomas Baenzinger, seven other people and nine businesses of making a series of investments in which the ballplayer lost almost $800,000.

title: Truly Uncle Sugar
description: It was inevitable, perhaps, that New York, Connecticut, nine other states and the District of Columbia have agreed to start a multi-state lottery, with weekly jackpots of $40 million, perhaps by fall 1987. The surprise is that the states got the jump on the Federal Government.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Executive Changes column in Business Day on Tuesday incorrectly listed the ownership of the Fireman's Fund Insurance Company. It is owned by the Fireman's Fund Corporation, not by the American Express Company.

title: Outerly Offended
description: To the Editor:

title: PANSOPHIC SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
STUDENTS FLY IN BUT FIND FEW PLACES TO ROOST
description: First, there's getting a place at a Boston college. Then there's getting a place in Boston.

title: BENEFICIAL'S SALE SEEN AS LIKELY
description: The Beneficial Corporation, the largest independent consumer finance concern in the country, indicated late yesterday that the company is for sale.

title: DRESSER TO BUY BACK 15% OF ITS STOCK
description: Dresser Industries Inc., citing the depressed conditions in the oil industry, yesterday said that it would reduce its debt and buy back 11.5 million outstanding common shares, about 15 percent of its common stock, during the next fifteen months.

title: VON STADE CONQUERS HER FEAR OF THE CONTEMPORARY
description: ''To be honest with you, I've always been a little frightened of contemporary music,'' the mezzo-soprano Frederica von Stade said the other day. ''I love reading through the songs I get in the mail - all singers get oodles of songs in the mail - and I always study the scores carefully to find out whether a piece is right for me. But I don't have perfect pitch, which is something I think you really need to sing some of the most difficult contemporary music. And a lot of it is very wearing on the voice. So most of the contemporary music I've sung has been written by composers who understand the voice and write idiomatically for it in what is basically a classical style - composers such as Thomas Pasatieri, Richard Hundley and Dominick Argento.''

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: An illustration on the front page of The Living Section on Wednesday that accompanied an article about ice cream showed six people at an ice cream parlor counter with sodas and sundaes.

title: Iran Rounds Up 2 'Terrorist Networks'
description: Iranian authorities announced today that they had rounded up two ''terrorist networks'' blamed for bombings that have killed 38 people and wounded more than 250 this year.

title: NAVY LIFTS LITTON BAN
description: The Navy today lifted its suspension of contracting with two large units of Litton Industries, which had been blocked temporarily from signing new Government contracts after a subsidiary was indicted for fraud.

title: FARAH MANUFACTURING CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain from litigation of $7,440,000.

title: METS A BASEBALL 'JEWEL' IN ATTENDANCE, REVENUE
description: The New York Mets are a glorious exception to major league baseball's prediction that its 26 teams will collectively lose $59 million this year.

title: RUSSIANS LINK DISASTER TO ARMS AIMS AND USE IT TO FURTHER FOREIGN POLICY
description: The Soviet Union's report on the causes and consequences of the Chernobyl nuclear accident tries to make the disaster serve the nation's foreign policy.

title: VILLAGE CLUBS FEATURING FESTIVAL SOUNDS
description: The Greenwich Village Jazz Festival begins today and runs through Sept. 1 at various clubs in the area. For ticket information, call the appropriate club. A special pass, available for $10 at all of the clubs, will allow listeners to purchase half-price admission tickets to all events during the festival; many of the clubs are also offering third sets free to those who have passes. Here is a schedule of events and locations: Today At 4 to 7 P.M. Village Gate, 160 Bleecker Street (475-5120). Art Blakey and the Jazz Messengers; Chico Freeman Quartet; Tim Berne Trio with Joey Baron and Hank Roberts; Herb Robertson Quintet, with Bill Frisell, Lindsey Horner, Tim Berne and Joey Baron; John Lindberg's Revolving Ensemble, with Tom Varner and Marty Ehrlich; Junior Mance-Marty Riviera Duo and Dotty Stallworth. Free, but there is a one-drink minimum.

title: IRISH SOLDIER IS KILLED IN LEBANNON
description: An Irish soldier serving with the United Nations peacekeeping force in southern Lebanon was killed today by a bomb along a road.

title: U.S. Judge Under Guard After Bomb Is Disarmed
description: A Federal judge who was the intended target of a pipe bomb returned to work under guard today after a bomb squad technician defused the bomb at the Federal Building here on Wednesday, the authorities said. A similar bomb exploded at the Fargo Post Office on Monday, injuring four workers.

title: AUCTIONS
description: PRIZED items in this fast-growing field of antiques include Strength Testers, Flip-Card Machines and Wheels of Fortune, and posters advertising such unforgettable sights as the Dog Child, the Gay Deceiver and Hugo the Blood-Sweating Hippopotamus from the River Nile.

title: Rehnquist in a Reply On 1969 Army Memo
description: Associate Supreme Court Justice William H. Rehnquist says he has ''no recollection'' of writing a draft Justice Department memorandum in 1969, in which he proposed Army surveillance of civilian anti-war protesters.

title: EXCERPTS FROM THE REPORT ON CHERNOBYL AND NEWS CONFERENCE IN MOSCOW
description: Following are excerpts from a report to be issued in Vienna on Monday by a Soviet Government commission investigating the Chernobyl nuclear disaster, and from a news conference in Moscow yesterday. The excerpts from the news conference were distributed by Tass, the Soviet press agency, and translated by The New York Times. Report on Chernobyl

title: Abducted Army Officer Reported Freed in Chile
description: An army colonel kidnapped by leftist guerrillas four days ago was set free by his captors on a Santiago street tonight, the Government said.

title: ROSE'S STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
ART: THE AVANT-GARDE FROM CHINA IN SHOW
description: CHINA, as it was or even as it is now, is not normally associated with Modernism.

title: DEAN FOODS CO reports earnings for Year to May 25
description: The company said it changed from a calendar year to a year ending the last Sunday in May for financial reporting purposes as a result of the April 1986 merger of Larsen Co.

title: TEXAS EXECUTES SECOND KILLER
description: A man sentenced to die for fatally shooting a convenience store clerk in the back of the head in a robbery that netted $25 was executed early Friday.

title: Lawsuit on Contras Dismissed in California
description: A lawsuit seeking a Government investigation of covert actions by the Reagan Administration in Nicaragua was dismissed today by a Federal appeals court here.

title: Mutual Fund Assets Up
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds increased $1.1 billion, to $231.92 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: BISHOP TUTU FACES TAUNT OF TREASON
description: Bishop Desmond M. Tutu, winner of the 1984 Nobel Peace Prize and a leading opponent of South Africa's white authorities, returned to Johannesburg from an overseas tour today to face a barrage of taunts from conservative whites accusing him of treason because of his attitude to international sanctions.

title: Futures Broker Ousted
description: The board of the Mid America Commodity Exchange expelled the First Commodity Corporation of Boston today and fined the firm $3.6 million. The fine is the largest levied against a brokerage house by any exchange. First Commodity was accused of violating the exchange's use of promotional material, as well as fraudulent and misleading sales practices.

title: Ford's Annuity Notes
description: The Ford Motor Credit Company yesterday sold $200 million of annuity notes, through Goldman, Sachs & Company. The notes are an unusual variation of traditional debt issues but have been issued in the past by British Petroleum in the Eurobond market and Equitable Life Leasing in the American market.

title: Early Shipment For I.B.M. Model
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said it had shipped the first model of its most powerful new generation of mainframe computers a year ahead of the company's original schedule.

title: Stocks End Day Mixed; Dow Declines Slightly
description: Stock prices ended narrowly mixed yesterday in the wake of the Federal Reserve Board's largely-expected discount rate cut. While blue-chip issues slipped a bit, the underlying market moved strongly ahead.

title: Public Opinion for Sale
description: The American Enterprise Institute, a Washington-based conservative research group that has recently been experiencing financial problems, is offering its bimonthly magazine, Public Opinion, for sale. The principal prospective buyer so far is Dow Jones & Company, which publishes The Wall Street Journal and has been seeking the acquisition for some time.

title: Soviet Foreign Trade Official Arrested on Customs Charge
description: A top foreign trade official and several customs officers have been arrested on charges of smuggling goods into the Soviet Union, the Government newspaper Izvestia reported today.

title: Soviet GATT Bid Opposed
description: The Reagan Administration will oppose the Soviet bid to participate in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the White House said today.

title: Mixed Feelings For Rozelle
description: In the last week, three National Football League teams and three former United States Football League backs have negotiated four-year contracts for large sums. Jim Kelly will get $8 million to play quarterback for the Buffalo Bills, Herschel Walker $5 million to run for the Dallas Cowboys and Kelvin Bryant $3.75 million to run for the Washington Redskins.

title: MOSCOW GIVES IN TO HUNGER STRIKER
description: Soviet visa authorities have told a 37-year-old hunger striker that she and her family can emigrate, her husband said today.

title: 'Adams Apple,' Suspense-Drama on CBS
description: Toni Adams (Sydney Walsh), the protagonist of ''Adams Apple,'' is one of those fantasy women that only the dog days of television could cough up. A private investigator who has been in the business for just six months, she nevertheless lives in what looks to be a million-dollar Manhattan apartment and earns enough money to be able to afford a spacious office and a full-time assistant.

title: ANALOG DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
The Often Inexplicable Ways of Babies
description: To the Editor:

title: The Calico Question
description: Reports from the California White House that one of the three newest members of the Reagan pet family is a male calico cat named Morris appear to be imprecise. Morris, yes; male calico, probably not.

title: ACTION INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
Swim Record Set By East German
description: Sylvia Gerasch, of East Germany, who saw one of her world records beaten three days ago, set another in the same pool today at the world swimming championships.

title: DEFENSE BY CHAMPION BRINS AN EASY DRAW
description: Gary Kasparov put forth a repaired Gruenfeld Defense to effortlessly draw the ninth game of his world championship chess match with Anatoly Karpov in London on Wednesday.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday MUSIC FOR BROOKLYN What kind of music won't be heard at the Prospect Park Band Shell this weekend? Samba, perhaps, but that's only because it was part of the program last weekend. From Scandinavian folk songs to bluegrass finger-picking, and from Irish ballads to a cappella gospel, the program for this weekend's ''Celebrate Brooklyn'' festival seems to have something for everyone. Tonight, Gone at Last, the exuberant Norwegian folk group, plays, along with the bluegrass guitarist Mike Soloway. Tomorrow night, the Clancy Brothers, the Irish folk group, bring along their nephew Robbie O'Connell and the Belfast balladeer Ray Collins for a program of songs - drinking songs, funny songs, rebel songs and love songs. Sunday night the featured group is Sweet Honey in the Rock, a female a cappella quintet. All performances are at 8 P.M. A $1 contribution is encouraged. The band shell is at Prospect Park West and Ninth Street, two blocks from the Seventh Avenue station on the F train. The rain site is the Prospect Park Picnic House. Information: (718) 768-0699.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: LIVE FLESH. By Ruth Rendell. 272 pages.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: A $165 million issue of Massachusetts general obligation bonds was offered yesterday, with maximum yield of 6.729 percent for a 6 1/2 percent bond due 2006 at a price of 97 1/2, through underwriters led by Morgan Guaranty Trust Company.

title: Greenwade Knew the Territory
description: Bunch Greenwade remembers watching his father leave for work, wearing a white shirt and tie, gunning his late-model Cadillac down the highway for eight or 10 days on the road.

title: CORADIAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
The Lifesaver Called Running Lights
description: There's a simple way to reduce highway fatalities by 3 percent and cut related property damage by perhaps twice that amount, all at a cost of just pennies per car. The Scandinavian countries found it years ago and Canada is about to. So will the United States, and better sooner than later.

title: Grey Gives Mitsubishi 'Associative Visuals'
description: Mitsubishi, another of the second-tier Japanese auto imports, also has a new campaign breaking this fall. The campaign, from Grey Advertising, is built around the theme, ''Perfecting the Experience.''

title: Leaving It to Reagan
description: The American people like Ronald Reagan and distrust the Soviet Union. Are these sufficient reasons for them to tolerate Mr. Reagan's malingering approach to arms control and his outright obstruction of a comprehensive test ban treaty?

title: Judge in Trial of Gotti Will Not Sequester Jury
description: A Federal judge said yesterday that he would not sequester the anonymous jury that is to hear Federal racketeering charges against John Gotti and six co-defendants.

title: A Play: 'Dear Uncle Sam'
description: A theatrical project at the National Archives has put a new twist on that old saw about a show with a cast of thousands. In this project it is the writing crew that numbers in the thousands - no, in the millions.

title: Iran Tanker Reported
description: Iran has chartered one of the world's largest supertankers to provide floating storage for its crude oil in the Persian Gulf, area oil industry sources said today. The 564,739-ton Liberian-registered Seawise Giant would probably be used at Iran's recently established floating oil terminal off Larak Island in the Strait of Hormuz, said the sources who spoke on condition they not be identified.

title: Panhandle Sets Oil Rig Merger
description: W. R. Grace & Company and the Panhandle Eastern Corporation said today that they had agreed to combine their oil-well drilling operations, a move they said would create the largest fleet of rigs operated by any company in the world. Terms were not released.

title: The Illusion In the Tax Bill
description: TAXES are hot potatoes: Everyone tries to pass them off to someone else. Most of the talk about who is going to gain or lose from tax overhaul has focused on who gets the hot potatoes first. But that is not the important issue. What ultimately matters is who ends up with the hot potatoes - not who starts with them.

title: For Richer, for Poorer, In Taxes and Ideology
description: As ideological marriages go, the union consecrated by the new tax bill must be one of this city's oddest couples.

title: WORKERS RETURN TO SLAYING SCENE
description: Amid tears and embraces, glassy stares and wrenching sobs, postal workers returned to their jobs here this morning, a day after a co-worker unleashed a murderous 10-minute barrage that killed 14 people.

title: Bundesbank Rates
description: The earliest that the Bundesbank can move to cut its own discount rate, after the Fed's half-point reduction on Wednesday, will be at a meeting of its policy-making council next Thursday, sources close to the West German central bank said today. The sources said a rate cut by the Bundesbank is likely but not certain. The bank could also postpone reducing its rate, currently 3.5 percent, until mid-September in the hope that the Fed would further reduce its 5.5 percent discount rate.

title: Magazine Ads Drop
description: In July, members of the Publishers Information Bureau, most of the country's largest magazines, carried collectively 8,835 ad pages, a decrease of 8.3 percent, from 9,634 pages in 1985. Estimated revenues for the month came to $298.1 million, a decrease of 4.4 percent, or $13.8 million, compared with July 1985.

title: Coldblooded Killers, Not Freedom Fighters
description: I would venture to guess that there are few who could say with precision what we mean by ''terrorism.'' One might well ask why we should spend our time quibbling about definitions when what is really needed is a plan of action. I submit that the issue is not simply one of semantics. Having a clear idea of the evil we seek to eradicate is, in many respects, a prerequisite to any meaningful response. Before we enact legislation to punish the political terrorist, we must know what category he fits.

title: Money, Money, Money
description: From the Democratic point of view, the bad news is that Republican political committees raised 5.3 times as much money as their Democratic equivalents ($186.1 million to $35.1 million) from January of 1985 through last June. The good news is that the disparity was better than it was in 1981-82, when, according to the Federal Election Commission, the Republicans raised 6.5 times as much as the Democrats ($161.2 million to $24.8 million).

title: Sun Belt Nursery Won by Tracy Locke
description: Sun Belt Nursery Group of Fort Worth has named Tracy Locke, Dallas, to handle its over $5 million in billings.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The measures being taken to decontaminate the populated places will generally lead to only temporary improvement of the radiation situation.'' - Official Soviet report on Chernobyl. [ A1:6. ]

title: SCREEN: BRANDNER'S '50/50'
description: IN ''50/50,'' which opens today at the Thalia, Uwe Brandner, the West German novelist and film maker, depicts a profoundly unsettled society. The film, which chronicles the severe midlife crisis of a Munich man who is an architect, paints a picture of modern-day West Germany that isn't very pretty -cold, inhuman, meaningless, aggressive, obsessed with its past and uncertain of its future. Even sex, which the film's characters pursue indefatigably, is largely second-hand. Leering salesmen stare lecherously at a woman trying on new outfits, a cabdriver asks his passenger to undress so he can ''just look,'' men stare at pictures of nude women in magazines while watching television. Like work, love and success, sex is ultimately unfulfilling. These characters, like many of the restless young Americans of the 1960's, would have understood Mick Jagger when he sang, ''I Can't Get No Satisfaction.''

title: SOVIET TRACTOR AIDE IS GIVEN U.S. REFUGE AFTER SUICIDE EFFORT
description: A Soviet tractor official who asked for political asylum after taking an overdose of sleeping pills is under Federal protection, the State Department said today.

title: An Arrest at White House
description: The Secret Serice arrested a homeless woman early today as she scaled the northeast fence of the White House with a makeshift ladder. The woman, Rosita Bourbon, 33 years old, was charged with unlawful entry, according to a Secret Service spokesman. He said White House guards were unable to determine why she was trying to cross the fence.

title: BLEECKER STREET CINEMA CELEBRATES JAZZ
description: A jazz film series begins tonight and runs through Sept. 4 at the Bleecker Street Cinema 2, 144 Bleecker Street. Admission to each screening is $5 for shows before 5 P.M. or $6 for those 6 P.M. and later. A $10 pass, available at clubs participating in the Greenwich Village Jazz Festival, will allow moviegoers half-price admission to all screenings. Information: 674-2560 or 674-2561. Here is a schedule: Today At 2, 4, 6, 8 and 10 P.M. ''Anything for Jazz'' (1980), with Jaki Byard; ''Lambert and Company'' (1964), with Dave Lambert; ''Day Break Express'' (1953), music by Duke Ellington; ''On the Road With Duke Ellington'' (1980).

title: GROW GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $2.5 million for both the quarter and year. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $1.2 million. The company said results for the latest periods reflect income from pension settlement and a change in method of accounting for pension costs; they also include results from operations of Perigo Co., acquired Jan. 1.

title: FLOW GENERAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $264,000 for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Net loss

title: GLENZ WINS MET ON UNUSUAL SHOT
description: A 50-yard bunker shot that stopped four inches from the cup of the 17th hole saved the day for David Glenz as he won the 71st Metropolitan Open Championship. Later in the lounge, fellow players' reactions were a mixture of surprise and disbelief that the ball stopped and backed up.

title: Chinese Guard Reported Slain In Clash With Soviet Troops
description: A Japanese newspaper said today that Chinese and Soviet border guards exchanged fire along the western sector of their frontier in July, and that one Chinese guard was killed and another was wounded.

title: Hurting for Help
description: Dick Vermeil, head coach of the Philadelphia Eagles from 1976 to 1982, was the football coach for three seasons in the early 1960's at Hillsdale High in San Mateo Calif. His familiarity with injuries to secondary school athletes may explain Vermeil's eagerness to serve as spokesman for the National Athletic Trainers Association in a national attempt to raise awareness among parents and administrators about preventable physical dangers to which high school athletes are exposed.

title: A.C.L.U. ACCUSES PROSECUTOR
description: The A.C.L.U. has filed a formal complaint against an assistant district attorney in Brooklyn accusing her of ''supression of evidence'' in two murder cases.

title: Jeantot Arrives Late
description: Philippe Jeantot, the 34-year-old French sailor who in 1983 won the first BOC singlehanded yacht race around the world, sailed into Newport, R.I., Tuesday night in preparation for the second running of the race. But Jeantot was late.

title: HITECH ENGINEERING reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $43,000. c-Net loss The company said the substantial increase in revenue is due to the company obtaining full operational status in January 1986 compared with its development stage in 1985.

title: LINCOLN LOGS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 1-for-12.5 reverse stock split paid July 24.

title: AUTHORITIES WIDEN EXPLOSION INQUIRY
description: Federal law-enforcement officials are trying to determine whether an Oregon Congressman promoted research by a retired Air Force colonel whose handmade antitank cannon accidentally discharged this week, injuring four people.

title: Two Russian Defectors To Join a Miami Circus
description: A Russian husband-and-wife acrobat team who defected from the Moscow Circus said Wednesday that they would join a Miami circus and tour the country as an independent act.

title: Newspaper Ads Up
description: The Newspaper Advertising Bureau has released the estimates for May newspaper advertising volume.

title: Vanbiesbrouck Signs
description: John Vanbiesbrouck, winner of the Vezina Trophy as the National Hockey League's outstanding goaltender last season, signed a new three-year contract with the Rangers yesterday. Vanbiesbrouck, a 1981 fifth-round draft choice, posted a 3.32 goals-against average in the regular season, fifth best in the league, then led the Rangers into the semifinal round of the Stanley Cup playoffs with a 3.27 goals-against average.

title: CITY MAY ABANDON PLANS FOR FINANCIAL-JOBS SCHOOL
description: A specialized public high school for financial studies, three years in the planning, has not gotten under way and may never be built, city and school officials said yesterday.

title: Bizet at City Opera
description: Rachel Rosales, Mark Thomsen, Robert McFarland and Harry Dworchak will star in the New York City Opera's performance of Bizet's ''Pecheurs de Perles'' at the New York State Theater tonight at 8 o'clock.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: The Third Annual Folk Heritage Festival, Lincoln Center (877-2011). Lincoln Center will present continuous free folk music of every variety for 10 hours this Sunday. The festival begins at noon with klezmer and marching-band music at the center's Fountain Plaza and moves to Damrosch Park at 1 P.M. The schedule is as follows: Gone at Last (Norwegian string-band music) at 1 P.M, the reunion of the Greenbriar Boys (John Herald, Ralph Rinzler and Bob Yellin) at 2, the North Carolina blues artists John Dee Holeman and Quentin (Fris) Holloway at 3, Hungaria (Hungarian folk music and dance) at 4, the Boarding Party (a vocal quartet specializing in sea songs) at 5, the folk-blues singer Richie Havens at 6, the Irish singer-fiddler Tom Dahill at 7 and the noted flatpicking folk and bluegrass guitarist Doc Watson at 8.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Cognitive Systems Inc., New Haven, has appointed Richard A. Lefebvre president and chief executive officer, replacing David Fox, who will become chairman of the executive committee.

title: BOLIVIA IS HOPING U.S. DRUG FORCES WILL EXTEND STAY
description: American and Bolivian officials say a military operation to destroy cocaine laboratories in this country has proved so successful that they want to keep American troops and helicopters here beyond the 60 days originally planned.

title: HOT SPOT IN SUN BELT: BOOM TOWN FOR GAMBLING
description: For a visitordriving through the blistering desert, the town of Laughlin seems an unlikely mirage: a cluster of a half-dozen casinos billowing in the heat, miles and miles from nowhere.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: PAOLO AND VITTORIO TAVIANI, the Italian film-making brothers who won international renown as the writer-directors of ''Padre Padrone'' and ''The Night of the Shooting Stars,'' recently embarked on their first English-language film, ''Good Morning, Babylon.'' The movie, which takes place between 1910 and 1917, tells the story of two Italian brothers - artisans in their father's cathedral-restoration business - who come to America to ply their craft and end up building sets on D. W. Griffith's epic 1916 silent movie, ''Intolerance.'' Vincent Spano and Joaquim De Almeida play the brothers, and Charles Dance the legendary director.

title: IMPRESSIONIST SHOW AT MET FROM SOVIET
description: THE exhibition of ''Impressionist and Early Modern Paintings From the U.S.S.R.'' has now arrived at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, where it can be seen through Oct. 5. Seen previously at the National Gallery of Art in Washington, and at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, it consists of eight paintings by Cezanne, nine by Gauguin, three each by Monet, Renoir and van Gogh, seven by Matisse and eight by Picasso.

title: PERES SAYS HE EXPECTS TO SEE MUBARAK
description: Prime Minister Shimon Peres says he expects to meet President Hosni Mubarak next month in Egypt.

title: JAZZ MASTERS AND NEWCOMERS ON STAGE, SCREEN AND STEAMBOAT
description: WHY not call up those jazz-fanatic friends of yours who live out of town? Go on! Make them suffer!

title: Litwinski to Perform
description: The avant-garde Polish composer Mieczyslaw Litwinski will perform music for voice, harmonium, hurdy-gurdy, Jew's harp, violin and kazoo at the New York Open Center, 83 Spring Street, tomorrow night at 8 o'clock. Admission is $8. Information: 219-2527.

title: RWANDA SEEKS AMERICAN IN NATURALIST'S DEATH
description: An official Rwandan Government publication said today that an American wildlife researcher was being sought as a primary suspect in the slaying of the naturalist Dian Fossey.

title: TYSON TO JOIN HBO'S SERIES
description: Mike Tyson, the undefeated heavyweight, announced yesterday that he would enter the Home Box Office heavyweight championship unification series.

title: Arbitraging Multisyllables on the Top Line
description: With all this concentration on the bottom line, a nagging, balance-sheet question remains: Is anybody looking at the top line? I find too many management types running their sharp, eagle eyes down long columns of figures. Why don't they ever look up? To be hard-nosed about it, up as high as the company letterhead.

title: 50 SECRET FIGHTERS SEEN READY
description: The United States Air Force has about 50 Stealth fighter planes and two operational squadrons deployed in the Nevada desert, unofficial sources familiar with the program said tonight.

title: WHAT DO CABBIES EARN? ANSWER IS KEY TO FARES
description: Ray Pena says he works more than 72 hours a week and makes $25,000 a year.

title: SURROGATE MOTHER SEEKS BABY
description: A hearing on temporary custody of a five-month-old baby girl was postponed today after court briefs filed by lawyers for the baby's natural mother asserted that the child's father might not be the man who agreed to pay $10,000 for rights to the child, which he contends was conceived through artificial insemination using his sperm.

title: Not Everybody Wants to Escape Jury Duty
description: To the Editor:

title: CONSUMER PRICES ARE UNCHANGED
description: Another steep decline in gasoline held consumer prices steady in July, offsetting increases in the cost of food, medical services and imported goods, the Government reported today.

title: Meyers Is Disgusted
description: The ruling by the Navy Department granting Napoleon McCallum permission to play for the Los Angeles Raiders as long as it does not interfere with his duties as a supply officer has left Lieut. Eddie Meyers of the Marine Corps, who is in the Atlanta Falcon training camp, ''a little disgusted.''

title: Tram Riders See Red Again
description: What's red and red and runs part time?

title: 'Dixie Dewdrop' Postponed
description: ''The Dixie Dewdrop,'' a country musical by R. Santinelli and Patrick Sky that was scheduled to open tonight, has postponed its opening to Aug. 29. The play will continue in previews at Intar Stage 2, 508 West 53d Street.

title: TAX BILL CONFUSING ON GAINS
description: Just how are capital gains going to be treated under the tax bill?

title: CERTRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss The company said the latest quarter loss is after a charge of $104,000 associated with the closing of a plastics injection molding facility.

title: CUOMO DEFENDING AIDES' EFFORTS TO TAKE HIRSCHFELD FROM BALLOT
description: Governor Cuomo, maintaining that there were ''substantive'' flaws in the designating petitions of Abraham Hirschfeld, yesterday defended his aides' efforts to remove Mr. Hirschfeld from the Democratic primary ballot for lieutenant governor.

title: TEC INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: HARKEN OIL & GAS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
WHITE-CLAD WORKERS CLEANING UP CHERNOBYL
description: On Soviet television, the workers in the front lines of the clean-up at the Chernobyl nuclear plant all wear white cloth caps, white mouth guards and white uniforms. They look eerily like surgeons operating with bulldozers and precast concrete blocks instead of scalpels and surgical thread.

title: Are We at War Yet?
description: To the Editor:

title: RAIL UNION ELECTS A DISSIDENT LEADER AS PRESIDENT
description: Robert Delaney, leader of a dissident group in the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers, defeated the union's president, John F. Sytsma, today in an election marked by bitterness and charges of fraud.

title: UNITED STOCKYARDS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
COURT OVERTURNS $100,000 AWARD IN MEDICAL EXAMINER'S DISMISSAL
description: A Federal appeals court ruled yesterday that Mayor Koch had not violated the constitutional rights of Dr. Michael M. Baden when he released written criticisms of Dr. Baden in announcing his dismissal as Chief Medical Examiner in 1979.

title: Protestants in Ulster Unite With Catholics in a Protest
description: Northern Ireland government workers, both Protestant and Roman Catholic, walked off their jobs today to protest threats against Catholics by Protestant paramilitary groups.

title: SCHOOL BOARD CONSIDERS PROPOSAL ALLOWING STRIP SEARCHES FOR DRUGS
description: The Warwick Valley School Board is considering adopting a new policy that will allow school officials in this Orange County community to strip search children for drugs.

title: NORTH AMERICAN HOLDING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HUGHES SUPPLY INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
CITY TO REPOSSESS A SCHOOL IT SOLD IN '83
description: The tortured story of 931 First Avenue, a turn-of-the-century public school at 51st Street that commands the crest of Beekman Hill, appeared to have been resolved in October 1983.

title: BARUCH-FOSTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: RAINOUT VEXES RASMUSSEN
description: Dennis Rasmussen's best plans did not leave room for a rainout last night.

title: FLOYD GAINS SHARE OF LEAD WITH 66
description: Ray Floyd, who won the United States Open championship at Shinnecock Hills in an exciting finish June 15, is feeling confident. ''I'm actually hitting the ball better than I did at the U.S. Open,'' he said today. ''My swing's a little better right now. I'm much longer right now.''

title: LENDL GAINS BUT ISN'T HAPPY
description: Like a lot of people, Ivan Lendl thought there was a glimmer of hope that the tennis world would see a new, more mature John McEnroe when he returned to tournament competition following a six-month sabbatical.

title: BROADWAY
description: IT isn't easy to describe Le Cirque Imaginaire other than as a circus of make-believe, a refinement and distillation of the essence of circus. Whatever it is - it's even been called a chamber-theater piece - it's going to be in New York for a limited engagement this year. Its stars and only players, aside from a few musicians, are a husband-and-wife team who have been touring, pruning and improving for 15 years.

title: AIDS Hopes Fuel ICN Stock
description: EVEN the glimmer of an AIDS cure can cause excitement, and this seems to be true on Wall Street as well.

title: ANAREN MICROWAVE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Motorola to Resume Sales of RAM Chips
description: Motorola Inc. plans to re-enter a major segment of the computer chip business that most American manufacturers have abandoned to the Japanese, industry analysts said today.

title: Caterpillar Layoffs
description: Caterpillar Inc. said it would lay off 850 hourly employees at three Illinois operations because of a 22-day-old strike at its Joliet parts plant.

title: Pennsylvania to Give Steelworkers Benefits
description: A state agency today ruled that the work stoppage at the USX Corporation's Pennsylvania mills was a lockout, not a strike, a legal distinction that entitles steelworkers idle since Aug. 1 in a contract dispute to collect unemployment benefits.

title: Stubborn Paint Finally Yields
description: Last May, admirers of the Brooklyn Bridge were startled to see a 10-foot swath of yellow paint besmirching the granite base of the Brooklyn tower.

title: 'Liars' Get Attention For Isuzu
description: JERRY DELLA FEMINA cannot stand most automobile commercials.

title: Private Plane Crashes At Fort Dix, Killing 3
description: A propeller-driven, single-engine private airplane crashed yesterday afternoon on an artillery range at Fort Dix, N.J., killing the three people aboard, according to military authorities.

title: No Multiyear Contracts
description: Fearful they might get stuck with having to pay players who become involved with drugs, Ballard Smith, the president of the San Diego Padres, said that in the future the team would not offer multiyear contracts. The decision is in direct response to the ruling issued July 30 by Thomas Roberts, the arbitrator, who has since been dismissed.

title: Don't Call It That
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPUTER MICROFILM INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TRIPUCKA TRADED BY PISTONS FOR DANTLEY
description: Frank Layden, the Utah Jazz coach, has finally found a team to take the high-scoring Adrian Dantley off his hands. Layden traded Dantley, a player he has been feuding with for the last two seasons, to the Detroit Pistons, along with second-round draft choices in 1987 and 1990 for Kelly Tripucka and Kent Benson.

title: SWEEP OF DODGERS KEEPS METS HAPPY
description: Lee Mazzilli said he has not stopped smiling for the last two weeks. Kevin Mitchell left the ball park twice this week wearing Bermuda shorts. Bob Ojeda said he goes to sleep each night telling himself, ''This is awesome, absolutely awesome.'' And Manager Dave Johnson said his main job is to make sure nobody falls off the happiest ship in baseball.

title: JURY REPORTEDLY TOLD OF BID BY ZACCARO FOR CABLE LOBBY
description: A New York State official has told a Queens grand jury that John A. Zaccaro sought a large payment to help arrange approval of a cable television franchise by the Queens Borough President, Donald R. Manes, according to a lawyer familiar with the testimony.

title: Chief Steps Aside At Allied Van Lines
description: Sidney Epstein, 63 years old, is stepping aside as the president of Allied Van Lines, the nation's largest mover of household goods.

title: RED SOX BATTER INDIANS, 24-5
description: Tony Armas drove in six runs with two homers, including a grand slam in a 12-run sixth inning, and Spike Owen scored a record-tying six runs tonight as the Red Sox routed Cleveland, 24-5. It was the most runs ever scored against the Indians.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: NEWPORT'S fading hydrangea shrubs may have seen better days this summer, but the city's evening life is still in full bloom. More so, some say, than at any other time this season.

title: ANOTHER RECORD FOR BIG BOARD SHORT INTEREST
description: The following Big Board companies show large changes:

title: SAVORING CROTON'S PAST AND PRESENT
description: CROTON-ON-HUDSON has been discovered many times: by the English explorer Henry Hudson, who weighed anchor in its deep bay on his way up an uncharted river; by engineers looking for a dam site to hold a reservoir for New York City's drinking water; by artists, bohemians and radicals in the early years of this century; by movie makers; by commuters seeking a near-rustic environment.

title: Debt Issue Tied to S.&P. 500
description: The first issue in the American market of debt securities whose value is linked to the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was offered yesterday by Salomon Brothers, on behalf of its parent, Salomon Inc.

title: Stolen Tickets Replaced
description: The New York Film Festival got its tickets yesterday, a new batch to replace those stolen on Wednesday from a locked delivery van.

title: AOI COAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
LEISURE CONCEPTS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Regional Prices Jump 0.7%
description: In New York and northeastern New Jersey, prices rose a sharp seven-tenths of 1 percent in July for the second consecutive month, according to a report from the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics.

title: Bonds for Facilities In Suffolk County
description: A $130 million issue of New York State Dormitory Authority revenue bonds to finance judicial facilities for Suffolk County was offered yesterday through underwriters led by Lazard Freres & Company.

title: AUSTIN WARREN
description: Austin Warren, a professor of English, an author and a literary critic, died Wednesday in Providence, R.I., where he lived.

title: McNEIL TO FACE GIANTS
description: Finally, the 1986 edition of Freeman McNeil returns.

title: People
description: * Lewis S. Alpern has been appointed senior vice president at D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles.

title: REDUCED TAX VALUE ON VACATION HOMES
description: Vacation homes bought more for their value as tax shelters than as tranquil escapes would be less attractive investments under the proposed tax legislation.

title: LAM RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a tax credit of $10,000 for the quarter and $290,000 for the year. c-Net income d-Includes a tax credit of $198,000.

title: STAGE: DANNER, WEAVER AND WALKEN IN 'STREETCAR'
description: When Blythe Danner's Blanche DuBois steps off the streetcar named Desire, she is teetering on her high heels like a child dressed up in her mother's clothes. With that character detail, the actress captures what Tennessee Williams described as Blanche's ''uncertain manner.'' While never entirely forsaking that childlike image, Miss Danner gradually enriches her portrait until by the end of Nikos Psacharopoulos's revival of ''A Streetcar Named Desire'' she embodies the desperation (as well as the dignity) of Williams's ''tiger-moth.''

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a dispatch from Moundsville, W.Va., Tuesday on allegations of misconduct within the Hare Krishna movement misstated the plea of Thomas Dresher to a murder charge. Mr. Dresher has pleaded not guilty in the 1983 disappearance of Charles St. Dennis.

title: POWER FAILURE BRINGS JITTERS AT RITES FOR BENIGNO AQUINO
description: A vast power blackout on the anniversary of the assassination of Benigno S. Aquino Jr. sent a tremor of apprehension through Manila tonight.

title: Soviet Cyclist Wins Road Race
description: Dmitri Konyshev of Gorky, the youngest member of the Soviet team, won the Golden to Boulder Mountain Road Race today, spoiling Andy Hampsten's hopes for a hometown victory in the Coors International Bicycle Classic.

title: TANDYCRAFTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
The U.N. Today: Aug. 22, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Preparatory Commission for International Seabed Authority and Law of the Sea Tribunal - 10.30 A.M.

title: A Star-Studded Audience
description: There were two shows at Wednesday night's performance of ''Cuba and His Teddy Bear'' at the Public Theater.

title: 28 YEARS OF SAINT LAURENT
description: A mannequin in a black velvet dress with long sleeves and a gray satin sash tied under the bosom is the first thing viewers see as they enter the new Museum of Fashion here on the Rue de Rivoli adjoining the Museum of Decorative Arts. It is the opening exhibit in the retrospective show of the clothes of Yves Saint Laurent called ''28 Years of Creation,'' which will continue through Oct. 26.

title: Investors Will Buy Bath Iron Works
description: The Bath Iron Works Corporation, one of the nation's largest shipbuilders, said yesterday it would be acquired by a group of investors led by Gibbons, Green, van Amerongen Ltd., a New York investment banking firm. Terms were not disclosed.

title: NMR OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of $304,952.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: The Feelies, the Ritz, 119 East 11th Street (254-2800). How many ways can a guitar be strummed? If any band knows, it is the Feelies, who have been the New York area's best-loved underground rockers since the late 1970's. Feelies songs revolve around simple chord patterns strummed in intricate cross-rhythms - sometimes gentle and pastoral, more often working up to a frenzied drone that barely leaves room for the band's conversational singing, the perfect rock for seething introverts. In the past, the Feelies have been one of rock's more reclusive bands, disappearing for years at a stretch; with the release of their second album, ''The Good Earth,'' they are back on the club-and-concert circuit. The pop-rock band Lifeboat opens tonight at 11, with the Feelies appearing about 12:30 A.M.; tickets are $10.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL YANKEES VS. OAKLAND A'S, at Yankee Stadium, 7:30 P.M. (Television - Channel 11, 7:30; Radio - WABC 770, 7:30).

title: Actions Taken in G.N.P. Leak
description: The Commerce Department said today that one person had resigned, one was dismissed and three had received letters of reprimand as the result of an investigation into the leak of sensitive economic data last September.

title: POSTMASTERS SEEK GREATER AUTHORITY
description: More than anything else, the nation's postmasters say, the shootings at an Oklahoma post office underscore their longstanding complaints about bureaucratic obstacles to managing postal workers and dismissing the unfit.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Aug. 11 about the Bank of New York misstated its status historically. It is the oldest bank in the United States operating under its original name.

title: Picking Up the Tax Pieces
description: For New York State, the tax wars have just begun. Federal tax reformers have struggled to the brink of victory, but their success will create three messes for high-tax states like New York.

title: Freedom Fighters
description: To the Editor:

title: EFFORT TO DEPORT SCHOLAR BRINGS CALLS FOR CHANGE
description: When Federal authorities released Choichiro Yatani Wednesday, saying they would no longer seek to deport him as a Communist, that apparently ended the matter for the 40-year-old doctoral candidate and teacher.

title: CREATIVE CONSULTING CORP INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $50,000.

title: NICARAGUA ASKING ROLE IN 3D WORLD
description: Nicaragua is seeking to become the next leader of the group of countries professing nonalignment, but some diplomats in Managua said the group might instead make a choice that would cause less controversy.

title: DEL PAINT MANUFACTURING reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: FLORIDA FEARS THAT LAKE OKEECHOBEE IS DYING
description: Lake Okeechobee, giant linchpin of the water resource network of south Florida and the Everglades, is dying, and the state government is mobilizing to rescue the lake and prevent what some experts fear could be an environmental disaster.

title: SOVIET TO WIDEN COMMERCIAL ROLE OUTSIDE ITS BLOC
description: The Soviet Union announced economic initiatives today that signaled a new willingness to become actively involved in the commerce and politics of Western business.

title: A Law Not Designed to Protect Our Wetlands
description: To the Editor:

title: AFTER WEEK OF CONFLICTING VIEWS, FRANCE RESTATES STAND ON P.L.O.
description: France's Foreign Minister says his Government believes that the Palestine Liberation Organization should be associated with any peace settlement in the Middle East.

title: A FATHER'S MEMORIAL IS HIS OWN MESSAGES OF LOVE
description: When his two young sons were growing up, Patrick Connolly suffered from a conflict that many parents face. He worked long hours, left for the office before his children woke up and sometimes got home after they had gone to bed.

title: An Israeli's Beirut Past and Washington Future; Two Standards
description: To the Editor:

title: AEQUITRON MEDICAL reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Letter: On Utility Regulators; Maine's Man for New York's P.S.C.
description: To the Editor:

title: REPORT ON LAP BELTS CRITICIZED
description: Two safety organizations have sharply criticized a recent report that suggested that back-seat passengers may be safer in some car accidents when they are not wearing a lap safety belt.

title: Owens-Corning Board Rejects Bid by Wickes
description: The board of the Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation rejected today a tender offer of $74 a share, or more than $2 billion, from the Wickes Companies.

title: U.S. WEIGHS SPECIAL DRUG SEARCHES FOR MEXICANS FROM JALISCO
description: The Reagan Administration is considering a plan to segregate residents of Jalisco State from other Mexicans crossing the border so they can be detained for rigorous searches for narcotics before being admitted to the United States, Administration officials said today.

title: Lee Enterprises
description: Lee Enterprises Inc., which publishes daily newspapers in 18 cities and owns six television stations, has agreed to buy two television stations and interests in two radio stations for $89 million from the May Broadcasting Company. Lee said it planned to buy KMTV of Omaha and KGUN-TV of Tucson, Ariz., as well as May's interests in two Omaha radio stations, KFAB-AM and KGOR-FM. the invention was that it allowed the fuel assembly to be used as a ''radial blanket,'' reducing neutron leakage while allowing the fuel to be moved. Westinghouse builds nuclear power plants and supplies operating fuel for them.

title: TUTU ASSAILS A CRITIC WHO SAID HE FEIGNS VIRTUE
description: Bishop Desmond M. Tutu today bitterly attacked a white Cabinet Minister who has accused him of calling for economic sanctions against South Africa while enjoying an affluent way of life.

title: Loser in Alabama Runoff To Be Write-In Candidate
description: Attorney General Charlie Graddick told supporters today that he would run as a write-in candidate for Governor of Alabama if court appeals failed to give him another chance at the Democratic nomination.

title: Soviet Says Border With China Is Quiet
description: A Foreign Ministry spokesman insisted today that the Soviet-Chinese border was quiet and refused to comment on a Japanese newspaper report that Soviet border troops fatally shot a Chinese soldier last month.

title: ENERGY VENTURES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Manila Prelate Critical Of Aquino Government
description: Jaime Cardinal Sin, in his first criticism of the Government of President Corazon C. Aquino, said today that the gains of the revolution that ousted Ferdinand E. Marcos were ''little by little being lost.''

title: PHYSICIANS INSURANCE CO (OHIO) (O) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: ALTEX INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a $847,000 writedown of oil and gas properties.

title: A FATHER OF TURKISH REPUBLIC
description: Former President Celal Bayar , who in a long political career helped found the Turkish Republic and was later imprisoned under a death sentence, died in a hospital here today. He was 104 years old.

title: BROCK EXPLORATION CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes gains from the effect of an accounting change of $332,000 and $42,000 for the latest quarter and year- ago period, respectively.

title: IN STRUGGGLE FOR BABY M., FIERCE EMOTION AND KEY LEGAL ISSUES
description: When Mary Beth Whitehead agreed last year to bear a child for William and Elizabeth Stern, she also agreed to relinquish all rights to the baby as soon as it was born. But after the birth of the child, conceived after she was artificially insemininated with the sperm of Mr. Stern, Mrs. Whitehead decided she was too emotionally attached to the infant to give it up. What she considered a private decision has sparked a fierce public debate.

description: b-Includes a tax credit of $52,000. c-Net loss The company said effective May 1, it began capitalizing certain software development costs in accordance with FASB Statement 86. title: The Importance of Significance
description: Col. Fletcher H. Griffis, who came into prominence in the battle over striped bass and Westway, is now Professor Griffis, although he still answers his telephone, ''Colonel Griffis.''

title: PHH GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The company said year-ago first quarter results were restated to reflect pooling of interests for acquisitions.

title: IN ONE RURAL TOWN, GAS LINE PLAN IS TRULY A CAUSE CELEBRE
description: In the crackerbox gymnasium of an old, country school here last week, townspeople gathered to hear power company plans for a natural gas pipeline that would slice through this hilly, rural town.

description: b-Net income

title: KILLER IN $25 ROBBERY IS EXECUTED
description: A man convicted of murdering a convenience store clerk in a robbery that netted $25 was executed Friday.

title: English Police Officer Cleared of Accusation
description: A senior Manchester police officer, assigned to investigate police actions in Northern Ireland, was cleared today of accusations of misconduct. A police panel ordered his immediate reinstatement.

title: LASER PHOTONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Inkster Leads
description: Juli Inkster had three consecutive birdies in a late charge today in shooting a four-under-par 67 for a two-shot lead after one round of the $225,000 Atlantic City L.P.G.A. Classic at Seaview Country Club. Jane Geddes, Ayako Okamoto, Judi Dickinson, Penny Pulz and Deb Richard were tied for second place at 69. Mrs. Inkster sank a four-foot birdie on the sixth hole, a 5-iron chip on the seventh and a one-foot birdie on the eighth.

title: McENROE DEFEATS ANNACONE BY 6-3, 6-2
description: The ''old'' John McEnroe produced a vintage performance tonight, hours after the new, yet somewhat rusted version barely survived a match in the $150,000 Norstar Bank Hamlet Challenge Cup.

title: Misericordia
description: First it was Hughie huddled on my doorstep. ''Alms,'' he cried.

title: U.S. Raid on Business Of Ohio Cannon Maker
description: Federal agents were examining a live shell and other items confiscated from a business owned by an Ohio man accused of transporting a makeshift 30-millimeter cannon to a gasoline station in Virginia, where it set off an explosion, officials said today.

title: TV AIDES REPORTEDLY MET MANES WITH ZACCARO'S HELP
description: In 1981, John A. Zaccaro introduced executives of a cable television company to the Queens Borough President, Donald R. Manes, before asking for a million-dollar payment to help the company gain a franchise in the borough, according to lawyers familiar with a grand jury investigation of the matter.

title: A BETTER WAY TO HELP THE GHETTO
description: The debate over minority business set-asides -the $6.2 billion program that reserves federal contract dollars for minority-owned companies - is often surrounded by lofty language, much of it self-serving. Most conservative critics want to abolish the set-asides, saying that they traduce the value of free and open competition. Liberals regard them as symbolic of America's commitment to minority enterprise and want to keep them.

title: PIRATES' 16 RUNS FLATTEN THE BRAVES
description: Sid Bream went 5 for 5 and drove in five runs tonight as Pittsburgh rapped out 19 hits in their biggest offensive showing in three years and defeated the Atlanta Braves, 16-5.

title: First Oklahoma Liability
description: The First Oklahoma Bancorporation, the holding company of the failed First National Bank and Trust Company of Oklahoma City, said today that at the end of the second quarter its liabilities exceeded assets by $30.2 million.

title: PAN AM TO PAY $1.95 MILLION FOR VIOLATIONS
description: Pan American World Airways has agreed to pay $1.95 million for violations of Federal regulations on aircraft safety maintenance, the Federal Aviation Administration announced today.

title: U.S. to Weigh Boeing Case
description: The Air Force will consider Federal conflict-of-interest charges against the Boeing Company and five former executives on Monday, military officials said today.

description: b-Includes tax credits of $306,000 and $663,400 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes tax credits of $188,100 for the quarter and $238,000 for the 6 months.

description: * Asea A.B., Stockholm, said its traction unit had received an order worth about $218 million for 20 high-speed trains from the Swedish state railways.
