title: Montana Rail Line Reopens
description: Railroad traffic has been restored since the derailment Wednesday night of a 44-car freight train here that resulted in a chemical explosion. Officials of Burlington Northern said, however, that the railroad's main line might not be fully repaired until the weekend. About 250 people were evacuated after one rail car containing ether and acetic acid caught fire and exploded.

title: Teacher and Student Qualify For World Title Competition
description: Five years ago a Long Island expert taught a friend's 16-year-old daughter to play bridge. In June the teacher and student, John Sheehan of Hempstead, L.I., and Dori Cohen of Oceanside, L.I., scored 74 percent in the Epson World Simultaneous Pairs.

title: SYSTEMS ASSOCIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
UNDER PRESSURE, FRIEDMAN QUITS ECONOMIC PANEL
description: Under a direct threat from Mayor Koch, Stanley M. Friedman, the Bronx Democratic leader, announced yesterday that he had resigned as chairman of the Bronx Overall Economic Development Corporation.

title: F.C.C. Will Deny Station Its License
description: The Federal Communications Commission announced today that a small radio station in Fredonia, N.Y., was denied renewal of its license after an administrative law judge determined that, among other violations, the station's owner had discriminated against blacks.

title: FLORIDA IS SPENDING MILLIONS TO UNDO U.S. RIVER PROJECT
description: A midmorning haze hangs over the flat waterway. A fish jumps and hits the surface with a splat. Insects drone in the heat. A brown and white bull, wading near a muddy bank, chews on a mouthful of weeds.

The accounting required by FASB 86 is prospective; therefore, the earnings in prior periods have not been restated.

title: GOODEN GETS 5-3 VICTORY
description: The temperature had dropped into the 50's by midafternoon. The wind was up and this was to be another of those nights when Candlestick Park would be embraced by the cold and the fog. It has been said before by a thousand baseball players: This is no place to play the game.

title: DOUBLEDAY IS BELIEVED UNLIKELY TO SELL METS
description: Doubleday & Company appears unlikely to sell the Mets, but has received ''expressions of interest from several companies wishing to acquire some or all of its assets,'' the company's investment banker, Dillon, Read & Company, said yesterday.

title: MORGAN KEEGAN & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Freedom, as Seen From Poland
description: The Polish historian Adam Michnik has emerged from prison to express ideas that transcend his problems with the Polish regime that kept him behind bars for 6 of his 39 years. His country's upheavals have taught him and a generation of Polish revolutionary intellectuals that liberty is more important than whichever ideology would justify withholding it.

title: STEELERS BEAT COWBOYS
description: Brian Hinkle returned a blocked field goal 65 yards for a touchdown and Rick Woods scored on a 22-yard interception return as the Pittsburgh Steelers defeated the Dallas Cowboys tonight, 41-28, in a National Football League preseason game.

title: THE LITTLE CABBY IS HURTING
description: Chances are that the next battered yellow cab you ride in will rattle while it rolls. Most likely it will be a fleet cab. Fleet cabs, as differentiated from taxis operated by owner-drivers, comprise 18 percent of the taxi force and are recognizable by their dilapidated appearance, because they are constantly in use and are leased by drivers obsessed with making time.

title: OFFICIALS STAGE DRUG BLOCKADE OF CITY HARBOR
description: An armada of Coast Guard vessels staged a ''blockade'' of New York Harbor Thursday night and yesterday, and teams of heavily armed guardsmen boarded dozens of pleasure boats and commercial vessels in search of drug smugglers.

title: DICKEY-JOHN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $147,000 for both the quarter and year. The company said the latest year operating earnings include earnings of $487,000 from the sale of distribution rights of certain products.

title: Melting Pot in a Cool Pool
description: Carlos Lloreda has been swimming this summer, back and forth and back and forth across the John Jay Pool - 51 miles in all, and more laps than anyone else, according to a little green chart kept by the City Parks and Recreation Department.

title: CONCERT: KID CREOLE AT PEIR 84
description: Long delays in setting up and the threat of rain couldn't prevent Wednesday's double bill at Pier 84 -with Kid Creole and the Coconuts and the Neville Brothers - from turning into one of the year's finest dance parties. Although an hour's delay in starting and another hourlong hiatus between sets made the concert a four-and-a-half-hour marathon, both bands showed how polymorphous funk can be.

title: Pepper Prices Advance
description: A shortage of white pepper supplies from main producers is putting spice into prices, which have jumped sharply this week, brokers said. Malaysian and Indonesian pepper have both shown strong gains, with Sarawak White for shipment in October and November trading today at around $6,100 a metric ton, up $800 from Monday's level, they said.

title: Renault Closing A Mexico Plant
description: Renault, the French state-owned car group, has decided to close its car assembly plant at Ciudad Sahagun in northern Mexico, because of losses.

title: Sigmund Menkes, 91; An Expressionist Artist
description: Sigmund Menkes, a New York painter whose work is represented in the collections of major art institutions here and abroad, died of a heart attack on Wednesday at his home in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. He was 91 years old.

title: RASMUSSEN HAS 4-HITTER
description: Dennis Rasmussen did not pitch like an expectant father last night. He called his wife early in the afternoon, went to Yankee Stadium and offered an efficient peformance: a four-hitter through eight innings, a 3-2 decision over the Oakland A's and his first victory in a month.

title: Israelis Say Cameroon Plans To Resume Ties Next Week
description: A resumption of diplomatic relations between Cameroon and Israel will be announced next week when Prime Minister Shimon Peres visits the West African republic, officials in Jerusalem said today.

title: 'CREEPS,' HORROR TALE
description: The newspaper advertisement for ''Night of The Creeps,'' which opened yesterday at the Loews Astor and other theaters, promised, rather optimistically, that the first 100 people to appear at the theater would be given free masks - presumably to shield their eyes from the terrifying spectacle on the big screen. Indeed, white masks that looked like the gauze shields doctors wear over their mouths were given out to the dozen or so people who turned out at the opening performance, though no one succumbed to the temptation to put one on.

title: Bar to Lilco Bid By Suffolk Upheld
description: A state appeals court yesterday upheld a ruling that prevents Suffolk County from trying to take over the Long Island Lighting Company.

title: GIANTS SEE JETS AS WARM-UP
description: The Giants and the Jets will meet Saturday night in their annual pro football version of a subway World Series. The sellout crowd of 76,000 at Giants Stadium may become excited, but to Coach Bill Parcells of the Giants it is just another opportunity to get ready for the season opener in two weeks.

title: HOMELESS TO BE DENIED OVERNIGHT STAYS AT OFFICES
description: Homeless families who refuse offers to stay at the city's shelters will no longer be allowed to spend the night at emergency assistance offices, the acting City Human Resources administrator said yesterday.

title: STANDEX INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

PLAYERS;
PITCHERS ACQUIRE SOPHISTICATED EDGE
description: When Philip Olson, playing for Sarasota, Fla., pitched a 5-0 no-hit victory over a team from Brunswick, Md., in the Little League World Series Wednesday, his teammates poured onto the field to congratulate him with high-fives, back-patting, hugs and hair-tousling. Olson's no-hitter was only the 10th in 40 years of Little League World Series play.

title: BENEFICIAL PLANS TO SEND STOCK UP
description: The Beneficial Corporation's stock soared yesterday following the company's indication that it was considering putting itself up for sale.

title: Jim Brown Arrested
description: Jim Brown, the Pro Football Hall of Fame running back, was arrested in Los Angeles again early yesterday, this time for investigation of spousal battery, a felony. Brown, 50 years old, who last played football for the Cleveland Browns in 1965 and then began a movie career, was released on $5,000 bail three hours after his arrest at 5:15 A.M. in an incident involving Debra Clark, his 22-year-old fiancee.

EX-KEY INVESTIGATOR OF WELFARE SYSTEM
description: George F. Berlinger, a New York businessman and philanthropist who was the State Welfare Inspector General from 1971 to 1974, died of complications arising from Alzheimer's disease yesterday at his home in Purchase, N.Y. He was 78 years old and also lived in Manhattan.

description: Ever since Ronald Reagan entered the White House, conservatives have dominated the Republican Party's political agenda, creating problems for its once-thriving liberal wing.

McCaskey Surgery
description: Edward McCaskey, the Chicago Bears owner, underwent open heart surgery yesterday, less than a week after suffering a heart attack, according to hospital officials. He was listed in stable condition at Rush Presbyterian St. Luke's Medical Center in Chicago, where he was transferred yesterday afternoon from Holy Family Hospital in suburban Des Plaines, said Phyllis Ferguson, a St. Luke's spokesman. She said that the operation was successful, and the ''propects for long-term recovery are good.''

title: Battle of Survival For Marginal Jets
description: Forget bragging rights. For many of the Jets, their meeting with the Giants Saturday night means trying to hang onto a job.

title: Buyback Terms Given By Anderson, Clayton
description: Anderson, Clayton & Company today announced the terms of its previously announced offer for its own stock, disclosing that it would buy back up to 8 million shares for $60 each. The company has 12.2 million shares outstanding.

title: SMALL BUSINESS, SMALL CLOUT
description: Small businesses are fighting to be heard by government, but based on the results of a five-day conference here this week it is an uphill battle.

title: A Do Ado
description: Robin Weir, Nancy Reagan's No. 2 hairstylist, will celebrate his annual 30th birthday in Washington tomorrow, attended by such celebrities as Katherine Davalos Ortega, the woman who signs everybody's money as Treasurer of the United States; Senators Paula Hawkins of Florida, Chic Hecht of Nevada and Larry Pressler of South Dakota, and Mayor Marion S. Barry and his wife, Effie. They and 50 or 60 others will join Mr. Weir at a pool party and then attend a performance by another Weir client, Joan Rivers, who introduced the hairstylist to some of his better-known Washington patrons.

title: Wheeling Steel Moving Offices
description: The Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation, wooed by tax incentives, will move its headquarters from Pittsburgh to Wheeling, the steelmaker's chief executive said.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for belwether issues.

title: THE SCREEN: 'CHAINSAW 2,' A SEQUEL
description: To leap into the teeth of the matter, whatever claim ''The Texas Chainsaw Massacre'' may have had to be a cut above the general run of slicers and dicers, its sequel, ''The Texas Chainsaw Massacre, Part 2,'' which opens today at the UA Twin and other theaters, is not first-grade chopped steak.

title: New York Convention Bureau Picks Chairman's Successor
description: Allan R. Johnson, the former chief executive officer of Saks Fifth Avenue, has been elected chairman of the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau, replacing Preston Robert Tisch, the new Postmaster General of the United States, the bureau announced yesterday.

title: Sun Distributors
description: The Sun Company said it had agreed to sell its Sun Distributors Inc. industrial distribution unit to The American Express Company's Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. unit.

title: 18 CHARGED AS $70 MILLION IN HEROIN IS SEIZED
description: A drug-enforcement task force yesterday made the largest seizure of heroin in New York in a decade, confiscating an estimated 70 pounds with a street value of $70 million, officials said.

A Way to Add Color To Motion Picture Film
description: A method of adding color to black and white motion picture film with the help of a computer is described in patent No. 4,606,625, granted this week to David M. Geshwind, a computer graphics consultant in New York.

description: ''I know black suffering from the inside. I don't want it for my people or any other people.''

description: President Reagan ordered a series of measures today designed to tighten the United States trade embargo of Cuba.

description: CENTRAL PARK

description: Stock prices rose moderately yesterday in slow pre-weekend trading.

description: California and New York financial institutions reached an agreement this afternoon that would permit New York banks to enter California's huge consumer market beginning in 1991.

title: PENTAGON HAILS NEW TEST OF ANTISATELLITE WEAPON
description: The Air Force successfully tested its antisatellite weapon today, the Pentagon announced.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Robbie Bosco, the former Brigham Young star quarterback who has been suffering from a sore shoulder, was placed on the injured-reserve list yesterday by the Green Bay Packers. . . . Sidney Green, a power forward for the Chicago Bulls, was traded to the Detroit Pistons for Earl Cureton, also a power forward. . . . Harmon Wages, the former pro football player and sports broadcaster, was hired as sports director of WTLV in his home city of Jacksonville, Fla. The hiring marked a return to broadcasting by Wages, who was convicted last November on misdemeanor cocaine charges and served three months in prison in Atlanta.

title: Transit Officer Guilty In Killing
description: A jury today convicted John Bruetsch, a New York City Transit Authority police officer, of murdering his wife, a New York City police officer, at her brother's home in Piermont, N.Y.

title: HONDURAS REJECTS U.S. PLAN FOR G.I.'S TO TRAIN CONTRAS
description: The Government said today that it would not allow the United States to use Honduran territory for training rebels fighting the Sandinista Government in neighboring Nicaragua.

title: Rebalancing the Divorce Scale
description: A funny thing happens to many women when their marriages end. Often, within the first year of divorce, their standard of living is apt to drop. That of their former husbands is apt to rise. To relieve such inequity, Governor Cuomo recently signed several amendments to New York's divorce law. To correct such inequity, several more are needed.

description: The Vatican is not considering any further action against the Rev. Charles E. Curran, officials there said today.

title: Mount Vernon Rodeo
description: They will be roping calves, wrestling steers and riding bulls at the Black World Championship Rodeo today at the Memorial Stadium, Garden Avenue and Sandford Boulevard in Mount Vernon, N.Y. Riders from Texas will be joining those from the metropolitan area for the event, sponsored by the Westchester Community Opportunity Program Inc. Shows are at 2 and 7:30 P.M. Admission is $10 ($8 for children). Tickets: 947-5850 or (914) 681-0365.

title: CABARET: LITTLE MILTON, CHICAGO BLUES
description: Chicago blues - tinctured with soul and jazz - came to Sounds of Brazil on Thursday night in the person of the singer-guitarist Little Milton. Milton Campbell was born in Mississippi in 1934 and started recording in Memphis; his singing, and especially his guitar playing, are reminiscent of B. B. King, who had a similar trajectory.

title: British Paper In Change
description: Eddie Shah, who led the revolution of Britain's newspaper industry with the first high-technology color national daily, has relinquished control of his troubled tabloid to its financial rescuers, sources at his newspaper said today.

description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $277,000 for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: HAMMOND BIRDIES FINAL HOLE TO LEAD
description: Donnie Hammond birdied the final hole today when he dropped a 15-footer to take a one-shot lead after two rounds of the 25th annual NEC World Series of Golf.

title: PRESENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
description: b-Net income

title: U.S BACKING MAN ON DISCRIMINATION
description: The Reagan Administration is urging the Supreme Court to strike down the first affirmative action preference for women that the Court has ever agreed to review.

title: American Medical In Restructuring
description: In a move reflecting the troubles plaguing the for-profit hospital chains, American Medical International said today that it would restructure its operations, eliminating its health insurance operations and focusing on its core business of running acute-care hospitals.

title: PIEDMONT NATURAL GAS CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Ohio State Dismissals
description: Two Ohio State football players have been dismissed from the team and another suspended for one game for what the coach, Earle Bruce, described only as violations of team regulations.

title: On Money as a Cure for Poverty
description: Instead of food stamps or housing vouchers or medical subsidies, why not give poor people what they most lack: cash?

title: RAPID TURNOVER FOR KOCH'S AIDES REFLECTS BOTH DESIGN AND DURESS
description: Only eight months into Mayor Koch's third term, his administration, through a combination of design, accident and duress, has undergone a staff overhaul so extensive that even the Mayor did not envision it when he jocularly promised to start the term with ''zero-based'' commissioners.

title: SAFECARD SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Drug Tests Ordered in Jersey
description: Mayor Frank Graves has ordered the 30 top officials in his administration to undergo urine tests for illegal drugs by Sept. 30, and he vowed to dismiss anyone found to be using drugs. Mr. Graves said the Police and Fire Chiefs would be among those tested, but he said there would be ''no wholesale testing'' of the city's 1,300 municipal employees. Mr. Graves who is also a state Senator, said he would take the test, and he suggested that City Council members also agree to be tested.

title: CARIER GOT GUNS AS GUARD MEMBER
description: The two pistols with which Patrick Henry Sherrill killed 14 co-workers and himself at the Edmond Post Office on Wednesday had been issued by the Oklahoma National Guard for him to use in a target competition, the authorities said today.

title: Salute to Puerto Rico By Bronx Arts Group
description: Stephen Somary will conduct the Bronx Arts Ensemble in ''A Salute to Puerto Rico'' twice tomorrow afternoon.

title: BARRETT RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 46. 1. This species of fish is an increasingly popular and lucrative catch for Long Island fisherman because of the soaring demand for sushi and sashimi in Japan, the United States and Europe. What kind of fish is it? 2. Using antiaircraft missiles, rebels downed a civilian airliner with 60 people aboard, the latest event in a chronic civil war that has pitted north against south in Africa's largest nation. Identify the nation and the warring factions. 3. After 15 years, the final curtain has unobtrusively dropped on the biggest, most publicized and most protracted legal wrangle in art history, a case that provided a loose basis for the current movie ''Legal Eagles.'' Identify the artist whose estate was at issue. 4. The tax savings that New Yorkers may realize under the legislation drafted by Congressional negotiators are about one-third less than they would have been if the negotiators had not made a last-minute decision. What decision was it? 5. ''The theologian has to play the role of the loyal opposition,'' said the Rev. Charles E. Curran, as he made an announcement. Who is he and what did he say? 6. In comments to a Mexican newspaper, President Reagan gave his bluntest statement yet about the ultimate aim of his Administration's policy in backing the Nicaraguan rebels. What did he say it was and how does that differ from his previous statements? 7.

title: Transamerica Air Operations Halt
description: Transamerica Airlines, a unit of the Transamerica Corporation, said today that it would discontinue all flight operations effective Sept. 30.

title: INTERNATIONAL TROT IS KIND TO DANCER
description: Stanley Dancer is hoping his past form holds in the $250,000 International Trot tonight at Roosevelt Raceway.

title: Jager Wins Gold As Biondi Gets 3d
description: Matt Biondi, the world's fastest swimmer, managed only third place today in the first 50 meters freestyle final ever held at the world championships, but another American, Tom Jager, took the gold.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL YANKEES VS. OAKLAND A'S, at Yankee Stadium, 7:30 P.M. (Television - Channel 11, 7:30; Radio - WABC 770, 7:30). METS VS. GIANTS, at San Francisco, 4P.M. (Television - Channel 9, 4 P.M.; Radio - WHN 1050, 4 P.M.). ORIOLES VS. CALIFORNIA ANGELS, at Baltimore, 2:15 P.M. (Television - Channel 4, 2 P.M.). ATLANTA BRAVES VS. PIRATES, at Pittsburgh, 7:05 P.M. (Television -WTBS, 7:05 P.M.) DODGERS VS. MONTREAL EXPOS, at Los Angeles (Radio - WCBS 880, 10:20P.M.).

title: Wife of Moderate Zulu Leader Is Killed is an Attack at Home
description: The wife of a moderate Zulu leader was killed tonight and two children were seriously wounded when attackers threw a grenade into their house and sprayed the building with automatic rifle fire, the Government said.

title: Bank Shift In Argentina
description: The president of Argentina's central bank, Alfredo Concepcion, resigned today amid infighting over how to deal with a resurgence of inflation.

title:
Patents;
Avoiding Leakage Of Nuclear Fuel
description: A fuel assembly for nuclear reactors, patented this week by the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, is designed to arrange uranium rods in a way that increases efficiency and avoids leakage.

title: CRASHES PROMPT SAFETY MEASURES BY CONNECTICUT
description: Responding to a recent rash of traffic accidents involving tractor-trailer trucks, Gov. William A. O'Neill today ordered a stepped-up safety enforcement effort on Connecticut highways.

title: UNITRODE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
description: b-Includes pretax gains from a fire insurance settlement of $500,000 and $895,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: ATE ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss and includes losses from discontinued operations of $112,000 for the quarter and $286,000 for the 6 months.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in New York Day by Day yesterday misidentified the theater where ''Cuba and His Teddy Bear'' is playing. It is the Longacre Theater.

title: U.S. and Soviet Agree On Nuclear Safety Pact
description: The United States and the Soviet Union signed a nuclear safety and research protocol today, permitting reciprocal on-site inspections of selected atomic research stations.

title: AFTER THE CABBAGE PATCH KIDS
description: The new Manhattan showroom of Coleco Industries is a world of fantasy-like settings and cheery background music, populated by those fabulously successful Cabbage Patch Kids and such recent arrivals as toy Rambo figures and Wrinkles puppies.

title: CAIRO SEEMS TO LOSE A CHANCE TO PROSPER IN A TIME OF PEACE
description: Egypt has frittered away the chance for basic economic and social change that peace with Israel brought, experts on the Middle East agree, and the country seems to be in more desperate shape today than before it signed the treaty in 1979.

title: SYNERCOM TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $59,000 and $818,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net income d-Includes tax credits of $172,000 and $373,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The company said its effective tax rate was revised during the latest quarter to reflect a reduction in anticipated investment tax credits during the last half of the year.

title: Girl Returns Home To Parents She Turned In
description: The girl who turned in her parents to the police on drug charges was released from a county shelter and allowed to go home to the mother and father she missed ''desperately,'' the family's lawyer said today.

title: PRIME MOTOR INNS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Term Often Invoked by Opposition Leader Stirs Emotion, Memories, Fear and Debate
description: It is emblazoned on Benazir Bhutto's manifesto, and she invokes it repeatedly in speeches. Yet throughout Pakistan there are people for whom the word inspires bitter memories and fear.

title: Garn Undergoes Tests To Help Daughter
description: Senator Jake Garn underwent tests today to determine whether he is a suitable candidate to donate a kidney to his diabetic daughter.

title: TWO TRUE HOPEFULS IN THE HOPEFUL
description: Racing's 24-day summer camp known as Saratoga ends Monday. When the campers gather round their winter fires of losing mutuel tickets to recall this summer, the memories will be mostly bitter: Remember the stewards who disqualified the wrong horse, the thunderstorms that pelted the track for a week, the walkout by the part-time mutuel clerks, the Travers traffic jam, and Ogygian staying in the barn for the month?

title: HOT ON THE TRAIL OF THE FISH COOKED MEDIUM RARE
description: It began, no doubt, with nouvelle cuisine. Chefs were running pieces of fish past the flame, serving them almost raw. If they had been beef, they would have been described as blood red.

title: MODERN CONTROLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

Patents;
Gold-Coated Implant For Arthritis Therapy
description: A gold-coated carbon implant, to be inserted in a joint for the treatment of arthritis, was patented this week by a Brooklyn chemist and is being evaluated by a Manhattan hospital. Ezekiel J. Jacob, the inventor, granted exclusive rights for one year under patent No. 4,606,354 to the Hospital for Joint Diseases-North General.

title: TV: 'PRISONER' SERIES, COMPLETE, ON CHANNEL 31
description: We should be skeptical when we hear the word ''classic.'' It no longer has a precise meaning. Nonetheless, there is a generally agreed-upon meaning: something that is excellent and endures. In this sense, ''The Prisoner'' is a television classic - a series intelligently, even brilliantly, made. Channel 31 is presenting ''The Prisoner'' this weekend in its entire 17 hours.

title: ORDERS FOR DURABLES UP 4.3% IN JULY
description: Orders to factories for ''big ticket'' durable goods jumped 4.3 percent in July, for the biggest one-month gain since 1984, the Government said today. But analysts said the news was not as promising as it might seem.

title: HEICO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
NORFOLK IS ENDING $1.9 BILLION OFFER TO U.S. ON CONRAIL
description: The Norfolk Southern Corporation said today that it was withdrawing its $1.9 billion bid to buy Conrail, the big Northeast freight line in which the Government has an 85 percent stake.

title: SUSPENSION TALK IRKS MORRIS
description: Joe Morris, the running back who left the Giants' training camp 17 days ago in a contract dispute, contended today that he was not under contract. His agent more or less said Morris was under contract. The Giants insisted he was and reiterated that they would not negotiate with him until he returned to camp.

title: MOLEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NEW MUSEUM IN VENICE OFFERS SHOW OF FUTURISTS
description: Pontus Hulten has made a career of being the stranger in town, and in this quintessentially insular city he is playing the role again with great discretion.

title: Vernon Young, 74, Freelancer For Film and Literary Reviews
description: Vernon Young, a freelance film and literary critic, died yesterday at Graduate Hospital in Philadelphia after a long illness. He was 74 years old and lived in Philadelphia.

title: FRONTIER THREAT REPORTED
description: Frontier Airlines, a subsidiary of People Express Inc., will file for bankruptcy protection on Monday, leaders of the pilots union said they were told by an attorney for People Express.

title: Woman Is Slain in Riverdale
description: A 68-year-old, wheelchair-bound woman, Edna Fumasoli, was stabbed to death yesterday after her unknown attacker apparently pushed his way into her apartment in the Riverdale section of the Bronx where she had lived for 28 years. She was found in her apartment at 3900 Greystone Avenue.

title:
Patents;
Sandwich Glass Panels For Huge Telescopes
description: Huge telescopes are expected to be producible from the honeycomb sandwich glass panels patented by an astronomer and a researcher at a University of Arizona laboratory in Tucson, Ariz.

title: ECI TELECOM LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: DIGITEXT INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Sports People; Pepitone Jury Selected
description: Eight jurors were selected yesterday in the trial of Joe Pepitone, the former Yankee first baseman. The four men and four women were selected in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn as the police searched for one of Pepitone's co-defendants who has been missing.

title: Long-Term Treasury Bonds Fall
description: Prices of long-term Treasury bonds fell and yields rose yesterday as more investors became concerned over the inflationary consequences of the Federal Reserve's moves to stimulate the economy.

title: Fed, in July, Eased Its Policy
description: Policymakers at the Federal Reserve decided at their July meeting to loosen credit conditions in an effort to stimulate the sluggish economy, according to minutes of the meeting released today.

title: MARQUEST MEDICAL PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
10TH GAME IS ADJOURNED
description: Gary Kasparov, the world chess champion, and Anatoly Karpov, the challenger, adjourned the 10th game of their championship match today.

title: 34 AIR CONTROLLERS IN WEST REASSIGNED AFTER DRUG ALLEGATIONS
description: Thirty-four air traffic controllers have been transferred to desk duty because of allegations of off-duty use of cocaine and hashish, the Federal Aviation Administration said today.

title: Georgia on Their Minds
description: Remember the report that the Democrats were considering announcing their 1988 convention site before the 1986 election so as to bolster their chances in one Senate contest? Well, it isn't going to happen.

title: VARO INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss and after a loss from discontinued operations of $342,000.

title:
Patents;
Extending Terms Past 17 Years
description: THE Patent and Trademark Office published proposals in its Official Gazette this week to formalize rules extending the terms of a some patents beyond the standard 17 years. If accepted, the rules will replace the informal guidelines based on a 1984 law.

title: SCHOLAR WILL TRY TO CLEAR NAME FROM VISA LIST
description: No longer facing the threat of deportation, the Japanese scholar Choichiro Yatani says he now intends to fight to clear his name of the State Department charge that he was a Communist.

title: 2 CITY LAWYERS HELD FOR 10 HOURS AFTER REFUSING JUDGE ON HEARING
description: Two city lawyers spent nearly 10 hours in an adult detention cell Thursday after a judge in Queens Family Court found them in contempt of court, a supervisor in the city's Law Department said yesterday.

title: Crime and Postage
description: The National Museum of American History is offering a program today chronicling the mostly unsung adventures of some of America's little-known public protectors, the postal inspectors. Included are oral histories, exhibits and video programs describing their efforts in tracking down hundreds of felons, including murderers, mail robbers, counterfeiters, swindlers and purveyors of obscene material.

title: An Israeli's Beirut Past and Washington Future
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, AUGUST 23, 1986
description: Companies

title: Rental Housing: A Sad Case
description: Rental housing in New York City, like agriculture in the Soviet Union, periodically generates a flurry of headlines, a rash of new initiatives and, ultimately, disappointing results. In each case, a major political figure ''discovers'' the problem, demands action and pledges fresh resources. In the Soviet case, at least, ''reforms'' and new incentives are usually promised. With both New York apartments and Soviet crops, time passes and the ''quick fix'' doesn't work. Finally, the public's attention is diverted elsewhere.

title: FOR THE ORACLE OF DELPHI, IS A FACTORY THE ANSWER?
description: In Delphi's golden age, when the ancients held it to be ''the navel of the world,'' those guilty of sacrilege in the sacred precincts of the Shrine of Apollo were thrown to their deaths from the easternmost of two mighty rocks that frame the sanctuary on the slopes of Mount Parnassus.

title: STATER BROTHERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
A Convention With Gentle Sounds
description: Lincoln Center was alive with a flock of flautists playing ''Amazing Grace.''

title: PIPE DEALERS DON'T EXPECT TO RESTOCK
description: One day after the police seized more than 1,500 glass pipes from his store in Greenwich Village, Ibrahim Hussein was looking for something new to sell.

title: JAPANESE SET SAIL TO VISIT ANCESTORS' GRAVES ON ISLES LOST TO RUSSIANS IN 1945
description: A group of Japanese, most of them elderly, have set sail from a northern port to make the first visits permitted in 11 years to ancestral graves on islands that Japan lost to the Soviet Union in 1945.

title: LIQUOR STORES ENTER THE CREDIT-CARD AGE
description: A credit card will buy just about anything these days: a ride in a taxi, a telephone call on an airplane, even (with a high enough credit limit) a car. One exception, at least until earlier this month in New York State, was wine and liquor sold in stores.

title: 2 Die in Demonstration Against Pakistan Chief
description: Security forces exchanged fire with demonstrators today, killing at least two people and raising the toll to 29 in over a week of protest against President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq.

title: SETTLEMENT OF SUIT IN LOS ANGELES MAY CLOUD FUTURE OF A LEGISLATOR
description: At a time when Los Angeles is struggling to meet Justice Department demands that it increase the Hispanic representation on the City Council, the city's only Hispanic Councilman has emerged at the center of charges that may cloud his political future.

title: JAMES RIVER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 27
description: The company said the sales and earnings for latest quarter reflect the acquisition of Crown Zellerbach Corp. on May 5, as well as the contribution to sales and earnings of Premoid Group, acquired by James River Corp. from Preco Corp. on Jan. 23, for the full quarter, and Canada Cup, acquired on May 12, and Handi-Kup, acquired on June 25.

title: FREUHAUF SETS BUYOUT BY MERRILL, MANAGERS
description: The noisy battle for the Fruehauf Corporation ended yesterday, with Asher B. Edelman dropping his bid for the truck trailer and auto parts manufacturer after two days of around-the-clock negotiations and Fruehauf agreeing to a $1.1 billion leveraged buyout deal.

title: BAYOU RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: CENTRAL HOLDING reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $147,000. The company said the latest quarter results include an after-tax gain of $800,000 from the sale of branch deposits.

title: THE SKEPTIC'S ERROR
description: President Reagan's Commission on Defense Management, created in the wake of the spare-parts scandals last year, recently finished its study with a series of tough proposals to improve the way the Defense Department is run. But, surprisingly, the commission found that things are not nearly as bad as they seem to the public. This finding reveals a problem as worrisome as the cost-overrun scandal itself.

title: More Car Bombs, This Time in Iran
description: Security is tight, but clearly not airtight, in Iran, a regimented Islamic state that has been at war with neighboring Iraq since 1980. Last weekend, some of the Iranian Government's enemies exploded a car bomb in the holy city of Qum, killing 13 people and wounding more than 100.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: THE Federal Superfund program to clean up hazardous- waste sites almost folded once again last weekend while Congress debated renewing the five-year program.

title: SCHOOLS UNDER PRESSURE ON LATER STARTING DATES
description: Like the thousands of children in South Carolina who are sorry to see their summer vacation end, Wim Pastoor also dreads the last Monday in August, when most of the schools in the state open for the fall.

title: Compassionate Coach
description: Two days after he suspended three players from the Ohio State football team for unspecified violations of team regulations, Coach Earle Bruce announced that the playing status of Greg Rogan, a 20-year-old junior cornerback, would not be affected by his arrest last Sunday on charges of speeding and drunken driving.

title: Indians Beat Red Sox, 5-4, to End Streak
description: Andre Thornton, a pinch-hitter, singled with the bases loaded in the ninth inning today as the Cleveland Indians ended a four-game losing streak by defeating the Boston Red Sox, 5-4. The victory was the first for the Indians over the Red Sox this season.

title: U.S. Turns Back Cuba In Volleyball Cup Final
description: The United States men's volleyball team crushed the Cuban squad, 15-8, 15-3, 15-7, to capture its second consecutive USA Cup title Friday night.

title: Q and A
description: Winter Golf

title: Bishop Tutu's Bitter Welcome
description: Bishop Desmond M. Tutu, a leading opponent of South Africa's white authorities, returned home to Johannesburg last week after a tour overseas. On arrival, the Bishop, winner of the 1984 Nobel Peace Prize, was castigated by conservative whites who accused him of treason.

title: Worker Shortage Is Bad Business
description: THE same sign with the same two words dot the front lawns and doors of thousands of businesses all over Long Island and much of the Northeast. The simple message: ''Help Wanted.''

title: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: A CERTAIN PEOPLE: American Jews and Their Lives Today, by Charles E. Silberman. (Summit, $8.95.) Charles E. Silberman's survey of American Jewish life and Jewish identity is ''both an objective and a personal work,'' Nathan Glazer wrote in The Book Review last year. ''The research is remarkably thorough,'' he said, ''and nothing he has found .c.c. shakes his optimism.'' Indeed, the tone is one of ''satisfaction or fulfillment.'' THE OLD GRINGO, by Carlos Fuentes. Translated by Margaret Sayers Peden and the author. (Perennial/ Harper & Row, $5.95.) ''Sensual and mind-pleasing'' is how Earl Shorris described Carlos Fuentes's novel in these pages in 1985. The tale is an imaginative conclusion to the life of Ambrose Bierce, the American writer who vanished in Mexico in 1914. The author, he said, ''takes the reader into the mythical, sexual, political, economic, moral maelstrom of inter-American relations.''

title: SOME IN HUDDLED MASSES MAY JUST BE CONSPIRING
description: OF the 200,000 Jews from the Soviet Union who have emigrated to the United States since the mid-1970's, about half have settled in the New York City area, predominantly in the Brighton Beach section of Brooklyn. There, in a middle-class neighborhood that the emigres have dubbed ''Little Odessa'' because it reminds them of the Crimean resort, what started as a small criminal element has been growing in numbers and power and becoming increasingly violent. Prosecutors in New York and Florida say they have uncovered ties between the immigrant gangsters and the long-established organized crime groups the Justice Department calls collectively the Mafia or La Cosa Nostra.

title: Banning Playboy In Braille Editions
description: THE literary merit of Playboy was weighed on the floor of the United States House of Representatives last year, and opponents, led by Chalmers P. Wylie, Republican of Ohio, found the magazine ''wanton.''

title: 9 Held Without Bail In Heroin-Ring Case
description: United States magistrates yesterday ordered nine accused narcotics traffickers held without bail pending further hearings this week. They were among 19 individuals seized Friday along with the largest cache of heroin confiscated in New York in a decade.

title: Pretoria Stock Sale Set For U. of Washington
description: The University of Washington's Board of Regents has voted to sell the university's holdings in companies doing business in South Africa because of that nation's policy of strict racial separation.

title: REDOING WOOD FLOORS: START WITH RIGHT FINISH
description: WHEN the time comes to refinish a hardwood floor, sanding the floor down to achieve a smooth, blemish-free surface is only the first step. The next step - selecting the actual finish - is in many ways just as important for the look you want, and if you want it to last.

title: ASBURY PARK BECOMES HOME TO A MUSEUM OF ROCK AND ROLL
description: THE Rock and Roll Museum here is only one room, but its 900 square feet burst with rock memorabilia that take fans on a 20-year tour of Jersey Shore music history.

title: Vivian Beth Levy to Wed Todd H. Reuben, C.P.A.
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Werner S. Levy of Forest Hills, Queens, of the engagement of their daughter, Vivian Beth Levy, to Todd Hayes Reuben, a son of Mr. and Mrs. S. Jesse Reuben of Potomac, Md.

title:
DANCE;
WEST AFRICAN ARTS COMING TO NEWARK
description: WHEN the International Afrikan-American Ballet crosses the Hudson River this week to dance in the streets here, the performers will bring history and culture, as well as entertainment, to an audience expected to number about 5,000.

title: Wetlands Law
description: To the Editor:

title: DUST TO DUST? NOT FOR MARCIA
description: THE LIMITS OF VISION By Robert Irwin. 120 pp. New York: Dedalus/Viking. $12.95.

title: Miss Anderson Wed to Lawyer
description: Maryellen Anderson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard E. Anderson of Littlestown, Pa., and William Gordon Prescott, a son of Mrs. William M. S. Prescott of Hanover, N.H., and the late Mr. Prescott, were married yesterday. The Rev. John McHugh, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Aquinas Chapel at Dartmouth College.

title: THOUGHTS AFTER THE UNTHINKABLE
description: STRANGER IN TWO WORLDS By Jean Harris. Illustrated. 388 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Company. $18.95.

title: LUTHERANS WEIGH PLAN FOR MERGER
description: When Martin Luther gave birth to Lutheranism out of discontent with the Roman Catholic Church of his day, he envisioned his new church as a harmonious one.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
HELPING THE HOMELESS
description: John Weiner loves books. He loves them so much, he gives them away. Tuesdays and Fridays, he sets up three tables in front of the Grace Episcopal Church on Church Street in White Plains, piles them high with books and lets passers-by have their choice. He asks nothing in return, but suggests that those who take books make a donation. The money goes to the Grace Church shelter for the homeless; since he began a month ago, he has taken in $1,500 in donations.

title: SOCCER AND FRIENDSHIP MARK CLUB'S TRIP TO ENGLAND
description: BOB CASSELLS found the girls in England more sophisticated than at home, while Matt Zimmerman said he thought that he and his teen-age teammates were treated more like adults there than they were in their Connecticut hometowns.

title: Don't Look for Morality In the Marketplace
description: To the Editor:

title: TOWN OFFERS TO SELL ITS DISPUTED LANDFILL
description: A STANDOFF between one of the more affluent towns in the state and one of its poorer rural cousins appears to have ended with the richer town backing down.

title: Stephen John Marconi Is Married to Joy P. Prizio
description: Joy Patricia Prizio, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony P. Prizio of Port Chester, N.Y., was married yesterday to Stephen John Marconi, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent J. Marconi of Canton, Conn. The Rev. Henry A. Boyle performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in Manhattan.

title: 4 DIE IN L.I. ROOMING HOUSE FIRE
description: A fire swept through a three-story rooming house in Massapequa, L.I., yesterday morning, killing four people and injuring seven others, including two firefighters, the authorities said.

title: Pamela Iris Bernstein Weds Michael A. Lynn
description: The marriage of Pamela Iris Bernstein, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert M. Bernstein of New York and Scarsdale, N.Y., to Michael Alexander Lynn took place last night at the Plaza Hotel in New York. The bridegroom is a son of Harold Lynn of New York and Southampton, L.I., and Suzanne Lynn of Floral Park, Queens.

title: CORRECTION
description: Part of remarks by Dr. Joseph J. Amato of Children's Hospital of New Jersey in Newark was dropped in an article last week about heart surgery.

title: Sexual Tolerance Hasn't Sent Sweden to Perdition
description: To the Editor:

title: HARD-HIT NORTHEAST FISHERMEN ASSAIL U.S. POLICY
description: Commercial fishermen in the Northeast say they are being hurt in a very lean year by a new Federal policy of seizing the entire catch of boats whose operators are suspected of breaking regulations.

title: Pravda Assails Prince As Preacher of Doom
description: The Communist Party daily Pravda today denounced the American rock star Prince and other singers who, it said, were teaching the younger generation to believe that nuclear war was inevitable.

title: SURPRISE AT THE HOMELESS AMONG US
description: MARK and Jean sleep on the porch behind the beauty shop. Don and Tina sleep behind some bushes nearby. Paul sleeps where he can. On rainy nights this summer the church porch can be crowded.

title: TAX CHANGES MAY TAKE THE ECONOMY ON A BUMPY ROAD
description: SOMETIME next month, at worst the month after that, barring some unforeseeable mishap, the House and Senate will pass, and President Reagan will sign, the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 - the product of a crisis-fraught, two-year, more-or-less bipartisan exercise in tax revision. In a tax-driven economy, the engine is about to be changed, with some consequences evident to everyone and many more that no one can foretell with confidence.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: THERE'S no getting around the fact that some people, voluntarily and not for business reasons, spend hours on the telephone every day, chitchatting with friends, pouring out woes, sharing triumphs. exchanging news and gossip. Some of these people have full-time paid careers, some, such as housewives and volunteer workers, have full-time unpaid careers, and some don't do anything more constructive than go to health clubs, eat spinach and endive salads, buy fine French furniture and spend money. The marathon talkers are not confined to any one group or sex.

title: LAP BELTS FOR SCHOOL BUSES ON LEGISLATIVE AGENDA
description: A LONG-RUNNING dispute over the value of seat belts in school buses could make its way to the floor of the Senate when the Legislature returns from its summer break next month.

title: Laura P. McPhee Becomes the Bride Of Stephen G. L. Murray in Princeton
description: Laura Pryde McPhee, a daughter of Pryde Brown and John McPhee, both of Princeton, N.J., was married there yesterday to Stephen Graeme Lawrence Murray, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Graeme Armstrong Murray of Wellington, New Zealand. The Rev. Patrick Connor performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Princeton University Chapel.

title: Louise Woods, 78, the Widow Of Former World Bank Chief
description: Louise Woods, widow of George D. Woods, the investment banker and former president of the World Bank, died yesterday in her Manhattan apartment after a long illness.

title: A WELL-DRESSED SOCIAL SET
description: Nowadays, the best place to find the young and best-dressed social set is almost anywhere. Maria-Flora Miller, a photography student, likes the rock-and-roll clubs where she dances in silk cocktail dresses. Mallory Harrington, a model, often dons Oscar de la Renta dresses and heads to benefits. And Kimberly Du Ross, an artist, has no patience for cocktail parties. She dines downtown on her evenings out, garbed in clothes that are basic, casual and monochromatic.

title: 2 French Soldiers Wounded in Lebanon
description: Two French soldiers with a peacekeeping unit were wounded by gunmen in southern Lebanon late Friday in the third incident involving United Nations forces this month, a United Nations spokesman said.

title: F. PALMER WEBER, 72, IS DEAD
description: Frederick Palmer Weber, a prominent labor and civil rights activist in the 1940's who later helped organize business people against the Vietnam War, died Friday. He was 72.

title: HOLIDAY BY BUS
description: There is a lot to be said for touring America by road instead of hopping about by air. If you have the time, bus travel can be an excellent way to find out what the country is like. With a driver responsible for transporting you safely, you are free to survey the passing scene, as I did recently on a 16-day tour in the East, South and Middle West.

title: JET'S DEFENSE SEEKS TO PUZZLE
description: Some years ago a New York coach was attempting to bring a historical perspective to his sport by quoting a well-known maxim.

title: Thomas Kent Jr. Weds Maude Wood
description: Maude Hunnewell Wood, a daughter of William P. Wood of West Grove, Pa., and Manchester, Mass., and the late Mia Atherton Wood, was married yesterday to Thomas D. Kent Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kent of Murray Hill, N.J., and Seabrook Island, S.C. The Rev. James Squire performed the Episcopal ceremony at the home of the bride's father and stepmother in Manchester.

title: Lowering the Pedestal Under Brooklyn's Beecher
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPARING BASICS IN TODAY'S VCR'S
description: Preview demonstrations of new video equipment are usually staged under a manufacturer's auspices, and only that manufacturer's own products are shown.

title: UPGRADING OF QUEENS PARK IS PLANNED
description: It is the city's second largest park, and the second most-visited. Its attractions range from sports stadiums to lakes and greenswards. Twice it housed World's Fairs.

title: Analysts Say New Tax Bill Still Favors Homeowners
description: THE new tax legislation now awaiting a final vote in Congress would have a sweeping, lasting effect on the residential housing market, but housing and tax specialists say it would not cause any sudden disruptions or affect the American preference to own a home rather than to rent one.

title: TWO ASSURED TALENTS
description: They have been called minimalist designers, even though they disown the label. It is too restrictive, contends Michael Kors -fashion is constantly changing. Simple, uncomplicated, even streamlined, more accurately describe his work, points out Zack Carr.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: NASSAU JOINS IN
description: IF the notion of making wine from grapes grown on Suffolk County farmland seemed far-fetched a little more than a decade ago, more unlikely still was the prospect of planting prime Nassau County Gold Coast real estate with grapevines.

title:
ART;
MAYAN THEMES IN STAMFORD SCULPTURE SHOW
description: ALTHOUGH it takes four men to lift one of her large pieces, the sculpture of Lila Katzen seems very light. This is due to its animation by lights playing across coiled and variously polished surfaces.

title: Cricket Hooper Weds in Quebec
description: Harriet Carrington Hooper, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Henry Hooper of Baltimore, was married yesterday to David Lee Jiranek, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo August Jiranek of Old Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Keith Perigore performed the Episcopal ceremony at the St. Barnabas Church in North Hatley, Quebec.

title: MUSEUM EXPLORES EVOLUTION OF FILM
description: ARISTOTLE, Edison and magic lanterns. Although seemingly unrelated, all played a part in the succession of ideas that led from the first crude attempts at projecting images to today's most sophisticated devices.

title: Going On in the Northeast
description: MAINE ANTIQUE CAR AUCTION

title:
ANTIQUES;
COLONIAL COUNTRY FAIR -- AND FREE
description: A COLONIAL Country Fair administered by the Department of the Interior's National Parks Service will be held Saturday and next Sunday from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. at the old Wick farm on Tempe Wick Road in Jockey Hollow. All activities are free.

title: BOSTON THEATER'S REPRIEVE GIVES HOPE TO THE ARTS
description: With its recent designation as a landmark, the Saxon Theater, a lush, Beaux Arts structure known as the Majestic for most of its 83 years, is assured of surviving the development frenzy that has gripped this city for the last decade. But to the arts community, the Saxon's victory is a small ray of light in an otherwise gloomy landscape.

title: GIFT TO PROTECT ROOSEVELT HOME IN HYDE PARK
description: A buffer of 86 wooded acres has been added to the Franklin D. Roosevelt National Historic Site here to help shield the area from commercial and residential development.

title: JOINT EFFORT OFFERED FOR VETERANS CLINIC
description: THE Veterans Administration is considering a joint venture for an outpatient clinic designed to serve veterans in eight South Jersey counties.

title:
STAGE VIEW;
'NICHOLAS NICKLEBY' SHOWS OFF DICKENS AS A LIVE ENTERTAINER
description: Charles Dickens had a recipe for the writing of novels: Make 'em laugh. Make 'em cry. Make 'em wait. It was not his own formulation - it was actually passed on to him by his friend, the mystery writer Wilkie Collins - but it served him well as a basis on which to erect his huge narrative structures.

title: MUSIC THEATER IN PHILADELPHIA
description: ''We have a mission to develop music theater as a distinctly American art form,'' Marjorie Samoff, founder and producing director of the American Music Theater Festival in Philadelphia, said recently. ''This is our third season, and already two productions born of the festival will be seen at Lincoln Center this fall. 'The Transposed Heads,' which will open our season in Philadelphia in September, is a co-production and will come to the Mitzi Newhouse Theater in New York the following month. And 'X,' an opera about the life of Malcolm X by Anthony Davis, which began in a workshop here in 1984, will come to the New York City Opera on Sept. 28. We're delighted that pieces begun here go on to have lives of their own.''

title: CUISINE OF INDIA, TROLLEYS IN HONOLULU
description: A Tasting Tour From Kashmir To Madras

title: WHY A NATIONAL GALLERY STIRS A COUNTRY'S DEEPEST PASSIONS
description: Just the other day, the directorship of the National Gallery in London was offered to a 43-year-old American, Edmund Pillsbury, who since 1980 has been director of the Kimbell Art Museum in Fort Worth.

title: STATE TO SELL BONDS FOR SWEEPING SUFFOLK COURT COMPLEX PLAN
description: THE State Dormitory Authority is preparing to sell bonds for a project that judges and lawyers in Suffolk County have sought for more than two decades - a new central court complex in western Suffolk that will largely consolidate the county's scattered and in some instances substandard court buildings.

title: NOW IT'S 'I LOVE DUTCHESS COUNTY'
description: NEARLY 10 years ago, a television commercial featured a cheerful fisherman vacationing along the Hudson River.

title: PAYSON PURCHASE EYED
description: A PROPOSED zoning change in the Town of North Hempstead is fueling rumors that the 100-acre Payson property - a section of the 500-acre Whitney estate in Manhasset - may be sold to become the new home of the North Shore Unitarian Universalist Church.

title: Three New Reasons to Fear Junk Bonds
description: EARLIER this summer, the Securities and Exchange Commission issued its first study ever of the market for high-risk bonds - so-called junk bonds. The study, which will strongly influence the Administration's policy toward junk bonds and, indirectly, toward the hostile takeovers that the bonds often finance, arrived at a startling conclusion: There is no cause for concern, even though junk bond issues have soared in recent years. Rather, the report concluded that junk bonds are an ''innovative reaction,'' with only such risks as were ''fully obvious'' to investors. There is no justification, it said, for limits to junk-bond financing in takeovers - or anywhere else, for that matter.

title: MUSEUM NURTURES BRONX AND ITS ART
description: He was a rugged-looking boy of 14 whose hands held a piece of his past and, with luck, his future: a watercolor seascape he had done from memory of a Santo Domingo beach a fantasy-world away from his life on 183d Street in the University Heights section of the Bronx.

title: Order in the Court
description: John Gotti, who is said by Federal prosecutors to be something like the chief executive officer of the Gambino organized crime family, went on trial last week on a variety of job-related charges. Mr. Gotti and six co-defendants were accused of racketeering acts including the murder of Paul Castellano, who used to be the Gambino family leader. Defense attorneys opened by questioning the fairness of the proceedings.

title:
CABLE TV NOTES;
REPLAYING THE 60'S MOTOWN SOUND
description: It would seem an alluring prospect for the vastness of a network audience: a six-part survey of some of the mainstays of Motown, the record label that, in the 1960's, produced Detroit's most transporting wares, after the automobile. The first hourlong chapter would provide an overview of the careers of the Temptations and the Four Tops; subsequent shows would do the same for Marvin Gaye, Smokey Robinson, Michael Jackson and the ''girl groups'' - Martha and the Vandellas, the Marvelettes and more. What, then, steered such a project to cable?

title: Marianna Murnane Is Wed
description: Marianna McDonnell Murnane, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Murnane Jr. of Locust Valley, L.I., was married at St. Dominic's Roman Catholic Church in Oyster Bay, L.I., yesterday to Herbert Ludlam Smith 4th, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Smith 3d of Mill Neck, L.I. The Rev. Stephen Babos performed the cermony.

title: NO END IN SIGHT FOR BASQUE TERRORISM
description: A recent surge in terrorism by the Basque separatist group E.T.A. has underlined how the 18-year-old group remains one of the most effective and elusive terrorist organizations in Europe and a thorn for Spain's young democracy.

title: Ghanaian Ex-Official Is Held for Questioning
description: A former Foreign Minister of Ghana has been arrested and is being held on unspecified charges for questioning in Accra, the capital, according to Ghana's Ambassador to the United States.

title: MORE EVIL THAT A 15-FOOT SPIDER
description: IT By Stephen King. 1,138 pp. New York: Viking. $22.95.

title: IMAGES OF EXPRESSIVE DANCING
description: As each dance year ends, one looks back and almost automatically summons up the most vital of the images that start out from the continual rise and fall of stage curtains. This year, the images that remain are chiefly of sudden windfalls of unusually expressive dancing with lessons to teach about performing and even about life. Out of the nothing of the unknown, to paraphrase Wallace Stevens, one has come on major weather.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: STARDUST: The David Bowie Story. By Henry Edwards and Tony Zanetta. (McGraw-Hill, $17.95.) David Bowie first attracted attention in the early 70's during a lull in pop music.

title: THE NEW EXEC
description: On the fifth morning of an important criminal trial in New York State Supreme Court, Justice Edwin Torres waved the lawyers up to the bench.

title: Advisers, Then and Now
description: True, Central America isn't Indochina, and Nicaragua isn't Vietnam. But old memories stir uneasily at the news that the Reagan Administration plans to send ''advisers'' to train Nicaraguan rebels.

title: POSTINGS: Rock Problem; U-Shaped Solution
description: For years, John H. Lese, a real-estate developer based in Rye, N.Y., walked past a large rock on a small plot of vacant land directly across the street from the Mamaroneck railroad station.

title: Employees of Sudan Airways Strike for Security Measures
description: Sudan Airways, the national carrier, suspended all its international and domestic flights today when employees went back on strike to press demands for security guarantees after rebels shot down a plane in southern Sudan last week.

title: The Anchors
description: I have watched all three of the network evening news programs (''The Anchors,'' by Alex S. Jones, July 27). Mr. Jones's article gave the reader an overall perspective of the complexities of the television news business (rather than presenting Dan Rather, Tom Brokaw and Peter Jennings in some kind of journalistic face-off).

title: Donna Friedman Weds
description: At Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I., last night Donna Elise Friedman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Friedman of Oceanside, L.I., was married to I. David Pelton, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Mervin J. Pelton of Atlantic Beach, L.I. Rabbi Eugene Lipsey performed the ceremony. Mrs. Pelton is a real-estate broker for Whitbread-Nolan Inc. in New York. Her husband is a vice president of investments at Drexel Burnham Lambert in New York.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: INVISIBLE WEAPONS. By Michael Wolfe. (Donald S.Ellis/Creative Arts, Paper, $8.95.) Imagine sitting in a bar one night with a bunch of cronies.

title: Space Technology To Run a Railroad
description: A SPACE guidance system to control railroad traffic?

title: Miss O'Connor Plans to Marry
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William B. O'Connor of Port Washington, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter Kathleen Ann O'Connor to John Quinn Donovan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard J. Donovan of Weymouth, Mass. The wedding is planned for December.

title: Protecting Officials
description: Two bills to deter the threatening and battering of officials at sports events have been introduced in the Michigan Legislature.

title: STORY OF AN AUTHOR AS A SCHOLAR
description: It was good to see Walter Anderson's new book, ''Courage Is a Three-Letter Word,'' included in Betsy Brown's July 27 round-up of books by Westchester-based authors [ Westchester Bookcase ] . Unfortunately, the information she included regarding Mr. Anderson's education was misleading and inaccurate.

title: Unseasoned
description: Even in January, you know the feeling. The first real snowstorm of the season, and the kids have outgrown their mittens.

title: BOWA MANAGES TEMPER AND TEAM
description: FOR the sake of his sanity, and the wits of his players, Larry Bowa has learned to ''back off'' in this, his debut season as manager of the Las Vegas Stars.

title: COHALAN FACES NEW HURDLE FOR COURT POST
description: FACED with a Republican hurdle to a possible State Supreme Court nomination, Suffolk County Executive Peter F. Cohalan has now been confronted with a Democratic obstacle as well.

title: 41 Hurt as Train Hits a Wall In a Philadelphia Suburb
description: A high-speed rail car overshot a platform in this Philadelphia suburb today and crashed through a wall today, injuring at least 41 passengers, the authorities said.

title: Dealing a One-Two Punch to Growth
description: THE euphoria on Capitol Hill about the benefits of tax reform is a rare bipartisan phenomenon that should make an economist reluctant to play the traditional role of wet blanket. But, alas, that is the destiny of our profession. Stepping back from the details of the 1986 tax reform bill and focusing on the big picture, it is evident that the impending changes in the Internal Revenue Code will depress the economy.

title: Warning on Alaska Volcano
description: Augustine Volcano is continuously erupting, producing a vigorous plume of ash and small earthquakes too numerous to count, and warnings have been issued to pilots and mariners, officials said today.

title: TOURIST DOLLAR IS TERMED GROWING PART OF ECONOMY
description: THE county has not yet begun to compete with Disney World or even with the Jersey Shore. It has no major attraction that draws throngs of people, and its beaches do not place it in the world-class resort category. But Westchester ranks third-highest of 62 counties in the state in travel-related income. Most of the spending is business-related, but promoters of tourism in the county say the number of tourists who come for pleasure is beginning to become a factor in those figures.

title: DRUNKEN DRIVERS FACE RISE IN FEES
description: ALTHOUGH Chuck L. Hardwick, the Assembly Speaker, recently blocked a measure that would have let the state Health Department's Division of Alcohol increase the fees assessed against drunken drivers, he says a compromise is possible before summer ends.

title: ALLIES SCRAMBLE FOR THE FARM RUBLE
description: AMERICA'S dwindling farm population now accounts for only 2.2 percent of the nation, fewer than 6,000,000 people. But the Federal Government's efforts to help those still on the farm have strained relations with some of Washington's closest allies.

title: JOB BOOM IMPERILS UNEMPLOYMENT AIDS
description: UNEMPLOYMENT in Connecticut has been hovering around 4 percent this year, compared with more than 7 percent nationally.

title: The Lost Wallet
description: AS I WRITE THIS, I HAVE been an undocumented person for a week. A pickpocket snatched my wallet and, along with it, all of the pieces of paper that give testimony to the man I am, to the very fact that I exist at all. It is a temporary condition, and I have not slept in the streets or been barred from the office. Nor have I felt as tragic as those paperless millions whose lives are rootless for want of a certificate that proves one's worth in the world to those who guard borders or offer work.

title: EVALUATING THE PAWNS
description: It is only a rough approximation to equate three pawns with a minor piece, so a considerable amount of thought must go into every such exchange.

title: L.I. WINE: THEY SAID IT COULDN'T BE DONE
description: IN 1977, less than a decade ago, one Long Island wine, a curiosity called Hargrave Vineyard Rose of Cabernet Sauvignon, was available.

title: SHAKESPEARE IN THE PARKS
description: DURING the prologue to Shakespeare's ''Taming of the Shrew,'' a company of itinerant players prepares to put on the play in a piazza in Padua.

title: SEA LINKS IN MALAYSIA
description: A cruise-ferry service in the South China Sea linking two widely separated parts of Malaysia is scheduled to begin Sept. 6. The service will connect peninsular Malaysia, where the capital, Kuala Lumpur, is situated, and the East Malaysian states of Sabah and Sarawak on the island of Borneo.

title: FOR YOUR INFORMATION
description: THE county is in the business of collecting taxes and garbage; the White Plains Public Library collects newspapers and magazines. The two decided to get together and collect information. Has ''1984'' arrived in 1986? Big Brother? ''I think we've moved beyond that,'' said Susan S. Egginton, manager of customer relations for the County of Westchester Data Processing Division of General Services. ''We're making available information already made available to the public, which has every right to access. We're not opening up private files to anyone.''

title: Tracy Anne Mergenthaler Is Married
description: The marriage of Tracy Anne Mergenthaler, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Francis William Mergenthaler of Westport, Conn., and Malcolm Weeks Robinson 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robinson Jr. of Wilton, Conn., took place yesterday at Trinity Episcopal Church in Southport, Conn. The Rev. Stephen J. Chinlund of Trinity and the Rev. Kieran O'Hearn, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated.

title: EXPERIENCE IS RICH WHEN A CHILD STAYS HOME FROM CAMP
description: I HAVE done something strange this summer. I did not send my 4-year-old daughter to camp. Because this statement usually meets with incredulousness, pity and, sometimes, 10-minute lectures, I am quite quick to explain that I did not plan it that way. Her staying at home just happened.

title: A SUMMERY SETTING IN WESTPORT
description: THE ''sweet smell of success'' for restaurants can arrive in mysterious ways.

title: A SOUTH AFRICAN CLERIC IS REPORTED TORTURED
description: A leading Roman Catholic prelate in South Africa was tortured during questioning by the authorities this week, and lawyers have appealed to that nation's Supreme Court to grant an immediate order barring further abuse, according to Catholic officials and court documents.

title: SOMETHING OUTSIDE IS OUTSMARTING ME
description: THERE'S something out there again tonight. I can hear it prowling about, searching, stealing, marauding. I'm getting scared.

title: Judge Enters Not Guilty Plea To Charges of Raping a Boy
description: Judge James Sloan of Alabama pleaded not guilty Wednesday to raping a 13-year-old boy and was released on a $70,000 personal recognizance bond.

title: EX-CABINET AIDE STIRS PHONE UPROAR IN NEW DELHI
description: Indian soldiers took over the central telephone exchange here today and began evicting 4,000 striking employees who are protesting the actions of a former Cabinet minister who went into the exchange armed with a pistol.

title: 10-Year-Old Arrested For Bank Extortion
description: A 10-year-old girl was arrested for demanding money from banks, the police said today.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: FORGET ME KNOTS. By Owen Brookes. (Holt, $15.95.) If you like spooky psychological thrillers, this one has a great premise. On the verge of her engagement to handsome, successful Barry Irving, 18-year-old Julie Wells is visited by someone from her past - Jo-Jo, her imaginary childhood friend.

title: Spotting the Real Costs of Regulation
description: Who Profits: Winners, Losers, and Government Regulation, by Robert A. Leone. Basic Books, N.Y. 248 pages, $17.95.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
GOLD COIN IS ISSUED FOR PEACE
description: The United Nations has designated 1986 as the International Year of Peace and Canada is commemorating the occasion with a $100 gold coin. This new coin, which was unveiled at the convention of the American Numismatic Association in Milwaukee, is the 11th in a series issued annually since 1976 by the Royal Canadian Mint.

title: WHERE FRANCE'S RULING CLASS TAKE THEIR CLASSES
description: NO. 13 Rue de l'Universite is a pre-eminent address in France, a unique locus of power and prestige. It is the headquarters of the Ecole Nationale d'Administration, known by its initials E.N.A., which has been the official training school for top Government bureaucrats since it was created by Charles de Gaulle after World War II.

title: PRIVATE SCHOOLS IN CITY TO INCREASE TUITION 10%
description: Tuition at private day schools in New York City is increasing an average of 10 percent this fall, according to a survey of a dozen leading schools.

title: RECENT RELEASES OF VIDEO CASSETTES
description: MOZART'S 'MAGIC FLUTE' Produced, written and directed by Ingmar Bergman, 1973, Paramount Home Video, 134 minutes. $59.95.

title: Susan Ellen Fine To Wed Nov. 22
description: Mr. and Mrs. Phil David Fine of Boston and West Hartford, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter Susan Ellen Fine to Arnon Absalom Mishkin, a son of Prof. and Mrs. Eli Mishkin of Brooklyn. The wedding is planned for Nov. 22.

title: Music
description: Music, like the rest of us, seems to suffer from the August heat, and this week it will be seeking relief out of doors. Besides Lincoln Center Out-of-Doors's Folk Heritage Day at 6 P.M. on Sunday, across the river (sometimes in it) more open-air concerts are scheduled.

title: Suffolk Center And Its Programs
description: I would like to correct some misinformation that appeared in your article of Aug. 3 concerning the proposed residential program of the Suffolk Child Development Center [ ''School Expansion Draws Opposition'' ] .

title: THE STRANGE AGONY OF SUCCESS
description: AT 33, Bill O'Donnell Jr. had succeeded. He was vice president of Bally Manufacturing, had an annual salary of $150,000, owned two Mercedes Benz's and an expensive house in Winnetka, Ill.

title: FROM TAIWAN TO TANGLEWOOD BY WAY OF A VIOLIN
description: As a young boy growing up in the small town of Hsin-Chu in Taiwan, Cho-Liang Lin read biographies of Jascha Heifetz, Fritz Kreisler and Yehudi Menuhin, and was fascinated by the behind-the-stage mystique of the performing artist.

title: CHESS MASTERS REACH A DRAW BEFORE RESUMING 10TH GAME
description: Gary Kasparov and Anatoly Karpov agreed to a draw in the 10th game of the their world championship chess match yesterday in London without resuming play. Kasparov, the 23-year-old titleholder, leads the 35-year-old ex-champion 5 1/2 to 4 1/2 points.

title: THE ANCHORS
description: In Alex Jones's article, Dan Rather is portrayed as being chagrined by the recent fall of CBS News from the primacy of its ratings in past decades.

title:
ART;
NEW WRINKLES ON USE OF PAPER
description: As a raw material for art, paper is among the most adaptable of media, capable of assuming many forms and serving many ends. Its versatility is demonstrated in ''On and Of Paper,'' the current exhibition at the new Temperance Hall Gallery in Bellport, where 10 artists put paper through its paces.

title: HERNANDEZ: FIRST BASEMAN WITHOUT PEER
description: ON Monday, he sprang to his left, snared the ground ball, and smoothly, if it is possible to appear smooth on your knees, threw the hitter out. On Wednesday, he charged a bunt, and with no time and no choices, grabbed the ball with his bare hand and caught the runner going to second base. On Friday, he cut across the front of the mound to intercept a bunt and made the force play at third.

title: College Football Schedules
description: AIR FORCE Aug.30-Hawaii; Sept.6-atTex.El P.; 20-Wyoming; 27-Colorado St.; Oct.3-at Utah; 11-Navy; 18-at N.Dame; 25-at S.Diego St.; Nov.8-at Army; 22-at Rice; Dec.6-B.Y.U. ALABAMA Aug.27-Ohio St.; Sept.6-V'derblt; 13-So. Miss.; 20-at Florida; Oct.4-N.Dame; 11-Memphis St.; 18-at Tennessee; 25-Penn. St.; Nov.1-at Miss.St.; 8-L.S.U.; 15-Temple; 29-Auburn ALFRED Sept.13-Mrcyhrst; 20-Canisius; 27-Ramapo; Oct.4-at Ithaca; 11-atSt.Lwrnc; 18-Hobart; 25-at Cortland; Nov.1-U.Buffalo; 8-atU.Rochstr; 15-at Buffalo St.

title: CHANGING DEMOGRAPHICS, AND POLITICS, IN LOS ANGELES
description: FIVE years ago black workers could still be seen in downtown hotels on jobs that sent a steady flow of income into the black neighborhoods of Los Angeles. Now almost all those jobs are held by Latinos, many of them recent immigrants. Five years ago Hispanic shops and restaurants lined several main boulevards just west of downtown. Now those boulevards are chockablock with Korean hotels and mini-malls.

title: GRAF DEFEATS DURIE IN 3 SETS, GAINS FINAL
description: Steffi Graf survived leg cramps and a stiff battle from Jo Durie to win a three-set semifinal today and advance to the championship round of the $150,000 United Jersey Bank Classic.

title: ALASKANS FACE THREAT FROM SURGING GLACIER
description: The Hubbard Glacier, an 85-mile-long ice mass, has moved several hundred feet in recent weeks to block Russell Fjord's narrow outlet with Disenchantment Bay, near the top of Alaska's southeastern panhandle. The movement has turned Russell Fjord into Russell Lake, now about a thousand feet deep, and imperils the area's salmon fishery.

title: NEW STRATEGY GLEANING JURORS FOR GOTTI TRIAL
description: Among the 15 people selected last week as prospective jurors in the Federal racketeering trial of John Gotti was a 59-year-old practical nurse who candidly told the court that she had heard television news accounts referring to Mr. Gotti as a ''godfather.''

title: Not All the Dust Has Settled at Chernobyl
description: THE Chernobyl disaster produced much more radioactive contamination and spread it over a much larger area than had been previously acknowledged, according to a Soviet report disclosed last week. The report, to be discussed tomorrow at a conference of the International Atomic Energy Agency in Vienna, also said residents of the area near the plant, in the Ukraine, may not be able to return for as long as four years.

title: TOWN DISPUTED ON LAW STUDY
description: WHEN Huntington Town Supervisor John J. O'Neil authorized the Town Comptroller to reimburse two town officials for a total of more than $15,000 in law school tuition, Mr. O'Neil did not expect it would become a major public issue.

title: Museums
description: There is something paradoxical about an exhibition of musical instruments. You see them, but you can't touch them, let alone play them. Sometimes they are innately beautiful. Sometimes they have had beauty thrust upon them, in the form of superfine craftsmanship. Sometimes they sound wonderful but are hideous to look at. Altogether, it's a complicated subject.

title: U.S. AIDES REPORT SOVIET LOST AIRBORNE LASER LAB IN A FIRE
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that a fire destroyed a Soviet airborne laser laboratory near Moscow in late May or early June.

title: Coke's Struggle
description: To the Editor:

title: EX-INMATES COMPLAIN OF MANAGUA JAIL
description: Beneath a hill in the center of Managua there is an underground jail where, according to former inmates, political prisoners are often held for days or weeks under harsh and disorienting conditions.

title: AND NOW, A TAP-DANCING DETECTIVE
description: ''THE Case of the Dead Flamingo Dancer,'' currently in its world-premiere run at the John Drew Theater at Guild Hall, began as a one-act comedy that the actor Dan Butler wrote as a lark for a tap-dancer friend.

title: NEW TOWN HALLS EASE SPACE SQUEEZE
description: AMONG the buildings that make up Stamford's skyline is a gleaming 10-story glass-and-steel structure that is to become the city's Government Center.

title: More Warnings From Dr. Doom
description: Interest Rates, the Markets, and the New Financial World, by Henry Kaufman. Times Books, N.Y. 258 pages, $22.50.

title: A Party for Nancy Reagan
description: Nancy Reagan was joined by friends and family members today for a belated 65th birthday party at the Reagan ranch near here. About 40 couples, including two of President Reagan's four children, Maureen and Michael, and their families were on the guest list for an afternoon barbecue. Mrs. Reagan's birthday was July 6. Mr. Reagan gave her a custom-made saddle, which Mrs. Reagan found waiting for her at the ranch.

title: LOOKING BOTH WAYS
