description: MY LIFE BETWEEN JAPAN AND AMERICA By Edwin O. Reischauer. Illustrated. 369 pp. New York: A Cornelia and Michael Bessie Book/ Harper & Row. $22.50.

title: SHARP 70 GIVES WADKINS TIE
description: Lanny Wadkins turned in an amazing exhibition of scrambling on a golf course today that included holing from off the green three times in a four-hole stretch, taking only seven putts on the back nine and 21 putts in the round and blasting in from a bunker.

title: Ms. MacDonald, E. J. McEneaney Exchange Vows
description: At the First Presbyterian Church in New Canaan, Conn., yesterday Bonnie Jeanne MacDonald, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter E. MacDonald of New Canaan, was married to Eamon James McEneaney, a son of Edward McEneaney of Cobleskill, N.Y., and the late Mary McEneaney. The Rev. Timothy Hood performed the ceremony.

title: TRANSFER OF CONTROLLERS SAID NOT TO HURT SAFETY
description: The Federal Aviation Administration said today that the grounding of 34 air traffic controllers on the West Coast over allegations of drug use will not compromise air safety.

title: STATE SERVICE LINKS PARENTS TO DAY CARE
description: WHEN Rosemary Talmadge moved to Connecticut in 1984 from Boston, she and her husband were concerned with finding child care for their 2 1/2-year-old daughter, Sarah.

title: Wendy Logan Married
description: Gwendolyn Cari Logan, the daughter of Emily Frenkel Soell of New York and Paul David Logan of Sarasota, Fla., was married last evening to Gary Kahn Stern, the son of Diana Lehrburger of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Richard Stern of Bronxville, N.Y. Rabbi Linda Goodman officiated at The Loft in Manhattan. The bride, known as Wendy, is a marketing and communications associate at the Young Presidents' Organization in New York. Mr. Stern is a financial consultant with Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith in New York.

title: THE PASSIONATE GELATERIA
description: The man has whipped cream on his elbow. The gentleman he serves across the counter has it in his mustache. The eyes of children gleam at table's edge like pieces of ripe, round fruit. Giolitti. 5:30 P.M. The siesta has ended, the passeggiata begins.

title: WESTCHESTER BOOKCASE
description: PARENTS AND KIDS TOGETHER by Lisa Lyons Durkin. Warner Books. 173 pages. $8.95. This imaginative book will tell a working mother or any busy parent how to get the most out of every minute spent with a young child. The author describes hundreds of ways of having fun and teaching the child at the same time, by letting the youngster share the parents' daily routines.

title: Reagan Gives The Sandinistas A Warning
description: President Reagan made his Central American policy more explicit last week. Unless Nicaragua agrees to become more democratic, he said in an interview with the Mexican newspaper, Excelsior, ''the only alternative'' will be for the United States-financed rebels ''to have their way and take over.''

title: FREE AGENTS KEPT WAITING BY OWNERS
description: The sound not heard in baseball these days is contract talk between players on the verge of becoming free agents and their clubs. The absence of negotiations is apparently part of the owners' strategy that worked so well for them last year. The longer they wait to negotiate, the owners believe, the greater the pressure the players will feel to accept what is offered.

title: POSTINGS: Marine Park Project; 21 Two-Bedrooms
description: As Avenue U slices through south-central Brooklyn, it cuts through Marine Park and creates a small block of developed land north of the Marine Park Golf Course.

title: One Dead in Train Derailment
description: Thirty-six cars of a 57-car Southern Pacific freight train derailed early today, killing one transient man, injuring three others and spilling a cargo of new automobiles, skates and teddy bears along the tracks, the authorities said.

title: Saratoga in Perspective
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: SHORTENED 'NANETTE' STILL HAS THE SPIRIT
description: WHAT could be more fitting than going to Atlantic City to see ''No, No, Nanette,'' which is about going to Atlantic City?

title: POSTINGS: Taxpayer Renovation; Adding a 3d Floor and a Glass Facade
description: The two-story taxpayer, like hundreds of others that line the avenues of New York, had stood essentially untouched since the 1930's.

title: QUEEN VICTORIA'S STOCKINGS
description: To The Editor:

title: NEW COUNTY EFFORT ON REFUSE
description: COUNTY officials produced a 67-page recycling guide for Westchester's 45 communities last week in the hope that their conversion of newspapers, glass, metals and other reusable materials into cash would not only prove profitable but also reduce the pressure on the county's overburdened garbage-disposal plant.

title: Don't Blame the Bill if We Have a Slump
description: THE tax bill approved last week by Congressional conferees represents real progress toward a more stable, less intrusive tax system. The new plan is consistent with the fundamental economic policy of the Reagan Administration. It signals a less activist role for government through the tax system, just as airline and trucking deregulation, an end to oil price controls, and deregulation of financial institutions have marked a less activist role for government by other means. It also marks the end of half a century of unsuccessful efforts to redistribute income through taxes.

title: CITY MUSEUM WITH A CONSCIENCE
description: WHY would a New Yorker want to see a historical exhibition on homelessness? Robert R. Macdonald, director of the Museum of the City of New York, continued the visitor's question: ''When all one has to do is go to Grand Central Station and you're stepping over people?''

title: JUSTICE, VENGEANCE, HEROES AND MAFIOSI
description: SICILIAN UNCLES By Leonardo Sciascia. Translated by N.S. Thompson. 205 pp. New York: Carcanet. $15.95.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE COMMODORE. By Jan de Hartog. (Cornelia & Michael Bessie/Harper & Row, $19.95.) Martinus Harinxma, the young World War II skipper in the 1965 novel ''The Captain,'' sails again.

title: Road-Improvement Dispute Impairs Forrestal Complex
description: PRINCETON UNIVERSITY is locked in a two-year-old battle with the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation and the New Jersey Department of Transportation as it lays the foundation for a $130 million shopping and office complex on Route 1.

title: LAST PLACE BEFORE THE SUN SETS
description: A HOLLYWOOD EDUCATION Tales of Movie Dreams and Easy Money. By David Freeman. 268 pp. New York: G.P. Putnam's Sons. $17.95.

title: EX-MEXICO POLICE CHIEF IN 2 TRIALS
description: After an 18-month manhunt and a two-year extradition fight, Mexico City's former Police Chief is on trial here in two separate courts on charges of extortion and illegal firearms possession.

title: Muscovites Rally for Peace And an End to Nuclear Arms
description: Thousands of Muscovites carrying posters calling for the elimination of nuclear weapons poured through the streets of the capital today for peace rallies dominated by anti-American themes.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of editing errors, an article on the Potteries in England (Travel, July 13) gave incorrect prices for ceramic ware and dates for a national garden festival in Stoke-on-Trent.

title: CONSUMER RATES
MOVING TOWARD A MORE EQUITABLE TENNIS PURSE DISTRIBUTION
description: The winner's share is getting more lucrative all the time. This year, for example, the men's and women's United States Open singles champions will each earn a staggering $210,000. There is also a waiting list of would-be tournament sponsors, lobbying for a date on the respective professional tours. It is not surprising then, that tennis is considered a sport of riches, played in exotic locations. Today, New York; tomorrow, Gstaad.

title: On Language; WITH ALL DELIBERATE VULGARITY
description: IF YOU ARE AN IMPRESSIONABLE minor, turn this page hurriedly without reading further; go watch the ax murder of a nude model by a lecherous alien on television instead. This is about vulgar speech in school and is too shocking for juvenile eyes.

title: RECENT RELEASES OF VIDEO CASSETTES
description: STEVE LACY: LIFT THE BANDSTAND Directed by Peter Bull, 1985, Rhapsody Films, 50 minutes. $59.95.

title:
GARDENING;
A BATTLE PLAN FOR THE WAR ON WEEDS
description: ANYONE who has pulled weeds on a hot August day will know what God had in mind when, as recorded in Genesis, He expelled Adam and Eve from the Garden of Eden with the exhortation that they would have to work and sweat to make the soil productive. In fact, it was also predicted that weeds and thorns would be around to make the job that much harder.

title: Cooling Valve Malfunctions At a Nuclear Plant in Jersey
description: A cooling valve malfunctioned during testing at the new Hope Creek Nuclear Generating Plant in southern New Jersey early yesterday, but plant officials said there was no danger and no radioactive release.

title: Police Kill Woman's Captor
description: Two police officers fatally shot an armed man who officials said had held a woman hostage for more than 12 hours and forced her to drive around all night at gunpoint. The woman, identified as Agatha Colby, 24 years old, of Charles County, Md., was unharmed. The man's identity was not released pending notification of relatives.

title: A SOVIET OFFICIAL ASSIGNED TO U.N. IS SEIZED AS A SPY
description: A Soviet physicist assigned to the United Nations Secretariat was arrested yesterday on a Queens subway platform as he gave $1,000 to an employee of an American defense contractor for three classified documents, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said.

title: GENETIC ENGENEERING MUST BE REGULATED
description: WHEN the microbiologist John Roe O'Neill avenged his wife and children who were killed in a terrorist bombing, he changed the course of human society for all time, for he created and released a gender-specific virus that killed only women.

title: NEW IMAGE IS SOUGHT BY VOTERS' LEAGUE
description: CONCERNED about declining membership, the Connecticut League of Women Voters wants to update its image.

title: PEKING SENTENCES AMERICAN AS SPY
description: An American citizen has been sentenced to 12 years' imprisonment in China on charges of spying for Taiwan, the New China News Agency said today.

title: White House Will Not Replace Solar Water-Heating System
description: The Reagan Administration says it will not replace a solar water-heating system that was installed in the White House in the Carter Administration.

title: PEPSICO EXTENDS FESTIVAL PLEDGE
description: PEPSICO'S seventh yearly Summerfare was a hit.

title: 7,500 U.A.W. Workers Strike at 3 Deere Plants
description: About 7,500 members of the United Automobile Workers struck three Deere & Company plants today after the union and the farm tractor manufacturer failed to agree on a new contract.

title: BOSWORTH: GETTING BETTER MEANS GETTING TOUGHER
description: HE had quickly become a leader of a defensive unit at the University of Oklahoma that had pushed, shoved, bullied, talked, fought, and, above all, played its way to a ranking atop the national college football polls. As a sophomore last season, Brian Bosworth won the Butkus Award as the outstanding linebacker in the nation. He forged a hairstyling statement rarely seen under football helmets: Flat (and yellow) on top, close-cropped on the sides, tail in the back. The Boz.

title: REAGAN URGES QUICK PASSAGE OF MEASURE FOR TAX OVERHAUL
description: President Reagan, saying ''absolutely no reason'' existed for further delay, urged Congress to give prompt passage to the tax bill approved by a House-Senate committee last week.

title: HOW TO USE THE LANDSCAPE TO ITS BEST ADVANTAGE
description: TAKING a breathtaking landscape photograph requires more than a breathtaking landscape. This is a lesson that all photographers who venture into the great outdoors learn almost immediately. But for some reason - perhaps discouragement -many of them never discover the techniques to help overcome this disparity between camera and eye.

title: FRANCE AIMS TO ENHANCE HUMAN RIGHTS ROLE
description: Every day 50 or so often aggrieved letters arrive at a mansion in Paris across the street from the Prime Minister's office, claiming mistreatment at the hands of the Government bureaucracy, demanding visas for a politically persecuted relative abroad or asking help in being released from a prison sentence.

title: Margaret C. Albertson Marries Brian Prindle
description: The marriage of Margaret Councill Albertson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph L. Albertson Jr. of Larchmont, N.Y., to Brian Edwin Prindle, a son of Elizabeth M. Prindle of Salem, Mass., and Dale Brown Prindle of Pittsfield, Mass., took place yesterday in Larchmont. The Rev. Richard Martin performed the ceremony at the Larchmont Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title: PESTO FINDS ITS WAY INTO A VARIETY OF DISHES
description: NOW that basil is standing a foot tall in the garden, it is time to make pesto again.

title: CLIFFHANGERS AND COFFEE CUPS: AT WORK WITH LEONARDO SCIASCIA
description: Leonardo Sciascia's farmhouse sits half-hidden on a hillside overlooking a landscape of vineyards and olive groves deep in south central Sicily, near the town where he was born 65 years ago. But he does not have a telephone or keep a car, and his house has no address. To visit the writer regarded by European critics as one of Italy's most distinguished novelists, it's almost necessary to make a wrong turn or two first. One such turnoff near Racalmuto led a recent visitor to a cul-de-sac named Via Pirandello - a symbolic accident.

title: Rider Dismounts For Horse Show
description: IF Mickey Mantle or John McEnroe lived at the farm on Majors Path in Southampton, chances are that autograph seekers would be lined up outside day and night.

title: One Scandal Case Nears End as Another Widens
description: Juries, grand and otherwise, took two city investigations into new territory last week.

title: PAUL SIMON BRINGS HOME THE MUSIC OF BLACK SOUTH AFRICA
description: ''M y new album really came about by accident,'' Paul Simon said. ''In the summer of 1984, a friend of mine gave me a tape of 'township jive,' the street music of Soweto, South Africa. It was a happy instrumental music that reminded me of 1950's rhythm and blues, which I have always loved. By the end of the summer I was scat-singing melodies over the tracks. I thought that the group, whoever it was, would be interesting to record with. And so I went on a search to find out who they were and where they came from.''

title: LINGERIE'S GREAT LEAP FORWARD
description: IN the Victoria's Secret lingerie shop on Madison Avenue, a transformation is going on. A woman, a self-described ''practical type'' given to wearing blouses with high collars and her boyfriend's old jeans, is buying slinky silk teddies and panties edged with lace.

title: Congressional Report Urges Change in Asia Trade Policies
description: Countries along the Pacific rim can continue to have strong economic growth if they avoid trade policies that emphasize their own national interests at the expense of others, according to a report released today by the Congressional Joint Economic Committee.

title: STUDENTS SENT OUT TO RECRUIT STUDENTS
description: WEARING jeans, sneakers and a polo shirt, Kenny Rodgers blended in well with the crowd at a Sunday evening gospel concert in the Lincoln Park bandshell here.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: THE GODMOTHER

title: A Low-Key Raider Hits the Limelight
description: WHEN word came on the afternoon of Aug. 8 that three judges in Manhattan had given a green light to his buying a larger stake in NL Industries, Harold C. Simmons knew just what to do. He called his broker and within minutes he had spent $63 million on another block of NL shares. With that stroke, Mr. Simmons, despite all of NL's attempts to remain independent and its appeal for judicial help, took title to 51.1 percent of the common shares, putting him in control of the big oilfield services company.

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: A PUBLIC transit plan for the Hudson riverfront redevelopment area has taken a significant step forward with the announcement of a $50 million Port Authority of New York and New Jersey investment in the project.

title: OPERA: 'DIE FLEDERMAUS' GETS A CHANGE OF CAST
description: THERE is much to enjoy in the New York City Opera's current production of ''Die Fledermaus'' by Johann Strauss. The music, of course, for all of its determined frivolity, is wonderfully eloquent, and composers as diverse as Webern, the great Minimalist, and Mahler, a great ''Maximalist,'' have come to worship at the shrine.

title: Thoughts on Boston Myth
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: FOR SCIENTIST, A PRIZE AND A QUEST
description: PAUL ADAMS, a 39-year-old neurobiologist at the State University of New York at Stony Brook, suddenly found himself $200,000 richer a few weeks ago, with no strings attached.

title: Linda Sanchez Is the Bride Of G. P. Ho, a Colleague
description: Linda Sanchez, the daughter of Justa Sanchez of Elizabeth, N.J., and the late Jesus M. Sanchez, and Gregory P. Ho, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald K. L. Ho of Honolulu, were married yesterday.

title: Elizabeth Dawes Weds John H. Knight
description: Elizabeth Anne Clarke Dawes, the daughter of Mrs. Gordon Townley Williams Jr. of Wyckoff, N.J., and Lyell Clark Dawes of Francestown, N.H., was married yesterday to John Harvie Knight, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Eliot Spalding Knight of Madison, N.J. The Rev. Lewis L. Stone performed the ceremony at All Saints' Episcopal Parish in Peterborough, N.H.

title: RACE FOR No. 2 MASSACHUSETTS POST HEATS UP
description: As the September primary approaches in Massachusetts, the contest for the relatively powerless job of Lieutenant Governor is attracting an unusual amount of attention, just as it is in New York.

title: BEEKMAN PLACE
description: WITH its immaculate, quiet streets lined with trees and handsome residences, Beekman Place has maintained a reputation as one of the most desirable places to live on the East Side of Manhattan.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: For once, we were in the right place. That is, we were not at home in Oceanside, but on a brief jaunt to the leafy Berkshires, and it was just as well, for everyone I know on the South Shore seemed to be there as well. ''Everyone'' is, of course, a slight exaggeration; maybe it was five or six people.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: EQUALITY AND EDUCATION: Federal Civil Rights Enforcement in the New York City School System. By Michael A. Rebell and Arthur R. Block.

title: MUSIC: ARRAU CONCLUDES MOSTLY MOZART FESTIVAL
description: WHAT more fitting conclusion to the 1986 Mostly Mozart Festival than a performance of the master's Symphony No. 40 in G minor (K.550)? It is probably Mozart's most beloved essay in symphonic form, a work so famous that it is, paradoxically, rarely heard in concert nowadays - a distinction it shares with Beethoven's ''Moonlight'' Sonata and a handful of other compositions. Neither of these masterpieces is by any means played out, but there are now so many different recorded performances available, and the scores have been so often used in films, on the radio and even, grotesquely, in television commercials, that interpreters with little new to say steer clear of the overly familiar music.

title: INSURANCE COSTS PUT CURBS ON RIDING
description: AFTER 32 years as a successful general contractor and carpenter, Rudy Grecho decided to put aside his tools and invest his earnings in a lifelong dream. Eight years ago, when the Rudan Stables in Eastchester went up for sale, Mr. Grecho quickly took the opportunity to purchase the facility, which leases its land from the county. Although the new enterprise was far less lucrative than his former business, Mr. Grecho and his brother, Dan, managed to sustain the operation through $10 hourly rentals for trail riding through 50 miles of woods and forest winding around lower Westchester. On an average weekend alone, said Dan Grecho, more than 80 riders would rent horses, providing the bulk of the stable's income.

title: U.S. DATA SAID TO CONCLUDE SOVIET MISTOOK KOREAN PLANE
description: The South Korean airliner shot down by the Soviet Air Force in 1983 was not on an espionage mission, but the Russians, in a series of blunders, believed they were attacking an American reconnaissance flight, according to a magazine article.

title: AN UNDAUNTED 'STARER AT ANIMALS'
description: THE CHIMPANZEES OF GOMBE Patterns of Behavior. By Jane Goodall. Illustrated. 673 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: The Belknap Press/ Harvard University Press. $30.

title: MATHEMATICIANS FINALLY LOG ON
description: COMPUTERS crunch numbers, make pictures, store data and perform arithmetic, and that is why pure mathematicians have long abhorred them.

title: COLLEGE PLANS MAJOR EXPANSION
description: RESPONDING to what they see as community needs, officials of Atlantic Community College expect to spend $14.7 million over the next few years to develop the 546-acre campus here. Plans call for:

title: Cracking Down On City Cyclists
description: Bicyclists, who are often accused of injecting an element of anarchy into city traffic that is otherwise merely disorderly, are being encouraged to pedal more softly around New York these days.

title: Pakistani Returns Home And Discusses Security
description: President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq returned to Pakistan today after a two-week pilgrimage to Saudi Arabia and immediately held top-level talks on domestic security.

title: CITY AGENCIES DIFFER ON DRUG TESTING
description: New York City agencies have widely disparate policies on drug abuse, leading to sharp variations in the way city workers and job applicants are tested for drugs and how they are treated if the tests are positive, a city study has found.

title: THAILAND'S ROYAL FAMILY IS LESS CAMERA SHY
description: FOR generations, Americans and Europeans have formed an image of the Thai monarchy from the breathless and often fanciful writings of the royal governess Anna H. Leonowens, a Victorian woman who, some historians now say, put pen to paper in an advanced state of culture shock. Mrs. Leonowens's autobiographical writings, ''The English Governess at the Siamese Court'' and ''The Romance of the Harem,'' gave rise to Margaret Landon's 1944 bestseller, ''Anna and the King of Siam,'' which became ''The King and I'' - and an entertaining legend took the place of history.

title: ANDRETTIS BATTLING FOR DRIVING TITLE
description: For the second year in a row, the P.P.G. World Series of Indycar Racing is a family event. Mario Andretti, 46 years old, and his 23-year-old son, Michael, are playing the same roles this year that the Unser father and son pair did last, when Al Unser narrowly edged his son, Al Jr., for the 1985 title in the last race of the season.

title: LOUGANIS, BIONDI PACE U.S.
description: Greg Louganis of the United States won the men's platform diving title for the third consecutive time at the world swimming championships today, but another American, Matt Biondi, stole the spotlight in the swimming events by taking his seventh medal.

title: Dance
description: The rest of the world may be on vacation but dancers will be performing all around the city this week. And several of the programs are of unusual interest.

title: IN THE LAURENTIANS, A FEW FRILLS
description: My family first came to Labelle in 1952, some 72 years after the priest and explorer Cure Antoine Labelle had planted a cross alongside the rapids on the Riviere Rouge to mark another parish in the string of settlements he was stretching north into the Laurentian wilderness.

title:
DINING OUT;
MEDITERRANEAN AIR IN HOPATCONG
description: THERE are many reasons for going to a restaurant. It may be the food, the way people are treated by the staff and the owners, the price or the atmosphere.

title: THE MAGIC RUNS OUT
description: Fatigue is an integral part of the game, particularly in major team events which may last for a week or more.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The New York Times Magazine today about the new NBC-TV series ''L.A. Law'' misstates the date when the pilot episode is to be shown. After the magazine went to press, NBC rescheduled the preview for Oct. 2 and set the premiere for Oct. 3.

title: INKSTER AND RIZZO SHARE LEAD
description: Patti Rizzo shot a three-under-par 68 today to tie Juli Inkster for the second-round lead of the $225,000 Atlantic City Classic.

title: MUSEUM DISPLAYING RARE YACHT PHOTOS
description: Stanley Rosenfeld, the New York yachting photographer who has filmed every America's Cup competition since 1930, hasn't had much time for boating in the last six weeks. He has spent his days working inside a chilly basement vault at the Mystic Seaport Museum instead. And with good reason.

title: McENROE, LENDL TO PLAY IN FINAL
description: A rejuvenated John McEnroe took another giant step in his effort to return to the top echelon of men's tennis when he beat Andres Gomez of Ecuador, 6-2, 7-6, today to reach the final of the $150,000 Norstar Bank Hamlet Challenge Cup.

title: EXPERTS SEE U.S. COCAINE PROBLEM AS CONTINUING DESPITE ANTIDRUG RAIDS
description: In New Mexico last month, the authorities seized 1,184 pounds of cocaine hidden in a pickup truck. Days earlier, the police seized 700 pounds of cocaine being smuggled into Phoenix, and 1,253 pounds in West Palm Beach, Fla.

title: MODEL TRAINS BEYOND THE REALM OF TOYS
description: Collectors of model trains normally fall into one of two categories. There are those who build functioning layouts with modern reproductions of period trains, and there are those who collect the originals and showcase them like precious antiquities.

title: Archivists Reply
description: To the Editor:

title: British Radar for Jordan
description: A British electronics company said today that it had won a $22.5 million order from the Jordanian Air Force. The company, Marconi Radar Systems, said it would supply new air-defense radars and modernize Jordan's existing radar system. Last year, Britain concluded a $405 million arms deal with Jordan that was financed through generous export-credit arrangements.

title: MERV GRIFFIN TUNES UP A NEW SHOW -- ONE WITH LESS TALK
description: After 23 years as a staple of the television talk-show scene, Merv Griffin will soon nod his head in agreement, laugh obligingly at someone's jokes and lean in a little closer to the couch to explore a guest's thoughts for the last time. On Sept. 5, ''The Merv Griffin Show'' will go off the air with a retrospective of highlights from over the years.

title: CATHOLICISM, DEMOCRACY AND THE CASE OF FATHER CURRAN
description: THE Vatican's censure last week of the Rev.

title: CONGRESS LOOKS BEYOND DEAVER CASE
description: ''FOREIGN interests, in our increasingly interdependent world, have a legitimate stake in many decisions made by our Government,'' Stuart E. Eizenstat, President Carter's chief adviser on domestic affairs, said recently. ''So long as their involvement is disclosed, there is nothing inherently wrong in their trying to influence our Government's decisions.''

title: LOOKING BACK AT GROWING UP IN THE 50'S AND 60'S
description: Like love and death, coming of age has long been a legitimate concern of serious artists. That arduous journey to adulthood, a trip made sooner or later by every child, is as fraught with peril and mystery as space travel. It has been chronicled in our literature in such novels as ''Great Expectations,'' ''This Side of Paradise'' and ''The Catcher in the Rye'' and has found its way into that most populist of art forms, the movies. ''Rebel Without a Cause'' and ''The Last Picture Show,'' among other films, have recorded the burgeoning adolescent and his struggles - coming to terms with parents, squabbling with authority, and of course, discovering sex and searching for identity (or vice versa).

title: THE WELL-ORGANIZED LIFE -- MORE THAN THE SUM OF ITS PARTS
description: I HAD lunch one day with a young banker who had Urban Professional written all over him, though he did seem to be more than passably interested in the arts.

title: Anne C. Twomey, Actress, Weds John Bedford Lloyd
description: At the Unitarian Church of All Souls in New York yesterday Anne Carolyn Twomey, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry F. Twomey of Gladwyne, Pa., was married to John Bedford Lloyd, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward B. Lloyd of Palm Beach, Fla., and Southport, Conn.

title: Christiana Gaddis Wed To Ferdinand Masucci
description: Christ the King Roman Catholic Church in New Vernon, N.J., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Christiana Peabody Gaddis, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Charles Gaddis of Cincinnati, to Ferdinand David Masucci, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis M. Masucci of South Orange, N.J. The Rev. Robert Sheerhan performed the ceremony assisted by the Rev. Celine McGrath, an Episcopal priest.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, AUGUST 24, 1986
description: International Praise for Zimbabwe and Zambia came from South Africa's six black-ruled neighbors for imposing sanctions against South Africa, but the six nations did not move as a group to impose similar sanctions. Instead, the so-called front-line nations issued what was viewed as an inconclusive communique Friday at the end of a meeting of heads of government in Luanda, Angola. [ Page 1, Column 6. ] The Korean airliner shot down by Russians in 1983 was not on an espionage mission, but Soviet forces, in a series of blunders, believed they were attacking an American reconnaisance flight, according to an article to be published by The Atlantic Monthly next month. The article is based on a review of American intelligence and on interviews with Soviet officials. It concludes that the plane's penetration of Soviet airspace resulted from navigational errors by the Korean Air Lines crew. [ 1:3. ] Three years of violence in Sri Lanka has uprooted more than 300,000 Sri Lankan Tamils, according to estimates by Government officials and human rights groups. Most of these uprooted ethnic Tamils, who make up Sri Lanka's largest minority population, are now displaced people in their own country, once South Asia's model of ethnic harmony, or in refugee camps in India. About 60,000 are in the West and Australia. [ 1:4. ] 50,000 Tamil refugees fled to Western Europe in the last five years. These mostly Hindu refugees fleeing a separatist insurgency in Sri Lanka are but one group who flee troubled third world nations for the welfare states of Western Europe.

title:
GARDENING;
A BATTLE PLAN FOR THE WAR ON WEEDS
description: ANYONE who has pulled weeds on a hot August day will know what God had in mind when, as recorded in Genesis, He expelled Adam and Eve from the Garden of Eden with the exhortation that they would have to work and sweat to make the soil productive. In fact, it was also predicted that weeds and thorns would be around to make the job that much harder.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE BAY OF SILENCE. By Lisa St. Aubin de Teran. (Franklin Watts, $15.95.) This disturbing novel of mystery, obsession and madness begins symbolically in Sestri Levante, a strange haven on the Italian Riviera also called ''the two-faced place.'' There a promontory divides two bays, the Bay of Fairytales and the Bay of Silence, which gives this novel - Lisa St. Aubin de Teran's fourth - its title. The novel, like one of its two main characters, is ''obsessed by twos,'' by truth and secrets, by speech and silence, by madness and dual and dueling definitions of reality. Twins, alter egos and schizophrenia add to the double weave of the book's fabric. The story is told in alternating narratives by a husband and wife who first honeymooned in Sestri Levante 13 years earlier and return to put their fractured lives back together. William is a graphic designer whose bitter childhood taught him that ''rock bottom is always lower than you think.'' Rosalind is a beautiful, strange and dreamy actress who ''grew up used and abused and neglected; almost starved by affluence.'' As an adult she becomes promiscuous yet detached, floating in a ''sea of non sequiturs,'' her dual nature alternating between a need for stability and a need for change. The couple have twin girls and then a baby son. The infant's mysterious death coincides with his mother's schizophrenic breakdown, and leads to the troubling climax of the book. All the details of menace and decay are told in a voice of confidence and control that is distinctly this novelist's (her previous novels include ''Keepers of the House'' and ''The Slow Train to Milan'').

title:
PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;
A GOTHIC VISION OF MAN SEEN WITH THE CAMERA'S EYE
description: Joel-Peter Witkin is one of the great originals of contemporary photography. He does not belong to any recognized school, and if he has any imitators, they are keeping a low profile. His work is most often compared, not to that of other photographers, but to that of long-dead painters and print makers who were also originals, particularly Goya and Hieronymus Bosch. Indeed, by the purest standards upheld at New York's Museum of Modern Art, he is scarcely a photographer at all, since he works over his negatives and prints to achieve effects that may have been in his mind's eye when he made the exposure, but are certainly not in the negative.

title: 'SOCIAL DISEASES': WHAT TIME IS IT?
description: To the Editor:

title: FRED HAMMER'S MONEY-LOSING IDEAS
description: CELEBRITY spotters often stop Frederick S. Hammer when he walks around this city. Some people even ask for his autograph.

title: THE ASSURED LOOK
description: She is everywhere these days, impossible to miss. She is the woman who exudes complete confidence in her abilities, whether striding down a street or an office corridor, commanding a telephone or a staff of 50, serving behind a counter or standing before one. She is equally expert at maneuvering the aisles of power and those of the supermarket, all the while moving with ease, with sureness. And she wants her clothes to reflect it.

title: Michelle Gewirtz Marries Cris Kako
description: The marriage of Michelle Dana Gewirtz and Cris Tokyua Kako took place yesterday at 126 Fifth Avenue in Manhattan, where Judge Alexander W. Hunter Jr. of the Criminal Court of the Bronx performed the ceremony. The bride is the daughter of Marilyn Gewirtz of New York and Jean Galiana of New York.

title: Aberrational Alms
description: People have been coming to Washington for years with their hands out, looking for help from the Government, so it's not surprising that the capital has developed a subculture of street beggars. The more ingenious among them try to increase their revenue with techniques or trademarks that set them apart from the ordinary run of panhandler.

title: YET ANOTHER WAY TO PROFIT FROM THE COMPUTER AGE
description: PAUL CATALANO was holding court in a three-acre man-made vault, 100 feet below the World Trade Center. Mr. Catalano, a white-haired grizzly bear of a man with a fierce handshake, a voice as rich as chocolate, and the heft of a heavyweight wrestler, affectionately smacked his left hand against one of the vault's 30-foot-thick walls while jabbing with his right toward shelf after shelf of computer tapes.

title:
EDUCATION WATCH;
BUSINESS SCHOOLS WITH A CONSCIENCE
description: PATRICK DURKIN, a young investment banker at First Boston Corporation, knows that it is wrong to cash in on inside information about pending mergers and acquisitions. But in some complicated financial dealings, when it is difficult to tell right from wrong, Mr. Durkin says he draws on the ethics education he had in business school to help him make the proper decision. Business school did not teach him moral values, he said - that came earlier in life - but rather how to think about the ethical consequences of everyday business decisions.

title: Diane Schwebel Affianced To Perry Dean Freedman
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jack P. Schwebel of Pound Ridge, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Diane Schwebel, to Perry Dean Freedman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Freedman of New York and Sag Harbor, L.I.

title: Gen. Roscoe Wilson; Led Air War College
description: Lieut. Gen. Roscoe C. (Bim) Wilson, a retired Air Force officer who was involved in the development of the atomic bomb and was later commandant of the Air War College, has died at the age of 81.

title: Giving Credit to Trevino
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: CARDS DOWN ASTROS ON COX'S SIX-HITTER
description: Danny Cox pitched a six-hitter for his fourth complete game of the season as the Cardinals beat Houston, 7-1, tonight, handing the Astros their third straight loss.

title: Spain Holds 8 in Bank Theft
description: Eight men have been taken into custody in the theft of $5.5 million worth of treasury bills from the Bank of Spain, the police said today. They said the eight, including a bank employee and a man posing as an army general, faced charges of selling the securities in the stock market.

title: THE ENEMIES TRY MORE TALKING WHILE THEY KEEP UP THE FIGHTING
description: IN their seventh year of war, Salvadorans have become wary of promises of peace. So there was little popular expectation of major progress last week when the rebels and Government officials agreed, in preliminary talks, to renew negotiations on Sept. 19 in Sesori, a town in eastern El Salvador. Salvadorans know that while both sides talk about peace the fighting goes on in the countryside.

title: TAILORED SUITS, HATS AND IMAGES OUT OF THE PAST
description: WHEN it comes to gussying up, the group of horse and carriage fanciers who gathered last weekend in Newport, R.I., take a back seat to no one. Unless, of course, the back seat in question is on a spiffy rig drawn by well-groomed stallions.

title: FRENCH COUNTRY PRIDE
description: LAGUIOLE IS A SMALL TOWN IN THE Aveyron area of France, a poor and almost savagely rural area in the high pasturelands of the Aubrac Mountains. Laguiole has always been known for its fine handmade folding knives, for its cheese (similar to cantal) and for a local rib-sticking dish of cheese and potatoes called aligot. But now, quite suddenly, this town is on the gastronomic map. A slight, modest, bespectacled 40-year-old cook named Michel Bras (he pronounces the ''s'') is rapidly emerging as one of France's greatest chefs. To paraphrase the French restaurant critic Henri Gault, it's as if the world had suddenly discovered an Yves Saint-Laurent working in a quiet mountain village.

title: ON A RIVIERA RAMBLE, ART SETS THE PACE
description: I wanted a break from modern art, which had found its way even up to the Scottish Highlands where I live. Enough of new masters; enough of drips and drabs.

title: POP: COCKBURNS' IMAGERY
description: ''T HERE'S a rainbow shining in a bead of spittle/Falling diamonds in rattling rain'' begins one of the verses of Bruce Cockburn's recent song ''World of Wonders.'' Lyrics like those, which discover opposing images of beauty and despair in a Chinese-box world of forces within forces, have long characterized the work of the Canadian singer-songwriter, who appeared at Town Hall on Thursday evening.

title: A CLASSICAL ACTOR WOWS BROADWAY IN A MUSICAL
description: Down the steps of the manor house he swaggers, the actor the audience has been waiting for.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: UNVEILING CLAUDIA: A True Story of Serial Murder. By Daniel Keyes. (Bantam, $17.95.) Unlike accounts of more celebrated cases, Daniel Keyes's book about the 10 brutal ''.22-caliber'' murders around Columbus, Ohio, in the late 1970's holds little general interest.

title: HISTORIC HOUSE GROWS: ADDING OLD TO OLD
description: OWNING the oldest house in Warren posed a dilemma 13 years ago for Frederick and May Hill, both art historians, when the need for more space became imperative and an addition imminent. How could they preserve the house's historic and architectural authenticity, yet ''add on?''

title: JAZZ: RON MATTHEWS QUARTET
description: THE quartet that the pianist Ron Matthews is leading at Whippoorwill, 18 East 18th Street, through today - with Branford Marsalis's husky tenor-saxophone sound carrying the tunes and the alert young rhythm section of Lonnie Plaxico and Louis Nash taking care of the hard swing - makes an attractive showcase for his distinctive approach to modern jazz traditions.

title: China Says 'Isolated Incident' Took Place on Soviet Border
description: The Chinese Foreign Ministry said today that an incident had occurred on the Soviet frontier, but it did not comment on a Japanese report that a Chinese soldier had been killed.

title: NINE STEPS FOR COLLEGE SPORTS
description: IF college athletics are to be cleaned up, what can be done promptly and effectively?

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Israelis, Russians Talk - a Little
description: Israeli and Soviet officials met for 90 minutes last week in Helsinki, the first diplomatic contact between the two nations since Moscow broke off relations during the 1967 Arab-Israeli war. But after the meeting, both Governments seemed cautious and could not even agree on whether there would be another meeting.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Minneapolis;
A New Bank That Fits In
description: FOR nearly three years, the architect Cesar Pelli returned here to walk the streets, first around a fire-damaged building and then around the hole in the ground left when it was demolished.

title: BRITISH URGE UNCLOAKING OF THEIR SECRETS ACT
description: Seventy-five years after the powers of British news reporters were considerably curtailed by the Official Secrets Act, a coalition of journalist, union and civic organizations are urging its repeal.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: For Use in the Home Or as Select Gifts The Silver Tree opened last May in Ossining offering arts, crafts, costume jewelry and some clothing from several countries, principally Mexico and India. Many of the wares are colorful and whimsical as well as unusual and useful, whether at home or as gifts.

title: RESORT STUDIES MONORAIL PLAN
description: DESPITE the misgivings of the New Jersey Monorail Authority Study Commission, city officials and a local task force plan to accept written proposals Friday for the design, construction and operation of a ''people-mover'' system to ease traffic congestion here.

title: QUARTERBACKS TIP BALANCE OF POWER
description: WHILE Oklahoma and the other powers of college football battle for the top spot, much attention will center on Notre Dame, where Lou Holtz will be expected to prove he was the right choice this time.

title: Kaoru Kihara Becomes Bride of Brendan Reilly Jr.
description: Kaoru Kihara, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Takato Kihara of Tsukumi, Japan, was married yesterday to Brendan Reilly Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Reilly of Windsor, Conn. The Rev. Stanley Azaro performed the ceremony at St. Gabriel's Roman Catholic Church in Windsor.

title: LOOKING AT THE PAINTER'S PROVENCE
description: The scene might be a still life from Paul Cezanne. Under the orange trees, at the foot of the ancient ramparts, the men are gathered in the yard of the central cafe, drinking pastis and playing boules. The pitch of those weathered silver balls, the way they roll and curl and rendezvous, is the sole focus of the men's attention. Nothing is about to spoil their concentration, not the winds at the ramparts, not those green valleys and vistas sloping down through Nice to the Mediterranean.

title: Destination Iowa
description: A sizable share of the Washington diplomatic community will take off tomorrow for what is sometimes regarded, rightly or wrongly, as a less than cosmopolitan capital - Des Moines - to participate in an international trade symposium. No fewer than 13 ambassadors and ranking representatives of 20 other countries are scheduled to make a four-day trip to Iowa, which is preparing to impress them with its manufacturing facilities.

title: A BRACING SUMMER ON THE LONDON STAGE
description: Not long ago July and August were the dog days of the British theater, a time when audiences and critics alike went paddling at the seaside, and no sensible impresario dreamed of opening a show. That period has now passed, as the summer of '86 is proceeding once again to prove. The American tourists on whom Shaftesbury Avenue has come so substantially to rely may not have been arriving in their usual battalions, thanks to a general suspicion that Europe this year is a blend of death-ray machine, shooting gallery and Blitz; but their numbers have been picking up of late, and plenty of fresh material is there to greet them. For instance, Alec McCowen is to be found in John Dexter's West End revival of T. S. Eliot's ''Cocktail Party,'' and Faye Dunaway is a short walk away, displaying her considerable emotional range in Harold Pinter's production of a play called ''Circe and Bravo.'' For instance, the Royal Shakespeare Company has just presented the premiere of Pam Gems's ''The Danton Affair,'' and the National Theater, not to be overshadowed by its rival, has opened an older, more mellow but no less lavishly staged piece, ''Jacobowsky and the Colonel.''

title: Puget Sound
description: To the Editor: The superb coverage of Puget Sound and its environs (Travel, Aug. 3) brought back warm memories of a number of trips to the area, my original inspiration having come from watching Jack Nicholson head home in the film ''Five Easy Pieces.''

title: The Letter of The Election Law
description: New York's election laws made at least as much news as the candidates last week, drawing protests from many quarters and reducing Abraham Hirschfeld to tears. They even figured in a spot of trouble for Mayor Koch.

title: RECENT RELEASES OF VIDEO CASSETTES
description: STATE OF THE UNION Starring Spencer Tracy, Katharine Hepburn, Angela Lansbury, Van Johnson, Adolphe Menjou; directed by Frank Capra, 1948, MCA Home Video, 122 minutes. $39.95.

title: Boston; Condominiums On an Island
description: AN innovative development team has found an answer to Boston's housing crunch: island living. By transforming an abandoned island in Boston Harbor into a 103-unit condominium complex, the developers are creating a resort-style beach-front community only 25 minutes by boat from downtown Boston.

title: Carol Lam Wed To Mark Burnett, Ph.D. Candidate
description: Carol Chien-Hua Lam, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sau-Wing Lam of Tenafly,. N.J., was married at the Tower Suite in Manhattan yesterday to Mark Steven Burnett, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Burnett of Lompoc, Calif. Algernon D. Black, a leader emeritus of the New York Society of Ethical Culture, performed the ceremony.

title: 5 Antiwar Protesters Get 7- to 8-Year Sentences
description: Five antiwar protesters convicted of breaking into two nuclear missile silos have been sentenced to prison terms ranging from seven to eight years.

title: WORK PLANS FOR ELDERLY NOTED BY LEGISLATOR
description: Regarding ''Retired Workers Returning to Part-Time Employment'' [ July 27 ] , Westchester County and municipal governments could meet the needs of those seniors who wish to work - but also want to work part time - by adopting either or both of the following programs:

title: A SUNDAY DRIVE IN SOVIET ISN'T SMOOTH SAILING
description: The Sunday drive in the country, long an American pastime, is still a developing art in the Soviet Union.

title: August Picking
description: Summertime and the picking is easy. The wild berries in the brambles hang in waiting bunches, the mussels in the tidal pools sit up in expectant clumps.

title: IMAGINE A NEW KIND OF TV SOAP: BLOOMSBURY COMES TO DALLAS
description: IN 1936 Virginia Woolf's nephew Quentin Bell wrote a play presenting his home at Charleston, in Sussex, as an archeological ruin of the distant future, visited by tourists. Mr. Bell called his play ''2036.'' He was only a half century off. This June, his prophetic scenario came true when a restored Charleston was opened to the public. Both Mr. Bell and his half sister, Angelica Garnett, children of Virgina's sister Vanessa Bell, have been very active in the movement to preserve their old homestead.

title: DANCE: HELEN DANNENBERG
description: HELEN DANNENBERG is an imaginative original with a quirky, faintly allusive movement style. That was evident in the program presented by the San Francisco-based choreographer and performance artist on Friday at the Bessie Schonberg Theater. Ms. Dannenberg is a funny woman, too -though she underplayed that side of herself on Friday - and she takes some unusual subjects as themes for her dances. But the evening, part of Dance Theater Workshop's ongoing summer ''Out-of-Towners'' series, was sometimes mystifying.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: COMRADES. By Clive Irving. (Villard, $19.95.) The historical novel has the potential to bring coherence and understanding to overwhelming events by focusing on a tidy drama set on history's stage.

title:
INVESTING;
Sifting the Street After Tax Revision
description: IT may be years before all the ramifications of the sweeping tax code overhaul are understood on Wall Street. But the experts have already begun to identify the stock sectors they think most likely to prosper in the proposed new tax environment. What stocks will be stellar performers? Elaine M. Garzarelli, director of sector analysis at Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc., has produced a list of 10 industry groups that will pay at least 5 percent less in taxes next year under the new plan. The lower taxes should translate into higher earnings -and higher stock prices. The list includes automotive after-market companies, cosmetics, electrical equipment manufacturers, tobacco companies, beverages, foods, retailers, drugs, drugstores and companies in the leisure-time category.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Winged Visitors Take In the Cape

title: PROSPECTS
description: Will Auto Leasing Slide?

title: People Express
description: To the Editor:

title: FOR GRAFFITI ARTISTS, TOUGH CRITICS AND A COUNTEROFFENSIVE
description: GRAFFITI in Connecticut is getting a lot of attention nowadays as residents grow tired of seeing colorful and sometimes lewd markings on their buildings, schools, buses, parks and sidewalks.

title: POLICE SUSPECT 'SHY' SAN ANTONIO OFFICER MAY HAVE BEEN A BRUTAL VIGILANTE
description: To friends and neighbors, Patrolman Stephen Richard Smith seemed a polite, shy man with a taste for classical music who liked to feed stray cats.

title: REPORT FINDS SURPRISING POPULATION GROWTH IN CITY
description: The New York metropolitan region, which lost 700,000 people in the 1970's, gained 416,000 people from 1981 through 1985, with New York City accounting for a surprising 44 percent of that increase, according to an analysis by the Regional Plan Association.

title: RIDGEFIELD HOT DOGS GIVEN GALLIC TOUCH
description: IN 1980, when Michael Soetbeer was out of work as a personnel director and looking for a job, his wife spotted a newspaper advertisement for someone to take over a hot-dog cart. She showed it to him ''just as a joke,'' he recalled.

title: LONDON'S HOME OF PROPER BROLLIES
description: Until recently in London, you could tell a true city gent by his bowler and brolly. While the bowler has gone the way of the bustle, the traditional brolly, all 25 inches of slim, rolled, wood construction, has rarely been more popular. At James Smith & Sons, umbrella and walking stick manufacturers since 1830, the only significant change in 156 years is in how far the city gents and ladies now come to purchase their traditional craftsmanship and quality.

title: FROM 'HILL STREET' TO 'L.A. LAW'
description: THE LIGHTS DIM IN A SCREENING room at the 20th Century-Fox lot in Los Angeles. Near the front sits a wiry man of 42 with graying hair and dark eyes that look softly out of a boyish face. Wearing a California-casual ensemble of slacks, sport shirt, sweater and running shoes, he is waiting with the cast of a new television series, ''L.A. Law,'' to see the results of the first day of filming.

title: THE STAR WARS SPINOFF
description: THE LANDSCAPED INDUSTRIAL park that flanks San Diego's Balboa Avenue hints of well-appointed board rooms, robotic assembly lines and healthy workers bronzed by weekends on the nearby beaches. The street is only a few minutes' drive from Sea World and other tourist magnets, and to the casual visitor it seems as far removed as an American suburb could be from any hint of war or weaponry. But the peaceful mien of the neighborhood is disturbed several times a week by the blast of a stunningly powerful cannon that sends flocks of startled birds into the air and sets off burglar alarms in parked cars over a wide area.

title: Thatcher Accepts Invitation to Visit Soviet
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher has accepted an invitation to visit the Soviet Union, her office said today.

title: LIPMAN LARGESSE ON DISPLAY
description: AT the time of its catalogueing in 1974, the Whitney Museum's collection included about 450 sculptures, of which one-quarter were gifts from Howard and Jean Lipman. It is thanks to this remarkable couple that the museum had acquired before 1970 three works apiece by Jasper Johns, Robert Morris and Robert Smithson, not to mention all nine of its Lucas Samarases and half of its 16 Alexander Calders.

title: The Case of William X
description: To the Editor:

title: Living for the Children Isn't Living
description: AS we all knew she would, Marlene threw a high school graduation party for her daughter, which turned out, of course, to be for herself. As we had guessed, Stephanie's scores on the Scholastic Aptitude Tests were recited to arriving guests, just as the college acceptances were intoned on our leaving.

title: GIANTS DEFEAT JETS, 20-16, ON 3 BIG PLAYS
description: The Giants made three big plays tonight and scored an inelegant 20-16 victory over the Jets in their annual preseason game.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL YANKEES VS. OAKLAND A'S, at Yankee Stadium, 1:30 P.M. (Television - Channel 11, 1:30; Radio - WABC 770, 1:30).

title: No More Hiding Behind Taxes
description: The historic tax reform bill hasn't even been signed into law, but in the week since it emerged from a Senate-House conference it has already had two lives. First came the thrill of getting the bill this far, to the brink of victory, against an army of special interests. Now a round of agonized second thoughts is setting in.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: August 24, 1986
description: Fiction

title: Q AND A
description: Brooklyn Subdivision

title: FIRES IN WEST OVERWHELM SPACE-AGE TECHNOLOGY
description: For three weeks firefighters have been using the most modern equipment in their arsenal - hand-held computers, infrared mapping and satellite dish antennas -to battle thousands of wildfires in southern Idaho and eastern Oregon.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Edward McCaskey, owner of the Chicago Bears, was reported in stable condition at Rush-Presbyterian-St. Luke's Medical Center in Chicago after undergoing open-heart surgery on Friday.

title: PACE PROFESSOR STUDIES THE ROOKIES
description: AS a member of the Penn State University Class of 1986, Lance Hamilton worked hard for four years to graduate Phi Beta Kappa in prelaw. As a member of the New York Giants rookie class of 1986, Lance Hamilton has only six weeks to work hard for a job that could earn him hundreds of thousands of dollars a year.

title: Developers' Battle Halts Jersey Riverfront Project
description: A TANGLED and sometimes bitter lawsuit between competing developers has stalled one of the first residential projects along New Jersey's Hudson River waterfront.

title: The Swooping, Enduring Gulls of Captree
description: CAPTREE is one of those inevitable but somewhat unpredictable frontiers where humanity meets nature in a blending of the manufactured and the elemental: where barnacles prey on a freshly painted hull, where sea gulls survey their strangely altered world from the top of a roadside lamp post.

title: GROWING MARKET FOR RECORDED LITERATURE
description: THIRTY years ago, Arthur Luce Klein was $30,000 in debt and on the verge of bankruptcy after starting a business. Nine months after organizing a recording company, Spoken Arts - a subsidiary of the Westminster Publishing Company - Dr. Klein's first project for the new company, a recording of German verse, sold poorly.

title: Emily Lazar Engaged To Jonathan H. Alter
description: Emily Jane Lazar, an associate producer for the CBS Morning News television program in New York, and Jonathan H. Alter, a general editor and the writer of the news media section of Newsweek magazine, plan to be married Oct. 18.

title: CARROTS AND STICKS
description: ARMS AND HUNGER By Willy Brandt. Translated by Anthea Bell. 208 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $15.95.

title: NEW TECHNOLOGY HELPS PARALYSIS VICTIMS REGAIN MOVEMENT
description: Demonstrations show that new technology using computer-stimulated electrical impulses allows some paraplegics and quadriplegics to walk, with balancing aid from crutches or walkers.

title: 'LIVING BESIDE A CULTURAL AND ECONOMIC COLOSSUS'
description: IMAGINE a movie-lover in St. Louis who checked the local paper and discovered that 97 percent of the films showing in his city were foreign. Or how about a book-lover in San Francisco who found that in every city store foreign authors had written 75 percent of the titles and that American books were consigned to an inconspicuous display quaintly called ''Americana.''

title: Short-Order Planning for the Masses
description: AS part of their push to become one-stop financial ''supermarkets,'' New York's largest banks and savings and loan associations have been offering customers a wide variety of nonbank products such as mutual funds, discount brokerage and insurance. Now many banks are going one step further by providing financial planning advice to help customers reconcile these investment opportunities with their financial needs.

title: U.S. AND EGYPT PLAN MANEUVERS CLOSE TO LIBYA
description: Egypt and the United States will conduct military exercises this week over the Mediterranean Sea not far from waters claimed by Libya, the Defense Department said tonight.

title: Miss Emery Wed on L.I.
description: The marriage of Deborah D. Emery, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John M. Emery of Cedarhurst, L.I., to John D. Maine Jr., the son of Mrs. Thomas Cutler of Brooklyn Heights and Mr. Maine of Philadelphia, took place yesterday at Trinity-St. John's Episcopal Church in Hewlett, L.I. The Rev. George Wickersham performed the ceremony.

title: Headliners; Double Duty
description: While the answer remains ''no'' on aircraft carriers, the United States Navy has abruptly changed its policy on civilian use of its football carriers. Navy Secretary John F. Lehman last week authorized Ensign Napoleon McCallum, a 23-year-old former Naval Academy running back, to play for the Los Angeles Raiders on weekends ''so long as there is no conflict with military duties.''

title: LOOKING BACK WITH NO REGRETS
description: IT has been 50 years since she won a gold medal in the discus throw in the 1936 Berlin Olympic Games - breaking the Olympic record by a remarkable 23 feet - and then stood on the victory stand and gave the stiff Nazi salute as the swastika flag was raised and her national anthem played.

title:
IN NEW JERSEY;
Panther Valley Enters Its Second Decade
description: SINCE the mid-1970's, Panther Valley, a 1,500-acre residential community of contemporary town houses, condominiums and single-family homes, has been taking shape against the gray-green backdrop of the Jenny Jump Mountains.

title: A GRUESOME PAST IS STILL HAUNTING UGANDANS
description: The elephant grass stands six feet tall here, knotted and tangled with scruffy coffee trees and broad green-leaved tops of wild banana plants. Farther off, in shorter grass, a row of skulls and a small heap of bones is a reminder of the recent past.

title: AN ART DECO MONUMENT TO HAGUE
description: THE imposing towers of Jersey City Medical Center, with their classic Art Deco interiors, are testaments to the power and glory of Mayor Frank Hague, whose tenure in Jersey City extended from 1917 to just after World War II.

title: Joellen Masters Weds Sculptor Aboard Schooner
description: Joellen McCulloch Masters, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hilary Masters of Ancramdale, N.Y., and Pittsburgh, was married yesterday off Provincetown, Mass., to Jeffrey Peter de Castro, a son of Mrs. Allen J. de Castro Jr. of Mystic, Conn., and the late Mr. de Castro. Justice of the Peace Sheila Silva performed the ceremony aboard the schooner Olad.

title: China Provisions
description: To the Editor: My husband and I have been to China twice and we would like to suggest some items that travelers should take with them, in addition to the ones enumerated by Nancy Harmon Jenkins in the article ''One Traveler's Packing List of Provisions'' (Travel, July 20).

title: Sally Warner Marries Donald Rhodes Malin
description: At the Scarscale (N.Y.) Congregational Church yesterday Sally Alden Warner, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kent Field Warner of White Plains, was married to Donald Rhodes Malin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald F. Malin Jr. of New York and Canaan, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. Avery D. Post, president of the United Church of Christ, performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. Phillip Washburn.

title: ARTS CELEBRATION SET FOR NASSAU, WITH CHANGES
description: REACHING the age of five can be an important milestone in any festival's life. Just how important the organizers of the Nassau County Celebration of the Arts will discover on Labor Day weekend.

title: METS TOP GIANTS TO LEAD BY 20
description: Bob Ojeda held up his hand to demonstrate just how he had altered his grip when throwing the changeup. ''It's a very subtle thing,'' he said. ''I was squeezing the ball just a little more.'' Dave Johnson said that one of his primary goals had been achieved when he left Ojeda in to pitch out of trouble, and Roger McDowell said that this game was as important as any other to maintain ''that good feeling.''

title: REAL RELIEF FOR WORLD DEBT
description: Move over, Gertrude Stein. A deficit is a deficit is a deficit? Not any more - at least not in the mind of the International Monetary Fund, which recently convinced itself that Mexico's public sector deficit is really a surplus.

title: IN LINDEN WORKERS STRUGGLE TO ADJUST TO A HIGH-TECH LIFE
description: FUZZY peach navel is the recommended drink at the Old Corner Inn here, one of the latest and most unlikely ripple effects of the American auto industry's march toward high technology.

title: MY NEW YORKS: WRITING 'A WALKER IN THE CITY'
description: ''A WALKER IN THE CITY,'' published in 1951 as a sensory memory of boyhood in the Brownsville district of Brooklyn, began as something else. When the war, Hitler's war, was over, I returned from wartime reporting in England to find that there was no room for me in New York except in a ramshackle painter's studio on Pineapple Street in Brooklyn Heights indifferently left to me when the painter moved on to big money in commercial art. He even left me his old paintings, which consisted of violently colored images, a whole series of concentration camp prisoners standing with clenched fists behind barbed wire.

title: On Second Thought
description: Rather than say exactly why they wanted to deport Choichiro Yatani, Federal officials decided last week to let him stay. Mr. Yatani, a Japanese student who first came to America in 1977, was detained by immigration officials on July 7, when he returned from an academic conference in the Netherlands, and was to have been deported. The agency said it had secret evidence that Mr. Yatani, a doctoral candidate at State University of New York at Stony Brook, was a Communist-affiliated subversive. Mr. Yatani denied the charges and sued the agency for attempting to deport him without a hearing.

title: Botha Pledges to Resist
description: President P. W. Botha accused the Western powers and the Soviet bloc today of trying to impose their will on South Africa, and he said he was prepared to fight the efforts of both sides. Mr. Botha was quoted as saying that East and West were gambling with this nation's peace and stability in a contest over who would control the Cape sea route.

title: PUERTO RICO FOCUS OF BRONX ENSEMBLE
description: THE Bronx Arts Ensemble is calling its concerts this afternoon ''A Salute to Puerto Rico.'' The program is highlighted by a performance of Manuel Gonzalez' Mass in C, the featured vocal soloists are Evangelina Colon and Abraham Lind, and the other singers are from the Boricua College Chorus.

title: Jamie Kyte Weds
description: At the First Presbyterian Church of Rumson, N.J., yesterday Jamie Anne Kyte, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Mathison Kyte Jr. of Fair Haven, N.J., was married to John Crim Sapoch 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sapoch Jr. of Princeton, N.J. The Rev. Foster Wilson performed the ceremony. Mrs. Sapoch, a development officer for the Rutgers University Foundation, will retain her name professionally. Her husband is an international banking officer for the First Fidelity Bancorporation in Newark.

title: Karen McDonald Engaged
description: Announcement has been made by Mrs. Edward J. McDonald of Brooklyn of the engagement of her daughter, Karen Ann McDonald, to Dr. James Patrick O'Connell, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James Joseph O'Connell of Scarsdale, N.Y. Ms. McDonald, the daughter also of the late Mr. McDonald, is a nursing care coordinator at the St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center, where her fiance is an anesthesiologist.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
AUTUMN CAN'T COME FAST ENOUGH
description: IT is August in Connecticut. It is hot. It is humid. My friend comes for lunch. She looks tan and summery in a crisp sort of way.

title: CLUB MOVES TO PROTECT VERMONT TRAIL
description: His years of hiking the Long Trail have taught Harry T. Peet Jr. to expect a glimpse of a deer, a dramatic view of the Green Mountains, a burst of color from a patch of wildflowers. In recent months, however, he has learned that a house lot, a radio transmission hut or a ''For Sale'' sign should come as no surprise.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: 4 SHOWS AT WESLEYAN

title: Lisa Meaders Plans to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Paul LeSourd Meaders Jr. of Bronxville, N.Y., and Southampton, L.I., have announced that his daughter, Phyliss Elizabeth Meaders, and Stephen Nash Hurley of Bronxville and Chilmark, Mass., plan to be married in November. The future bride is a daughter also of the late Patricia Rockefeller Meaders.

title: 'THE MYTHMAKER'
description: To The Editor:

title: GREENPORT LEGACY LIVES ON
description: THE crack of hammers and slap of paint brushes in Greenport churches these days mark the legacy of a 94-year-old man's love for the village in which he lived and died.

title: HELPING OUTDOOR SYSTEMS
description: Asked if the sound at outdoor concerts in New York's Central Park had improved this summer, a colleague replied ironically: ''Yes, the loudspeaker system breaks down more often.''

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE NEWLY BORN WOMAN. By Helene Cixous and Catherine Clement. (University of Minnesota, Cloth, $25. Paper, $12.95.) Published in France in 1975 as ''La Jeune Nee,'' this ground-breaking feminist tract was intended, we are told, for a wide audience.

title: Mario Biaggi Jr. Weds Ms. Tarantino of NBC
description: Carol Tarantino, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Tarantino of Franklin Lakes, N.J., was married yesterday to Mario Biaggi Jr., a son of Representative and Mrs. Biaggi of the Bronx. The Rev. John Leonard performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Demarest, N.J.

title: CRUELLY, GORGEOUSLY ACCURATE
description: JOHN SINGER SARGENT; His Portrait. By Stanley Olson. Illustrated. 310 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $16.95.

title: G.O.P. OFFICIALS VOICE WORRY ABOUT O'ROURKE'S CAMPAIGN
description: Leading Republicans in New York State are concerned that Andrew P. O'Rourke's campaign for governor is off to such a slow start that he could jeopardize the re-election of many Republican state senators and assemblymen.

title: 'BORN IN FLAMES' IS 90 MINUTES OF FIZZLE
description: ''B orn in Flames'' is a genuine curiosity. We are unlikely to see it in very many places other than Channel 13, which sensibly has tucked it away in an unpopular hour, 11 o'clock tonight. It will run for 90 minutes, although it is doubtful that even the few viewers on hand then will get past the first 10 or 15. ''Born in Flames,'' part of Channel 13's ''Independent Focus'' series, looks very much like a home movie. Friends, colleagues and relatives ham it up. Meanwhile, there is a solemn scenario, whose purpose a character in the film tries to explain. ''It is the story not just of women's oppression,'' she says heatedly, ''it is the story of sexism, racism, bigotry, nationalism, false religion in the black and state-controlled church, the story of environmental poisoning and nuclear warfare.'' In fact, ''Born in Flames'' is none of these. It is a vanity production, poorly done.

title: A Shocking Sports Story
description: I had thought the conduct of athletes could no longer shock me. After all, many ballplayers now score drugs as often as points, and appear as willing to shave the latter as they are their faces in television commercials.

title: Cable TV
description: For viewers in search of quality in films of the 1980's, this is a week of abundance. And the films in question - ''Tender Mercies,'' ''Chariots of Fire,'' and ''The Killing Fields'' - not only boast an impressive variety of Academy Awards, they also afford engrossing drama.

title: Firefighter's Dismissal Is Urged in Harassment
description: A city administrative law judge has recommmended that a firefighter be dismissed for his involvement in a scuffle with a female colleague that left her with a slashed finger.

title: RACE DISPUTES SPUR BOYCOTTS OF SCHOOLS IN 2 SOUTHERN STATES
description: A shortage of black teachers has led to a school boycott in a Georgia district, and a boycott in a Louisiana district has been called by black parents protesting the distances involved in court-ordered busing.

title: SALVADOR TO RENEW PEACE TALKS SEPT. 19
description: The Government of El Salvador and leftist rebels have agreed to hold a third round of peace talks, and according to a communique issued today the talks will begin Sept. 19 in the eastern Salvadoran farming town of Sesori.

title: Cyclist Suspended
description: Leslee Schenk of Boulder, Colo., who on Thursday won the 57-5-mile Golden-to-Boulder segment of the Coors International Bicyle Classic race, was barred from further participation the next day after she tested positive for a banned substance that she said was contained in an over-the-counter cold remedy.

title: THE NEW DIRECTIONS FOR FALL
description: Directions in home design are predicated on more than the imaginations of architects and decorators. Museum shows and auctions also shape the look of today's homes. Furniture, art and decorative objects spanning many centuries will be on view, and on sale, this fall. Some pieces, originally fit for a king, were executed by Europe's finest cabinetmakers. Others are among the most successful examples of what can be produced by machine for the mass market. Despite such diversity, design in general is moving in simpler directions. Architects are taking a more purely modern approach, getting their inspiration from those masters who epitomize clean lines and spare spaces. Interior design is getting simpler, too. A decorator may well buy a set of Louis XVI gilt armchairs, but he uses their ornate shapes to punctuate uncluttered, colorless interiors.

title: Nobel's Wife
description: To the Editor:

title: JERSEY CITY ACTS ON MEDICAL CENTER
description: THE City Council here has given Jersey City Medical Center - the last municipally owned public hospital in the state - preliminary approval to become a private, nonprofit institution. The conversion would be the first step toward building a new, $110 million facility a mile from the present site.

title: THE TROUBLES THEY SAW
description: TO TELL A FREE STORY The First Century of Afro-American Autobiography, 1760-1865. By William L. Andrews. Illustrated. 353 pp. Urbana: University of Illinois Press. $25.95. SISTERS OF THE SPIRIT Three Black Women's Autobiographies Edited by William L. Andrews. 245 pp. Bloomington: Indiana University Press. Cloth, $29.50. Paper, $8.95.

title: PETITIONS MAY POSE THREAT TO CHICAGO MAYOR
description: Chicago's perennially battling political factions opened fire on a new front this week, one that will play a major role in determining Mayor Harold Washington's chances of re-election.

title: Miss Mastroianni Marries R. J. Boe
description: Anna C. Mastroianni, the daughter of Dr. Luigi Mastroianni Jr. and Dr. Elaine Pierson-Mastroianni of Haverford, Pa., and Woods Hole, Mass., was married yesterday to Randall J. Boe, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Warren Boe of Iowa City. The Rev. John E. Priest, a Lutheran minister, performed the ceremony at the Church of the Messiah in Woods Hole.

title: STREETWISE ABROAD
description: The trunk was locked. The car was parked in a big open lot with lots of people, including policemen, wandering around. We planned to spend only half an hour looking at a major tourist attraction in the heart of Rome, and my wife and I felt secure as we tossed a shoulder bag with a few odds and ends into the trunk rather than drag it around the Baths of Caracalla.

title: The Challenge Of Change
description: It is frightening to recognize that Henry Adams's mid-19th-century prophecy that ''the engines [ man ] will have invented will be beyond his strength to control'' has been fulfilled (''The Challenge of Change,'' by Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr., July 27). With Chernobyl as an example, an anonymous Russian specialist observes, in Harrison Salisbury's article ''Gorbachev's Dilemma'' in the same issue, that ''we can no longer control technology.''

title: WHAT'S NEW ON THE CORPORATE BOOKSHELF
description: THERE are two schools of thought about what makes business tick.

title: Man Dies in Fall at Gorge
description: A Kingston man taking photographs at Platte Clove Gorge slipped on the moss-covered edge of a cliff Friday night and fell 100 feet to his death, the state police said. The victim, Michael Betkowski, 32 years old, was found at the bottom of the gorge near the Plattekill Creek in Hunter, about 40 miles south of Albany, said a state police spokesman, Sgt. Robert Houst.

title: Rounding Up Rare Ferrets
description: CONSERVATIONISTS captured near Meeteetse, Wyo., what were believed to be the last healthy six black-footed ferrets in the world and took them last November to a laboratory at the University of Wyoming in Laramie. The hope was to breed them - four females and two males - and restock the wild with their offspring.

title: Age Is Not a Crime
description: To the Editor:

title: Unwritten Obligations
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Lite Reading
description: For days, we've been brooding about a publishing house called Work-man, which is busily producing the aural equivalent of light beer - a cassette tape that will dispense ''Ten Classics in Ten Minutes.'' As Workman's publishers explained to William Greer of The Times, their aim is to ''cut down the literary canon to a lean pistol.''

title: Ann Lundquist, Artist, To Wed Basil Walter
description: Mr. and Mrs. James H. Lundquist of Sands Point, L.I., and New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ann Tecla Lundquist, to Basil Walter, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ned Foster Walter of Iquique, Chile. A November wedding is planned.

title: Ex-Philippine Diplomat Is Arrested in Italy
description: A former Philippine diplomat and close friend of former President Ferdinand E. Marcos was arrested here Friday on charges of illegally possessing weapons.

title: Verbatim; Mother Tongues
description: 'The point is, if we are testing math, let's test math, not mix math and language.'

title: IT'S PRIME TIME FOR TESTAVERDE
description: THE day the telephone rang at the Testaverde home in Elmont, L.I., with the call that helped change the life of their son the quarterback, he was not at home. Vinny Testaverde was in Virginia with his father and brother-in-law, looking for a prep school that would provide a transition year between Sewanhaka High School and the future.

title: A Young Fogy's Guide
description: THE RECENT REPORT in this space on the rise of the Young Fogies has elicited barrels of inquiries from readers. Here are a few, and their answers.

title: COD, STILL COMMON, AND STILL KING
description: No other creature, extinct or extant, has played a greater role in the history of coastal New England than the common cod. Today, 489 years after the English explorer John Cabot described the seas of this region as ''covered with fish,'' cod is still most often the catch of the day at the auctions on the fish piers in Boston, New Bedford and Gloucester.

title: Caution About Gorbachev's Dilemma
description: Harrison Salisbury's article ''Gorbachev's Dilemma'' (July 27) should be read with caution. To any seasoned Kremlinologist, Mr. Salisbury's unprecedented access to a number of high-level Soviet officials close to Mikhail S. Gorbachev would seem to be part of a carefully arranged scenario orchestrated by Anatoly F. Dobrynin, now Mr. Gorbachev's closest foreign-policy adviser and most knowledgeable expert on American politics and psychology.

title: HEAT, LIES AND FANTASIES
description: DEATH VALLEY & THE AMARGOSA A Land of Illusion. By Richard E. Lingenfelter. Illustrated. 664 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. $39.95.

title: GARDNER'S POSTHUMOUS NOVELS
description: To The Editor:

title: U.S. Women Row to Gold
description: The United States won gold medals in the lightweight fours without coxswain and lightweight double sculls today as the women's titles were decided at the world rowing championships.

title: Gas Leak at Chemical Plant Closes 3-Block Area on L.I.
description: The Nassau County police closed off a three-block industrial area here early today after they discovered gas leaking from a 2,500-gallon holding tank at a chemical company.

title: REDDING DOES SO LIKE MARK TWAIN
description: WHAT'S all this ruckus about not liking Mark Twain? If you read last week's essay by William H. Honan, ''Mark Twain Takes On Redding and Loses,'' you'd think we were a bunch of rubes too mean-spirited to honor one of the nation's greatest writers in his own town. Nothing could be further from the truth.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: An outgrowth of the Second Carnegie Inquiry Into Poverty and Development in Southern Africa (the first Carnegie inquiry 60 years ago focused exclusively on the white poor in South Africa), SOUTH AFRICA: THE CORDONED HEART (Gallery Press/ Norton, Cloth, $25. Paper, $14.95) is a book of photographs and accompanying text edited by Omar Badsha.

title: TAKE A LOOK: JIMBO AND CHRIS
description: ONCE upon a time they were a couple, engaged champions dancing at the Wimbledon victory ball in 1974 to the tune of ''The Girl That I Marry,'' celebrating their first Wimbledon singles titles.

title: REAL-ESTATE BOOM STIRS EAST END
