description: THE East End is in the throes of a real-estate boom that has rapidly escalated prices, increased demand for development and put growing pressure on local groups seeking to preserve open space.

title: Geralyn B. Orlovitz Weds Michael L. Rubenstein
description: At Temple Beth El in Stamford, Conn., last night, Geralyn Beth Orlovitz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Orlovitz of Greenwich, Conn., was married to Michael L. Rubenstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley E. Rubenstein of Great Neck, L.I., and Danbury, Conn. Rabbi Alex J. Goldman performed the ceremony.

title: John Watkins Is Married To Ms. Corsi in Maryland
description: At the Potomac (Md.) United Methodist Church yesterday, Kathleen Corsi and John Winslow Watkins, candidates for M.B.A. degrees at the Amos Tuck School of Business Administration at Dartmouth College, were married by the Rev. Timothy Funk.

title: VALLONE NAMES EX-FOES TO HEAD NEW PANELS
description: Ignoring the political tradition of rewarding friends and punishing enemies, Peter J. Vallone, the City Council majority leader, has created six new committees and turned them over to Council members who fought his rise to leadership in January.

title: Recent Sales
description: Metuchen $149,900 295 Middlesex Avenue *2*3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 60-year-old two-family; *2*fireplace, stone corridors, dishwasher; taxes $2,555. title: STATE EFFORT TO SAVE FARMLAND GAINING
description: CONNECTICUT has purchased the development rights to 13 farms in the state so far this year under its farmland preservation program, more than in any previous single year and about the same number that was purchased during the program's first six years combined.

title: ALABAMA PLAYER IS DECLARED DEAD
description: Willie Ryles, a University of Alabama defensive tackle who suffered a blood clot in his brain earlier this week, is brain dead and will be taken off life-support systems, doctors said today.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''What's seductive about it is, in a word, that it's simple.''

title: BONN, FEELING PRESSURE OF VOTERS, IS TRYING TO CURB REFUGEE INFLUX
description: In the face of grass-roots opposition to asylum-seekers from the third world, the West German Government has taken steps to discourage unwanted immigration.

title: VILLAGE AND SHELTER FIGHT ON EXPANSION
description: FIVE years after the village of Pleasantville lost a legal battle to prevent the establishment in the community of a shelter for abused women, the municipality is back in court trying to stop the 12-bed facility from expanding.

title: ANNUAL FAMILY VISIT REMEMBERED
description: THE annual family visit. The members included Aunt Kitty, Uncle George, Cousin Mildred, Mom and Dad and Grandma.

title: PASSAGE TO THE END OF INNOCENCE: SUMMER CAMP
description: Dear Mom and Dad, I'm having a good time here at camp. I've made some friends. The food is good. Today I went sailing. Write! Love, Colin

title:
GARDENING;
A BATTLE PLAN FOR THE WAR ON WEEDS
description: ANYONE who has pulled weeds on a hot August day will know what God had in mind when, as recorded in Genesis, He expelled Adam and Eve from the Garden of Eden with the exhortation that they would have to work and sweat to make the soil productive. In fact, it was also predicted that weeds and thorns would be around to make the job that much harder.

title: In Europe, Their Reception Is Bleak
description: Some 50,000 Tamil refugees have made their way from Sri Lanka to Western Europe in the last five years by elaborate air routes that sometimes include covert passage in trains or in cars that slip across frontiers at night.

title: Dana Katzman Married
description: The marriage of Dana Beth Katzman and Randi Glenn Wiston, graduates of the University of Rochester, took place last evening at the Rye Town Hilton in Rye Brook, N.Y. Rabbi Jack Stern Jr. performed the ceremony. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. David H. Katzman of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Mr. and Mrs. Sidney A. Wiston of North Valley Stream, L.I.

title: MOSCOW MAY BE READY TO DEAL ON ARMS CONTROL
description: THE idea that economic problems will impel Moscow toward making important compromises in the Geneva arms talks persists in the arms control debate. President Reagan himself gave support to this view when he said he was ''optimistic that we're going to make more progress than probably has been made in a number of years because of some of the problems that are concerning the General Secretary at this time.''

title: The Gorton-Adams Contest
description: After a quiet spring in which even the most ardent of their number despaired of wresting back the Senate seat formerly held by the venerable Warren G. Magnuson of Washington, the Democrats now believe they have a chance.

title: POSTURING
description: It increases muscular strength. It reduces tension and stress. It has a low potential for injury, and it doesn't even look like exercise.

title: FINANCING GUBERNATORIAL ELECTIONS
description: LAST January, the New Jersey Election Law Enforcement Commission held a public hearing on the state's gubernatorial financing program.

title: CANADA HONORS THE EXPLORERS
description: Similarity between the stamps of Canada and those of the United States is reinforced in a forthcoming Canadian explorers block to be released next Friday. It comes less than three months after the release of a United States block of four explorers stamps.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''States should establish a fair, measured process of review against standards, remedial planning and additional assistance, but with a final recourse to direct state intervention in the school district.

title: FOR FUND GUESTS, FAREWELLS CAN BE DIFFICULT
description: The three buses unloading smiling Fresh Air Fund children at the George Washington Bridge terminal last Monday had just returned to New York City from towns in Lancaster County, Pa., as pretty as their names - Pearl Bottom, Bird in Hand, Christiana and even Paradise.

title: LUCAS CREDITS FITCH
description: In his first public appearance since being released by the Rockets last March 14 because of cocaine abuse, John Lucas delivered a speech on Friday in Houston to the Teen Symposium for a Healthy Lifestyle in which he credited Coach Bill Fitch with saving his life. After the 32-year-old guard was released from the Rockets at Fitch's insistence last March because he failed a urine test for drug use, he immediately entered a drug-treatment program in California, something he had also done two years earlier with the Rockets.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in this section on July 20 about orphan drugs stated an incorrect figure for the number of Americans suffering from Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease. Between 50,000 and 100,000 Americans have the disease.

title: 'BREAKFAST,' A COMEDY
description: ''BREAKFAST With Les and Bess'' is a slight comedy by Lee Kalcheim that is currently receiving a first-rate production by the Arena Players Repertory Company in East Farmingdale.

title: RURAL VERMONT BEARING BRUNT OF NUCLEAR FAILURES
description: Andrew O. Butler remembers when the Vermont Electric Cooperative first brought power to his family's farm, 38 years ago, and how electricity gradually took over the backbreaking jobs of milking the cows, moving the feed, cleaning the barn and a host of others.

title: Drug Tests and The Bureaucracy
description: First the Cabinet, then the bureaucracy. That seemed to be the thinking behind a Justice Department plan under consideration at the White House that would require drug testing for Federal workers having access to sensitive material - or about 1.5 million of the 2.8 million civilian employees.

title: Martinez Clinches Title
description: Jorge Martinez of Spain clinched the world title today in the 80-c.c. class, finishing second to Pier Paolo Bianchi of Italy in the Grand Prix of San Marino, the 11th event of the world motorcycling championship. With only one world race still to go, Martinez has an unbeatable lead of 94 points.

title: U.N.'s Bloated Bottom Line
description: The United Nations bureaucracy, which has grown to 11,000 staff members, dozens of them high-salaried Under Secretary Generals and Assistant Secretary Generals, and an annual budget of $832 million, has long been criticized by the 10 governments that are billed for 74 percent of the total. Their fiscal concerns, which until recently carried little weight in the 159-member General Assembly, seemed last week to be getting more attention.

title: Virginia Ann Sweeney Wed to Michael McGovern
description: Virginia Ann Sweeney, a daughter of Dr. Eleanor M. Sweeney of New York and the late Humbert F. Sweeney, was married yesterday to Michael John McGovern, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James M. McGovern of Bronxville, N.Y. The Rev. John Costello performed the ceremony at St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church in Manhattan.

title: HOUSTON MAYOR STIRS ILL WILL OVER DISMISSALS
description: A wildcat walkout by city sanitation workers has ended, but some ill feelings linger as a result of Mayor Kathy Whitmire's refusal to rescind the dismissal of 91 employees.

title: GIVING UP A TERRORIST LIFE
description: ''There is a rhythm to armed fighting that is hard to break,'' Antton Alcocer Gabaldon was saying of his years as a terrorist.

title: CANSECO'S DOUBLE DOWNS YANKS, 2-1
description: Wasted opportunities. There have been so many for the Yankees this summer, and last night there was another. Their offense was reduced to a bases-empty home run by Willie Randolph in the sixth inning, and then they lost the game in the ninth, falling by 2-1 to the Oakland A's at the Stadium.

title: DRUG TESTING
description: The Anxiety and Depression Clinic in White Plains is looking for about 60 depressed Westchester residents who would be willing to try a new antidepressant drug, Tomoxitene.

title: U.S. AGENCY CITES LOW PAY IN NURSE SHORTAGE
description: The National Institutes of Health, unable to recruit enough skilled nurses to work under a Government pay scale that is $5,000 below Washington-area standards, says it has been forced to close 5 percent of the beds in its world-renowned clinical research center.

title: Less Isn't Always Better
description: IN the last few months, more real-estate agencies have started to promote the fact that they will negotiate their sales commissions rather than charge the industry's prevailing rate of 6 percent.

title: Court Nominees Cannot Plead Judicial Privilege
description: To the Editor:

title: Home Is Where One's Head Is
description: This is in response to the Aug. 10 article ''Finding Beauty, Seeking Roots,'' by Anthony Brandt.

title: Topics
description: SINCE I am now 8 1/2 years old, I am now eligible for football!'' My son had made his grand announcement. I thrust out of my mind all sorts of sarcastic and witty replies and in a moment of philanthropic splendor replied, ''Great, I'll even buy you kids a football.''

title: Martha McNamara Married in Darien
description: Martha Jeanne McNamara, a daughter of Francis J. McNamara Jr. of Darien, Conn., and the late Noreen E. McNamara, was married yesterday to James Richard Bordewick Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bordewick of Edina, Wis. The Rev. Francis E. Virgulak performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in Darien.

title: Plumbing the Past for Business Quotes
description: Money Talks: The 2,500 Greatest Business Quotes from Aristotle to Iacocca, edited by Robert W. Kent. Pocket Books, N.Y. 341 pages, $7.95 (paper).

title: Hard-Disk Help for 'Pile Builders'
description: MANY years ago, just out of college, I applied for a job as a line management trainee. Following a pleasant interview, I was given a tour of my potential colleagues' offices.

title: ETHIOPIA HINTING AT POLICY CHANGES
description: Military rulers in this nation often characterize Ethiopians as ''backward,'' and most often use the term in trying to explain why failed policies of the feudal past require a Marxist solution.

title: CANDIDATES BARNSTORMING STATE SEEKING G.O.P. VOTES
description: As the days to the primary election of Sept. 9 grow shorter, the schedules of the three Republican candidates for Governor are growing longer.

title: UNABASHED ROMANTICISM WAS ROMBERG'S SPECIALTY
description: As the centenary of Sigmund Romberg's birth approaches, his resolutely romantic operettas are fascinating new generations of listeners and producers. The chamber-sized Light Opera of Manhattan won favorable comment a year ago for the addition of ''The New Moon'' to its repertory, and on Tuesday the New York City Opera is to revive the 58-year-old work in a big-scale new production at Lincoln Center's State Theater.

The investigation, by the film director King Vidor, of a celebrated Hollywood murder case. 9 MURROW: His Life and Times, 10 6 by A.cM. Sperber. (Freundlich/Kampmann, $25.) The career of the CBS newscaster. 10 WHEN ALL YOU'VE EVER WANTED 9 19 ISN'T ENOUGH, by Harold S. Kushner. (Summit, $16.95.) A rabbi on ''the search for a life that matters.'' 11 THE MAN WHO MISTOOK HIS WIFE 11 21 FOR A HAT, by Oliver Sacks. (Summit, $15.95.) Strange neurological disabilities. 12 THE UNDERGROUND EMPIRE, by James 12 6 Mills. (Doubleday, $22.95.) How the global war on the drug trade is being waged - and is being stymied by diplomats and bureaucrats. 13 THE PASSION OF AYN RAND, by 2 Barbara Branden. (Doubleday, $19.95.) The life of the author of ''The Fountainhead'' and founder of a cult. 14 A LIGHT IN THE ATTIC, by Shel 15 171 Silverstein. (Harper & Row, $13.50.) Light verse, with drawings by the author. 15 IN SEARCH OF THE TROJAN WAR, by 13 8 Michael Wood. (Facts on File, $22.95.) Archeologists' search for the truth behind the Homeric legend; tie-in to a PBS series. Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 THE ROTATION DIET, By Martin 1 14 Katahn. (Norton, $15.95.) A regimen based on the Vanderbilt University Weight Management Program. 2 FIT FOR LIFE, by Harvey 2 53 Diamond and Marilyn Diamond. (Warner, $17.50.) A diet for weight loss and physical fitness. 3 CALLANETICS, by Callan Pinckney 3 39 with Sallie Batson. (Morrow, $17.95.) Exercises designed to enable women to look ''10 years younger in 10 hours.'' 4 MEDICAL MAKEOVER, by Robert M. 5 6 Giller and Kathy Matthews. (Beech Tree/Morrow, $16.95.) A ''no-willpower program for lifetime health.'' 5 WEBSTER'S NINTH NEW COLLEGIATE 61 DICTIONARY. (Merriam-Webster, $14.95.) A standard reference work in a revision that was made in 1983. And Bear in Mind

title: WETLANDS LAW
description: To the Editor:

title:
DINING OUT;
INDIA HOUSE RETURNS WITH FLAIR
description: FULLY recovered from the fire that forced its closing for six months, India House has been reconstructed in its vivid polychromatic splendor. It is a pleasure to report that the brilliant patchwork canopies and charming pictures have been restored, and the food, as richy variegated as the decor, is better than ever, every dish marked by tantalizing complexities of flavor.

title: GOVERNORS SEEK GREATER AUTHORITY OVER OPERATION OF PUBLIC SCHOOLS
description: The nation's governors called today for a radical restructuring of the public school system, including legislation that would give the states authority to declare districts that fail to meet basic standards ''bankrupt,'' then take over and reorganize them.

title:
GARDENING;
A BATTLE PLAN FOR THE WAR ON WEEDS
description: ANYONE who has pulled weeds on a hot August day will know what God had in mind when, as recorded in Genesis, He expelled Adam and Eve from the Garden of Eden with the exhortation that they would have to work and sweat to make the soil productive. In fact, it was also predicted that weeds and thorns would be around to make the job that much harder.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: WHEN Mark Twain decided to write about his hometown of Hannibal, Mo. - literary base for the adventures of Tom Sawyer and Huckleberry Finn - he chose a different name for that frontier village.

title: JAZZ: FESTIVAL BEGINS IN GREENWICH VILLAGE
description: THE Greenwich Village Jazz Festival opened Friday afternoon with three floors of free music at the Village Gate - and from the first notes, the place was packed. The festival encourages fans to visit the Village's jazz clubs through discounts and special programs, and Friday's program was a pretty fair sampling of Greenwich Village jazz.

title: NEWARK TO DISPLAY ITS CULTURE
description: THIS city will hold its second annual ''Festival of People'' - a showcase of its diverse cultures in a daylong celebration of the city's 150th anniversary of its incorporation - on Sept. 13.

title: Michele E. Arrix Wed To Terrance Whelan
description: Michele Elizabeth Arrix, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Arrix of New Canaan, Conn., was married there yesterday to Terrance Michael Whelan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Whelan of Hamilton, Mass. The Rev. James Grasso performed the ceremony at St. Aloysius Roman Catholic Church.

title: Why It's Better to Memorize in Japanese
description: To the Editor:

title: HABITS OF EXCESS: PHILOSOPHY AND PERSONALITY
description: SOME friends of mine who rented a summer house on Martha's Vineyard were pleasantly surprised to find among its furnishings a large and unusually erudite library - one that included a leather-bound volume of Pascal in French and another of Hegel in German. They were even more surprised to learn from their landlord that these books had been left behind by the previous owner. A professor at an Eastern university, he simply said that he didn't want them any longer.

title: Walter Brooke Is Dead at 71; A Stage, Movie and TV Actor
description: Walter Brooke, who began his acting career on the Broadway stage and appeared in 45 movies and hundreds of television shows, died here Wednesday. He was 71 years old.

title: Karen E. Kremer Becomes a Bride
description: Karen Emery Kremer, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Carl P. Kremer Jr. of Darien, Conn., was married there yesterday to Paul Allen McCulley, a son of Rev. and Mrs. Everett C. McCulley of Verona, Va. The Rev. Robert Nelson Back performed the ceremony at St. Luke's Episcopal Church.

title: Mary Bowditch And S. W. Allen Exchange Vows
description: Mary Dodge Bowditch, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick F. Bowditch of New York, Waterbury, Vt., and Point O'Woods, Fire Island, L.I., was married yesterday to Samuel Wilder Allen, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas E. Allen of St. Charles, Ill. Bishop John S. Spong of the Episcopal Diocese of Newark performed the ceremony at the Church of Point O'Woods.

title: MASSACRE AT A POST OFFICE
description: A FEW people said there was nothing strange about Patrick Henry Sherrill. A high school coach remembered him as ''easygoing.'' His Marine Corps record was clean. The Oklahoma National Guard had given him a good-conduct ribbon and allowed him to check out weapons, including two .45-caliber handguns and ammunition for a guard marksmanship contest he was to participate in next weekend.

title: PONIES -- INSURED -- RETURN TO PARK
description: RICHARD GENTILE peered excitedly between the legs of adults and older children for a glimpse of the pony he was going to ride.

title: PORTLAND, ORE.
description: From the Willamette River on a clear afternoon, Big Pink, the marble and reflective glass headquarters of U.S. Bancorp, stands guard above downtown, and walkers pause to lean over the seawall at Tom McCall Waterfront Park to watch the passing boats and barges. To the east, Mount Hood glows like a frosted blush rose, and, to the northeast, Mount St. Helens looks more like an overturned tea cup than a natural powerhouse.

title: James Ryan Wed To Susan Cronan
description: At St. Joachim's Roman Catholic Church in Rockport, Mass., yesterday Susan Christine Cronan, an associate in equity capital markets at the First Boston Corporation in New York, was married to James John Ryan, a vice president in corporate finance at First Boston. The Rev. Laurence Cedrone performed the ceremony.

title: EVERY PIANO IS A SOCIETY
description: THE SEVENTH DRAGON The Riddle of Equal Temperament. By Anita T. Sullivan. Illustrations by Sarah Bienvenu. 104 pp. Lake Oswego, Ore.: Metamorphous Press. $12.95.

title: TO THE MANNER BORN
description: Fashion, at its deepest and most personal level, is fantasy. Through it we play out a dream vision of the life we long for, often one at the furthest possible remove from our ''real'' life. For years, late-night discos all over the country have been full of stock clerks dressed as Hell's Angels and bank trainees disguised as streetwalkers or flamenco dancers. Now there is a new version of the same phenomenon: the passion of the urban American meritocracy for the costumes of the rural British aristocracy.

title: Susan Vaught Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. James Allison Vaught of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Marie Vaught, to Greggory Mark Baars, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernhard Ernst Baars of Dallas.

title: ANOTHER COLLEGE WILL OFFER A COURSE ON HOW TO BE A NANNY
description: IN response to the growing need for skilled in-home child care generated by the increasing number of two-career couples, Brookdale Community College here will offer a 100-hour training program for nannies next month. A similar program began at Union County College in Cranford this past spring.

title: THE ANCHORS
description: After more than a year of television monitoring as the editor of the Network News Report, a service that keeps track of all stories run on the ABC, CBS and NBC evening newcasts, I've decided no one network is consistently better at anything. I no sooner decide CBS has begun to emerge as a clear winner in economic coverage than it drops the ball for an entire week, only to bounce back the next, higher than ever.

title: POSTINGS: Yonkers Turnaround; Hospital Condos
description: The six-story building, the former Yonkers Professional Hospital, has been vacant for six years, contributing to the overall impression of decay in Southwest Yonkers. ''An abandoned building of this size attracts nothing but undesirables,'' said Kurt J. Wittek, a 26-year-old developer from South Norwalk, Conn.

title: BEHIND THE HARMS CENTER'S GRIFFIN
description: THE griffin - that mythological figure with the body and hind legs of a lion and the head and wings of an eagle - was known in classical antiquity as a guardian of the treasures of the gods. It has been referred to not only in Greek literature, but also by writers and artists through the ages - Dante, William Blake and Lewis Carroll, to name a few.

title: AGENT ORANGE AND THE ANGUISH OF AN AMERICAN FAMILY
description: WHEN ELMO RUSSELL ZUMWALT 3D WAS a 23-year-old Navy lieutenant, he patrolled the rivers in South Vietnam, where the dense green jungle hid snipers preying on American crews. To reduce casualties, the area was systematically stripped bare by mists of the chemical known as Agent Orange. Elmo's father, Adm. Elmo Russell Zumwalt Jr., as commander of the American in-country naval forces in South Vietnam, was the one who ordered this defoliation in 1968.

title: Speaking With One Voice on South Africa
description: The Senate left for home last weekend after an arduous and emotional debate over American policy toward South Africa. What was the message it left behind? In sum, it sent a very strong signal of its intent to President Reagan, and asked him to move against South Africa's white racist regime more quickly and decisively than he has.

title: UNDEFEATED GULCH WINS THE HOPEFUL
description: Gulch, the nation's leading 2-year-old, won his fourth start without a defeat in scoring a 2 1/2-length victory over Persevered in the $166,200 Hopeful Stakes today at Saratoga Race Track.

title: INSURANCE BILL IN DELAWARE AIMS TO 'MOTIVATE' HEALTH
description: Clean living may bring its own rewards, but a bill expected to become law in Delaware soon would reward ''healthy life-style behaviors'' with a reduction in medical insurance premiums or a direct rebate.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: SEEGER AND GUTHRIE

title: A BIG YEAR, TOO, FOR TED WILLIAMS
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: No, but I Read the Autograph

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: NICOBOBINUS By Terry Jones. Illustrated by Michael Foreman. 175 pp. New York: Peter Bedrick Books. $16.95. (Ages 10 and up)

title: POP: SIMPLY RED, WITH SOUL
description: THE English pop sextet Simply Red, which recently enjoyed a No. 1 United States single, ''Holding Back the Years,'' represents one of the most successful recent examples of the continuing English fascination with American soul music.

title: Gardening In the Sky
description: Those of us who are lucky enough to garden in the sky love to read about other terrace gardens (''3 Terraces,'' by Carol Vogel, Home Design, Aug. 3). The terraces featured in Carol Vogel's article were interesting and quite lovely.

title: ANOTHER LITTLE LEAGUE TITLE FOR TAIWAN
description: The 40th Little League World Series concluded here today with all-American pageantry and an internationally flavored championship game between Tainan City of Taiwan and Tucson of Arizona.

title: NEW YORK INSPECTORS CITE 17 FOOD OUTLETS FOR HEALTH OFFENSES
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 17 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: BEAUTIFUL REFUSERS
description: LETTER FROM CASABLANCA By Antonio Tabucchi. Translated by Janice M. Thresher. 122 pp. New York: New Directions. Cloth, 7.95. Paper, $7.95.

title: Carolyn Brooks Is Wed To a Cinematographer
description: Carolyn Brooks, a daughter of Rae Eastman of West Cornwall, Conn., and John Brooks of New York and North Haven, L.I., was married yesterday to David Gasperik, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Elmer Gasperik of Chicago. Edward W. Horn, Town Justice of East Hampton, L.I., performed the ceremony at the North Haven home of the bride's father.

title: TAMILS FLEE UNCERTAIN SRI LANKA FUTURE
description: Three years of growing violence in a country that was once South Asia's model of ethnic harmony has driven more than 300,000 Sri Lankan Tamils from their homes as refugees, according to estimates from Government officials and human-rights groups.

title:
CHILDREN'S BOOKS;
WHAT IS FIT FOR CHLDREN
description: NORMA KLEIN has written more than 25 books for children and young adults, many of which deal with childhood sexuality, nontraditional families and other controversial subjects. Her first children's book, ''Mom, the Wolf Man and Me,'' appeared in 1972. A story about the daughter of an unmarried, sexually active woman, it was quickly attacked for its subject matter. A number of Ms. Klein's other popular books have been removed from library shelves around the country. Indeed, according to an American Library Association listing of censored titles, she is among the most banned authors in any category: nine of her books have been banned. (In response to the increase in censorship activities by school boards, libraries and other groups in recent years, a coalition of organizations, including the A.L.A., the American Booksellers Association and the Association of American Publishers is sponsoring the third annual Banned Books Week from Sept. 20 through 27, which this year will emphasize censorship in the sciences, beginning with Copernicus and Galileo.) Mark I. West, a professor of English at the University of North Carolina, Charlotte, interviewed Ms. Klein in New York City about censorship and her work.

title: Jennifer Coyle Weds William Moseley
description: The marriage of Jennifer Alison Coyle and William Noyes Moseley, 1985 graduates of Lake Forest College, took place yesterday at St. Michael's Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich, Conn. Msgr. Thomas Guinan performed the ceremony.

title: WATCHING THE RHINE
description: The big river would seem to hold no mystery. One block from our house in Bonn, the Rhine slips along, fast, fat and confident in the winter and spring, trimmer in summer, right to left, toward Cologne, the Netherlands and the North Sea. It's familiar. I jog along the esplanade by the Rhine, ride my bike, walk the dog, who is bemused by the ducks clucking in the eddies, salute promenading friends and acquaintances who, too, have struck a certain easy rapport with this big brown ribbon of water that is wound around the romantic innards of the German soul.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: WINTER'S CHILD. By Dea Trier Morch. Translated by Joan Tate. (University of Nebraska, $19.95.) Dea Morch is a Danish writer with an acute eye and ear for the way people talk, look and act - in this case women in a hospital ward for problem pregnancies.

title: Archivists Reply
description: To the Editor:

title: Where Steak and Lobster Reign
description: THE Hedges Inn in East Hampton opened early in July under the management of the Palm. It could be called Palm Too, for the branch of the Palm in Manhattan.

title: BRINGING THE BOMB UP FROM THE BASEMENT
description: SECURITY OR ARMAGEDDON Israel's Nuclear Strategy. Edited by Louis Rene Beres. 242 pp. Lexington, Mass.: Lexington Books/D.C. Heath & Company. Cloth, $25. Paper, $12.95.

title: THE BAROQUE: RECORDER, FLUTE AND OBOE
description: For many readers, the word ''recorder'' will evoke a room full of 8-year-olds seated cross-legged in a circle, playing ''Au clair de la lune'' on plastic instruments in several competing tempos and keys simultaneously. One forgets that, despite its relatively low cost and the ease with which simple tunes can be learned on it, the recorder is an utterly serious instrument, with a history going well back into the Middle Ages. In the Baroque era, in fact, music of high virtuosity was composed for it, and it is from that period that most of the well-known recorder music comes.

title: A BASEBALL ERA ENDS IN WATERBURY
description: BASEBALL fans in Waterbury were to bid farewell to what may be their last minor league team today, the last scheduled date for Waterbury Indians of the Eastern League at Municipal Stadium.

title: Visiting Wineries
description: LONG ISLAND'S wineries are open for visiting and offer tours and tastings as well as wine for sale. Wine can even be purchased on Sundays.

title: Crew Safe as F-14 Crashes
description: An F-14 from the aircraft carrier America crashed at sea today, but both crew members ejected safely and were picked up by helicopter a short time later, United States officials said. They did not identify the crew or the area where the carrier was cruising when the crash occurred.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE CORRESPONDENCE OF FLANNERY O'CONNOR AND THE BRAINARD CHENEYS. Edited by C. Ralph Stephens. (University Press of Mississippi, $24.95.) The Flannery O'Connor industry is only beginning to gear up.

title: CONFUSION CLOUDS RIGHT-TO-KNOW LAW
description: THE final, most controversial provision of the 1983 Right-to-Know law - the requirement that the contents of all containers in the workplace be labeled - takes effect Friday the way every other provision in that landmark statute did: late, incompletely and amid much confusion.

title: 8 MORE VICTIMS OF OKLAHOMA SHOOTING ARE BURIED
description: Eight more burials were held today for victims of the mail carrier at the Edmond Post Office who killed 14 co-workers before taking his own life.

title: PAKISTAN'S RESTIVE ETHNIC AREAS TUG AT GENERAL ZIA'S CONTROL OF THE CENTER
description: FLAGS of opposition parties fluttered from housetops last week in this port city and in the countryside of Sind Province, as anti-Government rioting spread through southeastern Pakistan. Among the most prominent was the tricolor of the secessionist movement known as Long Live Sind.

title: Mona Perry Bienfait Weds
description: At Christ's Episcopal Church in Rye, N.Y., yesterday Mona Perry Bienfait, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles C. A. Bienfait Jr. of Rye, was married to Lieut.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: IN THE AIR

title: HE WHO IS IN CHARGE OF ALL THE PRESIDENT'S CAKE
description: Like many other Washingtonians, Roland Mesnier carries with him a bulky briefcase that holds the tools of his trade.

title: Brykt Wins First Time As a Pro in Bicycling
description: Twenty-two-year-old Stefan Brykt of the Bianchi team scored his first victory as a pro today when he won the 105-mile Morgul-Bismarck road race, the next-to-last stage of the Coors International Bicycle Classic.

title: DATA UPDATE: August 24, 1986
description: (Source: Bureau of Labor Statistics) *Five counties of New York City plus Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester, Rockland, Putnam, Bergen, Essex, Morris, Union, Hudson, Middlesex, Somerset and Passaic. #1 Index: December 1982 -100 #2 Index: 1967 -100

title: Fed Again Nudges A Drifting Economy
description: The Fed tried again to stimulate the economy with another half-point cut in the discount rate, to 5 1/2 percent. It acted the day after the Government reported that the G.N.P. grew at an incredibly slow six-tenths of 1 percent rate in the second quarter, not the 1.1 percent rate estimated earlier. But the fourth discount rate cut this year is unlikely to do much, many analysts say, because of pressures from imports, uncertainties over what the tax bill will do to capital spending and a general stubbornness of the economy. Indeed, big banks, usually quick to respond, did not immediately cut their prime rate.

title: CLASSICAL RECORDS ARE BIG BUSINESS IN NEW YORK
description: Nationally, classical music seems very much a minority art; elitist, even. Perhaps the most dramatic indication of that is classical music's slice of the total annual record sales pie, including LP's, CD's and cassettes. For years, the figure has hovered around 4 percent, only slightly larger than jazz.

title: Melinda Mitchell To Become Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Don S. Mitchell of Summit, N.J., have announced the engagement of their granddaughter Melinda Mitchell to John D. Shumway Jr., a son of Dr. and Mrs. Shumway of Cheshire, Conn. A November wedding is planned.

title: What Price the Meese Test Plan?
description: The Department of Justice is pushing the White House to order narcotics testing for more than half of all the Government's civilian employees - about 1.5 million people, most of them innocent of any connection with illicit drugs.

title: Lynne Sussman And Phillip Hyde Engaged to Wed
description: Leonard R. Sussman of New York has announced the engagement of his daughter, Lynne Sussman, to Phillip Hyde, the son of Laurin E. Hyde of New York and the late Marian Hyde. The wedding is planned for Nov. 9.

title: AFRICAN NATIONS PRAISE SANCTIONS BUT DON'T JOIN IN
description: Six of South Africa's black-ruled neighbors have issued a statement here praising Zimbabwe and Zambia for imposing sanctions against South Africa, but stopped short of moving as a group to impose similar sanctions.

title: LONG ISLANDERS
description: MANY people have a favorite photograph of themselves - and in the case of such celebrities as Bill Bradley, Peggy Fleming, Joe Frazier and Frank Sinatra, to name but a few, the photograph has been taken by George Kalinsky.

title: DATA BANK: August 24, 1986
Victoria Jennings Weds D. E. Ross
description: Victoria Brewster Jennings and Dennis Earl Ross were married yesterday at the Franklin (Mich.) Community Church by the Rev. Dr. Samuel F. Stout, a United Methodist minister.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: FOCUS ON PHOTOGRAPHY The Westchester Photographic Society has scheduled a lecture series for amateur photographers in conjunction with its exhibition opening Wednesday at the New Rochelle Public Library. More than 20 members of the society have placed their 1986 prize-winning photographs on view through Sept. 17. A display of old cameras and a variety of photographic and darkroom technical exhibits accompanies the show.

title: Average Westchester Sale Tops $300,000
description: ''I'D hate to have people think that $300,000 was the price of entry into Westchester,'' said P. Gilbert Mercurio, executive vice president of the Westchester Board of Realtors, as he released the latest figures on home sales in the county.

title: Some Camp Sites Extend Season
description: ONCE again, New York State's Department of Environmental Conservation is keeping some of the public campgrounds it operates within the Adirondack and Catskill Forest Preserves open beyond the traditional Labor Day closing date, official recognition, if you will, of many outdoor enthusiasts' conviction that fall is the sweetest time of year to be afield.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Santa Barbara, Calif.;
A $25 Million Business Center
description: A RUNNING track, showers for joggers and bicyclists, and works of art installed around the work place are features of the University Business Center now under construction in suburban Goleta. The developers say it is the largest research and development project ever built in Santa Barbara County.

title: Helen T. Rollins Becomes a Bride
description: The marriage of Helen Tremaine Rollins and William Aborn Lord took place yesterday in the garden at Harbor Gables, the home in York Harbor, Me., of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Rollins. The bridegroom is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert M. Lord Jr. of Providence, R.I., and York Harbor.

title: Dead Youth Whose Organs Were Donated Is Eulogized
description: A 16-year-old boy whose major organs were donated to five people was eulogized today as someone who gave hope and inspiration to others.

title: GOOD FAMILY RECIPES
description: TONGUES OF FLAME By Mary Ward Brown. 162 pp. New York: Seymour Lawrence/E.P. Dutton. $15.95.

title:
FOCUS: RENT CONTROLS;
H.U.D. Role Irks Local Agencies
description: TWO rental housing conflicts here have sparked charges that landlords are trying to evade local rent regulations by entering a mortgage-insurance program run by a Federal agency with the power to pre-empt rent controls.

title: Soviet Asks To Attend GATT Meeting
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev's campaign to defrost Soviet relations with the outside world advanced on several fronts last week.

title: WHERE TO TAKE RIDING LESSONS
description: THE following stables are among those in the county that offer lessons to the public:

title: COUNTRY SINGERS AND MEN
description: To the Editor:

title: HABIB CAPTURES ROOSEVELT TROT
description: Ulf Thoresen, who won world driving championships three times in Europe and once in Australia, made harness racing history tonight at Roosevelt Raceway. Thoresen, who is 40 years old, followed up his Aug. 2 Hambletonian victory by winning the $250,000 Roosevelt International Trot. He became the first driver to have winners in both races in the same year.

title: Executive Is Wed To Mrs. Bodman
description: Elizabeth N. Bodman of Scarsdale, N.Y., a trust administrator for the Chemical Bank in New York, was married yesterday to Richard F. F. Nichols Jr. of Darien, Conn., and Londonderry, Vt., chairman of Van Cleef, Jordan & Wood, investment advisers in New York. The Rev. Wallace Matsen performed the ceremony at the North Congregational Church in Woodbury, Conn.

title: JERSEY ORDERS VAPOR TRAPS ON ITS GAS PUMPS
description: New Jersey, facing a loss of Federal funds for not meeting a December 1987 air-quality deadline, has ordered gasoline stations to install equipment to trap noxious vapors released by their pumps.

title: DAISIES ARE DANDY TO DECORATE SUMMER BORDERS
description: There is no denying the appeal of daisies. As a group, daisies belong to large Sunflower Family (Compositae) which includes over 20,000 species, making it the largest group of flowering plants. The family is so large, in fact, that botanists have divided it into several ''tribes.''

title: NEW FACE IN SCHOOLS DISPUTE
description: AFTER a long search, Port Washington has hired a new school superintendent, and many residents hope that the step will end a series of bitter disputes involving the community's schools.

title: GOTHAM RESTORATION IS ON AGAIN
description: THE rehabilitation of the Gotham Hotel, the stately Fifth Avenue landmark that has been jinxed almost from its turn-of-the-century opening, is under way again, five years after the last attempt at restoration failed and left its handsome Beaux Arts fac,ade a boarded-up eyesore.

title: HEALTH PLANS ARE FEELING A LITTLE PEAKED
description: ROBERT HALEY said he panicked when the LTV Corporation, the giant steel maker, filed for protection under Federal bankruptcy laws last month and cut off health benefits for 78,000 retired employees. Mr. Haley, who worked for 31 years in LTV's Indiana Harbor mill south of Chicago, immediately postponed a double hernia operation because he said he could not afford it without insurance.

title: Karin S. Hawley Becomes a Bride
description: The marriage of Karin Seelmann Hawley, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. F. William Hawley of Greenwich, Conn., to Gregory Scott Beaulieu, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Beaulieu of South Windsor, Conn., took place yestereday at the First Presbyterian Church in Greenwich. The Rev. Richard Stearns performed the ceremony.

title: HOW A JUDY FREAK TURNED INTO A JUDY
description: CALL it a recreation, a performance or a tribute. But, insists Julie Sheppard, the 34-year-old singer-actress from the Essex County community of Belleville, her cabaret act - ''Julie, Julie, Julie'' - is not an impersonation of Judy Garland.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
ROOM WITH A VIEW
description: RODNEY GRIFFIN likes ''The Transformers.'' You might even say he loves ''The Transformers.'' In fact, he never misses an episode of the television cartoon show, even though it is broadcast during his working day.

title: MAKING SCENTS
description: Jill Resnick has not yet insured her nose with Lloyd's of London, but she's thinking about it.

title: THE CHALLENGE OF CHANGE
description: The problem today is that science and technology have far outpaced our society.

title: Dr. J. A. Boyce to Wed Deborah Roby Sept. 20
description: Mr. and Mrs. Vic Roby of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deborah E. Roby, to Dr. Joshua A. Boyce, the son of Lois Swirnoff of Brookline, Mass., and Los Angeles, and the late Richard Boyce. The wedding is planned for Sept. 20.

title: THERE'S NO COURTESY BUS TO THE U.S. OPEN FINAL
description: THE Pageantry. The Pomp. The Splendor. The Majesty. Oops. Wrong tournament.

title: FOR POLICE CADETS, A CRASH COURSE IN REALITY
description: Carlton Williams remembers an emotionally disturbed man who was banging his head against the ground. Thomas McManus remembers a bloody fight between two storekeepers in Queens. And Desiree Mejias recalls her first trip to the morgue.

title: NEW CHIEF SEES WEST POINT UPSWING
description: The United States Military Academy's new superintendent, Lieut. Gen. Dave R. Palmer, reached for a nautical image. The 184-year-old institution, he said, was a ship that had been through a storm but now was sailing in calmer waters.

title:
ON LONG ISLAND;
Wainscott Working to Keep Its Heritage
description: LOOKING toward Sagaponack, residents of the East Hampton hamlet of Wainscott decided some time ago that they did not like what they saw: expanses of very modern, individualistic and expensive summer homes soaring up at odd angles from former farm fields and seemingly marching Wainscott's way.

title: Patricia Zigarelli Engaged
description: Dr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Zigarelli of Mendham, N.J., and Delray Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter Patricia Ann Zigarelli to Steven Avery Smith, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Conley Avery Smith of Morganton, N.C. Miss Zigarelli is national sales manager for WRQX Radio in Washington. Her fiance is vice president of engineering for the Capitol Broadcasting Company and director of engineering for Brookville Realty Inc., both in Washington.

title: A FILM MAKER EVOKES THE WORLD OF FRANKFORT-ON-THE-HUDSON
description: In 1936, when Manny Kirchheimer was 5 years old, he and his family fled Hitler's Germany and settled in the Washington Heights section of Manhattan. They were not alone - by 1950 there were 20,000 Jews in Washington Heights, most of whom had come to this country from Germany between 1933 and 1941.

title: ENJOYING THE VIEW FROM RETIREMENT
description: I AM not, by nature, a rebellious man, but shortly after my 53d birthday, I began to feel that the mainstream of life had become too narrow and directional. I had been practicing dentistry in a small town in New Jersey for 26 years, beginning each down-in-the-mouth day among the ivories of some terrified patient. There must be, I told myself, something more to life than that.

title: THE ANCHORS
description: I don't care who reads the news as long as he speaks correctly, clearly and concisely.

title: Party Conflict
description: In the fall of an election year, Washington fund-raising affairs tend to compete with one another, sometimes even in the same political party. The Democratic National Committee has scheduled its annual $1,000-a-ticket gala for Sept. 24 at the Washington Hilton, and the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee, working feverishly to capture a Senate majority in November, is having its own $1,000 dinner in the Capital Hilton just six nights later.

title: Tourism Hurt in France
description: French tourism earnings fell five billion francs this summer season because of a sharp drop in the number of American visitors, Francesco Frangialli, director of tourism, said today. Mr. Frangialli said that many Americans had been kept away from France and other European countries by the weakness of the dollar.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Mr. Rehnquist's Opinion
description: Supporters of William Rehnquist's promotion to Chief Justice have not yet answered a serious charge against him: that he cast the deciding vote in a major case that he publicly prejudged before going on the Supreme Court.

title: First-Round Matchups
description: MEN

title: Work at 11 Deere Plants Halted After 3 Are Struck
description: Deere & Company announced today that it was shutting down production at 11 factories because of a strike by 4,300 union workers at three other plants.

title: President Quits At Winnebago
description: Gerald W. Gilbert, chief executive of Winnebago Industries, the nation's leading manufacturer of motor homes, has assumed the additional title of president.

title: RUNDOWN OF EVENTS IN CHAMPIONSHIPS
description: Of the 16 events scheduled in the world cycling championships, 12 will be held at the outdoor 7-Eleven Velodrome and four on the road at the Air Force Academy.

title: OPERA: CHANGES IN 'CARMEN'
description: THE New York City Opera's production of ''Carmen'' received a new title character, Don Jose, Micaela and Escamillo on Saturday night.

title: RECORDS: MEASURING SUCCESS
WOMEN, SUCCESS AND ROMANTIC ADVICE
description: The setting is a therapist's office. An attractive young woman who owns her own business is lying on the couch. Tears well in her eyes as she describes to the therapist her latest romantic disaster. Once again she has become involved with a Mr. Wrong. Once again she is feeling depressed about a relationship gone awry. She reaches for a tissue and asks the therapist in a plaintive voice, ''What am I doing wrong?''

title: Spreads Fall on Local Issues
description: Competition for new municipal bond issues has heated up to such an extent that securities dealers are reducing their charges on new bond underwritings.

title: Inkster Posts 209 To Win by 3 Shots
description: Juli Inkster broke open a close tournament with birdies on the 11th and 12th holes to beat Patti Rizzo by three shots today in the first $225,000 Atlantic City Classic.

title: BALLET: CANADIAN TROUPES PERFORM AT WOLF TRAP
description: Three Canadian ballet companies got together on Saturday night at Filene Center at Wolf Trap Farm for what was billed as a ''Canadian Ballet Extravaganza.'' One of the three American premieres presented had an unusual set. A strong breeze pressed rather dramatically through the open-air theater during an intermission. But that was as close as the evening got to extravagance or even anything more than mildly interesting.

title: Notre Dame Star Hurt in Car Crash
description: David Rivers of Notre Dame, one of the nation's top college basketball players, was seriously injured early today when he was thrown through the windshield of a van driven by a former teammate, Ken Barlow.

title: 30 YEARS AS NO. 2 IN WASHINGTON STATE
description: Britain, France and Israel were fighting Egypt over the Suez Canal. Pope Pius XII and William F. Knowland, the Senate Republican leader, made speeches critical of the Soviet invasion of Hungary. Dwight D. Eisenhower was re-elected to a second term as President.

title: USX Closure Seen Negatively
description: The recent ruling by Pennsylvania officials that the work stoppage at the USX Corporation was a lockout and not a strike has reinforced analysts and industry officials' predictions that the shutdown of the nation's largest steelmaker will be lengthy and damaging.

title: OPERA: A NEW CAST IN 'PEARL FISHERS'
description: THE City Opera's second cast for ''The Pearl Fishers'' appeared Friday night, and the best impression was made by Rachel Rosales, a young soprano in her second season here, as Leila. She is not yet a fully developed singer, but she has the instinct to make phrases, the absorption to win sympathy in a role that is not especially sympathetic on the page, and the imagination to attempt truly vocal communication with the audience. One hopes the company will nurture her toward the potential she disclosed at this performance.

title: Drayton Wins
description: Buster Drayton of the United States retained his International Boxing Federation super-welterweight title tonight, defeating Davey Moore when the referee stopped the fight in the 10th round.

title: BANK LAW SEEN NEAR IN TEXAS
description: A bill still under debate that would permit out-of-state banks to acquire Texas banks as soon as Jan. 1 is expected to be signed into law by Gov. Mark White Jr. before the end of this week, according to bank executives, lawyers and analysts here.

title: TOMORROW IS ANOTHER... BUDGET
description: The never-ending search for ways to trim military spending without giving up any beans or bullets has led the Pentagon into a show of fiscal legerdemain. Or is it ledger-demain?

title: Pirates' Manager Will Return in '87
description: Jim Leyland, the Pittsburgh Pirates' rookie manager, will return next season under an extension of his one-year contract, Leyland and General Manager Syd Thrift said today.

title: JET CORNERBACKS POSE PROBLEM
description: Their names are Jim Kelly, Tony Eason, Dan Marino and John Elway, and they have something in common besides having been first-round quarterbacks in the 1983 draft.

title: TOOLS OF A JURY: DIET PEPSI, THE DRIFTERS AND NOTES TO THE OUTSIDE
description: The jurors in the trial of John J. McLaughlin, the former president of the city's sealth and Hspitals Cororporation, arrived for their fifth day of deliberations early yesterday - singing the old Drifters hit ''Under the Boardwalk.''

title: U.S., Taiwan Talks Set
description: Negotiators for the United States and Taiwan open talks Monday expected to center on American demands that Taipei open its markets to United States cigarettes, wine and beer on favorable terms or face retaliation.

title: WHY HOUSING ACT OF 1986 ISN'T
description: Time is running out on the 99th Congress.

title: Power to Share
description: To the Editor:

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: The last-place team in the American League East this year has been playing near .500 ball. Has a season ever ended with all of a division's teams above the .500 mark?

title: Next Chief Chosen At Ocean Spray
description: John S. Llewellyn Jr. has been named to succeed the president and chief executive officer of Ocean Spray Cranberries Inc. During a transition period he will be executive vice president and chief operating officer, reporting to Harold Thorkilsen, who retires in December 1987.

title: Advertising; Hal Riney, From Coast To Coast
description: HAL RINEY, newly freed from his ties to the Ogilvy Group, is going national.

title: TENNIS, CITY STYLE
description: THE smell of a charcoal-broiled hamburger wafts over an open court. The wheels of the elevated train grinding to a halt at the Willets Point Station echo in the distance. Jet planes from La Guardia roar overhead, only several hundred feet above what must look like DecoTurf II runways from the air. On occasion, a public telephone rings. ''It must be your broker.''

title: Of Bus Drivers And Sewer Workers
description: Nearly 1,500 people stood in the Felt Forum in Madison Square Garden on Saturday and intoned in unison: ''One of these days - one of these days - POW! Right in the kisser!''

title: BIG WARNER HOLDER FOUGHT SHARE PLAN
description: In what appears to be the latest indication of friction between Chris-Craft Industries and Warner Communications Inc., Chris-Craft's six representatives on Warner's board voted last week against a proposal by Warner to sell $500 million of a new series of convertible preferred stock. The vote was disclosed in documents filed Friday by both companies with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: SUGGESTIONG THERAPY TO FRIENDS
description: IT happened high in the Colorado Rockies - his first anxiety attack.

title: CBS NEWS CHIEF RESPONDS TO CRITICISM
description: Van Gordon Sauter, the embattled president of CBS News, defended yesterday the decisions that have brought his leadership into question, and warned his detractors inside the news division that their complaints had assumed ''an unbecoming strain of petulance and self-righteousness'' that threatens to further damage the organization.

title: FITZGERALD AND PETERSON PERFORM AT WOLF TRAP
description: VIRTUOSIC, high-spirited jazz takes the stage in ''Ella Fitzgerald and Oscar Peterson On Stage at Wolf Trap,'' tonight at 9 o'clock on Channel 31. Mr. Peterson's flashy piano style and Miss Fitzgerald's exuberantly swinging vocals are perennial crowd-pleasers, and even in these routine performances, videotaped last year, they tickle the ear.

title: ASTROS' 5-1 VICTORY ENDS SLIDE
description: Jim Pankovits tied a career best with four hits and Dickie Thon had two singles and drove in two runs today to help the Houston Astros snap a three-game losing streak with a 5-1 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday

title: Suite 1112, Where Are You?
description: The Independent Counsel in the Michael Deaver investigation has been operating in a fashion more curious than anyone who has ever been in that low-oversight post.

title: YANKEES ROUTED; RELIEVERS FAIL IN 11-4 DEFEAT
description: The afternoon seemed to drift away slowly, turning from a day of promise to just another untimely defeat in the Bronx. The Yankees lost another game and another chance to gain some ground yesterday. Worse, they also lost their indispensable third baseman.

title: Corporate Pace Expected to Ease
description: The hectic pace of corporate bond financing last week, when new investment-grade issues totaled nearly $4.8 billion, is not expected to continue this week, as vacations decimate the ranks of corporate finance officers, underwriters and investors.

title: THE PAIN AND PLEASURE OF MOVING TO NEW YORK
description: TWO questions were on the mind of everyone at the seminar.

title: THE EMPTY CUBICLE
description: THE locker cubicle of Joe Morris in the Giants clubhouse in the Meadlowlands Saturday evening contained 1 name plate (20, Morris) 4 pairs of football shoes, 1 crumpled sweat suit in two halves, 4 hangers, 2 pairs of white sweat socks, 1 bottle of skin lotion, 1 stick deodorant and 0 Joe Morrises.

title: Courting Success
description: Is there really a home court advantage? That is a perennially popular question among statisticians, who over the years have conducted a variety of studies that have variously verified and debunked the persistent belief that a team enjoys an edge on its home turf.

title: NO INCREASE IN SPENDING EXPECTED
description: Even if interest rates drop further in coming days, capital spending, which has been depressed, is unlikely to revive any time soon, business analysts say.

title: 8 Climbers Killed in Alps By Unexpected Blizzards
description: Sudden blizzards killed at least eight climbers in the Austrian Alps this weekend and four more just over the border in West Germany, the police in the two countries said today.

title: BRADBURY TRANSFORMS 'FAHRENHEIT' FOR MUSICAL
description: Ray Bradbury, the author of hundreds of short stories, novels, screenplays, television mini-series, murder mysteries and poems, was here at the Eugene O'Neill Theater Center the other day trying his hand at something rather unexpected. A musical. ''It's important to be able to fail again,'' explained the prolific 66-year-old science-fiction writer who has been so successful at other forms. ''To fail and then succeed. It keeps me alert.''

title: SoHo Intact; Expressway Buried
description: Lower Manhattan Expressway.

title: GUNMAN WOUNDS FIVE ON L.I.
description: Five people, including a 6-year-old boy, were shot by a gunman in a Hempstead, L.I., auto repair shop, and a Freeport man was arrested in the shootings, the Nassau County police said yesterday.

title: NBC's Stereo Plan
description: The NBC television network said Friday that it would begin airing commercials produced in stereo sound, starting next month. ''Being able to implement their commercials in stereo should be a boon to the advertising community, which will now have the capability of adding diverse audio effects to their creative bag of tricks,'' said Michael J. Sherlock, an executive vice president at NBC.

title: HARD-LINE PALESTINIANS REJECT UNITY WITH ARAFAT
description: An attempt to close Palestinian guerrilla ranks has collapsed after hard-line factions based in Syria rejected reconciliation with the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, Yasir Arafat.

title: A Change of Leagues
description: While many of his fellow Princeton graduates took their diplomas in June and plunged into the Wall Street world of investment banking or crisscrossed the European countryside before beginning graduate or professional school, Eric Dreiband was determined to play football.

title: History, by Way of Bellevue
description: When the Smithsonian Institution decided to put on an exhibition that traces the development of medicine in the United States and the philosophy that all citizens are entitled to medical care, free of charge if necessary, it turned to Bellevue Hospital in New York for artifacts, photographs and, most of all, history.

title: MAC'S BACK IN TOWN
description: SOME of his more memorable moments have come at the United States Open, trading diatribes with Jimmy Connors, perservering against the ghost-like image of Bjorn Borg - the stoic Swede - standing across the net in the eerie twilight on the climactic Sunday. When John McEnroe won the Open for the first time in 1979, it was evident the championship was a perfect fit. On anyone else, it would need tailoring.

title: THE STATE FAIR SHOWS RUSTIC SIDE OF DETROIT
description: Not far from the glass towers and abandoned back lots of downtown Detroit, Shirley Wall milked her first cow, Orson edged out Checker in a hog race and Ryba's rum black walnut fudge was disappearing nearly as fast as the corn dogs.

title: U.S. PROTESTS SET OFF STORM
description: United States protests over what it says was the torture of an American narcotics agent by policemen in Guadalajara this month have raised a political storm here over the activities of the Drug Enforcement Administration.

title: Market Place; Warning Signs In Rate Cuts?
description: AT what point do falling interest rates stop flashing a green light for stock investors and start signaling economic distress? This question was raised again by market analysts after last Thursday's half-point cut in the Federal Reserve discount rate, to 5 1/2 percent.

title: DOING IT THE NAVY WAY
description: ONE of the most exotic acts of the summer is the gyration dance of the Navy Department, trying to stretch its rules by posting Ens. Napoleon McCallum close to the Los Angeles Raiders' camp, but with hours that can only frustrate all parties.

title: GOALS FOR HIRING TO STAY IN PLACE
description: White House advisers have delayed a recommendation for President Reagan to eliminate or amend an executive order requiring goals for hiring women and members of minority groups because of recent Supreme Court decisions upholding some affirmative action plans, according to the President's chief of staff.

title: SRI LANKA AND TAMILS ARE HOPEFUL ON EVE OF TALKS
description: The Government of Sri Lanka and a Tamil party are to begin a round of talks on Monday that both sides view as critical in determining whether a political solution to the country's ethnic violence is still possible.

title: WOMEN, BLACKS, SPOUSES TRANSFORMING THE MILITARY
description: In the 13 years since the United States ended the draft and returned to volunteer military service, blacks, women and young married people have transformed the nation's armed forces.

title: Redeinstitutionalization
description: The euphemists in New York State's Office of Mental Health call it ''reconfiguration of services,'' but it's a suspicious echo of a major policy fiasco known as ''deinstitutionalization.''

title: Of Budget Bills and Triggers
description: When Government officials announced last week that a Gramm-Rudman-Hollings sequester - the buzz word for mandated spending cuts under the budget-balancing law - would total $19.4 billion, that news coincided with the report that the second-quarter gross national product grew at an annual rate of only six-tenths of 1 percent.

title: AQUINO VISITS INDONESIA IN FIRST TRIP AS LEADER
description: President Corazon C. Aquino traveled to Indonesia today, leaving the Philippines for the first time since she came to power and brushing aside warnings of possible disturbances here during her absence.

title: The U.N. Today: Aug. 25, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Preparatory Commission for International Seabed Authority and Law of the Sea Tribunal - 10:30 A.M.

title: A TALENTED, COLORFUL CAST OF CHARACTERS
description: HANA MANDLIKOVA

title: MANDLIKOVA: FROM THE HEART
description: EVERYONE has known someone like Hana Mandlikova. She was the mischievous child who crossed the street just after her mother said not to. Or the stubborn adolescent who sneaked to the one movie her parents said she couldn't see. Now, those free-spirited youngsters have grown up to become the adults who always speak their mind, no matter what the consequences. You know the kind.

title: Yankees' Burns Optimistic
description: The visitor wore street clothes and carried a cane. He was supposed to be here the entire season, but this was the first time Britt Burns had come to New York and watched the Yankees play.

title: U.S. BANKS ADJUST FAST IN GERMANY
description: The West German Bundesbank has gone far in recent months to loosen securities markets, and an increased flow of underwriting and new financial products has American banks positioning themselves to benefit from the changes. Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York is issuing Germany's first mark-denominated certificates of deposit, and American banks joined last month in the first issue of mark-denominated Eurobonds since the Bundesbank lifted restrictions on foreign bank participation. Until now the banks could only trade bonds on the secondary market.

title: BUSINESSES FARMS FEED ARE COLLAPSING IN SOUTH
description: Here and across the South, in the areas hardest hit by drought, the historic spirit and economic structure of the region's agriculture are breaking down.

title: Not Wailing Wall
description: To the Editor:

title: Manville Plans Trust Fund
description: The Manville Corporation, the Denver-based maker of building products that is emerging from Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings, said Friday that it would establish a trust fund to pay off property damage claims against the company related to the use of asbestos in schools and other buildings.

title: Continental, United to Help
description: United Airlines and Continental Airlines said yesterday that they would begin accepting passengers ticketed on Frontier Airlines if there were space available, and subject to certain other conditions.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Aug. 25, 1986: Standard ProductsWatkins-Johnson United Illuminating CTUESDAY L

title: SATELLITE PHOTOS APPEAR TO SHOW CONSTRUCTION OF SOVIET SPACE SHUTTLE BASE
description: In the closest glimpse yet of a secret Soviet program, a private company yesterday released five satellite photographs showing large buildings and a long runway in central Asia that are apparently key support facilities for a space shuttle that is under construction.

title: Fortier, Aide to Reagan, Dies
description: Donald R. Fortier, the No. 2 member of the National Security Council staff and a top aide to President Reagan, died Saturday night at Georgetown University Hospital.

title: THOMAS EAKINS PROFILED ON 'AMERICAN MASTERS'
description: ''AMERICAN MASTERS'' continues tonight with a chapter on Thomas Eakins. The painter, scarcely recognized in his lifetime, is now widely praised. In death, apparently, he has triumphed over critics, bluenoses and other arbiters. ''American Masters,'' Channel 13's anthology series about our native-born and adopted geniuses, will be seen at 9 o'clock.

title: FOR POLICE, IT'S LUNCH AND RUN
description: Nobody knows the flavors of New York's neighborhoods better than the city's 21,197 ''constables on patrol'' (origin of the word cop). Yet no group is more frustrated when it comes to actually sitting down to a meal.

title: Settlement in Concert Death
description: The family of Wesley Allen Shelton, who was stabbed to death at a concert by the Rolling Stones in 1981, will receive a $4.7 million settlement, lawyers said. Most will be paid by Pace Concerts, which promoted the show, said Ed McAninch, an attorney for the Sheltons. The family said in their suit that security had been inadequate.

title: U.S. OPEN: A Talented, Colorful Cast of Characters; AND HOW TO WATCH THEM PLAY
description: IN ANY MATCH IN THE UNITED States Open Tennis Championships, the battle is fought on two fronts: technical and mental. By paying close attention to certain details, you can learn to recognize the subtle shifts in each area of the competition and get a truer appreciation of why one player wins and the other loses.

title: WORLD SERIES GOLF IS TAKEN BY POHL
description: Danny Joe Pohl, known to his friends as just plain Dan, hit into the woods and bounced out of the woods, hit into four bunkers, missed all but seven greens in regulation and drove onto only four fairways in an unusual victory march over the 7,139-yard Firestone Country Club South Course today.

title: BIG PARTIES, BIG ONIONS AND JUST MAYBE BIGFOOT
description: This city's favorite landmark, the Golden Gate Bridge, will be 50 years old on May 27, and in anticipation of the anniversary, San Franciscans are embroiled in a stormy feud over who may give it a birthday party.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: POSTCARDS This is the having-a-wonderful-time-wish-you-were-here season, the message scribbled on postcards by vacationers to those left behind, who like as not throw them away after glancing at the likenesses of distant land- and seascapes. It's a pity, because postcards are little historical documents of the times in which they are made. Any doubts that this is so are put to rest by a visit to the Gotham Book Mart Gallery, one flight above the wonderful bookshop at 41 West 47th Street (719-4448).

title: New Dr Pepper Owners Succeed on Second Try
description: Thomas O. Hicks and Robert B. Haas, the principals behind the Dallas investment firm of Hicks & Haas, are among the new owners of Dr Pepper, as well as its new co-chairmen.

title: PRESIDENT ENDORSES RISE IN U.S. SPEED LIMIT
description: President Reagan has endorsed ''in principle'' the call to repeal the nation's speed limit of 55 miles an hour and favors allowing states to set their own speed laws, the White House said today.

title: Christmas Spectacular
description: Christmas is still months away, but tickets will go on sale Wednesday at 8 A.M. for the ''Magnificent Christmas Spectacular'' at Radio City Music Hall, Avenue of the Americas and 50th Street.

title: CHERNOBYL BLAST LAID TO NEW CAUSE
description: As more than 500 scientists from 50 countries began converging here today to examine the Chernobyl nuclear disaster and how it can be used to improve nuclear safety, new information emerged on the cause of the accident.

title: CADBURY'S DR PEPPER ROLE CITED
description: Cadbury Schweppes P.L.C., the British company that has been aggressively building its soft-drink business in the United States, will announce soon that it is a member of the group that is purchasing Dr Pepper, the nation's fourth-largest soda company, sources said yesterday.

title: Officer Acquitted of Murder Gets His Pension Reinstated
description: An Allentown police sergeant who was found not guilty by reason of insanity in the slaying of his lover has won the right to a pension.

title: 2 INFANT CHILDREN DIE IN FIRE
description: Two infant children died and a third child was critically injured last night in a fire that swept through their family's two-story frame house at 1621 Melville Street in the Van Nest section of the Bronx, fire officials said.

title: LAST WAVES CHIEF
description: Capt. Joy Bright Hancock of the Navy, the third and last director of the Women's Reserve of the Naval Reserve, or the WAVES. died last Wednesday at Bethesda Naval Hospital. She was 88 years old and lived in McLean, Va.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * American Express Travel Related Services Co., a subsidiary of the American Express Co., has named Kenneth I. Chenault executive vice president, general manager of the Platinum/Gold Card division.

title: No Headline
description: The last time Steffi Graf was faced with conditions as gusty and unpredictable as those here this afternoon, she lost -to a table. That was last month in Prague when a strong wind blew the heavy, metal piece of furniture onto her right foot, breaking her toe and threatening to end what had been a year of surprising success for the 17-year-old West German.

title: HINAULT WINS IN COLORADO
description: Bernard Hinault ended his illustrious career as a bicycle stage racer here today by winning the 16-day Coors Classic.

title: Democrats Offer a True Alternative to Reagan's Foreign Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: SQUEEZE ON GULF COAST UTILITY (uf878)
description: Squeezed by the high costs of a new nuclear plant, a faltering regional economy and angry customers who have beaten back its bids for higher electrical rates, Gulf States Utilities is mired in deepening financial problems.

title: The Machine That Foils Phone Intrusions
description: To the Editor:

title: LETHAL GAS FROM NATURE
description: In heavy concentrations, hydrogen sulfide gas is extremely poisonous. It is sometimes a hazard in mines that have deposits rich in sulfide ores.

title: MAN, 29, IS CHARGED WITH MURDER IN L.I. BLAZE THAT LEFT FOUR DEAD
description: A 29-year-old Copiague man was arrested early today and charged with murder and first-degree arson in a boarding-house fire that killed four people in Massapequa on Saturday.

title: Martha Angus Weds Dr. C.J.F. Flach
description: Martha Elizabeth Angus, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Duncan Angus of Prescott, Ariz., was married yesterday to Dr. Christopher John Frederic Flach, a son of Patricia Kane Flach of New York and Amagansett, L.I., and Dr. Frederic F. Flach of New York. The Rev. William Roberts performed the ceremony at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York.

title: Alice J. Hausman Weds Jesse Berlin
description: The marriage of Alice J. Hausman, director of research for the health promotion program for urban youth at the Boston Department of Health and Hospitals, to Jesse Aaron Berlin, an independent biostatistical consultant in Boston, took place yesterday at Le Chateau in South Salem, N.Y. Rabbi Maurice Davis performed the ceremony.

title:
U.S. OPEN;
PAVING THE WAY TO A TITLE
description: DECOTURF II sounds like something Andy Warhol would put on his yard, if he had a yard. It is the playing surface at the National Tennis Center and a focal point of the United States Open, which begins tomorrow.

title: Irate Passengers Seek a Way Home
description: Long lines formed today at Denver's Stapleton International Airport, as passengers stranded by the shutdown of Frontier Airlines scrambled to make other travel arrangements.

title: Precedent for Profit
description: Apparently, success in the courtroom can be a mixed blessing. At least that is what one of Jan Kemp's attorneys said he has discovered since May 6, when her freedom-of-speech suit against the University of Georgia was resolved in her favor to the tune of $1.08 million.

title: JOHN CAUFIELD, A STATE SENATOR AND FIRE DIRECTOR OF NEWARK
description: John P. Caufield, the assistant leader of the Democratic majority in the New Jersey Senate and longtime Fire Director of Newark, died yesterday at St. Mary's Hospital in Orange. He was 67 years old and a resident of Newark, his native city.

title: AID TO FARMERS: CURE OR BAND-AID?
description: A decision by President Reagan on farm aid will cost the Government hundreds of millions, save many farmers thousands of dollars, save some of their farms and in some instances ease a threat of deepening distress for some rural communities.

title: LaRouche Ally Is Fined $500
description: The Democratic nominee for Secretary of State in Illinois has been fined $500 for presenting a slab of raw liver to a Roman Catholic Archbishop as a protest. The nominee, Janice Hart, a supporter of the political extremist Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr., was fined Thursday after her conviction of disorderly conduct stemming from the incident on May 7, 1985. She said she presented the liver to Archbishop Rembert Weakland of Milwaukee to protest what she said was his support for the International Monetary Fund.

title: F. PALMER WEBER, 72, IS DEAD
description: Frederick Palmer Weber, a prominent labor and civil rights activist in the 1940's who later helped organize business people against the Vietnam War, died Friday. He was 72.

title: THE INTOLERABLE HORROR OF LEGALIZED KILLING
description: The death penalty is again cracking the surface of public complacency. On the West Coast, an impassioned campaign has challenged the re-election bid of Rose Bird, Chief Justice of the California Supreme Court, largely because of her apparent aversion to enforcing the state's power of execution.

title: MONEY'S SWIFT MATCHMAKERS
description: On Wall Street, nine firms that most Americans have never heard of, employing hundreds of hyperactive brokers, are helping to keep New York in the thick of the worldwide financial action.

title: ISRAELIS STILL SEE FUTURE FOR TALKS WITH SOVIET
description: Israeli officials say that the discussion begun in Helsinki between Israel and the Soviet Union will continue in the coming year, but that its pace and scope will probably be determined largely by the Soviet Union.

title: Gulf Canada Shuts Operations in Beaufort Sea
description: The Gulf Canada Corporation, which early this year found the largest oil field yet discovered in the oil-rich Beaufort Sea of the Arctic Ocean, has decided to temporarily shut its operations there because of the depressed price of crude oil.

title: Sara Geffen Is Bride Of Leon Alan Geller
description: Sara Jane Geffen, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Abraham Geffen of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married at Beth El Synagogue there yesterday to Leon Alan Geller, a son of Philip Geller of Newton, Mass., and the late Ruth Geller. Rabbi Melvin Sirner performed the ceremony.

title: INDIANS BEAT RED SOX FOR NIEKRO'S 310TH
description: Joe Carter and Julio Franco hit two-run home runs today to support the six-hit pitching of Phil Niekro and Frank Wills and lead the Cleveland Indians to a 5-2 victory over the Boston Red Sox.

title: Open Performances
PARISH HELPS SAVE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: All her life, 40-year-old Diana Burns has lived in the same frame house in a working-class pocket of northwestern Brooklyn, a place where residents can laze beside a backyard fig tree and see the skyscrapers of Manhattan. She has also gone to the same Roman Catholic church all her life, St. Nicholas.

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary of Roy M. Cohn on Aug. 3 misidentified a staff member of the High Commissioner for Germany who resigned during an investigation by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's subcommittee in 1953. The official, who admitted having signed a nominating petition for a Communist candidate for the New York City Council in 1939 but denied having been a member of the Communist Party, was Theodore Kaghan, not Peter Kaghan.

title: LENDL DOMINATES MCENROE TO WIN FINAL
description: Even after being away from tournament play for six months, John McEnroe says that on his better days he can still beat the world's best players. Today was not one of his better days, though, and unfortunately for McEnroe his opponent in the final of the $150,000 Norstar Bank Hamlet Challenge Cup was the best player in the world, Ivan Lendl.

title: FOR SOME, NO PLACE IS HOME
description: THEY are heroes in their homelands, loved, even idolized by their countrymen for the skill with which they ply their trade. Yet they are exiles, expatriates who either choose, or are forced, to abandon their native lands.

title: FRONTIER AIRLINES, PRESSED FOR CASH, HALTS ALL SERVICE
description: Frontier Airlines, a major carrier in the West, was shut down yesterday, stranding thousands of passengers, and causing uncertainty for the future of People Express, which owns the airline.

title: 2 RACES FOR CONGRESS STIRRING INTEREST
description: Of the 34 Congressional districts in New York, 12 have Democratic primary contests next month and one has a Republican primary race. Only two of those races, however, have markedly stirred constituents or party leaders, and Richard L. Weingarten would rather that his district was not one of them.

title: MEMORY DECLINE IN ELDERLY FOUND TO BE OVERSTATED
description: Memory loss in elderly people is not nearly as great as had been widely assumed by psychologists who study memory and aging, according to reports today at the annual meeting of the American Psychological Association.

title: How 'Moderate' Is Saudi Arabia?
description: Successive American administrations have encouraged the notion that Saudi Arabia represents a force for ''moderation'' in the turbulent Arab world. The desert kingdom is regularly described as ''peace-loving'' and dedicated to the Western cause.

title: AMARILLO, UP 36%, TOPS TEXAS CITIES IN CRIME RISE
description: People here could sense it happening, but the figures were still stunning: Amarillo, the chief city of the Panhandle, leads Texas in a sharp statewide rise in reported major crimes this year.
