title: DISPUTED UNION ELECTION IS EMBARRASSING U.A.W.
description: A dispute over a union election held in June is causing embarrassment and concern within the United Automobile Workers, a union intensely proud of its reputation for democracy and rectitude.

title: Outdoors: Harvesting Shellfish
description: OFTEN forgotten in the more dramatic quest for rod and reel quarry, shellfishing offers the summer seacoast visitor a readily available source of food and pleasure.

title: Report Says Pentagon Drains Farm Counties
description: The military budget drains $12 billion more from the nation's major agricultural counties than the Federal Government returns in military contracts and farm program payments, a study said today.

title: FOR BHUTTO, A BIG ISSUE IS HER SEX
description: In a country where men still tend to consider most women weak and ineffective, the most popular and charismatic opposition leader is a 33-year-old woman whose fiery oratory has brought cheers from millions of men.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, AUGUST 25, 1986
description: Companies

title: Pretoria vs. Churches
description: To the Editor:

title: PHILADELPHIA'S FESTIVAL: A FOLK RITE OF SUMMER
description: As the driving rain turned gullies into wide streams and hayfields into quagmires, Diane McGuiler ducked under a tarpaulin 15 years ago on the Old Poole farm near here.

title: Nuns Stand Firm In Rejecting Abortion Doctrine
description: To the Editor:

title: PHONE SUPERPOWER ARISING IN FRANCE
description: When France's State-owned Compagnie Generale d'Electricite took control of ITT's European telephone business last month to become the world's second-largest telecommunications supplier, reactions were quite different on the two sides of the Atlantic.

title: Catching Up
description: Dale Berra, who was batting .231 as an occasional shortstop when he was released by the Yankees a month ago, has been playing steadily and at many positions for the Houston Astros' Tucson club in the Pacific Coast League. Through Friday, he was batting .224 after six games at third base, five at second base, one at shortstop and three in left field.

title: U.S. AIDES SAID TO DOUBT SOME WALKER STATEMENTS
description: The Government wants to postpone the sentencing of John A. Walker Jr. because prosecutors need more time to determine if he is telling the complete truth about his Soviet espionage operation, according to law-enforcement officials and other sources.

title: NICARAGUAN ACCUSED AS U.S. SPY
description: The Interior Ministry said today that it had arrested a Nicaraguan who it said was working for the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: JAPANESE, CITING NUCLEAR BAN, PROTEST U.S. SHIPS
description: Port calls by United States warships touched off scattered demonstrations across Japan today as protesters accused the Americans of bringing in nuclear weapons in violation of Japanese policy.

title: Holly S. Stein, a Lawyer, Marries Dr. H.H. Sollod
description: Holly S. Stein, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Stein of New York and Palm Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Dr. H. Hershey Sollod, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Aaron Sollod of Baltimore. Rabbi Stephen Foster performed the ceremony at the couple's home in Evergreen, Colo.

title: Apartheid Foes' Good Intentions Aren't Enough
description: To the Editor:

title: Jaime M. Greenwald Wed To Mark D. Freudenthal
description: At the Shelter Rock Jewish Center in Roslyn, L.I., yesterday Jaime Michele Greenwald, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Milton S. Greenwald of North Bellmore, L.I., and Mark Darryl Freudenthal, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodor Freudenthal of Jericho, L.I., were married by Rabbi Myron Fenster.

title: HAITI'S PRESS IS UNSHACKLED, AND UNBRIDLED, TOO
description: Shortly before dawn on the morning of Feb. 7, Philippe Jean-Francois excitedly leaned close to the microphone at a radio station in Haiti and exclaimed: ''The dictator Jean-Claude Duvalier is gone! He is gone for good!''

title: Departure at D.D.B.
description: Michael Mangano, who has worked for Doyle Dane Bernbach for 21 years and who has most recently been executive vice president and creative director, is joining Warwick Advertising with the same titles. Mr. Mangano's move comes at a time of upheaval at D.D.B., which is about to complete its merger with Needham Harper Worldwide. At Warwick, Mr. Mangano will share the creative director job with Jerry Prestomburgo, who is also gaining the executive vice president title.

title: Problems Seen In Eastern Bid
description: The takeover of Eastern Air Lines Inc. by the Texas Air Corporation has run into problems, industry sources said Friday. They said the Department of Transportation has become concerned about the ability of Pan American World Airways Inc. to mount a viable shuttle service at La Guardia Airport by Oct. 1.

title: UNSETTLING DAYS FOR DORSETT
description: It's not as if there had never been trouble here in paradise before. Indeed, from Duane Thomas's icy silence to the debate over whether Danny White or Gary Hogeboom would be the starting quarterback, the Dallas Cowboys have always had enough controversy to keep the pot boiling.

title: Underconfident Pepper?
description: Perhaps one reason that Representative Claude Pepper of Florida has enjoyed an uninterrupted career of 24 years in the House is that he never takes anything for granted.

title: Abby Hamlin Married To Robert A. Kandel
description: Abby C. Hamlin, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Isadore Hamlin of New York, was married yesterday to Robert A. Kandel, a son of Miriam G. Kandel of Hewlett Harbor, L.I., and Palm Springs, Calif., and the late James J. Kandel. Rabbi Arthur Hertzberg performed the ceremony at the Sign of the Dove restaurant in Manhattan.

title: PRESIDENT OF ISRAEL PARDONS 7 MORE IN SECURITY SCANDAL
description: President Chaim Herzog granted pardons today to seven more members of Israel's domestic intelligence service in connection with the beating deaths of two Palestinian bus hijackers.

title: Heather Dembert Becomes a Bride
description: Heather Tobi Dembert and John Steven Rafter were married yesterday at the Prospect Club at Princeton University by Rabbi Irwin Fishbein. The bride is the daughter of Donald F. Dembert of Scranton, Pa., and Mrs. Sol A. Davidson of Princeton.

title: FINDING NEW INSIGHTS INTO A LONG-HIDDEN PROBLEM: ABUSE OF THE ELDERLY
description: For five years Mrs. K. endured constant verbal and physical abuse. When she tried to leave her Bronx apartment, she was thrown to the floor.

title: A Lobby's Salvo
description: The gun lobby is not famous for subtlety. The Citizens Committee for the Right to Keep and Bear Arms, in the latest issue of its monthly newsletter, ''Point Blank,'' reports that its national advisory council has ''dumped'' three members of Congress from membership.

title: CYCLING IN U.S. GAINING GROUND IN AN UPHILL CLIMB
description: AT first Alain Bondue was puzzled by the motorists here who kept giving him a thumbs-up signal as he trained for the world cycling championships, which begin Wednesday.

title: YANKEES ROUTED; KRUKOW HAS A 4-HITTER
description: This does not occur often, but every now and then the Mets take a break from their glory days and give way to another team's heroes.

title: WHAT WENT WRONG AT CHERNOBYL: FURTHER DETAILS
description: A closer reading of report's data by Western scientists finds that the first major explosion that spewed radiation into the air was steam, and not hydrogen, as initially believed. A hydrogen explosion followed.

title: Women Abducted in Escape Of 2 From Louisiana Prison
description: A murderer and an armed robber escaped from a Louisiana prison, abducted a woman and forced her to drive to Houston, where they abandoned her and kidnapped another woman, the police said today.

title: EX-PEACE CORPS TEACHERS TRAINED FOR CITY DUTY
description: Cathy Cross, 24 years old, fresh from two years as a Peace Corps volunteer in Botswana, is a scarce commodity: she wants to be a science teacher in a New York City high school.

title: ZAMBIAN SENDS NEW PLEA TO U.S.
description: President Kenneth D. Kaunda said today that he would ask President Reagan to meet with the leaders of South Africa's black-governed neighbors to develop a new policy toward the region.

title: Big Name And Short Road
description: Trans-Manhattan Expressway.

title: North Yemen Oil Plan
description: North Yemen is seeking Iraqi expertise to help set up industries to exploit crude oil discovered in commercial quantities in 1984, Sanaa Radio reported. It said Oil Minister Ahmed Ali al-Muhani raised the matter in talks with Iraq's Oil Minister, Qassim Ahmed Taqi, who arrived in Sanaa today. North Yemen opened its first refinery with a 10,000-barrel-a-day capacity in April and is planning a pipeline to the Red Sea that can handle 200,000 barrels a day.

title: STAGE: 'NICHOLAS NICKLEBY' RETURNS
description: ''THE LIFE AND ADVENTURES OF NICHOLAS NICKLEBY,'' which returned to Broadway yesterday, is, at the same time, an abundant evocation of the world of Charles Dickens and a converging of the acting, directing and design artistry of the Royal Shakespeare Company.

title: Shoshanah Kahn Is Wed
description: At the Kingsway Jewish Center in Brooklyn yesterday Shoshanah Esther Kahn and Yan Wolfson, who are entering the Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University later this month, were married by Rabbi Manfred Fulda. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. Eli Kahn and Dr. and Mrs. Yevsey Wolfson, all of Brooklyn. The bride and bridegroom graduated in June from Stern College for Women and Yeshiva College, respectively.

title: RETIRED LTV STEELWORKERS BATTLE TO AVERT LOSS OF HEALTH BENEFITS
description: In Youngstown, Cleveland, Buffalo and Chicago, hundreds of retired LTV steelworkers are organizing an unusual rally and petition drive. Their aim is to make sure that 78,000 retirees do not lose their health benefits as a result of the company's filing for reorganization under bankruptcy laws.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: FRANCE, FIN DE SIECLE. By Eugen Weber. Illustrated. 294 pages. Harvard University Press. $20. A HUNDRED years ago, the

title: Chernobyl's Cost - and Benefits
description: Radioactivity is fiercely hostile to life. It can kill and maim quickly, or plant the seed of a cancer that will strike years hence. The amounts released from nuclear power plant accidents or nuclear weapons imperil communities as far away as the wind carries. Yet almost every developed society now believes it can safely tap the deadly forces of the atom, whether for nuclear energy or strategic defense. Don't the horrors of the accident at Chernobyl, now newly detailed by the Soviet Government, shake that belief to its foundations?

title: Leana Moritt, an Executive Of Record Company, Weds
description: Leana Moritt, a daughter of Judge and Mrs. Fred G. Moritt of Mattituck, L.I., and Philip Wild, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Wild of Roslyn Heights, L.I. were married yesterday. Rabbi Aaron Petuchowski performed the ceremony at the Moritt home.

title: MACHINE TOOL ORDERS FELL BY 6 PERCENT IN JULY
description: New orders for American-made machine tools dropped 6 percent in July from June's level, according to a report to be released today by the National Machine Tool Builders' Association.

title: Christine Hyer Weds William Homer
description: Christine Datri Hyer, the daughter of Dr. Foster J. Datri of Bridgewater, N.J., and the late Jole Gallina Datri, was married yesterday to William Innes Homer, a son of Mrs. Austin Homer of Merion, Pa., and the late Mr. Homer. The Rev. Patricia Youngdahl performed the ceremony at the Third Presbyterian Church in Rochester.

title: Fires on the Cote d'Azur Kill 2, Force 2,000 to Flee
description: Walls of fire driven by high winds ravaged thousands of acres of forest and vacation land on the Cote d'Azur today, leaving two people dead and about 100 people injured, most suffering from smoke inhalation.

title: The Biden Home
description: When he arrived in the Senate from Delaware in 1973, Joseph R. Biden Jr. distinguished himself from colleagues by not buying a house in the Washington area, preferring to commute daily by train to his Wilmington home.

title: Dr. Rosenfeld Is Wed To Dr. Henry Pollack
description: The marriage of Dr. Suzanne Rosenfeld, a pediatrician in private practice in Manhattan, and Dr. Henry Pollack, a research fellow in pediatric infectious disease at New York Hospital and Rockefeller University, took place yesterday in the university's garden. Rabbi Gary M. Bretton-Granatoor performed the ceremony.

title: Underdogs To Watch
description: While not among the favorites, these players are worth keeping an eye on. HENRI LECONTE

title: Persian Gulf Meeting
description: Oil and foreign ministers from the Gulf Cooperation Council will meet in the Saudi Arabian city of Abha on Tuesday to plan strategy to protect their interests on the world oil market. A council statement today said that ministers from Bahrain, Kuwait, Oman, Qatar, Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates would also review recent attacks on merchant shipping in the Persian Gulf related to the Iran-Iraq war. So far this year, 57 tankers in the Gulf have been attacked.

title: Indian M.P. Apologizes, But Strike Continues
description: A Member of Parliament who burst into the central telephone exchange waving a pistol over a delayed phone call apologized today.

title: FREUD AUTHOR REBUFFED ON SEVERAL LIBEL POINTS
description: In 1984, Jeffrey M. Masson, a psychoanalyst who wrote a controversial book on Sigmund Freud, filed a $10 million libel suit against The New Yorker after the magazine published a two-part article that Mr. Masson said portrayed him as ''unscholarly, irresponsible, vain, lacking in personal honesty and moral integrity.''

title: IS OPEN CLOSED TO MOST FANS?
description: The adage about Carnegie Hall now also applies to hte National Tennic Center in Flusning Meadows. How does one get to the United States Open? Practice. Practice

title: Governors Anxious On Tax Legislation
description: The nation's governors wrestled with their misgivings about the Federal tax bill today, but they acknowledged that there was little they could do to reopen the debate in Washington.

title: Briefcases
description: * T. Boone Pickens is coming to the nation's capital to rally support for the American shareholder. This week, the Texas oilman and corporate raider will begin his United Shareholders Association campaign, which plans to lobby Congress and the Securities and Exchange Commission for greater management accountability.

title: FOR MANY TAXPAYERS, EASIER FILING
description: The hundreds of provisions in the tax revision legislation might seem to suggest that the original objective of simplifying the tax system had been lost amid the political compromises of the Congressional conferees.

title: GOLD FOR U.S. MEN'S CREW FIRST SINCE '74
description: The Penn Athletic Club from Philadelphia won the gold medal in the heavyweight fours without coxswain at the World Rowing Championships today, the first world rowing title for American men in 12 years.

title: Rangers Defeat White Sox, 3-2
description: Charlie Hough (11-8) and Mitch Williams combined on a four-hitter, and Don Slaught drove in the winning run with a fifth-inning single as Texas beat Chicago, 3-2, tonight. It was the Rangers' ninth victory in as many games against the White Sox this season.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article Saturday about the resignation of Stanley M. Friedman as chairman of the Bronx Overall Economic Development Corporation described the submission of his resignation letter incorrectly. It was submitted to the corporation's board.

title: PRIESTS LEARN LANGUAGES OF NEW IMMIGRANTS
description: The communion hymn was sung in Italian, the Gospel was read in Spanish, and the sermon was delivered in English.

title: Teacher Dies at Home Of Dustin Hoffman
description: A 43-year-old prep school teacher was found dead Saturday morning in a hot tub on an estate in Roxbury, Conn., owned by the actor Dustin Hoffman, the police said yesterday.

title: BABIES OF CRACK USERS FILL HOSPITAL NURSERIES
description: Nurseries of New York City hospitals are being overwhelmed by growing numbers of babies born to users of the drug crack, city officials and doctors say.

title: Kraft to Acquire Keeler
description: Kraft Inc., one of the nation's largest food distributors, has signed a definitive agreement to acquire Keeler Foods Inc., a food distributor based in Santa Ana, Calif., for $16.4 million in cash and notes. Keeler, which had sales of $84 million last year, distributes more than 8,000 items such as meats, seafood, dairy products, and kitchen appliances, to about 3,000 accounts.

title: Wider Job For Bally Executive
description: Richard Gillman, who has been chairman and chief executive officer of Bally's Park Place Casino Hotel in Atlantic City, was also named last week to be president of Bally's Grand Inc., operator of two casino hotels in Nevada.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We do many things at the Federal level that would be considered dishonest and illegal if done in the private sector.'' - Donald T. Regan, White House chief of staff, on the Federal budget. [ A14:2. ]

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, AUGUST 25, 1986
description: International

title: Khomeini Says Iran Must 'Finish Off' Iraqi
description: The Iranian spiritual leader Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini said today that Iran must reject any arbitration in the Persian Gulf war, fight until victory and ''finish off'' President Saddam Hussein of Iraq.

title: Shipwreck Kelly Dies; Football Star in 30's
description: John (Shipwreck) Kelly, a star running back at the University of Kentucky in the early 1930's whose marriage in 1941 to Brenda Frazier, a socialite heiress, received national attention, died of a stroke Aug. 17 in Lighthouse Point, Fla. He was 76 years old.

title: UPSTATE, NEW PERCH FOR AN OLD EAGLE
description: A huge cast-iron eagle that once perched atop the old Grand Central Depot in New York City has come to rest in this tiny Catskill hamlet.

title: Washington Watch; Popular Plan From F.D.I.C.
description: With the number of bank failures ap-proaching the 100 mark this year, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation has been having a harder and harder time finding willing buyers for the insolvent institutions.

title: Sarah Stern Is Wed To Mark Rosenblatt
description: The marriage of Sarah May Stern, a special projects manager for Newsweek magazine, to Mark Rosenblatt, a consultant for McKinsey & Company in New York, took place yesterday at The Temple, Congregation Ohabai Sholom, in Nashville. Rabbi Stephen Fuchs performed the ceremony.

title: ALABAMA'S SHULA PREPARED FOR CHALLENGE
description: The apprenticeship began when he was a 10-year-old ball boy chasing footballs at Biscayne College, then the Miami Dolphins' training camp. His father, Don, was and is the head coach of the Dolphins and his brother, David, older by six years, had paved the way before him.

title: BLACK POLICE OFFICERS CITE FRUSTRATIONS AMID GAINS
description: The tear gas, fire hoses and bloodied night sticks of America's race riots were vivid memories when a small group of black police officers gathered in St. Louis in 1972.

title: Transcontinental Road Completed in Utah
description: After 30 years and 55 days, Interstate 80 is now one uninterrupted 2,900-mile route, linking the country from the Embarcadero Freeway in San Francisco to I-95 in Teaneck, N.J.

title: SHOCKER T. WINS MORRIS ON LATE RALLY
description: The second-largest crowd in the history of Saratoga Race Track, lured by free umbrellas on a rainy day, watched Shocker T. have a tougher time than expected winning the $111,400 John A. Morris Handicap for older fillies today.

title: GIANTS' GROUND GAME STALLED
description: The Giants' running game is in trouble. Coach Bill Parcells admits it, though he says he is trying to avoid making hasty changes because he does not want to overreact.

title: RENT STRIKE CHALLENGES APARTHEID
description: In the evenings, Johannes Matemba said, he takes the foam mattress from his backyard and lays it on the floor of the house he has lived in for 33 years and sleeps on the concrete.

title: 2 TV STATIONS ASSAILED ON HIRSCHFELD AD RULING
description: Abraham Hirschfeld accused two local television stations yesterday of interfering with the election for lieutenant governor by taking his campaign commercials off the air before an appeals court has ruled on his candidacy.

title: Accounting for the Head-Counters
description: The City of New York has shown in court, and the Federal Government has conceded, that the 1980 census substantially undercounted the city's population. Studies indicate that approximately half a million New Yorkers were omitted by the 1980 census. In other words, the number of people missed in New York City exceeds the number of people counted in many other large central cities, including Seattle, Denver and St. Louis.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: U.S. Unwittingly Put Secret Data Up for Sale
description: The Air Force unwittingly allowed computer tapes containing secret data about military satellites, aircraft and missiles to be offered for sale at public auctions of office furniture and supplies, Air Force auditors say.

title: Bridge: Frank Stewart's New Book Gives Tips on Dummy Play
description: For those who wish to sharpen their dummy play a new book in quiz format will be a most desirable purchase. It is ''Frank Stewart's Contract Bridge Quiz Book,'' available for $10.95 from The Bridge World, 39 West 94th Street, New York, N.Y. 10025.

title: Amy-Jo Koslow Wed To Dr. Jeffrey Willig
description: Amy-Jo Koslow, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Koslow of East Norwich, L.I., was married yesterday to Dr. Jeffrey Lloyd Willig, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Willig of Bayside, Queens. Rabbi Joseph Sternstein performed the ceremony at Temple Beth Sholom in Roslyn, L.I.

title: Carnegie Relics
description: An array of Carnegie Hall memorabilia, from seats dating back to 1891 to drawings of the current restoration project, will be on view beginning Sept. 4 at the New York Public Library at Lincoln Center, Amsterdam Avenue and 65th Street.

title: NO PULLBACKS, OFFICIALS SAY
description: Although American drug agents abroad face mounting threats from wealthy, well-armed drug traffickers, Government officials say they do not intend to pull back from foreign countries.

title: A GUIDE: SUBWAYS TO CAVIAR
description: How To Get There

title: RUSSIAN'S ARREST CALLED EXAMPLE OF SPY THREAT
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that the arrest on Saturday of a Soviet physicist assigned to the United Nations Secretariat illustrated a significant security threat posed by the large Soviet contingent here.

title: MANEUVERS BEGUN BY U.S. AND EGYPT
description: The United States and Egypt began joint military maneuvers today along the Mediterranean coast, in an activity that Pentagon officials said underscored the two nations' continuing security ties.

title: TV Schedule
description: A total of 82 hours of live action from the United States Open will be aired on CBS-TV and the USA cable network. Rain might effect schedule of matches.

title: 4 Western Firefighters Killed in Truck Accident
description: A National Guard personnel carrier taking firefighters back to a forest fire base camp after their shift swerved off a dirt road and rolled into a dry creek bed early today, killing four firefighters and injuring 17, officials said.

title: Dry, Temperate Day Nice Change for City
description: For the 53,000 swimmers at Jones Beach yesterday, the weather was on the chilly side - more in keeping with early fall - with wind gusts of up to 40 miles an hour kicking up the sand.

title: Treasury Issue Rates Decline
description: Interest rates on Treasury securities fell in quiet trading yesterday, with the largest declines coming for issues with the shortest maturities.

title: HARVEY V. FONDILLER
description: Harvey V. Fondiller, an editor and writer on photography, died Friday night at his home in Manhattan. He was 65 years old.

title: Minnesota City's Highway Funds
description: Bloomington, Minn., is offering $80 million of general obligation bonds through underwriters led by the Northern Trust Company in Chicago.

title: Texas Issues Statewide Alert For Two Louisiana Fugitives
description: A statewide alert was issued today for a killer and another inmate who escaped from a Louisiana prison and crossed the Mississippi River on a log.

title: CARBON DIOXIDE CALLED LIKELY CAUSE OF DEATHS
description: The release of asphyxiating gases from Lake Nios in Cameroon, which reportedly caused heavy loss of life, may have been touched off by the churning up of decaying sediments from the lake bottom, scientists said yesterday.

title: UNION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $1,130,000 and $3,367,000, respectively. c-Net loss and includes a loss of $1,045,000 from operations discontinued or disposed of under the company's asset redeployment plan and a non-recurring charge of $10 million associated with that plan. d-Net loss and includes a non-recurring charge of $24,100,000 associated with the asset redeployment plan. Year-earlier quarter revenue includes $4,013,000 attributable to operations discontinued or disposed of under the company's asset redeployment plan. Prior-year revenue includes $20,668,000 associated with operations discontinued or disposed of under an asset redeployment plan.

title: LSI LIGHTING SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NEW SERIES A BIG TV STEP FOR MOTOWN
description: The producer of ''Sidekicks,'' a new ABC television series scheduled to start next month, is not one of the big names in the field.

title: UNSTRUCTURED CLOTHES FOR THE FREEWHEELING MAN
description: What will the fashionable young man be wearing in 1987? A visit to the Designers' Collective gave a good indication: oversize sweaters in graphic patterns, unstructured jackets, neckties in 1950's patterns, colorful socks and loafers.

title: For Ties With Soviet Lawyers
description: The debate at the American Bar Association convention over the propriety of an agreement the association had entered into with a Soviet lawyers group was a healthy examination of an issue that has received too little public attention: what are the benefits our country should look for in the resurgence of exchange programs with the Soviet Union in arts, sports, science, education and other fields?

title: WHOOPI GOLDBERG ROLE: FROM SIDEKICK TO STAR
description: An elderly man pulls open the window of his third-floor apartment above the Italian bakery, leans out and scratches his head at the scene in the alley below. What he sees are three Whoopi Goldbergs hot-wiring a police motorcycle.

title: Fokker Venture
description: N. V. Fokker said it would sign an agreement soon with the Boeing Company, Messerschmitt-Bolkow-Blohm G.m.B.H. and the Indonesian aircraft maker IPTN to conduct a feasibility study into building a technologically advanced airplane by the mid-1990's. The 90-seat aircraft would use propfan engines, which potentially offer a 30 percent fuel saving over equivalent jets, a Fokker spokesman said.

title: Hutton Sues on Ernst Opinion
description: E. F. Hutton & Company filed a $45 million lawsuit yesterday against Ernst & Whinney, charging the Cleveland-based accounting firm with giving a clean opinion to a client it knew was defrauding Hutton.

title: NONDRUG THERAPY EASES PANIC ATTACKS
description: New psychotherapy techniques for treating panic attacks may be as effective - or in some cases, more effective -than the drugs now used for the problem, researchers reported today.

title: REVILING THE WIND
description: John McEnroe firmly believes that he is more sinned against than sinning. This is not new, for the tennis star with the hair-trigger temper has reviled linesmen, cameramen, reporters, fans, ushers and vendors for, as he supposed it, their noise, their rudeness, their ineptness. On Sunday, he took to task the wind at Jericho, L.I., where he lost in the final of the Hamlet to Ivan Lendl.

title: ENS BIO LOGICALS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss The company said the latest periods include results of Tele-Radio System Ltd., which was acquired in May 1985. All figures are in Canadian dollars.

title: Peru Bank Strike Ends
description: Banks throughout Peru reopened their doors today as employees returned after a 12-day nationwide work stoppage called by the Marxist-led bank workers' union, labor leaders said.

title: Risky Cornea Transplants
description: The same matching of tissues that improves the chance of success in heart transplants can also improve the likelihood that a cornea transplant will succeed, according to a recent article in The New England Journal of Medicine.

title: Man in Queens Kills Himself After Shooting His Wife Dead
description: A Queens man shot and killed his wife Sunday night during an argument, then wounded his stepson and killed himself, the police said.

title: Clemens Foiled in Bid for 20
description: A two-run home run by Ruben Sierra against Calvin Schiraldi broke a ninth-inning tie tonight as the Texas Rangers foiled Roger Clemens's bid for his 20th victory, beating the Boston Red Sox, 4-2.

title: SUPERIOR CARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
description: b-Includes a tax benefit of $422,000. c-Net loss and includes a loss of $156,114 from discontinued operations. The company said that due to the required accounting treatment for May 30, as a reverse acquisition, results reflect three months' figures for Hospital Capital and one month for Superior's Home Health Care agencies; results for recently-acquired Kimberly Services Inc. on July 14, are not included.

title: COLLEGE COST BURDEN ON FAMILY CALLED STABLE
description: College costs have increased sharply in the last few years, but remain relatively stable in proportion to the income of most families with children in college, according to a new study.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Best Products Co., Richmond, said it would dispose of 17 unprofitable Best stores and its Ashby's subsidiary, a chain of 33 discount apparel stores, resulting in a pretax charge of about $38 million in its third quarter ending Nov. 2.

title: MACHINE BEATS MAN ON ANCIENT FRONT
description: CENTURIES of wisdom about chess endgames - the established truths about who will win or draw when the game comes down to its last pieces - have suddenly been overthrown by a few weeks of work by computers.

title: Quaker Oats Account To Jordan, Manning
description: Quaker Oats said yesterday that it has assigned its Life cereal, Quaker 100 Percent Natural Cereal and several unspecified new products to Jordan, Manning, Case, Taylor & McGrath.

title: SYSTEMED INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Article 579786 -- No Title
description: A Federal judge today awarded more than $2.2 million in damages to female applicants who were denied maintenance jobs with the Missouri Highway and Transportation Commission because of their sex.

title: Hands Across America Falls Far Short of Goal
description: Hands Across America has not raised anywhere near the $50 million it had hoped to collect and now expects to have only about $20 million for the poor because of uncollected pledges and high expenses, a spokesman said Sunday.

title: Give Peru More Time And U.S. Friendship
description: To the Editor:

title: MAYOR OF WASHINGTON SEEKS INVESTIGATION OF PROSECUTOR
description: Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. today called for investigations by the Justice Department and Congress into ''abusive governmental intrusion and Government lawlessness'' that resulted in ''leaks to the press'' about him by the United States Attorney's office here.

title: WELLS FARGO LOWERS ITS PRIME RATE TO 7.5%
description: The Wells Fargo Bank yesterday cut its prime lending rate to 7.5 percent, from 8 percent, becoming the first large bank to do so since the Federal Reserve cut its discount rate last week.

title: TAFT IS CONSIDERING SALE OF 5 TELEVISION STATIONS
description: Just a year after the Taft Broadcasting Company moved to become a major force in broadcasting, it is considering the sale of five of its independent television stations, the company said yesterday.

title: CAUTIOUSLY, EDUCATORS BACK PLAN BY GOVERNORS TO IMPROVE SCHOOLS
description: Leaders of major education organizations applauded the nation's governors today for calling for a radical restructure of public schools but said that putting many of the recommendations into effect could be difficult.

title: BLACKS AND WOMEN FIND ROADS FOR ADVANCEMENT THROUGH LIFE IN MILITARY
description: When Staff Sgt. Jacob I. Wills was a drill instructor at the Marine Corps basic training base on Parris Island, S.C., in 1980, a white recruit from Georgia took one look at him and said: ''What's this - a nigger in charge?''

title: QUANTECH ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the year-ago quarter results include a loss from discontinued operations of $63,070.

title: Appeal for New Trial Denied To 3 Ex-Officers in Sex Case
description: A State Supreme Court justice in Queens has refused to grant a new trial to three former New York City police officers who were convicted of bribery and who had accused a juror of being ''allied with the prosecution.''

title: DANCE: CUMBRE FLAMENCA IN THE PARK
description: THERE was almost as much activity in the audience as on stage when Cumbre Flamenca performed Sunday night at Central Park's Delacorte Theater. A leading dance attraction in the New York Shakespeare Festival's Festival Latino this year and in 1984, Cumbre Flamenca drew standing ovations after nearly each of its eight numbers. There were sharp cries of delight and encouragement from the audience. But the fiery dancers, singers and musicians needed no encouragement. The night was cold and windy but it seemed utterly appropriate when smoke appeared to rise from the stage toward the end of the evening. Though no one quite matched the mesmerizing presence of El Guito in the 1984 engagement, the duende or demonic inspiration of flamenco was clearly in full possession here.

title: Between the Lines of the 14th Amendment
description: To the Editor:

title: Escaped Prisoner Kills Ex-Wife and 2 Others
description: A police helicopter and bloodhounds searched for an escaped prisoner who fatally shot his former wife and two others early today but left two teen-agers unharmed, the authorities said.

title: HAJI-SHEIKH BACK, IS BATTLING FOR JOB
description: The Giants' place-kicking situation is heading toward resolution. Whether it will be resolved in a day or a week remains to be seen.

title: POSTAL INSTANT PRESS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ON THE ROAD, TALK ISN'T CHEAP
description: Not long ago, Horace Greeley 4th was going west, on Route 46, when the phone rang.

title: FIRESTONE TIRE & RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes an after-tax gain of $6 million from the partial liquidation of LIFO inventories for the quarter, and a gain of $66 million from the cumulative effect of a change in pension accounting for the 9 months. c-Includes tax credits of $4 million and $5 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Murray Seeks Trade
description: Ron Shapiro, the agent for Eddie Murray, confirmed yesterday that the Baltimore Orioles first baseman had asked to be traded.

title: ADOBE RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company was formed last October. The company said full-cost ceiling impairment was recorded in the second quarter as a result of oil and gas price declines. This amounted to an extraordinary charge of $23,204,000.

title: ISRAELI AIDE CHARGED WITH L.I. BURGLARY ATTEMPT
description: An Israeli Government employee and an Ohio businessman have been charged with attempted burglary of an aviation parts business and a computer store here.

title: TENNIS UMPIRE'S UNPLEASANT VIEWING
description: The thought had occurred to the big man in the chair that the concept of sportsmanship in American tennis has gone the way of the grass court, the tiebreaker, the wooden racquet and the reasonably priced concession stand. Frank Hammond has been following the flights of tennis balls for 40 years, since he was a linesman at a Davis Cup match at the age of 15. The view from his umpire's chair has not been pleasant in the recent past, as taped highlights of outbursts at men's matches have taken their place on the 11 o'clock news alongside hockey fights, automobile-race crashes, steel cage wrestling matches and other events of grace and skill.

title: To Help the Third World's Smallest Businesses
description: To the Editor:

title: AUG. 11-20 AUTO SALES DOWN 1.3%
description: Sales of new cars by the major domestic manufacturers fell 1.3 percent in the August 11-20 period, hurt by a 10.4 percent drop at the General Motors Corporation.

title: A Sikh Is Seized In Killing of General
description: A Sikh wanted in the assassination of India's most-decorated military hero was arrested today, the United News of India reported.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: WHAT'S happening to downtown, which has been setting city styles for several years? As its magazines go national, its ''celebutantes'' turn up on talk shows and its books are pushed by established publishers, downtown is looking up.

title: Foreclosure Plea by Hunts
description: The Hunt brothers have asked a Federal judge to restrain their banks from seizing several properties posted as collateral for their family's ailing oil and drilling companies.

title: Economist Leaves First Boston Post
description: Albert M. Wojnilower, one of Wall Street's most influential analysts, has stepped down as chief economist at the First Boston Corporation, the company announced yesterday.

title: U.S. TO SEEK OLD ISRAELI SUB OFF EGYPT
description: The United States Navy is preparing to search Egyptian waters in the Mediterranean for the wreckage of an Israeli submarine, Defense Department officials said today.

title: DEATHS STUN INDIAN PUEBLO KNOWN FOR ITS FIREFIGHTERS
description: This Pueblo Indian town today mourned the death Sunday of four of its men in a truck accident after they had spent 12 hours fighting a fire in the Boise National Forest in Idaho.

title: INMATE IS EXECUTED BY INJECTION, THE THIRD TO DIE IN TEXAS IN WEEK
description: A man convicted of kidnapping a woman and killing her by burying her alive on a beach was executed by injection early today, becoming the third prisoner put to death in Texas in a week.

title: Amgen-Cetus Patent Dispute
description: Amgen, a biotechnology company based in Thousand Oaks, Calif., said today that it had filed a suit against the Cetus Corporation seeking a declaration that Amgen has not violated three of the four patents Cetus holds for interleukin-2, a possible anticancer treatment.

title: Silence in Post Offices Honors Slain Workers
description: The post office here and thousands of others across the nation fell silent this afternoon as workers remembered 14 colleagues killed last week at the hands of a disgruntled employee.

title: C.G.E. Will Seek Control of Lynch
description: Compagnie Generale d'Electricite said it was planning to seek control of Lynch Communications Inc., a maker of telephone transmission equipment based in Reno, Nev. Alcatel S.A., a subsidiary of the state-owned French telephone giant, already controls 46.7 percent of Lynch.

title: BRIEFING; An Anniversary
description: Today is the 66th anniversary of the ratification of the 19th Amendment granting women the right to vote, and the National Organization for Women is using the occasion to organize support for the proposed Civil Rights Restoration Act. The bill would make it unlawful for any institution receiving Federal money to discriminate against women or members of minority groups in any of the institution's programs, whether or not the Federal money was used specifically for the program at issue.

title: Restoring the Park's Courts
description: Tennis, everyone?

title: Better Than the Tram
description: To the Editor:

title: RESCUERS WARN OF EPIDEMIC; U.S. to Send Team
description: The United States will send a team of experts to Cameroon within 24 hours to investigate the emission of the toxic gas in a volcanic crater, Federal officials said today.

title: CORDERO WINS SARATOGA TITLE
description: Angel Cordero Jr. won his 11th straight riding title and Tappiano won the Spinaway Stakes as the annual 24-day Saratoga Race Track meeting ended today.

title: REDMEN TO LOSE BALDI FOR 1986-87
description: Marco Baldi, the 6-foot-11-inch St. John's University center, will not play for the Redmen next season and probably never again, according to a source in the school's administration.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL METS VS. PADRES, at San Diego. (Television - Channel 9, 10 P.M.; Radio -WHN, 1050; 10 P.M.) YANKEES VS.

title: JUDGE DISCLOSES RULING AGAINST HIM
description: A special judicial panel has found that Federal District Judge Alcee Hastings of Miami fabricated his successful defense against bribery conspiracy charges, a lawsuit filed by the judge disclosed today.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL CHICAGO (AL) - Called up Jack Perconte, infielder from its Class AAA affiliate in Buffalo: moved Bob James, relief pitcher, to the 21-day disabled list, from the 15-day disabled list.

title: Chaos and Crowds Lessen
description: The Frontier Airlines shutdown created chaos at many Western airports on Sunday, but crowds had dwindled by yesterday, United Press International reported. Travel agents said they were swamped with telephone inquiries from Frontier ticketholders.

title: AMERICAN TRAVELLERS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Skirmish Reported In Southern Lebanon
description: Lebanese guerrillas ambushed a patrol of the Israeli-backed South Lebanon Army militia Sunday, killing one trooper and wounding two, militia sources reported today.

title: GOVERNORS LEARN LESSON ON SCHOOLS
description: The nation's governors yesterday learned a hard lesson about the difficulty of improving the public schools.

title: METS RALLY TO WIN
description: This afternoon, Kevin Mitchell found in his locker stall his $89 Fila sneakers cut apart, ruined. He investigated, discovered that Bob Ojeda was the cutter, and walked right up to Ojeda and said, ''Bobby, I love you.'' These Mets are so happy, it can kill you.

title: CHYRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said results include operations of CMX Corp. from Jan. 1, 1985, and Digital Services Corp. from Feb. 1, 1985.

title: ALGOREX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $200,000 to adjust the carrying value of the company's New Hampshire facility. c-Includes a one-time charge of $3,704,000 related to the writedown of receivables and inventory, contract revaluations and the partial writeoff of goodwill of a purchased facility for both the quarter and year. The company said the latest full- year results were impacted by $2,030,000 for the net writedown of the New Hampshire facility and relocation costs.

title: RADIATION TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: BRIEFING; Calling All Defectors
description: The arcane art of political defection is the subject of a high-level panel discussion planned Sept. 4 by the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace. Panelists include William Colby, a former Director of Central Intelligence; Representative Lee H. Hamilton, Democrat of Indiana, chairman of the House Committee on Intelligence, and Vladimir Sakharov, a Soviet K.G.B. agent who defected in 1971. The dis-cussion, ''The C.I.A.-K.G.B. War and the Defector's Role,'' will accompany the premiere of a film, ''Yuri Nosenko, K.G.B.,'' which chronicles the defection of the high-ranking Soviet Intelligence officer in 1964.

title: People
description: * Anne Mahoney has joined Aspach Grossman Portugal, the graphics and design firm, as a principal.

title: BRIEFING; A Pickens Campaign
description: T. Boone Pickens, the Texas oilman who is the king of the raiders, is forming a stockholders organization to fight a growing trend by corporate boards of directors to adopt measures to thwart unfriendly takeovers.

title: Summer Breezes
description: Four American League batters are striking out at a pace that would give them 1986 totals surpassing the league's single-season record (175, by Dave Nicholson of the 1963 White Sox and Gorman Thomas of the 1979 Brewers) and threatening the major league mark (189, by Bobby Bonds of the 1970 Giants). These are the hitters in both leagues who had been fanned more than 100 times through Sunday's games:

title: HARPER & ROW PUBLISHERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income

title: HUDSON GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Year to June 30
ROSTER EXEMPTION GRANTED ON MORRIS
description: The Giants, who must reduce their 60-man roster to 50 by Tuesday, started the cutdown today by deactivating Joe Morris.

title: In a Light Decade, Less Light Than Meets the Eye
description: To the Editor:

title: GALANOS: INTRICATE ELEGANCE FOR FALL
description: James Galanos always has the last word, showing each season well after the other major designers in this country and Europe. Yesterday, he arrived in New York with the 200-piece fall collection he will be showing informally all week in a suite at the Plaza Hotel. The clothes are well worth waiting for. They rank with the best he's ever done.

title: Soviet Reports a Tornado
description: The Government newspaper Izvestia said today that a tornado killed one person and injured several others on Saturday in the area of Belinsky, in Penza Province in European Russia. A total of 148 houses were said to have been damaged.

title: South Korean Leader Shuffles His Cabinet
description: President Chun Doo Hwan shuffled his Cabinet today, replacing 10 of the 22 ministers, a presidential spokesman said.

title: HAZLETON LABORATORIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $38,000 and $12,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and a loss on the sale of assets from discontinued operations of $80,000 for the quarter and a gain on the sale of assets of discontinued operations of $632,000 for the year. c-Includes gains of $78,000 and $171,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, on the sale of assets from discontinued operations.

title: NEW YORK TESTING LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Kimberly-Clark To Lay Off 255
description: Kimberly-Clark of Canada Ltd., wholly owned by the Kimberly-Clark Corporation, said it would lay off 255 permanent workers and 100 temporary employees as part of a survival plan for its Terrace Bay Pulp Mill and related woodlands operations, which employ a total of 1,800 workers. The company said it would also suspend Woodlands Operations for two months starting Sept. 2 to reduce wood inventory and avoid a complete shutdown. Terrace Bay incurred a 1985 operating loss of $17 million, the company said.

title: Move by Lindner
description: The American Financial Corporation and its chairman, Carl H. Lindner, have purchased the equivalent of an 18.6 percent stake, which would amount to 2.63 million shares, in the Columbia Savings and Loan Association. On Aug. 14 and 15, American Financial bought $50 million worth of Columbia's 7 percent convertible subordinated debentures due Aug. 15, 2011. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, American Financial and Mr. Lindner said they bought the shares of the Beverly Hills thrift institution as an investment.

title: ADAC LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
description: b-Includes an unusual charge of $8,516,000.

title: 2 PLAYERS FROM L.I. ARE EASY TO PICK OUT ON THE HIGHWAY
description: Spotting a bridge player when he is hurtling along a highway is rarely possible, alftough bumper stickers sometimes provide a clue. But two Long Island players are permanently identifiable.

title: COLLINS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss c-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $60,473 and $116,547 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: POLITICS; Lessons on Being A Good Candidate
description: How do you beat a Democrat?

title: CALIFORNIA SENATE PASSES BILL TO SELL PRETORIA-LINKED STOCK
description: In the largest such move in the nation, the California Senate passed legislation today that would require state pension and university funds to sell more than $11 billion worth of securities in companies doing business in South Africa.

title: Won't Help Moslems, Suharto Tells Aquino
description: President Suharto told President Corazon C. Aquino of the Philippines today that he supported her and would not back Moslem rebels in the Philippines, officials reported.

title: ALASKA SHAKEN BY OIL-REVENUE DROP
description: As Alaskans look for ways to replace the oil royalties and taxes that no longer flow out of the state treasury, signs of economic distress abound here.

title: PRAB ROBOTS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SOUTH AFRICAN POLICE KILL BLACK, WOUND 8 IN A TOWNSHIP CLASH
description: One black man was killed today and eight people were wounded when officers fired birdshot and tear gas at a crowd of 500 people who were stoning a police vehicle, the Government said.

title: Telephone Politics
description: If you are put on hold when calling an office, you might hear what is known as elevator or dentist office music. But not at the re-election campaign headquarters of Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato.

title: Amiss With a Miss
description: To the Editor:

title: HAUSERMAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the latest results reflect a pension accounting change which increased net by $255,000, or 11 cents a share, for the year and resulted in a restatement of quarterly earnings. Accordingly, net income increased by 2 cents a share in the third quarter and by 3 cents a share in each of the other quarters of fiscal 1986.

title: REQUIRED READING; The Troubled Americas
description: Excerpts from ''Rebuilding Cooperation in the Americas,'' the 1986 report of the Inter-American Dialogue, a group of North American and Latin American politicians, diplomats, business leaders and scholars:

title: Medical School Offers $56 Million
description: The University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey is offering $56 million of bonds with a maximum yield tentatively set at 7.30 percent for bonds due in 2006 through underwriters led by Citibank.

title: ABUSES BY BOTH SIDES CONTINUING IN SALVADOR
description: The Salvadoran Government has made major strides in curbing human rights violations, but the evidence of abuses by both sides in the civil war indicates that human rights remain a major political issue in El Salvador, according to rights officials, foreign diplomats and interviews with refugees and political prisoners.

title: GEORGIA BONDED FIBERS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $354,000. c-After an extraordinary charge of $170,000 resulting from an insurance claim for both the quarter and year.

title: AHAB, FREUD AND NAZIS ON MELVILLEAN'S AGENDA
description: The Melvilleans (as they call themselves) are in full cry these days, flensing fresh cuts from the American novelist's life and writings. Among other matters, the Melville scholars are reinterpreting the author in light of feminism, Freud, the proletariat, Eros and even Nazi Germany.

title: FOREST FIRES RAVAGE RIVIERA FOR 3D DAY
description: Thousands of firefighters battled forest fires on the Riviera for a third day in a row today, but the fires, fanned by the stiff Mediterranean wind known as the mistral, leaped across gaps sometimes hundreds of yards wide, complicating efforts to extinguish them.

title: RONALD BATES, STAGE DESIGNER
description: Ronald Bates, an authority on the construction of permanent and portable stage floors who developed the ''Balanchine basket-weave floor,'' died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 54 years old.

title: Detroit Edison
description: The Detroit Edison Company said its board had approved a revised final cost estimate of $4.23 billion for its Fermi 2 power plant. It said a previous cost estimate of $3.77 billion set in November 1985 had been based on the plant beginning commercial operation in March. The plant is being tested at up to 5 percent of its power capacity.

title: 14-YEAR-OLD BOY WITH AIDS ATTENDS SCHOOL AFTER 2 YEARS
description: Smiling and lugging his books in a school gym bag, Ryan White, a 14-year-old AIDS sufferer, reported for the start of eighth-grade classes today, after parents who opposed his return dropped their battle because of mounting legal costs.

title: Rivers May Miss Year
description: David Rivers, the Notre Dame basketball star injured in a weekend automobile accident, may not recover in time to play this season, a surgeon said yesterday.

title: 'Me and My Girl' Sales Reach $1.1 Million in Week
description: ''Me and My Girl,'' the new musical comedy hit at the Marquis Theater on Broadway, is also a major hit at the box office. Ralph Roseman, the show's general manager, said yesterday that for the week beginning last Tuesday, total ticket sales amounted to $1,110,743.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, AUGUST 26, 1986
description: International

title: WOMEN ADVISE TEEN-AGE PROS
description: For many of the youngest female players who will be vying to unseat the defending women's champion, Hana Mandlikova, at this year's United States Open, the most important lessons of life as a professional athlete will not be learned on the tennis court but in a classroom in midtown Manhattan.

title: MCDOWELL ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $24,500 for the quarter, and $167,714 for the 6 months. c-Net income d-Includes a loss of $45,217 from discontinued operations. The company said it has been shedding many of its construction-related units.

title: HACH CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
PRICE BREAKTHROUGH ON LASER PRINTER
description: AS the Silicon Valley sales force stumbles through the latter part of a year of slumping sales, little attention seems to be focused on the true hardware success story of 1986. The myth under which the merry marketeers of the Valley labored was that veteran users of personal computers would trade in their old models as newer ones with fashionable features and escalated speed came along. But as computer sales lagged behind manufacturers' expectations, the truth turned out to be that computer users had become attached to the idiosyncratic company in which they had undergone their initiation and were loath to change their allegiance. But they were more than willing to buy new add-ons for their computers.

title: KEY RATES
M.A.C. PRODS CITY ON AID TO BUSINESS
description: A New York City program designed to help businesses relocate in the city instead of moving out of town has failed to use $6 million of the $19 million budgeted for its first two years of operation, according to official figures. But Mayor Koch praised the grants made so far as successes.

title: Will We Have Reaganvilles?
description: We have only begun to see homelessness in our society: it is bound to increase. Here, as elsewhere in the world, the phenomenon we call homelessness has been a long time in the making; and even if we were to begin now, which seems unlikely, it would take a decade to turn the situation around. But the least we can do is try to gain some understanding of its root causes.

title: CLAIRE'S STORES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
description: b-Net income The 1985 share earnings and shares outstanding have been restated for a 3-for-2 stock split in October 1985.

title: DESIGN FLAWS, KNOWN TO MOSCOW, CALLED MAJOR FACTOR AT CHERNOBYL
description: Western scientists said today that the Chernobyl nuclear disaster stemmed largely from reactor design defects that Moscow was warned about nine years ago and that the problems still existed at other Soviet nuclear plants.

title: SERIES ON 13 TAKES LOOK AT BRAZIL
description: BRAZIL, BRAZIL,'' a four-part series, begins tonight with what seems to be a contradiction: Brazilians are miserable; at the same time, they look awfully happy. Why are they this way? The series's opening episode, ''God, Football and Carnival,'' on Channel 13 at 10 o'clock, says the samba distracts them.

title: AT STADIUM, LAST CALM DAY
description: Henri Leconte sat on a green park bench under a tree yesterday, sipping a soft drink, taking in the sights like the rest of the fans. Bettina Bunge and Claudia Kohde-Kilsch jogged through the main gate, their morning run completed. A young man with a camera asked Hana Mandlikova to pose for a photograph, then boldly put his right arm around her shoulder as his friend said ''Say cheese.''

title: Fringe Benefit
description: Coach Mike Fratello of the Atlanta Hawks, on the significance of his being named to the team's board: ''What it means is that the vote to fire me will never be unanimous.''

title: Arco's Ex-Chief Quits Board
description: Robert O. Anderson, who began his career as an independent oil and gas operator and later built the Atlantic Richfield Company into the nation's sixth-largest oil concern, said he was resigning from Arco's board as of Sept. 1 and would start his own private oil and gas company in New Mexico.

title: VANZETTI SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: HUB SHAKEOUTS HARD TO AVOID
description: For years, airline analysts have contended that the pressure of competition would not allow any one city to serve as a hub for three or more carriers for long. The prospective shutdown of Frontier Airlines by its parent, People Express Inc., has reinforced that view.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: DOMESDAY

title: NETWORK TV NEWS PLAN IS CRITICIZED
description: Fifty-five television network news correspondents said in a statement released yesterday that a contract proposal being offered by ABC, NBC and CBS that would give networks the right to assign correspondents to technical duties would damage their ability to report the news.

title: PLATINUM BUOYED BY INVESTORS
description: Platinum's $100-an-ounce increase in recent weeks has come from a surge in demand by individuals, who until this year tended to overlook platinum as an investment vehicle, according to commodity specialists and consultants.

title: PUBLICKER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes for both the quarter and 6 months a gain of $1,678,000 from the settlement of litigation against Belcher Oil Co., which was recorded as of June 30, but is before a tax credit of $438,000. c-Net loss The company said the decline in sales is attributable to the sale or shutdown during 1985 and early 1986 of operations related to the sale of industrial ethyl alcohol, fuel grade alcohol, automotive and household cleaning products, bulk liquid storage and the company's contract packaging business.

title: Garren Leads
description: Gary Garren of Newport News, Va., shot a net 69 at the Dunes Golf and Beach Club today to grab a first-round two-shot lead in the men's championship flight of the 72-hole du Pont World Amateur Handicap Championship.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: New Tokens for Old
description: By turning September into ''Token Exchange Month,'' the Transit Authority has good news for anyone who has been hanging onto leftover solid brass tokens since June.

title: Kennedy Airport Should Beckon Foreign Visitors
description: To the Editor:

PINETREE COMPUTER SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

title: Life and Death In Dixie
description: Southerners' image as football worshippers is lent a measure of support in a set of statistics suggesting that Dixie has now supplanted the Eastern corridor of Ohio, Pennsylvania and New Jersey as the breeding grounds for the nation's most skilled players.

title: RADIATION SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
The Closest Call
description: Otto Jelinek, Canada's Minister of State for Fitness and Amateur Sport, is in New York this week to join other world-class athletic officials in the eighth International Sport Summit. But he remembers that he wouldn't be here at all if it hadn't been for a dramatic twist of fate 25 years ago, when he and his sister Maria were champion pairs figure skaters whose family had emigrated from Czechoslovakia to Canada 10 years before that.

title: SUBARU OF AMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 8-for-1 stock split in May.

title: WITH EYE TO NOVEMBER, DYSON STRESSES WEALTH
description: John S. Dyson has been an unusual candidate. He started out the year as a potential Democratic-Conservative candidate for State Comptroller. He is now the Liberal Party candidate for the United States Senate and is seeking the Democratic nomination in the Sept. 9 primary.

title: VOLUMNE LOWER
description: A flurry of institutional selling in the first hour of trading was sufficient to depress the stock market for the rest of the session.

title: JOHN HANSON SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Net loss and after a fourth-quarter write-off of about $10.5 million that the company had on deposit with the former Maryland Savings Share Insurance Corp. The company said that due to the tax loss carryforward on the write-off, it paid no taxes in fiscal 1986.

title: VISIONTECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 25
description: b-Net loss

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, AUGUST 26, 1986
description: Companies

title: Last Chance to Clean Up the Election
description: The courts, having turned New York's September primary election campaign into a discouraging legal brawl, now have the chance to make emergency amends.

title: TERMIFLEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
INTERNATIONAL ALUMINUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said earnings in the latest quarter and year included losses from discontinued operations of $535,000 and $2,038,000, respectively.

title: G.M. Offer To Trim Jobs
description: The General Motors Corporation said today that it is offering new incentives for white-collar employees to resign.

title: DESIGNHOUSE INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Year to May 31
description: b-After charges of $800,000 and a tax benefit of $664,000. c-Includes a $949,000 tax benefit. The company said the prior-year results have been restated to reflect a change in accounting for inventories. The company said of the charge of $800,000 in the latest year, $580,000 represents a provision for loss on slow-moving, damaged and excess inventory, and the balance represents provision for anticipated loss on the disposition of certain assets.

title: Partner Takes Unit To Coudert
description: Gordon Spivack and his partners and associates in the antitrust department at Lord, Day & Lord are moving to the Coudert Brothers law firm Oct. 1.

title: DANCE: GUATEMALAN RITES
description: JULIA VELA'S Ballet Moderno y Folklorico of Guatemala transformed a utilitarian modern theater into a colorful and joyous festival setting on Sunday afternoon, when ''El Pabaanc'' (''Ritual Theater'') was performed in the Newman Theater as part of the New York Shakespeare Festival's Festival Latino at the Public Theater. The beautiful folk costumes and vivid, endearingly naive masks greatly enhanced this outstanding production, as did the lilting, teasing music performed on folk instruments. And the dancers performed with a wonderful blend of modesty and vigor. But most of all, ''El Pabaanc'' was an impressive merging of the new and old.

title: TANDON SEPARATES COMPUTERS, DISKS
description: The Tandon Corporation, which recently introduced its own line of I.B.M.-compatible personal computers, said today that it would split the company into two independent units and separate its personal computer operations from its disk drive and subsystems business.

title: UNIMED INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CMX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $31,000 and $196,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net loss and the year includes an extraordinary credit of $162,000 from the forgiveness of debt.

title: TWO STARS MIRED IN QUANDARY
description: In one clubhouse, the self-proclaimed Mr. October, Reggie Jackson, talking about the autumn of his baseball years. In the other clubhouse, the man George Steinbrenner disparagingly labeled Mr. May, Dave Winfield, reacting to the latest verbal assault on him from the owner.

title: AN 'INTERCOM' DEBATE, 'WHY TERRORISM?'
description: AN ill-conceived and ill-matched ''debate'' - one of the least-enlightening 57 minutes of the summer - is offered tonight at 11 on Channel 13. Sadly, the program says more about the lack of news judgment by the management of this metropolitan New York public-television station than about the subject supposedly under discussion.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * AST Research Inc., Irvine, Calif., a developer of computer hardware and software, said its chief financial officer, Bruce Edwards, would leave at the end of the month to become chief executive at a newly formed company.

title: CAMEROONIANS GREET ISRAELIS IN EXUBERANT HEBREW
description: With Prime Minister Shimon Peres in town today to help usher in the restoration of relations between Israel and this West African nation, President Paul Biya of Cameroon organized a lavish reception befitting the occasion of the first visit in 20 years by an Israeli Prime Minister to a black African nation.

title: U.S. SAYS LIBYA MAY HAVE PLANS FOR NEW TERROR
description: Officials indicated today that Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi was planning terrorist attacks, and the White House warned that it was ''prepared to take whatever action is necessary'' to thwart the Libyan leader.

title: RESCUERS WARN OF EPIDEMIC
description: President Paul Biya of Cameroon said today that at least 1,200 people had died in a cloud of gas from a volcano that choked them to death as they slept in villages in northwest Cameroon.

title: 6 AIDS CHILDREN TO ATTEND SCHOOLS, CITY OFFICIALS SAY
description: Six of 13 children known to have AIDS or the less-severe disorder AIDS-related complex will be allowed to attend New York City public schools, city officials said yesterday.

title: Transamerica Lifting Its Insurance Image
description: Transamerica, in the process of selling its noninsurance subsidiaries, is trying to drive home its insurance image in a five-page ad in the coming issue of Time magazine.

title: MGM-UA SETS DEAL WITH HBO
description: The MGM-UA Communications Company said yesterday that it had agreed to license up to 72 movies over the next four years to Home Box Office, the nation's largest pay television service, in a deal that could be worth $300 million. The agreement is not exclusive.

title: SUCCESS ON DIABETES MAY AID TRANSPLANTS
description: Dramatic advances are showing strong promise for curing the most devastating type of diabetes and, at the same time, have led to profound new strategies for successful organ transplantation.

title: Ex-Redskin Has AIDS
description: Jerry Smith, a former all-Pro receiver with the Washington Redskins, says he is suffering from AIDS.

title: Rock Against Crack
description: Bill Graham, the rock-music impresario and manager, is shopping for a site for a huge concert in October to benefit anti-crack education.

title: NEW CHIP: VAST POWER ON HORIZON
description: Perhaps even as soon as next month, a new breed of personal computer will be introduced that is vastly more powerful than any other PC in use today. The new machine will use the Intel 80386 microprocessor, a chip that is likely to be the dominant brain of the best desktop computers at the end of this decade.

title: REALTY WOES SEEN IN TAX BILL
description: Many sectors of the real estate market are headed for a sharp reversal if the proposed tax bill becomes law, industry experts say.

title: SUMMIT HEALTH LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of $2,884,000 from extinguishment of debt for both the quarter and year. c-Net income.

title: SEACO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a $17,000,000 provision for loss on the disposal of container ship operations for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Net income Pretax foreign exchange losses equaled $95,000 in the latest quarter and $156,000 in the year-ago quarter, and $217,000 in the latest 6 months and $29,000 in the year-ago 6 months.

title: DESPITE UNUSUAL START, GAME 11 ENDS IN DRAW
description: The world chess champion, Gary Kasparov, and the challenger, Anatoly Karpov, today played the most complicated game yet in their championship series, but it ended in a draw.

title: COURT FINDS F.B.I. HARASSED SOCIALIST GROUP UNLAWFULLY
description: A Federal judge yesterday awarded $264,000 to the Socialist Workers Party, a tiny Trotskyist group, as damages for harassment and rights violations by the Federal Bureau of Investigation over a period of 18 years.

title: Police Chief of San Antonio Quits at Manager's Request
description: Police Chief Charles Rodriguez resigned today in a move City Manager Lou Fox said was not related to the investigation of an officer's slaying by another officer last week.

title: TRITON ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes a $31,921,000 writedown of oil and gas properties and other assets for the quarter, and for the year, an extraordinary charge of $575,000 from the early extinguishment of debt and a $49,926,000 writedown of oil and gas properties and other assets. c-Net income

title: Officials to Discuss How to Fight Drugs
description: Mayors, county executives and police chiefs from 21 states will attend a conference in the city today on how government can combat drug abuse.

title: YANKS FAIL TO GAIN
description: Morganna, baseball's notorious kissing bandit, made her long-awaited move against Don Mattingly last night, but the Yankees still weren't able to begin their long-awaited move on the Boston Red Sox.

title: CAMEROON AT A GLANCE
description: Geography Cameroon is a tropical West African country about the size of California. Situated on the Gulf of Guinea, it is bordered by Nigeria, Chad, the Central African Republic, Congo, Equatorial Guinea and Gabon. Population The population of 10 million includes more than 200 tribes, belonging to 24 major African languages. The official languages are French and English. About four-fifths of the people live in the French-speaking east. The main seaport and largest city is Douala. The capital, Yaounde, is the second largest city. About half the people practice African animist religions; Christians, in the south, account for one-third, and Moslems, in the north, for one-sixth of the population.

title: HAL ROACH STUDIOS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $412,113. c-Net loss

title: Different Speeds for Different Needs
description: There are two things truly uniform about the national 55-mile-an-hour speed limit: it is uniformly violated and it is uniformly mocked. President Reagan, hoping to boost Republican prospects this fall, has endorsed repealing it in favor of limits set by the states. This change is warranted regardless of politics.

title: Ryan Angers Shula
description: After 24 years as a head coach in the National Football League, Don Shula doesn't appreciate being accused of bending the rules, especially when the accusations come from an outspoken rookie head coach. The Miami Dolphins' head coach reacted angrily to complaints by the Philadelphia Eagles' Coach, Buddy Ryan, that the Dolphins flouted the rules.

title: Business and Health; The Sharp Rise In Drug Prices
description: AS anyone who has visited a pharmacist can confirm, prescription drug prices have been steadily climbing, even as overall inflation has eased. Retail drug prices rose 8.7 percent in the 12 months ended in July, more than five times the 1.6 percent increase in the overall Consumer Price Index, the Commerce Department said last week. Even when adjusted to minimize the short-term effects of slumping oil prices, the drug increase was more than twice the overall rate.

title: Mansion Burglar Held in Stabbing
description: The unemployed Albany man who broke into the Executive Mansion in 1984 while Governor Cuomo and his family slept upstairs has been charged with attempted murder and assault in another case, the police said today.

title: TVI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: 2 WOMEN WELCOMED (BY SOME)
description: Two nervous but optimistic women began training yesterday as New York City's first female sanitation workers, while many of their veteran colleagues insisted that Anne Pabon and Carlen Sanderson were unfit to haul 100-pound cans of ashes or 6-foot bags of household trash.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''All people heard was the explosion. They didn't know that toxic gas had been expelled, and it killed them while they were asleep.''

title: New Line Studied By N.J. Transit
description: N.J. Transit plans to issue within a few weeks a preliminary report on a proposed train line that would extend three rail systems to the Hudson River waterfront, according to agency officials.

title: MOSCOW SAYS ITS A-TEST HALT IS MILITARILY BENEFICIAL TO U.S.
description: The Chief of the Soviet General Staff said today that Moscow's moratorium on nuclear testing was militarily advantageous to the United States but had not disrupted the East-West balance of forces.

title: WILEY, JOHN & SONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Stranded Climber Dies After Mountain Rescue
description: A climber stranded overnight in winterlike weather died today after being carried off a 5,300-foot mountain by workers who rescued his companion, officials said.

title: PRESSURE ON IRAQ IS SEEN AS INTENT
description: Iran said today that it planned to resume exports of natural gas to the Soviet Union by the end of the year. The exports were broken off after the overthrow of the Shah in 1979.

title: Option Granted On Gates Learjet
description: The Gates Corporation said it had agreed to grant M. J. Rosenthal & Associates Inc., a New York investment firm, an option to acquire Gates' 64.8 percent holding in the Gates Learjet Corporation.

title: GRIST MILL CO reports earnings for Year to May 31
BRIEFING; Reagan and Fitness
description: A group called the Healthy American Fitness Leaders has selected President Reagan for an award next month because of his work toward making Americans healthy, notably his advocacy of drug testing for Federal employees.

title: The Sanctions Vote: A G.O.P. Milestone
description: Now that the dust has settled from the Senate vote on South African sanctions, what stands out is that mainstream Republicans, just three months before a critical midterm election, have fomented an open mutiny against the President. The Senate's stiff sanctions bill, passed 84 to 14, registered sharp disagreement with the President's view that such measures would ''destroy America's flexibility, discard our diplomatic leverage and deepen the crisis'' in South Africa.

title: Truck Accident Blocks I-91 North
description: A tractor-trailer loaded with cans of hair spray went out of control and crashed early today, bursting into flames and shutting down Interstate 91 northbound for nearly four hours here, the police said.

title: President Resigns Posts At Great Western
description: Great Western Financial Corporation said yesterday that Robert B. Holmes, its 54-year-old president, chief operating officer and director, is resigning to pursue other business interests. Great Western owns the nation's third-largest savings and loan association.

title: STIFEL FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 25
SOUTHLAND FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: U.S. INVESTIGATING FURTHER SPY CASES IN NEW YORK AREA
description: A Government prosecutor at the arraignment of a Soviet physicist on espionage charges said yesterday that other investigations ''of a similar nature'' were under way in the New York area.

title: MIXED FORECASTS OFFERED FOR MIDWEST'S ECONOMY
description: Small doses of optimism and somber warnings were delivered today for the Middle West at a regional conference of government officials here.

title: CHAPTER 11 DELAYED FOR FRONTIER
description: People Express Inc. said yesterday that it had put off until today placing its Frontier Airlines subsidiary under protection of the bankruptcy laws while it continued to seek other resolutions to Frontier's crisis. The airline stopped operating on Sunday.

title: IN A LIGHT DECADE, LESS LIGHT THAN MEETS THE EYE
description: To the Editor:

title: IDENTITY CRISES
description: Officer and Halfback

title: SHIP IN TAMIL AFFAIR IS FOUND
description: The West German freighter that was said to have dropped off 155 Tamil refugees near Newfoundland was docked today in the Canary Islands, Spanish and West German officials said.

title: SAINTS DROP TODD, EX-JET QUARTERBACK
description: Richard Todd, the quarterback the New Orleans Saints acquired from the Jets in 1984, was cut yesterday.

title: SPY SUSPECT BLENDED IN AMONG BRONX NEIGHBORS
description: When the Vogels - Murray, Yvette and their four boys - came home Friday from a two-month vacation in Israel, it was their tenant and upstairs neighbor, Gennadi F. Zakharov, who came downstairs at 7:15 A.M. to help carry the bags.

title: AUTOMATIC DATA PROCESSING INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in June. The company said the prior fourth quarter and full-year figures are restated for the pooling-of-interests acquisition of ROI Systems Inc. in November.

title: Farley/Northwest Weighs Offering
description: Farley/ Northwest Industries, the diversified manufacturer acquired in a $1.4 billion leveraged buyout last year, said it was considering a public offering to refinance its approximately $866 million in long-term debt and $39 million in short-term debt.

title: MONY Purchase
description: MONY Financial Services, formerly the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York, said that it had agreed in principle to acquire for an undisclosed sum the North American Mortgage Company of Houston. North American is the largest privately held mortgage banking company in Texas and the 10th largest in the nation with more than $2.5 billion in mortgage loans serviced. Under the purchase plan, North American would operate as an independent unit of MONY, which is a $15 billion group of companies providing investment, insurance, employee benefits and commercial credit operations.

title: Topics; Identity Crises; Dial M for Me
