description: Once upon a time in New York City, telephone exchanges had memorable monikers. There was PLaza and RHinelander, BUtterfield and LEhigh, GRamercy and CHelsea, and each evoked an image.

title: DRINKS AID CADBURY REBOUND
description: For generations, it has been a favorite axiom of the Cadbury family: ''There's one product that sells in good times and bad - a bar of chocolate.''

title: PRESSURE ON PEOPLE EXPRESS
description: People Express Inc., if it decides to seek bankruptcy protection for its Frontier Airlines subsidiary, would close off a big cash drain.

title: IN WORLD CAPITAL OF THE ICEHOUSE, A WAY OF LIFE HANGS ON
description: In the beginning, before air-conditioning and Miller Lite commercials, before 7-Eleven's and Kwik Stops, before Big Gulps and Slurpees, was the icehouse.

title: Holiday Buys Back 900,000 Shares
description: The Holiday Corporation said it had bought 900,000 shares of its common stock for $60 a share under its board's authorization last November to buy 2.5 million shares. The company said the purchase reduced the number of shares outstanding to 23.4 million, adding that 468,000 shares remain to be bought under the authorization.

title: No Headline
description: Q.

title: SHCHARANSKY REUNITED WITH KIN
description: Anatoly Shcharansky, the former Soviet activist, was reunited today with his mother, in their first meeting since she saw him in prison 19 months ago.

title: 'SEEING' ATOMS AND BONDS
description: PUSHING the frontiers of human vision deeper into the submicroscopic world, scientists have made the first pictures of atoms and the bonds that join them on a solid surface.

title: GRAND JURY IS CONVENED ON LOBBYING BY DEAVER
description: Whitney North Seymour Jr., the independent counsel investigating the lobbying activities of Michael K. Deaver, has convened a Federal grand jury that has taken the testimony of executives of at least two companies, according to several people familiar with the proceedings.

title: United Nations Chief Offers Sympathy to Cameroonians
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar has expressed his sympathy to the Government of Cameroon and the families of the victims of the toxic gas disaster in that country, a United Nations spokesman said today.

title: F.B.I.; They Who May Never Have Heard of Quiche
description: Donald Keith Williams doubtless would have preferred the prison of anonymity.

title: WICKES COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 26
description: b-Reflects $3.5 million, or 2 cents per primary, of net interest costs associated with the company's recently issued $1.4 billion of debentures, the proceeds of which are being used to finance acquisitions. c-Includes interest expense of $52,307,000 and $85,768,000 for the latest quarter and 6 months, respectively, compared with $28,883,000 and $44,359,000 (net of gains from retirement of indebtedness of $507,000 and $3,231,000) for the comparable 1985 periods; includes interest income for the latest quarter and 6 months of $9,711,000 and $11,040,000, respectively, compared with $10,942,000 and $12,874,000 in the comparable periods of the prior year. d-Includes extraordinary items from utilization of operating loss carryforwards of $6,213,000 and $11,029,000 for the latest quarter and 6 months, respectively, and $2,658,000 and $2,695,000 for the comparable periods of 1985. e-Includes a pretax gain of approximately $3 million from the sale of the company's investment in National Gypsum Co. Share earnings for the first half of 1986 and the second quarter of both 1985 and 1986 are after preferred stock dividends; there were no preferred stock dividends in the first quarter of last year.

title: Moderate Quake Hits Alaska
description: A moderate earthquake, registering 4.4 on the Richter scale, sent sharp jolts through the Anchorage area this afternoon, but no damage was reported, officials said. John Sindorf of the Tsunami Warning Center said the epicenter was 20 miles northwest of Anchorage. ''We felt it as a series of sharp jolts,'' he said.

title: GATT Expected to Bar Soviet Bid to Join Talks
description: The major nations of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade are not expected to let the Soviet Union join in a new round of global trade talks, international trade experts said today.

title: California Debt For Prisons
description: The California State Public Works Board is offering $346.5 million of lease revenue bonds on behalf of the Department of Corrections through underwriters led by L. F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin.

title: HERD OF MOUNTAIN GOATS IMPERILS OLYMPIC PARK
description: Sixty years ago, a dozen mountain goats were shipped across Puget Sound to the Olympic National Park as part of an experiment to see if these remarkable climbers would adapt to the isolated mountain terrain of the peninsula.

title: KINCAID FURNITURE CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
description: The company said the latest quarter and 6-month results include a charge of $138,000, or 4 cents a share, from expenses incurred in a secondary common stock offering.

title: FLOW SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income Retroactive effect has been given to the 3-for-2 stock split effective Oct. 14, 1985. The 1985 shares outstanding include common stock equivalents.

title: TALKS RESUME TO STOP SPREAD OF CHEMICAL ARMS
description: The United States and the Soviet Union will resume talks next week on stopping the spread of chemical weapons, Administration officials said today.

title: SPECIALIZED SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Buffalo Sabres have offered Gil Perreault a contract for the coming season, according to The Buffalo News. Perreault, a center who announced his retirement after last season, has said he may reconsider. . . . Davey Johnson of the Mets, who played in Japan for two years, will head a team of major leaguers on a seven-game tour of that country Nov. 1-9. . . . The friend of the actor and former football great, Jim Brown, told the police yesterday she did not want to press charges against Brown, who was charged with hitting her at his Hollywood Hills home, the police there said. Debra Clark, 21 years old, signed a form at the Hollywood Division station stating she did not want to have Brown prosecuted for last Friday's assault charge.

title: JACKSON B. KRUEGER
description: Jackson Burke Krueger, a former executive editor of The Dallas Morning News whose journalism career spanned more than four decades, died of cancer Sunday. He was 77 years old.

title: 150-Year Prison Term Sought for Convicted Spy
description: Federal prosecutors today asked that Jerry A. Whitworth be sentenced to at least 150 years in prison with no parole eligibility for 50 years on his conviction of espionage.

title: Careers; Corporate Staffs Get New Roles
description: MANAGEMENT consultants and recruiters have a perennial interest in what chief executives think, and often take surveys to keep up with trends.

title: THE FADING OF A DISEASE IS PUZZLING
description: EVERY so often a common disease disappears and doctors are not sure why. A case in point is rheumatic fever, an inflammatory disorder that can cripple and kill.

title: WESTWAY OPTIONS: SENSE OF RESTRAINT
description: The four alternatives to the abandoned Westway project that were offered by the State Transportation Department this month are essentially variations on a single theme - a relatively modest riverfront boulevard.

title: CYBERMEDIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income

title: U.S. WEIGHING AFRICAN TALKS
description: The White House said today that economic reprisals against South Africa had to be viewed in a regional context since they would have a ''ripple effect'' in southern Africa.

title: Negotiators Hopeful About Effort to Halt Long Hormel Strike
description: The bitter year-long strike against Geo. A. Hormel & Company may be coming to an end this week as union and company negotiators meet in a hotel in Des Moines, Iowa, to seek an agreement.

title: Market Place; Bullish Outlook For Baby Bells
description: IN a stock market increasingly dominated by earnings uncertainty, the seven regional Bell companies have performed handsomely. Last week they traded at record prices. And Wall Street analysts, looking ahead, generally regard the Baby Bells with favor.

title: THE FIFTIES. From Notebooks and Diaries of the Period. By Edmund Wilson. Edited with an introduction by Leon Edel. Illustrated. 663 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $25.
description: THE FIFTIES'' is the latest in the sequence of volumes that Leon Edel has put together from the notebooks and diaries of Edmund Wilson. Its predecessor, ''The Forties,'' was something of a disappointment - it seemed relatively skimpy and unrevealing after the volumes that had gone before. But with the new book we are once again made aware of the range of Wilson's powers, and the full amplitude of his personality.

title: LLC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $3,590,000 and $3,873,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and an extraordinary charge of $1,897,000 for the quarter; the year also includes a tax credit of $4,417,000 and an extraordianry gain of $216,000 from the early extinguishment of debt. c-Net loss and includes losses from discontinued operations of $6,054,000 for the quarter and $6,760,000 for the year.

title: JETS CUT UNHAPPY 2d-ROUND DRAFT CHOICE
description: For the first time in their history, the Jets today cut a second-round draft choice before his rookie season even started.

title: COCA TEA LEAVES SPELL TROUBLE
description: The captivating taste of a cup of tea in a hotel in Lima, Peru, has got a 27-year old British tourist in trouble with the law in Queens.

title: LIFTOFF OF WEATHER SATELLITE DELAYED
description: A leak of liquid oxygen from a fuel system has forced a third delay in the launching of a $37.3 million weather satellite.

title: EALING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The company said the latest 6-month results do not include Ealing's 42 1/2 percent participation in Ealing Electro-Optics Plc., a public British Company.

title: PT COMPONENTS reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
U.S. WAR ON DRUGS IS CALLED FAILING AND POORLY FINANCED
description: A political skirmish over the war on drugs erupted today at a meeting of the nation's governors, with a Congressional subcommittee chairman sharply criticizing the White House's handling of the issue.

title: New Basketball League
description: The formation of the International Basketball Association, an international league for players 6 feet 4 inches tall and under, was announced yesterday. The I.B.A. plans to open a 60-game season in the summer of 1987, with 12 North American franchises and an existing league in the Philippines.

title: University of Maine Names New Chancellor
description: The University of Maine system trustees today announced the election of Robert L. Woodbury to become the new chancellor of the university's seven campuses.

title: New York City Speeds $349.6 Million in Bonds
description: New York City, like many other local governments, has accelerated its borrowing plans to avoid some of the restrictions proposed by the Federal tax bill.

title: Conrail's Proper Parents
description: The corpse of the Reagan Administration's plan to merge Conrail with the giant Norfolk Southern rail system has finally been pronounced dead by its proponents. Elizabeth Dole, the Secretary of Transportation, now favors returning Conrail to private ownership by selling the Federal Government's 85 percent share of the stock. That's good news for Conrail, good news for private purchasers and good news for the public.

title: MEDTRONIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $671,000. The company said the 98 cents a share for the year-ago quarter also includes an 8 cents a share gain from the sale of real estate.

title: Advertising; Getting Together At D'Arcy
description: JACK BOWEN'S hands are not shaking, and he is sleeping well at night. ''That hasn't always been the case in the last year,'' joked the chairman of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles.

title: BANGOR HYDRO-ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: DINOSAUR HUNTERS TURN UP CLUES TO CARE OF THE REPTILES' YOUNG
description: SOME went to the high, arid badlands of northern Montana as professional paleontologists and others merely as fascinated amateurs. But by summer's end, all were seasoned dinosaur hunters sharing the satisfaction of having reaped one of the richest scientific bone harvests in recent history.

title: FIRST OKLAHOMA BANCORPORATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The company said the latest-quarter loss includes losses of $45,596,000 in the company's principal bank, First National Bank & Trust Co. of Oklahoma City, which the comptroller of the currency declared to be insolvent July 14. The company also said that with the beginning of the second quarter, results of operations and investment in the bank have been accounted for by the equity method of accounting. During the second quarter the bank realized a net loss of about $93.3million, resulting in a net worth deficit for the bank.

title: PRODUCERS MAY REOPEN 'RAGS'
description: 'Rags,'' the musical about Jewish immigration to America starring Teresa Stratas that officially closed Saturday night after four performances, may get a second life.

title: Dr. Merle Montgomery, Composer and Teacher
description: Dr. Merle Montgomery, a teacher and composer who played prominent roles in several national organizations concerned with music education and publishing, died of a heart attack Monday morning in Arlington, Va. She was 82 years old and lived in Chantilly, Va.

title: Farley/Northwest Sets Stock Offering
description: Farley/Northwest Industries, the maker of Fruit of the Loom and B.V.D. underwear, said yesterday that it would sell as much as $547.5 million worth of common stock to help repay its debt.

title: Savings Unit Deal
description: The Great Western Financial Corporation said its Great Western Savings unit had agreed to buy four Chase Federal Broward and Palm Beach County Savings branches with combined assets of $195 million from Chase Federal Savings and Loan Association. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Most Interest Rates Decline
description: Interest rates declined in most sectors of the credit markets yesterday. Securities dealers said investor demand was good, though speculative trading was subdued by summer vacation schedules.

title: KEWAUNEE SCIENTIFIC EQUIPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes income of $180,000 from the recovery of a loan that was previously written off. c-Net income and includes a gain from the sale of assets and businesses of $330,000.

title: MET-PRO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Quotation of the Day
description: ''There are mass graves because we only had a few laborers and we could not dig individual graves.

title: Dominican Sugar Unit
description: The State Sugar Council of the Dominican Republic is close to bankruptcy and may not be able to process the 1986-87 sugar harvest starting in September, Vice President Carlos Morales Troncoso said today. The state-owned company would normally produce around 500,000 metric tons of sugar in a season, or about four-fifths of the country's total output. The announcement sent the price of sugar higher on world markets.

title: Albeck to Bradley
description: Stan Albeck, the former coach of the Nets and later of the Chicago Bulls, was named basketball coach at his alma mater, Bradley University, a highly ranked team last season. The school was penalized this summer for National Collegiate Athletic Association violations, but Albeck said: ''This is the only college job that I would take in my life.

title: SPARTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: SUSPECT IN CAR THEFT IS SHOT DEAD BY OFFICER AT A PROJECT IN QUEENS
description: One of two suspected car thieves being chased by the police through a housing project in Queens was shot and killed by a housing authority police officer yesterday morning after the suspect drove into a cement pylon and jumped out of the car.

title: EDUCATORS VIEW GOVERNORS' PLAN WITH SKEPTICISM
description: The prospects for enacting the more radical proposals advanced by the National Governors' Association report on education have been viewed with skepticism by educators and school officials around the country.

title: Labor and Democrats
description: The Illinois branch of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. recently endorsed the re-election of Gov. James R. Thompson, a Republican, so when the labor federation met in Chicago recently, reporters asked Lane Kirkland, the national leader, if that wasn't odd. No, Mr. Kirkland said, the endorsement of a Republican wasn't unusual since organized labor is not an arm of the Democratic Party.

title: Advanced Micro's Plans in Japan
description: Advanced Micro Devices Inc., a semiconductor maker based in Sunnyvale, Calif., said it would open a quality assurance test center in Japan in January, to be followed by a design center later in 1987. The company said it planned to double the 45 employees it has in Japan by the end of the year.

title: GOVERNORS PREPARING TO CHALLENGE PRESIDENT OVER WELFARE REVISION
description: The nation's governors are preparing to challenge the Reagan Administration on welfare revision.

title: Destination America
description: In less than four years, the Vietnam Veterans Memorial has become one of the most visited of Washington's many monuments. But not all people who lost relatives or friends in Vietnam can come to the capital, so a record of it will be taken to them.

title: METS WIN, 11-6, WITH 21 HITS
description: The question of the day is this: Do the Mets ever feel embarrassed when they come on to another team's home field and take it over? Do they ever feel even a bit awkward when they come riding into town, like barons in their gold-stutted carriage?

title: 'D.C. COP,' A POLICE DRAMA ON CBS
description: THE innovation in ''D.C. Cop'' is the cop. Once he was a reporter on a Washington newspaper, but then he wanted to find real action. Did he find it? ''D.C. Cop,'' on CBS at 10 P.M., is too exhausted to say. It turns pale in the opening minutes.

title: EASTERN MERGER WITH TEXAS AIR BLOCKED BY U.S.
description: The Transportation Department today rejected the proposed acquisition of Eastern Air Lines Inc. by the Texas Air Corporation, saying the plan would reduce competition on the shuttle routes serving New York, Boston and Washington.

title: Don't Punish the Gifted In the Name of Equality
description: To the Editor:

title: Added Problem
description: Brian Tribble, charged in the cocaine-intoxication death of Len Bias, the basketball star at Maryland, is linked to a murder investigation in northeast Washington, according to papers filed in District of Columbia Superior Court. The documents did not reveal the name of the murdered person, but two Washington television stations reported that the victim was Karl Lance Joyner, 30 years old, who, the police said, was found dead of multiple gunshot wounds on a school playground July 7.

title: The Need for Parental Leaves
description: When our baby was born, my wife put together a six-month parental leave by adding sick days and vacation time to an unpaid leave allowed by her contract. I got a leave of two weeks, so between us, we had an easier time than most families.

title: THREE POST 68'S
description: BIRMINGHAM, ALA. Aug.,26 (AP)- Ron McCann, Brian Watts and Bob McDonnell shot 68's today to share the lead in the 86th United States Amateur championship, which was halted late in the first round by a thunderstorm.

title: The Perils of Radon, and Ignorance
description: Man's move from the cave to the house wasn't as salubrious as expected. Thousands of householders are discovering a bizarre hazard of living indoors - radon gas that seeps in from the soil and increases the risk of lung cancer. This is no marginal menace. Almost every house has some radon, and up to 12 percent of America's 75 million houses may have so much as to warrant remedial action.

title: Continental Bank
description: The board of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation has decided not to oppose the proposed takeover of three small Illinois banks, with about $170 million in total assets, by the Continental Illinois Bank and Trust Company of Chicago. Continental must still receive approval from the Comptroller of the Currency and the Federal Reserve. The banks are First Suburban Bank of Olympia Fields, the First National Bank of Deerfield, and the First National Bank of Western Springs.

title: FRONTIER BANKRUPTCY SEEN TODAY
description: People Express Inc. is expected to file for bankruptcy protection today for its Frontier Airlines subsidiary because attempts to find a buyer for the airline were unsuccessful, a source close to the negotiations said last night.

title: COURT BACKS ALABAMA DEMOCRATS
description: A special panel of three Federal judges refused today to alter the Democratic Party's ruling that Lieut. Gov. Bill Baxley received the most legal votes in the primary runoff June 24 and was the party's nominee for Governor.

title: Man Here Gets Free Gas
description: I am living in an area suffused with deadly radon gas. It was in the newspaper at breakfast. ''Deadly radon gas,'' the paper said.

title: 150-Year Prison Term Sought for Whitworth
description: Federal prosecutors asked Monday that Jerry A. Whitworth be sentenced to at least 150 years in prison with no parole eligibility for 50 years on his conviction of espionage.

title: Bozell, Jacobs Starting New Campaign and Job
description: The bull is back. Merrill Lynch & Company is reintroducing its lumbering mascot in a new campaign that will break this week during television coverage of the United States Open tennis tournament.

title: G.M.-Suzuki Deal Seen
description: The General Motors Corporation and the Suzuki Motors Company of Japan are expected to announce on Wednesday a $466 million joint venture to build subcompact cars and four-wheel-drive vehicles in Canada, according to industry sources and published reports.

title: U.S. SUES CHEVRON ON OIL REFINERY DISCHARGES
description: The Justice Department and the Environmental Protection Agency, in a joint action, sued Chevron U.S.A. today, charging ''excessive discharges'' of grease, chromium and other pollutants from a southern California refinery into Santa Monica Bay.

title: The Right Diet
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Mud: There Seems to Be More of It This Year
description: Much of the debate in the United States Senate race in Louisiana this summer has not been over unemployment or the oil industry slump, but over the numerals 1083.

title: FLOATING POINT SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income

title: PAKISTAN LEADER WARNS FOES ON FUTURE PROTESTS
description: President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq of Pakistan said today that he expected that Benazir Bhutto and other arrested opposition leaders would be released from prison soon, but that they would be arrested again if future protests were not peaceful.

title: Boeing Delay By Air Force
description: The Air Force said today it had delayed a decision on whether to take action against the Boeing Company in connection with $485,000 it paid to five employees who went to work for the Pentagon.

title: NL Chemicals Recalls Its Ex-President to Post
description: Fred W. Montanari, the president of NL Chemicals Inc. from its formation in 1979 until last year, was named its president again yesterday and also its chief operating officer. He replaces John R. Slowik, who the company said had resigned to ''pursue other interests.''

title: THE SCREEN: 'WE WERE SO BELOVED'
description: FROM time to time throughout ''We Were So Beloved,'' Manfred Kirchheimer's fine, poignant documentary about Jews who escaped Germany before the Holocaust, stories are told of ''ordinary'' Germans who risked all to help Jewish friends.

title: Zaccaro Lawyer Says Wrongdoing Is Denied
description: A lawyer for John A. Zaccaro said Mr. Zaccaro ''emphatically denies any wrongdoing in connection with the awarding of Cablevision franchises in Queens County.''

title: HECHINGER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
A 'Warm Line' to Avert War
description: Today in Geneva, American and Soviet officials are talking about how to prevent accidental war. Few people even in our Government are paying attention, yet these talks may have as much impact on preventing nuclear war as the negotiations on nuclear arms and missile defenses.

title: Threats Are Reported In Chilean Burning Case
description: Witnesses to the burning of two teen-agers, reportedly by security forces, have been arrested, harassed and threatened with death in an effort to get them to retract or change their testimony, according to a lawyer.

title: Legally Blind Man, 85, Killed In Fall Into Sidewalk Opening
description: An 85-year-old retired textile executive who was legally blind stepped into an open basement entrance on West 86th Street and fell 30 feet to his death, the police said.

title: PERSPECTIVES VARY FOR KICKOFF CLASSIC
description: The opening game of the college football season, the Chase Kickoff Classic matching Alabama and Ohio State at Giants Stadium Wednesday night, is billed as a preseason bowl game, but not so for the players, who began their rehearsals the first week of August.

title: JET LINEMAN WANTS SCRIPT TO COME TRUE
description: Before most player drafts, a pro team that wants to get a line on how certain athletes perform need only ask, and colleges, with big athletic budgets, are more than willing to provide films.

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: THE lifeguard's girlfriend is blond. Hasn't it always been so? Her tan is the color of Karo syrup. Her shoulders are broader than her hips. And when she swims, her head knifes perfectly through each wave, so that she emerges sleek and shiny, a golden seal.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 27, 1986
description: Companies

title: G.E. Engine Order
description: The General Electric Company said it had received a $175 million order for CF6-80C2 engines, including spares, to power six of the Boeing Company's 747-400 aircraft for KLM Royal Dutch Airlines. G.E. said KLM is the 14th customer to order the high-bypass turbofan engine, which has been chosen to power nine types of aircraft. Total sales of the engines now exceed $1.3 billion, with export sales valued at $1.15 billion, the company said. It said KLM's 747-400 deliveries will begin in February 1989, with completion by October 1989.

title: King, a Giant Since '78, Is Cut
description: Since Gordon King became the Giants' first-round draft choice in 1978, he played 84 games and started 58 for them as an offensive tackle and sometimes guard. He will neither start nor play for them anymore.

title: Miami Starter Penalized 1 Game
description: Winston Moss, the Miami linebacker who was ruled ineligible by the school for using an instructor's car, will only have to sit out one game, the National Collegiate Athletic Association ruled today.

title: ENTERTAINMENT PUBLICAIONS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Selma Shapiro Wed To James Silberman
description: Selma Ann Shapiro, president of Selma Shapiro Public Relations, was married at her home in Manhattan yesterday to James H. Silberman, president and editor in chief of Summit Books, a division of Simon & Schuster. Rabbi Lawrence Siegel performed the ceremony.

title: Transactions
description: COLLEGES BRADLEY - Named Stan Albeck basketball coach. FOOTBALL

title: DRUNKEN DRIVING FATALITIES DECLINING
description: The number of traffic deaths and accidents attributable to drunken drivers has dropped steadily over the last five years in New York and New Jersey, state statistics indicate.

title: Michnik's Release - a Double Game
description: On Aug. 11, Adam Michnik again found himself outside the walls of a Polish prison - the beneficiary but also the victim of a partial amnesty that granted the release of some political prisoners but not others. Normally, he would have been released in October; by letting him go early, the regime has sought to demonstrate its liberalism to Western public opinion. Yet this also confuses and disorients the Polish public.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: SUMMER NIGHTS These summer nights we sleep with the windows open wide, the bed pushed near the windows. No air-conditioner. Fake air gives my husband a crick in the neck. Besides there's a wonderful cross-draft he tells me. On hot summer nights I lie there, hear the surge, the ebb and flow of my neighbors' air-conditioners, and sometimes I can turn the sound into beating waves on a distant beach and smell the salt in the cross-draft.

title: Yes, Sailplanes
description: Excerpts from the recently published record of House hearings on Department of Defense appropriations for 1987, before the Defense Appropriations Subcommittee:

title: Guilty Plea in Florida In Drug Tampering Case
description: The first person to be charged in a drug-tampering case pleaded guilty today to lacing cold and diet capsules with rat poison and told the judge he had not meant to hurt anybody.

title: RESTAURANT MANAGEMENT SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug. 3
description: Share earnings reflect a 4-for-3 stock split paid July 29.

title: ON EVEREST, FINE DINING AT 17,500 FEET
description: Just over a week ago, before Mary Kay Brewster, a 27-year-old mountain climber from Boulder, Colo., left for the Himalayas, she told an acquaintance that just knowing she has a chance to be the first American woman to reach the 29,028-foot summit of Mount Everest will drive her to the top. Her incentive to get back down safely, she added, will be the meal and impressive wine selection that will be waiting at base camp for her and the other 34 members of the 1986 Everest North Ridge Expedition.

title: 11 Are Feared Killed By Storms in Britain
description: Heavy rain from the tail of Hurricane Charley flooded rivers and coastal towns in Ireland and Britain today and at least 11 people were feared killed by the floodwaters.

title: 25 MAYORS ASK MILITARY TO AID IN DRUG BATTLE
description: Twenty-five mayors gathered in New York yesterday and called for an increased use of the military to interdict drugs coming over the borders, new prisons for drug violators and hundreds of millions in aid to assist cities in the fight against drugs.

title: AMERICAN OFFICIALS SEEK TO QUELL NEW RUMORS ON LIBYA TERRORISM
description: A day after White House officials in Santa Barbara indicated that Libya was planning new acts of terrorism, Administration officials here expressed concern that speculation about such activity had got out of hand.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Durakon Industries, Lapeer, Mich., said its president, David W. Wright, has resigned.

title: On Thermodynamics, Count Newton Out
description: To the Editor:

title: WITT OF ANGELS BEATS YANKS ON 4-HITTER
description: When the Yankees reached the All-Star Game break, they were seven games behind Boston, but they were playing well and moving up. Six weeks later, the Yankees once again are seven games behind the Red Sox, but this time they are moving down.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: RETURN OF BECKETT In 1960, Samuel Beckett wrote ''Krapp's Last Tape,'' a curious 45-minute play about a man in his 60's who listens to what he said on tape 30 years ago and engages in a dialogue with that younger self.

title: CITY TRAGEDY: SLAIN MAN, 21, BURIED AT LAST
description: Douglas Benson is finally back home.

title: BANKER'S NOTE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
description: Share earnings reflect a 50-percent stock dividend paid May 30.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: ROGER'S VERSION. By John Updike. 329 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $17.95.

title: GUS W. GRAMMAS
description: Gus W. Grammas, adjunct professor and director of the technology and company management programs at the Graduate School of Business of Columbia University, died of cancer Monday at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 44 years old.

title: KEY RATES
Foote, Cone Purchase
description: Foote, Cone & Belding Communications said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire 50 percent of Publicite Michel Provost & Associates, a Canadian agency based in Montreal. Terms were not disclosed. The agency will be known as FCB/Provost.

title: EL SALVADOR REJECTS CONTRA TRAINING
description: El Salvador has joined two other Central American nations in publicly and categorically rejecting the use of its territory by United States soldiers to train Nicaraguan rebels.

title: FOR SUMMER CORN, A RIOT OF TASTES, RAINBOW OF COLORS
description: CORN aficionados will gladly suffer the dog days of summer when it means being able to sink their teeth into the freshest, sweetest, crunchiest local corn. Better to go without than chew on starchy corn picked days ago in Florida. They wait to savor only the best of the current crop.

title: CALIFORNIA REPUBLICAN, A FAST STARTER, MEETS CRANSTON REALITIES
description: This is one of those places that lay claim to seeing the future first. In the bosom of the high-technology area around San Jose, it is the home of many entrepreneurs and technicians, the heroes of Ronald Reagan's vision of America in the 1980's.

title: LEBANESE CHRISTIANS URGE TRUCE
description: Lebanon's top Christian leaders called today for a nationwide cease-fire to allow for talks with their Moslem rivals on how to end 11 years of civil war.

title: Global Growth: A Task for All
description: THE economic expansion in the United States that began in the fall of 1982 is now one of the longest in the postwar period, but some of its characteristics are more extraordinary than its length.

title: G.E. EXECUTIVE NAMED HEAD OF CBS
description: NBC, at the peak of its success, was thrust into the General Electric era yesterday with the appointment of Robert C. Wright, a prized executive from NBC's new parent company, as the network's president and chief executive officer, replacing Grant Tinker.

title: MUSEUM FINDS WOOD BLOCKS
description: The Boston Museum of Fine Arts said today that it has found in storage what it believes to be the only complete and original set of wooden printing blocks carved by Katsushika Hokusai, one of Japan's leading artists of the 18th and 19th centuries.

title: ADAMS RESOURCES & ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $501,000 for the quarter and $586,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes tax credits of $313,000 and $788,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. The company said the latest quarter and 6-month net includes a one-time charge of $810,000 for expenses on the company's early retirement program.

title: Farm and Home
description: Farm and Home Savings Association said its management was in preliminary talks concerning a possible sale. Farm and Home did not identify its suitor, or say whether more than one potential buyer existed. Farm and Home Savings, which had total assets in 1985 of $2.8 billion, added that the preliminary discussions have not been considered by its board, and any agreement which might be reached would be subject to regulatory approvals.

title: Grains of Salt for a Forecast of Reaganism's Doom
description: To the Editor:

title: STUFF YER FACE reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss The company said general and administrative costs have been reduced by 50 percent compared with last year, and it is anticipated this trend will continue throughout the remainder of the year.

title: CYCLIST IN PURSUIT OF DREAM
description: Most of the riders here at the world cycling championships, which open Wednesday, are worrying about their chances of winning a medal. Mike McCarthy, an 18-year-old from Manhattan, is still worrying about his chances of participating.

title: STREET EATS BECKON WITH INTERNATIONAL FLAVORS
description: TUCKED between parking meters and fire hydrants along Water Street in the financial district, food vendors form a kind of lunch-box production line, turning out tacos wrapped in foil, hand-dipped chocolate-covered ice creams called Love Bites, crispy fried chicken and rolls stuffed with cold cuts. From a stainless-steel truck, Foula and Elias Kalikas operate a kind of stand-up roadside diner.

title: Pepitone Trial Starts
description: The prosecutor in the drug trial of the former Yankee star Joe Pepitone said yesterday in his opening statement he would prove that Pepitone and two accomplices ran a ''successful drug-selling operation.'' The 45-year-old Pepitone and two former convicts - Thomas Carbone, 52, and Robert Oates, 47 - were arrested in Brooklyn's Brownsville section March 18, 1985, after their car ran a red light, the police said.

title: DRIVES, WALKS ENHANCED
description: 1.Shoes for Driving This is the age of special shoes for all kinds of activities - walking, jogging, aerobics and, now, driving the car.

title: Israeli Aide Faces Dismissal
description: An Israeli Government employee who was arrested Saturday and charged with attempted burglary of an aviation-parts business will be dismissed, Israeli Government officials said today. The Nassau County District Attorney's office said the 25-year-old employee, Ronen Tidhar, was found on the roof of a Valley Stream building, with another man, trying to pry open a skylight. Barukh Binah, press attache at the Israeli Consulate in Manhattan, said, ''I don't know what he was up to, but it was no business of the Israeli Government.''

title: Military Life as Real Life
description: One big wound the Vietnam War inflicted on America was diminished public support for the military, and one might expect today's all-volunteer services to be all the more alienated. Yet as Richard Halloran reports in The Times, the isolation may be breaking down. That's welcome news.

title: THE SCREEN: 'BLACK JOY,' WEST INDIANS IN LONDON
description: ''B LACK JOY,'' the British movie that opens today at the Embassy 3, is a spirited fable about a country boy from Guyana who learns the ways of the big city. No sooner has Benjamin Ignatius Samuel Jones arrived in the Brixton section of London, home to many West Indians, than people begin taking his money; they rob, cheat and sweet-talk him out of it until he learns how life is lived on the tough and tricky streets of Brixton. ''Black Joy,'' based on a play by Jamal Ali, is a pilgrim's progress, or retrogression.

title: Interest Rates Fall At Citicorp Sale
description: Interest rates fell sharply yesterday at Citicorp's regular weekly auction of commercial paper.

title: AMERICAN BRANDS IN WRITE-OFF
description: American Brands Inc. said yesterday that it would take an after-tax write-off of $100 million for the third quarter as a result of closing several tobacco plants. The company also announced a 2-for-1 common stock split and an increase of 1.375 cents in its quarterly dividend.

title: BLOOD BANKS PLAN NEW TESTS
description: In an effort to prevent 50,000 cases a year of a dangerous form of hepatitis, a majority of the nation's blood banks will begin screening blood donations with two additional tests in the next few months, health officials have announced.

title: Berlin Wall Is an Eastern Economic Necessity; Cain's Mark
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. CALLS RACIAL QUOTA FOR APARTMENTS ILLEGAL
description: A proposed settlement of a discrimination suit at the Starrett City housing complex in Brooklyn is unlawful because it would restrict the number of Hispanic and black residents, the head of the Justice Department's Civil Rights Division told a Federal judge yesterday.

title: A PORTRAIT OF ANDRE KERTESZ, ON 13
description: SHORTLY before the photographer Andre Kertesz died in his sleep last September at the age of 91, he agreed to be the subject of a television profile. The result is ''Andre Kertesz: A Poet With the Camera,'' a half-hour introduction to his life and art being shown tonight at 8:30 on Channel 13.

title: Clean Sweeps
description: Each of them won the pennant, and the last five of them won the World Series.

title: SPIRIT OF TROTSKY STOKES LIVERPOOL POLITICAL FIRES
description: Politics in this dark and lively city has become as bare-knuckled as life was on its docks before the collapsing economy made it the hard-times capital of the Labor Party.

title: Article 745386 -- No Title
description: Hurricane Charley is estimated to have caused $7 million in insured property damage along the coasts of North Carolina, Virginia and Maryland on Aug. 17, a spokesman for the Insurance Information Institute says. The damage figures do not include losses covered by the National Flood Insurance Program.

title: Berlin Wall Is an Eastern Economic Necessity
description: To the Editor:

title: JUDGE ACQUITTED IN 1983 SAYS PANEL WANTS HIM IMPEACHED
description: A special judicial panel has charged that Federal District Judge Alcee L. Hastings of Miami fabricated his successful defense against Federal conspiracy charges and should be impeached by Congress, Judge Hastings said today.

title: WYLE LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes a $895,000 gain on the sale of land for which no income taxes were required because of capital-loss offsets. c-Includes gains of $57,000 and $133,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: TRC COS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $76,625, $119,000, and $113,705 for the latest quarter and year and for the prior year, respectively.

title: U.S.-SOVIET REGIONAL TALKS OPEN
description: The United States and the Soviet Union opened high-level talks today on crisis areas around the world where the two nations often have competing interests.

title: Legionnaires' Disease Breaks Out in Wisconsin
description: Two cases of legionnaires' disease, one of them fatal, have been confirmed in an outbreak of sickness that has left 23 people ill and five dead, health officials said today.

title: McENROE DEFEATED BY ANNACONE
description: So the past three weeks have not been a ploy, after all. The perils of John McEnroe in Vermont, Toronto and Long Island were not an elaborate scheme designed to give his opponents a false sense of security as he plotted to win another United States Open championship. The McEnroe trademarks - curly hair, pained expression and even some of that famous touch at the net - were on display yesterday, but in the end, it was as if someone had sneaked on the Stadium Court and masqueraded as the former No. 1 player in the world.

title: Aquino Will Meet A Moslem Separatist
description: President Corazon C. Aquino will meet a Moslem secessionist leader, Nur Misuari, in the southern Philippines next week as a prelude to peace talks on the long rebellion on Mindanao Island, her brother-in-law Agapito Aquino said today.

title: GUADALAJARA BATTLES ITS DRUG IMAGE
description: For many outsiders, the reports that an American narcotics agent was tortured here this month merely consolidated Guadalajara's reputation as a violent city held hostage by drug barons and corrupt police.

title: Mary Moody Northen, Texas Millionaire, Dies
description: Mary Moody Northen, who headed 50 corporations and held the reins of the state's third-largest trust, died Monday. She was 94 years old.

title: JOE TARTO
description: Joe Tarto, a jazz and classical musician whose real name was Vincent Joseph Tortoriello, died Sunday at Morristown (N.J.) Memorial Hospital. He was 84 years old, and was a resident of Boonton, N.J.

title: The 'Sir or Madam' Malady
description: When Shimon Peres, Israel's Prime Minister, arrived in Cameroon Monday to help renew diplomatic relations, his hosts went to great lengths to create a warm welcome. Some greeted him in Hebrew; The Cameroon Tribune printed a front-page headline in huge Hebrew letters: ''Mr. Peres, Welcome to Cameroon.''

title: KARPOV'S TRICKY TACTICS ARE MET BY CLEVERNESS
description: Anatoly Karpov tried to confuse Gary Kasparov by tricky tactical play in the 11th game of their world championship chess match in London Monday, but his effort was met by equal cleverness and the play defused into a draw.

title: Case of Baby Trading Is Dropped in Georgia
description: A father may have been doing what was best for his 16-day-old daughter when he tried to swap her for a sports car, the authorities said, dropping a charge against the father of contributing to the deprivation of a minor.

title: Italians Sweep In 10,000 Meters
description: Stefano Mei, a 23-year-old Italian policeman, won the men's 10,000 meters in the European Track and Field Championships today, ending the five-year reign of Alberto Cova, a countryman, in the event.

title: 11 REPORTED SLAIN AND 62 WOUNDED IN SOWETO BATTLE
description: Eleven blacks were shot dead by security forces and 62 other people injured a night of street fighting that engulfed a section of Soweto overnight - the worst bloodshed in the vast township since riots a decade ago.

title: TENNESSEE WALKING HORSE DRAWING NEW CHEERS AND CHARGES OF CRUELTY
description: The ''big lick,'' as almost anyone who lives within a day's drive of this farm community knows, is the exaggerated, reaching, high-stepping gait that has made the Tennessee Walking Horse the South's flashy four-legged darling.

title: AN ECONOMY RESORTS TO PLASTIC BAGS
description: WHEN served a soft drink in a plastic bag, as you will be if you visit Nicaragua, the first thing to remember is never to untie the top. If you do, your drink may become your unwelcomed bath as it spills all over you. The correct procedure is to bite a small hole in the bottom corner of the bag and drink through it.

title: BIG B INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
BROWN-FORMAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
OPERETTA: 'NEW MOON,' ROMBERG STAGED BY CITY
description: ''L OVER, Come Back to Me,'' ''One Kiss,'' ''Wanting

title: Airline Workers Seek To Protect Seniority
description: To the Editor:

title: DIET GUIDELINES REVISED BY HEART ASSOCIATION
description: THE American Heart Association revised its ''healthy heart'' dietary guidelines yesterday, lowering its recommendation for total fat intake and giving specific recommendations for salt and alcohol consumption for the first time.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN PLAYERS KEEP UNOFFICIAL FOREIGN CONTACTS
description: Many of those who argue fiercely about South Africa seldom give thought to the white minority opposed to the apartheid policies of the Pretoria Government. This minority includes virtually all the bridge players, many of whom are from Jewish families that fled Nazi persecution in the 30's.

title: A New Frontier For Esquire Group
description: In a reversal of sorts, a men's magazine has given birth to a women's magazine.

title: NOVELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 26
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $225,000, or 2 cents a share.

title: PETROLITE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Baby-Sitting Course
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: MICHAELS STORES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug. 3
SUSPECT SEIZED
description: An 18-year-old woman who graduated last spring from the Baldwin School was found slain yesterday morning in Central Park. The police said she had apparently been sexually abused and strangled.

title: GENESEE BREWING CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
FOOD NOTES
description: Greenmarket Harvest

title: CALIFORNIA VOTES CHANGE IN UNITARY TAX METHOD
description: The California Legislature, to the cheers of lobbyists from Japan and Britain, voted today to overhaul this state's unitary method of taxing the income of multinational corporations.

title: Shift Sought in Policy On Pupils With AIDS
description: The president of a Queens community school board said yesterday that he would press the City Board of Education to disclose the names of the six students with AIDS or a less severe disorder, AIDS-related complex, to a teacher, a principal and a nurse in the schools they will attend.

title: CDI CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
PERSONAL HEALTH
description: AT least 90 percent of sexuality is said to be in the mind, and in recent years sex researchers and therapists have focused increasingly on the role that mental images play in sexual arousal and enjoyment. They have found that sexual fantasy is nearly universal, among women as well as men, and is often consciously used to enhance sexual pleasure.

title: Burroughs Offers Issues Totaling $700 Million
description: The Burroughs Corporation is offering $700 million of debt securities to help finance its $4.8 billion acquisition of the Sperry Corporation.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Tom Charters, the executive director of the Breeders' Crown, said this year's championship series for trotters and pacers will consist of 12 races.

title: Carbide Is Selling Another Business
description: The Union Carbide Corporation said it would sell its electrical carbon business as it continued a corporate restructuring intended to reduce debt and improve earnings.

title: Mort Glankoff Dead; Began Cue Magazine
description: Mort Glankoff, the founder and chairman of Cue magazine, the first city-regional entertainment and restaurant guide, died Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 85 years old.

title: Comeback, Or Comedown?
description: It has been more than seven years and, for Bill Hodges, a lot of miles since the evening of March 26, 1979, when the Hodges-coached and previously unbeaten Indiana State basketball team, paced by Larry Bird, lost to Michigan State and Magic Johnson in the national tournament's championship game. Stopped one victory short of his dream - a perfect season and an N.C.A.A. title - Hodges was soon overwhelmed by nightmares. His three post-Bird teams won a total of only 34 games, he lost his wife in a particularly dispiriting divorce case, and Kevin Thompson, a prized hometown recruit with whom he was close, died of cancer.

title: SUCCOTASH SOLUTION
description: CORN is without question America's favorite vegetable and it need hardly be said that it is in season right now. If you're not on a determined cholesterol and fat watch, enjoy corn on the cob in the traditional manner -freshly steamed and lavished with butter. If you are concerned about your fat and cholesterol intake, use this sweetly succulent seasonal vegetable in other, more healthful preparations, such as succotash, that American stew of corn and beans.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: I HAVE always believed that foods fall into one of two categories. There are serious, sophisticated foods, among them meat wrapped in puff pastry and baked until golden brown - dishes that are complicated to make, but have guaranteed allure. These are august and special occasions. Then there are fun foods - rustic dishes, if you will - that are easy to prepare. These include meatballs, stuffed cabbage and dishes known in French as ''en brochette,'' skewer foods cooked, preferably, over an open fire or over fiery coals. Shish kebab is probably the best-known skewer food, a gift from the Turks in the 13th century. What is so delightful about it is the variety of ingredients a home cook can use - fish, fowl, meats (including game) and vegetables.

title: Israel and Cameroon Renew Diplomatic Ties
description: Israel and Cameroon restored diplomatic relations today after a 13-year break. The move was part of Israel's campaign to expand ties with black Africa.

title: ENTERTAINMENT MARKETING INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Shoreham Puts Power Into Lilco's Network
description: The Shoreham nuclear power plant still does not have an operating license. But today, for the first time, the embattled reactor supplied electricity to thousands of Long Island homes.

title: LA-Z-BOY CHAIR reports earnings for Qtr to July 26
Water Utility's Sharp Growth
description: IT is no secret that electric and telephone utilities have fared handsomely in a stock market environment partial to companies with rising dividends. But another regulated industry - the water utilities - has turned in a stellar performance amid little fanfare.

title: A Publisher and His Mission
description: The nation's capital is home to a modest handful of publishers. But none are quite like Occidental Press.

title: Rough Campaigning At Brighton Beach Baths
description: John S. Dyson, who is running against Mark Green in the Sept. 9 primary for the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate, campaigned at the Brighton Beach Baths on Sunday - a traditional campaign stop for Democratic candidates.

title: IN CAMEROON, SCENES OF A VALLEY OF DEATH
description: A few died in their sleep without knowing what had hit them. But most of the inhabitants of this hamlet in northwest Cameroon were not so fortunate.

title: SPECIALIST IN TRANSSEXUALISM
description: Dr. Harry Benjamin, an endocrinologist who specialized in transsexualism and geriatric medicine, died Sunday at his apartment in the Murray Hill section of Manhattan. He was 101 years old.

title: 9 MONTHS ON TRAIL OF A MOOSE: LESSON IN WOODLAND SURVIVAL
description: In official records, he is Moose No. 1, but friends just call him Bullwinkle.

title: Iran Reports American Gave Information to Iraq
description: Iran said today that an American engineer under arrest in Iran on espionage charges had provided Iraq with information for an air strike on a key Iranian telecommunications center.

title: T.W.A. Attendants Lose Job Bid
description: A Federal district judge has ruled that flight attendants at Trans World Airlines who joined a strike earlier this year cannot use their higher seniority to replace 1,284 union members who crossed the picket lines.

title: 3 REPUBLICANS IN FIRST DEBATE IN CONNECTICUT
description: The three Republican candidates for governor, sharpening some of their differences for their primary election Sept. 9, today traded barbs about one another's records of leadership.

title: POVERTY RATE DOWN SLIGHTLY IN 1985, LEVEL OF '81
description: The national poverty rate declined last year by four-tenths of a percentage point, to 14 percent, the same level as in 1981, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: Rev. F.D. Kirkpatrick; Associate of Dr. King
description: The Rev. Frederick Douglass Kirkpatrick, a Baptist minister who was an associate of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, died Aug. 16 at St. Luke's Hospital. He was 53 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: AT ANDREW CUOMO'S FIRM, POLITICS AND THE LAW INTERSECT
description: In 1982, when Mario M. Cuomo was New York's Lieutenant Governor, his close friend and counsel, Jerry Weiss, left state government to open a small law firm in Manhattan. Mr. Cuomo strongly encouraged Mr. Weiss's venture because, as he wrote in his diary, it assured that he could ''provide for the future'' no matter what his political fortunes.

title: Japan Growth Said to Slacken
description: Japan's economy is moving at a slackening pace because of a rapid slowdown in investment by export-oriented manufacturers, caused by the yen's appreciation against the dollar, the Government's Economic Planning Agency said today in its June report of leading economic indicators.

title: Art of Roasting Peppers
description: AT this time of year, with vegetable gardens growing almost audibly in the backyard, inventive uses for produce are welcome. One technique for adding a delightfully smoky flavor to sweet bell peppers - red, green or yellow - is to char the skin over an open flame before slicing and serving.

title: AMERICAN AGRONOMICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The company said the latest quarter loss includes a $1.1 million writedown to book value of idle plant facilities.

title: Bank Bill Gains in Texas
description: The Texas House of Representatives approved today an interstate banking bill that would allow financial institutions from other states to buy Texas banks, with few limitations, beginning Jan. 1. The Senate, which passed a slightly different version last week, is expected to approve the revised bill as early as Wednesday and Gov. Mark White Jr. is expected to sign it. The bill passed the House by a vote of 116 to 24.

title: U.S. PETROLEUM DATA
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: THE ROAD TO REGULATING VENDORS
description: IN recent years, New York City has tightened its inspection system for vendors and the foods they sell, although Charles Reisberg, an assistant commissioner of the Department of Health of New York City, said that complaints about wholesomeness and healthfulness are ''negligible.'' ''There are complaints, however, about sidewalk congestion caused by all these street carts,'' Mr. Reisberg said.

title: Wickes Weighs Sweetened Bid
description: The Wickes Companies said today that it might sweeten its $2.1 billion bid for the Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation.

title: INFORMATION SOLUTIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Garren Is Leader In Amateur Golf
description: Gary Garren of Newport News, Va., held a one-shot lead today after two rounds in the men's championship flight of the third annual Du Pont world amateur handicap championship.

title: Strong Demand For City's Bonds
description: Strong investor demand enabled underwriters at Goldman, Sachs & Company to reduce yields slightly for New York City bonds and increase the size of the financing to $400 million, from about $350 million.

title: Nuclear Names
description: The Department of Energy assigns code names to underground nuclear tests.

title: SOVIET BUILDUP NEAR IRAN TESTED CARTER
description: The Soviet Union built up its forces on Iran's border in 1980, leading President Jimmy Carter to consider using nuclear weapons to stop a possible invasion of Iran, two of his advisers said today.

title: ROSS STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: The U.N. Today: Aug. 27, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Law of the Sea, Plenary and Special Commission No. 2 - 10:30 A.M.

title: 2 EXPERTS FORSEE DEATHS OF 24,000 TIED TO CHERNOBYL
description: Two Western nuclear experts said today that 24,000 people would probably die of cancer in the Soviet Union over the next 70 years from radiation released in the Chernobyl nuclear plant disaster.

title: GOULD TO SELL MILITARY BUSINESS
description: In a move that sparked new talk of a possible takeover, Gould Inc. announced today that it planned to find a buyer for its military systems business, which accounts for about one-quarter of the company's $1.4 billion in revenues.

title: SMUCKER, JM CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Andrew Cuomo Firm Did Hirschfeld Work
description: Among the clients of Andrew Cuomo's law firm, until yesterday, was a man the Governor's son was also fighting in court and on the political battlefields: Abe Hirschfeld.

title: EASY START FOR '85 WINNERS
description: It wasn't the way they remembered it.

title: LANDMARKS PANEL TURNS DOWN TOWER FOR SEAPORT DISTRICT
description: A double-tower structure meant to evoke 19th-century waterfront counting houses at its base and an Art Deco skyscraper at its 30-story peak was rejected yesterday by the Landmarks Preservation Commission on the grounds that it would ''dominate and overwhelm'' its little neighbors in the South Street Seaport Historic District.

title: Ford-VW Talks
description: The auto makers Ford and Volkswagen, facing slumping sales in Argentina, are holding talks on merging their operations in Argentina and Brazil, a source at Volkswagen said. Executives from the two companies have been negotiating for two months on various ''cooperation'' plans, said spokesmen at both companies. The source at Volkswagen said the results of the talks would be made public by the end of the year.

title: BULL'S NEW SPREE: DOW JUMPS BY 32.48
description: Stock investors went on a buying binge yesterday, sending the market averages soaring close to record levels. The heavy volume of trading, which delayed openings for many actively traded issues, was linked to extensive program trading of stock index futures after Monday's close. Program trading has been a major cause of the market's volatility this year.

title: CHILI'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
2 Plan to Leave Posts at Walker
description: Two top executives of Hiram Walker Resources Ltd. plan to resign from the company Sept. 30, in the wake of the company's acquisition by the Gulf Canada Corporation, according to proxy materials disclosed yesterday. The two are Alfred E. Downing, chairman and chief executive, and A. R. McCallum, chief financial officer.

title: Top Matches For Today
description: STADIUM Morning 11 o'clock - Hana Mandlikova vs. Marie-Christine Calleja Second Match - John McEnroe vs.

title: The Hometown Kid
description: What a bummer. Go out for the morning paper and step over two bag ladies and three bums and one screaming maniac. They should ship 'em all out of town and leave New York to us civilized New Yorkers. Got to get the paper so I can read up on the U.S. Open before I head out there.

title: FRENCH SCIENTISTS REPORT DISCOVERY OF AIDS VIRUS IN AFRICAN INSECTS
description: Specimens of numerous insects from central Africa have been found to contain the AIDS virus, according to French scientists, who stressed that, despite the discovery, transmission of AIDS to humans by insects was extremely unlikely.

title: A SCULPTURE PARK GROWS IN QUEENS
description: The largest outdoor space in New York City for the exhibition of monumental works of sculpture will open next month in Long Island City, Queens, where Mark di Suvero and Isamu Noguchi have collaborated in building a landscaped sculpture park on an abandoned riverside lot.

title: WINE TALK
description: LAST week, Joseph Seagram & Sons, the spirits industry Goliath that is also the second largest wine company in the United States, resigned from the Wine Institute, the promotional and lobbying arm of the California wine industry.

title: B.O.C.: R.S.V.P.
description: Keelhauling and such being a thing of the past, people who mete out maritime discipline these days are more likely to make a happy occasion of it. Take the case of Philippe Jeantot, who in 1983 became known as the Flying Frenchman for his record time in the first B.O.C. Challenge, a round-the-world race for soloists. Jeantot was three days late arriving in Newport, R.I., from France last week for preparations for the second Challenge, which begins Saturday. To make matters worse, he had failed to complete a 2,000-mile transoceanic qualifying voyage by Aug. 1 aboard Credit Agricole, his 60-foot sailboat.

title: DEB SHOPS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
ESTONIANS RESIST CHERNOBYL DUTY, PAPER SAYS
description: A group of Estonian reservists briefly resisted after they were called up to help decontaminate the zone around the Chernobyl nuclear reactor that burned in April, according to a Soviet regional newspaper.

title: AMERICAN BAKERIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 12
description: b-Includes tax credits of $754,000 and $1,456,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. The company said the year-ago quarter and 6-month periods include the operations of the St. Louis and Fort Worth, Texas, bakeries, which have been sold.

title: FOUR DEMOCRATS ASK FOR FURTHER INQUIRY ON REHNQUIST TRUST
description: Four Senate Democrats today requested a further investigation of allegations by Justice William H. Rehnquist's disabled brother-in-law that the Justice had acted unethically by failing for more than 20 years to tell him about a trust fund set up to help him through his illness.

title: Barge Fire on Mississippi Forces 1,500 to Flee
description: Lightning apparently ignited a barge carrying a poisonous chemical today, injuring about two dozen people and prompting the temporary evacuation of about 1,500 people from the New Orleans suburb of Kenner, the authorities said.

title: TED KNIGHT, WINNER OF 2 EMMY AWARDS FOR TELEVISION SERIES
description: Ted Knight, a veteran comic actor who won two Emmy Awards for his portrayal of a pompous, egotistical anchorman on ''The Mary Tyler Moore Show,'' died yesterday. He was 62 years old.

title: SOVIET ORGAN PRINTS WORK BY NABOKOV
description: A small-circulation chess magazine has printed the first work by Vladimir Nabokov ever openly published in his native land, hailing the once-banned emigre author of ''Lolita'' as a master of language and metaphor.

title: CHARLES S. WOOLSEY
description: Charles S. Woolsey, former counsel to the Federal Bureau of Public Roads in Washington, died of a heart attack Sunday while on vacation in Utah. He was 72 years old and lived in Albany.

title: American Symphony Sets Subscription Drive
description: A radio subscription drive for the American Symphony Orchestra will be held Sept. 7 on WQXR-FM (96.3) and AM (1560) from 9 A.M. to 2 P.M.

title: S&K FAMOUS BRANDS reports earnings for Qtr to July 26
SUNRISE MEDICAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $685,000 and $900,000 for the quater and year, respectively.

title: MEXICO CHARGES 11 OFFICERS IN ABUSE OF U.S. AGENT
description: Mexico's Attorney General said today that 11 members of the Jalisco state police had been charged with abuse of authority and causing bodily harm in connection with the Aug. 13 arrest and reported torture of a United States narcotics agent in Guadalajara.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL METS VS. PADRES, at San Diego, 10:05 P.M. (Television - Channel 9, 10 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 10 P.M.) BRAVES VS.

title: TAPPED PHONE CALL OFFERED IN 'PIZZA CONNECTION' TRIAL
description: A former Mafia chief's discussion of some shipments - which the prosecution has portrayed as major drug deals - was presented yesterday as key evidence in the ''pizza connection'' trial.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: SUFFOLK BILL WOULD BAR DRUG TESTING
description: Private and municipal employers in Suffolk County would be barred from conducting mandatory drug tests on most workers under a measure approved today by the County Legislature.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 27, 1986
description: International

title: BANKS JOIN PRIME RATE CUT TO 7 1/2%
description: Banks across America lowered their prime lending rate yesterday to 7 1/2 percent from 8 percent, but financial executives and economists were skeptical that the cut would do much to stimulate the economy.

title: AGENCY RENT-A-CAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 5-percent stock dividend paid in May 1986 and a 2-for-1 stock split paid in July 1986.

title: 2 Former Giants are Released
description: Scott Brunner, the quarterback, and Earnest Gray, the wide receiver, who were a former playoff passing combination with the Giants, were among the National Football League players cut yesterday as the teams reduced their rosters to 50 players.

title: Eastern Plagued by Problems
description: After losing $154.7 million in the first half of 1986, Eastern Air Lines Inc. appeared to be on the upswing in July, with its planes carrying passengers close to two-thirds of its total capacity.

title: New York Women Active in New York Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: BERNARD CHAUS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss The company said the income figures are pro-forma and are adjusted where applicable to eliminate the amount of stockholders-officers compensation paid in excess of base salaries, and are also adjusted for provision or credit for income taxes as if the company had formerly not been subject to S Corporation tax status, which terminated June 30.

title: Red Sox Romp, 8-1; Boyd Strikes Out 10
description: Dennis (Oil Can) Boyd pitched a four-hitter with 10 strikeouts, and Dwight Evans and Don Baylor hit home runs tonight as the Boston Red Sox broke a three-game losing streak with an 8-1 victory over the Texas Rangers.

title: Marketing Shifts to Promotion
description: PERHAPS the most fundamental change in consumer-product marketing in the last few years has been the shift in expenditures from traditional media advertising to promotion.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Friday about capital gains taxes incorrectly stated the effect of the top rate on overall income taxes. After 1987, the capital gains tax could go as high as 33 percent, but the tax on total income would stay close to 28 percent.

title: NEW ALBUM, NEW LIFE FOR FRANK MORGAN AT 53
description: FRANK MORGAN, the Los Angeles-based alto saxophonist, recorded his first album in 1955 and had to wait 30 years to make a follow-up. His mid-50's debut, ''Introducing Frank Morgan'' (GNP), was released soon after the death of Charlie Parker, his chief inspiration. Even then, Mr. Morgan's playing was fluent and impassioned enough to attract attention. But there was no shortage of saxophonists playing in the Charlie Parker idiom, and when Mr. Morgan slipped from public view soon after the album's release, others were ready to carry the torch.

title: Certifiably Catholic
description: The dispute between the Vatican and the Rev. Charles Curran may be best understood as a trademark controversy. The Vatican, which controls the official CatholicT trademark, has withdrawn Father Curran's right to use it. Now, when he appears in the marketplace of ideas, he cannot represent his teaching as CatholicT, that is, endorsed by the church.

title: New D.F.T.&P. Unit
description: Della Femina Travisano & Partners said it had formed a new unit that would do fashion and beauty advertising.

title: COURIER DISPATCH GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $148,000 on the sale of real estate.

title: S.E.C. Accuses P.R. Executive
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today accused Anthony M. Franco, a Detroit public relations executive, of violating Federal securities laws.

title: Shift Is Foreseen At G.E. Credit Unit
description: Gary C. Wendt will replace Robert C. Wright as chief executive of the General Electric Credit Corporation when Mr. Wright departs to take the helm of the National Broadcasting Company, another G.E. subsidiary, sources at G.E. said yesterday.

title: SCREEN: 'HARD TRAVELING,' A 40'S TALE
description: ''H ARD TRAVELING'' is a son's tribute to the late Alvah Bessie, from whose 1941 novel ''Bread and a Stone'' the movie has been adapted. Mr. Bessie was one of the ''Hollywood 10,'' left-wing screen writers and directors who were jailed for their refusal to testify in 1947 before the House Committee on Un-American Activities and were blacklisted afterward.

title: Berlin Wall Is an Eastern Economic Necessity; Open for Dumping
description: To the Editor:

title: Torn Will, Tangled Inheritance
description: The attorney held the tattered and taped document above his head and waved it dramatically at the judge.

title: New Office Expansion In Jersey
description: WHEN E.R. Squibb & Sons built its distribution center in Franklin Township in New Jersey's Somerset County in the mid-1960's, its neighbors were the chicken farms along Davidson Avenue.

title: Laidlaw Signs
description: Tom Laidlaw, the six-year veteran defenseman of the Rangers, has been signed to a new contract, details of which were not disclosed.

title: PETRIE STORES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug. 2
description: Latest 6-month results include operations of Miller-Wohl Co. and Winkelman Stores Inc. for 27 weeks, compared with 26 weeks in the year- earlier period, as a result of a change in fiscal years.

title: WAXMAN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of $238,000 from early extinguishment of debt for both the quarter and year. Latest quarter and year results include operations of Leran Cooper & Brass Inc. acquired Nov. 1, 1985, and Select-Line Industries Inc. acquired April 21, 1986.

title: New York Women Active in New York Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: TAINTED CHEESES: HOW DANGEROUS?
description: RECENT weeks have brought dismaying news to cheese lovers - warnings from the Federal Food and Drug Administration that a French cheese, Morbier Rippoz, is contaminated with the disease-causing bacterium Listeria monocytogenes. The cheese has been recalled by its importer, Crystal Food Import of East Boston, Mass., the F.D.A. said.

title: Austen's World
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: U.S. PLAN ON DRUGS IS SOUGHT
description: The president of the United States Olympic Committee called yesterday for a national policy on controlling drugs in sports, and said the Olympic committee would soon organize a conference of officials from the high-school level to professional sports. He also said an international conference would be called within a year in an attempt to establish worldwide uniformity on drugs in sports.

title: PARENTAL LEAVE BILL: ITS EFFECT ON MEN
description: THE 1950's notions of which parent should bring home the paycheck and which should schedule children's meals may be changed forever when Congress reconvenes next month. The legislators will vote on House Bill 4300, family and medical leave legislation guaranteeing both men and women the right to take a leave of absence from their jobs to care for a newborn, adopted or seriously ill child or to care for a seriously ill parent.

title: Steel Companies' Plea
description: Eight specialty steel companies today asked the Reagan Administration to take retaliatory action against Sweden for its sharply increased shipments of what they said was subsidized steel tubing and stainless steel wire. The Administration could decide to impose quotas or tariffs on Swedish exports.

title: London's New Man
description: The new British Ambassador to the United States, Sir Antony Acland, will arrive in Washington tomorrow without ceremony but just in time to notify the State Department that he is on duty and then to undertake his first official assignment: escorting the Prince of Wales on his American visit next week.

title: REAGAN PRESSES JAPAN ON OSAKA BIDS
description: President Reagan and Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone of Japan have intervened to insure that American companies get a chance to compete in the construction of an $8 billion airport at Osaka, Under Secretary of Commerce S. Bruce Smart Jr. said today.

title: WARNER COMPUTER SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
PONDEROSA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug. 14
CHANCELLOR EXPLORES KEY ISSUES
description: ''THE AMERICAN PROMISE'' is earnest and slightly self-conscious. Is John Chancellor really asking someone why she wants to have a baby? Mr. Chancellor isn't supposed to do that; he's supposed to ponder world events. Stay around, however, because ''The American Promise,'' on NBC at 10 o'clock tonight, does make its points.

title: G.M., SUZUKI IN CANADA TIE
description: General Motors of Canada Ltd. and the Suzuki Motor Company Ltd., Japan's fourth-largest automaker, today announced a $500 million (Canadian) joint venture to build Suzuki cars in Ingersoll, Ontario.

title: The U.N. Today: Aug. 28, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Law of the Sea, Plenary and Special Commission 2 - 3 P.M.

title: Classy Cathy Wins as Belmont Reopens
description: Classy Cathy, who won the Alabama Stakes at Saratoga 18 days ago, gradually wore down Life at the Top through a slow final furlong to win the $110,800 Gazelle Handicap yesterday as Belmont Park opened its fall meeting.

title: LUTHERANS BACK A USE OF QUOTAS FOR NEW CHURCH
description: The founders of a proposed Lutheran denomination of 5.3 million members have agreed to use quotas for women and members of minorities in choosing the church's national leadership.

title: GLOBAL NATURAL RESOURCES PROPERTIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $1,363,000 for the quarter and $2,035,000 for the 6 moths.

title: Frumps? Harrumphs
description: When John B. Fairchild, publisher of W, the New York fashion newspaper, visited Washington a few months ago to attend the White House Correspondents Dinner, he was appalled. Never, he is said to have observed, had he seen so many badly dressed women in one room.

title: COMPUTER NETWORK TECHOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said it did not record revenue in the year-ago quarter and 6-month period because it was still in the developmental stage.

title: Producers Say 'Rags' Will Not Be Reopened
description: The producers of ''Rags'' announced yesterday that they would not reopen the musical about Jewish immigrants in America despite appeals to do so from the cast.

title: INDEPENDENT TV GETS TIGHTER
description: Two years ago, independent television stations were beaming a bright picture. With a bigger share of television advertising dollars and improved ratings, they were giving the networks more of a run for their money than ever.

title: ALBERTSON'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Driesell Supported
description: The director of athletics at the University of Maryland, Dick Dull, has maintained his support for Charles G. (Lefty) Driesell after the school's basketball coach was not indicted by a grand jury investigating the drug-related death of Len Bias, Maryland's basketball star last season. ''He's still our coach, and rightly so,'' Dull said.

title: THIS TIME, CURREN IS OFF CENTER STAGE
description: Some players are at their best performing off Broadway, away from the big crowds dotted with celebrities, far removed from the scrutiny of the critics. Court 17 may be closer to a parking lot than the spotlight at the National Tennis Center, but given his experience at the United States Open last year, it did not bother Kevin Curren that he celebrated an opening-round victory in relative privacy yesterday.

title: Train Derailment Kills Two
description: A train derailed in eastern Colorado and killed two crew members, a Federal investigator said Tuesday. Gordon Inglis, acting head of the office of the National Transportation Safety Board in Denver, said an engineer and a conductor aboard the train were killed overnight. Their names were withheld. Mr. Inglis said the train was operated by Kyle Railroad, which took over the tracks formerly operated by the Rock Island Railroad.

title: EXXON PROMOTES 2 TO ITS TOP POSTS
description: The Exxon Corporation, the world's largest oil company, yesterday promoted its president, Lawrence G. Rawl, to chairman and chief executive officer, as expected. He will replace Clifton C. Garvin Jr., who retires Jan. 1. Lee R. Raymond will succeed Mr. Rawl as president.

title: IMPERIAL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
