description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $3,687,000 for both the quarter and 6 months, resulting from the company's reaching a settlement during the second quarter with the creditors of its discontinued building materials distribution subsidiary, Adobe Building Centers Inc. c-Net loss The company said the 1985 results give effect to losses from discontinued operations associated with Adobe of $265,000, or 5 cents a share, and $786,000, or 16 cents a share, in the second quarter and 6-month periods, respectively.

title: Alabama Hopeful Asks Court to Reverse Ruling
description: Attorney General Charles Graddick asked the Alabama Supreme Court today to reverse a Democratic Party decision that gave Lieut. Gov. Bill Baxley the party nomination for Governor.

title: NON-FARM OUTPUT DOWN
description: Non-farm business productivity fell at an annual rate of five-tenths of 1 percent in the second quarter, as the nation's output of goods and services declined for the first time since the end of the 1981-82 recession, the Government said today.

title: ANECO REINSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a realized investment loss of $26,000 for the quarter and a realized investment gain of $615,958 for the 6 months, and provisions for interest on convertible subordinated debentures of $68,425 and $542,300 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net loss and after a realized investment loss of $4,788 for the quarter and a realized investment gain of $21,540 for the 6 months.

title: BETTER HOPES FOR EARNINGS
description: WITH new highs set Tuesday and yesterday by the Big Board's composite index and Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, and with the Dow Jones industrial average nearing the record it set on July 2, there is a feeling in some quarters of Wall Street that there may be an upturn in the nation's drab economy after Labor Day.

title: AD HOC LIVING: PITCHING A PARTY TENT FOR THE SUMMER
description: PETER MOORE'S solution to his summer house problem has given him a unique opportunity to familiarize himself with the land on which he hopes to build one day. For the past two summers, Mr. Moore has pitched a tent on the three and a half wooded acres on eastern Long Island that he bought two years ago with Peter Pennoyer, his partner at the design firm Moore, Pennoyer, Torino Inc. in Manhattan.

title: Suppose a Briton Assaults a Yank
description: Excerpts from the report by Congress's Office of Technology Assessment, ''Space Stations and the Law: Selected Legal Issues'':

title: U.S. SETS BRIDGE LOAN TO MEXICO
description: The United States announced yesterday, as expected, that it would contribute roughly one-third of a $1.6 billion bridge loan being arranged for Mexico until more permanent financing can be assembled.

title: An Appreciation Of Bronx Historians
description: Their gifts might not warrant commemoration chiseled in marble, but donors to the Bronx County Historical Society offer something of great value: small records of day-to-day life that, together, compose the borough's history.

title: Top Matches For Today
description: STADIUM Morning 11 o'clock - Paul Annacone vs. Aaron Krickstein Second Match - Martina Navratilova vs.

title: DOREMUS ADDS RICHARD WEINER
description: Doremus & Company, the corporate and financial advertising and public relations subsidiary of BBDO International Inc., said yesterday that it had acquired Richard Weiner Inc., another public relations concern. Terms were not disclosed.

title: A POLISH TALE: THE FARMER, THE BANKER AND KAFKA
description: Stanislaw Kulaczkowski is a stubborn man. For almost four years he has tried to make and sell cinder blocks on his farm here, as permitted by law.

title: SUSPECT IS KILLED FLEEING OFFICERS IN BUS TERMINAL
description: A Port Authority police officer shot an unarmed man in the back of the head, killing him early yesterday morning in an underground area of the Port Authority Bus Terminal, the authorities said.

title: TENTATIVE ACCORD REACHED IN HORMEL STRIKE
description: Negotiators reached a tentative settlement tonight that could resolve the bitter yearlong meatpackers strike against Geo. A. Hormel & company in Austin, Minn. The agreement was reached in Des Moines by negotiators for Hormel and Joseph Hansen, the vice president of the United Food and Commercial Workers Union, who last spring was installed to run the Austin local after its militant leaders were suspended by the parent union for disobeying its back-to-work order.

title: Publication Is Delayed On Renata Adler Book
description: ''Reckless Disregard: Westmoreland v. CBS et al.; Sharon v. Time,'' by Renata Adler, originally listed for publication by Alfred A. Knopf next month, has been postponed briefly while undergoing a legal review by the publishing house.

title: Sam Goldaper on Pro Basketball; MANY TRADES, MANY REASONS
description: Since Draft Day 1986, the National Basketball Association has been undergoing a player upheaval of such vigor that if it continues, you won't be able to tell the players without a scorecard.

title: VACATIONING AT CAMPGROUNDS IS NOW HARDLY ROUGHING IT
description: Twenty years ago the typical campers came to the Lone Oak campground here with a tent, a grill and a lantern. After supper, they toasted marshmallows under the stars and marveled at the Berkshire Mountains in the distance.

title: CAESARS NEW JERSEY INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The company said in 1985, it recorded pre-tax net charges of about $2.7 million for the quarter and $3.8 million for the year,resulting from changes in reinvestment obligations under the Casino Control Act.

title: COTTAGE DECORATING, PLAIN AND SIMPLE
description: THE appeal of small country places - bungalows, fishing shacks, farmhouses or cottages - lies in their simplicity. Often, however, the rough-and-ready character of these buildings - the weathered woods, uneven floorboards, raftered ceilings and quirky spaces - is lost when an overzealous architect or decorator sits down at the drawing board. Rather than attempting to turn simplicity into grandeur, current design tides are moving in quite the opposite direction. The trick these days, according to two interior designers, is to make such houses livable without losing any of their indigenous flavor. Bare floors and walls, exposed beams, rattan or old Adirondack furniture and gently faded fabrics create casual rooms where summertime living is easy.

title: GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Manley Ends Holdout
description: Dexter Manley, the flamboyant defensive end who set a Redskins club record with 15 sacks last season, has ended a 33-day holdout, agreeing to terms with the team and reporting to Washington's training camp. Entering his sixth year in the league, Manley anchored the National Football League's No. 1-ranked pass defense last season. Manley's 15 sacks were fourth over all in the league.

title: Treasures Lost in the Finding
description: King George III's loss has become Delaware's gain. The hull of His Majesty's Ship deBraak was hauled up recently from the bottom of the Delaware Bay by a salvor's crane. Unfortunately the artifacts cradled in the hull were lost, and the hull itself may have to be sunk again if the state can't find the money to preserve it. The public interest would have been better served by leaving the wreck alone until it could be properly excavated by underwater archeologists.

title: MOOD INTENSE YET LIGHT AS SHAW REHEARSALS START
description: Greetings had been exchanged. A representative of Actors Equity had been and gone, leaving behind a pile of forms to be filled out. Seated around a big, battered table on stage at Circle in the Square, nine actors opened their scripts, picked up their pens, pencils and cigarettes, and became the wise, witty and foolish men and women of George Bernard Shaw's ''You Never Can Tell.'' The first rehearsal had begun.

title: BREAKING AWAY TO CHEERS OF THE CROWD
description: For the first time since 1912 in Newark, United States riders took to the track today in the world cycling championships with a home-field advantage.

title: RESIDENTS FIGHT PLAN FOR STATEN ISLAND'S FIRST CITY SHELTER FOR HOMELESS
description: The Koch administration is seeking to open Staten Island's first municipal shelter for the homeless, and a coalition of local groups is opposing the move.

title: Blasts at Ministries in Lima
description: Leftist guerrillas set off dynamite today in the bathrooms of the Ministries of Economy, Labor and Energy and Mines around midday, the authorities said. No one was hurt in the explosions.

title: RECITAL: MAKI, ORGANIST
description: IT is axiomatic that the organ is an orchestra in itself and natural that much orchestral music should have been transcribed or arranged accordingly. But this is a slice of the organ repertory that is not widely sampled in recitals, and so Paul-Martin Maki's concert of transcriptions at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine Tuesday evening was of special interest.

title: City Wants to Reopen Lead-Tainted Shelter
description: New York City plans to seek court permission tomorrow to reopen what would be the largest shelter for homeless families in the city, even though it has not eliminated many of the lead paint hazards in the building.

title: GRAHAM-MCCORMICK OIL & GAS PARTNERSHIP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a writedown of oil and gas properties of $8.6 million for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Net income

title: GUARANTEE FOR INVESTORS IN 3D WORLD
description: Aiming to increase capital flow into developing countries, a part of the World Bank announced a program today that eliminates the risk of loss for foreign investors in projects that the agency originates.

title: EX-HEAD OF CHURCH COUNCIL
description: Cynthia Clark Wedel, the first woman to be named president of the National Council of Churches, died of cancer Sunday at Goodwin House, a retirement community in Alexandria, Va. She was 77 years old.

title: CRAMER INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After pre-tax charges of $100,000 from writeoff of doubtful accounts and obsolete and slow-moving inventories, and $50,000 from provision for severance pay. c-Net income

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in Metropolitan Report on Monday with an article about the restoration of a cast-iron eagle in Phoenicia, N.Y., misidentified a man working on the eagle. He was Joseph Battle, not Dakin Morehouse.

title: Rivals May Be United
description: The 1978 Triple Crown series saw Affirmed and Alydar compete in three exciting races in which Affirmed won and Alydar finished second each time. Now those archrivals may both be stallions at Calumet Farm in Kentucky.

title: Maligned Heights
description: To the Editor:

title: Progress Made In 3-D Video
description: RECENT developments in 3-D technology have the potential of reviving the 3-D movie mania, especially on home television.

title: Firing in Berlin Escape Bid
description: East German border guards opened fire today at the fortified frontier with West Berlin to foil an escape attempt, Western police and military officials said. An amateur video-film broadcast on West German television showed a man being led away with his hands clasped behind his head.

title: EAST-WEST TROOP TALKS GAIN
description: Diplomats here said today that the United States had made a concession in talks with the Soviet Union by agreeing that NATO would give notice of troop movements from North America to Western Europe.

title: Birds, Bushes, Bucks
description: Accountants fear nothing more than uncertainty, so trepidation is abroad in the land among state budget-makers. The reason is the Federal budget-balancing law, which makes it hard for the states to predict just how much Federal money they will get and for which programs.

title: Kucinich Bows Out
description: Former Mayor Dennis Kucinich announced Tuesday that he was ending his independent campaign for Governor and instead would back Gov. Richard F. Celeste, a Democrat, in his bid for a second term against former Gov. James A. Rhodes, a Republican.

title: Governors Get Serious About Schools
description: Proclaiming ''the second wave of reform in American public education,'' the nation's governors would raise teacher salaries, give school managers greater flexibility and provide more early-childhood classes for disadvantaged youngsters. A National Governors' Association report also grabbed headlines with a proposal that states take over educationally ''bankrupt'' schools.

title: COMPUTER & COMMUNICATIONS TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $152,000 for the quarter and $267,000 for the year, and the year also includes an extraordinary income of $778,000 resulting from forgiveness of debt. c-Net loss d-Includes a tax loss of $193,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $60,000 for the year.

title: Alaska Air Plan
description: Alaska Air Group Inc. said it had received approval from the Department of Transportation to buy up to 51 percent of Jet America Airlines Inc. The department also approved Alaska Air's request to establish a voting trust to hold Jet America shares, the airline said. Alaska Air said it had agreed to restructure certain financial obligations of Jet America.

title: B-36 LOOSED HUGE H-BOMB ON NEW MEXICO IN '57 ERROR
description: Government documents show that a 42,000-pound hydrogen bomb, one of the most powerful ever made, accidentally fell from a bomber near Albuquerque 29 years ago, a newspaper said today.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Housing The oldest building in New York City is a Dutch Colonial farmhouse built in or about 1652 and still as far off the beaten path for most people as it was when it was in the distant Brooklyn farm country of East Flatbush. This is the Pieter Claesen Wyckoff House Museum, 5816 Clarendon Road, at Ralph Avenue, where tonight, from 6:30 to 7:30, the mood of past American periods will be evoked at an outdoor concert on the grounds.

title: ADDITIONAL CHARGES FILED AGAINST REAGAN MAID
description: A Federal grand jury today indicted Nancy Reagan's personal maid and three men on charges that they conspired to illegally export ammunition without a license from Richmond, Va., to Paraguay.

title: STEVENS, JP & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug. 2
description: b-Net loss and includes a charge to earnings for costs of restructuring certain operations and for estimated losses from then proposed divestments in the amount of $44.5 million after taxes, or $2.55 a share; this loss was offset in part by income items of $15,180,000, or 88 cents a share after taxes. c-Net loss and includes costs of restructuring amounting to $60,930,000 after taxes, or $3.49 a share, or $117,640,000 before taxes.

title: Offended by Coverage Of Rehnquist Trust
description: To the Editor:

title: NORTHEAST UTILITIES reports earnings for Year to July 31
QUICK CARE NEEDED AFTER CATCHING FISH
description: Unless you treat the fish you catch with care, no amount of culinary expertise will transform it into a delightful meal.

title: Dow, Bolstered by Oil, Edges up 0.28
description: Stock prices, bolstered by a strong oil sector, ended barely higher yesterday after Tuesday's broad advance.

title: Remaining Idaho Blaze Brought Under Control
description: Firefighters in the Boise National Forest have contained the last of thousands of blazes that destroyed timber and wilderness in nine Western states, the United States Forest Service said today.

title: FROM 2 VETERAN HELICOPTER PILOTS, VALOR AT NIGHT IN A JERSEY RESUCE
description: Most nights, John Francis and Gary Kane, helicopter pilots since the Vietnam War, shuttle gamblers between Manhattan and Atlantic City.

title: AMERICAN PIONEER SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $902,000 and $1,827,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes a tax credit of $825,000 for both the quarter and 6 months, and the 6-month also includes an extraordinary charge of $2,400,000 for litigation.

title: UNION BUILDS LOW-COST HOMES IN BOSTON
description: Tom McIntyre builds and sells houses at 40 percent below the going rate in Boston's costly real estate market. And he goes out of his way to make sure he doesn't make money on the deals.

title: Two Escaped Prisoners Free Hostage Unharmed
description: Two Louisiana prison fugitives released a hostage unharmed Tuesday near the Mexican border but remained at large, the authorities said today.

title: WORKING 80 ACRES, AMISH PROSPER AMID CRISIS
description: The mules fussed and the wagon's steel wheels rattled in the rose-lit dawn as Samuel Beiler, an Amish farmer, headed up the hill this morning to his fields.

title: A Genteel Game's Nasty Trend
description: British sports officials responsible for the long-pastoral game of cricket are worried that the ''yob problem'' - the hooligan fan behavior that has made British soccer notorious - is spreading to the gentler field of wickets and spinners, with racial abuse a favored weapon of the perpetrators.

title: MCCLAIN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 5-for-4 stock split paid May 1.

title: SWEATER OF VISITING MAYOR USED TO THWART A SUICIDE
description: A black sweater borrowed from a visiting mayor and a strip of white paper around a police officer's neck were enough to convince a homeless man, threatening to jump from the Brooklyn Bridge, that there was a priest he could talk to and some reason left for living.

title: CARRIER LOSS UPSETS MOUNTAIN STATES
description: In the Rocky Mountain region, the loss of Frontier Airlines could mean reduced service, higher fares and a loss of direct access to Stapleton International Airport, an important regional hub.

title: Sometimes Dad Is a Better Parent
description: To the Editor:

title: NAVISTAR PLANS TO REDUCE STAFF
description: The Navistar International Corporation said today that it plans to reduce its administrative staff by as much as 25 percent, or 450 employees, and modify certain provisions of its nonunion worker's health benefits plans.

title: Kassebaum Assails Pretoria
description: Senator Nancy Landon Kassebaum, Republican of Kansas, said during a one-day stopover in South Africa today that Pretoria lacked the leadership necessary to bring about meaningful change and could only maintain the status quo by taking the country ''further down the path of brute force.'' She was in Johannesburg to deliver the keynote address at a luncheon honoring 84 South African women, including the activist Winnie Mandela, wife of Nelson Mandela, the jailed leader of the African National Congress.

title: California Divestiture Clear
description: A plan to divest $10.6 billion in state funds invested in companies that do business with South Africa was approved today in the California Assembly and sent to Gov. George Deukmejian, who has said he would sign it.

title: G.M. SEEN OFFERING 2.9% RATE
description: The General Motors Corporation, in an effort to reduce its heavy stockpiles, will slash interest rates on 1986 cars on Thursday to 2.9 percent for three-year loans, automobile dealers said today.

title: Arrow President Chosen To Head Cluett, Peabody
description: Harris R. Hester, the president of the Arrow Company, was named president yesterday of its parent, Cluett, Peabody & Company.

title: The New Rainmaker
description: One of America's business leaders took me aside at one of those elegant New York dinner parties that a relentless pursuit of truth forces me to attend.

title: Pakistan Reports 2,000 Jailed in Two Weeks
description: At least 2,000 political opponents of President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq have been jailed in a two-weekcrackdown, the police said today.

title: Needham Gets Part Of Eveready Account
description: The William Esty Company, which had handled the Eveready Batteries account exclusively for 41 years, will now share the $25 million in billings with Needham Harper Worldwide, Chicago and Avrett, Free & Ginsberg.

title: ENVIRONMENTAL DIAGNOSTICS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BLUE JAYS TAKE 2; CUT GAP TO 5 GAMES
description: Tony Fernandez doubled home the winning run as a pinch-hitter in the eighth inning to break a 3-3 tie and give the Toronto Blue Jays a 6-3 victory and a sweep of their doubleheader tonight against the Cleveland Indians.

title: CHIEF OFFICER QUITS AT GENSTAR
description: The Genstar Corporation, which is now owned by Imasco Ltd., said its top two executives, Ross Turner and Angus Macnaughton, resigned and will be replaced by the president and vice president of Imasco.

title: Hail the Accused!
description: Whatever the leading preoccupation in Washington, power or politics, it is likely that public relations is a close runner-up.

title: INTEGRATED CIRCUITS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss

title: BASIC AMERICAN MEDICAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings are adjusted for a 10-percent stock dividend paid in June. The company said the latest quarter net income increased primarily as a result of the company's sale of its 50- percent investment in a therapy company joint venture, offset by a provision for the uncollectibility of certain third party receivables from prior years and a reduction of its investment in certain assets related to its Mobile Diagnostics Equipment subsidiary. The net effect of these transactions was an increase in net income of $1.3 million.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''By our action we wish to show the personal and collective support of the Church of Baltimore for international sanctions to bring pressure on the South African government and to end the inhuman practices of apartheid.'' - Archbishop William D. Borders, of Baltimore, on divesting stock in companies dealing with South Africa. [ A6:3. ]

title: ANDERSON, CLAYTON FINANCING PACT
description: Anderson, Clayton & Company said that it signed a definitive agreement with its lenders for $255 million of financing needed for a previously announced $480 million self-tender offer. The Houston-based food company, which is fighting a $56-a-share hostile tender offer from Bear, Stearns & Company and Gruss & Company, is offering $60 a share for up to 8 million of its 12.2 million outstanding shares.

title: CAMPAIGN TO KILL S.B.A. IS SCRAPPED
description: In a victory for small business and its advocates in Congress, the head of the Small Business Administration said today that the White House had scrapped its attempt to eliminate the S.B.A. as an independent Government agency.

title: AMERICAN EXPLORATION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a writedown of $1.8 million on the value of oil and gas properties.

title: CHECKING OUT REFINEMENTS
description: AFTER years of having only one style to chose from and few stores in which to shop, consumers can now find an array of water beds and can pick from this growing selection in a wide variety of mostly suburban stores. And along with the surge in popularity, spinoff industries have developed, affording the flotation sleeper dozens of accessories.

title: M'LAUGHLIN CLEAR OF BRIBERY COUNT
description: John J. McLaughlin, the former president of the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation, was found not guilty yesterday of accepting bribes and of stealing $250,000 from a wealthy heiress.

title: U.S. REAFFIRMS VIEW THAT QADDAFI PLANS NEW TERRORIST ACTION
description: The White House issued a new statement on Libya today, saying its assertions that Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi was planning new acts of terrorism were based on ''a realistic assessment'' by American officials.

title: Stable Fire Kills 13 Horses
description: Thirteen horses died early today as a result of a stable fire here, two of them as they were fleeing the blaze and were struck by a vehicle driven by the owner as he rushed to the scene, the state police said. Authorities said that 20 people were injured fighting the fire, at the River Meadow Horse Park, and that there was $1 million damage. The state police said 72 horses were in the stable when the fire broke out at 12:53 A.M. The cause was undetermined.

title: U.S. COURT BLOCKS PLAN TO USE AGENT ORANGE FUND
description: A Federal court plan to distribute more than $200 million among 250,000 Vietnam veterans and family members who claim injury from the wartime herbicide Agent Orange has been blocked by an appeals court.

title: Women Still Lag As Business Owners
description: To the Editor:

title: DEERE CHIEF TO RETIRE
description: Boyd C. Bartlett, Deere & Company's president and chief operating officer, said today that he planned to retire March 31, 1987.

title: ALASKA VOTERS REJECT GOVERNOR AND FORMER GOVERNOR IN A PRIMARY
description: Gov. Bill Sheffield was defeated by a 2-to-1 margin Tuesday in the Democratic gubernatorial primary by former State Senator Steve Cowper, a Fairbanks lawyer.

title: 17 YEARS OF THE WATER BED: A SOCIAL HISTORY
description: IT may never join the loftiest ranks of modern furniture design, those hallowed niches reserved for the likes of Mies van der Rohe or Charles Eames. And it is possible to overstate the cultural importance of the water bed. After all, the modern water bed began as a gurgling mass of velvet-topped vinyl, procured in bead-draped record stores along with incense and albums from the rock group Cream.

title: The Underpaid Lawyer
description: Washington has more lawyers per capita than any other city, with 40,000 members of the bar in either public or private practice.

title: GREAT WESTERN SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
JAPANESE LOAN TO AID IMPORTS
description: The Export-Import Bank of Japan has given a large loan to the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Company to buy $320 million worth of American imports.

title: Advertising; CONTINUING BATTLE OVER TOBACCO
description: THE two hearings held before a Congressional subcommittee this summer on banning tobacco advertising are only the start of what is shaping up as a major legislative battle.

title: DARKNESS BENEATH THE GLITTER: LIFE OF SUSPECT IN PARK SLAYING
description: Both the victim and the suspect in the strangling death Tuesday of an 18-year-old woman moved in the same Manhattan circle of privileged young people, a circle centered on the Upper East Side singles bar where the two spent the hours before the murder, the police and others close to the case say.

title: PENTAGON FEARS BUDGET CUTBACKS MAY FORCE DISCHARGE OF 600,000
description: The Pentagon calculates that it might have to discharge close to 600,000 active-duty and reserve personnel if spending cuts are imposed under the deficit-reducing law, officials said today.

title: Rehnquist Inquiry Is Rejected
description: Bob Dole, leader of the Senate's Republican majority, today rejected a request to reopen the Federal investigation of Associate Justice William H. Rehnquist and said the Senate will proceed as scheduled with his nomination as Chief Justice.

title: GOULD INVESTORS LP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After gains of $1,516,000 and $1,827,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, on disposition of properties, mortgages and investments. c-After gains on disposition of $363,000 for the quarter and $1,508,000 for the 9 months. The company said Gould Investors Trust was reorganized into Gould Investors L.P. May 13. Results prior to that date represent the operations of Gould Investors Trust.

title: YIELDS FALL AT BANKS
description: The ripple effect of last week's cut in the discount rate has produced lower yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds for the week ended yesterday.

title: SYMBOL TECHNOLOGIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax benefits from the utilization of net operating loss carryforwards of $454,000 and $1,075,000 for the latest quarter and year, respectively, and $123,000 and $253,000 for the year-ago quarter and year, respectively.

title: BULBS: THINKING LAVISHLY
description: NOW that there has been a touch of autumn in the air, it's high time to order spring bulbs the best way possible, by mail order. Procrastinators will have to make do with local garden centers and hardware stores but gardeners with more foresight will, by early September at the latest, have placed their orders with one of the goodly number of Dutch bulb companies. These concerns offer a greater selection of tulips, daffodils and so-called minor bulbs like alliums and snowdrops than is likely to be available locally.

title: Gotti Held Unfairly, Queens Man Asserts
description: Romual Piecyk, the Queens man who once acccused John Gotti of assaulting him but later changed his mind, visited the Federal Courthouse in Brooklyn yesterday to complain that Mr. Gotti was unfairly being denied bail and that the news media had made the reputed mob boss into a ''human monster.''

title: ALABAMA TURNS BACK OHIO STATE, 16-0
description: Alabama won the Chase Kickoff Classic in the fourth quarter tonight at Giants Stadium before a crowd of 68,296. But the Crimson Tide almost gave its victory away to Ohio State after time had run out.

title: SOUTH AFRICA PUTS SOWETO TOLL AT 12 IN TOWNSHIP RIOT
description: South African authorities reported today that 12 blacks died in overnight violence between residents of this black township and security forces.

title: Four Wineries Struck As Union Rejects Offer
description: The union representing more than 2,000 workers at a dozen wineries rejected a contract offer today, and harvest-time strikes were already under way at four wineries.

title: HERS
description: I KNOW a man who chases all around the world on business. And everywhere he goes, he grabs at women. An old-timey sort of philanderer, guilty, gleeful and duplicitous, he pretends that his wife has lately died. At home he lives in dread of his comeuppance. His wife, robustly healthy and vindictive by nature, so far knows nothing of his foreign intrigues. But since many of his conquests chase around the world on business of their own, it's just a matter of time, airline schedules and the inauspicious juxtaposition of planets. Soon this man and his wife will encounter a pretty lady from Paris or Dakar at some unlikely site like a tag sale in Connecticut. And he will hear the five most terrifying words in the English language. They are, Bill tells me, ''Hello, Bill, how are you?'' uttered in an unfamiliar female voice.

title: Disaster in New Hampshire
description: President Reagan declared a disaster for the state of New Hampshire today, the White House announced. The declaration directs the Federal Emergency Management Agency to use the disaster relief fund to supplement state and local efforts as a result of storm damage from July 29 to Aug. 10.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL BALTIMORE (AL) - Announced the recall of John Habyan, pitcher, from Rochester of the International League.

title: LLOYD RENEWS QUEST FOR NO.1
description: She says it's too late for major changes. Refinements, maybe. But that's all.

title: NUCLEAR EXPERTS PRESSING SOVIET ON SAFETY PLANS
description: Western nuclear experts said today that they did not believe the Soviet Union's announced plans to fix flaws in reactors similar to the failed Chernobyl unit would make them acceptably safe.

title: CONTRALTO'S MASTER CLASS
description: ''MASTER Class With Maureen Forrester,'' which will be shown on the Bravo cable network tonight at 10:30, is an amusing and instructive half-hour. Ms. Forrester has a contralto voice of regal dignity; it is therefore refreshing to find that she is also a warm, unpretentious and even earthy woman.

title: OPERETTA: ROMBERG'S 'NEW MOON' BY CITY OPERA
description: ''LOVER, Come Back to Me,'' ''One Kiss,'' ''Wanting

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, AUGUST 28, 1986
description: International

title: CONNECTICUT NATURAL GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a one-time charge of one cent a share from a loss on the repurchase of first mortgage bonds. Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in May.

title: Comptroller Charges Health Money Waste
description: New York City has failed to control an innovative medical program at Coney Island Hospital in Brooklyn, thus wasting public health money and undermining patient care, Edward V. Regan, the New York State Comptroller, said yesterday.

title: 'HERE A STAR, THERE A STAR, SOME LOSE THEIR WAY!'
description: MOST aspiring playwrights would probably kill to be Reinaldo Povod. As if it weren't enough that Joseph Papp decided to mount Mr. Povod's very first play, ''Cuba and His Teddy Bear,'' at the Public Theater, the producer recruited Robert De Niro, Ralph Macchio and Burt Young as stars. Then Mr. Papp moved the production to Broadway, where theatergoers are clamoring for tickets as they haven't for any serious new American play in this decade. Not a bad boost for a writer who's all of 26 years old.

title: BEN & JERRY'S HOMEMADE reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Duquesne Reclassified
description: Duquesne University's athletic program has been reclassified from Division I for 1986-87 for what Donald S. Nesti, the president of the school, called ''technical violations of N.C.A.A. bylaws'' involving the school's men's and women's swimming teams. The new unclassified status means the Dukes' men's and women's basketball teams will be ineligible for the Atlantic-10 Conference and National Collegiate Athletic Association tournaments.

title: 1942 WELLES FILM FOOTAGE RECOVERED
description: Footage from Orson Welles's 1942 uncompleted Brazilian semidocumentary, ''It's All True,'' believed lost for four decades, was discovered last year at the Paramount Studios vault in Hollywood. On Saturday some of that footage, compiled into a 22-minute short entitled ''It's All True: Four Men on a Raft,'' will have its premiere at the Venice Film Festival.

title: A MOOR ACCESSIBLE GARDEN
description: ON a sunny patio at Beth Abraham Hospital in the Bronx, members of the hospital's garden club gathered recently to harvest the ripe rewards of a summer's labor.

title: Republic Health Buyout Called a 'Tough Road'
description: When an investor group of stockholders and management completed its $835 million buyout of the Republic Health Corporation last week, Dr. LeRoy A. Pesch, the majority owner and chairman of the new REPH Acquisition Company, said, ''It has been a long and tough road.''

title: TREASURY NOTES OFF MODESTLY
description: Treasury note and bond prices fell modestly yesterday, reversing part of the gains over the previous two trading sessions.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Greg LeMond, the first American to win the Tour de France, has been awarded a $40,000 judgment in a 1984 lawsuit in which he charged that a Swiss manufacturer used him in a commercial endorsement without his permission. The United States District Court victory in Reno is LeMond's second victory in two such suits. . . . Lucien DeBlois, the right wing of the Montreal Canadiens, has become a National Hockey league free agent and can sign with another team without compensation to the Canadiens. . . . The medical condition of David Rivers, the guard on Notre Dame's basketball team, improved so much that he was moved out of an intensive-care unit in Elkhart, Ind. Rivers suffered a deep cut across his stomach in an automobile accident early last Sunday.

title: The Wright Stuff
description: Steele's Sports of Grafton, Ohio, the touring slo-pitch softball team that hasn't yet found a field that's too big or fences that are too high (Scouting, May 6), went into the record books again Tuesday night. In a 59-7, 51-15 doubleheader sweep of two area all-star teams in Rock Hill, S.C., Charles Wright, a 6-foot-5-inch, 245-pound Georgian who plays third base for the nation's top-ranked Super Division club, went to bat 15 times and hit 12 home runs, six in each game.

title: SPY SUSPECT IS HELD DESPITE PLEAS
description: A Soviet physicist accused of being a spy was held without bail yesterday by a Federal magistrate despite a request from the Soviet Ambassador to the United States that the physicist be released to the diplomat's custody.

title: TIERCO GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss Results for the 1986 periods include a $1,777,897 non-recurring gain from the sale of securities.

title: LIFE OF INDIANA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
N.A.A.C.P. IN DISPUTE WITH EX-STAFF LAWYERS
description: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People is embroiled in a bitter dispute with a number of its former salaried lawyers over hundreds of thousands of dollars in legal fees.

title: Crowley Leads In Amateur Golf
description: Bobby Crowley, a 33-year-old 7-handicapper from Cedar Hill, Tex., moved into the lead in the men's championship flight after the third round of the Du Pont World Amateur Handicap Championship today.

title: Conflict Resolution for Pension-Fund Managers
description: To the Editor:

title: AIRLINE DEREGULATION DEBATED
description: Mounting distress in the airline business, illustrated this week by the shutdown and threatened bankruptcy filing of Frontier Airlines, has revived debate about the wisdom of what was once regarded as the very model of successful deregulation of a major American industry.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Bank of New York Co. has elected to its board John C. Malone, president and chief executive officer of Tele-Communications Inc.

title: KEY RATES
INTERNATIONAL AID REACHES CAMEROON
description: International relief has begun flowing into the mountainous region of this small West African nation where an estimated 1,500 people died in a cloud of poisonous volcanic gas last week.

title: BISHOPS HIRE JESUIT WHO BACKED WOMEN AS PRIESTS
description: The National Conference of Catholic Bishops will hire a Jesuit theologian as a top doctrinal adviser despite the recent disclosure that he signed a letter nine years ago favoring ordination for Roman Catholic women, the bishops conference announced yesterday.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS

title: The Worth of Winfield
description: George Steinbrenner recently said that, yes, he had paid too much for Dave Winfield. Before the 1981 season he signed Winfield for nearly $20 million for 10 years. ''It was much too much,'' said Steinbrenner recently. ''For that money, a man must be a genuine superstar.''

title: U.S. OIL SOUGHT FOR STOCKPILE
description: In an explicit attempt to support the oil industry, the Reagan Administration announced today it was soliciting bids from domestic producers to supply crude oil for the nation's strategic stockpile.

title: Q&A
description: Q. The cabinets and panels in my kitchen are stained a dark brown, with a clear finish over the stain. I want to paint over all this wood. I plan to sand and clean the surfaces thoroughly, apply a coat of a stain-killing primer or sealer, then apply two coats of oil-base enamel. I don't know if the old finish is varnish or lacquer, but I cannot do the job if the old finish must be removed first. Also, if painting over the old finish will cause problems, I won't do it. Will the sealer I plan to use as a first coat keep the new paint from peeling? A. If you sand thoroughly and make sure all wax, polish and soil is cleaned off, then you should have no problem with paint peeling, as long as the varnish or other finish is sound and sticking firmly. In other words, if the varnish (or lacquer) underneath lets go, it will take the paint off with it. Using the stain-killer as a first coat is a good idea because that is the best way to make certain the stain color won't bleed through the paint. The sealer will also help insure a good bond when the paint is applied. Q. My apartment is on the top floor of an old five-story apartment house and the roof is tarred, making summer heat a problem. Is there a coating I can apply to the roof surface to help reflect away the heat, and will coating the windows with a reflecting material also help? A. The answer to both questions is yes.

title: Good Gets Better
description: For David Glenz, head pro at the Morris County Golf Club in Convent Station, N.J., a good year keeps getting better. Glenz shot final rounds of 68 and 69 yesterday for a 54-hole total of four-under-par 212 and won the Nissan Golf Classic at the Woodlake Country Club in Lakewood, N.J. It was the third major victory of the season for Glenz, who won the New Jersey Open in July and the Metropolitan Golf Association Open last week.

title: ONE WEEK AND $29,000 TO STRIP A BANK

Mr. Elkind, the owner of Lost City Arts, a Manhattan company that sells architectural artifacts, was surveying the interior of what was once the headquarters of the Second National Bank of Philadelphia: brass chandeliers, molded glass lamps, stone benches with velvet seats, iron grillwork, plaster rosettes, mahogany paneling, the ornate gallery clock behind the eagle and, 40 feet above him, 100 panels of stained-glass ceiling.

title: WARY EYE ON CELEBRITY STATUS

After years of effort, after his rise through the men's tennis rankings from No. 389 to 256 to 94 to 13, Annacone yesterday reached what seems to have become the zenith of American achievement: the network television appearance much too early on the morning after.

The service is open to the public.

Phillips, the state police said. Mr. Phillips was not injured.

title: Mexico Must Help Itself

By extending large-scale aid but not asking the Mexicans to clean up their act - to adopt realistic economic policies, crack down on corruption and begin the slow and difficult transition toward free elections, pluralism and decentralization - we are ushering our neighbor into a volatile, dependent client relationship.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: ALTHOUGH building a raised wooden deck is normally considered a sizable project beyond the capability of most do-it-yourselfers, almost anyone can build a ground-level deck. The work can be done piecemeal as time permits, and the method described here can create an attractive outdoor living area with practically all the advantages of a raised deck. It is also often far better than a concrete or masonry patio in that it will reflect less heat and will blend in better with most landscaping.

title: On Bearing Someone Else's Baby
description: Elizabeth Stern, a 40-year-old New Jersey pediatrician, cannot bear a child. Mary Beth Whitehead, a 30-year-old New Jersey housewife, can. So, with the Infertility Center of New York acting as agent, Mr. and Mrs. Stern leased Mrs. Whitehead's reproductive potential for $10,000. She was to be artificially inseminated with Mr. Stern's sperm, bear the baby and then give it to the Sterns.

Caution on Contract

The Islanders are careful what they say about the physical defenseman because Bill Torrey, the president and general manager, has not been able to reach a compensation agreement for Curran with Harry Sinden, the Bruins' general manager.

description: The Cyclops Corporation shareholders voted against a proposed sale of its steel and non-residential construction businesses at a special meeting, the company said.

title: HENDERSON SPARKS YANKS TO 4-2 VICTORY
description: Their slumps have gone hand in hand. When Rickey Henderson struggled, it seemed as if he took the Yankees with him. But tonight, Henderson hit a home run to lead off the game, scored two runs and helped the Yankees to a 4-2 victory over the Seattle Mariners.

title: Ryles's Funeral
description: Willie Ryles, the Alabama defensive lineman who died last week from a blood clot in the brain after collapsing on the practice field Aug. 18, was buried today. Coach Ray Perkins, his staff and the team flew here after Wednesday night's 16-10 victory over Ohio State in the Chase Kickoff Classic. They were among 800 people at services in the Fourth Street Baptist Church.

title: FILM: LOSEY'S 'STEAMING'
description: ''Steaming'' was shown as part of the 1985 New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Sept. 28, 1985. The film opens today at the Baronet, 59th Street at Third Avenue.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: A Letter From Tutu
description: Archbishop Desmond Tutu, leader of the fight against South Africa's racist policies, has become the latest in a long line of activists to turn to mass mailing of fund-raising appeals from Washington.

title: SUSPECT CALLS PARK SLAYING ACCIDENTAL
description: In a videotaped statement, the man accused in the Central Park slaying of 18-year-old Jennifer Dawn Levin told authorities that after striking and killing the young woman during a sexual liaison, he watched from nearby as her body was found by a cyclist and then removed by the police, investigators disclosed yesterday.

title: PAUL McCARTNEY GOES BACK TO THE HARD SOUND
description: A funny thing happened to Paul McCartney on the way to making his next album. Or, to be more specific, it happened to his co-producer, Hugh Padgham. ''When we started working on the record, Hugh came in one day and said he'd had a dream,'' Mr. McCartney recalled when he visited New York this week. ''He dreamed he woke up one morning and had made this really bad, syrupy album with me, an album he hated, and that it had blown his whole career. We took that as a little warning.''

title: Cards Sign Anderson
description: The St. Louis Cardinals yesterday claimed Dennis Thurman, the defensive back waived by the Cowboys a day earlier, then signed Ottis Anderson, the running back, to a new three-year contract.

title: Minor Car Accident For Princess Caroline
description: Princess Caroline banged her car Saturday into a rock outcropping about 200 yards from the spot where her mother, Princess Grace, was fatally injured in a car crash in 1982, a palace spokesman said today.

title: OWENS MOVES TO THWART TAKEOVER
description: Seeking to deflect an acquisition attempt from the Wickes Companies, the Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation today announced a sweeping recapitalization and restructuring of its business.

title: U.S. Appears to Issue Mixed Signal to Press
description: At the end of July, according to Administration officials, President Reagan ordered his aides to get two messages across to Libya: that the Administration was seeing new signs of Libyan involvement in terrorist activity, and that it remained ready to punish Libya with military force if that activity continued.

title: WHITWORTH GETS 365-YEAR TERM FOR SPYING ROLE
description: Jerry A. Whitworth was sentenced today to 365 years in prison and was fined $410,000 for his role in a Soviet spy ring that the Government has characterized as the most damaging espionage conspiracy in decades.

title: LINCOLN CENTER FESTIVAL ROLLS MERRILY TO AN END
description: Lincoln Center's four-week Out-of-Doors Festival of free events will wind up its season this weekend in a burst of cosmic merriment. Mimes, jugglers, stilt-dancers, steel-drummers, an improvisational troupe and more than two dozen clowns will turn the outdoor plazas into a comic carnival, with the American Symphony Orchestra providing two breezy musical interludes on Sunday.

title: Rock Quadruple Bill
description: Yo La Tengo, Antietam, Christmas and Big Dipper will play a rock quadruple bill tomorrow at CBGB, 315 Bowery, at Bleecker Street (982-4052), beginning about 10 P.M. Tickets are $8.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: ERIC ROHMER, the French film maker whose series of six ''moral tales,'' as he called them, including ''My Night at Maud's,'' ''Claire's Knee'' and ''Chloe in the Afternoon'' established him as a commercial and critical success, has said he is interested ''in the depiction of what goes on inside man.'' He explored that question for more than 10 years. In 1980, he began what he called his ''Comedies and Proverbs'' series to focus on what goes on inside women. ''Summer,'' which opens today (review on page C5), is the fifth film to concentrate on female characters. The film is about a lonely young woman, recently estranged from her boyfriend, who is searching for somewhere to spend her summer holidays.

title: BURROUGHS MIGHT SELL SPERRY AEROSPACE UNIT
description: The Burroughs Corporation said yesterday that it might sell the aerospace and marine group of the Sperry Corporation, the rival computer maker that Burroughs has agreed to buy for $4.8 billion.

title: FAMILIAR CAST RETURNS FOR WOODWARD
description: Racing fans got the unusual opportunity to bet on the same horse race twice recently, and will get to do so again tomorrow.

title: Bouts Canceled At Felt Forum
description: Iran Barkley of the Bronx never got a chance to defend his Continental Americas middleweight championship last night at Felt Forum because the challenger, Charles Carter of Yakima, Wash., tested positive twice for cocaine, according to the New York State Athletic Commission.

title: When a Child Informs on Parents
description: When a Texas police sergeant who coordinates a successful crime reporting program was quoted as saying that ''we get husbands turning in wives, wives turning in husbands - we've even had mothers turn in their sons,'' he had not yet run across children who informed on their parents. But that is what happened recently in Tustin, Calif., where a 13-year-old girl turned in her parents for possession of marijuana and cocaine.

title: Partial Score
description: Have you heard about the T-shirts that are doing a brisk business in Houston?

title: THE SCREEN: 'SUMMER,' ERIC ROHMER COMEDY
description: DELPHINE (Marie Riviere), the Parisian secretary who's at the center of Eric Rohmer's exquisite new comedy, ''Summer,'' doesn't fit easily into a world of preconditioned responses. Like all of Mr. Rohmer's women, from Maud and Claire to Pauline, Delphine is unusually pretty and maddening in her steadfastness to her own decisions. She thinks for herself, which isn't easy for those around her. She's a pebble in everyone's shoe, particularly when she's a house guest.

title: Bid for Color Tile
description: Color Tile Inc. said General Felt Industries had proposed to buy the company for $30 a share.

title: U.S. STEEL'S RETIRED CHAIRMAN
description: Edwin H. Gott, former chairman and chief executive officer of the United States Steel Corporation, now the USX Corporation, died Wednesday at his home in Pittsburgh after a brief illness. He was 78 years old. Mr. Gott joined United States Steel in 1937 as an industrial engineer at its Ohio Works in Youngstown. Two years later he was transferred to the Clairton Works in Pennsylvania and in 1941 to the Gary Works in Indiana, the company's largest steel-producing plant. At the Gary Works he received a series of promotions and within a few years was named assistant general superintendent of South Works, a few miles away in South Chicago.

title: SOVIET VOICES SUPPORT FOR LIBYA
description: The Foreign Ministry said today that the Soviet Union ''supports Libya in its desire to defend its national sovereignty,'' but did not specify what steps, if any, Moscow would take in the event of American military action against Libya.

title: Culture To Keep Kids Busy
description: Back in 1972, Al Dale, a public events specialist for the National Park Service, began running summer dances at Fort Dupont in Anacostia, a low-income neighborhood in southeast Washington.

title: CITY OVERHAUL OF TAXI SYSTEM IS ANNOUNCED
description: Sweeping changes in the licensing of New York City taxicab drivers and a special undercover operation to find drivers who refuse to take passengers to requested destinations were announced yesterday by the chairman of the Taxi and Limousine Commission.

title: Mexican Boxers Win a Big One
description: Occasionally in recent years, there have been suggestions that fighters might benefit if they took a long enough timeout from beating up on each other to band together and form their own labor movement. South of the border they've already done so, and in Mexico City this summer a strike by more than 250 meagerly paid professionals knocked out a dozen scheduled cards at the popular La Arena Colisseo and left the capital without any boxing at all.

title: Diner's Journal
description: DO you get riled at the thought of paying $15 or more for a bowl of pasta with a simple sauce? If so, you might head downtown to West Hudson and Horatio Streets in Greenwich Village, along the Hudson River, to the Pasta Pot, a breezy four-month-old restaurant where all pastas on the menu are $6.50. Don't expect fancy uptown dishes with lobster or fresh salmon in the fettuccine. What you get are fresh and well-seasoned renditions of linguine with clam sauce, ziti with broccoli, noodles with pancetta and herby tomato sauce, linguine Bolognese and the like.

title: Lois Pitts Agency Quits Harrah's Account
description: After three weeks of unsuccessful negotiations, Lois Pitts Gershon Pon/ GGK announced that it had resigned the $5 million Harrah's Marina gambling casino account over philosophical differences.

title: FRONTIER FILES FOR BANKRUPTCY
description: Frontier Airlines yesterday filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy code. Its parent, People Express, questioned whether Frontier would ever fly again.

title: NUN RAPED IN CONVENT BASEMENT
description: A nun was raped in the basement of a Manhattan convent late yesterday afternoon by a former handyman at the convent who last night surrendered to authorities, the police said.

title: ARTURO GODOY
description: Arturo Godoy, who lost two heavyweight championship bouts to Joe Louis in 1940 during a career of more than 370 fights, died of cancer and diabetes Wednesday.

title: PUBLIC SCHOOL STUDENTS TO ATTEND 'CRACK' SESSION
description: Students at every level in the city's public school system will take part in a one-day ''teach-in'' this fall designed to inform students about the dangers of the drug crack, Mayor Koch said yesterday.

title: Another Easy Match for Graf
description: Tennis has a pace of its own, except in those rare instances when a player's skills are such that at the end of a match, the question asked most often is not ''Who won?'' but ''How long?''

title: Disaster in Cameroon Reported 'Under Control'
description: Government and American officials said today that the situation in northern Cameroon, where 1,500 people were killed by volcanic gas, now appeared to have been stabilized.

title: AIR FORCE BLOWS UP A TEST MISSILE AS FLIGHT OVER PACIFIC GOES AWRY
description: The Air Force blew up an unarmed intercontinental missile today when problems developed in a test flight over the Pacific Ocean, officials said.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: DIGGING UP THE MOUNTAINS. By Neil Bissoondath. 247 pages. Viking. $15.95.

title: Bronx Arts Ensemble
description: The Bronx Arts Ensemble will play music by John Freeman, Richard Strauss and Robert Kurka twice on Sunday afternoon, under the direction of Jonathan Tunick.

title: The U.N. Today: Aug. 29, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Law of the Sea, Plenary and Special Commission 3 - 10:30 A.M.

title: ST. JOHN THE DIVINE ALSO SERVES MUSIC
description: ''There are only two ways of coming to terms with playing inside the Cathedral of St. John the Divine,'' Michael Barrett, the conductor of the cathedral's orchestra, said recently. ''I try to choose repertory which has very slow harmonic motion. That seems to cut down on the mud factor. And then I overarticulate: short notes become incredibly short, and legato passages tend to be more marked than usual. You get a tad more definition that way.''

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: FRIDAY: 'THE LAST JEWS OF POLAND'

title: Experiment, Research And the Artificial Heart
description: To the Editor:

title: COUNTDOWN TO THE FESTIVAL'S END
description: The Greenwich Village Jazz Festival continues through Monday at various clubs in the area. For ticket information, call the appropriate club. A special festival pass, available for $10 at all of the clubs, will allow listeners to purchase half-price admission tickets to all festival events; many of the clubs are also offering third sets free.

title: Accounts
description: * Sandoz Corp. to Bloom Agency, New York, for $20 million in billings to handle Ex-Lax Pharmaceuticals and the Triaminic cold and cough medicine line, including a new test-product called neocitran.

title: 3 LAWYERS ACCUSED IN FALSIFYING OF TESTIMONY IN SUITS AGAINST CITY
description: Lawyers and private investigators used two witnesses who were paid to give false testimony in three negligence cases that won $1.9 million from the city, officials asserted in court papers yesterday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, AUGUST 29, 1986
description: The Economy

title: JETS END PRESEASON ON UPBEAT
description: Freeman McNeil was trying too hard and struggled tonight, but Ken O'Brien was able to look downfield without seeing stars as the Jets' preseason ended in a wild 37-30 victory over the Philadelphia Eagles.

title: PERKIN-ELMER FIGHTS SPRAWL
description: Like a chain of fast-food restaurants, the plants and office buildings of the Perkin-Elmer Corporation dot the landscape of southwestern Connecticut. Now the high-technology concern, with a suburban sprawl of 17 separate operations along a 20-mile corridor between its headquarters here and Danbury, is trying to bring its operations closer to home.

title: A DYR Office Sold to Dentsu
description: Young & Rubicam and Dentsu Inc. said that the New York office of their joint venture agency, DYR, would be sold to Dentsu to resolve a client conflict. Terms were not disclosed.

title: 'SPITTING IMAGE,' POLITICAL CARICATURES
description: AN NBC press release gingerly describes ''Spitting Image'' as irreverent. Actually, the show, created and produced in London, is scathing - outrageously and hilariously scathing. In Britain for the last couple of years, its more prominent targets, represented in wicked caricature by life-sized puppets, have been portrayed as a dotty Queen Elizabeth, a dimwitted Prince Charles and a regally snooty Margaret Thatcher who, after requesting her hairdresser to do something that will please everybody, has her head sliced off with a styling razor. Some of those routines have been seen here on Cinemax.

title: New York City vs. Its Housing
description: New Yorkers know all too well that their city suffers from the worst housing shortage in the country. But what they may not know is that the city itself is making the shortage a lot worse - and aggravating its own budget problems as well - by holding thousands of properties off the market in what is called the in rem program.

title: Siemens Quashes Rumor on Gould
description: Siemens A. G. said it had no plans to take over all or part of Gould Inc., an American electronics company.

title: CHEFS OF WORLD LEADERS SHARE HEADQUARTERS
description: You open the door of the refrigerator and there you find 20 pounds of camel meat staring back at you. What to do with it? Otto Goebel has the answer.

title: Let Beauty Stay in the Eye of the Beholder
description: To the Editor:

title: THREE DAYS OF FESTIVALS AND FANFARE
description: LAST-FLING urges to celebrate summer can be satisfied with abandon as the Labor Day weekend ends the traditional vacation season.

title: MILITANTS SHOW MUSCLE AS BONN SOCIALISTS MEET
description: The left wing of the opposition Social Democrats scored a victory on NATO-related security policy at a convention in Nuremberg that ended today.

title: ON FINANCIAL SYSTEM REFORM
description: HARDLY a day goes by when developments in the financial markets do not provide still another graphic illustration of the extent to which the speed, volume, value and complexity of financial transactions have increased. Indeed, while much has been written about this, the long-term implications for the structure and functioning of markets and institutions here and abroad are not easy to fully anticipate.

title: BLIND WIN RULING ON BRAILLE PLAYBOY
description: A Federal District judge ruled today that the Library of Congress violated the First Ammendment rights of blind people by eliminating Braille editions of Playboy magazine.

title: ART: EXHIBITION OF INDIAN MANUSCRIPTS AT LIBRARY
description: IT is a matter of great satisfaction to this regular visitor to the New York Public Library on Fifth Avenue at 42d Street that no one person will ever get to know everything that is in it. Even the regiment of computers that is now available to every researcher will not be able to do the trick. Computers may make most of us look silly at chess, but when it comes to going through 86 boxes that no one ever thought it worthwhile to look into, we have them beaten every time.

title:
THE REGION GEARS UP FOR SUMMER'S LAST FLING;
WESTCHESTER
description: Westchester's Labor Day weekend promises much this year, from organized song fests and other entertainments to the hiking and exploring that visitors always find appealing in this wooded county.

title: Two-Wheelers' Convoy In Times Square
description: It takes quite a lot of commotion to turn heads in Times Square, which has rather a lot of commotion to begin with, as evening falls.

title: INQUIRY ON DATA LEAKS WIDENED
description: The Commerce Department said today it has widened an investigation of suspected leaks of sensitive economic data to include reports that the 1.1 percent rise in leading indicators announced this morning was known in the financial markets Wednesday.

title: GENE-ALTERED PLANT TO GET TEST
description: The crop will consist of only 20 plants, but experts say the tiny tobacco stand may lead to an inexpensive genetic way to fight costly plant-devastating insects.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Tom Watson, the offensive lineman from Syracuse University who pleaded guilty June 12 to sexual misconduct, will be on probation this year and will be suspended for the first five games. Watson, a senior from East Patchogue, L.I., was expected to start the opening game against Mississippi State Sept. 6. . . . Carlton Fisk, the catcher for the White Sox, made an appearance for the American Association of Oral and Maxillafacial surgeons to educate the public about the dangers of smokeless tobacco.

title: 2 Die as Cargo Plane Crashes At Airport in Texarkana, Ark.
description: A cargo plane attemping to land at Texarkana Regional Airport crashed just short of the runway and burned today, killing the two people aboard, the authorities said.

title: 3 IN F.A.A. ARE CLEARED IN INQUIRY ON DRUG USE
description: Three of 34 air traffic controllers under investigation of off-duty drug use here have been cleared of any wrongdoing, the Federal Aviation Administration announced today.

title: LUTHERANS DEBATE ON HEADQUARTERS
description: Religious bodies once had the luxury of choosing their headquarters for reasons of faith, history or sentiment, but these days the cost per square foot for office space and the ease of air travel are more likely to figure in the selection.

title: CHERNOBYL'S TOLL IN FUTURE AT ISSUE
description: A statistical dispute arose here today at an international symposium over a projection that the Chernobyl nuclear disaster may cause 24,000 cancer deaths over the next 70 years.

title: Mexico Heard From
description: Newspaper offices receive elaborate sets of background information all the time. But seldom like the ones delivered around the capital yesterday by representatives of Mexico, a country that currently has its share of monetary, drug and emigration problems.

title: Life Sentence for Head Of Anti-Jewish Group
description: The leader of an anti-Jewish survivalist group was sentenced to life in prison today for second-degree murder in the death of a 5-year-old boy on the group's farm.

title: Sunkist Growers To Pay Settlement
description: Sunkist Growers Inc. has agreed to pay a $375,000 fine to settle Government charges that it missed a Government-imposed deadline on a forced sale of assets, Federal regulators said.

title: Bouts for Unbeatens
description: Tyrell Biggs, an Olympic gold medalist, and Mark Breland, both unbeaten as professional boxers, will fight scheduled 10-round bouts Sept. 14 at Harrah's Marino in Atlantic City, the promoter Dan Duva announced yesterday. Biggs (10-0 with seven knockouts) will meet Purcell Davis of Detroit (3-4 with nine knockouts) in a heavyweight bout. Breland (13-0, with eight knockouts) will fight a welterweight match with Reggie Miller (8-5 with 11 knockouts) of Lake Charles, La.

title: AMERICAN REPRETORY THEATER SETS 20TH ANNIVERSARY SEASON
description: The American Repertory Theater, which is celebrating the 20th anniversary of its founding by Robert Brustein, has announced its schedule for the 1986-87 season at Harvard's Loeb Drama Center in Cambridge, Mass.

title: Real-Estate Agent Is Charged With Burglaries at 6 Listings
description: A real-estate agent has been arrested on charges that he committed burglaries in at least six Manhattan apartments that had been listed with his agency, the police said yesterday.

title: G.M. CONFRONTS HARSH REALITY
description: The General Motors Corporation's offer today of historically low 2.9 percent financing is an attempt by the giant auto maker to cope with the consequences of its institutional overoptimism.

title: Judge Indicates He Backs Nonstrikers at T.W.A.
description: A Federal district judge says 1,284 union flight attendants who ignored picket lines in a strike against Trans World Airlines earlier this year are entitled to keep their jobs.

title: 34 PHARMACISTS AND PHYSICIANS SEIZED IN FRAUD
description: Detectives raided scores of physicians' offices and drug and medical-equipment stores in poor areas of New York City yesterday, charging four doctors and 30 pharmacists and pharmacies with Medicaid fraud.

title: U.S. SAYS LOCKHEED OVERCHARGED BY HUNDREDS OF MILLIONS ON PLANE
description: The Lockheed Corporation appears to have overcharged the Defense Department by hundreds of millions of dollars for the C-5B military transport plane, the Air Force said today. The Government plans to seek repayment.

title: WOMAN IN PROGRAM FOR EX-MENTALLY ILL CHARGED IN SLAYING
description: A former mental patient who had been placed in a Washington Heights apartment by a mental-health agency was charged yesterday with killing one of her two roommates.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, AUGUST 29, 1986
description: International

title: While the World Grows
description: By 2016 there will be twice as many people in the world, and most of the growth will take place in the poorest countries. That darkens the future for Kenya, for instance, with the world's highest birth rate, or Bangladesh, where 10 million in a work force of 30 million are unemployed and 3.5 million babies are born every year. The enlightened thing for America to do is help such countries conduct humane family planning. What it has just done instead is petulantly stamp its foot and close its purse to the two most effective international agencies.

title: FILM: 'REFORM SCHOOL'
description: ''R EFORM SCHOOL GIRLS,'' which opens today at the U.A. Twin and other theaters, is supposed to be funny. The publicity release describes it as ''an outlandish action parody.'' But for those among us who don't get a kick out of seeing young girls branded with hot metal, beaten by rubber hoses, terrified, brutalized and driven to suicide, the movie isn't exactly a thousand laughs.

title: THE 'WISE OLD HEAD' BEHIND PLANE VENTURE
description: Fourteen years ago, three men put up $50,000 each to start the International Lease Finance Corporation. Their first purchase was a DC-8 jetliner, which they financed partly with advances on the lease. This week, the company said it was purchasing 30 jets worth $840 million.

title: ANNACONE LOSES AT OPEN
description: Perhaps Andy Warhol's vision of the world of the future can also be applied to tennis. Warhol said that everyone will be famous for 15 minutes. Paul Annacone may have had his turn earlier this week when he defeated John McEnroe in the first round of the United States Open and became an overnight celebrity, appearing on television the next morning during the time early risers are having their second cup of coffee.

title: Sabres' Dykstra Injured
description: Steve Dykstra, a defenseman for the Sabres, was hospitalized after his car went off the road and flipped over in a Buffalo suburb. The 23-year-old Dykstra was thrown from his car after he missed a curve in Amherst, N.Y. The car slammed into a curb and went end over end before stopping in a gully. He complained of stomach and pelvis pain, but his condition was upgraded later from serious to satisfactory.

title: Professor Is Awarded Tenure Despite Views
description: Acting at nearly the last minute, Roman Catholic bishops have granted tenure at Catholic University here to a canon law professor who has taken stands at odds with church leadership on some issues.

title: What Court Upheld In LaRouche Case
description: To the Editor:

title: Crowley Wins Amateur Golf
description: Bobby Crowley of Cedar Hill, Tex., shot a net 70 today and posted a four-shot victory in the men's championship flight of the Du Pont World Amateur Handicap Championship.

title: LTV Asks Waiver On Pension Plans
description: The LTV Corporation, which last month filed for bankruptcy protection, said it would seek to defer pension plan contributions due Sept. 15 to its steel and energy products retirement plans.

title: Conversions Still Blossom in Brooklyn
description: The conversion of large, nonresidential buildings into housing may have trailed off in Manhattan in the mid-1980's, but it remains in full flower in some older neighborhoods of Brooklyn.

title: GIANTS PLAN TO SELL LUXURY-BOX FIRM
description: The New York Giants plan to sell the subsidiary that controls nearly all of the $40,000-a-season luxury boxes at Giants Stadium.

title: U.S. and Mexico in Pact To Extend Radio Hours
description: Thousands of daytime AM radio stations will be permitted to extend their broadcasting hours because of an agreement signed today between the United States and Mexico.

title: WHERE RUMORS ARE FACTS OF LIFE
description: Rumors on sensitive economic data have always been a fact of life in the credit markets. But now, as traders learn that yesterday's hot rumor was on the money, they are reassessing how they should react when the next rumor comes along.

title: Elder Joins Steelers
description: The Pittsburgh Steelers, hampered by the loss of their top cornerback, signed Donnie Elder, who was released by the Jets earlier this week, and waived Emil Boures, an offensive guard. The signing of Elder came three days after Dwayne Woodruff, the veteran cornerback, underwent a major knee operation that will sideline him for the season.

title: Treasury Issues Up Modestly
description: Prices of Treasury securities closed modestly higher yesterday, with the longer maturities posting the best gains. Dealers said the credit market was again dominated by rumors that key Government economic statistics had been leaked.

title: CAPTORS IN LEBANON WARN AGAINST ANY RESCUE EFFORTS
description: A statement apparently written by the underground terrorist organization known as Islamic Holy War warned today that the group would kill the American hostages it is holding if any attempt is made to rescue them by force. It also threatened a dire fate for whoever attempted such a rescue. ''We warn everyone who contemplates any foolish military or security action to free the captives that his as well as their fate would be much worse than that of United States marines on the outskirts of Moslem Beirut,'' a statement issued here said.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Company Briefs report in Business Day on Tuesday about the purchase of DBS Inc. misidentified the acquiring company. It is the Data Card Corporation.

title: CUOMO PLANS EFFORT TO GET SCHOOLS TO RETURN TO TEACHING OF 'VALUES'
description: Governor Cuomo, declaring that public schools had abandoned an important responsibility, said today that he was drawing up proposals to restore the teaching of ''values.''

title: Rock at the Ritz
description: The Lyres, the Reducers and Tiny Lights will play a rock triple bill tomorrow at the Ritz, 119 East 11th Street (254-2800); Tiny Lights will open at 11 P.M. Tickets are $10.

title: The Apollo Stompers
description: The pianist-saxophonist Jaki Byard will lead his Apollo Stompers big band in a program of Charlie Parker's music tonight through Sunday at the Jazz Cultural Theater, 368 Eighth Avenue, above 28th Street (502-4300). Sets begin at 10 P.M. and midnight; admission is $8, or $5 for students and the elderly.

title: 7 Teacher Strikes Keep 22,000 Out of School
description: Strikes by teachers in seven school districts in Illinois, Michigan and Pennsylvania left nearly 22,000 students without instructors yesterday.

title: Koch Touts His Lotto System
description: Here is a winning lottery system.

title: FEDERAL STUDY ON YOUTH URGES FIXED SENTENCES
description: A Justice Department study has recommended that state legislatures adopt fixed penalties for juveniles convicted of crimes, a proposal that could dramatically alter the way young offenders are punished.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL BALTIMORE (AL) - Recalled John Habyan, pitcher, from Rochester of the International League. Promoted Jeff Ballard, pitcher, from Charlotte of the Southern League to Rochester.

title: MATES GATHER FOR FOOTY ON THE TELLY
description: The Sydney Swans were finding it stormy going. Over 10,000 miles away Wendy Casey, eyes glued to the television screen, took a swig of Foster's Lager, raised her arms and shouted encouragingly, ''C'mon you drongos!''

title: Plan for Export Group
description: The governors of the Northwest's four major timber-producing states are pushing the formation of an export-promotion consortium with their counterparts in western Canada to ease overseas barriers to sale of the region's softwood lumber. Gov. John Evans of Idaho and the Governors of Montana, Washington and Oregon have backed the proposal.

title: Dances by David Gordon On 'Alive From Off Center'
description: David Gordon takes the everyday and abstracts it into small jewels of dances. The dances are made of extremely plain yet emotionally laden moves and gestures, linked with a deceptive simplicity. The dancers are like flies, some plain, some exotic, in amber situations. There is a sense of that special terrain in a program about the post-Modernist choreographer, which will be presented on Sunday at 10:30 P.M. on Channel 13. The half-hour program, directed by Edward Steinberg, Mr. Gordon and Bob Muens and produced by KTCA-TV in Minneapolis-St. Paul, is part of the ''Alive From Off Center'' series.

title: 3 Arrested in Attacks On Blacks in Toledo
description: Four white men were arrested today in connection with shotgun attacks this week on the houses of two black families living in a white neighborhood, and city officials have formed a committee to ease racial tension.

title: Reagan Out of The Closet
description: President Reagan has come out of the closet about his goal of overthrowing the Sandinista Government of Nicaragua. But his hope to use the so-called ''contras'' to do it looks more and more like an idea whose time will never come.

title: About Those Drug Tests
description: In case you were wondering if they are smoking or inhaling suspicious substances over at the White House these days, rest assured. According to officials there, everyone has passed the drug tests that have been encouraged by President Rea-gan as part of the national effort to combat the use of illicit drugs.

title: A Chance for Peace in Sri Lanka
description: There now seems to be a fair chance for a decent end to the civil war that has bloodied Sri Lanka and sent refugees flocking to Germany, Canada and elsewhere. With a nudge from worried India, President J.R. Jayewardene has finally made an offer that his island's Tamil minority ought not to refuse. He has agreed to the principle of genuine autonomy for a Tamil province in the north, and for pragmatic compromise in ethnically mixed eastern areas. It's a promising opening toward ending the conflict that afflicts the 15 million people on the island once known as Ceylon.

title: BY THE WATER
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. THE CHART HOUSE, High Street and the Hudson River, Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. (914-693-4130) - *(June 8, 1986) Eating clams and oysters from the recently installed oyster bar might help assuage your appetite as you wait for a table at this popular Westchester restaurant.

title: LEGIONNAIRES' DISEASE OUTBREAK IN COAST HOSPITAL
description: An outbreak of legionnaires' disease at the City of Hope National Pilot Medical Center in Duarte, Calif., has affected six patients, three of whom died, hospital officials said today.

title: BOTH SIDES ACT TO STRENGTHEN POSITIONS ON STALLED AGENT ORANGE PLAN
description: Both a Federal judge in Brooklyn who approved a plan to distribute more than $200 million among those who say they are victims of Agent Orange and the lawyers opposing the plan maneuvered yesterday to strengthen their positions in the face of an appeals court order blocking the proposal.

title: Addenda
description: * Miller Lyers Bruce DallaCosta Harrod Mirlin in Toronto has entered into a joint venture with the retail advertising specialist Warren Kornblum to form a retail agency to be known as MMB Kornblum International.

title: METS BRING SMASH HIT HOME
description: ''It's going to be incredible,'' said Wally Backman. ''Bigger than we even know,'' said Howard Johnson. And late Wednesday night, Dave Johnson sat in the visiting manager's office as bags were packed and thrown hurriedly for the trip back to New York, and he said, ''They're going to come out in droves.''

title: LABOR DAY PARADE CALLED OFF THIS YEAR
description: One holiday fixture will be absent this year. The Labor Day parade was canceled by Thomas Van Arsdale, the new head of the New York City Central Labor Council, who explained that it had diminished in popularity.

title: The Vatican's Ouster of Curran: a Pyrrhic Victory
description: This time, Vatican conservatives won, but their victory will be Pyrrhic. The Vatican bureaucracy has now successfully carried out a threat it originally raised 20 years ago, when it first attempted to chop down the Rev. Charles E. Curran, a theologian at Catholic University of America, in Washington.

title: United Is Winner On Frontier
description: For United Airlines, there is much to relish in the collapse of its deal to buy Frontier.

title: In the New York City of the 1980's, You Are What You Ride
description: To the Editor:

title: GIANTS' BACKFIELD UNSETTLED
description: Although Joe Morris has returned, the Giants still have a problem at running back. A mysterious injury to George Adams has left them short-handed, and with 11 days before their season opener they are seeking a solution.

title: Topics: Headed Home
