description: The '86 Mets ''Come see my amazin' Mets,'' said manager Casey Stengel of a team that lost 112 games in 1965, ''which in some cases have played only semi-pro ball.'' This season, it's not impossible that the Mets might win 112 games.

title: UNDERAGE DRINKING SPARKS A TRAGEDY AND DEBATES
description: Amid allegations that underage drinking was widespread at the East Side bar frequented by both the victim and suspect in Tuesday's strangling death of an 18-year-old woman, state liquor officials said yesterday that they lacked the manpower to crack down on bars that serve minors.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: The Skatalites, Village Gate, Bleecker and Thompson Streets (475-5120). The Skatalites - Jamaican jazz musicians who have an authoritative way of swinging a 60's ska beat with a basic foundation of reggae -have been performing tropical jazz and ska instrumentals every Sunday at the Village Gate, and backing a special guest each week, usually a singer from one or another tropical pop idiom.

title: Hudson Valley
description: From art shows and a country fair to flying kites and throwing boomerangs, the Hudson Valley offers a wide array of activities this weekend.

title: Top Matches For Today
description: STADIUM Morning 11 o'clock - Stefan Edberg vs. Kevin Curren Second Match - Jimmy Connors vs.

title: Wilson at Joanna
description: The pianist Jack Wilson is appearing tonight through Sunday at Joanna, 18 East 18th Street (675-7900). Sets are at 8:30 and 11 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is a two-drink minimum.

title: SOUTH AFRICA COURT EASES PRESS CURBS
description: Two key restrictions on reporters seeking to cover unrest under South Africa's emergency decree have been relaxed in recent days because of court challenges to their legality.

title: Golf Champion Upset in Amateur
description: Mitch Voges, a carpet sales manager from Simi Valley, Calif., upset the two-time champion Jay Sigel with an 8-foot birdie putt on the 20th hole today in the first round of the 86th United States Amateur Golf Championship.

title: HIRSCHFELD LOSES IN TOP COURT AND QUITS RACE
description: Representative Stan Lundine was virtually assured of the Democratic nomination for lieutenant governor yesterday as New York State's highest court refused to hear an appeal by his challenger, Abraham Hirschfeld, who had been removed from the primary ballot.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There's no indication of a broad-based improvement in the economy, even though July is a big number.

title: GOVERNORS AS GROUP: HARD TO SEE PARTY DIVISION
description: After four days of watching the nation's governors at their annual convention, Michael N. Danielson, a professor of public affairs at Princeton University, said an uninformed observer would have a hard time telling which were Democrats and which were Republicans.

title: Alertness of an Opponent Can Be a Helpful Indicator
description: One element in bridge psychology calls for an assessment of the mental state of an opponent. Is there reason to think that he is alert? Or does the evidence suggest that he is sleepy? And what inferences can be drawn as a result?

title: SLAYING'S NOTORIETY TOUCHES YOUNG CROWD ON 'THE CIRCUIT'
description: For an inner circle of young men and women who grew up on the Upper East Side, the children of investment bankers and entrepreneurs, the graduates of such elite private schools as Brearley, Collegiate and Dalton, Dorrian's Red Hand is a neighborhood clubhouse.

title: Nothing to It
description: The victory in Mexico was not the only breakthrough scored by boxers Wednesday.

title: IN THE NEW YORK CITY OF THE 1980'S, YOU ARE WHAT YOU RIDE
description: To the Editor:

title: Museums' Art On The Block
description: WHILE much attention has been paid over the last several years to the architectural endeavors of museums across the country, curators and boards of trustees have been busy reviewing more than facades and floor plans. Indeed, buying and selling holdings is a routine part of museum life. And recently the number of works from museum collections coming up at auction has increased significantly. Last season, for example, Christie's sold about 1,000 lots from 37 institutions amounting to $6.4 million, nearly double its figure from the previous year. At Sotheby's, last spring's sales alone totaled $7.8 million of deaccessioned works (art removed from a museum collection in order to sell it) from such institutions as the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, the Los Angeles County Museum of Art and the Art Institute of Chicago.

title: AGENCY CRITICIZED ON WILDLIFE ROLE
description: The Environmental Protection Agency repeatedly violated the Endangered Species Act by failing to protect threatened animals and plants from pesticides, according to a report prepared for the agency.

title: New Chief Scientist Is Named by I.B.M.
description: Ralph E. Gomory, a senior vice president of the International Business Machines Corporation and head of its research division, will become chief scientist. He also has been named to head an organization consolidating the company's research division, technology assessment and university relations functions.

title: Nature as Demon
description: The modern world reveres ''natural.'' It's a vitalizing adjective, a signal of beneficence in fruit juice or bran cereals, a guarantee that subtle man-made poisons are absent. Mother's milk is natural, spring water is natural, organic tomatoes are natural. But so is the poisonous gas that has erupted from a lake bottom in Cameroon, claiming 1,500 lives. As with radon gas now known to menace millions of homes; as with the earthquake that shattered Mexico City; as with the volcanic mudslide that killed 21,000 Colombians, nature can still shock and horrify us.

title: Burger Clears the Use Of Donovan Evidence
description: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger refused yesterday to grant a stay that could have prevented certain evidence from being used in the fraud trial of former Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan, officials at the Bronx District Attorney's office said.

title: ANNIE POWELL
description: Annie Powell, Britain's first Communist Mayor, died today at her home in the Rhondda Valley of South Wales, her family said.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Reggae Night '86, the Brooklyn Museum, Washington Avenue and Eastern Parkway. Labor Day brings the West Indian-American Day carnival parade to Brooklyn, along with a host of calypso and Caribbean music concerts. Tonight is an all-star reggae show, with two major instrumental groups - the jazz-tinged Skatalites and Augustus Pablo's mournful, modal reggae group, with the leader on the tootling melodica - and the singer Sugar Minott. Also on the bill are the Heptones vocal group and the singer Barrington Levy. At 8 P.M.; tickets are $20. Ticket information: (718) 773-4052.

title: A SLICK PLAY ON A SLICK FIELD
description: With the runner thundering in from one direction and the ball flying in from another, John Gibbons of the Mets settled in for the big crash, as a catcher must, with shoulders squared and body tense. He could see the ball coming and he could hear the runner.

title: KARPOV USES NUANCE TO MAKE LIFE EASIER
description: Anatoly Karpov used an improved version of the Queen's Gambit Declined to make a comfortable draw in the 12th game of his world championship chess match with Gary Kasparov in London on Wednesday.

title: PRETORIA NOW SETS SOWETO TOLL AT 21
description: The South African authorities revised the death toll upward today in the Soweto strife of two days ago, saying 21 blacks had died - 9 more than were officially acknowledged on Wednesday.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL METS VS. LOS ANGELES DODGERS, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. (Television -Channel 9, 7:30; Radio - WHN 1050, 7:30).

title: Stock Prices Mixed; Dow Off 4.36
description: The stock market ended mixed yesterday, held in check by continued worry that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries may fail to limit output. Oil company shares fell yesterday after several strong sessions.

title: Fruehauf Planning Sale of Some Assets
description: The investment group that acquired the Fruehauf Corporation last week for $1.1 billion said yesterday that it planned to sell some of the company's assets to pay for the leveraged buyout.

title: G.M. OFFERS SWEEPING PLAN
description: The General Motors Corporation yesterday introduced a sweeping sales incentive program and said it would delay introducing its 1987 models until early October.

title: UNION SAYS HORMEL PACT DOES NOT GUARANTEE JOBS FOR STRIKERS
description: Union negotiators announced today that they had reached a settlement with Geo A. Hormel & Company in a bitter, yearlong labor dispute in Austin, Minn.

title: Death Sentence in Georgia
description: A jury has ordered the death penalty for Carlton Gary, who was convicted of raping and murdering three elderly women. The jury deliberated about three hours before making its recommendation Wednesday to Judge Kenneth Followill of Superior Court, who set a mid-October execution date. Mr. Gary, 35 years old, was charged in the slayings of Florence Scheible, 89, Martha Thurmond, 69, and Kathleen Woodruff, 74. District Attorney William Smith has also contended Mr. Gary was responsible for four other stranglings, although no charges have been filed in those cases.

title: POLICE SPORT NEW LOOK IN SPEEDING CRACKDOWN
description: Cruising down the Connecticut Turnpike here today in his sporty Pontiac Trans Am, Steve Kosiorowski spotted what he was looking for: A speeding car, which tailgated another car, then shot past it in the right-hand lane.

title: SLOW GAIN IMPLIED BY 1.1% JULY RISE IN ECONOMIC INDEX
description: The Government index designed to predict what the nation's economy will do climbed 1.1 percent last month, its second-best performance this year, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: East Germans Crash Through Checkpoint
description: An East German family drove a truck through the Checkpoint Charlie crossing in the Berlin wall under fire from East German border guards early today.

title: Young Inmates Develop Green Thumbs
description: From the seed of an idea has blossomed an ambitious project at Rikers Island, with the help of one private agency and two city agencies.

title: BLUE JAYS CUT LEAD TO 4 1/2
description: Tony Fernandez and George Bell each had four hits as the Toronto Blue Jays won their fifth consecutive game tonight, routing the Cleveland Indians, 9-1, with a 16-hit attack.

title: SOVIET SEES NO SUMMIT GAIN AS REGIONAL TALKS WIND UP
description: The United States and the Soviet Union said today that three days of talks here on regional issues had failed to narrow differences between the two countries.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Arpad Industries, Englewood Cliffs, N.J., a holding company, named Hugh U. Rindermann president.

title: U.N. Unit Denies It Aids Forced Abortion in China
description: Officials at the United Nations Fund for Population Activities, reacting to the withdrawal of a $25 million American contribution, denied today that the fund supported coerced abortion in China and accused American groups of using the issue as a pretext for cutting aid for all family planning methods.

title: Outbreak by Inmates In Virginia Put Down
description: Inmates took over several buildings at a medium-security prison for about an hour today, attacking guards with mop buckets, chairs and trays, and ransacking the commissary.

title: A MERGED DDB GETS A LAST SALUTE
description: MOMENTS before the conclusion of the stockholders' meeting yesterday at which Doyle Dane Bernbach was merged out of independent existence and into the Omnicom Group, Paula Green, who had been a copywriter at the agency during its glory days two decades ago, stood up and injected a little emotion into what had until then been a perfunctory, by-the-numbers affair.

title: Montgomery Ward Shifts Top Officers
description: As part of its previously announced restructuring, Montgomery Ward & Company said that it had reorganized its senior management around two new divisions. Bernard W. Andrews, executive vice president, has been named to the new position of president of the home and automotive division.

title: IN THE NEW YORK CITY OF THE 1980'S, YOU ARE WHAT YOU RIDE
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Sees No Sign Mexico Will Curb Agents
description: Administration officials said today that they saw no evidence that Mexico intended to restrict the activities of American drug agents in that country.

title: Postseason Peek
description: If Houston takes the division title without much late pressure, the pitching matchups in the National League championship series will probably look like what appears below. Here's how the four leading starters for each team fared in the regular-season Mets-Astros series, which was won by New York, seven games to five:

title: Arms Race Starves Third World
description: To the Editor:

title: REAGAN APPROVES 2% RAISE FOR FEDERAL WORKERS
description: President Reagan today approved a pay increase of 2 percent next year for 2.1 million civilian Federal employees, saying that economic conditions precluded a larger raise.

title: Long Island
description: For those who have been dieting all summer with nothing to listen to but ocean sounds in seashells, now is the time to break loose: Long Island will be offering special treats for both the palate and the ears over the Labor Day weekend.

title: Saudis Free 113 Iranians Arrested in Pilgrimage
description: Saudi Arabia has released 113 Iranians arrested three weeks ago during the annual pilgrimage to Islam's holiest shrines, the official Iranian news agency reported today.

title: Workers' Pay Rises by 4.5%
description: Annual pay of workers in the United States, including part-timers, rose an average $833, or 4.5 percent, last year to $19,186, the Government said today.

title: SURGE IN TRAFFIC EXPECTED IN CITY OVER WEEKEND
description: New York City's bridges, tunnels, highways and airports are expected to be packed this Labor Day weekend as millions of travelers flock to or flee the city.

title: AIR FORCE'S DELAY SAID TO KEEP U.S. TO '79 ARMS PACT
description: Administration officials said today that the United States would not exceed the limits of the 1979 strategic arms treaty before a possible summit meeting between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: JERSEY HOUSE TIED TO MARCOS IS PUT UNDER MANILA'S CONTROL
description: A judge gave the Philippine Government authority today to take control over a 13 1/2-acre estate near here linked to Ferdinand E. Marcos, the deposed Philippine President, that has been stripped of most of its contents.

title: NAVY RECOVERS FROM YEARLONG RECRUITING SLUMP
description: Of the 81 Navy recruits who were sworn in at a Cincinnati Reds baseball game at Riverfront Stadium recently, more than 75 percent had scored in the upper mental categories in their military entrance tests.

title: Nuclear Reactors Must Be Designed Differently
description: To the Editor:

title: Ready for Flushing Friday?
description: Pity the poor unsuspecting tourist who stumbles into the Flushing area of Queens late this afternoon. In addition to the normal exodus of New Yorkers carrying Western civilization toward the Hamptons and New England, there could be one of the hellacious sports traffic jams in history.

title: BROADWAY
description: THE revival of J. B. Priestley's ''When We Are Married'' is one of the major attractions of the current London theater season, and there's a very good possibility that it will be on Broadway next fall. Emanuel Azenberg, the producer, and American Actors Equity have been discussing bringing over the original British cast, and it's hoped that a reciprocal arrangement will be worked out. Behind the project are Mr. Azenberg and Jujamcyn Theaters on this side of the ocean, and - over there - Ray Cooney, artistic director of the Theater of Comedy Company, and Duncan Weldon of the Haymarket Theater.

title: SCREEN: 'CARAVAGGIO,' A PORTRAIT OF THE ARTIST
description: FROM the paintings of Michelangelo Amerighi da Caravaggio, Derek Jarman, a British director and scriptwriter, has dreamed up a life of the rough-living painter of the late Italian Renaissance, who died in 1610, still in his 30's, full of honors and scandals. The adventurous exhibition opens today at Cinema 3.

title: NORSE ISLANDS, ENTREATED: HEED THE WHALES' CRIES
description: When Birgir Danielsen was a boy 50 years ago, the word of a community whale kill was of an order of excitement that combined death and sustenance, festivity and tradition amid the steel-blue sea cradling this archipelago's wild beauty.

title: Convicted Drug Dealer Gets Additional 10-Year Sentence
description: Leroy (Nicky) Barnes, who is serving a life sentence without parole for narcotics trafficking, was sentenced yesterday to a concurrent 10-year prison term on a separate racketeering conspiracy charge to which he pleaded guilty three years ago.

title: Revisiting a duo on the West Side
description: WHEN the Odeon opened six years ago, it was a lonely lighthouse in the remote and deserted port of TriBeCa.

title: AN ADVENTURER SETS SAIL ONCE AGAIN
description: Warren Luhrs concedes that he has been an adventurer for as long as he can remember. He's 42 years old now, but hasn't forgotten the advice his father gave him when he was growing up in East Orange, N.J.

title: The Reagan Papers
description: It is not exactly a best seller, but the National Archives reports that 446 copies have been sold of a volume that contains the public papers of President Reagan in the second half of 1983.

title: Relief Trucks Said to Reach War-Torn South Sudan Area
description: A convoy of 26 trucks carrying 700 tons of relief food arrived in the southern Sudanese town of Juba Wednesday night, the World Food Program said today.

title: Pick Any Topic and Call It Political Science
description: It is a truth universally acknowledged that political scientists prefer dissecting the past to predicting the future. It makes for fewer miscalculations.

title: People
description: * Marianne C. Hussey has joined Kornhauser Calene as a senior vice president.

title: AMERICAN WAS HELD 8 YEARS IN THE GULAG
description: Alexander M. Dolgun, an American who spent eight years in Soviet labor camps, has died of kidney failure. He was 59 years old.

title: Frigitronics Unit Faces Sale
description: Revlon Inc. said yesterday that it would sell the intraocular-lens business of Frigitronics Inc. to Johnson & Johnson as soon as Revlon completes its previously announced attempt to gain control of the eye-care equipment concern.

title: NUCLEAR REACTORS MUST BE DESIGNED DIFFERENTLY
description: To the Editor:

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: NEW YORK partygoers are a pretty sophisticated lot, but the guests at the American Standard Showroom on Wednesday night agreed this was truly something different. None of them had ever been to a party in a bathroom showroom.

title: New Jersey
description: The last holiday weekend of the summer season in New Jersey offers ample opportunities for family outings in picturesque settings.

title: HARDER TIMES IN CATALOGUES
description: JUST as fashions fall out of favor, so do forms of merchandising. A case in point: the once-popular business of catalogue showrooms, a convenient way of shopping for discount items.

title: Romberg's 'New Moon'
description: ''The New Moon'' by Sigmund Romberg, with book and lyrics by Oscar Hammerstein 2d, Frank Mandel and Laurence Schwab, will be performed five times this weekend by the New York City Opera.

title: Connecticut
description: Connecticut will celebrate its ties to the land and to the sea on this last long weekend of summer.

title: JAZZ FESTIVAL WRAPS UP WITH A BANG
description: WHEN the Greenwich Village Jazz Festival got started four years ago, the idea was to spotlight the wealth of music available, year-round, at the Village's jazz clubs. Now, however, the festival has gathered momentum - and clubs bring in major draws for the occasion. The festival ends with a bang this weekend, offering be-bop, swing, modal jazz, a bop-centered big band and even folk-tinged jazz. Along with the Village's usual galaxy of club sets, available at a discount during the festival, there will be two special events at Sweet Basil - with performers that will be new even to club regulars.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * American Telephone and Telegraph Co. said it had proposed nearly $20 million in price increases for the local channel portion of interstate private-line services that terminate in Florida and Georgia.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds rose $1.5 billion, to $233.38 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: 3 NAVY BATTLE GROUPS IN NORTH AFRICA REGION
description: A naval battle group centered on the aircraft carrier John F. Kennedy arrived at the mouth of the Mediterranean Sea today, bringing to three the number of such groups concentrated just north of Africa.

title: ART: BAMANA SCULPTURES FROM AFRICA AT THE MET
description: THE Museum of Modern Art's '' 'Primitivism' and 20th-Century Art'' was a large and thorough examination of modernism's affinities with and debt to tribal art that was virtually without precedent. Some observers felt the 1984 exhibition backfired visually because, in the end, the European masters with acquired primitivism were no match for the anonymous artists to whom it came naturally.

title: Judge Ben C. Duniway Dies; Served on 9th Circuit Court
description: Ben C. Duniway, a senior judge on the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, has died after a short illness. He was 78 years old.

title: Employee Unions Sue Safeway
description: Safeway Stores Inc. said that unions representing its employees had filed suit in California Superior Court in Alameda County against the company; Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, and others, including Safeway shareholders and the banks providing financing for the pending leveraged buyout of the supermarket chain.

title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT ANSWERS
description: Often an event captures headlines, then fades from view with important questions unanswered - questions that defy news reporting, at least for a while. This column periodically reviews the status of such questions.

title: TEXFI INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug. 1
description: b-Includes a net gain of $2,825,000 from a debenture exchange for both the quarter and 9 months. c-Net income

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Weekend yesterday about Labor Day activities on Long Island gave an incorrect date for a performance by the Concert Pops of Long Island. It is scheduled for tonight at 8:15 on the North Shore, at Tappen Beach in Glenwood Landing on Shore Road.

title: BURKHART PETROLEUM reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the latest-period results reflect the Dec. 31, 1985 merger of Burkhart and Henderson Petroleum Corp.

title: AN ALBANIAN JEW FLEES. WITH GRIM TALE TO TELL
description: An Albanian Jew escaped to Greece this week, bringing a rare account of the continued existence of Europe's most isolated and repressed Jews.

title:
Patents;
Solar Cells Protected In Space
description: A METHOD of protecting solar cells used on spacecraft from deteriorating and losing power has been invented for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

title: PERKIN-ELMER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Latest-year results include a $5.6 million gain on the sale of a subsidiary's stock, and a provision for restructured operations of $7.3 million. Year-ago per-share net calculated before patent infringement settlement and provision for restructured operation was $1.77.

title: EXPERTS IN VIENNA OUTLINE NEW PLAN FOR A-PLANT SAFETY
description: An international symposium outlined a broad program to improve safety at the world's nuclear power plants today, but some experts expressed uncertainty over whether the plan could be put into effect.

title: CASEY'S GENERAL STORES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
R-2 CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BARRY'S JEWELERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
COMPUTONE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Year to May 31
description: b-Net income The company said the 1986 net loss includes $8 million for inventory adjustment, $3 million for an increase in its allowance for doubtful accounts, a writeoff of $2.7 million for Goodwill associated with previous acquisitions and $1.6 million related to future lease obligations and lease-hold improvements at closed stores, as well as severance obligations due to terminated senior employees. The $1.6 million also includes a writeoff of capitalized costs on software, which no longer is marketed.

title: DRUG CONVICTIONS IN CITY TRAIL THOSE IN THE SUBURBS
description: Seventy-two percent of those arrested for felony drug dealing in the New York suburbs last year were ultimately convicted on felony charges, according to figures released today, while only 39 percent in New York City were convicted of felonies.

title: AT TEEN-AGER'S FUNERAL, TEARS FOR A VIBRANT LIFE
description: With psalms and muffled sobs, with memories of a zestful life and anger at a violent death, hundreds of relatives and friends yesterday mourned for Jennifer Dawn Levin.

title: CHEMLAWN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
QUIET TOWN IS NOISY WITH REVOLT
description: After World War II, Gabriel Domonkos went to an Army surplus depot in Newark and bought the casing of a dud bomb for $1. He rigged the shell as the seat of a swing. For years, it was a favorite backyard toy.

title: GENERAL WARNS OF POSSIBLE LIBYA-BACKED ATTACKS IN EUROPE
description: The United States military commander in Europe said today that he had warned American military personnel and families there to be on the alert for new terrorist attacks supported by Libya.

title: Jet America Rejects Two Bids
description: Jet America Airlines Inc. said today that it could not accept either of the two competing bids for the company and instructed its shareholders to await ''further developments'' before tendering their shares.

title: Your Money; Seeing I.R.A.'s In a New Light
description: ALTHOUGH an Individual Retirement Account will not retain its universal attractiveness if the tax revision bill is enacted, an I.R.A. may still be valuable to many who will not be able to use it for making tax-deductible contributions.

title: COMMERCIAL FEDERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of $400,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary gain of $991,000 for the year. Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in May.

title: Reichmann, Allied Talks
description: Toronto's Reichmann family and Allied Lyons P.L.C. of Britain are negotiating an end to their bitter dispute over ownership of the liquor division of Hiram Walker Resources Ltd. A series of meetings were held in London last week, and for most of this week in a Toronto hotel, but Allied said today that a deal has not been reached.

title: LOCAL PRIDE EMERGING THEME SONG IN '86 CAMPAIGNING FOR SENATE SEATS
description: The images that flash by on the television screen could make the most crochety Idahoan smile with pride.

title: A Kennedy Poll
description: A new independent poll in the Massachusetts race to select a Democratic candidate to succeed the retiring House Speaker, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., is something of a surprise: Joseph P. Kennedy 2d is no longer the clear front-runner.

title: JEWISH CONGRESS ASSAILS U.S. REPORT
description: The American Jewish Congress yesterday sharply attacked the recommendation of a White House study group that the Rev. Pat Robertson's Christian Broadcast Network be given a special role in fighting the spread of illegal drugs.

title: How to Save the 'Thrifts'
description: The Congressional committees in charge of banking have finally agreed on a plan to shore up the insurance fund that protects depositors in savings and loan associations. The complicated proposal, allowing Federal insurers to borrow $15 billion against the collective credit of the thrift industry, is fine as far as it goes. But much more is needed - more money to cover the likely liabilities of failing institutions and more initiative from regulators who don't yet seem to comprehend the depth of the industry's woes.

title: JUDGE IN VERMONT UPHOLDS COCAINE CHARGES AGAINST FERRARO'S SON
description: A Vermont judge refused today to dismiss cocaine charges against John A. Zaccaro Jr., the son of Geraldine A. Ferraro, the 1984 Democratic Vice-Presidential candidate, and said that evidence of cocaine found in his apartment could be used against him.

title: GENERAL METAL & ABRASIVES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: BOEING SUSPENDS 19 IN DRUG INQUIRY
description: Nineteen employees at a nearby Boeing Company plant that makes hydraulic systems for military and commercial aircraft have been suspended from their jobs because they reportedly used drugs or alcohol at work, company officials said today.

title: Lorenzo Tucker Dies; Stage and Screen Actor
description: Lorenzo Tucker, a stage and screen actor who played leading roles in early black films, died of lung cancer Aug. 19 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 79 years old.

title: DANCE: 'CONSPIRACIES,' WITH DANIEL EZRALOW
description: Daniel Ezralow is an unforgettably gutsy and intelligent virtuoso dancer. He has shown promise as a choreographer. His gifts are such that one feels disturbed rather than disappointed by ''Conspiracies and Collaborations,'' a program of dances Mr. Ezralow presented on Tuesday at the Bessie Schonberg Theater as part of Dance Theater Workshop's ''Out-of-Towners'' series.

title: Nicklaus Son Out
description: Jack Nicklaus II, the son of the golfer Jack Nicklaus, shot an 85 yesterday as he failed to make the cut in his first professional tournamnet, the Federal Express St. Jude Classic. He shot an 81 in the first round.

title: HERBICIDE EXPOSURE LIKED TO GREATER RISK OF CANCER
description: Farmers and workers exposed to herbicides face a much higher risk of lymphatic cancer than others, according to a new study by the National Cancer Institute and the University of Kansas.

title: Digital Equipment
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation is expected to introduce a personal computer next week that is compatible with International Business Machines Corporation Personal Computers, according to industry sources. A spokesman for Digital Equipment, however, declined to comment on the speculation, saying only that the company planned to hold a press conference next Thursday. The estimated cost of the computer, called the Vaxmate, is $4,300.

title: LAWYER WEIGHS PLEA OF INSANITY IN PARK SLAYING
description: The man accused of the Central Park strangulation of 18-year-old Jennifer Dawn Levin may plead that he was insane at the time of the crime, his lawyer said yesterday.

title: Requiem for Diplomats
description: You are young, and bright and passionate about world affairs. What profession do you enter? In most countries, the answer of choice is diplomacy. In our country, the choice is harder. The American Foreign Service has dwindled in influence; the danger now is that it will dwindle in appeal, opening the prospect of an American foreign policy without the strong professional underpinning it badly needs.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, AUGUST 30, 1986
description: The Economy The trade deficit soared to a record $18 billion in July, with imports twice as large as exports for the first time, the Commerce Department said. Economists expressed dismay at the figures, which defied expectations that a steady fall in the dollar would by now have started to reverse the trade flows. [ Page 1. ] The results raise questions about the Administration's management of the economy, with Democrats contending that the numbers are furthur evidence of stagnation. [ 31. ] Advance news in the financial markets of key economic statistics appears to have resulted from astute forecasting or luck, the Commerce Department said after a preliminary examination of two possible leaks. [ 33. ] The price of U.S. wheat offered to the Soviet Union was lowered in an effort to persuade Moscow to buy four million metric tons. Agriculture Department officials said the value of the wheat subsidy was raised to $15 a metric ton, from $13 a metric ton. [ 31. ] Sales of new houses in July fell 5.6 percent, the fourth straight drop. But analysts still expect the 1986 total to be the biggest since at least 1979. The average price rose to $116,900, a record. [ 32. ] Prices that farmers get for raw products were generally steady in August, despite record-high market prices for hogs and broiler chickens, the Agriculture Department said. [ 32. ] Companies The Hunts sought bankruptcy protection for their flagship, the Placid Oil Company, one of the largest privately owned independent oil companies in the nation.

title: A.T.&T. Ends Quotron Deal
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company and Quotron System Inc. said yesterday that they would end their agreement to jointly develop products for the financial services market.

title: Verdell Roundtree, 57; College Fund Official
description: Verdell L. Roundtree, an educator and vice president for national programs of the United Negro College Fund, died, apparently of a heart attack, Tuesday at the John F. Kennedy Medical Center in Edison, N.J. She was 57 years old and lived in Plainfield, N.J.

title: Fighter Challenges Test
description: Charles Carter, who was banned from a fight Thursday night against Iran Barkley at Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum at the last moment because he tested positive for cocaine, said the test was inaccurate. ''I had been using medication for a bad back, a cold and a nasal condition,'' Carter said.

title: 5 Executed in China
description: Two police officers and three railway workers were executed this month for a series of murders, rapes and armed robberies in the northern Chinese city of Jinzhou, the official China Legal News newspaper said today. The five men used firearms, hand grenades and other weapons to carry out at least 29 crimes between March 1979 and January of this year, the paper said. ''On Aug. 7, their life of crime ended on the execution ground in a volley of gunfire,'' it said.

title: SOONER FEDERAL SAVINGS BANK & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-After extraordinary gains of $363,000 and $661,000 for the latest and prior years, respectively.

title: CROWLEY MILNER & CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income

title: SCREEN: AMERICANS IN SOVIET
description: The latest addition to the nouveau cold war action genre, ''Born American,'' gives us three young Americans who bumble their way across the border from Finland into the Soviet Union and wind up in a prison camp. Why are the these all-American guys on a hunting trip in Finland instead of, say, Minnesota? The film never explains, so it helps to know that it was shot in Finland, produced by a Finn, Markus Selin, directed by his compatriot Renny Harlin, and written by the two of them; only the actors and some financial backing are American-made.

title: Walesa Is Questioned By Warsaw Police
description: Lech Walesa, the Solidarity founder, was questioned by the police today about his links to the underground opposition movement and later issued a statement demanding the release of all political prisoners.

title: BOLIVIAN MINE WORKERS GO IN A 24-HOUR STRIKE
description: Mine workers began a 24-hour strike today to protest the detention of 162 labor and opposition leaders under a Government-imposed state of siege.

title: CPI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 19
description: b-Includes a gain on the disposal of discontinued operations of $184,000 for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $3,558,000 and $207,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and the 6-month period also includes a gain on disposal of discontinued operations of $3,350,000.

title: TENNESSEE PAPER FOUNDER OBSERVES 50 YEARS AT HELM
description: When the golden anniversary drew near for The Chattanooga News-Free Press and its founder, Roy McDonald, Mr. McDonald had a host of silver medallions struck to honor the occasion. Each contained one Troy ounce of fine silver, and each showed him standing among his beloved presses, reading a fresh copy of the newspaper that began daily publication 50 years ago this Sunday.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 8. 1. Poisonous gas in Cameroon escaped from a lake in a volcanic crater, wiping out almost the entire population of four villages. 2.

title: SOUND ADVICE reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Transworld Resignation
description: Charles J. Bradshaw resigned yesterday as the president, chief operating officer and a director of the Transworld Corporation in a difference of opinion over the company's expansion plans.

title: Leak of Health Records
description: The National Institutes of Health is conducting an internal investigation to determine if one of its employees was the source of a syndicated news column that reported that the lawyer Roy Cohn was suffering from AIDS.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: FLUSHING MEADOWS

title: 3 HUNT BROTHERS PUT OIL CONCERN INTO BANKRUPTCY
description: The flagship enterprise of the wealthy Hunt brothers filed today in bankruptcy court for protection from its creditors, a victim of low oil prices.

title: MATTHEWS & WRIGHT GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: 1. This was a result of an unusual geoglogical catastrophe. What happened? 2. Lawyers representing 250,000 Vietnam veterans and family members who claim injury from the wartime herbicide Agent Orange successfully blocked a Federal court plan that would have distributed more than $200 million among their clients. Why did the lawyers argue against the award? 3. Blutrich, Falcone & Miller, a New York City law firm established in 1982, has attracted special interest, to a large degree because of its junior partner. Who is he? 4. Sexual fantasy is nearly universal (in men/in women/in men and women), according to recent studies. 5. A review of evidence gathered by American intelligence agencies, which has not been made public, contradicts the initial contention by the United States about a 1983 event. What event was it and what was the contention? 6. Paul Annacone eliminated John McEnroe with a four-set victory in the United States Open tennis championship, the earliest that McEnroe had been eliminated in (8/9/10/11) years at the Open. 7. The White House abandoned its plans to eliminate an independent Government agency by transferring its operations to the Commerce Department. What agency was involved? 8.A renowned film director once said he thought ''It's All True,'' an uncompleted semidocumentary believed lost for four decades, was cursed and marked the downfall of his career in Hollywood, according to the man who compiled footage into a 22-minute short. Who was the director? 9.

title: DARLING, TEUFEL ENTER NOT GUILTY PLEAS
description: Ron Darling and Tim Teufel of the Mets entered pleas of not guilty today on charges of aggravated assault stemming from a scuffle with two police officers outside a Houston nightclub on July 20.

title: MATTINGLY PLAYS 3D IN VICTORY
description: The night seemed to turn into a succession of unlikely events. Ron Guidry pitched a mere one and one-third innings, Don Mattingly played third base for the first time in his big-league career, and the Yankees squandered a 5-0 lead in the second inning.

title: Captain of Tamil Ship Defends His Actions
description: The captain of the Aurigae, the freighter that brought 155 Sri Lankans to the coast of Canada, says he merely took the Tamil refugees ''where they wanted to go.''

title: ESPRIT SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $470,000 and $1,346,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $2,751,000 for the quarter and $3,498,000 for the year. d-Net loss

title: MEDEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CIRCLE K CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
GETTING PASSAGE ACROSS GEORGETOWN
description: It was a sultry summer evening and Ben Page, a summer intern at the Brookings Institution, had just emerged from a Georgetown bar with two friends. In search of another bar, the three were starting across the middle of M Street when, suddenly, a policeman beckoned them and charged them with jaywalking, fining them $5 each.

title: Student Pilot Dies in a Crash Of 2 Planes in Orange County
description: A student pilot was killed and his instructor critically injured yesterday in the midair collision of two small airplanes about to land at the Orange County Airport in Montgomery, N.Y., the state police said.

title: AMERICAN STORES CO reports earnings for 13wks to Aug 2
description: b-After a non-recurring charge of $3.5 million taken at the company's Jewel Food Stores unit.

title: U.S. SAID TO PICK BLACK DIPLOMAT TO BE AMBASSADOR TO SOUTH AFRICA
description: The Reagan Administration has tentatively decided to nominate Edward J. Perkins, a career diplomat, as the first black American Ambassador to South Africa, Administration officials said today.

title: Montreal Blast Puts Off Game
description: An explosion and fire in an unfinished tower of Olympic Stadium today caused tonight's game between the Montreal Expos and San Diego Padres to be postponed and rescheduled as part of a Saturday doubleheader.

title: Bridge; Play by a Skilled Opponent Can Be a Helpful Indicator
description: There are times when it is useful to know that an opponent is in the highest class. If you can safely assume that he has made the right technical play, reading the distribution accurately may be possible.

title: ELECTRO-KINETIC SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss The company said that no taxes are expected in 1986 as a result of tax loss carryforwards.

title: ABRAMS INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Further Imprisoning Those Behind Bars
description: Not since before the Attica rebellion in 1971 have prisoners in New York State been subjected to such severe restrictions on access to reading materials as have been imposed by the Department of Correctional Services. An administrative order recently mandated that ''books, magazines, newspapers and periodicals may be received [by prisoners] from publisher or approved distributor only.''

title: SAGE-ALLEN & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug. 2
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in May.

title: British Telephone
description: British Telecommunications P.L.C. has asked three companies to tender to supply a further batch of digital telephone lines in a program worth some $:1 billion over the next three to four years, according to Clive Foxell, the company's procurement managing director. At a press conference held to mark the opening of a new digital exchange in London's financial district, he said that the General Electric Company P.L.C., the Plessey Company, and the Thorn-Ericsson joint venture of Thorn EMI and Telefon A.B. L.M. Ericcson were invited to supply the lines.

title: BLOOD OF ORGAN DONOR REVEALS AIDS ANTIBODIES
description: Large transfusions masked AIDS antibodies in blood samples from a traffic accident victim whose organs were later transplanted into two other people, hospital officials said Thursday.

title: FRONTIER WORKERS HOLD WAKE
description: As the news of Frontier Airlines' demise sank in, its 4,700 employees looked for culprits to blame for their troubles and began to cope with the necessity of rebuilding their lives.

title: AN INCREASE IN COMMUTER VANS PROMPTS A CALL FOR REGULATION
description: Private commuter vans, many of them illegal, are proliferating in New York City, aggravating midtown Manhattan traffic congestion and costing the Transit Authority $12 million to $20 million a year in lost bus and subway fares, according to a study released yesterday.

title: BROOKLYNITE PLEADS GUILTY TO EVADING STATE GAS TAX
description: A Brooklyn man with reputed ties to organized crime has pleaded guilty to evading state gasoline taxes in a scheme to confuse auditors with paperwork. He has agreed to pay $3 million in back taxes over the next five years, the authorities said yesterday.

title: LOCAL FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The company said its provision for loan losses for the quarter was $5.6 million, compared to $348,000 a year- ago. A portion of the reserve was related to a loan Local Federal participated in to the First National Bank & Trust Co. of Oklahoma City, which failed in July.

title: A TROUGH OF LOW SURGERY
description: The biggest question in American medicine will soon be settled not at Johns Hopkins but at CBS-TV headquarters. Question: Who will get the ''teledoc'' job on the network's new morning television show?

title: ALLIED SUPERMARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
JERSEYAN DENIES SLAYING FOSSEY
description: A researcher accused of killing the anthropologist Dian Fossey in Africa declared his innocence today, and his attorney said the United States was trying to make his client a scapegoat.

title: SHONEY'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug. 3
description: Latest 9-month results include the operations of Shocap Inc. from the beginning of the fiscal year, which was accounted for as a pooling of interest. Share earnings reflect a 5-for-4 stock split paid last month.

title: CHOP SUEY, AT 90, IS STILL A MYSTERY
description: Well, we goofed. We missed the 90th anniversary of the introduction of chop suey to New York. But considering the esteem in which this faux Chinese dish is held, perhaps no one really cares.

title:
Patents;
Food Decoy Mat
description: A food decoy mat designed to attract waterfowl was patented this week by William H. Wright, a Washington patent attorney who is also a hunter. Patent 4,607,447 indicates that the plastic sheet, which carries pictures of grain, can be used either on dry land or under water to lure the birds. A license will be available for manufacture.

title:
COMPANY NEWS;
BANKRUPTCY THREAT FOR PETRO-LEWIS
description: The Petro-Lewis Corporation, the ailing oil and gas company, said yesterday that it expected to lose $419 million in the year ended June 30 and that it would file for bankruptcy if a tender offer for the company was unsuccessful. Petro-Lewis, which lost $43.6 million in fiscal 1985, also said it would write-down about $56 million in oil and gas reserves.

title: McENROE, FLEMING ARE DISQUALIFIED
description: The second exit John McEnroe made from the United States Open this week was even more frustrating than the first. Dressed in his white tennis work clothes and a black leather jacket, McEnroe walked angrily to his Mercedes sports car yesterday and drove away from the National Tennis Center, probably only to encounter a traffic jam that had already spoiled his day.

title: TII INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
CHEMICAL FABRICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: CORRECTION
description: A Moscow dispatch Aug. 5, on an announcement by the Kremlin that it would hold talks with Israel, referred incorrectly to the status of talks between Israel and Poland. Although the two countries have agreed to set up interest sections in Warsaw and Tel Aviv, they have not opened discussions on establishing consular relations.

title: GRAND AUTO INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 27
description: The company said the year-ago second quarter earnings were unusually high as a result of a LIFO adjustment.

title: U.S. MAY CHANGE STANCE ON VOTING
description: A Justice Department official said today that the department might adopt a policy of approving some state redistricting plans and changes in voting procedures that would unintentionally have racially discriminatory results.

title: MORRIS RETURNS TO GIANTS' ACTIVE ROSTER
description: Joe Morris was restored to the Giants' active roster today and Coach Bill Parcells said the running back would play in Saturday night's final preseason game here against the Pittsburgh Steelers.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, AUGUST 30, 1986
description: International Moscow learned by seismic means and satellite intelligence of three unannounced American underground nuclear tests, a Soviet military official in Washington said. The official, Col. Vitaly L. Kotyuzhansky of the Soviet Defense Ministry, said the American tests were of low yield. Describing when the tests took place, he said Moscow's ability to detect the explosions showed that verification of a testing moratorium was not as difficult as Reagan Administration officials have suggested. Administration officials confirmed that the tests had taken place. [ Page 1, Column 4. ] Morocco is canceling a treaty aimed at union with Libya. King Hassan II of Morocsaid he was ending a treaty of union with Libya because of Libyan criticism of his meeting with Israel's Prime Minister. [ 3:5. ] A warning to U.S. military personnel and families in Europe to be on the alert for new terrorist attacks supported by Libya was issued by the United States military commander in Europe. The commander, Gen. Bernard W. Rogers, said he issued the warning because of signs of renewed activity by Col. Muammar el- Qaddafi, the Libyan leader. [ 2:3. ] Naming a new envoy to Pretoria is under consideration by Reagan Administration officials. Barring some unforeseen problem, Edward J. Perkins, a career diplomat and currently Ambassador to Liberia, will be the new ambassador to South Africa, the officials said. Mr. Perkins would be the first black to fill the post. He would replace Herman W. Nickel, who will be stepping down in October, the United States Embassy in Pretoria announced.

title: MUGABE IS FIRM ON SANCTIONS
description: Prime Minister Robert Mugabe said today that his country would impose a tough package of economic sanctions against South Africa even though Zimbabwe recently renewed a special trade agreement with Pretoria.

title: DELAYS ARE EXPECTED IN WEEKEND REPAIRS NEAR LINCOLN TUNNEL
description: Long delays for motorists using the Lincoln Tunnel are expected on weekends for nearly two months beginning today because of construction on the viaduct that connects the tunnel with primary routes in New Jersey, transportation officials said yesterday.

title: Ford Mexico Plant
description: The Ford Motor Company said that next year it will begin building 130,000 Tracer subcompact cars a year at a new plant in Hermosillo, Mexico, with 100,000 of those destined for the United States.

title: Padres' President Suspends Gossage
description: Rich Gossage, the San Diego Padre relief pitcher, has been suspended without pay for the rest of the season for criticizing the team's management, Ballard Smith, president of the Padres, announced today.

title: Unheeded Warnings
description: To the Editor:

Officer Joe Was Part of Growing Up in New York
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 DIE IN U.S. COPTER'S CRASH
description: A Marine Corps helicopter carrying 21 people crashed in the Atlantic Ocean off the coast of Norway today, killing two people, Navy officials said. Six others were missing.

title: California Bill Would Set 1/ Deposit on Containers
description: After 20 years of debate, California lawmakers have passed a bill aimed at recycling soda and beer cans and bottles.

title: Factory Control in China
description: China has begun an experiment to free factories in 16 small cities from state or Communist Party control, The People's Daily said today.

title: Britain Denies Airbus Plane Shift
description: Britain has denied reports that it is on the brink of pulling out of the European Airbus plane project because the Government was not prepared to put up $1 billion for the program.

title: GANTOS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2

PATENTS;
Monitor and New Way To Cool Nuclear Plant
description: A system for monitoring operating conditions in a pressurized water nuclear power plant and displaying them has been devised for the Babcock & Wilcox Company, New Orleans. Patent 4,608,223 was granted this week to Robert C. Twilley Jr., an engineer who is now a nuclear sales representative in the western states.

title: Give Cab Owners and Drivers a Raise
description: To the Editor:

title: Filipino at Marcos House In Jersey Faces Queries
description: An attorney for President Corazon C. Aquino of the Philippines obtained a subpoena today to question Orlando C. Dulay, a former Philippine Army colonel and provincial Governor, about the stripping of a mansion in Lawrence Township linked to Ferdinand E. Marcos, the deposed Philippine President.

title: Will Brooklyn Heights Lose Sight of Manhattan's Skyline?
description: The Brooklyn Heights Promenade is a magnet for strollers, joggers, lovers, photographers, tourists and those playing hooky from work or school. The July 4 Liberty Weekend fireworks saw it filled to its capacity of an estimated 100,000 people, the police turning away late arrivals. No public place offers a finer view of the harbor's expanse and the Manhattan skyline - one of the world's great views. Unfortunately, that view now is threatened.

title: ALPINE INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $52,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary loss of $32,000 for the year. c-Net loss and after an extraordinary loss of $1,693,000 for both the quarter and year. The company said its board declared a 5-percent stock dividend, payable Oct. 15 to shareholders of record Sept. 15; in 1981 a similar 5-percent stock dividend was paid.

title: Walker's Debut Set
description: Herschel Walker, the most publicized fifth-round draft choice in the history of the National Football League, will make his debut with the Dallas Cowboys tonight in their final preseason game, against the Houston Oilers. The Cowboys made Walker a fifth-round choice in 1985 after he had signed with the Generals of the United States Football League.

title: FRONTIER: RUGGED, BIG-HEARTED
description: Weathered ranchers, well-heeled oilmen, dungareed backpackers and vacationers in T-shirts jackets were the stock in trade of Frontier Airlines.

title: CORRECTION
description: A brief article in Weekend yesterday on the New York City Opera's production of Sigmund Romberg's ''New Moon'' gave incorrect performance times for tomorrow. It will be presented at 1 P.M. and 7 P.M. at the New York State Theater.

description: Educational and religious leaders disagreed yesterday over the assertion by Governor Cuomo that schools had abdicated their responsibility to teach values to students.

description: To the Editor:

title: FRANCE VOICES DOUBTS OVER FORCE IN LEBANON
description: Disturbed by recent clashes between its forces and local Moslem militias, the French Government has become increasingly unhappy over the situation facing its contingent in the United Nations peacekeeping force in southern Lebanon, according to diplomats and officials.

title: East German Beats U.S. Cyclist
description: Lutz Hesslich defeated Mark Gorski in the amateur men's match sprint at the world cycling championship here tonight. The 27-year-old Hesslich, an East German who is the defending world champion, triumphed in two successive quarterfinal over his American opponent.

title: BEDFORD COMPUTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
'NICKLEBY' ACTORS CREATE 'NEW' ROLES
description: At the close of Act I in ''The Life and Adventures of Nicholas Nickleby,'' the revival of which opened this week at the Broadhurst Theater, the play's handsome young hero holds out his hand to a crippled waif.

title: TENNIS MAKES ITS MARK OFF THE COURTS
description: The United States Open at Flushing Meadow isn't the only tennis game in town this week. There is exciting action on the sidewalks of Manhattan, too, where that venerable mainstay of the courts, the white cable-knit tennis sweater with its familiar navy-striped V neckline, is making its presence felt.

title: Plant Explosion Injures 3
description: Three workers were listed in critical condition today with burns over most of the body after an explosion at a pyrotechnic plant, the authorities said. The officials said they had not determined the cause of the blast at the Kilgore Manufacturing Corporation, which manufactures signal flares and other pyrotechnic devices for the military.

title: DYSON REPORTS SPENDING $4.7 MILLION ON CAMPAIGN
description: John S. Dyson, who is seeking the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate from New York, has already spent $4.7 million on his primary campaign, according to financial reports filed yesterday with the State Board of Elections.

title: COMMERICAL SHEARING INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The latest figures reflect the acquisition of Cuno Inc. in January.

title: The Weight of Trash, and Tradition
description: Something about Carlen Sanderson and Anne Pabon brings out the Galahad in certain New York men. These courteous souls worry about the women's exposure to heat and cold, and fear that they may sometimes find themselves far from an attractive restroom. The men fret over their lifting heavy objects and one confesses - probably with a blush - to concern about ''women's'' problems.

title: RECORD TRADE DEFICIT SEEN AS ELECTION ISSUE
description: A startling record in the nation's foreign trade deficit in July has heightened questions about the Administraton's management of the economy and increased chances that trade will figure prominently in the November elections.

title: TRADE DEFICIT SETS $18 BILLION RECORD AS IMPORTS CLIMB
description: The nation's trade deficit soared to a record $18 billion in July, with imports twice as large as exports for the first time ever, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Democracy on Hold in Bolivia
description: Until this week the Bolivian Government of Victor Paz Estenssoro was Washington's prize example of responsible democracy, both for its austerity economics and its fight against cocaine. Now the example is turning into an embarrassment as Bolivia declares a state of siege and rounds up important critics.

title: Judaism Lessons By Telephone
description: An unusual call-in telephone service is helping Orthodox Jews observe the complicated laws of the Old Testament and the Talmud.

description: An experimental rocket fuel exploded today while it was being tested today by a major military contractor, killing an engineer and burning his supervisor.

description: To the several categories of westerns, such as spaghetti westerns and Far Eastern westerns, may now be added the corporate western.

description: An airline pilot trying to land today was forced to make an emergency climb to avoid hitting a man who had wandered onto a runway at O'Hare International Airport.

description: In observance of Labor Day, the stock markets and commodity exchanges and most businesses in the United States and Canada will be closed Monday. Federal, state and local government offices will also be closed.

PATENTS;
Radar Aids Surveillance By Penetrating Foliage

description: Jodi A. Pearson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest H. Pearson of West Hartford, Conn., was married yesterday to Paul T. McLoughlin, a son of Mrs. Maurice E. McLoughlin of New York and Cohasset, Mass., and the late Mr. McLoughlin. The Revs.

title: RED SOX LEAD CUT TO 3 1/2 AS CARTER BELTS 3
description: Joe Carter hit three home runs, drove in four runs and went 5 for 5 tonight, leading the Cleveland Indians to a 7-3 victory over the Boston Red Sox.

description: The Agriculture Department today lowered the price of American wheat offered for sale to the Soviet Union in an attempt to bolster President Reagan's month-old initiative for grain exports to that country.

title: RAGAN, BRAD INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
DRAMA AT THE BERLIN WALL: A WILD DRIVE TO FREEDOM
description: A man who swerved a dump truck through East German police gunfire early today and escaped through the Berlin wall had a friend and their baby huddled on the floor under the windshield, the West Berlin police said. None of the three were hurt.

title: TAKING COMPUTERS TO COLLEGE
description: THIS is the time of year when fathers look at their car trunks with a determined eye. As they prepare to take their children to college, they begin figuring out ways to squeeze in an extra quilt or box of granola bars. Now there is a new addition to the tape decks and toaster ovens that have made up the standard arsenal of dormitory gear - the computer.

description: ''My father never really cared about money,'' Bunker Hunt once said about H. L. Hunt, the billionaire Dallas oilman. ''It was just sort of how they kept the score.''

title: Reliance-Lilco Tie
description: The New York-based Reliance Financial Services Corporation, a unit of Saul P. Steinberg's Reliance Group Inc. said today that it reduced its stake in the Long Island Lighting Company to 5.4 percent, or about 6 million shares, from 6.3 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Reliance gave no reason for the sale of the utility company's shares. Lilco's stock closed at $11.625, unchanged, in New York Stock Exchange trading today.

description: ''I feel like the luckiest man alive,'' the rock singer John Fogerty said yesterday before leaving Memphis. His concert at the city's Mud Island Amphitheater on Wednesday night was his first since the breakup of his band, Creedence Clearwater Revival, in 1972.

description: The Broadway show that really needs no clothes is looking for people who really do.

description: Japan posted a record trade surplus in July, when unemployment also set a record, according to Government figures released today.

Among the bluebloods running for engraved silverware and glory are Lady's Secret and Precisionist in the Woodward Stakes at Belmont Park today, classy Europeans turf stars in the Arlington Million tomorrow, and the brilliant 3-year-olds Ogygian and Mogambo in the Jerome Handicap at Belmont Monday afternoon.

description: Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc. said yesterday that it had received several offers of more than $180 million for its Philadelphia-based chain of John Wanamaker department stores.

description: Some months ago, two influential Democratic Assemblymen from Brooklyn, Albert Vann and Roger L. Green, took the unusual step of backing a candidate seeking to unseat an incumbent Civil Court judge in next month's Democratic primary election.

title: G.M. SALES QUICK TO RESPOND
description: In Chicago, Frank Chevrolet sold 28 cars Thursday, about double the usual daily rate, according to Zollie Frank, the agency's president.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: SHOCK DELAYS CAMEROON MOURNING
description: There is an old Cameroonian saying that goes, ''The infant and the old woman go back.'' What it means is that the very young and the very old are expected to die - to go back -but not those in between. It is the death of those in between that requires an explanation.

title: MARKET RUMORS: LUCK, LEAK OR SKILL?
description: The Commerce Department said today that a preliminary examination of two possible leaks this week of sensitive economic data showed that the rumors began circulating on Wall Street before the numbers had been calculated.

title: GIANT FOOD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 9
Coke Suit Pact
description: The Coca-Cola Company has settled two lawsuits against its Columbia Pictures Television division by acquiring Four D Productions to get rights to the popular ''Barney Miller'' TV series.

title: DREAMS OF A TITLE END ON HIGHWAY
description: The clock on the floor of the grandstand court said quarter after 2, and the crowd was yelling and clapping in impatient rhythmic anticipation. It was as if word had seeped out that Bruce Springsteen was about to play in a small rock and roll club in Flushing. The masses were coming from everywhere, toting their zoom lenses, their Italian ices and their nachos. They had arrived to see John McEnroe, and they were getting tired of waiting.

title: Holdouts on Tax Bill
description: When conferees from the House of Representatives and the Senate approved the far-reaching tax bill earlier this month, some confusion surrounded the final vote and it was reported at the time that only two nays could be heard. Now that the dust has settled and some written votes have been received, the final tally is in: 16 in favor, 5 opposed.

title: Cuomo Backs His Son On Law-Business Ties
description: Governor Cuomo has defended his son Andrew, saying that he did not see any problem with his belonging to a law firm whose clients have business dealings with the state.

title: Cobanco Merger
description: Pacific Western Bancshares said it would merge with Cobanco Inc. in a stock transaction that would leave current owners of each company holding 50 percent of the combined company's equity.

title: STOCKBROKER IS SENTENCED FOR MURDER AFTER 4 TRIALS
description: Murray R. Gold, the former stockbroker convicted of killing his former in-laws after a fourth trial, today received a prison term of 25 years to life in the 1974 double murders.

description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $27,000 for the quarter, and for the year includes an extraordinary gain of $1,722,000, after a loss in an affiliate of $1,473,000. c-Net loss and includes a loss in an affiliate of $3,400,000. description: Sales of new single-family houses fell in July for the fourth straight month, declining 5.6 percent to the lowest level since last fall, the Government said today.

description: The Nets are interested in giving an offer sheet to Orlando Woolridge, the Chicago Bulls' 6-foot 9-inch free-agent forward. Woolridge, a former Notre Dame player, and his agent, Larry Fleisher, met Wednesday night for several hours with Dave Wohl, the Nets' coach.

title: Nicaragua Is Working Toward Autonomy for Miskito Indians
description: To the Editor:

description: The company is listed on the Montreal Stock Exchange. All figures are in Canadian dollars.

title: HOUSTON FAST LANE A CAUTIONARY TALE
description: Possibly no urban creature in America is more wedded to the automobile than the Houstonian. And the saga of the Katy ''transitway'' offers new evidence of how difficult it is to change such habits.

title: OJEDA WINS 15TH ON A FIVE-HITTER
description: The Mets came home from some highly broadening travel in a buoyant mood last night, and took one more step forward when they knocked off the Los Angeles Dodgers, 2-1, behind the five-hit pitching of Bob Ojeda.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Plunge
description: Bond investors abandoned their usual pre-Labor Day weekend caution yesterday and aggressively snapped up short- and long-term Treasury debt after the Government reported a record trade deficit for July. As a result, Treasury bill rates and yields on coupon notes and bonds tumbled.

description: b-After a charge of $303,000 from the early extinguishment of debt for both the quarter and 6 months. The company said in the latest quarter and 6-month periods per share operating net and final net were less than one cent after preferred dividend requirements.

description: Job cuts announced by Telefon L. M. Ericsson include 4,000 between now and the end of 1988 and 2,000 in the next 12 months, the company said.

title: WATSCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
TORONTO-DOMINION BANK (CANADA) reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange. The bank said net non-accrual loans decreased by $91 million to $1.42 billion during the latest quarter, and the bank also said that due to the uncertain outlook in the energy sector, it has not revised its second-quarter estimate of 1986 loan-loss experience of $450 million, despite the recent improvement in oil prices. For the latest 9 months, the bank said its actual loan-loss experience was $333 million, up from $218 million a year ago, and the bank also said the provision for loan losses was $263 million in the latest 9 months, up from $192 million a year ago.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''When people realize that there are almost no children for the school, I think that is when it will really hit them.'' - Gemuh Akuchu, from the Lake Nios region of Cameroon. [ 1:3. ]

title: PRICES PAID TO FARMERS HELD STEADY IN AUGUST
description: Prices that farmers receive for raw products remained steady in August, despite record-high market prices for hogs and broiler chickens, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Perry Fined $2,000
description: William Perry, the Chicago Bears' defensive tackle, has been fined $2,000 for his ferocious late tackle of Neil Lomax, the quarterback for the St. Louis Cardinals, in an Aug. 23 exhibition game, a Chicago television station reported yesterday.

title: G.M.'s Lotus May Relocate
description: The Lotus sports car company, which was taken over by the General Motors Corporation in January, is considering a move to the Netherlands because the British Government has refused to back its expansion plans with financial help, industry sources said today. Lotus wants to increase production from 800 cars a year to 7,000 at its eastern England plant.

title: Seven Killed in Crash Of Plane in Wyoming
description: A twin-engine plane crashed and burned after takeoff, killing all seven people on board, the authorities said today.

title:
PATENTS;
Method Marks a First For Human Cell Fusion
description: Staff members of the National Institutes of Health were awarded a patent this week that marks the first time anyone has been able to fuse together human cells. Patent 4,608,339 was granted George H. Yoakum and three associates.

title: Judge Rules in Case Of Garbage Pail Kids
description: A Federal district judge agreed today to order Topps Chewing Gum Inc. to stop producing Garbage Pail Kids stickers while he considers whether they violate the copyright of the Cabbage Patch Kids dolls.

title: GARRISON STRUGGLES TO ADVANCE AT OPEN
description: She remains symbolic of a people's hope, constantly reminded that when she plays it is not just for herself, her family and her closest friends, but also for scores of people she has never met. Now, in the midst of her fourth professional season, Zina Garrison says she has learned to live with the burden of being the most successful of the few black players on the tennis tour.

title: WELLCO ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Year to June 28
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $680,000 for the latest year and $540,000 for the prior period. Share earnings are adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split paid May 9.

title: Of the Titanic and Other Man-Made Disasters
description: To the Editor:

title: SECONDARY A CONCERN FOR JETS
description: The barrage of passes completed against the Jets' cornerbacks in their final preseason game Thursday night had Coach Joe Walton thinking today of things to come.

title: DELTA LAUNCHING MAY BE NEAR
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration is ready to try the first launching of a Delta rocket since one exploded May 3, an aerospace magazine reported today. The rocket would carry a secret military payload on a research mission for the proposed defense against missiles, the magazine said.

title: BLIMP TO SIT OUT DRUG WAR
description: The Customs Service announced today that the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company was volunteering a blimp to help the Government wage its war on drugs, but Goodyear later withdrew the offer.

title: PEOPLE CUTS BACK DIVIDEND
description: In a move to help its cash position, People Express Inc. said yesterday that it would not pay a quarterly dividend of 66 cents a share on some of its preferred stock. It had suspended payment on the common last month.

title: SOUTH LEBANON MOSLEMS APPEAR DETERMINED TO DISLODGE U.N. FORCE
description: Moslem militants backed by Iran have begun what appears to be a determined campaign to dislodge the United Nations peacekeeping force from southern Lebanon.

title: MOROCCO CANCELING TREATY AIMED AT UNION WITH LIBYA
description: King Hassan II of Morocco announced today that he was canceling a treaty of union with Libya because of Libyan criticism of his meeting with Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel.

title: DESPITE SETBACKS, A STILL-LARGER-THAN-LIFE TEXAS FAMILY
description: Even as the Hunt financial empire seems to be crumbling, the Hunt family, which includes 15 children whom H. L. Hunt fathered by three women over 35 years, remains the stuff that makes television soap operas and potboiler novels pallid by comparison.

title: WEEKS BEFORE SLAYING NEIGHBORS REPORTED MINORS DRINKING AT BAR
description: Eight weeks before the killing of Jennifer Dawn Levin, a community group had told state liquor authorities that underage drinking was rampant at Dorrian's Red Hand, the bar where the 18-year-old woman spent the hours before her death with the 19-year-old man the police say strangled her.

title: 3 LUTHERAN GROUPS IN U.S. VOTE MERGER TO STRENGTHEN ROLE
description: Three Lutheran churches voted overwhelmingly today to merge into a single, more diverse and more effective denomination of 5.3 million members.

THE SCREEN: 'BULLIES'
description: ''Bullies,'' which opened at the RKO Twin yesterday, is about a nice man and his nice wife and her nice son who meet some people who aren't very nice.

title: K. C. Harris to Marry Susan Bellamy in Fall
description: Susan Irene Bellamy, an account executive at Ogilvy & Mather, a New York advertising agency, and K. Carter Harris, a vice president of Merrill Lynch Money Markets Inc. in New York, plan to be married in November. Their engagement has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. William M. Bellamy Jr. of Chappaqua, N.Y. The future bridegroom is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Jack Kenneth Harris of Louisville, Ky.

title: Rebecca Cornell Weds Thomas Ahrensfeld Jr.
description: Rebecca Cornell and Thomas F. Ahrensfeld Jr. were married yesterday by the Rev. Philip Carr-Harris at St. John's Episcopal Church in Pleasantville, N.Y., where the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Barry L. Cornell, and the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Ahrensfeld, all reside.

title: Bo Jackson to Royals
description: Bo Jackson, the college football Heisman Trophy winner who chose a baseball career, is headed for the Kansas City Royals after a summer in the minors with the Memphis Chicks of the Southern League. The contract the former Auburn University star signed with the Royals called for him to report to the parent club Sept. 1, when major league rosters are expanded to 40 players.

title: Chirac Tells New Caledonians Everyone Will Vote in Election
description: Prime Minister Jacques Chirac of France stressed today that all the people of the troubled French territory of New Caledonia would have a voice in its future.

title: Cross Burned by Ku Klux Klan At Rally on Connecticut Farm
description: The Ku Klux Klan, rallying today at what was billed as a national convention, burned a cross on an isolated farm here as more than five dozen police officers ringed the site.

title: BATTERY PARK CITY IS A TRIUMPH OF URBAN DESIGN
description: If there is any attitude that characterizes this moment in architecture, it is an indifference toward the idea of urbanism, a feeling that individual parts matter a great deal more than wholes. Our buildings are generally not made to be part of a larger place; however well designed, they are dropped in, one beside the other, with almost nothing to tie them together. They are prima donnas, not ensembles. Against this backdrop Battery Park City, the immense complex moving steadily toward completion on a 92-acre landfill site along the Hudson River in lower Manhattan, is close to a miracle. For here there is a sense of place, and it is a powerful and generally convincing one. It is not perfect - but it is far and away the finest urban grouping since Rockefeller Center, and one of the better pieces of urban design of modern times.

title: CORRECTION
description: Some copies of the Sunday Real Estate section of The Times distributed in New Jersey and on Long Island today have an incorrect date at the top of the first page. The pages inside the section have the correct date, Aug. 31.

title: Sunday Observer; SEX AND MATURITY
description: UPON HEARING THAT the editors of Playgirl magazine were choosing the 10 sexiest men in America, I thought it best to prepare my family for what might be a trying experience.

title: FREEING OLDER HOUSING WITH NEW
description: A SUBJECT that has long intrigued housing analysts is the chain of moves set in motion by new residential construction. The assumption is that each new unit creates a potential for freeing an existing unit as a household moves onward.

title: Data Bank: August 31, 1986
THE CARNEGIE HALL OF THE FUTURE
description: A few years ago, when a particularly large chorus came to sing at Carnegie Hall, the hall's management rented rooms for the performers at a nearby hotel - not for sleeping, merely for dressing. And after the singers had changed into concert attire, they were lined up along the street to the stage entrance while, according to one former Carnegie official, ''We prayed and did an Indian war dance to keep the rains from coming.''

title: POLITICAL SKIRMISH REVIVES IN CHICAGO
description: Amid charges of fraud, racism and political opportunism, the fight over the format of Chicago's forthcoming mayoral election has moved into the courts with no early resolution in sight.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
RIVER VIEWS
description: ''The Hudson River is a major natural resource in the county and a major part of our lives here, for food and transportation and recreation,'' said Barry Samuel, deputy commissioner of the Westchester County Department of Parks, Recreation and Conservation. ''There is a lot of interest in it.''

title:
ART;
WHEN A PERIOD LASTS A LIFETIME
description: THE long-term, single-minded pursuit of a narrow, self-imposed esthetic discipline is rare among visual artists, most of whom undergo the periodic changes in style or viewpoint that we associate with a developing career.

description: COUNTING WET NOSES

description: IN a dispute growing out of Port Chester's plans to redevelop a large section of its downtown area, the village's Corporation Counsel has resigned. ''I am evidently in the way of these trustees and appointees who want to proceed with this 'deal,' '' Monroe Y. Mann wrote in his letter of resignation.

title: PRECISIONIST WINS WOODWARD BY 4 3/4
description: Precisionist collared Lady's Secret at the furlong pole and drew off by 4 3/4 lengths in brilliant time to win the $332,500 Woodward Stakes yesterday at Belmont Park.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:
