title:
GARDENING;
MATURITY THE KEY IN HARVESTING POPCORN
description: ABOUT this time of year, it is certain that someone who has planted popcorn for the first time will wonder what to do with it. After all, sweet corn is being harvested, so why not popcorn?

title: THE ROAD TO MANDALAY, ALL-ENGLAND TENNIS
description: AN ASIAN TOUR: ANCIENT CITIES, ROYAL PALACES

title: Art
description: Galleries come and go. Sometimes they go, like Dick Bellamy's Oil & Steel Gallery, when we would have preferred them to stay.

title: Learning Greek
description: I predict that Paul Beeching has an additional pleasure awaiting him in his reading of Homer in the original - that of succumbing to the aural bewitchment of epic. His own account of Miss Tew, whose ''lips move as she reads the great poem,'' show that she was deriving pleasure from the interplay of rhythm, sound and content. ANN ELLIS HANSON Princeton, N.J.

title: GUIDELINES BOARD WEIGHS NEW RENTS
description: AFTER a series of angry hearings, the Rent Guidelines Board is scheduled to set rent increases or decreases for an estimated 50,000 apartments in 18 Westchester communities Wednesday night. The landlords are seeking a 13 percent increase, while the tenants have called for a 10 percent rollback.

title: A TOWN DIVIDED BY THE GRIZZLY
description: IN THE SPRING, TWO young grizzly bears, just out of a winter's sleep, wandered down out of the timbered high country of the Rocky Mountains and onto the prairie near Choteau, a small ranching community in central Montana. They knocked over a half-dozen commercial beehives and fed on the honey and larvae within. Although they hurt no one, their presence has sparked near-hysteria. The chief topic of conversation in this dusty town's two cafes - usually the rain or the fierce wind that howls down from the Rockies - is the bear issue. It has polarized the town, dividing those who think the bears pose a serious threat to people and livestock from those who want to protect the bears.

title: Miss Andrews Weds Henry Nesvadba
description: The marriage of Emily Philler Andrews, a daughter of Emily C. Wadsworth of Geneseo, N.Y., and Philadelphia and Avery D. Andrews 2d of Washington, to Henry Nesvadba took place yesterday at Christ Church Anglican Cathedral in Montreal. The bridegroom is the son of Mary Nesvadba of Sutton, Quebec, and Henry Nesvadba of Henrysburg, Quebec.

title: Torey Aronow Is a Bride
description: Victoria Stacey Aronow and David Arthur Herrigel, 1986 graduates of the Emory University School of Law, were married yesterday at the Four Seasons Hotel in Philadelphia by Judge Marvin R. Halpert of the Court of Common Pleas. The bride, known as Torey, is a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Phillip Z. Aronow of Haddonfield, N.J. The bridegroom is a son of Joy McGill and Bruce D. Herrigel, both of Union Township, N.J.

title: RESORTS MOVING ON TAJ MAHAL
description: THE Taj Mahal is on schedule for opening next summer, according to Resorts International officials, who feel its convention capacity will offset any negative impact from a ''tightening'' gambling market.

title: Melissa I. Dewey Becomes a Bride
description: At the First Unitarian Church of Dedham, Mass., yesterday Melissa Ide Dewey, a daughter of Joy Anne Dewey of Nantucket, Mass., and Joseph Eaton Dewey of Williamstown, Mass., was married to John MacQuarrie Gilbert, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Norman R. Gilbert of Weymouth, Mass. The Rev. Elizabeth Stevens performed the ceremony.

title: Dr. Jo Ann Carson Engaged to Be Wed
description: Dr. Jo Ann Carson, an attending pediatrican at St. John's Hospital in Elmhurst, Queens, and Timothy Jameson Lord, a vice president in the financial futures and options division at Merrill Lynch Capital Markets in New York, plan to be married Oct. 11.

title: RESTAURANT MANAGER CATERS TO STARS OF THE SCREEN
description: FOOD and film are the stuff of Elmirinda Schenne's life.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: ANOTHER FIRST: GREECE'S FIRST FEMALE ENVOY
description: Greece has just appointed its first Ambassador to Cuba. She is Elisabeth Papazoi, a structural engineer who holds university diplomas in town planning, applied computer information techniques and agricultural sociology and economy.

title: TORT SYSTEM NEEDS REFINING
description: AN insidious crisis is threatening New Jersey. Astronomical increases in the cost of liability insurance are undermining businesses, towns, school boards and nonprofit organizations.

title:
ART;
TO PAINT IT, SHE FLEW OVER IT
description: ONE of the significant upheavals in contemporary art concerns the use of the landscape theme. It is now sometimes perceived as a sighting from an airplane, or as a subject incorporating outer-space phenomena. It can reflect environmental worries through the choice of material and attitude, or it can entice the imagination by substituting an undefined flat surface for traditional illusions.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN DATING SERVICES
description: MATCHMAKING - a feature of societies both ancient and modern -has become big business. A surging interest in marriage, fueled in part by this year's much-publicized Yale/Harvard study showing that women over 30 have slim chances of getting married, has caused many people to step up spouse-stalking efforts. There are also more divorced people on the eligibility list: Last year, the divorce rate rose 2 percent, to five divorces per 1,000 Americans. And many single people pursuing careers insist they do not have the time to spend looking for companions.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: BITBURG IN MORAL AND POLITICAL PERSPECTIVE. Edited by Geoffrey H. Hartman. (Indiana University, Cloth, $29.95. Paper, $9.95.)

title: HURRICANE POTENTIAL STRESSED BY OFFICIALS
description: THE hurricanes that threaten New Jersey at this time of year carry an awesome potential for destruction, but scientists and emergency and weather experts say a hurricane rarely actually strikes the state.

title: PORTRAIT OF AN AGING RECOVERY
description: FORECASTING the economy's ups and downs is as uncertain as predicting the weather. Right now the economic outlook is decidedly cloudy, despite some bright spots. Interest rates have fallen by more than half since the early 1980's. And inflation, aided by declining oil prices, has been checked decisively.

title: FOR CHILDREN AT CAMP, A RARE AMITY
description: Nine-year-old Wendy Powell had only one problem at Camp Homeward Bound - ''those ugly chipmunks.''

title: AREA APPLE INSTITUTE CONTINUES TO SERVE
description: In reference to Robert A. Hamilton's Aug. 10 article on the proposed Connecticut apple marketing order [ ''Local Apples: For a Foothold in Big Time'' ] , congratulations on a fine and informative piece. I would, however, like to clarify one point regarding the New York and New England Apple Institute.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM KILTS TO WHITE TIE
description: Top Hat:Starring Fred Astaire, Ginger Rogers, Edward Everett Horton, Helen Broderick, Eric Blore; directed by Mark Sandrich, 1935 RKO Home Video 97 minutes. $29.95.

title: New Life for a Loft Building
description: When the city arranged a lucrative package of tax abatements and low-cost energy to keep Shearson Lehman/American Express from building a computer center and office tower in New Jersey, officials said their main hope was to preserve jobs.

title: A Racial Quota Case in Brooklyn
description: Starrett City in Brooklyn is a prime target in the Reagan Administration's fight against the use of racial quotas in subsidized housing. For one thing, it is one of the largest such projects in the country.

title: 3 ORGANIZATIONS FORM ARTS RESOURCE CONSORTIUM
description: Three organizations serving the American arts community have formed an Arts Resource Consortium to provide legal and technical assistance to artists and arts associations and to operate a 15,000-volume research library, which is to open Tuesday.

title:
GARDENING;
MATURITY THE KEY IN HARVESTING POPCORN
description: ABOUT this time of year, it is certain that someone who has planted popcorn for the first time will wonder what to do with it. After all, sweet corn is being harvested, so why not popcorn?

title: WHEN INSPIRED AWFULNESS BECOMES INTERESTING
description: Every craft has its dark secrets and music criticism's must be among the darkest. Or perhaps it is no secret to you that a truly bad performance, for instance, may be more palatable than a merely competent one to the hardened reviewer. Not only more palatable, but absolutely, joyously welcome. After all, there usually is nothing worth saying about a so-so performance other than that it took place. Back in the office, the reviewer hopefully looks at his notes and discovers only a few doodles or enigmatic notations such as ''sensible tempos'' or ''why Beethoven?'' Nobody wants to write about a tepid performance and nobody should have to read about one.

title: FINDING SUCCESS IN THE CHINESE MARKET
description: BY the end of its first year in business, Sun Associates Inc. in Elmsford, an international trading and consultant company, had one customer but nevertheless managed to gross $7.5 million. Four years later, Sun Associates, still with the same single customer, has quadrupled sales to post figures of $28 million gross this year.

title:
GARDENING;
MATURITY THE KEY IN HARVESTING POPCORN
description: ABOUT this time of year, it is certain that someone who has planted popcorn for the first time will wonder what to do with it. After all, sweet corn is being harvested, so why not popcorn?

title: 4 IN LEAD OF ST. JUDE TOURNEY
description: Howard Twitty, seeking his first PGA Tour victory of the year, bogeyed the 18th hole today to fall in a four-way tie after three rounds of the $500,000 St. Jude Golf Classic.

title: Syria Backs Talks to End Lebanese Civil War
description: Syria, the main power broker in Lebanon, voiced support today for proposed talks between Moslems and Christians on ending the 11-year-old Lebanese civil war.

title:
BACK TO SCHOOL: TIMES GET TOUGHER;
COLLEGES TRY THE HARD SELL
description: ''It's 1986. Do you know where your class of 1991 is?''- Theme of an upcoming college and university advancement development conference.

title: Twins Win Swimming
description: Karen and Sarah Josephson of Bristol, Conn., twin sisters, today won the duet event in the Lotte Cup, an international synchronized swimming competition, edging the world champion team of Carolyn Waldo and Michelle Cameron of Canada.

title: THE DANCE: SALLY GROSS AND CREACH/KOESTER
description: One of the most enjoyable feature of ''Dance and Performance,'' the ongoing free series being sponsored by Creative Time and Central Park's SummerStage, has been the festival's telling mixes of styles. One such mix occurred on Friday at the Central Park Bandshell in a program shared by Sally Gross and Company and Terry Creach/Stephen Koester and Dancers . Delicacy and gutsiness met and co-existed, as did ''female'' and ''male'' art and two quite different generations of postmodernist choreographers and performers.

title: Bolivia Calls Out the Army To Halt Marchers
description: For weeks, Bolivia has insisted it is in dire straits. It appealed to Washington for $100 million to help replace revenues lost as a result of last month's United States Army-assisted crackdown on cocaine laboratories.

title: Artistic Bologna
description: To the Editor: William Weaver's excellent article ''Scholarly, Epicurean Bologna'' (Travel, June 29) justifiably celebrates the intellectual and gastronomic delights of the famous Emilian city.

title: California Assembly Opposes Bias on AIDS
description: California has approved legislation barring job and housing discrimination against AIDS victims.

title: Giant Step
description: To the Editor:

title: Leaving the Law For Wall Street
description: Actually, I was not surprised to read that lawyers are jumping ship to join the investment banks (''The Faster Track: Leaving the Law for Wall Street,'' by Tamar Lewin, Aug. 10). No one ever accused students who flocked to the large corporate law firms of wishing to enhance society.

title: Kate Hersey Has Wedding
description: The marriage of Kate Simmons Hersey, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Andruss Hersey of East Orleans, Mass., to John Stiles Dickerson 4th, the son of Mrs. Dickerson Jr. of Newagen, Me., and the late Mr. Dickerson, took place yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Holy Spirit in Orleans, Mass. The Rev. Peter Stone performed the ceremony.

title: CORRECTION
description: In a review of Jean Harris's book, ''Stranger in Two Worlds'' Aug. 24, information on the disbursement of the book's royalties was incorrect. The State Crime Victims Board announced this month that the royalties must be turned over to the board and deposited in an escrow account for five years, so that victims affected by the author's crime can file civil suits.

title: SOME DETAINEES FREED
description: Miners today ended a 24-hour strike protesting the nationwide state of siege, and the Government freed some of the 162 people it had detained, officials said.

title: 'Microcosmos' and Evolution
description: To the Editor:

title: TALKIN' UNION: GOMPERS AMONG THE SCHOLARS
description: December will mark the 100th anniversary of the founding of the American Federation of Labor. As the labor movement prepares to celebrate Labor Day this year, however, unease permeates its ranks. While 35 percent of the work force was organized in the 1950's, today the figure is only 18 percent - a postwar low -and there is no evidence the slide has ceased. So upsetting is this downward trend that the A.F.L.-C.I.O. issued a self-evaluation a year ago actually suggesting, among other things, that some working people might feel more comfortable joining independent associations rather than their industry's union. Has the labor movement lost that much of its drive and vision, critics of the report asked. Are American workers, in the words of the old organizing song, that antagonistic to the idea of ''talkin' union?''

title: 5 CENTURIES OF FRENCH DRAWINGS IN 2 COLLECTIONS
description: Is there such a thing as a dull French drawing? Of course there is. In statistical terms, the world is full of them. We are speaking, after all, of 500 years during which every artist drew and many of them drew every day. Necessarily, turkeys abound.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''Next thing, what G.M.'s going to do is say, 'Come on down, we're going to make the payments for you.' '' -An unnamed G.M. dealer, on the latest incentive program.

title: Model Derailments
description: Warner LeRoy's stylish new Potomac restaurant has a brass-plated model train that enchants patrons by chugging through the dining room.

title: ROCK: BIG COUNTRY, FROM SCOTLAND
description: THE Scottish band Big Country was making a concert film of its show Wednesday at Pier 84, so it brought along elaborate lights and a stage set of vaguely Gothic ruins. There was also a camera crew, whose cranes and busyness lent an air of artificiality to a band that is generally a model of earnest sincerity. Few other rock singers would, as Stuart Adamson did, describe the audience response as ''humbling.''

title: Data Update: August 31, 1986
description: (Source: HSH Associates) *Rates on most adjustable mortgages are set 1 to 3 percentage points above these indexes.

title: POSTINGS: Tudor City; Trying Again
description: Tudor City, a quiet enclave of English Cottage architecture built in the 1920's in midtown Manhattan, has been anything but peaceful.

title: OPERA: 'THE NEW MOON' GETS NEW CAST
description: MANY will find the New York City Opera's current production of ''The New Moon'' - music by Sigmund Romberg and book and lyrics by Oscar Hammerstein II, Frank Mandel, Laurence Schwab and Robert Johanson - a sweet, old-fashioned evening of fun. Others will acknowledge the handsome sets, the ebulliently staged fight scenes and the sumptious ensemble singing, yet still wish the City Opera had spent its efforts on a more nourishing composition.

title: Is This Equitable?
description: To the Editor:

title: STRONG POINT IS PITCHING
description: EVEN though the Yankees sent some of their brightest minor-league prospects to the major leagues this season - Bob Tewksbury and Doug Drabek were the most notable - this has not been the best of seasons for an organiztion that was making bold efforts to steer away from the temptations of the free-agent market. But the Yankees are no less enthusiastic now than they were before.

title: Talks on Gossage Ban
description: With the Major League Baseball Players Association standing by on the sidelines ready to file a grievance over his suspension for the remainder of the season, Rich (Goose) Gossage, his agent, Jerry Kapstein, and his lawyer, Bob Teaff, will meet tomorrow with San Diego team officials in an effort to settle the issue involving the Padres' relief pitcher.

title:
FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS;
D. B. Cooper: Undying Legend
description: NEARLY 15 years after the skyjacker known as D. B. Cooper parachuted from a jetliner with $200,000 in ransom money and vanished, most of the $6,000 ultimately recovered was split between an insurance company and a boy who found the water-stained, partly decomposed $20 bills.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: ENTREPRENEURS OF THE OLD WEST. By David Dary. (Knopf, $22.95.)

title: INCEST VICTIMS: OUT OF THE DARKNESS
description: BARBARA, a 27-year-old nurse, was suffering from depression and starving herself when she returned home to Long Island from West Germany in 1984 and began counseling with a local therapist.

title: TWAIN DEFEAT HURT REDDING
description: First Selectman Mary Anne Guitar was on the winning side at the Aug. 7 Town Meeting in Redding. Ordinarily, it is a good thing for a politician to be allied with the winning team.

title: Steps of Rome
description: To the Editor: Louis Inturrisi's article on the stairways of Rome (Travel, Aug. 3) describes the steps at the monument to Victor Emmanuel II in Rome as ''purely decorative. No one is allowed to tread these hundreds of steps, to pass over them and to feel what they have to say.''

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent

title: STRONG EARTHQUAKE HITS 3 EAST EUROPEAN NATIONS
description: A strong earthquake early today sent people fleeing from their homes here and in the Bulgarian capital of Sofia and also rattled through eastern Yugoslavia.

title: Making Sure that Like Meets Like
description: THERE is scarcely a dating service around that is not trying to grab a specific niche of the singles market.

title: EDWARD LARKIN, PUBLIC SERVICE COMMISSIONER
description: Edward Paul Larkin, the senior member of the state Public Service Commission in Albany, died yesterday of pulmonary distress in Albany Medical Center. He was 71 years old and lived in Hempstead, L.I., where he had served as the town's Presiding Supervisor in the late 1950's.

title: DEBATING FISH IN GREENPORT
description: FOR more than a decade the Village of Greenport has been losing the boatyards and fish-processing plants that have inspired many travel writers to describe it as ''a sleepy little fishing village.''

title: Frances Thompson Bride Of Mark Francis Ricciardi
description: Frances Rutledge Thompson was married yesterday to Mark Francis Ricciardi. The Rev. Dr. William P. Barker, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Bard Thompson, in Harding Township, N.J.

title: MEXICAN ARMY REKINDLES ITS LOVE FOR HORSES
description: Ever since Hernan Cortes, the Spanish explorer and conquerer, brought the first horses to Mesoamerica, the Mexicans have had a love affair with the horse.

title: AS DROP IN OIL PRICES HURTS THE ELITE, TEXAS TRIES TO ADJUST
description: The names of those struggling to hold their empires together are some of the best known in Texas: Clint Murchison, Cullen Davis and now the Hunt brothers of Dallas.

title: Sound; DIGITAL RECORDING LEADS TO REFINEMENTS IN CASSETTE TAPES
description: Tape manufacturers have lately been refining their product in an effort to keep abreast of the sonic advances gained through digital recording.

title: TWAIN DISTRICT STUDY WAS REDUNDANT
description: I am so tired of combating reams of nonsense issued over the so-called Mark Twain Historic District in Redding.

title: Article 894486 -- No Title
description: WHILE students and most educators are concerning themselves with the start of the new school year this week, the State Office of Policy and Management will be turning its attention to next September - and the State Department of Education's first-ever billion-dollar budget request.

title: Joseph P. Harris,Katherine O'Neil Are Wed in Ohio
description: Katherine Marie O'Neil, a daughter of Mrs. Robert A. O'Neil of Akron, Ohio, and the late Mr. O'Neil, was married yesterday to Joseph Paul Harris, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph P. Harris of Pomona, N.Y. The Rev. Donald Cozzens performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Elms Convent Chapel in Akron.

title: Anne Alstott Plans to Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Rosemary L. Kincaid of Buffalo, Wyo., and David F. Alstott of Lafayette, Ind., of the engagement of their daughter, Anne Lester Alstott, to Louis Gordon Crovitz, the son of Elaine K. Crovitz of Durham, N.C., and Herbert F. Crovitz of Chapel Hill, N.C. A Dec. 7 wedding is planned.

title: James Morrissey To Wed Lena Lu
description: An October wedding is planned by Lena Tsu-Yin Lu, a banker, and James M. Morrissey, a lawyer, the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Chun-I Lu of Taipei, Taiwan, and New York, have announced. The bridegroom-to-be is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard E. Morrissey Jr. of Hanover, N.H.

title: A CHEER FOR SUMMER'S END
description: LABOR DAY is usually considered to be the last vestige of summer. There is always a tear shed as the last burger of the season is tossed on the grill. But I think that tear is not one of regret but one of joy.

title: HOW MANY MORE CARDS DOES GARCIA HAVE TO PLAY?
description: PERU'S young President, Alan Garcia Perez, is by instinct a gambler, a man who believes that only through daring actions, such as limiting military expenditures and foreign debt payments, can he find the resources necessary to attack the acute domestic problems he inherited.

title: Twists and Turns On Agent Orange
description: The $180 million settlement Vietnam veterans reached with manufacturers of Agent Orange two years ago was hardly the end of the case. When the Federal District Court devised a plan to distribute the money, the veterans' lawyers contested that, too.

title: ACCOUNTABILITY IS A PRIME NEED
description: WHEN the Avon Board of Education's insurance policy renewal arrived recently and school officials saw the district's premium had jumped from $380 a year to $95,000, they were certain they were looking at a typographical error.

title: Neighbors Say No To Contra Training
description: The Reagan Administration's plans to accelerate the fighting in Nicaragua are provoking opposition among Nicaragua's neighbors.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Labor Day, 1995

title: MUSIC: ALFRESCO CONCERT BY WEST SIDE PLAYERS
description: ON a cool, clear Friday afternoon - with temperatures that would have seemed less unusual in October than in late August - the Lincoln Center Out-of-Doors Festival presented the West Side Chamber Players in ''A Salon Concert of Music Heard in the Time of the Statue of Liberty, circa 1886.''

title: CHARLES RIVER GETS DRAMATIC CLEANUP
description: Last year, two automobiles had to be dredged from the Charles River before a local environmental group could hold its annual community swim, intended to prove that the ill-reputed waters were safe enough for swimming.

title: JAZZING UP THE OLD MOVIE HOUSE
description: THE other night, most people at the glossy Beekman Theater on Manhattan's Upper East Side were laughing at ''Ruthless People,'' one of the summer's popular comedies. Movie mogul Garth Drabinsky - who has been called ruthless himself - had other things on his mind. Like banning smoking from the balcony, putting real butter on the popcorn and redesigning the theater.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: For the Very Young And the Slightly Older

title: LEAVING LAW FOR WALL STREET
description: Tamar Lewin's article emphasizes that those who choose a career on Wall Street are motivated by ''society's increasing preoccupation with wealth as a measure of achievement.''

title: New Sources Found
description: To the Editor:

title: Reagan Hails Economic Gain In Speech Marking Labor Day
description: President Reagan, in a Labor Day tribute to the nation's workers, today promised better times ahead for farmers and others who have yet to share in its economic recovery.

title: COACH AND COLLEGIAN IN FINAL
description: Chris Kite, the No. 1 player for Wake Forest, and Buddy Alexander, golf coach at Louisiana State University, advanced to the final of the 86th United States Amateur Golf Championship today.

title: Wintering With Sea Birds
description: Paddle silently along with baby sea lions and gray whales, snorkel with dolphins and porpoises, explore hundreds of miles of beaches and dunes uninhabited except for wintering sea birds, all the while piloting a sea kayak in the calm waters of Magdalena Bay on the Pacific coast of Mexico's Baja Peninsula.

title: CARDINALS TOP REDS ON CONROY 3-HITTER
description: Tim Conroy pitched seven hitless innings, retiring 21 batters in a row at one point, to lead the St. Louis Cardinals to a 5-2 victory tonight over the Cincinnati Reds, who had won six in a row.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Pete Vuckovich, the 1982 American League Cy Young Award winner, who had retired but is now attempting a comeback after several years of shoulder problems, will rejoin the Milwaukee Brewers tomorrow and pitch the next day against the Minnesota Twins. . . . Southern Illinois University-Edwardsville has forfeited eight of last season's 23 victories because Anthony Webster, its forward-center, carried only eight credits during one quarter last season, four fewer than required by the National Collegiate Athletic Association. The Cougars, 23-7 last season, reached the quarterfinals of the Division II play before losing, 77-73, to Wright State. . . . Carey Scurry, who starred for Long Island University and was the second selection of the Utah Jazz in 1985, has signed a three-year contract with the team. . . . John Walker and Rod Dixon of New Zealand have entered the Mercedes Mile on Fifth Avenue on Sept. 13.

title: REPORTER'S ARREST IN MOSCOW SEEMS LIKE RERUN OF '77 CASE
description: Almost every detail of Nicholas Daniloff's detention today appeared to be a replay of a case involving an American journalist in 1977.

title: Studying, Driving -- and Hunting Mates
description: FOR some singles, the agony of making that initial phone call to ask for that first date is the worst part of meeting. So some singles services are looking for ways to make the icebreaking conversations easier.

title: Record Lows Recorded In 43 Cities Around U.S
description: Cold Canadian air covering the eastern half of the nation yesterday made the closing days of August feel like the opening days of November, shattering record lows in 43 cities from Texas to Rhode Island for the third day.

title: IN THE VENETO, A CHESS GAME AS BIG AS LIFE
description: ''For some minutes Alice stood without speaking, looking out in all directions over the country - and a most curious country it was. . . . 'I declare it's marked out just like a large chess-board!' Alice said at last. 'There ought to be some men moving about somewhere - and so there are!' she added in a tone of delight, and her heart began to beat quick with excitement as she went on. . . . 'Oh, what fun it is! How I wish I was one of them! I wouldn't mind being a pawn, if only I might join - though of course, I should like to be a queen best.''

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM KILTS TO WHITE TIE
description: Animal Stories:CC Studios 30 minutes. $29.95.

title: POINTLESS SANCTIONS AGAINST CUBA
description: President Reagan's latest economic and immigration sanctions against Cuba are absurd and futile gestures. The Cuban actions that provoked him are surely annoying, but what is the point of getting angry at bad weather?

title: HOW SIBERIA CONCENTRATED HIS MIND
description: DOSTOEVSKY The Stir of Liberation 1860-1865. By Joseph Frank. Illustrated. 395 pp. New Jersey: Princeton University Press. $29.50.

title: Speak Up!
description: To the Editor:

title: Top Matches For Today
description: STADIUM Afternoon Noon - Boris Becker vs. Sergio Casal Second Match - Mary Joe Fernandez vs.

title: RIDING OUT A SCANDAL TESTS KOCH'S BALANCE
description: IT says something about the climate in New York City government these days that a former senior official can be convicted of grand larceny, forgery and filing false documents, and the Mayor is relieved. That is what happened last week in the case of John J. McLaughlin, the first city official to come to trial since the advent early this year of the New York City corruption scandal.

title: Did Wall Street Receive a Tip?
description: Last week's principal economic reports may have been as notable for speculation about them as for light they shed on the nation's condition.

title: TENDER BREEZE AND STEAMING FOOD
description: IT is still relatively rare to find a Connecticut restaurant where you can dine outside comfortably, at well-spaced tables, in an airy, bug-free environment. But if you are in the vicinity of Washington Depot, a new restaurant named Jonathan's is such a place.

title:
BACK TO SCHOOL: TIMES GET TOUGHER;
NEW STANDARDS TO TEST PUPILS
description: FEWER students will return to Long Island's public schools when classes reopen this week, but they will find new, expanded and tougher curriculums designed to improve their education, school officials say.

title: HOUSING COUNCIL AWAITS MUNICIPAL DECISIONS
description: THE New Jersey Council on Affordable Housing is watching the mails closely these days, waiting for letters from towns that want to be protected from suits forcing them to accept more low- and moderate-income housing.

title: Giants Need Morris, Badly
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Scenario for a U.S. Intervention in Nicaragua
description: To the Editor:

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: The Chocolate of the Afflicted

title: Chinese Official Charges U.S. Is Interfering With U.N. Aid
description: A Chinese official charged today that Washington was interfering in China's affairs by cutting off contributions to the United Nations Fund for Population Activities.

title: Lake District
description: To the Editor: Reading ''The Poet's Landscape'' (Travel, Aug. 3) brought back memories of a winter's journey to the Lake District. One outing on a track covered with newly fallen snow, complete with neo-Gothic church and bleating sheep, brought us to Rydal Mount. I was surprised to find it open at that time of year and pleased to discover no other visitors. We were given what amounted to a private tour, following which we were ushered into Wordsworth's parlor and served tea and ginger biscuits. With a roaring fire going, we sat rested and warmed, looking out over the snow-covered Dora's Field. Thus fortified, we set out for Dove Cottage (unfortunately closed for the season).

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: HEROES AND VILLAINS. By Jerry Bumpus. (Fiction Collective, Cloth, $13.95. Paper, $6.95.)

title: CHANGES ABOUND AS SCHOOL YEAR OPENS
description: AS the new term begins this week, New Jersey's 2,255 public schools will be responding to an almost dizzying array of educational changes that have recently been set in motion. In addition, the school year promises to bring a number of legislative and philosophical battles that are likely to lead to more major changes in the way schools are run.

title: INTERESTING INDIAN SPECIALTIES
description: TO the growing roster of Indian restaurants on the Island, add the Bombay Brasserie in East Meadow. The chef-owner was formerly with the luxurious Raga Restaurant in Manhattan, and he has brought some interesting specialties to Nassau County.

title: KREMLINOLOGY COMES IN FOR REVISION
description: NOT so many years ago, a clash of troops along the Chinese-Soviet border would almost certainly have provoked a tirade from the Kremlin. But when such an event was reported several weeks ago, the Foreign Ministry brushed it off with a few calm words. The low-key reaction was a measure of how much the style, and to some extent the substance, of Soviet foreign policy has changed under Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: C. H. Butcher Cleared Of U.S. Fraud Charges
description: The former banker C. H. Butcher Jr. was found not guilty today of defrauding depositors in a savings institution that collapsed in 1983.

title: HOLLYWOOD'S SPOTTY RECORD ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: As a summer rich in recycled monsters, refurbished romances and slow-witted comedies draws to a close, the moviegoer may feel a craving for something that somehow connects with the real world. It is as natural as the need for a fresh salad after a spree of junk food.

title: NUISANCE AND NOSTALGIA AT EX-U.S. OPEN SITE
description: For two weeks every summer, when Steven Petersell answers the phone at the West Side Tennis Club, he knows what he will hear. And he has an answer ready.

title: Opponent of Zia Returns To Pakistan and Is Seized
description: A leading opponent of President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq was arrested at the Karachi airport today when he returned after nine years in exile, the police said.

title: WE ARE BOTH PROUD ATHLETES, BUT SEAVER IS BLESSED
description: TOM SEAVER and I are friends.

title: Soda Mergers
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Die in Crash as Fire Truck Runs Red Light and Hits Car
description: Three people died today when a fire truck went through a red light and hit their car, the authorities said.

title: EVICTION NOTICES SET OFF SOWETO
description: For months and even years, black activists have been withholding rents in South African townships as way of attacking the system of segregation and depriving local authorities, by latest estimates, of $500,000 a day. Last week, the Government tried to evict the rent strikers in Soweto, the sprawling township near Johannesburg, touching off the most lethal 24 hours of urban violence there in years.

title: Margery Weber Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Everett D. Weber of Gloversville, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Margery Susan Weber to Lawrence B. Orell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Orell of Baldwin, L.I. Miss Weber is a market representative for boys' wear at Associated Dry Goods Inc. in New York. Her fiance is a vice president and associate media director of Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein Inc., a New York advertising agency. She graduated from Skidmore College and he from Hofstra University.

title: Speeding as A Right Reserved To the States
description: Western states have lobbied for the repeal of the 55 mile-an-hour speed limit since it became law after the Arab oil embargo in 1974. While the limit may make sense on the Beltway around Washington, D.C., they complain, it is not suited to the empty stretches of highway west of the Mississippi.

title: AT EDINBURGH THIS YEAR, DRAMA PLAYED THE LEAD
description: When Frank Dunlop took over as director of the Edinburgh Festival in 1984, he was the first theater man to run the world's largest cultural extravaganza. His track record included creating the Young Vic in London, working as Sir Laurence Olivier's associate at the National Theater, and directing on Broadway and in Brooklyn. At this year's festival (the 40th) his hand is apparent: For the first time ever, drama dominated music.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: FEDERAL, state and local agencies are trying for the first time to control water pollution from sources other than discharge pipes.

title: Mitterrand Interceding For a Cuban Dissident
description: One of Cuba's most prominent dissidents has sought refuge in the French Embassy here, and Western diplomats say President Francois Mitterrand is quietly trying to persuade Fidel Castro to allow him to leave the country.

title: Seoul Charges 154 Students; Leftists Facing Crackdown
description: Prosecutors said today that 154 students had been charged with trying to topple the Government of President Chun Doo Hwan.

title: New Football Honor
description: The first Jim Thorpe Award to recognize the nation's top collegiate defensive back will be presented Dec. 9 in Oklahoma City. Gov. George Nigh of Oklahoma announced the establishment of the award, which is sponsored by the Jim Thorpe Athletic Club.

title:
MUSIC;
2 CHORAL GROUPS AUDITIONING
description: TWO choral organizations, each in its eighth season, are holding auditions for membership. The Bergen Chorale, conducted by Paula Biran, and the Princeton Pro Musica, under by Frances F. Slade, will each present four concerts this season.

title: EDUCATING 19th-CENTURY SCHOOLGIRLS
description: THE ability to paint was considered essential for a well-bred young lady in the early part of the 19th century. It signified that she was educated and refined, and it was encouraged at the academies where middle- and upper-class families sent their daughters for secondary education.

title: American Agents Stake Out Mexico
description: The principal trading between the United States and Mexico last week seemed to be in disagreements and protests involving illegal drugs. Mexican newspapers and politicians challenged the presence on Mexican soil of American narcotics agents.

title: U.S. Tells Texas Air 'No' on Eastern Deal
description: A thumbs-down was given to the merger of Texas Air and Eastern by the Transportation Department. It said the combination would be anti-competitive, particularly in the Northeast Corridor, where Eastern's and Texas Air's New York Air shuttles compete. But Texas Air, which had planned to buy Eastern for $676 million, said it is confident it can revise its plan to meet the Justice Department objections. Among the possible deals are a sale to Pan Am of more landing slots at La Guardia airport, which would remove the objections about the shuttle routes.

title: SOVIET FMILY REUNITED AT J.F.K.
description: Alexander Kostomaroff was reunited at Kennedy International Airport yesterday with the woman he divorced almost seven years ago so he could leave the Soviet Union.

title: 'Oooo' Cheer Isn't New York's
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Piggvar Leads U.S. In Sweep at Roosevelt
description: Piggvar, driven by 59-year-old Stanley Dancer, led the United States to a sweep in the $100,000 Challenge Cup tonight at Roosevelt Raceway.

title:
ART;
RESIDENT ART SHOWS BRING NEW LIFE TO PUBLIC SPACES
description: THESE days we are accustomed to finding art everywhere, so it is not surprising to discover it at the Westport Town Hall and the Southport train station.

title: Patricia R. Roska Becomes a Bride
description: Patricia Regina Roska and Richard Hagen Macy, who graduated from Wesleyan University with the class of '84, were married yesterday in Berwick, Pa. The Rev. Joseph Arevelo, a cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony at Immaculate Conception Roman Catholic Church.

title: SURVIVAL OF THE FITTEST
description: IF you have, of an evening, been twiddling the dial in the neighborhood of Channel 21, our own public television station, you may have noticed that it seems to have been taking to nature more than ever.

title: Miss Gardner to Wed F. L. Ames in October
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John Lowell Gardner of South Hamilton, Mass., of the engagement of their daughter, Rebecca Burnett Gardner, to Frederick Lothrop Ames, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David Ames of North Easton, Mass. The wedding is planned for Oct. 4.

title: Anne Bottomley Engaged
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. James L. Bottomley Jr. of Princeton Junction, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter Anne Louise Rainville Bottomley to Robert Philip Smit, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip D. Smit of New York.

title: T>ransactions
description: BASEBALL BALTIMORE (AL) - Recalled Mike Young, outfielder, from its Class AAA affiliate in Rochester: sent John Habyan, pitcher, to Rochester.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE SPANISH CIVIL WAR: A History in Pictures (Norton, $29.95) and THE SPANISH CIVIL WAR 1936-39 (Grove Press, $20) both commemorate the 50th anniversary of the start of the Spanish Civil War. The first of these books gives us an excellent picture history of that brutal and complex conflict. We see the prelude to the war, its very first days, the atrocities committed by both sides, the battles and the heroism of the combatants; at the end we see the smug smiles of the victors and the tragedy in the faces of the vanquished. Most of the pictures are photographs; by far the most artful are the posters, and the Republic, which lost the war to the Nationalists, gets the best of it here. There is a photograph of a Nationalist pilot at his cockpit controls as he prepares to drop his bombs. Man, that unruly beast, bears accurate witness to his own crimes. One of the finest posters esthetically, a dissolute face alongside bottles of wine, reads: ''A drunkard is a parasite. Let's eliminate him.'' In a striking photograph, volunteers of the anti-Stalinist revolutionary group P.O.U.M. are lined up ready to depart for the front. On the far left, standing head and shoulders above the others, is George Orwell. The final chapter contains a remarkable painting by Xavier Bueno titled ''The Spanish Soldier'' and inscribed ''To my friend . . . who died in defense of Madrid.'' Tinted in magenta is a huge bleeding figure wearing a poncho and standing in a niche, gun in hand, head bowed.

title: THE FALL OF ICARUS
description: WARTIME WRITINGS 1939-1944 By Antoine de Saint-Exupery. Translated by Norah Purcell. With an introduction by Anne Morrow Lindbergh. 237 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $12.95.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: August 31,1986
description: FICTION

title: Elizabeth Murray To Marry Oct. 25
description: Mr. and Mrs. Morgan J. Murray of Morristown, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Meyer Murray to Dr. Rahul Kalahastri Naidu, a son of Dr. and Mrs. K.J. Naidu of Evanston, Ill. The wedding is planned for Oct. 25.

title: Q AND A
description: Island Sailing: Question:Where can I obtain information, including costs, on chartering a sailboat with crew for a week's vacation in the Caribbean in November? - K. S., New York Answer:Information is available from several yacht brokers with long experience in arranging crewed charters. Costs vary according to a boat's comfort and what its owner believes it is worth, but generally a week's charter will cost around $2,000 for two people, $4,000 for four, $5,000 for six and much more for larger, more luxurious craft. These rates include the crew (a skipper and cook and, on larger boats, one to three assistants as well), all meals and, often, an open bar. The high season runs from mid-December to the end of April; outside that period, rates are generally about 10 percent less. September and October are regarded as the hurricane season; in November the weather is generally clear. Among islands on which many charter sailboats are based are St. Thomas and Antigua.

title: Single Travelers
description: To the Editor: I would like to add my voice to Evelyn G. Siegel's (Letters to the Editor, Travel, July 26) on the subject of excessive penalties for single travelers.

title: AGUILERA BEATS DODGERS BY 6-3
description: They are unchallenged, almost untouched, and they just keep rolling along: 5 straight victories now, 11 in their last 12 games, 87 in the 129 played this season, the Mets still pouring it on.

title: THABIT KOMBO
description: Thabit Kombo, a major figure in Tanzanian politics for more than 20 years, died Friday, his family announced.

title: INJURY CUTS SHORT CYCLIST'S BID
description: The dream ended for Scott Berryman early this morning, just as the sun began lightening the sky, when he climbed onto his bicycle and realized that he was too badly hurt to continue riding in the world championships.

title: A NEW INSPSECTOR BATTLES TERMITES
description: THE congregation of Christ Episcopal Church here was unaware their building had any problems until last March, when hundreds of termites crashed their annual flea market.

title: CHASING AFTER GOD AND SEX
description: ROGER'S VERSION By John Updike. 329 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $17.95.

description: Melvin Bratton scored two of his three touchdowns on first-period runs of 34 and 12 yards as Miami opened its season tonight by rolling to a 34-14 victory over South Carolina.

title: Lovable Folks
description: To the Editor:

title: HARDY WATERLILIES WERE THE LEGACY OF ONE HYBRIDIZER
description: ''W hat I need most of all are flowers, always, always.'' So said the painter Claude Monet to a visitor he took around his famous garden at Giverny soon after the turn of the century. It was for this reason, perhaps, that Monet found the Marliac hybrid waterlilies so fascinating. An established specimen bears a dozen fragrant, cup-shaped blossoms at a time and stays continuously in bloom from mid- May until the onset of cold weather.

title: A CROWDED DEFENSE TABLE IN PALERMO
description: ITALY'S attention will turn again this week to the courtroom in Palermo where 470 Mafiosi suspects are on trial. Prosecutors will be trying to solve the mysteries of the Green Box, the Disappearing Key and the Missing Dossier.

title: OJEDA DEAL A BONANZA
description: IS there anything left in the farm system that graduated Darryl Strawberry and Dwight Gooden and paid the ransom for Keith Hernandez and Gary Carter and so many of the other stars of 1986?

title: Business Films
description: To the Editor:

title: LEAVING THE LAW FOR WALL STREET
description: There must be some quality that attracts so many to the practice of law. The article on young lawyers is sadly superficial in its effort to contrast the practice of law with investment banking.

title: Hard Time
description: Jerry A. Whitworth, who was characterized in court as ''one of the most spectacular spies of the century,'' drew a sentence to match last week - 365 years in prison and a $410,000 fine. He was convicted in July of having been part of an espionage ring headed by a Navy colleague, warrant officer John A. Walker Jr., who pleaded guilty and testified against Mr. Whitworth.

title:
RECORDINGS;
KARAJAN'S FOURTH CYCLE OF BEETHOVEN'S NINE
description: Complete recordings of Beethoven's nine symphonies, like complete recordings of Wagner's ''Ring,'' tend to occupy a special niche in the hearts of music lovers and record producers alike. As the procrustean bed of Romanticism, the very salt of the musical earth, the Nine are considered the backbone of any serious record collection. From a marketing point of view, they form an ideal product. Unlike Brahms's four symphonies, of which there are too few to give the buyer the thrill of purchasing a really substantial chunk of history, or Mahler's 10 (if one includes, as Kubelik and Haitink have, the unfinished 10th), which are simply too long to yield a manageable package, and still debatable as to musical value, Beethoven's nine symphonies strike the happy balance of aggregate length and unequivocal respectability. Like complete editions of Shakespeare, therefore, The Nine are released in boxed sets conspicuous for their dignity - sober gilt lettering on the outside, cover embellishment usually incorporating a suitable portrait of the composer or a soulful one of the maestro in question, and a substantial book of essays within.

title: 2 Soviet Athletes Break World Marks in Track
description: Yuri Sedykh and Marina Stepanova of the Soviet Union set world records and Gelindo Bordin of Italy won the men's marathon in the European track and field championships today.

title: SPEAKER BATTLING FOR PARTY BACKING
description: THE Speaker of the Connecticut House of Representatives, R. E. Van Norstrand, finds himself in a strange situation. No one can remember when a Speaker was refused re-endorsement by his own party.

title:
NATURE WATCH;
COMMON SPIDER CRAB
description: Libinia emarginata

title: FOR CAR-POOLER, IT'S A VEHICLE FOR SANITY L>By ARTHUR J. VISELTEAR; Arthur J. Viseltear lives in Guilford.
description: I OWN a 10-year-old station wagon, and for the last eight years, I've been getting 90 miles to a gallon of gas. How is that possible? Simple: I car pool.

title: TUITION RISING AT MOST COLLEGES IN THE COUNTY
description: AS students return to campus for the 1986-87 academic year, tuitions at private colleges in the county are 5 to 11 percent higher than last year. Nationwide, tuition charges are increasing an average of 7 to 8 percent.

title: ATHENS SPURNING A TRUMAN STATUE
description: Mayor Dimitris Beis said today that the Socialist-run Athens City Council would stand by its decision not to re-erect the statue of Harry S. Truman, which was destroyed by vandals in March, despite a commitment by Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou to restore it.

title: COURT REMOVES FUENTES FROM BALLOT IN YONKERS PRIMARY
description: A CLOSELY-contested primary race among three Democratic candidates for the 83d Assembly seat held by Republican Nicholas A. Spano intensified last week as an appeals court disqualified one of the candidates.

title: Anti-'Blight' Measure Gets a Test
description: EVEN though builders are not expected to break ground for R.H. Sailors & Company's $180 million development for several months, the 1.7 million-square-foot residential and commercial complex already has had an effect far greater than its size on this city's real-estate climate. Sailors spent more than $1 million to persuade the Kansas City Council and local residents to allow it to build, and the struggle was more than a typical residents-vs.-developer fight.

title: Alaska Bucks a Political Trend
description: In a political season in which incumbents generally have fared even better than they usually do, Alaska's Democratic primary provided an exception. By a 2-to-1 margin, former State Senator Steve Cowper, a Fairbanks lawyer, defeated Gov. Bill Sheffield in his bid for a second term.

title: Problem of Fear At Soup Kitchen
description: FOR three years, the Trenton Area Soup Kitchen had been a downtown haven, serving hundreds of hungry and homeless people each week in the basement of the historic First United Methodist Church of New Jersey. Shortly before Thanksgiving last year, a long-simmering complaint about the kitchen came to a boil.

title: Houston Marks 150 Years
description: This city of 1.6 million people is observing its 150th anniversary today, but the celebration is clouded by economic distress. Festivities include a picnic in Sam Houston Park with magicians, clowns and other entertainers, a four-foot-tall birthday card to sign, and boat rides on Buffalo Bayou. Houston is trying to cope with the oil industry's slump, as exemplified by a double-digit unemployment rate.

title: Miss Nalbantian Wed To Michael S. Brandt
description: At St. Vartan Armenian Cathedral in New York yesterday, Carol Elizabeth Nalbantian, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Nalbantian of New York and Port Jefferson, L.I., was married to Michael Stephan Brandt, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Brandt of Lansing, Ill. The Rev. Carnig Hallajian performed the ceremony and Archbishop Tiran Nersoyan gave the blessing.

title: 'NEW BRITS' AND HYPOCRITES
description: BRIDESHEAD BENIGHTED By Auberon Waugh. 221 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $16.95.

title: CALIFORNIA'S TOUGH LINE ON APARTHEID
description: IN AN unusual emotional gesture, most members of the California Assembly in Sacramento rose up Wednesday and applauded a black Assemblywoman from Los Angeles. For seven years Maxine Waters had been fighting for approval of legislation that would require the state pension system to dispose of stocks in companies that do business with South Africa. The Assembly had just given final approval to her bill, one of the strongest messages of disapproval yet to South Africa over its racial policies.

title: Learning Greek
description: The story of Paul Beeching, who has taken up the study of classical Greek at the age of 50, was a delight to read. I was fortunate to have felt the pull of the language at an earlier age (I majored in it at college) and, at the age of 43, I took the next step, which I commend to Mr. Beeching: I am learning Sanskrit. RONALD K. SIPHERD Oakland, Calif.

title: ANALYSIS SAID TO PINPOINT SOURCE OF ACID RAIN
description: The ''signatures'' of air polluters in the Middle West are on the acid rain damaging lakes and forests in the Northeast, according to two University of Rhode Island scientists who have recently patented a technique for analyzing acid rain.

title: SOVIET DISSIDENT REPORTS NEW K.G.B. THREAT
description: A Soviet dissident who was freed from a Siberian prison camp five months ago after serving three years at hard labor has told friends that the K.G.B. has threatened to send him back to prison again.

title: Hustler Ordered to Pay $2 Million for Photos
description: A Federal appeals court ruled Friday that Hustler magazine must pay a free-lance photographer $2 million for unauthorized publication of 11 nude photographs of Elizabeth Ray.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: GREEK FESTIVAL

title: Egyptian Court Sentences 5 In a Conspiracy With Libya
description: A court sentenced two Egyptians in absentia to 25 years at hard labor today for conspiring with Libya to launch subversive and terrorist acts inside Egypt.

title: TENNIS PRO, 27, SEES LATE START AS ASSET
description: AFTER losing the first two sets, 6-4, 7-6, and falling behind, 0-5, in the third set in his first-round match against Marcel Freeman at the United States Open last Tuesday, Bud Schultz finally held service to make it, 1-5.

title: THE INITIAL REACTION
description: THE WRITER ALISON LURIE TELLS of a journalist who dressed to match his assignments. Setting off to interview the rich and powerful, he wore Savile Row suits and John Lobb shoes. But when he felt these accouterments were not sufficiently impressive, he promptly added a monogrammed shirt.

title: TO SOME FARMERS, AT LEAST, WATER IS TEXAS' LIFEBLOOD
description: OIL may be the economic lifeblood of Texas, but another liquid is perhaps ultimately more crucial - water. And there always seems to be either too little or too much of it.

title: Virginia Byrne Plans to Marry D. M. Marzonie
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph M. Bryne 3d of Florham Park, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Virginia Marie Byrne to Douglas Michael Marzonie, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Marzonie of Northville, Mich. A December wedding is planned.

title: OBEDIENCE TRAINING OF THE 80'S IS DONE BY PET PSYCHOLOGISTS
description: A Beverly Hills doctor and his wife recently confronted an awkward problem. Their dog, a large German shepherd, refused to let the husband into the bedroom when his wife was there.

title: Photography
description: While perhaps not of the same exalted rank as Edward Weston or Ansel Adams, Laura Gilpin (1891-1979) was a gifted 20th-century photographer, and the fact that her work is relatively little known lends credence to arguments that the history of photography shortchanges the accomplishments of women. Now through Sept. 13, however, we have a welcome chance to become acquainted with the whole of her 60-year career, in an exhibition of more than 100 prints at the IBM Gallery, Madison Avenue at 56th Street.

title: Thomas R. Ferry Weds Miss Crum
description: Nancy Ann Crum, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. M. Colyer Crum of Weston, Mass., was married yesterday to Thomas Riker Ferry, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Riker Ferry of Short Hills, N.J. The Rev. Benjamin LeFevre, the bride's uncle and a Dutch Reform minister, performed the ceremony in the chapel at the Concord (Mass.) Academy, of which the bride is an alumna.

title: TOPICS
description: THERE were a lot of people in the room, little groups giggling and chattering like sparrows about their particular subjects of interest. There were people in the hall and men in the lounge at the other end, talking shop and telling jokes. The room was decorated, the mood jovial though austere.

title: Pantelleria
description: To the Editor: Susan Allen Toth's article ''On an Austere Italian Island'' (Travel, July 6) interested me, as I visited Pantelleria from June 15 to Sept. 1, 1943, with the 12th Air Force as a member of the 1005th Signal Company of the 19th Service Group.

title: Mehta and Bernstein To Lead Israeli Group
description: Zubin Mehta and Leonard Bernstein will conduct the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra at Avery Fisher Hall on Sept. 8 and 13, respectively, in concerts celebrating the orchestra's 50th anniversary. On Sept. 8, under Mr. Mehta, the violinist Pinchas Zukerman and the cellist Yo-Yo Ma will play the Brahms Double Concerto, and the Women's Chorus of the New York Choral Artists will perform in ''The Planets,'' by Gustav Holst.

description: The marriage of Joan Ellen Goldfeder to Jonathan David Kaufelt, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley P. Kaufelt of New Brunswick, N.J., took place Friday at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Howard Goldfeder of Cincinnati. Rabbi Alfred Gottschalk, the president of the Hebrew Union College in Cincinnati, performed the ceremony.

description: CATHEDRAL CONCERT SERIES

description: THE MAN FROM MARSEILLE. By J. P. Smith (St. Martin's, $11.95.)

title: CALIFORNIA LAWYERS MOVE ON ALL-MALE CLUBS
description: A controversy over whether lawyers and judges should belong to private clubs that restrict their membership to men has arisen again in professional organizations in California.

title: The U.S., the U.N. And Abortion
description: The United States had been the financial mainstay of the United Nations Fund for Population Activities for 17 years, until a dispute over population control in China got in the way. Anti-abortion activists, demanding that China soften its pressure - often implemented through abortions - for one-child families, persuaded the Reagan Administration to withhold part of its support from the fund last year.

title: Melissa Chassin to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Murray Joel Chassin of Roslyn and Westhampton Beach, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Melissa Ann Chassin to Jeffrey Alan Weiller, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin A. Weiller 3d of Stamford, Conn., and Beckett, Mass. Ms. Chassin graduated from Syracuse University. Her fiance, a graduate of Alfred University, received a master's degree in finance from Emory University.

description: Susan Joyce Hakim,the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gabriel Nicholas Hakim of Tenafly and Elberon, N.J., was married last night to Andrew Steven Kronfeld, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred N. Kronfeld of Tenafly and Delray Beach, Fla. Rabbi Irving Spielman performed the ceremony at the Tammy Brook Country Club in Cresskill, N.J.

title: REFUGEES IN SUDAN WORRY RED CROSS
description: International Red Cross officials have voiced new concern over the situation of more than 120,000 people in the south Sudanese city of Wau, saying the threat of starvation there had considerably worsened since air shipments of food were cut off by fighting two weeks ago.

title: SO DO ABUSES
description: A guerrilla war between Tamil separatists and Government forces is beginning to take its toll on Sri Lanka's strong democratic institutions, according to civil-rights groups and other Sri Lankans.

title: GOING THROUGH LIFE WITHOUT THE PRERFECT TAN
description: THAT'S me over there. No, not that one, that one. The one with the scraggly braids, knock-knees and bathing suit with the little pleated skirt. The one squinting at the sunlight and clutching some seashells. The third oldest of eight kids. And the one who doesn't get a tan.

title: INDIANAPOLIS TO HOLD VIOLIN COMPETITION
description: ''I think competitions are a neccessary part of musical life,''

title: MUSEUM TO PRESERVE FIFE AND DRUM
description: ON many a warm summer evening, the sound of piping fifes and the throbbing of drums ripples through the small towns in the Connecticut Valley, as it has for hundreds of years. Fife and drum music may have been a Bicentennial craze for some, but here, in small towns like Essex, Deep River and Chester, the musical tradition is very much alive.

title: LOW-PRICED CARS AND ELECTRONICS FROM SOUTH KOREA FLOODING U.S.
description: Products made in South Korea are flooding the United States, and some experts say Korea is challenging Japan as the leading low-price supplier of everything from small cars to video recorders.

title: DIOCESE HOLDS ITS OWN
description: THE Diocese of Rockville Centre, with 90 elementary and 15 secondary schools and almost 45,000 students, may see only a slight decline in enrollment this year, according to a spokesman.

title: Superpower Contacts: A Variety of Forums
description: American and Soviet negotiators are holding talks on arms control, regional issues and other matters, including human rights. Besides those negotiations, there are several specially convened meetings to prepare for talks scheduled in Washington on Sept. 19 and 20 between Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze. That meeting is to prepare for a possible summit conference between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader. Here is a list of the talks in progress. ARMS-PACT NEGOTIATIONS NUCLEAR AND SPACE ARMS TALKS Goal: Agreements on three separate issues - strategic long-range arms, space and defensive systems and medium-range arms. The American goal is to negotiate a treaty reducing strategic arms that does not block President Reagan's Strategic Defense Initiative, the space-oriented missile defense research program popularly known as ''Star Wars.'' The Soviet Union seeks to reduce arms and also to restrict the ''Star Wars'' program. The two sides are working on a separate treaty to limit American and Soviet medium-range arms.

title: Diane B. Burstein Wed To James H. Angel Jr.
description: The marriage of Diane Bess Burstein, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Burstein of Tenafly, N.J., to James Harvey Angel Jr., a son of Dorothy Angel of Cleveland and Mr. Angel of West Palm Beach, Fla., took place last evening at the Meadowlands Hilton in Secaucus, N.J. Rabbi Philip Berkowitz performed the ceremony.

title: TRADITONAL FRENCH CUISINE
description: OVER the past 10 years culinary bandwagons with such labels as French Nouvelle, New American, California and Natural Food have led many chefs, cooking schools and restaurants to re-evaluate and rejuvinate their thinking, a reconsideration that has resulted in a felicitous dining evolution. Free to borrow here, adapt there, contemporary practitioners of the kitchen arts reshaped classical techniques and ideas, setting great store on the personal rather than on the national, on experiment and surprise rather than on skillful conformity.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: LESSONS IN MANAGEMENT;
SOME BIG THOUGHTS IN SHORT FORM
description: In a 30-week stint writing commentaries for a now defunct cable television program for business, Russell L. Ackoff, professor emeritus of management science at the University of Pensylvania's Wharton School, developed what he calls a taste for ''trying to express an idea succinctly.'' Many of the commentaries have been collected in a book by Mr. Ackoff, ''Management in Small Doses,'' from which the following articles are excerpted. Say What?

title: Having a Baby Despite Sterility
description: CAROLE JALBERT, 39 years old and married to a policeman in Danvers, Mass., was unable to give birth because she had a hysterectomy at 21. But she has a baby anyway, with the help of her married sister.

title: CHIEF BBC OFFICIAL OF THE LAST 3 YEARS
description: Stuart Young, chairman of the British Broadcasting Corporation, died Friday in a London hospital after a long illness, the BBC said. He was 52 years old.

title: Sports of The Times; The Courage Of the Gentle
description: THE recent news that Jerry Smith has been suffering from AIDS for eight months was met with what, on the surface, might seem an unusual reaction from his former Redskins football teammates.

title: PLANNED TOWER ATOP OLD BUILDING UPSETS TRIBECA
description: Those who dwell among the 19th-century mercantile buildings in lower Manhattan see what is there: small lofts like those on White Street, some still devoted to the textile trade, others housing a newer wave of artists and their families.

title: YANKEES LOSE, 1-0, TO SWIFT'S 2-HITTER
description: The pitching matchup was hardly deserving of comparison. Tommy John had 22 seasons in the big leagues, 264 victories and the incalulable expertise that goes with both. Bill Swift was in only his second season in the majors, had won just once this season and spent nearly six weeks in the minors after a dullish start.

title: INDIANS INCLUDING NIEKRO IN PLANS FOR NEXT SEASON
description: Phil Niekro and Dan O'Brien had a brief chat in the Cleveland Indians' clubhouse one day last week. They will have a longer conversation when the Indians return from their current road trip. Niekro is one of the Indians' starting pitchers. O'Brien is the Indians' senior vice president in charge of negotiating contracts. When Niekro and O'Brien meet again, they will negotiate a contract for next season.

title: Going Home
description: To the Editor:

title: TOUGH ODDS AGAIN FOR HOUSE HOPEFUL
description: The fight seemed as lopsided as David against Goliath: a cadet against West Point and the Army brass.

title: REALTY BOOM ECHOING IN THE CLASSROOM
description: NEW YORK CITY is in the midst of a real-estate boom, and if the last few years are any indication, its classrooms and lecture halls will soon be teeming with thousands of people who want to be a part of it.

title: Sports of The Times; Carter Counting Down
description: IT was six days ago in San Diego when Bob Sikes, the assistant trainer of the Mets, was assigned to give Gary Carter a bit of rehabilitation.

title: JETS, LOOKING FOR HELP, SIGN HOLMES
description: In a move designed to strengthen their defensive secondary, the Jets today signed Jerry Holmes, the cornerback who had started for them for three years before he moved to the United States Football League.

title: BEST SELLERS: AUGUST 31, 1986
description: FICTION

title: 2 SIDES HOPEFUL AS SRI LANKA TALKS END
description: Negotiations that participants describe as the most substantive ever to take place between the Sri Lankan Government and ethnic Tamils seeking regional autonomy ended tonight with both sides hoping they can now bring Tamil guerrillas into the peace process.

title: CLEMENS IS FIRST 20-GAME WINNER
description: Roger Clemens became the major leagues' first 20-game winner this season as the Red Sox scored a 7-3 victory today over the Cleveland Indians.

title: GRANOLA OF THE MIND
description: MIDTERM REPORT The Class of '65: Chronicles of an American Generation. By David Wallechinsky. Illustrated. 418 pp. New York: Viking. $19.95.

title: FROM SOUP TO STEW, A GASTRONOME'S OASIS
description: In the culinary desert that by and large is the Arab world, Morocco is a glorious oasis. Whether you find yourself in Ifrane, a picturesque resort city nestled in the Atlas mountains, or in the narrow, twisting alleys of mysterious Marrakesh, in Casablanca, the throbbing, bustling commercial heart of the country, or in far-flung Layoun, the Saharan city on the sea, you can expect to eat well, and possibly even memorably.

title:
ART;
THREE EXHIBITIONS OF SPARE BUT REFRESHING WORK
description: THE period around the dog days of August usually spell lean times for gallery goers.

title: STAFF SHORTAGE PLAGUES STATE LIQUOR AUTHORITY
description: The New York State Liquor Authority, an agency that wields virtually total control over the sale of alcoholic beverages, has been perennially troubled by what officials call a shortage of enforcement personnel.

title: A U.S. JOURNALIST IS HELD IN MOSCOW
description: The Moscow correspondent for U.S. News & World Report was detained by the authorities today after being handed a package containing two maps marked ''top secret'' by a Soviet acquaintance.

title: Former Justice in Texas Gets 6-Year Jail Term for Bribery
description: A former justice of the Texas Supreme Court has been sentenced to six years in Federal prison for trying to bribe a banker in a drug money laundering scheme.

title: Mary Atwater Is Wed To William L. Rankin
description: Mary Elizabeth Atwater, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James D. Atwater of Columbia, Mo., was married there yesterday to William Lamar Rankin, the son of Cecile Rankin of Gastonia, N.C., and the late William Lamar Rankin Jr. The Rev. Randall Zoellner, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Newman Center of the University of Missouri in Columbia, where the bride's father is dean of the School of Journalism.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: KENYA. By John Halkin. (Beaufort, $17.95.)

title: Candidate World Citizen
description: In 1949, Garry Davis renounced his American citizenship and declared himself the ''first world citizen.'' Since then he has provided symbolic ''world passports'' to others at a fee of $20, and three years ago conducted an unopposed campaign for president of the world.

title: Playing Softball In China
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: LABOR DAY is summer's last hurrah, traditionally celebrated at a hot beach or over a hot barbecue.

title: TRENTON CONSIDERING ADDITIONAL CURBS ON TICKET SCALPING
description: TWO bills that would amend the 1983 ticket-scalping laws are expected to reach the State Senate floor this fall.

title:
DINING OUT;
SPECIALTIES FROM NORTHERN ITALY
description: ITALIAN restaurants seem to sprout up in the Garden State like so many summer zucchini; but too few of them, alas, have the taste and panache one finds in the mother country.

title: Nancy Nammack Engaged to Wed Kevin T. Curran
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Jerome W. Nammack Jr. of Garden City and Remsenburg, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Anne Nammack, to Kevin Thomas Curran, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Curran of Baldwin, L.I. The wedding is planned for Oct. 18.

title: COHALAN RESPONSE TO DRUG TEST BILL AWAITED
description: THE Suffolk County Legislature's approval last week of a measure that would prohibit mandatory drug testing of public and private employees in the county is certain to capture national interest. But the future of the bill is uncertain since it still must be approved by County Executive Peter F. Cohalan.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: DIORAMAS AT THE FAIR A highlight of this year's Country Fair given by the Scarsdale Historical Society will be a collection of 14 miniature dioramas designed and constructed for Tiffany's Christmas windows. The fair, which has been held for the last 12 years, will run from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. Saturday at the society's Cudner-Hyatt House complex, 937 White Plains Road, Scarsdale. Admission is free.

title: NEVER WISE- BUT OH, HOW SMART
description: THE FIFTIES From Notebooks and Diaries of the Period. By Edmund Wilson. Edited by Leon Edel. Illustrated. 663 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $25.

title: AD SPURS A 'BORED' GUYANESE TO BUILD CITY CONCRETE PLAN
description: Mustapha Ally had been living in semiretirement in a suburb of Washington for seven years when he saw a newspaper advertisement: New York City was looking for someone to build a concrete plant.

title: NEW ECCENTRICITY: THE WAVE
description: It had to happen sooner or later and the smart money was on it happening at the United States Open. During the second set of Boris Becker's match against Cassio Motta of Brazil on a chilly Friday night, about 20,000 fans performed the first recorded wave at a Grand Slam event. Becker and Motta watched the show, then politely applauded before resuming their match. Becker thought the whole thing was exciting.

title: THE NEGLECTED BARGAIN IN ADJUSTABLES
description: THE traditional fixed-rate mortgage is the overwhelming choice for people buying or refinancing homes, and for good reason: The composite average of 15- and 30-year conventional loans dipped to 10.11 percent last week, and some aggressive lenders dropped 30-year rates to 9.5 percent - the lowest in eight years.

title: ROUTE 1 BUS TRIAL SET
description: NJ TRANSIT is about to see if there's room to expand its Route 1 bus routes in Mercer County.

title: KELLY GETS 60 YARDS AS BILLS LOSE, 31-17
description: Walter Payton ran for two touchdowns and Jim McMahon passed for one in a second-quarter rally today, leading the Chicago Bears to a 31-17 victory over the Buffalo Bills.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: ''SO what are you going to show us, Tom?'' one of the visiting directors asked. ''A toxic waste dump? A petrochemical storage facility?''

title: FOR QADDAFI, A SEMBLANCE OF OLD FORM
description: Diplomats here say they believe that, to judge from a sudden burst of public appearances, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi seems to have shaken off the deep depression that appeared to engulf him after the American bombing raids last April.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: A PERIOD OF CONFINEMENT. By Moira Crone. (Putnam, $18.95.)

title: ON THE TRAIL OF GERTRUDE STEIN
description: You drive through picturesque and seasonally golden fields of wheat northwest of Paris, and in this small town about half an hour from the city there is an old and somewhat dilapidated stone house where two rather dowdy, spinsterish, middle-aged women are talking to each other in front of movie cameras. One, played by Linda Hunt, is a very delicate, almost porcelain Alice B. Toklas, wearing a black skirt and a silk blouse, a white sweater and gold earrings; the other, larger and more robust, dressed in a studiously drab basic brown pleated skirt, a vest and sensible sandals is the legendary author of the ''Autobiography of Alice B. Toklas,'' Gertrude Stein, being played by the British actress Linda Bassett.

title: Operaworks Series Delayed
description: The Operaworks season of chamber operas scheduled for September at Symphony Space, Broadway and 95th Street, has been postponed because of logistics problems, the company has announced. The series - a double bill of Stravinsky's ''Soldier's Tale'' and Poulenc's ''Babar, the Little Elephant,'' Lukas Foss's comic opera based on Mark Twain's ''Jumping Frog of Calaveras County,'' and ''The Martyrdom of St. Magnus,'' by Peter Maxwell Davies - will be presented in the spring. The dates will be announced when a schedule is set.

title: Dr. Susan Bassett Wed to Architect
description: Dr. Susan Bassett, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. C. Andrew L. Bassett of Bronxville, N.Y., and Robert Sander Wilson, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Dwight E. Wilson Jr. of Troy and East Greenbush, N.Y., were married yesterday. The Rev. Bonnie Jelinek, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony at the Church of Holy Spirit in Orleans, Mass.

title: COST OF PUBLIC EDUCATION TO INCREASE BY 5.2%
description: It will cost an average of $4,263 to educate each of the nearly 40 million pupils in the nation's public schools this fall, according to a Government report.

title: Wachovian Roots
description: To the Editor:

title: LEAVING LAW FOR WALL STREET
description: This summer we have been accorded two views of the legal culture by The New York Times Magazine: the life of a corporate litigator (''The Litigator,'' by Cary Reich, June 1) and lawyers who have left the practice of law to become investment bankers. The articles describe two different career paths for lawyers.

title: Q AND A Shawn G. Kennedy
description: Fees for Late Rents Question: My landlord has charged me $15 late fees for rent checks mailed on the 14th and 15th of the month. I refused to pay these fees. Then she returned a rent check and said I must pay the late fees before she would accept further rent checks. Is she within her right to charge late fees for checks mailed by the 15th of the month? . . . J. M., Brooklyn

title: GIANTS DEFEAT STEELERS
description: Joe Morris returned to action for the Giants tonight and did well enough. Ali Haji-Sheikh returned to action and did only fair. But the Giants got their usual big plays on defense, mixed in a few good pass receptions and scored a comfortable 17-3 victory over the Pittsburgh Steelers.

title: SHRIVER DEFEATS AN OLD FRIEND
description: Their relationship goes back to the days when they were both in grade school playing tennis for fun, not for profit.

title: SALISBURY FAIR FOR ANTIQUE LOVERS
description: SEPTEMBER is always a special month. It not only marks the beginning of the magnificent New England foliage season, but it also is the time when collectors, antiques dealers and museum curators gather in Salisbury for the annual outdoor antiques fair there.

title: LAKE CHAMPLAIN
description: A current slogan calls the Lake Champlain Valley ''New England's West Coast.'' In a way it is - a west coast on a 435-square-mile inland lake with a panorama of the Adirondacks of New York and the Green Mountains of Vermont facing each other across its cool, blue width. Vaguely carrot shaped, it stretches north for 120 miles to Canada and forms the boundary between Vermont and New York. Narrow and riverlike in the south, it expands to 12 miles at its widest point between Plattsburgh, N.Y., and Burlington, Vt.

title: WHEN THE TOUR PACKAGER GOES BROKE
description: Every so often, travelers are painfully reminded how damaging it can be when a major travel company suddenly goes out of business. Hundreds, sometimes thousands, of people may be stranded in distant places, with hotels refusing to accept prepaid vouchers and with airlines declining to fly them home. Thousands of others, who have paid for trips that they have not yet taken, may find that they will get nothing in return. As a result, consumers are perennially advised to check carefully the records and reputations of any companies whose offerings they are tempted to buy.

title: Bringing Some Sanity to Work-Fare
description: I cannot think of a single solitary reason why it is good for anyone to get something for nothing, especially if I am the one providing the something.

title: CARNEGIE HALL IS SUBJECT OF EXHIBITION AT -- OF ALL PLACES -- LINCOLN CENTER
description: WHEN Lincoln Center was planned in the late 1950's, Carnegie Hall was slated for demolition. Some feared that the city could not support two major concert halls, and it wasn't until the last minute that Carnegie Hall was saved from the wrecker's ball.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Orlando, Fla.;
A Faster Pace Than Expected
description: WHEN Olympia & York, the Canadian development company, began looking for expansion opportunities in Florida several years ago, it decided the Orlando area was well suited for its philosophy of steady growth. But company officials say something unexpected has happened with their first Orlando project, Olympia Place.

title: AFTER 2 YEARS, DONOVAN FRAUD TRIAL SET TO BEGIN IN THE BRONX By SELWYN RAAB
