description: The case began as a murder investigation in the Bronx. Then it grew into a fraud indictment implicating an organized-crime figure, the top executives of a major construction company, a New York state senator and a White House Cabinet officer.

title: NEW YORK PLANS HOSPITAL RULES FOR TRANSPLANTS
description: State health authorities are adopting new regulations to control an expected increase in organ transplants at New York hospitals.

title: HANDS-ACROSS-AMERICA PLEDGES UNKEPT
description: Thousands of participants in Hands Across America last May 25 have failed to fulfill pledges totaling $7 million to $8 million to fight hunger and homelessness, according to organizers of the charity drive.

title: Disgusted With South Africa
description: As President Reagan ponders whether to veto sanctions against South Africa, he'll find it hard to ignore the new violence that has brought more death to Soweto. He'll find it much harder to ignore what has happened in California. His conservative friend, Gov. George Deukmejian, now favors what he vetoed a year ago - a bill requiring the state to sell $11 billion of investment in companies doing business in South Africa.

title: EXPERTS HUNT FOR KNOWLEDGE AT AQUARIUM
description: The study of the dolphin brain is just one of several research projects at the New York Aquarium, which has combined public education, entertainment and science since its founding in 1896.

title: PENTAGON-TO-CONTRACTOR JOB SHIFT IS PROFILED
description: A survey by a Government agency has turned up evidence that many former Pentagon officials are hired by private companies to work on the same weapon projects they supervised when they worked for the Government.

title: WHEN TV LOOKS AT THE SHADOWY WORLD OF DRUG ABUSE
description: Television, as has been remarked, does not necessarily tell us what to think, although it does tell us what to think about. Accordingly, the drug problem is now on the national agenda. Television both reflects the agenda and helps shape it; the relationship is almost symbiotic. Drugs are now a legitimate preoccupation of Congress and the White House; the networks, therefore, are preoccupied, too. And yes, there is a chicken-and-egg question about television and the national agenda, although the question does not apply to all issues. Men and women who run for office, especially in an election year, may promote issues because the promotion looks good on television. At the same time, television may promote some issues itself. When it does, however, fervor and interest on the part of office-holders rise. If television is worried about an issue, political constituents must be worried. Politicians react to television; television reacts to politicians. It is one way the agenda is shaped, and it is not an entirely bad way to shape it.

title: SUMMER WEATHER AVERAGE
description: DESPITE the grumblings of some weekend vacationers who can never get enough sun, meteorologists say, this summer has been pretty average in temperatures and the ratio of sunny to cloudy and rainy days.

title: QUILTS PAY GLORIOUS HOMAGE TO OLD GLORY
description: Quilt makers have traditionally been flag-wavers.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM KILTS TO WHITE TIE
description: Mozart's 'Cosi Fan Tutte' A Drottningholm Court Theater production, conducted by Arnold Ostman; directed by Willy Decker, 1984 Thorn EMI/HBO Video 141 minutes. $39.95.

title: FINANCES BESET CAMP FOR HANDICAPPED
description: SPIRITS ran high as Camp Oakhurst, for physically handicapped children and adults, celebrated its 80th anniversary recently, but an undercurrent of anxiety over money problems tempered the good feelings.

title: CRIME
description: A first novel, ONE OF US IS WRONG (Tor/St. Martin's, $14.95) moves confidently along, is written with style, deftly impresses its characterizations and presents a macho hero who is not lacking in sensitivity. Only a rather conventional ending, with some unbelievable heroics, strikes a somewhat false note, but even this is palatable because we have come to believe in the hero.

title: HALF A POOL IS BETTER THAN ONE
description: ''IT'S hot! Why not come over to swim in our half-pool?''

title: A CONGRESSIONAL REPLAY SPLITS THE POWER BROKERS
description: THE Sixth Congressional District in southern Queens, where Mario Cuomo grew up, has since changed ethnically if not economically - it remains a community of middle-income home-owners - and now it is changing politically, too.

title: FOR WALKER, A NEW LEAGUE AND OLD QUESTIONS
description: HERSCHEL WALKER seemed out of place in the cramped quarters of his box-shaped hotel room. At the very least, the room was a far cry from Walker's spacious condominium in New Jersey, with its breathtaking view of evergreens and rolling hills. All this room offered was a double bed with marmalade-colored spreads, a phone with a footlong cord and a view of Interstate 695.

title: IN THE HILLS OR BY THE OCEAN, WRITERS ARE CLINGING TO SUMMER'S INSPIRATION
description: ''You just go up-island and get lost,'' said Neal Kissel, a 19-year-old taxi driver and would-be writer, when asked where Martha's Vineyard's famous literati live. ''Walk up any road into the woods. They're behind the trees.''

title: Susan Klugman Engaged To Wed David Gorobetz
description: The engagement of Susan Debra Klugman, a third-year medical student at New York University, and David S. Gorobetz, a lawyer, has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Arnold I. Klugman of New Rochelle, N.Y. Mr. Gorobetz is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Raynard Gorobetz, also of New Rochelle.

title: Enter the Cab of Tomorrow, Buckle Up and Smile at the Camera
description: To the Editor:

title: Foreman in Comeback
description: George Foreman, the former heavyweight champion, who has been in retirement since 1977, says he is back in training and planning to resume his boxing career in November. Foreman, 37 years old, told the Los Angeles Times he was running six miles a day and sparring at his Marshall, Tex., ranch under the guidance of his trainer, Charley Snipes.

title: A GATHERING OF FRIENDS AT THE START OF A LONELY VOYAGE
description: WE sit huddled around her like a loving honor guard, trying to pierce the pain of her loss. We ply her with coffee and tiny sweet cakes carried in by neighbors who soundlessly serve and clean up.

title: Recent Sales
description: Bound Brook $85,000 318 East Street 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 50-year-old duplex; remodeled kitchen, study; taxes $1,142. Franklin Lakes $214,500 912 Hilltop Terrace 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 35-year-old ranch; recreation room, brick fireplace; taxes $1,659.

title: Turkel Case
description: To the Editor:

title: POSTINGS: In Southampton; Room To Grow
description: Carl Froebel, president of the National Investor Data Service, started his company in 1979 in Southampton, L.I., with one employee. The company, a software developer for the financial investment industry, has since grown to 45 employees.

title: 10 PLAYS TO OPEN EAST COAST ARTS CENTER
description: THE long-awaited, much publicized and greatly delayed premiere of New Rochelle's East Coast Arts Center will take place in mid-October. And as if to prove it was worth the wait, the center, three years in the works, will open with a plethora of new plays - 10 by actual count, and all at once.

title: Beth Ellen Blau Is Wed To Joshua Heydemann
description: The marriage of Beth Ellen Blau, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Blau of Oceanside, L.I., and Joshua Werman Heydemann, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerry Heydemann of Evanston, Ill., took place last evening at the Hewlett-East Rockaway (L.I.) Jewish Center. Rabbi Stanley Platek performed the ceremony.

title: Jodie Wisniewski Wed in Michigan
description: Jodie Louise Wisniewski of the Graham & James law firm and Robert Emmett King Jr., of the Rogers & Wells law firm, both in New York, were married yesterday in Bloomfield Hills, Mich. The Rev. James F. Anderson performed the ceremony at the Presbyterian Kirk in the Hills.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Wau is at the end of its rope. Wau is being strangled to death, and there are no ways of bringing in the food that would enable the city to survive.''

title: NO MORE ZERO-SUM GAME
description: THERE ARE A bunch of us black men between the ages of 39 and 45 who share the bond of being in the first generation that took full advantage of the civil rights laws of 1963-65. Few of us felt genuinely comfortable with that new privilege, because, from birth, we were conditioned to feel that life would be a zero-sum game.

title: GROWING ROSES AS BIG BUISNESS
description: ''A ROSE by any other name'' may smell as sweet to Juliet's family, but for the Pierson family in Connecticut, the only roses that count bear their own name.

title: FOR JAPAN'S OPPOSITION, THE ISOLATION DEEPENS
description: Japan's fractured and long-suffering political opposition has been deprived of true power for so many years that it had seemed their situation could not grow more desperate.

title: ANOTHER WORLD BREAKS THROUGH
description: THE BEET QUEEN By Louise Erdich. 338 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $16.95.

title: BILLBOARDS MAKE CITY A GALLERY
description: ''I'VE seen it up,'' said the artist Elizabeth Bilinski. ''It's got graffiti on it already.'' She was speaking of her own work, and she sounded very pleased.

title: SCHOOL PRIZES: ADDITIONAL VIEWS
description: Re: ''School Prizes: Wrong Emphasis?'' Opinion Page, Aug. 10: Awards can spur pupils to try harder, but they have become a business and their proliferation must be monitored. After finding honor certificates crushed in desks and seeing sports trophies gathering dust, I changed my criteria for awards.

title: Primary Embarrassment in New York
description: New York's election law, as interpreted by its highest court, gives politicians plenty of ammunition for ballot warfare, and it broke out with a vengeance in this fall's Democratic primary campaign. As the dust settles with only a week to go, Abraham Hirschfeld, a candidate for lieutenant governor, is off the ballot. So are scores of able local candidates. And the state stands embarrassed for permitting such an affront to democracy.

title: DANCE AND DRAMA AS TRAINING FOR LIFE
description: THIS city does not have to look beyond Ellison Street for a powerful symbol of cultural and community regeneration. The Inner City Ensemble Theater and Dance Company, a school and performing company for teen-agers, is an example of how one person's vision can transform individual lives and enrich a community.

title: CLUTTERED ATTICS HOLD BITS OF HISTORY FOR MUSEUM DEDICATED TO BROOKLYN
description: Out of dusty attics, dank basements and cluttered closets, Brooklynites are spinning the web of their history.

title: PLAN WOULD SHIFT MORE DRUG CASES TO U.S. COURTS
description: Law-enforcement officials are working on a plan to relieve the crush of narcotics cases on the state court system in New York City by expanding the role of the Federal courts in the prosecution of such cases.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
FROM AUSTRALIA AND SWITZERLAND
description: Although the United States Treasury will introduce its new gold and silver bullion coins in just a few weeks, foreign governments are entering the U.S. marketplace with their new bullion pieces. Among the most intriguing are those from Switzerland and Australia. Switzerland has unveiled four pure gold ''Helvetias'' plus a pure silver 5-ounce bullion piece. Australia has come out with four gold pieces known as ''Nuggets.''

title: Formative Component?
description: To the Editor:

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL METS VS. LOS ANGELES DODGERS, at Shea Stadium, 1:30 P.M. (Television -SportsChannel, 1:30 P.M. and 7:45 P.M. taped; Radio - WHN 1050, 1:30).

title: MARCOS STILL MANAGES TO CAST A SHADOW
description: NOTHING much happened in Manila last week while President Corazon C. Aquino was away in Indonesia and Singapore. That was in itself an event, in view of widespread worries about a coup attempt or other trickery by supporters of the former President, Ferdinand E. Marcos. Jolted by unsettling incidents and rumors, the Philippines has become something of a nation of worriers.

title: STOCKHOLM EAST-WEST PACT CALLED NEAR
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that recent concessions by the Soviet Union and the United States had significantly improved the chance for an East-West agreement in coming weeks on guidelines to avoid an accidental war in Europe.

title: ORGANIZATION SAILORS
description: THE UNITED STATES NAVY 200 Years. By Edward L. Beach. Illustrated. 564 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $24.95.

title: DEREGULATION CAN AMOUNT TO HEAVY WEATHER
description: SOME said the events of the week proved that deregulation had come full circle and that Government should get involved in the airline industry again. Others said that the White House was trying to convince the business community that its relaxed antitrust policies had limits.

title: CAUSE, EFFECT AND DEATH IN CAMEROON
description: THE shores of Lake Nios in Cameroon are blanketed with lush vegetation nourished by rich volcanic soil, and the prime grazing land surrounding the isolated mountain lake has made it a modest population center.

title: POLICE-SAY MAN USED TRANSIT AUTHORITY ID TO ROB TOKEN CLERKS
description: A Bronx man, using identification he had stolen from a Transit Authority supervisor, gained entrance to six subway token booths in the past two weeks and robbed the attendants, a transit police spokesman said.

title: WELCOME TO TOMORROW: SETTLING IN THE U.S.
description: BEING told that immigration is not easy is rather like being told death is final. No one wants to believe it, and once it has happened it is too late to ask for explanations.

title: A PAUPER'S LEGACY: SMILE FOR EVERYONE AND $327,504.61
description: For years Julius C. Silverman walked the city's main street in his baggy clothes, chatting with merchants and passers-by, running small errands for a few dollars, feeding pigeons and eating the ice cream bars he loved. A storehouse of gossip, he made daily trips to the local newspaper, giving tips to reporters and editors.

title: Humana's Uncertain Prognosis
description: The stock of Humana Inc., the hospital management company that once dazzled institutional investors, has sagged from its 1985 peak of $36.25 a share to less than $23 this week. An earnings recovery that many analysts had predicted for this year has not materialized, and the question now is whether earnings will rebound at all.

title: PRIEST TO APPEAL VATICAN MOVE TO DISMISS HIM
description: The Rev. Charles Curran, saying that he would be a Catholic theologian ''no matter what happens,'' said today that he was formally appealing the Vatican's attempt to dismiss him from the faculty at Catholic University.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: THEY'RE not the biggest nuisance in the world but, unlike other nuisances, they're a constant. Day in and day out, they're with us. If they're not, we're in serious trouble because it means they're lost, which is not quite a disaster but almost, or they've been mislaid or forgotten, which means we're locked out of such essential places as home, office, car or safe-deposit box.

title: 8 Marines Die as Copter Crashes Off Norway
description: United States military officials said today that eight marines were killed when a CH-46 Sea Knight helicopter taking part in NATO exercises crashed into the Atlantic Ocean off Norway.

title: TRAVELS WITH TIFFANY
description: THE EVENING TWILIGHT CASTS A glow over the crisp white tablecloth in Elsa Peretti's rooftop dining room in Rome. Here, the table has been set to perfection with many of the designer's own wares. Her large ceramic soup tureen is filled with pasta e fagioli, an Italian soup of beans and pasta. The menu following this first course calls for a bowl of barely steamed spinach, seasoned with olive oil and lemon juice, and roast shank of veal.

title: OFFICIALS CITE 43 FOOD OUTLETS
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 43 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: INVESTORS LOSING FERVOR FOR CONDOS
description: ONE of Fairfield County's most popular investment opportunities and topics of cocktail party conversation - buying a condominium and turning it over at a handsome profit - is about to lose its luster as a result of the sweeping changes being made in the tax code.

title: 'LOTTO FEVER' HOT IN MASSACHUSETTS
description: In a state where it seems more people can tell you the winning Megabucks numbers than the day of the week, a recent survey showing that Massachusetts has the highest rate of lottery spending by a long shot came as no shock.

title: SEAT-BELT USAGE UP ON STATE'S ROADS
description: MOST Connecticut motorists are buckling up and more of them are walking away from accidents uninjured as a result of the state's eight-month-old seat-belt law, police officials say.

title: REALTOR JOINS DRIVE FOR WILDLIFE AREA
description: IN an unusual partnership, a wildlife group has teamed up with a Connecticut real-estate concern to turn eight acres of prime shoreline property into a conservation area.

title: Noel A. Chandonnet Jr. To Marry Sarah Sears
description: The engagement of Sarah Patricia Sears to Noel Andrew Chandonnet Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Chandonnet of Potomac, Md., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. F. Gerard Sears of Port Washington, L.I., parents of the bride-to-be. The wedding is planned for Oct. 25.

title: Conversions Spreading Into New Neighborhoods
description: A FEW years ago, the 12-story Britannia apartment complex, which stands at the corner of Central Park West and 102d Street in a long-neglected area of Manhattan, would have seemed an unlikely choice for a proposal to convert rental apartments into owner-occupied residences.

title: A Tale of Two Fish
description: The biggest fish story of the summer that unofficially ends this weekend was the one about the 3,450-pound great white shark that didn't get away from Captains Donnie Braddick and Frank Mundus, 25 miles south of Montauk Point in the Atlantic Ocean.

title: TODAY'S HORROR FILMS VS. YESTERYEAR'S
description: To the Editor: I was extremely irritated by Walter Goodman's article ''Within Us All Lurks the Secret of Classic Horror'' [ Aug. 3 ] . This kind of ''everything-was-better-in-the-old -days'' criticism makes the modern storyteller want to beat his or her head against the wall.

title: 26 in Philadelphia Sentenced To Jail in an Abortion Protest
description: More than two dozen anti-abortion activists were sentenced to jail Thursday for staging a sit-in for two and a half hours at a busy clinic.

title: THE DIFFERENT BEATS ALONG DIFFERENT STREETS
description: THE bad news for campaigning politicians and other parade lovers is that the Labor Day Parade - which has been with New Yorkers off and on since 1882 - has been canceled this year. Thomas Van Arsdale, the new head of the New York City Central Labor Council, decided not to ask union members to show the flag ''on a holiday they could spend at the beach.''

title: Lutheran Groups Vote to Forget Their Differences
description: Three Lutheran denominations joined last week, having decided, like several other divided Protestant groups before them, that they had been kept apart more for historical than doctrinal reasons. The three denominations, meeting in different cities, voted with only a few dissenters to form a church called the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America.

title: A HOME AWAY FROM HITLER
description: NEW SCHOOL A History of the New School for Social Research. By Peter M. Rutkoff and William B. Scott. Illustrated. 314 pp. New York: The Free Press. $22.50.

title: IN ARKANSAS, OLD FERRIES SAIL ON TROUBLED WATERS
description: Several times each week, H. T. Williams will ease his car aboard the Spring Bank ferry and wait grimly while it pulls loose from the mud and makes for the opposite bank of the Red River, a few hundred yards away.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Lexington, Ky.; 'Farm Town's' Finance Tower
description: IN 1948, Life magazine described this community as ''an agrarian city, and content to be so.''

title: Karen Silpe, a Lawyer, Wed to S. H. Millstone
description: At Temple Emanuel in Great Neck, L.I., last night Karen Jeanne Silpe, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Silpe of Jericho, L.I., was married to Samuel Herman Millstone, a son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Max Millstone of Mount Washington, Md. Rabbi Philip J. Bentley performed the ceremony.

title: MOISEYEV'S DANCERS EDGE CLOSER TO BALLET
description: At times, Igor Moiseyev talks like the rebel he was in 1925, when he and other young dancers of the Bolshoi Ballet spoke out against the stern classical rules that defined and confined Russian dance. Now 81 and revered in his homeland as a national icon, the man who made folk dance an art is still fighting his old battle with ballet.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Tucson, Ariz.;
Hughes Land Idle No More
description: LIKE everything else about him, the real-estate dealings of Howard Hughes were shrouded in mystery. So residents were not notably surprised when he quietly bought 20,000 acres of undeveloped desert near here in 1951 and let most of it sit idle, even refusing easements for utilities, roads or schools.

title: Jeanne Gromer to Marry Thomas A. Smith in Fall
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Gromer Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Jeanne Katharin Gromer to Thomas Anthony Smith, a son of Judge and Mrs. Walter E. Smith of Boise, Idaho. An October wedding is planned.

title: Steven Lindauer Weds Miss Kelly
description: Katharine Houghton Kelly, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Kelly Jr. of Dallas and Greensboro, Vt., was married yesterday to Steven Paul Lindauer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John William Lindauer of Denver. The Rev. Jerold D. Shelter performed the ceremony at the Preston Hollow Presbyterian Church in Dallas.

title: A Tool Box for On-Screen Tutorials
description: ONE of the most difficult questions facing any trailblazing software package is the one put to it by the potential user, namely, ''What do I do with it?'' I myself have on a number of occasions fallen into the trap of not looking at a program because I couldn't instantly figure out what it was for. The most recent occurrence of this quandary for me was with Dan Bricklin's Demo Program ($74.95 for the I.B.M. PC and compatibles from Software Garden Inc., West Newton, Mass., 02165, (617) 332-2240).

title: TWO SCHOOLS OF THOUGHT ON LIBYA
description: AFTER staying out of sight most of the time since the United States bombed Libya in April, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi began to reappear in public again last week, playing host to visiting leaders and appearing at a rally in Tripoli.

title: STRIKING NURSES CITED FOR CONTEMPT IN BOSTON
description: A judge cited a nurses' union for contempt today for defying his order barring a 48-hour strike against three city-owned hospitals.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: RAMPAGE. By Justin Scott. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.)

title: STUDY SAYS 5% OF YOUNG ADULTS ARE ILLITERATE
description: An unreleased Federal study shows that 5 percent of America's young adults are illiterate and 20 percent are semiliterate, even though 98 percent completed the eighth grade.

title: Schorr-CBS Links
description: Daniel Schorr, the radio commentator, has an office at the downtown Washington headquarters of National Public Radio, which is across the street from the Washington bureau of CBS News, an organization that employed Mr. Schorr for many years. Despite the proximity, however, Mr. Schorr never stopped in at his old haunt after he left CBS with some acrimony in 1976 when he got into a dispute with a Congressional committee over his release of secret findings of an intelligence investigation.

title: Robin Crawford Weds Andrew Heller
description: Robin Vicki Crawford, the daughter of Mrs. Frank A. Crawford of Glastonbury, Conn., and the late Mr. Crawford, was married yesterday to Andrew Mark Heller, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Preston B. Heller Jr. of Chagrin Falls, Ohio. The Rev. Joseph Infantini performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Abbey Chapel of Mount Holyoke College in South Hadley, Mass.

title: CREATIVITY IN DESIGN OF NEW ISSUES
description: The United States Trust Territories have been feeding collectors a steady diet of interesting stamps. The emerging nations of the Marshall Islands and Palau have used a blend of imaginative themes, skilled artists and liberal issuing policies to create a philatelic stature well beyond their tiny geographic size.

title: WESTCHESTER KENNEL CLUB TO HOLD SHOW AT LYNDHURST
description: EIGHTY-ONE years ago, the Westchester Kennel Club held its first show. The event, in White Plains, attracted 330 dogs and lasted four days. Next Sunday, this most prestigious of outdoor Eastern dog shows takes place at Lyndhurst, the national landmark in Tarrytown.

title: AS LAKES CHANGE, A DEBATE GROWS
description: EARLIER this month a state wildlife agent shot seven snapping turtles in Yorktown's Sparkle Lake. Thereafter, a turtle scare gripped the town and the shores of the lake were mostly empty for several weeks, although it was pointed out that there was no record of a turtle ever injuring a swimmer.

title: Good Numbers
description: The bad numbers are still way too high - 717 alcohol-related highway fatalities in New York State alone last year. But the good numbers of lives saved are also rising.

title:
IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN;
IRVINGTON
description: ON the surface, Irvington, N. J., seems to be a withering urban community. But beyond the old, decaying buildings and the vacant lots overgrown with weeds is a township poised on the brink of change.

title: AIDES SAY REAGAN PLANS TO RELAX ARMS-TALK STANDS
description: The Administration intends to modify its strategic arms negotiating position to narrow some differences with the Soviet Union, according to a wide range of American officials.

title: Sandra Podesta Is a Bride in Rye
description: Sandra Lynn Podesta, a daughter of Aldo C. Podesta of Rye, N.Y., and the late Carol Conant Podesta, was married yesterday to Jeffrey Damon MacDougall, a son of Mr. and Mrs. K. Blair MacDougall of Moorestown, N.J. The Rev. Paul E. Hoffman performed the Lutheran ceremony at the Apawamis Club in Rye.

title: RESIDENTS AT PRIVATE LAKE ASSESS NEEDS
description: WHEN Emil Scordato of Eastchester hastily assumed the presidency of the Lake Isle Home Owners Association, after the death of the previous president, he was given boxes of loose papers pertaining to Lake Innisfree, the private lake on which he lived.

title: 007's Last Minutes
description: All must have seemed normal aboard the aircraft. Ninety minutes after takeoff and about 700 miles from Anchorage, Korean Air routine called for the stewardesses to change into their native dress. Snacks and orange juice and sandwiches were served to tourist passengers (those in first class were provided with more elegant fare), and then it would be time once again for another in-flight movie. In another 90 minutes, with cabin lights turned off and window shades down, Flight 007 flew into the range of Soviet radar; 30 minutes later it penetrated Soviet airspace.

title: AQUINO INSPIRES ARTISTIC RENAISSANCE
description: History is quickly becoming art in the Philippines, where the unexpected rush of events in February is being distilled by painters, writers and playwrights.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article in the World section last Sunday misstated the conclusion of a National Security Council document.

title: THE MILITARY'S MORE MODEST MEANS
description: AS they meet behind closed doors in the annual August ritual that will lead to the presentation this winter of another budget request, military leaders are coming to grips with an era in which few expect more than nominal growth in military spending.

title: The Governors' Show of Interest
description: The nation's governors would raise teachers' pay, give administrators more flexibility, expand early-childhood education and allow students and parents a wider choice of schools. At the same time, they said in a report that dominated their annual convention last week, they would take greater control of the public schools.

title: Ms. Leeds and Christopher HarlandCorporate Finance Specialists, to Wed
description: Ashley Leeds, an associate in corporate finance at Shearson Lehman Brothers, and Christopher M. Harland, an associate in the corporate finance department at Morgan Stanley & Company, both in New York, plan to be married Sept. 28.

title: A SMALL VERMONT RESORT FEARS BIG-CITY GRIDLOCK
description: This picture postcard community in southwestern Vermont, whose townspeople treasure autonomy, is under pressure these days.

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT;
AT SEA WITH SLAMMIN' SAM, FISHERMAN
description: WHILE the morning sun tried to punch an early path through the dense shroud of Oregonian fog, golf's greatest living legend, Sam Snead, gave his fishing pole a sudden hard jerk backward as though instinctively sensing a salmon were about to strike his deep-sea lure trailing astern.

title: Maryland Anticipates a Historic Senate Race
description: The first time one woman ran against another for the United States Senate was 26 years ago in a race that was described at one point as ''a powderpuff derby.''

title: Roman Retains Title In Draw With Laciar
description: Gilberto Roman of Mexico retained his World Boxing Council super-flyweight title tonight in a 12-round draw against Santos Laciar of Argentina.

title: NOAH UPSET BY WILKISON
description: No one among the fans at the Stadium Court expected him to ride in on horseback, the new American tennis hero. For one thing, Tim Wilkison just does not look the part, dressed in a rumpled vest and a baseball cap that he says he wears like blinders, helping him to focus on the task at hand. His game has been improving, but still, Wilkison's name has never come up during discussions about John McEnroe's successor as the best this country has to offer.

title: FOR THE BAKER, RIPE, FRESH FRUIT COMES TO THE FORE
description: JUST as summer's vegetable crop inspires the salad maker, the fruits suit the baker. Fresh ripe peaches, plums, nectarines and berries become tarts, cakes, quickbreads, pies and pancakes. These are seasonal delights that can be enjoyed for at least another month.

title: SOME OUNCES OF PREVENTION THAT LOWER HEART RISK
description: WHATEVER Americans are doing to reduce cholesterol and fat consumption, the American Heart Association thinks it is not enough.

title: Child Abuse Measure Signed
description: A bill that earmarks $10 million for states to improve programs to prevent child abuse and to prosecute offenders has been signed into law by President Reagan, Representative Joseph J. DioGuardi, a Westchester Republican who co-sponsored the bill, said Friday.

title: JURISDICTIONAL DISPUTE DEVELOPS OVER HUNTS' BANKRUPTCY PETITIONS
description: An attempt by the wealthy Hunt brothers to have bankruptcy proceedings for their Placid Oil Company administered in the Federal Bankruptcy Court in New Orleans has been challenged by a Federal district judge in Dallas.

title:
IN NEW JERSEY;
Condos Ready to Rise Over Maplewood
description: THE western border of Maplewood runs up the side of South Mountain, one of the tallest in the state at 598 feet. On a site just below its crest, a local developer plans to build Maplewood Tower, a 10-story condominium that will take advantage of the natural surroundings and an unbroken view of the Manhattan skyline.

title:
INVESTING;
Promise and Pitfalls of Closed-End Funds
description: NOT since the Roaring 20's have so many closed-end mutual funds been offered to the public. In recent weeks, Martin Zweig, Mario Gabelli, David K. Schafer, and other investment managers have registered shares for proposed closed-end stock funds. Indeed, one fund that Merrill Lynch will offer in October - the All-Star Equity Fund - is to be managed by five different investment management firms.

title:
GARDENING;
MATURITY THE KEY IN HARVESTING POPCORN
description: ABOUT this time of year, it is certain that someone who has planted popcorn for the first time will wonder what to do with it. After all, sweet corn is being harvested, so why not popcorn?

title: A Bargain Price and a Personal Touch
description: DATING services do not stop at advertising in their pursuit of new names for their files. Some offer complimentary memberships; others even guarantee a certain number of dates.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: PRIDE IN WATERLOO Charley Pride, who had to settle for being a singing sensation when he fizzled in baseball, will be at Waterloo Village Saturday evening for one performance only.

title:
CABLE TV NOTES;
MTV AIMS TO IMPROVE AWARDS SHOW
description: ''This is our Super Bowl,''

title: IN LITCHFIELD, NO CHANGES AND NO PIPELINE
description: IN this distant northwestern corner of Connecticut, most people envy my address. Taconic cannot be found on many road maps and I have no street address. I live off a dirt road that has no name. Very hard to find.

title: EARLY BASIE RECORDINGS ARE REISSUED IN A NEW SERIES
description: The Count Basie band that came bursting out of Kansas City in 1936 was a definition-in-action of swing. Originally it was a group of nine that played for floor shows and dancing in Kansas City's Reno Club, built around a rhythm section that has never been equaled and the contrast between two very dissimilar tenor saxophonists, Lester Young and Herschel Evans. The musicians were all experienced in the art of setting up spontaneous horn riffs behind a blues singer or a soloist, and during its Kansas City days the band's entire ''book'' of arrangements was said to fit inside one small suitcase.

title: ELECTION '86: UNCERTAINTY ON ISSUES CLOUDS RACES
description: The 1986 election campaign, the last of the Reagan era, is developing into a contest with few nationwide themes and with both parties agreeing on two central propositions: President Reagan is enormously popular, and his economic policies are very unpopular in parts of the country suffering from hard times.

title: Alison A. Keating To Become Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. James W. Keating of Wellesley Hills, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Alison Anne Keating to Robert Gustaf Hedlund 3d, a son of Caroline Lamb of Berkeley, Calif., and Mr. Hedlund Jr. of Chicago. A December wedding is planned.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error in a brief review of Adrian Forsyth's ''Natural History of Sex'' July 13, the author of ''Men in Groups'' was listed incorrectly. The author is Lionel Tiger.

title: A MONTH FOR SELF-HELP
description: TO make people aware of the wide range of support groups open to them in the state, September has been declared Self-Help/Mutual Support Month in Connecticut.

title: STATE ADDING A TOOL FOR 8TH GRADE MATH
description: WHEN the state's 35,000 public school eighth-graders return to their classrooms this week, each will receive a pocket-sized calculator in addition to the usual stack of textbooks.

title: MOTOR BANGS, STOMACH CHURNS
description: WHAT a beautiful day! The sun is shining, the gentle zephyrs wisk about and Mother Nature is in her glory. What a day for a drive in the country.

title: BUSHNELL TO FEATURE CYCLE OF ORCHESTRAS
description: MOST seasonal openings in Connecticut are a month or more away, but two major ones are in the more immediate offing: the Bushnell Hall inaugural concert is on Saturday and the curtain rises at the reorganized Connecticut Grand Opera a week later.

title: CORRECTION
description: A listing that accompanied an article about Roncevalles (Travel, June 15) gave an incorrect location for a hotel.

title: TIME TRAVELING IN MOROCCO
description: It is only across a narrow strait from Spain, but it feels as remote as a place in the ''Thousand and One Nights.'' Its medieval cities survive, intact, unchanged and quite as lively as ever, but in the course of a 50-year French protectorate its people learned a second language so that someone unfamiliar with Arabic can still manage. It is one of the oldest kingdoms in the world and remains, despite its constitution, a well-nigh absolute monarchy. But even those ancient customs seem young compared to the span of the country's history: Morocco, today, offers a fascinating blend of cultures placed in a variety of beautiful landscapes.

title: PARK IS CARVED FROM SOUTH BRONX LOT
description: For 12 students from Brown University, summer vacation began in a garbage-strewn vacant lot in the South Bronx. By vacation's end, they and more than 25 residents of the neighborhood had transformed the lot into a park.

title: Wedding in Fall For Sarah Nutt
description: Sarah Hovey Nutt, who is with the CBS Television Network in New York as director, market analysis, and Thomas M. Van Leeuwen, a vice president in the equity research department at E. F. Hutton & Company in New York, plan to be married Oct. 25.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
GOOD CAUSES
description: The fall social season is beginning with two gala events. Marvin Hamlisch will perform at the Fantasy Ball, the annual benefit of the American Cancer Society, Westchester Division, on Saturday at 8 P.M. at the Performing Arts Center of the State University of New York in Purchase. The internationally known composer, pianist and entertainer will play his hits from such shows as ''The Way We Were,'' ''A Chorus Line'' and ''The Sting,'' and he will introduce a ballad from his coming Broadway musical ''Smile.''

title: John Kennedy Brown To Wed Wendy Buck
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles Austin Buck of Bernardsville, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Wendy Elizabeth Buck to John Kennedy Brown, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James Crosby Brown Jr. of Blue Hill, Me. A January wedding is planned.

title: A BALLET HIT OF DECADES PAST LIVES AGAIN ON FILM
description: Ballet fans can be singleminded in their devotion to the art they love. Thus many balletomanes attend every performance by their favorite companies and regularly send notes and flowers to their favorite dancers. A few carry balletomania to even greater extremes. One such balletomane is Victor Jessen, a Danish-born engineer who moved to Los Angeles in 1929. What makes his obsession with ballet remarkable is the fact that he has been able to preserve moments from dance history: since the 1930's he has surreptitiously filmed all or parts of more than 30 dance productions and he has donated the resultant 80,000 feet of film to the Dance Collection of the New York Public Library.

title: DEMOCRATS FOCUS ON SEAT LOST IN '84
description: Two years ago, in a defeat that still rankles Westchester Democrats, the 20th Congressional District seat long held by Richard L. Ottinger, who was retiring, went to Joseph J. DioGuardi, a Republican running for the first time.

title: TENANT PROTECTION SOUGHT IN SUFFOLK
description: WHEN tenants of the Birchwood-on-the-Green apartment complex in Oakdale received a thick legal document in the mail last Thanksgiving, many of them panicked.

title: LE NOUVEAU TRAVELOGUE
description: THE SPIRIT OF MEDITERRANEAN PLACES By Michel Butor. Translated by Lydia Davis. 147 pp. Marlboro, Vt.: The Marlboro Press. $15.95.

title: 2 Transit Officers Stabbed
description: A transit police officer was stabbed in the arm Friday night while issuing a summons to a man for smoking on a subway in Queens, and another officer who came to her aid was also slashed by the suspect, the transit police said.

title: Television
description: Summer may be waning but not those undimmed film bargains on the homescreen, both on cable and broadcast. Agatha Christie fans should catch a showing of the exotic baffler, ''Death on the Nile'' (1978), with a typically cunning plot and fine cast headed by Peter Ustinov, as sleuth Hercule Poirot, Mia Farrow, Maggie Smith, Bette Davis and David Niven. There's also a tingling musical score just to keep the suspense percolating - Monday at 8 P.M. on ABC. The best ''Show Boat'' (1936), the Irene Dunne-Allan Jones version, docks on Sunday - 8 P.M. on Channel 21. ''The Man in the Gray Flannel Suit'' (1956), an intelligent drama about a disillusioned Manhattan commuter, with Gregory Peck, Jennifer Jones and Fredric March, makes a rare, if late appearance - Friday at 2 A.M. on Channel 5. There is the engrossing ballet-world story, ''The Turning Point'' (1977), with Anne Bancroft and Shirley MacLaine - Monday at 12:30 P.M. on Channel 11 -and the entertaining ''Executive Suite'' (1954), a power-play tale with William Holden, Fredric March, Barbara Stanwyck, June Allyson, Paul Douglas, Louis Calhern and Shelley Winters - Sunday at 3 P.M. on Channel 9. And don't overlook the beautifully restrained sideline cameo by Nina Foch, as a wise secretary.

title: Third-World Officials Urge Curbs on Pretoria
description: Foreign ministers of the movement of nations professing nonalignment called today on the organization to adopt a stiff package of wide-ranging economic sanctions against South Africa.

title: BROTHER ANSELM, IN A FAMILY WAY
description: I SEE A LONG JOURNEY Three Novellas. By Rachel Ingalls. 141 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $14.95.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Little Creek, Del.,Fights to Survive

title: TAMORI: JAPANESE TELEVISION'S UBIQUITOUS STAR OF THE HOUR
description: In Japan, where surprise can be an unwelcome commodity, the virtue of predictability is celebrated on television four times a week on three different networks by the seemingly inescapable sight of Tamori, the funny man in the dark glasses.

title: RELIC OF AN 1898 CRIME GOES HOME TO VIENNA
description: For 87 years after the asassination of Empress Elizabeth of Austria here, Geneva's city morgue housed a macabre, and all but forgotten, relic of that sensational crime in the 1890's.

title: Family Matters
description: A recent report from the Federal Bureau of Justice Statistics gives welcome evidence that there's something more sensible to do about domestic violence than suffer in silence: call the cops.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: THE courtyard of a suburban co-op isn't exactly a soccer field, but for a group of eager, leggy boys with a ball, it's sometimes an O.K. substitute. Dusk had given way to deep-blue night, and a firefly glimmered here and there, when the youths tumbled from the patio of the apartment onto the nearby grass.

title: KABUKI AND NOH FLAVOR A 'MEDEA' IN CENTRAL PARK
description: It has bonfires and a Greek chorus bearing Japanese stringed instruments. It has a star dressed in a glittering headdress and a multicolored 44-pound robe made in part from the backs of 50 antique-silk sashes, and it ends with that star flying with a howl up into the sky. It is described by its producer as ''a Japanese production of a Greek tragedy with a New York accent.'' It is the Toho Company's staging of ''Medea.''

title: Calling In the Credit Counselors
description: MOST of us have lived through a cash crisis where ''there is too much month left at the end of the money,'' as the saying goes. Usually the crunch is short-lived - but for some, red ink becomes a way of life.

title: POSITIONAL SACRIFICES -- RARE BUT WELL-DONE
description: Sacrifices for positional advantage are rarer than they might be because they require the postponement of satisfaction for a considerable number of moves. Yet this very limitation is also the source of their force: The defender, seeing the booty close at hand and the detriment far away or nebulous, is lured to capturing what he shouldn't.

title: FOCUSING ON THE MUSIC OF 'VIENNA 1900'
description: The visual arts of fin-de-siecle Vienna are enjoying an unprecedented popularity today. The Museum of Modern Art's ''Vienna 1900: Art, Architecture and Design,'' which runs through Oct. 21, is only the latest in a prestigious series of similar exhibitions throughout the Western world, most notably in Paris and Vienna itself.

title: HIGH SCHOOL BY THE CREDIT RATHER THAN THE CALENDAR
description: IT is a proposal aimed at those who drop out, and useful for those who excel: Frank L. Smith Jr., the recently arrived head of New York City's high schools, is examining the possibility of abolishing the distinctions between grades 9 through 12 and simply requiring a specific number of credits for graduation.

title: To Sell The House Or Keep It?
description: WHEN a homeowner is transferred to another city, whether indefinitely or for a limited period, he usually faces the choice of keeping his residence and renting it out or selling and buying something in the new location.

title: COMPOSER TRACES ROOTS IN JEWISH MUSIC
description: ''DO you remember the original 'Jazz Singer' film with Al Jolson?'' David Amram asked recently.

title: Emptying Trash
description: Whatever doubts their male colleagues might have, Carlen Sanderson and Anne Pabon don't think their training as New York City's first female sanitation workers will go to waste. In their first days on the job last week, Ms. Sanderson (top) and Ms. Pabon seemed unaffected by occasional grumblings that women were unfit to haul 100-pound cans of ashes.

title: NEW & NOTEWORTHY
description: STARS AND BARS, by William Boyd. (Penguin, $6.95.) Henderson Dores, an Englishman working for an art auction house in New York, looks forward to plunging into the American experience - and his hopes are more than realized on a business trip to visit an eccentric Southern family. Caroline Seebohm said in these pages last year that William Boyd's novel ''has some funny and perceptive things to say about English shyness as opposed to American spontaneity.'' His talent for evoking a place, she said, ''serves him brilliantly here.'' THE OLD CENTURY: And Seven More Years, by Siegfried Sassoon. (Faber & Faber, $11.95.) The English poet Siegfried Sassoon's autobiographical narrative of his childhood and adolescence is ''a book of ineffable charm,''

title: Jinxed Rockets
description: Some occupant of the heavens is visibly irritated at the noisy trespasses of rockets. How else to explain the failure of two more American rocket types last week, the fifth and sixth this year?

title:
ANTIQUES;
INTIMATE SHOW AT HISTORIC SITE
description: WITHOUT dependency on volume, the annual antiques show at the Hunterdon Art Center is an intimate, sophisticated presentation in the beautiful setting of an historic mill overlooking the south branch of the Raritan River.

title: LABOR'S NEW MILITANTS ARE GETTING MORE PUSHY
description: THE annual summer meeting of the executive council of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. earlier this month addressed many of the usual topics. The nation's labor leaders said the economy was bad, deplored the trade imbalance and criticized the Government of South Africa.

title: NEW EFFORT IS MADE TO PROTECT JAY SITE
description: ''A NICE try, but we're not selling,'' Diane G. Millstein, a Larchmont developer, said last week, referring to a bill sponsored by Representatives Joseph J. DioGuardi, Republican of New Rochelle, and Hamilton Fish Jr., Republican of Millbrook, that would preserve the Jay property bordering Long Island Sound and the City of Rye. Her company owns the property and hopes to develop 39 single-family homes on the site.

title: H.M.O.'s
description: To the Editor:

title: U.C.L.A. End Ineligible
description: Derek Tennell, a two-year starter at tight end for U.C.L.A., has been declared academically ineligible, the university announced today. Tennell, who caught 24 passes last season, will not travel to Oklahoma when the Bruins open their season Saturday against the defending national champion.

title: Elizabeth Thomas Browning Married To Patrick Michael Riley in Westport
description: Elizabeth Thomas Browning, the daughter of Priscilla Edwards Browning of Westport, Conn., and Robert E. Browning of Milford, Conn., was married yesterday to Patrick Michael Riley, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. John Charles Riley of Miami. The Rev. Robert Ficks 3d, assisted by the Rev. Roger Schellenberg, performed the ceremony at Christ and Holy Trinity Episcopal Church in Westport.

title: Like Texas, the Hunts Are Hurting
description: For decades, the ruins and rebounds of the late H. L. Hunt and his sons have been among the grand symbols of entreprenueurial ups and downs. Last week, they became symbols again, of decline of a region into what may be its darkest days.

title: PEOPLE WHO SNIFF AT SUCCESS
description: DIARY OF A YUPPIE By Louis Auchincloss. 215 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $16.95.

title: SUMMER PARTY DRESSES FLOUNCE IN
description: LOW-CUT short party dresses have been a mark of this summer, and they are every bit as full of rococo flounce as they were in their heyday 30 years ago, when the likes of Marilyn Monroe and Kim Novak filled them most admirably.

title: 1793 ENGLISH FARCE SET IN THE OLD WEST
description: WITH ''air-conditioning in the summer and heat in the winter,'' as the artistic director Joe Brancato put it, and overall renovations close to complete, the enterprising Penguin Repertory Company opened a somewhat delayed year-round season Aug. 22.

title: Harriman as a Supporter of Vietnam Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: Comedy
description: David Cale, who is appearing Sunday afternoon as part of the Central Park SummerStage series of performance art and comedy events, is possibly the most gifted, young comic monologuist to emerge from the downtown performance art world since Spalding Gray. Mr. Cale, who grew up in England, and came to America to be a pop musician, uses his own experience as the springboard for disturbing, surrealistic tales that have the heightened imagery of events remembered during a feverish nightmare. His delivery is wide-eyed and intense, a grownup version of the spooky-funny style of a couselor relating ghost stories to children around a campfire.

title: SUMMER WITH THE CHILDREN -- NOT AS PLANNED
description: SUMMER was the compromise. I had to work, but wanted to be with my children. After much mental anguish, I was fortunate to formulate a schedule wherein I'd work nearly all year and be off most of the summer. So there I was at home. Alone. The three siblings were all out with their friends and had left their dedicated mother dedicated to nothing. (''Hi, Mom!'' Whooosh. ''By, Mom!'')

title: 'Roger's Version'
description: THE language of fiction is a medley. The novelist, unlike the lyric poet or essayist, must command many styles and speak to us through a plurality of borrowed or imitated discourses as well as in what passes for his or her own voice. There are at least five distinct discursive strands interwoven in the texture of John Updike's ''Roger's Version.'' Four of them will be familiar to readers of his previous novels, but the fifth is, I believe, a new development, or acquisition, and a remarkably interesting one.

title: South Overtakes the North
description: South Korea's emergence as a major international exporter contrasts with its dire circumstances after the Korean War ended in 1953. In those days, the South lagged behind the Communist North, which possessed most of the country's industry.

title: Manchester United Suffers Third Defeat
description: Manchester United suffered its third consecutive defeat in the English League soccer season today, losing, 1-0, at home to Charlton Athletic.

title: SUFFOLK OFFICIAL TAKES EXCEPTION
description: In Frank Lynn's article entitled ''Cohalan Faces New Hurdle for Court Post,'' on Aug. 24, placing quotation marks around a statement which I allegedly made to unnamed county legislators defies belief.

title: HARVARD SET TO CELEBRATE WITH RAINBOW AT END OF 350 YEARS
description: To celebrate its 350th birthday, Harvard University is trimming the ivy, putting its best brains forward and even putting itself at the end of an inflatable plastic rainbow.

title: KEEPING POSTED ON NEW WATERFOWLING AND HUNTING RULES
description: THE 1986-1987 small game and waterfowling seasons in New York State will be similar to those of last year, with two notable exceptions in the latter: There will be no hunting of canvasback ducks, the brant season will be reduced from 50 days to 30, and the daily bag limit for them from four to two.

title: Merryl J. Maleska To Be Wed Nov. 1
description: Merryl Jean Maleska and Nathan Lord Wilbur of Cambridge, Mass., plan to be married Nov. 1.

title: JAZZ: OLIVER JONES, PIANO
description: THE fleet-fingered Canadian pianist Oliver Jones came to Sweet Basil Thursday afternoon for a Greenwich Village Jazz Festival showcase. He led a trio (with Skip Beckwith on bass and Terry Fox on drums) in a set of standards, blending dazzling speed with bluesy feeling - a rare combination.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
SAVORING THE TRIUMPH OF A SOFTBALL CAREER
description: THE Pickups are No. 1 at last - in the ''B'' division of the Town of North Castle Men's Softball League.

title: Transition at the C.I.A.
description: To the Editor:

title: IN LIBYA, TROOPS ON ALERT AND TRIPS TO THE COUNTRY
description: The movements of American naval battle groups in the Mediterranean north of Africa have increased the level of nervousness among residents of this desert country.

title: INMATES TO HOLD 'RUN FOR LITERACY'
description: THERE will be less running room than in most marathons, but a good many of the runners training for the 26-mile race in Ossining this coming weekend are used to close quarters.

title: Cost of Credit Cards
description: For a time, sentiment rose in Congress for a bill that would limit interest rates on credit cards, since those rates were staying high while other rates were falling. But so much opposition from the banking industry arose that the idea was dropped in favor of a measure that would require full disclosure of interest rates and fees.

title: CASINO DEVELOPING 'FANTACITY'
description: A NEW neighborhood, ''Fantacity,'' has joined Chelsea, Chelsea Heights, Venice Park, Bungalow Park and the Inlet in this city.

title: WITH AUTOMATION, MORE CAN BE LESS
description: ONCE upon a time there were two rings used to set proper exposure on single-lens reflex cameras. One, a dial atop the camera, set the speed of the shutter; the other, a band wrapped around the lens, set the aperture. You turned one or the other until the built-in meter needle lined up with the mark, and a well-exposed image was assured. It was a very simple system - so simple, in fact, that it is still found on most adjustable cameras. But for tyros and technophobes, it wasn't simple enough.

title: Big Rate Increases Seen For Boston Water Users
description: Water users around Boston should expect big rate increases soon to help finance the multibillion-dollar cleanup of Boston Harbor, officials said Wednesday.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM KILTS TO WHITE TIE
description: Jimmy Buffett: Live By the Bay MCA Home Video 87 minutes. $29.95.

title: On the Defensive
description: It may seem to Federal District Judge Alcee L. Hastings that he barely has time to warm his bench these days without someone trying to remove him from it. In 1983, Judge Hastings was acquitted of charges that he conspired to solicit a $150,000 bribe.

title: FOR A CHANGE, POLITICIANS ARE GOING ALONG TO GET ALONG
description: THE blips on the political radar screen of Brooklyn this year are small but unusual -most of the perennially warring factions in the borough have not only ceased warring but are actually cooperating.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
WORKING TUNES
description: JEFF MAIN believes Labor Day should be more than the third day of a three-day weekend. So tomorrow, at 4 P.M. at Cranberry Lake Preserve in North White Plains, Mr. Main will be playing songs on the guitar that celebrate the working man. Roy Diggit and Dan Einbinder, singers who work aboard the sloop Clearwater, and Rick Nestler, from the vessel Sojourner Truth, will also be there. The audience will be asked to sing along and to share their memories of work, whether on the farm or in the factory or with some mega-corporation. Admission to the event is free.

title: Traffic Clogs Roads Near City's Airports
description: Traffic around New York's three major airports yesterday was described as extremely heavy, and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey cautioned drivers to allow at least an extra hour to get to the airports today and tomorrow.

title: EUROPE IS BRACING FOR CHERNOBYL'S GRIM LEGACY
description: FOUR months later, Chernobyl still has a raw, frightening actuality in the European consciousness. At a contentious symposium in Vienna last week on the nuclear catastrophe, Soviet scientists strove to display the vaunted ''glasnost,'' or openness, of the Gorbachev era, and to reassure their Western counterparts that ''gross human error'' had been responsible for the explosion that wafted poison and fear over the Continent. But the Russians were obliged to concede that design shortcomings in the graphite reactor had played a role. Their Western questioners concluded that even the projected modifications to the outdated Chernobyl-type plants would not make them safe.

title: DISPUTE OVER MURDER HEIGHTENS BORDER TENSIONS
description: The way he tells it, things were fairly quiet for the sheriff of Starr County, Eugenio (Gene) Falcon Jr., in the predawn hours six days ago. It was about 6 A.M. and he says he was still puttering around his house in his underwear.

title: ARMS SHIP LEAVES WAKE OF MYSTERY IN PERU
description: A small cargo ship flying the Danish flag radioed the nearby port of Callao on June 6 to say it would be docking shortly. Hours later, it turned around, sped north and left in its wake a mystery of conspiracy and corruption that has kept Peruvians entertained ever since.

title: FOR A STAND-UP BUNCH, A RAMP TO GO SIDEWAYS
description: At the beginning of this summer, 14-year-old Frank Carpino sat down at the kitchen table one night and made drawings for a huge skateboard ramp in the woods behind his house.

title: THE YEN RAPIDLY COME OF AGE
description: SOMETIME over the next year, Los Angeles County is likely to become the first American municipal government to borrow Japanese yen. It would thus join a host of big corporate borrowers, among them the likes of I.B.M. and Walt Disney, that are taking advantage of low Japanese interest rates to issue bonds in yen rather than in dollars.

title: TEACHER'S 'HEAVEN'
description: ''It's teacher's heaven, but don't let the word get out,'' Regina Guyer of Bridgehampton said.

title: UPDIKE MOVIE DISMAYS FOLLOWERS OF WITCHCRAFT
description: Filming of ''The Witches of Eastwick'' has been going on here this summer, and the witches of Boston - and Salem and Beverly, too - are none too pleased about it.

title: RUTGERS FELLOWSHIPS A LURE
description: A PRICE is mentioned, and there is hesitation - there are, after all, other offers to consider, and the options have to be weighed carefully. An incentive is put on the table, sweetening the pot. Still, other deals are available if this one falls through.

title: MAN PREVAILS OVER HIS PROSPECTIVE DINNER
description: A FEW days ago, friends of ours who had been in Maine, brought back two live lobsters as a present and dropped them off at our house. They were in a bag with an icepack, and when I opened the bag to check on their condition, the one on top gazed at me with a baleful look from his one visible eye. Then he waved his feelers about menacingly and brought his claws, fortunately rubber-banded, up as though to strike. I closed the bag and put it and its squirming contents into the fresh meat drawer of the refrigerator, after first emptying the drawer of any fresh meat. I didn't want our prospective dinners to eat red meat, wax strong and vicious and oppose actively and violently the fate I was intending to visit upon them.

title: WHILING AWAY THE EVENING HOURS
description: The tournament day can be a very long one. At the Summer Nationals in Toronto last month many players, by their own choice, went into action at 9 A.M., snatched a sandwich for lunch and played again at 2 P.M. and 8 P.M. When the major activity ended shortly before midnight, there were other options open to them. The insatiable enthusiasts played in a midnight Zip Swiss Teams with a fast time limit: five minutes per deal instead of the usual seven-and-one-half. Others, more passive, attended a lecture, discussion or panel show involving some of the leading figures in the game.

title: AMERICAN SKIPPER KNOCKED OUT OF START
description: Two collisions today marred the start of the BOC Challenge, the singlehanded yacht race around the world. Thursday's Child, the leading United States contender in the race, was involved in one of the mishaps.

title: SCHOOL PRIZES: ADDITIONAL VIEWS
description: The article titled ''School Prizes: Wrong Emphasis?'' posed questions about the very few awards given to elementary school students when they graduate from the sixth grade. The writer, Pat Bard, also thought that the categories of awards should be enlarged, such as for poetry, penmanship, etc. She wonders about the ill effects on those who never get a prize as well as those few who always get the top prize.

title: CALLING DR. SPIN
description: IT WAS AN EVENT,'' wrote Paul Taylor in The Washington Post about the Michigan Republican primary election, first of the 1988 campaign, ''. . . that attracted a phalanx of high-priced political operatives, 'spin doctors,' exit pollsters and reporters who all set out to tease meaning from an election designed to yield none.''

title: RIVER RUNNING IN THE WILDERNESS
description: ''There is something beautifully final in certain phases of river travel; you make your decision and pick your course,'' R. M. Patterson, a British-born adventurer, wrote of his first trip on the South Nahanni River in 1927. ''You are committed and there is no turning back - you must make it or swamp. The result is a supreme peak of physical effort and a split-second awareness of changing water: and mentally a sort of cold excitement and exhilaration -a high point of living.''

title: SHAKESPEARE'S MOOR IS A JAPANESE AINU IN SHOZO SATO'S 'KABUKI OTHELLO'
description: ''Kabuki Othello,'' an unusual fusion of Eastern and Western classical theater forms, will have its premiere performance Sept. 17 in the rural serenity of this small community in Chester County, some 25 miles northwest of Philadelphia.

title: Enter The Cab of Tomorrow, Buckle Up and Smile at the Camera
description: To the Editor:

title: Tax Bill Puts Penalty On Loans of the Past
description: To the Editor:

title: IRELAND'S SEAFARING SMOCK
description: Generations of fishermen setting sail from Kinsale harbor in County Cork in southwestern Ireland have worn a version of the smock, a traditional garment favored by seafarers on the Celtic coasts of Europe - Brittany, Cornwall, Wales and Scotland as well as Ireland.

title: Carol Giacomo Is Married
description: Carol A. Giacomo, a national security reporter in the Washington bureau of the Reuters News Agency, and Joseph C. Marquette, chief photographer for The Philadelphia Inquirer, were married yesterday.

title: FROM LUMBERYARD TO PLAZA
description: Waterfront development along the Hudson River has traditionally meant the construction of large factories or warehouses.

title: STATE INTENSIFYING SAFETY BELT DRIVE
description: THE scenario is simple: A family is driving down a local street when, suddenly, another vehicle runs a red light. Metal grinds on metal and glass shatters.

title: LAUGHING ALL THE WAY TO THE BORDER
description: THE ANTI-SOVIET SOVIET UNION By Vladimir Voinovich. Translated by Richard Lourie. 325 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $19.95.

title: Houston Mayor Rehires Workers Who Led Strike
description: Mayor Kathy Whitmire has reversed herself and rehired 84 garbage collectors who led a wildcat strike earlier this month to protest layoffs.

title: LOW TURNOUT SHUTS TOBACCO MUSEUM
description: THE U. S. Tobacco Museum in Greenwich, a Connecticut landmark and a reminder of a time when tobacco had a more benign reputation, was to close permanently today because of low attendance.

title: WHEN THE SCRIPT READS CANCER
description: ''MALIGNANT?'' He's got to be out of his mind, I thought.

title: Amsterdam's Turn For the Limelight
description: Amsterdam, often viewed as a lively but limited stopover on the way to somewhere else, is promising that a longer stay will be especially worthwhile next year.

title: 1,500 SLAVE DESCENDANTS AT CAROLINA 'REUNION'
description: On the same cypress-shaded plantation where his ancestors arrived in chains 200 summers ago, 80-year-old John Thomas Baum cleared his throat under his white straw hat today and recited the slavery story he had heard as a child.

title: CURRYING FLAVOR
description: A WRITER FOR BOMBAY magazine once mused in print that the phrase ''to curry favor'' was coined by someone who had dined on Indian cooking prepared on Ismail Merchant's stove. Mr. Merchant is the producer of many films, including ''The Bostonians,'' ''Heat and Dust'' and, most recently, the much-applauded, well-received ''A Room With a View.'' He is also the author of a splendid cookbook, ''Ismail Merchant's Indian Cuisine,'' first published in England and scheduled to be brought out in this country next month by St. Martin's Press. It is an exemplary work, and a complete departure from what you normally expect in a book on Indian food. It is not national. It does not deal with traditional concepts. And it is not regional. It is simply one man's inspired notion of what his native land's cookery should taste like. It is tailored to his own sophisticated and remarkably original palate. And the recipes are easy to follow.

title: WHEN A REGULATOR DOUBLES AS REPO MAN
description: PAUL HEAFY is telling the one about the shaggy 200-pound mechanical gorilla. A few months ago, his office repossessed the giant contraption, which sways back and forth and opens and closes its mouth when turned on. But the problem was, he says, what value to place on the gorilla. And who on earth would buy it? ''That's where you need to be innovative,'' said the 34-year-old Mr. Heafy. ''I brought it to my office and invited the local television stations. It got great publicity, and then we put the gorilla up for auction.''

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM KILTS TO WHITE TIE
description: Tunes of Glory Starring Alec Guinness, John Mills, Susannah York, Dennis Price, Gordon Jackson; directed by Ronald Neame, 1960 Embassy Home Entertainment 107 minutes. $39.95.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM KILTS TO WHITE TIE
description: Romeo and Juliet:Featuring Rudolf Nureyev, Carla Fracci, Margot Fonteyn; choreographed and directed by Mr. Nureyev, 1982 Kultur 129 minutes. $79.95.

title: BERNSTEIN TRIUMPHANT
description: IN A WASH OF WEEPY EMOTION, Leonard Bernstein stepped down as music director of the New York Philharmonic in 1969, assuming the title ''laureate conductor.'' Laureates sometimes carry with them an air of doddering grandeur. But at the age of 50, Bernstein was still full of fire, mostly fueled by ambitions to fulfill his interrupted promise as a composer. Instead, the 1970's turned into Leonard

title: IN SINGAPORE, ONE TONGUE FROM MANY ROOTS
description: Many things, from cuisine to religion, may divide the Chinese, Malay, Indian and Tamil people of Singapore, despite sporadic Government efforts to drum up, if not invent, a sense of national unity. But Singaporeans have had no trouble at all devising a national language all their own. They call it Singlish.

title: FINNISH PRESIDENT FOR 25 YEARS
description: Urho K. Kekkonen, Finland's President for more than 25 years, until an incompacitating illness forced his retirement in 1981, died early today at his home in Helsinki. He was 85 years old.

title: Alpine Styles
description: Roger Marshall, we are told, departed from Tibet, with ''a girlfriend and a photographer,'' to establish a 21,000-foot camp on Everest's north side. Chris Chandler perished on the world's third-highest peak with ''just his wife and one porter.''

title: MITTERRAND ROLE IS CITED IN GREENPEACE AFFAIR
description: Two prominent French journalists, in a book-length study of the Greenpeace scandal, have concluded that President Francois Mitterrand gave advance approval to the sinking of an anti-nuclear protest ship in New Zealand.

title: Queries About the Downed Jet
description: The appalling circumstances in which our loved ones died were the worst nightmare realized. How many nights have we lain awake imagining the horror of their final moments? With no bodies recovered, we have been deprived of the healing ritual of a funeral service, and the intangibility of the unseen event keeps us in perpetual mourning.

title: Wendy Markus To Wed in Fall
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Markus of Wayne, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter Winifred Anne Markus to Watt Wetmore Webb 3d, a son of Prof. and Mrs. Watt W. Webb of Ithaca, N.Y. The wedding is planned for Oct. 26.

title: Rating Rentals: Survey Cites Best
description: IF you are going to rent a car, the best place to do it is Fort Myers, Fla., or Tulsa, Okla., according to a survey by the United States Auto Club. And the best company to rent from is . . . well, there's the rub.

title: Learning Greek
description: The decision to learn an ancient language, as discussed by Paul Q. Beeching, in ''Learning Greek'' (About Men, Aug. 10), may be a not-uncommon phenomenon of the jubilee year.

title: DOLPHIN BRAIN STUDIES SHED NEW LIGHT ON MENTAL SKILLS
description: What's on a dolphin's mind? The playful demeanor of dolphins and the relative ease with which they and their whale cousins can be trained have long raised speculation on the intelligence of marine mammals.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LOVE IN THE MIDDLE AGES. By Helen Barolini. (Morrow, $17.95.)

title: The E.P.A. Takes A Look at Itself
description: The Environmental Protection Agency became its own stern critic last week, acknowledging that it had repeatedly violated the Endangered Species Act by failing to protect threatened animals and plants from pesticides. ''There is no question about it,'' said John A. Moore, assistant administrator of the agency for pesticides and toxic substances.

title: NOW EVEN PIEDMONT FLIES THE FAST LANE
description: IN his eight and a half years at Piedmont Airlines, William R. Howard has tried to rub off some of his own grandiose style on the carrier. He is a man of expensive Jamaican cigars and London-tailored suits. He avidly collects motorcycles and antique cars, and sometimes pilots his own plane to the Florida Keys, where he has a second home and a yacht.

title: Child Abuser Sentenced
description: Gerald Amirault, 32 years old, has been sentenced to 30 to 40 years in prison for sexually abusing nine children in his care at a day-care center. He could be paroled in 20 years. Juliane Bellario, his attorney, said the verdict and sentence would be appealed.

title: Alpine Styles
description: In his effort to report on the smaller, essentially European, style of alpinism, Trip Gabriel leaves a skewed impression of the state of the art in the United States (''One Man vs. Everest,'' Aug. 10).

title: U.S. IS REORIENTING CIVIL AID TO EGYPT
description: The United States is reorienting its huge program of civilian aid to Egypt, which has pumped more than $10 billion into this country in the last decade.

title: LOCAL HERO
description: ''Turn left up Maid Marian Way,'' said the gangly lad with the Midlands accent as he pointed to an improbably named three-lane highway choked with morning traffic, ''and you'll see Robin Hood in front of the castle, halfway up the hill.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, AUGUST 31, 1986
description: International

title: OUTSIDER IN A SILENT WORLD
description: WHEN I WAS born, the obstetrician looked at my mother and traced the hourglass figure of a woman. It was his way of telling her she had had a baby girl. The doctor then walked over and clapped his hands near my head to see if I would respond. He went back to my mother and, smiling, pointed to his ears and nodded. Everyone in the delivery room was relieved I was a ''normal'' baby.

title: Verbatim; Keep Out
description: 'We are not a nation of immigration and do not want to become one.It is simply impossible that the Federal Republic of Germany become a haven for all those who are in material need but are not fleeing from political persecution.' Chancellor Helmut Kohl, announcing measures to stem the flow of refugees, principally from the Middle East, Africa and South Asia.

title: TURKEY DETAINS EX-ASTRONAUT
description: A former American astronaut, James B. Irwin, said he was detained most of today by local Turkish policemen after allegations that he engaged in espionage while searching for Noah's Ark. He denied the charge.

title: Back to School For AIDS Children
description: At least six children who are known to have AIDS or AIDS-related complex will be allowed to attend public schools, New York City officials announced last week. No one other than their families and their doctors is to know who they are or where they are enrolled.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN DRAMAS ECHO CRIES OF THE BELOVED COUNTRY
description: A group of black playwrights sought recently to put on a production in a segregated black township near Johannesburg, playing to a black audience generally starved of theater. At the last moment, however, the playwrights discovered that their work, part of the nation's theater of protest against the racial policies that afflict black lives, could not be performed - not because the white targets of the drama had so decreed, but because the township's youthful black protesters had decided that entertainment itself was inappropriate to a nation in turmoil. So the production was canceled. On other occasions, the authorities themselves have intervened to ban black protest theater, or to restrict the size of the audience that might see some works deemed to be subversive or inflammatory. ''We are sandwiched,'' said Matsemela Manaka, one of South Africa's best-known black playwrights, ''between the state and the climate inside the country.'' The authorities ordered, for instance, that one of Mr. Manaka's earlier works might only be played to small audiences.

title: HOW TO PUT UP A TELEVISION ANTENNA
description: INSTALLING your own television antenna will save considerable money, since having the work done professionally often costs more than the antenna.
